headline: Master of His Domain; Lord of the Manor; Now, Director
text: 3:01 p.m. | Updated If he can see a metaphor for racial harmony in a black and white cookie, and explain the similarities between breaking up and knocking over a Coke machine (“You can’t do it in one push”), surely Jerry Seinfeld understands how to communicate with actors. But he has rarely tried his hand at directing until now.

headline: Spillonomics: Underestimating Risk
text: In retrospect, the pattern seems clear. Years before the Deepwater Horizon rig blew, BP was developing a reputation as an oil company that took safety risks to save money. An explosion at a Texas refinery killed 15 workers in 2005, and federal regulators and a panel led by James A. Baker III, the former secretary of state, said that cost cutting was partly to blame. The next year, a corroded pipeline in Alaska poured oil into Prudhoe Bay. None other than Joe Barton, a Republican congressman from Texas and a global-warming skeptic, upbraided BP managers for their “seeming indifference to safety and environmental issues.”

headline: Al and Tipper Gore Split Up
text: Al and Tipper Gore announced today that they were separating after 40 years of marriage.

headline: Bradley Expresses Confidence in Security Measures
text: IRENE, GAUTENG, South Africa — A day after arriving in Johannesburg, the United States soccer team held its first training session here Tuesday in preparation for an eagerly awaited showdown with England on June 12.

headline: TimesCast | June 1, 2010
text: Today, the U.S. weighs response to Israeli raid, BP delays plan to cut oil pipe and laid-off workers take to the kitchen.

headline: Fete Accompli | El Museo del Barrio Gala
text: What: El Museo del Barrio‘s annual fund-raising event on Thursday night raked in $1.1 million for the Latino cultural center – which could be because the New York institution is so beloved or because it’s one of the few events on the charity circuit where people actually dance.

headline: Zach Braff to Star Off Broadway in ‘Trust’
text: After eight seasons starring on the comedy “Scrubs,” Zach Braff will return to a New York stage this summer in the Off Broadway production of the dark comedy “Trust,” a new play by Paul Weitz, the co-director of the films “About a Boy” and “American Pie.” Joining Mr. Braff in the ensemble cast at Second Stage Theater will be the Tony Award-winning actress Sutton Foster (“Thoroughly Modern Millie”), Bobby Cannavale (a Tony nominee for “Mauritius”), and Ari Graynor (“The Little Dog Laughed”).

headline: Eliminating Al Qaeda’s No. 3, Again
text: According to the SITE Intelligence Group, which monitors jihadist Web sites, Al Qaeda said in a statement published on Monday that a senior figure in the movement had been killed by an American missile in Pakistan’s tribal areas.

headline: Health and the Broken Heart
text: Do people really die of broken hearts? The toll that love and loss can take on the heart is getting more attention following the unexpected death of Hollywood husband Simon Monjack, who was found dead in his bed at age 39, just five months after the loss of his wife, actress Brittany Murphy.

headline: For Federer, Imagination Matches His Skill
text: He chipped Soderling’s big first serve short to the forehand, a ball that Soderling misplayed to begin the game. This time, however, Soderling ripped a heavy topspin inside in deep to Federer’s forehand corner.

headline: Can a Small Company Say No to Whole Foods?
text: True Body Products of Richmond, Vt., makes all-natural, affordable, and — for now — unscented soaps. True Body’s president, Janice Shade, co-founded the company in 2007 and is its sole employee. The soaps, which are sold at 45 Whole Foods stores in the North Atlantic and Northeast regions, Fred Meyer in the Northwest, household product marketplace alice.com, and at independent cooperatives and natural food stores, are made under contract with a Vermont manufacturer. True Body began shipping in September 2008, and had 2009 sales of about $45,000.

headline: Justice Dept. Faults Attack Readiness
text: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department’s inspector general has concluded that the department is not fully prepared to respond to a terrorist attack involving an unconventional weapon.

headline: Berdych Reaches Semifinals
text: PARIS – Battling rain delays and a muddy court, Tomas Berdych of the Czech Republic powered his way into the French Open semifinals with a convincing victory over Mikhail Youzhny of Russia, 6-3, 6-1, 6-2.

headline: We Made It Ourselves | CB Sides’s Burger Booster
text: In her column We Made It Ourselves, Charlotte Druckman writes about restaurants and small businesses with interesting house-made treats.

headline: A Maker of Mayors Has His Moment in the Spotlight
text: From the back porch of Gracie Mansion, John V. Lindsay looked into the camera and ate crow: “I guessed wrong on the weather before the city’s biggest snowstorm last winter. And that was a mistake. But I put 6,000 more cops on the street. And that was no mistake. The school strike went on too long, and we all made some mistakes. But I brought 225,000 more jobs to this town. And that was no mistake.”

headline: Escape Clause Seen for Goldman and the S.E.C.
text: Is there a way for Goldman Sachs and the Securities and Exchange Commission to reach a compromise on settling securities fraud charges against the firm? John Carney of CNBC.com thinks there is, and he believes Goldman and the S.E.C. may both be able to claim victory in their legal fight.

headline: Go Tell the Spartans: Upload Your Video
text: A university is hoping that a campaign evoking its athletic prowess can help educate the outside world on its other types of achievements — not to mention reminding alumni about the importance of supporting their alma mater.

headline: Life as Bret Michaels Knows It
text: On Monday night VH1 offered a preview of what is to come later in the year: the first half-hour of “Bret Michaels: Life as I Know It.” This spring Mr. Michaels, of the band Poison and “Rock of Love” fame (and recent winner of “Celebrity Apprentice”), had an emergency appendectomy, suffered a hemorrhage near his brain, a “mini-stroke” and was found to have a small hole in his heart, so production of this rock-stars-are-just-like-you-and-me reality series will resume when he fully recovers. To what can we look forward? Mr. Michaels channeling the contrived normalcy of Ozzy Osbourne and all of the suburban-dad musicians who have come to cable television before him.

headline: Malaria: A Student’s Firsthand Account
text: Kristine Silvestri, a recent graduate of Elon University in North Carolina, has written a post about contracting malaria while she was on a study abroad program in Ghana.

headline: Q&A: A Low-Key Spot for Surfing
text: Q.

headline: TimesCast: Responding to the Israeli Raid
text: In today’s TimesCast, The Times’s Ethan Bronner discusses the implications for the already fragile relationship between the United States and Israel after an Israeli raid on a flotilla trying to break the Gaza blockade.

headline: Music Director Leaving Spoleto Festival USA
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — News broke out on Monday at the Spoleto Festival USA here after a placid opening weekend. Emmanuel Villaume, the French conductor who has been the festival’s music director for opera and orchestra since 2001, announced that he would leave at the end of the season. Mr. Villaume, who is also artistic director and principal conductor of the Slovenian Philharmonic Orchestra and principal conductor of the Slovak Philharmonic Orchestra, cited time pressure as a major factor in his decision.

headline: Bailouts in Retrospect
text: My good friend Allan Sloan has a great Fortune column out today.

headline: Ship Sinking Aids Ruling Party in S. Korean Vote
text: BUCHEON, South Korea  The sinking of the South Korean warship Cheonan, apparently by a North Korean torpedo, has provoked an international crisis that has embroiled big powers like the United States and China. But here in South Korea, it has had another effect: buoying the country’s once embattled conservative, pro-American president, Lee Myung-bak.

headline: Judge Rules Moody’s and S.&P. Aren’t Underwriters
text: A federal judge in Manhattan ruled Tuesday that it was unfair to hold Moody’s Investors Service and Standard & Poor’s liable as “underwriters” on securities offerings needing their ratings, as he rejected fraud claims by investors on the safety of $63.4 billion of mortgage-backed debt, Reuters reports.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Monsoon Wedding’
text: With wedding season beginning, A. O. Scott looks back at the director Mira Nair‘s 2001 film “Monsoon Wedding.” The movie chronicles a Punjabi family who come together in Delhi to celebrate a marriage. Mr. Scott calls the film “an especially vibrant and satisfying example of a wedding movie,” a genre that often combines melodrama and farce with equal measure. Mr. Scott finds much here to admire, saying that “Mira Nair draws together an unruly tangle of plots and subplots, and handles them with clarity and grace.” Have you seen “Monsoon Wedding?” Please share your thoughts on the film.

headline: Electric Car Warning Sounds: Don’t Expect Ring Tones
text: Although no one (at least yet) is making them do it, automakers are preparing to introduce quiet electric and plug-in hybrid cars that make sounds to alert pedestrians, the blind and others to their presence.

headline: Bees, Birds and Words to Ban From the Internets Crew
text: Ah, spring, the season of migratory returns and real estate nightmares, of discovering suddenly that your neighbor believes see-through mesh undershirts are acceptable outerwear in all situations.

headline: Polish Pilot Saw Chance of Landing
text: MOSCOW  About 14 and a half minutes before the plane crash in April that killed Poland’s president and many of its top officials, the pilot delivered bad news to the president’s chief of diplomatic protocol: The fog was so thick that they could not safely land.

headline: Updates
text: Apropos of our recent conversation here about how far parents should go to support (and finance) their children’s dreams, there is an article today by my colleague Clifford Levy about young Americans training to dance with the Bolshoi ballet in Moscow. The youngest, like 12-year-old Julian McKay, shares an apartment with his mother and younger brother, while his father visits regularly from the family’s farm in Montana. Older students, like 15-year-old Joy Womack, are completely on her own, and her Texas family struggles to pay the $18,000 a year for her tuition.

headline: Why Photocopiers Have Hard Drives
text: In a Bucks post last month, “The Identity Theft Threat from Copiers,” we highlighted the risks associated with copying sensitive information on copy machines that have hard drives and provided some information to help consumers better understand the risks and protect themselves.

headline: The Morning Skate: Blackhawks Survive Carcillo and Flyers’ Pressure
text: The mark of many Stanley Cup champions is that they can play any style and win. So far in this Cup final, the Blackhawks have won an offensively oriented (albeit sloppy) game in the opener and now, Monday night’s 2-1 victory (Jeff Z. Klein’s Times article), a more physical game in which they were often forced to play defensively and rely on goaltending.

headline: Hotels: Fewer Deals but Low Rates
text: IF you haven’t booked a hotel for your summer vacation, don’t expect to see the same types of recession specials that hotels were offering last year.

headline: Memorial Day Racing on TV: Fox Wins Again
text: Lewis Hamilton, Dario Franchitti and Kurt Busch may have been the winners of their respective auto races Sunday, but which race — the Turkish Grand Prix, the Indianapolis 500 or the Coca-Cola 600 — had the winning telecast?

headline: Game 2 Produces Strong Ratings
text: The Chicago Blackhawks’ 2-1 win over the Philadelphia Flyers in Game 2 of the Stanley Cup finals on NBC Monday night generated a 4.1 preliminary overnight Nielsen rating, the highest on record for the second game of the series, and up 21 percent from last year’s Detroit-Pittsburgh contest.

headline: Tenet Confirms It Is in Talks to Buy Healthscope
text: Tenet Healthcare confirmed on Tuesday that it was holding preliminary talks about acquiring Healthscope, the second largest private hospital corporation in Australia.

headline: Dating, Sex and Herpes
text: Can you have herpes but never even know it? Can the herpes simplex virus spread even if you don’t have symptoms? And how do you navigate the maze of sex and dating when you know you are infected with herpes?

headline: Stop, Laptop Thief!
text: There are a large number of antitheft software applications designed to protect laptops, smartphones and now, iPads. When your device is stolen, the application, which runs in the background when possible, does things like report its location, snap a picture with the device’s internal camera, display a message and lock the machine.

headline: The Week That Was: Team Nos. 100-94
text: Paul Myerberg of The Times hasn’t stopped writing long-winded college football previews; he’s just changed addresses, for now. The Countdown will return to The Quad later in the summer, but can be found at Pre-Snap Read.

headline: Where Public Workers Run the Show
text: State and local public employees hold the biggest share of the work force in Wyoming, and the lowest share in the District of Columbia. Take a look:

headline: Vain Glorious | Fragrances for the Affianced
text: What: Histoires de Parfums at J. Crew’s new bridal emporium.

headline: Schiavone in Semifinals After Her Latest Upset
text: PARIS  Caroline Wozniacki of Denmark was 10 when Francesca Schiavone of Italy last reached the quarterfinals at Roland Garros. It was nine years ago.

headline: Why Nudibranchs? And Readers’ Questions
text: Nudibranchs are fascinating because of what they tell us about the evolutionary process, but the story of how I became interested in them is a little less sophisticated. As a child growing up in the San Francisco Bay Area, I started visiting the California Academy of Sciences, and seeing the exhibits and aquarium are some of my earliest memories. Little did I know that I would end up working there for 28 years and counting.

headline: Kruse Auction House Has License Revoked, Owner Suspended
text: Kruse International, the Indiana auction company that has been a major player in collectible car sales for nearly 40 years, had its license revoked and was fined $70,000 by the Indiana Auctioneer Commission last week. The commission also suspended the company’s owner and auctioneer, Dean Kruse, for two years.

headline: Year-End Round-Up | Social Studies, History, Geography and Civics
text: As you may know, our daily lesson plans are on summer vacation and will return in early September. In the meantime, we’ve got some surprises in store for both teachers and students, starting with our Summer Reading Challenge. If you receive our e-mail, you’ll see our summertime materials under the heading “Summer Special.”

headline: Disney Puts Tickets on a Facebook Site
text: LOS ANGELES  The Walt Disney Company has created what it believes is a first-of-its-kind application allowing Facebook users to buy tickets to “Toy Story 3” without leaving the social networking site and while, at the same time, prodding their friends to come along.

headline: Regulators Examine 2 Ford Sedans After Mats Catch Accelerator Pedals
text: DETROIT — Federal regulators are examining whether one of the problems that caused Toyota to recall millions of vehicles also exists on two Ford sedans, and they warned drivers of all vehicles to make sure their floor mats were properly installed.

headline: Democrats Have Failed, G.O.P. Leader Tells Convention
text: New York Republicans opened their three-day convention at the Sheraton Hotel in Midtown Manhattan on Tuesday with hopes of overcoming disunity within their own ranks, challenging the Democrats who control every statewide office, and emerging victorious in November.

headline: A Waiting Game for Fishermen
text: PORT SULPHUR, La.  These waters have been closed longer this time than anyone here can remember.

headline: A Bullish View of Wind Power Out West
text: Wind energy has plenty going for it: it is clean, unlimited in supply and the most economical source of renewable power. Its clearest drawback is unreliability: sometimes the wind just does not blow.

headline: New Feature: Great Ideas From Our Readers
text: We know you’re out there, and we want to give you credit: whether you’re a teacher, parent, coach, librarian, tutor, counselor, adviser or administrator, if you’ve used The Times to teach, please tell us what you did, why and how.

headline: Pre-refuting William Galston
text: So William Galston has an article in the New Republic questioning Keynes — and me. He lays great stress on the Reinhart-Rogoff claim that growth slows substantially when debt exceeds 90 percent of GDP.

headline: Benmosche: We Have Options for A.I.A.
text: While shares in the American International Group have fallen after the company said it would not compromise on the purchase price of its Asia life insurance unit, the insurer’s chief executive, Robert H. Benmosche, is urging employees to keep their heads up.

headline: A Maker of Mayors Has His Moment in the Spotlight
text: In the City Room, Sam Roberts writes that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and two of his predecessors, Rudolph W. Giuliani and Edward I. Koch, are teaming up to honor David Garth, the political advertising guru who helped each of them get to Gracie Mansion. Go to City Room »

headline: Larry McMurtry Joins the E-Book Rush
text: For the first time, Larry McMurtry has agreed to make his books available in electronic-book form, Simon & Schuster announced on Tuesday.

headline: A Changing Art Scene in Paris
text: The Rue Louise Weiss, an unprepossessing street in southern Paris that was hailed, at the turn of the century, as emblematic of the renaissance of France’s contemporary art scene, is fading.

headline: Andrei Voznesensky, Russian Poet, Dies at 77
text: Andrei Voznesensky, who as one of the Soviet Union’s boldest and most celebrated young poets of the 1950s and ’60s helped lift Russian literature out of its state of fear and virtual serfdom under Stalin, died Tuesday at his home in Moscow. He was 77.

headline: Pictures of the Day: The West Bank and Elsewhere
text: Our show begins with a series of images revealing the fierce reaction to Israel’s attack on a flotilla of ships bound for Gaza (Slides 1 through 6). The fallout widened on Tuesday amid growing criticism of the raid, which left nine activists dead. Egypt reopened its border with Gaza to allow aid to pass through, and activists said they had sent another ship toward the area.

headline: The Morning Line: Pletcher Ends Another Hex
text: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

headline: Putting Queens on the Tourism Map
text: Queens is the first and last place many tourists see when they arrive in New York, but one they rarely visit. Home to John F. Kennedy and La Guardia Airports, it has long been seen as a place to pass through on the way to or from Manhattan.

headline: More on Cortney Munna’s Student Loan Tale
text: This weekend’s “Your Money” column profiled Cortney Munna, a 26-year-old San Francisco resident who ended up with nearly $100,000 in student loan debt after finishing her undergraduate degree at New York University. Here, she responds to some of the nearly 600 comments on the story.

headline: Queens Students Sickened, Probably by Contaminated Water
text: Updated, 6:15 p.m. | About 80 children at Public School 20, an elementary school in Flushing, Queens, became ill Tuesday afternoon, apparently after drinking from water fountains that were contaminated by an air-conditioning chemical, the Department of Education said.

headline: Not Exactly Preaching to the Choir
text: A basement theater in Long Island City is an unlikely place to see a miracle. But the Lord  and Off Off Broadway  works in mysterious ways.

headline: Some iPads Can’t Take the Heat
text: What lovely New York weather we had this weekend: sunny, high 80s and a light breeze. Perfect for lying around outside and reading a good book. That is, if the book you are hoping to read is not on an iPad.

headline: Case Study | Vintage Cocktails
text: Everyone knows that aging a spirit transforms it from fiery youthfulness to softly purring maturity, with the requisite increase in prestige and price to match. The mixologist Tony Conigliaro, who owns 69 Colebrooke Row in London’s Islington district, has been taking the process a step further, aging fully prepared cocktails.

headline: Mere Silence Doesn’t Invoke Miranda, Justices Say
text: WASHINGTON  Criminal suspects seeking to protect their right to remain silent must speak up to invoke it, the Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday, refining the court’s landmark 1966 ruling in Miranda v. Arizona.

headline: Perfectionist Parents
text: I do not claim to have ever been a perfectionist. A peek into my closets will confirm that. But whatever orderly tendencies I once had were challenged — and conquered — by the early days of parenting. Think of flawlessness as the rock and infancy is the hard place. Do those caught in between ever fully recover?

headline: Upscale Mexican Food in Philadelphia
text: Stephen Starr, who owns a string of high-profile restaurants in Philadelphia including Buddakan and Morimoto, has gone south-of-the-border– opening El Rey, a moderately priced Mexican restaurant in the city’s Center City neighborhood, last month.

headline: Posada Is Closer to Returning
text: Jorge Posada, on the disabled list since May 17 with a hairline fracture in his right foot, arrived at Yankee Stadium on Tuesday expecting to be in the lineup. Instead, it looks as if he will have to wait another day.

headline: Kirsten Dunst Forgoes Laughs in Return to the Witness Stand
text: Just over eight months after The New York Post declared her “Kirsten Dunce,” the actress Kirsten Dunst showed up in a Manhattan courtroom on Tuesday with a complete personality makeover.

headline: How Soderling Knocked Off Federer
text: Robin Soderling stunned the defending French Open champion, Roger Federer, in four bone-crushing sets, avenging last year’s straight-sets thrashing by Federer and ending Federer’s streak of 23 appearances in a Grand Slam semifinal at 23. If revenge is a dish best served cold, then Soderling’s huge serving and brutal ball striking kept Federer from finding any warmth on the cold, rainy day.

headline: So Far, Revivals Eclipse Newer Pieces in City Ballet’s Season
text: So far this season, the main story at New York City Ballet has been not the new ballets but the old ones. I have watched two Robbins ballets (“Opus 19: The Dreamer” and “I’m Old Fashioned”) with, amazingly, greater admiration than I felt with their original casts. In Balanchine’s “Serenade” the corps de ballet brought an intensity and a wealth of inflections that had been lacking in the ballet’s last appearances here, and at one performance Teresa Reichlen (in the Russian dance) and Sara Mearns (as the Dark Angel) were both incandescent.

headline: Off the Menu: 1st Ave Steak Shoppe
text: Lesley Bernard has turned Permanent Brunch into a place with a different focus: steak. 1st Ave Steak Shoppe will serve four cuts, eight ounces, all grass-fed or natural, with pickles, and salad, $17 to $22. Other side dishes are available as are wines, beers and spirits, but no cocktails.

headline: The TV Watch: An ‘Oprah’ Visitation for the Royal She
text: She may be in disgrace, again, but Sarah Ferguson, the Duchess of York, still hasn’t lost her regal touch. Telling Oprah Winfrey on Tuesday about being caught on tape soliciting a £500,000 bribe from an undercover tabloid reporter posing as an Indian businessman, Ms. Ferguson kept referring to herself in the third person – the royal she.

headline: Rachel Alexandra May Race on June 12
text: Despite two disappointing losses, Jess Jackson has not given up on Rachel Alexandra, and now is looking at three options to run the reigning Horse of the Year on June 12. He has circled races in Kentucky, New York and Delaware.

headline: ‘The Passage’
text: Wolgast had been to the Compound only once, the previous summer, to meet with Colonel Sykes. Not a job interview, exactly; it had been made clear to Wolgast that the assignment was his if he wanted it. A pair of soldiers drove him in a van with blacked out windows, but Wolgast could tell they were taking him west from Denver, into the mountains. The drive took six hours, and by the time they pulled into the Compound, he’d actually managed to fall asleep. He stepped from the van into the bright sunshine of a summer afternoon. He stretched and looked around. From the topography, he’d have guessed he was somewhere around Telluride. It could have been further north. The air felt thin and clean in his lungs; he felt the dull throb of a high-altitude headache at the top of his skull.

headline: The Justice Department Seeks Evidence of Crimes in the Gulf
text: More than 40 days after 11 men died in an inferno when that deep-sea oil well blew its top, President Obama and Attorney General Eric Holder announced that criminal investigations were part of the broader inquiry into the petro-calamity in the Gulf of Mexico. The announcements came after several weeks in which Justice Department officials had publicly spoken only of civil cases.

headline: Blumenthal Is on the Air in Connecticut
text: Richard Blumenthal, the Democratic nominee for Senate in Connecticut, has gone up with his first television advertisements of the campaign, casting himself as a fighter willing to go to bat for his state’s residents.

headline: Disney and Facebook Join Hands to Move Some Tickets
text: In what may be the first such initiative, Walt Disney Pictures has entered into an agreement with Facebook in which users of the social-networking site will be able to purchase tickets to Disney’s upcoming “Toy Story 3” as well as alert their friends to join them. Brooks Barnes has the full story.

headline: Literary Novelist Turns to Vampires and Finds Pot of Gold
text: Justin Cronin is the author of an epic, multimillion-dollar, 766-page novel that stars bloodthirsty creatures that run in packs and savagely kill people at night. And he’s planning to turn it into a trilogy.

headline: Economist: Blame Government for the Crisis
text: As the search for causes of the financial crisis continues in Washington, one economist, Russell Roberts of George Mason University, says he believes that it was inept government policy, not Wall Street greed, that allowed the financial system to spin out of control.

headline: Lexus Drives to the Jagged Edge
text: Drinking and driving do not mix. Is that why Lexus is shattering a Champagne glass in a new commercial?

headline: The Pink Tea Cup Returns
text: The resurrection of the Pink Tea Cup in Greenwich Village, which closed in January, will soon open nearby and on a much grander scale than the venerable soul food restaurant. The new owner, Lawrence Page, has given it a polished setting with more than 100 seats, a full bar, a lounge, a cabaret and also a 600-seat catering hall. It came about fortuitously. Mr. Page, who owned the Actors Playhouse on Seventh Avenue South, had already rented the space to open a wine bar, but when the Pink Tea Cup closed he decided it had to be saved. So he moved it over to the space he already had and what had been the Actors Playhouse. The classic soul food menu for breakfast, lunch and dinner has also been expanded, with dishes like rack of lamb with lobster mashed potatoes, as well as some lighter dishes. Mr. Page has Glander Glover, who had been a chef at the original restaurant for 15 years, back in the kitchen, along with the executive chef, Angela Groover. “I want an all-female kitchen,” Mr. Page said. It opens June 7.

headline: On Location in Transylvania
text: Ligia Valcu’s home in Brasov, Romania, an alpine village 100 miles north of Bucharest, is surrounded by cobblestone streets and quiet gardens.

headline: Morgenthau Withdraws From Fire Dept. Case
text: Bowing to concerns over his appointment but fiercely defending his record, Robert M. Morgenthau stepped down on Tuesday from his role overseeing the city’s efforts to increase the number of minority firefighters in response to a long running discrimination lawsuit.

headline: In Romania, Creating a Bohemian Attic
text: BRASOV, ROMANIA  Surrounded by cobblestone streets and quiet gardens, Ligia Valcu’s home, here in this alpine city 100 miles north of Bucharest, miraculously escaped razing during the communist era, when many traditional buildings were torn down and replaced with drab apartment buildings.

headline: Half a Dozen States Delay Tax Refunds
text: Procrastination is no longer just for the taxpayers who wait until the last moment to file their tax returns. Thanks to the economic downturn, at least a half-dozen cash-poor states are now delaying their tax refund checks.

headline: Readers Take No Ifs, Ands or Cigarette Butts on the Sidewalk
text: The New York city sidewalk is a battleground. Residents take issue with tourists who walk too slowly. Singletons get annoyed when confronted with double strollers in their way. And non-dog-owners who must swerve to avoid a steaming pile may have the urge to curse Lassie, and her owner, who failed to stoop to scoop.

headline: Strike Status at Honda in China Is Uncertain
text: SHANGHAI — A Honda spokesman in China said operations had resumed on Wednesday after a strike at the Japanese automaker’s transmission plant in southern China had shut down production.

headline: Loans That Vanished in a Property Bust Reappear
text: The W Hotel in Union Square has had an eventful six months. The 270-room hotel changed hands in December after the private equity division of Dubai World defaulted on a $117 million mezzanine loan in the face of dwindling business. But the lender, LEM Mezzanine, could itself lose the hotel in coming months as a result of its filing for bankruptcy protection earlier this year.

headline: The iPad Pulse Reader Scales the Charts
text: June 8 | Updated  Apple removed the Pulse News Reader from the App Store after the New York Times Company objected to it. It was later reinstated. See our post on the matter.

headline: On The Things They Carry
text: Soldiers from the First Battalion, 87th Infantry Regiment of the 10th Mountain Division from Fort Drum, N.Y., talked about the things they plan to take with them.

headline: Another Los Angeles in ‘Gardener’
text: LOS ANGELES  Quiet on the set was no small order last week, as Chris Weitz, probably best known as the director of “The Twilight Saga: New Moon,” worked a grittier side of the street on this city’s largely Hispanic East Side.

headline: Showing the Benefits of ‘Green’ Retrofits
text: The practice of retrofitting buildings with simple, environmentally friendly technology like more-efficient boilers and better-quality windows has been around for years, but there is little research on how much energy these changes actually save  and by extension, how much money they can save landlords and lenders.

headline: Recasting the Cold War as the Hitchcock Years
text: In 1962, as he was shooting “The Birds,” Alfred Hitchcock had an encounter on the Universal Studios lot with an older version of himself, mysteriously arrived from 1980 with some sobering news about life, death and cinema. This meeting (inspired by a short prose piece called “August 25, 1983,” by Jorge Luis Borges) is one of the conceits of “Double Take,” Johan Grimonprez’s intriguing new film. Mark Perry, sounding uncannily like the man himself, narrates the fictitious younger Hitchcock’s account of this peculiar event, while two look-alikes, including Ron Burrage, a longtime and well-known Hitchcock impersonator, act it out.

headline: House Hunting in France
text: A six-bedroom house with details like beamed ceilings, wood floors and marble staircases.

headline: Husband’s Expectation Meets Life, and Loses
text: Were it not for the election of the country’s first African-American president two years ago, we might all be a little bit more worked up about the regressive race comedies on basic cable television. We might be writing letters and protesting and demanding a remake of “The Jeffersons.”

headline: House Hunting in ... France
text: A SIX-BEDROOM HOUSE IN PROVENCE

headline: In Memoir, Christopher Hitchens Looks Back
text: Christopher Hitchens was in boarding school and barely out of short pants when he first learned that “words could function as weapons.” He was small, bad at sports and got picked on. He worried he was becoming “a mere weed and weakling and kick-bag.” So one day he turned on a tormenter. “You,” the young Mr. Hitchens declared, “are a liar, a bully, a coward, and a thief.” His stunned tormentor slunk away.

headline: What You Get for $500,000
text: Properties for sale in Atlanta, Los Lunas, N.M., and Portland, Ore.

headline: What You Get for ... $500,000
text: ATLANTA

headline: Home Cooks Take to the Street
text: The Greenpoint Food Market in Brooklyn provides an audience for amateur home cooks looking to enter the food world.

headline: Gaza: Reaction in Iraq, Pakistan and Afghanistan
text: Israel’s deadly commando raid on a flotilla of pro-Palestinian activists heading for Gaza drew widespread media coverage across the Middle East, and farther afield in Afghanistan and Pakistan.

headline: Voters Make Choices in 3 Primaries
text: The primary election season advanced on Tuesday, with voters in Alabama, Mississippi and New Mexico selecting their party’s nominees for the general election in dozens of federal and state races.

headline: Activists Pledge to Send More Ships to Gaza
text: Updated | 10:05 p.m. After Israeli commandos killed nine pro-Palestinian activists — and detained about 600 more — while intercepting a flotilla of ships trying to break through a naval blockade to deliver 10,000 tons of aid to Gaza on Monday, Israel’s government and groups behind the protest continued to blame each other for the deaths.

headline: Israeli Force, Adrift on the Sea
text: ARAD, Israel

headline: Exotic Isle for Artists, Right in City
text: When New York City artists plan their workdays, they usually don’t have to factor in a ferry boat.

headline: Sculptors With a D.I.Y. Style
text: Three solo gallery shows in Chelsea present younger artists working primarily in sculpture: Johannes VanDerBeek, Josephine Meckseper and Siobhan Liddell.

headline: Creative Debate Among Sculptors, Not Too Loud
text: Artistically speaking, West Chelsea — land of several hundred art galleries — is a tower of Babel spread on the horizontal. On any given day, scores of different visual languages are being spoken at once, often in raised voices. Arguments made by one show for one aesthetic position are immediately, sometimes violently, countered by the show next door. The effect can be cacophonous and confusing, although the other extreme is probably more disconcerting: when too many shows are talking alike.

headline: At Spoleto, a Departing Director and a Premiere
text: CHARLESTON, S.C.  News broke out on Monday here at the Spoleto Festival USA after a placid opening weekend. Emmanuel Villaume, the French conductor who has been the festival’s music director for opera and orchestra since 2001, announced that he would leave at the end of the season.

headline: Unemployed and O.K. With It, if They’re Not Alone
text: People are less unhappy about being unemployed if their friends are also out of work, according to a new study from the World Bank based on British data.

headline: A More Cheerful New York Subway Map
text: Sometime this month the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will release its redesign of the New York subway map, the first new version since 1998. Short of reducing the number of subway lines, there is probably little more that designers can do to make the city’s subway map easier to decipher.

headline: Rethinking the Gaza Blockade
text: Updated, June 2, 12:05 p.m. |  Rime Allaf, from Chatham House in London, says that the only solution is for the U.S. to rein in Israel.

headline: Beirut’s Updated Lebanese Cuisine
text: A few of the restaurants and dishes that are revitalizing Beirut’s dining scene.

headline: At Co-op City, Trash Piles Up as Workers Go on Strike
text: Mountains of trash bags sprouted across Co-op City on Tuesday as residents and office workers rushed to perform basic maintenance tasks left undone by more than 500 unionized janitors, groundskeepers and parking attendants who went on strike in a contract dispute.

headline: A Chorus of Echoes, for Better and Worse
text: Fresh from his success conducting the complex score and loony characters of Ligeti’s “Grand Macabre” in the New York Philharmonic’s triumphant production last week, Alan Gilbert faced a very different challenge on Monday during the orchestra’s annual Memorial Day concert at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.

headline: Frustrated Posada Is Eager to Return
text: The first time reporters approached Jorge Posada on Tuesday, he said that he was finished answering questions about his status. A while later, after he had cooled off, he explained the source of his frustration.

headline: ABC Kitchen
text: ANOTHER day, another restaurant from Jean-Georges Vongerichten. The latest is ABC Kitchen, a winsome sprawl on the ground floor of ABC Carpet & Home, luxe Manhattan’s best source for Ganesh statues and pillows marked with nautical signal flags. As has become custom for Mr. Vongerichten of late, it is very good.

headline: Reviewing ABC Kitchen, in ABC Carpet and Home
text: This week’s review is of ABC Kitchen, one of the roughly 6,000 restaurants that Jean-Georges Vongerichten appears to have opened on Earth and other planets in the last year.

headline: Is There Still Hope for Syrah?
text: FORESTVILLE, Calif.

headline: 10 Ideal Syrahs From California
text: I remember visiting the Santa Barbara wine country 10 years ago and feeling impressed by the syrah wines coming from the area, and by the prospects of California syrah in general. It was supposed to be the new merlot, a popular wine that even wine-lovers could embrace. By 2002, potential problems for California syrah were already becoming apparent.

headline: Jobs Bill vs. Deficit, a Showdown in the Senate
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Icahn Extends His Hostile Bid for Lions Gate
text: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn once again extended his hostile tender offer for Lions Gate Entertainment on Tuesday and the company responded by saying the offer has once again been rejected by shareholders, Reuters reports.

headline: YouTube Dominates Online Video Views
text: Although Google’s purchase of YouTube hasn’t paid of financially, it has clearly made Google a giant in the world of online video, displaying more than 13 billion videos during the month of April.

headline: Rossi a Surprise Omission From Italy
text: The American-born forward Giuseppe Rossi, who left his home in Clifton, N.J., at age 12 to pursue his dream of playing international soccer for Italy, was cut Tuesday from the final 23-man Italian World Cup roster.

headline: Flavors of the Garden in Shortbread Cookies
text: Fragrant lavender, refreshing lemon thyme, earthy fennel pollen, rich cinnamon basil and spicy ginger are the flavors of these buttery little bites from Napa Valley. They are made with premium ingredients like Straus Family Creamery butter, and tread the line between sweet and savory.

headline: A Blade That Makes Pizza Cutting Easier
text: If you have ever been frustrated using the often flimsy wheel-type pizza cutters, which sometimes make a ragged mess of the pie, here’s the tool for you. It’s a big, gently curved 14-inch stainless-steel blade with a hardwood handle that neatly cuts the pie straight across as you use a rocking motion. It works extremely well on other flatbreads, like focaccia, and is even sharp enough to make short work of a pile of herbs on a cutting board. A hole near one edge of the blade allows you to store it on a hook.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Looking Ahead

headline: Kyochon and Bon Chon
text: THE crisp, tawny pleasures of Korean-style fried chicken aren’t new to New York. But this year, what had been a low-frequency contest between two chains based in South Korea, with a few local branches, intensified as each opened a flagship within a few months and a few Midtown blocks of each other.

headline: For Would-Be Cooks in New York, a School With Small Classes
text: If you go back some 20 years, you will find dozens of small, hands-on cooking schools for home cooks all around New York. Then came the mega schools, with scores of courses for would-be chefs as well as amateurs, and those more intimate classes became more scarce. For the last eight years, Jennifer Clair (second from left), a former chef and food editor, has been teaching individuals and small groups in the Hudson Valley, and in people’s homes in Manhattan. This spring she opened a school in Chelsea and now has an expanded schedule of full participation sessions. There is a maximum of 10 students in each, and they include a meal at the end. Children’s classes and private classes are also available.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Dips and Grills 101

headline: Young Food Entrepreneurs Make Their Future by Hand
text: THEY carry home-grown radishes and red-cooked pork. They transport dozens of empanadas, juggling sheet pans on the G train. They pack boxes of butterscotch cupcakes, Sichuan-spiced beef jerky and grapefruit marmalade. They haul boiled peanuts, ice-grinding machines, sandwich presses and at least one toaster oven painted hot pink.

headline: Organic Gin Just Like Farmers Make (but Legal)
text: Gin, mixed in a martini, is the epitome of sophistication. There is nothing rustic about it. But in this age of everything artisanal and organic, you now have Farmer’s Gin. It’s a small-batch production from the people who make Crop Harvest Earth organic vodkas, based on grains from organic farms in the upper Midwest and infused with classy herbs like elderflower, lemon grass and angelica, besides the required juniper.

headline: Dried Limes, a Middle Eastern Secret for Flavoring Soups and Stews
text: FOR years I had been walking past dried limes in Middle Eastern markets. Dusky brown things slightly larger than Ping-Pong balls, ringed with faint, ghostly stripes, they always seemed vaguely sinister. Even one of their common names  black limes  conveyed an air of culinary menace.

headline: Top Chefs and Restaurateurs Are Drawn to Beirut
text: Beirut

headline: Sour Beer Is Risky Business, Starting With the Name
text: BREWERS of barrel-aged sour beer take risks and practice patience. They wait as long as three years to see whether the cloudy liquids resting in oak ripen into shades of gold or raspberry and develop the ideal tart, tangy flavors, or become undrinkable, ravaged by aggressive yeasts. It’s an expensive gamble.

headline: The Israeli Commandos and the Flotilla
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cooking Up a Dream
text: In New York City, the recent economic downturn has thrown many good cooks — both professional and amateur — out of work. Dozens of them are now trying to start careers as food entrepreneurs, making cupcakes and kimchi, beef jerky and kombucha, and selling at the city’s new weekend food markets. You’ve probably seen some. Do you have any favorites?

headline: Alaska Wants to Drill
text: To the Editor:

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,073 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Tuesday:

headline: First Aid for the Economy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Europe’s Debt Crisis Starts to Weigh on Manufacturing
text: FRANKFURT  Signs emerged Tuesday that Europe’s sovereign debt crisis was feeding through into the euro area economy, as unemployment rose and a survey pointed to a slowdown in the recovery of manufacturing, with a sharp decline in Greece.

headline: Ball Kids Wake Up the French Open
text: PARIS  The children line up outside Court No. 1 before the gates open to the public. There are 250 of them, les ramasseurs de balles, the gatherers of the balls. They are between 12 and 16 years old, and they dress in matching shirts and shorts.

headline: Mayor Proposes Cutting School Nursing Positions
text: New York City workers may be facing layoffs. Libraries are bracing to lose financing, and caseworkers are girding for bigger loads. Now add to the list of victims of citywide budget cuts nursing positions at small schools, public and private.

headline: After Flotilla Raid, U.S. Is Torn Between Allies
text: WASHINGTON  Struggling to navigate a bitter split between two important allies, the Obama administration on Tuesday tried to placate an outraged Turkish government while refusing to condemn Israel for its deadly raid on a flotilla of aid ships bound for Gaza.

headline: The Gores Separate After 4 Decades
text: After 40 years of political defeats and policy triumphs, Al and Tipper Gore announced they would separate.

headline: Two Dried Lime Recipes, One Traditional, One Anything But
text: Though they look kind of like lumpy little rocks, dried limes actually have all kinds of uses as a flavoring. They are excellent used whole in soups and stews as well as lentil and bean dishes; when ground up, they’re great rubbed directly onto steaks or chops, or combined with other spices and a bit of oil to make a paste for rubbing on seafood.

headline: 3 Mayors Seek to Honor a Master of Campaigns
text: From the back porch of Gracie Mansion, John V. Lindsay looked into the camera and ate crow: “I guessed wrong on the weather before the city’s biggest snowstorm last winter. And that was a mistake. But I put 6,000 more cops on the street. And that was no mistake. The school strike went on too long, and we all made some mistakes. But I brought 225,000 more jobs to this town. And that was no mistake.”

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:
