text: U.S. Opens Criminal Inquiry

headline: North Korea Trying for Unexpected in World Cup Again
text: JOHANNESBURG  North Korea’s soccer team arrived Tuesday at the World Cup, where it will be supported by cheerleaders recruited from China, led by a forward born in Japan and prohibited at home from receiving free television coverage provided by fellow competitor and political rival South Korea.

headline: Concussion Committee Breaks With Predecessor
text: WASHINGTON  They accused a fellow doctor of minimizing solid evidence of the dangers of football concussions. They concurred that data collected by the N.F.L.’s former brain-injury leadership was “infected,” said that their committee should be assembled anew, and formally requested that the group’s former chairman, Dr. Elliot Pellman, not speak at a conference Wednesday.

headline: Entrepreneur or Unemployed?
text: Berkeley, Calif.

headline: For Rugby Fans, a First Trip to Soweto
text: SOWETO, South Africa  The wildly zealous fans of rugby’s Blue Bulls are a decidedly white lot but for the blue paint they smear on their faces and the blue wigs they fit over their scalps. They customarily attend games at Pretoria’s Loftus Versfeld Stadium, where they are comfortably among their own kind and the language over the loudspeakers is Dutch-rooted Afrikaans.

headline: New N.Y. Schools Face Extra Pain From Layoffs
text: Glancing down the hallway at the Brooklyn Brownstone School, Nakia Haskins, the principal, did a quick calculation.

headline: Assumptions Go Asunder as Gores Split
text: WASHINGTON  In the baby-boomer psychodrama of the 1990s, Al and Tipper Gore supposedly had the enduring marriage while the union of the other half of their buddy movie  Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton  seemed not so likely to last.

headline: Investment in Rolen Is Paying Off for the Reds
text: ST. LOUIS  When Scott Rolen surveys the Cincinnati Reds’ clubhouse, he likes what he sees. It is not because the Reds are leading the National League in most important offensive categories, as they were through Monday. Lots of players can hit, Rolen said, but how many can really play? There is a difference.

headline: Cuckoo!  Cuckoo!
text: A few weeks ago, I was walking through a wood in the English countryside when I heard the unmistakable call of the cuckoo. For some reason, it caused me to fall into a reverie, and as I walked, I began to meditate on that iconic bird and what it represents.

headline: What to Watch: Serena Williams vs. Samantha Stosur
text: Samantha Stosur used her superb kick serve and heavy topspin forehand to keep Justine Henin off balance and well behind the baseline. It’s a smart play against a one-handed backhand to get the ball up out of the strike zone, forcing the smaller Henin to hit a lot of balls at shoulder level or higher. This also pushed Henin well off the baseline, and Stosur pounced on anything short to score the huge upset.

headline: Is Steve Jobs Big Brother?
text: Steve Jobs is in the running for two trophies: comeback of the decade and villain of the year.

headline: Speaking Up to Stay Silent
text: The Miranda warnings remind suspects of their right to remain silent but were never particularly clear on what happens when a suspect actually stays silent. Can the police question the suspect? If so, can they do they so for just a few minutes or as long as they want?

headline: The Continuing Pain of 9/11
text: Too many years after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, the House is ready to consider proper health care and compensation for thousands of emergency responders and residents of New York City who developed grave illnesses from the clouds of dust and toxins at ground zero.

headline: Suffolk Meltdown
text: The problem of homeless sex offenders is causing a political meltdown on Long Island. In Suffolk County, like places all over the country, sex offenders are barred from living near schools, parks, pools or any other place children gather. Some communities  usually poor  have ended up with more offenders than others. Tensions have risen.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 1, 2010

headline: Israel and the Blockade
text: The supporters of the Gaza-bound aid flotilla had more than humanitarian intentions. The Gaza Freedom March made its motives clear in a statement before Monday’s deadly confrontation: “A violent response from Israel will breathe new life into the Palestine solidarity movement, drawing attention to the blockade.”

headline: Coach Follows His Father While Leading His Way
text: “I am my father.”

headline: Spain Struggles to Agree on a Path to Recovery
text: MADRID  Caught between a populace resistant to more austerity measures and investors demanding budget cuts and more flexible labor markets, the Spanish government is finding it increasingly difficult to keep a grip on power.

headline: Hero to Conservatives Often Follows Centrist Path
text: WASHINGTON  After a pair of votes the other day on some fine points of a major financial regulatory bill, Senator Scott Brown of Massachusetts ducked out of the Capitol and back to his office, where he traded his suit and tie for softball gear to lead his staff in an afternoon match-up against the office of Senator Lamar Alexander of Tennessee.

headline: Japan’s Premier Will Quit as Approval Plummets
text: SEOUL, South Korea  Prime Minister Yukio Hatoyama of Japan, who swept into power last year with bold promises to revamp the country, then faltered over broken campaign pledges to remove an American base from Okinawa, announced Wednesday that he would step down.

headline: When Friends Fall Out
text: As a friend of both Turkey and Israel, it has been agonizing to watch the disastrous clash between Israeli naval commandos and a flotilla of “humanitarian” activists seeking to break the Israeli blockade of Gaza. Personally, I think both Israel and Turkey have gotten out of balance lately, and it is America’s job to help both get back to the center — urgently.

headline: San Diego Police Investigate the Death of a Mexican Man Resisting Deportation
text: LOS ANGELES  The San Diego police are investigating the death of a Mexican man who was struck with a baton and shocked with a stun gun by federal officers as he resisted being deported. The Mexican government and a human rights group condemned the death, which comes after Mexico has condemned Arizona’s tough new immigration enforcement law.

headline: Altria to Pay $971 Million to Resolve a Tax Dispute
text: The Altria Group, the nation’s largest tobacco company, announced on Tuesday that it would pay $971 million to resolve a tax dispute concerning leasing transactions in the years 2000 through 2003.

headline: Blog That Found a Market for Sports News Is Purchased
text: The Big Lead, an independent blog that Jason McIntyre began as a hobby, is fixated on sports media, news and gossip. Along the way, it has built a devoted, if not huge, social media following.

headline: Memorial Is Shaping Up Perfectly
text: DUBLIN, Ohio — It has been said that when it comes to grooming his Muirfield Village Golf Club course for the Memorial Tournament, Jack Nicklaus’s attention to detail is such that he could spot a fly dropping in a pepper mill. So when he announced Tuesday that he did not find a single thing wrong during two tours of the course over the weekend, veteran Nicklaus watchers were stunned.

headline: Calcavecchia Heads to Seniors Tour, Grinning All the Way
text: DUBLIN, Ohio — Mark Calcavecchia, who defied the stereotype of the typical PGA Tour player for almost three decades, will play in his 24th and final Memorial Tournament this week. Calcavecchia, 50, will be grinning all the way to the Champions Tour.

headline: Turkish Funds Helped Group Test Blockade
text: ISTANBUL — Since 2007, a small group of hard-core activists has repeatedly tried to sail cargo-laden ships into Gaza in an effort to thwart Israel’s blockade. But when the Free Gaza Movement teamed up with a much wealthier Turkish organization to assemble a flotilla, it became more than a nuisance, supercharged by the group’s money, manpower and symbolic resonance into what Israel sees as a serious and growing threat.

headline: To Take Baby Pictures of the Universe, Click Here
text: Here was a model for the next great time machine, just over John Grunsfeld’s shoulder in a field in Battery Park: a giant telescope that will be launched in 2014 and sent one million miles from Earth. By looking deep into space, it will collect light and images that have been traveling since nearly the beginning of the universe, and send them back here.

headline: Pennsylvania: Tax Revenue Falls Short
text: Tax revenue for the state was $125 million short of projections for May, leaving the state with a $1.2 billion shortfall for the budget year ending June 30, the State Department of Revenue said. Through 11 months of the fiscal year, Pennsylvania has collected $24.6 billion, or 4.8 percent less than expected for that period in Gov. Edward G. Rendell’s $27.8 billion budget. Mr. Rendell has identified about $700 million of cuts and additional revenue to make up part of the gap.

headline: Skype on the iPhone Goes 3G … Finally
text: Skype, a leading provider of inexpensive phone calls over the Internet, has finally completed a long-awaited move to make its service available over AT&T’s 3G network.

headline: Videos Carry On the Fight Over Sea Raid
text: When Israeli commandos attacked the so-called Freedom Flotilla, both sides were well armed — with video cameras — and both sides have released a blizzard of video clips as evidence that the other side was the aggressor in the conflict on Monday, which left nine activists dead.

headline: Big Setback for A.I.G. in Repaying Taxpayers
text: The American International Group scuttled the deal to sell its huge Asian life insurance arm to Prudential of Britain for about $35 billion, in a major setback to repaying the government for its 2008 rescue.

headline: Study Finds Blacks Blocked From Southern Juries
text: In late April in a courthouse in Madison County, Ala., a prosecutor was asked to explain why he had struck 11 of 14 black potential jurors in a capital murder case.

headline: Photo Replay: June 1
text: A view of the day in sports, with the French Open in Paris and World Cup preparations in South Africa.

headline: 20 in Black Caucus Ask for Curbs on Ethics Office
text: WASHINGTON — Twenty members of the Congressional Black Caucus, including its chairwoman, are asking the House to severely restrict the powers of an independent ethics office that has spent much of its first full year investigating accusations of wrongdoing among black caucus members.

headline: Afghan Assembly Expected to Back Peace-Talk Plan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai opens his showcase event of the year on Wednesday, a national peace convention that is expected to endorse his plan to negotiate with the Taliban and other opposition groups fighting his government.

headline: Telefónica Bid Is Rebuffed
text: Portugal Telecom said on Tuesday that Telefónica had raised its bid for a venture that controls Brazil’s largest wireless operator to about 6.5 billion euros ($7.99 billion).

headline: A Million Miles From Earth
text: A new space observatory described as the successor to the Hubble Space Telescope is on display at the World Science Festival at Battery Park.

headline: Tribesman of Kenya
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Today’s fishing expedition had me pulling in a red herring on my first cast, as I entered in “Light Brigade” at 20 Across. After discovering the three other theme phrases ended in HOOK, LINE and REEL, I was puzzled as to how “brigade” fit in. Finishing off the NE corner of the puzzle set me straight.

headline: S.E.C. Is Said to Seek to Bar Wall St. Financier
text: As it investigates a suspected kickback scheme in New York’s pension system, the Securities and Exchange Commission has been pushing to bar Steven L. Rattner, a prominent financier and former adviser to the Obama administration on the auto industry, from working in the securities industry for up to three years, according to three people told of the discussions.

headline: Afghan Police Earn Poor Grade for Marja Mission
text: MARJA, Afghanistan  Three months after arriving in the most dangerous area of Afghanistan’s Helmand Province, a contingent of specialized Afghan police officers has logged a mediocre performance while being almost wholly dependent on American supervision and support, Westerners who work with the officers said.

headline: For Rugby Fans, a First Trip to Soweto
text: Thousands of white rugby fans descended on Soweto, South Africa's largest black township, for a match between the Pretoria Blue Bulls and the Soweto Stormers. For many, it was their first visit.

headline: Deep Underwater, Oil Threatens Reefs
text: Last September, marine scientists studying deep-sea biology in the northern Gulf of Mexico lowered a submersible robot off the side of a government research vessel and piloted it 1,300 feet to the ocean floor.

headline: Cleanup Costs and Lawsuits Rattle BP’s Investors
text: BP shareholders are fleeing the company’s stock amid growing uncertainty about the ultimate bill for cleanup costs, lawsuits, fines and damage to the oil giant’s reputation.

headline: Morgenthau Withdraws as Monitor on Fire Jobs
text: Bowing to concerns over his appointment but fiercely defending his record, Robert M. Morgenthau stepped down on Tuesday from his role overseeing the city’s efforts to increase the number of minority firefighters in response to a long-running discrimination lawsuit.

headline: Guatemala Struggles to Recover After Storm
text: GRANADA, Nicaragua  Victims of the first tropical storm of the region’s hurricane season began returning to their storm-battered homes in Guatemala on Tuesday because of a lack of emergency food and beds to house them, relief officials said.

headline: A Storyteller Loses the Story Line
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Foxconn Raises Worker Pay 30%
text: The Foxconn Technology Group, a giant contract electronics manufacturer that experienced a series of worker suicides, said it would raise salaries by at least 30 percent, more than previously indicated.

headline: Hanes Banks on Strong Tie With Star
text: Michael Jordan, the longtime star of commercials for Hanes, has a new sidekick to sell the apparel company’s undershirts. The twosome appear side by side as airplane seatmates. Mr. Jordan was previously paired with the actor Charlie Sheen, who was dropped from company advertising. He was arrested in the winter in a domestic violence dispute.

headline: Vazquez’s Performance at Stadium Is a Good Start
text: Javier Vazquez did not remember the last time he started a game at Yankee Stadium, and with good reason. The cacophony that tends to accompany his starts there  boos, hisses, jeers  never polluted the air Tuesday night because Vazquez did not let it.

headline: Liberia Aids U.S. in Drug Fight
text: Over the past three years, United States authorities say, South American drug traffickers have worked to build a base in the West African nation of Liberia, where vast quantities of cocaine could be sent by boat or plane and then reshipped to markets in West Africa and Europe.

headline: Mets Want Perez to Move Aside for Niese
text: SAN DIEGO  Four Mets left-handers pitched Monday, but the only one who performed well was in the minor leagues.

headline: Fear Grips a Family
text: A look at the world's largest family suffering from Alzheimer's disease, and the hope that they may help scientists find answers for everyone else.

headline: Watching as the Baton Is Passed
text: Flights from São Paulo to New York City take 10 hours. But what if I was asked to do the same trip, but taking my sweet time – say, three months – inching up the hemisphere by bus, Amazonian riverboat and, who knows, maybe even the occasional llama?  That pretty much describes my dream trip. And on someone else’s dime? You can’t be serious.

headline: Blackhawks Are on a Roll in Stanley Cup Finals
text: The Flyers have all kinds of reasons to be nervous going into Game 3 of the Stanley Cup finals Wednesday in Philadelphia, and all kinds of reasons to be confident.

headline: In Era of LeBron, Kobe Isn’t Stepping Aside
text: LOS ANGELES  At the time, it appeared that Jerry West needed his purple and gold checked. West, the keen talent evaluator and executive who orchestrated the trade that brought a teenaged Kobe Bryant to the Los Angeles Lakers, said during last season’s playoffs that LeBron James had better skills as a player than Bryant did.

headline: The Vanishing Mind
text: By studying an extended family in Colombia where Alzheimer’s is seen in the early 40s, scientists hope to find a treatment for Alzheimer’s patients worldwide.

headline: Black Congressman Loses Alabama Primary
text: WASHINGTON  Representative Artur Davis of Alabama, who sidestepped the state’s black political leadership in hopes of building a diverse coalition of voters in his campaign for governor, was rejected on Tuesday by Democratic primary voters, with the state agriculture commissioner, Ron Sparks, seizing a decisive victory.

headline: Patient Voices: Alzheimer's Disease
text: A slow decline in memory, an inability to complete simple tasks, the concern about long-term care - eight men and women speak about living with and caring for someone with Alzheimer's disease.

headline: Lidstrom Puts Off Retiring
text: Nicklas Lidstrom, the Red Wings’ 40-year-old defenseman, signed a one-year, $6.2 million contract to return to Detroit instead of retiring. He has spent all of his 18 N.H.L. seasons with Detroit.

headline: Kazuo Ohno, a Founder of Japanese Butoh, Dies at 103
text: Kazuo Ohno, a founder of Butoh, the influential Japanese dance-theater form whose traditional look of darkness and decay evoked for many the horrors of the wartime bombings of Japan, died on Tuesday in Yokohama, Japan. He was 103 and had continued to perform beyond his 100th year.

headline: Federer’s Loss Raises New Possibilities
text: It was supposed to be a dream final between a brawny Spaniard with legendary wheels and a Swiss legend with a powerful forehand, especially after the Madrid Open final, the first match between Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer in exactly a year. Billed as the ultimate test for the greatest player ever, attempting to defeat the greatest clay courter ever, the dream tantalized until Robin Soderling’s blistering strokes crushed it like a piñata.

headline: Corrections
text: A film review on Thursday about “Sex and the City 2” misstated the title of a song Liza Minnelli performs in the movie. It is “Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It),” not “All the Single Ladies,” which is a line from the song.

headline: Bailout Haunts Any A.I.G. Deal
text: The wrangling over the American International Group’s Asian insurance unit clarifies what the board of Prudential of Britain should have known all along: A.I.G. is beholden to the American taxpayer. While accepting a lower price might have been a rational business decision, it also would have further opened A.I.G. to criticism that it was shortchanging its owners — in this case, to help a foreign insurer.

headline: A Family’s Torment as Relatives Slip Away
text: The anguish of Alzheimer’s in a sprawling extended family in Colombia may be hardest on those still lucid enough to know they have it, or those who know they could.

headline: A Perplexing Case Puts a Doctor on the Trail of ‘Madness’
text: In 1982, Dr. Francisco Lopera, a Medellín neurologist, was puzzled. A 47-year-old patient was losing his memory, and so had his father, grandfather and seven other relatives.

headline: Alzheimer’s Stalks a Colombian Family
text: YARUMAL, Colombia — Tucked away on a steep street in this rough-hewn mountain town, an old woman found herself diapering her middle-age children.

headline: A Worldwide Whirlwind on Woodwinds
text: Steve Gorn, primarily a Bansuri flute player, told his story to Ozier Muhammad of The Times:

headline: Phys Ed: Does Massage Help After Exercise?
text: Michael Tschakovsky, an associate professor in the School of Kinesiology and Health Studies at Queen’s University in Kingston, Ontario, enjoys a post-exercise massage as much as anyone. But unlike those of us who happily drowse through the massage therapist’s assurance that the pummeling and kneading is speeding blood flow to our muscles and draining them of built-up lactic acid, Mr. Tschakovsky took notes. His academic specialty is the study of blood flow to muscles, particularly in diseases like diabetes, and he decided to put the therapists’ words to the test.

headline: Happy Feet or Kicking It New School
text: Imelda Marcos is unlikely to attend any matches of the 2010 World Cup, but she (and her prodigious collection of quality footwear) will find some kindred spirits gallivanting across the green soccer fields of South Africa in the latest high-fashion (and high-priced) kicks (or boots, or cleats). Few could rival the collection of the former first lady of the Philippines, but when it comes to soccer cleats players can never have too many shoes. In fact, they probably need more feet!

headline: Steve Jobs Muses on All Things Apple
text: For Steven P. Jobs, the chief executive of Apple, the timing of his public appearance at the D8 conference could not have been better. Last week, Apple surpassed Microsoft to become the world’s most valuable technology company. A little more than a decade ago, Apple was struggling for its life, and many tech pundits were predicting its demise.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Video View of Guatemala Sinkhole
text: Just in case anyone had doubts about the reality of the extraordinary sinkhole that formed in a crowded district of Guatemala City — following a similar incident in the city in 2007 — this Associated Press video report closes the case. [There’s more on Guatemala City’s shaky underpinnings in the Daily Beast.]

headline: S.E.C. Is Said to Be Seeking to Bar Rattner
text: As it investigates a suspected kickback scheme in New York’s pension system, the Securities and Exchange Commission has been pushing to bar Steven L. Rattner, a prominent financier and former adviser to the Obama administration on the auto industry, from working in the securities industry for up to three years, according to three people told of the discussions, The New York Times’s Michael Barbaro reports.

headline: Alabama Voters Reject Coalition Bid
text: WASHINGTON  Representative Artur Davis of Alabama, who sidestepped the state’s black political leadership in hopes of building a diverse coalition of voters in his campaign for governor, was rejected Tuesday by Democratic primary voters, with the state agriculture commissioner, Ron Sparks, seizing a decisive victory.

headline: Word of the Day | diligence
text: diligence •\ˈdi-lə-jən(t)s\• noun

headline: Big Setback for A.I.G. in Repaying Taxpayers
text: 1:49 a.m. | Updated Prudential said Wednesday that it was negotiating an end to its talks with A.I.G.

headline: E-Books by McMurty
text: E-BOOKS BY MCMURTRY

headline: Zach Braff to Star Off Broadway in ‘Trust’
text: After eight seasons starring on the comedy “Scrubs,” Zach Braff, below, will return to a New York stage this summer in the Off Broadway production of the dark comedy “Trust,” a new play by Paul Weitz, the co-director of the films “About a Boy” and “American Pie.” Joining Mr. Braff in the ensemble cast at Second Stage Theater will be the Tony Award-winning actress Sutton Foster (“Thoroughly Modern Millie”), Bobby Cannavale (a Tony nominee for “Mauritius”) and Ari Graynor (“The Little Dog Laughed”). Mr. Braff’s last major theater role in New York was as Sebastian in the Shakespeare in the Park production of “Twelfth Night,” in 2002. In “Trust,” Mr. Braff will play a wealthy married man who “looks to find something real in the most unlikely of places,” according to a statement from Second Stage. Directed by Peter DuBois (“Becky Shaw”), the production is scheduled to begin preview performances on July 23, open on Aug. 12, and run through Sept. 5. PATRICK HEALY

headline: Seinfeld, the Director
text: If he can see a metaphor for racial harmony in a black-and-white cookie, and explain the similarities between breaking up and knocking over a soda machine, surely Jerry Seinfeld, left, understands how to communicate with actors. But he has rarely tried his hand at directing until now. Mr. Seinfeld, the comedian and sitcom star, will direct his friend and fellow stand-up comic Colin Quinn in “Long Story Short,” a one-man show that Mr. Quinn will perform at the Bleecker Street Theater, publicists for the show said on Tuesday. The play is Mr. Quinn’s attempt to cover 2,000 years of history in about 75 minutes. The show, produced by Columbus 81 Productions, is scheduled to run from June 19 to Aug. 15. Let’s hope Crazy Joe Davola isn’t in the audience on opening night.

headline: Saudis on MTV May Face Charges
text: Three Saudi youths who appeared in a recent broadcast of the MTV documentary series “True Life” could be brought to court by the Saudi Arabian religious police, which are suing them for the crime of “openly declaring sin,” Reuters reported. The “True Life” episode called “Resist the Power, Saudi Arabia,” which was first shown on May 24, chronicled three young Saudis who tried to resist their homeland’s strict morality: Aziz, who is trying to meet a girlfriend on a date; Fatima, who makes cloaks in colors other than black; and Ahmad, who wants women to be able to hold elected office. A Jeddah court official confirmed to Reuters that a lawsuit had been filed against the three, who were identified by only their first names in the episode. The court, which follows Islamic law, said it would take at least a week to decide whether to proceed with a trial. Penalties for convictions on morality offenses can include corporal punishment and imprisonment. MTV did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

headline: More Theater for Boston
text: The Boston theater landscape is set to expand significantly in September with the inaugural season of ArtsEmerson, a programming arm of Emerson College, with 17 professional stage productions through May 2011 including “The Laramie Project” and its sequel, “The Laramie Project: Ten Years Later”; two works by the director Peter Brook; and Elevator Repair Service’s adaptation of “The Sun Also Rises.” The season will begin on Sept. 23 with a one-week run of “Fräulein Maria,” a re-imagining of “The Sound of Music” by the choreographer Doug Elkins. Other highlights include “Petrushka,” created by the puppeteer Basil Twist, set to Stravinsky’s classic score; two Irish imports, “The Cripple of Inishmaan” by Martin McDonagh, above, from the Druid Theater and Mark O’Rowe’s “Terminus” from the Abbey Theater; and a production of “The Merchant of Venice” by the Theater for a New Audience, starring F. Murray Abraham as Shylock. Emerson College established ArtsEmerson last year to oversee productions at the 1,186-seat Cutler Majestic Theater and the new Paramount Center in Boston. PATRICK HEALY

headline: License to Shill
text: Calvin Trillin and Edward Koren on how old establishments are licensing brands to become “hep.”

headline: Repeats Beat Reality
text: Week two of “The Bachelorette” was down sharply in the ratings on Monday night, bringing a low-rated end to the Memorial Day weekend. That ABC reality show drew an average of 7.6 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates, down from the 9.1 million who tuned in a week ago for the show’s sixth-season premiere. ABC ranked second in the ratings on the night behind CBS, which led with a lineup of repeats. A rerun of “CSI: Miami” (8 million) on CBS outdrew the second-season debut of ABC’s “True Beauty” (5.4 million), a reality show in which beauty contestants are unsuspectingly judged on their moral qualities. NBC was third over all with its coverage of Game 2 of the National Hockey League’s Stanley Cup Finals, averaging approximately 6 million viewers in prime time. Fox ranked fourth with repeats of “Lie to Me” (3.3 million) and “The Good Guys” (3 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Is Peter Jackson’s Hat in the ‘Hobbit’ Ring?
text: As the producers of “The Hobbit” seek a new director for the film adaptation of that J. R. R. Tolkien fantasy novel, they may have a replacement in their midst who already knows a thing or two about translating Tolkien’s texts to the big screen: Peter Jackson, left, an executive producer and screenwriter on “The Hobbit.” In an interview with The Dominion Post of New Zealand, Mr. Jackson, the Academy Award-winning director of the “Lord of the Rings” trilogy, said that if necessary he would step in as director of “The Hobbit,” pending his commitments to other films. Over the weekend Guillermo del Toro said he was withdrawing as director of “The Hobbit,” citing the continued delays of its start of production. (The film is planned to be released in two parts in 2012 and 2013 by MGM, which put itself up for sale last year and is still seeking buyers.) Among his coming films, Mr. Jackson is producing “The Adventures of Tintin: The Secret of the Unicorn” as well as an untitled sequel. But Mr. Jackson told The Dominion Post that his directing “The Hobbit” was not an impossibility. “If that’s what I have to do to protect Warner Brothers’ investment, then obviously that’s one angle which I’ll explore,” he said, adding, “The other studios may not let me out of the contracts.”

headline: Mets’ Pelfrey Wins Fourth Start in a Row
text: SAN DIEGO  One night after a cartoonish game in which the basepaths were constantly choked with Padres runners and two dozen total runs were scored, the Mets got a refreshingly well-pitched game from the man who is becoming their stopper, their workhorse, and surely an impending All-Star.

headline: News Quiz | June 2, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: South Africa: Union Threatens to Quit Governing Alliance
text: In the most significant sign yet of cracks in South Africa’s governing alliance, Cosatu, the trade union federation with two million members, threatened Tuesday to quit if the African National Congress, the party in power, takes disciplinary action against Cosatu’s general secretary, Zwelinzima Vavi. Cosatu said it had learned that an influential A.N.C. committee had decided that Mr. Vavi should be sanctioned for saying publicly that the party was perceived as soft on corruption that is said to involve government ministers. A.N.C. officials would not comment.

headline: Taliban Attacks Shake Afghan Peace Gathering
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai’s peace council, called a jirga, came under fire from inside and out on its first day Wednesday.

headline: Burundi: Candidates Accuse Government of Voter Fraud
text: Five presidential candidates, including a former president and former rebel leader, said Tuesday that they would boycott the June presidential election over allegations of voter fraud. They accused the government of rigging local elections last month in which candidates belonging to the ruling party of President Pierre Nkurunziza won by wide margins. The number of votes counted, the five said, had exceeded the number of registered voters.

headline: Canada: Man Taken Off Plane Is Questioned by U.S. Officials
text: A man who was removed from a Mexican airliner in Montreal after it was denied entry to the United States airspace because of his presence was turned over to American officials on Tuesday, the Canada Border Services Agency said. The man, Abdirahman Ali Gaal, was taken in handcuffs from a flight from Paris to Mexico City on Sunday. A Homeland Security spokesman, Matthew Chandler, said American officials were questioning Mr. Gaal, who was born in Somalia and is a legal, permanent resident of the United States, but he would not say why Mr. Gaal was being held.

headline: Dominican Republic: Suit Over Haitian Descendants
text: Civil rights lawyers filed a case before the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights on Tuesday challenging the Dominican Republic’s treatment of Dominican-born people of Haitian ancestry. Although Haitians have worked in the Dominican Republic for generations and their offspring had long been entitled to Dominican citizenship, in recent years the Dominican government has decided that the offspring of illegal immigrants are not Dominicans. The suit was filed on behalf of a Dominican-born man who has been denied a certified copy of his birth certificate.

headline: Bailout Will Haunt Any A.I.G. Deal
text: The wrangling over the American International Group’s Asian insurance unit clarifies what the board of Prudential of Britain should have known all along: A.I.G. is beholden to the American taxpayer, Reuters Breakingviews writes.

headline: Loans That Vanished in a Property Bust Reappear
text: The W Hotel in Union Square has had an eventful six months. The 270-room hotel changed hands in December after the private equity division of Dubai World defaulted on a $117 million mezzanine loan in the face of dwindling business. But the lender, LEM Mezzanine, could itself lose the hotel in coming months as a result of its filing for bankruptcy protection earlier this year, Jotham Sederstrom reports in The New York Times.

headline: Telefónica’s New Bid Is Rebuffed by Portugal Telecom
text: Portugal Telecom said on Tuesday that Telefónica had raised its bid for a venture that controls Brazil’s largest wireless operator to about 6.5 billion euros ($7.99 billion), Bloomberg News reported.

headline: American Apprentices at the Bolshoi Ballet
text: WHAT is the Bolshoi Ballet?

headline: Citigroup Unit Being Revamped for Sale
text: Citigroup is closing 330 branches of its consumer finance business as part of an overhaul aimed at finding a buyer for the unit, the bank said Tuesday according to The Associated Press.

headline: Neo-Frugalists
text: Thrifty young consumers.

headline: In Bid to Quell Anger Over Raid, Israel Frees Detainees
text: JERUSALEM  Israel worked Wednesday to defuse rising international anger by agreeing to a rapid release of all detainees  including those suspected of attacking its soldiers  taken after the deadly nighttime raid of six ships seeking to break its blockade of the Gaza Strip.

headline: Pru in Talks to End Deal; Costs at $662 Million
text: Prudential Plc, the British insurer, said Wednesday that it was in negotiations to cancel its planned takeover of the Asian life insurance unit of American International Group.

headline: Oil Spill Inquiry Chills Traders at the Close
text: Stocks in the United States were dragged lower by the energy sector after the government announced on Tuesday that it was opening investigations into the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, The New York Times’s Christine Hauser reported.

headline: Germany Balks at Opel Aid for G.M.
text: General Motors received a setback Tuesday in its effort to secure 1.1 billion euros in German aid for its money-losing Opel unit, after a government panel declined to endorse the request, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: N.Y.S.E. Gets Starbucks as Part of Revamp
text: “If you had told me 20 years ago that one day we would be sitting down and able to drink coffee on the floor, I would not have believed it,” Neil Catania, chief executive of MND Partners, 29-year veteran of the New York Stock Exchange told The Financial Times.

headline: Bad News Fridays
text: No one likes revealing bad news. But lately, Wall Street has taken to sneaking out some of its less palatable developments right before the weekend. Such timing may keep to the letter of transparency rules, but hardly the spirit, Reuters Breakingviews says.

headline: Sports News Blog Is Sold
text: The Big Lead, an independent blog that Jason McIntyre began as a hobby, is fixated on sports media, news and gossip. Along the way, it has built a devoted, if not huge, social media following.

headline: Biglari Extends Offer for Advance Auto Shares
text: Sardar Biglari, the activist investor who took over Steak n Shake after a widely publicized struggle in 2007 and renamed it Biglari Holdings, said Tuesday his company had extended an offer to buy up to 1.6 percent of the shares of Advance Auto Parts from Tuesday until Friday.

headline: Do You Have a Summer Job?
text: Some wealthy parents want their teenaged children to work so that they can appreciate the value of what they want and have, but the job market for teens is shrinking. Do you have a job? Why or why not? Do you think it is important for teenagers to have jobs?

headline: Buffett to Testify at Crisis Panel Wednesday
text: Warren E. Buffett and the chief executive of credit rating agency Moody’s are scheduled to face questions Wednesday from a bipartisan panel probing the roots the financial crisis.

text: What the stock market giveth the Massachusetts pension fund, it also taketh away.

headline: Paris Exhibition Questions Where ‘Here’ Is
text: “One’s destination is never a place but rather a new way of looking at things,” the writer Henry Miller once said. “Perspectives,” a new exhibition opening June 4 at the Louis Vuitton Cultural Center, aspires to understand space, the world and the essence of travel through works by two French artists, Odile Decq and Camille Henrot.

headline: Porter Aviation Grounds I.P.O.
text: Porter Airlines, a popular Canadian-based regional carrier that flies to New York City, Boston and Chicago, delayed its initial public offering Tuesday because of unfavorable market conditions caused by volatility in the equity markets, The Associated Press reported.

text: Today’s idea: Our use of spare time is now less about passive viewing and more about engaging — from Flickr and Facebook to online political action — an author says. And new insights into human motivation help explain this historic shift, says another.

headline: Cancer and Me
text: Regular readers of this blog and my Friday and Saturday columns no doubt have noticed that my productivity has plunged. I want to explain.

headline: ‘You Hired a Chef and You’ve Never Tasted His Food?’
text: I have worked with actors, athletes, composers, dancers, musicians and models. I am not saying that chefs are the highest strung or tightest wound group I have come across, but I would not hesitate to say they play second fiddle to no one. Holy smoke!

headline: Ametek Acquires Medical Device Parts Maker
text: Ametek, which makes electric motors, battery chargers and products for aerospace, defense and other industries, said Tuesday it had acquired the privately held Technical Services for Electronics for an undisclosed amount, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Prudential Faces Fallout From Failed Deal
text: After the collapse of the deal to sell the American International Group’s huge Asian life insurance arm to the British insurer Prudential, the firm appears to be headed for some significant fallout.

headline: Quarterfinal French Open Showdown: Jankovic vs. Shvedova
text: PARIS – The light was fading on an English summer afternoon last year at Wimbledon as the two unknowns battled into a third set. About 100 friends, family members and the curious gathered at the sides of the distant court.

headline: China to Subsidize Electric Cars and Hybrids
text: The Chinese government appears determined to electrify transportation, and it is putting money in place alongside its rhetoric.

headline: Couche-Tard Begins Tender Offer for Casey’s
text: Alimentation Couche-Tard, the Canadian convenience store operator, went hostile in its pursuit of Casey’s General Stores, beginning a tender offer for its American counterpart and announcing its plan to nominate an alternate slate of directors.

headline: An Earpiece With Controls You Can See

headline: Service Members Share Thoughts on the Personal Items That Come With Them
text: The New York Times again invites members of the military who are serving, or have served, in Afghanistan to help us document the daily life of this war in photographs, video and writing. Take us on a tour of the FOB, introduce us to your friends, describe the hardships of deployment and the humor that helps you pass the time.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: It’s another red-letter day for regulators. The New York Times has the scoop on the S.E.C. wanting to ban Steve Rattner. The German cabinet just advanced in its crusade against short-selling. China’s clamping down on rare earths, etc. etc. Still, it’s not all doom and gloom for the private sector: Nomura has tripled management’s pay.

headline: Jupiter Seeks $322 Million in I.P.O.
text: Jupiter Asset Management, the British fund firm, is seeking to raise as much as £220 million ($322 million) in an initial public offering that would value the firm at £868 million, on the high end.

headline: Oil, Inertia and the Energy Quest
text: I had to run down to the supermarket yesterday during a break from tracking the petro-calamity that continues to unfold in the Gulf of Mexico. Walking through the frozen-food section, I was reminded just how far this country is from being engaged in the “energy quest” that’d be needed not only to wean ourselves from oil but also to limit the human influence on the planet’s climate system. The oil disaster doesn’t belong to BP, or to President Obama or his predecessor; we all own it.

headline: A Video Camera Has Become the Newest Weapon in Global Crises
text: As Brian Stelter writes in Wednesday’s New York Times, the latest weapon in international disputes has become the video camera. The power of moving images to drive public opinion in the midst of an unfolding crisis became apparent with the video of a young woman, Neda, dying of a head wound during protests in Iran. So it’s little wonder that in the confrontation this week between Turkey’s Freedom Flotilla and the Israeli Navy, both sides came armed with cameras. The truth, though, remains elusive. Mr. Stelter writes:

headline: A Proliferation of Plumes?
text: Tony Hayward, the chief executive of BP, claimed recently that his company’s testing has shown “no evidence” that any of the oil in the Gulf of Mexico is lurking beneath the ocean surface. Oil is lighter than water, Mr. Hayward explained, and will rise to the top.

headline: The Early Word: Midterm Wins and Losses
text: One of the most closely watched races in recent months has been the one for Alabama’s governor. Representative Artur Davis, a longtime Congressman, was defeated in the Democratic primary on Tuesday night in his bid to become the state’s first black governor.

headline: Action Sought Against Wall St. Financier
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: Conan O’Brien to Fans: Tweet This
text: Most theater events begin with a warning to turn off cell phones and portable communication devices but not Conan O’Brien‘s Legally Prohibited From Being Funny on Television Tour. During Mr. O’Brien’s stop at Radio City Music Hall on Tuesday night (which Alessandra Stanley reviews here for The New York Times), the former “Tonight Show” host not only encouraged his audience members to tweet during the performance but also gave them a suggested hashtag – #triumph – so their tweets could be collected in one convenient location.

headline: Another View: Punting Financial Reform
text: Daniel Alpert, managing director of Westwood Capital, looks at what financial regulatory reform still needs to accomplish.

text: Q.

text: When it comes to investing, stick with what you know.

headline: Alabama Voters Reject Coalition Bid
text: WASHINGTON  Whether it was his vote against the health care legislation or his strategy to sidestep the state’s black political leadership, the decisive defeat of Artur Davis in his quest to become the first black governor of Alabama illustrates the limits of trying to replicate the strategy that helped carry President Obama to office.

headline: Prosecutor Says Plea Deal Reached in Sheen Case
text: A Colorado prosecutor said Tuesday night that an agreement had been reached with Charlie Sheen, the “Two and a Half Men” star, in a case involving a domestic dispute between Mr. Sheen and his wife, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Ask a Bartender: Round 2 Responses
text: In Friday’s weekend section Frank Bruni wrote about Doug Quinn, who has tended bar at the original P. J. Clarke’s on Third Avenue only since 2003. “But in that time, he has become a legend, the bartenders’ bartender.” We asked readers to submit questions for Mr. Quinn. Here is his second round of responses.

headline: The Voices of Alzheimer’s
text: In the latest Patient Voices segment, producer Karen Barrow explores the frightening and confusing world of Alzheimer’s. She captures the voices of both patients and loved ones who are struggling with issues of independence, long-term care and making the most of the time they have left.

headline: How a Soccer Star Is Made
text: The youth academy of the famed dutch soccer club Ajax is grandiosely called De Toekomst — The Future. Set down beside a highway in an unprepossessing district of Amsterdam, it consists of eight well-kept playing fields and a two-story building that houses locker rooms, classrooms, workout facilities and offices for coaches and sports scientists. In an airy cafe and bar, players are served meals and visitors can have a glass of beer or a cappuccino while looking out over the training grounds. Everything about the academy, from the amenities to the pedigree of the coaches — several of them former players for the powerful Dutch national team — signifies quality. Ajax once fielded one of the top professional teams in Europe. With the increasing globalization of the sport, which has driven the best players to richer leagues in England, Germany, Italy and Spain, the club has become a different kind of enterprise — a talent factory. It manufactures players and then sells them, often for immense fees, on the world market. “All modern ideas on how to develop youngsters begin with Ajax,” Huw Jennings, an architect of the English youth-development system, told me. “They are the founding fathers.”

headline: The Ajax Soccer Academy: From Boys to Pros
text: An inside look at the grooming grounds for European soccer talent.

headline: Training to Play the World's Game
text: The sights and sounds of the fabled youth academy of Ajax Amsterdam, where boys start working at age 7 to become professional soccer players.

headline: Interests And Ideas
text: Lambert has a righteous rant about my Monday column, in which I decried the emerging conventional wisdom that we need to tighten monetary and fiscal policy, but didn’t say much about who is responsible for this emergence.

headline: Complete Video of Israeli Raid Still Missing
text: Updated | 6:15 p.m. On Wednesday, Israel’s military posted another 70 seconds of video shot during the commando raid Monday that killed nine people on board a ship that was protesting Israel’s naval blockade of Gaza by trying to break it. Unlike previous clips of the raid uploaded to the Israel Defense Forces YouTube channel — which has been live since the Israeli offensive in Gaza in December 2008 — this footage (embedded above) appears to have been shot by activists or journalists on the ship and edited by the I.D.F.

headline: Jankovic Beats Shvedova to Reach Semifinals
text: PARIS – Yaroslava Shvedova, the unseeded Russian-born player who represents Kazakhstan, broke Jelena Jankovic’s serve in the first game of their French Open quarterfinal match at Roland Garros. It looked like a sign of Jankovic’s weakness.

headline: Do Backyard Chickens Lay Run-of-the-Mill Eggs?
text: That’s the conclusion of a Washington Post taste test, in which the writer pits the products of birds she raises herself with the contents of supermarket cartons:

headline: The Changing World, Alpine Edition
text: OK, so I’m currently in Interlaken, Switzerland to talk to the Swiss Economic Forum tomorrow. Robin and I were last here about 15 years ago. And it has changed.

headline: Bloomberg Moves to Block Teachers’ Raises
text: Updated, 12:10 p.m. | After warning of widespread teacher layoffs for months, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced Wednesday morning that the city would eliminate planned raises for all of its public-school teachers and principals for the next two years, which he said would “save the jobs of some 4,400 teachers.”

headline: Wednesday Reading: Late Tax Refund Checks
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Interview With Anand
text: The impact and influence of Viswanathan Anand, the world champion, on his home country of India seem apparent from this interview on NDTV. It seems to have been recorded prior to his defense of the title last month in Bulgaria.

headline: A Mint.com for Investments
text: A Bits blog post from Claire Cain Miller, “Wikinvest Introduces Tool to Track Investments,” details how the start-up Wikinvest plans to introduce an investment tracking tool on Wednesday similar to Mint.com’s spending and savings tracking tool.

headline: Stosur Beats Serena Williams and Surges Into Semifinals
text: PARIS – Samantha Stosur of Australia started strong, pounding the ball from corner to corner and running top-seeded Serena Williams to distraction, but Williams, smacking aces at key moments, would not yield. Their quarterfinal French Open duel lurched forward as a contest of will and power.

headline: Encouraging a High-School Dropout
text: Graduation time. For so many families it is the finish line, the goal, the motivating force behind years of encouragement and disappointment, cajoling, threatening, juggling and sacrificing. It can, for better or worse, come to seem like the measure of successful parenting — getting them to that diploma, launching them into the next chapter properly prepared.

headline: Panel Seeks More Police Training on Sex Crimes
text: Responding to concerns that sexual assault complaints have been mishandled by the police in New York, a task force appointed by Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly has recommended new training protocols for officers dealing with sex crime victims.

headline: Hey, Mr. Critic!
text: Is there a vegetarian in your family, some kinda-vegan sprouts-eater who sometimes (but only sometimes!) eats quail? Are there Atkins-style meat eaters who eschew all roughage, who refuse to countenance fish? Do you have to take these people to dinner? The mailbox brought two of just these sorts of questions.

headline: Grid Confronts a Threat from Mother Nature
text: A report just issued by the Energy Department and the North American Electric Reliability Corporation, known as Nerc, an industry group that polices the power grid, lists three categories of threats to the grid: coordinated cyber- and physical attacks, pandemic disease and electromagnetic damage.

text: In this post, I will connect the transformative quality of writing with the searing fearlessness of college essays, or college essays as they should be.

headline: Rwanda Says Jailed American Tried to Kill Himself

headline: What Pets Can Teach Us About Marriage
text: Do you greet each other with excitement, overlook each other’s flaws and easily forgive bad behavior? If it’s your pet, the answer is probably yes. But your spouse? Probably not.

headline: Hands-On Theater (at Times With Fists)
text: AT the first performance of an early run of “Amerissiah” in 2008, Derek Ahonen, the director and playwright, was becoming increasingly, intensely angry. The audience was not laughing. He could forgive the cast forgetting some lines or even performing drunk, but botching jokes was far worse. At the curtain he charged backstage and screamed at the company.

text: The latest procedure to try to contain the oil gushing into the Gulf of Mexico hit a snag on Wednesday when a saw that was being used in a crucial part of the operation became stuck, officials said.

headline: Midsize S.U.V.’s Score Well in Rollover Test
text: Last year, the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety began testing vehicles to see how they would fare in rollover crashes, which claim about 10,000 lives each year, according to government figures.

headline: Do You Still Hear the People Sing? ‘Les Miz’ Celebrates a Quarter-Century
text: To celebrate the 25th anniversary of the musical “Les Misérables” three different productions of the show will be performed in London over the Oct. 2 and 3 weekend, including a concert at the O2 arena that will feature Nick Jonas as Marius, Lea Salonga as Fantine, Alfie Boe as Jean Valjean and Matt Lucas and Jenny Galloway as the Thenardiers, the producers announced on Wednesday.

headline: Using Theater as a Salve to Soothe Minds

headline: Un-Innocents Abroad: The Drubbing
text: “HOW the hell did we get into this mess?” When Sarah Jessica Parker asked that question on the first episode of the HBO series “Sex and the City” in 1998, it came in the midst of an opening monologue that signaled the end of one kind of pop cultural heroine (“No one has breakfast at Tiffany’s”) and the birth of a new one (“Welcome to the age of un-innocence”). Her name was Carrie Bradshaw, a New York writer and wit whose search for true love with a man never got in the way of her sex drive or close female friendships. Romance was dead, the show announced, but female desire was alive and kicking, usually in $400 designer heels.

headline: Paterson Proposes Juvenile Justice Overhaul
text: Gov. David A. Paterson introduced legislation on Wednesday to begin overhauling New York’s troubled juvenile prison system, in what aides described at a first step toward broader changes long sought by critics of the system.

headline: On Alabama Coast, a Sense of Urgency

headline: First-Place Reds Follow Scott Rolen’s Lead
text: ST. LOUIS — First, an admission: I’ve made a lot of dumb predictions here. It turns out the White Sox are not, in fact, running away with the A.L. Central. But I did have a feeling this spring about the Cincinnati Reds, and sometimes those feelings are right. And after two months -– a small sample, but still -– the Reds are leading the defending champion St. Louis Cardinals by a game in the N.L. Central.

headline: Sit. Stay. Appreciate: Music for Dogs

This morning, my wife was testing out a route for a fitness hike she leads each week and I got to tag along.

headline: Obama Wants to Roll Back Tax Breaks for Oil Companies

headline: Marina Abramovic’s Costume Change
text: After wearing a stark, floor-length robe for seven hours a day, six days a week since March 14, the artist Marina Abramovic, for the closing party of her exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art on Tuesday, changed into — what else? — a custom-made dress and a black jacket made from the skins of 101 snakes by Riccardo Tisci of Givenchy.

headline: 12 Killed in Rampage in Rural Britain

headline: For Nicklaus, Another Milestone in a Career Filled With Them
text: DUBLIN, Ohio – It is now official. By the year 2013, Jack Nicklaus – who has won everything worth mentioning in golf – will have done everything worth mentioning in the game.

headline: In Rome, Really Local Food
text: AT Urbana 47, a restaurant and cafe in the Monti district of Rome, everything is for sale. The light fixtures, the used furniture, and the ingredients used in each dish can all be packed up and carried away, or delivered to your home.
