text: Tickets for the N.B.A. finals, which begin Thursday in Los Angeles, are in high demand, and the allure of a renewed Celtics-Lakers rivalry is compelling fans to open their wallets.

headline: A Viennese District Is Reborn
text: A CENTURY ago, the Karmeliterviertel, or Carmelite Quarter, in Vienna teemed with Jewish life. In Leopoldstadt, Vienna’s second district, across the Danube canal from the city center, the Karmelitermarkt square bustled with shoppers. Along nearby Taborstrasse, opulent Jewish theaters and coffeehouses provided entertainment.

headline: Buffett Defends How Rating Agencies Are Paid
text: 3:58 p.m. | Updated David Segal of The New York Times provides more details of Warren E. Buffett’s rather tepid defense of Moody’s.

headline: ‘Glee’ Soundtrack Stays on Top
text: Oldies topped the Billboard album chart this week, barely, with a sluggish showdown between “Glee” and the reunited Stone Temple Pilots.

headline: Slings, Arrows, Self-Pity. What a Kidder!
text: “Legally Prohibited From Being Funny on Television” is what Conan O’Brien calls the comedy tour that he brought to Radio City Music Hall on Tuesday night. That presumes that he was funny on television.

headline: Ackman on the Rating Agencies: ‘Wait to Rate’
text: One of the most-watched presentations at last week’s Ira Sohn Investment Research Conference was William A. Ackman’s latest broadside against the credit rating agencies.

headline: An Imbalanced Chess World
text: There is almost no doubt that chess is played everywhere. After all, it only takes two people and a set, which makes it portable and convenient. But how popular is the game? Though hardly definitive, a new study suggests that chess’s appeal is uneven.

headline: Nadal Advances to Semifinals
text: PARIS  —  Racing well beyond the width of the court in near acrobatic fashion, Rafael Nadal had managed some spectacular shots. Still, he was serving uphill, trailing by 4-5 and by 5-6 in the first set of his quarterfinal match against his Spanish countryman Nicolás Almagro.

headline: The Contrarian
text: As a British-American critic, essayist and all-purpose iconoclast, you are known as one of the defining voices of the new atheism. But your just-published memoir, “Hitch-22,” is in fact an exercise in worship — male hero worship. Is it fair to say that you look upon the British novelist Martin Amis as the Messiah?  No, to the contrary. That’s exactly what would make us both throw up. Trust is not the same as faith. A friend is someone you trust. Putting faith in anyone is a mistake.

headline: Founders of Gallery Owned by Christie’s to Step Down
text: In 2007 Christie’s announced with great fanfare that it had bought Haunch of Venison, a gallery with locations in New York, Berlin and London. At the time many in the art world questioned the potential conflicts an auction house could have owning a private gallery, especially when it came to issues such as sharing clients or buying and selling at auction.

headline: Artifacts | Marina the Magnificent
text: It was no surprise that the audience present on Monday for the end of Marina Abramovic’s epic, 716-hour sit at the Museum of Modern Art gave her a tremendous ovation. The remarkable thing was the extent, and especially the sound, of it. The cheers lasted a good 15 minutes, filling the museum’s towering atrium with the sort of unbridled excitement that often greets (male) sports stars after a big win. Then again, when a woman of 63 has been sitting in the same chair almost daily for three long months, locking eyes with at least 1,545 individuals without moving or speaking, before 700,000 gawkers who came to watch, she deserves more than a pat on the back. A mental health exam might be in order, for instance. Or a long hot bath. But also a medal for heroism.

headline: U.N. Report Highly Critical of U.S. Drone Attacks
text: WASHINGTON — A senior United Nations official said on Wednesday that the growing use of armed drones by the United States to kill terrorism suspects was undermining global constraints on the use of military force. He warned that the American example would lead to a chaotic world as the new weapons technology inevitably spread.

headline: Upfront Market Starts to Move
text: The major broadcast networks and advertisers are beginning to make deals for commercial time in shows that will appear during the 2010-11 television season.

headline: Will Insurance Be Given to Those Who Can’t Afford It?
text: Q.

headline: Steve Reich and More at June in Buffalo
text: BUFFALO, N.Y. — Perhaps because, at heart, June in Buffalo is a university program — it takes place on the campus of the University of Buffalo — the atmosphere is more low key than that of, say, the Tanglewood Festival of Contemporary Music. The lectures so far have been attended mostly by the young composers who are participating in the program and by some of the school’s year-round students. Not many listeners seem to have wandered in from the community (people, for example, beyond college age).

headline: LeBron James Likes Gaga and Suspense
text: In the most anticipated interview of the N.B.A. off-season, LeBron James confirmed that he is a big fan of Lady Gaga and Warren E. Buffett and that he wants to win championships.

headline: U.S. Team Is Nestled in a Bucolic South African Bubble
text: IRENE, South Africa – The United States has set up camp at the Irene Country Lodge in a rustic area between Johannesburg and Pretoria. The lodge is across the street from a working dairy farm, restaurant and country store that has been around since the late 1800s.

headline: Ice Box Is 3-1 Favorite for the Belmont
text: Ice Box drew the No. 6 post position and was made the 3-1 favorite for the 142nd running of the Belmont Stakes on Saturday.

headline: Celtics Slowly Recovering From Injuries
text: The line for the Boston Celtics’ training room may be getting a bit smaller on the eve of the N.B.A. finals.

headline: IPad Efficiency, and a Teenager in the Press Corps
text: Michael R. Bloomberg: the iPad mayor?

headline: Quote Unquote | Mad Hatter
text: – Philip Treacy discusses who will play him in the Isabella Blow biopic to Vogue UK. We see the similarity… sort of…

headline: A Swirling Current Beneath a Smooth Surface
text: MUSIC REVIEW

headline: Melzer Rallies to Upset Djokovic in Five Sets
text: PARIS — Jurgen Melzer of Austria worked his way back into a struggle that was all but lost, then powered his way to victory over Novak Djokovic of Serbia, 3-6, 2-6, 6-2, 7-6 (3), 6-4, in the quarterfinals of the French Open.

headline: Kindles Soon To Be Available at Target
text: Beginning on Sunday, the Kindle e-reader will be sold in Target stores nationwide, Target announced on Wednesday. It will be the first brick-and-mortar store to sell the Kindle, which previously was available only through Amazon.com.

headline: The Culture of Narcissism
text: Any study that tries to quantify empathy needs to be taken with a grain of salt, but you can take this particular survey yourself — and if you do, you’ll probably find its empathy-measuring questions credible enough to be at least disquieted by these findings:

headline: Living With Music (Videos): A Playlist by Sharon Oreck
text: Sharon Oreck is a film, video and commercial producer, and the author of “Video Slut: How I Shoved Madonna Off an Olympic High Dive, Got Prince Into a Pair of Tiny Purple Woolen Underpants, Ran Away From Michael Jackson’s Dad, and Got a Waterfall to Flow Backward So I Could Bring Rock Videos to the Masses.”

headline: The Shock Heard Round the World
text: David Brooks: Gail, I’m going to get to Tipper and Al in a moment, but first let me ask you a question: Is there an international epidemic of stupidity going on, perhaps caused by sunspots or something?

headline: Video on Netanyahu’s Facebook Page Says Activists Plotted ‘a Terrorist Attack’
text: Updated | 6:01 p.m. As my colleagues Isabel Kershner and Sabrina Tavernise report, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu defended the deadly commando raid on a flotilla of activists challenging Israel’s naval blockade of Gaza on Wednesday, telling Israelis, “It is our duty and our responsibility according to international law and common sense to prevent by air, sea and land the smuggling of weapons into Gaza.”

headline: The Morning Skate: An Irreverent Pronger Creates a Disturbance
text: A current readers’ poll on TSN’s Web site asks, “What do you think of Chris Pronger taking the puck after Games 1 and 2.” As of this writing, about 19,500 votes have been cast with 41.4 percent selecting, “Genius – it takes the pressure off his team,” and 58.5 percent choosing: “Don’t like it. Not a good show of sportsmanship.”

headline: Ford to End Production of Its Mercury Line
text: DETROIT  Edsel Ford conceived the Mercury brand in the 1930s as a way to fill the gap between basic Fords and luxury Lincolns. Now, that gap will again go unfilled.

headline: The Takeaway From the Failed A.I.A. Deal
text: 4:03 p.m. | Updated Prudential Plc will be able to escape its deal to buy the American International Group’s Asia life insurance unit with only a relatively minor financial penalty. But there are other lessons to be learned here.

headline: Richard Migliore, a Peerless Horseman, Retires
text: Richard Migliore, the jockey known affectionately in New York simply as The Mig, will never ride a racehorse again. It was not his choice to retire Wednesday morning: the doctor told him that he had sustained one broken neck too many and that he would be risking his life if he got on another horse.

headline: The Rail Bookshelf: ‘Randy Romero’s Remarkable Ride’
text: Teresa Genaro writes regularly about New York racing at Brooklyn Backstretch.

headline: Panasonic FX75 Goes Wide and Bright
text: The new Panasonic Lumix DMC-FX75 is fronted by a very wide and bright lens — two features that should make it a versatile snap-shooter. This touch-screen camera is also eminently portable, housed in a chassis that measures a superslim 0.9 inch.

headline: 2010: Honey-and-Ricotta Mousse With Strawberry-Rhubarb Broth
text: By Melissa Perello, chef and owner of Frances in San FranciscoFor the strawberry-rhubarb broth:

headline: 1989: Rhubarb-Strawberry Mousse
text: This recipe appeared in The Times in an article by Olwen Woodier; it was adapted from Mallards Restaurant at Arrowwood in Rye Brook, N.Y. 11/4 pounds rhubarb, finely diced

headline: Recipe Redux: Rhubarb-Strawberry Mousse, 1989
text: Monolithic vintage desserts have their charms. A rhubarb-strawberry mousse that ran in The Times in 1989 is buoyant and absolute, with cream easing the tart sting of the fruits. A mousse can be any food that has a light and foamy texture. This sweet one, adapted from Mallards Restaurant at Arrowwood in Rye Brook, N.Y., is created by folding whipped cream into a rhubarb-and-strawberry purée firmed up with gelatin. If you didn’t whip the cream, you’d end up with panna cotta. As is, or combined with whipped egg whites, you enter the land of chiffons and charlottes. Mousse is the neutral middleman: not very flashy, but dependably, well, moussey.

headline: Florida G.O.P. Figure Indicted
text: Updated: MIAMI — Jim Greer, the big spender hand-picked by Gov. Charlie Crist to run the Republican Party of Florida, was charged on Wednesday morning with six felony counts tied to what the authorities described as a secret scheme to funnel political donations to a shell company Mr. Greer set up “for personal enrichment.”

headline: Jane Lynch and Lara Embry
text: Jane Lynch and Lara Embry were married Monday at the Blue Heron Restaurant in Sunderland, Mass. Jeannie Elias, a friend who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: By the Numbers: A-Rod’s Grand Slams
text: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

headline: A Trick to Earn More Interest
text: In response to my colleague Tara Siegel Bernard’s recent post on the best places to store down payment money for a home, a reader commented with a tip that we thought was worth sharing.

headline: Greater New Yorkers | Tala Madani
text: The Moment homes in on five artists from “Greater New York,” an exhibition that runs through Oct. 18 at MoMA P.S. 1 in Queens.

headline: Ray Stevens Comes Streaking Back With Immigration Song
text: If there’s an upside to the polarized debate over illegal immigration in the United States, it’s that it has put Ray Stevens back in the limelight. When we last heard from Mr. Stevens, the novelty country-music star who gave us “Ahab the Arab” and “The Streak,” it was probably via a Dr. Demento album we were loaned by a friend at summer camp or a stray reference to him on “The Simpsons.” (Admittedly, we missed his 2002 hit, “Osama Yo’ Mama.”)

headline: TerraCycle
text: Tom Szaky, the founder and C.E.O. of TerraCycle, explains how he saved his company despite mounting manufacturing costs.

headline: The Kno, a Tablet for the College Market
text: The success of the Kindle and iPad has sparked a slew of tablet-wannabes. Some are imitators, while others are trying to bring new ideas to the tablet and e-reader concepts.

headline: Town House in Crane Collapse Is for Sale
text: THE collapse of a 22-story construction crane in March 2008 on the East Side of Manhattan killed seven people, crushed a building and rattled the city. It was the first of two fatal crane accidents that year.

headline: Ex-Officer Is Convicted of Sexual Abuse
text: A former police officer was convicted on Wednesday of sexually abusing two women in Manhattan who had been lured by promises of applications for jobs and programs for their children.

headline: Katrina and Climate: Case Dismissed?
text: Back in 2005, a group of landowners on the gulf coast filed a federal lawsuit against energy and chemical companies, arguing that they were directly responsible for greenhouse gas emissions that exacerbated the effects of Hurricane Katrina. It named more than 30 companies, including oil giants like Chevron, BP and Exxon Mobil.

headline: How I Saved My Company: TerraCycle
text: TerraCycle has gotten a lot of media attention for its unusual business model: Basically, it takes waste and turns it into a wide range of products, from fertilizer to computer bags to kites. Co-founded by Tom Szaky, who dropped out of Princeton University to start the company, TerraCycle, which is based in Trenton, N.J., has been the subject of an Inc. magazine  cover story, a National Geographic reality show, and a recent profile in the Wall Street Journal.

headline: No Hawk-Eye to Help Out Djokovic
text: PARIS – The French Open remains the only Grand Slam that has not implemented the multiple-camera tracking system called Hawk-Eye, which uses a sort of animated replay system to be the final arbiter of line calls at Wimbledon and the Australian and United States Opens.

headline: The Morning Line: Singing a New Belmont Tune
text: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

headline: Mercury: A Brand Without a Cause
text: Ford Motor Company said it would stop production of Mercury vehicles in the fourth quarter and discontinue the brand.

headline: The Crew Behind a One-Woman Show
text: YOU were the child of glamorous but emotionally absent narcissists; your own credo is “Never take advantage of anyone.” You were drunk or high for much of the 1980s; you got sober when you realized that no matter what quantities of drugs and alcohol you consumed they no longer had an effect. You were an art-critical flop who spent decades in the professional wilderness; you were then so suddenly taken up by the establishment that collectors now stand in line for your work. Your pictures sell for $400,000; you insist that you will never give up teaching, so what if it pays two cents?

headline: World Cup Chic | Kehinde Wiley’s Fancy Footwork
text: With the World Cup games in South Africa just days away, soccer balls aren’t the only things spinning out of control. The New York City artist Kehinde Wiley’s “Africa Lifestyle” sneakers and sports apparel for Puma are creating their own brand of hysteria. Puma has been supplying African soccer teams with uniforms since 1997, when it signed on with Cameroon. Wiley’s own partnership with the brand began two years ago with a commission to capture the spirit of the game through life-size paintings of Africana footballers like Samuel Eto’o of Cameroon, John Mensah of Ghana and Emmanuel Eboué of Ivory Coast. The paintings have been touring the globe with pit stops in Paris, London, New York, Beijing, Tokyo, Milan and Johannesburg, where they will land just in time for next week’s kickoff.

headline: ‘Phantom’ Now Available to Students
text: 6:36 p.m. | Updated  All of those drama clubs with a spare chandelier, organ and motorized boat — not to mention enough playing space for a subterranean lair — are now in luck: “The Phantom of the Opera” is available, for the first time, for productions at high schools and colleges in the United States and Canada, the licensing executives for the musical are to announce on Thursday.

headline: Laurent Manrique Is Taking Over Country in the Carlton Hotel
text: Laurent Manrique, who spent many years working in New York, including at Peacock Alley in the Waldorf-Astoria, then relocated to San Francisco, where he worked at Campton Place and then Aqua, will open a restaurant and lounge in what is now Country in the Carlton Hotel in Murray Hill.

headline: Trunk Show
text: As extra-long board shorts recede in popularity, men are coming to appreciate the virtues of showing some leg.

headline: Palin Backs Murkowski Rival in Alaska
text: Sarah Palin, who has not been shy of late about endorsing candidates around the country, made her presence felt back home in Alaska on Wednesday, backing a Republican primary opponent of Senator Lisa Murkowski.

headline: A Lifeguard for Before You Get to the Beach
text: ATTENTION, reality-television producers: If you’re desperately looking for a quick summer replacement show, here you go. Get Ronen Jehezkel to meet you at Parke & Ronen, the fashionable swimwear store that he and his partner, Parke Lutter, own on Ninth Avenue in Chelsea. Mike him up, plant the camera and wait.

headline: 20 Young Writers Earn the Envy of Many Others
text: There are 10 women and 10 men, satirists and modernists, from Miami and Ethiopia and Peru and Chicago. And none of them were born before 1970.

headline: Answers From a Train Operator
text: Following is the first set of responses from Dennis H. Boyd, who operates trains on the No. 4 Lexington Avenue subway line.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Kabul and Elsewhere
text: In Afghanistan, President Hamid Karzai’s peace council, called a jirga, came under fire on its first day Wednesday. The Taliban responded before the president even finished speaking, as a rocket exploded within a few hundred yards of the jirga tent. “Some are trying to fire rockets,” he said, shrugging off the attack. “Everyone is used to it; even my 3-year-old son is used to it.”

headline: Transit Maps in the Palm of Your Hand (No Refolding Required)
text: In some cities, pulling out a transit map is an open invite to solicitations from panhandlers, swindlers and car services. But you can avoid such nuisances if you own a smartphone.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Robot Surgery
text: In this week’s New York Times Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein finds out about some fledgling alternatives to Facebook from Jenna Wortham, a Times technology reporter who covers digital culture and the Web. These social networking upstarts have emerged at a time of widespread concern over the privacy policies of Facebook, and Ms. Wortham says their creators see a potential opportunity, offering different ways of sharing information.

headline: Buffett Warns of Possible Call for Muni Bailouts
text: The billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett warned Wednesday afternoon that many state and local governments would soon face a “terrible problem” in refinancing their debt loads, and that some could eventually need to be bailed out by the federal government.

headline: Advising Graduates
text: You never know what moment a child will remember as transformative. When I think back on my memories of well-timed advice and wise counsel from my parents, most were happenstance and off the cuff.

headline: The Beautiful Game’s Serious Blemish
text: While much of the (male) world rejoices with anticipation for the impending World Cup to commence in South Africa on June 11, most Irish (male and female) continue to be livid and feel slighted for being excluded from this event by dint of an egregious refereeing error in Ireland’s qualifying match against France. The referee awarded the French an all-decisive goal that had involved an obvious hand-play by the French superstar Thierry Henry thus catapulting the French into the tournament on the basis of a clear rule infraction.

headline: Finding America, Searching for Identity
text: The case has been amply stated that “Superman” is the quintessential immigrant story. Born on an alien planet, he grows stronger on Earth but maintains a secret identity tied to a homeland that continues to exert a powerful hold on him even as his every contact with those origins does him harm.

headline: In May, Lower Ratings for Larry King
text: In May “Larry King Live” scored its lowest monthly viewer total in nearly 20 years.

headline: Products for Sensitive Skin
text: Some women with skin prone to allergic reactions seek out preservative-free skin care. Odacité, which makes a moisturizer, a night serum and a cleanser in the $40 to $120 range, does not add preservatives; its products are made to order, marked with a use-by date and mailed to the customer, so they never sit on store shelves.

headline: New Korean Skin-Care Import
text: By the end of June, the Sulwhasoo skin-care line will open an island in Bergdorf Goodman, its first outpost in the United States. The 12 products sold there will include an $80 primer and a $220 ginseng cream.

headline: Top Players Have Up-and-Down Day at French Open
text: PARIS  The day after the usually unflappable No. 1 men’s player was overpowered by a rising, hard-hitting player at the French Open, the No. 1 women’s player suffered the same end.

headline: As Certain as Taxes: New Version of Office
text: Certain landmark events come around every few years, giving some reassuring structure to our lives. You know: Presidential elections. Summer Olympics. Remakes of “A Christmas Carol.”

headline: Turning Heads, and Topping Them, Too
text: THE German hat designer Rike Feurstein has the sort of discovery story that most fledgling designers can only dream about. One winter day in 2007, almost a year after opening a little atelier in Berlin, Ms. Feurstein was in Manhattan and spontaneously popped into Barneys New York. She was wearing her classic Faye hat, a jaunty outsize caboose-style cap crocheted from almost rope-size wool yarn. The hat caught the eye of a floor manager, who enthusiastically flipped through the look book Ms. Feurstein had with her; within 48 hours an order was placed.

headline: Push for Europewide Oversight of Credit Raters
text: The European Commission on Wednesday urged centralized oversight of credit rating agencies and stricter rules on bank directors to help prevent financial crises, James Kanter of The New York Times reports from Brussels.

headline: Table for 5, Rookies Need Not Apply
text: THEY have had probably 1,000 lunches over the last 25 years, starting in a Mexican fast-food restaurant and moving upscale around New York, and now they lunch at the best table at Michael’s, the popular Midtown media mecca.

headline: Thrifty Wi-Fi That Travels With You
text: Wi-Fi is everywhere.

headline: The Woman Behind Jean-Georges’s Juices
text: ABC Kitchen With Jean-Georges has a very healthy scene — especially in the front bar — not to mention good food with an emphasis on local and organic ingredients. But the healthiest aspect of Jean-Georges Vongerichten’s latest venture is just out the back door. At the cozy Elixir Bar, Brandi Kowalski, one of the restaurant’s managers, is taking juicing to the next (sustainable) level.

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. Al and Tipper Gore call it quits. The Weed Eater he gave her for her birthday should have been a tip-off that their love was too hot not to cool down.

headline: Throwing Stones at Builders’ Crass Houses
text: There’s a long tradition in theater of skewering journalists, lawyers and politicians, but architects, by comparison, have gotten off easy. In this age of the “starchitect,” that is bound to change, as demonstrated by two new dramas that present  and then undercut  the persona of the uncompromising visionary who dreams up buildings.

headline: The New Yorker’s ’20 Under 40’
text: For the first time in more than a decade, The New Yorker will publish a “20 Under 40″ list of fiction writers in its next issue, coming out Monday. Such lists, of course, tend to be controversial, or at least vulnerable to second-guessing and criticism. The editors in the fiction department at The New Yorker are certainly on guard for it.

headline: Make Bikes in the U.S., or Go Abroad to Cut Costs?
text: A SMALL bicycle company for big riders, Super Sized Cycles, manufactures and adapts bicycles for overweight riders who are too big for conventional bikes. The five-year-old business, which is based in Vermont, had sales last year of $104,000.

headline: Carly Fiorina Means Business
text: On a cloudless spring afternoon, Carly Fiorina strode onto an outdoor stage in Pleasanton, Calif., with the happy, hungry expression of someone not just confident of an enthusiastic reception but counting on one. She surveyed a riot of signs artful and artless — “Give us liberty, not debt,” “Pelosi’s gavel is the new health care colonoscopy” — and beamed. For the stemwinder on bloated government that she was about to deliver, there was probably no better audience than these thousands of angry rebels, spread across acres of fairgrounds near San Jose for a special Tea Party rally. And there was definitely no better date than this one: April 15. Tax day.

headline: This Year, Men’s Semifinals Should Be Televised Live
text: Both French Open men’s semifinal matches should be carried live on Friday, not on tape delay as they were last year, dismaying fans watching on NBC and the Tennis Channel.

headline: Pacific Crossing: Brahms by Way of Seoul
text: Western classical music has long flourished in Korea: where Western missionaries go, music tends to follow. In recent decades South Korean musicians like the Chung siblings  the violinist Kyung-Wha Chung, the cellist Myung-Wha Chung and the pianist and conductor Myung-Whun Chung  and more recently Hahn-Bin, a violinist, have led prominent international careers. And South Korea is a flourishing market for Western visitors, as the New York Philharmonic discovered in its Seoul concerts in 2008 and last year.

headline: Would You Build Bikes in the U.S. or the Far East?
text: We have just published a case study of Super Sized Cycles, a company based in Vermont that manufactures and adapts bicycles for overweight riders who are too big for conventional bikes.

headline: Egalitarian Virtues Trump Fireworks
text: Steve Cardenas is an earthbound jazz guitarist, more at home with the stir of a rhythm section than the whoosh of solo heroics. This makes him a pervasive but subtle presence on the scene: a consummate accompanist, not particularly known as a bandleader. But the balance may be shifting a bit. Last week he released a strong album, “West of Middle” (Sunnyside), his first for an American label. It features a clutch of unostentatious, intelligent originals, most of which he played at the Jazz Standard on Tuesday night.

headline: Around the Grill | Share Your Barbecue
text: With Memorial Day comes the unofficial beginning of barbecue season, a time to gather around the grill for food and fun. “Around the Grill,” a summer series from The New York Times, will feature articles, video and reader-submitted material. Many of you have already begun submitting barbecue photos, recipes and stories.

headline: Italy Focuses on a Princeton Curator in an Antiquities Investigation
text: It has been five years since a former curator of the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles went on trial in Rome for conspiring to traffic in stolen antiquities. The case has become a cornerstone of Italy’s aggressive campaign to recover ancient treasures from around the United States and has led major American museums to make their peace with the Italian government. As the museums have relinquished dozens of artworks that Italy claims were looted, receiving loans of other objects in exchange, officials on both sides have talked about a new era of collaboration.

headline: Award to Aid Playwright and the Play
text: A new annual playwriting award, providing $50,000 to an emerging writer and an additional $100,000 toward the production costs for mounting the recipient’s play, has been established by the foundation of Arthur Laurents, the Tony Award-winning Broadway director, playwright and librettist, and Tom Hatcher, his partner, according to organizers of the award.

headline: Colorado Prosecutor Says a Deal Is Reached in Charlie Sheen Case
text: A Colorado prosecutor said on Tuesday night that an agreement had been reached with Charlie Sheen, below right, the “Two and a Half Men” star, in a case involving a domestic dispute between him and his wife, The Associated Press reported. Arnold Mordkin, the chief deputy district attorney of Pitkin County, confirmed the agreement to The A.P. but declined to provide details. Mr. Sheen was arrested in Aspen on Christmas Day after his wife, Brooke Mueller Sheen, called 911 after an argument. Mr. Sheen was charged with second-degree assault, menacing and criminal mischief, and he originally pleaded not guilty to those charges in March. Yale Galanter, a lawyer for Ms. Sheen, told The A.P. that a plea agreement had been reached, adding that the terms could not be revealed because “a deal is not a deal until the judge approves it.” Mr. Sheen’s trial was scheduled for July 21, but he is now scheduled to be in court on Monday for a hearing. Last month he announced that he had reached an agreement to return to “Two and a Half Men” for two more seasons.

headline: ‘Glee’ Soundtrack Stays On Top
text: Oldies topped the Billboard album chart this week, barely, with a sluggish showdown between “Glee” and the reunited Stone Temple Pilots. “Glee: The Music, Volume 3  Showstoppers” (Columbia), the fourth soundtrack to the popular Fox show  a fifth will be released on Tuesday  is No. 1 for a second week, with sales of 63,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan. “Stone Temple Pilots” (Atlantic), the band’s first new release in nine years, was close behind, with slightly fewer than 62,000. Album sales were relatively healthy in the first few months of 2010, with most No. 1’s selling more than 100,000 copies, but lately they’ve been dismal. Also on this week’s chart, Justin Bieber’s “My World 2.0” (Island) is No. 3, with 50,000; Lady Antebellum’s “Need You Now” (Capitol Nashville) is No. 4, with 46,000; and Usher’s “Raymond vs. Raymond” (Jive) is No. 5, with 35,000.

headline: Sit. Stay. Appreciate: Music For Dogs
text: Woof woof, woof woof woof! Arf, arf! Bark! If the preceding composition made no sense to you, then you’re probably not in the target audience for a new work by Laurie Anderson, above with her husband, Lou Reed, that is written for dogs. On Sunday the Sydney Opera House will host the debut of Ms. Anderson’s 20-minute piece composed of high-frequency noises that dogs can hear but that are inaudible to human ears, Agence France-Presse reported. (For the owners of the recital’s intended listeners, there will also be spoken word and string music elements.) The recital, called “Music for Dogs,” is being presented as part of Vivid Live arts festival in Sydney, whose curators are Ms. Anderson and Mr. Reed. Announcing the dog-friendly composition at a news conference, Ms. Anderson explained that at a previous event, she thought: “Wouldn’t it be great, if you were playing a concert, and you look out and you see all dogs? And so I said, ‘If I ever get the chance to do something like that I would do it.’ ” (A concert listing advises that all dogs in attendance must be on leashes, and all humans must be attached to those leashes.)

headline: Christie’s Alters Gallery Management
text: In 2007 Christie’s announced with great fanfare that it had bought Haunch of Venison, a gallery with locations in New York, Berlin and London. At the time many in the art world questioned the potential conflicts that an auction house could have in owning a private gallery, especially when it comes to issues like sharing clients or buying and selling at auction. Now the Haunch of Venison founders, Harry Blain and Graham Southern, are leaving the gallery on Aug. 31. While nobody wants to talk publicly about what caused the split, some contemporary-art dealers say Mr. Blain and Mr. Southern tried to buy back the gallery from Christie’s but were unsuccessful. “We decided we wanted to change direction,” Edward Dolman, Christie’s chief executive, said in a telephone interview. “We want to invest in the business and grow it, finding new spaces and building a bigger team. Harry and Graham felt more comfortable with a smaller operation.” Mr. Dolman added that Christie’s would continue to own the gallery and that it would be run with the co-directors Emilio Steinberger and Barrett White in New York and Matthew Carey-Williams in London. Mr. Blain said he and Mr. Southern planned to continue working together.

headline: Topping Fish With a Classic Onion Sauce
text: Although they have been available at farmers’ markets for a month or more, juicy spring onions are still a nice treat. So is the locally fished wild bass in our neighborhood Greenmarket. Hey — that sounds like the start of dinner, doesn’t it?

headline: Media Companies Support Filmmaker in Chevron Case
text: A group of 13 media companies has filed a friend-of-the-court brief on behalf of Joe Berlinger, below left, the documentary filmmaker who is appealing a federal district judge’s ruling that the oil company Chevron may subpoena the outtakes from his film “Crude.” The brief, filed on Tuesday in the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in Manhattan, by a group including NBC Universal, the Directors Guild of America, HBO and The New York Times Company, says the work of these companies “will be seriously jeopardized” by the judge’s decision and its effect on journalists’ privilege. Last month Judge Lewis A. Kaplan of Federal District Court in Manhattan ruled that Mr. Berlinger would have to turn over more than 600 hours of footage from “Crude,” his documentary about the Ecuadorians who sued Texaco (now owned by Chevron), accusing it of contaminating their water. Chevron said Mr. Berlinger’s footage could be helpful to the company as it seeks to have the suit dismissed and pursues an international treaty arbitration related to the litigation. The appellate court has ordered a hearing on Tuesday to consider the subpoena and stayed the subpoena until that hearing.

headline: Life Along the Gowanus
text: Although so polluted it was placed on the federal Superfund list, the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn is popular with many who live nearby.

headline: Celebration at the Edge of Decay
text: IN the claustrophobic confines of New York City, nothing marks the beginning of summer like an open-air dance party. And in South Brooklyn on the Sunday of Memorial Day weekend, summer commenced at an event space known as the Bklyn Yard.

headline: Still Dancing, Her Way, From the Soul
text: Alicia Alonso, the longtime director of the National Ballet of Cuba, no longer dances with her feet, which, on Monday afternoon at a hotel near Lincoln Center, were daintily crossed at the ankle in a pair of ladylike slingbacks. She is also virtually blind. But when she talks about ballet, her hands, coppery and weathered, flutter near her face as slender fingers, flashing rings and pale pink nails spin and leap through delicate choreographic feats.

headline: Packing the Computer for a Move
text: Q. What’s the best way to pack up my computer for a cross-country move?

headline: Private Collection Becomes Very Public
text: SAN FRANCISCO

headline: Superfun Site
text: The Bklyn Yard is open Fridays to Sundays all summer. On Fridays the space hosts a beer garden that opens at 6 p.m. (no cover). Saturdays are generally centered on food, such as a lobster bake cooked up by the Red Hook Lobster Pound (cover varies). And the Sunday Best dance party is $8 advance, $12 at the door. The Yard is at 388-400 Carroll Street, on the canal. Visit bklynyard.com for more details.

headline: Which Minor to Ruff? Declarer Puzzles It Out
text: The oldest bridge event still being contested is the Goldman Pairs. It was first played in New York City in 1929, when it was won by Oswald Jacoby and George Reith. (Remember, it was only in 1925 that Harold Vanderbilt had invented contract bridge.)

headline: Theater Talkback: Summer Reading List
text: Summer is not, for most people, peak theater-going season. Yes, there are charming festivals in bucolic settings (that includes Al Pacino doing Shakespeare in Central Park this year). But for most folks, the period between Memorial Day and Labor Day is a time to get out of Dodge, to exchange urban industry for pursuits that involve dressing down and chilling out, not dressing up and going out.

headline: ‘Jersey Shore,’ Without the Sun
text: PAULA BEGOUN, a beauty writer who calls herself the Cosmetics Cop, thought she had heard every silly claim about sunless tanners: that new flower extracts can extend the life of a tan by up to two weeks (they can’t); that spray tans no longer smell funky or turn you a funny orange (they do, mostly); that you no longer need to worry about the color rubbing off on your sheets (you do).

headline: Brazil’s Best Player: A Goalkeeper?
text: Musa Okwonga is a writer of Ugandan descent. In 2008, his first book on soccer, “A Cultured Left Foot,” was nominated for the William Hill Sports Book of the Year Award, and was named the best sports book of 2008 by Britain’s Independent newspaper.

headline: Eyebrow Shaping, Pain Included
text: Usually taking tweezers into your own hands is the only way to get a free eyebrow shaping in Manhattan. Not on June 17, when the Ramy brow bars in three Duane Reade stores will offer free shaping from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.

headline: Classic Ads: Mercury
text: With Ford’s announcement on Wednesday that it would discontinue its Mercury brand, a Merc-sponsored cruise down memory lane seemed in order.

headline: Looking for Missing Culprit in Credit Ratings ‘Mess’
text: The Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission on Wednesday seemed to get its fill of the problems and conflicts at the credit rating agencies, hearing from three panels, including one featuring the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett.

headline: Two Different Pictures of Hospitals
text: The Dartmouth Atlas of Health Care mines Medicare data to identify variations in hospital spending around the country. Dartmouth researchers sometimes argue that the highest-spending regions — those in the darkest color — tend to have the worst health care.

headline: Jamaican Forces Accused of Killing Unarmed Men
text: KINGSTON, Jamaica — As the battle for Tivoli Gardens raged, soldiers knocked on a door at Building 27. Inside, 16 or 17 people were huddled for safety, including a 22-year-old barber named Errol Spence. His family said a soldier searched him and did not find any evidence that he was one of the gunmen shooting at security forces. Still, one police officer asked Mr. Spence’s sister a question that at first confused her.

headline: When Poets Rocked Russia’s Stadiums
text: Since the collapse of the Soviet empire in 1991, Russian poetry has begun to resemble American poetry in ways that are both fascinating and sad. What’s fascinating is how talented, and how different from one another, Russia’s young poets are. What’s sad is how little they are read, and how little they matter. Whatever reach contemporary poetry had in Russian society has vanished like wood smoke.

headline: WeRewards Pays You to Check In
text: It sounds like one of those improbable come-ons that is an invitation to a scam: “Get paid to Tweet.”

headline: High Talent at Low Prices
text: THE jewelry designer Monique Péan, one of three designers to win the 2009 CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund prizes for up-and-coming talent (the others were Patrik Ervell and Sophie Théallet), makes pieces that often cost upward of $5,000.

headline: Critics Question Study Cited in Health Debate
text: In selling the health care overhaul to Congress, the Obama administration cited a once obscure research group at Dartmouth College to claim that it could not only cut billions in wasteful health care spending but make people healthier by doing so.

headline: Made for Prowling
text: IS there such a thing as a tasteful animal print? This ladylike simple sheath dress from Ann Taylor easily goes from office to cocktail party to a nightclub ($158).

headline: Fitting More Into That Bag
text: LONGCHAMP’S gut renovation of what the store calls La Maison Madison boutique plays homage to Le Pliage, its ubiquitous nylon and leather bag; the company estimates it has sold more than 16 million since its introduction in 1993. An accordionlike wall, an architectural reference to the bag’s folding design, displays each model and color, creating a rainbow from lilac to citrine ($90 to $270). The new Kate Moss for Longchamp line is available, including the Glastonbury, with a shoulder strap that can go across the chest, messenger style ($780). Longchamp Madison Avenue, 713 Madison Avenue (63rd Street); (212) 223-1500, longchamp.com.

headline: The Art and Craft of Terrariums
text: Long a fixture of classrooms, a new breed of modern, elegant and highly detailed terrariums is gaining favor with young design enthusiasts.

headline: Pop Up, Jump Under
text: VICTOR HSU, above, who calls himself the chief propagandist for the sneaker brand Jump, is getting the word out with a pop-up store in the Dumbo neighborhood of Brooklyn; it is called Jumbo, an acronym for Jump Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass. Jumbo will have its opening party Thursday from 6:30 to 10 p.m.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,392 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,074 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: When Boomers Get Dementia
text: Updated, June 3, 1:05 p.m. | Marc E. Agronin, a geriatric psychiatrist, joins the discussion, pointing out the significant challenges to treating dementia patients.

headline: Graduation Rates, by State and Race
text: Across United States public schools, just 74.9 percent of students who were freshmen in the fall of 2004 graduated from high school on time in 2008, according to a report from the National Center for Education Statistics.

headline: Dell’s Streak, the Harbinger of Smartphone-Tablet Hybrids
text: On the heels of the Kno, a tablet for the college market, Dell introduced its own take on the tablet on Wednesday. The Streak, a 5-inch touchscreen device, had made appearances earlier at Google’s developer conference, but it received a fuller introduction at D8, The Wall Street Journal’s technology conference on Wednesday.

headline: Scouting Report
text: OPENING

headline: ‘The Bucolic Plague’
text: Chapter 1: October 13, 2006

headline: On Location: Coastal Design in Gloucester, Mass.
text: An antiques dealer’s Massachusetts home that is anything but a standard-issue New England clapboard house.

headline: David Rosenthal to Leave Simon & Schuster
text: David Rosenthal, the publisher of Simon & Schuster, is leaving the company, he said on Wednesday. Simon & Schuster is expected to announce Mr. Rosenthal’s successor on Thursday morning.

headline: Rusticating Sophisticate Commits Chicken-Lit
text: Josh Kilmer-Purcell is proud of his talent for making things sparkle. It’s a gift that came in handy during his career as a drag queen and later served him well in advertising. It was also helpful when, in 2006, Mr. Kilmer-Purcell and his partner, Brent Ridge, bought and beautified a run-down 200-year-old New York State showplace beyond Albany.

headline: A New England House With Fluid Design
text: Gloucester, Mass.

headline: Pompeii and Venetto Vases
text: From front and back, Pompeii and Veneto look like traditional vases. It is only from the side that the unconventional aspect of Lam Chiu Nam’s and Terry Yam’s design reveals itself — the vases are completely open.

headline: Swiss Tree Museum Opens June 14
text: On June 14, Enzo Enea, a Swiss landscape architect, will open his Tree Museum on the shore of Lake Zurich, in Rapperswil-Jona, Switzerland.

headline: Shrubs That Make Good Neighbors
text: FOR seven years, my next-door neighbor Paul and I abided by a gentleman’s arrangement to protect our privacy. I agreed to put on pants and a shirt whenever I got around to it — 10 o’clock, noon — while enjoying the glow of sunlight through my big kitchen window. Paul, whose bedroom sits on the other side of a 10-foot-wide driveway, agreed to keep his curtains closed.

headline: Sales at Broadway Panhandler and Online
text: Broadway Panhandler’s summer cookware event, June 9 to 13, offers savings of up to 70 percent on a selection of merchandise (a 10 1/4-inch Le Creuset enameled cast-iron grill pan, center, originally $170, is $50; a three-piece knife set by Global, right, regularly $222, is $160; and an All-Clad stainless mini tagine, left, originally $75, is about $30); 65 East Eighth Street (Broadway), (212) 966-3434 or broadwaypanhandler.com.

headline: ‘Re: Crafted’ Focuses on Innovative Homes
text: “Re:Crafted” ($50; the Monacelli Press), by Marc Kristal, is not about macramé or log cabins.

headline: Terrariums Make a Comeback
text: IT was an unseasonably hot Saturday in April, and the three dozen terrariums on display in a booth at the Brooklyn Flea were sweating, the moisture turning into beads on their glass containers. Katy Maslow and Michelle Inciarrano, who were selling the miniature gardens, answered questions from passers-by. An antique magnifying glass sat nearby, for those who wanted a closer look.

headline: The H-SLM Chair by Javier Cristiani
text: In designing the H-SLM chair, Javier Cristiani, the founder of Hemisferios, an architecture firm in El Salvador, set himself a challenge: “I wanted to create a three-dimensional shape” out of a flat material, he said, “without any additional structure.” To accomplish his goal, he took a single piece of metal, had a welder bend it by hand and then bolted it to a stainless-steel base so that it would “read as two very different elements.” H-SLM comes in two versions: a metal chair built by hand ($250), which has slight variations, and a fiberglass model ($280), above, that is lighter and more uniform because it is made in a mold. Mr. Cristiani, who is colorblind, made the prototype in a vibrant orange, a color he can see well; the chair also comes in yellow, green, black and white (the fiberglass version can be ordered in a combination of two colors as well). Information: (011-503) 2237-9565 or hemisferios.com.sv.

headline: OK, a Los Angeles Design Store, Opens a Branch
text: OK, a design store not far from the Beverly Center in Los Angeles, has established itself in the last 10 years as a go-to destination for those interested in modernism — in every category from books and jewelry to home furnishings. Two weeks ago, a second location opened in Silver Lake.

headline: Underground Parking at Home
text: Louis Coleman is director of sales for Vasari, a Guthrie, Okla., business that recently began selling residential car lifts. Hydraulic lifts in multicar garages are nothing new, but what makes Vasari’s system special is that instead of raising one car above another, it lowers one car into a subterranean chamber, allowing another car to be parked on top of the lift’s canopy (which now serves as the floor of the garage). Prices start at around $40,000, installed.

headline: Three Easy Upgrades for Late Adopters
text: ONCE upon a time, when big, boxy tube television sets roamed the earth, anything related to home-entertainment technology was so complicated and costly that many mere humans were cowed into a state of terrified indecision.

headline: New Benefits for Same-Sex Partners
text: President Obama on Wednesday extended a modest package of benefits to the same-sex partners of federal employees, a move that will make them eligible for day care, travel and relocation allowances, employee assistance programs and, in some cases, enable them to inherit retirement benefits.

headline: Greece to Sell Assets to Help Pay Down Deficit
text: Greece announced Wednesday its plans for a big sale of state-owned assets, as the struggling government moved to shrink its huge budget deficit and fulfill the terms of an international rescue package.

headline: A Raucous G.O.P. Convention Favors Lazio for Governor
text: Former Representative Rick A. Lazio emerged as the Republican Party’s preferred candidate for governor at an often raucous convention in Manhattan on Wednesday, leaving the party’s hopes in the hands of a candidate who even its own chairman has not embraced.

headline: Amazon to Sell Its E-Reader at Target
text: Beginning on Sunday, the Kindle e-reader will be sold in Target stores nationwide, the company announced on Wednesday. It will be the first brick-and-mortar store to sell the Kindle, which had been available only through the Amazon Web site.

headline: Official Admits Militancy’s Deep Roots in Pakistan
text: LAHORE, Pakistan  Days after one of the worst terrorist attacks in Pakistan, a senior Pakistani official declared in a surprising public admission that extremist groups were entrenched in the southern portion of the nation’s most populous province, underscoring the growing threats to the state.

headline: Ex-Chief of Nickelodeon to Head BBC’s U.S. Unit
text: The British Broadcasting Corporation said Wednesday that it brought in Herb Scannell, a former president of Nickelodeon, to run its growing operation in the United States.

headline: I’ll Have a Vodka, With a Splash of Celebrity
text: THERE are certain Bruce Willis signatures — the bald head, the self-deprecating humor and the cockiness — and he brings them all to a new campaign for Sobieski vodka. Mr. Willis serves as the brand’s celebrity spokesman, and he owns a small percentage of the Polish vodka maker’s parent company.

headline: Posada Back in Lineup, but Not Behind the Plate
text: The Yankees’ catching circumstances could include ingredients for uneasiness. Jorge Posada, the veteran incumbent, returned Wednesday night after a stay on the 15-day disabled list.

headline: Savored by the Palate, or as Part of a Portfolio
text: GENEVA  A simple Internet real estate ad caught Filip Opdebeeck’s eye in 2007: “Strongbox for rent.” The strongbox turned out to be a three-room vault beneath one of the many banks in this Swiss financial center, one room originally for bank archives, another for stock certificates, the third for gold.

headline: $239,000 Conductor Among M.T.A.’s 8,000 Six-Figure Workers
text: In an era of generous municipal salaries and union-friendly overtime rules, it may not come as a complete shock that there are thousands of Metropolitan Transportation Authority employees — 8,074, to be precise — who made $100,000 or more last year.

headline: A Knock-Down, Drag-Out — Yawn
text: WASHINGTON  Something has been missing from the fight over the Supreme Court nomination of Elena Kagan: the fight.

headline: Handling the French Open’s Dirty Laundry
text: PARIS  On the first day of the French Open, 256 players were in the singles draws. About 4,500 articles of clothing were sent to be washed.

headline: A Message, With Fries on the Side
text: PARIS  McDonald’s France is broadcasting a gay-themed advertisement, under its current slogan, “Come as you are.”

headline: Photo Relay: June 2
text: A view of the day in sports, with the French Open in Paris, a Flyers victory in Game 3 of the Stanley Cup and a disputed call in the Tigers-Indians game in Detroit.

headline: Raging Bull All Grown Up and Leading the English
text: JOHANNESBURG  The life and times of Wayne Rooney, England’s star and star-crossed forward, can be floridly traced in the body art of his tattoos.

headline: Abortion Foes Advance Cause at State Level
text: At least 11 states have passed laws this year regulating or restricting abortion, giving opponents of abortion what partisans on both sides of the issue say is an unusually high number of victories. In four additional states, bills have passed at least one house of the legislature.

headline: After Spate of Suicides, Technology Firm in China Raises Workers’ Salaries
text: SHANGHAI  Stung by labor shortages and a rash of suicides this year at its large factories in southern China, Foxconn Technology said Wednesday that it would immediately raise the salaries of many of its Chinese workers by 33 percent.

headline: At Toyota, a Cultural Shift
text: Last month, when Steve St. Angelo, a longtime executive at Toyota in the United States, traveled to Japan, it was an eye-opening journey.

text: To the Editor:
