text: To the Editor:

headline: Nuclear Option on Gulf Oil Spill? No Way, U.S. Says
text: The chatter began weeks ago as armchair engineers brainstormed for ways to stop the torrent of oil spilling into the Gulf of Mexico: What about nuking the well?

headline: For Fairer Elections
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bids Submitted for Newsweek Sale
text: Two magnates, a conservative publisher and the company that bought TV Guide for $1 have all raised their hands as potential buyers of Newsweek.

headline: Workplace Flexibility
text: To the Editor:

headline: Publisher of Simon & Schuster Is Leaving
text: David Rosenthal, the publisher of Simon & Schuster, is leaving the company, he said on Wednesday. Simon & Schuster is expected to announce Mr. Rosenthal’s successor on Thursday morning.

headline: As Oil Slips Away, So Do Chances for Obama
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama is supposed to leave Washington in 10 days for Indonesia, Australia and Guam, but with oil still gushing into the Gulf of Mexico, some in the White House are wondering whether the weeklong trip should be scrubbed.

headline: An Assault, Cloaked in Peace
text: Washington

headline: Zong Hopes to Offer One-Click Android Payments
text: Apple’s iAd platform, when it is first used this summer, will display embedded advertisements on mobile devices. Some ads could have the ability to complete transactions.

headline: China Says It Will Tighten Controls on Rare Minerals
text: SHANGHAI  China is planning to tighten its control over its rare earth minerals by allowing just a handful of state companies to oversee the mining of the scarce elements.

headline: Back Where It Began With the Mariners, Griffey Is Retiring
text: ST. LOUIS  Ken Griffey Jr., whose sweet swing launched 630 home runs and electrified a generation of fans, announced his retirement Wednesday after 22 major league seasons.

headline: Gee, Gee, Gee, Gee, Sprint Celebrates Its Next Innovation
text: Confused about 3G? Look out. Here comes 4G.

headline: The Way We Design Now
text: It’s strange to think that just a few years ago, it felt as if design schools and studios nationwide must have been holding special screenings of “The Graduate.” Down the aisles of Target, in the pages of Dwell and the showrooms of SoHo, there was nary a natural material in sight: the future was plastic.

headline: Castillo Is Hobbling Along
text: 12:30 a.m. | Updated

headline: Putting a Precocious Palate to Work
text: Pascaline LePeltier, 29, has been wine director at Rouge Tomate, a restaurant with an obsession for healthful pairings of food and beverages, since June 2009. She joined its staff in 2007 as a consultant to its nutritious beverage program, a k a the liquid menu. A native of Angers, France, in the Loire Valley, she studied philosophy before switching fields and training in Paris with Potel et Chabot, a high-end caterer.

headline: A Botched Raid, a Vital Embargo
text: Jerusalem

headline: Off-Duty Officer in Fatal Bronx Crash Had an Alcohol Level Twice the Legal Limit
text: The off-duty New York City police officer who crashed his car on the Bronx River Parkway last month, killing himself and a fellow officer and seriously injuring four women, had a blood-alcohol level twice the legal limit, the authorities said on Wednesday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 2, 2010

headline: Heaviest Users of Phone Data Will Pay More
text: They spend hours watching video on their phones, downloading songs, browsing the Web, sending photos to friends and generally using mobile devices as full-fledged computers. They are the data hogs.

headline: Moose Alert! It’s Funny, Till You Hit One
text: WEST CORNWALL, Conn.

headline: Paterson Bill Would Begin Overhaul of Youth Prisons
text: Gov. David A. Paterson introduced legislation on Wednesday to begin overhauling New York’s troubled juvenile prison system, in what aides said was a first step toward broader changes long sought by critics of the system.

headline: Reckoning in the Gulf
text: The criminal and civil investigations announced by the Justice Department this week into the disastrous oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico are clearly necessary.

headline: Hitting Streak Lifts Shadows Over a Campus
text: The mobile TV vans have returned to the Florida International University campus, driven by celebration rather than sorrow.

headline: For Nannies, Hope for Workplace Protection
text: In a city of secret economies, few are as vital to the life of New York as the business of nannies, the legions of women who emancipate high-powered professionals and less glamorous working parents from the duties of daily child care.

headline: Apple and the Regulators
text: Mobile computers like Apple’s iPhone and iPad are among the most transformative information devices since the personal computer. So it makes sense for the Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department to review Apple’s policies governing programmers’ access to its devices to see if they violate antitrust laws.

headline: Ties to U.S. Played Role in Downfall of Japanese Leader
text: SEOUL, South Korea  When Prime Minister Yukio Hatoyama of Japan abruptly stepped down Wednesday, largely for his failure to move an American air base off Okinawa, he was essentially admitting he had not won popular support for a prominent campaign pledge: ending Japan’s postwar dependence on the United States for its security.

headline: Oil Companies Weigh Strategies to Fend Off Tougher Regulations
text: WASHINGTON — When the Obama administration imposed new restrictions last week on offshore drilling in the wake of the BP oil spill, officials carved out an exemption that received little public attention: Companies working in shallow waters, unlike deep-sea operators like BP, could again begin drilling for oil and gas.

headline: They Must Be Doing Their Job
text: The good news from the House is that its new independent Office of Congressional Ethics is doing a strong enough job to prompt outcries from members whose behavior has come under scrutiny. The bad, if predictable, news is some of those lawmakers are trying to strip the office of its powers.

headline: U.S. to Push for Bank Rules in Other Large Economies
text: WASHINGTON  The Treasury secretary, Timothy F. Geithner, said Wednesday that the United States would urge the world’s largest economies to pursue a financial overhaul agenda that would “restore fiscal sustainability over the medium term.”

headline: None Is Best
text: Many food manufacturers and restaurant chains have been reformulating products to significantly reduce or eliminate partially hydrogenated oils, which contain dangerous artery-clogging trans fat. Concerns that companies searching for alternatives would turn to unhealthy  but not quite as harmful  saturated fat, say from butter or palm oil, appear to be unfounded.

headline: Tax Collection in Louisiana Fell Sharply in First Quarter
text: NEW ORLEANS  Most states continued to collect less in taxes during the first three months of the year than they did during the same period last year, with the steepest decline here in Louisiana, a report on state taxes to be released Thursday finds.

headline: Rondo Expands Game and the Celtics’ Success
text: LOS ANGELES  Rajon Rondowill not enter a 3-point shooting contest any time soon. In his expanding repertory, Rondo’s perimeter shooting is a work in progress. But when he drives to the basket, he can split a forest of players in the lane and pull the ball behind his back as though it were tethered to his fingers like a yo-yo.

headline: Nicklaus Backs Woods for Ryder Cup Team
text: DUBLIN, Ohio — Jack Nicklaus created a bit of a stir last week when he was widely quoted as saying that the United States Ryder Cup captain Corey Pavin “would need a brain scan” if he were to leave Tiger Woods off the 2010 squad that will meet the European Ryder Cup team in Wales this September.

headline: U.S. Trade Representative Injured
text: Ron Kirk, the United States trade representative, was injured in a car accident on Wednesday in Grand Prairie, Tex., a suburb of Dallas, where he was mayor from 1995 to 2002.

headline: Arkansas Ad-Mania
text: With the Democratic runoff in Arkansas looming, it’s no surprise that both Senator Blanche Lincoln and her challenger, Lt. Gov. Bill Halter, are throwing advertisements up on television.

headline: For 5th Year, Child Sex Abuse Bill Dies in Legislature
text: For four years, advocates for sexually abused children had fought a battle in the New York Legislature to open a legal window that would allow victims to file lawsuits against predators long after the statute of limitations had expired.

headline: New Goal for Woods: Making the Cut
text: DUBLIN, Ohio  Tiger Woods said something Wednesday at Muirfield Village Golf Club that he had probably never said before at a professional golf tournament. Twice during his morning news conference and once after he had won six skins in the afternoon skins game, Woods essentially said he was hoping to make the cut at this weekend’s Memorial Tournament.

headline: Spill May Prompt Energy Mergers
text: BP is shaping up to be the oil industry’s Lehman Brothers. The toxic ingredients that led to that Wall Street firm’s implosion are abundant in the Gulf of Mexico disaster: flawed risk management, systemic hazard and regulatory incompetence. Moreover, as in the financial industry, the policy response will almost certainly lead to seismic changes in the energy business.

headline: First Dude’s Trainer Hopes for First Triple Crown Win
text: Dale Romans has won training titles in Kentucky and Maryland and Indiana. He developed Kitten’s Joy into the 2004 champion male turf horse and won the Dubai World Cup, the world’s richest race, with Roses in May the following year.

headline: 3-Day Fast Is Latest Call to Overhaul Immigration
text: With the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island as a backdrop, more than 40 people, including several New York politicians and clergy members, gathered in Battery Park on Wednesday to start a three-day fast to press for a comprehensive immigration overhaul.

headline: Protesters Gather at BP Gas Stations
text: BP’s shares have suffered in the stock market, but local convenience stores have become an increasingly visible venue for public displeasure with the company’s inability to stop the spread of oil in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: "In Character" by Sobieski Vodka
text: In a series of "Bruce Has Ideas" commercials, Bruce Willis  makes it clear he has a stake in the vodka company.

headline: "Vodka Thursdays" by Sobieski Vodka
text: In a series of "Bruce Has Ideas" commercials, Bruce Willis  makes it clear he has a stake in the vodka company.

headline: Fishermen Wait on Docks as Oil Gushes
text: DULAC, La. — This time of year, Eric Authement would normally be buying about 70,000 pounds of shrimp a day from the boats that line the Grand Caillou Bayou and spread their winglike nets in the bays, marshes, coastal waters and inlets along the coast.

headline: New Israeli Tack Needed on Gaza, U.S. Officials Say
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration considers Israel’s blockade of Gaza to be untenable and plans to press for another approach to ensure Israel’s security while allowing more supplies into the impoverished Palestinian area, senior American officials said Wednesday.

headline: Ex-Officer Is Convicted on Charges of Sex Abuse
text: A former New York City police officer was convicted on Wednesday of sexually abusing two women whom he had lured by promising to give them applications for jobs and after-school programs for their children.

headline: Saving Israel From Itself
text: When reports first circulated on Twitter of a deadly attack by Israeli commandos on the Gaza flotilla, I didn’t forward them because they seemed implausible. I thought: Israel wouldn’t be so obtuse as to use lethal force on self-described peace activists in international waters with scores of reporters watching.

headline: A Brief ‘Box Office’ Move
text: Lincoln Center’s Calder sculpture, “Le Guichet” (“The Box Office”), will take up temporary residence at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, a move to be announced on Thursday. Lincoln Center presented the sculpture as a temporary gift to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg at its spring gala last month, offering to let him place the artwork anywhere in the city for 90 days. The sculpture, made of black steel plate, has sat on the north plaza outside the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts since 1965. The sculpture will leave the Lincoln Center campus on Thursday and be installed at the garden on Friday. “The Osborne Garden will frame ‘Le Guichet’ in an entirely new and evocative way,” said Scot Medbury, president of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

headline: Onetime J.F.K. Arrivals
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Who’s to credit (or blame) for a crossword? We’ll get to that, but first Liz Gorski’s puzzle …

headline: Stadium Doubleheader: A Reception and a Bout
text: In the grand hall at Yankee Stadium on Wednesday, Scotty Ballan, 12, handed two of his pinstriped bar mitzvah yarmulkes to Yuri Foreman, the super welterweight champion and a rabbinical student who is defending his title Saturday night against Miguel Cotto.

headline: In Colorado Race, Too, White House Dangled Job
text: 7:35 a.m. | Updated On Thursday, the White House confirmed that it had approached Andrew Romanoff, a Colorado upstart candidate, about a possible administration job in order to head off “a costly battle between two supporters.” But he said he was committed to the race, and that ended the discussions without any formal job offer, according to the White House’s statement.

headline: S. Korea’s Governing Party Surprised by Election
text: SEOUL, South Korea — President Lee Myung-bak’s party has suffered a surprising setback in local elections that were widely seen as a referendum on his handling of North Korea’s alleged torpedoing of a South Korean warship.

headline: Castillo May Be Headed for the Disabled List
text: SAN DIEGO  After watching Luis Castillo hobble around the basepaths Tuesday night, Mets Manager Jerry Manuel could barely take it any more.

headline: Day 43: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: Oil Nears Florida Panhandle

headline: Even as Posada Returns, Cervelli Maintains Impact
text: Of all the runs batted in during the Yankees’ 9-1 victory over the Baltimore Orioles on Wednesday night, the most painful was the one by Francisco Cervelli in the third inning.

headline: Mayor to Cancel Teachers’ Raises, Averting Layoffs
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Wednesday that the city would withhold across-the-board pay increases for public school teachers and principals for the next two years to “save the jobs of some 4,400 teachers.”

headline: Corrections
text: EDITORS' NOTE

headline: Perfect Game Thwarted by Faulty Call
text: When history is in your grasp, the easy thing to do is embrace it. With two outs in the ninth inning in Detroit on Wednesday, the first-base umpire, Jim Joyce, could have called the Cleveland Indians’ Jason Donald out on a close play at first base. Make a fist, raise a forearm, and Armando Galarraga becomes the 21st pitcher  and third in the last four weeks  to throw a perfect game.

headline: McCartney Is Honored at White House
text: WASHINGTON  A Beatle met the president when Sir Paul McCartney performed at the East Room of the White House on Wednesday night.

headline: Zuckerberg on the Hot Seat
text: About 20 minutes into his on-stage interview at the D8 conference, Mark Zuckerberg had to take off his hoodie, the black sweatshirt that has become his trademark and that he said he never took off.

headline: What if the Oil Just Kept Flowing
text: Smoke billowing from ignited oil fields in Kuwait, April 1991 (NASA):

headline: A Perfect Game, Except for One Call
text: Armando Galarraga, a 28-year-old Detroit Tigers right-hander with a nondescript career record, had faced 26 Cleveland Indians hitters on Wednesday night and retired them all. The 27th, Jason Donald, a rookie shortstop playing his 15th major league game, was all that stood in the way of a record third perfect game of the season.

headline: In California, a Step Toward B.Y.O.B. (Bring Your Own Bag)
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Paper or plastic? Neither.

headline: A Brief ‘Box Office’ Move
text: Lincoln Center’s Calder sculpture, “Le Guichet” (“The Box Office”), will take up temporary residence at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, a move to be announced on Thursday. Lincoln Center presented the sculpture as a temporary gift to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg at its spring gala last month, offering to let him place the artwork anywhere in the city for 90 days. The sculpture, made of black steel plate, has sat on the north plaza outside the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts since 1965. The sculpture will leave the Lincoln Center campus on Thursday and be installed at the garden on Friday. “The Osborne Garden will frame ‘Le Guichet’ in an entirely new and evocative way,” said Scot Medbury, president of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

headline: Obama Says He’ll Push for Clean Energy Bill
text: PITTSBURGH  President Obama said Wednesday that it was time for the United States “to aggressively accelerate” its transition from oil to alternative sources of energy and vowed to push for quick action on climate change legislation despite almost unanimous opposition from Republicans and continued skepticism from some Democrats.

headline: California: Drugs Contributed to Death
text: A Mexican man who died Saturday after he was hit with a baton and shocked with a stun gun by immigration officers deporting him had signs of methamphetamine abuse and high blood pressure, the San Diego medical examiner said Wednesday. The man, Anastacio Hernández-Rojas, 32, died of a heart attack, with methamphetamine abuse and high blood pressure listed as contributing factors. He fought with officers as they prepared to walk him through a gate into Mexico. An officer shocked him with a Taser.

headline: Benefits Extended to Same-Sex Partners
text: President Obama on Wednesday extended a modest package of benefits to the same-sex partners of federal employees, a move that will make them eligible for day care, travel and relocation allowances, employee assistance programs and, in some cases, enable them to inherit retirement benefits. But Mr. Obama lamented that federal law  the Defense of Marriage Act  prevents him from extending the full range of health and retirement benefits to federal employees. He called on Congress to pass legislation that would allow him to do so.

headline: Bloggingheads:  Gaza and Zionism
text: John McWhorter, left, of the Manhattan Institute and Glenn Loury of Brown University debate what the blockade of Gaza says about Israel.

headline: Getting Ready for Niese
text: SAN DIEGO — Manager Jerry Manuel said that Jon Niese would be called up to start Saturday against the Marlins at Citi Field, and acknowledged that the Mets would love to have Oliver Perez accept an assignment to the minor leagues to make room for Niese on the 25-man roster.

headline: What to Watch: Schiavone vs. Dementieva
text: Francesca Schiavone’s one-handed backhand is a thing of beauty. It is as formidable as it is flowing, and brings to mind Richard Gasquet’s gorgeous one-hander. Both players have long, loose follow-throughs, with the shoulder joint an elastic hinge that allows the racket head to accelerate through the ball. Today she faces Elena Dementieva, a rival since their days in the juniors, and she will stride onto Court Philippe Chatrier as the first Italian woman to reach a Grand Slam semifinal. After a first-round, first-set hiccup, Schiavone has motored through the draw without dropping another set.

headline: Colorado: Pastor Starting Over
text: The Rev. Ted Haggard, who resigned as president of the National Association of Evangelicals in 2006 after he admitted having a sexual encounter with a former male escort and buying drugs, announced Wednesday that he and his wife, Gayle, would start a new church. The Haggards said they planned to open the church in the coming weeks, but had not found a specific location. Mr. Haggard said the church would be open to everyone, but especially those going through difficult times. “Because of what we’ve been through, I may be qualified to help other people in need,” he said.

headline: One Strike From Victory, Mets Lose Again on Road
text: SAN DIEGO  A trip that began so ominously for the Mets, with Corey Hart’s game-ending home run in Milwaukee, ended in similarly devastating fashion Wednesday.

headline: Texas: Huge Cache of Guns Is Seized
text: Federal authorities are investigating the origin of one of the largest gun seizures ever on the Mexico border: a cache of 147 assault rifles with banana clips and bayonets discovered in a truck being driven down a residential street in Laredo on Saturday, the local police said. Officers acting on a tip pulled over the truck and arrested the men inside after a short chase. Inside, they discovered 147 new AK-47 rifles, still in their boxes; 263 high-capacity magazines; 53 bayonets; and 10,000 rounds of ammunition  enough for a small army. Federal agents from Immigration and Customs Enforcement took the men into custody.

headline: In Blagojevich Corruption Trial, a Political Window
text: CHICAGO  As jury selection in the corruption trial of Rod R. Blagojevich begins on Thursday, people here are less curious about what they may learn about the impeached former Illinois governor than they are about who else will be tainted in the proceedings.

headline: What to Watch: Stosur vs. Jankovic
text: The compelling wins over Justine Henin and Serena Williams leave Samantha Stosur in an awkward place. By all rights, beating those two greats should have earned Stosur the trophy already. But she os still two matches from winning, and she faces another former world No 1, Jelena Jankovic , in Thursday’s semifinal. Jankovic is the ultimate tough out, a seasoned player whose strength is an absence of weaknesses, but whose weakness is a lack of strengths.

headline: 8 Charged in Brooklyn in Sex-Trafficking Case
text: Prompted by a wide-ranging investigation into the cases of about 15 girls who said they were forced into prostitution, District Attorney Charles J. Hynes of Brooklyn said Wednesday that he was creating a Sex Trafficking Unit to take aim at those who sexually exploit women and girls.

headline: Palmetto Political Passions
text: The political sex scandal spotlight is on South Carolina, which has hogged that stage so much lately you’d think it would be willing to give somebody else a turn.

headline: In a Thriller, the Flyers Make a Series of It
text: PHILADELPHIA  Claude Giroux, a high-scoring third-line forward on the Philadelphia Flyers’ formidable depth chart, deflected defenseman Matt Carle’s shot past Chicago Blackhawks goaltender Antti Niemi at 5 minutes 59 seconds of overtime, giving the Flyers a thrilling 4-3 victory and a chance to even the Stanley Cup finals when it resumes on Friday.

headline: Mongolia’s Unforgiving Freeze
text: Paula Bronstein is a senior staff photographer with Getty Images, based in Bangkok, who has covered Afghanistan extensively. She has been a photojournalist more than 25 years and, most recently, took second place as photographer of the year (freelance/agency) in the Pictures of the Year International contest. In March, she traveled to Mongolia for Getty and spoke about the trip last month, by telephone, with James Estrin. The exchange has been edited for clarity and brevity.

headline: File-Sharing Pioneers Now Selling Music
text: In the music business, they would call it a comeback.

headline: Questions About Bledsoe in Alabama
text: The Birmingham City Schools superintendent, Craig Witherspoon, said that he would meet with Alabama state athletic officials on Monday in Montgomery, Ala., to discuss Eric Bledsoe, the former Kentucky star point guard.

headline: Judge Delays Hearing in Case of Failed Times Sq. Bombing
text: A judge has postponed a hearing set for this week in the case of a naturalized United States citizen from Pakistan charged in the failed Times Square car bombing.

headline: Thailand: From Protest to Sales Pitch
text: Struggling to its feet again two weeks after a military crackdown that cleared Bangkok streets of protesters, the Rajaprasong commercial district is offering residents what one newspaper calls “shopping therapy.” In place of the propaganda slogans of the protests , the big department stores shout their wares with promotions like “Bliss is Back@Gaysorn,” “Salon de Style,” “We Love Rajaprasong” and “Welcome Back, Shoppers,” promising huge discounts of up to 80 percent on goods that survived the shutdowns and the fires.

headline: China: Tank Cartoon Censored on Eve of Anniversary of Tiananmen Square
text: Days before the anniversary of China’s 1989 assault on pro-democracy protesters in Tiananmen Square, Chinese censors have forced one of the nation’s more outspoken newspapers to excise a cartoon that appears to refer to the crackdown. In a series of cartoons commemorating International Children’s Day, the newspaper, Southern Metropolis Daily, based in Guangdong Province, depicted a child drawing a line of tanks, a man standing before them. The cartoon seemed to evoke the most famous photograph of the Tiananmen protests, in which an unarmed man brought a column of Chinese tanks to a standstill by refusing to move from their path. Friday is the 21st anniversary of the Tiananmen Square crackdown.

headline: Canada: Quebec Party’s New Effort to Limit English in Quebec Schools
text: The separatist Parti Québécois tied up Quebec’s legislature with procedural maneuvers on Wednesday after the Liberal government introduced new restrictions on English language schooling. The opposition party thinks that the new legislation, introduced after the province lost a case at the Supreme Court of Canada, does not sufficiently limit access to English language education. The court dismissed an earlier law that had limited access to the English-speaking public school system.

headline: Word of the Day |  hinterland
text: hinterland •\ˈhin-tər-ˌland, -lənd\• noun

headline: Murphy’s Comeback Hits a Snag
text: SAN DIEGO – Daniel Murphy’s bad-luck spring appears to have gotten much worse. Murphy sustained what appeared to be another serious injury to his right knee while playing second base for Class AAA Buffalo on Wednesday.

headline: Peter Orlovsky, Poet and Ginsberg Muse, Dies at 76
text: Peter Orlovsky, who inspired Beat writers like Allen Ginsberg, with whom he had a romantic partnership for decades, and who wrote emotionally naked, loopy and occasionally luminescent poetry of his own, died in Williston, Vt., on Sunday. He was 76, and lived in St. Johnsbury, Vt.

headline: Tobias Wong, Witty Designer and Conceptual Artist, Dies at 35
text: Tobias Wong, a designer whose outrageous sendups of luxury goods and witty expropriation of work by other designers blurred the line between conceptual art and design, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 35.

headline: No Surprise: U.S. Rejects Nuclear Option for Gulf Oil Gusher
text: It was always inconceivable that President Obama would consider using a nuclear explosion to cut the flow of oil from the unrelenting seabed gusher in the Gulf of Mexico — no matter how many other options faltered.

headline: News Quiz | June 3, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Swiss Panel Backs UBS-U.S. Deal and Urges Referendum
text: A Swiss parliamentary committee recommended Wednesday that the full Parliament back an agreement with the United States to hand over data on clients of the bank UBS who are suspected of tax evasion, Reuters reported.

headline: Bids Submitted for Newsweek Sale
text: Two magnates, a conservative publisher and the company that bought TV Guide for $1 have all raised their hands as potential buyers of Newsweek, Jeremy W. Peters and Joseph Plambeck report in The New York Times.

headline: U.S. to Push for Bank Rules in Large Economies
text: The Treasury secretary, Timothy F. Geithner, said Wednesday that the United States would urge the world’s largest economies to pursue a financial overhaul agenda that would “restore fiscal sustainability over the medium term.”

headline: File-Sharing Pioneers Now Selling Music
text: In the music business, they would call it a comeback. Almost a decade ago, Niklas Zennstrom and Janus Friis, European technology entrepreneurs, unleashed the Napster-like file-sharing program Kazaa on the Web, allowing millions of users to freely download songs, movies and TV shows.

headline: Nikkei Leads the Gains in Asian Stock Markets
text: Asian stock markets rose on Thursday, led by Japan, where the Nikkei 225 index more than recouped losses from the previous day after the Japanese prime minister, Yukio Hatoyama, resigned, Bettina Wassener writes in The New York Times.

headline: Le Monde Seeks a Financial Savior
text: In newly liberated Paris in 1944, a French journalist, Hubert Beuve-Méry, founded Le Monde in the spirit of the Resistance, pledging to keep the newspaper “politically, economically and morally” independent.

headline: Greece to Sell Assets to Help Pay Down Deficit
text: Greece announced Wednesday its plans for a big sale of state-owned assets, as the struggling government moved to shrink its huge budget deficit and fulfill the terms of an international rescue package, David Jolly reports in The New York Times.

headline: GeneroCite
text: “Generous city” – a term used by French architects to describe a new approach to urban planning in Paris.

headline: Attack at Sea
text: WHAT event has opened a rift between Turkey and Israel? WHAT was the purpose of the flotilla’s voyage?

headline: Does Your Generation Have Too Much Self-Esteem?
text: A Sunday Magazine article ponders whether “millennials” — or those born between 1982 and 2002 — have been so “spoiled by parents who overstoked their self-esteem, teachers who granted undeserved A’s and sports coaches who bestowed trophies on any player who showed up” that they won’t be able to handle the demands of the working world, especially during a recession. What do you think?

headline: Finance Chief Chosen as Next Japanese Leader
text: TOKYO  Hoping for a second chance to fulfill a historic election mandate for change, Japan’s governing Democratic Party on Friday chose a plain-spoken finance minister with activist roots to be the party’s next leader.

headline: I Do Not Think That Word Means What You Think It Means, OECD Edition
text: The OECD’s chief economist responds to my column about the pain caucus:

headline: Things Everyone In Chicago Knows
text: Which happen not to be true.

headline: Israel Signals New Flexibility on Gaza Shipments
text: JERUSALEM  While still insisting that its blockade of Gaza is essential to its security, the Israeli government is now shifting its position, “exploring new ways” of allowing goods to reach the coastal enclave, an Israeli official said Thursday.

headline: V.C.’s Like the Sound of Pandora
text: From Liz Gannes at GigaOm:

headline: Rashomon In The OECD
text: It seems to me that much of the sensible debate over macroeconomic policy (as opposed to the nonsense debate — I cannot for the life of me see the case for monetary tightening) comes down to how you see this picture, which in some version has been making an appearance at various meetings I’ve been in lately:

headline: Bid For Euro Zone ‘Government’ Gains Ground
text: French-inspired plans to create an “economic government” for the euro zone took a step forward on Wednesday when the European Council president, Herman Van Rompuy, threw his weight behind the idea, Reuters reported.

headline: Zuckerberg on the Hot Seat
text: From Miguel Helft at Bits:

headline: Savored by the Palate, or as Part of a Portfolio
text: A simple Internet real estate ad caught Filip Opdebeeck’s eye in 2007: “Strongbox for rent.” The strongbox turned out to be a three-room vault beneath one of the many banks in this Swiss financial center, one room originally for bank archives, another for stock certificates, the third for gold.

headline: Marin Software Gets $11.2 Million More in Funding
text: From Anothy Ha at VentureBeat:

headline: Hedge Fund Manager Accused of Fraud Is Arrested
text: United States officials say an American fugitive wanted for money laundering and other financial fraud has been arrested in Poland, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Market Slide May Dent AgBank I.P.O. Valuation
text: The Agricultural Bank of China may struggle to get the kind of valuation it wants as it gears up to introduce one of the world’s biggest initial public offerings into a market that has slumped  a fifth in just six weeks, Reuters reported.

headline: Limits on Risk Said to Fuel Trader Exodus
text: On Wall Street, an exodus is under way and banks are trying to work out what to do about it.

headline: Treasury Optimistic on A.I.G. Repayments
text: The Treasury secretary, Timothy F. Geithner, on Wednesday looked beyond the collapse of a deal by American International Group to sell off a subsidiary, saying the insurance giant has other options for repaying $182 billion government bailout, Reuters reported.

headline: Pru Confirms Deal to End the Deal
text: It’s all over but the (shareholder) shouting.

headline: Churchill Downs Sews Up Deal for Youbet
text: Churchill Downs, the racetrack operator, completed its acquisition of online horse race betting site Youbet.com, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Comcast Spent $3.1 Million on Lobbying in 1st Quarter
text: Comcast  spent $3.1 million in the first quarter lobbying on its acquisition of a controlling stake in NBC Universal, among other issues, The Associated Press reported, citing a disclosure report.

headline: Spanish Dance Troupe Celebrates 30 Years
text: When people first hear the name National Ballet of Spain, they usually assume that the distinguished company performs works like “Swan Lake” and “Giselle.” But to the Spanish, the term ballet simply means dance — in this instance, traditional Spanish dance. To discover its breadth, beauty and theatricality, one need only spend an evening at the grand Teatro de la Zarzuela (Calle de Jovellanos, 4; 34-91-524-54-00), where the company will perform from July 8 to 18. For its 30th anniversary season, the troupe (teatrodelazarzuela.mcu.es) will present an extensive program of works from the Bolero School, a type of elegant and exuberant dance popular in the 18th century.

headline: Maginot Lines and Illusions
text: Peter Boone is chairman of the charity Effective Intervention and a research associate at the Center for Economic Performance at the London School of Economics. He is also a principal in Salute Capital Management Ltd. Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: BookRenter Expands Its Reach in Textbooks
text: Since Web sites like Chegg and BookRenter started renting textbooks, some students have been avoiding college bookstores. Now the bookstores want in on the game.

headline: What Girls Want: Boyfriends
text: Today’s idea: Today’s teenage girls “reluctantly endure the hookup culture,” but what they really want is boyfriends, an article says. Popular culture reflects this desire in Taylor Swift’s songs, “High School Musical,” the “Twilight” series and “Glee.”

headline: Air Products Extends Takeover Bid for Airgas
text: Air Products & Chemicals extended by two months the expiration date of its $5.1 billion hostile takeover bid for rival Airgas, with Airgas reiterating its opposition to the offer.

headline: F.S.A. Hits JPMorgan With $48.9 Million Fine
text: From DealBook colleague Julia Werdigier:

headline: Barclays and Citi Make Senior Hires
text: Barclays Capital has poached three senior investment bankers from Citigroup in London, while Citi has made three senior hires of its own, Reuters reported.

headline: The Coke Zero and Mentos Car
text: Video | The range on this baby might get you to the nearest 7-Eleven for refueling, if it happens to be across the street:

headline: I Know I’m Doing This Wrong
text: Is it reasonable for me to expect my employees to spontaneously suggest improvements to our operations? Or should I be glad that they are concentrating on their work? They put a lot of effort into doing their jobs, which are highly skilled and technical and involve constant physical exertion. Still, the guys on the shop floor spend a lot of time sanding, and I know from experience that this doesn’t require much thought — it does require very careful attention, which is different.

headline: Roaming Oil Blob: You’re the Host
text: Even with the most exquisitely scaled map, it can be difficult to understand the scope of the oil spill as the sheen spreads over the open gulf. But imagine if the rig exploded in your hometown.

headline: P.E. Shops Might Not Exit New Look Soon
text: Apax Partners and Permira Advisers may not find an exit this year from their investment in New Look, after the British retailer postponed plans for an initial public offering.

headline: Speed Read for Thursday, June 3
text: Here are some highlights from Thursday’s edition of The New York Times:

headline: Should M.L.B. Join N.F.L. With Replay Challenges?
text: The N.F.L., with replay challenges, is much less likely to have an episode like the umpiring error that cost Armando Galarraga a perfect game. If the Tigers’ Jim Leyland had the same right as the Lions’ Jim Schwartz in challenging a few calls per game, we wouldn’t be in this fine mess. Is it time for baseball to join the 21st century?

headline: Get in Line for 4,600 Free Electric Car Battery Chargers
text: Early adopters who buy an electric car, already set back by the cost of the vehicle, may have their mood further soured by the need to also buy a home charger, with an average price of about $2,000. But some city dwellers are in luck, because a federal grant will allow them to get the charger for free.

headline: The Mouse That Roars: Slovenia (Not Slovakia)
text: MARIBOR, Slovenia — Roam the mountains and vineyards of Slovenia, and its citizens and soccer players will regularly remind a foreign visitor of two verities.

headline: For Hedge Funds, Short Bets in Education?
text: Hedge funds on the hunt for their next big shorting opportunity have, at least according to the Business Insider, found their next tasty target: the for-profit educational industry.

headline: D.O.J. Said to Be Keeping Eye on Live Nation
text: Despite approving the merger of Live Nation and Ticketmaster Entertainment in January, the Justice Department is keeping watch over the new concert promotion and ticketing behemoth, The New York Post reported.

headline: Dear FloFab: Would You Like Fresh Black Pepper on That?
text: Each Thursday, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

headline: Schiavone Reaches Final After Dementieva Retires
text: 8:53 a.m. | Updated PARIS — Italy’s Francesca Schiavone walked into the French Open women’s final today with a 7-6 victory over Russia’s Elena Dementieva, who defaulted moments after losing a first-set tiebreaker and walked off the court.

headline: Q.&A.: From Zune to iPod
text: Q.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: With so many I.P.O.’s in a holding pattern, Nielsen’s announcement comes as something of a relief for a private equity industry otherwise slowed in its attempts to cash out. If a few more buyout shops get freed up, maybe they can use that cash to save the old media — not just Newsweek, but also Le Monde.

headline: Nocturnalist | Taking the Canvas Digital
text: Computer buffs use iPhones, algorithms and the Internet in creating art.

headline: Funeral Is Held for Dennis Hopper
text: The body of Dennis Hopper was buried on Wednesday following a memorial service at a church in Ranchos de Taos, N.M., The Associated Press reported. Mr. Hopper, the eccentric, wide-eyed actor of “Apocalypse Now” and “Blue Velvet,” and the director, co-writer and co-star of “Easy Rider,” died on Saturday from complications of prostate cancer. He was 74.

headline: White House Discussed Jobs With Candidate
text: WASHINGTON  What started off as an effort by President Obama’s advisers to steer his party through a stormy campaign season has mushroomed into a sharp debate over whether the White House went too far in using its power to eliminate challenges to Democratic incumbents.

headline: A Bill to Protect Nannies Advances
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: The Promise of a Foal
text: Liz O’Connell is a professional horsewoman who just finished foaling season at Anstu Farm in Millbrook, N.Y. She is a member of the New York State Task Force on Retired Race Horses and is active in rehoming off-the-track thoroughbreds. She is a graduate of Cornell University’s College of Agriculture and Life Sciences.

headline: The Early Word: The Jobs Trade
text: The White House is facing increased scrutiny over its efforts this election cycle to clear Democratic primary fields for preferred candidates.

headline: Touring the Collapse
text: We knew there were people who benefited from the crisis, and some didn’t even have to embark on a career in short-selling to do so.

headline: U.S. Retailers Report Lackluster Sales Gains
text: Consumers appeared to take a breather from shopping last month as sales at the nation’s retail stores posted only modest increases.

headline: Another View: Can Biotech Survive Icahn?
text: Bill George, a Harvard business professor, looks at the conflicts within the biotechnology industry between short-term and long-term gains.

headline: City Tightens Rules on Artificial Turf
text: The synthetic surfaces used in playgrounds and sports fields around the country have been a hot-button issue for years. Many park officials find that replacing grass or asphalt in play spaces with artificial turf, often material from shredded tires, allows for year-round use and cheaper maintenance. But environmentalists and parks advocates say the trend ignores potential hazards from lead and other toxins found in some of the materials, and from the extreme heat that they produce.

headline: 8 Scientists Share $3 Million in Prizes
text: Scientists competing to build humongous telescopes, elucidate the machinery by which brain cells signal each other and manipulate individual atoms and molecules into submicroscopic structures were among the winners of one of the richest prizes in science, the $1 million Kavli Prize, announced Thursday by the Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters.

headline: Ask a Bartender: The Final Round
text: In last Friday’s weekend section Frank Bruni wrote about Doug Quinn, who has tended bar at the original P. J. Clarke’s on Third Avenue only since 2003. “But in that time, he has become a legend, the bartenders’ bartender.” We asked readers to submit questions for Mr. Quinn. Here is his third and final round of responses.

headline: Tom Hanks Returns to ‘The Pacific’
text: Following his starring role in “Saving Private Ryan” and his work on the HBO miniseries “Band of Brothers” and “The Pacific” (on which he is an executive producer with Gary Goetzman and Steven Spielberg), Tom Hanks was not quite finished chronicling the American experience in World War II. On Nov. 2, HBO Home Entertainment will release the 10-part “Pacific” series, which dramatized the stories of three Marines who fought against Japan, as a DVD box set. A special Blu-Ray box set, also to be released on Nov. 2, will include even more enhanced features than the standard DVD release.

headline: The Lucky Cancer Patient
text: Regular readers of The New York Times may have noticed the recent absence of Floyd Norris, the paper’s chief financial correspondent. In a new blog post, Mr. Norris explains that he has received a cancer diagnosis and has been undergoing radiation treatments.

headline: Thursday Reading: Paper, Plastic or B.Y.O.B.
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Jonathan Karp to Head Simon & Schuster
text: Simon & Schuster on Thursday named Jonathan Karp, the publisher and editor in chief of Twelve, as the publisher of its flagship imprint.

headline: Live Analysis: Stosur Routs Jankovic
text: 11 a.m. | Updated  PARIS – Samantha Stosur of Australia raced to a straight-set victory over Jelena Jankovic of Serbia, 6-1, 6-2, in the semifinals of the French Open women’s singles. The victory capped a powerful week of upsets by Stosur, who defeated Justine Henin and Serena Williams en route to the finals.

headline: Hopeful Outlook on Jobs Gives the Market a Lift
text: Stocks rose on Thursday as speculation that a jobs report on Friday would bolster optimism in the economy overshadowed concern about slowing growth in China.

headline: Ensuring Math Isn’t Just a Museum Exhibit
text: I had a jarring moment Wednesday night as I talked with some of the science, math and engineering luminaries attending the World Science Festival celebration of the achievements of the physicist Stephen Hawking. In the crowd was Glen Whitney, a young mathematician who excitedly explained that he was creating the country’s first Museum of Mathematics.

headline: Paladino Moves Forward With Candidacy
text: Carl Paladino, the wealthy Buffalo developer and outspoken candidate for governor, said Thursday morning that he would spend about $500,000 to petition his way onto the Republican ballot and create a third party aimed at attracting Tea Party supporters.

headline: Alaskan Editor Who Took Aim at Palin Antagonist Apologizes
text: When the kerfuffle over the decision of the author Joe McGinniss to move in next to Sarah Palin blew up, the editor of the Mat-Su Valley Frontiersman had some fun with the national media’s fascination the Palin’s decision to build a fence. But what was a fairly amusing walk through the story ended rather darkly:

headline: Should I Go to All My Child’s Games?
text: For many parents, having a child involved in sports is both a blessing and a curse. Sports are great for a child’s health and physical and emotional development, but attending every game can be a challenge for busy working parents.

headline: Americans Make Goalkeeping Cool in England
text: IRENE, South Africa — For much of the history of soccer, England has provided the model for American players. But now the Yanks are teaching the limeys a thing or two about the game, at least between the sticks.

headline: A Night With Broadway's Stars
text: Angela Headley, a homeless mother, will step on stage at Lincoln Center Thursday night to perform with Broadway stars as part of a fund-raiser for Covenant House International.

headline: Ex-Goldman Analyst Ordered to Pay $27.8 Million
text: A former Goldman Sachs analyst who pleaded guilty to running an insider trading scheme and later fled while on probation has been ordered by a federal judge to pay nearly $27.8 million, Reuters reports.

headline: A Perfect Night Ruined
text: For anyone who has watched or played baseball, any sport for that matter, from the littles to the majors, Wednesday was a very difficult day. And a worse day still for Jim Joyce.

headline: Popcast:  Steve Lacy’s ‘November,’ Stone Temple Pilots and More
text: This week: Ben Ratliff discusses Steve Lacy’s “November” and posthumous jazz records, and Jon Pareles reviews the Stone Temple Pilots reunion album. Ben Sisario is the host.

headline: A Baseball Natural Just Wanted to Be Normal
text: His name and his talent forged a destiny for Ken Griffey Jr. He was going to be famous, whether he liked it or not. Yet in many ways, Griffey, who retired on Wednesday after 22 major league seasons, simply wanted to be normal. The inherent contradiction is part of what made him as fascinating a person as he was a ballplayer.

headline: Obama Returns to the Gulf on Friday
text: In the continuing efforts by the White House to demonstrate President Obama‘s commitment to minding the sprawling Gulf oil spill, the administration announced today that he would return to the region tomorrow for another visit. It will be his third in a little more than a month since the explosion killing 11 workers that spawned the vast leakage.

headline: Admiral Says Oil Pipe Is Cut, a Key Step in Halting Leak
text: NEW ORLEANS  Delicately manipulating a 20-foot-long shear at depths of nearly a mile, technicians successfully snipped a key riser pipe on Thursday in their effort to contain the oil spewing into the Gulf of Mexico from a stricken undersea well. They prepared to cap the severed pipe later in the day with a dome that they hoped would allow them to funnel the oil to tankers on the surface.

headline: The Times to Host Political Polling Site FiveThirtyEight
text: The New York Times said Thursday that it would begin hosting the popular blog FiveThirtyEight and make its founder, Nate Silver, a regular contributor to the newspaper and the Sunday magazine.

headline: Coalition Calls for Boycott of Comedy Central Over Cartoon Depicting Jesus
text: 11:06 a.m. | Updated A coalition of organizations that seek to promote what they see as religious values and family-friendly programming said on Thursday that they were calling on prospective sponsors to boycott advertising on a planned Comedy Central animated series that would satirize Jesus Christ.

headline: Times Readers Suggest Fixes for Oil Spill
text: As my colleague William Broad reports, the United States is not planning to heed calls from armchair engineers to fire a nuclear weapon at the damaged BP well still gushing into the Gulf of Mexico — simply because, in the words of one official, “It’s crazy.” That said, as Mr. Broad notes, ideas about how to cap the well are flowing onto the Web nearly as fast as oil into the water.

headline: Perfect Fit
text: Bruce Cameron Clark’s shop sells suits to hedge fund presidents, Saudi princes and rock stars.

headline: Yankees React to ‘The Call’
text: Normally, pitching seven innings of one-run ball will get you noticed. But it was easy to overlook Phil Hughes and everyone else who pitched gems of their own Wednesday night, thanks to one missed call in Detroit.

headline: Let’s See What You’re Grilling
text: City Room is inviting readers to share their  pictures from around the grill as well as favorite recipes, as part of this summer’s “Around the Grill” series of articles and videos. You can submit a photo of your get-together or submit a recipe and a photo of your dish.

headline: Sending More Money South of the Border
text: Walk around immigrant neighborhoods anywhere in the United States and you will see signs in storefronts each offering the cheapest rate to send money back home. In Mexico and other Latin American countries, these flows from workers, known as remittances, help support families, back new businesses and even plug holes in the balance of payments account.

headline: In Leaked Lecture, Details of China’s News Cleanups
text: BEIJING  As the nation held its collective breath, China’s first astronaut, Yang Liwei, floated back to the motherland, having orbited Earth 14 times in the Shenzhou 5, or Divine Capsule.

headline: Galarraga’s Thoughts the Morning After
text: Armando Galarraga, a picture of class and dignity after losing his perfect game Wednesday night on an umpire’s missed call, appeared on “The Frank Beckmann” show on WJR-AM in Detroit Thursday morning.

headline: On Our Radar: Oil-Drenched Wildlife
text: The picture looks grim for wildlife along the gulf coast; a BP employee suggests the true animal death toll is being obscured.

text: There’s an eerie silence settling over our Forward Operating Base. The generators are shutting down one by one, and every night there are fewer lights.

headline: E.P.A. Tightens Sulfur Dioxide Limits
text: WASHINGTON  The Environmental Protection Agency issued a new health standard on Thursday for sulfur dioxide emissions, the first such revision in nearly 40 years.

headline: Touchstones in Concert, Reweaving Harmonies
text: EAST PALO ALTO, Calif.

headline: 36 Hours in Salt Lake City
text: THERE’S a new party in Salt Lake City. Utah liquor laws were normalized last year for the first time since 1935, allowing patrons simply to walk into a bar and order a drink, as if they were in any other city. Add to that a budding film scene (a spillover effect from the nearby Sundance Film Festival), a fresh crop of indie galleries and boutiques, and an open-door stance toward refugees and immigrants, which has made the city more cosmopolitan. The city even passed an anti-discrimination law last year that protects lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender residents — and with backing from the Mormon Church.

headline: Carrie Fisher to Continue ‘Drinking’ on HBO
text: If you missed Carrie Fisher‘s very public peace-making with her Hollywood upbringing and her perpetual status as the heroine of a certain beloved outer-space epic, you’ll soon be able to catch it on a television not far, far away. On Thursday, HBO said that it will show a feature-length documentary based on “Wishful Drinking,” Ms. Fisher’s one-woman show that was presented by Roundabout Theater Company at Studio 54 earlier this year.

headline: Against Instant Replay
text: Extraordinary cases make bad law. In a sense, Armando Galarraga’s non-perfect perfect game, spoiled by an umpire’s call on what should have been the 27th out, offers the strongest possible exhibit for expanding instant replay’s role in baseball. Who wouldn’t want to have seen Galaragga take his rightful place in the history books, making this remarkable baseball season — whose first two months have already featured two perfect games and a no-hitter — more remarkable still? And after watching the post-game agony of Jim Joyce, a distinguished umpire whose career will be forever marred by this one unforgivable call, who would deny the next disastrously-erring ump the chance to watch a replay on a video monitor and make the whole thing right?

headline: A Weekend in Salt Lake City, Utah
text: Salt Lake City is a bastion of creativity, full of intimate restaurants and retro design shops.

headline: Touring British Columbia’s Wine Country
text: The breathlessness about British Columbian wine comes from the glory of the Okanagan Valley landscape.

headline: British Columbia’s New Vine Trail
text: LAST October, my husband and I packed the kids in the car and drove north 300 miles from Seattle to western Canada’s key wine country, the Okanagan Valley in British Columbia.

headline: Ramallah Attracts a Cosmopolitan Crowd
text: THE open-air deck pulsed with the rhythmic dancing of hundreds of young people, their hands raised toward the pine trees above them, needles sparkling yellow, red and blue in the disco lights. Couples watched from the sides by bonfires, huddling against the breezes billowing in from the valley below the club.

headline: Ramallah’s Night-Life Scene
text: This city on the West Bank offers music, dancing and a liberal attitude.

headline: In Washington, D.C., K Street Steps Out of Its Suit
text: TIME was that the streets radiating out and down from K Street in Washington — hallowed ground for lobbyists and image-makers — were a fusty culinary landscape of white tablecloths, blue blazers and standard steakhouses. But in recent years, those looking for a less predictable menu have migrated to ever more inventive, and ethnic, restaurants opening on and around the K Street strip.

headline: International Eats in Washington, D.C.
text: Japan, Britain, India and Philadelphia contribute cuisines to the byways surrounding K Street.

headline: Rue McClanahan, Actress and ‘Golden Girls’ Star, Has Died
text: Rue McClanahan, the brassy actress who stirred equal parts Southern charm and sex appeal into her roles on television shows like “Maude,” “Mama’s Family” and “The Golden Girls,” has died, People magazine reported. The death was announced by Ms. McClanahan’s manager, Barbara Lawrence, who said that the actress died on Thursday morning of a stroke. She was 76.

headline: World Cup Ball Is Already in Goalkeepers’ Heads
text: Johannesburg

headline: In Your Child’s Shoes
text: I believe parents can often sense what their children are feeling. I suspect we can’t do that as often as we think we can. That’s particularly true as they grow older, and deliberately hide things from us, and also when life throws them challenges we have never faced.

headline: Dementieva Explains Surprise Withdrawal
text: PARIS -– A torn calf muscle in her left leg, injured in the second round of play, forced Elena Dementieva to retire at the end of a single set in the semifinals of the French Open, she told reporters following her surprising exit from the court.

headline: Angry and Confused in Detroit
text: DETROIT — Tigers fans were still steamed at the umpire Jim Joyce the day after his blown call cost pitcher Armando Galarraga a perfect game on Wednesday night at Comerica Park.

headline: Schiavone in Final After Dementieva Retires
text: PARIS  A curious match of contrasting styles looked no more than halfway over. But as Francesca Schiavone sat in her chair after winning a first-set tie breaker, Elena Dementieva approached.

headline: Oil Could Reach Atlantic Coasts
text: For weeks there have been discussions about the potential for the spreading Gulf of Mexico oil slick to slip around Florida and flow up the East Coast. Now a suite of simulations, run by an international team of ocean and climate scientists, shows this is a likely outcome should the flow remain unabated this summer. The researchers stress there are caveats and uncertainties, most notably related to the state of the gulf’s highly variable loop current in coming weeks. (The Department of Energy put out its own fact sheet stressing that the simulations are highly uncertain.)

headline: Vigorous Exercise Linked With Better Grades
text: College students who want to boost their grades can start by boosting their level of exercise, new research suggests.

headline: Before and After: Coral as Litmus Test
text: In an article in Wednesday’s Times, I wrote about a scientific voyage last summer on which marine biologists discovered one of the largest coral reefs in the northern Gulf of Mexico, 1,300 feet down on the seafloor in frigid temperatures and total darkness.

headline: Paige Rense Noland to Retire From Architectural Digest
text: Paige Rense Noland, the longtime editor in chief of Architectural Digest, will be retiring at the end of August, Condé Nast announced on Thursday.

headline: Calculating How Much That Overdraft Will Cost
text: If you didn’t already know that overdraft fees were a bad deal, ING Direct will do the math for you.The online bank introduced an overdraft calculator on Thursday, which will compute how much you would pay should you spend more than what you have in an ING Electronic Orange Checking Account. So if you overdrew by $100, you would pay 14 cents in interest on the line of credit used to cover the amount (that’s assuming you don’t pay it back for a week).

headline: Solti Award for Music Director of New York Youth Symphony
text: The Solti Foundation U.S. has given Ryan McAdams, the music director of the New York Youth Symphony, a $10,000 prize for emerging conductors, the foundation said on Thursday. Mr. McAdams, 28, has been advancing quickly in the orchestra world, making recent appearances with the New York City Opera, the Los Angeles Philharmonic and the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra, among others. He is a former protégé of Alan Gilbert, the music director of the New York Philharmonic.

headline: City to Pay $10 Million to Man Framed for Murder
text: The city said it reached a $9.9 million settlement agreement on Thursday with a man who was released from prison nearly two decades after being framed for a murder he did not commit by a police officer who doubled as a mob hit man.

headline: Errors End Perfect Games, Even Ones by Umpires
text: Armando Galarraga deserves praise for the way he has handled himself after the blown call by Jim Joyce that cost him a perfect game on Wednesday. Galarraga, the Tigers’ right-hander who will henceforth be remembered as the unluckiest pitcher in baseball, sets a great example for children. Trust me, as a Little League coach, I’ll be using his example of sportsmanship, perspective and respect for authority.

headline: Sam Sifton’s 50 Current Favorite New York Restaurants

headline: A New Kind of Coffee Bar
text: Coffee and chocolate are natural partners, though it took Elizabeth Montes of Sahagún, the tiny artisanal chocolatiere in Portland, Ore., to take it beyond the obvious “two great tastes that taste great together” to a mash-up so pure they become an integrated whole. Meet KA-POW!, a chocolate bar made with coffee — in other words, a coffee bar.

headline: Year-End Round-Up | Language Arts, Literature, Journalism and Fine Arts
text: As you may know, our daily lesson plans are on summer vacation and will return in early September. In the meantime, we’ve got some surprises in store for both teachers and students, starting with our Summer Reading Challenge. If you receive our e-mail, you’ll see our summertime materials under the heading “Summer Special.”

headline: Stosur’s Serve Delivered Her to the Final
text: A torn calf muscle forced Elena Dementieva to retire after losing a first set tiebreaker to Francesca Schiavone. The sudden turn of events caught everyone by surprise, including Schiavone, who had just reached her chair after winning set point on an errant backhand by Dementieva. The quick end to the match meant that Samantha Stosur and Jelena Jankovic would go on much sooner than either player anticipated for their semifinal match.

headline: Filmed to a Pulp
text: STEPHEN KING once said of the novelist Jim Thompson: “He was crazy. He went running into the American subconscious with a blowtorch in one hand and a pistol in the other, screaming his goddamn head off. No one else came close.”

headline: Teachers’ Night at the Apollo: The Results Are In!
text: Around the time the ninth New York City public-school teacher was being booed offstage Wednesday night at Harlem’s legendary Apollo Theater, City Room started wondering who at the Education Department could have possibly endorsed the notion of an Apollo Amateur Night devoted exclusively to city teachers. Or whether the event, billed as a way to spotlight teachers’ hidden talents (see video), was really some sort of crafty bargaining tool intended to show them that raises or no raises, they should consider themselves lucky to have their classroom jobs.

headline: U.S. by the Numbers
text: To paraphrase the Beatles: You know their names, now here are their numbers … sash and all and a look at the entire uniform and team gear.

text: AT&T will no longer offer an unlimited data plan, and a lot of smartphone owners may be wondering how that affects them. For most, it’s an opportunity to save money.

text: Steven P. Jobs predicted earlier this week that the personal computer was going to go the way of the farm truck: It won’t disappear but it will be relegated to a niche role by popular mobile devices like smartphones and tablets.

headline: Merkel's Favorite for German Presidency Loses Out
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel suffered a setback Thursday when her preferred candidate to be Germany’s next president, Labor Minister Ursula von der Leyen, lost the race after a leading conservative premier, Christian Wulff, was chosen by regional party leaders.

headline: Google and Hearst Make Digital Acquisitions
text: Deal-wise along Madison Avenue, it is not quite back to the frenzied buy-up days before the financial crisis. But two acquisitions announced on Thursday indicate that there is a quickening pace of deal-making as the economy seems to improve — particularly deals in the digital realm, which retained most of its allure even in the recent downturn.

headline: Republicans Choose Challenger for Senate
text: Closing out a raucous and at times contentious state convention on Thursday, New York Republicans designated Bruce A. Blakeman, a lawyer and former Nassau County legislator, as their preferred candidate to run against against United States Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand this fall.

headline: Classic Clash: Lakers Offense vs. Celtics Defense

headline: Matthew Bourne’s ‘Swan Lake’ to Return to New York
text: “Part cartoon, part spoof of the British royal family and part lyric poem” is how Anna Kisselgoff described Matthew Bourne’s “Swan Lake” in her original review of Mr. Bourne’s reinterpretation of the ballet classic featuring a male corps in 1998. “It may not be as spectacular or profound as the 19th-century original, but it is a polished entertainment, clever in its choreography and uninhibited in its tender moments,” she added. Now the Tony Award-winning production will return to New York for a limited run from Oct. 13 through Nov. 7 at City Center. Tickets for the performances, produced by City Center, Sadler’s Wells Theater of London and Back Row Productions, will go on sale on Monday.

headline: Fed Chief Urges Banks to Do More for Small Business
text: DETROIT  Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, said Thursday that banks needed to increase lending to small businesses to reduce unemployment and help the economic recovery.

headline: Sex Symbol With an Unearthly Twist
text: COMEDY is hard, it’s often said. But how easy can it be portraying a French-speaking, Russian musical genius when you’re a Dane who doesn’t speak French, Russian or play the piano? “I was looking forward to going down to Paris, having some coffee, saying some lines and producing some emotions,” the actor Mads Mikkelsen said of his role in “Coco Chanel & Igor Stravinsky,” a biopic about the real-life affair between the French fashion designer and Russian composer. “Instead, it was like going back to school.”

headline: Ruling Averts Chaos in Bronx Courts

headline: Chevy Tosses a Slider to Tigers’ Next-to-Perfect Pitcher
text: DETROIT — Hey, Armando Galarraga! You didn’t get a perfect game. But you did get a car.

headline: Valeo Hires Merrill to Explore Potential Sale
text: Valeo, one of the largest auto parts makers in France, has hired Bank of America Merrill Lynch to advise it on strategic alternatives that may include a sale, two people with direct knowledge of the matter told DealBook on Thursday.

headline: HauteLook Scoops Up $31 Million in Financing
text: The market for private online sample sales is only getting more competitive: HauteLook, which sells luxury clothing for women, men and children, as well as home furnishings and beauty products, has raised a fresh round of venture financing.

headline: Ohio Player | Collier West
text: Five years ago, after leaving her post as a visual director for the Limited Brand’s Express, Suzi West opened her shop Collier West in Columbus, Ohio. The boutique is located in the Short North District, an ever-expanding strip of galleries, boutiques and cafes which seems to cater to the stylish employees of local empires like Express and Abercrombie & Fitch. Collier West is filled with all sorts of stylish bric-a-brac from crystal chandeliers to John Derian decoupage to necklaces made from reclaimed bits and baubs. “Suzi likes all things French and anything made by hand,” says one staffer. “You won’t find anything produced in China.” Indeed, on one recent visit, there were organic bath towels made by a women’s collective in Ethiopia, colorful silk bangles from India, and one-of-a-kind chunky cocktail rings that came with a nice Midwestern price of under $40 dollars.

headline: Determining Your Company’s Value: Recasting the P.&L.
text: One of the first steps in the process of valuing your business is to recast, or normalize, your most recent profit and loss statements. At the heart of this process is a subject that is familiar here at You’re the Boss — it’s another example of the importance of cash flow.

headline: Answers From a Train Operator, Part 2
text: Following is the second set of responses from Dennis H. Boyd, who operates trains on the No. 4 Lexington Avenue subway line.

headline: Three American Subplots in Flotilla Drama
text: On Thursday, Turkish and American officials confirmed that one of the nine activists killed in an Israeli commando raid on Monday on a ship challenging Israel’s naval blockade of Gaza was an American citizen.

text: The White House is sending staff to Arizona for consultations with state and local authorities about immigration issues and the deployment of national guard troops to the state.

headline: Good Sportsmanship and a Lot of Good Will

headline: On Dance: A Physics Lesson From Karole Armitage
text: Erotic is not a word usually associated with physics, but that is one of the ways Karole Armitage describes the complicated subject she explores in her new work “Three Theories.” The choreographer has created the piece, which takes on relativity, quantum mechanics and string theory as part of the 2010 World Science Festival this week in New York. We asked Ms. Armitage about science, its relationship to dance, and the influence of her father, a biologist, on her work. “Three Theories” will have its New York premiere on Thursday night at Cedar Lake Theater in Chelsea; it runs through Sunday.

headline: Carrefour Chief Pursues Strategy to Strengthen Home Market
text: PARIS — The chief executive of Carrefour is staking the future of the giant French retailer on a simple strategy: strengthen at home, then either dominate or withdraw abroad.

headline: Bringing Doctors to the Dying Patient’s Bedside

headline: Making Sure Patients Don’t Die Alone
text: In today’s Doctor and Patient column, Dr. Pauline Chen writes about an innovative program that pairs medical students with lonely patients at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. The program represents an expanding movement in medical education that emphasizes the human side of medical care. Dr. Chen writes:

headline: For ‘Next to Normal,’ a Real-Life Couple
text: The real-life married couple Marin Mazzie (“Kiss Me, Kate”) and Jason Danieley (“Curtains”) will take over the roles of Diana Goodman and her husband, Dan, in the Broadway musical “Next to Normal” on July 19, the production said on Thursday. The roles mark the first time that the couple has appeared together in a Broadway musical; they last worked together on a major New York production in 1996 in the Off Broadway play “The Trojan Women: A Love Story,” and were married a year later. Ms. Mazzie, a three-time Tony Award nominee who most recently appeared on Broadway this spring in “Enron,” will succeed Alice Ripley, who won the Tony for best actress in a musical in 2009 for her portrayal of Diana, a woman suffering from bipolar disorder. Ms. Ripley is departing the show to prepare to play Diana in the North American tour, scheduled to begin in November. Mr. Danieley will replace Brian d’Arcy James (“Shrek”), who took over the role of Dan last month from J. Robert Spencer; Mr. d’Arcy James will rejoin the cast of the play “Time Stands Still” when it returns to Broadway in the fall. Ms. Ripley and Mr. d’Arcy James are to give their final performances on July 18.

headline: IndyCar Series Changes Engine Rules to Become Relevant Again
text: Seeking to establish itself as a technological proving ground again, and hopefully stoke competition as a result, the Izod IndyCar series announced Wednesday that it had developed a new engine strategy for the 2012 season. The new generation of engines, the series said in a news release, will be more powerful and efficient than the current formula.

headline: Low-Rider Report | Stop the Sag
text: “Stop the Sag” sounds like a great bra ad, but as anyone who has seen the billboard on Fulton Street in Brooklyn will attest, it’s actually the slogan of a campaign against low-riding baggy pants, initiated by State Senator Eric Adams, to encourage young people to look (and feel) more professional.

headline: Ultimate Fighter Turns Into an Actor, Ultimately

Animated by Mr. T in a Mohawk and enough gold jewelry to buy Trinidad and Tobago, B. A., as he was called, was a fool-pitying mercenary whose temperature was often at a steaming boil.

headline: TV Calls: Outrage for Cleveland, Mourning in Detroit
