headline: Cameron Rejects Rush to Tighten Gun Laws
text: LONDON  Prime Minister David Cameron said Thursday that Britain “should not leap to knee-jerk conclusions” about the need for tougher gun laws in the wake of the shooting rampage in northwestern England on Wednesday that left 13 people dead, including the gunman.

headline: Alternative Therapies for Raynaud’s
text: Can biofeedback, fish oils, dietary supplements or other remedies ease the feelings of coldness, numbness and tingling in the fingers and toes of people with Raynaud’s disease? Those are among the questions posed by readers in a recent posting on the Consults blog. Here, Dr. Fredrick Wigley of Johns Hopkins Medical School responds to readers asking about alternative therapies for Raynaud’s phenomenon. For more information, see Dr. Wigley’s earlier responses in “How Serious Is Raynaud’s Phenomenon?”, “Ask the Expert: Raynaud’s Phenomenon” and The Times Health Guide: Raynaud’s Phenomenon.

headline: Lifting the Cap
text: If oil companies had to pay the true costs of spills, you have to think the companies would take more precautions. But they don’t. A big reason is the $75 million cap on economic damages that Congress created in 1990.

headline: Boutique Finds Talent More Elusive Than Clients
text: Talk about the difference a year makes on Wall Street. The clients are back, but the top talent is harder to find.

headline: Road to Stardom: When Bob Hope Defined Himself
text: WITH three of its six titles new to DVD, Universal’s “Bob Hope: Thanks for the Memories Collection” offers some fresh insight into the development of one of America’s most revered and culturally resonant comedians.

headline: A Location Change for Showtime Chief
text: MATTHEW C. BLANK, the chief executive of Showtime, which is home to shows like “Nurse Jackie” and “Californication,” has sold his East Side apartment and is moving downtown.

headline: For Teenagers, Job Outlook Brightens Somewhat
text: The dismal summer-job outlook for students got a bit brighter after the House passed of the American Jobs and Closing Tax Loopholes Act — potentially 14,500 jobs brighter in New York, according to two lawmakers who represent parts of the city.

headline: Another Death-of-Books Forecast
text: From the company that brought you Betamax: Sony predicts that e-book sales will outpace print book sales within five years. Not that they’re biased or anything.

headline: Cuts From the Garden
text: Simple pruning tips for flowering shrubs.

headline: Failure Highlights Woes Facing Spanish Banking
text: “In the name of Jesus Christ, amen.” With this blessing, the chairman used to open board meetings of CajaSur, a Spanish savings bank controlled by the Roman Catholic Church that was one of the country’s better-known lenders. But last month, to avoid collapse, CajaSur was taken over by Spain’s central bank,  Raphael Minder of The New York Times reports from Córdoba, Spain.

headline: Hotel Review: Room Mate Emma, in Barcelona
text: THE BASICS

headline: Reporters Dispute Israeli Account of Raid
text: Updated | 5:02 p.m. On Thursday, Al Jazeera English broadcast an interview with Jamal Elshayyal, one of the channel’s journalists who was on board the Mavi Marmara on Monday when it was intercepted by Israeli commandos enforcing a naval blockade on Gaza.

headline: Restaurant Review: Bo Cinq in Amsterdam
text: You have to wonder what young Amsterdam professionals did on Friday nights before Bo Cinq opened last October. This brasserie and bar, in a touristy area in the city’s canal belt, features North African food and a lively scene. Twenty- and 30-somethings throng the 79-foot-long concrete bar, drape themselves on the sofas and easy chairs in the enormous lounge or, if they are lucky enough to secure a reservation, dine in the nooks and crannies of the candle-lit restaurant.

headline: A Lesson in Pruning From an Expert
text: This is the second installment in a summer-long look at the creation of a new flower garden and the restoration of some existing landscaping. The first article in the series looked at how to get the garden ready for planting. You can find it here.

headline: Fed Chief Urges More Lending to Small Business
text: Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, said Thursday that banks needed to increase lending to small businesses to reduce unemployment and help the economic recovery, Nick Bunkley of The New York Times reports from Detroit.

headline: Balk, Blasts and Another Yankees Victory
text: When a team as free-falling as the Baltimore Orioles meets a team as high-flying as the Yankees, the results sometimes seem preordained and present themselves early and symbolically. Such was the case Thursday afternoon at Yankee Stadium during the Yankees’ 6-3 victory, their fifth consecutive triumph and the Orioles’ eighth consecutive defeat.

headline: Should a Bad Call Change Baseball?
text: It has been called the worst call in baseball in the last 25 years. On Wednesday night, with two outs in the ninth inning in Detroit, Tigers pitcher Armando Galarraga was on the cusp of throwing a perfect game when the first-base umpire, Jim Joyce, called the Cleveland Indians’ Jason Donald safe at first base. It didn’t look close. Joyce has apologized for the error. On Thursday morning, Baseball Commissioner Bud Selig was considering the unusual move of overturning the call.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Gaza and Elsewhere
text: One of the nine people killed in an Israeli commando raid on a flotilla of ships heading for Gaza this week was a United States citizen of Turkish descent, officials in Turkey and Washington said Thursday. The development added a new diplomatic complexity as Israel struggled to defuse rising international anger over its raid on six ships seeking to break its blockade of the Gaza Strip, where officials from the Hamas movement were reported on Thursday to be resisting Israeli efforts to deliver truckloads of goods seized from the flotilla.

headline: Vain Glorious | Go with the Glow
text: What: “Park Ave Princess” Matte Waterproof Bronzer from the all-natural beauty brand Tarte.

headline: A Conductor’s Passion for ‘Porgy’
text: GEORGE GERSHWIN called “Porgy and Bess” a “folk opera,” emphasis on opera, and lived to see the premiere, on Broadway, in truncated but substantially operatic form. At that time the piece was sung virtually all the way through, but the version that traveled the world after Gershwin’s death, in 1937, was effectively a musical comedy, with spoken scenes framing musical numbers that  apart from “Summertime”  were invariably performed much too fast.

headline: The Morning Skate: Margins Thin in Tight Cup Final
text: When two teams are as well matched as the Flyers and Blackhawks are in the Stanley Cup final, one of the factors that will separate them are the mistakes that allow one team to capitalize on a breakdown.

headline: A Texas Doctor With a Possible Cancer Cure
text: Plain, plodding and relentlessly expositive, “Burzynski” tries to wrestle medical clarity from a snarl of science and human suffering. The price paid, however, is a documentary as visually arid as it is topically fertile.

headline: Made to Order, $5,000 Antidote to a Casual Age
text: If you need a suit, go to Men’s Wearhouse. If you need a bespoke suit — well, first a definition of bespeaking:

headline: Cameron Pursues Role in Stanching Gulf Gusher
text: Alarmed by the ongoing oil gusher in the Gulf of Mexico, James Cameron, the film director and longtime user and developer of deep-sea technology, helped organize a meeting of experts at the Environmental Protection Agency on Tuesday and spoke about it Wednesday night at the Wall Street Journal’s “D: All Things Digital” conference near Los Angeles.

headline: Movement and Music to Stir the Soul
text: MARY LOU WILLIAMS, the jazz pianist, arranger and composer, said that the first time she saw Alvin Ailey’s work, “I went out of my mind, and I don’t do that often.” In 1971 Ailey had what he described as “one of the greatest creative experiences of my life.” That year he and Williams created something of a religious experience  funky, soulful and luminous  known as “Mary Lou’s Mass.”

headline: Classical Crossover: Let Them Jump Genres
text: To the Editor:

headline: Living Art vs. Artifact
text: To the Editor:

headline: Players Channel Their Inner ‘Idol’
text: Four days before he knocked out the world No. 1 and defending champion, Roger Federer, from the French Open, Robin Soderling was wearing a platinum blonde wig and singing ABBA into a microphone.

headline: Agnès Jaoui: Not Woody Again
text: To the Editor:

headline: Summer Shakespeare, Outside and Urban
text: Joseph Papp first presented free Shakespeare performances in Central Park more than 50 years ago. Today, like heat advisories and smelly subway stations, Shakespeare among the elements is intrinsic to summer in the city.

headline: Nathan Lane: And Don’t Forget ‘Butley’
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘The Last Stand’
text: Americans have lived with the familiar images of the “Old West” for more than two centuries. But for those who actually participated in the events of that past, the West was dynamic, unpredictable, and startlingly new. Native horse culture was only a few generations old by the time Lewis and Clark ventured west in 1804, and ever-building pressure from the East meant that the tribes’ territories and alliances remained in near-constant flux throughout the nineteenth century.

headline: Changes to Chase’s Continental Credit Cards
text: Yesterday, Chase made a number of changes to its two most popular credit cards that earn miles in Continental’s OnePass frequent flier program. Here are a few of the highlights, though you can read details in the news release.

headline: Is There More Life for Two Off-Broadway Musicals?
text: Commercial producers have expressed interest in extending the lives of two generally well-received Off Broadway musicals, “Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson” and “The Kid.”The Public Theater is exploring ways to transfer “Bloody Bloody” to Broadway next season, according to two producers who have spoken to executives at the Public about the show.

headline: Last Stand? Yes. Last Word? Never.
text: Few events in American history have generated as much commentary as the 1876 Battle of Little Bighorn, and George Armstrong Custer has become one of those contested figures who have been mythologized to the point of caricature: glorified as a romantic figure of frontier individualism and reviled as a glory-seeking avatar of genocidal hatred. In more recent years Custer’s story has also been told with more detail and dispassion: in Jeffry Wert’s 1996 account of his military maneuvers (“Custer: The Controversial Life of George Armstrong Custer”), and in Evan S. Connell’s novelistic classic, “Son of the Morning Star: Custer and the Little Bighorn” (1984).

headline: Remembering Iraq
text: Reports from Baghdad after a coordinated attack by Al Qaeda on May 10 were grim. The bombing was the latest in a series of large-scale attacks by Sunni extremists that began last August after a long and uneasy period of relative peace in the capital. The news of this and the previous attacks held importance for me. For nearly a year, my men and I patrolled areas fewer than ten miles from where Iraqi emergency personnel sifted through the smoldering remains.

headline: Error After the Fact Can Do Justice to Galarraga
text: Armando Galarraga’s perfect game is gone. Umpire Jim Joyce blew the call at first base with two out in the ninth inning Wednesday night, and that cannot be undone. (Perfection apparently requires the umpires to reach that same standard.) Yet there is still a way to get Galarraga into the record book, and one man has all the power.

headline: Prakash Jha’s ‘Godfather,’ Bhopal Version
text: Prakash Jha’s new Hindi film, “Raajneeti,” takes a dim view of the Indian political scene. Extortion, intimidation and murder (with car bombs, wooden bats and, less creatively, guns) engage the movie’s politicians far more than any platform or position.

headline: Sculpture Is a Trip for Twins and Met
text: Summer on the Metropolitan Museum’s roof has typically meant circling a pedestal or two before moving on to cocktails and the view. But with “Big Bambú,” a walk-in/walk-on, site-specific, thoroughly exhilarating sculpture by the twin brothers Doug and Mike Starn, the museum has raised the bar.

headline: Dell Chief Has Considered Taking Company Private
text: Dell‘s chief executive, Michael S. Dell, said Thursday afternoon that he had considered taking the company he founded private and that the transformation of the computer maker was still incomplete, Reuters reports.

headline: Masa Takayama’s New House Has Lots of Room for Dinner Guests
text: NEW YORKERS are serious about lots of things, like food, art and  of course  real estate.

headline: Devi’s Chef Is Leaving to Open a New Indian Restaurant
text: Hemant Mathur, the chef and founding partner at Devi, will leave in a couple weeks to open his own place, Tulsi, at 211 East 46th Street. The name of the restaurant, which he and his partners expect to open in September, means holy basil in Hindi.

headline: The Week Ahead: June 6 — 12
text: Art

headline: City Hall, 3:26 P.M.
text: A hole outside City Hall is the site of an archaeological dig this week. Workers have been testing to determine the age of an underground wall unearthed during the construction of a subbasement utility vault. The Landmarks Preservation Commission says that the wall appears to date from the 18th or early 19th century and may have been associated with the First Almshouse, a poorhouse that stood on the site from 1736 to 1797.

headline: Glories of Nature, Tamed by Man
text: One of the greatest landscapes of the Romantic era can be found right in the middle of Manhattan. It isn’t a Turner, a Friedrich, a Delacroix  or anything in a museum, for that matter. It’s the 843-acre “Greensward” plan designed by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux in the mid-19th century  or, as we know it, Central Park.

headline: On the Road to Rock, Fueled by Excess
text: “He’s one of the last remaining rock stars!” says Aaron Green, referring to Aldous Snow, the “him” in the new film “Get Him to the Greek.” The Greek is a famous concert hall in Los Angeles, and the guy to whom the film’s imperative title is addressed is Aaron himself.

headline: The Politics of Espionage and Redemption
text: Thursday night marks the return of “Burn Notice” for its fourth season. A hit spy series on USA, “Burn Notice” chronicles the adventures of a former government spy (Michael Westen, played by Jeffrey Donovan) who washes up in Miami where he tries to right the wrongs of various underdogs with the help of his sidekicks Fiona (or just “Fi,” Gabrielle Anwar) and Sam (Bruce Campbell). The creator of the series, Matt Nix (whose latest show, “The Good Guys,” recently made its debut on Fox), answered some of our questions via e-mail. He’d like to hear from readers as well, so fire away. Send along your inquiries and we’ll post Mr. Nix’s responses here.

headline: For Residents of Homeless Shelter, a Night to Shine
text: Yvette Alston pulled a strapless dress with a gold waistband out of her locker at the homeless shelter on West 41st street where she lives.

headline: iPads Take to the Air
text: Travelers may not have to actually buy an iPad to use one on the road. The device has already gained a foothold in various hotels, and the latest to adopt the iPad is Jetstar Airways, a subsidiary of the Australian airline Qantas, which recently  announced plans to roll out iPads as part of its in-flight entertainment options.

headline: Painting Thin Air, Sometimes in Bright Blue
text: WASHINGTON  By now, hero worship of the French artist Yves Klein (1928-62) should be a thing of the past. Sure, he was charismatic, movie-star handsome and a black belt in judo, and he had a gift for provocative gestures. At the age of 19, on the beach with two friends, a poet and an artist, Klein “signed the sky” as his first work of art. In the mid-1950s he developed a smoldering ultramarine pigment that in a stroke of branding genius, he patented and named International Klein Blue.

headline: House Tour: Ticonderoga, N.Y.
text: WHAT Three-bedroom house.

headline: Cleopatra’s Underwater Kingdom
text: PHILADELPHIA  It may be best to dispel any illusions immediately. The only certain images we seem to have of the last queen of Egypt, Cleopatra VII, have no discernible resemblance to the painted faces of Elizabeth Taylor or Claudette Colbert or Sarah Bernhardt. Those visages can be contemplated with far more sensuous contentment than the Egyptian queen’s bulbous, knotty and eroded features stamped on gold coins from the first century B.C.

headline: I Call Your Name
text: My husband and I are expecting. But every time we discuss a baby name with family and friends, someone claims it, saying they’ve always wanted to use it. This has happened four times already. Their responses range from surprise that we’d steal their baby name to threats of never speaking to us again. Some of these people are still single! Don’t we have the right to name our child anything we like?

headline: Oil, the Loop Current and the Atlantic
text: Many have fretted that oil from the spill in the Gulf of Mexico could spread to the Florida Keys and then northward up the Atlantic. Now, the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colo. has come up with some computer modeling suggesting that the spill could extend along thousands of miles up the Atlantic coast as early as this summer.

headline: Theater Listings: June 4 — 10
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

headline: Yves Klein at the Hirshhorn
text: Images from a new exhibition in Washington.

headline: Queen of the Nile
text: Images from an exhibition about Cleopatra at the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia.

headline: Feeding the Comedy Beast Without Serving Leftovers
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: The Revenue Picture, State by State
text: State revenues rose in the first quarter of this year, largely because two states raised a lot of money through tax hikes, according to the Rockefeller Institute of Government.

headline: 2010 Chevrolet Corvette Grand Sport
text: The Grand Sport borrows just enough of the looks and performance of its upmarket brethren.

headline: Sampling the Scene
text: Parties mentioned in this article:

headline: Obama Will Tout Medicare Rebates
text: With the government preparing to put the proverbial checks in the mail, President Obama is planning a televised town hall meeting on Tuesday with senior citizens to trumpet one of the most popular provisions of his landmark health care bill: a $250 rebate to help Medicare beneficiaries pay for prescription drugs.

headline: Social Disrobing and Other Party Fare
text: IT was Friday night, and the face paint was optional, but few people abstained. Why? Because here was a woman in pasties and a giant pink beehive talking to a guy in a unitard with a balloon for a head, who called himself the Eye of Disorient. There was a woman in a nude body stocking, with artfully applied glitter, go-go dancing on a platform. A daughter of a Factory star was nearby, alongside some art school kids, television writers and other nightlife denizens. And everywhere there were tchotchkes and doodads, glowing in the black light.

headline: Bronx Zoo’s New Lion Cubs Are Impossibly Cute
text: I SUFFER from cat envy.

headline: Treating the World’s Sorrow and Pain
text: At one point in “Living in Emergency: Stories of Doctors Without Borders,” Mark Hopkins’s new documentary about that Paris-based humanitarian group, an Australian doctor stationed in Congo, his tongue loosened by a lot of local beer, unloads his scorn for Unicef and other, similar organizations. They approach mass suffering, he says, by way of theories, meetings and high-minded statements of principle, whereas he and other Doctors Without Borders physicians meet the consequences of war, epidemic and natural disaster one patient at a time.

headline: Senate Leader Urges Action on Energy Bills
text: In another sign that Democrats plan to harness outrage over the BP oil spill to help pass a comprehensive energy and climate change bill, Senator Harry Reid wrote to six committee chairmen on Thursday calling for new proposals to respond to the current and future disasters, for inclusion in the broader package the Senate will debate this summer.

headline: A Duo’s Switch in Roles Is Made in Harmony
text: When Dave Rawlings and Gillian Welch sing country music together, they don’t stay within the safety zone of harmonizing in thirds. Sometimes it’s a wider interval; often it’s narrower; and sometimes, but only for a few notes at a time, they sing in unison. This is true whether she sings lead and they’re performing under her name  which is usually the case  or vice versa, which was the case for Wednesday night’s show at the Bowery Ballroom by the Dave Rawlings Machine.

headline: Prime Meats No Longer Cash Only
text: It still does not take reservations, but Prime Meats, the popular, relatively expensive, 19th-Century-ish German-style restaurant in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, has at least added one 21st- Century luxury. It has started to accept payment by American Express card.

headline: Finding Other America in Slums and on Farms
Lehman Plans Auction of Its Modern Artworks
Lincoln Center Closes Roof Lawn
text: Even on the Upper West Side, it seems, this is the season of lawn-care problems. Just two weeks after opening its new sloping roof lawn, Lincoln Center on Tuesday had to close it.

headline: Urban Camping, Bargemusic, Museum Mile Festival
text: New Yorkers who feel the need to escape the concrete jungle and return to the wild can take advantage of the Urban Park Rangers’ free family camping trips. The outings are held on select weekends through September, in parks throughout the five boroughs. All you need is a sleeping bag and a flashlight; the rangers provide the rest, along with the chance to hike at night and observe nocturnal creatures. Or simply lie back, eat some s’mores and do a little stargazing. Families can sign up for trips on specified registration dates but space is limited. (Details are at nycgovparks.org; search for “family camping.”)

headline: A Musical Exploration of Insomnia and Oblivion
text: Music inspired by night and sleep and the discontinuity between the two formed the backbone of “Illuminating Darkness,” a program by the Da Capo Chamber Players at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday evening.

headline: It’s Official: Murphy Is Out for the Season
text: Daniel Murphy came to spring training in February as the starting first baseman for the Mets, although he knew that Ike Davis was lurking in the minor leagues.

headline: Cuomo in Rift With Working Families Party
text: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo is pressuring the embattled Working Families Party to install placeholder candidates for governor and attorney general at the party’s convention on Saturday, according to three people who were briefed on Mr. Cuomo’s actions.

headline: Coalition Seeks Boycott of Comedy Central Series
text: A coalition of organizations that seek to promote what they see as religious values and family-friendly programming said on Thursday that they were calling on prospective sponsors to boycott a planned Comedy Central animated series that would satirize Jesus Christ. The group, Citizens Against Religious Bigotry, which includes leaders from the Media Research Center, the Catholic League and the Parents Television Council, said that the series represented a double standard in light of the network’s decision to censor an episode of “South Park” that mocked the Prophet Muhammad, the founder of Islam. In April, Comedy Central bleeped the audio of a “South Park” show that said a character was the Prophet Muhammad disguised in a bear costume. The move came after the show’s creators, Trey Parker and Matt Stone, were named in ominous messages posted on revolutionmuslim.com, the Web site of the Islamic group Revolution Muslim. Comedy Central said last month that it was developing a show called “JC,” in which Jesus tries to lead a normal existence in New York. The series has not yet been added to the network’s schedule or shown to the public. The coalition said it had written to some 250 advertisers urging them not to support the series. Tony Fox, a press representative for Comedy Central, said: “ ‘JC’ is an idea and an idea only. Perhaps the Citizens Against Religious Bigotry should save their energy for the moment if and when this series ever makes air.”

headline: Solti Award For Music Director of New York Youth Symphony
text: The Solti Foundation U.S. has given Ryan McAdams, the music director of the New York Youth Symphony, a $10,000 prize for emerging conductors, the foundation said on Thursday. Mr. McAdams, 28, has been advancing quickly in the orchestra world, making recent appearances with the New York City Opera, the Los Angeles Philharmonic and the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra, among others. He is a former protégé of Alan Gilbert, the music director of the New York Philharmonic. The foundation also gave two career assistance awards: $5,000 to Kazem Abdullah, 30, a former assistant conductor at the Metropolitan Opera who made his debut there last year, and $3,500 to Robert Trevino, 26, who made his New York conducting debut at the New York City Opera’s VOX: American Opera series. The foundation, which supports young conductors, was established by the family of Georg Solti, the longtime music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, after his death in 1997.

headline: Police Station Chemistry: She’s New, and He’s a Flirt
text: Judging by its silly title, not to mention the feathered hair and police station banter, “Buddy Cop 2” seems as if it could be a joke-filled love letter to Mel Gibson and Danny Glover. But don’t be fooled. Set in the 1980s, this downtown gem, full of minor-key revelations and offhand epiphanies, roots its quirky charm in an earnest and surprising realism.

headline: ‘Talent’ Is Tops but NBC Isn’t
text: The second night of the NBC reality competition “America’s Got Talent” topped the ratings on Wednesday, but the network placed third for the night over all. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 10.1 million viewers tuned in for the second installment of “America’s Got Talent” auditions, in Dallas. Fox averaged the most viewers on the night, attracting 7.3 million for “So You Think You Can Dance” from 8 to 10, while CBS was a close second with sitcom repeats followed by reruns of “Criminal Minds” (8.1 million) and “CSI: NY” (8.6 million). ABC finished in fourth place with comedy repeats and a new episode of “Happy Town” (2.8 million).

headline: Tennis Meets Obstacle Course
text: CARDIO tennis is like recess with a racket. A trademarked exercise class taught around the world and gaining ground in New York, it promotes movement on a court while keeping instruction and angst at a minimum. Think of it as playing at tennis.

headline: For ‘Next to Normal,’ a Real-Life Couple
text: The real-life married couple Marin Mazzie (“Kiss Me, Kate”), top right, and Jason Danieley (“Curtains”), below right, will take over the roles of Diana Goodman and her husband, Dan, in the Broadway musical “Next to Normal” on July 19, the production said on Thursday. The roles mark the first time that the couple have appeared together in a Broadway musical; they last worked together on a major New York production in 1996 in the Off Broadway play “The Trojan Women: A Love Story” and were married a year later. Ms. Mazzie, a three-time Tony Award nominee who most recently appeared on Broadway this spring in “Enron,” will succeed Alice Ripley, who won the Tony for best actress in a musical in 2009 for her portrayal of Diana, a woman suffering from bipolar disorder. Ms. Ripley is departing the show to prepare to play Diana in the North American tour, scheduled to begin in November. Mr. Danieley will replace Brian d’Arcy James (“Shrek”), who took over the role of Dan last month from J. Robert Spencer; Mr. d’Arcy James will rejoin the cast of the play “Time Stands Still” when it returns to Broadway in the fall. Ms. Ripley and Mr. d’Arcy James will give their final performances on July 18.

headline: The Morning Line: Belmont Shares Spotlight
text: Bennett Liebman is the Executive Director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

headline: Flowers That Bloom Between Abysses
text: Referring to the Beethoven piano sonata universally known by the evocative nickname  “Moonlight”  (Op. 27, No. 2), Liszt deemed the bright Allegretto between its moodier outer movements “a flower between two abysses.” Thomas Sauer, a pianist and the director of the Mannes Beethoven Institute, said Liszt’s observation provided a structure for the opening concert of this year’s series, presented on Wednesday evening.

headline: HBP to Film Carrie Fisher’s Show
text: If you missed Carrie Fisher’s very public peacemaking with her Hollywood upbringing and her perpetual status as the heroine of a certain beloved outer-space epic, you’ll soon be able to catch it on a television not far, far away. On Thursday, HBO said that it would broadcast a feature-length documentary based on “Wishful Drinking,” the one-woman show by Ms. Fisher, right, that was presented by Roundabout Theater Company at Studio 54 earlier this year. The show, in which Ms. Fisher shares stories of her childhood with her parents, Debbie Reynolds and Eddie Fisher, and re-coils her hair in the coif she sported as Princess Leia in “Star Wars,” was called a “brut-dry, deeply funny memoir of a show” in a review by Ben Brantley in The New York Times, yet somehow escaped the attention of the Tony Award nominating committee. HBO said that its documentary will be directed by Randy Barbato and Fenton Bailey (“Monica in Black and White,” “The Eyes of Tammy Faye”), and will combine footage of the show, to be taped on June 25 at the South Orange Performing Arts Center in South Orange, N.J., with archival footage and other interviews. A premiere date for the documentary was not announced.

headline: Fresh Adventures With Balanchine, and Jazzy Footwork With Rodgers
text: The four ballets that entered New York City Ballet repertory on Wednesday night didn’t add up as a rich program. They will return in combination with other works, perhaps to better effect, during this month. But they did open up different aspects of ballet both in fulfillment and, just as often, in potential.

headline: 520 Days Inside a Simulated Spacecraft
text: As The Lede explained last year, Russian preparations for travel to Mars revolve around experiments in a hanger in Moscow, where teams of researchers have been spending increasingly long periods locked inside a simulated spacecraft.

headline: Ask the Dancers: Young Americans in Russia Respond
text: Earlier this week Clifford J. Levy wrote about Julian MacKay and Joy Womack. The two budding ballet dancers are among a small group of Americans who have ever trained at the prestigious and competitive Bolshoi academy in Moscow. We asked readers to submit questions to the two dancers. Here is the first round of responses.

headline: What to Watch: Soderling vs. Berdych
text: While the tennis world is abuzz after Robin Soderling’s upset of Roger Federer, don’t count out his semifinal opponent, Tomas Berdych, who has quietly demolished opponents on his way to the final four at Roland Garros. In his five matches, he has not lost a set; in fact, he’s only lost 43 games. He easily handled Andy Murray in the Round of 16, then followed that up by overpowering Mikhail Youzhny.

headline: Dancing Their Way to a Tony Nomination
text: The pleasures of dance and choreography come from strange sources. It is not without embarrassment that I report my recent delight in a male pole-dancing Pierrot in Cirque du Soleil’s “Banana Shpeel.” And I am somewhat shamefaced in mentioning my pleasure in the caged-birds number performed by the transvestite chorus in the current production of “La Cage aux Folles.”

headline: Rereading ‘The Man Who Loved Children’
text: There are any number of reasons you shouldn’t read “The Man Who Loved Children” this summer. It’s a novel, for one thing; and haven’t we all secretly sort of come to an agreement, in the last year or two or three, that novels belonged to the age of newspapers and are going the way of newspapers, only faster? As an old English professor friend of mine likes to say, novels are a curious moral case, in that we feel guilty about not reading more of them but also guilty about doing something as frivolous as reading them; and wouldn’t we all be better off with one less thing in the world to feel guilty about?

headline: Up Front: Jonathan Franzen
text: In his essay for this issue, Jonathan Franzen, the author of “The Corrections,” makes a strong case for Christina Stead’s novel “The Man Who Loved Children,” which he feels deserves a much wider readership than it has so far achieved.

headline: Action on the Stage Imprinted on the Eye
text: All kinds of things can happen at a contemporary dance performance besides actual dancing. (And I mean all kinds of things.) But Dusan Tynek, a Czech choreographer who has lived in New York since 1992, makes traditional kinds of dance: pieces with recognizable steps, set to music, possessed of beginnings, middles and ends.

headline: Hasan di Tiro, Who Led Indonesia Rebels, Dies at 84
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Hasan di Tiro, the founder of the Indonesian rebel group the Free Aceh Movement, which fought Jakarta in a three-decade war of independence before disbanding under a peace accord in 2005, died Thursday in the provincial capital, Banda Aceh. He was 84 and had returned from exile in 2008.

headline: Jazz Listings

headline: Man Meets Mermaid (There’s a Catch)
text: Tucked inside “Ondine,” the latest from Neil Jordan, is a wisp of a tale about a mythical sea creature and the sailing man who crosses paths with this being. As admirers of Mr. Jordan know, this director of “The Crying Game” and “The Butcher Boy” and, more recently, the macabre revenge story “The Brave One,” has a fondness for fantasy worlds. While the genre coordinates of his fictions change from film to film  they sometimes skew toward comedy, other times toward horror and occasionally someplace in between  the line between fantasy and reality in both his stories and in his characters’ heads often remains blurred.

headline: C.A.A. Talks to Buyout Firms Over Potential Alliance
text: LOS ANGELES — The Creative Artists Agency, the entertainment and sports powerhouse, has been in discussions with private equity firms like Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and TPG about a potential alliance or joint venture to build up its sports business, people briefed on the talks told DealBook.

headline: Report Warned Wal-Mart of Risks Before Bias Suit
text: More than six years before the biggest sex discrimination lawsuit in history was filed against Wal-Mart Stores, the company hired a prominent law firm to examine its vulnerability to just such a suit.

headline: Salute of the Stars, Cosmic and Otherwise
text: As the host of the opening-night gala performance of the World Science Festival at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday evening, Alan Alda promised a trip through the cosmos “at the speed of art.” And on this occasion, at least, art stepped lively.

headline: Which Team Has the Right Stuff to Win the Title?
text: Carlton J. Chin, a fund manager, and Jay Granat, psychotherapist, are authors of “Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological & Mathematical Method.”

headline: Careful, That Test Tube Might Be Incubating a Bouncing Baby Monster
text: The two recognizable stars of “Splice,” a pleasurably shivery, sometimes delightfully icky horror movie about love and monsters in the age of genetic engineering, are Adrien Brody and Sarah Polley, a well-matched pair of earthbound oddities. Given their respective performative idiosyncrasies and, as important, their singularly nontraditional beauty, the pair’s casting immediately signals that the director Vincenzo Natali is after something different. With Ms. Polley and Mr. Brody on board, there’s a chance that despite the big-studio brands on the movie, you’re not headed into genre purgatory with the usual disposable plastic people who often populate (and perish in) mainstream horror. When these two bleed, you might actually care.

headline: Out of Toothpaste or Toilet Paper? Buy It Online
text: The founders of Diapers.com managed to start a company selling a commonplace product and turn it into a darling of the tech world. Now its founders are trying to do it again, with Soap.com.

headline: Case of the Kidnappings and the Scared Island
text: Like the child-killing clown in Stephen King’s “It,” the bogyman known as Cropsey was, to the children of Staten Island, a morphing symbol of evil. Hook-handed or ax-wielding, he was said to haunt the grounds of the abandoned Willowbrook State School for the mentally disabled, pouncing on the unwary and unprotected.

headline: Plan for Relief Wells Spurs Hope Amid Caution

text: Initial casting for the September revival of Tony Kushner’s Pulitzer Prize-winning “Angels in America” includes Zachary Quinto and Billy Porter, according to two theater executives involved with the Signature Theater Company production.

headline: Almost-Forgotten Leino Plays Memorable Role in Playoffs for the Flyers
text: PHILADELPHIA  Few things seem to delight a hockey player more than the promise of extra ice time. Peter Laviolette, the Philadelphia Flyers’ coach, made such a guarantee this week to Ville Leino, who was not even dressing for games when the playoffs began in April.

headline: Standing in a Tunnel’s Path, and Forced to Leave

Like other businesses and landlords in the area, she has been warned that a giant tunnel-boring machine is coming to her neighborhood and that she will have to move as her building is marked for demolition.

headline: To Save an Afghan Boy

headline: A Big Cartoon Dog Tries the O.C.
text: The 200-pound Great Dane who lumbers through “Marmaduke” just can’t help himself. When his owners, Phil and Debbie Winslow (Lee Pace and Judy Greer), are snuggling in bed, that darned dog (voiced by Owen Wilson) has a habit of noisily releasing gas that is noxious enough to erase any immediate prospects of romance.

headline: Solar Power Keeps Cart Fleet in Motion
text: About a year ago, the Sebonack Golf Club in Southampton, N.Y., retrofitted its golf carts with solar cell roof panels. Sebonack said it was the first American golf course with a solar-powered cart fleet. The roof panels convert daylight into power and charge the cart as it is being driven.

text: Containment Effort Progresses

headline: Yelp and OpenTable Join Forces
text: On Thursday evening, Yelp.com, the user-generated review Web site, and OpenTable.com, the restaurant reservations site, announced an integration that will allow Yelp users to make a restaurant reservation directly from a Yelp.com review page.

headline: Investors Demanding Social Justice
text: As instances of business malefaction pile up  Enron, Madoff, Goldman Sachs, A.I.G., Toyota, BP, and we’re just clearing our throats with that lineup  the concept of corporate responsibility has acquired the sour air of an oxymoron for many people. Laura Berry is not one of them.

headline: BP’s Natural Gas Joint Venture in Russia Is in Bankruptcy
text: MOSCOW  The British oil giant BP conceded another setback Thursday in its struggle to recover hundreds of millions of dollars in investments from a venture to sell Russian natural gas to China.

headline: Housing for Sex Offenders
text: To the Editor:

headline: Filmmaking Stripped Bare
text: Julie Davis’s trifling romantic comedy, “Finding Bliss,” is a goofy ode to the liberating benefits of pornography. Its heroine, the strait-laced Jody Balaban (Leelee Sobieski), is an aspiring director with a degree from New York University’s film school who goes to Hollywood to break into the movie business. When the only job to be found is editing pornographic films for Grind Productions, she grits her teeth, averts her eyes and settles down to work, determined to bring a softer feminine perspective to the company’s hard-core products.

headline: Eating Together: The Bonds We Formed at Our Table
text: To the Editor:

headline: Our Cluttered Minds
text: Socrates started what may have been the first technology scare. In the “Phaedrus,” he lamented the invention of books, which “create forgetfulness” in the soul. Instead of remembering for themselves, Socrates warned, new readers were blindly trusting in “external written characters.” The library was ruining the mind.

headline: Smart Students Go After Intel’s Science Prize
text: Three enterprising high schoolers blaze a path to the holy grail of science contests in “Whiz Kids,” an unabashed celebration of geekitude, idealism and the will to win.

headline: New York G.O.P. Selects Candidate for U.S. Senate
text: Closing out a raucous and at times contentious state convention on Thursday, New York Republicans designated Bruce A. Blakeman, a lawyer and former Nassau County legislator, their preferred candidate to run against Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand this fall.

headline: Keeping Score: Act of Perfection Remains Random
text: There have already been two perfect games this season, and that’s not counting Armando Galarraga’s near-miss on Wednesday night.

headline: In Supreme Court Work, Early Views of Kagan
text: WASHINGTON  As a young law clerk working for Justice Thurgood Marshall at the Supreme Court in September 1987, Elena Kagan wrote an angry memorandum urging her boss to try to overturn a conservative appeals court ruling that had questioned the constitutionality of a rent-control ordinance.

headline: City to Pay $9.9 Million Over Man’s Imprisonment
text: New York City agreed on Thursday to pay $9.9 million, the largest personal settlement in its history, to a man who served almost two decades in prison but was released after evidence surfaced that he had been framed for murder by a corrupt detective.

headline: Woods Is Tied for 50th After a First-Round 72
text: DUBLIN, Ohio  Geoff Ogilvy and Tiger Woods finished at the same time Thursday evening, but not the same place. The two were separated by about 100 yards on the 9th and the 18th greens, by seven strokes on their scorecards and by nearly 50 places on the leader board after their first rounds at the Memorial Tournament.

headline: Thousands in Turkey Mourn Victims of Israeli Raid
text: ISTANBUL — It was a day of mourning for Turkey on Thursday, as a crowd of several thousand people streamed down a central boulevard here, bearing eight coffins draped in Turkish and Palestinian flags, one of them carrying an American citizen.

headline: Accused of War Crimes, and Living With Perks
text: THE HAGUE — Since the days after World War II when people accused as Nazi criminals awaited their fates in the grimness of Nuremberg Prison, reformers have dramatically reshaped the standards under which suspects accused of the vilest war crimes are being held.

headline: Off Broadway Vampires
text: Jordan Galland’s “Rosencrantz & Guildenstern Are Undead” has one great idea (and it’s not the title). An Off Broadway production, the film tells us, might actually be a vampire play  written and produced by bloodsuckers to gather an unsuspecting audience of potential victims. Now we know why sitting in a downtown theater can feel like living death.

headline: Daniel K. Tarullo, a Star Regulator at the Fed
text: WASHINGTON  As finishing touches are put on the most comprehensive rewriting of financial rules since the Depression, a 57-year-old former law professor is emerging as one of the most influential financial regulators in the United States.

headline: Google to Give Governments Street View Data
text: Google is bowing to the demands of three European governments and says it will begin surrendering the data it improperly collected over unsecured wireless networks.

headline: Pentagon Told to Save Billions for Use in War
text: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates has ordered the military and the Pentagon’s civilian bureaucracy to find tens of billions of dollars in annual savings to pay for war-fighting operations, senior officials said Thursday.

headline: Rue McClanahan, Actress and Golden Girl, Dies at 76
text: Rue McClanahan, who helped make “The Golden Girls” a long-running television hit playing the saucy, man-devouring Southern belle Blanche Devereaux (in one scene she made a date at her husband’s funeral), died Thursday in Manhattan. Unlike Blanche, she had no trouble admitting her age, 76.

headline: The Stories of the 2008 Democratic Convention
text: “Convention,” a behind-the-scenes documentary about the 2008 Democratic National Convention in Denver, is clearly meant to be inspirational  a salute to civic-mindedness and the importance of the little guy at the big event. To the extent that it is, it’s a bore. Fortunately, much of “Convention” is tragicomic rather than uplifting, demonstrating that what went on outside the arenas and stadiums where the candidates appeared was often its own version of absurdist political theater.

headline: Belgium’s Catholic Church Struggles to Regain Trust
text: LEUVEN, Belgium  It may be no accident that the Roman Catholic Church in Belgium is taking a more aggressive response to child abuse by priests.

headline: Tennis Channel Starts to Get Noticed
text: ROGER FEDERER, Justine Henin and the Williams sisters have all been upset at the French Open, but one major player seems to be on something of a winning streak  the Tennis Channel.

headline: Jury Selection Starts, Slowly, in Blagojevich Trial
text: CHICAGO  Finally, 18 months after the arrest of Rod R. Blagojevich, the ousted former governor of Illinois, he found himself seated at a table in a courtroom here Thursday, staring at the people who may decide his fate.

headline: For West, Distance Adds Peace to Rivalry
text: Emotional detachment was never one of Jerry West’s strengths. His passion was too great, his perfectionist impulses too powerful to allow for objectivity or perspective — on the basketball court or in the executive suite.

headline: Strip Club in Old School Draws Ire
text: The old Pioneer School in Neoga, Ill., recently reopened as a strip club, shocking Cumberland County residents.

headline: Dealbook: C.A.A. Is in Talks With Investment Firms
text: Creative Artists Agency, the legendary Hollywood talent agency that has, in recent years, branched out into many other businesses, is in talks with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and other private equity firms over a possible deal involving an expansion into sports. A full report is up on our sibling blog, DealBook.

headline: Worst Call Ever? Sure. Kill the Umpires? Never.
text: Let’s say Jim Joyce made the worst umpiring call in the history of baseball. Of course, Armando Galarraga of the Detroit Tigers was cheated of a perfect game, but he was cheated honestly, within the rules.

headline: Logs Show Coast Guard Saw Threat Early
text: Coast Guard officials grasped the potential threat of a catastrophic spill in the first days after the explosion on board the Deepwater Horizon drilling rig, estimating that 64,000 to 110,000 barrels a day of crude oil could possibly gush out of the well in the event of a complete blowout, according to Coast Guard logs.

headline: A Jobless Rate Still Unaffected by New Hiring
text: SCHAUMBURG, Ill.  After hemorrhaging jobs for months, the economy is finally starting to add them. Yet the unemployment rate is not really budging because of people like Regina Myles.

headline: A Perfect Game? Too Bad. But I Got Robbed, Too.
text: You don’t have to be a baseball pitcher from Detroit throwing the game of your life to get robbed in the big city. Heck, you don’t even have to play baseball to get robbed, cheated, wronged  to have your own perfect little game called life on any particular day botched by that great and menacing and half-blind umpire that is New York.

headline: We Might Decide to Fly
text: It would be nice if airlines would commit on their own to treat their passengers right: ensuring, at a minimum, that if you buy a ticket you get a seat and have a reasonable expectation of reaching your destination on time and with your luggage. In today’s world  where air travel is more of an ordeal than an adventure  this is, unfortunately, not the case.

headline: Russia Turns a Deaf Ear as Killing Cries for Justice
text: MAGAS, Russia  Only one spectator showed up for the final hearing in the killing of Magomed Yevloyev. He was a broad-beamed, ruddy-faced man in a carefully pressed black suit, and once in the courtroom he removed his tall fur hat, set it on the bench beside him and waited for a chance to speak.

headline: JPMorgan Penalized by Regulator in Britain
text: LONDON  JPMorgan Chase was fined a record £33.32 million ($48.6 million) on Thursday by the financial regulator in Britain for failing to keep client funds separate from the firm’s money.

headline: The White House Employment Agency
text: With one questionable phone call to a Colorado Senate candidate, the White House has again found itself on the defensive over its maladroit political operation. If it does not want a reputation as a full-employment clearinghouse for unapproved candidates, or further invite an investigation, the administration needs to impose some common sense on that operation  and soon.

text: CÓRDOBA, Spain  “In the name of Jesus Christ, amen.”

text: Israel’s government has decided to tough out the criticism of its attack this week on a six-ship flotilla trying to run the Gaza blockade. The story, and the anger, aren’t going away.

headline: Defense to Cite Operator Error in Fallen Crane
text: The lawyer for a contractor charged with manslaughter in a crane collapse on the East Side of Manhattan that killed seven people in 2008 plans to argue that the crane’s operator may have been at fault.

headline: Jobs Saved: 4,400
text: Mayor Michael Bloomberg of New York City made the sensible choice this week when he opted to freeze teachers’ salaries instead of laying off teachers. That is good news for the city’s children and for the estimated 4,400 teachers who would have lost their jobs. It is an equitable solution in tough times.

headline: Justice Souter’s Class
text: Justice David H. Souter left the Supreme Court nearly a year ago without really saying goodbye. There were no pre-retirement interviews of the sort that Justice John Paul Stevens gave to several journalists this spring. There were no farewell press conferences like those that several justices who retired during the 1980’s and 1990’s were willing to endure for the sake of placing their own codas on their Supreme Court careers.

headline: Scope of Unread Heart Tests in Harlem Hospital Widens
text: New York City hospital officials said Thursday that the problem of unread echocardiograms at Harlem Hospital Center was bigger than they had initially believed, and that a review of thousands of records had found six patients who might have been deprived of necessary medical treatment because the results of their heart tests were not read by doctors.

headline: Mets Lose Murphy for Rest of Season
text: After finally recovering from the right knee sprain he sustained near the end of spring training, and from the disappointment of losing his starting first baseman’s job, Daniel Murphy sat with Omar Minaya in the visitors’ dugout at a Florida ballpark last month and expressed his overriding desire to get back on the field.

headline: Another Torrent BP Works to Stem: Its C.E.O.
text: BP, already bedeviled by an out-of-control well spewing millions of gallons of oil into the Gulf of Mexico, now finds itself with one more problem: Tony Hayward, its gaffe-prone chief executive.

text: WASHINGTON  Maybe it should have just stuck with Snap, Crackle and Pop.

headline: Texas: Man Accused of Aiding Al Qaeda
text: A Texas man was indicted in Houston on Thursday, accused of trying to provide money and equipment to the branch of Al Qaeda in Yemen. The indictment said that the man, Barry Walter Bujol Jr., 29, of Hempstead, exchanged e-mail messages with the radical Yemeni-American cleric Anwar al-Awlaki starting in 2008, seeking his advice in assisting Al Qaeda. Mr. Awlaki sent him from Yemen a copy of his tract “44 Ways of Supporting Jihad,” prosecutors said. The Federal Bureau of Investigation, after learning of the e-mail messages, sent an informer posing as a member of Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula to contact Mr. Bujol, an American. From the informer, Mr. Bujol obtained equipment for the group, including global positioning system devices, telephone calling cards and a military compass. He was arrested May 30 after he boarded a ship bound for the Middle East with the equipment.

headline: Oblast Between Kursk and Tula
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — My first thought about this puzzle: “What a grid!”

headline: Race to Sanity
text: Sometimes it seems as if we’re doomed to fight a new culture war between orthodox liberals who have lavish faith in the power of government and orthodox conservatives who have almost no faith at all.

headline: City Police Commissioner and Councilman Clash
text: To those in the City Council chamber on Thursday, the bitter exchange between Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly and Councilman Albert Vann over a letter from the lawmaker to the commissioner might have been confusing.

headline: Times to Host Blog on Politics and Polls
text: The New York Times said Thursday that it would begin hosting the popular blog FiveThirtyEight and make its founder, Nate Silver, a regular contributor to the newspaper and its Sunday magazine.

headline: Head of Boutique Publisher Joins Simon & Schuster
text: Five years after establishing the Twelve imprint of the Hachette Book Group, a tiny, author-focused division that never publishes more than 12 books a year, Jonathan Karp said on Thursday that he was leaving his post as publisher and editor in chief to join Simon & Schuster as publisher.

headline: Breakfast With Dean Kagan: A Student Journalist’s Eye-Opener
text: When I was 19 and a rookie student reporter, I asked out Elena Kagan. Harvard deans don’t usually respond to e-mails from overzealous freshmen looking for scoops, but she did, and within seven minutes we had a date: breakfast, the Charles Hotel, 8:30 a.m.

headline: David Stern and the Free-Agent Summit
text: LOS ANGELES — The possibility that Dwyane Wade, as he said recently, was convening a free-agent summit with LeBron James, Amar’e Stoudemire, Joe Johnson, Chris Bosh and others to see how they might best navigate the summer signing frenzy, did not draw the ire of N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern.

headline: U.S. Call for Stress Tests Abroad Lacks Credibility
Save Us, Millennials
text: When an electorate is red-faced and fist-clenched, when the collective national blood pressure is 160 over 100, when the big issues of the day are mired in tired minds, it’s time to turn to the great, renewable resource of any vibrant democracy: the kids.

headline: Bloggingheads: High Tech Idiots
text: Robert Wright, left, of Bloggingheads.tv and Harry McCracken of Technologizer discuss missteps by tech companies.

headline: White House Talk Lightens Tone of Dispute on Immigration Law
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama and Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona have not been shy in taking jabs at each other over immigration policy.

headline: A Mayor by Her Side, but Politics Woos Her, Too
text: The two Republican political operatives had come from Washington to see whether Diana L. Taylor would consider running for the United States Senate. It did not take much prodding.

headline: Going Solar Is Harder Than It Looks, a Valley Finds
text: ALAMOSA, Colo.  The nightmare in the Gulf of Mexico, as oil spews unchecked from BP’s wrecked well, makes this high mountain valley seem even more idyllic than it is. Energy here, from the sun, is free, abundant and clean. For generations of farmers, and the hippies in the 1970s who went off the grid with their sun-powered water-heaters, and most recently the large-scale solar companies that have come looking for a new kind of harvest in one of the nation’s sweet spots for renewable energy, the sun is an anchor of life.

headline: Report of Famed Coach’s Death Is Retracted
text: On Thursday evening, the Internet buzzed with the news that John Wooden, the legendary basketball coach who led U.C.L.A. to 10 national championships in 12 years, had passed away at age 99. Twitter lit up with sage quotes from the beloved coach, and The Washington Post put up a simple, mournful headline: “John Wooden Dies at 99.”

headline: At UConn, Success Makes Baseball Fun Again
text: STORRS, Conn.  Perhaps the best baseball team to play at the University of Connecticut has characters who, collectively, are as loopy as a curveball.

headline: Florida Beaches Full as Playtime Runs Short
text: PENSACOLA, Fla.  When Tony and Jodie Delatte watched the gloomy news Wednesday night  sticky blobs of oil landing on the white beaches of Mississippi and Alabama  they knew right away what they had to do.

headline: Amid Losses From a Spill, Chefs Fear for Oysters
text: PORT SULPHUR, La.  Paul Prudhomme, the chef who put Cajun cooking on the map three decades ago, was bobbing in a boat on Thursday on a slate-gray stretch of Barataria Bay. A cable’s throw away, Dickie Brennan, a restaurateur from one of New Orleans’s most famous restaurant families, floated on another boat.

headline: Sotomayor Making Good on a Commitment to a Scrappy College With a Family Tie
text: When Sonia Sotomayor agreed to deliver last year’s commencement speech at Hostos Community College, the school was thrilled. Her mother, Celina, had graduated from the college’s nursing program in 1973, and Ms. Sotomayor was an exemplary role model, having traversed an invisible canyon  from a Bronx housing project to Princeton University to a prominent seat on the federal bench.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 3, 2010

headline: Zimbabwe: Diamond Researcher Is Arrested
text: Farai Maguwu, who leads the Center for Research and Development in Mutare, the leading civic group investigating human rights abuses in the Marange diamond fields, turned himself in to the police on Thursday and was charged with providing false information to Abbey Chikane, the Kimberley Process monitor appointed to ensure that the diamonds mined there are not being sold illicitly to fuel conflict. Mr. Maguwu met with Mr. Chikane on May 25. Since then, Mr. Maguwu’s brother has been picked up for questioning, and his cousin has been arrested and charged with obstructing justice. “This is a message to civil society that there’s a price for fighting for your rights  no one is safe,” said Mr. Maguwu’s lawyer, Tinoziva Bere.

headline: China: 3 Suspects Replace Wrongly Jailed Man
text: Police officials in central China say they have solved an 11-year-old murder case in which the corpse was used as evidence to imprison a man for a killing that never took place. The imprisoned man, Zhao Zuohai, had been arrested in a village in Henan Province a decade ago and forced to confess to killing a man with whom he was seen fighting. The main evidence was a headless torso found in the village well. In April, after Mr. Zhao had served 10 years of a 29-year sentence, the man he was supposed to have killed showed up alive. He was released, and officials admitted that he had been tortured to confess to a crime that did not exist. The body in the well, the police now say, belongs to Gao Zongzhi, The Beijing News reported. The police confirmed Wednesday that they had detained three men in his killing.

headline: Robert L. McNeil Jr., Chemist Who Introduced Tylenol, Dies at 94
text: Robert L. McNeil Jr., a pharmaceutical executive who introduced Tylenol in 1955 as a competitor to aspirin for pain relief, died on May 20 at his home in Wyndmoor, Pa. He was 94.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: A Female Trainer With an Old-School Pedigree
text: Alexis Barba is enjoying her role as the belle of the Belmont Stakes. She liked being zoomed to the top of the Empire State Building and smiled brightly for the news photographers awaiting her the other day.

headline: Add the Bullpen to the Mets’ List of Woes
text: There was great interest paid to the fact that Johan Santana threw 123 pitches Wednesday — was it too much, or too little? — but it was really Francisco Rodriguez who had an inordinately heavy workload in that game.

headline: Revert
text: Lynne Geyser writes: "My son and I are in disagreement concerning the use of the word revert. The only usage I find acceptable is 'to return to a previous state.' He uses it (and claims that his Bahamian/English friends use it) to mean 'to get back to someone.' That is, instead of saying, 'I will get back to you with that information or with respect to that issue,' they say, 'I will revert to you.' Can you shed some light on this?"  Revert, as the major American and British dictionaries have it, does indeed primarily refer to a return to a former condition, belief or practice. For instance, George Vecsey, a sports columnist for The New York Times, recently wrote of the woeful New Jersey Nets, "Jason Kidd, Kenyon Martin and Richard Jefferson reached the finals in 2002 and 2003, but the Nets have since reverted to their haunted roots."  Secondary senses of the verb include the legal one, denoting the return of something to its previous owner, as in the contractual boilerplate, "All rights revert to the author after publishing." In evolutionary biology, it can signal an atavistic throwback to an ancestral type. To someone familiar with only these traditional meanings of the word, "I will revert to you" might sound like a bizarrely personal take on either property law or genetics.

headline: Stuck on You
text: My friend Scott once laughed in my face when I told him I didn’t like driving a car with Massachusetts plates in Texas. I’m from Texas, you see, and when I visit my native state in a rental car, I don’t want to be mistaken for a Yankee. Scott, incredulous and logical, pointed out that it really didn’t make the slightest difference what inferences drivers on the roads I traveled might make about my geographical roots, insofar as I would never have any real-life dealings with them. Who cares what strangers in other cars think about you?

headline: Dizzying Symptoms
text: “I feel a swimming in my head,” mumbled the voice on the phone. Dr. Stephanie Pouch, a resident in her second year of training, wasn’t sure what to make of this elderly gentleman’s strange complaint. Was he feeling dizzy? He wasn’t sure; all he could say was that his head was “swimming” and that he almost passed out. Uncertain of the cause or even the nature of the complaint, Pouch sent the man to the emergency room. She was on call that day at the University of Chicago Medical Center. She would figure it out when he got there.

headline: First Love, Once Removed
text: The young man who came to see me a few months ago didn’t knock but stood at the doorway to my office. He was wearing baggy jeans, sneakers, a T-shirt and a baseball cap. His mink brown hair was cropped close to his head. He was handsome, with full lips and blue eyes.

headline: Heist School

Blagojevich may be the one who ran the gantlet of television cameras on Thursday as his corruption trial got under way, but the focus will soon be on a group of lawyers who entered the Dirksen Federal Building unnoticed: prosecutors with the United States Attorney’s Office for the Northern District of Illinois.

headline: Hospital’s Design Is Guided by Experiences of Youth

headline: Obama Warns BP on Paying Big Dividends Amid Oil Spill
text: NEW ORLEANS  President Obama visited the Gulf Coast on Friday and chastised BP for paying billions of dollars in dividends to shareholders and on advertising to save its image while some people whose livelihoods were wrecked by the company’s oil spill were reporting difficulties in getting their claims paid.

text: LOS ANGELES  This was the type of game Lakers Coach Phil Jackson relishes, in which Kobe Bryant is not employed as an escape valve with the ball in his hands and the outcome on his shoulders.

headline: Salary Cap Is a Threat to Hawks’ Continued Success
text: The Blackhawks hold a 2-1 lead over the Philadelphia Flyers going into Game 4 of the Stanley Cup finals in Philadelphia tonight. If the Hawks end their 49-year championship drought and hoist the Cup in the next few days, their fans should take a picture of the celebration and cherish the memory.

headline: News Quiz | June 4, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Donald Windham, Novelist and Memoirist, Dies at 89
text: Donald Windham, a novelist and memoirist who left vivid pictures of literary life in New York, both fictional and factual, when he was an intimate of Tennessee Williams, Lincoln Kirstein and Truman Capote, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89.

headline: Spain Wins World Cup, Sort Of
text: A goal by David Villa in the 61st minute proved to be the game-winner as Spain won its first World Cup title, defeating Brazil in the final of the 2010 tournament in South Africa.

headline: Giuseppe Taddei, Latecomer to the Met, Dies at 93
text: Giuseppe Taddei, a distinguished Italian baritone who made his Metropolitan Opera debut to glowing notices in 1985 at the astonishing age of 69 (though he would gladly have sung there decades earlier, he said, if only the Met had asked him nicely), died on Wednesday at his home in Rome. He was 93 and had continued his operatic career until he was well into his 70s.

headline: Irwin Rosten, Nature Documentary Filmmaker, Dies at 85
text: Irwin Rosten, a documentary filmmaker who introduced television audiences to the depths of the ocean and the interior of the human body and mind, died on May 23 in Los Angeles. He was 85.

headline: Benjamin Lees, Versatile Composer, Dies at 86
text: Benjamin Lees, an iconoclastic American composer who spurned modern musical trends in favor of work that was lyrical, tonal and widely described as approachable, died on May 31 in Glen Cove, on Long Island. He was 86 and had recently returned to the New York area after living in Palm Springs, Calif., for many years.

headline: Daniel K. Tarullo, a Star Regulator at the Fed
text: As finishing touches are put on the most comprehensive rewriting of financial rules since the Depression, a 57-year-old former law professor is emerging as one of the most influential financial regulators in the United States.

headline: Morgan Stanley’s Asia Chairman to Step Down
text: Morgan Stanley announced on Friday that Stephen Roach, the chairman of the bank’s Asia operations and one of the region’s most high-profile economists, would relocate from Hong Kong to New York, in part to take up a teaching position at Yale University, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

headline: Japan Elects a New Premier, Fifth in Four Years
text: TOKYO  Naoto Kan, a plain-spoken finance minister with activist roots, was elected prime minister on Friday, making him the fifth Japanese leader in four years.

headline: Investors to Scour AgBank I.P.O. Docs for Clues
text: Investors will scour a preliminary prospectus for Agricultural Bank of China‘s almost $30 billion I.P.O. for updates on its book value and bad loans. The financial update is expected later on Friday as part of China’s fourth-biggest bank’s dual listing in Shanghai and Hong Kong, slated for July, Reuters reported.

headline: Europe Needs More Action on Debt, Chrysler Chief Says
text: The European bailout of Greece may have prevented “catastrophic” results but Europe needs to take further action to resolve the region’s debt crisis, Chrysler Chief Executive Sergio Marchionne said on Thursday.

headline: David Salle: ‘Some Pictures From the 80’s’
text: Twenty-five years on, David Salle’s paintings of the 1980s haven’t gotten any nicer. They still unsettle, still resist assimilation. The 10 here, made from 1980 to 1985, show a young artist coming into his own: a precarious balance of dystopian and decorative.

headline: Bjarne Melgaard: ‘The Synthetic Slut: A Novel’
text: In Bjarne Melgaard’s case, the road of excess leads not to a palace of wisdom, but to a chaotic theater of psychological conflict.

headline: Pru Chairman Says No Change Coming at Top
text: Prudential‘s management team is under no pressure to step down over the British insurer’s failed $35.5 billion bid to buy A.I.G.‘s Asian life unit, Chairman Harvey McGrath said in an interview published on Friday in The Financial Times.

headline: Alison Elizabeth Taylor: ‘Foreclosed’
text: Marquetry, or intarsia wood inlay, tends to be associated with luxury. (Think of the Duke of Urbino’s “Studiolo” at the Metropolitan Museum or the furniture at Versailles.) But for a few years now Alison Elizabeth Taylor has been nudging this centuries-old craft into more plebeian territory, using wood veneer to depict everyday life around her hometown, Las Vegas.

headline: Douglas Florian: ‘Letting in the Light’
text: The artist and poet Douglas Florian is best known for writing and illustrating award-winning children’s books that are wittily educational, especially about animals. Working in gouache with collage, he depicts just about anything with an impressive combination of accuracy and improvisation and is similarly free with language.

headline: $25,000 for Your Best Video
text: If you’re serious about shooting and editing original video, you probably already know about Vimeo, the video-sharing site for ambitious videographers and their fans. But you may not know that Vimeo is having a contest that will deliver a $25,000 award for the “best original video.”

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about pop culture sites misstated the Web address for Gorilla vs. Bear, dedicated to independent music. It is gorillavsbear.blogspot.com, not gorillavsbear.com.

text: OK, I have to weigh in briefly on this debate between Mark Thoma and Scott Sumner. Mark is being too gentle here: on this issue, Scott is just wrong — actually wrong on two levels.

text: Computers are giving some investment companies a new edge in the markets by making trades on data before it even reaches other investors, The Wall Street Journal reports, citing market players and researchers who have looked into the trading.

text: The British oil giant BP conceded another setback Thursday in its struggle to recover hundreds of millions of dollars in investments from a venture to sell Russian natural gas to China, The New York Times’s Andrew E. Kramer writes.

headline: Private Club in London Goes Public (for Lunch)
text: So-called gentlemen’s clubs in Britain have long been shielded from the masses, and some even continue to prohibit women of any class. Until last month, the Milroy (5 Hamilton Place, W1J) was no exception. But now the hand-carved staircase, the newly restored tapestries and the Venetian chandeliers leading to its restaurant’s luxurious and extravagant dining rooms can be seen by the public — at least at lunchtime.

headline: Catalonia Asks Bank to Reconsider Merger Plans
text: The Generalitat de Catalunya has asked La Caixa Laietana, the last Catalan savings bank yet to be merged under Spain’s broad efforts at financial consolidation, to reconsider its plans to enter a “cold merger” with a group of savings banks led by Caja Madrid, a person at the regional government’s department of economics said Friday.

headline: Joe Drape’s Belmont Picks
text: The field for Saturday’s 142nd running of the $1 million Belmont Stakes. The New York Racing Association oddsmaker, Eric Donovan, set the morning-line odds. Joe Drape made the selections in order of preference.

text: Infogroup is urging shareholders to ignore the objections of two of its biggest investors and approve the database provider’s proposed $460 million sale to private equity firm CCMP Capital Advisors later this month, The Associated Press reported.

text: The Rothschild Group said on Thursday that it has named Jim Lawrence as its chief executive for North America, as the global firm seeks to bolster its practice here.

text: Isolated for decades behind Asia’s bamboo curtain, communist Laos will soon take a great leap into the global capitalist marketplace with the debut of a stock exchange to fuel a quiet mining and hydropower boom, Reuters reports.

text: The collapse of Prudential‘s deal to buy the American International Group‘s Asian life insurance arm has cost investment banks lucrative fees, put the British insurer’s top brass under fire and deprived the American taxpayer of a big payback.

On Thursday, General Odierno seemed to make it official, releasing a letter to United States troops here that set Sept. 1 as a milestone.

headline: Comparing This Recession to Previous Ones: Job Changes

Note: Because employment is a lagging indicator, the dates for these employment trends are not exactly synchronized with National Bureau of Economic Research’s official business cycle dates.

headline: Tip of the Week: A Google Delivery
text: If you don’t want to spend all your time trawling the Web for updates on your favorite topics, have Google deliver the latest articles directly to your e-mailbox. Just create a Google Alert, which is a message full of links to current news articles, video clips and other sources concerning your subject. Visit Google’s alert page, and in the search box, type in the topic you’re interested in, say, “New Orleans Saints.” Pick the types of sources you want to draw from, as well as the frequency and number of results you’d like to see. Fill in your e-mail address and click the Create Alert button to stop chasing the latest information and have it come to you.

headline: Getting Our Heads Around the Spill
text: Like many people, I have been reading the news about the oil spill and have an overwhelming desire to understand the entirety of the problem in the gulf. Stories like these are overwhelmingly complex, and it takes countless contributions from lone individuals and groups to begin to get a feel for what is happening.

headline: Q.&A. With S.&P.’s President on the State of Ratings
text: The credit rating agencies have been under continuing assault for the triple-A ratings they gave to billions of dollars of mortgage-backed securities that turned out to be virtually worthless when the housing market collapsed, propelling the financial crisis.
