headline: BP Boss’s Gaffes Collected on YouTube
text: As my colleagues Jad Mouawad and Clifford Krauss report, in addition to capping the flow of oil from its damaged well into the Gulf of Mexico, BP is also hard at work trying to contain the damage done to its public image by the steady flow of unfortunate words from Tony Hayward, its “gaffe-prone chief executive.”

headline: Wuz You Robbed?
text: No one disagrees that Armando Galarraga, the Detroit Tigers pitcher, was robbed of a perfect game the other night — not even the umpire who robbed him of it with a very bad call. Mr. Galarraga has shown considerable class in dealing with what has to have been among the most disappointing moments in his life. He even shook the ump’s hand.

headline: Deng Is Said to Have Backed Tiananmen Violence
text: BEIJING  The former Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping ordered the military to try to limit injuries when it moved against Tiananmen Square protesters 21 years ago, but told it to be ready to “shed some blood” if necessary, according to an unpublished diary said to document internal decisions that led to the violent crackdown.

headline: Cyprus Leaders Criticize Turkey During Pope Visit
text: PAPHOS, Cyprus  In the presence of Pope Benedict XVI, Cypriot religious and political leaders unleashed a furious broadside on Friday against Turkey, whose troops have occupied northern Cyprus since 1974.

headline: Room for Debate: Should a Bad Call Change Baseball?
text: Should there be greater use of video replays in baseball to prevent such errors? How would that change the game, for better or worse? A panel of experts, including Buzz Bissinger, Jim Bouton, Jason Turbow and Keith Olbermann discuss over at our Room for Debate blog. Some excerpts:

headline: Graphic Books Best-Sellers: ‘The Sopranos’ Meets the Reservation
text: Welcome to the world of “Scalped.” Setting: South Dakota’s fictional Prairie Rose Indian Reservation. Volume 6 of this series, published by Vertigo and written by Jason Aaron and illustrated by R.M. Guera, enters the softcover list at No. 5 this week. “Scalped,” with all its betrayal, violence and sex, has been aptly described as “The Sopranos” on an Indian reservation.

headline: The Morning Skate: Pronger’s Roadbocks Concern Blackhawks
text: These Stanley Cup playoffs have had a few underwhelming and novel controversies, like “Sand-gate” (the Canadiens’ alleged ploy to ruin the Flyers’ skates during the conference championship) and “Puck-gate” (Chris Pronger’s puck thievery after the first two games of the final). But an old reliable issue — the changing standards of officiating in the postseason — could be a feature of Game 4 of the Blackhawks-Flyers series on Friday night in Philadelphia.

headline: Chinese Military Impedes Ties to Pentagon, Gates Says
text: SINGAPORE  While China’s relations with the United States are improving in many areas, particularly on political and economic issues, China’s military is blocking efforts to strengthen ties with the Pentagon, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates told reporters on Friday.

headline: Friday Reading: More Unemployed People Start Looking For Work
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Inside the List
text: THE GIRL WITH THE STRUNK AND WHITE TATTOO: Stieg Larsson’s “Girl Who Kicked the Hornet’s Nest,” the third installment in his world-conquering Millennium trilogy, grabs the No. 1 spot on the hardcover fiction list. In the press run-up to the release, a few commentators noted an odd trans-Atlantic drift in the book’s title, which was rendered “The Girl Who Kicked the Hornets’ Nest” in Britain. As it turns out, this probably isn’t an instance of Larsson’s publisher nodding. According to Carol Fisher Saller, editor of the “Q & A” page at The Chicago Manual of Style Online and the author of “The Subversive Copy Editor,” a cheeky how-to book for comma jockeys published last year, “hornet’s nest” is the spelling in the 11th edition of Merriam-Webster’s Collegiate Dictionary (preferred by Chicago), while the Oxford English Dictionary lists “hornets’ nest.” “Evidently the change for the U.S. edition follows convention,” Saller said in an e-mail message.

headline: The Return of Manufacturing?
text: One possibly bright spot in the May jobs report, which was released today, was in manufacturing.

headline: Complaint Box | Assumptions
text: Maneuvering through New York City as a person with cerebral palsy can be a constant irritation. Just making my way down subway stairs at rush hour, with people breathing down my neck, is holy terror. But it is not the physical strain of steps and crowds that is my main source of anxiety. It is the naïve, inappropriate and sometimes downright mean comments that people make.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE GIRL WHO KICKED THE HORNET’S NEST,  by Stieg Larsson (Knopf, $27.95.) In the third installment of the pulse-racing trilogy featuring Mikael Blomkvist and Lisbeth Salander, the pair are threatened by an adversary from deep within the very government that should be protecting them.

headline: Paperback Row
text: STRENGTH IN WHAT REMAINS,  by Tracy Kidder (Random House, $16.) Kidder’s hero is a young medical student from Burundi who barely survives the civil war and genocide and manages to flee to New York City. Starting out with $200 in his pocket and sleeping in Central Park, the young man is eventually befriended by people who give him a place to live and help him make his way to university and medical school. This is “a story about survival,” Dwight Garner said in The Times. “It is just as notably about profound human kindness.”

text: To the Editor:

headline: A Tardy Education
text: To the Editor:

headline: Wages Up, and the Education Gap Grows
text: We covered the basics of the jobs report in earlier posts. Here are some details — on the rise in wages, the drop in part-time workers who want to work full-time, the increase in the workweek and the growing gap between unemployment for college graduates and everyone else:

headline: The Forces of Decline
text: To the Editor:

headline: Justice League
text: Two new children’s books from the brand-name writers Rick Riordan and John ­Grisham present special challenges for the adult reader — not that their publishers or target audiences care. But you, dear reader, are presumably not 11, so I offer this age-appropriate report.

headline: Summer, Interrupted
text: From the “Odyssey” through “On the Road” and beyond, journeys have always featured prominently in the literary tradition. The disrupted journey — the aim that goes wildly off course — is a type of story with a particular wayward appeal, and it’s one that happens to perfectly suit the storytelling talents of the artist and novelist Lynne Rae Perkins.

headline: Bound by Friendship
text: Remember passing a secret note to a friend in class, folding it as small as possible and handing it off beneath the desk to avoid detection? Or, on the receiving end, quietly unfolding the tiny missive and finding the message inside? Even if it only said “Hi!” or “Can I borrow a pencil?” the silent exchange, meant for your eyes only, felt vaguely thrilling. Your friend’s handwriting might be brisk or slouchy, but it was interesting to look at and added to the feeling of getting to know him or her.

headline: Beauty Among Beasts
text: For mystery readers, every book is a beach book and every day is a beach day. But even genre novels present a variety of escapist choices.

headline: 20 More Cookbooks
text: A COOK'S JOURNEY TO JAPAN: Fish Tales and Rice Paddies, 100 Homestyle Recipes From Japanese Kitchens. By Sarah Marx Feldner. (Tuttle, $27.95.) A charming, accessible introduction to Japanese home cooking.

headline: Gardening Books
text: Looks like we’re back to minding our peas and kumquats. This season, gardening books will tug us into the vegetable patch, and it’s but a slip of the muck boot into the chicken coop and pigpen. Where we go from there is anyone’s guess, but as I recall, last time around the rural life left us hungry for . . . Big Macs and TV dinners. Perhaps, though, while we’ve been spinning through this great cycle of dharma, we’ve ratcheted ourselves up to a higher level. We’ll see.

headline: Travel Books
text: It might be just a coincidence. Or another sign of publishing’s adaptation to the age of austerity. In any case, this season’s most interesting travel books have gone into staycation mode. Their authors aren’t any less curious about the wider world, but they tend to be nest builders, not vagabonds. Some, of course, have built nests in pretty remote places. Others are getting views of the open road without packing a suitcase. And one manages to have it both ways: pulling up stakes whenever the mood strikes, bringing her home right along with her.

headline: Cookbooks
text: It turns out America didn’t plunge into the Greater-Than-Great Depression that clouded last summer, but the jams and pickles we were spooked into putting up (and giving as budget-conscious gifts) seem to have reawakened the country’s can-do spirit. When a fashion-magazine writer I used to know started a home-canning blog called Saving the Season, I knew homesteader chic had come out of the larder.

headline: Carnivore’s Travels
text: Riding the wave of beef chic, the Canadian food writer Mark Schatzker travels to seven notably carnivorous countries on four continents and consumes 100 pounds of cow flesh in search not only of the perfect steak but also of the science behind its flavor. On a journey that starts in Texas and winds through France, Scotland, Italy, Japan and Argentina, he visits local farms, dines at meat meccas and traces the lineage of cattle. Throughout this blur of travelogue and food criticism, he sprinkles references to religion, history, anthropology, biochemistry and philosophy. (Who knew Roland Barthes was so interested in steak tartare?) Yet without fail, the conversation comes back to one question: What makes steak so tasty? Is it the breed or the feed? Marbling or aging? Preparation, cut or something else entirely?

headline: Updated: iPad 3G Shortage Won’t Bar Getting Unlimited Data Plan, AT&T Says
text: 1:04 p.m. | Updated to reflect decision by AT&T to allow customers who order a 3G iPad by June 7 to purchase an unlimited monthly data plan.

headline: The Message Is the Message
text: By the late 1940s, the art gods (gallery impresarios) had decreed that commercial artists be banished from galleries and museums unless they hid their tainted pasts. Of course, this changed when Andy Warhol, who started his career as a fairly successful editorial and advertising ­illustrator-designer, turned the art world on its soup can. Since then, the list of crossover artists has increased to the point where, arguably, it is difficult to be a contemporary artist without having an applied or commercial art pedigree — or at least without once having designed a T-shirt. Yet one of today’s most celebrated artists, Barbara Kruger, who began as a graphic designer for Condé Nast and helped pioneer (along with Lawrence Weiner, Ed Ruscha and Jenny Holzer, among others) a genre that liberally employs typography and advertising techniques, met with initial resistance not from myopic art pundits but from shortsighted fellow designers.

headline: Sex, Lies and Narrow Escapes
text: Megan Kelso is best known for elegant, small-scale comics (like “Watergate Sue,” serialized in The New York Times Magazine) with a historical or memoiristic bent. So it’s surprising and wonderful that ARTICHOKE TALES (Fantagraphics, $22.99), her first novel-length work, is the sort of world-­building fantasy story that comes with a family tree and a map on its endpapers. It’s also the sort of fantasy whose characters have artichoke leaves for hair, which means it doesn’t have to pass an anthropological stress test.

headline: South Africa Scores!
text: As hundreds of thousands of soccer fans pour into South Africa to watch the World Cup, we asked residents from five of the nine host cities what shouldn't be missed. While sharing their favorite things to eat, see and do, they all agreed on a few larger truths: some streets could be safer, the beaches are beautiful, the cities electric and the wildlife unparalleled. This week, with the eyes of the world upon them, they are ready to show it all off.

headline: Outside South Africa’s Stadiums
text: Residents of World Cup cities recommend places to eat, shop and sightsee after kickoff.

headline: Robin Domeniconi New Brand Officer at Elle
text: Robin Domeniconi has been named the new chief brand officer for Elle magazine, overseeing its content, advertising and marketing.

headline: Hello to All That
text: When I arrived in New York in 1980, Ann Beattie was, for many young aspiring fictionists, one of the two most influential writers in the country, the other one being Raymond Carver. Beattie’s influence, and her rumored proximity, seemed pervasive, a part of the cultural landscape. Her stories were appearing regularly in The New Yorker. Beattie’s feckless middle-class postgraduates, still mourning the demise of the ’60s, seemed like older versions of me and my friends, albeit with better taste. As clueless as her characters sometimes seemed, they were terribly clued-in, worldly and semiotically correct. Just as an earlier generation used to read Hemingway in part to learn what to drink and where to travel, we read Beattie in part to learn what to listen to and read and what to wear. It seems to me that it was a Beattie story that first alerted me to the existence of Billie Holiday.

headline: Ask the Dancers: Part 2
text: Earlier this week Clifford J. Levy wrote about Julian MacKay and Joy Womack. The two budding ballet dancers are among a small group of Americans who have ever trained at the prestigious and competitive Bolshoi academy in Moscow. We asked readers to submit questions to the two dancers. Here is the second round of responses. Read the first round here.

headline: The Normandie Breathes Again
text: For a few short moments, a breath of life pushed through the lungs of a steam whistle that once gave a loud presence to the Normandie, the French luxury liner that was known as the fastest, most fashionable way to get to Europe in the 1930s.

headline: Nadal Cruises Past Melzer in Semifinal
text: PARIS –- Rafael Nadal of Spain made his way back into the French Open men’s finals with a straight-set victory over Jurgen Melzer of Austria 6-2, 6-3, 7-6 (6).

headline: The Inner Air Guitarist Unleashed
text: Air guitarists can take one small step toward reality with PaperJamz, a set of musical instruments that look as if they’ve been run over by a steamroller.

headline: Car of Intrigue for a Man of Mysteries
text: ON a recent afternoon, Timothy Sheard, a 62-year-old mystery novelist, was leaning against his cherry red car, which was drawing attention from passers-by on an otherwise quiet Brooklyn street.

headline: Broadcaster Helps Man Struggling in River
text: Ron MacLean, one of the most recognizable sportscasters on Canadian Broadcasting Corp.’s “Hockey Night in Canada,” is known for his unflappable manner.

headline: Jay, Daisy, Nick and Cassie
text: A Couple of years ago, when the Australian filmmaker Baz Luhrmann bought the rights to “The Great Gatsby,” the move generated a fair amount of what Hollywood calls “buzz.” On the red carpet at the Academy Awards last year, the director, accosted by curious members of the press, called “Gatsby” “a great, iconic story” with remarkable contemporary resonance. “If you reread it now,” he declared, “you’ll see how powerful and meaningful it is in this time.” But last September Luhrmann retreated from the project, telling Newsweek, “I’ve not decided which thing I will commit to.” Conceding, “I own the rights to ‘Gatsby,’ ” he added, “I own the rights to it and a whole lot of other books.” It’s dispiriting to think of one of the greatest of the Great American Novels jumbled among a pile of books, not top of the heap. But, as Nick Carraway reflects at the story’s outset, “a sense of the fundamental decencies is parcelled out unequally at birth.” In this case, however, humility may hide behind the mask of hubris: it takes audacity to wrap the gilded name of Gatsby around your own shoulders and hope to wear it with grace. The prospect is daunting — or ought to be.

headline: A Solar Boom: Who Owns It?
text: Who has power in the high, sunny expanse of southern Colorado’s rural San Luis Valley?

headline: Starting the Summer in Paris
text: Arriving in Paris the other morning on assignment, I did what most of the bleary-eyed do: I immediately checked my Blackberry to see what I had missed over the Atlantic. According to a press release, VIP guests at the Marina Abramovic dinner—the subject of Eric Wilson’s diverting dead snake thread—were dressed by Givenchy, the host, with the letters RTW or HC after each name to denote a ready to wear or haute couture wearer.

headline: Corvette Plays Dress-Up: Now Isn’t That Special?
text: TESTED: 2010 Chevrolet Corvette Grand Sport

headline: Mozart: Keyboard Music, Vol. 1
text: The real draws are Mr. Bezuidenhout’s lively interpretive imagination and the deftness with which he uses the fortepiano’s distinctive coloration to bring the music to life.

headline: Scaling Wagnerian Mountaintops
text: A SURPRISE highlight of the Metropolitan Opera season was the double triumph of the charismatic 41-year-old German tenor Jonas Kaufmann in touchstone roles of the Italian and French repertories. In April major cast changes came to two new productions that had been introduced in the fall: Luc Bondy’s “Tosca,” with Mr. Kaufmann taking over as an impassioned Cavaradossi, and Richard Eyre’s “Carmen,” with Mr. Kaufmann as a vocally elegant but wildly volatile Don José.

headline: Indiana Revokes License of Kruse Auction House
text: KRUSE INTERNATIONAL, an auction company that has been a force in collectible-car sales for nearly 40 years, has had its license revoked by the Indiana Auctioneer Commission, which also fined Kruse $70,000. The commission suspended the company’s owner and auctioneer, Dean Kruse, for two years.

headline: A Reunion of Le Mans Corvettes as New Version Heads to France
text: Salinas, Calif.

headline: Worlds of Trouble
text: To shape the everyday happenings of the world into a good story — isn’t that what novelists are supposed to do best? Yet readers must often choose between “literary fiction,” understood to be works of well-written but meandering prose about the “real world” of human relationships, and “commercial fiction,” fast-paced novels in which plot is everything. The literary is assumed to be cerebral and artistic, the commercial mindless and entertaining. One suspects that nobody is completely happy with this divide. So it is a joy to discover, every once in a while, a writer whose prose and plotting take something from both camps. As Ted Mooney proves in his nuanced literary thriller  “The Same River Twice,”  it is perfectly possible to find a novel that has it all.

headline: Love’s Demons
text: William Beebe, an early deep-sea explorer, once described descending into the ocean in a diving helmet like this: “The moment one is submerged, the reality of the absolute apartness of this place is apparent.” That’s exactly what it feels like reading Charlie Smith’s hallucinatory new novel, “Three Delays.” A few pages in, you’ll feel as if you’re immersed in an absolutely separate world.

headline: Companies Crack Down on Defining Dependents in Benefit Plans
text: To the list of letters that produce a groan when they arrive in your mailbox  a jury duty summons, past-due tax bills  add this one: a “dependent audit.”

headline: Before Dying Quietly, Mercury Made Some Noise
text: The Ford Motor Company called a halt to Mercury production on Wednesday, ending the 71-year history of an automobile that never quite found its place in the Ford corporate lineup. And while the larger story of Mercury may be bland fare, the “winged messenger” spent some brief but exciting moments in the motorsports limelight.

headline: Getting Audited by Your Health Insurer
text: In Friday’s Patient Money column, Lesley Alderman writes about getting audited. But it’s not a tax audit. This one comes from your health insurance plan.

headline: Diapers in Kindergarten?
text: Noelle Howey’s son is almost 4. He is not potty-trained. And on one hand, she has visions of him 10 years down the road “still obsessed with Batman and sporting ‘Toy Story 7’-themed training pants in XXL.”

headline: Into Africa
text: Before the rise of the Internet, before the elimination of international bureaus at magazines and newspapers, the Africa beat in the 1990s epitomized both the dangers and the romance of the foreign correspondent’s life. As dictators fell, tribal animosities exploded and wide areas of the continent dissolved into anarchy, a pack of reporters and photographers shuttled from bush war to coup d’état, documenting the upheaval.

headline: Nadal to Face Soderling in an Intriguing Final
text: PARIS  If not for Robin Soderling, Rafael Nadal might be going for his sixth consecutive French Open title on Sunday. Instead, he is one match away from his fifth over all  only to find Soderling, the rangy, hard-hitting Swede, in his way again.

headline: Letter: Kindness of Strangers
text: To the Editor: Matt Gross’s piece “Frugal Europe, On Foot” (May 23) charmed and inspired me. I, too, love the Carpathian Mountains, though I know them better from Romania. Standing on the hill overlooking the Danube, with Budapest sprawling across the opposite bank, counts as one of the grand visual experiences in Europe, right along with Florence seen across the Arno from the Forte di Belvedere.

headline: Evidence of a Virtual Gathering in Tiananmen Square
text: On Friday, as the world marks the anniversary of China’s brutal crackdown on demonstrators in Beijing’s Tiananmen Square in 1989, the blog TechCrunch notes that government censorship of the Web seems to have found a new target, the social network Foursquare:

headline: The 'Innocent Prisoner's Dilemma'
text: Expected to show remorse, the wrongfully convicted in America's prisons face a moral dilemma.

headline: Crucible of Pain
text: Marisa Silver is one of California’s most celebrated contemporary writers, but she’s never done much for its glamorous, good-life image. Her debut in The New Yorker in 2000 — gold rush days on the West Coast — was a grim story about a young Los Angeles limo driver discovering a near-suffocated baby in an abandoned suitcase. Her skillful, moving 2008 novel “The God of War” gave us an impoverished family in a desolate, sun-blasted trailer park near the Salton Sea.

headline: South Korea Asks U.N. Council to Act Against North Korea
text: SINGAPORE  South Korea has asked the United Nations Security Council to take action against North Korea over the sinking of a South Korean warship, the South Korean president said Friday.

headline: Back at Work and as Contentious as Ever
text: It’s nice to see that everything is back to normal in Sheldon H. Solow’s real estate empire.

headline: In the Ballpark
text: Everyone knows that baseball players lie and cheat. But in one department, at least, they deserve credit for their transparency. Ever since the days of Babe Ruth, many ballplayers have admitted with no sense of shame that they couldn’t be bothered writing their own books. Some have gone so far as to admit that they couldn’t be bothered reading their own books.

headline: Breaking Down Soderling’s Victory
text: Robin Soderling prevailed in a tough five-set victory over Tomas Berdych, in a match that featured big serving and powerful groundstrokes. Berdych led, two sets to one, with superb serving, great shotmaking and a sliding, underspin defense that at times flustered Soderling, but he could not summon the will and energy for a final surge to win the match. Soderling regained his composure in the fourth set, and played with focus and purpose to advance to the final for the second straight year.

headline: Head to Head on Energy and Climate
text: There’ve been times when I’ve sparred with David Roberts, a smart, funny, valuable voice on energy and the environment over at Grist. We have held different views on the shape of the climate problem and the merits of various efforts to tackle it, and that’s why it’s always fun to go head to head.

headline: Whom Would You Cast as Roy Cohn?
text: With Thursday’s news that the coming Off Broadway revival of “Angels in America” has begun to complete casting, including Zachary Quinto (“Star Trek”) as Louis and the singer Billy Porter as Belize, there’s plenty of chatter in the theater world about actors who might take other parts — except, that is, for the formidable role of Roy Cohn.

headline: Student Challenge Favorite | Life Online
text: Man, was it hard to choose.

headline: Now Booking | Dutch Treat
text: “I don’t like anonymous hotels. I want people to wake up and immediately know where they are,” says Wilfried van Winden, the architect of the new Inntel Hotel Amsterdam Zaandam. He needn’t worry. The 160-room property is probably the most memorable example of gingerbread cottage architecture since Hansel and Gretel. Its quirky façade consists of nearly 70 irregularly stacked wooden houses fastened onto a concrete cement frame.

headline: Backing a Candidate, With Tuna in Every Pot
text: The first e-mail message came on May 24: Sandra Lee, the Food Network home and style personality, would be available for interviews at Madison Square Park on June 3, promoting some tuna in a pouch and a healthy-heart campaign. The blasts kept coming: blaring invitations to meet Ms. Lee, the champion of semi-homemade cuisine (gilding the lily that is vanilla frosting from a can, for example, with cocoa and cinnamon).

headline: Culture’s Ambassador
text: The idea of a substantial book about a major musical figure that pays relatively little attention to his music might seem counterintuitive — or, to put it less politely, pointless. That “Duke Ellington’s America” succeeds as well as it does is a tribute both to its author and to its subject.

headline: Beyond ‘Real Time’ Reporting, Forecasting Future Traffic Jams
text: WITH huge increases in the use of traffic cameras, roadway sensors and GPS-linked devices like cellphones, transportation agencies are now grappling with a flood of data available to tell them how well vehicles are (or are not) moving.

headline: Should I Help Out the Ex?
text: My ex-husband and I could not revise our child-support arrangement ourselves, so we took it to court. At the hearing, my lawyer, a specialist in family law, was better prepared than his, a generalist who made numerous mistakes in preparation and presentation. The hearing officer’s recommendation included several large calculation errors, most in my favor. Each side has 20 days in which to report such errors. Am I ethically obligated to do so? NAME WITHHELD, PENNSYLVANIA

headline: Upfronts: Two Down, Three to Go
text: Two of the five big television networks that broadcast in English have completed their sales of commercial time for the coming season in what is called the upfront market.

headline: What We Miss
text: It is one of the most famous psychological demos ever. Subjects are shown a video, about a minute long, of two teams, one in white shirts, the other in black shirts, moving around and passing basketballs to one another. They are asked to count the number of aerial and bounce passes made by the team wearing white, a seemingly simple task. Halfway through the video, a woman wearing a full-body gorilla suit walks slowly to the middle of the screen, pounds her chest, and then walks out of the frame. If you are just watching the video, it’s the most obvious thing in the world. But when asked to count the passes, about half the people miss it.

headline: The Freegan Establishment
text: I cruised through the West Side of Buffalo last summer with a young man named Kit who was looking to acquire a house. Kit was a 20-year-old Las Vegas native who had just arrived in Buffalo. He had the look of a mountain man fresh off the trail: his face was tanned, his brow was covered in sweat and his hair was pulled back haphazardly in a ponytail. He wore a bandanna around his neck, and his shorts and T-shirt looked as if they were his only set of clothes. He was also barefoot. Kit looked poor — destitute, even — but he was very excited about a grand, old house that he had his eye on.

headline: What a Freegan Calls Home
text: A revolving cast of drifters occupies an abandoned mansion in Buffalo.

headline: Affirmation, Etched in Vinyl
text: FOR years I tried to construct a viable idea of my long-gone father by piecing together scraps of other people’s memories. I was only 6 when he died, and most of what I knew of him came from my mother, who considered him the embodiment of evil and tried at every opportunity to turn me against him. If I was going to be able to counter her poisonous tales, I needed empirical evidence of his humanity.

headline: Christmas in May
text: Last Christmas, my neighbor Martha roasted a goose, perfectly. And since there were only four of us, she promised we’d eat the leftovers together sometime.

headline: What We Misunderstand
text: Consider an experiment economists call “the ultimatum game”: The experimenter gives one player, the sender, $20 to distribute between himself and another player, the receiver. An egalitarian sender might propose a split of $10 each. A more selfish sender might propose to give the receiver only $1, keeping $19 for himself. If the receiver accepts the deal, the two players collect their shares. If the receiver rejects the deal, both walk away with nothing. Were humans perfectly rational, the receiver would accept whatever is offered: even a dollar is better than nothing, right? Instead, researchers find, receivers will reject an overly lopsided deal, gladly giving up their shares just to punish the stingy senders.

headline: Weekend Competition: Red Sky at Night
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to share the words, phrases, sayings and superstitions they use to describe (and decry) the weather.

headline: Sex Symbols Squared
text: In Raquel Welch’s new book there’s a photograph of her and some other actress going at it hammer and tong in the 1972 movie “Kansas City Bomber.” In Pam Grier’s new book there’s a photograph of her and some other actress going at it tooth and nail in the 1971 movie “The Big Doll House.”

headline: The Urgency of Javelin’s MAC Battle
text: Javelin Pharmaceuticals ended its submissive stance on Thursday, filing suit against its agreed acquirer, Hospira, in Delaware’s court of chancery.

headline: The Ancient Art of Foot Treading
text: Among the winemaking practices that many people assume to have been largely retired is the ancient art of foot treading, that is, stomping the grapes with your feet. But among the syrah producers I discussed in my column, two of them, Arnot-Roberts and Wind Gap, are adamant foot treaders.

headline: Five Rice Dishes to Steam Up Your Table

headline: Unemployment News

text: Beyond his policy agenda, Stephen P. Younger is hoping to distinguish himself from previous New York State Bar Association presidents in another area.

text: Philadelphia Flyers forward Scott Hartnell has found a nice home during the past few weeks of the playoffs, part of an effective line with Ville Leino and Danny Briere. His line will be counted on for more offense on Friday night as the Flyers enter Game 4 in Philadelphia down, 2-1, to the Chicago Blackhawks.

headline: Papers Released From Kagan’s Clinton Years
text: The William J. Clinton Presidential Library is releasing on Friday more than 46,000 pages of documents stemming from Elena Kagan’s days as a White House official in the 1990s, the most expansive trove of information to date about the Supreme Court nominee.

headline: G.M. Plans a Technology Venture Firm
text: General Motors said Friday that it was committing $100 million to form its own venture capital firm as it seeks new technologies that can provide an advantage over competitors, The New York Times’s Nick Bunkley reports from Detroit.

headline: Second Set of Activists Steams Toward Gaza
text: JERUSALEM — Days after a deadly confrontation at sea when Israeli commandos raided a flotilla trying to challenge the naval blockade of Gaza, a vessel owned by the Free Gaza Movement carrying humanitarian supplies and a small group of pro-Palestinian activists was on the way, scheduled to arrive early on Saturday.

headline: The Insider | Jeff Schwarz
text: Everything’s coming up rosé for Jeff Schwarz this summer. The Wall Street suit traded his pin-striped career for culinary school, yoga and a chiller life in Montauk. Two weeks ago, he opened the graffiti-covered Love, A Yoga Space with business partner Sian Gordon in his sandy town, and simultaneously took over The Crow’s Nest with hotelier and restaurateur Sean MacPherson. Chef Schwarz is already firing up the kitchen stove to feed the hungry and glamorous (dinner first; weekend lunch soon); a complete overhaul of the landmark will make its debut next year. Here, the entrepreneurial beach dude’s guide to summer living.

headline: Ferguson: ‘Isn’t That Lovely?’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: Sir Paul McCartney played at the White House last night. He dedicated the Beatles song “Michelle” to the First Lady. Isn’t that lovely? And then for Joe Biden, he played “Fool on the Hill.”

text: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

text: The race to create absurd LeBron James recruiting pitches shifted into overdrive this week, with entries by New York’s mayor, a moving company and an eager group of Chicago Bulls fans.

headline: Workers in China Accept Deal, Honda Says
text: SHANGHAI  Honda reported an accord late Friday with about 1,900 workers who went on strike two weeks ago at its transmission plant in southern China, ending a walkout that had crippled the automaker’s production in this country.

headline: Bank Asks Again, ‘Tennis, Anyone?’
text: For the third consecutive year, the British bank HSBC is going wacky for Wimbledon in New York.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Ted Mooney
text: This week: a conversation with Ted Mooney about his new novel, “The Same River Twice”; Bruce Handy on children’s books by John Grisham and Rick Riordan; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: Immigration Debate Defines Race in California
text: IRVINE, Calif.  Meg Whitman was almost at the end of a 30-minute town hall-style meeting here, responding to questions about taxes and spending, schools and unemployment. But one topic had not come up, so Ms. Whitman, a Republican candidate for governor, raised it herself, serving up a stern attack against illegal immigration and a promise that she would protect California’s borders.

headline: Summer Reading Romance
text: Summer reading, for all its suggestion of soft breezes and cheap thrills, can be an awfully fraught proposition. Sometimes you turn down the lights at the beach house or lakeside cabin only to discover that the genteel Italian travelogue or much-hyped cyber-thriller you’ve brought along is rather dull company.

headline: Canalside Club’s Season Opener Was Really a Farewell
text: Last Sunday, the summer season blasted off at Bklyn Yard, the open-air dance club, bar, taqueria and boccie-court complex along the banks of the Gowanus Canal near the Carroll Street bridge. The Times Styles section waxed euphoric in an article published Thursday about the hundreds of partiers swaying to a German D.J.’s techno beats and lining up for sangria.

text: On Thursday, General Motors announced that the base Cruze will start at $16,995 when it goes on sale in September.

headline: DeWyze Lands Anthem Gig as Sales Lag
text: Lee DeWyze, who won “American Idol” last week, has gotten a big gig: he will sing the national anthem at Game 2 of the N.B.A. Finals on Sunday, when the Boston Celtics play the Los Angeles Lakers. The game, at the Staples Center in Los Angeles, will be his first major appearance since winning “Idol” on May 26, MTV News reported.

headline: Collarini, a New York Native, Reaches Boys Final
text: PARIS –- Andrea Collarini, an 18-year-old born in New York and raised mostly in Argentina, reached the boys singles final on Friday by beating No. 9 Duilio Beretta of Peru, 6-3, 6-3.

headline: TimesCast: Obama’s Signals
text: In today’s TimesCast, Rick Berke, the national editor, discusses President Obama’s goals as he heads once again to the Gulf Coast to look at the oil leak’s effects, while The Times’s Matt Bai offers a preview of his Week in Review piece about the signals the president is sending to the American public about his leadership.

headline: Answers From a Train Operator, Part 3
text: Following is the third and final set of responses from Dennis H. Boyd, who operates trains on the No. 4 Lexington Avenue subway line. He has responded to readers’ questions about his work and career at New York City Transit.

headline: The Bklyn Yard Is Closing
text: The Bklyn Yard, an outdoor arts and performance space along the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn, is shutting down.

headline: Afghan Jirga: Debates Over Leadership and the Role of Women
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The appointment of a former Afghan president, Burhanuddin Rabbani, as chairman of the National Consultative Peace Jirga has once again raised questions about the government’s relationship with its most vocal political opposition, the United National Front.

headline: Lehman Plans Auction of Its Modern Artworks
text: 5:23 p.m. | Updated When it comes to untangling bankruptcy situations, art is often collateral damage. That’s the case with Lehman Brothers, which declared bankruptcy in 2008, and its money management company Neuberger Berman. That unit’s senior team has since bought it, but Lehman’s creditors still retain a 49 percent interest, The New York Times’s Carol Vogel writes.

headline: Yes, You Can Say No to Whole Foods
text: Earlier this week, we introduced you to the True Body Products founder Janice Shade, who was considering whether to expand her company by adding a scented line of soaps in response to a request from her retailer Whole Foods. We asked for your thoughts, and you responded with lots of helpful and passionate comments.

headline: Resort Report | Michael Kors’s Eco Kick
text: “Park Avenue Granola” is how Michael Kors referred to the organic cashmeres and cottons on the models at the showroom presentation of his resort collection. The undyed fabrics still maintained the super-deluxe quality and cool sportswear cuts we have come to expect from Kors (and there were other, apparently inorganic pieces, too, like a great orange taffeta peasant style tank dress and a white linen pant suit worn with flat sandals). But as he said, if you can wear it and feel you are doing a little something extra for the planet, then why not? It’s his first venture into such territory and it looks sophisticated — especially the hemp canvas trench coat. Yes, hemp.  So yes, Michael. Why not?  If sustainability can really catch on and mean something and still look great, then why not, indeed?

headline: Brooklyn Concert Series Finds a Fan in Senate
text: For four years, the hippest of New York’s hipsters have flocked to the free Pool Parties concerts in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, drawn by lineups of up-to-the-minute indie-rock and inner-child diversions like dodge ball in the blazing summer sun.

headline: Can Newsmax Save Newsweek?
text: Trying to run a print newsweekly in a dot-com age is such a hard job that I’ve been less eager than some critics to second-guess the decisions that Jon Meacham has made as editor of Newsweek, which currently finds itself bleeding money and up for sale. But the news that the right-wing media company Newsmax has placed a bid to buy Meacham’s magazine helps clarify one of the obvious problems with his recent attempt to reinvent Newsweek as an opinion-driven, essay-oriented journal of ideas. This problem is implicit, for instance, in the positive spin that New York Magazine’s Chris Rovzar puts on the prospect of a Newsmax-owned Newsweek:

headline: Michelle McGann and Jonathan Satter
text: THE golfer Michelle McGann readily admits that, for her, spending as many as 270 days a year on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour wasn’t particularly conducive to forming stable, productive relationships.

headline: Will Wall Street Gains Ease Main Street Pains?
text: Personal bankruptcies climbed near a five-year high in May while corporate defaults continued to fall, showing a growing divide between the fortunes of Main Street and Wall Street. But as businesses take on more risk, they are expected to begin hiring more workers, a move that may stem the rise in bankruptcies.

headline: Getting the Most Euros for Your Buck
text: While researching hotels for a recent trip to Italy, I found that several places offered discounts if you paid in cash.  They were mostly smaller hotels, and they offered discounts of 6 to 10 percent, on average. The savings aren’t enormous by any means — but they can easily add up to the cost of a nice dinner.

headline: Our Hard-Hitting Belmont Picks
text: The Rail’s contributors make their Belmont selections. Here’s how we stand through two legs of the Triple Crown.

headline: Apple iPad’s Automotive Infiltration
text: The Apple iPhone was automobile-friendly practically out of the box: you could download apps to unlock and start your car remotely, track your gas mileage, find good off-the-beaten-path burger places and more.

headline: Travel Deals: National Park Service Waives Fees This Weekend
text: Nothing to do this weekend? More than 100 national parks that usually charge entrance fees will be free this Saturday and Sunday. The national park service offered free admission earlier this year, during National Park Week in April, and they’ve added an additional summer weekend to the list of fee-free days this year. If you can’t make it out this weekend, the parks will grant free admission again on Aug. 14 and 15, Sept. 25 and Nov. 11.

headline: Arts & Leisure Preview: Carole King, Manohla Dargis, Michael Winterbottom and More
text: Wisdom, insights and observations from this weekend’s Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

headline: The Human Equation in Water Disputes
text: —From “The Organic Machine: The Remaking of the Columbia River.”

headline: Woman Sentenced for Having Husband Killed
text: Nearly 20 years after a real estate tycoon was shot to death in front of his Upper East Side apartment by a hit man in a Hollywood-style contract killing, the woman who prosecutors said was behind the plot received her punishment on Friday.

headline: Nutrition: Study Examines a Diet From TV Ads
text: If Americans ate only foods advertised on TV, a new report says, they would consume 25 times the recommended amount of sugar and 20 times the amount of fat they need, but less than half the dairy, fiber and fruits and vegetables.

headline: After Lakers Pour It On, Frustration Bubbles Over
text: LOS ANGELES  It emanated from the showers, a one-word expletive at an ear-piercing decibel level that curled around the corner with such ferocity that it brought a locker room packed with reporters and some players to attention.

headline: A Stroll Along Bedpan Alley
text: IN the mid-1900s, the stretch of hospitals along First Avenue from 23rd to 30th Street, most of them the work of McKim, Mead & White, had developed a remarkable coherence. But since World War II, many have been demolished. Even so, a walk up this broad, noisy street offers a glimpse of what it used to be like on what is often called bedpan alley.

headline: "C'mon LeBron's Running"
text: A street musician performs a song to lure the basketball player Lebron James from Cleveland to New York.

headline: Blended Families Face a Thicket of Financial and Emotional Issues
text: Divorce is back in the news: Al and Tipper Gore are separating after 40 years of marriage. Their announcement set off the pundits, who rolled out the old statistic that about half of all marriages end in divorce. And if that number is not discouraging enough, Deborah Smiley, a wealth planner at PNC Wealth Management, said that some 70 percent of second marriages end in divorce.

headline: Israelis Explain, and Mock, Flotilla Clash
text: Last Updated | Sunday | 12:15 p.m. On Friday, The Jerusalem Post published the accounts of an Israeli commando who took part in Monday’s deadly raid on a ship challenging the naval blockade of Gaza. The day before, a columnist for the right-leaning Israeli newspaper released a satirical music video, “We Con the World,” which suggests that the activists on board the flotilla were, in fact, violent provocateurs.

headline: Streetscapes/ First Avenue
text: A walk up the stretch of First Avenue hospitals from 23rd to 30th Street offers a glimpse of what it used to be like on what is often called bedpan alley.

headline: Living in Forest Hills Gardens, Queens
text: A small neighborhood tucked away in central Queens offers preserved historic houses and abundant greenery.

headline: For New Series, A&E Borrows From Rodgers and Hart: ‘If They Asked Me, I Could Write a Book’
text: First came television series that were based on books. Then came books that were based on television series. They were followed by books inspired by television characters who are authors, like the line of “Murder, She Wrote” mysteries that bills Jessica Fletcher as a co-author with Donald Bain.

headline: Young Is the One. No Vote, That Is
text: Chances are Representative Don Young holds no personal grudges against Kansas’ Emporia State University or North Carolina Central University.

headline: That Repair Bill Is Huge, but There Are Reasons
text: WE all know the frustration when an appliance breaks down (usually a month out of warranty) and we call to have it repaired. We’re given a window of several hours  if we’re lucky, or half a day if we’re not  when the service guy will show up. He comes in, fiddles around for 10 minutes and then charges $150.

headline: Letter: Cass Sunstein Wants to Nudge Us
text: The article on Cass Sunstein and the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs (May 16) suggests that the government's estimates of the value of life draw on ‘‘surveys - taken at malls, among other places - that asked passers-by how much more they would need to be paid to take on a job that carried, for instance, a 1-in-10,000 risk of death.'' The standard governmental practice for over a quarter century has been to rely instead on labor-market studies that analyze data from thousands of workers. My labor-market estimates of the value of life have been used by government agencies since 1982. The article also indicates that E.P.A. regulations costing a bit more than E.P.A.'s value-of-statistical-life estimate "would be scuttled." There are many E.P.A. regulations that involve a cost per expected life saved in excess of $100 million - far above any value-of-statistical-life estimate used for benefit-cost tests. The real challenge continues to be that of striking a meaningful balance between cost and risk so that we target our life-saving resources most effectively.W. Kip ViscusiUniversity Distinguished Professor of Law, Economics and ManagementVanderbilt UniversityNashville

headline: World Cup History by the Numbers
text: If you are anything like me, knowing your World Cup history is tricky. I happily remember my favorite moments, and try to forget moments of absolute dread. And when it comes to the details, I easily get into friendly debates about past tournaments because my memory isn’t what is used to be (or probably never was).

headline: To Stay Focused, Americans Are Keeping It Light
text: IRENE, South Africa — Robbie Findley expects an overwhelming World Cup experience when he enters Royal Bafokeng Stadium next week, but even knowing that will not dampen the inevitable surprise.

headline: Ex-Lehman Executives Seek Dismissal of Lawsuit
text: A host of former Lehman Brothers executives, including the longtime chief executive Richard S. Fuld Jr. and three ex-chief financial officers, sought on Friday to dismiss a lawsuit over the defunct investment bank’s use of the Repo 105 accounting technique.

headline: War Stories From Blended Families
text: This week’s Wealth Matters column is about the tricky financial planning questions that arise when mom or dad remarries. Inevitably, the children from the first marriage are suspicious of the new spouse, and if the new spouse has a child with mom or dad, the children from the first marriage resent it if the new child is more indulged than they were as little ones.

headline: Private Rocket Has Successful First Flight
text: The first flight of a privately developed rocket that may eventually carry NASA astronauts to space took off Friday afternoon and reached orbit in what appeared to be a nearly flawless trip.

headline: Jon Robin Baitz Takes New Play Off Broadway
text: Citing the current Broadway imperative of casting star actors, the playwright Jon Robin Baitz said on Friday that he had decided to move his latest work “Other Desert Cities” (formerly titled “Love and Mercy”) from Broadway’s lineup for the 2010-11 season and instead have the work produced at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center.

headline: Woods Shoots 69 in Second Round
text: Tiger Woods has not yet worked his way into contention in the Memorial Tournament in Dublin, Ohio, but he took another step closer to regaining his form on Friday, hitting a few more shots that pleased him during a second-round 69 that left him at three under par, 10 strokes behind the leader, 21-year-old Rickie Fowler.

headline: Chrysler Is Recalling Caliber and Compass for Accelerator Pedal Problem
text: Chrysler is recalling about 25,000 of its 2007 Dodge Caliber and Jeep Compass models because the accelerator pedal could stick.

headline: It’s Only a Game. Isn’t It?
text: Most baseball writing is not exactly about baseball. Jim Bouton’s classic tell-all, “Ball Four,” spends more time on the players’ high jinks than the players’ play. As the grammar in its title hints, HUB FANS BID KID ADIEU (Library of America, $15), John Updike’s imperishable farewell to Ted Williams (an essay now available in book form), concentrates not on the “Kid,” but on the fans. While few books delve deeper into baseball’s intricacies than “Moneyball,” the advanced statistics Michael Lewis writes about are merely the particulars of his case study; his book is about “the art of winning an unfair game” — any unfair game.

headline: Mets Designate Matthews for Assignment
text: The Mets made some roster moves on Friday although the fate of pitcher Oliver Perez, who has resisted a move to the minor leagues, was not immediately clear.

headline: Inside Allen Ginsberg’s Photo Diary
text: “Photography is an art for lazy people.” So said Robert Frank, the celebrated Swiss photographer, to Allen Ginsberg, the celebrated New Jersey poet, as they gathered in a Lower East Side flat to make a movie. Frank was at the height of his fame after publishing his monumental collection of photographs, “The Americans,” but had newly re-imagined himself as a beatnik and filmmaker. Also assembled in that apartment were Jack Kerouac, Gregory Corso, and an ensemble cast of hangers-on, lovers, admirers, and jazzmen, ready to conceive another erratic self-portrait.

headline: Phishing for the General
text: WASHINGTON — If you get an Internet appeal from Gen. Ray Odierno, the senior American commander in Iraq, asking you to pay lots of money to get your son or daughter out of combat duty, don’t believe it. And certainly don’t send the $200,000.

headline: How Green Was Their AstroTurf
text: On the afternoon of Oct. 7, 1968, minutes before the first pitch of Game 5 of the World Series, NBC cameras were trained on a patch of center field in Tiger Stadium, where the Latin pop-jazz guitarist José Feliciano began to sing the national anthem. Feliciano’s version of  “The Star-Spangled Banner”  was slow, melancholy and achingly personal, and contained maybe three notes from the original. At the height of the anti-Vietnam War movement and urban unrest, such an unexpected stylistic choice amid the ­sacrosanctity of the Series was viewed as melodic defiance. In an era when the Establishment and the counterculture clashed daily, this crossroads proved surreal (though no more surreal than the Tigers rallying from 3-1 down to defeat the mighty Cardinals in seven games).

headline: What Brain Scans Can Tell Us About Marriage
text: THE sudden breakup of Al and Tipper Gore’s seemingly idyllic marriage was the latest and among the sharpest reminders that the only two people who know what’s going on in a marriage are the two people who are in it.

headline: Restaurants Raise Money to Help the Gulf Region
text: When good food and the people who gather it are threatened by a disaster, chefs and diners have often rallied behind them. As the Gulf Coast oil spill continues to destroy some of the most fertile seafood beds in the United States, benefits are being planned.

headline: ‘L Word’ Creator Enters Uncharted Territory
text: SCRIPTED TV shows regularly spawn reality versions. “Desperate Housewives” on ABC begat the Bravo “Real Housewives” franchise. “Gossip Girl” on CW gave rise to “NYC Prep,” also on Bravo. Even “Green Acres,” starring Eva Gabor, is partly to blame for “The Simple Life,” with Paris Hilton.

headline: Why the Board Doesn’t Need a Trim
text: Q.

headline: Hungary Warns of Greek-Style Crisis
text: PRAGUE — Fears that the debt crisis could migrate to central Europe were stirred Friday after a senior Hungarian government official said the previous government had manipulated budget figures and lied about the state of the economy, but most financial experts dismissed the remarks as a ham-handed negotiating ploy.

headline: Upsizing in a Co-op Can Cost You
text: Q.

headline: Voices: Irish, South African and Honky-Tonk
text: Blk Jks

headline: The Find-Your-Headset App
text: I lose my Bluetooth headset all the time.

headline: This Lease Won’t Be Renewed
text: Q.

headline: A Question of ‘Double-Dipping’
text: Q.

headline: ‘Do You Like It Here?’
text: 9:16 p.m. | Updated Here is a link to the study referenced below. At the bottom of this post is a note, received after this post was published, from one of the authors of the study.

headline: At French Open, Williams Sisters Win Another Doubles Title
text: PARIS  Venus and Serena Williams remember the first time they played doubles together, more than 20 years ago, when they were “superyoung,” Serena said. And when they thought about it Friday, they could not stop laughing.

headline: Resort Report | Yves Saint Laurent, Short and Chic
text: The Yves Saint Laurent cruise show was an uptown affair at the French Consulate General on Fifth Avenue. In a beautiful chandeliered room and set to a live string quartet, Stefano Pilati showed a sophisticated collection that deftly alluded to the 70’s hey day of YSL — via the 40’s. There were butterfly prints, above the knee skirts, lots of shorts and multiple shades of pink. My favorite look was an abstract design that reminded me of a mushroom alien — with just enough print for when you don’t feel like wearing a floral dress.

headline: Convicted of Murder as Teenager and Paroled at 41
text: DIANA ORTIZ waited in a cagelike room at the Fishkill Correctional Facility that winter morning in 2005, going over it in her head again and again. She needed to find the right words, conjure the right emotions, strike the right balance between remorse for her role in the killing of an off-duty police officer and recognition of all that she had accomplished in the 22 ½ years since.

headline: A Belmont for the Horses, and the Horseplayers
text: Does anyone remember who won the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness Stakes? Anyone know where Super Saver and Lookin at Lucky are right now? Neither will be in the starting gate at 6:32 p.m. on Saturday for the 142nd running of the Belmont Stakes.

headline: Afghan Peace Talks End With Plea to Combatants
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistan’s first national peace convention concluded Friday with a direct appeal to the Taliban and other insurgents to break with Al Qaeda, while urging a series of good-will gestures from foreign governments to end detentions and bombardments and to remove Taliban leaders from a wanted list.

headline: Uncommon App
text: A guilty conscience needs no accuser. The narrator of  “The Tell-Tale Heart”  knows this, as does Raskolnikov. But unlike them, Addison Schacht, the conflicted hero of “The November Criminals,” is less interested in committing a crime than solving one. And though no one in the admissions office at the University of Chicago has asked Addison to discuss the murder of his high school classmate Kevin Broadus, he uses the application’s essay assignment (“What is your best quality? What is your worst quality?”) as a chance to get some things off his chest. The result is no tidy, eager-to-please essay but a book-length spiel — concerning, among other things, Virgil’s “Aeneid,” Holocaust jokes, dope dealing, friends with benefits, classic cinema, adolescent ennui, Latin grammar and syntax, Jewish numerology, anti-Semitism, struggles with guilt, the hypocrisy of liberal politics, race relations in the United States, the philosophical downside of living in D.C. and, oh yeah, who killed Kevin Broadus. The list of topics sometimes makes this novel, Sam Munson’s first, feel a bit shaggy. But, more often, “The November Criminals” is both a thoughtful coming-of-age story and an engaging teenage noir. Think of it as an existential murder mystery for the stoner pre-­college set — Keanu Reeves’s  “River’s Edge,”  as written by Camus.

headline: ‘The November Criminals’
text: I. You've asked me to explain what my best and worst qualities are. So let me begin by saying that it's hard, ladies and gentlemen, for me to consider myself a bad person. I mean, I experience qualms, sometimes more serious and sometimes less. Everyone, evena real champion of immorality, sees himself as good. Or as working for the good, no matter if his actions — looked at one by one — are transparently self-serving, murderous, etc. Kind of a strong argument against the value of terms like good or bad. People feel this way even now, in 1999, when we're all supposed to be repenting and wailing and gnashing our teeth. But you can't go through life without making any distinctions. And selling small-to-medium amounts of weed to safe, calm rich kids (which I spent much of my spare time these past four years doing) is not a behavior worth agonizing over. That would make it seem too important, you know? I don't even need the money.

headline: Kagan on Assisted Suicide
text: During her days in the Clinton White House, Elena Kagan rarely expressed her personal opinion in writing. But when administration officials contemplated asking Congress to make assisted suicide a federal crime, she proclaimed it “a fairly terrible idea.’’

headline: Tour New York City Like a Local
text: With its many riches (cultural, culinary, historical), New York is not the easiest city to navigate. So, of course, there are a number of iPhone apps to help travelers do just that — with a local attitude.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Gulf Coast and Elsewhere
text: For the first time since April 20, the news agencies have started to transmit extensive close-ups of pelicans and other oil-slicked wildlife on the Gulf of Mexico. (“Putting a Face on the Gulf Oil Leak.”) Charlie Riedel of The Associated Press took a series on Thursday when he accompanied Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana to East Grand Terre Island. That’s also where Win McNamee of Getty Images shot on Friday (Slide 1).

headline: Obama to Name Retired General to Top Spy Post
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama has picked Lt. Gen. James R. Clapper Jr. as director of national intelligence, tapping a retired officer with decades of experience to improve coordination of the nation’s sprawling spy apparatus amid increasing threats at home and escalating operations abroad.

headline: In the Heart and Soul of Cuba
text: Adriana Teresa is the cofounder of FotoVisura and the publisher and creative director of Visura Magazine. She curated and produced the FotoVisura Latin American Pavilion at the recent New York Photo Festival, including the show “Baobabs.” Though she collaborated with Raul Cañibano Ercilla on the show, she has never met him face to face. All their exchanges occurred by e-mail, over limited Internet access.

headline: Hey, Mr. Critic!
text: The morning mail brings squeaks of worry about where to eat near Lincoln Center and the theater district, and on the upper sides of Manhattan both east and west. The wholesome patterns include parents and anniversaries. We won’t be addressing either the vegans or the vegetable-phobic today!

headline: The Week in Pictures, June 4
text: A look back at the week’s events in New York City and the region.

headline: A Marriage Falls Victim to a Child’s Disorder
text: Researchers announced this month that having a child with autism does not increase the odds that parents will divorce. It was a refutation of the commonly held — but little documented — belief that the strain of caring for an ill or challenging child regularly tears couples apart.

headline: My New York: Fall Favorites
text: Notable locals share what they like to do in the city.

headline: Brooklyn’s New Hipster Outpost
text: Cocktail lounges, dancing dens and organic restaurants are drawing the young and hip to Prospect Heights.

headline: A Weekend in New York City
text: Rooftop bars and three-star Italian restaurants make the list of the city’s newest hot spots.

headline: A Tour of New York Cemeteries
text: See intriguing monuments, beautiful grounds and the final resting places of the rich and famous.

headline: The Frugal Traveler in New York
text: Matt Gross explores the city’s more affordable (and enjoyable) corners.

headline: New Hotels Brighten Downtown
text: The city’s gritty neighborhood is now a glossy lifestyle magazine come to life.

headline: Seth Kugel’s Weekend Finale
text: Radio City and the famed Peter Luger Steak House make the list of activities for the author's final weekend in New York.

headline: New York’s Hidden Parks
text: These green oases offer refuge from the city’s frenetic pace.

headline: Urban Fishing
text: Fishermen find scores of fish along New York City’s southern coastline.

headline: A Weekend in New York City
text: The latest places to stroll, shop and dine.

headline: Public Spectacles | Art in Plein Air
text: New York City has never been short on public spectacle, but starting this week there will more to ogle when a slew of outdoor installations go on view.

headline: Obama, the Oil Spill and the Chaos Perception
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama is that rare politician who is also a gifted writer, and he understands the power of a good metaphor. So you had to believe, on some level at least, that the president could appreciate the poetic significance of that cloud of oil, ubiquitous on cable television all last week, spewing endlessly from a 5,000-foot-deep puncture in the Gulf of Mexico. Mr. Obama’s administration, too, had been breached, and the accumulating cloud threatened to obscure its considerable achievements — particularly the comprehensive reforms of health care and federal education spending — as the president heads toward the halfway point in his term.

headline: ‘Hamas: The Islamic Resistance Movement’
text: Stephen Farrell, a foreign correspondent for The New York Times who manages the At War blog, and Professor Beverley Milton-Edwards, of Queen's University, Belfast, trace Hamas's early roots in the Muslim Brotherhood, its creation during the opening clashes of the first Palestinian Intifada in the late 1980s and its inexorable rise to emerge as a serious rival to the Palestine Liberation Organization led by its more secular nationalist opponent, Fatah.

headline: Putting a Face on the Gulf Oil Leak
text: The oil leak in the Gulf of Mexico finally has a face.

headline: When Soros Decided to ‘Go for the Jugular’
text: With the euro falling below $1.20 on Friday, it seems like a good time to recall the bear raid on the British pound that the billionaire hedge fund manager George Soros made in 1992.

headline: Former Time Executive Buys Ziff Davis
text: Vivek Shah, a former Time Inc. executive, has bought Ziff Davis, the media company that operates nine technology sites, including PCMag.com.

headline: Immigrant Convicted of Breaking Trade Sanctions on Iran
text: An Iranian immigrant who said he came to the United States “to live the American dream” was convicted on Friday of violating American trade sanctions on Iran by using an informal money-transfer system known as hawala to move money between Iran and the United States. Hawala dates back hundreds of years and operates outside normal banking channels.

headline: Shopaholic Confessions
text: In 1883, Émile Zola warned that in the department store, then emerging as a hallmark of modern Paris, church doctrine had been replaced by the religion of the cash register. Even in today’s challenging economic environment, a saunter through any luxury shopping emporium confirms the accuracy of this view. So too does Linda Grant’s “Thoughtful Dresser,” a zealous affirmation of the consumerist creed: “I’m entitled. Entitled to be walking along Bond Street and entitled to go inside Hermès and inquire the length of the waiting list for a Birkin handbag.” An English writer whose novel “The Clothes on Their Backs” was shortlisted for the Man Booker Prize in 2008, Grant has no use for the spiritual counterargument: “Better people than myself might sit under the great dome of St. Paul’s and contemplate God and infinity. Good luck to them.” For her money, shopping is the ultimate “balm for the troubled soul,” even when times are tough. “Because in a recession the last thing I want to feel is depressed, and depressed I would feel if I was wearing dreary, cheap clothes. . . . You need to buy now the costumes you will need for the impoverished future.”

headline: Hamas, Israel and Gaza: No Way Out?
text: Israel’s deadly commando raid on a flotilla of aid ships headed to Gaza has once again pushed the Islamist Palestinian movement Hamas into the forefront of Middle East politics.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 6
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: For Mickey Kaus, Winning Isn’t the Point
text: Los Angeles

headline: Ailing Ozawa Cancels Europe Tour
text: The conductor Seiji Ozawa, who has been undergoing treatment for esophageal cancer, has canceled a weeklong tour in Europe with the Saito Kinen Orchestra to conserve his strength for performances in Carnegie Hall in December, a representative said on Friday. Mr. Ozawa was to have performed in Prague, Vienna, Berlin and Paris from Dec. 3 to Dec. 10 before opening Carnegie’s Japan NYC festival with the orchestra on Dec. 14. “He said:  ‘Cancel Europe, I’ve got to go to Carnegie,’ ” Ronald Wilford, his manager, said on Friday. “That’s a tough tour,” Mr. Wilford added. “That’s why he said no. Carnegie is absolutely right on.” Mr. Ozawa is artistic director of the Carnegie festival. He is also principal conductor of the Vienna State Opera.

headline: Sunday Preview
text: Cape Town, Johannesburg, Port Elizabeth, Durban and Pretoria are among the nine host cities expecting hundreds of thousands of tourists for the World Cup in South Africa next week. Meet residents of these five cities, who offer their own personal mini-guides on where to shop, eat, and enjoy a night on the town.

headline: Obama Allies Start Health Care Push
text: Close allies of the Obama administration, seeking to rally the public behind President Obama’s landmark health care bill, are planning to spend $25 million over the next five years to promote the measure and beat back mischaracterizations of it that could harm Democratic candidates.

headline: Actress Apologizes for Remark
text: Kristen Stewart, right, has apologized for comparing the swarm of paparazzi around her to a rape. In an interview in the British edition of Elle magazine, Ms. Stewart, the 20-year-old star of the “Twilight” movies, described her feelings about being pursued by photographers, saying, “What you don’t see are the cameras shoved in my face and the bizarre intrusive questions being asked, or the people falling over themselves, screaming and taunting to get a reaction.” She added, “The photos are so  I feel like I’m looking at someone being raped.” Her remarks drew wide criticism online since becoming public on Wednesday, and while in South Korea promoting her latest film, “The Twilight Saga: Eclipse,” she apologized for her word choice. “I really made an enormous mistake  clearly and obviously,” she said, in an interview published on People.com on Friday. “And I’m really sorry about my choice of words.”

headline: Basketball Helps ABC
text: Pro basketball and a special prime-time edition of “Jimmy Kimmel Live” lifted ABC to No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday night. Although Nielsen’s final numbers for the game were not immediately available, early estimates for Game 1 of the N.B.A. Finals were up 17 percent from the first night of the series last year, when 13 million viewers tuned in. Before the game, ABC began the night on a high note, earning 7.6 million viewers at 8 for a basketball-themed “Jimmy Kimmel Live.” Meanwhile, Fox averaged 8.5 million viewers from 8 to 10 for a two-hour “So You Think You Can Dance.” That reality competition easily outperformed repeats on CBS to make Fox runner-up for the night, behind ABC. NBC was in fourth place, with reruns of its comedy line-up struggling to top 3 million viewers.

headline: Baitz Moves Play Off Broadway
text: Citing the current Broadway imperative of casting star actors, the playwright Jon Robin Baitz, below, said on Friday that he had decided to move his latest work, “Other Desert Cities” (formerly titled “Love and Mercy”), from Broadway’s lineup for the 2010-11 season and instead have the work produced at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center. Jeffrey Richards  who had been one of the producers for the play on Broadway  cited Mr. Baitz’s comfort with that theater, which, at 299 seats, is about half the size of the smallest Broadway houses. The Newhouse was also home to productions of other Baitz plays. The Tony Award-winning director Joe Mantello (“Take Me Out,” “Assassins”) will direct “Other Desert Cities,” which is scheduled to begin preview performances on Dec. 16 and open on Jan. 13, a spokesman for Lincoln Center Theater said on Friday. In a telephone interview Mr. Baitz said he had decided that the familiar scale and trappings of the Newhouse were a better fit for both him and for the play. “I’m very comfortable there at Lincoln Center,” Mr. Baitz said.

headline: Male ‘Swan’ to Return
text: “Part cartoon, part spoof of the British royal family and part lyric poem” is how Anna Kisselgoff of The New York Times described Matthew Bourne’s “Swan Lake” in a 1998 review of Mr. Bourne’s reinterpretation of the ballet classic featuring a male corps. She added, “It may not be as spectacular or profound as the 19th-century original, but it is a polished entertainment, clever in its choreography and uninhibited in its tender moments.” Now the Tony Award-winning production will return to New York for a limited run from Oct. 13 to Nov. 7 at City Center. Tickets for the performances, produced by City Center, Sadler’s Wells Theater of London and Back Row Productions, will go on sale on Monday.

headline: Graphic Bullying
text: Beyond the fight for truth, justice and the American way, comic books have tackled issues far and wide: prejudice, drug abuse, world hunger and more. Dark Horse Books, a division of Dark Horse Comics, is adding school bullies to that roster. In October the company will publish “Heart Transplant,” by Andrew Vachss, about a teenager who is tormented in junior high school. Mr. Vachss, the author of a series of novels about Burke, an ex-con turned private eye, is also a lawyer with a focus on child abuse. “Heart Transplant” is illustrated by Frank Caruso and includes an essay by Zak Mucha, a social worker, who examines the bullying phenomenon and the effect on its victims.

headline: Promoters Scramble as Bklyn Yard Loses Its Lease
text: The Bklyn Yard, above, an outdoor arts and performance space along the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn, is shutting down. For four years it held concerts by big indie names, including Dan Deacon and José González, and was a home for Sunday Best, a popular dance party. But in an announcement on Friday on the Yard’s Web site (bklynyard.com), MeanRed, the promoter behind the concerts, said it had lost its lease for the space. The Yard opened its season last weekend and had announced a full series of concerts and other events through Labor Day. In a telephone interview, Justin Carter, an independent promoter who organizes Sunday Best, said the news had caught him by surprise. This Sunday’s show, he said, would be moved to Littlefield, a club at 622 Degraw Street in Carroll Gardens that has served as its rain site, but after that plans weren’t clear.

headline: ‘Phantom’ Now Available for School Licensing
text: All of those drama clubs with a spare chandelier, organ and motorized boat  not to mention enough playing space for a subterranean lair  are now in luck: “The Phantom of the Opera” is available, for the first time, for productions at high schools and colleges in the United States and Canada, the licensing executives for the musical announced. Until now “Phantom” has not been available for performances by any groups or producers beyond the 24-year-old Andrew Lloyd Webber/Cameron Mackintosh production that has played in London, New York and Las Vegas and toured cities around the world. R & H Theatricals, the licensing arm of the Rodgers & Hammerstein Organization, which is handling “Phantom,” did authorize four American high schools and two colleges to mount pilot productions in 2007-8  essentially to test-drive the Broadway/London script at a school level. A spokesman for the licensing division said the pilot productions had been deemed successful. Applications for the show are being accepted for performances beginning Sept. 1.

headline: Not Just Another Subdivision for Developable Estates
text: Old Westbury

headline: In Low-Key Buffalo, a New-Music Milestone
text: BUFFALO  This city may not seem as glamorous a place for a summer new-music festival as Tanglewood in Massachusetts or Ojai in California, and puzzlingly, the University at Buffalo does relatively little to promote the annual June in Buffalo festival, which the composer Morton Feldman founded in 1975.

headline: The Great Outdoors
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Connoisseur of Cast-Offs
text: OF the many keepsakes in Roberto Garcia’s apartment in the Longwood section of the South Bronx, he is especially proud of the refinished oak dresser in his bedroom, a piece he grew up with.

headline: Forest Hills Gardens, Queens
text: LIVING in Forest Hills Gardens, a tucked-away hamlet in central Queens, wasn’t difficult for John Hazleton, who knew he wanted to move in when he first stepped into Station Square and saw a sea of red roofs and abundant greenery. Ernest Bristol, another resident, wanted to be near Manhattan but also the fresh air of Forest Park, while Ruby Ross Goodnow appreciated the chance to have a well-built house, nice neighbors, and her own garden and dogwood trees.

headline: At the Ardsley, Art Deco the Way It Was
text: THE lobby of the Ardsley, a co-op on Central Park West at 92nd Street, is ready for its close-up. The designer Scott Salvator spent about two years restoring the building’s Art Deco interior  a series of spaces totaling about 4,000 square feet  before declaring the job complete. Though the work was largely finished over a year ago, Mr. Salvator wasn’t happy until a mirrored wall constructed off-kilter was rebuilt and paint-splattered curtains were replaced.

headline: How to Be a Brainy Renter
text: EVERYONE has heard a nightmare story of a newbie in Manhattan’s crazed rental market: the crooked brokers, the bait-and-switch online advertisements, the cajoling landlords, the thousands of dollars spent  and sometimes lost  in deposits.

headline: An Apartment for Under $1,500, or Bust
text: WHEN Jen Rosenbaum told her colleagues that she was determined to find an apartment for just $1,200 to $1,500 a month, they laughed. Clearly, she was on a fool’s errand. “My co-workers said it is not going to happen, you are insane,” she said.

headline: Richard Meier
text: Mr. Meier, 75, is the managing partner of Richard Meier & Partners Architects and a recipient of the Pritzker Architecture Prize.

headline: In Westchester, the Sales Pace for High-End Houses Picks Up
text: IN Westchester, well known for its pricey homes and estates in sought-after locales like Bedford and Chappaqua, many buyers and sellers are wondering whether the high-end sector of the real estate market is rebounding  or still mired in the downturn that took hold two years ago and has been slow to let go.

headline: Occupant Was Here
text: To the Editor:

headline: The 20-Year Mortgage Alternative
text: MOST people who took out jumbo mortgages during the financial crisis got hit with high interest rates as lenders and investors recoiled from anything that seemed even remotely risky. Now that market conditions have improved, some of these borrowers are looking to refinance into lower-rate mortgages, but they may not want to start over with a 30-year loan.

headline: A Rising Tide in Waterfront Values
text: ON the waterfront, at least, it appears the dense clouds covering real estate property values have dissipated.

headline: Chic in Review | The Suri Cruise Effect
text: Bastian, MichaelWill soon add women’s line to his collection with Gant. Yippee.

headline: About That Coloring Book in the Kagan Files
text: Elena Kagan may well have learned to color inside the lines as a Clinton aide.

headline: Spiriting Through in Many Languages
text: When the jazz singer Stacey Kent softens her sharp tangy voice to croon a ballad like “Corcovado” (the whispery Jobim standard known in English as “Quiet Nights”), a wonderful transformation takes place. Her metallic vocal edge melts, her phrasing relaxes, and her suppressed vibrato begins to quiver.

headline: Block Parties, Bake Sales, Superspies and Assassins
