text: Unless you’re trapped on an airplane or enjoying movie night at the penitentiary, you have no excuse for watching “Killers.” A brain-deadening collision of high concept and low standards, this frenetic time waster from Robert Luketic requires Ashton Kutcher to play a superspy and Katherine Heigl to play  well, the same bubbly-sexy-anxious chick she always plays. Guess who succeeds.

headline: Why Cameron Is Diving Deep on Gulf Oil
text: James Cameron, best known as one of the world’s most successful filmmakers, this week found himself slammed in some circles for pulling together a brain trust of underwater technology experts to provide advice to the Obama administration for next steps in the unfolding Gulf of Mexico petro-calamity.

headline: Hewing to Tradition, Straining Against Limits
text: Sachal Vasandani seemed to want to take requests for his encore at Joe’s Pub on Wednesday night, but consensus proved elusive. So after some dithering, he left the choice to his pianist, Jeb Patton, who picked “I Remember You.” That standard had been faintly foreshadowed, to anyone paying attention: Mr. Vasandani interposed its melody during his set closer, briefly planting Johnny Mercer’s lyrics in unfamiliar soil.

headline: Venerable British Museum Enlists in the Wikipedia Revolution
text: The British Museum has begun an unusual collaboration with Wikipedia, the online, volunteer-written encyclopedia, to help ensure that the museum’s expertise and notable artifacts are reflected in that digital reference’s pages.

headline: Inside-Out Lamb Persillade
text: Mark Bittman updates a classic lamb dish.

headline: Leg of Lamb With Kick
text: I LIKE rack of lamb but think it’s overrated, one of those “luxury” (that is, expensive) meats that, like tenderloin of beef (whence filet mignon comes), is far less flavorful, indeed less enjoyable, than almost all the supposedly lesser cuts from the same animal. So I figured there had to be a better way to employ persillade  a combination of parsley and garlic  than to smear it on top of a rack.

headline: Using Parsley and Garlic to Flavor Lamb
text: Persillade, the combination of (mostly) parsley and garlic, has many uses. My favorite: stuffing a boneless leg of lamb. I explain how in this week’s Minimalist column.

headline: Sending an Old Dreamer Airborne
text: Dancing as Kitri in “Don Quixote” on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, Natalia Osipova proved herself the most sensational ballerina now before the public. Kitri was the first major role for which Ms. Osipova  a Russian star of the Bolshoi Ballet, now in her second spring season as guest artist with American Ballet Theater earned international acclaim. It’s clear why. She has a gamine quality; you can imagine this Kitri as the most riveting of street urchins. And she’s a theater animal. The turn of her head, the flash of her smile, the immediacy of her response to the music, the intensity of her attention to her colleagues: these and other signs show she is never more alive than onstage.

headline: ‘The Same River Twice’
text: Chapter 1

headline: M.T.A. Broke Law With Layoffs, Judge Rules
text: In the latest back-and-forth over the legality of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s layoffs of hundreds of subway station agents, a judge ruled Friday that the authority violated the law when it closed booths and laid off about 260 agents last month without holding public hearings.

headline: Avery Likes an Underdog
text: The Rangers bad boy Sean Avery, who had 11 goals and 20 assists this season, took a crack at handicapping the Belmont Stakes on The Rail. He sided with the underdog, picking the 20-1 shot Stay Put to win. Stay Put won at Churchill Downs on Kentucky Derby day.

headline: Student Debt and a Push for Fairness
text: If you run up big credit card bills buying a new home theater system and can’t pay it off after a few years, bankruptcy judges can get rid of the debt. They may even erase loans from a casino.

headline: From France, Works of Fanfare and Gentle Majesty
text: You might have expected the New York Philharmonic to sound at least a little weary when it took the Avery Fisher Hall stage on Thursday night. Last week many of these musicians were achieving audacious heights in Gyorgy Ligeti’s demanding operatic farce, “Le Grand Macabre.” On Monday evening, the orchestra presented its annual Memorial Day concert at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine. Thursday’s program required rehearsals, one open to the public on Thursday morning.

headline: Why Bankruptcy Won’t Rid You of Student Loans
text: This week’s Your Money column is about the treatment of student loans in the federal bankruptcy code and whether this treatment ought to change. Currently, it’s nearly impossible for people to get rid of student loans in bankruptcy court, even though people in over their heads with credit card or gambling debts can often discharge those loans.

headline: Motion Filed for Injunction Against LimeWire
text: The Recording Industry Association of America late Friday afternoon filed a motion for a permanent injunction against LimeWire, the file-sharing service found liable for copyright infringement in May.

headline: Honey, I’ve Got a Scene to Do. Be Right Back.
text: In the Broadway farce “Lend Me a Tenor,” Jan Maxwell as the jealous wife Maria Merelli, spends 30 minutes onstage during the two-and-a-half-hour show, throwing tantrums in heavily accented Italian. The rest of the time, Ms. Maxwell reverts to her soft-spoken though still pointed self backstage, as she keeps an eye on her 14-year-old son, Will Maxwell-Lunney, who spends most performances doing his homework in her dressing room.

headline: AT&T Seems a Little Greedy
text: Thursday, I wrote about AT&T’s new Internet-service plans for iPhones and other smartphones. Instead of $30 for unlimited Internet use, new customers will be asked to choose between two limited-data plans: $15 for 200 megabytes a month, or $25 for 2 gigabytes. I noted that most people will save money with the new plans, sometimes lots of it. (Existing customers can keep the $30 unlimited plan if they like, even if they get new phones.)

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 6
text: More Photographs

headline: Caesar Salad With True Flavor
text: IT must be my inner masochist that compels me to order Caesar salads over and over. No matter how many times I’ve been disappointed by soggy croutons, bland mayonnaise dressing and a dearth of garlic and anchovies, I persist, hoping that one day I’ll meet a salad that lives up to my expectations.

headline: After Sleeping In, a Two-Wheel Tour
text: Kelly Cutrone, 44, is the founder of the public relations firm People’s Revolution and, most recently, the star of the Bravo reality show “Kell on Earth.” The show chronicles her busy days at work, where she curses out bumbling interns in long bleep-filled rants, and at home in SoHo, where she is a single mother of an 8-year-old daughter, Ava. She visits the home she rents in Cold Spring, N.Y., as often as she can on the weekends, but Sundays in the city are not uncommon.

headline: In Rome, Newsstands as Mini-Malls (and Unlikely Architectural Wonders)
text: ROME  They’re not exactly Borrominis or Berninis. But some of the newsstands around here, in their crazy, Collyer Brothers fashion, have come to look almost as baroque.

headline: Dancers Move on Foot; Audiences Travel by Bus
text: In “longing two,” a journey for the body and the mind, the choreographer Donna Uchizono finds the distance in closeness, and intimacy where it seems as if there were miles separating the viewer and the dancer.

headline: So Sunny and Blonde and Young at Heart
text: With her sweet, soft voice that coos and dips in jazzy loops and spirals, blond hair that cascades about her face in ringlets and a wide-eyed Alice in Wonderland zest for adventure, Nellie McKay exudes the carefree spirit of a precocious child skipping through a meadow on a sunny afternoon. It is an ideal persona for conjuring the essence of Doris Day, to whom Ms. McKay pays delicious, heartfelt homage in “Normal as Blueberry Pie: A Tribute to Doris Day,” her debut at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency.

headline: A Little Quantum Science to Go Along With the Leotards and Point Shoes
text: What’s the more intractable problem, the conflict between quantum mechanics and the theory of general relativity, or the difficulty of finding an elegant meeting of ballet and modern dance?

headline: The Week in Pictures for June 4
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City. Subjects include a new United States citizen, a mother’s grief and teachers’ night at the Apollo.

headline: Two Endplays, Not One, Make a Contract
text: The Sunday Swiss Teams at the Eastern States Regional in New York City last week was won by Arch McKellar of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.; Greg McKellar (Arch’s nephew) from Kingston, Ontario; Michael Lipkin of New York City; and Alex Perlin of Metuchen, N.J.

headline: Proposed Closings of City-Subsidized Facilities
text: Map of facilities that may be closed due to budget cuts.

headline: Grilling and Grinning at the N.F.L. Party
text: Hey, welcome to our N.F.L. party. Glad you could make it. Before we check out the pool and patio, let me show you around. You thirsty? Rex Ryan is mixing drinks; practically everyone here has taken a shot from the guy. Ryan’s already declared himself to be the life of the party – the “all-time life of the party,” in fact.

headline: G.M.’s Gift of a Luxury Car Stuns a Few
text: DETROIT  A free sports car for a Detroit Tigers baseball player was not among the reasons the government saved General Motors from financial collapse. Nor was a year’s supply of diapers and other gifts for a Minnesota woman who gave birth behind the wheel of a Chevrolet Cobalt.

headline: I Spied Your Red Heart (Tattoo Mine?)
text: Tattoos will get you noticed — often by members of the opposite sex. The following poems about tattoos were “found” last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are the subject headings. ALAN FEUER

headline: Chronicle of a Changing City
text: INDIESCREEN, an independent movie house on Kent Avenue, could probably devote itself full time to running the works of all those Williamsburg indie filmmakers. Marco Ursino, a co-owner, said the lineup would include a mix of revivals, new indies and selections of older ones that he has accumulated as the organizer of the Brooklyn International Film Festival. The 10-day festival began Friday at the Brooklyn Heights Cinema and had its first events at indieScreen on Saturday.

headline: We Are LeBron
text: Cleveland personalities came together to sing an ode to the basketball player LeBron James in an effort to keep him in the city.

headline: Tony Who?
text: Q. The Tony Awards will be held next Sunday. So who was Tony?

headline: Kicking Off Summer on the Jersey Shore
text: Roommates pile into a Belmar, N.J., beach house over the Memorial Day weekend to begin a summer of sand, tans and beer pong.

headline: With Drilling Stopped, Losses Could Multiply
text: Chett Chiasson, the executive director of Port Fourchon in Louisiana, has a message for President Obama  and any Americans who have applauded the administration’s decision to halt deep-water drilling in the Gulf of Mexico: You just don’t get it.

headline: Summer Rituals | Down South With Family
text: Spending the summer with relatives gives a 10-year-old girl from Brooklyn a taste of rural life and a peek at her family’s roots.

headline: Where the Party Is Perpetual
text: Belmar, N.J.

headline: A Gay Catholic Voice Against Same-Sex Marriage
text: WASHINGTON  “I spent the summer before college reading Shakespeare and staring out the window and occasionally being a roadie for my friend’s band,” says Eve Tushnet, the celibate, gay, conservative, Catholic writer. That was all good fun, she says upon meeting in Union Station, but she was ready for more, although she knew not what. “I was hoping for something very different in college.”

headline: Research on Uncovering the Mystery of Alzheimer’s
text: To the Editor:

headline: Credit Ratings and Risk, as Seen by Standard & Poor’s
text: To the Editor:

headline: Day 45: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: Cap on Ruptured Well Captures Some Oil

headline: Gay Marriage Case
text: To the Editor:

headline: Two New Putters That Are Worth a Look
text: There is no piece of golf equipment more personal, more like a relationship, than the association of putter and golfer. Most people go through dozens of putters in a lifetime. Some pros go through hundreds. Some players are a little more faithful. My colleague Dave Anderson, who is a very good putter, has used the same flat stick for decades.

headline: Plenty of Reasons to Leave the House
text: THE flip of the calendar to June is a sign that family outing season is right around the corner, with New Jersey public schools letting out later this month. Following are some ideas for day trips, or even half-day trips, with entertainment-starved, math-homework-weary children:

headline: Bell Rings Again at Yankee Stadium
text: Fistiana, in all its raffish glory, is back in Yankee Stadium. It took almost 34 years from the chaos of the last boxing card to bring the tradition back to the Bronx night air, but late on Saturday the junior middleweight champion Yuri Foreman will defend his title against Miguel Cotto, a former welterweight champion.

headline: When Bing Was King
text: AS a music-loving teenager from Massapequa, Ray Osnato haunted antiques shops and the offices of music publishers in Manhattan looking for original band arrangements from the era he loved most  the 1920s and 1930s, when the syncopated rhythms of jazz insinuated themselves into the previously staid sounds of society dance music.

headline: A Festival That Caters to Body and Mind
text: YOU could hear Philip Glass play piano solos next Sunday night at Sprague Memorial Hall in New Haven. You could see Conor Lovett (of Gare St. Lazare Players Ireland) do “Moby-Dick” as a one-man show at the Long Wharf Theater the following week. You could, on various days, take a tour of artworks by Connecticut’s own Sol LeWitt. And on June 19, on New Haven Green, you could see a free concert by the Blind Boys of Alabama.

headline: Is the Embargo Good for the Jews?
text: It’s been a good week to stay out of the water, and those who got too close paid the price — President Obama’s situation in the Gulf of Mexico just getting stickier, former President George W. Bush got a little too casual about waterboarding, and the world discovered that Israel’s vaunted special forces cannot walk on water after all.

headline: What New York Needs: More Water Taxis
text: From water’s edge you can cross the Hudson River  or the East River, as you prefer  in less time than it often takes to wait for the subway. Even at the height of rush hour, you’ll get a seat, quite likely one near a window. From out on the water, the city you think you know will seem taller, more glamorous, more cinematic.

headline: Parole for Police Officer’s Killer
text: A state parole board has voted to release a man who has served 35 years in state prison for the killing of a New York City police officer in 1973, the authorities said Friday.

headline: Tag Sale Is Fake; Poster Is a Roz Chast Artwork
text: THERE’S something amiss with certain tag-sale posters tacked up in Fairfield County. For one thing, the address listed is nonexistent. For another, the image bears an uncanny resemblance to a New Yorker cartoon.

headline: Pope Names Bishop
text: Pope Benedict XVI has named the Rev. David O’Connell, who just stepped down after 12 years as president of the Catholic University of America, to be the next bishop of Trenton, a diocese with about 800,000 Roman Catholics. Father O’Connell, a priest with the Vincentian religious order and a frequent commentator on Catholic issues, will succeed Bishop John M. Smith.

headline: Political Survivor Inherits Japan’s List of Troubles
text: TOKYO

headline: A Show in Which One Color Will Do
text: With their quiet simplicity, Robert Ryman’s paintings are a welcome contrast to the content overload of much contemporary art, although those who subscribe to the “my grandchild could have done this” school of art criticism might find it hard to appreciate the aesthetic merits of white paint smeared on a canvas. But there is another school of criticism, generally referred to as formalism, that says painting about painting is a valid avenue of artistic inquiry.

headline: Qaeda Leaders in Iraq Neutralized, U.S. Says
text: WASHINGTON  Iraqi and American forces have killed or captured 34 of the top 42 leaders of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, cutting off the terrorist organization from its foreign sponsors and raising questions about whether it can reconstitute, the senior American commander in Iraq said.

headline: Tying Memorial Record With Look of a Winner
text: DUBLIN, Ohio  Until now, the temptation regarding the rookie Rickie Fowler has been to focus on the externals  the flat-billed skater hat pulled down over his flowing locks, the form-fitting clothes in an array of hues, the faster-than-a-thought swing, his 21-year-old swagger-with-a-smile demeanor.

headline: Nearly Perfect in Detroit
text: Detroit

headline: Blue Jays Trying to Keep Momentum
text: Even without Roy Halladay, its longtime ace, Toronto has managed to stay competitive this season in the American League East. As the Blue Jays prepared to meet the Yankees for the first time in 2010, they can feel proud of a surprising 31-24 record that has them tied with Boston for third place in the division, with New York within hailing distance in second.

headline: Sneakers in the Trash Were Made for Recycling
text: “I know perfectly well,” Cynthia Magnus said, “that garbage is not glamorous.”

headline: We Are LeBron
text: Comparing Cleveland's and New York's video campaigns to assess why each city would be a worthier place for LeBron James.

headline: On the Street | Making Memories at Coney
text: A new era starts with the opening of Luna Park, as the landmark Cyclone and the boardwalk still provide plenty of thrills.

headline: Batteries Power New Talk of Cheating in Cycling
text: Cycling’s long history with doping means that any dramatic victory is as likely to create suspicion as admiration. But the whispers surrounding Fabian Cancellara’s decisive wins in two of this spring’s most important races have a novel twist: they accuse him of using a tiny electric motor to help power his legs.

headline: The Spill and Energy Bill
text: The nation’s political leaders have had a lot to say in recent years about America’s addiction to fossil fuels and the need to find cleaner, more climate-friendly alternatives. In recent weeks, they have had a lot to say about the Gulf of Mexico oil spill. On Wednesday, President Obama put them together.

headline: Luring a Star: Big City Beckons; Cleveland Begs
text: In the front row, Ted Strickland, the governor of Ohio, croons into the microphone, shoulder to shoulder with Dick Goddard, the ageless Cleveland weatherman. Around them on a soundstage, a chorus chimes in plaintively: city clerks, radio personalities, blues musicians, the ponytailed Norton Furniture pitchman Marc Brown.

headline: Turkey’s Fury
text: Turkey is understandably furious about Israel’s disastrous attack on the Turkish-flagged aid ship that tried to run the Gaza blockade. Eight Turks and a Turkish-American died. Turkey’s demands for the release of detained activists (all are now free) and for an international investigation (Israel is balking ) are reasonable.

headline: Conferences Consider Expansion, Not Tradition
text: The Big Ten and Pac-10 Conferences have always clung to their traditional roots with white-knuckle fervor. They have gone to great lengths  at the expense of a college football playoff system  to make sure that their champions play in the Rose Bowl.

headline: Justice Souter’s Counsel
text: Two recent moments have brought to mind Chief Justice John Roberts’s simplistic description of a Supreme Court justice as an umpire who confines himself to calling balls and strikes. The first was the reminder in Detroit on Wednesday night that umpires are highly fallible, and their calls subjective, even when something as important as Armando Galarraga’s nearly perfect game is at stake.

headline: Bring On the Primaries
text: Here is the most basic rule about primaries: more choice is better for voters. Yet in New York State, such competition is pitifully rare. And in the last two weeks, New Yorkers have seen how antiquated election laws discourage primary candidates from healthy competition. Even when some party leaders decide they want a free for all  as Democrats and Republicans both attempted in the last two weeks  New York’s convoluted election code conspires to make that almost impossible.

headline: Tempting Area for Exaggeration Meets Tools of the YouTube Era
text: WASHINGTON  It happened again. Another candidate for office is struggling to reconcile misleading statements he made about his record in the military. This time, it is Representative Mark Kirk, a Republican from Illinois running for the Senate, apologizing for misleading statements he made about, among other things, serving in the first Iraq war and in Kosovo.

headline: Immigrant Convicted of Violating Iran Embargo
text: An Iranian immigrant who said he came to the United States “to live the American dream” was convicted on Friday of violating the Iran trade embargo by using an informal money-transfer system known as hawala to move millions of dollars between the United States and Iran.

headline: Airlines Work to Catch Up to the Digital Age
text: Airlines have made great technological leaps in recent years, allowing passengers to check in from home or download boarding passes on their smartphones. But if you’ve ever been stranded at an airport during a raging thunderstorm, chances are you will end up standing in a long line watching a gate agent typing furiously on an outdated computer.

headline: Day After Day, the Agony in the Gulf
text: To the Editor:

headline: Plans for Ground-Floor Bar Make Residents Hit Roof
text: The Central Park West Café, depending on whom you ask, would be either a serene wine bar with a Duke Ellington ambience or a rowdy, ear-splitting, velvet-roped nightclub.

headline: Disaster in the Amazon
text: BP’s calamitous behavior in the Gulf of Mexico is the big oil story of the moment. But for many years, indigenous people from a formerly pristine region of the Amazon rainforest in Ecuador have been trying to get relief from an American company, Texaco (which later merged with Chevron), for what has been described as the largest oil-related environmental catastrophe ever.

headline: Pelicans, Back From Brink of Extinction, Face Oil Threat
text: FORT JACKSON, La.  For more than a decade, the hundreds of brown pelicans that nested among the mangrove shrubs on Queen Bess Island west of here were living proof that a species brought to the edge of extinction could come back and thrive.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 4, 2010

headline: Elections Aren’t for Sissies
text: Loads of exciting primaries next week! Although it’ll be hard to top the one in South Carolina, where two Tea Party candidates are fighting about a lie detector test and a state senator has argued that racist comments he made over the radio don’t really count since the interview occurred in a bar.

headline: Rise in Suicides of Middle-Aged Is Continuing
text: For the second year in a row, middle-aged adults have registered the highest suicide rate in the country, according to the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: Days of Planning Led to Flotilla’s Hour of Chaos
text: ISTANBUL — It was just getting light when the Turkish boat, packed with 546 activists, descended into chaos, and Mahmut Coskun, a Turkish doctor on board, was in the middle of it.

headline: Israel Faces Deepening Tensions With Turkey Over Raid, and Bond With U.S. Frays
text: WASHINGTON — Tensions deepened between Turkey and Israel on Friday, and a new fissure threatened to open between the United States and Israel, as the three countries continued to deal with the fallout from Israel’s deadly raid on a humanitarian aid flotilla off Gaza.

headline: Bloggingheads: Israel, Pariah?
text: Robert Farley, left, of the University of Kentucky and Daniel Drezner of ForeignPolicy.com discuss the international fallout from Israel's flotilla raid.

headline: India’s Young and Poor Rally to Another Gandhi
text: AHRAURA, India  Rahul Gandhi’s helicopter descends out of the boiling afternoon sky and a restless, sweat-soaked crowd of 100,000 people suddenly surges to life. Men rush forward in the staggering heat. Teenage boys wave a white bedsheet bearing a faintly cheeky request: We Want to Meet the Prince of India.

headline: African States Weigh 50 Years of Independence
text: DAKAR, Senegal  In a fancy resort on the French Riviera this week, limousines bearing African leaders gathered at the doorstep of France’s president for the France-Africa Summit, a time-honored ritual involving pledges of mutual love and, not surprisingly, some backbiting.

headline: Budget Cuts Hit a Brooklyn Area Over and Over
text: Christina Nieves’s life revolves around a handful of blocks in Brooklyn: Drop off her 4-year-old daughter and 2-year-old son at the Strong Place day care center. Make sure her 75-year-old grandmother, who uses a wheelchair, makes it to lunch at the Gowanus Senior Center. Then, on too many occasions to count, take her son, who is asthmatic and prone to seizures, to the Wyckoff children’s clinic.

headline: Cigarette Makers and Retailers Sue to Block Rule Requiring Antismoking Posters
text: The nation’s three big tobacco companies, and trade associations representing hundreds of New York City bodegas and convenience stores, are challenging the city’s latest salvo in the antismoking wars: graphic images of diseased brains, lungs and teeth that are posted where cigarettes are sold.

headline: In Hours Before Bouts, Another Test of Strength
text: Brad Jacobs is remarkably calm for someone in charge of the 200 workers feverishly setting up a boxing ring, a 60-foot-high canopy and 6,000 folding chairs on the field in Yankee Stadium. Never mind that the installation is about four hours behind schedule and a slate of fights, including a headline bout between Miguel Cotto and Yuri Foreman, is just a day away.

headline: What We’re Reading: Zuckerberg’s Hoodie
text: Here’s a selection of what the tech editors and reporters have been reading this week.Zuckerberg’s Bizarre Facebook Insignia Revealed, And What It Means — blogs.sfweekly.comNick Bilton says: Mark Zuckeberg’s hoodie has a bizarre insignia inside; here’s what it looks like.Official Google Blog: Hello from the Hiveplex — googleblog.blogspot.comNick Bilton says: Googlers decide search isn’t enough. Now they’re making honey, too, installing Google beehives.

headline: Iran’s Supreme Leader Assails Opposition
text: Days before the first anniversary of the antigovernment protests that rocked Iran, the nation’s supreme religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, renewed his attack on opposition leaders on Friday, saying that they had betrayed the values of the 1979 Islamic Revolution.

headline: United Nations: More Police Officers for Haiti
text: The Security Council approved the sending of an additional 680 police officers to join the peacekeeping mission in Haiti to help maintain order during the earthquake recovery.

headline: Glimpses of Kagan’s Views in Clinton White House
text: WASHINGTON  A new cache of documents from Elena Kagan’s days as an adviser to President Bill Clinton shows that she frequently scribbled notes in the margins of memorandums yet rarely expressed forceful views. But on at least one question that came before the Clinton White House  whether to make assisted suicide a federal crime  Ms. Kagan was adamant.

headline: France: Minister Guilty of Making Racist Comments
text: A French cabinet minister who is a close friend of President Nicolas Sarkozy faced fresh calls for his resignation on Friday after a Paris court found him guilty of making racist remarks. Interior Minister Brice Hortefeux was fined $900 and asked to pay an antiracism group $2,400 in damages for what the judge called “private insults of a racial nature.” Mr. Hortefeux was caught on video at an event in September making comments that were widely perceived as anti-Arab. He will appeal the ruling, said his lawyer, Nicolas Benoit.

headline: Zambia: Editor Sentenced for Opinion Piece
text: Fred M’membe, the editor of The Post, a newspaper highly critical of the government, was sentenced on Friday to four months of hard labor for contempt of court. The charge stems from his decision to publish a commentary by a Zambian lawyer, Muna Ndulo, who is based in the United States. The opinion piece concerned the prosecution of another Post editor, Chansa Kabwela, and appeared last December during her trial. Ms. Kabwela, who was charged with distributing pornography after publishing a photo of a woman in childbirth, was later found not guilty. In 1995, Mr. M’membe received the International Press Freedom Award bestowed by The Committee to Protect Journalists.

headline: China: Calligraphy Scroll Is Sold for $64 Million
text: A scroll of classical calligraphy dating back almost one millennium has been sold at an auction in Beijing for $64 million, which appears to be the largest amount ever paid at auction for a single piece of Chinese art, according to reports on Friday by several official Chinese news organizations. The calligraphy was done around 1095 by Huang Tingjian, a leading scholar and poet of the Song dynasty. The auction was held on Thursday by the Poly Group, which has a vast historic art collection and is one of the largest art auction houses in China. The buyer of the artwork remained anonymous. There was no independent confirmation of the record set during the auction. One report said the previous record amount paid at auction for a piece of Chinese art was $34 million, for a Yuan dynasty vase sold in 2005 at an auction in London.

headline: Former Manager at Time Inc. Buys Ziff Davis
text: Vivek Shah, a former Time Inc. executive, has bought Ziff Davis, the media company that operates nine technology Web sites, including PCMag.com.

headline: Czech Republic: Talks Toward a New Government
text: President Vaclav Klaus on Friday asked the leader of the center-right Civic Democrat party, Petr Necas, to lead talks on forming the next government, after three center-right parties cumulatively won the most votes in elections last weekend. The three parties won a combined 118 seats in the 200-member lower house. If they can form a government, the parties would have a strong mandate to enact changes they promised during the election campaign, including reducing the country’s deficit and fighting corruption. Mr. Necas, a former social affairs minister respected for his no-nonsense manner, is the most likely candidate to be the next prime minister.

headline: Boston Skyscraper Nickname
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Here’s a rarity — a themed Saturday puzzle. It’s not a full-blown theme, but it does have 10 symmetrically placed entries that are tied together using the same clue: “Triumphant shout.” Half of these shouts are used in games (one in soccer, although it could be a bullfight) with the balance comprising cries of a more multipurpose nature.

headline: Schiavone and Stosur Look for Each Other’s Flaws
text: The women’s singles final between Francesca Schiavone and Samantha Stosur is as improbable as any Grand Slam final in recent memory. Just a year ago, the two met in the first round at Roland Garros, with Stosur winning in straight sets. While Stosur has captivated the tennis world with her back-to-back victories over Justine Henin and Serena Williams, followed by her lopsided one hour dismantling of Jelena Jankovic, Schiavone has quietly fought her way through a series of tough, seasoned opponents to become the first Italian woman to vie for a Grand Slam singles title. Both stories are compelling, and they point to an increasing depth in the women’s game.

headline: Having Seen Stats, Yanks Get First Look at How Blue Jays Stack Up
text: TORONTO  By now the Yankees know that the Rays and the Red Sox are formidable, and that the Orioles are not. But what about the Blue Jays, their other American League East rival? In an odd twist of scheduling, the Yankees and the Blue Jays, who meet 18 times, did not to play each other until Friday night, two months into the season.

headline: Gay? Whatever, Dude
text: Last week, while many of us were distracted by the oil belching forth from the gulf floor and the president’s ham-handed attempts to demonstrate that he was sufficiently engaged and enraged, Gallup released a stunning, and little noticed, report on Americans’ evolving views of homosexuality. Allow me to enlighten:

headline: Little Chains That Could... And Still Do
text: Although businesses like Starbucks that began elsewhere now seem to dominate New York’s street corners, chains that got their start in the city are thriving.

headline: With Niese Coming, Perez Is Still in Limbo
text: The Mets shuffled their roster Friday, but Oliver Perez remained a nebulous part of it. Perez, a former starting pitcher banished to the bullpen, has not accepted a demotion to the minor leagues.

headline: Murray Stein, Crusader Against Water Pollution, Dies at 92
text: Murray Stein, who for more than 20 years led the federal government’s fight against water pollution and did much to overcome the prevailing attitude that the nation’s waterways could serve as sewers, died May 24 at his home in Falls Church, Va. He was 92.

headline: Paul Garabedian, Mathematician at N.Y.U., Dies at 82
text: Paul R. Garabedian, a mathematician whose computer computations helped lead to fuel-efficient wings for modern jetliners, died May 13 at his home in Manhattan. He was 82.

headline: Iman: A Model's Journey
text: Iman's path from her birth in Somalia to fashion stardom in the 1980s and '90s has included modeling, and also family, business ventures and philanthropic work.

headline: Between the Farm and the Table
text: DON LEWIS, the owner of Wild Hive Farm, rolled open a door to reveal his milling machinery and shoved a somewhat aggressive goat named Annabelle aside. Inside stood a modern Amish-style stone-burr mill, with 20-inch pink granite grinding stones. “It’s basically the same machine that was used 100 years ago, with a few more bells and whistles,” he said.

headline: Fear (and Shopping) When Big Stores Move In
text: Rhoda and Edward Green sat in the lobby of their building on 100th Street recently, engaged in a classic Upper West Side activity: collecting signatures on a petition.

headline: Serving Up a (Very) Cold One
text: The Great Burnside Ice Company has been churning out ice in East Hartford since 1911  and remains one of only three firms producing block ice in New England. A decade ago, Bob McClellan, the owner, decided to branch out, establishing the Olde Burnside Brewing Company.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Iman: Not Just Another Pretty Face
text: THE supermodel Iman hasn’t walked a runway in 21 years. Yet at almost 55 years old, with that famous Modigliani profile and copper-toned skin, she’s as gorgeous as ever.

headline: Corrections
text: A capsule summary on Friday about an article on buildings that will be demolished for a tunnel under the Hudson River referred incorrectly to letters being sent out about the project. The letters are going to 3,000 businesses, residents and others, not just to residents. It also misstated the contents of the letters. As the article correctly noted, they lay out the plans for the tunnel; they do not warn residents that they will be displaced. (While some businesses will be demolished, no residences are to be.)

headline: City Drops Plan to Charge Rent to Shelter Residents
text: The Bloomberg administration has abandoned a controversial decision to charge rent to working homeless families living at city shelters, officials announced on Friday.

headline: Two Styles of Pizza, Some Waiting
text: BLAME it on Mother’s Day, I thought.

headline: A Dubious Way to Prevent Fiscal Crisis
text: So where were we?

headline: Personality Plus
text: While large-scale producers typically issue impersonal, programmatic wines, boutique wines tend to reflect the winemakers’ personalities. That seems especially true at Lenz, in Peconic, where Eric Fry has overseen the cellar for two decades.

headline: Persian Delicacies, Made for Sharing
text: DELICIOUS food served in large portions at low prices has been a successful formula for Ravagh Persian Grill. The original Ravagh is on East 30th Street in Manhattan, with another on the Upper East Side. The Long Island branch opened in Roslyn Heights in 2001.

headline: BP Funneling Some of Leak to the Surface
text: HOUSTON — BP and government officials said Friday that a cap installed over a gushing well in the Gulf of Mexico was funneling some oil and gas to the surface, but they cautioned that much was still leaking and that it would be days before they could declare this latest containment effort a success.

headline: A Tour for the Taste Buds
text: Restaurant weeks — citywide dining-out promotions in which participating restaurants offer a special menu at a set price — have taken off in New Jersey. Montclair started one last year. So did Atlantic City. And New Brunswick had its first one in April.

headline: John Wooden, Who Built Incomparable Dynasty at U.C.L.A., Dies at 99
text: John Wooden, a staid Midwesterner who migrated to U.C.L.A. and became college basketball’s most successful coach, earning the nickname the Wizard of Westwood and an enduring place in sports history, died Friday at Ronald Reagan U.C.L.A. Medical Center, where he had been hospitalized since May 26. He was 99.

headline: With Diplomas in Hand, but Without Legal Status
text: Stories of hardship are easy to find among community college students, and the class of 2010 at Queensborough, in Queens, is no different.

headline: With Backdrop of Glamour, Wal-Mart Stresses Global Growth
text: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark.  Wal-Mart’s past was as a humble five-and-dime store in nearby Bentonville, but at its shareholders’ meeting here Friday, the retailer said its future would be in distant lands.

headline: Italian Specialties From Garden and Sea
text: THE server at Bàcio seemed out of her element, nonplused by a near cross-examination from a diner at the next table about the origins of the seafood. Finally, the diner relented, admitting he was concerned about whether it had been tainted by the Gulf of Mexico oil spill.

headline: Dickey Stays, Then Uses Bat and Knuckleball to Win Again
text: The Mets made several roster changes Friday before they defeated the Florida Marlins, 4-3, at Citi Field, but pitchers R. A. Dickey and Oliver Perez remained.

headline: The Yankees Get Some Firsthand Knowledge of the Blue Jays’ Ability
text: TORONTO  Mucking through the American League East for the last two months presented the Yankees an unassailable truth: The Rays and the Red Sox are formidable, and the Orioles are not. But what about their other division rival, the Toronto Blue Jays?

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: John Wooden’s Career
text: John Wooden, a staid Midwesterner who migrated to U.C.L.A. and became college basketball’s most successful coach, earning the nickname the Wizard of Westwood and an enduring place in sports history, died.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405..

headline: Wooden as a Teacher: The First Lesson Was Shoelaces
text: Start at the bottom. Since that is the way John Wooden initiated his basketball players, it is also a good way to study the life of this early 20th-century man who died Friday at age 99.

headline: General Manager Ferry Leaves the Cavaliers
text: The Cleveland Cavaliers and General Manager Danny Ferry mutually announced their parting Friday, less than two weeks after the organization fired Coach Mike Brown.

headline: A Disaster Reaches Beyond the Gulf Coast
text: As BP continues to struggle to plug the leak at the bottom of the sea, the president tries to convince the country that he is on top of the crisis, and the first oil laps the coasts of previously untouched states, Americans far from the gulf are feeling touched by the disaster. A sampling:

headline: Brand Officer Named at Elle Magazine
text: Robin Domeniconi has been named the new chief brand officer for Elle magazine, overseeing its content, advertising and marketing. Ms. Domeniconi most recently worked as a vice president at Microsoft, where she was in charge of sales and marketing for media properties. But she has a history in the magazine world, too, having run sales and marketing at Time Inc. and working as publisher and president of Real Simple. Carol Smith left the position at Elle in April to work at Condé Nast, overseeing the company’s new epicurean group. Ms. Domeniconi starts full time in July, according to Hachette Filipacchi Media U.S., Elle’s publisher.

headline: S.E.C. Delays Start of Exchange Trading Curbs
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission delayed trading curbs for Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index listings when they rise or fall 10 percent in five minutes, saying they will be implemented within two weeks. The announcement was made in an e-mail statement. NYSE Euronext said earlier Friday that it would not start its trial of the system on June 7 because it had not received S.E.C. authorization. The Nasdaq OMX Group is prepared to introduce circuit breakers on the S.& P. 500 companies it lists on June 14, pending S.E.C. approval, a spokesman, Robert Madden, said.

headline: Agricultural Bank of China to Sell Shares
text: The Agricultural Bank of China, one of the nation’s biggest lenders, will sell a 15 percent stake in what may be the world’s largest initial public offering on record. The state-owned bank plans to sell 22.235 billion shares in Shanghai and 25.411 billion shares in Hong Kong, excluding an over-allotment option, according to a prospectus posted on the securities regulator’s Web site Friday. Agricultural Bank will compete for investors’ money with publicly traded rivals that plan to raise a combined $32 billion in stock and bond sales even with bank valuations near record low levels. Agricultural Bank will have 26.73 billion shares outstanding in Hong Kong after the offering, which includes 25.411 billion shares sold to the public and another 1.32 billion shares held by China’s national pension fund. The prospectus did not give a price range for the share sale or an amount that the lender would seek to raise. China’s securities regulator said it would review the plan on June 9.

headline: Flyers Stay Steady at Home, Clawing Back Into Series
text: PHILADELPHIA  The Stanley Cup finals are this close: the Flyers and the Blackhawks have won each of their home games, the Flyers lead in goals scored by one (15-14), and neither team seems able to take control of the series.

headline: The Abuse of Afghan Girls Sold Into Marriage
text: To the Editor:

headline: Geriatric Care Managers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Albert Ending His Role on ‘Monday Night Football’
text: Marv Albert said Friday that he was ending his eight-year run as the radio voice of “Monday Night Football” on the Westwood One network. He said that “something had to go” in a schedule that includes 50 regular-season and playoff basketball games for TNT and 25 Nets games for the YES Network. “That’s a lot of time on the road,” he said.

headline: Inferno in Dhaka, Bangladesh
text: An electrical explosion plunged a neighborhood of Bangladesh’s capital into darkness and ignited a shop of flammable chemicals, creating a toxic inferno that killed at least 117 — including 15 members of a wedding party — and injured more than 100 others.

headline: Israeli Military Boards Gaza Aid Ship
text: ASHDOD, Israel — Israel prevented a new attempt to break its blockade of Gaza on Saturday when its naval commandos boarded a vessel owned by the Free Gaza Movement carrying humanitarian supplies and prominent activists and steered it to this Israeli port.

headline: Cap on Well Is Reported to Recover 6,000 Barrels of Oil
text: HOUSTON  A cap placed over a leaking well spewing oil into the Gulf of Mexico has recovered about 6,000 barrels during the first 24 hours it has been in operation, Adm. Thad W. Allen of the Coast Guard said Saturday morning.

headline: U.S. Urges G-20 Nations to Spur Domestic Demand
text: BUSAN, South Korea  The American Treasury secretary, Timothy F. Geithner, told his counterparts at a Group of 20 conference on Saturday that they should not rely on spending by American consumers for their economic recovery, and he urged Japan, Germany and China to bolster domestic demand.

headline: A Memory of the 1970 Belmont, in the Slop
text: Leslie Knauf is a writer, editor, marketer and horsewoman in upstate New York who has been attending the races at Saratoga for nearly 50 years. She began riding horses at 9 and owned several thoroughbreds over the years that she rode for pleasure. She’s confident they taught her far more than she ever could teach them.

headline: For the French Derby, 23’s a Crowd
text: While allowing a field of 20 in the Kentucky Derby has stoked plenty of controversy, the Americans can be thankful this year they’re not in France: We will have a field of 23 in this year’s French Derby, to be run on Sunday.

headline: A Good Start for U.S. in 3-1 Victory Over Australia
text: All in all, this was an encouraging performance for the Americans. No tournament-threatening injuries (as far as we kn0w), and a great boost to morale. Findley and Buddle looked like they belonged, Dempsey looked aggressive and alert, Donovan stayed in one piece. Onyewu’s fitness will be a concern, but the other defenders were reasonably solid, with the exception of the reckless DeMerit. Jonathan Bornstein, a second-half sub, made a couple of deft tackles under pressure, which must have reassured Coach Bradley. England awaits, now, but the USA players can head into that match with confidence rather than trepidation.

headline: Saturday Word: BP and Economic Consequences
text: President Obama pledged Saturday to make BP pay for the economic consequences of the oil rig explosion in the Gulf of Mexico and to stand with the people of the region “until they are made whole.”

headline: Schiavone Beats Stosur for French Open Title
text: PARIS – Italy’s Francesca Schiavone threw off conventional wisdom and upended Australia’s Samantha Stosur in a stunning victory, 6-4, 7-6 (2), to win the French Open women’s single-s title.

headline: The Morning Line: Belmont Day Arrives
text: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

headline: Ace Greenberg Really Doesn’t Like Jimmy Cayne
text: Alan C. Greenberg’s new book, “The Rise and Fall of Bear Stearns,” could easily be renamed “The Terror of Jimmy Cayne,” given the numerous pages that the firm’s former chief executive devotes to bashing his successor.

headline: Penalties Aplenty for Having Too Many Clubs
text: On a very cold morning Jeff, Kyle, Larry and Mike meet on the practice range to warm up. Jeff is not sure how well the ball will carry that day, so he has brought two drivers to the range. Kyle and Larry each have the same weighted training club with a grip that is molded to their hands. Also unsure of the weather, Mike has brought 18 clubs to the range, wondering which will work best in the cold. After warming up, all four players head to the first tee.

headline: A Beautiful Sport, an Ugly Industry
text: Joe Meagher writes from New Hampshire, hoping against hope that his beloved California Golden Bears will somehow make it to the Rose Bowl before he is forced to leave this mortal coil. They had better hurry up.

headline: Kimmel: ‘Happy National Doughnut Day’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: Happy National Doughnut day to everyone. This is why America is such a great country: 64 percent of our population is overweight and yet we still have National Doughnut Day.

headline: Oil Spill May Be Big, but New York Is Safe, Study Shows
text: Surfing has a way of making the problems of the real world seemingly disappear, at least for as long as one is lucky enough to be in the water.

headline: Gunmen in Iraq Kill Politician Aligned With Allawi Coalition
text: BAGHDAD  Attackers dressed in military uniforms on Saturday gunned down a politician aligned with the secular coalition that won the most seats in Iraq’s elections in March, the police and relatives said. He was the second candidate from the bloc to be killed in northern Iraq since the vote.

headline: Latin America Still Divided Over Coup in Honduras
text: MEXICO CITY  No longer is the ousted Honduran president hiding out in an embassy compound, and no longer is the man who replaced him thumbing his nose at the world.

headline: Roots in Kashmir Tug Hindus Home
text: SRINAGAR, Kashmir  The ceremony is simple and common. A Hindu priest lights a fire, places some herbs, clarified butter and other offerings atop it and through its peculiar alchemy the smoke purifies everything it touches.

headline: Cycling Allegation Propelled by Video Analysis on YouTube
text: As my colleague Ian Austen reports, the development of a tiny motor that can be hidden inside an ordinary bicycle has led to rampant speculation from cycling fans and even some professional riders that secretly motorized bicycles have already been used in professional races.

headline: Obama Urges Clapper’s Confirmation
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama urged the Senate to quickly confirm his new pick for director of national intelligence, Lt. Gen. James R. Clapper Jr., asking that the retired Air Force general’s nomination not become hostage to Washington politics.

headline: The Nelson Mandela World Cup
text: In 2000 I worked with the Bafana Bafana soccer team, which was then coached by Carlos Queiroz. It was preparing for the African Cup of Nations. There were three indelible memories from my time there — and most of them came away from the soccer field.

headline: Music Stirs the Embers of Protest in Iran
text: Parisa remembers the precise moment she heard her first song by Shahin Najafi, an Iranian rapper living in exile in Germany, on her illegal satellite television in the small city of Karadj, west of Tehran.

headline: Bradley Has U.S. Right Where He Planned
text: JOHANNESBURG  Once there was a man who carved a duck from a block of wood. Asked how he did it, the man said, “I just got rid of everything that didn’t look like a duck.”

headline: ‘Easy Rider’ Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — I’m not going to say too much, but instead direct you to the constructors’ notes at the end of the post. They’ve got two additional quotes that are as entertaining as the one in today’s acrostic. They’ve also got a proposition in their first paragraph that I hope you’ll take them up on.

headline: For Paul Family, Libertarian Ethos Began at Home
Five Players Who Outranked Jeter, if Only Briefly
text: The first pick of the 1992 draft sits alone at his desk in the visiting manager’s office at Waterfront Park in Trenton, four hours before an Eastern League game. His fills out charts as a laptop hums. The groundskeeper stops by with a weather report: storm clouds are coming. Of course.

headline: Scientists Cite Advances on Two Kinds of Cancer
text: CHICAGO  Using two opposite strategies, one focused and one broad, scientists say they have made progress in taming two of the most intractable types of cancer.

headline: Wooden Journeyed Far, Anchored By His Roots
text: It was always startling, never surprising, for the high school coach to look up and see the historic but humble man in the corner of the gym, doing what he loved. That would be watching young people practice basketball.

headline: Schiavone Beats Stosur for Open Title
text: PARIS — The point before she won the most improbable of French Open championships, Francesca Schiavone of Italy volleyed a perfect backhand into the empty space across the net.

headline: Cap Slows Gulf Oil Leak as Engineers Move Cautiously
text: HOUSTON  Oil continued to pour from a runaway oil well in the Gulf of Mexico on Saturday as engineers worked to close two of four vents on a capping device lowered onto the gushing riser pipe.

headline: Don’t Bet on Home Continent in African World Cup
text: JOHANNESBURG  The World Cup opens Friday, and this host city is draped in the flags of the 32 participating nations. With the world’s biggest sporting event coming to Africa for the first time, hope wafts across the continent that one of the six African teams might win.

headline: N. Korea Reports Death of Official Guiding Succession
text: SEOUL, South Korea  A top North Korean official believed to be working to secure an eventual transfer of power from Kim Jong-il, the ailing North Korean leader, to one of his sons died last week, but analysts say they do not think it will impede the succession process.

headline: Abigail Ford, Adam Winkel
text: Dr. Abigail Alice Daisy Ford and Adam James Winkel were married Saturday in New York. The Rev. K. Gabriel Gillen performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Joseph’s in Greenwich Village.

headline: Letters: Hank Jones, Richard Blumenthal and Semantics
text: Here is some additional reader response to my most recent columns, “A Private Room With a Narrow View,” “The Candidate and the War,” and “Semantic Minefields.”

headline: Growing Obesity Increases Perils of Childbearing
text: As Americans have grown fatter over the last generation, inviting more heart disease, diabetes and premature deaths, all that extra weight has also become a burden in the maternity ward, where babies take their first breath of life.

headline: Anne Godwin, Benjamin Cauthren
text: Anne Virginia Godwin and Benjamin Paul Cauthren were married Saturday. The Rev. Joseph S. Dietz, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Butler Memorial Chapel at Marymount Convent in Tarrytown, N.Y.

headline: Irit Rasooly, David Goldman
text: Irit Rachel Rasooly and David S. Goldman are to be married Sunday at Ohr Kodesh, a synagogue in Chevy Chase, Md. Rabbi Yaacov Bieler is to perform the ceremony, with Rabbi Haskel Lookstein taking part.

headline: Carly Brooks, Brad Prutkin
text: Carly Ann Brooks and Brad Adam Prutkin were married Saturday at LaPlaya Beach and Golf Resort in Naples, Fla. Rabbi Jeremy Winaker, a cousin of the bridegroom, officiated.

headline: Julie Yang and Alexander Shih
text: Dr. Julie Yang and Alexander Shih were married Saturday evening at the Ritz-Carlton New York, Battery Park, in Manhattan. The Rev. Isaac Lim, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

headline: Carly Tushingham, Eric Arnold
text: Carly J. Tushingham and Eric Arnold were married Saturday in an outdoor ceremony in the garden of Frankies 457, a restaurant in Brooklyn. The Rev. Janice L. Sutton, a minister of the Trinity United Methodist Church, performed the ceremony.

headline: With U.S. Aid, Warlord Builds Afghan Empire
text: TIRIN KOT, Afghanistan  The most powerful man in this arid stretch of southern Afghanistan is not the provincial governor, nor the police chief, nor even the commander of the Afghan Army.

headline: Buddle and U.S. Plant the Flag in South Africa
text: ROODEPORT, South Africa  The United States and Australia are teams with similar World Cup ambitions, but the Americans showed themselves to be better prepared Saturday in a 3-1 victory in an exhibition game.

headline: Holly Weiss, Michael Schechter
text: Holly Michelle Weiss and Michael Benjamin Schechter were married Sunday at the Barney Estate in Springfield, Mass. Rabbi Herbert N. Schwartz officiated, and Cantor Morton Shames took part in the ceremony.

headline: Mara Zusman and Jeremy Greenberg
text: Mara Zusman and Jeremy Greenberg are to be married Sunday evening at the Pavilion, an event space at the Ronald Reagan Building and International Trade Center in Washington. Rabbi Greg Harris is to officiate.

headline: Claire Higgins, David Hathaway
text: Claire Farley Higgins, a daughter of Pamela Leib Higgins of Gladstone, N.J., and Decatur S. Higgins Jr. of Peapack, N.J., was married Saturday evening to David Bradley Hathaway, a son of Nancy N. Hathaway and David R. Hathaway of Millbrook, N.Y. The Rev. Edward Johnston, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the home of the bridegroom’s parents.

headline: Kelly Moriarty and Leelai Demoz

headline: Banks Say No. Too Bad Taxpayers Can’t.

headline: A New News Media Outlet Reflects Different, Though Still Familiar, Times
text: Twelve years ago, I was busy starting a weekly print magazine, The Industry Standard, which quickly became an icon of the dot-com era. On the way up  in less than three years we grew to more than 400 employees from an initial staff of about 40  we were the proverbial symbol of the Internet boom, with a smart, young staff putting out a smart, fat magazine, and marketers competing to underwrite both our press runs and our parties. On the way down  a brutal eight months in which our revenues declined by 75 percent while our investors played a game of financial chicken that ended in a bankruptcy filing  we were similarly a metaphor for the hubris and failed dreams of a most unusual time.

History is denied! Incompetence reigns! Something must be done! Expand instant replay!

headline: A War for Hearts and Minds, Economically Speaking
text: A YEAR ago, Ian Bremmer was invited to the Chinese Consulate in New York, along with a group of economists and scholars, to discuss the financial crisis. Shortly after he arrived, Mr. Bremmer, a political risk consultant who has been widely published, was surprised to hear a Chinese diplomat ask them, “Now that the free market has failed, what do you think is the proper role for the state in the economy?”

headline: The Most Popular Gym Is the City Itself
text: LOS ANGELES  In Santa Monica, women in skintight yoga pants and sunglasses with lenses the size of lazy Susans trot up and down giant concrete steps. Men who look like they could hoist a Mercedes hang from a telephone pole, and trainers roll out yoga mats in the middle of the sidewalk.

headline: Schiavone Wins With Confidence
text: With her incandescent smile and even brighter play, Francesca Schiavone lit up Paris, the City of Lights, with an electrifying performance, beating Samantha Stosur, 6-4, 7-6 (2), to win the French Open. Schiavone outplayed Stosur, who seemed stunned by Schiavone’s daring play and fist-pumping displays of confidence. After beating Justine Henin, Serena Williams and Jelena Jankovic to reach the final, Stosur was considered the favorite to win. But it was Schiavone who played to win, outhitting and outserving the powerful Stosur. In many ways, she beat Stosur at her own game, serving big and setting up her groundstrokes to keep Stosur on the move and off-balance.

headline: A Quick Trim at the Track
text: Forget the clopping of hoofs, it was the clipping of hair that beckoned Saturday at Belmont Park.

headline: Lessons From the Sub Shop
text: I GREW up at the Jersey Shore and played football at Point Pleasant Beach High School as a running back and a defensive back. We always had a big rivalry with Point Pleasant Borough High, in the next town.

text: Drosselmeyer, with the Hall of Fame jockey Mike Smith aboard, outran Nick Zito-trained Fly Down in the stretch to win the Belmont Stakes on Saturday by 3/4 of a length.

headline: The Doctor Payment Follies
text: The formula that is used to pay doctors who treat Medicare patients is producing increasingly absurd results. If it were to be followed this year, doctors would face a 21 percent cut in payments for the tests, procedures, office visits and other services they provide to elderly Americans.

headline: Justice in the Jury Box
text: In 1986, when the Supreme Court reached a landmark decision forbidding prosecutors from routinely excluding blacks from juries without a good explanation, Justice Thurgood Marshall warned it would not end racial exclusions. Some prosecutors, he wrote in a concurring opinion, would simply invent phony reasons.

headline: Walk the Talk
text: In its devastating decision to allow an uncontrolled flood of corporate money into federal elections, the Supreme Court tried to head off critics by endorsing full disclosure of fat-cat donors. It is not enough. But Congress can repair some of the damage by passing the “Disclose” campaign finance reform.

headline: Prime Number
text: 50: The age at which people start feeling better about themselves after years and years of feeling steadily worse, according to a new study published online in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. The study was based on the results of a 2008 Gallup poll of 340,000 people nationwide. People start out at age 18 feeling pretty good about themselves, the study found, but then feel worse and worse until they hit 50. At that point, there is a sharp reversal, and people keep getting happier. By the time they are 85, they are even more satisfied with themselves than they were at 18.

headline: Early and Back Home
text: The birds begin. Ethel, the border terrier, stretches and yawns beside me. I listen for a while, then consult the time. It is so much earlier than I’d thought — 5:11 and nothing to do about it except listen for a little longer, then get up. I have the brief, puritanical thought that I should know all these birds by their songs. Perhaps they’re the same birds I hear at twilight, some of whose names I know.

headline: Mozart for Microbes
text: Mozart's music is thought to stimulate the mind. But can it also stimulate microbes? A sewage treatment plant in the German town of Treuenbrietzen, about an hour’s drive from Berlin, is trying to find out, according to Spiegel Online. For the last two months, the plant has been treating its biomass-eating microbes to Mozart played on a special stereo system designed to replicate the vibrations and sounds of a performance in a concert hall. The thinking is that the sonic waves of Mozart, along with oxygen added in the treatment process, will spur the microbes to break down sewage more efficiently, saving money.

headline: Downgrade the Ratings Agencies
text: WARREN BUFFETT may be the Oracle of Omaha, but even he is hamstrung by credit ratings agencies. Appearing on Wednesday before the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, he said that as the chairman of Berkshire Hathaway, he has “no negotiating power” with Moody’s and Standard & Poor’s, the two major agencies, because ratings were “required in many cases by the rules.”

headline: Don’t Get Mad, Mr. President. Get Even.
text: IT turns out there is something harder to find than a fix for BP’s leak: Barack Obama’s boiling point.

headline: Back Then: 1989
text: Last week, Chinese censors forced one of the nation's newspapers to excise a cartoon that appeared to evoke perhaps the most famous image of the June 1989 protests at Tiananmen Square. Here’s how The Times described the confrontation at the time: “It all started with a man in a white shirt who walked into the street and raised his right hand no higher than a New Yorker hailing a taxi. ... The man stood only half as tall as the lead tank. But his body language made it clear: He wanted the slow-moving column halted, and halt it did, the huge treads on the lead tank grinding to a stop just a few feet from his face. It was a close call — the tank came perhaps a second or two of killing him — and it seemed to encapsulate many of the confrontations in recent days between the citizens and the army: the touch-and-go maneuvering, with soldiers not sure when to press on and when to retreat; the determination of the demonstrators, brave and unyielding in ways that might have been unthinkable a few weeks ago.”

headline: Dressed to Distract
text: It’s hard to feel sorry for a woman who frets about being too beautiful.

headline: Yanks, With Suddenly Listless Lineup, Are Baffled Again by Blue Jays
text: TORONTO  Extra-inning games can have redemptive powers. Struggling hitters get more at-bats, often against the underbelly of a bullpen, and one clutch hit can erase a day’s worth of futility. The opposite can also be true, as demonstrated Saturday by the Yankees in their second consecutive loss to the Toronto Blue Jays. A single by Aaron Hill off Chad Gaudin scored Edwin Encarnacion in the bottom of the 14th inning and gave the Blue Jays a 3-2 victory, leaving the Yankees to wonder whether their offense ever cleared customs.

headline: Fighting Words

headline: A Scare, a Scar, a Silver Lining
text: My doctor’s call came early last month just as I was completing a column noting that 41 percent of Americans come down with cancer. That statistic felt as remote as a puff of cloud in the stratosphere — until my physician, Gary Raizes, gently began to break the news to me that I had a tumor in my right kidney.

headline: The Ballgame and the Sideshow
text: When I covered the 1982 Lebanon war, I learned something surprising about wars: they attract all kinds of spectators, meddlers, do-gooders and do-badders. They use the conflict and the attention it generates to play out their own identity issues, passions and biases. My favorite in Beirut was a gentleman who showed up in August 1982 as the Palestinian guerrillas were sailing out of Beirut harbor. His name  I am not making this up  was Arthur Blessitt, the “Sunset Boulevard Preacher.” He had walked to West Beirut from Israel to pray for peace, dragging a 13-foot-long wooden cross with a little wheel on the bottom.
