text: Re “A Private Room With a Narrow View” (May 30), about a reporter’s blog after looking around the room where the late jazz musician Hank Jones lived:

headline: 11 Tournaments Over 2 Weeks Create a Competitive Logjam
text: The past couple of weeks should have dispelled any doubts about the vitality of chess. It would be hard to imagine a busier schedule.

headline: Op-Classic, 1998: Catching Perfection
text: Every week, the Opinion section presents an essay from The Times's archive by a columnist or contributor that we hope sheds light on current news or provides a window on the past.

headline: Pilot and Passenger Are Injured When Small Plane Hits 2 Buildings on Long Island
text: A small private plane with two men aboard slammed into two unoccupied commercial buildings on Long Island on Saturday after a series of practice takeoffs and landings from Long Island Islip MacArthur Airport, the authorities said.

headline: On Niese’s Bright Day, Perez’s Cloud Grows Darker
text: First, the Mets witnessed a veteran left-hander being run out of town for being too hittable. Then they watched his young replacement, whom few on the Florida Marlins seemed able to hit.

headline: Invasion of the Serenity Saboteurs
text: YOGA is about casting off petty annoyances and toxic judgments — a seemingly Sisyphean task for those hopped up on New York City living. But what if irritation trails you right onto your mat, in the guise of ring tones, exhibitionists or bliss-busting interruptions?

headline: Unfiltered Oakley Rips the Knicks
text: If the Knicks are counting on their esteemed alumni to sell LeBron James on the glory of New York, they should choose carefully. Charles Oakley won’t offer much of an endorsement.

headline: Bulls Reportedly Hire Celtics Assistant
text: LOS ANGELES — The Boston Celtics assistant Tom Thibodeau helped solve two of the N.B.A.’s coaching vacancies in the span of a few hours Saturday. According to multiple reports, Thibodeau accepted an offer to coach the Chicago Bulls after the New Orleans Hornets finally abandoned their pursuit of him and came to terms with the Portland assistant Monty Williams.

headline: Stretch | Invasion of the Serenity Saboteurs
text: Yoga is about casting off petty annoyances and toxic judgments — a seemingly Sisyphean task for those hopped up on New York City living. But what if irritation trails you right onto your mat, in the guise of ring tones, exhibitionists or bliss-busting interruptions?

headline: Gasol Critiques News Media, Not Garnett
text: It was an observation, not a critique or an insult. But under the glare of the N.B.A. finals, even a seemingly innocent remark can fuel a firestorm, as Pau Gasol just learned.

headline: John W. Douglas, Champion of Civil and Human Rights, Dies at 88
text: John W. Douglas, a lawyer who championed civil rights and human rights as an assistant United States attorney general in the Kennedy and Johnson administrations and later in private practice, died on June 2 at his home in Washington. He was 88.

headline: Helen K. Chinoy, Theater Historian and Educator, Dies at 87
text: Helen Krich Chinoy, a theater historian who collected the views of actors and directors about their crafts and documented the contributions of women to the American theater, died May 24 in Turners Falls, Mass. She was 87.

headline: At Memorial, Pros in Their 20s and Scores in the 60s
text: DUBLIN, Ohio  Like the rain-swollen rivers roaring through the grounds at Muirfield Village on Saturday, golf’s new wave of 20-somethings swept up on the leader board in the Memorial Tournament. They served notice that the events of the past few weeks  the win at Quail Hollow by Rory McIlroy two days before his 21st birthday and the 22-year-old Jason Day’s victory at the Byron Nelson Golf Classic  are the leading edge of a trend.

headline: With Danger Offshore, the Oyster Is Celebrated
text: NEW ORLEANS  Aaron Jones made his way through the crowd to the foot of the stage, chin raised. An oyster shucking contest was under way, and the master of ceremonies was going around distributing oysters to audience members as if giving Communion, dropping one in Mr. Jones’s open mouth.

headline: Drosselmeyer Wins the Belmont Stakes
text: Horses rarely blast away from their rivals in the Belmont Stakes. Unless their name is Secretariat, they endure the mile-and-a-half marathon. The third leg of the Triple Crown is much like the city of New York: grueling but rewarding, gritty but great.

headline: Oh, What a Wonderful Day!
text: Astute readers may have noticed that I’ve been neglecting this blog lately — and my Sunday column explains why. About a month ago, a tumor was discovered in my right kidney, and it was removed 10 days ago in a three-hour surgery. I still feel like I’ve been hit by a truck, but maybe a smaller truck than it felt like yesterday. And the tumor turns out to be benign. So I’m celebrating.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: A Private Army Guards an Afghan Highway
text: The most powerful man in Oruzgan Province is not the governor or the police chief, but a semiofficial warlord.

headline: Nadal and Soderling, by the Numbers
text: At Roland Garros, Rafael Nadal’s driving, superspin forehand peels off the red clay, knocking opponents off-balance and sometimes blowing them off the court. His breakneck mobility allows him to track down almost everything they throw at him, forcing them to take bigger risks and hit ever closer to the lines. He is 21-0 on clay this year, 37-1 at six French Opens and at one point had a record streak of 81 victories on his favorite surface. He is the best player on clay, perhaps the best clay-court player of all time.

headline: A Burly Chestnut Prevails
text: Atop Drosselmeyer, a 13-1 shot, the Hall of Fame jockey Mike Smith gave the trainer Bill Mott his first Triple Crown victory.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 5, 2010

headline: The Isolated Con Dao Islands
text: This archipelago off Vietnam’s southeastern coast is one of Southeast Asia’s most breathtaking getaways.

headline: Bouts at Yankee Stadium
text: Fans yelled, boxers sweated and Miguel Cotto defeated Yuri Foreman at Yankee Stadium.

headline: A Weekend in Santa Fe
text: The New Mexico capital isn’t just tacos and turquoise anymore.

headline: Paterson Aide to Lead OTB After Its Chairman Quits
text: The top aide to Gov. David A. Paterson will lead New York City’s troubled Off-Track Betting Corporation, whose chairman resigned on the eve of the Belmont Stakes, New York’s largest racing event, officials said on Saturday.

headline: Belmont’s New Anthem
text: I’m the new Sinatra,And since I made it here,I can make it anywhere,Yeah they love me everywhere.

headline: Cotto Stops Foreman in Ninth Round
text: Fighting for his father, who died in January, for his legion of Puerto Rican fans and for his continued standing among boxing’s elite, Miguel Cotto won the first main-event bout at the new Yankee Stadium on Saturday night and handed Yuri Foreman his first loss.

headline: Vows: Jen & John
text: Jennifer Wharton and John Fedchock, both trombone players, met at a jazz club where Mr. Fedchock was releasing his album. He immediately saw special sparks in her eyes.

headline: Lost Decade, Here We Come
text: The deficit hawks have taken over the G20:

headline: E.T., Dial 911
text: Video | Uplifting Spielberg classic reimagined as horror-film preview:

headline: Biking in Rome: An Extreme Sport
text: Given its smoggy air, aggressive motorists and pervasive lack of respect for traffic laws, Rome isn’t exactly the safest city to traverse on two wheels. In March, however, the local government pledged to transform the Italian capital into a cyclist’s utopia by 2020.

headline: The Rail’s Final Scoreboard, Year 3
text: With 10 points of a possible 18, Melissa Hoppert set a new Rail blog record with her 2010 Triple Crown race predictions, and Alex Brown became the first blogger to be shut out. Our guest pickers, Jim Rome, David Simon and Sean Avery, combined for 2 points. The final standings follow, and you can also view our results from 2009 and 2008. (Explanation: We use a 3-2-1 point breakdown for win-place-show. A horse picked to win must win to earn points; however, a horse picked to place or show must merely finish in that position or better.)

headline: A Second Look at the U.S. Win
text: The bright spots outnumbered the United States team’s missteps Saturday, but they did not outshine the problems.

headline: Can the Rescued Pelicans Stay Clean?
text: In an article on Saturday in The Times, my colleague John Rudolf and I wrote about brown pelicans, a species that became extinct in Louisiana, bounced back in the 1990s and is now being threatened by the oil spill. John’s reporting centered on heartbreaking scenes at a rescue center in Fort Jackson, La., where trained workers are struggling mightily to clean and rehabilitate birds.

headline: Nadal Wins His Fifth French Open Title
text: With clouds looming over the French Open men’s final, Rafael Nadal found a way to make the sun in his tennis world shine again. Nadal faced down Robin Soderling, the same opponent who knocked him out in the fourth round last year, a harbinger for a regressive year of sore knees and lackluster results. But healthy and confident once again, the Mallorcan King of Clay raced to a straight-set win over the giant-chopping Swede, 6-4, 6-2, 6-4.

headline: The Sunday Word: Midterms and Oil
text: Washington has its eyes on the slow progress in efforts to contain the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico today as engineers work to seal a cap placed over the gushing pipe. At the same time, politicos are gearing up for a busy election week with House, Senate and gubernatorial primaries in eleven states Tuesday.

headline: A Series of Lapses Preceded Oil Gusher
text: Once in awhile I’ll be filing mini-posts adapted from Twitlonger:

headline: Side Trip in Toronto
text: To make visiting clubhouses feel a little less unfamiliar, some players bring along mementos from home. A. J. Burnett, for instance, keeps a four-faced Buddha statue in his locker wherever the Yankees go. Then there is Phil Hughes, who displays a hat and a hockey puck with the team logo of the Tampa Bay Lightning.

headline: Valentino Rossi’s Broken Leg
text: Valentino Rossi broke his leg Saturday in practice for the Italian Grand Prix in MotoGP, the highest level of motorcycle racing, and doctors say he will need at least six weeks to recover before he can return to racing. At age 31, Rossi has won seven titles at the highest level of motorcycle racing – six in MotoGP and one in the previous top category of 500cc – and so he can be thought of a little as the Michael Schumacher of motorcycle racing.

headline: Cap Said to Recover 10,000 Barrels of Oil a Day
text: HOUSTON  A cap placed over a ruptured well spewing oil into the Gulf of Mexico is capturing about 10,000 barrels a day, indicating engineers are making some progress in stanching the flow, Adm. Thad W. Allen of the Coast Guard, who is commanding the federal response to the disaster, said Sunday.

headline: Reasons for the Decline of Horse Racing
text: We all know that horse racing is in decline. Thoroughbred racing declined nationally in handle by 7.3% in 2008, by 9.8% in 2009, and by 8.4% in the first four months of 2010. In New York State, total handle on horse racing fell by more than 10 percent in 2009. When you consider the changes in the consumer price index, New York racing handle is approximately 20 percent of what it was in 1974. What happened here? This article represents a subjective attempt to review what happened both in the nation and in New York State to bring about the fall from grace of the racing industry.

headline: Two Arrested at Kennedy Airport on Terror Charges
text: Two New Jersey men who were bound for Somalia with the stated intention of joining an Islamic extremist group to kill American troops were arrested at Kennedy International Airport late Saturday, federal and local authorities said on Sunday.

headline: When the Old West Met the Southern District
text: Justly famous and frequently in the news — it has played home to the Madoff matter and, more recently, to the Times Square bomb scare case — the federal courthouse of the Southern District of New York is arguably the most important local courthouse in the country.

headline: Could Progress on Catching Oil Mask Ongoing Blowout Threat?
text: Adapted from Twitlonger:

headline: Nadal Wins His Fifth French Open Title
text: PARIS  Rafael Nadal cried.

headline: The Morning Line: A Godfather Beats the Dudes in the Belmont
text: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

headline: Catholic Bishops Deplore Mideast Christians’ Plight
text: NICOSIA, Cyprus  In a document presented here on Sunday by Pope Benedict XVI, bishops from across the Middle East called on Christians to become a dynamic minority in a conflict-ridden region and attributed their declining population here to “instability” caused by the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, the war in Iraq and unrest in Lebanon.

headline: An Initiative to Ease Student Loan Debt
text: Ron Lieber, who used his Your Money column last week to tell the story of a graduate of New York University struggling to pay off $100,000 in student loans, provides something of a sequel this weekend. He examines efforts underway to change a little-known aspect of bankruptcy law, one that makes it “nearly impossible” to get rid of student loan debt.

headline: Why Is Salvaged Oil Going to BP Instead of U.S. Reserves?
text: BP should be required to contribute a barrel of oil to the U.S. Strategic Petroleum Reserve for every one salvaged from its gushing well.

headline: Afghan Leader Forces Out Top 2 Security Officials
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai forced two of his top three security officials to resign Sunday over their failure to prevent attacks on last week’s peace council in the capital, Afghan and American officials said, creating shock and concern among Western officials about such serious changes in crucial ministries even as the American war effort here reaches a critical phase.

headline: Leisurely Practice for U.S. Before Real Work Starts
text: PRETORIA, South Africa — It was difficult to tell who was more excited to be out at Pilditch Stadium on Sunday for the United States team’s open training session: the 365 South African youths invited by the American embassy and USAID-affiliated projects, or the buoyant 20-year-old forward with bright yellow boots.

headline: Velotti Wins Boys Championship
text: PARIS – An American-born teenager recruited from Argentina by American tennis officials lost in the finals of the French Open junior boys championship to one of his best friends. The New York-born Andrea Collarini, 18, lost in straight sets, 6-4, 7-5, to Agustin Velotti, 18. The pair had played on the same Argentine Junior Davis Cup team. Both acknowledged their friendship in postmatch interviews.

headline: Hungary Is Playing Political Games on Debt
text: By the numbers, Hungary is not Greece.

headline: Long-Lost Silent Films Return to America
text: A late silent feature directed by John Ford, a short comedy directed by Mabel Normand, a period drama starring Clara Bow and a group of early one-reel westerns are among a trove of long-lost American films recently found in the New Zealand Film Archive.

headline: Foxconn Increases Size of Raise in Chinese Factories
text: SHANGHAI  For the second time in a week, Foxconn Technology, the world’s largest contract electronics manufacturer, said that it planned to substantially raise the salaries of its huge Chinese workforce.

headline: Yes, We Did Get Caught In A Thunderstorm
text: How did you guess?

headline: The Morning Skate: Flyers the Better Team Through Four Games of Final
text: Game 5 of the Stanley Cup finals is Sunday night in Chicago, and it’s now a best-of-three series with the Flyers having won, 5-3, in Friday’s Game 4 by playing the best sustained stretch of hockey either team has managed in this hard-to-define series.

headline: Israel Ambassador Rejects Flotilla Clash Inquiry
text: JERUSALEM  Israel’s ambassador to Washington said Sunday that his country would reject an international inquiry into last week’s deadly raid on a Turkish ship, but there was still no formal announcement from Jerusalem on the matter.

text: The trailer for Robert Lepage's new production of Wagner's "Ring" cycle for the Metropolitan Opera (Video courtesy of the Metropolitan Opera).

headline: Silent Treasures
text: Images from several long-lost American films recently found in the New Zealand Film Archive.

headline: Containment Cap Appears to Cut Oil Flow
text: BP's latest efforts to contain the Gulf Oil spill appear to be working: Oil is still leaking, but the cap seems to be minimizing the flow of oil. (Video: MSNBC)

headline: Police Say Terror Suspects Planned Jihad
text: The New York Police Department released new information regarding the two men who were arrested on terror charges at Kennedy Airport. (Video: MSNBC)

headline: Reliance of India Approves Plan to Sell a 26% Stake
text: NEW DELHI  Reliance Communications, one of the largest mobile-phone providers in India, with 106 million subscribers, plans to sell a 26 percent stake to raise cash to cover costs that include $1.8 billion for licenses for high-speed data services.

headline: Should This Be the Last Generation?
text: Have you ever thought about whether to have a child? If so, what factors entered into your decision? Was it whether having children would be good for you, your partner and others close to the possible child, such as children you may already have, or perhaps your parents? For most people contemplating reproduction, those are the dominant questions. Some may also think about the desirability of adding to the strain that the nearly seven billion people already here are putting on our planet’s environment. But very few ask whether coming into existence is a good thing for the child itself. Most of those who consider that question probably do so because they have some reason to fear that the child’s life would be especially difficult — for example, if they have a family history of a devastating illness, physical or mental, that cannot yet be detected prenatally.All this suggests that we think it is wrong to bring into the world a child whose prospects for a happy, healthy life are poor, but we don’t usually think the fact that a child is likely to have a happy, healthy life is a reason for bringing the child into existence. This has come to be known among philosophers as “the asymmetry” and it is not easy to justify. But rather than go into the explanations usually proffered — and why they fail — I want to raise a related problem. How good does life have to be, to make it reasonable to bring a child into the world? Is the standard of life experienced by most people in developed nations today good enough to make this decision unproblematic, in the absence of specific knowledge that the child will have a severe genetic disease or other problem?

headline: Amniotic Rocking, Broken by Morton Feldman’s Whisper Quiet
text: For New Yorkers who regularly attend classical music performances, Bargemusic, the converted coffee barge that has served as one of New York’s more distinctive musical destinations since 1977, has represented comfort and tradition. From its start this makeshift floating hall, moored near the eastern foot of the Brooklyn Bridge, has hosted concerts of standard repertory solo and chamber works, with performances that are consistently admirable and often inspired.

headline: A Journal of the Plague Century: Civilization Goes Viral. Stuff Ensues.
text: “I won’t lie to you,” says the colonel in charge of a hidden military installation where hush-hush medical research on the thymus gland is being conducted. “There are risks.” One of those risks, enthusiastically described by Justin Cronin in his jumbo science-fiction fantasy novel, “The Passage,” is that a viral plague will be unleashed and wipe out almost all of humanity  though not before Newsweek puts out an issue with a ghastly picture and the words “Believe It” on its cover.

headline: Reliance of India Looks to Sell a 26% Stake
text: Reliance Communications, India’s second-largest mobile phone provider with 106 million subscribers, plans to sell 26 percent of the company in an effort to raise cash to cover costs that include $1.8 billion for licenses for high-speed data services, The New York Times’s Heather Timmons reports from New Delhi.

headline: Yankees’ Offense Arrives Just in Time to Avoid a Sweep
text: TORONTO  There is a two-second delay on the game broadcast in the visiting manager’s office at Rogers Centre, something that Joe Girardi did not know until he turned on the television in the eighth inning Sunday afternoon. The crowd roared, but he did not know why. When Robinson Cano’s single skipped into left field, driving in the winning runs in the Yankees’ 4-3 victory against the Toronto Blue Jays, a thought entered his mind: “Sometimes I think I should get thrown out in the first.”

headline: Manuel’s Positive Energy Ignites Mets
text: Of all the strategic decisions a manager makes over the course of a game, whether calling for a pitching change, switching a defensive alignment or ordering an unexpected dash on the basepaths, there are also the less-nuanced motivational tools to employ.

headline: Playing for the Grand Slam Even if Trumps Break Badly
text: Strong 4-4-4-1 hands cause problems. That is why the Italians invented the Roman two-diamond opening, showing that shape with 17 to 24 high-card points. The example in the diagramed deal occurred during the top bracket of the Memorial Day Round Robin Teams at the Eastern States Regional in New York.

headline: Sure, Go Ahead
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — This puzzle has more going on than usual for a Monday. I like it. The first four theme answers have something in common, and then the fifth provides the explanation. Each has OK somewhere in the first half and ME somewhere in the second.

headline: New CDs
text: CHRISTINA AGUILERA

headline: His Heart Is in the Art of Sleuthing
text: There might be a few agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who could sit down at a piano and run through a Chopin Fantasie to calm their nerves, as Robert K. Wittman used to do. But there probably aren’t many who could also chat knowledgably about Cézanne’s influence on Soutine. Or who have studied formalism at the Barnes Foundation art museum outside of Philadelphia. Or who have found themselves in Hollywood, Fla., eating lunch with  and probably being targeted by  two large French assassins nicknamed Vanilla and Chocolate, while tantalizingly close to recovering paintings from the biggest art heist in American history, the 1990 robbery of the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston.

headline: Mystery Hotel: They Check In, but They Don’t Check Out
text: “Persons Unknown” was created by Christopher McQuarrie, who wrote the screenplay for the 1995 thriller “The Usual Suspects,” and that pedigree alone should seal the success of this new NBC series that begins on Monday.

headline: New Portraits of Grief and Wanderlust
text: Chamber music concerts focusing on contemporary works often attract small audiences. But the organizers of the Tribeca New Music Festival needed to find a larger space this year after events sold out during the last two seasons at the Flea Theater downtown.

headline: Vowels Ring in New Suite for Chorus
text: While introducing Kirke Mechem’s Suite for Chorus, which was given its New York premiere by the New Amsterdam Singers on Thursday evening at the Church of the Holy Trinity on the Upper East Side, the conductor Clara Longstreth pointed out that in the realm of vocal music most composers select the text, then write the score. For Mr. Mechem, on the other hand, words were secondary in this work, which treats the choir like a symphonic or chamber ensemble and uses consonants and vowels as strings might incorporate pizzicato and varied bowing strokes.

headline: A Cuban Folk Song Pioneer
text: Outside Carnegie Hall on Friday night were knots of demonstrators, for and against the Cuban government. Inside was an uproar of adulation: repeated standing ovations, eagerly shouted requests, Cuban flags and banners unfurled, fervent singalongs, roses hurled onstage. The object of it all was a bespectacled, casually dressed man with a gentle voice and an acoustic guitar: Silvio Rodríguez, the 63-year-old Cuban songwriter who is making his first tour of the United States since 1980.

headline: Welcome to the Dance, Bugsy Siegel. Care to Say a Few Words?
text: True or false: New York City Ballet is the home of neo-classical dance, the living tribute to the abstract, pared-down aesthetic with which George Balanchine revolutionized 20th-century ballet?

headline: Callaway Sisters Have Serious Fun With ’60s Songs
text: Ah, the ’60s. The further that tumultuous decade, whose spirit extended well beyond it, recedes into the mist, the more its popular music becomes grist for lighthearted nostalgia with a tinge of camp. Preadolescents in those days, the singers Ann Hampton Callaway, now in her early 50s, and Liz, her slightly younger sister, were born a little too late to throw themselves headlong into the fray. But in their show, “Boom!” (as in boomer) on Friday evening at Town Hall, they remembered the music with deep affection.

headline: The Subtlety of Gods and Goddesses
text: The sheer range of dance in New York is as great a marvel as any of the individual high points. Last week I caught DanceAfrica; a modern-dance world premiere; ballets by Balanchine, greatest of ballet choreographers; and the superlative dancing of the ballerina Natalia Osipova. Yet, strange as this may sound, the single performance that seemed the truest revelation of dance itself came in the Indian form of Odissi, opening Erasing Borders: Festival of Indian Dance at the Asia Society.

headline: MLB Network Expands Coverage of Draft
text: A year ago, the MLB Network carried its first amateur draft, in which Stephen Strasburg was the No. 1 overall pick by the Washington Nationals. For its second go-round with the draft Monday, the network has made a few changes.

headline: An Ailing Ozawa Won’t Tour Europe
text: The conductor Seiji Ozawa, who has been undergoing treatment for esophageal cancer, has canceled a weeklong tour in Europe with the Saito Kinen Orchestra to conserve his strength for performances at Carnegie Hall in December, a representative said on Friday. Mr. Ozawa, right, was to have performed in Prague, Vienna, Berlin and Paris from Dec. 3 to Dec. 10 before opening Carnegie’s Japan NYC festival with the orchestra on Dec. 14. “He said: ‘Cancel Europe, I’ve got to go to Carnegie,’ ” said Ronald Wilford, his manager. “That’s a tough tour,” Mr. Wilford added. “That’s why he said no. Carnegie is absolutely right on.” Mr. Ozawa is artistic director of the Carnegie festival. He is also principal conductor of the Vienna State Opera.

headline: And Now, Charlie Sheen, the Acting Teacher?
text: Charlie Sheen may teach acting as part of the community service he is most likely going to be sentenced to in a domestic violence case he is settling in Aspen, Colo., The Associated Press reported. Paige Price, artistic director of Theater Aspen, said that lawyers for Mr. Sheen, below, had approached her about the possibility of his volunteering with the company. “I certainly think he has the career credentials,” Ms. Price told The A.P., adding: “He could possibly teach a class or do question-and-answer sessions. If this could benefit the Theater Aspen’s actors or students, I would certainly be amenable to it.” Mr. Sheen was charged with criminal mischief and assault after a fight with his wife, Brooke Mueller Sheen, in a home they were renting in Aspen last Christmas. Arnold Mordkin, Pitkin County chief deputy district attorney, confirmed that an agreement had been reached and that there had been discussions about Mr. Sheen doing “useful public service” with the theater, but declined to confirm details until a judge approved the deal in court on Monday. “He’s really not getting anything different than the average person under similar circumstances would receive,” Mr. Mordkin said.

headline: A Sharp Drop at the Box Office
text: Movie box-office receipts dropped by 24 percent from the comparable weekend last year, to an estimated $125 million from $165.3 million. “Shrek Forever After,” in its third week, held on to the No. 1 spot with an estimated $25.3 million in weekend ticket sales, taking in about $183 million in ticket sales to date. Two new comedies, “Get Him to the Greek” and “Killers,” posted tepid openings. “Get Him to the Greek,” from Universal Pictures, placed second with $17.4 million in domestic ticket sales for the weekend, while “Killers,” from Lionsgate, was third with $16.1 million. The two films together took in far less than the $45 million collected by “The Hangover,” a comedy that opened in the comparable weekend in 2009. The weekend’s decline follows soft openings last week by “Sex and the City 2,” from Warner Brothers, and “Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time,” from Walt Disney. “Prince of Persia” this week fell to the No. 4 spot, as ticket sales dropped 54 percent from last weekend, to $13.9 million, for a total of about $59.5 million since it opened. “Sex and the City 2” placed fifth with $12.7 million in sales, down 59 percent, for a total of $73.4 million.

headline: Screenings of ‘the Cove’ in Japan Are Canceled
text: Movie theaters in Japan have canceled the opening screenings of “The Cove,” a documentary that shows the clandestine killing of dolphins in Taiji, Japan, Reuters reported. The film, directed by the photographer Louie Psihoyos and winner of this year’s Oscar for best documentary feature, has recently been protested by Japanese groups that defend the practice of dolphin and whale hunting as part of the country’s cultural tradition. Cinemart Theaters in Tokyo and Osaka have canceled screenings scheduled for this month out of fear for the safety of moviegoers, after receiving threatening phone calls and warnings of protests from groups that consider the film “anti-Japan,” said a spokeswoman for the film’s Japanese distributor, Unplugged. Other than a showing at the Tokyo International Film Festival last October, the Japanese public has not yet been given an opportunity to see the movie. “It’s not right that a small minority of extremists could take this right away from them,” Ric O’Barry, a former dolphin trainer featured in the film, said in a statement, adding, “To do so is a clear threat to democracy.”

headline: Footnotes
text: Funeral plans for Gary Coleman were postponed this weekend after a Utah lawyer, Kent Alderman, produced a 1999 will that named an executor, The Associated Press reported. The discovery of the will could help end a fight for custody of Mr. Coleman’s body between his former wife, Shannon Price, and his estranged parents, Edmonia Sue and W. G. Coleman. Frederick Jackman, a lawyer for Mr. Coleman’s parents, said the executor named in the will is Dion Mial, a friend and former manager. ... The actress Cybill Shepherd, the director Lee Daniels and the pop singer Lady Gaga were among those honored at the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation’s Media Awards in San Francisco on Saturday night. Also among the recipients were the Public Broadcasting System, for its documentary “Ask Not,” about the Army’s “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy, and the multimedia presentation “The Stonewall Riots: 40 Years Later,” a look at the present and future of the gay rights movement, by aarp.org.

headline: End May Be Near for Bavetta
text: LOS ANGELES — In an N.B.A. finals bathed in tradition, one familiar figure is missing from the court. Dick Bavetta, one of the league’s most tenured, colorful and polarizing officials, was not assigned to the series and is probably finished as a finals referee.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,393 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,075 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans last week:

headline: Longer-Term Use of Drug May Fight Ovarian Cancer
text: CHICAGO  The widely used cancer drug Avastin can help keep ovarian cancer in check, but only if used for a long period of time, researchers reported here on Sunday.

headline: Russian Mine Blast Study Says Officials Hid a Fire
text: MOSCOW  An official investigation will show that management at the Raspadskaya coal mine in western Siberia intentionally concealed a fire that had smoldered for days underground before two catastrophic explosions last month, according to Russian news reports on Sunday.

headline: At a Triathlon, Swimmers Beat Out the Tar Balls
text: FAIRHOPE, Ala.  Any triathlon is a contest of speed and endurance. But for the competitors who gathered in this manicured waterfront community on Mobile Bay, donning rubber bathing caps and goggles on a sticky Alabama morning, this year’s race had another potential challenge: the risk of tar balls.

headline: Is Any Job Better Than No Job?
text: The Labor Department’s monthly jobs report released Friday was not good news. Though 431,000 jobs were created in May nationwide, the bulk of them were workers hired by the federal government to help with the Census — jobs that will disappear in a few months. Only 41,000 private jobs were created, far short of expectations of 150,000 to 180,000 jobs, and unemployment rates remained steady. Economists estimate that the U.S. needs to add more than 100,000 jobs a month just to keep pace with new workers — high school and college graduates — entering the market.

The middle-school football teams lured the fastest and the strongest. The middle-school and summer-league basketball teams grabbed the tallest and the quickest.

headline: The Tanker, Continued
text: For almost a decade, the Air Force has bungled attempts to replace its fleet of Eisenhower-era KC-135 refueling jets. The procurement process has been grossly mismanaged and tainted by corruption and favoritism. Now Congress seems ready to add to the confusion with legislation intended to ensure that the American contractor, Boeing, beats out its European rival, the aerospace consortium EADS, for the $50 billion contract.

headline: Listen to the Miners
text: At an emotional hearing in the West Virginia hills where 29 miners died in April, mine workers dared to tell lawmakers the truth. One miner said that any employee who publicly complained about lethal hazards was soon a “marked man” and risked being fired. Others described slipshod safety routines, weak regulations and regulators more interested in protecting management’s profits than the lives of miners.

headline: Challenger in Arkansas Is Unafraid to Ruffle

headline: 4 Palestinian Divers Killed Near Gaza by Israeli Navy

headline: ‘Fences’ Revival Recoups Investment
text: The Broadway revival of August Wilson’s “Fences,” starring Viola Davis and Denzel Washington, below, has recouped its $2.8 million capitalization after only eight weeks of performances, the producers Carole Shorenstein Hays and Scott Rudin announced on Monday. The critically acclaimed production, which has received the most Tony Award nominations ever  10  for a play revival, began preview performances on April 14 and opened on April 26; the limited engagement is scheduled to end on July 11. Usually only one-quarter to one-third of Broadway shows recoup their original investment, and most require many months to do so; having popular stars in the cast has helped some recent plays, like “God of Carnage” and “A Steady Rain,” recoup more quickly. Like those productions “Fences” is one of the few hit plays in recent years that have grossed more than $1 million in a single week; the production has also twice set box office records at its home, the Cort Theater, most recently when it hit a figure of $1,024,316.50 last week. Among the play’s nominations for Tony Awards, which will be presented on Sunday, are best revival of a play, leading actor (Mr. Washington), leading actress (Ms. Davis), featured actor in a play (Stephen McKinley Henderson) and direction of a play (Kenny Leon).

text: Some of Prudential‘s largest shareholders have approached a former chief executive of the British insurer, Mark Tucker, over a possible return to the helm of the company, according to British press reports.

headline: AgBank Releases Preliminary Prospectus
text: The Agricultural Bank of China, one of the nation’s biggest lenders, will sell a 15 percent stake in what may be the world’s largest initial public offering on record, the company said in an eagerly awaited preliminary prospectus posted Friday on the securities regulator’s Web site.

headline: Romance and Commitment in Middle Age
text: For most couples, the butterflies of early romantic love eventually disappear. But brain scan studies show that couples in lasting relationships can achieve something even better.

headline: The Fed Weighs In on Credit Card Reform
text: Last year, when Congress passed the Credit Card Accountability, Responsibility and Disclosure Act, it declined to extend new consumer protections against certain card company practices to small business accounts. This was in part because some legislators expressed concern that nobody had properly studied how such a move might affect the price and availability of credit for small companies. So Congress directed the Federal Reserve to look into the matter. The nation’s monetary policy makers recently delivered their conclusion. It was not terribly conclusive.

headline: Introducing: Schott’s Daily Lexeme
text: Schott’s Vocab is honored and delighted to have joined forces with the inestimable Oxford English Dictionary to offer each day a word of note.

headline: Webber Retained at Red Bull for 2011
text: There was probably no better way for Red Bull to draw an end to the controversy of the Mark Webber/Sebastian Vettel collision at the Turkish Grand Prix on May 30 than to also put to an end speculation about Webber’s contract for next year.

headline: What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
text: Two weeks ago we began our summer reading “Student Challenge” with this question, and Friday we chose our first “favorite” from among the submissions.

headline: Environmental Smoke
text: News Parody | From The Onion:

headline: Madoff: From Swindler to Celebrity?
text: It would be hard to describe Bernard L. Madoff, who is currently serving a sentence of 150 years in federal prison in Butner, N.C., for defrauding investors of tens of billions of dollars in his Ponzi scheme, as popular.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: On our minds? Our minds. The NYT looks at the life of a multitasker, and offers a free quiz to test your multitasky-ness (if you don’t have the time, but decide to do it anyway, we can tell you the answer now).  Meanwhile, markets continue to digest the news from Hungary.

headline: Carlyle Chief: Buyout Business on Upswing
text: David M. Rubenstein, a founder of the Carlyle Group, is apparently feeling pretty optimistic about the private-equity industry these days.

headline: Belmont Ratings Drop
text: The Belmont Stakes on Saturday on ABC generated a 3.1 preliminary overnight rating, plunging 38 percent from the 5.0 last year for Summer Bird’s victory. The rating is measured from 5:30 to 7:15 p.m. Eastern. From 5 to 5:30, the 1.4 rating was down 42 percent from last year.

headline: Submit Your Funny Caption
text: Vacation From Well | Tell us what’s going on in the picture above (use the comment link below). It’s the latest of the uncaptioned images we’re posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. The latest funniest captions are at right.

headline: Eyeing Russia? Better Hire Body Guards
text: From Matt Marshall at VentureBeat:

headline: N. Korea Reshuffle Seen as Part of Succession Plan
text: SEOUL, South Korea  As its leader, Kim Jong-il, was watching, North Korea’s rubber-stamp Parliament fired its prime minister and elevated his brother-in-law to the government’s No. 2 post on Monday in a sweeping government reshuffle.

headline: On Our Radar: BP Buys Search Terms
text: Public relations, BP style: the company buys up oil-related search terms on Google. It’s “proactive for the brand,” a marketing guru opines.

headline: The Temporary Vegetarian: Empadinhas de Palmito
text: When Angela Mariani, a novelist based in Rio de Janeiro, visits New York City, she often hosts a party at her pied-à-terre, hiring Antonia Ferreira, a Brazilian cook and caterer in Queens. To start each event, Ms. Ferreira offers a tray of empadinhas de palmito, tiny, two-inch-wide savory tartlets filled with hearts of palm in a béchamel sauce. The delicate, buttery crust crumbles on the first bite.

headline: No Talking Required for These 411 Calls
text: Google’s GOOG411 service popularized a way for people to get business phone numbers for free, instead of paying up to $2.00 to get a phone number from a wireless or landline carrier. You just dial 800-GOOG411, and voice prompts ask for the name and city of the business, and the business name. When found, the voice recites the number, and either dials it for you or sends you the number and address as a text message.

headline: Congress Returns to Tackle Jobs Aid, Medicare Fees
text: Congress returns Monday for a four-week stretch that is scheduled to be capped by a Supreme Court confirmation hearing, always a classic piece of Senate theater.

headline: At Ford’s, the 4th of July and South Africa
text: Political and entertainment notables turned out in Washington Sunday for the annual Ford’s Theatre Gala, an invitation-only fête that brings together a venerable crowd in the theatre where President Abraham Lincoln was shot.

headline: Newsweek: Crowd-Sourcing the Next Version
text: In today’s Media Equation column, I made my own attempt to address the very tough math of re-making a version of Newsweek that would survive and thrive in a busy, wired news ecosystem. With the magazine up for sale, others have weighed in: Jeff Bercovici of Daily Finance suggests that Newsweek begin by paying attention to the magazine and little else,  and Lee Siegel argues in the New York Observer that its current leadership is to blame. But rather than do forensics on what went wrong — at bottom, the world changed — we asked a folks by e-mail and on Twitter for new answers.

headline: Cameron Warns Britons of Austerity
text: LONDON  Prime Minister David Cameron said Monday that Britain’s financial situation was “even worse than we thought” and that the country would have to make savage spending cuts to bring its swelling deficit under control.

headline: Altegrity to Buy Kroll for $1.13 Billion
text: Altegrity, an analysis and security services company, agreed on Monday to buy Kroll, one of the best-known investigative services providers, from the current owner, Marsh & McLennan, for $1.13 billion in cash.

headline: The Early Word: Spill Concentration
text: President Obama will spend his day dealing with the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, meeting with his Cabinet to discuss the administration’s response to the crisis and receiving a briefing from Adm. Thad W. Allen, the commandant of the Coast Guard and the point man for the federal response to the spill.

headline: Kristen Stewart ‘Enjoys’ the MTV Movie Awards: A Photo Essay
text: We understand, Kristen Stewart, that the past week was not an easy one for you. If, amid similar circumstances, we were also made to attend an awards show-cum-“Jersey Shore” infomercial to promote our movie franchise about choosing between a vampire and a werewolf, we’d also react like this:

headline: Rangel Is Not Ready to Leave Just Yet
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: Unplugged: Take the Challenge
text: Imagine life without your cellphone, your online social networks or e-mail. If this seems like a foreign concept to you, you’re not alone. These technologies have become  so constant in many of our lives we can’t see ourselves without them even as the impact of them on our personal and professional lives — and even our brains — is being discovered.

headline: Does Studying Economics Make You More Republican?
text: Several academic studies have found that there is a link between education levels and civic behavior. But a new study from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York has concluded that how much economics people study can influence their political activity and how they spend their spare time.

headline: Are You Hooked on Technology?
text: Do you sometimes think about reaching for the fast-forward button, only to realize that life does not come with a remote control?

headline: Lloyds Shareholders’ Huge Claim Over HBOS
text: Shareholders of the Lloyds Banking Group made a compensation claim Saturday of £14 billion ($20.2 billion) against the British Treasury, the businessman Sir Victor Blank and the Lloyds chief executive, Eric Daniels, who they maintain masked HBOS’s “huge debts” in the run-up to the government-mediated rescue deal, The Guardian reported.

headline: Looking for Liability in BP’s Gulf Oil Spill
text: Peter J. Henning follows issues involving securities law and white-collar crime for DealBook’s White Collar Watch.

headline: Ask a Brooklyn Blogger
text: This week, Louise Crawford, the founder of Only the Blog Knows Brooklyn, and creator of the annual Brooklyn Blogfest, will be responding to readers’ questions about her life as a blogger and her experiences in the blogging community in Brooklyn.

headline: U.S. Soldier Arrested in Wikileaks Inquiry After Tip From Former Hacker
text: Wired’s Threat Level blog reported late Sunday that “an Army intelligence analyst who boasted of giving classified U.S. combat video and hundreds of thousands of classified State Department records to whistleblower site Wikileaks,” was arrested by the Pentagon.

headline: Q.&A.: Sharing on Flickr
text: Q.

headline: Falcon Chicks and Errant Clicks
text: Rent-free Brooklyn loft, very convenient to/from Staten Island. Easy bridge access. Nearly 700 feet in the air. Unbeatable views of the New York harbor, Statue of Liberty, Lower Manhattan, etc.

headline: Tensions Simmered in Zappos Sale to Amazon
text: 5:03 p.m. | Updated At the time that Zappos.com announced its sale to Amazon.com last year, several reports said that the shoe retailer’s management — specifically its chief executive, Tony Hsieh — did not want to sell.

headline: Speed Read for Monday, June 7
text: 1. More competition from newspapers: local sports sites are drawing ardent fans and leaving objectivity behind.

headline: Greg Mankiw on the Soda Tax
text: Greg Mankiw, the economist and blogger, had a column in the Sunday Times considering — and expressing skepticism about — a soda tax. In recent months, New York, Philadelphia and Washington have all considered imposing a tax on sodas and other artificially sweetened beverages. So far, none has done so.

headline: Dogs Dig Laurie Anderson’s ‘Music for Dogs,’ Appropriately
text: In so far as no one was bitten and nearly everyone stayed where he or she was supposed to, the debut of Laurie Anderson‘s “Music for Dogs” was deemed a howling success by its audience and their owners, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Valentino Rossi Fractures Leg, Out for 6 Weeks
text: Dani Pedrosa may have won the MotoGP Italian Grand Prix, but the bigger news was that Valentino Rossi, the seven-time champion, broke his leg in practice on Saturday.

headline: Rule of the Gun
text: Just in case you missed it, our colleague Dexter Filkins writes in today’s paper about the multitude of private contractors who act as armed escorts for NATO and American convoys in Afghanistan’s lawless roads. These groups, some appearing to be “little more than gangs with guns” are entangled with both with the Taliban they are supposed to be guarding against and the many officials who have blood and political ties to Hamid Karzai.

headline: Apple Shows Off New iPhone With Better Display
text: Steven P. Jobs, the chief executive of Apple, took the stage on Monday for a keynote at Apple’s annual Worldwide Developers Conference, held at the Moscone West convention center in San Francisco. As expected, he introduced a new phone, the iPhone 4, and shared news about apps on the iPad and iPhone.

headline: Monday Reading: Some are Unsatisfied with BP’s Payouts
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Over Here
text: This quotation appears in a nice article about Britain’s recent election, from last week’s New Yorker. (Only an abstract is online.) The speaker is Robert Choate, director of the Institute for Fiscal Studies in London. He’s talking about Britain, of course. But the description applies to another country, too.

headline: Fragrant Fronds, Pungent Bulbs: Cooking With Fennel
text: Wild fennel grows all over California, and the other day I discovered a huge patch on a residential street in Los Angeles. Unfortunately there was nowhere to park, so I couldn’t stop to gather it. Instead, with fennel on my mind, I headed to my local supermarket.

headline: Farfalle With Stewed Fennel, Artichokes and Peas
text: This pasta is inspired by a signature springtime Sicilian dish made with all of the vegetables below, plus fava beans. To simplify, I’m giving you a choice of fava beans, which must be skinned, or peas. It’s delicious no matter which you choose. The fennel brings a wonderful, sweet flavor to the mix.

headline: Helen Thomas Dropped by Her Speakers’ Agency
text: Update: Helen Thomas announced on Monday that she is retiring. The Caucus has details.

headline: Who Are We to Judge? After ‘Idol,’ Kara DioGuardi Gives Us Some Counsel
text: How much time should an “American Idol” judge be given after the end of the season to kick up her heels, relax a little and be spared the pesky questions of annoying reporters? As soon as Kara DioGuardi takes a vacation, we’ll let you know.

headline: Couscous With Fennel, Chickpeas and Chard
text: This is typical of many Tunisian vegetable stews, made fragrant with spices (caraway, cumin, coriander seeds), beans and vegetables.

headline: Fennel and Red Pepper Salad
text: This is one of my favorite salads. I make it for buffets all the time because it never gets soggy  the longer the vegetables marinate, the tastier the salad is.

headline: Oven-Roasted Fish With Fennel
text: One of the classic dishes of the French Riviera is sea bass grilled with fennel fronds. That’s the inspiration for this simpler fish preparation. I use firm white fish fillets  those recommended by the Environmental Defense Fund include Pacific cod, Pacific halibut or striped mullet  roasting them in the oven with the fennel stalks trimmed from the bulbs on top. I serve them atop pan-cooked fennel.

headline: To the 2010 3-Year-Olds: We Hardly Knew Ya
text: This wasn’t exactly the most scintillating Triple Crown season. There is nothing wrong with three different horses capturing the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness Stakes and the Belmont Stakes. In 2007, Street Sense, Curlin and Rags to Riches proved they were big-time talents with huge hearts and gave us five weeks of oohs and aahs.

headline: Quote Unquote | Cruise Control
text: –Michael Kors complains about the semantics of fashion, preferring the name destination. We guess Kors won’t be collaborating with Royal Caribbean anytime soon.

headline: A Q-and-A With Jil Sander
text: Jil Sander is among the best-known fashion designers in the world. She is also among the most private, rarely giving interviews, especially after walking away from the design house that bears her name first in 2000 and then, finally, in 2004. A profile of Ms. Sander by Suzy Menkes, fashion editor of the International Herald-Tribune, can be found here.  These are excerpts from the interview with the Hamburg-based designer that Ms. Menkes recently conducted for that profile.

headline: Chrysler Recalls 570,000 Jeeps and Minivans
text: Chrysler is recalling more than half a million minivans and Jeep Wranglers, the automaker told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: More Reading: Employers Auditing Your Dependents
text: Last Saturday’s Patient Money column, “Companies Crack Down on Defining Dependents in Benefit Plans,” described an increasingly common health care cost-cutting tactic among employers: dependent audits.

headline: Prognosis: Do Your Neighbors Know CPR?
text: Your chance of surviving sudden cardiac arrest may depend on what neighborhood you live in, a new study suggests.

headline: Goldman Gets Subpoena From Financial Crisis Panel
text: 6:15 p.m. | Updated The commission investigating the causes of the financial crisis said Monday that it had subpoenaed Goldman Sachs and harshly accused the investment bank of trying to delay and disrupt its inquiry, The New York Times’s Sewell Chan reports from Washington.

headline: Taking Questions on Social Security
text: “Ask an Expert” is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

headline: More Musicians Cancel Performances in Israel
text: A music promoter in Israel said that the country was being subjected to “cultural terrorism” as more artists canceled planned performances there, Agence France-Presse reported.

headline: Dispersal of Oil Means Cleanup to Take Years, Official Says
text: Although the Coast Guard had trained for the possibility of cleaning up a disastrous oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, it had never anticipated that oil would spread across such a broad area and break up into hundreds of thousands of patches as the current spill has done, the commander heading the federal response to the spill said Monday.

headline: Trial Lawyer Aims to Be Top State Prosecutor
text: Sean Coffey, one of five candidates for the Democratic nomination for attorney general, has one of the most varied resumes of anyone seeking the job.

headline: Will I Qualify Immediately for the Insurance Exchange?
text: Q.

headline: What Lies Beneath: Holes Full of Fire, Water, Darkness
text: This is a brief followup look at holes, building out of coverage here of the extraordinary orifice that swallowed a building and street corner in Guatemala City after the region was struck by a raging tropical downpour. (Interestingly, an American geologist living in that city has concluded that this hole, and another that formed there in 2007, are not technically sinkholes at all, but the result of stormwater drainage eroding the loosely packed pumice, laid down in past volcanic activity, that underlies the region.)

headline: Countrywide Settles Fee Complaint
text: WASHINGTON  Countrywide Home Loans and its mortgage servicing unit, which are now part of Bank of America, agreed on Monday to pay $108 million to settle federal charges that the company overcharged customers who were struggling to hang onto their homes.

headline: Policy and Politics Collide on the President’s Path
text: President Obama, struggling for balance on a political oil slick, gave a speech last week that seemed to contradict itself.

headline: Esurance Still Has ‘Character’
text: In advertising, the insurance category is replete with colorful characters, the better to potentially stand out amid the clutter. Of course, with all the geckos, cavemen, ducks and other critters, the characters create a crowd of their own, which makes one company’s decision to change how it uses its character noteworthy.

headline: Countrywide to Pay $108 Million to Settle F.T.C. Case
text: 1:27 p.m. | Updated The Federal Trade Commission announced Monday that two Countrywide Financial mortgage-servicing companies had agreed to pay $108 million to settle charges that they collected excessive mortgage-servicing fees from financially troubled homeowners, The New York Times’s Edward Wyatt reports from Washington.

headline: What We’re Reading: Investing in Hogs
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Siblings’ Two Worlds Collide in War Over Chinese Art Trove
text: For decades, a shrewd Chinese émigré in New York with a puff of silver hair dominated the rarefied market for ancient Chinese art. Going by the anglicized name C. C. Wang, he sold centuries-old pieces for millions, including 60 works that went to the Metropolitan Museum of Art and are sometimes shown in the C. C. Wang Family Gallery on the museum’s second floor.

headline: Helen Thomas Retires in Wake of Anti-Israel Remarks
text: Updated:  Helen Thomas announced on Monday that she was retiring, moments after the White House Correspondents Association said it was considering stripping her of her front-row press room seat.

headline: Beckham, in a Galaxy Far Far Away
text: David Beckham, Daft Punk, Snoop Dogg and Noel Gallagher walk into a bar. On the planet of Tatooine. File this Adidas spot for the World Cup under kind-of-amazing. Who do you think is sexier: the bearded Becks or a Millennium Falcon-era Harrison Ford?

headline: New York State Cracks Down on E-Waste
text: There’s a far better place than the trash bin for your old computer monitor. Like plenty of other electronics items, it may contain toxic substances like lead, mercury and cadmium that are hazardous to the environment and human health if mismanaged.

headline: Loving the Winners
text: Remember when Rafael Nadal was finished? (Hint: it was last year.) Tennis’s colorful star was written off, in conventional-wisdom circles. His knees were toast, victims of his relentless playing style. His mad dash of a career was unsustainable. He was tennis’s comet, having blazed across the sky only to burn out at 23.

headline: Are Foreign Currency Loans Endangering Eastern Europe?
text: Fears that Hungary is on the road to fiscal ruin seemed to ease Monday, after bond investors realized that the nation’s budget problems do not rise to Grecian levels.

headline: Goldman’s Chinese Media Headache
text: 12:59 p.m. | Updated For years, Goldman Sachs has built up its operations in China, becoming perhaps the most successful Western financial firm in that red-hot market.

headline: Update: Helen Thomas To Retire
text: Our sister blog, The Caucus, has the news that Helen Thomas will retire following her inflammatory remarks on Israel.

headline: The Claim: Keep Stitches Dry and Covered Up After Surgery
text: THE FACTS

headline: 2 New Jersey Men in Terrorism Case Go Before a Judge
text: Two New Jersey men who were arrested as they prepared to begin what prosecutors said was a carefully thought-out journey to an Islamic insurgent group in Somalia made their first public appearance on Monday since being taken into custody.

headline: A Murder Mystery Unfurled in a College Admissions Essay
text: Every so often on The Choice, we traverse into do-not-try-this-at-home territory, and the story told in a new novel called “The November Criminals” would seem to fit that category.

headline: Del Toro Writes a Sad Farewell to ‘The Hobbit’ and Its Fans
text: As Guillermo del Toro shed his mantle as director of “The Hobbit” and returned to being another filmmaking fellow in a wide world, he posted a bittersweet note on a J. R. R. Tolkien Web site that explained his decisions for leaving the project in further – if not complete – detail.

headline: Medicaid Cut Places States in Budget Bind
text: Having counted on Washington for money that may not be delivered, at least 30 states will have to close larger-than-anticipated shortfalls in the coming fiscal year unless Congress passes a six-month extension of increased federal spending on Medicaid.

headline: TimesCast | June 7, 2010
text: Today, BP's containment dome captures more oil than the company can process, 11 states including California prepare for Tuesday's primaries, and a look at marital dynamics after 40 years.

headline: Small Advances Against Pancreatic Cancer
text: Rarely is it said that someone is lucky to have had cancer. But Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the Supreme Court might be one such person.

headline: Capistrano Swallows Start Country Club Life
text: The famous cliff swallows of Mission San Juan Capistrano are moving up in the world. The Orange County Register is reportingthat the migratory birds that travel annually between Argentina and the historic Southern California church, made a new home this spring at the Vellano Country Club in Chino Hills.

headline: Resort Report | Donna Karan After Dark
text: This cruise season Donna Karan focused her attention on what to wear after the sun goes down. She took the word Resort out of her program completely, choosing instead to show all evening looks for “Holiday.” In a palette of black, white and navy, she moved from a man’s tuxedo to long, languid Grecian gowns. The masculine influence was softened in sumptuous pajama-style palazzo pants and smoking jackets paired with light pleated skirts. These are just the type of easy pieces to make a woman to feel chic after dark whether she spends her holiday on the island of Manhattan or somewhere decidedly more exotic.

headline: Ask the Expert: Pancreatic Cancer
text: June 10, 4:41 p.m. | Updated Thanks for all your questions. See Dr. O’Reilly’s responses in the Related Posts section, below. Additional responses will be coming soon.In this week’s Science Times, Jane Brody, the Personal Health columnist, writes about the challenge of pancreatic cancer, an illness that is detected and treated at a potentially curable stage in fewer than 20 percent of those who have it. The disease, which became more common in recent decades with the rise in cigarette smoking, has also been linked to obesity, diabetes, lack of exercise, certain pesticides and chemicals and other factors. Some patients also have a family history of the disease.

headline: Are Cavaliers Wooing Izzo?
text: Could Cleveland Cavaliers owner Dan Gilbert be looking to his alma mater, Michigan State, for a head coach?

headline: Merkel Unveils Austerity Package for Germany
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel on Monday unveiled a major austerity package aimed at finding savings of more than €85 billion by 2014, but it was immediately criticized by the opposition and trade unions, which pledged that they would unite to fight cutbacks they claimed would undermine the country’s generous social welfare system.

headline: Numberplay: The Playful Mr. Gardner
text: Last week, we bid a fond farewell to Martin Gardner, who died on May 22. However, fond farewells have a habit of lingering on, and we will not take leave of the spirit of Mr. Gardner just yet. As a not-unknown poet once said, “Parting is such sweet sorrow, that I shall say good night till it be morrow.” In our case, circumstances have conspired to prolong our farewell at least one week. And it is only fitting. After all, if puzzling were geometry, we have just lost our Euclid.

headline: Iraqi Students in Baghdad
text: Final exams started this month for tens of thousands of students at Baghdad University, the country’s largest institute of higher learning. The university’s College of Education for Women has 4,000 students required to take a total of 10 exams and 4 labs.

headline: World Trade Center Site, 11 A.M.
text: A memorial pool is taking shape at ground zero.

headline: NBC News Hires Newsweek’s Michael Isikoff
text: NBC News has hired Michael Isikoff away from Newsweek at a time when the newsweekly magazine is up for sale.

headline: Chicago’s Goal Soundtrack
text: Every time the Chicago Blackhawks score a goal at the United Center, the arena disc jockey cues up a catchy tune.

headline: Bove Cuts His Price Target for Bank of America Stock
text: Richard X. Bove, the banking analyst at Rochdale Securities, cut his price target for Bank of America on Monday to $22.80 a share from $27.50, saying the bank faced “serious challenges” from multiple sources.

headline: An End for Helen Thomas and the Helen Thomas Rules
text: Photographs

headline: Tips for Searching for Complaints Online
text: Consumers should start their search for complaints about a company online at my3cents.com, according to a report released on Monday by the Consumer Federation of America.

headline: Sit Under the Apple Tree With Me, Juice Brand Asks
text: Want to know a juicy marketing secret? As soft drinks contend with challenges like health concerns and the economy, juices are stepping up their advertising efforts.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: A question here in the May 24 issue, about a new television commercial for AT&T that pays tribute to — or is a ripoff of — the art installations by Christo and Jeanne-Claude that feature orange fabric — has stimulated lively debate. What follows are some of the reader comments the commercial has generated.

headline: New Season of ‘Torchwood’ Is Coming to Starz
text: This may seem redundant to say about a character who is essentially unable to die, but Capt. Jack Harkness will live on. On Monday, the Starz cable channel announced that it will show a new season of “Torchwood,” the science-fiction series on which John Barrowman portrays Captain Jack, the immortal leader of the Torchwood team. The series, about a clandestine organization that investigates (and often battles) extraterrestrial threats to this planet, has already had three hit seasons on BBC in Britain and BBC America in the United States, culminating in 2009 with the five-episode arc “Children of Earth,” which knocked off major characters who didn’t share Captain Jack’s invulnerability.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Avery Dennison Office Products, Brea, Calif., part of the Avery Dennison Corporation, named the Newport Beach, Calif., office of Doner as agency of record for its office and consumer products like school supplies and binders. Billings were not disclosed. The unit had not had an agency of record for several years, hiring agencies on a project basis.

headline: Part 1: Answers on Pets in Dorms
text: As a follow-up to an article I wrote for Sunday’s Times on pet-friendly college campuses, I’ve asked Deb Duren — the vice president for student services at one such college, Stephens in Columbia, Mo. — to answer selected reader questions on The Choice this week.

headline: More Art on Your iPhone
text: Can’t make it to Washington this summer for the Yves Klein exhibition at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden? Now you can tour the exhibition virtually, via the Hirshhorn’s first iPhone application.

headline: Family Studies
text: Families are treasure troves of data, but mining them is slow, incremental work. What happens within countless individual households both reflects and creates change in society as a whole, yet studying family dynamics is intrusive (often requiring a researcher’s constant presence in the house) and time-consuming (following families over decades, as children grow).

headline: The Insider | Coby Farrow
text: The Insider profiles emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here, the New York chef Coby Farrow shares his essentials. Farrow is a founding member of The Secret Table, a collective of chefs who commandeer closed restaurants for pop-up culinary and social events. Having relied on word-of-mouth and referrals, Farrow and crew will go semi-public on June 20th at Highbar with an event to celebrate the summer solstice and to launch their new Web site.

headline: It’s More Than Just Opening the Books
text: I have always told anyone who asks that opening the books at your company will produce results. But I never say it will be easy. It takes discipline and hard work to see things through. And the work never ends because business never ends — you have to stay with it.

headline: India Steadily Increases Its Lead in Road Fatalities

headline: India's Highways of Death
text: Every day in India, 320 people are killed in traffic accidents, the highest rate in the world. What will happen as new roads are built and thousands of drivers are taking the wheel?

headline: On Newest iPhone, Another Camera

headline: Prosecutors Make Their Case for Terror Sentence

headline: 10 Ways to Support English Language Learning With The New York Times
text: Many people don’t realize that The New York Times can be quite accessible for English Language Learners. Due to its focus on current events and news, using The Times to learn vocabulary and practice reading can be much more inviting and rewarding than a textbook. And NYTimes.com has some extra tools and features that are particularly useful for language learning.

headline: Oswald’s Getaway Cab Sold for $35,750
text: Because of a Jack Ruby bullet, Lee Harvey Oswald never had his day in court. The gavel has nevertheless come down on Mr. Oswald’s account many times since his death – if only at memorabilia auctions.

headline: ‘You Are Responsible for Any Spills’
text: This photograph was taken at a BP filling station in southern Virginia where the management wants to be sure customers are aware that they are responsible for any spills.

headline: Why Apple’s iBooks Numbers Are Meaningless
text: There was e-book news on Monday at Apple’s Worldwide Developers Conference: Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, said that big publishers had told him that sales of e-books for the iPad now accounted for 22 percent of all e-book sales.

headline: A Cautionary Word on Sand Berms
text: A recent report by four federal geologists reiterates some of the concerns that have been raised about the unintended consequences of a proposal to protect the Louisiana marshes from oil damage by a six-foot-high sand berm.

headline: The Contractual Structure of Private Equity
text: SonicWall, a maker of Internet security equipment, agreed to be acquired last week by a consortium including the private equity firm Thoma Bravo and the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan. According to Factset MergerMetrics, the transaction, valued at $717 million, is the 17th private equity acquisition so far this year of a public company worth more than $100 million. This compares with 20 such transactions announced for all of last year.

headline: Euro-Zone Finance Ministers Strike Deal to Create a Safety Net
text: BRUSSELS — A deal was struck Monday to establish a 440 billion-euro safety net for debt-laden countries in the euro zone, a move that officials hope will calm the markets that have helped prompt a slide in the value of the euro.

headline: More Spill Coverage: No Top Hat for Couric
text: Affirming that the Gulf of Mexico oil spill is Story No. 1 for the nation’s news media, CBS News said Monday that it would station its morning and evening newscast anchors there once a week “for the duration of the crisis.”

headline: Keeping the Artists in Williamsburg and Attracting the Bankers
text: Some New Yorkers  no matter how uncreative their jobs and lives may be  love to mention how they live in neighborhoods once romantically settled by poets, painters and musicians.

headline: ‘Annie’ Returning to Broadway
text: Little girls, little girls, get ready. The musical “Annie” will be revived on Broadway in the fall of 2012 to mark the 35th anniversary of the original production, with Thomas Meehan, who wrote the show’s book, on board to update the script for the first time for maximum appeal to modern audiences, the producer Arielle Tepper Madover said on Monday.

headline: Gangster Sparrows
text: Q. I recently saw a bizarre scene in the park: two sparrows ganging up on a third, pecking him unrelentingly. The aggressors were dark-feathered; the bullied bird was smaller and lighter in color. What might have been going on?

headline: High-Quality Photos in Low Light
text: If you snap a lot of photos in low-lighting conditions, you probably know that point-and-shoot cameras deliver pretty poor image quality once the sun goes down. Of course, you can use flash to get crisper photos, but that kills the ambience of soft natural lighting.

headline: All Eyes on England, Prepping for World Cup Opener
text: MORULENG, South Africa — South African teenagers in red Liverpool jerseys and Manchester United sweatshirts jumped up and down with vuvuzela-blowing compatriots wearing Bafana Bafana shirts. They were all shrieking the names of England’s players: Gerrard. Rooney. Terry. Especially John Terry.

headline: Sri Lankan Official Says War Hero Could Be Executed for ‘Treason’
text: In an interview with the BBC, Sri Lanka’s powerful defense minister, Gotabaya Rajapaksa, exploded with rage and said that the former head of the country’s military, Gen. Sarath Fonseka, who was lauded last year for defeating a Tamil separatist insurgency, could be hanged for reportedly claiming that the government had ordered the military to execute prisoners.

headline: When a Child Gets Hurt, a Sibling May Be at Risk
text: Summer is trauma season for children  everyone outside, out of school, riding bikes, climbing trees, playing around bodies of water, and all too often getting hurt.

headline: Agriculture: In Poor Countries, Experts Set Up Shop to Help Farmers Handle Plants and Insects
text: Many poor countries offer no agricultural services to subsistence farmers and have little or no money for cars and fuel that would let agents journey to rural areas to offer help. Now a development organization based in Britain wants to step into the breach by expanding a program of plant-health clinics in many more countries.

headline: She Doesn’t Trust You? Blame the Testosterone
text: The glue that binds a human society together is trust. But people who trust others too much are likely to get taken for a ride. Both trust and distrust, it now seems, are influenced by hormones that can induce people to ratchet their feeling of trust up or down.

headline: Resort Report | Jason Wu’s New (Wave) Look
text: Perhaps Jason Wu was thinking about the documentary “Two in the Wave,” which is about the relationship between Godard and Truffaut and is playing at the Film Forum this month. His Resort collection was inspired by Godard’s muse, Anna Karina. The collection included signature evening looks we’ve come to expect from Wu, but I was excited to see the menswear-inspired separates—especially the striped sweater and sailor pant look on Rose.

headline: 10 NATO Soldiers Die in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Insurgents killed 12 NATO soldiers on Monday, 7 of them Americans, military officials said. It was the worst single day for the foreign forces operating in Afghanistan in over seven months.

headline: Behavior: No Sex, Please: You’re Sleeping
text: Some people sleepwalk; others talk in their sleep. Now a study finds that 1 in 12 patients with sleep disorders reported having had sex while they were asleep.

headline: Two Years Later, Gasol Makes Contact
text: LOS ANGELES  Each time Pau Gasol finishes practice at the Lakers’ training facility, he is presented with his own version of “Let’s Make a Deal.”

headline: An Old Nuclear Problem Creeps Back
text: The American nuclear industry, primed to begin new construction projects for the first time in 30 years, is about as eager for an operating problem at an old reactor as the oil industry was for a well blowout on the eve of opening the Atlantic coast to oil drilling.

headline: Identifying Accident Prone Children
text: Can a serious injury to one child unsettle the whole family, changing behavior patterns in a way that puts all the children at increased risk? That’s the issue explored by pediatrician Dr. Perri Klass in the latest 18 and Under column.

The Israeli military said that an Israeli naval force spotted what it called a “squad of terrorists wearing diving suits” and fired on them, killing some of the suspects.

headline: Obama Tells Graduates: No Excuses
text: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., – President Obama has been telling the nation that he takes responsibility for cleaning up the oil spill in the Gulf. On Monday, he will impart his buck-stops-here philosophy to an audience of high school graduates, as he tells them, “Don’t make excuses. Take responsibility not just for your successes but for your failures as well.’’

headline: A Rubber Ducky Takes Flight(s)
text: A decade ago, my young niece Tasha Kim made a two-inch rubber ducky applique for me. I began taking it along on assignments around the world. It joined other essentials in my field pouch like extra camera batteries, flash cards, Swiss Army knife, toilet paper, notebook, granola bar, bottled water and luck.

headline: At Long Last, Stables Are Empty
text: After a fruitless campaign to stay put, Shamrock Stables shut its doors Monday morning as the final horse carriage rolled out onto West 45th Street, leaving behind the odds and ends of a family-owned business that was once a major part of New York City’s carriage-horse industry: bales of hay, untended manure, an old trunk filled with horseshoes and a pair of boots.

headline: Star-Dusted Tunes, Out for a Moonwalk
text: As affably easygoing as the early jazz that wound through his music like a lazy river: that would describe this season’s final program of the 92nd Street Y’s Lyrics & Lyricists series, devoted to Hoagy Carmichael, the proto-Midwest hipster. Carmichael, who has been described as the first singer-songwriter in a tradition that includes obvious descendants like James Taylor and Tom Waits, once described himself as sounding “like a shaggy dog looks.” He added, “I have Wabash fog and sycamore twigs in my throat.”

headline: Peters, Stritch to Join ‘Night Music’ Cast
text: In an unusual bit of major star re-casting on Broadway, the actresses Bernadette Peters and Elaine Stritch said in interviews on Monday that they will join the current revival of “A Little Night Music” in July to take over the roles of Desiree and Madame Armfeldt, now played by Catherine Zeta-Jones and Angela Lansbury.

headline: Farewell, My Lovelies: A Ballerina Hangs Up Her Toeshoes
text: There are only two dancers in Balanchine’s “Duo Concertant,” and each has some time to think onstage while listening to the pianist and violinist play the opening of its Stravinsky score.

headline: Family Ties: To Crime, Used Cars and God
