headline: Daring to Discuss Women in Science
text: The House of Representatives has passed what I like to think of as Larry’s Law. The official title of this legislation is “Fulfilling the potential of women in academic science and engineering,” but nothing did more to empower its advocates than the controversy over a speech by Lawrence H. Summers when he was president of Harvard.

headline: Stopping to Smile on the Way to Sadness
text: I walked into my patient’s room, waving a copy of her lab work in the air. Her white blood cell counts were finally high enough for her to leave the hospital. It had taken her awhile, and this was her third try at chemo, but finally she’d reached the magic number that would get her a ticket home.

headline: Mea Culpa at Prudential for Failed Bid
text: LONDON  The chairman of the insurance giant Prudential apologized on Monday for the costs incurred by the failed takeover of A.I.G.’s Asian business, but he rejected calls for him and the chief executive, Tidjane Thiam, to resign.

headline: Samurai Shopper | Squatting at Anthropologie
text: When the Samurai Shopper is busy not shopping (from 10 PM to 6 AM), she does, like common folk, surf cyberspace in search of the mesmerizing. One captivating late-night haunt is www.unusuallife.com full of voodoo donuts and scenically daft architecture, where I fantasize living in, say, an upside-down house in the Polish village of Szymbark.

headline: Findings May Alter Care for Early Breast Cancer
text: CHICAGO — For many women with early-stage breast cancer, treatment may become considerably less arduous, researchers say.

headline: Queen Mary 2 Back at Usual N.Y. Dock
text: After a brief detour, the world’s largest ocean liner, the Queen Mary 2, was back in Brooklyn on Monday, taking on passengers — a little slower than usual — for another trans-Atlantic crossing.

headline: New Cast for ‘Night’
text: In an unusual bit of major star recasting on Broadway, Bernadette Peters, above left, and Elaine Stritch, right, said in telephone interviews on Monday that they would join the revival of “A Little Night Music” to take over the roles of Desiree and Madame Armfeldt, now played by Catherine Zeta-Jones and Angela Lansbury. Ms. Peters said that Stephen Sondheim, who wrote the music and lyrics for the show, proposed the idea to her this spring and urged the producers to cast her. Ms. Stritch said that no one  including herself  was claiming credit for suggesting that she step into the role of Madame Armfeldt. “No one is going to own up to it until they see how I do,” said Ms. Stritch, who sang “The Ladies Who Lunch” in the original Broadway production of Mr. Sondheim’s “Company.” The change has led to a longer life for the revival, which had been set to close on June 20. A spokesman said that Ms. Zeta-Jones and Ms. Lansbury would play their final performances on that date, and that then the show would be dark until performances resumed on July 13 with Ms. Peters and Ms. Stritch.

headline: ‘Annie’ Revival Planned
text: Little girls, little girls, get ready. The musical “Annie” will be revived on Broadway in the fall of 2012 to mark the 35th anniversary of the original production, with Thomas Meehan, who wrote the show’s book, on board to update the script for the first time, the producer Arielle Tepper Madover said on Monday. The 1977 Tony Award winner for best musical, “Annie” ran for almost six years and has spawned countless tours and regional productions, but it has been revived on Broadway only once, in 1997, a production that drew negative reviews from critics and ran only seven months. Ms. Madover declined to offer a theory about why that revival failed, but said that hers would be different because Mr. Meehan would be working with the script and “a new creative team will look to modernize the show.” The story (as if anyone didn’t know) of a little orphan girl who warms the hearts of Daddy Warbucks, Franklin D. Roosevelt and just about everyone except the mean orphanage manager Miss Hannigan, “Annie” will not be updated out of the Great Depression, Ms. Madover said. Rather, Mr. Meehan plans to look at the dialogue and the structure of the plot for ways to sharpen the storytelling. (Mr. Meehan won the 1977 Tony for best book, one of seven Tonys that the production received.)

headline: Gates Effort to Focus on Mother and Child
text: The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation said it would spend $1.5 billion over the next five years on maternal and child health, family planning and nutrition programs in developing countries, representing a new emphasis for the foundation, whose health efforts so far have focused on infectious diseases, vaccines and H.I.V. and AIDS.

headline: Laurie Anderson Work a Hit With Dogs
text: In so far as no one was bitten and nearly everyone stayed where he or she was supposed to, the debut of Laurie Anderson’s “Music for Dogs” was deemed a howling success by its audience and their owners, The Associated Press reported. The concert was performed for the first time outside the Sydney Opera House on Saturday as part of the Vivid Live arts festival that Ms. Anderson is organizing with her husband, Lou Reed. The 20-minute work consists of thumping beats, whistles and high-pitched electronic sounds that cannot be heard by human ears, The A.P. said, as well as whale sounds that worked some four-legged concertgoers “into a frenzy.” (Others, The A.P. said, simply “stared at the stage with glazed eyes,” which in our experience is not necessarily an indication of a bad show.) A Jack Russell terrier named Oliver made a break for the stage, The A.P. reported, dragging his owner along with him. But all in all, Ms. Anderson said: “That was the most amazing concert I’ve ever, ever gotten to give! It’s really a dream.” Above, a fan at the event.

headline: N.B.A. Vs. N.H.L.
text: The latest showdown between the Los Angeles Lakers and the Boston Celtics lifted ABC to No. 1 in the ratings on Sunday as the network garnered the highest preliminary ratings for Game 2 of the N.B.A. Finals in six years. Nielsen’s overnight estimates for the game were slightly higher than ABC’s ratings on Thursday for Game 1, which drew an audience of 14.1 million viewers. CBS was second on the night, earning 10.2 million viewers for “60 Minutes,” while NBC averaged roughly 6 million viewers for its coverage of Game 5 of the Stanley Cup Finals. Fox finished fourth on the night.

headline: More Musicians Cancel Shows In Israel
text: A music promoter in Israel said that the country was being subjected to “cultural terrorism” as more artists canceled performances there, Agence France-Presse reported. Over the weekend the alternative-rock band the Pixies (right, Black Francis, the band’s lead singer) withdrew from what would have been its first show in Israel, as part of the Pic.Nic music festival scheduled in Tel Aviv this week. “We’d like to extend our deepest apologies to the fans, but events beyond all our control have conspired against us,” the group said in a statement. The bands Gorillaz and the Klaxons have also withdrawn from the festival after the raid by Israeli commandos on a Gaza-bound flotilla. Last month Elvis Costello canceled two concerts in Israel this summer, citing the complexities of the continuing Israeli-Palestinian conflict. After the announcement of the Pixies’ cancellation, Shuki Weiss, the promoter of the Pic.Nic festival, said in a statement, “I am full of both sorrow and pain in light of the fact that our repeated attempts to present quality acts and festivals in Israel have increasingly been falling victim to what I can only describe as a form of cultural terrorism which is targeting Israel and the arts worldwide.”

headline: Del Toro’s Sad Farewell
text: As Guillermo del Toro shed his mantle as director of “The Hobbit” and returned to being another filmmaking fellow in a wide world, he posted a bittersweet note on a J. R. R. Tolkien Web site that explained his decisions for leaving the project in further  if not complete  detail. Last week Mr. del Toro said on TheOneRing.net that he was withdrawing as director of “The Hobbit,” which MGM is planning for release as two films in 2012 and 2013. In a message posted on Sunday on that same site, Mr. del Toro wrote that his “commitment to the project demanded enormous sacrifices both in personal and professional terms,” requiring him to relocate “my entire life and family to New Zealand” after he joined the project in 2008. Though he has made other films that required location shoots and took years to come together, Mr. del Toro wrote, “rarely do you relocate for such massive amount of time specially when you have to do major ironclad agreements to put in deep freeze other contractual obligations with multiple studios.” He added: “So  while the cited delays, contractual complexities or obstacles, cannot be attributed to a single event or entity  you will simply have to believe that they were of sufficient complexity and severity to lead to the current situation.” A new director has not been announced.

headline: Kroll-Altegrity: A Reunion of Sorts
text: Monday’s announcement of a merger of Altegrity and Kroll signaled a homecoming of sorts for executives at the two security consulting firms.

headline: Enlisting Patients in the Fight to Cut Costs
text: Dagmar Frias never really got the hang of her asthma medications. She would use an inhaler whenever she started wheezing, but the drugs she was supposed to take every day remained in her dresser drawer, untouched.

headline: iAd, Therefore iAm
text: How eager are advertisers to get behind the iAd mobile advertising platform being introduced by Apple? Some are sending news releases to herald their participation.

headline: A Conflict Between the Press and the President in the Gulf Spills Into View
text: Speaking to the people of the Gulf Coast a week ago last Wednesday from Grand Isle, President Obama assured them that his administration would keep focused on the massive oil spill and its consequences.

headline: Few Hometown Heroes at a Hip-Hop Showcase
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  As hip-hop rites of passage go, the annual Summer Jam, hosted by the New York radio station Hot 97, is ostensibly an event of genre-wide significance, but really it’s an opportunity for local boosterism. Summer Jam is supposed to be a reminder not just of the importance of New York hip-hop but also of New York as vital turf where outsiders come to prove themselves.

headline: Measuring Dependence on Social Security
text: One particular challenge to cutting entitlements is conveyed by this chart:

headline: A Teenage Wasteland With an All-Seeing Eye
text: While you have been busy trying to figure out how your teenager might productively spend the summer, generating microloans to Nepalese weavers or interning at the State Department, ABC Family has had very different ideas.

headline: Empathy in the Mailbag
text: If your grandmother was like mine, she told you what happened when you assumed.

headline: Champion of the Shtetl, Defender of the Poor
text: Move over, Iron Man. Step aside, Robin Hood. A new hero has come to town: Hershele. Hershele Ostropolyer. Doubtless he prefers his cholent stirred, not shaken. That is, if he could afford it.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Carrie'
text: A.O. Scott reviews Brian De Palma's 1976 film based on Stephen King's 1974 novel.

headline: Rosés, With All Due Respect
text: FEW wines are both as beloved and belittled as rosé. Since its return to fashion in the last five years or so, the public has embraced it as a wine of summer. Yet bottles of rosé seem to come with neon-red warning signs admonishing consumers that they run the risk of pomposity if they dare to critically assess the wines.

headline: ‘Friday Night Lights’ Watch: Bad Parenting
text: Once again Friday night’s episode of “Friday Night Lights,” proved to be an evocative treatise on miserable parenting. Early on we see Vince scouring the empty fridge in his apartment right before the camera finds its way to the image of his mother sacked out on a bench outside. She didn’t forget to pick up the milk because she is too harried; she is too strung out to remember to do it in the first place. The series checks off every category of bad mother or father: Vince’s mom is an addict; Becky’s mom is an obsessive too focused on the transgressions of Becky’s dad to really be in the moment with her daughter. Did anybody else feel worse for Becky that her mom was screaming into the dad’s voice mail during the pageant than they did over the fact that he didn’t bother to show up?And how about that pageant? (I loved Becky’s correcting of the M.C. — “It’s just ‘Wicked.'”) There is something so incongruous — in a good way — about Becky being on the beauty pageant circuit, since she is so not a Texas looker. The show hammered this home with its shots of her competitors. Her confidence — her aggressiveness with Riggins — is constantly at odds with her rebellious hair and unconventional prettiness, and I’m finding myself really riveted by the tension. Becky is also the first central female character to be ordinary looking. (Tyra, Julie and Lyla — knockouts all.) And what’s amazing is how self-assured she is in spite of her clearly bad family life. She knows how to perform: I like the way her confidence was contrasted with Vince’s, when he is asked to deliver a speech at a pancake breakfast after a great turn in his football game. He is at a loss and further confused by J.D. McCoy’s Dale Carnegie-like ease in front of an audience.

headline: Bragging Rights: President Obama Studied Here
text: PRESIDENT OBAMA’S rise from a single-parent household and a background of modest means has been well documented, though some of the touchstones of his past have faded into history.

headline: Tenet Ends Talks to Acquire Healthscope

text: Like quite a few others in the wine media in New York last week I was invited to a tasting of the wines of Valentini, the great producer in Abruzzo.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Carrie’
text: Just in time for prom season, A. O. Scott looks back at “Carrie,” Brian De Palma‘s 1976 horror film, based on Stephen King‘s novel, about a bullied young high school student named Carrie White (Sissy Spacek) who uses her telekinetic powers on prom night to unleash a blood-drenched vengeance on her tormentors.

headline: For Mission to Mars, a New Road Map
text: GALVESTON, Tex.  “Game-changing” and “affordable” are perhaps the most repeated adjectives spoken by NASA officials in the last few months.

headline: Ann Beattie, Reliving of a Time of Fame
text: YORK, Me. — Thirty-five years ago, Ann Beattie was the most popular and admired writer of her generation. Every other week, it seemed, she had a story in The New Yorker. Her novel  “Chilly Scenes of Winter”  became a kind of bible among 20-somethings, and Ms. Beattie, with her high cheekbones and long, straight auburn hair, acquired a certain folksy, Joni Mitchell-like glamour.

headline: New iPhone Accessories Race to Market
text: Just hours after the official news of release of the new iPhone 4, the first accessories for the phone are being announced.

headline: Resort Report | Thakoon’s Street Smarts
text: Nautical lacing was a recurring detail in Thakoon’s resort collection. The cotton fabrics — some crisp, some washed — and the faded prints felt fresh. A pair of sheer chiffon polka-dot pants paired with a little cropped jacket gave off a French, 70’s feel. But the look book pictures, which were styled with downtown accessories like a plastic bag from a bodega, sunflowers, a camera, even Thakoon’s dog Stevie — reinforced how wearable and cool these clothes are. More in tune to a girl’s day off in the city than a cruise to the Bahamas.

headline: A Revival With Irish Roots, Two Fathers and Multiple Layers of Meaning
text: LOS ANGELES  John Cage died 18 years ago and Merce Cunningham almost a year ago, but their work still divides audiences. As the stage lights faded at the end of the Cage-Cunningham “Roaratorio” on Sunday, the women on either side of me exclaimed, “Thank God!” But there followed an ovation, which baffled them.

headline: In New Space Race, Enter the Entrepreneurs
text: NORTH LAS VEGAS, Nev.  At the Bigelow Aerospace factory here, the full-size space station mockups sitting on the warehouse floor look somewhat like puffy white watermelons. The interiors offer a hint of what spacious living in space might look like.

headline: An Inflatable Space Station
text: In four years, a small company called Bigelow Aerospace is to launch a private space station that will be leased to governments, companies and perhaps space tourists.

headline: A Woman With the Firepower to Silence Those Street Wolves
text: I have never been sexually harassed. Walking down the street, I have never had a stranger say anything suggestive or complimentary about my appearance (though one night last summer a homeless man in Midtown Manhattan did sneer “Nice get-up” as I passed by in yellow shorts and a bright blue polyester shirt with a huge collar).

headline: Even a Soloist Can Use Some Help Now and Then
text: The central conceit of John Heginbotham’s “One-Man Show” is that it is not a one-man show at all. It’s a three-man-and-a-woman show that gives more or less equal stage time to all the performers, even if Mr. Heginbotham’s narrative — he is magically granted his dying wish to be the star of his own show at Joe’s Pub — tries to drive the action.

headline: Big Deal | Your President Slept Here
text: In 1981, a junior at Columbia named Barack Obama rented apartment 3E at 142 West 109th Street. Now, for $1,900 a month, you can, too. If possible traces of a future president’s DNA aren’t a sufficient draw, the one-bedroom on the third floor has exposed brick walls and wood floors. Read more in Real Estate.

headline: Company on the Verge of a Social Breakthrough
text: Responding to growing user concerns about privacy and growing scrutiny from American and European regulators of privacy practices, Mark Zuckerberg, the founder and chief executive of Facebook.com, last month tried to explain his company’s core principles in an op-ed piece in The Washington Post.

This first clip shows one of her many memorable skirmishes with the former White House spokeswoman Dana Perino:

headline: Pru Chairman Apologizes for Failed Takeover Bid
text: The chairman of the insurance giant Prudential Plc apologized on Monday for the costs incurred by the failed takeover of the American International Group’s Asian business, but he rejected calls for him and the chief executive, Tidjane Thiam, to resign, The New York Times’s Julia Werdigier reports.

headline: Report of Theft From Polish Jet Bodies
text: MOSCOW  Four Russian soldiers assigned to guard the still-smoldering remains of a Polish airliner and the 96 people who died in the crash collected bank cards that belonged to victims and withdrew funds from their accounts, said Vladimir V. Markin, a spokesman for the Investigative Committee of the Russian general prosecutor.

headline: Reviving Fast Lanes at Security
text: The stereotype of the business traveler dashing to catch a plane with minutes to spare was long ago retired; 9/11 and unpredictable security lines took care of that. And any hopes that private companies could run faster alternative lanes proved too optimistic after the companies closed down a year ago.

headline: Clinton Pleads Case for Honduras
text: LIMA, Peru  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton pleaded Monday with Latin American countries to welcome Honduras back into their circle, a year after the country’s left-leaning president was ousted in a coup that has left a residue of bitterness throughout the region.

headline: Estonia Raises Its Pencils to Erase Russian
text: TALLINN, Estonia  Sometime before year’s end, a man with a clipboard will drop by one of this city’s best schools, the Tallinn Pae Gymnasium, and the staff will begin to fret. He will saunter from classroom to classroom, ignoring the children and instead engaging in seemingly trivial chitchat with many of the teachers, 20 minutes at a time.

headline: Using Appeals to Emotions to Sell Paint
text: THE collapse of the housing market has hurt paint sales, with total revenue for exterior paint falling 12 percent from 2007 to 2009, according to a recent report by Mintel, a market research company. But interior paint has fared better, with sales slipping just 3 percent during the period, because of what Mintel calls “a silver lining” to the downturn: cocooning. As short-on-cash people spend more time at home, sprucing up the rumpus room with a fresh coat of semigloss apparently seems to be worth the expense and effort.

headline: In Washington, Brisk Sales for First Look at Pitcher
text: Stephen Strasburg has yet to throw a pitch for the Washington Nationals, but he already is being hailed in the news media, at the box office and online as the team’s savior.

headline: Deal to Create Giant Firm for Corporate Intelligence
text: The owner of Kroll, one of the best-known providers of corporate investigative services, agreed on Monday to sell the firm to Altegrity, another security specialist, for $1.13 billion in cash.

headline: On Brink, Flyers Face Decision on Goalie
text: Peter Laviolette, the Philadelphia Flyers’ coach, said just before lunchtime Monday that he knew who would start in goal Wednesday when the Flyers will try to stave off elimination against the Chicago Blackhawks in Game 6 of the Stanley Cup finals in Philadelphia. But first, he wanted to tell his players.

headline: ‘A Very Deep Hole’
text: I know the president has a lot on his mind, but the No. 1 problem facing the U.S. continues to fester, and that problem is unemployment.

headline: Imagining the Worst in BP’s Future
text: It seems unthinkable, even now, that the disastrous oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico could bring down the mighty BP. But investment bankers get paid to think the unthinkable — and that is just what they are doing.

headline: Obama Uses Off-Color Language on Spill
text: KALAMAZOO, Mich. — President Obama has been criticized for his seeming lack of outrage over the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. But his outrage meter was on high Monday during an interview to be broadcast Tuesday on NBC’s “Today” show.

headline: In Alabama, a Home-Grown Bid to Beat Back Oil
text: MAGNOLIA SPRINGS, Ala.  James Hinton looked over a barge jutting into the mouth of a 6,000-acre estuary last weekend and said, “If we can make this work, if the oil don’t get in here, 1,275 miles of bay and river coastline will be protected.”

headline: Name Change at Agency to Remove ‘Retardation’
text: ALBANY  For the second time in a year, New York legislators are considering changing the name of one of the only state agencies in the country with “retardation” still in its title.

headline: History for Dollars
text: When the going gets tough, the tough take accounting. When the job market worsens, many students figure they can’t indulge in an English or a history major. They have to study something that will lead directly to a job.

headline: City Makes a Wish on a Basketball Star
text: Starting at its highest political reach, New York has put muscle into a campaign to lure LeBron James, considered by those who are schooled in basketball to be among LeBest players of all time. The Cleveland Cavaliers have him. But Mr. James becomes a free agent in three weeks. After that, he may go where he wishes.

headline: Albany Lawmakers Pass Big Cuts in Health Care
text: ALBANY  State lawmakers approved $775 million in cuts and other savings from New York’s health care budget on Monday after Gov. David A. Paterson inserted the reductions into emergency spending legislation submitted to the Legislature to keep the state government from shutting down.

headline: When Out to Dinner, Don’t Count the Watts
text: At Maialino, the Roman-style trattoria on Gramercy Park, they hover in groups of two and three. At the Standard Grill in the meatpacking district, they snake through the cafe, restaurant and patio. And at Recipe, a rustic spot on the Upper West Side, they cluster near the entrance as an enticement.

headline: For ESPN and Univision, the U.S. Is a Soccer Country
text: ESPN and Univision are paying more than ever to carry the World Cup in the United States, proof that the quadrennial soccer tournament that begins Friday keeps increasing in value.

headline: Pushing a Liberal Agenda, With Democrats as Target
text: WASHINGTON  From the capital to Arkansas, liberals plan to spend this week aiming some not-so-friendly fire at President Obama and Congressional Democrats.

headline: Beltway Contrast: Happening vs. Hapless
text: The ascension of Stephen Strasburg to the Washington Nationals on Tuesday coincides with the nadir of their Beltway neighbors, the Baltimore Orioles. The moment could symbolize a seismic shift in the relevance of the teams, unless it has already happened.

headline: Learning Something From Books, Before Their Texts Even Begin
text: If the Kindle and its competitors ultimately do vanquish the printed book, stories will keep going, but inscriptions, as we know them, will not. Inky, intimate, idiosyncratic  a good inscription is the bonus in a used book, the plot before the plot, a hint of relationships beyond the ones imagined by the volume’s author. One can see some creative entrepreneur pitching Kindle right now with this concept: one-of-a-kind inscriptions, sold along with the book for a small premium, to lend it that history-imbued, sentimental feeling.

headline: A Classical Education: Back to the Future
text: I wore my high school ring for more than 40 years. It became black and misshapen and I finally took it off. But now I have a new one, courtesy of the organizing committee of my 55th high school reunion, which I attended over the Memorial Day weekend.

headline: Nationals Pick Harper, but Not as a Catcher
text: SECAUCUS, N.J.  The Major League Baseball draft is beginning to follow a script, and not just because it is now televised in prime time.

headline: Doctors Who Aid Torture
text: Disturbing new questions have been raised about the role of doctors and other medical professionals in helping the Central Intelligence Agency subject terrorism suspects to harsh treatment, abuse and torture.

headline: What Is Goldman Hiding?
text: Congress created the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission last year to investigate the causes of the meltdown. Many banks, financial firms and other witnesses have cooperated. But not Goldman Sachs.

headline: Primaries Test Mood of Voters at Midterm
text: LOS ANGELES — Republican candidates made a final and frenzied plea to California primary voters on Monday, each claiming to offer the most viable and formidable challenge to their Democratic competitors, who, unchallenged by their own party mates, remained largely silent.

headline: Can BP Ever Get It Right?
text: The world knows that BP failed to plan for the disastrous blowout in the Gulf of Mexico. Now we discover that BP did not plan for success either.

headline: Group Objects to 2 Members of Tobacco Safety Panel
text: An ethics watchdog group filed a challenge on Monday against two members of a new federal advisory committee for tobacco product safety, saying they should be disqualified because they are consultants for drug companies that make smoking cessation products.

headline: Albany’s Chance to Be Tough on Crime
text: The gun lobby has been hard at work these past few weeks in Albany trying to block smart legislation that would help police officers solve violent crimes. The measure would require, starting in 2012, that all new semiautomatic pistols sold in New York State be equipped with microstamping technology that would allow police officers to quickly match empty bullet casings found at crime scenes to the weapons that fired them. California already has enacted a similar law.

headline: Former Manager of Iowa Slaughterhouse Is Acquitted of Labor Charges
text: The former manager of a kosher slaughterhouse in Iowa that was the site of a 2008 immigration raid was acquitted on Monday of criminal charges that he knowingly employed under-age workers at the plant.

headline: Notre Dame Is at Center of Expansion Discussion
text: In March, on an unseasonably warm morning in New York City, Notre Dame Athletic Director Jack Swarbrick seemed to push the collegiate conference expansion discussion from theory to reality. He told a small group of reporters that the Irish would reconsider their football independence if it appeared that “seismic” change to the college football landscape was on the horizon.

headline: Obama Conveys Principle to Students
text: KALAMAZOO, Mich.  President Obama has been telling the nation that he takes responsibility for cleaning up the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. On Monday, he imparted his buck-stops-here philosophy to an audience of high school graduates, telling them: “Don’t make excuses. Take responsibility not just for your successes. Take responsibility where you fall short as well.”

headline: Army Leak Suspect Is Turned In, by Ex-Hacker
text: WASHINGTON  It was only last month that a 22-year-old Army intelligence analyst in Iraq, Specialist Bradley Manning, reached out to a former computer hacker who apparently seemed like a kindred soul.

headline: Romo’s U.S. Open Bid Is Derailed by Weather
text: Dallas Cowboys quarterback Tony Romo will not be playing in the United States Open at Pebble Beach. After carding a one-under-par 71 in his first 18 holes to put himself in contention for one of two spots at a 36-hole sectional qualifier in The Woodlands, Tex., outside Houston, Romo withdrew when inclement weather caused the second round to be suspended until Tuesday.

headline: Mass Grave Found in Mexican Mine
text: Authorities in a southern Mexican state popular with tourists reported Monday that 55 bodies -- more than double the number initially thought -- had been recovered from an abandoned silver mine apparently used by drug gangs as a mass grave.

headline: Trade Group Sees Profit in ’10 for Airlines as a Whole
text: BERLIN  With the accelerating pace of the global recovery bringing a renewed surge in demand for air travel, an industry body predicted Monday that the world’s airlines would report a combined profit of $2.5 billion this year, a substantial improvement from the steep losses of the previous two years.

headline: U.S. Presses Its Case Against Iran Ahead of Sanctions Vote
text: WASHINGTON — With a vote on new sanctions against Iran only days away, the Obama administration is making the case to members of the United Nations Security Council that Iran has revived elements of its program to design nuclear weapons that American intelligence agencies previously concluded had gone dormant.

headline: As China’s Wages Rise, Export Prices Could Follow
text: SHANGHAI  The cost of doing business in China is going up.

headline: Shamrock Stables Shuttered
text: After years battling horse carriage critics and city officials forcing them to leave, Shamrock Stables finally closes. This long expected closing will allow new land for housing redevelopment.

headline: Adding Glitz to Baseball’s Draft
text: SECAUCUS, N.J. — Like its more famous counterparts in the N.F.L. and N.B.A., Major League Baseball’s draft is now a made-for-television spectacle. But one problem remains: unlike in the other drafts, most of the players selected are anonymous to the average fan.

headline: The Week That Was: Teams Nos. 93-87
text: Paul Myerberg of The Times hasn’t stopped writing long-winded college football previews; he’s just changed addresses, for now. The Countdown will return to The Quad later in the summer, but can be found at Pre-Snap Read.

headline: Rate of Oil Leak, Still Not Clear, Puts Doubt on BP
text: Staring day after day at images of oil billowing from an undersea well in the Gulf of Mexico, many Americans are struggling to make sense of the numbers.

headline: Game 2 Viewership Increases
text: The Boston Celtics’ win over the Los Angeles Lakers on Sunday night on ABC in Game 2 of the N.B.A. finals attracted an average of 15.5 million viewers, up from the 14.1 million for the comparable game last year. The Celtics’ knotting of the series competed against NBC’s broadcast of Game 5 of the N.H.L. finals, which was won by Chicago, 7-4, over Philadelphia. The N.H.L.’s 4.0 overnight rating was up 54 percent over last year’s Game 5 between Pittsburgh and Detroit.

headline: Hungary Disclaims Comparisons to Greece
text: BUDAPEST  Hungary’s center-right government pledged on Monday to contain its budget deficit and to cut spending as it continued to backtrack from its previous suggestions that the country was in danger of suffering a Greek-style crisis and defaulting on its debt.

headline: Hit Parade
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Solvers, or at least editors, expect theme answers in early-week puzzles to be symmetrically distributed in the grid. There must be a great many ideas that don’t quite work out because one part is too long or too short. Finding great themes must be to some degree a matter of serendipity, but I suspect that with experienced constructors like Peter A. Collins, it’s more a case of careful observation.

headline: Top Queens Republican Is Said to Be Mired in an Inquiry Into Bloomberg Campaign Funds
text: John F. Haggerty Jr. has endeared himself to many top Republicans over the last two decades, working for a mayor named Bloomberg and a governor named Pataki, as well as an attorney general, a comptroller and an Assembly minority leader.

headline: In Iowa, Other Issues Crowd Out Gay Marriage
text: DES MOINES  When Iowa became the first Midwestern state to legalize same-sex marriage a year ago, opponents said the issue would drive future political races, and some even pledged to work to remove the State Supreme Court justices behind the decision.

headline: Design Choices That Were Once Unique

headline: Web of Shell Companies Veils Trade by Iran’s Ships
text: On Jan. 24, 2009, a rusting freighter flying a Hong Kong flag dropped anchor in the South African port of Durban. The stop was not on the ship’s customary route, and it stayed only an hour, just long enough to pick up its clandestine cargo: a Bladerunner 51 speedboat that could be armed with torpedoes and used as a fast-attack craft in the Persian Gulf.

headline: President Obama on NBC's "Today"
text: President Obama's temper was on display during an appearance on NBC's "Today" show.

headline: The Promise and Unfulfilled Potential of South Africa’s President
text: SIYATHEMBA, South Africa  President Jacob Zuma, the son of a widowed maid, tried to reason with the rowdy crowd in this restive township. He had come to fix their broken public services, he assured them, but their angry heckling kept drowning him out.

headline: Reporter Retires After Words About Israel
text: To many in Washington, two sets of rules seemed to apply for journalists covering the president: those for regular White House correspondents, and those for Helen Thomas.

headline: Corrections
text: A film review on Friday about “Get Him to the Greek” misstated the title of a television series in which one of the film’s stars, Elisabeth Moss, appears. It is “Mad Men,” not “Mad Man.”

headline: Karzai’s Isolation Worries Afghans and the West
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghan observers and Western officials are interpreting the forced resignations of Afghanistan’s two top security officials as another worrying sign of President Hamid Karzai’s increasingly impulsive decision making and deepening isolation from his backers, both within Afghanistan and abroad.

headline: For Teixeira, Breaking Out of Slump Takes Twice the Work
text: A 6-year-old Mark Teixeira picked up a whiffle bat and took a few left-handed swings. Practicing that unnatural stroke intrigued him, and he would test it in Little League blowouts or at the park with friends. When he was a freshman in high school, his father urged him to take it seriously. It was time for him to become a switch-hitter.

headline: Team Meeting and Manuel’s Cool Demeanor Help Keep Mets Afloat
text: As Mets General Manager Omar Minaya puts it, Jerry Manuel is “not a meetings guy.”

headline: Poor Ratings for Belmont Stakes
text: The Belmont Stakes won by Drosselmeyer on Saturday generated a 3.0 rating for ABC, with an average of 4.86 million viewers, one of the Triple Crown race’s worst performances ever. The rating fell 32 percent and the viewership dropped 27 percent from last year, when Summer Bird won.The figures are from the period from 5:24 to 7:10 p.m. eastern, which is called the race portion.

headline: Game 2 Draws Big Ratings
text: The Boston Celtics’ win over the Los Angeles Lakers on Sunday night on ABC in Game 2 of the N.B.A. finals attracted an average of 15.5 million viewers, up from the 14.1 million for the comparable game last year. The Celtics’ knotting of the series competed directly against NBC’s broadcast of Game 5 of the N.H.L. finals, which was won by Chicago, 7-4, over Philadelphia. Its 4.0 overnight rating was up 54 percent over last year’s Game 5 between Pittsburgh and Detroit.

headline: Bombs Explode Outside Homes of Iraqi Police Officers, Killing 4
text: BAGHDAD  A series of bombings outside the houses of police officers in western Iraq on Monday killed four people and wounded at least 20 others, signaling a new tactic by insurgents seeking to spread chaos three months after a national election that has not yet delivered a clear winner.

headline: Mets Get Pitcher in Pelfrey Mold
text: With the recent success of Mike Pelfrey in their minds, the Mets picked a similar player Monday in the first round of the Major League Baseball draft.

headline: Doctors and Hospitals Say Goals on Computerized Records Are Unrealistic
text: WASHINGTON  In February 2009, as part of legislation to revive the economy, Congress provided tens of billions of dollars to help doctors and hospitals buy equipment to computerize patients’ medical records.

headline: Bernanke Forecasts a Fitful Recovery
text: WASHINGTON  The American economy will probably be slow to recover, with joblessness remaining high for some time, Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said on Monday evening.

headline: Day 48: The Latest on the Oil Spill

headline: The Morning Skate: Cup Series Twists Chicago’s Way
text: This very twistable, turnable Stanley Cup final series has now twisted and turned the Blackhawks’ way, putting them one win away from the championship with their strong offensive performance to win Game 5, 7-4 (Jeff Z. Klein’s Times story here).

headline: Colorado: New Regulations for Medical Marijuana
text: Gov. Bill Ritter Jr. signed two bills into law on Monday intended to increase oversight of Colorado’s medical marijuana industry. Under new regulations in the bills, municipalities can ban marijuana dispensaries. Doctors must also conduct a physical exam of any patient they prescribe marijuana to and are prohibited from having a financial relationship with a marijuana dispensary. “The companion measures I signed today strike a delicate balance between protecting public safety and respecting the will of the voters,” said Mr. Ritter.

headline: Yankees Draft Shortstop With First Pick
text: For the second consecutive year, the Yankees used their first-round draft selection on a high school position player.

headline: David Markson, Postmodern Experimental Novelist, Is Dead at 82
text: David Markson, whose wry, elliptical novels probing the scattered mind of the artist and the unruly craft of making art were frequently called postmodern and experimental and almost always surprisingly engaging and underappreciated, died Friday in his Greenwich Village apartment. He was 82.

headline: Races to Watch in Tuesday's Elections
text: Many of the elections on Tuesday will test the strength of the anti-incumbency movement.

headline: Joseph Strick, Who Filmed the Unfilmable, Dies at 86
text: Joseph Strick, an Academy Award-winning director, screenwriter and producer known for filming the unfilmable  in particular weighty, bawdy literary works whose screen adaptations often ran afoul of censors worldwide  died on June 1 in Paris. He was 86 and had made his home in Paris since the 1970s.

headline: A Spotlight Big Enough for One Bad Guy at a Time
text: The troubles of BP, the British oil giant, have certainly handed Goldman Sachs a public relations reprieve. Similarly, the Wall Street firm’s travails after accusations of fraud took Toyota’s recall problems off the front pages.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 7, 2010

headline: Mets’ Top Pick Has Gone the Distance
text: Matt Harvey, the Mets’ first-round draft pick Monday, gave the scouts following him quite a scare April 23, when he threw 157 pitches in a complete game for North Carolina against Clemson. Harvey struck out 15, and allowed six hits, three runs and one walk in the Tar Heels’ 5-3 victory.

headline: Marvin Isley, Bassist in Isley Brothers, Dies at 56
text: Marvin Isley, a bassist who provided the foundation for his family’s hit-making R&B band, the Isley Brothers, died on Sunday at a hospice near his home in Chicago. He was 56.

headline: From Out of Spotlight, Algeria Plots a Way Through
text: From all the pregame chatter and transatlantic gamesmanship in the dwindling days before the World Cup, it may seem as if there are only two teams — England and the United States — in Group C in South Africa. With those teams’ much-anticipated game Saturday monopolizing attention before the tournament, Slovenia and Algeria, the two other teams in the group, seem to be standing on the shoulders of giants.

headline: Photo Replay: June 7
text: A view of the day in sports as soccer teams and their fans grew more excited for the start of the World Cup.

headline: Sugar to Offer Local Deals Alongside Celebrity Gossip
text: Sugar Inc., the blog network for women, updates its readers on the latest in celebrity gossip, fashion, beauty, parenting and cooking. Now it will update them about the best places to go in their towns for discounted services.

headline: Martine Franck’s Pictures Within Pictures
text: I’ve often looked at photographs and wondered what the subject was thinking while the picture was being taken.

headline: Vera B. Saeedpour, Scholar and Archivist of the Kurdish Culture, Dies at 80
text: Vera Beaudin was newly divorced and a recent arrival in Harlem when a stranger knocked on her door one night carrying flowers and coffee cake. She fell in love, married and learned about the plight of his oppressed people.

headline: Federation President Announces His Ticket — and a Wave of Endorsements
text: Kirsan Ilyumzhinov, the president of the World Chess Federation, which is also known by the acronym FIDE (for Fédération Internationale des Échecs), has announced his ticket for re-election.

headline: On the Hunt for the Next Gisele
text: Alisson Chornak, a Brazilian model scout, searches the Rio Grande do Sul region for girls with the right mix of straight hair, light eyes and fair skin.

headline: Texas: One Worker Killed in Gas Explosion
text: A work crew digging a ditch accidentally struck a natural gas line on Monday, causing a giant explosion in a rural area near Cleburne, about 50 miles southwest of Dallas. Brian Fine, the Hood County emergency management coordinator, told The Associated Press that one worker’s body was found Monday night some distance from the blast site. The victim’s name was not released. Thirteen other workers were accounted for, and Capt. Jerry East with the county sheriff’s office said that six people were taken to a hospital and that four of them had been released. He did not know the status of the others.

headline: Word of the Day | fanaticism
text: fanaticism •\fə-ˈna-tə-ˌsi-zəm\• noun

headline: Focusing on Future, Premier in Japan Unveils Cabinet
text: TOKYO  Japan’s new prime minister named a cabinet on Tuesday aimed at refocusing his governing party on the nation’s huge political and economic problems and making a break with the financial scandals that dogged his predecessor.

headline: European Soccer Revenue Climbs, but So Do Salaries
text: PARIS  The economic downturn has yet to damage the revenue of the main European soccer leagues, but rising wages are a concern for the future, according Deloitte’s Review of Football Finance.

headline: News Quiz | June 8, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Off Runway, Brazilian Beauty Goes Beyond Blond
text: RESTINGA SÊCA, Brazil — Before setting out in a pink S.U.V. to comb the schoolyards and shopping malls of southern Brazil, Alisson Chornak studies books, maps and Web sites to understand how the towns were colonized and how European their residents might look today.

headline: Imagining the Worst in BP’s Future
text: It seems unthinkable, even now, that the disastrous oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico could bring down the mighty BP. But investment bankers get paid to think the unthinkable — and that is just what they are doing, The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

headline: Hungary Denies Comparisons to Greece
text: Hungary’s center-right government pledged on Monday to contain its budget deficit and to cut spending as it continued to backtrack from its previous suggestions that the country was in danger of suffering a Greek-style crisis and defaulting on its debt, Dan Bilefsky reports in The New York Times.

headline: Euro Zone Finance Heads Strike Deal on Safety Net
text: A deal was struck Monday to establish a 440 billion-euro safety net for debt-laden countries in the euro zone, a move that officials hope will calm the markets that have helped prompt a slide in the value of the euro, Stephen Castle reports in The New York Times.

headline: Finding Supermodels in Rural Brazil
text: A model scout searches for the next Gisele Bündchen in a region known for genetic cocktails prized by the beauty industry.

headline: In Space Race, Enter Entrepreneurs
text: At the Bigelow Aerospace factory here, the full-size space station mockups sitting on the warehouse floor look somewhat like puffy white watermelons. The interiors offer a hint of what spacious living in space might look like.

headline: Bernanke Forecasts a Fitful Recovery
text: The American economy will probably be slow to recover, with joblessness remaining high for some time, Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said on Monday evening, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

headline: Merkel Introduces German Austerity Package
text: Chancellor Angela Merkel on Monday introduced a major austerity package aimed at finding savings of more than 85 billion euros by 2014, but it was immediately criticized by the opposition and trade unions, which pledged that they would unite to fight cutbacks they claimed would undermine the country’s generous social welfare system.

text: India’s Reliance Communications has approved a plan to sell a minority stake to a bidder like Etisalat, AT&T or MTN Group, sending its stock up as much as 6.5 percent in Monday trading.

headline: Banks Eyeing G.M.’s I.P.O. Are Asked About Lending
text: Banks that want to participate in General Motors‘ initial public offering are being asked about lending lines for the ailing U.S. automaker, according to John J. Mack, the chairman of Morgan Stanley, Reuters reported.

text: Tavern on the Green lives.

headline: Blackwater Founder Puts Company on the Block
text: Xe Services, the American security firm formerly known as Blackwater that has faced criticism for its work in Iraq and Afghanistan, is pursuing a sale of the company, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Morgan Said to Eye Deeper Brokerage Cuts
text: Morgan Stanley is preparing to wield the axe over its brokerage business, with plans to close down 300 branch offices and cut as many as 1,200 jobs in order to bring down costs related to the integration of the Smith Barney unit it bought from Citigroup last year, Fox Business reported.

headline: Getting to Know Barceló at Madrid Exhibition
text: The last page of the Spanish edition of Architectural Digest (officially reduced to just AD — pronounced “Ah Day” in Spanish — on the cover) is each month devoted to a different style maven’s list of “10 things that make me happy.” The actresses, interior designers, and other creative types doing the choosing change every issue, but some of the items making the list often do not. The work of the artist — and high priest of the Spanish contemporary scene — Miquel Barceló is among the most frequently cited, as it is in the current issue.

headline: Bilfinger Plans $1.1 Billion I.P.O. of Australian Unit
text: Bilfinger Berger of Germany announced Tuesday that it is planning to spin off its Australian unit,  Valemus, in an initial public offering it hopes will raise as much as 1.39 billion Australian dollars ($1.1 billion).

headline: Bharti and Zain Close on $9 Billion Deal
text: Indian telecommunications provider Bharti Airtel completed its acquisition of the African assets of Zain, Kuwait’s biggest phone company, the Indian operator’s chairman, Sunil Mittal, announced in New Delhi Tuesday, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: ‘Easy Rider,’ Right-Wing Classic?
text: Today’s idea: Far from simply glorifying the drug-infused hippie counterculture, the 1969 film “Easy Rider” contains a deeply conservative, Christian message, an argument holds. It’s a morality tale right up there with Chaucer.

headline: Coke Pours $715 Million Into Dr Pepper Deal
text: Coca-Cola will pay Dr Pepper Snapple Group $715 million for the right to continue selling Dr Pepper drinks once it acquires its North American bottler, Coca-Cola Enterprises, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Newcrest to Seal $8 Billion Deal for Lihir by Fall
text: Newcrest Mining said on Tuesday it has finished its due diligence on rival Lihir Gold and expects to complete the $8.4 billion deal by September, Reuters reported.

headline: Swiss ABB to Buy Chloride Group for $1.25 Billion
text: ABB, the Swiss engineering group, is buying British-based Chloride Group for an agreed £860 million ($1.25 billion), as it seeks to improve its automation offering.

headline: Bonuses Said to Push Macquarie Bankers Toward Exit
text: Australian investment bank Macquarie Group, known in the country as the “millionaires factory,” may be about to lose large numbers of senior staff members from its growing North American and European arms after two consecutive years of low bonuses, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Casey’s Rejects Hostile Bid From Couche-Tard
text: 7:20 a.m. | Updated Casey’s General Stores urged shareholders on Tuesdayto reject a $1.9 billion hostile bid from Alimentation Couche-Tard, the Canadian convenience store operator.

headline: It’s the Economy, Mr. Bernanke
text: I just read a story about a speech that Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, gave the other day. “Unfortunately, lending to small businesses has been declining,” Mr Bernanke told a meeting of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago’s Detroit branch. “Indeed, outstanding loans to small businesses dropped from almost $700 billion in the second quarter of 2008 to approximately $660 billion in the first quarter of 2010.”

headline: Senate Said to Scale Back ‘Carried Interest’ Tax
text: Senate Democrats are closing in on an agreement to slightly soften a tax hike on executives at private equity firms, hedge funds and other investment partnerships, passed in the House last month, Bloomberg News reported, citing a Senate aide.

headline: Energy and Chemical Companies Help Give the Market a Lift
text: Stocks were mostly higher on Tuesday as increases in energy and material shares helped to offset a down day for technology.

headline: What Life Lessons Has Adversity Taught You?
text: Times Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof recently underwent surgery because he had a tumor in his right kidney. In a weekend column he reflects on the experience, ending with “it’s never too early — cancer or no cancer — to start appreciating our wondrous world, instead of disparaging its imperfections.” What have you learned from the challenges in your own life, even if they weren’t as dramatic as a cancer diagnosis? How often are you able to remember and act on those lessons?

text: The private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management has stanched draining losses, Breakingviews says. It is a part owner of Talecris Biotherapeutics, which is being sold to Grifols for $3.4 billion.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Well, it seems clear that BP doesn’t stand for “be prepared,” regardless of the signs they hang at their gas stations. Now that the worst has happened, the company could be put in play. But they’re not the only ones in trouble: the UBS client data deal just hit a snag, and you have to wonder what Justice thinks about it.

headline: CFDA Awards: Spreading the Love
text: If the 2010 awards show of the Council of Fashion Designers of America had been a little shorter, it would have been a winner. I thought this show in particular had everything going for it — a solid, competitive group of designers, new faces and names (some of us remember when the finalists in the top categories were always Ralph, Donna, Calvin and so on), and very imaginative and well-done videos. One would much rather laugh at the image of the industry, as people did so vigorously during the P. Diddy video, than witness another occasion for self-congratulation. And there were still a few of those moments.

headline: Building a New Dish
text: People ask me all the time where I get ideas for “new” dishes. My answers are a variation on this theme: Most — if not all — dishes are new only to me; they’re not really new at all.

headline: More Ups and Downs at Aspen Music Festival
text: Is the altitude finally getting to everyone? The dizzying swings of fortune for Alan Fletcher, the president and chief executive of the Aspen Music Festival and School in Colorado, continue. Mr. Fletcher, who was fired by the executive committee of the festival’s board of trustees last October, rehired by the full board in November and given a vote of no confidence by the festival corporation (including board members, faculty and others) in April, has now had his contract extended for two years, through September 2012. The decision was made at a special meeting of the board on Monday, at which Rob LeBuhn, its chairman for the last year, announced that he was stepping down, effective immediately, in response to a majority vote. Mike Murray, the vice chairman, has been named acting chairman. The board will elect a new chairman, possibly at its next scheduled meeting on June 29. The festival is also looking for a new music director to replace David Zinman, who resigned in April, strongly criticizing Mr. Fletcher. The festival season opens on July 1.

headline: Away From the Bustle, American Team Entertains Itself
text: IRENE, South Africa — Clint Dempsey’s easy Texas twang and quick-quipping manner belie an intense soccer player. And he says he relishes the time here at a quiet ranch, far away from the vuvuzela racket of Johannesburg or the coastal party scene of Cape Town. There’s enough World Cup energy inside him, inside this driven American team.

headline: China Says North Korean Shot and Killed 3 of Its Citizens
text: SHANGHAI  The Chinese Foreign Ministry said Tuesday that a North Korean border guard shot dead three Chinese citizens and wounded one last week in northeast China, prompting the Chinese government to file a formal complaint.

headline: Fashion Award Show Aims at Younger Audience
text: A TELLING moment came midway through the American fashion industry’s big awards night at Lincoln Center on Monday when Sean Combs, the music and apparel mogul, appeared in a series of funny MTV-style video clips that spoofed scenes from popular films like “Avatar” (Mr. Combs landed on Pandora to open a Tom Ford store) and “The Blind Side” (he and some Rag & Bone models tackled Sandra Bullock’s Leigh Anne Tuohy.)

headline: Lincoln Bucks Tide; Business Leaders Win in California
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Blanche Lincoln of Arkansas survived a tough challenge from her party’s left wing on Tuesday to capture the Democratic nomination in a runoff primary election, resisting the anti-incumbent wave that has defined the midterm election year.

headline: F.S.A. Clamps Down on Client Money Rules
text: The Financial Services Authority of Britain fined two firms Monday for failure to correctly protect and segregate their clients’ money, just days after it penalized JP Morgan a record £33.32 million ($48.6 million) for the same reason.

headline: What the Heck? Swear Words in but Ratings Down at MTV Movie Awards
text: The MTV Movie Awards — which, it has already been established, were not entirely successful at keeping Kristen Stewart entertained on Sunday night — were also unable to build on the viewership the event has enjoyed in recent years. The 2010 Movie Awards show averaged 4.6 million total viewers during the two-hour broadcast on MTV, MTV2 and VH1, Reuters reported. That’s a decline of 13 percent from the 2009 show, which was watched by 5.3 million people and was the Movie Awards’ best outing since 2004. In its own news release, MTV said that 16.4 million viewers had tuned in at any given time during the 2010 awards, a 2 percent gain from last year by that measure.

headline: Soldiers Charged in Polish Crash Theft
text: MOSCOW  Four Russian soldiers assigned to guard the smoldering wreckage of a Polish airliner in April were charged Tuesday with stealing bank cards from an official who died in the crash, said Vladimir I. Markin, a spokesman for the investigative committee of the Russian general prosecutor.

headline: A New Twist on the ‘Smart’ Window
text: The Department of Energy estimates that commercial and residential buildings consume 40 percent of our nation’s energy. Most of this energy is used for heating and cooling, but much of it is wasted because of leaky walls and windows.

headline: Ghosts of Dorm Rooms Past
text: Last month’s article about “Dorm Rooms With Bragging Rights” unleashed a torrent of memories from On the Record readers and rounded out our road map to one-time, campus crash-pads of many famous Americans. The map sometimes took On the Records far from the five boroughs.

headline: Describing Grief
text: More than once on Motherlode, grieving parents have written about the inadequacy of language in the face of their loss. There are no words to describe the pain of burying a child, and specifically there is no word to label their new, lifelong status. If you lose a spouse, you are a widow; if you lose a parent, you are an orphan. But what about when you lose a child? How do you name something you cannot comprehend?

headline: Fallon: ‘A Name That Gives Me Confidence’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: Today, President Obama spoke at Kalamazoo’s central high school graduation ceremony in Michigan. He told the students they could be anything they want to be, but if they could be oil leak experts, that could be great.

headline: ‘Brief Encounter’ Headed to Broadway
text: The acclaimed British theater adaptation of the 1945 Noël Coward film “Brief Encounter,” which was a popular draw last winter at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn, will be performed on Broadway in the fall at Studio 54, the Roundabout Theater Company has announced. Adapted and directed by Emma Rice, “Brief Encounter” is scheduled to begin preview performances on Sept. 10 and open on Sept. 28; the limited engagement is set to end Dec. 5. Casting is expected to be announced soon. Roundabout, in association with the producers David Pugh, Dafydd Rogers and Cineworld, will present the production by the Kneehigh Theater of Cornwall, England.

headline: Now Booking | A Tale of Two Palazzi
text: A down-at-heels economy (not unheard of in this country, after all) seems to be no deterrent to Italy’s hotel business. Among several new openings in the past year, two new luxury properties are making a splash, beginning with Palazzo Caracciolo, which opened last November in Naples. Before it was a hotel, this 13th-century building was a palace, a fortress, and a noble mansion. And what remains today is a legacy of regal monumentalism, from the immense cobbled courtyard where once horses and chariots were kept to the lemon trees growing up a giant pergola near the entrance. No doubt this is what caught the eye of the European hotel group, Accor, which restored and remodeled the property to include 144 rooms (from about $122 to $1,060), some of them split-level suites, decorated with rich red and white fabrics and Baroque- and Rococo-style furnishings.

headline: AOL’s New Phase and Phrase: It’s a ‘Start-Around’

headline: Unpublished Manuscripts by Stieg Larsson Are Found

Case in point: the national library of Sweden said it has recently come into possession of several unpublished manuscripts by Stieg Larsson, the author of “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,” Agence France-Presse reported.

headline: Horror on the L Train, and the Rest of the Story

A man who got on, still with his iPod headphones in, began talking to those of us seated in front of him.

headline: The Life Aquatic
text: There’s something about the onset of summer that prompts even the most diehard urbanites to dress like sailors. But there’s a fine line between indulging in a little naval gazing and looking like an extra on shore leave from “On the Town.” AANDD, a new line of three unisex bags from the architect/industrial designer Adam Davidson, gets the seafaring tone just right, with waxed rope handles and a predominantly navy color scheme. “I wanted to get past the usual garment center sources for hardware,” Davidson says. “So I looked at marine hardware and just fell in love with it.” The roomy Sea Bag is Davidson’s take on the weekender, with large exterior pockets and a detachable leather shoulder strap; the Sea Duffle is a cross between a shoulder bag and a sailor’s duffle; and the Courier is a leather messenger bag with a two-tone reversible flap that zips on and off. “Women’s bags tend to be bling-heavy, while men’s bags shy away from any risk-taking when it comes to details,” adds the designer. “The idea is to find the middle ground.” Aandd bags are available at Maryam Nassir Zaddeh, 123 Norfolk Street, (212) 673-6405. Prices range from $425-$625.

headline: Countdown to the Tony Awards

headline: Fire Hazard Forces Broad G.M. Recall
text: DETROIT  General Motors on Tuesday said that it was recalling 1.5 million cars and trucks from the 2006 to 2009 model years because their heated washer-fluid system could short circuit and cause a fire.

headline: Biden Praises Kenya Leaders for Political Cooperation
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. stood at a lectern in Kenya’s capital on Tuesday afternoon with the sun peeking out behind the clouds and a huge grin spreading across his face.

headline: Why Didn’t the Raccoon Cross the Road?
text: Walk anywhere in New York on a glorious day and you see parents dealing with peril, and potential peril. Kids topple over on sidewalks. Kids fall off bikes. Kids fall off skateboards. Kids fall off jungle gyms. Teeth are chipped. Arms are broken. Noses bleed. Street crossings are fraught with terror.

headline: Court Puts Hold on Arizona’s Campaign Fund
text: The Supreme Court on Tuesday barred officials in Arizona from providing matching funds to candidates for state office who accept public financing, a program meant to help them keep pace with the unlimited spending of candidates who don’t take public financing.

headline: A Bond in Devotion to Haiti Is Left Shattered
text: Husband and wife tried not to let tension seep into their last days together. On Jan. 4, he would leave the family home in Queens for Haiti, where he was working to reduce deaths from natural disasters  not just the hurricanes that Haitians have come to expect, but also a threat he believed was bigger, if less well known: earthquakes. She begged him not to go.

headline: The Back of Teixeira’s Baseball Card
text: ABOARD ACELA No. 2151 – The last thing Mark Teixeira told reporters before he left Rogers Centre on Sunday afternoon was that “the back of my baseball card says it all.” Well, not exactly. The back of his card reveals staggering statistics – 250 homers, six consecutive 105 R.B.I. seasons, an on-base plus slugging of .911 – but not everything.

headline: Polls Reflect Anti-Incumbent Mood
text: As voters in a dozen states cast ballots today, two new polls further highlight the anti-incumbent mood sweeping the nation.

headline: The Re-Marriage of Mitch Daniels
text: There are scores of interesting nuggets about the 2012 dark horse scattered throughout Andy Ferguson’s profile of Indiana’s governor, but for a press corps that’s struggling to believe in love in the wake of the Gore break-up, I suspect that this one will have the most appeal:

headline: Pushing Back at Cancer
text: Why does cancer seem so profound to us when compared to other diseases? And why do some patients clam up about their illness, while others are compelled to bear witness?

headline: In Baseball, N.F.L.’s Use of Replay Gets a Look
text: As Major League Baseball wrestles with the notion of expanding the use of replays to review calls like the one last week that cost Detroit Tigers pitcher Armando Galarraga a perfect game, an idea gaining popular currency is to give every team one replay challenge in each game.

headline: Remember the Copenhagen Accord?
text: Back in December, representatives of more than 190 nations gathered in Copenhagen under the auspices of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change to debate the fate of the world. They did not agree on much, but at the end of two contentious weeks they produced a three-page document known as the Copenhagen accord [pdf]. Delegates did not formally adopt it; instead, they voted to “take note” of it.

headline: Italians Give Art, as Well as Take It Back
text: Is it a good cop-bad cop routine? Italian prosecutors are in offensive mode — investigating a curator at the Princeton University Museum of Art and a dealer in a case involving the possible illegal export of antiquities — but the Italian Ministry of Culture seems to want to play nice. It will loan several ancient sculptures, including three portrait busts from a tomb on the outskirts of Rome, to the Indianapolis Museum of Art for at least two years, beginning in January, the museum announced on Tuesday.

headline: Carried Interest Tax Raise Is Softened
text: From Carl Hulse at The Caucus:

headline: Cuomo Says 3 Companies Defrauded Haitians
text: In his latest salvo against immigration fraud, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Tuesday that he had filed lawsuits accusing several companies of preying on the Haitian population in New York by fraudulently offering immigration services following the earthquake that devastated Port-au-Prince.

headline: In Search of Gray-Shanked Doucs
text: Friday, June 4, 2010

headline: The Blog Prophet of Euro Zone Doom
text: BARCELONA, Spain — For years, almost nobody paid attention to the sky-is-falling alarms of Edward Hugh, a gregarious British blogger and self-taught economist who repeatedly predicted that the euro zone could not survive.

headline: Roberto Bolle Withdraws From ABT Performances
text: Fans of the Italian dance star Roberto Bolle will be disappointed this spring ballet season. Mr. Bolle, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, has withdrawn from performances with the company because of an ankle injury, the company announced on Tuesday. Mr. Bolle was scheduled to appear in “Swan Lake” on June 21 and “Romeo and Juliet” on July 8. Marcelo Gomes, another principal, will replace Mr. Bolle in both “Swan Lake,” dancing opposite Veronika Part as Odette/Odile, and  “Romeo and Juliet,”  with Paloma Herrera.  The company‘s spring season continues through July 10.

headline: ‘Funny Girl,’ With Sher at Helm, Aims for Broadway Revival
text: “Funny Girl,” the hit 1964 musical about Fanny Brice that helped cement Barbra Streisand as a star, is expected to have its first Broadway revival in the spring of 2012 under the direction of Bartlett Sher (“South Pacific”), the producer Bob Boyett said in a telephone interview on Tuesday.

headline: Raccoon Parenting
text: Seems raccoon mothers use the same techniques on their young ones as human mothers.

headline: The Choosiest of the Charters
text: The charter schools in New York City that were hardest to get into last fall were not those that are most frequently in the spotlight, according to admissions data the schools supplied to the state.

headline: Halfalogue
text: An overheard one-sided cellphone conversation.(Half + dialogue)

headline: Resort Report | Carolina Herrera, Beyond the Pale
text: An Impressionist palette and a parasol print were the jumping off points for Carolina Herrera’s resort collection. Prints throughout ranged from festive, like a gold flecked watercolor, to graphic – think polka dots and a black-and-white check. Almost hidden among the elegant gowns was the perfect white cotton dress. The shoes, made by Manolo Blahnik, are not to be missed – strappy heels in pale shades of lizard or a bejeweled T-strap style.

headline: Obsessions | Diaper Burn
text: I was thrilled and slightly horrified last week to discover that our local drugstore was now selling Huggies in a faux-denim pattern, with trompe l’oeil seams, back pockets and signs of denim distress. The diapers had already caused some controversy when ABC refused to air its commercial – a toddler pictured as a man-about-town dressed in a button-down Oxford shirt and denim diapers getting ogled by the ladies and climbing into a convertible – because it aired the word “pooping” on screen. The hypocrisy here is frankly hilarious, considering that the ABC program “Grey’s Anatomy” has used the word “douche” not in the medical sense, but as a pejorative put-down, and a character on the 1990’s ABC program “NYPD Blue” routinely used the word with its popular pairing, “bag.” Compared to that, what’s wrong with a little poop?

headline: Rothschild Hires Board Committee Specialist
text: Rothschild said on Tuesday that it had hired a former Lazard executive as the head of its special committee and fiduciary practice in the United States, as the investment bank continues to bolster its North American operations.

headline: Why Would I Sign Up for a ‘Bronze’ Plan?
text: Q.

headline: Part 2: Answers on Pets in Dorms
text: As a follow-up to an article I wrote for Sunday’s Times on pet-friendly college campuses, I’ve asked Deb Duren — the vice president for student services at one such college, Stephens in Columbia, Mo. — to answer selected reader questions on The Choice this week.

headline: White House Threatens Veto of Move to Thwart E.P.A.
text: The White House made clear on Tuesday what had been assumed for months – that it does not like a resolution sponsored by Senator Lisa Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, that would thwart the Environmental Protection Agency’s ability to regulate greenhouse gases.

headline: The Merchants That Don’t Take Cash
text: My husband and I recently got back from a nearly cashless vacation.

headline: New Mary Jane for ‘Spider-Man’ Musical
text: Three months after losing the film actress Evan Rachel Wood because of lengthy production delays, the upcoming Broadway mega-musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” has a new choice for love interest Mary Jane Watson: Jennifer Damiano, the 19-year-old theater actress who plays the testy teenage daughter, Natalie, in the Broadway musical “Next to Normal.”

headline: Finals Drama Boosts Ticket Prices
text: The N.B.A. Finals, with the Lakers and Celtics tied 1-1, has produced an uptick in ticket prices.

headline: Altidore Returns to Full Training
text: JOHANNESBURG — “Training was good,” Jozy Altidore said. “The team looks really focused. You can tell everyone is excited for this weekend.”

headline: Thoughts From Tech Blogs on the iPhone 4
text: On Monday, Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, officially introduced the iPhone 4, complete with an internal gyroscope, longer battery life, a 5-megapixel camera and a new front-facing camera that will allow video chats over Wi-Fi.

text: David Frum argues that the relative stability of a politically-divided Cyprus, half Turkish and half Greek, offers a model for Israel and Palestine:

text: The director Joe Berlinger will not have to turn over more than 600 hours of unused footage from his documentary “Crude” to the Chevron oil company, pending his appeal of a subpoena for the footage.

headline: Workers at Co-op City Are Back on the Job
text: More than 500 Co-op City employees agreed Tuesday to end their weeklong strike and return to work as union leaders and the development’s managers pledged to resume stalled contract negotiations.

headline: Whom Would You Choose as a Commencement Speaker?
text: Nicholas D. Kristof votes for Bono and J.K. Rowling as two of his favorite commencement speakers ever, while his readers suggest candidates from Steve Jobs to Kurt Vonnegut. Whom would you choose? Why? What would you like him or her to talk about?

headline: Commencement: Things To Read, Watch, Teach and Do
text: Here’s a round-up of interesting Times stuff to celebrate this year’s graduates (and those who teach them).

headline: Top Draft Picks Not Always Top Players
text: On Monday, the Yankees and Mets chose their first-round draft picks. With fans (and general managers, no doubt), hope springs eternal. Will Cito Culver, a shortstop from Rochester, N.Y., be the next Derek Jeter? Will Matt Harvey, a standout pitcher at North Carolina, turn into a Mike Pelfrey?

headline: Descartes Letter Returns Home
text: PARIS – A rare four-page letter written in 1641 by the French philosopher René Descartes and stolen in the 19th century was given back on Tuesday to the Institut de France.  The letter was found in the library of Haverford College, which decided to return it.

headline: Teaching (Other) Children About Sex
text: You are an enlightened and proactive parent. You talk to your child about sex in age-appropriate ways and a matter-of-fact-tone. You make sure to answer only the question they are actually asking, rather than layering on more than they want to know, but you don’t shy from using correct nouns. You pat yourself on the back for shepherding your child toward adulthood in a responsible and open way.

headline: It’s Not Just a Game, It’s a Promotion
text: LONDON  European retailers are betting on the soccer World Cup to help increase sales by promising cash for goals.

headline: Big-Name Guests Help Larry King’s Ratings
text: Bolstered by heavily promoted interviews with Barack Obama and Lebron James, CNN’s Larry King last week enjoyed some of his highest-rated shows in many months.

headline: Cape Cod Residents Keep the Chain Stores Out
text: PROVINCETOWN, Mass.  It was a family-owned T-shirt shop that sent Barbara Rushmore on a mission to ban chain stores from this quaint and quirky seaside town.

headline: A Last Line of Defense? National Parks at Sea
text: Today is World Oceans Day, an occasion to pay homage to the seas — perhaps a sober occasion, in view of the catastrophic oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: A Bleating Soundtrack for Soccer
text: SOWETO, South Africa  The 94,700-seat Soccer City Stadium is shaped like a calabash, a gourd used as a cooking pot. When the World Cup opens here Friday, though, the stadium will sound like a giant, throbbing beehive with the incessant blowing of plastic trumpets that are the cause of much celebration and consternation.

headline: It’s Just a Few Deals, but the Office Market Is Stirring
text: In January 2007, not long before the market for commercial buildings peaked, Scott Rechler, the scion of a Long Island real estate family, sold the Reckson Associates Realty Corporation to S. L. Green Realty, Manhattan’s largest office landlord. The $4 billion deal included five Midtown office buildings.

headline: Upfronts: CBS Completes Ad Sales for Next Season
text: CBS has joined CW and Fox Broadcasting in completing the sale of commercial time to advertisers ahead of the start of the 2010-11 television season.

headline: Atlantic Magazine Tallies ‘Ideas of the Year’
text: Magazines that publish “Best Of” lists usually wait until the end of the year, but The Atlantic has decided to dispense with such conventions and publish its ‘’14 ¾ Biggest Ideas of the Year” list now. (The ¾ is not a reference to publishing a list during the summer, but rather refers to one of the ideas: the increasing trend toward legalizing marijuana.)

headline: Reviewing Torrisi Italian Specialties
text: This week’s restaurant review is of Torrisi Italian Specialties, an Italian grocery, lunch spot and marvelous dinner establishment on Mulberry Street.

headline: U.N. Is Set to Vote on Iran Sanctions
text: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations Security Council is scheduled on Wednesday to impose new sanctions against Iran over its nuclear program, taking aim at the financial might of the Revolutionary Guards Corps as well as Iran’s military and nuclear industries with the addition of 41 enterprises to the blacklist.

headline: Torrisi Italian Specialties
text: THERE is one piece of framed art at Torrisi Italian Specialties, a tiny and terrific new restaurant on Mulberry Street at the very top of Little Italy. It is a large photograph of Billy Joel, a reproduction of a promotional still released with his album  “The Stranger,”  in 1977.

headline: Grass Fed | Stinging Nettles
text: Nettles are symbolic of punishment and plague. They are frequently associated with witchcraft and potion making (nettle tincture is supposed to be a tonic for the hay fever and pollen problems common at this time of year) and mentioned when one wants to add a little mystical color to a story (which is how I know they grow wild at Stonehenge). In a Times article last year about hardships faced by the residents of Pikalevo, Russia, bubbling pots of nettle stew are conjured as illustrative evidence of the toughness of the times.

headline: Panoz Introduces the Abruzzi at Le Mans
text: Panoz Auto Development, a small sports car company based an hour north of Atlanta, was founded in 1989.

headline: Cavaliers Confirm Interest in Izzo
text: 4:34 p.m. | Updated Cleveland Cavaliers confirmed days of swirling rumors, with new General Manager Chris Grant saying at a news conference Tuesday that the team is pursuing Michigan State Coach Tom Izzo.

headline: Air Travel’s Costly Future
text: ANYONE who flies regularly knows that the state of air travel is bleak, so it may be encouraging to hear that the federal government has put together an influential group to suggest ways to fix the industry’s most pressing problems.

headline: Letter: Cruising Portugal
text: To the Editor: Regarding “Portugal Old, New and Undiscovered” (May 30), my husband and I took a cruise on the Douro River in October 2007, which started in Oporto.
