headline: Pictures of the Day: Gaza and Elsewhere
text: Egypt had enforced the land and sea blockade of Gaza since Hamas took full control there in 2007. However, responding to public outrage over the Israeli raid on a Turkish ship of activists bound for Gaza, Egypt opened its border crossing at Rafah, allowing passengers to flow through until further notice.

headline: Baseball Says Perez Injury Legitimate
text: After examining the circumstances surrounding Oliver Perez’s placement on the 15-day disabled list, Major League Baseball is satisfied he has a legitimate injury.

headline: Suit Takes Aim at Discover’s Payment Protection Program
text: A class action lawsuit recently filed in New Jersey accuses Discover of engaging in deceptive business practices to enroll cardholders into its payment protection program without their knowledge or permission.

headline: Hotel Auction Site Offers Posh Digs at a Bargain
text: Promising the presidential suite for the price of a budget motel room, a hotel auction site called Off & Away recently began operating online.

headline: Power Grows for Striking Chinese Workers
text: SHANGHAI  China’s wage contagion continues to spread.

headline: At Ad Panel, Words of Wisdom, Some Carefully Chosen
text: Three leaders in the creative side of the advertising industry imparted their wisdom at a panel on Tuesday — although one was constrained over just how forthcoming he could be.

headline: Council’s Dire Warning on Carried Interest Tax
text: The Private Equity Council, the industry’s lobbying group, took another shot on Tuesday at the proposed increase in taxes on carried interest profits by investment partnerships, asserting that plans to more than double the effective tax rate for fund managers could reduce private equity investments by $7 billion to $27 billion a year.

headline: A Leader Waits to Learn When to Leave the Stage
text: PHILADELPHIA  A parade of slow exits constitutes the apt conclusion of “Leaving,” the Vaclav Havel play making its American premiere at the Wilma Theater here. The friends and family of a newly deposed chancellor being ousted from his government-owned villa depart the stage one by one, ceding the territory to a representative from the new regime.

headline: Times Company Objects to News-Reader App
text: Last week I wrote about the Pulse News Reader, a popular iPad application developed by two students at the Stanford Institute of Design that collects and presents articles from Web sites of news organizations like The New York Times.

headline: Omnivorous | When Brooklyn Met Normandy
text: Roberta’s sneaks up on you, a cinder-block bunker in Bushwick that looks like a bar and acts like a pizzeria while stealthily turning out some of New York’s most creative and refined food. Last Friday night, Roberta’s chef Carlo Mirarchi was joined in his tiny kitchen by Alexandre Gauthier of La Grenouillère, a Michelin-starred auberge in Normandy, and Brooks Headley, the pastry chef at Del Posto (and former drummer for Born Against) for one of the “Friendly Dinners” from Omnivore, a French publication that’s as much a political organization as it is a guide to where to eat.

headline: Videos Deepen Mystery of Iranian Scientist
text: The mystery of an Iranian nuclear scientist who Iran says was kidnapped and tortured last year by American agents deepened Tuesday, as Iran publicized what it called a videotaped statement from him that proved its claim. That videotape was contradicted by a second videotape posted on the Internet in which a man who identified himself as the same scientist said he was studying happily in the United States.

headline: Where to Eat and Watch the World Cup
text: IN addition to every sports bar in town, many restaurants will show World Cup matches from South Africa, offering special food deals and drinks, often themed to the nationalities of the competing teams on particular days. Some matches will be shown live, starting at 6:30 a.m. The tournament begins on June 11 and continues through July 11. The restaurants here are among those with plans; contact them for details.

headline: S.C. Governor’s Race Offers Drama
text: LEXINGTON, S.C. – South Carolina has a reputation as a cradle of traditional, good ol’ boy politics, even by Southern standards. But with few hours of voting left in Tuesday’s gubernatorial primaries, the front-runner by all estimates is a 38-year-old, Indian-American, Sikh-turned-Methodist woman, state Representative Nikki Haley.

headline: The ‘Incidentaloma’ Problem With Medical Scans
text: It is delightful news that The New York Times columnist Nicholas Kristof’s kidney mass, detected by a CT scan performed for another reason, turned out to be benign rather than a cancer, as he recently wrote in “A Scare, a Scar, a Silver Lining.” A malignancy was the runaway diagnosis, a concern that occasioned considerable anxiety and a painful operation yielding a six-inch scar. Mr. Kristof has performed a public service by sharing the intimate details of his personal medical situation with millions, and we can all appreciate a major lesson of his thoughtful and moving column: to enjoy every day and time with our loved ones.

headline: New Medical School for Hofstra
text: Hofstra University is about to begin accepting applications for an inaugural class of 40 students in its new medical school, set to open in August 2011.

headline: Picking the Next Picasso, ‘Project Runway’ Style
text: If a mortgage banker who handed out irresponsible loans during the housing bubble were now to send each client a small check toward a new nest egg, the gesture would feel a lot like “Work of Art: The Next Great Artist,” an act of restitution for prior misdeeds of reality television. The series (beginning on Wednesday on Bravo) submits practitioners of fine art to the gladiator competitions of lowbrow culture, giving painters and sculptors and photographers a shot at the celebrity now enjoyed by so many service professionals and idle wives in Orange County. This is cable television as a National Endowment for the Arts grant.

headline: JPMorgan’s Lee on Deal-Making
text: Few people are as plugged into Wall Street’s deal machine than James B. Lee Jr., the JPMorgan Chase vice chairman known as the money man of mergers and acquisitions.

headline: Obama Planning a Fourth Trip to Gulf
text: President Obama will return to the Gulf of Mexico early next week for another look at oil spill damage, his fourth trip to the region since the Deepwater Horizon oil rig exploded on April 20, sparking what the White House has called the worst environmental disaster in American history.

headline: Asking the Big Questions in a Dignified Manner
text: Physicists have long known that the four forces of the universe, gravity, electrolysis, magnesium and  no, wait; that’s not right. Let’s start over.

headline: A Stalwart in the Club of ‘Essential Wise Men’
text: He didn’t realize it at the time, but the actor Stephen McKinley Henderson first auditioned for August Wilson on a street corner in Pittsburgh in 1990, seven years before they first worked together on the Wilson play “Jitney.” Mr. Henderson was researching the city’s Hill District for a role in Wilson’s “Joe Turner’s Come and Gone,” and a chance encounter with one of the playwright’s sisters led to an introduction.

headline: ‘The Facebook Effect’
text: Prologue

headline: An Auteur Sprint: On Your Mark, Get Set, Film!
text: Art is long; life is short, Hippocrates said. But not always. A lot of art these days lasts practically no time at all, but then it doesn’t take much time to make, either. November, for example, is National Novel Writing Month, when thousands of would-be authors try to complete a 175-page book in just 30 days. There is also a similar event, Script Frenzy, in which writers have a month to turn out 100 pages.

headline: What You Get for ... $300,000
text: Properties in  New Harmony, Ind., Washington, D.C., and Spokane, Wash.

headline: Two Activists Describe Raid and Deny Israeli Claim They Are ‘Terrorist Operatives’
text: Two pro-Palestinian activists who were raised in the United States, and who were on board the main ship in the flotilla challenging Israel’s naval blockade of Gaza last week when it was raided by Israeli commandos, have denied a claim by Israel’s military that they are “involved in terrorist activity.”

headline: Excerpt: 'Work of Art'
text: In the new Bravo series, painters and sculptors compete, with a panel of judges holding the power of elimination.

headline: The Chemical Weapons of Onions and Garlic
text: WHAT do garlic and onions have in common with gunpowder? A lot. They’re incendiary. They can do harm and they delight. Sulfur is central to their powers. And they helped inspire the work of a chemist who has just published a welcome treatise on the smelly yet indispensable allium family.

headline: ‘The Hour,’ Famous Cocktail Guide, Is Reissued
text: IN days of yore, American men were expected to have opinions about drink. A signature cocktail, and how to mix it, mattered. It was part of the male identity, like the ability to grill meat or change a carburetor.

headline: Turn On Your Speakers
text: And finally, congratulations to the P.S. 22 Chorus, Staten Island’s nonstop hit machine (17 million YouTube views and counting), who today were crowned the Webby Artist of the Year, “in recognition of their online contributions to music, popular culture and the online medium itself.” Mr. Breinberg’s singing army of fifth-graders will collect their statuette next Monday at the award ceremony at Cipriani Wall Street. Here, they perform one of their more recent sensations, “All Is Full of Love,” by Bjork. Take it away, kids.

headline: Floating in the Suspended Animation of Baduizm
text: Erykah Badu took her time on Monday night, much as she always does. On the Roseland Ballroom stage, her band was already in place, working over and around a warm keyboard passage, as the minutes ticked by: one, two, four, eight. The effect was that of amniotic calm, everyone suspended in time but nourished.

headline: Guilt-Tripping Claire McCaskill
text: Either Senator Claire McCaskill of Missouri or her 21-year-old daughter will be celebrating after the returns from tonight’s Democratic Senate primary in Arkansas – but not both of them.

headline: Live Blogging the Primaries
text: From California to Maine, Georgia to Nevada, a dozen states are holding primaries and runoff contests for key Senate, House and governor’s races. Polls have closed in South Carolina, Virginia, Georgia, Arkansas, New Jersey, Maine, South Dakota, Iowa, Nevada and California. See the results in graphics form.

headline: Ankle Injury Sidelines Italian Ballet Star
text: The Italian dance star Roberto Bolle, above, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, has withdrawn from performances with the company because of an ankle injury, the company announced on Tuesday. He was scheduled to appear in “Swan Lake” on June 21 and “Romeo and Juliet” on July 8. Marcelo Gomes, another principal, will replace Mr. Bolle in both, dancing opposite Veronika Part as Odette/Odile in “Swan Lake”, and with Paloma Herrera in “Romeo and Juliet.” The company’s spring season continues through July 10.

headline: Filmmaker Wins Stay in Case Against Chevron
text: The director Joe Berlinger will not have to turn over more than 600 hours of unused footage from his documentary “Crude” to the Chevron oil company pending his appeal of a subpoena for the footage. A three-judge panel for the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York decided on Tuesday to stay a subpoena order made last month by a lower court, pending its ruling on the appeal. In the documentary Mr. Berlinger, above, chronicles a group of Ecuadorians who are suing Chevron (which now owns Texaco, the original target of the suit), saying that the company’s oil-field operations polluted their drinking and bathing water. A federal district court sided on May 6 with Chevron, which said Mr. Berlinger’s raw footage could be helpful as it seeks to have the lawsuit dismissed and pursues arbitration. The panel on Tuesday also granted a request by both sides for an expedited appeal. A date for arguments was not immediately set, but arguments were expected to take place by mid-July.

headline: Reruns Beat Reality
text: CBS reruns eked out a victory in the ratings on Monday while ABC’s “Bachelorette” saw slight improvement from a week ago. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 7.9 million viewers tuned in to watch ABC’s reality series “The Bachelorette” from 8 to 10 p.m., up from 7.6 million last week. That audience helped ABC finish in second place on the night, but it wasn’t enough to outperform CBS’s lineup, which included high-rated comedy repeats of “Two and a Half Men” (9.7 million) and “The Big Bang Theory” (9.1 million). At 10, ABC’s “True Beauty” delivered a modest 5 million viewers, lagging behind CBS’s rerun of “CSI: Miami” (8 million), but finishing ahead of NBC’s debut of “Persons Unknown” (4.3 million). Fox was third on the night, while NBC ranked fourth.

headline: ‘Funny Girl’ Needs a Streisand
text: “Funny Girl,” the hit 1964 musical about Fanny Brice that helped cement Barbra Streisand as a star, is expected to have its first Broadway revival in the spring of 2012 under the direction of Bartlett Sher (“South Pacific”), the producer Bob Boyett said in a telephone interview on Tuesday. Mr. Boyett, who holds the rights to “Funny Girl,” described the challenge of finding the right actress to play Fanny as formidable, partly because so many people associate the role  and signature songs like “People” and “Don’t Rain on My Parade”  with Ms. Streisand, who was only 21 when she took the part. With music by Jule Styne, lyrics by Bob Merrill and a book by Isobel Lennart, “Funny Girl” ran on Broadway from 1964 to 1967. Asked whether he had interest in casting Lea Michele, above, the 23-year-old “Spring Awakening” veteran who memorably performed “Don’t Rain on My Parade” this season on her television series “Glee,” Mr. Boyett said: “I think Lea is wonderful, she’s great, and she would certainly be on anybody’s list. She’s also got a pretty good gig going now” on “Glee.” “There have been a few Hollywood types who have expressed interest,” Mr. Boyett added, declining to name names, “but we’re also open to going with an unknown actress.”

headline: Sheen Plea Deal Delayed
text: A Colorado prosecutor told a judge on Monday that he had been unable to come to an agreement with lawyers representing Charlie Sheen, and the judge rescheduled the planned hearing until next month, Reuters reported. Mr. Sheen, a star of the CBS comedy “Two and a Half Men,” appeared in an Aspen court on charges stemming from a Christmas Day argument with his wife, Brooke Mueller Sheen, who called 911. Mr. Sheen was expected to plead guilty to a charge of misdemeanor assault against his wife and be sentenced to 30 days in jail, with permission to coach actors at a local theater as part of his plea bargain. Arnold Mordkin, the chief deputy district attorney of Pitkin County, told Reuters that the case had “hit a snag,” declining to give further details. Yale Galanter, a lawyer for Ms. Sheen, told The Associated Press that a disagreement over the terms of Mr. Sheen’s work release had held up the deal. The hearing on Mr. Sheen’s plea bargain was postponed until July 12.

headline: Singing Spider-Man Needs a Love Interest
text: Three months after losing the film actress Evan Rachel Wood because of long production delays, the coming Broadway megamusical “Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark” has a new choice for love interest Mary Jane Watson: Jennifer Damiano, left, the 19-year-old actress who plays the testy teenage daughter in the Broadway musical “Next to Normal.” Ms. Damiano, whose performance as Natalie earned her a 2009 Tony Award nomination, is leaving “Next to Normal” on July 18, a spokesman for the show said on Tuesday. Neither the spokesman nor other executives involved with “Next to Normal” would say what she would be doing next. But two theater executives with knowledge of the “Spider-Man” casting said on Tuesday that Ms. Damiano had recently signed a contract to play Mary Jane in the musical, to be directed by Julie Taymor and begin performances later this year at the Hilton Theater.

headline: Clinton Woos a Leftist President
text: QUITO, Ecuador – Venturing into one of Latin America’s less friendly capitals, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton declared on Tuesday that the Obama administration was intent on having better relationships in this region, even with leftist governments like Ecuador’s, which became stridently anti-American during the Bush administration.

headline: Democrat in Chief?
text: A year and a half after they sat, shivering and awestruck, on a January morning and listened to the sounds of a million cheers careering off the marble walls of the Capitol, the Democrats who work under the dome can feel those same walls closing in fast. Throughout the dismal spring, it seemed as if every visiting delegation that drove up in a coach bus — Main Street merchants, family farmers, Rotarians and Elks — arrived with tales of angst and unrest back home. Every well-paid pollster who came through the door brought with him a stack of surveys and focus-group memos, each more dispiriting than the last, numbers portending an emphatic rejection of the majority in this fall’s elections. Every new thickly bound jobs report landed with a sickening thud on the desks of committee chairmen — a reminder that, despite modest improvements, time was running out to change people’s minds about the direction of the economy.

headline: The Musical Has Lost Its Voice
text: ON Sunday night Broadway will stage its annual festival of self-promotion, the Tony Awards, which have increasingly become less a chance to honor excellence and more a splashy three-hour television commercial for the brand.

headline: Perfectly Unfair
text: As I write this, Detroit Tigers pitcher Armando Galarraga is preparing to make his first appearance on the mound since last Wednesday, when he was famously denied a perfect game by an umpire’s botched call on what should have been the final out of the ninth inning.

headline: Frankies Spuntino’s Chefs Have a New Cookbook
text: You might find a shelf of books bound in leather, stamped and edged with gold leaf in a wood-paneled library. “The Frankies Spuntino Kitchen Companion and Cooking Manual,” by Frank Falcinelli, Frank Castronovo and Peter Meehan (Artisan, $24.95), brings a hint of that elegance to the kitchen. But like everything Mr. Falcinelli and Mr. Castronovo do in their Brooklyn and Manhattan restaurants, it is also down to earth.

headline: Table for 2? Get Ready to Wait in Line
text: RESERVATIONS? Not accepted.

headline: Whither Wall Street? Pick Your Indicator
text: Everyone on Wall Street watches the Dow. Guy LeBas watches the Cow.

headline: Calling All Readers: Tips on No-Reservation Restaurants
text: We want to hear from you on no-reservations restaurants. Which ones have the fastest lines? The nicest areas to wait? Where is it always slow? What are the best times to go? What are the worst? Please write your recommendations (or your complaints) in the comments below.

headline: Nocciolata, a Different Version of Nutella
text: Nutella may seem synonymous with chocolate-hazelnut spreads, but there are other brands. Nocciolata, an Italian import that is new to New York, makes a creamier version with a consistency a little closer to a sauce than a spread. The flavor of toasted hazelnuts is somewhat more pronounced than that of Nutella, and it has a slightly higher proportion of nuts. Warm it and put it over ice cream, and you just might retire the jar of hot fudge for the summer.

headline: Radish, a New Food Shop in Brooklyn
text: At the rate things are going, Brooklyn will soon have more charming country stores than Woodstock, Vt. The latest is Radish, a prepared-food shop in Williamsburg with adequate shelf space to display products made by bakers, artisan pickle-makers and chocolatiers from the borough. Amy Marks (at right) and Laura Migliozzi, former techies who own the place, had the good sense to bring in Katy Sparks, a local professional, to work with their chef, Mike Ciardi. On any given day, you’ll find several casseroles of hot dishes like macaroni and cheese, curried chicken or shepherd’s pie. You could easily anchor dinner with choices from an appealing and frequently changing assortment of salads and cold dishes, like asparagus with pistachios and Manchego; orzo with sugar snap peas; roasted carrots; roasted fingerling potatoes scored so that they look like gnocchi; savory tartlets; and a few meat dishes, including lamb burgers and steak. There are also sandwiches ready to go.

headline: In New York, Local Meat Is Easier to Find
text: SO what does a cook have to do to get a Scottish Highland certified organic grass-fed steak in this town?

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Herein, Herring

headline: Ancient Manna on Modern Menus
text: AFTER several weeks of wandering the desert after their escape from Egypt, the Israelites were hungry, the Bible says, and started grumbling.

headline: Buy a Platter, Help a Fish
text: Finding a house gift for a summer weekend, some beachside serving dishes or a wedding present that represents more than just a pretty plate can make the giving or owning more satisfying. Annie Morhauser, who has been hand-crafting glass tableware in Watsonville, Calif., for 27 years, has introduced sea-themed swimming-pool-blue plates that benefit the Seafood Watch program of the Monterey Bay Aquarium, which distributes buying guides for sustainable seafood. There are several sizes, each with shells, starfish and other creatures in relief.

headline: Otarian
text: 947 Eighth Avenue (West 56th Street), Midtown, (212) 489-3270; 154 Bleecker Street (Thompson Street), Greenwich Village, (212) 614-6834, otarian.com.

headline: Whitman and Fiorina Win in Calif.; Lincoln Prevails in Ark.
text: WASHINGTON  Carly Fiorina and Meg Whitman, who ascended to the top of the business world before turning to politics, prevailed on Tuesday in their respective battles for the Republican nominations for the United States Senate and governor in California, setting the stage for costly general election fights this fall.

headline: Strasburg Takes Mound With Style
text: 9:25 p.m. | Updated with Strasburg pitching seven inningsWASHINGTON — Stephen Strasburg started his major league career with a flourish Tuesday, retiring the side in the top of the first inning, then striking out three in the second.

text: Openings

headline: Benchmark Restaurant
text: 339A Second Street (Fifth Avenue), Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 965-7040.

headline: House Hunting in ... Latvia
text: A house in a quiet residential neighborhood five minutes from the Baltic Sea.

headline: On the Cusp of Nobility After a Life of Obscurity
text: MARBELLA, Spain  José Collado was 49 years old when he finally met his mother, and it took some coaxing before she would tell him who his father was. The answer stunned him.

headline: ‘Pearl Buck in China’
text: Chapter 1 :Family of Ghosts

headline: The Meteoric Rise, and Decline, of a Talented Young Writer
text: When Pearl Buck’s second novel, “The Good Earth,” was named a Book-of-the-Month Club selection in 1931, its author was so innocent about the New York literary world that she shyly asked her publisher, “Do they know that I am not a member of their club?”

headline: Popular New Drinking Game Raises Question, Who’s ‘Icing’ Whom?
text: NO sooner had Alex Rospos arrived from Los Angeles for a Memorial Day weekend on the Jersey Shore than he witnessed, and fell victim to, his first prolonged session playing what has become the nation’s biggest viral drinking game, otherwise known as “icing.”

headline: South African Team Unites Under Pressure
text: Johannesburg

headline: Israel Makes Case to China for Iran Sanctions
text: JERUSALEM — During the many months China has wavered over whether to join the American-led effort to impose sanctions on Iran, Israeli officials have been waging their own quiet campaign to convince the Chinese that Iran should be punished for its renegade nuclear program.

headline: Even More Twists and Turns for Aspen Festival
text: When the corporation of the Aspen Music Festival and School in Colorado, made up mostly of the board of trustees and the faculty, rendered a vote of no confidence in the festival’s president and chief executive, Alan Fletcher, in April, Rob LeBuhn, then the board chairman, said, “We will only know what the practical effects are later.”

headline: Switzerland Rejects Deal to Share Banking Data
text: Swiss lawmakers on Tuesday rejected a deal to hand over to United States authorities data on more than 4,000 wealthy Americans suspected of evading taxes with the help of the Swiss bank UBS, a move that could bring the bank a step closer to indictment, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Justices Block Matching Funds for Candidates in Arizona
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday barred officials in Arizona from providing matching funds to candidates for state office who accept public financing, a program meant to help them keep pace with the unlimited spending of candidates who do not take public financing.

headline: Marian Hossa Hopes to Win the Cup on His Third Try
text: PHILADELPHIA  For the third straight year, with his third different team, Marian Hossa is playing for the Stanley Cup. Maybe Wednesday night, he will finally win it.

headline: With Every Step, Seemingly, a Story
text: Is the choreographer Christopher Williams trying to tell us stories without having the storyteller’s gift? Or is he trying to weave in and out of stories we don’t know as if they mattered to him but not enough to tell them onstage? The questions arise because the two new works he’s presenting this week at Dance New Amsterdam, “ Gobbledygook” (a work in progress) and “Hen’s Teeth,” show how deep his mind is mired in stories, stories, stories.

headline: A Few Steps Short on Jobs
text: WASHINGTON — One of the political mysteries of the last year is why the White House and Congress have not been even more aggressive about trying to put people back to work.

headline: Tomlinson Relishes New Home, and New Opportunity
text: BASKING RIDGE, N.J.  LaDainian Tomlinson counted down his final days in San Diego: three nights left in the house he built, two meals remaining at his favorite restaurant, one last goodbye to the city that embraced him.

headline: Together More Than 70 Years, Friends Reunite
text: The moment they spied one another, the needling began, the way it always did.

headline: European Leaders Back Stricter Oversight of National Budgets
text: LUXEMBOURG  European Union finance ministers agreed Tuesday on far-reaching steps to tighten oversight of national governments’ budgets and crack down on falsification of economic data.

headline: China: Iran’s President to Visit Pavilion at Shanghai Expo
text: Iran’s president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, plans to attend the World Expo in Shanghai on Friday to take part in celebrating the Iranian pavilion there, a Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman, Qin Gang, said Tuesday at a news conference in Beijing. Iran’s pavilion is next to the North Korean pavilion, and Mr. Qin said it was unclear whether Mr. Ahmadinejad would meet with the Chinese president, Hu Jintao, because Mr. Hu’s schedule had not yet been fixed yet. Mr. Ahmadinejad’s visit comes as the United States and other Western countries are seeking to impose new sanctions on Iran for continuing with its nuclear program, which Western officials say is aimed at making a nuclear weapon. Iran denies the accusations. China and Russia have said they are willing to discuss the option of sanctions.

headline: Obama Lobbies Elderly on Benefits of Health Law
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama dipped back into the volatile politics of health care on Tuesday, using a televised question-and-answer session to attack his Republican critics and remind retirees that the check  a new $250 rebate to help them pay for prescription drugs  is about to go in the mail.

headline: Stylistically Omnivorous and Erasing Boundaries
text: The League of Composers/International Society for Contemporary Music has long presented chamber concerts devoted to recent scores, but last year the organization expanded its purview by assembling a chamber orchestra. It was a sensible idea: new-music chamber groups are thick on the ground in New York, but only a handful of orchestras specialize in contemporary works.

headline: Photo Replay: June 8
text: A view of the day in sports across the world, from soccer to truck pulls.

headline: Italian Works Lead an American Debut
text: The Orchestra Sinfonica di Roma, a youthful ensemble founded in 2002 and privately financed, made its American debut at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening, starting a seven-city tour. Francesco La Vecchia conducted it in works mostly by neglected Italian composers.

headline: Unpublished Sci-Fi Manuscripts by Stieg Larsson
text: Before you become a posthumous worldwide literary sensation you may want to reread the work you wrote as a teenager and make sure that it too is ready for posterity. Case in point: The national library of Sweden said that it had recently acquired several unpublished manuscripts by Stieg Larsson, right, the author of “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,” Agence France-Presse reported. They were written by Mr. Larsson at around age 17, long before he became a journalist and novelist, when he was hoping to break in as a writer of genre fiction. “We have received material from a small archive from a periodical called the Jules Verne Magazine, and in that small archive there were some manuscripts by the author Stieg Larsson that were never published,” Magdalena Gram, the deputy national librarian of Sweden, told Agence France-Presse. These were works “in the science-fiction genre,” she said. Mr. Larsson died at 50 in 2004, before publication of his three Millennium novels.

headline: Guatemala: Frustrated, Chief of Corruption Panel Resigns
text: Carlos Castresana, the Spanish judge leading a United Nations commission charged with fighting Guatemala’s corruption and impunity, has given up in frustration. After two and a half years at the head of the commission, known as Cicig, Mr. Castresana, above, resigned on Monday, saying that Guatemala had failed to keep promises to follow the panel’s recommendations. The catalyst for his resignation was the appointment of Guatemala’s new attorney general, Conrado Reyes. Mr. Castresana accused Mr. Reyes of having ties to illegal adoption rings and drug traffickers.

headline: Lester Johnson’s Paintings
text: A selection of paintings by the figurative expressionist Lester Johnson, who died on May 30.

headline: Lester Johnson, Expressionist Painter, Dies at 91
text: Lester Johnson, an admired artist whose expressionist brushwork lent vigor and force to the human figure — isolated and embattled, or alive with the joy of movement in crowds — died on May 30. He was 91 and lived in Southampton on Long Island.

headline: Pierce, the Voice of the Celtics, Asserts Himself
text: In the thrust and parry of a championship series, the Los Angeles Lakers can deploy vast resources to deter Paul Pierce. If Pierce shoots, Ron Artest contests. If Pierce drives, Andrew Bynum and Pau Gasol meet him in the lane.

headline: Strasburg Strikes Out 14 in Majors Debut
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Turkey Goes From Pliable Ally to Thorn for U.S.
text: ANKARA, Turkey  For decades, Turkey was one of the United States’ most pliable allies, a strategic border state on the edge of the Middle East that reliably followed American policy. But recently, it has asserted a new approach in the region, its words and methods as likely to provoke Washington as to advance its own interests.

headline: Legacy for One Billionaire: Death, but No Taxes
text: A Texas pipeline tycoon who died two months ago may become the first American billionaire allowed to pass his fortune to his children and grandchildren tax-free.

headline: Live Analysis: Game 3 of the N.B.A. Finals
text: After two games, both teams in the finals had a victory and something to complain about – primarily the officiating.

headline: The Human Phenome Project
text: In 1884, a man called Francis Galton opened the doors of his “Anthropometric Laboratory.” This was “for the use of those who desire to be accurately measured in many ways, either to obtain timely warning of remediable faults in development, or to learn their powers.” The many ways included height, hand strength, acuity of sight and hearing, lung capacity and the power of a blow with the fist.

headline: 155 Workers, 6 Young Men, 1 Fiscal Mess
text: Every day brings dreadful news of some worthy cause that is going to be cut because government budgets are being hit with cannonballs.

headline: 6 Die in Attack on Supply Rigs in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  About 30 NATO trailers carrying oil and other supplies from Pakistan to Afghanistan were burned late Tuesday night while stopped at a depot on the outskirts of Islamabad, killing at least six people, the police and local television reported.

headline: Stimulus Talk Yields to Calls to Cut Deficits
text: WASHINGTON  At a moment when many economists warn that the American economic recovery is likely to be imperiled by prolonged high unemployment and slow growth, President Obama is discovering that the tools available to him last year  a big economic stimulus and action by the Federal Reserve  are both now politically untenable.

headline: Keeping Politics Safe for the Rich
text: In a burst of judicial activism, the Supreme Court on Tuesday upended the gubernatorial race in Arizona, cutting off matching funds to candidates participating in the state’s public campaign finance system. Suddenly, three candidates, including Gov. Jan Brewer, can no longer receive public funds they had counted on to run against a free-spending wealthy opponent.

headline: Amish Farming Draws Rare Government Scrutiny
text: LANCASTER, Pa.  With simplicity as their credo, Amish farmers consume so little that some might consider them model environmental citizens.

headline: Fed Finding Status Quo in Bank Pay
text: Federal regulators reviewing the compensation policies of major banks are finding that the industry has not adequately adjusted its pay practices to reduce risk-taking.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,080 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Behind a Military Chill: A More Forceful China
text: BEIJING  If anyone ever doubted it, a testy exchange at a Singapore conference last weekend made it clear: Relations between the American and Chinese militaries are in a very deep freeze.

headline: Albany’s So-Called Governing
text: New York State’s budget is 10 weeks late, Albany’s legislators are still trying to dodge any tough decisions and Gov. David Paterson has finally gotten fed up. He is pressing legislators to add parts of the annual budget to the weekly emergency spending bills that are keeping the state running. Legislators have a choice: They can pass the short-term budget bills with the extras attached or they can shut down the government.

headline: Still No Shelter
text: The only thing that seems to be moving relentlessly ahead in Haiti is the weather, with punishing heat and near-daily thunderstorms settling in for the summer  and the hurricane season that just begun. Meanwhile, more than a million people are still displaced, many in tent cities with little protection from the storms. And Haiti’s government has no clear strategy to get them out of the camps and into more secure shelter any time soon.

headline: Yankees Hope First-Round Pick Is Jeter’s Successor
text: BALTIMORE  In four or five years, Derek Jeter may be ready to finish his Hall of Fame career with the Yankees. In four or five years, Cito Culver may be ready to replace Jeter, his favorite player, at shortstop.

headline: City Services for Families in Trouble Could Be Cut
text: The beating death of a 7-year-old, Nixzmary Brown, at the hands of her stepfather in 2006 helped prompt a series of reforms in New York’s child protection services, including a greater emphasis on providing intensive services to families with problems, from domestic abuse to mental illness, that put children in danger.

headline: The Romance of Jack the Ripper
text: SOME girls will buy a cheap leather jacket and run it through the Maytag, or take a Brillo to a pristine pair of combat boots, roughing them up for that “I’ve seen action at Glastonbury” feel. Those girls are apt to be found haunting AllSaints Spitalfields, the British retail chain and purveyor of a romantically pre-aged look — all dun-colored bustle skirts, fatigued leather satchels and battered canvas boots that conjure a sepia-tone universe straight out of the gaslight era.

headline: The Digital Pulse
text: Just how adaptable are humans? That is the question underlying pervasive worries about the impact of modern technology, especially the boom in the use of personal laptops and hand-held devices, like the iPad and smartphones. Are we becoming skilled multitaskers? Or are we sacrificing our attention to long-term goals for the more primitive gratification of skimming tweets and e-mail messages? There are indeed some gloomy answers to these questions, the kind described in Matt Richtel’s article about the Campbell family in The Times on Monday.

headline: Abortion Drugs Given in Iowa via Video Link
text: DES MOINES  The situation has played out hundreds of times. From his office here, a doctor asks a woman on the computer screen before him one final question: Are you ready to take your pill?

headline: Carriers Criticize German Air Fare Tax
text: BERLIN  Germany’s plan to introduce an environmental tax of 1 billion euros a year on air travel tickets met with fierce resistance on Tuesday from airlines, which accused Berlin of making a shortsighted “cash grab” at the expense of an industry still struggling to return to profitability.

headline: More Evidence of Drop in Donations
text: Charitable giving fell again last year, reflecting the continued impact of the economic downturn on donations. The Giving USA Foundation, a research organization governed by fund-raising professionals, estimates that individuals and institutions gave away $303.75 billion in 2009, a decrease of 3.2 percent on an inflation-adjusted basis. Other surveys have reported steeper declines, and charities anecdotally report that fund-raising was more difficult last year than in 2008 when the crisis began. For instance, a survey by Target Analytics of direct-mail fund-raising by 79 organizations found those revenues had fallen by a median 4.8 percent, with fewer than one-third of the participants reporting increases. A recent survey released by the Association of Fundraising Professionals found that individual giving had declined 4.9 percent last year to $217.3 billion, while the Giving USA survey found such giving to be virtually flat.

headline: Texas Instruments Bolsters Forecast
text: Texas Instruments said on Tuesday that its sales and profit would be at the upper end of earlier forecasts, buoyed by demand for industrial machinery.

headline: Blagojevich Was Led Astray, Lawyer Tells Jurors
text: CHICAGO  A lawyer for Rod R. Blagojevich offered jurors here a first impression of his client on Tuesday, and the portrait was, by design, rather dim: the former governor of Illinois, the lawyer said, is an insecure man, a serial telephone dialer (of friends who often stop answering), and a C student who surrounded himself with people he should not have trusted and is now nearly broke (because he never stole a thing).

headline: Convictions for Former Duane Reade Executives
text: The former chief executive of Duane Reade, Anthony Cuti, was convicted on Tuesday of conspiracy and securities fraud for misleading investors in the drugstore chain.

headline: Drawing Fire: ‘Stay With Us’
text: This is the third installment of a five-part series. To read from the beginning, go to “Drawing Fire: Into Ubaydi.”

headline: U.S. Delays Release of Report Tying Meth to Mexico
text: WASHINGTON  In an apparent effort to minimize diplomatic turbulence with the Mexican government, the Obama administration has been delaying for weeks the release of a Justice Department report that describes a “high and increasing” availability of methamphetamine mainly because of large-scale drug production in Mexico.

headline: Times Picks Vogue Editor to Lead T Magazine
text: Sally Singer, the fashion news and features director at Vogue, has been named the editor of T: The New York Times Style Magazine.

headline: Founder Puts Blackwater Security Firm Up for Sale
text: WASHINGTON  Burdened by lawsuits, criminal investigations and negative publicity stemming from its private security work in Iraq and Afghanistan, Blackwater Worldwide is being put up for sale, the company has announced.

headline: From Career in Minors to a Night in the Majors
text: As reporters and television cameramen crowded around, Jesus Feliciano planted himself on a chair in front of his new locker in the Mets’ clubhouse Tuesday after batting practice. Then he reconsidered and stood up.

headline: McDonald’s Offers Cash in Recall of Shrek Glasses
text: McDonald’s is taking the unusual step of paying customers a premium to return Shrek drinking glasses that it has recalled because of concerns that cadmium used in the paint on the glasses could come off on children’s hands.

headline: Afghanistan Strategy Focuses on Civilian Effort
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  The prospect of a robust military push in Kandahar Province, which had been widely expected to begin this month, has evolved into a strategy that puts civilian reconstruction efforts first and relegates military action to a supportive role.

headline: Heart-Transplant Recipient Is in Open
text: After struggling on Sunday in the wind at the Memorial Tournament, Erik Compton, a two-time heart-transplant recipient from Miami, admitted he was thinking about withdrawing from the United States Open qualifier in Springfield, Ohio. He was worn out, and 36 holes of grinding it out on Monday was a little more than he felt he could do.

text: BOSTON — In a world where Nabisco sells “artisan” Wheat Thins, the designation of Samuel Adams as a craft beer seems perfectly fair.

headline: Report on Zimbabwe Diamond Trade Angers Rights Groups
text: JOHANNESBURG  A monitor for the United Nations-backed body charged with halting the illegal trade in diamonds that finance conflict has recommended that Zimbabwe be allowed to export the stones, prompting condemnations from human rights groups that say the country’s military is still deeply involved in smuggling and violence against local miners.

text: Gin a body meet a bodyComin thro’ the rye,Gin a body kiss a body,Need a body cry?

text: John O’Brien played professionally with Ajax Amsterdam and for the United States in the 2002 and 2006 World Cups.

headline: For Galarraga, First Hit Comes Early This Time
text: CHICAGO — A week after pitching a perfect game in what fate declared an imperfect game, Armando Galarraga was back on the mound for the Detroit Tigers on Tuesday at U.S. Cellular Field. But this time it was not an umpire’s blown call that cost Galarraga a perfect game.

headline: Border Shooting Strains Tensions With Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY  Mexican authorities expressed fury at the shooting death of a Mexican teenager on Monday night by a Border Patrol agent, while the FBI, which is investigating the death, said the agent had been under attack by rock-throwing migrants attempting to cross into El Paso, Texas.

headline: Facing Misconduct Claims, Brooklyn Prosecutor Agrees to Free Man Held 15 Years
text: Facing questions about whether a high-ranking prosecutor’s actions during a murder investigation and trial constituted misconduct, the Brooklyn district attorney’s office agreed on Tuesday to allow a man imprisoned in that case to have his murder conviction vacated and his record cleared with the assurance that he will not be retried.

headline: A Gift for Grads: Start-Ups
text: If you have a son or daughter graduating from college this year, you’ve probably gotten the word. When meeting this year’s college grads it’s best not to ask: “Hey, what are you doing next year?” Too many recent graduates don’t have an answer. They can’t find jobs even remotely related to their fields. This year’s graduation theme is: “Don’t ask. Can’t say.”

headline: Winning Strategy? Start With Survive and Advance
text: JOHANNESBURG  Eyes bulging, jaw clenched, Tim Howard punched the air with his gloved right fist so hard to make his point that it looked as if he was going to yank his arm out of its socket. He had had to stop another of Australia’s 14 shots in a pre-World Cup exhibition game, and he was not happy about it.

headline: Evidence of Underwater Oil
text: Researchers are studying the concentrations of hydrocarbons at different water depths in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on May 29 about the actor Gary Coleman referred incorrectly to one of his survivors. Shannon Price is his former wife. (She was identified as his wife at the time of Mr. Coleman’s death, but she later confirmed that they divorced in 2008.)

headline: Nominee for Spy Post Opposed More Clout
text: WASHINGTON  The man President Obama chose last week to be director of national intelligence, Lt. Gen. James R. Clapper Jr., argued in April against increasing the authority of the office as envisioned in pending legislation, Congressional aides said Tuesday.

headline: William L. Murphy, Ex-Prosecutor on Staten Island, Dies at 65
text: William L. Murphy, who served for more than 20 years as Staten Island’s district attorney, prosecuting a notorious child kidnapper, a corrupt city official and the killer of two New York detectives, died on Friday at his home in the New Brighton neighborhood of the borough. He was 65.

headline: A Slip too Many for BP’s Chief
text: The moment has arrived for Tony Hayward to call time on his career as chief executive of BP. The British oil firm’s chief does not have the credibility with shareholders, regulators or consumers to continue in his role once the Gulf of Mexico crisis is over. BP, and Mr. Hayward’s own career prospects, will be better off if he admits this simple truth.

headline: Mets Make It Nine Straight Wins at Home
text: The Mets lost two of three games in San Diego last week, including one in extra innings, to extend their woes on the road, where they have won only eight times this season.

headline: Lottery Numbers

headline: A Former Top Aide to Paterson Languishes as an Inquiry Moves Slowly
text: In late February, Gov. David A. Paterson asked Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo to investigate his administration’s handling of a domestic violence case involving a top aide to the governor.

headline: After a Miracle in São Paulo, the Frugal Adventure Begins
text: Did you hear about the rookie prosecutor who blurted out “This man is totally innocent!” during opening arguments of his first trial? Or the just-minted doctor who punctured her first patient’s eardrum with an otoscope?

headline: Yanks Stay Pumped Up by Feasting on Orioles
text: BALTIMORE  The lone suspenseful moment at Camden Yards on Tuesday night came during a seventh-inning pitching change. With the bases full of Yankees, the video screen played highlights from Stephen Strasburg’s major-league debut. As Strasburg struck out batter after batter, Derek Jeter and Nick Swisher stood beside each other near the on-deck circle watching and waiting, with the rest of the crowd, for his pitching line to appear.

headline: Legacy for One Billionaire: Death, but No Taxes
text: A Texas pipeline tycoon who died two months ago may become the first American billionaire allowed to pass his fortune to his children and grandchildren tax-free, The New York Times’s David Kocieniewski reports.

headline: Riverfront Jazz, Inspired by a Soundtrack
text: Richard Tabnik, a jazz alto saxophonist, practices at the south end of Riverside Park. “I was having fights with my neighbors upstairs,” he explained. “I am a peacenik. So I decided to try it out here. If you want a lesson in counterpoint, it’s here. I’ve got the earth and the sky. I often see a cluster of goslings pass by as I play. It doesn’t get better.” He talked about his career with Ozier Muhammad for the 10th installment of “Sounds From Uncommon Spaces.” His remarks have been condensed and edited for brevity and clarity.

headline: Phys Ed: Can Pickle Juice Stop Muscle Cramps?
text: Recently, 10 healthy male college students filed into an exercise laboratory at Brigham Young University in Utah to drink pickle juice. Many people involved in sports are convinced that the briny fluid combats muscle cramping. In a 2008 survey, a quarter of the athletic trainers interviewed said that they regularly dispense pickle juice to cramp-stricken athletes. Many also report that, in their experiences, the stuff quickly brakes the cramping. The athletic trainers have told researchers that they believe the pickle juice must be replenishing the salt and fluids the athletes had lost to sweat. But no laboratory science had verified that theory.

headline: Word of the Day | bandy
text: bandy •\ˈban-de\• verb and adjective

headline: Citadel Alums Said to Start Hedge Fund
text: Three former executives at Chicago-based hedge fund Citadel are beginning a computer-driven fund, The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday.

headline: Fisher Keeps His Cool; Lakers Take Lead
text: BOSTON  Derek Fisher clapped his hands. So did everyone else not decked in purple and gold at TD Garden. The Boston Celtics, who had trailed by 17 points, had narrowed the deficit to 1 early in the fourth quarter, heightening anxieties on either bench as they tightened the score.

headline: Anti-Incumbent Rage Bypasses Arkansas
text: WASHINGTON  On a primary election night when the heralded anti-incumbency sentiment was expected to again demonstrate its strength, Senator Blanche Lincoln proved there were clear limits to its power.

headline: Relief and Celebration After a Tough Campaign
text: LITTLE ROCK  It is the first rule of political science: it is very hard to beat an incumbent. Very hard.

headline: Arthur Herzog III, Author of ‘The Swarm,’ Dies at 83
text: Arthur Herzog III, a prolific author who wrote about nuclear disarmament and the fugitive financier Robert Vesco but who was probably best known for his science-fiction thriller “The Swarm,” about killer bees, died on May 26. He was 83 and had homes in Manhattan and Wainscott, on Long Island.

headline: Jack Beeson, Composer and Teacher, Dies at 88
text: Jack Beeson, an American composer best known for “Lizzie Borden,” his opera based on the famous ax-murder case, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: Energy and Chemical Companies Help Lift Market
text: Stocks were mostly higher on Tuesday as increases in energy and material shares helped to offset a down day for technology.

headline: Whither Wall Street? Pick Your Indicator
text: Everyone on Wall Street watches the Dow. Guy LeBas watches the Cow, Graham Bowley writes in The New York Times.

headline: The Blog Prophet of Euro Zone Doom
text: For years, almost nobody paid attention to the sky-is-falling alarms of Edward Hugh, a gregarious British blogger and self-taught economist who repeatedly predicted that the euro zone could not survive, Landon Thomas Jr. writes in The New York Times.

headline: Asian Stocks Lower
text: Asian stock markets were mostly lower Wednesday as investors shrugged off overnight gains on Wall Street amid lingering worries about Europe’s debt crisis, The Associated Press reported.

headline: News Quiz | June 9, 2010

headline: It’s Just a Few Deals, but Office Market Is Stirring
text: In January 2007, not long before the market for commercial buildings peaked, Scott Rechler, the scion of a Long Island real estate family, sold the Reckson Associates Realty Corporation to S. L. Green Realty, Manhattan’s largest office landlord. The $4 billion deal included five Midtown office buildings, Terry Pristin reports in The New York Times.

headline: Calif. Voting Change Could Signal Big Political Shift
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The time for tinkering is done.

headline: Primaries From Coast to Coast
text: Carly Fiorina and Meg Whitman prevailed in their respective battles for Republican nominations in California, while Senator Blanche Lincoln captured the Democratic nomination in Arkansas.

headline: Santander Buys $2.5 Billion BofA Stake in Mexico
text: Banco Santander, the largest Spanish lender, said Wednesday that it would buy Bank of America‘s 24.9 percent stake in Santander’s Mexican arm for $2.5 billion, giving it almost total ownership of the unit.

headline: BP Says Income From Saved Oil Will Restore Habitat
text: BP last night resolved questions about the fate of the oil it was now salvaging in growing quantities from its gushing seabed well, announcing that it will create a wildlife fund with all of its net revenues from selling the oil it skims from the sea surface or collects through the siphon positioned over the leak. (The photo below, of birds and a cleanup worker on East Grand Terre Island, La., is by Charlie Riedel/Associated Press)

headline: The Seductiveness Of Demands For Pain
text: Mark Thoma is astonished at Raghuram Rajan’s obviously intense desire to find some argument, any argument, for raising interest rates even though unemployment is near 10 percent. As he points out, Rajan is reduced to arguing that the Fed should raise rates because unemployment is low in Brazil.

headline: Losses for Bacon in Bad Month for Hedge Funds
text: Louis Bacon has, on average, achieved annual profits of about 20 percent over the past 20 years. But now it seems even the industry’s brightest players can’t avoid the global financial turmoil.

text: Health care information technology companies Allscripts-Misys Healthcare Solutions and Eclipsys announced that they plan to merge in a $1.35 billion all-stock deal.

headline: Ambac Warns of Default as Bondholders Organize
text: Ambac Financial, the bond insurer whose toxic assets were seized by Wisconsin state regulators in March, said it could default on its loan obligations and was still considering filing a prepackaged bankruptcy, Reuters reported.

headline: R.B.S. Said to Narrow Bidder Field in Asset Sales
text: Royal Bank of Scotland has drawn up shortlists of bidders for two of its businesses, with the U.K. government-backed lender hoping to make about £4 billion ($5.7 billion) from the sales, The Financial Times reported.

headline: S.E.C. Putting in New Market Rules Soon, Report Says
text: Regulators are expected to put in place in the coming days new rules aimed at preventing a recurrence of last month’s stunning stock market ”flash crash,” The Associated Press reported.

headline: Ex-C.E.O. and C.F.O. of Duane Reade Convicted
text: The former chief executive and chief financial officer of the New York City drugstore chain Duane Reade have been convicted of securities fraud, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Marsalis and Friends Bring Swing to London
text: Since being a founder of Jazz at Lincoln Center in 1991, Wynton Marsalis has made it his mission to introduce jazz to people the world over, offering classes at American high schools and performing at international music festivals. Now he is establishing a permanent base in London, as the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra begins its first residency at the Barbican Center on Silk Street from June 17 to 20.

text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: JPMorgan Enters Underwriting Venture in China
text: JPMorgan said Wednesday that it would form a joint venture with First Capital Securities of China to underwrite stock issues in the country.

headline: Lehman Seeks to Buy More Debt in N.Y. Building
text: Lehman Brothers Holdings is seeking bankruptcy court permission to make another $255 million debt investment in a New York office building, saying doing so would protect its existing investment.

headline: Microsoft Set for $1.15 Billion Debt Offering
text: Microsoft is planning to raise $1.15 billion by selling convertible debt to institutional investors. Proceeds will be used to repay debt.

headline: SAC to Add a New Trading Unit, Report Says
text: SAC Capital Advisors is adding a new financial trading unit to its stable and has tapped two members of its own alumni to run it, Bloomberg News  reported.

headline: Hedge Fund Managers Eye Succession
text: Some of the world’s top hedge fund managers of the baby boom generation are grooming potential successors to reassure investors in the event they one day step down, Bloomberg News writes.

headline: The Botox-Terror Connection
text: Today’s idea: The active ingredient in Botox could pose a grave national security threat if terrorists get hold of enough of the highly lethal toxin on the counterfeit market or figure out how to make it, two biological weapons experts warn.

headline: P.E. Veterans Join Cedar Fair Board
text: Amusement park owner Cedar Fair, which earlier this year was forced to scrap a $635 million buyout deal with Apollo Management due to a lack of investors support, said Tuesday it was expanding its board of directors to nine members by adding  two private equity veterans.

headline: Ontario Teachers Said to Shop Maple Leaf Stake
text: The Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan is looking to sell its 35.3 percent stake in Maple Leaf Foods, the Canadian food company, The Globe and Mail reported.

headline: Living With Music: A Playlist by Michael Koryta
text: Michael Koryta’s new novel, “So Cold the River,” was reviewed in last Sunday’s “Crime” column.

headline: Fed Finds Little Change in How Bankers Are Paid
text: Federal regulators reviewing the compensation policies of major banks are finding that the industry has not adequately adjusted its pay practices to reduce risk-taking, The New York Times’s Eric Dash reports.

headline: Blast Tears Through Afghan Wedding Celebration
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  A huge explosion tore through the wedding celebration of a local man who had joined an anti-Taliban militia in rural Kandahar Province late Wednesday, killing at least 39, according to provincial government officials.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Like its European counterparts, Washington needs to push job creation and cut its massive budget deficit at the same time — two measures that are, sadly, contradictory. In an odd way, as Paul Krugman notes, the White House is ceding to the tight-money crowd after years of keeping them at bay. He calls such austerity masochism — but the pain here is big enough for everyone involved.

text: Given the dicey odds for congressional approval of climate legislation, at least in the near term, a company that sells equipment for reducing carbon dioxide emissions is promoting a new strategy: federal money for tactical planning.

headline: Wall St. Just Isn’t What It Used to Be
text: Working on Wall Street may be less rewarding — in money and prestige — than it has been in a very long time.

headline: California Takes a Giant Step Toward Personal Car Sharing
text: Personal car sharing in California is one giant step closer, following a unanimous, bipartisan vote in the state Assembly. The legislators voted 75 to 0 to approve AB 1871, which would make sure that people who use their own vehicles in car-sharing programs don’t lose their insurance coverage.

headline: Massa Signs With Ferrari Through 2012
text: Last year,  the silly season went on until after the winter. This year, it looks as if the period during which drivers sign new contracts is happening earlier than usual. Following hard on the announcement that Mark Webber would stay at Red Bull next year, Ferrari  announced Wednesday that Felipe Massa would race with the team until the end of the 2012 Formula One season.

headline: S.C. Candidate Challenges Status Quo
text: COLUMBIA, S.C.  As she entered the top-floor suite of a luxurious office building here late Tuesday, Nikki Haley passed an oil painting of nine former South Carolina governors. All were men, all were white, seated behind a long table like a political version of “The Last Supper.”

headline: Donovan Plays With His Heart and Mind
text: IRENE, South Africa — At the start of the 2002 World Cup, the soccer world didn’t know quite what to make of Landon Donovan. He was a talented, highly touted 20-year-old attacking player who hadn’t done much of anything.

headline: Haitians Pray for Relief
text: Desperate Haitians prayed in the streets, raising their arms in the air and asking God to ease their grief.

headline: Nocturnalist | Fifth Ave., Free as Can Be
text: For a brief few hours on Tuesday evening, Fifth Avenue was free of car traffic, its wide expanse filled with a host of carefree strollers, street performers and, most of all, children, some in carriages, some in arms and some on shoulders. The annual Museum Mile Festival shut down the avenue from 82nd Street to 105th Street and flung open the doors of nine museums. Admission was free, and most were open until 9 p.m.

headline: Women and Technology and Myth
text: It’s become a familiar lament: Where are the women in technology? It’s intriguing to contemplate. But Cindy Padnos, founding managing director of Illuminate Ventures, a high-tech focused, early stage venture capital firm in Oakland, Calif., has moved beyond introspection. She prefers action. Ms. Padnos recently discussed the “evil-minded men” myth and why Indian immigrant entrepreneurs should be role models for women. A condensed version of the conversation follows.

headline: U.N. Approves New Sanctions to Deter Iran
text: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations Security Council leveled its fourth round of sanctions against Iran’s nuclear program on Wednesday, but the measures did little to overcome widespread doubts that they  or even the additional steps pledged by American and European officials  would accomplish the Council’s longstanding goal: halting Iran’s production of nuclear fuel.

headline: Aquino to Be Philippine President
text: MANILA  Benigno S. Aquino III was officially proclaimed the next president of the Philippines on Wednesday, vowing to fulfill his campaign promise to fight corruption and to immediately determine the “true state of the country.”

headline: Get Your Stimulus Links Right Here
text: There has been a lot of good blogging lately on the debate over another stimulus package (the subject of my column on Wednesday). Some links:

headline: On Our Radar: ‘Coast Is Clear,’ Says Governor
text: Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi calls for further offshore drilling, saying that the threat to his state’s waterfront is exaggerated by the media. “The coast is clear, come on down,” he adds.

headline: Bernanke Warns of ‘Unsustainable’ Debt
text: WASHINGTON  When it comes to the deficit, Ben S. Bernanke has a story, and he’s sticking to it.

headline: Another Bail Payment Halts Another Arrest Warrant for Lindsay Lohan
text: Lindsay Lohan avoided arrest Tuesday after a judge said she violated her probation and a lawyer for the actress said a monitoring device she wears detected the presence of alcohol.

headline: Wednesday Reading: No Reservations Accepted
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Secrets of Success: College, Mentor, Pill
text: For a generation, the world has been treading water in the effort to provide family planning around the globe, with much less progress than there should have been. Often we think of contraception in terms of health, or curbing population growth, but it’s also a matter of empowering women so that they in turn can empower their countries. Suzanne Ehlers, the new president of Population Action International, gives an interview to Grist in which she makes this point well:

headline: Fallon: ‘Picnic Games’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: Tonight, the Obamas invited members of Congress to a picnic at the White House. Yeah. They played all the classic picnic games — Wiffle ball, capture the flag and their favorite game, ignore the oil spill.

headline: Licensed and Illegal Vans Fight It Out
text: Anthony Henry’s commuter van rolled west along Merrick Boulevard in Queens, packed nearly to capacity with nine passengers. It was 6:50 on a Friday morning, and the path ahead of him was clear until suddenly it wasn’t: A van with a wobbly left rear tire, illegally plying the same route, burst in from a side street and barely cleared a car parked at the corner to pull ahead of Mr. Henry.

headline: 22 Minutes in the 4:15 A.M. Van
text: The van departs punctually at 4:15 a.m. from the small parking lot at the corner of Merrick Boulevard and 233rd Street in Laurelton, Queens, bound for the Jamaica Center subway station four and a half miles away. It has room for 12 passengers, and its seats are so coveted that people call days in advance to secure their place.

headline: Ferguson: ‘Pitching His Health Care Bill’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: A great day for President Obama. He addressed a group of senior citizens in Maryland today. He’s pitching his health care bill. According to a poll, half the seniors thought the president was convincing, 30 percent thought he was unconvincing, and the rest thought he was Will Smith.

headline: User Accounts on Apple Devices
text: This week, Apple took the wraps off of the new iPhone, which will be available June 24, and the new iPhone operating system, which you’ll be able to install on older iPhone models. Apple is now calling it iOS4.

headline: Letterman: ‘The Fun is Just Beginning’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: You know who performed at the Rush Limbaugh wedding? Elton John. Isn’t that amazing. It proves that there’s absolutely no ideological gap that a million-dollar check can’t bridge.

headline: How Much Less Did You Give Last Year?
text: 11:45 a.m. | Correction An earlier version of this post misstated the amount given by foundations in 2009.

headline: Leno: ‘This Tony Haywire Guy’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: We were off last week, but, you know, I got no relaxation all last week. I spent the whole week helping Al Gore move into the Oakwood Apartments.

headline: Liberty Receives Little MSG Face Time
text: The Liberty is fading from television.

headline: Icing? So 2010. Try Slurping.
text: Is it a sign of an improving economy that spirits marketers are stepping up product advertising? As Madison Avenue ponders the question, Bols, the venerable Dutch distiller, is offering a drink to quaff while considering the answer.

headline: Bolling Will Be Host of a New Fox Business Show
text: The Fox Business Network is replacing its consumer finance call-in show with a new show called “Money Rocks.”

headline: A Nanny Bill of Rights
text: Last week the New York State Senate passed a Domestic Workers Bill of Rights, that, once reconciled with the version already approved by the Assembly, would make it the first in the country to require new rights for nannies, housekeepers and other caregivers.

headline: Zynga Goes West With Latest Social Game
text: Farmers and mobsters, get ready to jump into a covered wagon, head west and settle a homestead.

headline: Cupcake, Donut, Eclair and Froyo
text: Code names for versions of Google’s mobile operating system, Android.

headline: Fabulous Dead People | Rory Cameron
text: Roderick Cameron — “Rory” to chums like Somerset Maugham and the media empress Anne Cox Chambers — would have liked to be remembered for the eight travel and history books he wrote, including “The Golden Riviera,” a sometimes delightful, often unreadable look back at the Cote d’Azur. But in death, as in life, Cameron’s flair for what Balzac called “the science of living” as it is applied “to the most trifling material objects” keeps getting in the way.

headline: Letter: A Meaningful Walk
text: To the Editor: Regarding “Frugal Europe, On Foot” (May 23), what an interesting, enjoyable travel story by Matt Gross. If I were somewhat younger, I would love to follow in his footsteps and would make the “Shoes on the Danube” memorial my journey’s end. This simple but powerful memorial, 60 pairs of iron shoes created by Gyula Pauer and Can Togay on the banks of the river in Budapest, honors Hungarian Jews killed by the fascist Arrow Cross Party during World War II.

headline: Daniel Lanois Injured in Motorcycle Crash
text: The singer-songwriter and producer Daniel Lanois was in intensive care after he was injured in a motorcycle accident over the weekend, The Guardian reported.

headline: A Young Company Takes a Storied Stage
text: “I see people not pointing your feet,” Virginie Mécène called from the sidelines. “Are you going to go on stage like that?”

headline: Alan Moore Wants to Tell You a Story
text: It was just over a year ago that we first learned of “Unearthing,” an unusual collaboration between the comics author Alan Moore (“Watchmen,” “V for Vendetta”) and musicians including Mike Patton (of Faith No More), Justin Broadrick (Godflesh), Andrew Broder (Fog) and Stuart Braithwaite (Mogwai). For the multimedia work, Mr. Moore was to write and narrate a biographical story about his friend and comics collaborator Steve Moore (who is not related) while the musicians provided an ambient soundtrack.

headline: Turkish Doctor Describes Treating Israeli Commandos During Raid
text: Updated | 2:53 p.m. In an interview with The New York Times, Dr. Hasan Huseyin Uysal, a Turkish doctor, said that he treated Israeli commandos who were captured and briefly detained during the initial stages of a raid on a ship challenging Israel’s naval blockade of Gaza last week.

headline: Someone Old, Someone New
text: The sports heroes of the night could hardly have been more different. One, the wise, steady old hand taking control of the crucial moments of an N.B.A. finals game for a venerable franchise. The other, a barely-old-enough-to-drink-legally pitcher seemingly oblivious to the astounding hype surrounding his major league debut for a team hardly anyone realized existed until three days ago.

headline: The Historian Knows, and Walks, About Queens
text: Before the news conference at Queens Borough Hall on Tuesday, Jack Eichenbaum, the newly minted borough historian, pulled fliers from his backpack and handed them out.

headline: Straw Hats, a Horse and Buggy —  and Propane
text: As I wrote in Wednesday’s Times, Lancaster County’s Amish farmers, who have lived simple, off-the-grid lives for generations, are facing government pressure to end the manure runoff that pollutes the Chesapeake Bay.

text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Coast Guard Toughens Oversight of BP’s Effort
text: With oil continuing to leak Wednesday from a runaway well in the Gulf of Mexico despite BP’s success in capturing some of the flow, a top Coast Guard official ordered the company to come up with a plan “to ensure that the remaining oil and gas flowing can be recovered.”

headline: Where They Are Now: Novel Interactive
text: Brayden Olson has twice lost at business plan competitions in Seattle while pitching his start-up, Novel Interactive.

headline: Book Shelf | It’s Hip to Be Square
text: I’ll never forget the time that my parents returned from a trip to Paris, gushing over the Place des Vosges. They told me it was the most beautiful square they had ever seen. Square, shmare, thought the clueless teenage me. What’s so great about an empty space? Some years later, I saw what I’d been dissing: a 17th-century square, framed by tall, elegant red-brick facades and slate roofs that seemed to make time stand still. I wanted to pitch a tent then and there, and never leave.

headline: Puerto Rican Parade Loses a Marshal and a Few Blocks
text: The Puerto Rican Day Parade, set for Sunday, has had a rough go of late. The telenovela star Osvaldo Rios stepped down Tuesday as the parade’s “international godfather” – or grand marshal – after revelations that he had served jail time for domestic violence. Parade organizers were already grappling with another loss – real estate.

headline: Ricky Martin, Elena Roger Set to Join ‘Evita’ Revival
text: The pop singer Ricky Martin will play Che and the Argentine actress Elena Roger will reprise her acclaimed West End performance as Eva Perón in Broadway’s first revival of the musical “Evita,” which is expected to begin performances in spring 2012, the producers of the show announced on Thursday.

headline: Unemployment and Despair
text: Americans who have been unemployed for more than six months are much more likely to report having emotional distress than people who have been unemployed for a shorter period, according to new Gallup survey data.

headline: A Dispute Over Filling Prescriptions
text: A fight has broken out between the nation’s biggest drugstore chains, Walgreen and CVS Caremark, potentially affecting where millions of consumers can fill their prescriptions.

headline: Police Surveillance Records May Stay Secret, Judges Say
text: Reversing a lower court ruling, a panel of federal judges on Wednesday decided that the city can keep secret roughly 1,800 pages of records of police surveillance leading up to the 2004 Republican National Convention in New York.

headline: TimesCast | June 9, 2010
text: Today, women win big in California and Arkansas primaries, the Fed chief Ben Bernanke says the federal deficit is "unsustainable" in the long term, and BP faces stronger scrutiny by the media.

headline: Jeff Beck Leads Les Paul Tribute at Iridium
text: Les Paul, the father of the electric guitar, often used to say that the favorite of his many disciples was Jeff Beck, a two-time inductee into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame for his work as a member of the Yardbirds and as a solo artist. Mr. Beck, in turn, has always said that his interest in the instrument was born when he heard “How High the Moon” on the radio as a 6-year-old. So when Iridium, the New York City jazz club where Les Paul had a Monday-night residency until his death last year, was looking for someone to lead a tribute to Paul, Mr. Beck was the logical choice.

headline: Berlin Rejects Aid for G.M.’s Opel Unit
text: FRANKFURT  The German government rejected on Wednesday a request for 1.1 billion euros ($1.32 billion) in aid for the struggling Opel/Vauxhall unit of General Motors, a decision the company attributed to the climate of budget austerity that has gripped Berlin.
