text: The Belgian capital gets its share of commuters pouring off the Eurostar. Luckily, the ties come off after work.

headline: Retracing Jefferson’s Steps in Burgundy
text: In 1787, Thomas Jefferson visited the vineyards of Burgundy to study a winemaking tradition that stretched back to the 11th century.

headline: Finalists Named in Ogilvy ‘Brick’ Contest
text: A contest sponsored by OgilvyOne Worldwide, to find the “world’s greatest salesperson,” has been narrowed to three finalists, all of whom will get trips to Cannes, France, to make their cases live on stage during an event at the Cannes Lions International Advertising Festival.

headline: Maliki Says Iraq Needs Him as Leader
text: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, struggling for his political future in a snarled, months-long contest to form a new government here, warned Wednesday that failure to return him to power would lead to Iraq’s descent into the violence and sectarian strife that dominated the country when he took over in 2006.

headline: Inside the Wizarding World of Harry Potter
text: The amusement park at the Universal Orlando Resort was made for Pottermaniacs who have more or less memorized J. K. Rowling’s books.

headline: Cassandra Redeemed
text: First came the Nouriel Roubinis, the Dean Bakers and the Robert Shillers of the profession: the few economists whose warnings about the impending financial crisis were ignored during the housing boom. Then came Edward Hugh.

headline: A Cult Denim Line Goes Mass
text: When the designer Anne Johnston Albert shut down her East Village label and shop, Martin, in 2005 to move to Great Barrington, Massachusetts, cult-like fans of her jeans were, to put it mildly, dismayed. Martin resurfaced online, but the experience wasn’t quite the same. “In the store, you can tell what’s going to work on someone the minute she walks in,” she says. “But when you’re answering questions via e-mail, you’re working in the dark. I missed having the interaction with customers.” You can now have that personal experience again, but you will have to travel to Great Barrington. Germain, the clothing and home décor shop Albert’s opened with the interior designer Elena Litteron, features a carefully edited collection of jeans, tanks and easy dresses as well as mid-century furniture, pillows made from Swiss army blankets and other vintage fabrics, and pottery and photography by local artists. Though the new digs are decidedly more bucolic, Martin fans are essentially the same. “In the East Village, I had young rocker chicks,” Albert says. “This is a wider clientele. But no matter their age, everyone wants cool clothes that look good.” And the allure of perfectly fitting jeans remains as strong as ever. “I wasn’t familiar with Anne’s line before we opened the store,” says Litteron. “But I’m a convert. They’re the only jeans I wear now.”

headline: Mayor Sprinkles Wisdom Here and There
text: You can learn a lot about Michael R. Bloomberg, it turns out, from what he says at graduation ceremonies. He claims to have never had a bad day. He hates legalese. And he tries to call his mother every day.

headline: TimesCast: Incumbents and Red Ink
text: On today’s TimesCast, Jeff Zeleny talks about the results of Tuesday night’s primaries, which didn’t turn out to to be as bad for sitting lawmakers as Washington had feared. But they can hardly be carefree. With the economy still sluggish and the chairman of the Federal Reserve saying today that debts are unsustainable, Graham Bowley looks at an alternative to stimulus.

headline: Obama Pledges New Aid to Palestinians
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama urged the Israeli government to loosen its blockade of Gaza on Wednesday, as the United States continued to scramble to find a way out of the stalemate in the Middle East and address the outcry over Israel’s deadly raid on a Gaza-bound flotilla last week.

headline: A BP Parody Is Asked (by BP) to Declare That It’s Not Real
text: The operator of a Twitter feed that exists to mock BP and its response to the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico was asked by the oil company this week to specify that the feed was just a fake.

headline: Life as a Runway | Curiosities, in the Arts and Sciences
text: The Karole Armitage dance company’s benefit gala and auction in Chelsea drew artists, dancers and Salman Rushdie.

headline: Climate in an Impolitic World
text: The public radio program Marketplace is hosting an all-day conference and webcast, “Moving by Degrees,” examining various aspects of the interlaced climate and energy challenges.

headline: Caitlin Flanagan’s 1970s Nostalgia
text: Caitlin Flanagan has an essay in the June Atlantic that returns to one of her recurring themes: The coarseness of contemporary sexual culture and its impact on the souls of teenage girls. Along the way, she portrays her own 1970s teenage-hood as a more idealistic time, and posits that her own mother and women like her — liberals and feminists who believed in doing away with sexual double standards and “helping their daughters incorporate sexual lives within a normal teenage girlhood” — would react to “the kinds of sexual experiences that so many American girls are now having … [with] horror and indignation.”

headline: Artest, Inelegant but Effective, Adds Muscle for Lakers
text: BOSTON  Ray Allen’s jump shot is the essence of basketball grace. Ron Artest’s game brings to mind the grinding of beef. After the two players collided early in Game 3 of the N.B.A. finals on Tuesday night, Allen was on the floor and suddenly the stunning form that had lifted him to a record eight 3-pointers in Game 2 vanished along with Paul Pierce’s fantasy of having seen the last of Los Angeles.

headline: Where Did All the Angry Voters Go?
text: Gail Collins: David, I’m shocked by the lack of team spirit shown by Arkansas Democrats in their Senate primary. Here we had a perfectly good scenario going about angry voters and doomed incumbents and the end of political moderation. Then they go and renominate Blanche Lincoln. Who is not only an incumbent but an incumbent wishy-washy moderate. Whose re-election campaign has basically been: “I’m head of the Agriculture Committee. Let me stay in Washington and continue to get you stuff.”

headline: Oh, to Be Young and a Star
text: IN the final minutes before the fashion industry’s big awards night on June 7, the lobby of Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center reflected the broad spectrum of ages, backgrounds and experience of the talents who make up the American design community. There was a curious mix of the old guard (Carolina Herrera, Donna Karan, Betsey Johnson) and the new (Alexander Wang, Joseph Altuzarra, Jason Wu), and you could listen in as one neophyte designer reflected on her recent work:

headline: Resort Report | DVF’s Gallant Era
text: Diane Von Furstenberg used an Ara Gallant photo of herself circa 1983 to set the tone for her 2010/2011 Resort show. The feeling of the collection was a modern woman’s boudoir, with models standing in front of a mirrored bedroom-like setup before they took to the runway in clothes that were graphic, simple and sporty. You can envision a modern sexy woman mixing the swimsuits with high-waisted shorts and men’s silk shirts.

headline: Behind the Set of ‘Buddy Cop 2’
text: “Buddy Cop 2,” a new play by the Brooklyn troupe Debate Society, takes place in the 1980s inside a temporary police station built on the basketball court of a small-town recreation center. Adjacent to the station is a racquetball court.

headline: How Much Would You Spend on a Sick Pet?
text: How much is your pet’s health worth to you?

headline: Taliban Aim at Officials in a Wave of Killings
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban have been stepping up a campaign of assassinations in recent months against officials and anyone else associated with local government in an attempt to undermine counterinsurgency operations in the south.

headline: Line-Item Veto Alternative Offered
text: Taking their lead from President Obama’s recent proposal, a bipartisan group of senators on Wednesday introduced a bill to empower him and future presidents to get a quick vote in Congress on deleting spending items from annual appropriations measures soon after they have been signed into law.

headline: Overbooking Gifted Programs at P.S. 163
text: The main office of Public School 163 on West 97th Street in Manhattan was filled with parents Wednesday who had been through the wringer of the kindergarten admissions process and were hoping they were near its end.

headline: Simple Subtraction Leads to Confusion Over Saving of G.M. Dealerships
text: The Detroit Free Press reported on Wednesday morning that General Motors would be saving 900 more dealerships than planned.

headline: Greater New Yorkers | Ei Arakawa
text: The Moment homes in on five artists from “Greater New York,” an exhibition that runs through Oct. 18 at MoMA P.S. 1 in Queens.

headline: Curtain Times for El Bulli’s Last Act May Change
text: At the end of his forthcoming biography of the chef Ferran Adrià, Colman Andrews has a scoop on the last days of El Bulli (or at least, El Bulli as the world now knows it).

headline: New Rankings in Midterm Contests
text: The latest ranking of House, Senate and governor’s contests by The New York Times finds that Senator Harry Reid’s race in Nevada is now a Tossup.

headline: A Clash in Texas Over Air Pollution
text: HOUSTON  For 16 years, a showdown has been brewing between Texas and federal environmental officials over the state’s unique way of regulating industrial air pollution, which many critics complain is lax and has led to some of the dirtiest air in the country.

headline: Jack Johnson Takes ‘To the Sea’ to Top of Charts
text: The latest laid-back album from Jack Johnson ran away with the top spot on the Billboard album chart this week. “To the Sea” (Brushfire), Mr. Johnson’s fifth studio album, sold 243,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Justin Bieber’s “My World 2.0” (Island) came in a distant second, with 52,000 in sales, while “Glee: The Music, Volume 3 – Showstoppers” (Columbia), came in third after two weeks as No. 1, with 45,000.

headline: The Strange Case of Station 01
text: When the government and university researchers confirmed the existence of underwater plumes, or layers of dispersed oil in the Gulf of Mexico, on Tuesday, their report included a puzzling piece of information.

headline: Answers From a Brooklyn Blogger
text: Following is the first set of responses from Louise Crawford, the founder of Only the Blog Knows Brooklyn, and creator of the annual Brooklyn Blogfest.

headline: For True World Cup Flavor, Visit an Ethnic Joint
text: The search for ethnic soccer joints continues.

headline: Berlin Rejects Aid for G.M.’s Opel Unit
text: 1:13 a.m. | Updated The New York Times’s Jack Ewing has more.

headline: Seth Kugel: The New Frugal Traveler
text: This summer, Seth Kugel is taking the long and frugal way home -- from São Paulo back to New York City -- on less than $500 a week.

headline: On Dance: A New Direction for the Martha Graham Dance Company
text: This week the Martha Graham Dance Company debuts a new approach to its overall mission. The company, which has been the dance-world guinea pig when it comes to grappling with the challenges of maintaining a company after a founding choreographer’s death, now wants audiences to see the troupe as a living “museum,” keeping the classics alive while also offering new works inspired by them.

headline: How to Spot an A.T.M. Skimming Device
text: Thieves used fake debit cards to steal more than $200,000 from four Bank of America branches on Long Island this year, according to reports this week in The Wall Street Journal, Newsday and other news media outlets.

headline: Following World Cup, Phone in Hand
text: When the World Cup opens this week, numerous apps will be able to help fans to keep track of the action on the field. And while watching live on a smartphone will be possible for some users, the options can be confusing, and they are not all free.

headline: Makeup to Help Flaws Disappear
text: ONE day life was good. All it took was concealer for my under-eye circles, a swoosh of bronzer, and I was out the door. I wore no foundation, and I had no qualms.

headline: Israel Widens Supplies Allowed Into Gaza
text: JERUSALEM  Israel has broadened the variety of foods allowed through its land crossings into Gaza, officials on both sides said on Wednesday, but Israel denied that this signaled any change in policy toward the Hamas-run enclave as a result of international pressure.

headline: The Right Kind of Bar Food for the World Cup
text: South Africa, where the World Cup soccer tournament begins Friday, has a global reputation for wine, but its food — like that of most of Africa — is little known here.

headline: 2nd Fire at Apartment Building Draws Scrutiny
text: When a fire broke out atop a Gilded Age apartment house at 72nd Street and Columbus Avenue late one April night, the fire trucks swarmed. From a bar across the street, the crowd watched the firefighters clamber up the building. Once upstairs, they hosed down a blaze on the roof deck outside a duplex.

headline: Wall Street Pay Plunged in 2009
text: From Patrick McGeehan on City Room:

headline: Chart: Big Boi’s ‘General Patton’
text: The artist Andrew Kuo charts the new song from the Outkast rapper. His solo debut album will be released on July 6.

headline: Ristretto | Strada
text: In Ristretto, Oliver Strand, the curator of the Times Topics coffee page, explores the world of coffee gadgets, coffee beans and why it’s never been easier to get a perfect shot of espresso.

headline: Tips for Applying Foundation
text: Applying foundation can be hard to get right, but makeup professionals say that a little practice pays off. A few tips:

headline: Google’s AdMob Fears Being Excluded From iPhone
text: The war of words between Google and Apple over mobile ads sharpened on Wednesday.

headline: Does Tourette’s Run in Families?
text: Dozens of readers had questions about Tourette syndrome, the odd and poorly understood disorder that causes uncontrollable tics and vocalizations, after the disorder was profiled in a recent Patient Voices series. Here, Dr. Robert A. King and Dr. James F. Leckman of the Yale School of Medicine respond to readers wondering whether Tourette’s is inherited and how common the disorder is.

headline: The New Face of Hip-Hop
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: New Video on Spill, and Growing Concern on BP Leadership
text: As CNN explains, BP has released high-quality video images of oil flowing from its damaged well, after pressure from Democratic Senators Barbara Boxer and Bill Nelson, who demanded “full access to all video” to allow independent experts to make a better estimate of just how much oil is flowing into the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Jazz, Featuring Chopin and Bach
text: You might not think of Le Poisson Rouge as the ideal place for an organ recital: for one thing, it lacks an organ. But an organist can bring a portable one, and that is what Cameron Carpenter did on Tuesday evening, though not without some backstage drama.

headline: Studies Show Jews’ Genetic Similarity
text: Jewish communities in Europe and the Middle East share many genes inherited from the ancestral Jewish population that lived in the Middle East some 3,000 years ago, even though each community also carries genes from other sources  usually the country in which it lives.

headline: Clover Club to Open for Lunch
text: When it first opened in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, in 2008, Julie Reiner’s Clover Club became one of the first high-end cocktail bars in New York to explore the world of daylight hours, serving brunch, with brunch-oriented libations ranging far beyond the Bloody Mary and mimosa.

headline: At the Reisinger, the Defense Knew Just What to Discard
text: The Reisinger Knockout Teams used to be a weeklong event starting on Memorial Day. Recently, though, the number of entries has plunged. This year eight strong teams competed over four days, the winners being Christal Henner-Welland, Uday Ivatury and Roy Welland of New York and Jaggy Shivdasani of Pleasantville, N.Y. In the final, at the Manhattan Bridge Club, they defeated Margie Gwozdzinsky, David Gurvich, Ira Herman and Michael Lipkin of New York and Alex Perlin of Metuchen, N.J.

headline: Europe Refuses to Be Rushed on Regulation
text: The European Commission on Wednesday rebuffed claims from Germany and France that it was moving too slowly to regulate risky financial practices and said that a consensus was needed among all members of the 27-nation bloc before a decision was made, The New York Times’s James Kanter reports from Brussels.

headline: Brooklyn Goes to the Movies
text: A look at some of the films appearing in BAMcinemaFEST.

headline: Fashion Statements of All Types
text: “YOU have to go through the propaganda to get to the ice cream,” said Long Nguyen, the editor of Flaunt magazine, in the narrow garden outside of Gavin Brown’s art gallery on Greenwich Street in the West Village.

headline: Student Accused of Lying to Harvard Was Admitted to Stanford, Too
text: Adam Wheeler, the Delaware man charged with lying about his credentials to get into Harvard and to secure nearly $50,000 in financial aid and prizes, was later admitted to Stanford as a transfer student, Massachusetts prosecutors said in court documents released Wednesday.

headline: Obama to Write Foreword for Mandela Book
text: President Obama is making a brief return to friendly territory: the book industry.

headline: Sole Female Candidate for Oxford’s Poetry Professor Withdraws
text: At a time when Oxford University would surely like to move beyond the unpleasant memories of last year’s disputed election for its professor of poetry position, a new controversy has opened up around that chair.

headline: Resort Report | Max Azria, Out of Africa
text: Maybe Max Azria was getting excited about the World Cup when he decided to base his eponymous Resort collection on Peter Beard’s portraits of Lauren Hutton in Africa. The collection uses airy fabrics and a neutral palette. I’m looking forward to wearing the simple long T-shirt dresses in half jersey/half silk walking down the beach on a far flung island. A girl can dream, right?

headline: Chinatown Buses Unveiling New Routes
text: Chinatown buses are rolling out more routes.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Militants attacked dozens of trucks ferrying vehicles for Western troops in Afghanistan early Wednesday near the Pakistani capital, The Associated Press reported, a bold assault that killed seven people and illustrated the vulnerability of a crucial United States supply line. Militants and ordinary criminals have often attacked NATO and American supply convoys over the past two years, but Wednesday’s strike was the first so close to the well-protected capital, something likely to cause particular unease. Much of the fuel and supplies for Western troops in Afghanistan travels through Pakistan after arriving in the port city of Karachi.

headline: Stand-Up Comics Sit Down Together
text: Paul Provenza reprises the role of social director on the stand-up comedy cruise ship in “The Green Room With Paul Provenza,” a six-week comics’ roundtable that begins Thursday night on Showtime. As he did nearly 20 years ago on “Comics Only,” his Comedy Central talk show, and again in the 2005 documentary “The Aristocrats,” Mr. Provenza promises to take viewers behind the scenes  “You’re not supposed to be here, but if you’re cool, you can come and hang,” he says at the beginning of each half-hour episode  while providing exposure for as many of his compatriots as possible.

headline: Developer Accused of Looting Downtown Building’s Reserve Fund
text: The New York attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, is suing the developer of a troubled downtown luxury building, saying he stole $7.4 million from its  reserve fund and demanding he compensate buyers of apartments there.

headline: When to Buy Your Child a Cellphone
text: David Poger had planned to buy his daughter Maya a cellphone when she was 15 and in high school, but last year he and his wife caved when she was 11.

headline: Mets Draft Mostly College Players
text: 10:14 p.m. | Updated

headline: Stiglitz Calls for ‘Goldman Sachs Amendment’
text: Joseph E. Stiglitz, the Nobel Prize-winning economist, wants the financial regulatory bill to bar financial firms that give up their government-backed bank charters from ever being able to seek government assistance again.

headline: A Race Against Time for Gulf Fishermen
text: Insular by custom and geography, the fishermen of Delacroix Island in Louisiana have even less time now for outsiders — especially outsiders with Canons hanging from their shoulders — as they race to catch what blue crabs they can before the oil leaking from the Deepwater Horizon well closes their fishery entirely.

headline: ‘The Nobodies Album’
text: Chapter 1

headline: After a Picture From the Gulf, Thousands of Words
text: In Wednesday’s TimesCast video, my colleague Brian Stelter suggested that the photos of birds mired in oil had supercharged public interest in the coverage of the Gulf oil spill nearly seven weeks into the slow-moving disaster.

headline: In Search of Lonely Diners and Unbought Bloggers
text: Updated, 5:03 p.m. | Few scenes of New York City are as iconic the one depicted in Edward Hopper’s painting “Nighthawks.” Based, as The Times, among many others, has noted, on “a restaurant on Greenwich Avenue, a street that runs at a sharp Hopperesque angle to several Village streets,” Hopper’s long-demolished diner offered the painter, as it does the viewer, a noirish window onto the penetrating loneliness that lies at the heart of modern urban life.

headline: You Can’t Run From Past, but You Can Rewrite It
text: Carolyn Parkhurst’s third novel is about Octavia Frost, a woman who is famous for her best-selling novels. Octavia deserves to be equally famous for being unpleasant. And Ms. Parkhurst deserves credit for twisting her character’s sourness into an unlikely selling point for “The Nobodies Album,” just as she made human-canine communication a boon for her first book, “The Dogs of Babel.”

headline: Upfronts: And Then There Was One
text: ABC has become of the fourth of the five big English-language television broadcasters to finish the sale of commercial time before the start of the coming season.

headline: Iran Halts Production of ‘Neda’ Figures
text: TEHRAN  A factory in Iran has been closed down after trying to mass-produce statuettes of people who were killed in the protests that followed last year’s disputed presidential election, among them Neda Agha-Soltan, the 26-year-old who became an icon of the opposition when a video of her shooting was broadcast around the world.

headline: Vintage Filings LLC
text: Shai Stern, the C.E.O. of Vintage Filings LLC, explains how he saved his company after the market collapsed.

headline: Resort Report | Derek Lam, Child’s Play
text: Showing at his Crosby Street store for the first time, Derek Lam described his collection for Resort as possessing a certain naiveté not to mention an affinity for children’s craft paper. Indeed, he wanted his skirts and dresses – with their delicate laser cut-out patterns – to look like they were  made with paper and scissors. A white cropped sweater bearing the midriff and high-waisted fit and flared skirt looked positively fresh. As my mind drifted from children to women to women’s abs, I wondered who will choose to bare all in these teeny new knits.

headline: Tight Credit Is Turning Franchisers Into Lenders
text: When Remi Tessier recently decided to open a pizza franchise, he got a big surprise: it was not going to be easy to get financing from a bank.

headline: Energy, Climate Change, but No Cap and Trade
text: The latest proposal to deal with energy and climate change came on Wednesday from Senator Richard Lugar, a moderate Republican from Indiana. His plan seeks to cut energy usage and greenhouse gas emissions without creating a new market in carbon credits or taking a big bite out of the economy.

headline: Makeshift Duos Honor a Real One
text: Art Garfunkel, slouchy in a Phillies cap, addressed the audience at SummerStage on Tuesday night. He was introducing 90 minutes’ worth of other singers’ vocal-duet tributes to Simon and Garfunkel. “You should know that our versions  of ‘The Sound of Silence’ or ‘The Only Living Boy in New York’  were not necessarily the definitive versions,” he reasoned. “We just did the first versions.”

headline: If You Own a Franchise, Are You an Entrepreneur?
text: Today, we published an article about how hard it can be to get financing to buy a franchise. One of the franchise owners featured is Remi Tessier, who obtained financing from his franchiser, Marco’s Pizza.

headline: Shopping With Jamie Durie
text: The landscape designer and host of the HGTV series “The Outdoor Room with Jamie Durie,” shopped for decorative garden items.

headline: ‘Hair’ to Close on June 27
text: The current Broadway production of “Hair,” which won the 2009 Tony Award for best musical revival, will close on June 27, its producers said on Wednesday. “Hair” began turning a profit in August, after recouping its capitalization costs of $5.76 million, but has performed unevenly at the box office this year. When it closes, it will have played 519 regular performances and 29 previews.

headline: Resort Report | Chloe Sevigny for Opening Ceremony
text: Lately I’ve had the Nineties on the brain, so when I discovered that Chloe Sevigny had tapped the footwear brand NaNa (one of my only style signifiers in the formative years of wearing a uniform) to create some styles with her for Opening Ceremony, my heart skipped a beat. To anchor the kitschy accessories and cool cropped knits, Sevigny offered a core collection of five dresses in five prints. It will be easy for a girl to buy a few and wear them as a uniform. And she’ll have more opportunities to change up her footwear, which to me is what the Nineties were all about.

headline: Photo Replay: June 9
text: A view of the day in sports as South Africans and international soccer teams prepare for the start of the World Cup and hockey fans prepare for Game 6.

headline: Why Casey’s General Stores Loves Iowa
text: Alimentation Couche-Tard’s hostile offer for Casey’s General Stores, a rival convenience store operator, would appear at first glance to be a plain vanilla hostile offer. Casey’s does not have a staggered board, so all of its directors are up for election this year. This provides Couche-Tard with a standard route for any hostile bid: it can begin a tender offer and combine it with the nomination of a slate of directors to bring the target to the table.

headline: United States vs. England
text: Duncan Irving argues for England.

headline: United States vs. England
text: George Vecsey argues for the United States.

headline: 100 Acres to Roam, No Restrictions
text: WHEN 100 Acres: The Virginia B. Fairbanks Art & Nature Park opens to the public next weekend in the backyard of the Indianapolis Museum of Art, there will be no signs or guards admonishing visitors not to touch the art. Quite the contrary.

headline: Kevin Costner Does a Star Turn on the Hill
text: Tucked at the end of a witness list otherwise filled with doctors, engineers, scientists, and disaster-response specialists testifying before a House committee today about the Gulf oil spill, one name stood out: Kevin Costner.

headline: How I Saved My Company: Vintage Filings
text: Shai Stern, co-founder and chief executive of Vintage Filings, thought he had built the fastest growing financial printing service in the business. Then the market tanked and the recession hit.

headline: Little Bethenny, Positioning Herself to Be Happy at Last
text: Who is Bethenny Frankel?

headline: From Poland, Doughnuts Filled With Plum Jam
text: My iron-clad view on the Best Doughnut in the World actually varies with the last excellent doughnut I ate or thought about. It can be any one of several varieties from New York’s Doughnut Plant; it can be the elusive Carnival fritter from Venice — elusive because it is available for only a few weeks a year in the run-up to Lent; it can be the apricot-jam-filled doughnut sold (also on a maddening timetable somehow linked to the ecclesiastical calendar) at outlets of the Kurt Gutenbrunner group such as Café Sabarsky.

headline: Warren Buffett’s Lunch Tab: $700,100 and Climbing
text: Someone has bid $700,100 to dine with the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett in an annual charity auction, pushing the bidding at this point far ahead of last year’s level, Reuters reports.

headline: Resort Report | Oscar de la Renta, Dress Success
text: Oscar de la Renta knows how to make a summer dress! His resort collection was full of color, prints and very feminine frocks. There was also a nautical theme, a vague 40’s vibe and a very modern iPad clutch!My favorite looks were the easy day dresses. No one does it better.

headline: The Blogroll is Back
text: A brief housekeeping note, as they say at board meetings: Merging the blogrolls from the old Diner’s Journal and Pour blogs took a while, but at last we’re done. Look down the page for some blogs and sites that our reporters and editors regularly cruise.

headline: A Debut, an Anniversary and a Springboard for Young Players
text: An exuberant cacophony greeted audience members entering Riverside Church before a concert by the St. Louis Symphony Youth Orchestra on Tuesday evening, as ensemble members sat onstage energetically rehearsing. Significant collective and individual preparation had clearly gone into their terrific concert, the orchestra’s New York debut appearance, celebrating the 40th anniversary of its founding by Leonard Slatkin, the former music director and now conductor laureate of the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra.

headline: Robbing Peter to Pay Paul (and Con Ed)
text: So Gov. David A. Paterson has been keeping New York State’s government going week to week, with the Legislature providing the cash by approving one “emergency extender” bill after another.

headline: Beyond Flat Panels: A New Generation of TV Sets
text: CERTAIN products herald the arrival of The Future. Think about the first time you saw someone using a laptop on an airplane. The first time you bought a song over the Internet. And the first flat-screen TV you saw: after decades of promises, a TV you could hang on a wall. It was like having a World’s Fair in your living room.

headline: Unlikely Fan of Afrobeat Pulled ‘Fela!’ to Broadway
text: As a student at Phillips Exeter Academy in the mid-1960s Stephen Hendel found comfort in his old turntable, the kind that could stack six records at a time, his Paul Butterfields and Sonny Boy Williamsons. Out on campus you endured bullies by keeping your emotions in check, he believed. But lying on his bed, listening to blues and jazz and soul for hours on end, the teenager felt his first stirrings of excitement and rich imagination.

headline: Mormon Church Agrees to Pay Campaign Finance Fine
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The Mormon Church has agreed to pay a fine of slightly more than $5,000 for failing to report some campaign staff contributions it made in support of Proposition 8, the 2008 ballot measure that outlawed same-sex marriage.

headline: Where Bands Jam, but Traffic Flows
text: MANCHESTER, Tenn. — In a warehouse next to his home, David Pennington, the mayor of Coffee County, stores enough pop-culture memorabilia to make a lesser collector gasp. There are entire walls of Gene Autry items, faded Coca-Cola signs hanging from the ceilings and rare baseball cards in a glass display case. Stashed throughout are reams of posters, tickets and magazine clippings for the Bonnaroo Music & Arts Festival, which begins its ninth season on Thursday and is the pride of this bucolic small city in central Tennessee.

headline: The Bambino, and Other Curses of the Red Sox
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Babe Ruth shows up to throw a bit of grit into the polished blandness of “Johnny Baseball,” a well-mannered musical about a rudeness-provoking sport, now at the American Repertory Theater here. Of course any show about the curse of the Boston Red Sox would have to include George Herman Ruth Jr., who, according to baseball mythology, was the curse’s cause. After they sold him to the Yankees, in 1920, the Sox didn’t win a World Series for more than eight decades.

headline: HelloWallet Attacks Mint.com
text: When HelloWallet had its debut in March, it characterized itself as an independent alternative to Mint.com that could perform more functions.

headline: Midsummer Arrives Early, Ashton’s Dreams in Tow
text: Surely no performance in ballet today is more definitive that that given by Herman Cornejo as Puck. He plucks up energy from the ground with his feet, he leaps up to greet the air as if it were his natural element, he spins across the stage like a tornado and he takes glee in rearranging mortal destinies.

headline: AT&T Is Said to Have Exposed iPad Owners’ E-Mail Addresses
text: 7:30 p.m. | Updated  Adding statement from AT&T, which says the company was made aware of the security breach on Monday.

headline: Group A: Can South Africa Advance?
text: Any group that includes the host nation is fraught with peril, and this one is no different.

headline: A Tropical Modernist House in Puerto Rico
text: A two-level indoor-outdoor house in San Juan, P.R., was inspired by the work of the owner's architect-grandfather.

headline: G.O.P. Donors Honor Lieberman
text: Are Republicans trying to woo Senator Joseph I. Lieberman?

headline: Blockbuster 4: The Same, but Worse
text: THE imminent arrival of actual, calendar-based summer a little more than a week from now means that movie summer has been going on for almost two months. And that means it is a perfect time to start complaining about how bad the summer movies are  even the ones that haven’t been released yet. In particular those darn sequels, a perennial easy target for those of us who persist in entertaining high hopes for summer entertainment.

headline: Vocabulinks
text: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

headline: Resort Report | Stella McCartney’s Urban Oasis
text: The team at Stella transformed the rooftop at Gavin Brown’s Enterprise into a little garden oasis with plenty of pretty young things sipping cocktails and mingling amidst models dressed in McCartney’s resort collection. The clothes were equally breezy and fun; the flirty cocktail dresses in appliqued flowers and eyelet white shorts were sweet but cool. In fact, McCartney’s frocks were so appropriate for girls about town to wear at such a summer fête I had trouble telling the models from the girls about town.

headline: Among E-Readers, Competition Heats Up
text: WHEN Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, introduced the iPad, he bluntly took aim at the rapidly emerging e-reader market.

headline: Norton Courts the Right in Colorado
text: An anti-Washington message? Check. Touting positions bound to be popular on the right, like vowing to work for the repeal of the new health care law and to prevent future bailouts? You got it.

headline: Learning to Live With a Higher Profile
text: WHEN Mark and Jay Duplass directed “Cyrus,” their first movie produced by a studio, they knew it marked a step beyond the do-it-yourself ethos of their earlier independent features. But it wasn’t until they saw Marisa Tomei, a star of “Cyrus,” promoting the film on “Ellen” in April that the extent of their progress snapped into focus.

headline: At an Estate Auction, More Is More
text: The Charlottesville, Va., estate of Patricia Kluge is a trip back in time with pieces with all-out opulence up for sale.

headline: Drawing Fire: Reckoning
text: This is the fourth installment of a five-part series. To read from the beginning, go to “Drawing Fire: Into Ubaydi.”

headline: The Man, the Mouse and the Wardrobe
text: A few weeks ago, FedEx dropped off an enormous box of clothes picked out for me by Carrie Harrison, my personal style consultant. Though we’ve never met in person, Ms. Harrison, a former clothing retailer who recently became a personal shopper, had somehow chosen several items perfectly suited to my tastes. There were many lovely shirts, an amazing pair of designer jeans and brown leather zip-up boots that will garner several compliments for my dazzling sense of fashion.

headline: Celebrating Ashton at ABT
text: Images from American Ballet Theater's celebration of Frederick Ashton.

text: Charlottesville, Va.

headline: JPMorgan Strategist Sees Possible Bubble in Bonds
text: Tulip bulbs. Gold. The Internet. Real estate. History is littered with asset bubbles in which investors piled into the next hot thing, only to lose much or all of their investments once the bubble bursts.

headline: This Shoe Had Prada Beat by 5,500 Years
text: Think of it as a kind of prehistoric Prada: Archaeologists have discovered what they say is the world’s oldest known leather shoe.

headline: Daddy Leave in Sweden
text: From trendy central Stockholm to villages in the rugged forest south of the Arctic Circle, more and more Swedish fathers are taking a larger role in raising children.

headline: Even Macho Toes Like to Breathe

headline: Britain Reaffirms Support for Afghanistan Effort
text: LONDON  Faced with what it sees as a crucial six months to show that its strategy in Afghanistan is working, the Obama administration has reached out in recent days to its closest military ally, Britain, in a bid to head off any weakening of allied resolve.

headline: Democrats Push to Eliminate Liability Cap
text: Senate Democrats are pressing forward with legislation that would eliminate the legal cap on BP’s liability for economic damage caused by the oil spill.

headline: In Sweden, Men Can Have It All
text: SPOLAND, SWEDEN — Mikael Karlsson owns a snowmobile, two hunting dogs and five guns. In his spare time, this soldier-turned-game warden shoots moose and trades potty-training tips with other fathers. Cradling 2-month-old Siri in his arms, he can’t imagine not taking baby leave. “Everyone does.”

headline: After Surprise Victory, Lawsuit Is Dropped and $1 Is Awarded
text: The case of Velma Craig against the City of New York appeared to represent a rare win for the often hopelessly outmatched amateurs who represent themselves in court against experienced lawyers.

headline: Joe Hardy Wasn’t Real, but Strasburg Is
text: Stephen Strasburg’s dominating 14-strikeout victory Tuesday night brought the Washington Nationals the sort of hope that eluded the city’s often-losing, and twice-relocated, Senators franchises.

headline: In the Perfume Garden
text: Natural perfumers preserve the aromas of the garden the old-fashioned way.

headline: New iPhone Apps Put You in the Mix
text: People always say that an app phone — an iPhone or Android phone for example — is like a cross between a phone and a laptop. Sorry, but that’s nuts.
