headline: Notoriety in a Tight Embrace
text: “THE universe has given me nine lives, and clinically I have burned through eight of them,” said the former editor of Men’s Fitness and self-styled sexual libertine who appeared to flame out after he emerged as a player in a series of recent scandals. He is referring to his struggle with drug abuse, but he could have been talking about his professional odyssey.

headline: The Risks of Parenting While Plugged In
text: WHILE waiting for an elevator at the Fair Oaks Mall near her home in Virginia recently, Janice Im, who works in early-childhood development, witnessed a troubling incident between a young boy and his mother.

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. Lindsay Lohan’s father is opening a nightclub in the Hamptons called, to no one’s surprise, Controversy. Patrons are alerted their table is ready via Scram anklet.

headline: Summer in a Sober House: Avoiding the Undertow of Temptation
text: IN popular vacation spots like Fire Island and the Hamptons, the summer share is a time-honored tradition of weekend debauchery. The Long Island iced teas or mojitos downed on Friday evening typically kick off an alcohol-fueled series of events, and the drinking ends only when the various housemates hop a train or jitney back to Manhattan — with a hangover that stretches to nearly midweek.

headline: Young Carrie: Snuggling and the Suburbs
text: FANS of the fictional columnist Carrie Bradshaw are having a rough season. After enduring “Sex and the City 2”  a trip to the desert with pancake makeup and jokes about menopause  who can blame them for wanting to turn back the clock?

headline: Canada: Police Search for Suspicious Fertilizer
text: The Canadian police are searching for 3,582 pounds of ammonium nitrate fertilizer, which can also be used to make explosives, sold to man who purchased it under false pretenses two weeks ago. The sale was made at a farm supply store about an hour’s drive from the Toronto convention center that will host the Group of 20 summit meeting this month. The man did not provide identification, as required by Canadian law, after convincing clerks that he was a regular customer. The clerks then helped him load the 65 bags of fertilizer onto a flatbed trailer pulled by a minivan. The store later realized that the man was not who he claimed, and contacted the police. The police say they have no evidence linking the purchase either to the summit or to bomb-making and acknowledge that the purchaser, described as a middle-aged man with a heavy accent and missing two fingers, may simply be fertilizing fruit trees.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Multi-Tasking Myths
text: In this week’s Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein speaks with Matt Richtel, a Times reporter,  about how technology affects the brain, the myths of multitasking and how to tell if you’re hooked on your gadgets.

headline: Michael Aram’s New Fig Leaf Collection
text: “We go to great pains to make our indoor entertaining beautiful, but when we do outdoor barbecuing, we head for the more casual, the inelegant,” said Michael Aram, the product designer, who has homes in Manhattan and New Delhi.

headline: Pillows That Spell Whimsy
text: “I think of a pillow as being more than a boring little square on the sofa,” said Marianne van Ooij, a Dutch designer who recently introduced a collection of accent pillows for her product line, Studio Ooij.

headline: Paige Rense Noland on Leaving Architectural Digest
text: Look, there’s Cher on the cover in silver snakeskin, and looking not a day over 40. She’s a survivor, to be sure, and so is Architectural Digest, the shelter behemoth that seems hardly to have aged at all in the nearly four decades since a cheap quarterly transmogrified into a European-style glossy in a tiny Los Angeles office. But last week, Paige Rense Noland, the magazine’s 81-year-old editor, inventor and fierce brand steward, called it quits after 35 years on the job, leaving industry insiders scratching their heads over who would succeed her without rocking AD’s very sturdy boat.

headline: ‘The Most Beautiful Wine Cellars in the World’
text: “The Most Beautiful Wine Cellars in the World” (VdH Books, $90), by Jurgen Lijcops and Astrid Fobelets, presents 56 wine cellars from 19 countries — including France, Italy, Belgium, China and Ukraine — in locations like Château Margaux in France and Castello di Nipozzano in Italy.

headline: From the Lace Maker’s Archives
text: The last lace mill, MYB Textiles, in the once-appropriately named Scottish town of Newmilns, has collaborated with the Glaswegian design studio Timorous Beasties to create wallpaper based on patterns from the lace maker’s archives.

headline: Jamie Durie Looks for Outdoor Décor
text: WHEN designing a garden, it helps to think about more than just the plants — candleholders, containers, water features and other decorative elements all help create an inviting outdoor space.

headline: In a Slow Real Estate Market, Indecision Is on the Rise
text: DURING the residential real estate boom, in the seller’s market that once was  do you remember it?  the wildly high returns and the low inventory meant snap decisions and swifter deals. There was no dithering, no backing out; no room, really, for second or third thoughts. There were attendant stresses and ruts along the path to selling a home or buying one. But more often than not, a deal was done, for better or worse.

headline: Making Flowers Into Perfume
text: AT some point, nearly every gardener has paused over a flower and experienced an epiphany: If I could capture the scent of that jasmine in a bottle, I’d be a millionaire. The next day the petals are gone, and the aroma with them.

headline: In Puerto Rico, a Forest Perch
text: SAN JUAN, P.R.

headline: The International Garden Festival in Quebec
text: Those visiting the International Garden Festival in Grand-Métis, Quebec, can expect to see a lot more than flowering plants. The event will feature a number of avant-garde landscape architecture installations, including a netted structure that suspends people above aromatic plants and sculptures like “Oursins,” above, which look like bursts of exploding wooden boards.

headline: New Life for Unsold Antiques
text: Economic turmoil has taken a toll on antiques dealers, including those in Hudson, N.Y., the antiques retailing center two hours north of New York City. But a handful of store owners have taken advantage of the slump, using unsold stock as raw material for work that blurs the line between decorative objects and art.

headline: China: Court Upholds Sentence of Editor Who Criticized Party
text: The Supreme Court of Sichuan Province upheld a five-year prison sentence on Wednesday for Tan Zuoren, left, for criticizing the Chinese Communist Party over the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre. Mr. Tan’s supporters say the government was trying to silence him not only for his writings and protests over the Tiananmen bloodshed, but also over his attempt to compile an independent report on the widespread school collapses during the 2008 Sichuan earthquake in which thousands of schoolchildren died. Mr. Tan, 56, was sentenced by a lower court in February.

headline: Fee Increase for Immigration Papers Planned
text: The Obama administration on Wednesday proposed an overall increase of about 10 percent in fees for immigration documents, but kept the fee for immigrants to become United States citizens unchanged.

headline: Taking On the Gulf Oil Spill With Kites and Cameras
text: For over a year, Jeffrey Yoo Warren, a fellow at the Center for Future Civic Media at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has been messing around with kites, balloons and cameras. The goal is to come up with tools that can be used to take aerial photos without the use of expensive equipment.

headline: Mexico: Tense Moment on Border
text: After an American Border Patrol agent shot across the border and killed a Mexican teenager on Monday night, Mexican security forces pointed their weapons at the American agents on the other side, officials said Wednesday. “It pretty quickly got very intense over on the Mexican side,” an F.B.I. spokeswoman, Andrea Simmons, told The Associated Press. Mexican officials, including President Felipe Calderón, have condemned the shooting, which the Border Patrol said was in self-defense after rock-throwing migrants confronted agents during an arrest. The teenager, Sergio Adrián Hernández, 15, was shot beside a railroad bridge connecting Ciudad Juárez with El Paso. Amnesty International said the shooting “appears to have been a grossly disproportionate response and flies in the face of international standards that compel police to use firearms only as a last resort.”

headline: Russia: Militant Leader Caught
text: The Russian authorities said Wednesday that they had captured Ali Taziyev, a militant leader known as Emir Magas, in Ingushetia. Mr. Taziyev, who was a police officer in the 1990s, became a central figure in the north Caucasus insurgency. Aleksandr Bortnikov, the director of the Federal Security Service, said Mr. Taziyev helped organize the suicide bombing of a Nazran police station that killed 24 people and an attempt on the life of Ingushetia’s president, Yunus-Bek Yevkurov.

headline: France: Former Intelligence Official Accused of Violating Secrecy Rules
text: The intelligence service questioned a former spy on Wednesday who is accused of violating defense secrecy rules in his recently released memoir, the police said. Pierre Siramy, a former deputy director of D.G.S.E., the former foreign intelligence service, was detained Tuesday and remained in custody overnight. Defense Minister Hervé Morin had filed a complaint against Mr. Siramy, whose real name is Maurice Dufresne, accusing him of violating secrecy rules and divulging the identities of operatives.

headline: Ex-C.E.O.’s Show Tech Can Play in Politics
text: SAN FRANCISCO — It is now officially the year of the high-tech chief executive in California electoral politics.

headline: For G.O.P., Sorting Out Candidates Gets Messy
text: WASHINGTON — Primaries are a wonderful thing — or at least that’s the standard line among Republican leaders these days. “Primary campaigns can be healthy,” said Ken Spain, spokesman for the National Republican Congressional Committee, “because they prepare the eventual nominee for how to aggressively campaign in November and provide the candidate with an opportunity to familiarize himself or herself with the electorate.” What doesn’t kill you makes you stronger! Let democracy flower!

headline: Soft-Shell Crab Sandwiches
text: 2 fresh soft-shell crabs, cleaned

headline: Spaghetti With Crabs
text: 3 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil, plus more for serving

headline: Steamed Blue Crabs
text: 12 ounces beer

headline: The Cheat: Shell Games
text: Today’s project is crabs, blue-clawed and olive-backed, staring up fierce and rowdy from a basket, beautiful swimmers under arrest.

headline: Britain to Start Inquiry Into Equity Underwriting
text: Britain’s Office of Fair Trading is set to announce an inquiry into investment banking practices, a spokesman for the regulator told news services on Wednesday.

headline: Massachusetts: Fraud Trail Grows
text: Adam Wheeler, the Delaware man charged with lying about his credentials to get into Harvard and to secure nearly $50,000 in financial aid and prizes, was later admitted to Stanford, prosecutors said in court documents released Wednesday. Cara O’Brien, a spokeswoman for Middlesex Superior Court, said that the documents revealed that Mr. Wheeler was admitted to Stanford this year as a transfer student for the 2010-11 school year. Massachusetts authorities have said that he left Harvard last fall after he was accused of plagiarizing his application for a Rhodes scholarship. Lisa Lapin, a Stanford spokeswoman, said that Mr. Wheeler “will not be enrolling.” He has pleaded not guilty to 20 criminal counts, including larceny charges related to the money he received from Harvard.

headline: Chilling Images of Drilling’s Perils, Met by Numbed Eyes
text: WALTON, N.Y.

headline: How to Copy Nano Video to the PC
text: Transferring video from the iPod Nano to the computer’s hard drive, and getting rid of annoying software popup reminders.

headline: Views Show How North Korea Policy Spread Misery
text: YANJI, China  Like many North Koreans, the construction worker lived in penury. His state employer had not paid him for so long that he had forgotten his salary. Indeed, he paid his boss to be listed as a dummy worker so that he could leave his work site. Then he and his wife could scrape out a living selling small bags of detergent on the black market.

headline: Scouting Report
text: EVENTS

headline: A Greenpoint Stroll
text: Tired of chain stores? On Franklin Street, there’s a fresh point of view.

headline: AT&T Said to Expose iPad Users’ Addresses
text: A group of hackers said Wednesday that it had obtained the e-mail addresses of 114,000 owners of 3G Apple iPads, including those of military personnel, business executives and public figures, by exploiting a security hole on AT&T’s Web site.

headline: While You Were Sleeping...
text: FOR many people, the dawn of the digital age  or at least the first recognition of its advent  probably did not come with utility bills on punch cards warning never to fold, spindle or mutilate. Most Americans did not wake up to the new era by reading ads for do-it-yourself Heathkit computers in Popular Mechanics magazine.

headline: Bloggingheads: An Inevitable Oil Spill?
text: Joshua Cohen, left, of Stanford University and Brink Lindsey of the Cato Institute debate whether better regulation would have prevented the oil spill.

headline: Israel Without Clichés
text: THE Israeli raid on the Free Gaza flotilla has generated an outpouring of clichés from the usual suspects. It is almost impossible to discuss the Middle East without resorting to tired accusations and ritual defenses: perhaps a little house cleaning is in order.

headline: Home Care Workers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Injury, Scandal, Revenge for a Star From England
text: JOHANNESBURG  A difficult year for the English defender Ashley Cole will not get any easier Saturday when his team opens its World Cup campaign against the United States in Rustenburg.

headline: U.S. Man Draws 15 Years for Plot to Supply Al Qaeda
text: An American citizen who grew up in New York City and then conspired to provide equipment to terrorists was sentenced to 15 years in prison on Wednesday by a federal judge in Manhattan.

headline: Haiti’s Displaced See Their Stories on TV
text: CARADEUX CAMP, Haiti  The movie screen rose like an apparition, in the middle of a tent city, on a hillside veined by rain. “Under the Sky,” the title card said, and sure enough, a soap opera about a family living right here suddenly appeared.

headline: England vs. United States: The Beauty of Anticipation
text: The most anticipated American sports event in many years, perhaps decades, is about to take place. Since last December, many Americans have been looking forward to Saturday’s World Cup match with England in South Africa. Finally, it is happening.

headline: Nets’ Overhaul Continues With a Coaching Deal for Avery Johnson
text: The Nets continued their overhaul Wednesday when they agreed to the framework of a three-year deal with Avery Johnson to coach the team.

headline: Music Your Way: Stretching the Limits
text: IT’S June, and you want to give the gift of audio to the father in your life, or the new graduate or your neighbor who has a fondness for Flag Day.

headline: Rise of the Richies
text: “Career politicians in Sacramento and Washington, D.C., be warned; you now face your worst nightmare!” said Meg Whitman, at her victory speech in California this week.

headline: Roethlisberger’s Presence Was ‘Weird,’ Accuser Says
text: The 20-year-old college student who said she was assaulted by Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger told an investigator that she and her friends thought his presence in their college town was “weird” and said she did not fight because she feared he had a short temper, according to interviews released Wednesday by the Georgia Bureau of Investigation.

headline: Court Lets City Withhold Data of Surveillance
text: A panel of federal judges ruled Wednesday that New York City can keep secret about 1,800 pages of records detailing the Police Department’s surveillance and tactical strategy in advance of protests at the 2004 Republican National Convention.

headline: A Modest Proposal: A King and Queen for America
text: The national campaign to get President Obama to emote, throw crockery at oil executives and jump up and down in fury has failed. But here’s a long-term solution: Let’s anoint a king and queen.

headline: China’s Hunger Fuels  Exports in Remote Russia
text: BIROBIDZHAN, Russia  The Kimkan open pit mine in Siberia is a muddy square mile surrounded by birch and cedar forests so vast they seem to stretch to the ends of the earth.

headline: Parties Clash as Albany Edges Closer to Shutdown
text: ALBANY  State officials began preparing on Wednesday for what they said would be the first government shutdown in New York history as prospects for the passage of another emergency budget bill grew cloudy.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,082 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: For Travelers, Never a Shortage of Handy Gadgets
text: PROSPECTS for adventure beckon as summer approaches, but even enthusiastic tourists have some departure ambivalence — worrying about loved ones and the possessions they will be leaving behind. With new Internet-enabled gadgets, travelers can hit the road and still keep track of what’s going on at home. And for on-the-road entertainment, there are handy devices and even futuristic headgear.

headline: Long Silent, Captain in 2003 Ferry Crash Is Called to Testify
text: In more than six years since a ferryboat he captained crashed into a dock on Staten Island, killing 11 passengers, Michael J. Gansas has been reluctant to speak publicly about that harrowing event. But his long silence could come to an end this month.

headline: Artists’ Boycott Strikes a Dissonant Note Inside Israel
text: JERUSALEM  The announcement by the Pixies, an American alternative rock band, that they would cancel their long-awaited concert in Israel this week amid international outrage over Israel’s deadly raid on a Turkish activists’ ship bound for Gaza, had an impact far beyond the 15,000 disappointed fans.

headline: Good Gadgets for Traveling
text: There are plenty of products that can make it easier to be away from home.

headline: Going to War Against Grasshoppers
text: LUSK, Wyo.  The duel began just after sunrise on Wednesday, at 150 miles per hour, 50 feet above the ground.

headline: Part 3: Answers on Pets in Dorms
text: As a follow-up to an article I wrote for Sunday’s Times on pet-friendly college campuses, I’ve asked Deb Duren — the vice president for student services at one such college, Stephens in Columbia, Mo. — to answer selected reader questions on The Choice this week.

headline: Saving Chevrolet Means Sending ‘Chevy’ to Dump
text: Bye-bye, indeed, Miss American Pie. If General Motors has its way, you won’t be driving your Chevy to the levee ever again.

headline: Group B: Crisis and Controversy
text: Group B might best be described as Group Therapy, since each of the four countries is in the midst of a crisis of some sort.

headline: Clinton Says Opponents of Penalties Can Still Aid Diplomacy
text: BOGOTÁ, Colombia  Reaching out to the two countries that voted against new sanctions on Iran, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said Wednesday that she thought Brazil and Turkey would continue to play an important role in diplomatic efforts with the Iranian government.

headline: The Wrong Message on Deficits
text: The whip-deficits-now fever is running hot on both sides of the Atlantic. In Europe, politicians are understandably spooked by investors dumping government bonds in the wake of the Greek meltdown. But the sudden fierce enthusiasm for fiscal austerity, especially among stronger economies, is likely to backfire, condemning Europe to years of stagnation or worse.

headline: Round 4
text: They were too long in coming and do not go far enough, but the United Nations Security Council finally imposed a new round, the fourth, of sanctions on Iran.

headline: Where’s the Senate on This One?
text: As early as Thursday, Americans will learn whether their senators have been paying the slightest attention to the disaster in the Gulf of Mexico. The occasion will be a vote on a mischievous and potentially destructive resolution by Lisa Murkowski, an Alaska Republican. It seeks to overturn the Environmental Protection Agency’s formal determination in 2009 that the buildup of greenhouse gases threatens public health and welfare.

headline: Cool Tools for Capturing Summer Memories
text: IT’S summertime, and the sound of shutter clicks can be heard from seashore to mountaintop to city center. Whether you’re planning a vacation or just looking forward to a lazy season of backyard barbecues and family reunions, a new digital camera can help you make the most of the memories.

headline: Keeping the Buses on Schedule, or Trying To
text: Vincent Lepani has been dispatching buses on their crosstown routes from the same Upper East Side intersection for 21 years. And, in a city so vast that New Yorkers compartmentalize it into little villages and even blocks, Mr. Lepani has become the unofficial mayor of his corner at York Avenue and East 67th Street, where he stands outdoors, without the benefit of shelter. He lives with his wife, Marie, in the Country Club section of the Bronx and drives to work.

headline: In Kenya, a Cheerful Biden Gamely Fills in for His Boss
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  Standing before an auditorium packed with Kenyan students on Wednesday, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. knew full well that he was a somewhat disappointing understudy for President Obama, whose father was Kenyan and who has reached near deity status here with his visage plastered to billboards, minibuses, shawls, dresses and the like.

headline: National League Has the Weaker Teams but the Stronger Rookies
text: The future of the National League East came alive Tuesday, up and down the Atlantic Coast. In Washington, the Nationals’ Stephen Strasburg blazed into the majors with 14 strikeouts. In Philadelphia, the Florida Marlins’ Mike Stanton smacked three hits in his debut. In Queens, the Mets’ Ike Davis ended the game with a home run into the upper deck.

headline: Replay Takes Court as the Game’s Newest Star
text: BOSTON  Between Kevin Garnett’s dunks and Derek Fisher’s drives, a new star emerged Tuesday night in the N.B.A. finals: the flat-screen monitor.

headline: BP Account on Twitter? Just a Joke; K thx bye
text: With corporate imbroglios now come online parodies  sometimes very popular ones.

headline: A Pitcher for the Padres Is Proving Unhittable
text: Luke Gregerson’s relief appearance for the San Diego Padres on Tuesday night was nothing particularly unusual for him, and that is what is so extraordinary.

headline: Scramble to Save Big 12; Nebraska Said to Be Leaving
text: Officials from Texas and Texas A&M will meet Thursday morning in Austin in a last-ditch effort to save the Big 12 Conference. The regents, presidents and athletic officials from the universities are scheduled to meet with the hope of figuring out how to keep the conference together now that the departures of Nebraska and Colorado appear imminent.

headline: Diaz Builds His Profile and Power Beyond the Bronx
text: As Ruben Diaz Jr. stepped onto a sidewalk in the South Bronx, his shiny black shoes the color of his air-conditioned Tahoe, a flock of violins began to play.

headline: Contractors Who Build Office  Interiors Face Inquiry on Possibly False Bills
text: The interior-construction industry is hidden from the view of most New Yorkers, but billions of dollars a year are spent building and rebuilding the walls and guts of the city’s corporate towers.

headline: Less-Distracting Gifts for the Gadget-Happy Motorist
text: THE desire to marry cars with the latest, most convenient gadgetry goes back decades — even further back than the CB radios of the 1970s. Today, with rising concerns about the dangers of distracted driving, gift givers have to take into account not only the tastes and interests of the driver, but also the impact on highway safety.

headline: A Chevy by Any Other Name …
text: If General Motors does attempt to phase out the word Chevy, as an internal memo suggests, it won’t just be fighting decades of its own promotional efforts — it will be thumbing its newly upturned nose at more than a half century of musical references.

headline: Wal-Mart Finds Ally in Education
text: What promises to be a lucrative arrangement between the country’s largest retailer and an education company based in West Virginia started with an unsolicited e-mail message in October.

headline: The Style and Skill to Reach the Final
text: JOHANNESBURG

headline: Peace Protest, London-Style
text: LONDON -– Above the engine noise of red tourist buses and black taxicabs grinding through Parliament Square, the thud-thud-thud of rotors sometimes drifts down from above the clock tower that houses Big Ben.

headline: Law Limits Rise in Health Insurance Rates
text: Gov. David A. Paterson has signed legislation that gives the state the power to block what it deems unreasonably high health insurance premium increases for millions of New Yorkers.

headline: Efforts to Limit the Flow of Spill News
text: When the operators of Southern Seaplane in Belle Chasse, La., called the local Coast Guard-Federal Aviation Administration command center for permission to fly over restricted airspace in Gulf of Mexico, they made what they thought was a simple and routine request.

headline: Ultrathin Laptops Offer Affordable Power and Ease
text: FIVE years ago, a laptop an inch thick and weighing four pounds cost $2,000. Today the same type of laptop, but thinner, lighter and lasting longer on a single charge, is available for as little as $399. And there’s even more good news for those interested in buying a lightweight computer at a low price.

headline: Democrats Seek Votes on Spending Bill
text: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats searched Wednesday for support to pass a $140 billion package of tax breaks, safety-net spending and tax increases on the affluent as lawmakers worried that a final chance to take broad aim at unemployment before the November elections could slip away.

headline: Rivers Calls Foul on Refs
text: BOSTON — Celtics Coach Doc Rivers used his news media session on Wednesday to continue his critique of the officiating during the Celtics’ loss to the Lakers in Game 3 of the N.B.A. finals. After a night’s worth of sleep — or tape review — Rivers was still not happy.

headline: Currency Devaluation Increases Hardship for North Koreans
text: A currency devaluation in North Korea late last year was for some the worst disaster since a famine that killed hundreds of thousands in the mid-1990s.

headline: Bug Wars
text: Bug wars have long punctuated life in the nation’s grassy midsection, but this year is an exclamation point.

headline: Cross-Connections
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Mike Nothnagel is known for his very tough Friday and Saturday puzzles, but today he proves he can do a simpler Thursday-style crossword as well. As Thursdays go, this one isn’t as wild and crazy as some, but it’s clever and interesting, and the way everything cross-connects can make your head spin. If you’re not careful, you can get a false sense of déjà vu when clues that seem to be familiar turn out to be different.

headline: The Sounds and Songs of Stanley Cup Rivals
text: PHILADELPHIA  While the Flyers and the Blackhawks have waged a fierce battle for the Stanley Cup, the singing of “God Bless America” and “The Star-Spangled Banner” has its own competition for bragging rights between the cities of Philadelphia and Chicago.

headline: So Many Phone Add-ons, You’ll Need More Pockets
text: THE problem with shopping for phone gadgeteers who have everything is obvious: they have everything. But there are a few categories of gifts suitable for even the most acquisitive fans: functional items that they don’t know about, that they may not realize they need or that are just too modest to make it onto the wish list. Then there are items that seem too extravagant for people to buy for themselves.

headline: A Call to Triple U.S. Spending on Energy Research
text: WASHINGTON  The United States is badly lagging in basic research on new forms of energy, deepening the nation’s dependence on dirty fuels and crippling its international competitiveness, a diverse group of business executives warn in a study to be released Thursday.

headline: Safety Features Planned for Radiation Machines
text: GAITHERSBURG, Md.  Manufacturers of radiation therapy equipment said at a patient-safety conference here Wednesday that within the next two years their new equipment and the software that runs it would include fail-safe features to help reduce harmful radiation overdoses and other mistakes.

headline: Doubleheader for Mets and Padres
text: The Mets and the Padres were rained out on Wednesday night and will make up the game on Thursday as part of a day-night doubleheader. Johan Santana will face Mat Latos in the regularly scheduled game beginning at 1:10 p.m. Fans who held tickets to Wednesday’s game can use them to attend the second game of the doubleheader, which will start at 7:10 p.m. Jon Niese will pitch for the Mets.

headline: Spanish Bank to Buy Larger Stake in Mexican Unit
text: Banco Santander, the Spanish bank, said on Wednesday that it would buy Bank of America’s 24.9 percent stake in Santander’s Mexican arm for $2.5 billion, giving it almost total ownership of the unit.

headline: The Digital Alarm Clock Gets a Makeover
text: A new wave of alarm clocks are looking to inject new life into the clock radio.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 9, 2010

headline: The Reality of Life for Louisiana Fishermen Is an Unpalatable Choice
text: For a few afternoons last week, life seemed almost normal in Plaquemines Parish, La., a hub of fishing industry where the Mississippi meets the Gulf of Mexico. At the annual seafood festival in Belle Chasse, people lined up for rides and sandbagging contests. Piles of crawfish cost $6, a dozen oysters $12. A Seafood Queen was crowned.

headline: Washington Post Reporter Cancels Book Party Appearance
text: Of all the image problems the media has, few are as bruising as the perception that journalists are too cozy with the powerful people they cover.

headline: ‘Home Run Drill’ Pays Off
text: The hitting coach Kevin Long had a feeling Nick Swisher and Mark Teixeira would hit home runs Tuesday. Early that afternoon, they were practicing their swings in a drill Long devised that he likes to call, quite simply, “The Home Run Drill.”

headline: Leader Abruptly Leaves a For-Profit Prep School
text: Claremont Preparatory School, a for-profit school founded in Lower Manhattan in 2005, has abruptly changed its leadership, telling parents by e-mail on Wednesday that its headmaster was not returning and that an interim replacement had been appointed.

headline: Sabathia and the Yankees Pound Their Favorite Punching Bag Again
text: BALTIMORE  C. C. Sabathia is having two separate seasons, one against the Baltimore Orioles, the other against everyone else. When he faces Baltimore, Sabathia does not lose. When he faces everyone else, a diminished version seems to pitch, and the inconsistency is puzzling the Yankees.

headline: Strasburg at Citi Field This Season? Unlikely
text: Mets fans hoping to see Stephen Strasburg pitch in person may have to wait until next season or hit the road.

headline: 3-D Pitches (Glasses Not Included)
text: IF men seldom make passes at girls who wear glasses, as Dorothy Parker would have it, what, then, to make of commercials that require men and girls, and everyone else, to wear glasses?

headline: U-Haul to Settle With Trade Agency in Case on Truck Rental Price-Fixing
text: WASHINGTON  U-Haul International, the rental truck and trailer company, agreed on Wednesday to settle price-fixing charges with the Federal Trade Commission after the agency claimed that U-Haul had invited its closest competitor to fix prices on one-way truck rentals from 2006 to 2008.

headline: Financial Bill Would Create World Model, Volcker Says
text: MONTREAL  Paul A. Volcker, the former Fed chairman and an economic adviser to President Obama, said on Wednesday that sweeping financial reform legislation now before Congress would make the United States a model for the world.

headline: Nevada Challenger Lifted by Tea Party Ardor
text: Even among the nation’s most febrile political contests, few choices are as stark as the one Nevada voters will make between a circumspect four-term senator, one of the most visible emblems of Democratic power in Washington, and a largely unknown former state lawmaker with 10 grandchildren, whose fondness for weightlifting and for her .44 Magnum won the ardor of the Republican Party base.

headline: Oil Prices Yawn at the Big Spill
text: Hamper oil drilling and motorists will pay, industry groupies warn. But the drop in crude prices since BP’s Gulf of Mexico blowup suggests deepwater wells have a picayune impact on the market for oil. It’s a reminder that America relies on imports anyway and it won’t make any real difference to ban difficult drilling until oil companies prove it is safe.

headline: Group C: Early Anticipation for Americans
text: Few early matches in the World Cup have brought the anticipation of the United States-England game on June 12 in Rustenburg. A number of Americans play club soccer in England and will not lack for familiarity with their opponents when they take the field. The teams have met only once in the World Cup, when the United States defeated England, 1-0, in Brazil in one of the tournament’s most storied upsets.

headline: Questions After Political Unknown Wins
text: COLUMBIA, S.C  South Carolina Democratic leaders were surprised Wednesday by the victory of a long-shot candidate for the United States Senate  and appeared even more surprised by his reported criminal background.

headline: Abraham Nathanson, Bananagrams Inventor, Dies at 80
text: Abraham Nathanson, who at the age of 76 invented Bananagrams, a fast-moving letters-and-words game that became a runaway hit, died on Sunday at his summer house in Narragansett, R.I. He was 80 and lived in Cranston.

headline: An Aborted Late-Night Wave Between Hosts
text: How this for a crossover act? A late-night star waving across the continent — and across networks – to another late-night star.

headline: Blackhawks Win First Stanley Cup in 49 Years
text: PHILADELPHIA — A 49-year-old Stanley Cup drought ended in a flood of anxiety.

headline: China’s Trade Rose in May; Surplus Grows
text: HONG KONG — Unexpectedly strong exports from China in May suggested that international trade remained buoyant despite Europe’s debt troubles. But a $19.5 billion trade surplus for the month indicated by the figures published Thursday was also likely to re-ignite pressure on Beijing to let its currency appreciate against the U.S. dollar.

headline: N.F.L. Has Deal for Online Game
text: The N.F.L. reached a licensing deal with the online game company Quick Hit, bolstering a rival to Electronic Arts’s “Madden NFL.” The deal is the N.F.L.’s first licensing arrangement for an online game, a league spokesman said. Its exclusivity arrangement with E.A.  struck in 2004 and extended in 2008  is for a console-based “action simulation,” the league said. Quick Hit’s product is played through an Internet browser. The game, “QUICKHIT Football,” is free to play and generates revenue when users buy add-on features.

headline: 4 Wounded in Coney Island Shooting
text: Four people, including a mother of seven and a man identified as her son, were wounded during a shooting in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn on Wednesday night after an argument turned violent, the police and witnesses said.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Tickets to Finals Will Cost
text: According to SeatGeek.com, which tracks the price of event tickets on the secondary market, tickets for Thursday’s Game 4 at TD Garden in Boston are averaging $549. That represents a $99 drop from its high of $648 prior to Game 3.

headline: In Arkansas, Battle Over, It Is Time for Another
text: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  Senator Blanche Lincoln can hear you, Arkansas.

headline: A Drought Ends for Chicago
text: The Chicago Blackhawks ended their Stanley Cup drought of 49 years with a 4-3 overtime victory over the Philadelphia Flyers to win the Stanley Cup finals in six games.

headline: Disney Hopes Wall of Water Will Revive Theme Park
text: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Can an expensive fountain extravaganza finally turn the Walt Disney Company’s California Adventure theme park here into a hit?

headline: Disney Says It Will Close 5 ESPN Zone Restaurants
text: The Walt Disney Company is closing five ESPN Zone restaurants, saying the economics of the business became too challenging.

headline: Marina Semyonova, Star of Bolshoi Ballet, Dies at 102
text: Marina Semyonova, the first great Russian ballerina to emerge in the Soviet era, who for two decades was the prima ballerina of the Bolshoi Theater and became a revered teacher after her retirement in the early 1950s, died on Wednesday in Moscow. She was 102.

headline: Word of the Day | judicious
text: judicious •\jü-ˈdi-shəs\• adjective

headline: Peter J. Hall, Costume Designer for Opera, Dies at 84
text: Peter J. Hall, who parlayed his wartime experience designing camouflage for the British Army into a distinguished career as a costumer for the world’s most celebrated opera and theater companies, died on May 27 in Dallas. He was 84 and a Dallas resident.

headline: Jack Johnson Takes Top Spot on Chart
text: The latest laid-back album from Jack Johnson, below, ran away with the top spot on the Billboard album chart this week. “To the Sea” (Brushfire), Mr. Johnson’s fifth studio album, sold 243,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Justin Bieber’s “My World 2.0” (Island) came in a distant second, with 52,000 in sales, while “Glee: The Music, Volume 3 — Showstoppers” (Columbia) came in third after two weeks as No. 1, with 45,000. The fourth and fifth spots are the same as the previous week, as Lady Antebellum’s “Need You Now” (Capitol Nashville), the best-selling album of the year, is No. 4, with sales of 41,000. Usher’s “Raymond vs. Raymond” (Jive) followed, with 35,000. JOSEPH PLAMBECK

headline: Broadway Is Losing Its ‘Hair’
text: The current Broadway production of “Hair,” which won the 2009 Tony Award for best musical revival, will close on June 27, its producers said on Wednesday. “Hair” began turning a profit in August, after recouping its capitalization costs of $5.76 million but has performed unevenly at the box office this year. The announcement comes two weeks after the producers of the London production of “Hair” said the West End show would close when the current cast departs in September; tickets had been on sale through January 2011. A national American tour of “Hair” is scheduled to begin in October in New Haven and continue to 20 cities. On Friday, to mark the 500th performance of “Hair” on Broadway, free tickets will be given to the first 500 people in line when the box office opens at 10 a.m. at the Al Hirschfeld Theater, the producers said. Directed by Diane Paulus, this “Hair” began as a free show in the summer of 2008 at the Public Theater’s Delacorte Theater in Central Park, before moving to Broadway in March 2009. When the Broadway production closes, it will have played 519 regular performances and 29 previews. PATRICK HEALY

headline: Strong Finish for ‘Glee’
text: Fox’s “Glee” ended its first full season on Tuesday on a high note, attracting 10.9 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates, the series’s largest audience without the benefit of following an episode of “American Idol.” Fox placed third for the night over all. ABC was No. 1 for the night with its coverage of Game 3 of the N.B.A. Finals. CBS was second with repeats of its crime shows. NBC was fourth. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: BP Concerns Drag Down Other Stocks
text: Investors were shaken Wednesday by the prospect that BP might cut its dividend, pulling down the broader market, Susanna G. Kim writes in The New York Times. In the last hour of trading, the major indexes on Wall Street — led by energy shares — turned lower, erasing gains of more than 120 points on the Dow Jones industrial average.

headline: Martin and Roger Join ‘Evita’ Revival
text: The pop singer Ricky Martin will play Che and the Argentine actress Elena Roger will reprise her acclaimed West End performance as Eva Perón in Broadway’s first revival of the musical “Evita,” which is expected to begin performances in spring 2012, the producers of the show announced on Wednesday. The show remains one of the most popular of the composer Andrew Lloyd Webber and the book writer and lyricist Tim Rice; the original Broadway production ran from 1979 to 1983 and won seven Tony Awards. Mr. Martin, 38, above left, has one previous stint on Broadway, as the besotted French student Marius in “Les Misérables” in 1996. Ms. Roger, 35, above right, drew rapturous critical notices as Evita in the 2006 revival of the show in London. Performance dates were not announced beyond spring 2012, and additional casting and creative team members will be announced later. PATRICK HEALY

headline: Daniel Lanois Injured in Motorcycle Crash
text: The singer-songwriter and producer Daniel Lanois was in intensive care after he was injured in a motorcycle accident over the weekend, The Guardian reported. Mr. Lanois, a Quebec-born musician who has worked as a producer on albums including Bob Dylan’s “Time Out of Mind,” Willie Nelson’s “Teatro” and U2’s “No Line on the Horizon,” crashed his motorcycle in Los Angeles on Saturday. A statement from his label, Jive Records, did not specify his injuries but said that because of their “severity,” Mr. Lanois, above, had canceled his summer tour and all other “promotional activity” for the next two months.

headline: Another Bail Payment Prevents Lohan’s Arrest
text: Lindsay Lohan avoided arrest Tuesday after a judge said she had violated her probation and her lawyer said a monitoring device Ms. Lohan wears detected the presence of alcohol. After a meeting on Tuesday with prosecutors and Ms. Lohan’s lawyer, Judge Marsha Revel of Los Angeles County Superior Court said Ms. Lohan, above, had violated the terms of her release, based on results from a court-ordered alcohol monitor, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Lohan, the  “Mean Girls”  and “Parent Trap” star, was ordered to wear the monitoring device in May after missing a probation hearing stemming from her 2007 arrests on drunken-driving and misdemeanor drug charges. At that time an arrest warrant had been issued for Ms. Lohan and revoked when she posted $100,000 bail. On Tuesday another warrant was issued for Ms. Lohan, and bail was doubled to $200,000 — this one revoked when she paid up. Ms. Lohan wrote on her Twitter account that her monitoring device “wasn’t set off,” adding that it was “physically impossible” because she had done “nothing for it to go off.” But Ms. Lohan’s lawyer, Shawn Chapman Holley, said in a statement that the device indicated the “presence of a small amount of alcohol” after she attended the MTV Movie Awards on Sunday night, according to The A.P.

headline: Barbara Kingsolver Wins Orange Prize
text: Barbara Kingsolver has won the Orange Prize for Fiction for “The Lacuna,” her tale of a young man growing up in the political turmoil of Mexico and the United States in the mid-20th century. The British prize, decided by a panel of five judges, is given annually for the best novel written by a woman in English. It comes with an award of about $47,000. Daisy Goodwin, the chairwoman of the judges, said in a statement, “We chose ‘The Lacuna’ because it is a book of breathtaking scale and shattering moments of poignancy.” Among the other finalists was Hilary Mantel, who was seen by many as the favorite for her “Wolf Hall,” which won the Booker Prize, Britain’s most prestigious literary award. Ms. Kingsolver’s other books include “The Poisonwood Bible,” “Prodigal Summer” and “Pigs in Heaven.” JULIE BOSMAN

headline: Bernanke Warns of ‘Unsustainable’ Debt
text: When it comes to the deficit, Ben S. Bernanke has a story, and he’s sticking to it, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

headline: News Quiz | June 10, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Financial Bill Would Create World Model, Volcker Says
text: Paul A. Volcker, the former Fed chairman and an economic adviser to President Obama, said on Wednesday that sweeping financial reform legislation before Congress would make the United States a model for the world, Ian Austen reports in The New York Times.

headline: A Tablet to Let Students Replace Notebooks and Textbooks
text: The Kno is a new twist on the tablet and e-reader concept, aimed at the college market; it allows students to view textbooks on two digital screens much as they would view them in their analog versions, with text, color images and graphics.

headline: Help in Finding the Most Economical Data Plan
text: Now that AT&T no longer offers a $30-a-month unlimited data plan, many smartphone owners may wonder how that affects them. For most, it’s a chance to save money.

headline: A Call to Triple U.S. Spending on Energy Research
text: The United States is badly lagging in basic research on new forms of energy, deepening U.S. dependence on dirty fuels and crippling its international competitiveness, a diverse group of business executives warn in a study to be released Thursday, John M. Broder reports in The New York Times.

headline: Yankees to Face Halladay
text: Perhaps no team was happier to see Roy Halladay traded to the National League than the Yankees, who faced him in 11 of 12 series against Toronto over the last two seasons.

headline: Do You Know Boys Who Regard Girls as ‘Prey’?
text: The Op-Ed columnist Maureen Dowd writes about a dangerous game played at one elite prep school in which teenage girls were targeted as “prey” by boys who awarded “points” based on sexual encounters. Do you know boys who treat girls this way? What do you think can be done about it?

text: Today’s word, in association with the invaluable Oxford English Dictionary, is

text: From Thomas Friedman’s column in The New York Times:

text: 2:04 p.m. | Updated The New York Times’s Julia Werdigier has more about the central bank’s decision.

headline: Panel Assails A.I.G. Bailout for Distorting Market
text: 1:41 p.m. | Updated with Treasury comment The Congressional Oversight Panel on Thursday lambasted the government’s decision to rescue American International Group in September 2008, saying the bailout continues to have “a poisonous effect on the marketplace.”

headline: Ex-C.E.O.’s Show Tech Can Play Role in Politics
text: It is now officially the year of the high-tech chief executive in California electoral politics, The New York Times’s Brad Stone writes.

headline: Genzyme and Icahn Settle Proxy Fight
text: Genzyme, one the oldest and largest biotechnology companies in the United States, said Wednesday that it had reached a settlement with Carl C. Icahn in their bitter proxy contest.

text: From Lora Kolodny at You’re the Boss:

headline: China Watchdog Approves Agricultural Bank I.P.O.
text: China’s stock regulator has approved Agricultural Bank of China‘s plans for an initial public offering in Shanghai and Hong Kong that would be worth well over $20 billion, making it perhaps  the world’s biggest ever, despite current market doldrums, The Associated Press reported.

headline: F.B.I. Raids Reported Boiler Room in Manhattan
text: Ten men, including a former Securities and Exchange Commission employee, were arrested Wednesday and charged with running a $12 million scheme to cheat investors using a Manhattan boiler-room operation with mob links, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Palm Settles Hewlett-Packard Deal Suit
text: Palm said that it has settled a class-action suit brought by shareholders who argued they did not get the best deal when directors approved the company’s acquisition by Hewlett-Packard for $1.4 billion in cash, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Markets Rebound, Rising Almost 3%
text: The stock market roared back to life on Thursday, driving the Dow Jones industrial average firmly above 10,000, as investors latched on to hopes that maybe, just maybe, the economic scene was not quite as bleak as it seemed.

headline: Lakeland Financial Buys Back TARP Shares
text: Lakeland Financial on Wednesday said it bought back all of the 56,004 shares of preferred stock issued to the Treasury Department in exchange for federal bailout aid.

headline: Iran Warns of ‘Reduced’ Ties With U.N. Inspectors
text: PARIS  One day after the Security Council approved new sanctions against them, the authorities in Tehran threatened on Thursday to revise their relationship with the United Nations’ nuclear watchdog, using familiar language that has in the past presaged moves to limit global oversight of Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: Sam Zell Eyes Deal for Rewards Network
text: Sam Zell, the real estate investor, has his eye on Rewards Network, a provider of dining rewards programs for restaurants.

headline: Armani’s A/X Brand Offers Quite the Groovy ‘Pad’
text: When it comes to the Internet, fashion brands have been all over the map. Some have embraced being online, while others have welcomed the Web as much as they would being forced to sell a million garments to Filene’s Basement or T.J. Maxx.

headline: Will Obama Push for Financial Stability?
text: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: Dustin Keller With a Sushi Suggestion
text: Jets tight end Dustin Keller, who is a budding restaurateur, will write a food column once a month for the Fifth Down. Today, he is writing a restaurant review of Sushi Lounge in Morristown, N.J.

headline: Riding the Dragon at Hong Kong Boating Festival
text: You have to love a sport that involves a coxswain banging on a Chinese drum while skimming over the water.

headline: Britain Reaffirms Support for Afghanistan Effort
text: PARIS  Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain flew to Kabul, Afghanistan, on Thursday, saying this would be the “vital year” for the campaign against the Taliban.

headline: Final UBS Vote Delayed Until Next Week
text: The final Swiss parliamentary vote on the agreement with the United States over UBS client data has been delayed until next week, a hostage of domestic politics.

headline: S.E.C. Said to Investigate 2nd Goldman C.D.O.
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission is ramping up an investigation of a second complex mortgage deal by Goldman Sachs, The Financial Times reported, citing people close to the matter.

headline: Rothstein Gets 50 Years for Ponzi Scheme
text: Scott Rothstein, a former lawyer from Florida, was handed a 50-year prison sentence Wednesday, after he pleaded guilty earlier this year to orchestrating a Ponzi scheme that defrauded $1.2 billion from investors, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: How ‘Middle Powers’ Became U.S. Rivals
text: Today’s idea: Post-cold-war democracy replaced Westernized elites in Turkey and Brazil and turned the two “middle powers” into rivals of the world’s pre-eminent democracy, the United States, a scholar writes.

headline: Ackman Makes His Case for Citigroup
text: When it comes to Citigroup, William Ackman thinks he has spotted value in the bank that the market missed.

headline: Providence Receives 7 Bids for Bresnan
text: Providence Equity Partners, the private equity firm that has reportedly put Bresnan Communications on the block, has received seven bids of more than $1 billion for the broadband provider, Reuters reported, citing a source familiar with the situation.

headline: Dutch Voters Split, and Right Surges
text: THE HAGUE — Campaigning for Dutch elections this week, the outspoken anti-immigration politician Geert Wilders outlined a host of extreme policies including a ban on the Koran and a tax on the wearing of head scarves.

headline: Travails of a Charter Captain
text: Brad Schmit captains charter boats for sport fishermen in southern Louisiana, and like most charter boat captains in the region, he has seen his business struggle from the effects of the BP spill.

headline: Neuberger Said to Consider Future I.P.O.
text: Even as Neuberger Berman celebrates its first year as a private and independent company, the money manager’s executives are moving toward an initial public offering, Reuters reported.

headline: Never Mind a Loaf of Bread and a Jug of Wine, Times Square Gets Doughnuts and Coffee
text: Passersby who were puzzled by a mysterious billboard atop One Times Square — bearing not much more than the address of a Web site, missionfresh.com — wonder no more. On Thursday morning, the sign is to be revealed as a pitch for the Dunkin’ Donuts unit of Dunkin’ Brands.

headline: Speed Read for Thursday, June 10
text: Here are some highlights from Thursday’s edition of The New York Times:

headline: Lincoln Victory Bolsters Measure Opposed by Banks
text: Senator  Blanche Lincoln’s surprise primary election victory in Arkansas means, ironically, that legislation to rein in Wall Street could end up being more to the liking of liberals who opposed her, The Associated Press said.

headline: Cadillac Redesigns Logo Again
text: Cadillac’s new logo, shown off quietly in November, is now showing up in television commercials and is on the 2011 SRX.

headline: A Woman’s World
text: Today’s idea: With men now in the minority in the American work force, the postindustrial world increasingly looks better-suited to women, an article says. A gender role reversal is under way that might even surpass simple equality.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Mixed signals from the world economy this macroeconomic morning: Britain’s central bank has just decided not to raise interest rates, in the hopes that easy money will help get the British economy off its knees. On the other side of the globe, China’s exports are unslowed despite the debt troubles of one of its best customers, Europe. So Beijing is looking north toward the wastes of Siberia to feed its steel mills.

headline: While We Were Out…
text: This happened:

headline: The Early Word: Presidential Condolences
text: It’s a politically and emotionally charged day for President Obama, who is meeting with the family members of the 11 workers killed in the oil rig explosion in the Gulf of Mexico 52 days ago.

headline: Central Bank Extends Cash Lifeline and Gives Pep Talk
text: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank extended its cash lifeline for banks on Thursday, while its president, Jean-Claude Trichet, urged national euro zone regulators to take steps to resuscitate confidence in the health of their financial institutions.

headline: Q.&A.: Putting Your iPod Nano Videos on Your Computer
text: Q.

headline: Better Together
text: Their doctor calls Carrie and Tulane Howard “the ‘Rear Window’ couple.” They spend hours sitting by the bay window, in the house they bought in Northwest Washington, D.C., in 1951, looking out at their garden and beyond it to Rock Creek Park.

headline: Doubleheader Racing Weekend
text: Once again the Canadian Grand Prix has been scheduled on the same weekend as the world’s greatest endurance race, the 24 Hours of Le Mans. That means  a lot of racing fans around the world will be watching television all weekend long!

headline: City Allowed to Withhold Surveillance Data
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: ‘We’re Tired of Kicking Each Other’
text: The United States team is tired. It’s not a question of fitness — the strength and conditioning coach Pierre Barrieu has been praised by the coach and players all week. But there is a sort of fatigue setting in.

headline: Nocturnalist | Starring Divas on Four Legs
text: There are plenty of human performers at “Cavalia,” but the horses are the headliners.

headline: Now Reading | A Warhol Tell-All
text: Christopher Trela first discovered John Wilcock’s long out-of-print “The Autobiography and Sex Life of Andy Warhol” while browsing a rare-book stall at a Fifth Avenue street fair in 1991. Wilcock, who was a travel reporter for The New York Times before becoming a founding editor of both The Village Voice and Interview magazine, visited the Factory for seven years, up to five times a week. Casual conversations with the likes of Leo Castelli, Ultra Violet, Charles Henri Ford and Lou Reed, culled at the height of Warhol’s fame, eventually culminated in this oral history, which Wilcock self-published.

headline: Why I Hired Chef Joe
text: It was not love at first sight. Joe Isidori, all tall, dark and handsome, was not out to charm anyone. Well spoken and polite, he seemed to be wearing an invisible helmet and pads from his high school football days. So guarded was Mr. Isidori that he kept his passions under his toque, and his personality under wraps. The less he revealed, the more I felt myself clamming up.

headline: Ladies and Gentlemen, the Comedy Stylings of Kid Rock! (Also, CMT Music Awards Presented)
text: If neither Betty White nor Neil Patrick Harris is available to preside over your televised awards ceremony, might we humbly suggest you consider Kid Rock? On Wednesday night’s broadcast of the CMT Music Awards in Nashville, Kid Rock, the rap-rock-country crossover star, proved to be quite the kidder himself. And even when his folksy-sleazy shtick wasn’t dominating the show like Carrie Underwood – and he wasn’t getting yelled at for smoking on stage – he sure seemed to be having a good time.

headline: Pregnant or Fat?
text: A pregnant woman stands on a crowded subway train — and stands and stands and stands…

headline: On the Trail of Methane and Plumes
text: Scientists from Texas A&M and the University of California, Santa Barbara, will try to measure the size of the gulf oil spill more precisely by taking continuous measurements of methane with machines that can also fingerprint deep-water oil plumes to track their dispersal.

headline: Delay on Lanes Angers East Side Cyclists
text: Cyclists in East Harlem were not happy this week.

headline: Thai Leader Offers Reconciliation Plan
text: BANGKOK  Addressing the nation three weeks after a military crackdown on protesters, Prime Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva presented what he called a “letter to the Thai people” on Thursday, calling for reconciliation in a country shaken and divided by months of turmoil and scores of deaths.

headline: Nat Hentoff on Duke Ellington
text: The Village Voice writer and journalist talks about his relationship with the jazz musician.

headline: What Crisis Panel Faces in Its Fight With Goldman
text: Peter J. Henning follows issues involving securities law and white-collar crime for DealBook’s White Collar Watch.

headline: Muggles Take Flight at the Wizarding World of Harry Potter
text: DID my homework before being dispatched to check out the new Wizarding World of Harry Potter attraction at the Universal Orlando Resort. Knew I’d be drinking some butterbeer. Knew I’d be talked at by paintings and have my mind blown by a high-tech ride. Did not, however, know that I’d be nearly trampled to death by a mob of post-Potter depressives.

headline: A Wizardly Getaway
text: Staff editor Neil Genzlinger covers the newest Universal Studios attraction, the Wizarding World of Harry Potter.

headline: How Old Can a ‘Young Writer’ Be?
text: The June 14 issue of The New Yorker, perhaps the premier showcase for American fiction, features a list of “20 Under 40” — that is, 20 accomplished writers under the age of 40. Many of the names are familiar: Joshua Ferris, Jonathan Safran Foer, Nell Freudenberger, Rivka Galchen, Nicole Krauss, Gary Shteyngart, ZZ Packer, Wells Tower.

headline: Lady Gaga Doesn’t Preach, Exactly
text: Presumably among the 8.3 million views on You Tube of Lady Gaga’s new “Alejandro” video there are people who enjoyed the music and the gear (great underwear — thanks, Calvin Klein), and then resumed their regular activities, not shocked but maybe bemused.

headline: New Amusement Parks in 2010
text: THE Harry Potter theme park may be grabbing a lot of attention lately, but the amusement park industry has other tricks up its sleeve this year. Across North America new and “re-themed” amusement parks have opened, and standout rides at established venues are drawing crowds. Whether you’re drawn to the two thrilling roller coasters named for the Nascar legend Dale Earnhardt, who was known as the Intimidator, or are more inclined toward a junior coaster piloted by Sesame Street’s Grover, you’ll most likely find something in this sampler of new attractions that’s just your speed.

headline: Inside the Beltway Climate War
text: Eric Pooley, the deputy editor of Bloomberg Businessweek, spent long stretches of the last three years immersed with a variety of combatants in the intensifying battle over legislation aimed at putting a price on carbon dioxide emissions.

headline: Thursday Reading: Indecision in the Real Estate Market
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Boyle in Discussions to Sing for Pope
text: It’s not a done deal yet, but Susan Boyle may soon be singing for an authority figure who will hopefully go a little easier on her than Simon Cowell. A spokesman for the Roman Catholic Church in Scotland told The Associated Press that Ms. Boyle, the homegrown singing sensation who was discovered last year on the reality competition “Britain’s Got Talent,” was likely to perform for Pope Benedict XVI during a papal tour this fall. While negotiations are still taking place, The A.P. said, Ms. Boyle is expected to sing during an open-air papal Mass at Bellahouston Park in Glasgow on Sept. 16. The event is part of a four-day trip by Benedict, during which he will also address Parliament and beatify John Henry Newman, a cardinal who converted to Catholicism in the 19th century. In a statement, a spokeswoman for Ms. Boyle told Reuters: “Susan’s management are currently looking at the possibility of this happening.”

headline: Fallon: ‘A Water Gun Fight’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: A few days ago, Vice President Biden and Rahm Emanuel had a water gun fight during a party at Biden’s house. Meanwhile, Sasha and Malia spent the last few days trying to solve the BP oil crisis.

headline: Ferguson: ‘A Hot Temper’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: It was on this day in 1934 the first Donald Duck cartoon premiered. He’s 76 years old. You’d think if America loved a 76-year-old guy with a hot temper so much, we would have elected John McCain.

headline: What We’re Reading: Mobile Evolution
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Letterman: ‘Trained to Become Terrorists’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: At one time, Barack Obama lived in New York City. Obama hasn’t lived in this apartment here in New York City since 1981, but oddly enough, it’s still where he picks up his Pottery Barn catalogs.

headline: Barras Bravas
text: Latin American soccer hooligans

headline: Leno: ‘Women Won Big’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: BP is now saying they’ve captured anywhere from 35 percent to 75 percent of the oil that is gushing out of the well. Of course, you’ve got to keep in mind they usually lie anywhere from 85 percent to 95 percent of the time.

headline: Kodak Is Bringing Facebook to CVS
text: Kodak has just friended Facebook, and it has a status update for you.

headline: Eurofile | Springtime in Paris
text: In Alexander Lobrano’s new column, “Eurofile,” the author of “Hungry for Paris” writes about the best tables (and beds) on the continent.

headline: Group D: Germany Faces Uphill Battle
text: Only a cynic or an Englishman would discount Germany’s chances in any World Cup, but this may be the naysayers’ year. First, the Germans were placed in the most difficult first-round group, with two teams that reached the second round in 2006 (Ghana and Australia) and another (Serbia) with a World Cup pedigree stretching back to the first tournament in 1930. Then the German captain, Michael Ballack, sustained an ankle injury that will keep him from playing.

headline: Which Boat to Take?
text: There are two ways to go down the Preguiças River from Barreirinhas, the perfectly acceptable two-bit town that serves as a base for visiting Lençóis Maranhenses National Park, and Atins, a coastal speck of a village on the edge of the park that sounds like it’s more my style.

headline: Bike Removal, an 81st Precinct Inquiry, and Medals
text: A decision to remove bicycles from along a presidential motorcade in Lower Manhattan in April was made by a supervisor overseeing that portion of the roadway, and not by the brass and headquarters. And while the action was appropriate, from a security standpoint, the bicycle-removal operations could have been handled better as far as community relations go.

headline: Dear FloFab: My Boyfriend Is a Human Dumpster!
text: Each Thursday, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

headline: Ground Zero Deal Gives Plaintiffs $712.5 Million
text: Lawyers for the city and about 10,000 rescue and cleanup workers who say their health was damaged at ground zero announced Thursday that they had negotiated a new, $712 million settlement to replace one that a federal judge rejected three months ago.

headline: Senators Losing Patience With U.S. Policy on China
text: WASHINGTON  Leading senators frustrated by a lack of progress by the Obama administration signaled on Thursday that they were willing to consider retaliatory measures to address China’s policies on trade, currency and intellectual property.

headline: Youth League Fights AIDS With Soccer
text: MAWEWE, South Africa  Far from the World Cup, in this poor, rural village where there are no paved roads, no nets on the goals and no shoes for many of the players, Clement Nkala, 17, sat in a chair in his soccer uniform and held out his finger to be pricked for an H.I.V. test.

headline: Plane Crash, Random Ax and Distant Brooklyn Bar
text: The plaques, statues and memorials that fill the city’s parks and cling to the facades of its buildings mostly fade into the background of each busy day.

headline: New iPhone Creates Familiar Dilemma for Existing Customers
text: Oh, sigh.

headline: Q&A: Fun for a 4-Year-Old in New York
text: Q.

headline: Popcast: Christina Aguilera and Dave Rawlings and Gillian Welch
text: This week, Jon Pareles discusses Christina Aguilera’s new album, “Bionic,” and the Dave Rawlings Machine — featuring Mr. Rawlings and his longtime songwriting partner, Gillian Welch — performs live in the studio. Ben Ratliff is the host.

headline: The Challenges of Spending a $100 Bill
text: We recently came across a Facebook status update from a friend of Bucks who had trouble spending a $100 bill. Here’s what she wrote: “I think it wld be easier to spend hungarian florints than pay with a $100 bill in nyc. people act like you’re a con artist for even trying.”

headline: Izzo to Visit Cleveland Today
text: It’s another installment of “As Izzo Turns,” the ongoing drama of Michigan State Coach Tom Izzo’s negotiations with the Cleveland Cavaliers.

headline: Targeting the Tiniest
text: A major school of thought in environmentalist thinking is that small is beautiful. Can that apply as well to killing billions of insects with chemicals?

headline: Anti-Straw Men And Austerity
text: There should be a standard phrase for the construction of anti-straw-men — for attributing to your intellectual opponents sophisticated, reasonable positions they do not in fact hold, ignoring the nonsense they actually espouse. Whatever you call it, that’s what Brad DeLong is doing in his comment on a previous post of mine.

headline: Venison, or Rather, the Strokes Reunite in Britain
text: It’s not only the coming “A-Team” and “Karate Kid” movies that are making some of us nostalgic for our wayward, pop-culture consuming youths: in a London club on Wednesday night, it was 2001 all over again as the once and future New York buzz band the Strokes played their first live show in four years, BBC News reported.

headline: A Rising Urgency in Israel for a Gaza Shift
text: GAZA — Three years after Israel and Egypt imposed an embargo on this tormented Palestinian strip, shutting down its economy, a consensus has emerged that the attempt to weaken the governing party, Hamas, and drive it from power has failed.

headline: Resort Report | Calvin Klein’s Palette Cleanser
text: Francisco Costa showed a collection of clean symmetry at Calvin Klein. Even the models’ hair had perfect lines — worn blunt and straight. A white pantsuit was crisp and chic. Longer dresses and skirts looked modern. The lightweight velvets in pale shades of yellow, pink and blue stood out as a lovely repose in the mostly white and beige collection. Accessories-wise, a pair of tinted, round sunglasses were designed to lay flat on a surface. After the show, they were laid out backstage — arms splayed out like flattened insects.

headline: Fiorina’s Hairy Moment
text: Oh, you know it’s the year of the women in politics — just two days past big-state primaries with successful female candidates — when the chatter is all about their hair.

headline: Why Patients Aren’t Getting the Shingles Vaccine
text: Four years ago at age 78, R., a retired professional known as much for her small-town Minnesotan resilience as her commitment to public service, developed a fleeting rash over her left chest. The rash, which turned out to be shingles, or herpes zoster, was hardly noticeable.

headline: Ahnoiled
text: Sight Gag | Found at The Daily Dish:

headline: G.M. Says Chevy Memo Was ‘Poorly Worded’
