headline: Arizona Tonys-Watching Party Canceled
text: A Tony Awards viewing party that was to take place Sunday night at a theater in Tempe, Ariz., has been canceled.

headline: Who’s Spending Again? The Rich and the Old
text: Consumer spending has risen over the last year, and the savings rate has fallen. Given that the job market is still soft, it seems reasonable to ask: Which Americans would actually feel comfortable significantly increasing their spending in this environment?

headline: Many Blustery Days at Citi Field
text: With a league-leading 23 victories at home this season, the Mets appear to have the wind at their backs at Citi Field, literally as well as figuratively.

headline: Uneasy on Camera, Paterson Opens Up on Radio
text: “Another night, another Met loss,” the caller sighed. “And it’s starting to be frustrating, as it was last year.”

headline: S.E.C. Approves Market ‘Circuit Breakers’
text: WASHINGTON  The Securities and Exchange Commission approved rules on Thursday intended to prevent a repeat of last month’s sudden plunge in the markets.

headline: English Language Learners and the Power of Personal Stories
text: We’ve asked Larry Ferlazzo, a prolific blogger and Twitter user who has written a recent book called “English Language Learners: Teaching Strategies That Work,” to do a guest post for us today.

headline: Oy, Canada
text: Marshall Auerback points out that the new UK government, in arguing that fiscal austerity won’t destroy the economic recovery, is pointing — wrongly — to Canada’s experience in the 1990s. Actually, it’s even worse than Auerback says.

headline: Divers Get Close-Up Views of Oil in Gulf
text: The spread of oil below the surface of the Gulf of Mexico is starting to alienate even strong supporters of drilling in the region. As this video report from The Associated Press shows, divers who shoot underwater video of marine life around abandoned oil platforms in the Gulf of Mexico have been documenting the spread of the oil from BP’s damaged well recently.

headline: S.E.C. Approves Market Circuit Breaker System
text: 4:22 p.m. | Updated The New York Times’s Edward Wyatt provides more details of the new rules on circuit breakers.

headline: Spring Real Estate Market Roars In but Tiptoes Out Early
text: This year, the burst of real estate action that marks the spring season came early in New York. Manhattan saw a big sales spike in March, well before the market’s usual busy season in May and June. But now, instead of going into the expected overdrive, some brokers say, sales have started to stall.

headline: TimesCast | June 10, 2010
text: Today, BP shares slump on political pressures over its dividend payments, an American athlete uses soccer to teach H.I.V. prevention to South African children, and teaching a basset hound how to hunt.

headline: The Toast of Chicago
text: Perhaps the most amazing part of the Blackhawks’ Stanley Cup championship is that it took a monstrously long time coming (49 years) and yet happened so quickly. Four years ago, they were still among the laughingstocks of the N.H.L. Maybe the laughingstock of the N.H.L.: an Original Six team seemingly stuck in the Original Six era, owned by a curmudgeon who thought local television broadcasts would spell the end of his business.

headline: Oil Spill Shuts the Nation’s Oldest Oyster-Shucking Company
text: The oldest oyster-shucking operation in the country shucked its last oyster on Thursday, a victim of the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: T. R. Knight Finds New ‘Life in the Theater’
text: Based on the 2009 that T. R. Knight had, it can be safely said that he knows a thing or two about life (and death) in the television industry. What does he know about “A Life in the Theater”? Enough to be cast as the co-star in the coming revival of that David Mamet play, its producers said on Thursday.

headline: Answers About Social Security: Part 3
text: “Ask an Expert” is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

headline: A Well-Wired Hong Kong Offers a Link to the Dead
text: HONG KONG  Hong Kong, one of the world’s most wired societies, is taking the Internet to a higher level.

headline: Secondhand Smoke and Mental Health
text: Smokers are known to suffer from high rates of depression and other mental health problems, and now a study reports that even people exposed to secondhand smoke are at significantly increased risk  and more likely to be hospitalized for mental illness.

headline: N.F.L. Scouts for Refs in Public Housing
text: In a scene out of Hollywood, a wise coachlike figure in a neatly pressed polo sat in a darkened classroom surrounded by young, sweaty men watching football tapes. When a lineman tackled the quarterback, a chorus of “ohs” echoed through the room.

headline: Does Google Have Bing Envy?
text: 2:42 p.m. | Updated Reflecting Google’s removal of the image experiment from its home page.

headline: Seeing Things | Playmountain in L.A.
text: Angelenos may want to consider a staycation this summer. The cult-favorite Tokyo design shop Playmountain is in residence at Heath Los Angeles until Sept. 5. Playmountain, which occupies a tiny space in Tokyo’s Sendagaya neighborhood, is known for its tightly curated selection of simple, hand-crafted objects, from children’s toys to furniture.

headline: British Resist Push for BP to Halt Dividends
text: British investors in BP are growing increasingly frustrated with the White House’s involvement and comments about the company’s efforts to clean up the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, and partly blame politicians for the sharp drop in BP’s stock price, The New York Times’s Julia Werdigier reports from London.

headline: Peugeot Sets Pace at 24 Hours of Le Mans Qualifying Session
text: From our colleagues at Formula One:

headline: Pelosi Calls for BP to Suspend Dividends
text: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi called Thursday for BP to stop dividend payments to shareholders until small business owners hurt by the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico are made whole.

headline: Iranian Opposition Leaders Call Off Protest
text: The Iranian opposition leaders Mir Hussein Moussavi and Mehdi Karroubi issued a joint statement on Thursday calling off plans for protests on Saturday, the anniversary of the disputed presidential election that they claim was rigged.

headline: Arts Center Near Seattle Gets $25 Million – And a New Name
text: The Performing Arts Center Eastside (PACE) in Bellevue, Wash., has received a $25 million gift — said to be the third largest donation in the United States to a single arts institution since 2007 — from the Tateuchi Foundation to help build a performing arts hall in the suburbs of Seattle, the center announced on Wednesday.

headline: Soros Sees ‘Act II’ of Financial Crisis
text: The billionaire investor George Soros said Thursday that the financial crisis was entering “Act II” as Europe’s fiscal problems worsen and governments are pressured to cut spending to curb budget deficits — a move that may push the global economy back into recession, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Genocide Verdicts in Srebrenica Killings
text: PARIS  Judges at The Hague handed down two rare genocide convictions on Thursday, sentencing two security officers for the Bosnian Serb Army to life in prison for their roles in the 1995 Srebrenica massacre, the worst single episode in a decade of war that left 100,000 dead and tore the Balkans apart.

headline: Following Jefferson Through the Vineyards
text: WHEN Thomas Jefferson embarked on his grand tour of France in 1787, he claimed the journey was for his health. A broken wrist sent him on a circuitous route, 1,200 miles south from Paris to take the mineral waters at Aix-en-Provence, and on the way he planned to fulfill his professional obligations as America’s top envoy to France, researching French architecture, agriculture and engineering projects.

headline: 36 Hours in Brussels
text: AS the seat of the European Union, Brussels gets its share of gray suits pouring off the Eurostar. Luckily, the ties come off after work. Beneath the buttoned-down facade is a lively capital that follows its own sartorial trends, indulges in decadent flavors (especially when it involves beer) and exhibits a witty, even wacky sense of humor. What other city would erect an entire museum to a single comic book series? Or to an artist famous for painting faceless men in gray suits?

headline: Hawaiiana, Beyond the Hula Doll
text: WHAT do people take home from Hawaii? Most likely, memories: a bite of fresh pineapple, a swim in the ocean, a Technicolor sunset. Typical souvenirs — T-shirts, a bouncy hula-doll figurine, a shell necklace — hardly do the natural beauty of the islands justice.

headline: The Senate and CO2
text: 10:30 p.m. | Updated  The proposal to consider the “resolution of disapproval” put forth by Senator Lisa Murkowski, the Republican of Alaska, was rejected, 57 to 43.

headline: American Historian Wins Norway’s Holberg Prize
text: The historian Natalie Zemon Davis, probably best known for her work “The Return of Martin Guerre,” which was made into  a 1982 film with Gérard Depardieu, won Norway’s 4.5 million kroner ($680,000) Holberg Prize on Wednesday for her narrative approach to history, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Happily Donating Teeth to the Cup Cause
text: So what would you give up to win the Stanley Cup?

headline: Way Back Machine | Another Age of Terror
text: At 2 a.m. on April 30, 1919, a postal worker named Charles Caplan was heading home to Harlem on the subway. It was the end of a long night’s shift, and Mr. Caplan, who worked in the city’s main post office, at 30th Street and Eighth Avenue, was reading — of all things — a newspaper article on a mail bomb that had recently exploded at the home of Thomas Hardwick, a Democratic senator from Georgia. Something caught his eye.

headline: Will New York Rebel Against Fracking?
text: A well blowout that shot gas and water polluted with drilling fluids as high as 75 feet into the air in Pennsylvania is a vivid reminder how a new generation of gas drilling is becoming more of a presence in the Northeast.

headline: Paying for the Shingles Vaccine
text: As Dr. Pauline Chen reports in today’s Doctor and Patient column, few older patients are getting vaccinated against shingles, a debilitating condition that results from reactivation of the chicken pox virus.

headline: BP Musings
text: A few questions and answers on BP:

headline: Group E: Up for Grabs
text: After the World Cup draw in December, each of the four teams assigned to Group E must have held a certain belief, beyond natural optimism, that it could advance to the knockout round.

headline: Upfronts: For the Big Broadcasters, What a Difference a Year Makes
text: The upfront market for the sale of commercial time ahead of the start of the new television season is over for the five big English-language broadcasters, with results that represent a nice bounce from last year’s downbeat outcome.

headline: Shakespearean Juggling in the Park
text: IN “The Merchant of Venice,” Shakespeare’s callow nobleman Bassanio beseeches and bootlicks his way into marrying the heiress Portia, but their future together seems iffy by the end of the play. The actor Hamish Linklater, who is playing Bassanio in a new Shakespeare in the Park production, developed an unusual theory about the role during rehearsal: After the events of “Merchant,” he decided, Portia divorced Bassanio and he went on to live the roaming existence of another Shakespearean character, Autolycus, the royal manservant turned roguish peddler in “The Winter’s Tale.”

headline: In San Diego, a Little Italy Gets Bigger
text: LITTLE ITALY NORTH in San Diego has long been the unsung, gritty industrial cousin to the main part of Little Italy’s restaurant row, essentially cut off from its southern half by two busy streets and a decidedly different mindset. But as many of the area’s machine shops and warehouses have closed, a nascent design district, featuring art galleries and home décor stores, has taken root in their former digs.

headline: Belgrade Opens Up With Amps On
text: IT was the first-year anniversary party for Kulturni Centar Grad, an underground club in Belgrade, and a young crowd in vintage finery milled about expectantly. Pink lights reflected off glasses of wine, and cigarette smoke hung in the air. To whistles and applause, a man in a white suit, striped tie and white fedora strode onstage.

headline: Book Review: Adventures Among Ants
text: Adventures Among Ants: A Global Safari with a Cast of TrillionsBy Mark W. MoffettUniversity of California Press, 280 pages,$29.95 hardcover

headline: Restaraunt Review: Chef Point Café in Watauga, Tex.
text: On a recent Friday night, there were so many cars at the Conoco gas station in Watauga, Tex., 15 miles north of Fort Worth, you would have thought there was a fuel shortage. But no one was at the pump. Customers were instead crowded into the station’s convenience store, flipping through old issues of Auto Trader and trying not to upset the racks of beef jerky as they waited at least an hour for the hostess to tell them their table was ready.

headline: Biliary Obstruction
text: A slide show explaining a blockage in the tubes that carry a liquid called bile from the liver to the gallbladder and small intestine

headline: Hotel Review: The Allegria in Long Beach, N.Y.
text: THE BASICS

headline: Venice? No, Berlin by Boat
text: WHETHER lured by its historic or cultural riches, visitors to Berlin are often surprised to find that the German capital sits on a vast system of waterways and is home to more bridges than Venice. When the city was divided decades ago, large parts of Berlin’s rivers, lakes and canals became unused border zones or half-forgotten industrial areas. But in the years since, they have gradually meshed with the city, transforming from an almost overlooked urban footnote into a network of recreation and possibility.

headline: When Banks Looked Like a Million Bucks
text: STILL think there’s no such thing as a bank that’s too big to fail?

headline: On Our Radar: BP’s Safety Record
text: Documents suggest that BP repeatedly disregarded safety and environmental regulations over the past decade.

headline: 2010 BMW S 1000 RR
text: The S 1000 RR opens up a whole new segment for BMW motorcycles.

headline: Answers From a Brooklyn Blogger, Part 2
text: Following is the second set of responses from Louise Crawford, the founder of Only the Blog Knows Brooklyn, and creator of the annual Brooklyn Blogfest.

headline: Anchor-Baby Loophole
text: A constitutional guarantee of American citizenship to all children born in the U.S. a provision which some claim is exploited by illegal immigrants

headline: A Trip Back to the Days of Airline Food
text: Maybe I don’t get around as much as I did when I lived in Tokyo for 12 years. Maybe I have become like many fliers in United States, immune to the declining service and disappearing amenities on many commercial flights. Heck, I hardly miss those scratchy little pillows anymore.

headline: ‘Green’ Hotel and Hostel Opens in Prague
text: A building dating from 1935 might not be the spot  you’d expect for a “green” hotel, but that’s exactly what you’ll find at Mosaic House, opening tonight off Karlovo Namesti in the New Town area of Prague.

headline: ‘The Cleveland Show’ Is Picked Up for Third Season
text: Viewers will be seeing even more of Cleveland Brown’s “happy mustache face” and hearing more from Mike Henry, the actor and producer who provides that animated character’s voice. On Thursday, the Fox network said that it had ordered a third season of “The Cleveland Show,” the cartoon comedy spun off from its animated hit “Family Guy.”

headline: If I Marry, Will I Lose Coverage?
text: Q.

headline: McCain Urges Obama to Back Regime Change in Iran
text: Senator John McCain called on the United States on Thursday to support regime change in Iran, saying that the latest United Nations sanctions are “inadequate” and that it is unrealistic to expect the current government in Tehran to stop pursuing nuclear weapons, supporting terrorism and cracking down on its own people.

headline: A Collection, of Sorts, for LeBron
text: Let it be known: what could be a summer of LeBron-related stunts is officially under way.

headline: U.S.C. Sports Receive Harsh Penalties
text: Citing major violations by U.S.C.’s football and men’s basketball programs, the N.C.A.A. on Thursday barred the Trojans’ football program from bowl games in the 2010 and 2011 seasons. U.S.C. will also be forced to vacate all victories in which the Heisman Trophy winner Reggie Bush participated beginning in December 2004  including the Orange Bowl victory that produced the Trojans’ Bowl Championship Series title in January 2005  and will be docked 10 scholarships in each of the next three seasons.

headline: Blackout in Tam Kỳ, but No Dengue Fever
text: Thursday, June 10: Tam Ky, Vietnam

headline: Twitter Buys an Analytics Company
text: Twitter on Thursday announced that it had acquired Smallthought Systems, the company behind an analytics service called Trendly that tracks real-time changes and user trends for Web site owners.

headline: 2011 Ford Mustang
text: There’s a lot of throwback in the Mustang’s engineering that defines its charms and limitations.

headline: Immigrants’ Hunger Strike Ends With ‘Die-In’
text: For 10 days, a group of illegal immigrants had staged a round-the-clock hunger strike in front of the building in Midtown Manhattan that houses Senator Charles E. Schumer’s office, calling on him to take immediate action on a bill that would provide a path to citizenship for young illegal immigrants.

headline: The Oil Supply Picture, Post-Spill
text: What will be the long-term impact of BP’s disastrous gulf oil spill on American oil supplies?

headline: Video Shows Haiti Earthquake’s Impact
text: Harrowing security camera video has been distributed by Reuters showing the crumbling of Haiti’s national palace during the devastating earthquake that struck the country, and ruined its seat of government, on January 12.

headline: Obama Consoles Oil Rig Families
text: Television is filled with images of oil spill victims, from out-of-work shrimp boaters to endangered pelicans covered in sticky muck. On Thursday, the people some have called forgotten victims – the families of the 11 workers killed when the rig exploded – met with President Obama and Democratic lawmakers to press for more compensation.

headline: Under Pressure, Teachers Tamper With Tests
text: The staff of Normandy Crossing Elementary School outside Houston eagerly awaited the results of state achievement tests this spring. For the principal and assistant principal, high scores could buoy their careers at a time when success is increasingly measured by such tests. For fifth-grade math and science teachers, the rewards were more tangible: a bonus of $2,850.

headline: Quote Unquote | It’s Not Rocket Science
text: –Cindy Crawford’s 8-year-old daughter Kaia explains her career plan, before she becomes an actress or a teacher or something that requires brains. Having Cindy Crawford as your mom doesn’t count as a special skill?

headline: Group F: Easy Path for Italy
text: Its roster may creak with soccer dotage, but if Italy can’t clamber out of this lukewarm group and into the knockout round, it would foment the kind of national indignation that visits many a football country and provides one of the last great forms of free entertainment.

headline: 2010 World Cup: Fighting AIDS
text: An American soccer star joins the TRIAD Trust using the game to educate children and young adults about how to protect themselves from contracting H.I.V.

headline: Expert Answers on Pancreatic Cancer: Genetics and Screening
text: Dozens of readers recently posed questions about pancreatic cancer to the Consults blog. Here, Dr. Eileen O’Reilly, a pancreatic cancer expert at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, addresses concerns about the role of genetics in pancreatic cancer and who should be screened for the disease.

headline: Crowdsourcing the F.C.I.C.’s Goldman Investigation
text: The Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission has been livid with Goldman Sachs, which sent 5 terabytes worth of data on its mortgage-linked investments in response to repeated requests. That’s what we call a good-old fashioned document dump.

headline: A Stimulus Package With No Jobs?
text: Is it possible to botch stimulus spending on renewable energy projects? Florida and the federal Department of Energy have found a way, according to the Energy Department’s inspector general.

headline: Militia Is Said to Be Target of Afghan Wedding Attack
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The groom and 17 of the guests at a rural Kandahar wedding party attacked by a suicide bomber on Wednesday night were members of an anti-Taliban guard organization encouraged initially by American Special Operations forces, and the bomber’s goal appeared to be to undermine support for the group, elders and government officials in the area said Thursday.

headline: Game Is Beautiful, on and Off the Field
text: Midfielder Yael Averbuch helped lead Sky Blue F.C. to the championship of Women’s Professional Soccer in the league’s first season. Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., product by way of the University of North Carolina, will be filing to the Goal blog during the defending champions’ 2010 season.

headline: Over Here, Underemployed, Overqualified
text: WASHINGTON — With millions of Americans out of work or underemployed themselves, it is no surprise that resettlement organizations in the United States are facing a problem placing Iraqi refugees in jobs. Not only is the job market tough, but many of the Iraqi refugees are also apparently overqualified for the jobs that are available.

headline: The Full Soros Speech on ‘Act II’ of the Crisis
text: Here’s the full text of George Soros speech on Thursday at the Institute of International Finance in Vienna, which DealBook described earlier.

headline: Tax Bill Would Benefit Small Businesses — and Burden Some, Too
text: The Senate this week takes up a tax extenders bill with provisions that are sure to please small businesses. The American Jobs and Closing Tax Loopholes Act of 2010 — which has already passed the House twice and the Senate once — resuscitates many business tax benefits that expired at the end of last year. It also revives provisions in the stimulus bill that have bolstered Small Business Administration lending by increasing loan guarantees and eliminating borrower fees. Several times those measures have expired before winning short-term extensions from Congress, but they have not yet been renewed after running out of money and legal authority at the end of May. This bill will extend them through the end of the year.

headline: Ilyumzhinov on the Election, His Opponent and His Alien Abduction
text: The Russian newspaper Gazeta has published an interview with Kirsan Ilyumzhinov, the president of the World Chess Federation, in which he discussed his campaign to be re-elected, his opponent — Anatoly Karpov, the former world champion — and his claim that he was once abducted by extraterrestrials.

headline: The World Cup, Apps for That
text: Technology is set to meet soccer at a smartphone intersection when the World Cup begins Friday. This is a leap forward in technology with a clutch of iPhone apps that will enable fans to track games, watch highlights and glean information on players and teams.

headline: A New Leapster
text: This week, Leapfrog unveiled Leapster Explorer, a re-engineered, Flash-based edition of one of its most established educational gadgets. It will cost $70 and is aimed at ages 4 to 9. And when it arrives in stores on July 15, it will face stiff competition, far greater the original Leapster did in 2003, when the Game Boy Advance was state-of-the-art.

headline: J.W. Anderson | Personal Designs
text: One of the breakthrough talents at London’s MAN day, the men’s-wear event organized by New Gen and Fashion East, was J.W. Anderson. The 26-year-old designer’s proto-grunge-adventurer collection had raw energy but was well developed and produced, with clothes and accessories joining to offer a complete vision that was commercially viable but creatively uncompromising. Anderson worked on a collaboration with Dazed Digital and Oki-Ni.com to stream the show live and sell the collection online. Not surprisingly, it sold out instantly.

Far removed from the misery on the ground, he has created canvases that would not be out of place in a gallery of modern art. See “An Awful Beauty in Hungarian Floods.”

headline: Watson to Host Documentary Screening to Honor Late Caddie

headline: An Awful Beauty in Hungarian Floods
text: As anyone knows who has followed the photo documentation of the catastrophic Deepwater Horizon oil leak, aerial pictures tend by their nature to obscure the damage done at surface level and below. At the same time, however, there is no denying that high-altitude views exert an abstract attraction of their own. Sandor H. Szabo, a photographer for the MTI Hungarian News Agency, has been taking the long view of the flooding in his country that has displaced about 4,000 people. Far removed from the misery on the ground, he has created canvases that would not be out of place in a gallery of modern art. They are well worth examining in “Full Screen” mode.

headline: Travel Gadgets, New and Improved?
text: A heap of travel gadgets hitting the market brings the comfort of home — and images from there, too — to people on the road, Christine Negroni reports in The Times. Among the offerings: a personal video system that allows you to aim wireless cameras at say, your cat’s food bowl and view it real time on the Web; a battery-run charger for mobile devices; and goggles with a built-in monitor that for the viewer is the equivalent of an 80-inch screen. Seriously. Our former Frugal Traveler compiled a list of gadgets last year, and so have Time and Travel and Leisure. But a narrow poll of In Transit editors — who are partial to smartphones and travel guides — indicates that we could still use some suggestions. Got any favorite devices that you just can’t leave home without?

headline: Stream of Conviviality for Leopold Bloom’s Day
text: BLOOMSDAY may not have reached the nerd heights of Comic-Con, but it’s still a glorious expression of fandom. Each year, in honor of the raunchy, transcendent Dublin day recounted in James Joyce’s  “Ulysses”  — which details the comings and goings of Leopold Bloom on June 16, 1904 — acolytes rejoice with readings, parties and pub crawls. Few subcultural gatherings merge high and low with quite as much pluck.

headline: Resort Report | Rag & Bone’s Knit Picks

The show was not about what a girl wears on a yacht but what she wears to go gallery hopping in Chelsea or to catch a film at BAM. Especially covet-worthy are any of the multitude of chunky sweaters which are available in gray, navy and black.

headline: A Ball Field That Feels Like Home

Die-hard devotees of Softball Lite  my local pickup coed game  head instead for Zinsser Park in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., to play ourselves. We’ve been doing it, rain or shine, until the snow flies, for nine years.

headline: A Bike Tour for Art Lovers, a Show for ‘Fela!’ Fans, Capoeira Lessons and a Korean Film
text: Any art lover can visit a museum, but the more adventurous can take to the streets for the New York City Department of Transportation’s free bike tour on Saturday. From 9:30 a.m. to noon, a guide will lead cyclists across Manhattan to murals, sculptures and mosaics sponsored by the Urban Art Program, an effort to invigorate the city’s streetscapes. At select stops, the artists will be on hand to talk about their work. Riders are invited to meet on the north side of 23rd Street and Broadway, at Madison Square Park, with bike, helmet, lots of water and a camera. (Registration is requested: rsvp.bikes@dot.nyc.gov or 212-839-7211.)

The company starts to feel like a company, junior dancers acquire more roles, stars appear in the work of several different choreographers in quick succession, and ballet itself again becomes interesting and diverse.

headline: Martyrs: Roasted, Beheaded or Maimed
text: NEW HAVEN  Two 17th-century paintings by the same artist, each depicting a comely, partly naked woman, welcome viewers to “Italian Paintings From the Richard L. Feigen Collection,” a high-quality exhibition at the Yale University Art Gallery here. One, by Orazio Gentileschi from around 1628, is a run-of-the-mill depiction of the penitent Mary Magdalene, half reclining on her side on the cold floor of a shadowy cave. A dark orange blanket covers her legs and lower torso, leaving her breasts and shoulders exposed. Leaning with one elbow on a large, open book, her long hair flowing over its pages and a skull nestled under her arm, she gazes heavenward with a pious, melancholy expression.

headline: Where Life Is Cold, and Kin Are Cruel
text: Even before the real trouble starts — with suspicious lawmen on one side and a clan of violent drug dealers on the other — Ree Dolly faces more than the usual litany of adolescent worries. Her father, locally renowned for his skill at cooking methamphetamine, has vanished, and her emotionally hollowed-out mother has long since abandoned basic parental duties, leaving Ree (Jennifer Lawrence) to run the household and care for her two younger siblings. The family lives in southwestern Missouri, a stretch of the Ozarks that is both desolate and picturesque, words that might also suit “Winter’s Bone,” Debra Granik’s tender and flinty adaptation of a novel of the same title by Daniel Woodrell.

The spoils of this season are such that a large trove of 1970s and ’80s Lichtensteins arrived last month without much fanfare at the Gagosian Gallery on West 24th Street, overshadowed by another Gagosian coup  Monet’s late paintings  a few blocks away.

headline: A Comic’s Life and Times: Enter Talking or Mocking
text: Joan Rivers  where have you been all my life? That, at least, is what I thought after watching (twice) the documentary “Joan Rivers: A Piece of Work.” Directed by Ricki Stern and Annie Sundberg, this convulsively funny movie takes an up-close and sometimes queasy-personal approach to its motormouth subject, who, when she’s not making you howl with laughter (or freeze up in horror), brandishes her deeply held hurts, fears, prejudices, poor judgment and bad taste as if they were stigmata.

headline: Behind Closed Doors With Bloomberg
text: As far as media-friendly politicians go, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is nowhere near the top of the list. Mr. Bloomberg — a media tycoon is his own right — has been known to bristle at questions he doesn’t like and seems to find the New York media something of an annoyance.

headline: On the Horns of Abundance: Jazz Festivals Resound
text: AN extraordinary amount of jazz hits New York over the next two weeks: four festivals, about 150 sets, and much of it extracurricular to the usual riches at the clubs. It’s a time of marathons and breadth and goes in heavy for the new: not just youth, but also new aesthetic combinations, new attitudes toward repertory, new influences and paradigms, new clubs and theaters. Unlike some past jazz festival seasons, with more brand-polishing and sentimental favorites, this one  in the aggregate  can really show you where both the music and the culture of jazz in New York have gotten to.

headline: Stanley Cup Finals Ratings
text: The sixth and final game in the Stanley Cup Finals on Wednesday, in which the Chicago Blackhawks won their first championship since 1961, delivered the hockey series’s best ratings in 36 years and lifted NBC for the night. Nielsen’s preliminary overnight ratings for the game were up 41 percent compared with last year’s Game 6, a match that earned 5.8 million viewers. Pending final ratings, NBC appeared to rank second for the night behind Fox, which led over all with “So You Think You Can Dance” (8 million). CBS was third with reruns. ABC was fourth.

headline: Dell in Talks to Settle Intel Claims With S.E.C.
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Dell said on Thursday that it was in talks with the Securities and Exchange Commission to resolve allegations that it and its founder and chief executive, Michael S. Dell, engaged in financial irregularities related to the company’s dealings with Intel.

headline: Backtracking, G.M. Says Please, Call It a Chevy
text: Responding to negative reactions to an internal memorandum discouraging use of the word Chevy, General Motors moved on Thursday to explain its strategy and to reassure consumers that it still valued the popular nickname for Chevrolet.

text: “Rubicon” seems irresistible: a suspenseful series laced with conspiracy and espionage in the style of classic 1970s thrillers like “Three Days of the Condor” and “The Parallax View.”

headline: Songs That Rock the Boat, With Heart and Soul, Too
text: On the face of it, Frank Loesser, one of Broadway’s all-time great wielders of urban slang, and Karen Oberlin, a demure pop-jazz singer who radiates a subdued glamour, are not a natural fit. Had he lived in a later time, Loesser, who died in 1969, might have turned a Martin Scorsese movie like “Raging Bull” into a hard-boiled pop opera.

headline: Integrating Ensembles to Build a Hybrid Work
text: After proudly making note of the Martha Graham Dance Company’s 84th season, the troupe’s artistic director, Janet Eilber, allowed herself a small joke, telling the audience at the Joyce Theater, “We do have a different group of dancers with us tonight” rather than the original members.

headline: Youth’s Joy in Movement, Energetic and Unfettered
text: The annual School of American Ballet workshop has been a talent-spotting highlight of the New York balletomane’s year ever since George Balanchine and Alexandra Danilova instituted the performances in 1965. In the lobby of the Peter Jay Sharp Theater before Saturday afternoon’s first performance this year, old hands reminisced about seeing Gelsey Kirkland, Kyra Nichols, Peter Boal and Monique Meunier in their student days.

headline: Turning Points
text: In 2007, the anthropologist Mary Douglas published a groundbreaking, if little-­noticed, book, “Thinking in Circles,” which argued that many seemingly disjointed, chaotic or arbitrarily organized ancient narratives — for example, the Book of Numbers in the Hebrew Bible — are carefully designed to be read in a circular, rather than linear, form. A circular or “ring” narrative is one in which events come to a decisive point in the middle and then lead back, in parallel fashion, to the point of entry: ABCBA. Unlike a conventional (we might say ABCDE) narrative, which builds to a world-altering climax near the end, a ring narrative appears symmetrical and “exhaustively coherent,” like a snowflake. “When every element in the composition interacts with all the others,” Douglas writes, “and nothing is extraneous or unnecessary, everything contributes to embellish the pattern.”

headline: Tapping the Roots of American Music
text: The closing concert of the enterprising Riverside Symphony’s 29th season, on Wednesday evening at Alice Tully Hall, was a thematic program that pulled together 20th-century works with roots in American vernacular music.

headline: ‘Roy Lichtenstein: Still Lifes’

headline: Inquiry Finds Graves Mismarked at Arlington
text: WASHINGTON — The remains in more than 200 graves at Arlington National Cemetery may be incorrectly identified, the secretary of the Army said Thursday, as he announced a shake-up in the cemetery’s management. In some cases, remains were found in graves listed as empty, and occupied grave sites were unmarked.

text: Just because you can do something, does that mean you should? It’s a question that might have saved us a lot of pain in recent months if both Goldman Sachs and British Petroleum had asked it of themselves during the last decade.

headline: Three Readings on History
text: David Bentley Hart explains why you shouldn’t trust Hollywood’s account of the destruction of the Great Library of Alexandria.

headline: Guilds Express Concern About Possible Miramax Sale
text: Representatives of Hollywood’s principal guilds have told the Walt Disney Company that they have serious concerns about the possible sale of its Miramax Films unit to an investor group organized by David Bergstein. A number of his companies are the subject of involuntary bankruptcy proceedings in which the guilds are creditors.

headline: Honey, He Sold the Kids
text: My brother-in-law persuaded my husband to take out a large line of credit at the bank, then forged his signature and transferred the money to his own account. When we threatened to report him, their father paid the loan, but our credit was ruined. My brother-in-law never made restitution, and the family acts as if this never happened. I’ve stopped attending family events, but my husband still goes with the children. Don’t you think he’s setting a bad example?

headline: Referees Brush Up on Curses in 17 Languages
text: JOHANNESBURG  When it comes to selecting just the right swear word to hurl at a referee, Wayne Rooney is a walking thesaurus. In exchanges with officials, he mixes and matches with such flourish, he might be confused for Roget’s bawdy cousin.

headline: American Airlines Again Considers Sale of Regional Unit
text: 12:29 p.m. | Corrected The parent company of American Airlines said on Thursday that it was again considering selling American Eagle, its regional airline unit, even as it named a new chief executive for the subsidiary.

headline: 4 Guys Who Still Like to Blow Things Up
text: The biggest hurdle that confronted the makers of the “The A-Team,” the raucous, winking big-screen version of the raucous, winking small-screen 1980s television show, wasn’t logistical. The problem wasn’t how to demolish this van (throw something heavy on it) or destroy that helicopter (write a software program) or toss bodies through the air (cue the stunt men and more software).

headline: Depression-Era Woes, Echoing in the Present
text: There’s nothing for sale in the vacant store where “Can You Hear Their Voices?” is being performed. No shelves, registers or clerks, either. Yet there’s constant talk of money, of business, of labor. The play, a nifty piece of agitprop from the Depression, isn’t shy when voicing ideas about the American economy, and this production, as heavy-handed as it sometimes turns, doesn’t have to stretch too far to find parallels to current events.

headline: New Estimates Double Rate of Oil Flowing Into Gulf
text: A government panel on Thursday essentially doubled its estimate of how much oil has been spewing from the out-of-control BP well, with the new calculation suggesting that an amount equivalent to the Exxon Valdez disaster could be flowing into the Gulf of Mexico every 8 to 10 days.

headline: The Forecast for Tony Night: Mixed
text: AS a new Broadway theater season loomed last summer, some producers couldn’t wait to start forecasting the 2010 Tony Award races, whispering that there would be three front-running new musicals to watch: “The Addams Family,” “American Idiot” and “Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark.”

headline: In This Remake of an ’80s Martial Arts Fable, It’s Jacket On, Jacket Off
text: You don’t need a hot tub time machine to tell you that we are in the midst of an ’80s pop-culture revival. It’s hardly surprising, since the kids who grew up watching the movies and television of that decade  “The A-Team” and “The Karate Kid,” to restrict ourselves to films opening this week  are now old enough to make and approve projects of their own. A lot of franchises that started out back in those kind-of-innocent, not-so-simple times have kept on going ever since. “The Terminator,” for instance, and Bruce Willis.

headline: Can the U.S. Punish BP’s Shareholders?
text: The United States Justice Department said on Wednesday that it was considering legal action to block British Petroleum from paying dividends to make sure the company covers all costs related to the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. Interior Secretary Ken Salazar has said BP would be asked to pay energy companies for losses if they had to lay off workers because of the moratorium on deepwater drilling.

headline: More Than 200 Graves Misidentified at Arlington
text: At least 211 people are buried in unmarked or misidentified graves at Arlington National Cemetery, top Army officials announced on Thursday. Two top employees at the cemetery were disciplined as a result of what Secretary of the Army John M. McHugh described as “dysfunctional” management, according to a report on the Stars and Stripes Web site.

headline: Should Bush Keep His Heisman?
text: Now that the N.C.A.A. has forced Southern California to vacate all of its victories that Reggie Bush participated in beginning in December 2004, some are wondering if Bush will lose the Heisman Trophy he won in 2005.

headline: Bringing Comparison Shopping to the Doctor’s Office
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Americans comparison-shop for items as small as groceries and as big as cars. But they rarely compare prices on their health care. When a doctor recommends a test or a procedure, most patients simply go where the doctor tells them to go.

headline: Who Is Alvin Greene?

text: Software companies like Adobe, Apple and Microsoft have long had to battle software pirates. Now these companies are beginning to face some trickier contenders: free Web-based software.

headline: Vietnam and Iraq Invade a Marriage
text: When bad acting happens to good actors, it’s sometimes hard to know where to look. My attention kept straying to my shoes, to the back of the chair in front of me, to the tacky patio furniture of the set, in order to avoid having to watch Kathleen Chalfant and George Bartenieff flail their way through “Prophecy,” a long and ludicrous new play written and directed by Karen Malpede at the Fourth Street Theater in the East Village.
