headline: In Johannesburg, Drawn to a Life of Crime
text: “Jerusalema,” in the awkward title “Gangster’s Paradise: Jerusalema,” has two meanings, neither of which involves the Middle East. It refers to a figurative city on a hill, the promise of dignity and economic equality held out to black South Africans at the end of apartheid; and a literal one, the Johannesburg neighborhood Hillbrow, where that promise dissolved into poverty and rampant crime.

headline: Brooks, Maker of Elite Shoes, Takes Aim at the Fun Run Crowd
text: BROOKS SPORTS, the footwear and apparel brand founded in 1914, has for most of its history made shoes for a variety of sports, but in 2000 it narrowed that focus considerably to just running shoes, with models today retailing for $85 to $140. The strategy paid off. Brooks sprinted through the downturn with annual growth of 5 to 10 percent over the last three years, and reported revenue totaling nearly $200 million in 2009.

headline: Teenage Girl, Sailing Solo, Is Missing
text: A 16-year-old girl trying to sail solo around the world was missing in the Indian Ocean some 2,000 miles east of Madagascar, according to her family, who said Thursday that she had encountered treacherous seas.

headline: Veterans Helped Guide Youthful Blackhawks
text: PHILADELPHIA  Patrick Kane, the 21-year-old Chicago Blackhawks prodigy with a patchy playoff beard, paused just long enough during the Stanley Cup celebration on the ice Wednesday night to mug for a photo with four buddies from back home in Buffalo.

headline: Feeling Better at 50
text: To the Editor:

headline: What Marja Tells Us of Battles Yet to Come
text: MARJA, Afghanistan  Each day, American foot patrols move through farmers’ fields and irrigated villages. And each day some are ambushed or encounter hidden bombs. The patrols turn into gunfights in withering heat, or efforts to dismantle the bombs or treat the wounded. Casualties accumulate with the passing weeks, for Americans and Afghans alike.

headline: The Value of Humanities Studies, and the Sciences
text: To the Editor:

headline: Day 51: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: President Meets With Workers’ Families

headline: The Dartmouth Research on Health Care Spending
text: To the Editor:

headline: S.E.C. Chief Promotes More Rules for Trades
text: MONTREAL  Last month’s market volatility and concerns over unfair trading may require new controls on electronic trading systems, Mary L. Schapiro, the chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said on Thursday.

headline: U.S. Fury at BP Stirs Backlash Among British
text: LONDON  Spewing oil and alienating Americans with its chief executive’s impolitic remarks, BP may be Public Enemy No. 1 in the United States. But in Britain, where the company is a mainstay of the stock market and a favorite of pension funds, investors and politicians are becoming increasingly angry at the blistering attacks from across the Atlantic.

headline: Boehner on Who Must Pay What for Spill
text: So where exactly does John Boehner stand on whether the federal government should chip in for the cleanup of and damages caused by the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico?

headline: Education by Chance
text: With a little tweaking “The Lottery” would fit nicely into the marketing materials for the Harlem Success Academy, a public charter school founded by Eva Moskowitz, a former New York City councilwoman. On one level, this heart-tugging documentary recounts the experiences of four children competing in the academy’s annual intake lottery. On another, it’s a passionate positioning of charter schools as the saviors of public education.

headline: Mind Over Mass Media
text: Truro, Mass.

headline: Celebrity Adviser Faces More Fraud Charges
text: The fraud case against Kenneth I. Starr, the jailed financial adviser to the stars, expanded Thursday, with prosecutors listing more elderly entertainment industry figures as victims and nearly doubling their loss to $59 million — a figure expected to climb, The Associated Press Reports.

headline: Marketing Venture From Bateman and Arnett Takes Off With Orbit
text: The comedians Will Arnett and Jason Bateman are introducing their first videos created in concert with brands, five months after announcing DumbDumb, something they call a “sponsor-driven advertising and production company.”

headline: Celtics Beat Lakers to Even Series
text: BOSTON — When it mattered most, the Celtics’ best players — the ones that have already guided them to one championship — sat while the bench provided the lead and the eventual 96-89 victory in Game 4 of the N.B.A. finals that evened the best-of-seven at 2-2. Boston hosts Game 5 on Sunday.

headline: Investment Adviser Indicted in Wider Fraud
text: Kenneth Ira Starr, the New York investment adviser who represented actors including Sylvester Stallone and Wesley Snipes, was indicted on Thursday on charges of stealing at least $59 million from clients, almost double the amount previously thought.

headline: Mexico’s Coach Feeds a Nation’s Obsession
text: JOHANNESBURG  Of all the opponents that South Africa could have faced Friday in the first World Cup match on African soil, none will probably be better prepared for the noise and emotion and altitude than Mexico.

headline: Heated Opposition to a Proposed Mosque
text: A church may be a church, and a temple a temple, but through the prism of emotion that still grips many New Yorkers almost a decade after 9/11, a mosque can apparently represent a lot of things.

headline: Guilds Said to Tell Disney of Concerns on Miramax Talks
text: LOS ANGELES  Representatives of Hollywood’s principal guilds have told the Walt Disney Company that they have serious concerns about the possible sale of its Miramax Films unit to an investor group organized by David Bergstein.

headline: Phillies Are Swatting and Flailing
text: PHILADELPHIA

headline: Drawing Fire: Remains of the Day
text: This is the last in a five-part series. To read from the beginning, go to “Drawing Fire: Into Ubaydi.”

headline: A Basic Civil Right
text: After a nearly three-week trial in January, and a lengthy hiatus while lawyers fought over documents, closing arguments are scheduled for Wednesday in a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of Proposition 8, California’s ban on same-sex marriage.

headline: Drug Maker Seen as Uncooperative on Inquiry
text: A Congressional investigation into a recent recall of children’s Tylenol and other pediatric medicines has been stymied by the manufacturer, Johnson & Johnson, investigators say, raising the prospect that new measures  like issuing of subpoenas to compel cooperation  could be invoked.

headline: Beyond Iran Sanctions, Plans B, C, D and ...
text: WASHINGTON  No one in the Obama White House believes that, by themselves, the newest rounds of sanctions against Iran’s military-run businesses, its shipping lines and its financial institutions will force Tehran to halt its 20-year-long drive for a nuclear capability.

headline: The Message From Arkansas
text: They may not have won, but discontented Democrats sent an important message to the Obama administration on Tuesday by mounting an unexpectedly strong primary challenge to Senator Blanche Lincoln of Arkansas. For the White House to minimize the efforts of unions and others who helped support that challenge suggests a tone-deafness to the growing restlessness in the Democratic Party.

headline: A Potato Remade for Industry Has Some Swedes Frowning
text: SKARA, Sweden  Johan Bergstrom, a blond and boyish man of 31, who farms here with his father, reached into the dark, soft soil and extricated a tennis-ball-size potato, holding it gently so as not to snap off any of a half-dozen white shoots that were growing out of the potato’s eyes. He advised against tasting the potato, whose dulcet name Amflora belies its harsh flavor, a result of genetic jiggling that has made it almost pure starch.

headline: Real Justice for Juveniles
text: Gov. David Paterson of New York has sent the Legislature a juvenile justice bill that would achieve two urgently important goals. It would improve the quality of the leadership and care in the state’s often dangerous and inhumane juvenile facilities. And it would ensure that only children who need to be institutionalized  because they present a risk to the public  end up in the facilities.

headline: Deal for Ground Zero Workers
text: After the World Trade Center attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, thousands of people worked heroically, searching for remains and clearing the rubble. Too many later paid a price for not having adequate respirators or other equipment. They grew sick, many with respiratory illnesses. Or they grew increasingly anxious about how the stew of noxious chemicals would affect their health in the years to come.

headline: Gay Couples Gain Under Violence Against Women Act
text: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department has decided that federal prosecutors should enforce criminal provisions in the Violence Against Women Act in cases involving gay and lesbian relationships, a newly disclosed memorandum shows.

headline: Iran Defends Rights Record as Opposition Cancels Rally
text: UNITED NATIONS  As Iran defended its record before the United Nations Human Rights Council, calling itself a model of Middle East democracy, opposition leaders in Tehran on Thursday canceled a weekend rally marking one year since the country’s disputed presidential election because the government did not give them a permit.

headline: Plan Would Allow Abortions at Military Hospitals
text: WASHINGTON  The fight to allow gay and bisexual people to serve openly in the military is already drawing political blood in Washington, but tucked into the same 852-page Pentagon policy bill as the repeal of “don’t ask, don’t tell” is a little-noticed amendment that takes on another emotionally charged issue: making abortion easier for military women in war zones.

headline: Scoring Low, More Pupils Face School This Summer
text: An estimated 21,000 elementary and middle school students scored at the lowest levels on state math and reading exams, New York City education officials said Thursday, meaning that twice as many students in those schools as last year will be required to enroll in summer school.

headline: Contractors Told to Prepare for Moon Program’s End
text: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has greatly scaled back the work it will do in the coming months on its program to return astronauts to the moon, telling companies working on the program to set aside money to cover its potential cancellation.

headline: In Louisville, View of Banks’ Role in the Everyday
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  A $238 million basketball arena is rising on Main Street, financed through a bond deal underwritten by Goldman Sachs.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Here’s to Jacques-Yves Cousteau
text: Friday marks the 100th anniversary of the birth of Jacques-Yves Cousteau, who is an absolute hero of mine (and that’s not a word I toss around much).

headline: Surprising Immigration Crackdown Advances
text: BOSTON  Lawmakers were tangled in budget talks inside the Massachusetts Statehouse this week, but a 19-year-old college student spent even more time at the gold-domed building on Beacon Hill.

headline: General Forecasts Slower Pace in Afghan War
text: BRUSSELS  The top United States and NATO commander in Afghanistan, Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, acknowledged Thursday that efforts in Kandahar to drive back Taliban insurgents were likely to take significantly longer than planned, raising new questions about what can be achieved in southern Afghanistan before the end of the year.

headline: Bitterness Follows End of a School
text: After more than a century on the West Side of Manhattan, St. Michael Academy had assumed the traits of some of its best students: cash poor, underestimated by peers, capable of defying expectations with breathtaking regularity.

headline: Congressional Negotiators Start Effort to Merge Versions of Financial Reform Bills
text: WASHINGTON  Negotiators from the House and Senate gathered on Thursday to merge two bills representing the most comprehensive changes to financial regulation since the Depression, but the script they acted out was largely being written elsewhere.

headline: How Failure Became an Option
text: Needing a break from the omnipresent BP oil cam, I went back and watched the spirit-resuscitating “Apollo 13.”Oh, to revel in the days when we could fix anything with duct tape and American self-confidence! Sad to say, it looks like a time capsule.

headline: South Africa’s Hopes Extend Beyond Field
text: JOHANNESBURG — The World Cup begins here on Friday with excitement at so elevated a level that even many of the unhappy are happy.

headline: A Place to Kick Back
text: Freddie LjungbergAge: 33Occupation: Soccer playerComing Project: Kicking off his instructional camp, Freddie Ljungberg’s Advanced Soccer Clinic at Suncadia, in Cle Elum, Wash., Aug. 20-22

headline: An Early Campaign Gaffe Makes a Non-Issue Big
text: You can parse a voting record. Flip-flops  political ones  are fair game. But don’t talk about a woman’s hair.

headline: Uncertainty Marks Start of Expansion
text: One of the most chaotic off-season days in the recent history of college sports left the Pacific-10’s signature member, Southern California, bludgeoned by a landmark N.C.A.A. ruling. Although the penalties included a two-year postseason ban and the loss of 30 scholarships, the most significant development Thursday was the major restructuring of the landscape of collegiate athletics.

headline: Prune and Grow
text: Sixteen months ago, Congress passed a stimulus package that will end up costing each average taxpayer $7,798. Economists were divided then about whether this spending was worth it, and they are just as divided now.

headline: Hundreds Held in Drug Raids in 16 States
text: WASHINGTON  A coordinated series of law enforcement raids across 16 states this week resulted in the arrests of 429 people accused of participating in smuggling and transportation networks for Mexican drug cartels, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. announced Thursday.

headline: Judge Denies Bail for Men in Terror Case
text: NEWARK  A federal judge denied bail on Thursday to two New Jersey men accused of trying to fly to Somalia to join an Islamist insurgent group.

headline: Senate Rejects Republican Effort to Thwart Carbon Limits
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Thursday defeated a Republican-led effort to prevent the Environmental Protection Agency from curbing greenhouse gases as lawmakers road-tested arguments for a future fight over climate change legislation.

headline: Explorer Born June 11, 1910
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Having tribute puzzles appear on significant birthdays is a crossword tradition, and Birthday Number 100 seems significant enough. We’re looking for an explorer born a century ago today. Since the anniversary falls on a Friday, we end up with a very open themeless-style grid (only 26 blocks) that’s light on the number of theme entries but fills the Friday requirements for fans of late-week puzzles.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: A.S.P.C.A.’s Veterinary Forensics
text: A.S.P.C.A.’s senior director of veterinary forensics is the “captain” of a new canine C.S.I. unit.

headline: At Jackson’s Side, And Patiently Waiting His Turn
text: BOSTON  In a pivotal moment of the Los Angeles Lakers’ 2009 title run, Brian Shaw drew a blank, literally and deliberately, with a hint of creative mischief.

headline: Red Bulls Grab the Back Page
text: In the annals of New York sports, one of the goals is to garner the back page of the city’s tabloid newspapers (which in actuality, are the front pages of the sports sections of The New York Post and The Daily News).

headline: A.I.G. Needs A.I.A. Deal Soon
text: The credibility of the chief executive of A.I.G. was damaged by the failure of Prudential of Britain to buy its Asian unit. He needs to execute Plan B to restore it.

headline: Vija Celmins:  ‘New Paintings, Objects and Prints’
text: Starting in 1977 the artist Vija Celmins devoted a lot of energy to 11 small stones. First she made sure they were fabulously (really) diverse: tiny and darkly smooth as opposed to larger and delicately mottled or glassily angular and crystalline. The largest was brown with white flecks and a white Saturn-like ring. Next Ms. Celmins cast the stones in bronze and over the next five years painted each cast until it was absolutely identical to the original. The piece, “To Fix the Image in Memory,” is a mind-bending, eye-stretching poetic wonder: a universe of visible and invisible differences, a solar system in which each surface presents a galaxy of details. Each stone is a world unto itself — except for its twin.

headline: West Bank: Local Elections Put Off
text: The Palestinian Authority decided Thursday to postpone local elections that had been scheduled for July 17 in the West Bank. A spokesman said the balloting had been put off until further notice. No official reason was given for the delay.

headline: Barbados: Clinton Pledges Aid
text: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton pledged $124 million in American aid to the Caribbean region over the next two years to combat a surge in drug-related violence. Meeting with Caribbean leaders in Barbados, Mrs. Clinton said the region needed American help to crack down on “the highest rate of interpersonal violence in the world.” Responding to concern among the leaders that oil from the spill in the Gulf of Mexico could reach their shores, she said, “We earnestly hope that does not happen.”

headline: Rodriguez Exits Game in First Inning
text: BALTIMORE  Alex Rodriguez played third base and batted cleanup on opening night, and he has started all but two games since. That spell of durability has reinforced his value to the Yankees.

headline: Adolf Dietrich and Richard Phillips: ‘Painting and Misappropriation’
text: The Swiss wildlife and landscape painter Adolf Dietrich (1877-1957) has an unlikely ally in Richard Phillips, a contemporary artist given to large canvases and confrontational imagery. Mr. Phillips has been borrowing themes from Dietrich for years and now makes good on his debts in a stirring show at the Swiss Institute.

headline: Op Out of Ohio: ‘Anonima Group, Richard Anuszkiewicz and Julian Stanczak in the 1960s’
text: Op Art never gets old. “Op Out of Ohio” presents about 30 eye-dazzling optical works from the ’60s by five painters who did time as students or teachers at Oberlin College or the Cleveland Institute of Art. All were also included in “The Responsive Eye,” the landmark 1965 exhibition of perceptual abstraction at the Museum of Modern Art in New York, and went on to exhibit internationally. Richard Anuszkiewicz and Julian Stanczak remain the best known. The others — Ernst Benkert, Francis Hewitt and Ed Mieczkowski — formed a collaborative called “Anonima.” Working in studios side by side, they investigated problems in perception and design with quasi-scientific zeal.

headline: Virginia: Diocese Wins a Battle Over Property
text: The State Supreme Court ruled Thursday against nine conservative congregations that split from the Episcopal Church and tried to take their church properties with them. The Episcopal Church and the Episcopal Diocese of Virginia fought hard in court to retain the properties, worth tens of millions of dollars, in part to deter other breakaway parishes from running off with their assets. The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the ruling of a lower court that had sided with the conservatives in applying a law on how to divide church property when congregations fracture. But the battle is not over. The Supreme Court sent the case back to a lower court to decide a different legal question: whether the denomination or the parish actually owns the properties.

headline: Rousting Africa’s Sleeping Giant
text: Soweto, South Africa

headline: Population Shows a Racial Shift
text: Two large suburban counties flipped from having white majorities to having white minorities last year. Gwinnett County, outside Atlanta, and Contra Costa County, near San Francisco, showed the change as minorities edged closer to becoming a majority of the nation's youngest children. More than 500 of the nation's more than 3,000 now fall in that category. The census estimates released Thursday also quantified the impact of the recession on former population magnets. California recorded the largest net loss of population to other states, 98,000, followed by New York and Michigan. As of July 1, 2009, racial and ethnic groups other than non-Hispanic whites accounted for 48.6 percent of all births and 48.3 percent of children younger than 5.

headline: As Crime Rate Drops, New York’s Jail Population Falls to Lowest Level in 24 Years
text: Fewer inmates are behind bars in New York on any given day than at any time in the past 24 years, and the number admitted to the city’s jail system has fallen below 100,000 for the first time since 1987.

headline: Izzo Meets With Cavaliers
text: Michigan State Coach Tom Izzo met with the Cleveland Cavaliers about their coaching vacancy on Thursday, confirming that the interest between the parties is mutual.

headline: While Waiting on James, Cavaliers Meet With Izzo
text: Michigan State Coach Tom Izzo met with the Cleveland Cavaliers about their coaching vacancy on Thursday, validating speculation that the interest between the parties was mutual.

headline: Photo Replay: June 10
text: Soccer madness takes over on the eve of the start of the World Cup.

headline: Ratings Boost for Game 6
text: The Chicago Blackhawks’ Game 6 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers attracted 8.28 million viewers on NBC, the most since 8.29 million watched Game 3 of the 1974 finals. The viewership for Wednesday night’s overtime game was 43 percent better than the 5.8 million who watched last year’s Game 6, and 4 percent higher than last year’s Game 7. ¶Guy Boucher was hired as the coach of the Tampa Bay Lightning. Boucher, 38, the former coach of the American Hockey League’s Hamilton Bulldogs, becomes the youngest coach in the N.H.L. boucher (AP)

headline: In These Difficult Times, New York State’s Motto Could Be: Will Tattoo for Food
text: Week to week. That’s how the great state of New York is making do during these sorry days of fiscal ridiculousness. Since the state has seen fit to get along without an annual budget, an emergency spending bill gets approved every week authorizing just enough money to enable New York to squeeze through the next seven days.

headline: Students to Protest Possible End of Free Rides
text: Students are planning to walk out of 23 high schools to demonstrate outside City Hall against the threatened end of free bus and subway rides to and from school, protest organizers said Thursday.

headline: ‘Empire of the Summer Moon’
text: Chapter 1: A New Kind of War

headline: Men on Horseback
text: Why does Custer persist? Nearly 134 years after his last stand, a military debacle that cost the lives of all 210 men under his immediate command, George Armstrong Custer remains such an iconic figure in the American pageant that mere mention of his name evokes an entirely overromanticized era in the American West. By all rights he should be a footnote. That he enjoys the glory of single-name recognition is a testament to the power of personality, show business and savvy public relations. Custer wasn’t just an Indian fighter. He was one of the first self-made American celebrities.

headline: Russo Finding His Way in Outfield
text: BALTIMORE  The Hall of Fame pitcher Jim Palmer was about to walk out of the Yankees’ clubhouse when he stopped the defensive star of Wednesday’s game. “Nice play,” Palmer told Kevin Russo, pumping his hand. “You can play defense.”

headline: Italy: Wiretapping Bill Advances
text: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi’s conservative government won a vote in the Senate on Thursday on a bill that restricts wiretaps and fines media organizations that report information derived from wiretaps used in criminal investigations before the case goes to trial. The bill, which now goes to the lower house for final approval, would require a three-judge panel, instead of a single judge, to approve a wiretap; limit the number of days for a wiretap; and require special authorization to listen in on priests.

headline: Recovering the Dead in Haiti
text: On a trip to Haiti in April, Angel Franco, a staff photographer at The Times, met a man called Sony, who had given himself the task of recovering the bodies of his neighbors in the devastated Fort National neighborhood of Port-au-Prince; bodies that were still buried under rubble three months after the earthquake. In this conversation with James Estrin, Mr. Franco recalled what led up to their meeting and how both men memorialized their encounter. It’s been edited for brevity and clarity.

headline: Word of the Day | diadem
text: diadem •\ˈdi-ə-ˌdem, -dəm\• noun

headline: Billions of Dollars Ride on Teams’ Maneuvers for New Stadiums
text: Jed York, the 29-year-old president of the 49ers, made his way to the American Legion hall in Santa Clara on Tuesday night.

headline: A Violent Incident Leaves Scars, and Perhaps a Tough New Law
text: Every fire begins with a spark. For San Francisco’s controversial proposed sit/lie law, the inciting incident happened on a Wednesday night in early December in the Haight  an act of violence so brutal it inspired a grass-roots movement.

headline: Alameda Stirred Up on Tax Plan
text: For years, it was the eclectic Eastern European goods that enticed shoppers into Jenny Turcinovic’s store in Alameda: gummy candy from Serbia, fine Croatian chocolates and bottles of mineral water from Romania and Turkey.

headline: Moving Gay Films Into the Mainstream
text: The Women’s Basketball Coaches Association declined to screen “Training Rules,” a groundbreaking documentary about a homophobic college basketball coach, at a coaches’ conference in San Antonio during the women’s Final Four tournament in April. But Kathy Wolfe was not deterred.

headline: Friday’s Matchups: Mexico vs. South Africa and France vs. Uruguay
text: Mexico vs. South Africa

headline: Judge Provides Impetus for Cook County Jail’s ‘Virtual School’
text: Long before he was assigned to the Cook County Court’s criminal division six years ago, Judge John Kirby was all too familiar with the logjam of nonviolent drug cases on the court’s docket  14,000 annually according to a Justice Department study released last month.

headline: Redemption for Hawks and Kane
text: They’re calling it the most dramatic goal in franchise history, the one Patrick Kane scored against the Philadelphia Flyers four minutes into overtime Wednesday night, enabling his Blackhawks to hoist the Stanley Cup for the first time in 49 years.

headline: New Leader of DDB Must Bring Luster Back
text: In February 2008, 40-year-old Paul Tilley, head of the creative department at DDB Chicago, one of the city’s largest and most prominent advertising agencies, checked into the Fairmont Hotel just steps from the agency’s offices and, soon after, leaped to his death from an upper floor.

headline: A Lament for the Blues in Their Backyard
text: Buddy Guy said he was worried about the blues.

headline: Keeping Score: One Game Says Little About Strasburg
text: It did not take long for declarations of greatness to start after Stephen Strasburg’s debut for the Washington Nationals on Tuesday.

headline: Bench Lifts Celtics to Tie Series
text: BOSTON  The fashionable “Beat L.A.” chants had all but faded from TD Garden, the oxygen bled from the building by Ray Allen’s misfires, Kobe Bryant’s impossible jumpers and Derek Fisher’s intensity. An anxious air hung over the Boston Celtics on Thursday as they teetered on the edge of a heavy series deficit.

headline: Former ‘Grey’s Anatomy’ Star Turns To ‘a Life In the Theater’
text: Based on the 2009 that T. R. Knight had, it can be safely said that he knows a thing or two about life (and death) in the television industry. What does he know about “A Life in the Theater”? Enough to be cast as the co-star in the coming revival of that David Mamet play, its producers said on Thursday. Mr. Knight, left, who last year left his role on “Grey’s Anatomy,” will portray John, a young actor, in the 1977 Mamet work, which will be on Broadway for the first time. He appeared on Broadway in the 2001 revival of “Noises Off” and in “Tartuffe” in 2003. Appearing opposite him in the role of Robert, the mentor, will be the Broadway veteran Patrick Stewart.  “A Life in the Theater” will be directed by Neil Pepe and presented at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater. Preview performances are scheduled to begin on Sept. 23.

headline: Boyle And the Pope?
text: It’s not a done deal, but Susan Boyle, right, may soon be singing for an authority figure who perhaps won’t prejudge her the way Simon Cowell did. A spokesman for the Roman Catholic Church in Scotland told The Associated Press that Ms. Boyle, the homegrown singing sensation who was discovered last year on “Britain’s Got Talent,” was likely to perform for Pope Benedict XVI, right, during a papal tour this fall. While negotiations were still taking place, The A.P. said, Ms. Boyle is expected to sing during an open-air papal Mass at Bellahouston Park in Glasgow on Sept. 16. In a statement, a spokeswoman for Ms. Boyle told Reuters “Susan’s management are currently looking at the possibility of this happening.”

headline: Lone Female Candidate Quits Oxford Poetry Race
text: At a time when Oxford University would surely like to move beyond last year’s disputed election for its professor of poetry position, a new controversy has opened up around that post. The Guardian reported that Paula Claire, the only woman in the running for the position, withdrew from consideration, saying the election process was “seriously flawed” and favored another contender, Geoffrey Hill. Last year the Nobel Prize-winning poet Derek Walcott withdrew from the election after Oxford academics were sent anonymous packages containing pages from a book describing a decades-old act of sexual harassment that he was accused of having committed. Ruth Padel, the first woman in more than 300 years to win the seat, resigned after it was learned that she had sent e-mail messages alerting reporters to that book. Ms. Claire, a poet in Oxford, told The Guardian she was frustrated that the university’s official announcement of candidates described her as a “performer and artist” but not as a poet, and that a flier in Oxford’s Gazette, the official journal of the university, said Mr. Hill was “quite simply a giant” and “the finest living poet in English today.” Ms. Claire said: “That is grossly over the top. They shouldn’t allow it ahead of the election.” A representative of Oxford told The Guardian, “No special arrangements have been made for this election that are inconsistent with normal university operations in this respect.”

headline: China Inflation Rises to a 19-Month High
text: New data from China on Friday cemented the view that the country’s giant economy powered ahead in May  though a marked rise in inflation also raised the pressure on Beijing to slow the booming pace of growth.

headline: Kid Rock, as Comedian, at Country Music Awards
text: If neither Betty White nor Neil Patrick Harris is available to preside over your awards ceremony, might we suggest you consider Kid Rock? On Wednesday’s broadcast of the CMT Music Awards in Nashville, Kid Rock, above, the rap-rock-country crossover star, proved to be quite the kidder, describing Lady Antebellum as “the hillbilly Fleetwood Mac, except I suspect they don’t do drugs or sleep with each other,” and asking , “Will you just have my baby and let’s get it over?” (She replied, “If it’s a girl, maybe.”) Carrie Underwood won video of the year for “Cowboy Casanova” and performance of the year for “Temporary Home.” Lady Antebellum won group video of the year for “Need You Now,” and Miranda Lambert earned her first CMT award, winning female video of the year for “White Liar.” Keith Urban won male video of the year for “ ’Til Summer Comes Around.”

headline: Arizona Tonys Party Canceled
text: A Tony Awards viewing party that was to take place Sunday in Tempe, Ariz., has been canceled. The event, which was to include a telecast of the ceremony prior to its being broadcast on the local CBS affiliate, was to be held at A.S.U. Gammage, an Arizona State University theater that presents touring productions of Broadway shows. “We didn’t get the turnout we wanted,” said Colleen Jennings-Roggensack, the executive director of the theater and a member of the board of governors of the Broadway League, which administers the Tonys with the American Theater Wing. Despite a news media blitz, only about 300 tickets were sold for the event at the theater, which seats 3,000.

headline: $25 Million, and a New Name, For Arts Center Near Seattle
text: The Performing Arts Center Eastside in Bellevue, Wash., has received a $25 million gift  said to be the third largest donation in the United States to a single arts institution since 2007  from the Tateuchi Foundation to help build a performing arts hall in the suburbs of Seattle, the center announced on Wednesday. The new five-story, 135,000-square-foot building in downtown Bellevue  designed by the architect Norman Pfeiffer  will include a 2,000-seat concert hall and a 250-seat cabaret-style space. Groundbreaking is scheduled to start in fall 2011 with an opening planned for 2013. In recognition of the grant, the institution will be renamed the Tateuchi Center, a tribute to the Japanese-American humanitarian, entrepreneur and business leader Atsuhiko Tateuchi, who died in 2007.

headline: Flash Crash: The New Normal?
text: The “flash crash” in United States stock markets that shook investors on May 6 may be the first of many as the market’s herd mentality is exacerbated by ultrafast trading strategies that are rapidly spreading around the world and across asset classes, experts said Thursday.

headline: Movie Listings and Film Series
text: Movies

headline: Horror and Injustice Play Starring Roles
text: It is one of the most stunning moments in “Enemies of the People,” a documentary that revisits the Cambodian killing fields of the late 1970s, and a high point of the Human Rights Watch Film Festival opening on Friday at Lincoln Center. Thet Sambath, a Cambodian journalist whose father and older brother were among the two million slaughtered by the Khmer Rouge, coaxes a Cambodian farmer who carried out its lethal orders to describe his method of execution.

headline: Vladimir Arnold Dies at 72; Pioneering Mathematician
text: Vladimir I. Arnold, a Russian mathematician who discovered important theorems that found application in astronomy, mechanics and even weather forecasting, died June 3 in Paris. He was 72 and had homes in Paris and Moscow.

headline: Peter Keefe, Creator of Cartoon ‘Voltron,’ Dies at 57
text: Peter Keefe, the creator and executive producer of “Voltron: Defender of the Universe,” a hugely popular 1980s cartoon series that helped prepare the way for other Japanese-style animation in the United States, died on May 27 in Rochester. He was 57.

headline: Crispian St. Peters, Singer of the Hit ‘Pied Piper,’ Dies at 71
text: Crispian St. Peters, a British pop singer of the ’60s best known for his buoyant hit “Pied Piper” and his soulful version of “You Were on My Mind,” died on Tuesday at his home in Swanley, Kent, England. He was 71.

headline: News Quiz | June 11, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: S.E.C. Approves Circuit Breaker; Urges New Rules
text: Last month’s market volatility and concerns over unfair trading may require new controls on electronic trading systems, Mary L. Schapiro, the chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said on Thursday, even as the agency approved circuit breakers for the exchanges.

headline: In Louisville, a View of Big Banks’ Everyday Role
text: A $238 million basketball arena is rising on Main Street, financed through a bond deal underwritten by Goldman Sachs. At the corner of Main and Fourth sits a branch of UBS Financial Services, the brokerage arm of the giant Swiss bank. Once known as Whiskey Row, Main Street and the surrounding blocks are now lined with bank towers: BB&T, PNC, National City and Your Community Bank.

headline: E.C.B. Extends Cash Lifeline and Gives Pep Talk
text: The European Central Bank extended its cash lifeline for banks on Thursday, while its president, Jean-Claude Trichet, urged national euro zone regulators to take steps to resuscitate confidence in the health of their financial institutions, Jack Ewing and Julia Werdigier write in The New York Times.

headline: Blackhawks 4, Flyers 3
text: WHEN was the last time the Chicago Blackhawks won the Stanley Cup?WHEN was the last time you were overjoyed by the outcome of a sporting event?

headline: Guy Hands, Citigroup and the Fight for EMI
text: One of the best ways to get inside the head of British private equity boss Guy Hands is to study what gift he gives for Christmas. For years, Mr. Hands has sent friends and business associates a book he has recently read along with a letter discussing the work. The gift is designed to be both thoughtful and thought-provoking, Reuters reports.

headline: Mandela Misses Day 1 of Games to Mourn
text: JOHANNESBURG  Heartbreak intruded on the opening day of the World Cup soccer games when Nelson Mandela’s 13-year-old great-granddaughter Zenani was killed in an auto accident early on Friday.

headline: Plane Locates Teenager Sailing Solo
text: A 16-year-old girl trying to sail solo around the world who was missing in treacherous seas in the Indian Ocean has been found by an Australian search plane and is in good condition, her parents said on Friday.

headline: Dealing With Chermany
text: So here’s where we are: China has done nothing to change its policy of massive currency manipulation, and its exports are surging. Meanwhile, Europe is going wild for fiscal austerity. Angela Merkel says that budget cuts will make Germany more competitive — but competitive against whom, exactly?

headline: Fujitsu and Toshiba Said to Mull Mobile Deal
text: Fujitsu and Toshiba are in talks to merge their mobile phone businesses, two sources told Reuters, in a move that would create Japan’s No. 2 cellphone maker in a rapidly shrinking market.

headline: Misplaced Optimism
text: I wish I could believe in this Macroeconomic Advisers claim that there is a zero chance of a double-dip recession. But when they say that this probability

headline: U.S. Fury at BP Stirs Backlash Among British
text: Spewing oil and alienating Americans with its chief executive’s impolitic remarks, BP may be Public Enemy No. 1 in the United States. But in Britain, where the company is a mainstay of the stock market and a favorite of pension funds, investors and politicians are becoming increasingly angry at the blistering attacks from across the Atlantic, The New York Times’s Sarah Lyall and Julia Werdigier write.

headline: Congress Starts to Merge Financial Reform Bills
text: Negotiators from the House and Senate gathered on Thursday to merge two bills representing the most comprehensive changes to financial regulation since the Depression, but the script they acted out was largely being written elsewhere, The New York Times’s Sewell Chan writes.

headline: Are Your Teachers Under Too Much Pressure?
text: An article today reports on an increase in teachers caught tampering with their students’ standardized tests and scores. Because those scores now often determine which teachers get bonuses and tenure, some say the higher the stakes are, the more teachers will cheat. Do you agree? Do you think this shows that changes in education, including the testing required under No Child Left Behind, are putting too much pressure on your teachers? Or do you think there are just a few “bad apples” who cheat, and that public school teachers are no more pressured than they ever were? Do you think it’s fair to judge teacher performance on student scores in general?

headline: Dell in Talks With S.E.C. to Settle Intel Claims
text: Dell said on Thursday that it was in talks with the Securities and Exchange Commission to resolve allegations that it and its founder and chief executive, Michael S. Dell, engaged in financial irregularities related to the company’s dealings with Intel, The New York Times’s Miguel Helft reported.

headline: Comparison Shopping for Health Care
text: Americans comparison-shop for items as small as groceries and as big as cars. But they rarely compare prices on their health care. When a doctor recommends a test or a procedure, most patients simply go where the doctor tells them to go.

headline: Bonnaroo: Thursday’s Four-Word Reviews
text: Non-Commissioned Officers: Shouty kickoff, afternoon steam.

headline: Markets Rebound, Rising Almost 3%
text: The stock market roared back to life on Thursday, driving the Dow Jones industrial average firmly above 10,000, as investors latched on to hopes that maybe, just maybe, the economic scene was not quite as bleak as it seemed.

headline: Guilds Tell Disney of Concerns on Miramax Talks
text: Representatives of Hollywood’s principal guilds have told the Walt Disney Company that they have serious concerns about the possible sale of its Miramax Films unit to an investor group organized by David Bergstein, The New York Times’s Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes reported.

headline: Japan Leader Warns of Greek-Like Debt Crisis
text: Japan could face a financial mess like the one that has crippled Greece if it does not deal urgently with its swelling national debt, the new prime minister warned Friday, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Bateman and Arnett Raise Curtain on Marketing Venture
text: From Brian Stelter at Media Decoder:

headline: Spanish Banks Strike Preliminary Deal to Merge
text: Caja Madrid and Bancaja said Thursday that they had reached an initial agreement that would create the largest savings bank in Spain as the country’s financial sector continues to consolidate under burgeoning debt worries.

headline: New Violence in Kyrgyzstan Leads to Troop Deployment
text: MOSCOW  At least 46 people were killed and hundreds were wounded in clashes that began late Thursday and continued into Friday in the south of Kyrgyzstan, the Central Asian nation whose president was ousted in riots in April.

headline: Twitter Buys an Analytics Company
text: From Nick Bilton at Bits:

headline: Goldman’s Cohn: No Indication of Settlement
text: The president of Goldman Sachs Group said on Thursday that there is “no indication” that the investment bank is close to settling fraud charges with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Reuters reported.

headline: Going Green in Mumbai
text: In this often hot and crowded city, it can be difficult to escape the blaring horns and careening rickshaws, not to mention the hordes of fellow pedestrians. Luckily, the ever-popular Marine Drive promenade and the Hanging Gardens are not the only green spots in town. For a short morning stroll, check out the leafy neighborhood of Five Gardens, just a five-minute drive from the teeming Dadar train station. While the gardens are a bit rundown, the sidewalks are wide and well shaded, particularly around the stately bungalows of the Dadar Parsi Colony.

headline: Calpine Sews Up Credit Line for Conectiv Deal
text: Power producer Calpine said Thursday that its subsidiary, New Development Holdings, completed a $1.4 billion credit agreement that will help fund Calpine’s purchase of Conectiv Energy, The Associated Press reported.

headline: After the Euphoria, Mourning
text: It is game day, and sometimes a reporter awakes to find that the news just got personal.

headline: Peltz’s Trian Approached for Wendy’s/Arby’s
text: Nelson Peltz said his hedge fund, Trian Fund Management, has received interest from a third party about a possible takeover involving Wendy’s/Arby’s Group, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: TPG to Pay $1.4 Billion to Buy Vertafore off Rivals
text: TPG Capital has agreed to pay $1.4 billion to buy Vertafore, a provider of insurance software, from rival private equity firms Hellman & Friedman and JMI Equity, The Seattle Times reported.

headline: More on Soliciting Employee Ideas
text: I’d like to thank everyone who contributed a comment to my post about soliciting suggestions from my employees. There were some very interesting ideas and quite a few questions as well, so I’d like to start by offering a clearer picture of how I interact with my employees and why information doesn’t flow easily among us. As with many of my business problems, textbook solutions don’t always seem to work within the context of our reality.

headline: Stray Questions for: David Means
text: David Means’s fourth story collection, “The Spot,” is reviewed in this Sunday’s Book Review.

headline: Stray Questions for: David Means
text: David Means’s fourth story collection, “The Spot,” is reviewed in this Sunday’s Book Review.

headline: Bonnaroo: Rediscovering Dynamics
text: Bonnaroo’s warmup day, Thursday, activates only the smaller stages, and only for part of the day. It’s a field test for the festival and for the booked bands, who may return another year on a larger stage.

headline: Pope Pleads for Forgiveness Over Abuse
text: VATICAN CITY  Addressing the sexual abuse crisis from the seat of the Roman Catholic Church before thousands of white-robed priests, Pope Benedict XVI on Friday begged forgiveness, saying the church would do “everything possible” to prevent priests from abusing children.

headline: Private Equity’s $445 Billion Problem
text: The private equity industry has $445 billion burning a hole in its pocket and it could soon turn into a problem, Investor’s Business Daily writes.

text: Here are some highlights from Friday’s edition of The New York Times:

headline: Rethinking the Stop Sign
text: Nearly three decades ago, Gary Lauder received a traffic ticket. “I didn’t come to a complete stop at an intersection,” he said in a phone interview. “There were zero oncoming cars, and I rolled. The ticket only raised revenue and maybe filled a quota. It really bugged me.”

headline: Cuban Plans to Tender Lions Gate Shares to Icahn
text: It looks like Carl C. Icahn will get a little help from  Mark Cuban in his bid to win control of Lions Gate, a CNBC interview with the Dallas Mavericks owner suggested Thursday.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: The Main Street/Wall Street split may be rhetorically useful in Washington as the financial overhaul gets ironed out, but on the ground, the two are in it together for better or for worse. On the other side of the pond, Europe’s troubles are still echoing, with Spain denying reports that it has asked for aid from the euro zone rescue fund.

headline: An Up-and-Down Week Concludes on a Positive Note
text: Stocks ended a roller-coaster week with a gain on Friday, as the technology sector responded to strong results from the chip maker National Semiconductor, while a positive report on consumer confidence offset a decline in retail sales.

headline: Putting Photos on the iPad, No PC Required
text: I bought an iPad from Apple last week — Wi-Fi-only, the cheapest model, for $499. And it’s awesome. This year’s “it” gadget has many talents, and chief among them is its ability to share photos, face to face rather than online. Just like the old days when they had those photos printed on paper.

headline: F.B.I. Readies for Mortgage Fraud Clampdown
text: Mortgage fraudsters beware. The F.B.I. is gearing up for a nationwide clampdown in a new effort to slow the kind of lending practices that led to the housing crash of 2008, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Parsing Europe’s New Biofuel Rules
text: Companies that produce biofuels are broadly cheering the introduction of a certification system by the European Commission. The system, unveiled on Thursday, is supposed to ensure that the industry does not lay waste to forests, drain peat lands or destroy other zones of environmental value in the course of production.

headline: New Tony Award Gets (Unofficial) Theme Song
text: After ArtsBeat reported on Thursday that the Tony Award statuette was getting a larger, heavier redesign for Sunday night’s ceremony, at least one reader was inspired with more than just wistful yearnings for the past.

headline: Suicide Car Bomber Kills 5, Including 2 U.S. Soldiers, in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  A car packed with explosives detonated near a military patrol on Friday in the restive Iraqi province of Diyala, killing two American soldiers, an Iraqi policeman and two Iraqi civilians, the American military said.

headline: The Early Word: The Spill (Estimate) Grows
text: President Obama has asked to meet with officials from BP next week, as the federal government greatly expanded its estimate of how much oil is spewing into the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Tip of the Week: Enjoying the World Cup
text: The World Cup starts today and soccer fans can keep up on all the latest results with a variety of free desktop widgets, gadgets and browser add-ons. For example, the Fédération Internationale de Football Association, the group that governs international soccer, has a page of World Cup widgets to deliver tournament news right to one’s blog, Facebook, MySpace or iGoogle page. FootieFox, an add-on for the Firefox browser, is another option for quietly checking the scores at work.

headline: What if Goldman’s Settlement Was $15 Billion?
text: Execution Noble, which makes trades on behalf of big investors, raised the possibility of Goldman Sachs‘s settlement over various investigations going as high as $15 billion, according to The Street.com. It said a “desk analyst” at Execution thought such a figure would knock $27 off of Goldman’s share price, which was at $133.77 on Friday morning.

headline: Zimbabwe Watches the Cup Next Door
text: According to The Zimbabwean, an independent weekly newspaper produced by exiled journalists, soccer fans in Zimbabwe are watching the world gather in the neighboring country of South Africa and using a visit from Brazil’s national team to express their frustration with their current president, Robert Mugabe.

text: Pop/Jazz

headline: New Route for Pride March Unsettles W. 9th St.
text: For 39 years, the Pride March celebrating the city’s gay population had made its way to the heart of Greenwich Village by way of West Eighth Street. It made its debut one year after the Stonewall riots, and it has become a colorful annual Village tradition.

headline: Alcohol, Diet and Pancreatic Cancer Risks
text: Smoking is a recognized risk factor for cancer of the pancreas, but do other forms of tobacco use increase your risk? What about what you eat or drink, or your exposure to certain chemicals? Dr. Eileen O’Reilly, a pancreatic cancer expert at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, responds to readers who had questions on the Consults blog.

headline: The Animal-Cruelty Syndrome
text: On a late May afternoon last year in southwest Baltimore, a 2-year-old female pit bull terrier was doused in gasoline and set alight. A young city policewoman on her regular patrol of the neighborhood of boarded-up row houses and redbrick housing developments turned her squad car onto the 1600 block of Presbury Street and saw a cloud of black smoke rising from the burning dog. She hopped out, ran past idle onlookers and managed to put out the flames with her sweater. The dog, subsequently named Phoenix, survived for four days with burns over 95 percent of her body, but soon began to succumb to kidney failure and had to be euthanized.

headline: Left Behind: New York’s Shelter Dogs
text: A look at dogs that were found in shelters throughout the state. Many showed signs of violence or neglect.

headline: The Morning Skate: A Memorable End to Blackhawks Cup Victory
text: When Patrick Kane executed his little “juke and jive,” as Craig Simpson called it over “Hockey Night in Canada,” enabling him to freeze Kimmo Timonen just long enough to build a little outside speed, it looked like a move that could lead to a scoring chance. But Timonen stayed with him and kept his path closed. So from near the goal line, Kane just whipped the puck toward Michael Leighton’s skates.

headline: Last in a Series of Answers on Pets in Dorms
text: As a follow-up to an article I wrote for Sunday’s Times on pet-friendly college campuses, I’ve asked Deb Duren — the vice president for student services at one such college, Stephens in Columbia, Mo. — to answer selected reader questions on The Choice this week.

headline: Complaint Box | Shopping Ahead

My finger poised on the delete button, I took a second look at an e-mail message from Abercrombie & Fitch. The company was offering me a sneak peek at its back-to-school line.

headline: Theater Talkback: A Season of ‘Glee’
text: The first full season of “Glee” ended in both tragedy and triumph. Sniffle sniffle. Thanks not to the dastardly machinations of Sue Sylvester but pure celebrity snobbery on the part of Olivia Newton-John and Josh Groban — natural guest judges for a high school singing contest in Ohio — the club from McKinley High finished third in the finals.

headline: Women Don’t Help Each Other?
text: Recently, someone asked me why women don’t support each other in business. The question threw me because it presumed a fact that seemed dubious at best — and completely contrary to the reality I’ve experienced, both personally and through the stories I’ve written about women who own businesses. The “cat fight” narrative might draw viewers to reality TV shows and romantic comedies, but it’s not helpful to the female business owner eager to learn from and share with her peers.
