headline: Friday Reading: Comparison Shopping for a Doctor
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Guatemala Attorney General Ousted
text: MEXICO CITY  Guatemala’s constitutional court has removed the nation’s embattled attorney general, appearing to head off a growing political crisis in a country besieged by organized crime and corruption.

headline: We Three Things | Tables of Content
text: Tabletops are the daily canvases upon which we sketch. A glance at someone’s coffee table, kitchen island or even computer desktop offers a revealing self-portrait: bookworm, neat freak, train wreck, mom. (My own tabletops tell short stories of collection and compulsion.) What gets randomly, or precisely, set down can be read like tea leaves; our surfaces are anything but shallow.

headline: Police Kill Palestinian Driver in East Jerusalem
text: JERUSALEM  Israeli border police officers fatally shot a Palestinian man in the contested East Jerusalem area on Friday after he hit them with his car, the Israeli police said, although the exact circumstances remained unclear.

headline: Wait, Did the Stimulus Work?
text: Edward Glaeser’s post from last week has been getting a fair amount of attention. But I think there is some potential for misunderstanding what Mr. Glaeser was actually saying about the stimulus program.

headline: Van Gundy Provides X’s, O’s and Oddities
text: It was natural, at least for Jeff Van Gundy, to segue in the telecast of Game 1 of the N.B.A. finals from marveling at the 14-year-old Kobe Bryant’s watching Michael Jordan during the 1993 playoffs to being jilted by a girl at the same age.

headline: Singing the Praises of Fennel
text: In 1824, the writer Thomas Appleton sent his friend Thomas Jefferson a batch of garden seeds from Naples. The broccoli and cauliflower from the region were beyond compare, he wrote, but he saved his highest praise for the fennel.

headline: Another View: Improving Corporate Governance
text: Jonathan F. Foster, managing director of Current Capital, explains that while splitting the leadership of a company and its board generally improves governance, the quality of the people is the key factor for success.

headline: That Was Fast – Brooklyn Party Space Returns
text: The party will go on. A week after the Bklyn Yard, the popular performance space on the banks of the Gowanus Canal, announced that it was closing, Justin Carter, a D.J. and promoter who has produced weekly events there, said his party, Sunday Best, will continue. “We’ve worked it out so we’re going to be able to have a shot at it,” Mr. Carter said in an interview. “The response that got poured out when people saw the space was shut down was really intense, and we think that people really want to see something happen here.”

headline: A Two-Trick Pony From Ford: 305 Horses, 31 M.P.G.
text: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.

headline: This Bike Knows if You Lean Left or Right
text: WITH the electronics for antilock brakes and a drive-by-wire throttle already in place, it was logical for BMW to make a multimode traction control system available for its top sport bike. As it has done for its cars, BMW built a great deal of sophistication into the system it created for the S 1000 RR — for instance, endowing it with the ability to cope with wheelies.

headline: Inflation, and We Mean That in a Good Way
text: MOTORCYCLE racing is not for the faint of heart  or for the fragile of collarbone.

headline: A BMW Finally Runs With the Biggest Dogs
text: WHILE the performance credentials of BMW’s cars are firmly established in the minds of enthusiasts  and reinforced by an advertising tagline that positions the company as the maker of “the ultimate driving machine”  BMW’s motorcycle division has never been widely accepted as the builder of ultimate riding machines.

headline: Public Defender Lawsuits, Now and Then
text: A group of New York lawyers are up in arms over the mayor’s plan to change the way lawyers are provided for indigent defendants. The mayor is overstepping his authority by creating a plan that is contrary to county law, the lawyers say, and the move would significantly hurt the quality of legal services provided to those who cannot afford a lawyer.

headline: Jets Cut Personal Seat Licenses Again
text: With the first regular-season game in their new stadium three months away, the Jets have again slashed the price of thousands of personal seat licenses in a bid to ensure that their homes games are broadcast on television.

headline: Obama Urges Quick Vote to Spur Jobs
text: WASHINGTON – President Obama, returning to his theme of “jobs, jobs, jobs,’’ called on Congress Friday to pass a string of initiatives aimed at spurring hiring by small businesses, including a plan to take $30 billion from the fund that bailed out Wall Street financial institutions and steer it to community banks to lend to small firms.

headline: Inside the List
text: STUFF LUKE’S DAD SAYS: “---- My Dad Says,” the potty-mouthed Twitter feed started last August by Justin Halpern, has earned its creator a television deal and, now, a No. 1 best seller. (The book moves to the top of the nonfiction list this week, supplanting “Spoken From the Heart,” a bunch of stuff Laura Bush said.) It has also inspired some imitators, including the Twitter feed “---- My Darth Says.” So far that one’s pretty unfunny, but let’s give Lord Vader his best shot: “If the Internet doesn’t settle down, I’m going to start a one-man campaign to feed Betty White to a Bantha.”

headline: The Week in Pictures, June 11
text: A look back at the week’s events in New York City and the region.

headline: John Waters Looks Back
text: The best measure of the film director, trash maestro, Baltimore enthusiast and all-around anti-­tastemaker John Waters’s influence on a couple of generations of aspiring oddballs is that he’s made himself obsolete. From reveling in tabloid depravity to embracing the poetry of thrift-shop kitsch, his fringe aesthetic went legit long ago. Now just an­other boutique in the lifestyle mall, it boasts outlets from academia to Broadway.

headline: The Return of Katherine Dunn
text: After Katherine Dunn’s novel “Geek Love” was nominated for a National Book Award in 1989, her hometown newspaper described her as “happily at work” on a new novel, “Cut Man,” which was “to be published by Knopf next fall.”

headline: Gates Criticizes Turkey Vote Against Sanctions
text: BRUSSELS  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates expressed frustration with Turkey on Friday over its refusal to support a new round of United Nations sanctions against Iran, but he suggested that the alliance between Washington and Ankara remained robust.

headline: Leo Castelli’s New York Story
text: Most art dealers, by definition, sell pictures and make money and enter the history books only as footnotes. But Leo Castelli, who opened a gallery in New York in 1957 and became the leading dealer of Pop Art and early Minimalism, deserves to be remembered in full-size type. A trim, courtly émigré who had worked as a banker in prewar Europe, he was fluent in at least five languages and able to extol a Warhol soup can or a Richard Serra lead-pipe sculpture even in Romanian, which had tangible benefits. His achievement was to globalize American art in an age when Europeans still thought that “made in the U.S.A.” was a label best reserved for washing ­machines.

headline: Up Front: Questions for Deborah Solomon
text: You review Annie Cohen-Solal’s biography of Leo Castelli in this issue, taking a break from your “Questions For” column in The Times Magazine. Do you mind if we pose some questions to you?

headline: When Electric-Car Batteries Die, Where Will They End Up?
text: A DECADE from now, owners of electric cars, having driven their share of clean and green miles, may encounter a dashboard light flashing an unwelcome message: Check Battery.

headline: Neighborhood Joint | Frank’s Sport Shop
text: This unofficial Bronx landmark serves aspiring athletes of all ages as well as professionals and their teams.

headline: Manila Vice
text: The Philippines, it might be said, is a country in search of an identity. Its colonial Spanish rulers brought with them the Roman Catholic Church, making the archipelago the largest Christian state in Asia. Adherence to church doctrine has given the country one of the world’s higher birth rates, but the church’s moral teachings haven’t made much of an impact. Having a mistress is de rigueur for political figures. Young prostitutes ply their trade in Manila’s strip clubs, then go to Mass on Sunday. After the Spanish departed, the Americans left their mark. “We will become American,” says Cristo, one of the characters in Miguel Syjuco’s ambitious new novel about the Philippines. “Our children will learn to speak American. When they are ready, we will send them to America to be educated.”

headline: Border Crossings
text: Karen Connelly’s passionate and poetic memoir begins with her arrival in Burma in 1996 at the age of 27. Brash, naïve and bubbling with confidence, she is enchanted by the country, but also determined to “catch at least a glimpse of the truth — something beyond the beautiful images that are so readily available to the foreign eye.”

headline: Low-Speed Vehicles With an Acceleration Problem
text: 12:05 p.m. | Updated

headline: Beyond ‘Real Time’ Reporting, Forecasting Future Traffic Jams
text: An article last Sunday about a traffic-prediction system developed by I.B.M. for use by the New Jersey Turnpike Authority referred incorrectly to plans for an announcement of a trial project. While I.B.M. and its public relations agency, Ketchum, said an announcement was planned for June 8, turnpike officials said subsequently that no such announcement had yet been scheduled.

headline: Heroes, Studs and Raging Bulls
text: Of the many famous athletes I’ve rooted against, none ever seemed more odious than Jimmy Connors. To this day, his mug repels me in a way that not even O. J. Simpson’s does, perhaps because I didn’t start rooting against O. J. until after he retired. Why this hatred of Jimbo? Martin Amis has explained it quite nicely, writing in 1994 about the supposed dearth of “personalities” in tennis:

headline: Answers About Social Security: Part 4
text: “Ask an Expert” is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

headline: Lamentation
text: Anne Carson’s new book comes in a box the color of a rainy day, with a sliver of a family snapshot on the front. Inside is a Xerox-quality reproduction of a notebook, made after the death of her brother, including text and photographs and letters, pasted-in inkjet printouts, handwriting, paintings and collage. “Nox” has no page numbers, and it’s accordion-folded. It carries a whiff of visual art multiple or gift shop souvenir or “Griffin & Sabine.” But trust me: it’s an Anne Carson book. Maybe her best.

headline: Off The Track
text: It’s not easy to pull off running shoes with anything other than running clothes. Then again, if you’re the dapper T contributor and L’Uomo Vogue fashion editor Robert Rabensteiner, who has been known to wear a three-piece suit with Crocs-like slip-ons, they go with anything.

headline: Will Medicare Cover My Adult Children?
text: Q.

headline: For Oil’s Cousin, Good Luck and Bad
text: How about the news for oil’s hydrocarbon cousin, natural gas?

headline: Bright Young Things
text: The phrase “new female voice of her generation” has been flung around to describe 28-year-old Emily Gould, setting up ridiculously high expectations for her first book, a melancholy essay collection called “And the Heart Says Whatever.” Every so often a young woman is presented that way. She writes an article or a book that speaks frankly about navigating a changing world with little or no guidance. She’s a fluid writer — and a looker. Her photo is blown up on book jackets and magazine covers. Think of Elizabeth Wurtzel; farther back, Joyce Maynard. These women may not turn out to be generationally representative at all, but idiosyncratic, even oddball. Editors still hunt for the next one. (Photo not optional.)

headline: Paperback Row
text: THAT OLD CAPE MAGIC,  by Richard Russo (Vintage, $15.) Russo’s seventh novel begins and ends with a wedding, and its subject is “family, family, family,” our reviewer, Roxana Robinson, said. Along the way, she added, there are the elements we’ve come to expect from Russo: “a complicated skein of plotlines, deep connection to place, and affection for the large cast of characters who blunder and struggle through his pages.” The protagonist’s “wonderfully awful parents” are a highlight.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: WALKS WITH MEN,  by Ann Beattie (Scribner, cloth, $17; paper, $10.) Set in the early ’80s, Beattie’s novella is the story of an older man instructing a young literarily inclined woman in the ways of the world, even though she soon begins to see through him.

headline: ‘The Second Sex’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fangs for the Memories: Final ‘Twilight’ Movie Split in Two
text: Even if you’ve never read a “Twilight” book in your whole undead life, you’re probably aware that “Breaking Dawn,” the fourth and final entry in Stephenie Meyer‘s novels about a young vampire and the human woman who loves him, is possibly the strangest in that series. (Among other plot twists, the human Bella gives birth to the vampire Edward’s baby, and the werewolf Jacob becomes romantically bonded to that baby.) So what’s the best way to handle the cinematic adaptation of such a weird work? Break it into two movies, of course.

headline: Coffee Talk
text: To the Editor:

headline: Step 1, Scan; Step 2, Chow Down
text: On the Screen

headline: The Art of Pain
text: “Almost I rushed from home to tell you this,” begins “Melancholia,” the opening poem in Paul Guest’s first collection, “The Resurrection of the Body and the Ruin of the World”:

headline: Place Your Bets
text: Few things will kill an hour of time faster than a slot machine. Now you can turn your iPhone or iPod Touch into one.

headline: Helen Zhu and Richard Ho
text: FOR most couples, the bedroom is a sanctuary from the stress of busy lives, a place to fan the flame of growing love. But for some seeking to make their way in the tech world, the room often doubles as an office with multiple laptops fanned across the bed, the click of computer keys serving as a 24/7 soundtrack.

headline: Guaraná Jesus: Crisp, With a Slightly Tart Aftertaste
text: One of my favorite guilty pleasures in traveling to a distant land for the first time, is that I suspend my no-sugary-soda policy and try whatever regional soft drink the local crowd favors. Sometimes, they’re terrible (I’m looking at you, Peru, with your neon-yellow Inca Kola that tastes like melted circus peanuts) and sometimes they’re fantastic. (Uruguay’s Paso de los Toros grapefruit soda rocks. Fresca, pffft!)

headline: Margaritaville to Open Despite Oil Spill
text: Even as Reuters reported “heavier concentrations” of oil washing up on the shores of western Florida, one new $50 million hotel is still planning to open its doors this month. The 162-unit Margaritaville Beach Hotel (165 Fort Pickens Road), from Jimmy Buffett, is on track to open in late June along the  Pensacola Beach. The hotel says its décor goes for a “barefoot elegance” – fresh orange juice upon arrival, teak furnishings, beach bar out back – inspired by the music and laid-back lifestyle of its proprietor. There’s even access to the nearby public beach.

headline: Sigmar Polke, German Painter, Dies at 69
text: Sigmar Polke, an artist of infinite, often ravishing pictorial jest, whose sarcastic and vibrant layering of found images and maverick, chaos-provoking painting processes left an indelible mark on the last four decades of contemporary painting, died yesterday in Cologne, Germany. He was 69; the cause was complications of cancer, according to Gordon Veneklasen, a partner at the Michael Werner Gallery New York, the artist’s chief American representative.

headline: Niese Happy His Hamstring Has Healed
text: At first Jon Niese was unhappy when the Mets put him on the disabled list, but after throwing the game of his life and one of the finest games in the pitching-rich history of the Mets, he had no complaints.

headline: At the Clubs, on the Beach and in a Grim State
text: Ariel Pink’s Haunted Graffiti

headline: Disease Threatens Japan’s Beef Trade
text: MIYAZAKI, Japan  It is a calamity for this quiet cattle community. A prized black calf born last fall will soon be killed, part of the mass destruction of livestock in Japan’s battle against its worst foot-and-mouth disease outbreak in at least a century.

headline: A Laboratory for Violence
text: There are many ghosts in Beirut’s Martyrs Square, among them numerous courageous and outspoken Lebanese journalists. Samir Kassir, a political commentator and opponent of Syrian meddling in Lebanon, was murdered by car bomb in June 2005. A year earlier, he had summed up the Lebanese paradox in a conversation with Michael Young: “Yes, we were a laboratory for violence, but we were also, before that, a laboratory for modernity, and in some ways we still are.”

headline: Tug of War Over Izzo Continues
text: Michigan State Coach Tom Izzo took a short plane ride from Lansing, Mich. to Cleveland Thursday, something he’s done many times.

headline: Musical Version of ‘Elf’ Heading to Broadway
text: A musical adaptation of the 2003 film “Elf,” which starred Will Ferrell as a human raised among Santa’s little helpers, will help kick off the holiday season on Broadway in November with a limited run at the Al Hirschfeld Theater through Christmas and New Year’s Day, according to three people with knowledge of the plans.

headline: Kitchen Comfort
text: What do you say about a novel in which the most interesting character is a glacier? Hold on, don’t flip to the best-seller lists quite yet. This isn’t the damning judgment it might seem, because this is no ordinary glacier: it’s the Siachen, the largest in Asia and, dare I say it, the most human chunk of flowing ice on earth. “From the helicopter it looked like a giant man’s tongue outside his mouth, licking a woman’s belly.” That’s how Kirpal (Kip) Singh, the chef who narrates this novel by the Indian-Canadian writer Jaspreet Singh, describes it. “Siachen was a big tattoo on a pregnant belly.”

headline: Bars Turn to Texting to Warn of Rowdy Patrons
text: PORTLAND, Me.  As patrons at Bull Feeney’s danced to a ’90s cover band and sipped from cans of Pabst Blue Ribbon, Eric Coulombe, the manager, fiddled with what he says is the latest weapon against the rowdiness and fighting that has long plagued the bar scene in this seaside city  an iPod Touch.

headline: The Force Behind HBO’s Documentaries
text: ONE recent midday eight producers, editors and researchers of an HBO documentary on postwar traumatic stress, “Traumatology: The Art of Coming Home,” were gathered in Sheila Nevins’s “documentary clubhouse”  a pale turquoise, art-filled 12th-floor apartment on East 86th Street in Manhattan, downstairs from her home, that serves as an editing room. They were there to view work in progress, but Ms. Nevins, the president of HBO Documentary Films, wanted to talk about one producer’s unusual medical condition.

headline: Kagan Expressed Broad View of Religious Freedom
text: WASHINGTON  As a young White House lawyer, Elena Kagan waded deeply into politically volatile issues like abortion, immigration and religious freedom that may eventually come before her if she is confirmed to the Supreme Court, according to documents released Friday.

headline: A High-Five for the Invisible Hand
text: The word “market” tends to set off a religious war. Opponents accuse proponents of blind faith in the Miracle of the Market. The proponents too often seem to confirm this accusation by overpromising and underproving what the market can do. (Opponents are often guilty of equally unthinking belief in the Immaculate Government Intervention.) Each side recites its creeds, giving heart to the faithful but making no converts.

headline: Teaching a Reluctant Hound to Hunt
text: A basset hound goes to hunting class; whales are dying off Argentina; oil is coming to Plaquemines Parish; and Venice sparkles.

headline: Competing in My Own Reality Show
text: A STUDENT in my summer writing class announced one day that he was going to star in a new reality show. Professional matchmakers were combing the globe to find him a wife.

headline: Control Issues Shake College Sports
text: By some sort of cosmic coincidence, one of the biggest spectacles in international sport, the World Cup, kicked off on Friday, fresh on the heels of a day when the purely American spectacle of college sports erupted in one big messy fireball.

headline: Proud, Painful Art on Baghdad’s Blast Walls
text: BAGHDAD — Baghdad’s blast walls are a blank canvas. They reflect Iraqis’ shared history — both proud and painful facts of life here in the capital.

headline: Life Costs More Here, Unless You’re Hiring
text: New York City may be the most expensive place to live in America, but it is not the most costly place to employ people.

headline: In Our Image
text: For all their daily efforts to disembowel one another, American foreign policy experts agree on one thing: the United States needs a new, coherent and practical strategy for the 21st century. Peter Beinart’s “Icarus Syndrome: A History of American Hubris” doesn’t attain this policy nirvana. Still, it’s a highly readable and useful hundred-year account of American ventures abroad that can serve as a path to understanding past failures and uncovering why policy renewal is now proving so elusive.

headline: Letterman: ‘Separate Oil From Seawater’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: Yesterday, British Petroleum stock dropped $17 billion in value. And the executives at British Petroleum say they have no idea what happened. I kind of have an idea. I kind of think maybe I got a hunch.

headline: What We’re Reading: Goldman Still More Disliked than BP
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Obama Takes a Hard Line Against Leaks to Press
text: WASHINGTON  Hired in 2001 by the National Security Agency to help it catch up with the e-mail and cellphone revolution, Thomas A. Drake became convinced that the government’s eavesdroppers were squandering hundreds of millions of dollars on failed programs while ignoring a promising alternative.

headline: Five Questions for Sean Hayes
text: It’s been a newsworthy few months for the actor Sean Hayes. He came out of the closet in the national gay magazine The Advocate.  He was the subject of a widely-discussed Newsweek essay that questioned his ability as an openly gay man to play straight in the Broadway revival of “Promises, Promises.” On Sunday, he’ll host the live broadcast of the Tony Awards at Radio City Music Hall. Next week the sitcom “Hot in Cleveland,” which he’s producing, will begin airing on TV Land with a cast that includes Betty White.Mr. Hayes, who is nominated for a Tony for his performance in “Promises, Promises,” took a break during a rehearsal Thursday to talk with ArtsBeat about his full plates.  Following are excerpts from his conversation.

headline: Leno: ‘A Cheap, Effective Solution’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: BP, which of course stands for “Born Polluted,” is spending $50 million on a p.r. campaign to make themselves look good. In fact, they said they would burn the midnight oil if they hadn’t spilled it.

headline: Fallon: ‘Snooki Never Got the Message’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: You guys heard about Al Gore and Tipper splitting up? Everybody is talking about it. Everyone’s blogging about this, and now there are reports online that his daughter and her husband are splitting up. I bet this is the one week where Al Gore wishes he didn’t invent the Internet.

headline: Leave No War Behind
text: Probably no group of intellectuals has had a greater impact on American politics over the last four decades than the neoconservatives. The Rolling Stones even sang a song about them. Yet who or what exactly is a neoconservative? Over the years the meaning of the word has changed. Initially it referred to a coterie of liberals and leftists, absorbed in domestic policy issues, who raised questions about the efficacy of Lyndon Johnson’s Great Society programs in the mid-1960s. Today, neoconservatives seem restricted for the most part to the Republican Party and are advocates of a muscular foreign policy. Irving Kristol, who once described himself as a liberal “mugged by reality,” was one kind of neoconservative. His son, William, a lifelong Republican, is an entirely different kind.

headline: The Doubleheader Hits High Gear
text: It may be a down day on the track in Le Mans, but the drivers who will compete in the 24-hour race are on parade, and there is a buzz in the air. The grid is set for the world’s greatest  endurance race: The former Formula One driver and hometown boy Sébastien Bourdais placed a Peugeot on the pole position Thursday night.

headline: Weekend Competition: As I Always Say…
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists are posed a simple task.

headline: TimesCast | June 11, 2010
text: Today, the oil spill takes a toll on jobs in the Gulf, negotiations heat up over financial reform on Capitol Hill, and South Africa plays Mexico to open the 2010 World Cup.

headline: Student Crossword | The World Cup
text: Get ready for the 2010 World Cup with our Student Crossword. You can find the answers here.

headline: My Nanny, Myself
text: In response to my post about the new domestic workers law on Wednesday, a reader, J., left a lengthy comment (No. 18) questioning the combative lens that some put on the subject.

headline: Valiant Effort by S. Africa in Opener
text: JOHANNESBURG  The World Cup came to Africa on Friday for the first time, and South Africa proved to be an eager and proud host, if not a completely satisfied participant.

headline: The Oil Spill’s Spillovers
text: In watching coverage of the crisis in the Gulf of Mexico, I — like many others — have been wondering what kind of effects it might have on alternative energy development in the United States. Are venture capitalists, expecting a tipping point, scrambling to invest in new technologies? Can we expect a flurry of new research and development spending in as-yet untried fuel sources?

headline: My Backlogged Pages
text: In this age of Amazon recommendations and Kindle downloads, I still rely on the old-fashioned services of a book buyer. My personal book buyer has an uncanny ability to anticipate my tastes. He has introduced me to out-of-print novelists, obscure playwrights and classic philosophy tracts. I’ve enjoyed nearly all of his choices, though quite a few remain stacked in my bookshelf, still unread.

headline: Company Involved in G.M. Recall Said the Problem Runs Deeper
text: When General Motors recalled almost 1.4 million 2006-9 vehicles this week, the company said a system that heated the windshield-washer fluid could cause fires, even in vehicles that were turned off. As part of the recall, G.M. said it would remove the system.

headline: On Stage With Marian Seldes
text: A looks at the actress’s 60-year career in the theater.

headline: The 60-Year Stage Life of Marian Seldes
text: On the day last January when Marian Seldes was planning to see her friend Angela Lansbury in the Broadway revival of  “A Little Night Music,”  she fell in her apartment, injuring her shoulder. Since the show must go on, even when it’s not hers, she sat through the three-hour musical, went backstage to say congratulations (“Angela was wonderful, of course”), then had dinner with friends. The consummate actress, Seldes did an expert job of hiding her pain, but by meal’s end the friends insisted on taking her to the emergency room. Her shoulder was so badly broken that it was replaced with a titanium model. She spent six weeks in rehab and is still undergoing physical therapy.

headline: ‘Bunch Muncherasi MD’
text: I was vacuuming the bedroom one afternoon some months back when I moved a few books aside and spotted a dusty old scrap of paper. I recognized it instantly, and all at once realized my adult life had become a series of wrong turns.

headline: America’s Next Top Kill
text: You’re a veteran of the Iraq war and a former Navy submarine officer who’s now a scholar of nuclear policy at Columbia University. You’re also among the newly emergent big-bang crowd that wants to blow up the leaking well in the Gulf of Mexico.  I advocate the demolition of the well. It’s feasible to use nuclear explosives. The Russians did it four times with a 100-percent success rate. But I fear the mere mention of the nuclear option has only given opponents and unnamed oil engineers a straw man to attack.

headline: Lifelong Earning
text: Think of a person wearing an identity-related symbol and you probably think of logos. But wearable symbols don’t have to be connected to brands. Noncorporate examples range from military patches to motorcycle-gang emblems, but one of the most appealing is the merit badge. While the classic form is associated with youthful scouts, in recent years the merit badge has crossed over into the adult world and is lately getting a digital twist.

headline: Pop-Up Stars
text: In earlier times, major-league baseball players held regular jobs in the off-season. They managed bowling alleys, drove trucks, raised hogs.

headline: Unedited Video of Israeli Raid Posted Online
text: Iara Lee, a Brazilian-American filmmaker and activist who was shooting a documentary on the flotilla of ships that was intercepted last week on its way to Gaza, has posted one hour of unedited video online that shows the early stages of the Israeli commando raid.

headline: The Value of Losing a Business Competition
text: In business competitions, as in business, the odds of winning are stacked against entrepreneurs. Of course, the chance to meet investors and partners and to get expert feedback — along with the possibility of scoring prize money — are chief among the reasons students tend to compete. But why would companies that are already up and running, and in some cases venture backed, risk it? And when they lose, is it worth it?

headline: A Lack of Oxygen
text: I am a physician. Near the end of a flight, the elderly man beside me said he did not feel well and mentioned a history of heart disease. As we landed, he slumped forward in his seat. I thought it urgent to give him oxygen. The flight attendant brought it but refused to allow me to administer it without permission from a supervisor, which we awaited in vain. He was helped off the plane in a wheelchair, placed on a stretcher and taken to a hospital. Promptly giving him oxygen could have lessened the damage from a heart attack and eased his pain. Should I have administered it without permission? LAWRENCE S. SCHIFFMAN,LEEDS, MASS.

headline: Playing at Sexy
text: Last month, over the course of one workday, six friends sent me a link to the same video along with messages that said, “Have you seen this?” I had, but I clicked it each time anyway. I just couldn’t stop myself. The clip showed a troupe of 8- and 9-year-old Los Angeles girls in a national dance contest. Wearing outfits that would make a stripper blush, they pumped it and bumped it to the Beyoncé hit “Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It).” The girls were spectacular dancers, able to twirl on one foot while extending the other into a perfect standing split. But I doubt that two million people had tuned in simply to admire their arabesques. As with TV phenomena like “Toddlers and Tiaras,” the compulsion to watch was like the impulse to rubberneck at an accident, but in this case the scene was a 12-car pileup of early sexualization.

headline: Pebble Beach’s Water Hazard Is a Doozy
text: The layout and location of the Pebble Beach Golf Links, site of this week’s United States Open, can bring about some unusual rules situations, specifically because the course has holes that abut what is arguably the largest lateral water hazard in the world (i.e., the Pacific Ocean). For example, this week players may choose to drop a ball in a dropping zone outside of a bunker instead of in a bunker when taking relief under the water hazard Rule (Rule 26). The long bunker to the left of the 18th fairway at Pebble Beach is immediately adjacent to the ocean.

headline: The Defense of Computers, the Internet and Our Brains
text: If you’re reading this blog post on a computer, mobile phone or e-reader, please stop what you’re doing immediately. You could be making yourself stupid. And whatever you do, don’t click on the links in this post. They could distract you from the flow of my beautiful prose and narrative.

headline: Pulse
text: Viktor & Rolf create white blouses that are basic but not boring, a bag that combines beauty and function, and more items.

headline: BP Directors to Discuss Suspension of Dividends
text: HOUSTON  BP said Friday that its board of directors would meet Monday to discuss whether to suspend the company’s dividend to pay spill-related claims.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Sloane Crosley
text: This week: Sloane Crosley on her essay collection “How Did You Get This Number?”; Deborah Solomon reviews a new biography of the art dealer Leo Castelli; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: Vain Glorious | Products for the Boys of Summer
text: Who: Jack Black

headline: Counting ‘Feathered Folk’ in the Bronx
text: Usually when people get this worked up over Baltimore Orioles arriving in the Bronx, they are New York Yankee fans. But John Delaney is a Mets fan. He is also a publicity man for the Wildlife Conservation Society and an avid bird-watcher.

headline: Rehnquist Was Asked to Review Wiretapping Program
text: WASHINGTON  The legal battle over the Bush administration’s program of eavesdropping without warrants has never reached the Supreme Court. But it may have come closer than previously known, as a result of an approach to Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist prompted by National Security Agency employees who believed the program violated the law.

headline: Across Iran, Anger Lies Behind Face of Calm
text: TEHRAN  One year after Iran’s disputed presidential election, the familiar rhythms of life have returned here. Through a widespread, sustained and at times brutal crackdown, the government has succeeded in suppressing a protest movement that shook the nation for months after the re-election of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, which the opposition said was fraudulent.

headline: Reliance Industries to Buy Indian Broadband Company
text: NEW DELHI  India’s bitterest family feud got down to business on Friday.

headline: Gunmen Kill 19 at Drug Rehab Center in Northern Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY  Getting treatment for drug addiction has become a dangerous activity in the northern state of Chihuahua, where gunmen allied with drug cartels have staged numerous attacks on rehabilitation centers, including a particularly vicious massacre on Thursday night that left 19 men dead, the authorities said Friday.

headline: The Government’s Elite and Regulatory Capture
text: The fate and scope of financial reform is now left to the Senate and House conference committee, which is putting together the final bill. It is an unsettling time as the struggle over derivatives reform, the Volcker Rule and untold nuances and seemingly minor provisions are left to jockeying among elected representatives. Yet, while there are many good things in the bill that should form the core of any financial reform and subsequent acts by Congress, there is one area — perhaps the key one — that this bill fails to address.

headline: When a Playwright and His Play Are Separated
text: Michael Golamco is a young West Coast playwright whose “Year Zero” has received praise during its run at Second Stage Uptown. ArtsBeat asked him to write about what it’s like to drop in from one coast, work with new collaborators, and then leave the play (which closes on Sunday) behind. Here’s what he had to say:

headline: Letter: M.I.A.’s Agitprop Pop
text: A cover story on M.I.A.? Why? What has she ever done that is truly substantive or important? Media folks love talking about her because she merits all the right buzzwords: multicultural, cutting-edge, globalized hip-hop, etc. And it is all true.

headline: Letters: The Why-Worry Generation
text: Readers respond.

headline: Letter: What Happened to Valor?
text: In her article, Katherine Zoepf purports to show that “since 9/11, the military has awarded remarkably few Medals of Honor.” That conclusion follows from the comparison of medals awarded per serving service member and thus will be higher in times of heavy fighting and lower when only a small part of the military is engaged. A far better measure is the ratio of awards to combat deaths. For the span from 9/11 to now, there have been six medal awards and 4,279 combat deaths, for a ratio of about 1 to 713. In World War II there were 292,131 combat deaths and 464 medals, a ratio of 1 to 629: in the 94th Infantry Division, we had 1,200 combat deaths and one Medal of Honor.

headline: Letters: The Teachers’ Unions’ Last Stand
text: As the superintendent of a small, rural school district in northwestern Pennsylvania, I read Steven Brill’s article (May 23) with interest. I recently testified before the House Committee on Education and Labor concerning problems with the president’s reform framework. Our district did not participate in our state’s Race to the Top application for one very simple reason: The four reform frameworks would be impossible to implement. Small, rural school districts are often isolated, and finding teachers to fill openings caused by the reform frameworks would be impossible.

headline: Iterate
text: If you use Facebook much, you know the drill. You log on for your social-networking fix, and the site looks different from how you remembered it, either subtly or radically so. An endless stream of design changes can leave users feeling unsettled — or even irate, as has been the case with the latest uproar over Facebook’s privacy settings. Why all the behind-the-scenes tinkering? It’s the way of the Web these days: everything is iterating.

headline: The Electric Smart: A Car That Seems to Demand Batteries
text: The battery-powered Smart car is based on the 1-liter, 3-cylinder gas version introduced to the United States in 2008, but it sure doesn’t drive like one.

headline: Life Costs More in N.Y.C., Unless You’re Hiring
text: New York City may be the most expensive place to live in America, but it is not the most costly place to employ people,  Patrick McGeehan writes on the City Room blog.

headline: Ruling in Bonds Case Sets Back Prosecutors
text: A federal appeals court in San Francisco ruled on Friday that prosecutors would be barred from using what they say are positive drug tests and doping calendars in the perjury case against Barry Bonds, significantly hurting the government’s case.

headline: Inside the ‘Circus’ of Oxford’s Poetry Professor Election
text: World Cup, shmorld cup — if you’re not following the heated election for the professor of poetry at Oxford University, you’re missing out on some intense and cutthroat competition.

headline: Google News Gives News Organizations a Chance to Stand Out
text: Many mainstream news organizations have long viewed Google News as a threat to their interests.

headline: The Glee Generation
text: THERE’S a scene in the 1985 college comedy “The Sure Thing” in which John Cusack, then as now an avatar of insouciant hipster cool, climbs into a car that’s supposed to take him cross-country to Los Angeles. He doesn’t know the student couple he’s riding with; he merely answered the ad they posted on the campus ride board. They turn out to be his worst nightmare.

headline: The View From Inside
text: An hour’s drive northwest from Baton Rouge sits the Louisiana State Penitentiary, known as Angola, the largest maximum security prison in the United States. On the site of a former slave plantation, it currently houses close to 5,000 inmates and covers more ground, at 18,000 acres, than the island of Manhattan. Surrounded on three sides by the Mississippi River, its stunning physical isolation and distinctive antebellum feel have provided the backdrop for numerous feature films and documentaries, including  “Dead Man Walking,”   “Monster’s Ball”  and  “The Farm.”  For Southerners, especially African-Americans, Angola is both a prison and a state of mind, a relic from before the civil rights era, when white supremacy was the custom and racial segregation was the law.

headline: Two Wheels, High Drama and an App
text: You don’t have to like bicycling to love Lance Armstrong, but you do have to like drama. And with one month until this year’s Tour de France, you can follow Mr. Armstrong’s story on your iPhone with a new, free Team RadioShack app.

headline: Reviewing Glenn Beck
text: Media Matters for America has an early look at Glenn Beck’s novel, “The Overton Window.”

headline: Capello, Super Cool
text: RUSTENBURG, South Africa — In a terse, nine-minute news conference after England’s final training session before its Group C opener, Manager Fabio Capello failed to mention the United States team or a single American player. Not in English and not in Italian.

headline: Random Acts of Science
text: Quantum mechanics is the most revolutionary scientific theory to appear in the past 150 years. In the atomic domain, it superseded laws first set out by Isaac Newton a quarter of a millennium earlier and has since had an unbroken string of successes. Today, it continues to give an utterly reliable account of the behavior of the subatomic world, yet there are nagging doubts that there is something rotten at its core.

headline: Answers From a Brooklyn Blogger, Part 3
text: Following is the third and final set of responses from Louise Crawford, the founder of Only the Blog Knows Brooklyn, and creator of the annual Brooklyn Blogfest.

headline: Final: Uruguay 0, France 0
text: After the first day of the 2010 World Cup and all the pomp and circumstance, there was nothing that sorted out the direction that Group A will take with both games ending in draws.  Uruguay, an underdog like South Africa was when it faced Mexico, is no doubt feeling better after playing to a scoreless draw with France.

headline: Notes on a Scandal
text: Enter the New Zealander Eleanor Catton, stage left, delivering a wildly brilliant and precocious first novel (she’s in her mid-20s) that’s not easy to describe. Nonlinear and occasionally tricky to follow, it’s a series of plays within plays; and as in a piece of experimental theater, its characters often break mid-dialogue to confess in startlingly honest asides or snatch at one another’s thoughts, with lighting and music added during moments of high drama or hushed intimacy. The play’s not just the thing, it’s everything. If Catton seems to be getting up in your face with high art, that’s because she knows her tale has been told before and she wants to make it new.

headline: So an Herb Walks Into a Bar ...
text: IN an enclave better known for bodacious beach bodies, pumping dance clubs and misbehaving reality TV stars, there’s a mixology movement afoot in Miami, led by the cocktail gurus at the Living Room, the bar and lounge of the W South Beach hotel and residences.

headline: The High Cost of Loving Your Phone
text: OUR cellphones have become love objects. We take them everywhere and stare at them constantly. We panic when they are lost and grieve when they die. We even clothe them.

headline: ‘Hope for America’
text: A new exhibition at the Library of Congress surveys the political humor of Bob Hope and others.

headline: Tribe of One
text: More than 800 pages long and the result of nine years’ labor, Joshua Cohen’s third novel, “Witz,” is a deliberate act of excess that’s also an exercise in omission — the product of a negative aesthetic that emphasizes what isn’t there. In telling the story of the last Jew alive, for example, Cohen omits the word “Jew.” And within the loose skeleton of a coming-of-age story, he negates the premise of growth through experience by having his central character be born “full size, at full intelligence . . . with glasses and hairy.”

headline: TV Gives Dance a Boost, and That’s Good, Right?
text: IN the 1990s the British producer Nigel Lythgoe confronted an unanticipated and unsettling side effect to the popularity of his television series “Gladiators”: children were emulating the show’s cast members, slamming into one another on playgrounds without helmets and hurting themselves.

headline: U.S. vs. England: A Divide as Wide as an Ocean
text: The United States opens its 2010 World Cup against England on Saturday in a match that has generated more than a few chest-poking arguments in bars and pubs on both sides of the pond. David Hirshey and Roger Bennett, authors of “The ESPN World Cup Companion,” come to the game from opposite ends of the field. One is from New York and came of age watching Brazil’s mind-blowing World Cup champion of 1970. The other, born in Liverpool, suffered as England found increasingly theatrical ways to shatter the hearts of a nation in the late ’80s and early ’90s.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 11
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: To the Second Sequel, and Beyond!
text: WOODY is back! Buzz returns! And now joining them, a teddy bear that smells like strawberries!

headline: Consumer Wins Chance to Be Ad Star
text: A 21-year-old from Highland Heights, Ky., has won a contest sponsored by Progressive Insurance to appear with Stephanie Courtney, the actress who plays the popular Flo character in Progressive advertising.

headline: Arts & Leisure Preview: Drake, Charles Isherwood, the Duplass Brothers and More

headline: Flash Floods Sweep Through Arkansas Camps
text: LODI, Ark.  At least 16 people were killed and dozens more were unaccounted for after flash floods raged through campgrounds in western Arkansas early Friday morning.

text: Sang and Minja Ji filled their Queens home with original and unusual works of art.

headline: Opening Up the Market for Instant Trades
text: Market regulators took steps on Friday to try to level the playing field in the growing technology war on Wall Street, proposing rules that would force exchanges to provide equal access to high-frequency traders that want to locate their speedy trading computers nearby.

headline: Why Teenagers Don’t Talk to Parents About Sex
text: FEW things are more alarming to the modern hyperparent than a silent teenager. And for good reason: The quiet ones usually have something to hide.

headline: Resort Report | Louis Vuitton, Still Sweet on the 50’s
text: In keeping with Marc Jacobs’s fall collection for Louis Vuitton, the theme for Resort was 50’s. This time around it translated into sweet colors, full skirts and, yes, great accessories, from straw fedoras to eyeglass chains, and my favorite resort shoe so far: a strappy-brown leather sandal with a floral-print insole.

headline: Dealing With Sexy-Dancing 7-Year-Olds
text: In the New York Times Magazine this weekend, my colleague Peggy Orenstein looks at the latest example of girls “play-acting at sexy” and wonders if maybe there is a silver lining — evidence that “girls were taking charge of their sexuality, transcending the double standard,” or that they grew up to be “more comfortable in their skins or more confident in their sexual relationships, if they asked more of their partners or enjoyed greater pleasure.”

There were questions about brunch, about tasting menus and about much more. Herewith four good people with four good queries, along with my answers.

headline: For Better, for Worse, for B.M.I.
text: BLAME the pizza. That’s what Jennifer Deans does. She blames the pizza she and her husband devoured on a regular basis for the combined 95 pounds they gained in the four years that they have been married.

headline: Sara Manning, Carter Griffin
text: Sara Marielle Manning, the daughter of Teresa J. Manning and William J. Manning of Darien, Conn., was married Saturday to Carter Haynes Griffin, a son of Virginia R. Griffin and Haynes G. Griffin of Greensboro, N.C. The Rev. Ronald T. Evans, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated at the Figure Eight Island Yacht Club in Wilmington, N.C.

headline: Cooking Tools: Barbecue Gadgets
text: No one epitomizes the pursuit of barbecue like my father-in-law. John’s DVR is half-full of barbecue-related cooking shows, and he spends hours reading online commentary on proper smoking techniques. He uses natural gas when he’s in a hurry, and charcoal when he’s got all day, and can discuss the benefits of each. His esteem for the Weber brand is akin to another demographic’s feelings for Apple — that is, he believes it’s not just the best, but that it has no credible competition.

headline: Hadley Spanier, Edouard Cuilhé

text: From her perch on her utility vehicle, Leoda Bladsacker surveyed the latest heartbreak along the seven-mile beach in Grand Isle on Thursday afternoon. In a normal summer, the town and barrier island of some 1,500 people about 110 miles south of New Orleans would have been teeming with 10 times that many vacationers from elsewhere in Louisiana looking to fish and swim.

headline: Chevy Love: A Final Word
text: General Motors caught a lot of flack this week for an internal memo that advised employees to refer to Chevrolet by its proper name, and not by the common shorthand Chevy, under penalty of a 25-cent fine. A day later, the company issued a retraction of sorts, saying the memo had been “poorly worded.”

headline: Commentary Is All About Commentary These Days
text: The evolution of a tiny group of mostly Jewish New York intellectuals from left-wing radicals in the late 1930s and ’40s to confidants of the Reagan and both Bush administrations continues to fascinate. Those who made the journey from left to right, and those who jumped off the rope swing along the way, have already told their pungent versions of events in books, memoirs, manifestos, documentaries, magazines, newspapers and conferences.

headline: Detective Is Honored on the Kind of Court He Loved
text: In the Steinway section of Astoria, Queens, there is a little park in the middle of a residential block with a pair of narrow concrete handball courts. On weekend mornings for the last 35 years, these courts unofficially belonged to a dozen or so retirees who lived nearby and played paddle ball year round.

text: The World Cup, in South Africa through July 11, will remind millions of TV viewers that soccer is a global game. At the Red Bull Arena in Harrison, the shiny Major League Soccer stadium that opened in March as home of the New York Red Bulls, the food is cosmopolitan, too.

text: About 600 students walked out of their high schools on Friday to rally outside City Hall in support of free student MetroCards, which the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has threatened to discontinue.

text: MANCHESTER, Tenn. — Conan O’Brien was swarmed with love on Friday afternoon at Bonnaroo, where he performed as part of his “Legally Prohibited From Being Funny on Television” tour.

text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two senior Afghan officials were showing President Hamid Karzai the evidence of the spectacular rocket attack on a nationwide peace conference earlier this month when Mr. Karzai told them that he believed the Taliban were not responsible.

text: If President Obama's drilling moratorium lasts six months, many oil rigs will leave the Gulf of Mexico, probably for years, leaving workers in the local oil industry scared and frustrated.

text: THE disappearance of the federal estate tax this year has created confusion and frustration among the wealthy, even among those who stand to benefit from it. And this has sent them in droves to amend documents that they may have to change again next year.

text: This week’s “Wealth Matters” column notes the boom in business for lawyers and financial professionals who help people with estate planning.

text: The push is on to turn the Securities and Exchange Commission into a self-financed agency that is not wholly dependent on the whims of Congress for its budget.

text: Michelle Obama stopped by the Department of Labor today to speak at a ceremony marking the 90th anniversary of the establishment of the Women’s Bureau, noting that “even after 90 years of hard work, we’ve still got a long way to go.”

headline: The Party, in Exile
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Mamaroneck, N.Y.
text: IN his 73 years, Sid Albert has never lived anywhere but the 3.2-square-mile village of Mamaroneck, on Long Island Sound. “Why would I?” he asked. “I’ve found everything I’ve ever wanted, right here.”

headline: Has Obama Forgotten Darfur?
text: Darfur seems to have been forgotten, but the killings continue. After a lull, the pace of killings has increased lately, with some 600 people killed violently last month alone. As Newsweek notes, that’s more than in any month since U.N. peacekeepers arrived.

headline: Wary? Yes. Ready to Make Nice? Nope.
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  How best to foment a Dixie Chicks reappraisal in the country music world? Maybe they can tape a Funny or Die sketch with Toby Keith, their old sparring partner in cultural politics. Maybe Taylor Swift can start covering “Landslide” or “Not Ready to Make Nice” in concert. Maybe, simply, they can make great country songs, and play them.

headline: A Slave Escapes, a Story Unfolds
text: RIVERSIDE, Conn.  “Is Greenwich ready for bestiality?” a well-dressed woman said during the intermission of Hans Werner Henze’s “El Cimarrón” (“The Runaway Slave”), which opened on Thursday evening at the Theater at St. Catherine of Siena in the Riverside section of Greenwich.

headline: Seeking Clarity in the Unconventional
text: For his first season as the music director of the New York Philharmonic, Alan Gilbert has come up with some ambitious, fresh ideas. They include presenting the staged production of Ligeti’s bleakly satirical modernist opera “Le Grand Macabre,” a risky venture that proved a triumph in three performances two weeks ago.

headline: Summery Sounds of a New Hall Opening
text: ROCKPORT, Mass.  New England teems with modest chamber music festivals each summer, and from a distance many look attractive if not always immediately distinguishable. The Rockport Chamber Music Festival in this town 40 miles north of Boston (not to be confused with, say, the Bay Chamber Concerts in Rockport and Rockland, Me.) has just set itself apart from the crowd with a striking new home, the Shalin Liu Performance Center, which the festival inaugurated on Thursday evening to open its 29th season.

headline: Open Tee Times Designed for Maximum TV Exposure
text: The tee times for the 2010 United States Open were released Friday, and the U.S. Golf Association did its usual thorough job planning the first two rounds for maximum television exposure.

headline: Wake-Up Time for a Dream
text: Sheila Bair, the chairwoman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, began her week with a bit of honest heresy, the kind that only she, among all the bank regulators, seems willing to utter in the wake of the financial crisis.

headline: Awaiting Holidays’ Electronics (and Sales)
text: There is no more important annual event in interactive entertainment than E3, the Electronic Entertainment Expo. Closed to most of the public, E3 next week will attract tens of thousands of developers and journalists to the Los Angeles Convention Center, where the games and systems that will supposedly drive the industry through the fall, the holiday season and beyond will be showcased.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 12
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Terrestrial Wanderings in a Place Rich With Atmosphere
text: With “Luce Nascosta,” or “Unseen Light,” the Italian choreographer Mauro Bigonzetti has created his fourth work for New York City Ballet. Such knowledge would be more gratifying if his latest effort revealed something profound about his art or, for that matter, about the company’s dancers.

headline: The Comedian as Politician, and Often Vice Versa
text: WASHINGTON  “It’s great for a comedian to be honored in Washington,” Bob Hope said when he was celebrated at the Kennedy Center in 1985. “If there was ever a city that knew how to get laughs ... .”

headline: A Quiet Song, With Feeling
text: Life has changed greatly for many Iranians in the year since the political crisis began that was unleashed by the re-election of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad. For photojournalists, life has changed fundamentally.

headline: The Tony Is Given a Mini-Makeover
text: For the first time in 43 years, Tony is growing up. The Tony Award statuette  a medallion mounted on a black pedestal with a curved armature  has gotten taller and heavier in advance of Sunday night’s ceremony at Radio City Music Hall. It now stands five inches tall, up from three and a quarter inches, and weighs 3 1/2 pounds, a two-pound gain. (The new model is above left, next to the old.) Howard Sherman, the executive director of the American Theater Wing, which administers the Tonys in partnership with the Broadway League, said the previous one felt light in the hand, and the change was meant to make it “feel more substantial.” “We know the physical scale of the Oscars, Emmys and Grammys,” he said. “While we’re not attempting to keep up with the Joneses, we felt this is a significant award, and it could feel and look a bit more significant.” When the first Tonys were given in 1947, winners received scrolls and a money clip, for the men, or a compact, for the women. In 1949, the award was turned into a medallion inside a presentation case. In 1967, the year the awards were first televised, the medallion was mounted onto a base.

headline: N.B.A. Championships Score Big Points for ABC
text: The showdown between the Los Angeles Lakers and the Boston Celtics scored another ratings victory on Thursday night, delivering the highest-rated Game 4 of the N.B.A. Finals since 2004. Although Nielsen’s final results were not immediately available on Friday, preliminary numbers showed Game 4, broadcast on ABC, drew slightly better ratings than Game 3 on Tuesday, which was watched by nearly 16 million people. ABC was the night’s top-rated network while CBS ranked second with repeats of its crime shows “CSI” and “The Mentalist.” Fox was third, garnering 6.6 million viewers for “So You Think You Can Dance.” NBC placed fourth with comedy repeats and its new show “100 Questions” (2.3 million).

headline: City Critic: The Future of Mass Transit?
text: A six-month M.T.A. trial allows riders to use credit cards with PayPass logos to “tap” their way onto trains and buses.

headline: Musical Version of ‘Elf’ Heading to Broadway
text: A musical adaptation of the 2003 film “Elf,” which starred Will Ferrell as a human raised among Santa’s little helpers, will help kick off the holiday season on Broadway in November with a limited run at the Al Hirschfeld Theater through Christmas and New Year’s Day, according to three people with knowledge of the plans. Thomas Meehan (“Annie,” “The Producers”), who is writing the show’s book with Bob Martin (“The Drowsy Chaperone”), said in a telephone interview that “Elf the Musical” was in “very good shape, very fun shape” and was set to arrive at the Hirschfeld some time in November. The music is by Matthew Sklar and the lyrics by Chad Beguelin, who collaborated on the musical adaptation of the movie “The Wedding Singer.” Two theater executives, who spoke on condition of anonymity in order to discuss the show ahead of its official announcement, said that the director and choreographer Casey Nicholaw (“Drowsy Chaperone,” “All About Me”) would direct “Elf” and that the run was expected at this point to be limited, similar to recent holiday-timed shows on Broadway like “Irving Berlin’s White Christmas” and “Dr. Seuss’ How the Grinch Stole Christmas!” The current tenant at the Hirschfeld, the musical revival of “Hair,” has announced that it will close on June 27.

headline: Final ‘Twilight’ Movie to Be Split in Two
text: Even if you’ve never read a “Twilight” book in your whole undead existence, you’re probably aware that “Breaking Dawn,” the fourth and final entry in Stephenie Meyer’s novels about a young vampire and the human woman who loves him, is possibly the strangest in that series. (Among other plot twists, the human Bella gives birth to the vampire Edward’s baby, and the werewolf Jacob becomes romantically bonded to that baby.) So what’s the best way to handle the cinematic adaptation of such a weird work? Break it into two movies, of course. Summit Entertainment, the movie studio behind the “Twilight” films, will release the film version of “Breaking Dawn” as two separate movies, The Hollywood Reporter said. Both will be directed by Bill Condon (“Gods and Monsters,” “Dreamgirls”), above, with the first part to be released on Nov. 18, 2011, and the second planned for the following year. The third, less strange movie in the cycle, “The Twilight Saga: Eclipse” will be released on June 30. The breaking up of “Breaking Dawn” follows other cinematic literary adaptations that have been divided into two films, including “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows” (which will be released in two parts in 2010 and 2011) and “The Hobbit” (planned as two films for 2011 and 2012).

headline: Brooklyn Party Space To Return In a Flash
text: The party will go on. A week after the Bklyn Yard, the popular performance space on the banks of the Gowanus Canal, announced that it was closing, Justin Carter, a D. J. and promoter who has produced weekly events there, said his party, Sunday Best, would continue. “We’ve worked it out so we’re going to be able to have a shot at it,” Mr. Carter said in an interview. “The response that got poured out when people saw the space was shut down was really intense, and we think that people really want to see something happen here.” Before the shutdown, Sunday Best had already booked D. J.’s for this summer, starting with Dam-Funk this Sunday, who will appear as planned. (Above, the D. J. Michael Mayer at a Sunday Best engagement.) The space, now to be known simply by its address, 400 Carroll Street, has drawn thousands of people over the last four summers for a mix of outdoor dance parties, concerts, fashion and food events, serving as a destination in a developing neighborhood. Mr. Carter would not specify what deal he and his fellow party promoters  the D. J.’s Eamon Harkin and Doug Singer  struck with the landlord, but some changes will be made. The space, already sparsely decorated, will be “bare bones,” Mr. Carter said, though a spinning disco ball will remain. For now, liquor will not be permitted on the premises, though Mr. Carter said he and his partners would pursue the proper licensing to allow for that as soon as possible.

headline: Book Planned About Raid On Gaza-Bound Flotilla
text: The publisher of “Going Rouge,” a Sarah Palin parody book, is turning to Israel’s recent raid on a flotilla of aid ships bound for Gaza as its next subject. The publisher, OR Books, specializes in books that are based on current events and rushed to publication quickly. Paperback and digital copies of the new book, “Murder on the Mavi Marmara,” are expected to be available on July 28. It will be edited by Moustafa Bayoumi, a professor of English at Brooklyn College and the author of “How Does It Feel to Be a Problem?,” and contain a retelling of the attack by eyewitnesses, and analysis of the blockade and the conflict in the region.

headline: Wild Cuban Rhythms, Loose in North America
text: The thing about Pupy y los Que Son Son, one of Cuba’s greatest dance bands, is how casual it is about blowing a hole through you. It’s the almost absurdly high confidence, attack and playfulness, the band’s whole wizardly performance rhetoric  especially in rhythm and vocals  that’s astonishing, if only because it’s so seldom seen here. But at the end of the night, it’s not heroism; it’s professionalism.

headline: Gaining a Diamond Entry to a Two-Point Hand
text: Roy Welland and Christal Henner-Welland of Manhattan (husband and wife) not only captured the Reisinger Knockout Teams last week; during the Eastern States Regional the previous week, they also won the top bracket of the Thursday-Friday Knockout Teams with Lapt Chan of New York City and Steve Garner of Chicago.

headline: Lewis’s Tempters, Meticulously Paving the Road to Hell
text: The Devil has rarely been given his due more perceptively and eruditely than in C. S. Lewis’s “Screwtape Letters,” an epistolary novella that examines the Christian religion from the point of view of the other side. And in a humorous and lively stage adaptation by Jeffrey Fiske and Max McLean now playing at Westside Theater, he is every inch the cunning English gentleman he is often purported to be.

headline: ‘Brooklyn Bridge Song’
text: No matter what time of day it is in New York City, someone somewhere is always waking up to a new day or going to sleep after a long one.

headline: And the Toughest Preschools to Get Into Are …
text: The tiny full-day prekindergarten at Public School 321 in Park Slope was the toughest public preschool program to get into for the coming school year, according to admissions data released by the Department of Education on Friday.

headline: All-Nighters: Brooklyn Bridge Song
text: A night in New York inspired a song by Sxip Shirey and an accompanying video by Michael Arthur and John D. Ivy. Song performed by Sxip Shirey and Aimee Curl, from the album "Sonic New York."

headline: Japan’s Prime Minister Warns That Debt Could Bring a Crisis Like That of Greece
text: TOKYO  Japan’s newly installed prime minister startled the nation on Friday by warning that it could face a financial crisis of Greek proportions if it does not tackle its colossal debt.

headline: Mobile Uploads Spur Facebook Video Growth
text: Facebook’s nearly half a billion users are now uploading 20 million videos each month, many of which are shared through mobile phones.

headline: Country Music Stars on a Quest for Another Continent

headline: Davis and Robinson: ‘Like Shrek and Donkey’

headline: Using Meat Mainly for Flavor
text: SINCE I began eating more plants and less meat, I’ve experimented with using small amounts of meat in ways that exploit its flavor without making it central to the dish. In this recipe  pasta with spring vegetables  the meat is literally a garnish, but one with huge impact.

headline: Dressing Up Pickled Herring
text: EVERY year, at my birthday brunch, guests elbow each other over the smoked salmon, while a bowl of pickled herring sits forlornly, mostly untouched. I should probably stop buying it, but I like it, and it’s my birthday, after all.

headline: A Quick Kiss of Plastic, and Ready to Ride
text: It was there, at the corner of 110th Street and Lexington Avenue, between a neighborhood botanica and the DeWitt Clinton Houses: the future of New York transportation. One flight down in the No. 6 subway station, the left-most turnstile bore a new electronic reader. Clutching my specially enabled credit card, I made an initial approach, only to be cut off by a rider attempting to swipe a plain old MetroCard  a MetroCard, can you believe these people?  and experiencing all the usual setbacks. But eventually she made it through, and my turn was at hand.

headline: Sarah Heist, Robert Lynn
text: Sarah Jean Heist, a daughter of Mary H. Heist and Richard L. Heist of Hamburg, N.Y., was married there Saturday to Robert Francis Lynn, a son of Antonetta A. Lynn and Frank X. Lynn of Kings Park, N.Y. The Rev. George E. Knab, a Roman Catholic priest and an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at SS. Peter and Paul Church.

headline: Political Futbol …  and Football and Basketball
text: The Thread is not so hopelessly naive as to suppose sports will ever be free of politics. Still, with the Chicago Blackhawks ending a 49-year Stanley Cup drought and a potentially epic N.B.A. finals playing out, it was tempting to dream of a return to athletic purity. Don’t worry, such illusions were quickly shattered. And it all began with these:

headline: Nicki Eicher, Roni Sebastian

Downey of New York, was married Saturday to Joshua Dylan Silberstein, a son of Linda Llerena-Hudak of Gaithersburg, Md., and Howard J. Silberstein of Arlington, Va. Also participating was Mrs. Hayashi’s husband, Gaylon Ferguson, a senior teacher of Shambhala.

headline: For Mets, Camden Yards Offers a Welcome Respite
text: BALTIMORE  The tattered old black catcher’s mitt that R. A. Dickey carries around with him has his last name on it, but it has been passed around from catcher to catcher, from Joe Mauer in Minnesota to Josh Thole in Buffalo to Henry Blanco and Rod Barajas with the Mets.

headline: Grief Links Members of a Persecuted Muslim Sect
text: GLEN ELLYN, Ill.  The phone rang early on the morning of May 28 in Tariq Malik’s home outside Chicago, the suburban sky still night-dark. From the hour alone, Mr. Malik and his wife, Riffat Jariullah, knew something was wrong. The voice of her brother, all the way from Pakistan, told them as much with his breathless instructions.

headline: Yanks Win, but Focus Is on Rodriguez’s Injury
text: Andy Pettitte had a milestone night and the Yankees seized an early lead, then Mariano Rivera closed out another victory in the Bronx.

headline: Academic Battle Delays Publication by 3 Years
text: Academic disputes usually flare out in the safety of obscure journals, raising no more than a few tempers, if not voices. But a paper published this week by the American Psychological Association has managed to raise questions of censorship, academic fraud, fair play and criminal sentencing — and all them well before the report ever became public.

text: Major League Baseball’s 2010 amateur draft wrapped up Wednesday, with a total of 1,525 players selected over three days. As with last year, about half of those chosen are pitchers, and a third of the selections are high school players.

text: Martha Elena Rojas and Peter Ian Asen were married Saturday at Chace Farm Forever in Warren, R.I. Peter Covino, a poet and colleague of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the ceremony, officiated.

headline: Afghanistan: Violence Claims 14
text: Eleven Afghans and three NATO soldiers were killed in violence Friday in Afghanistan. A suicide bomber wearing a burqa walked into a bazaar in Zabul Province, as a foot patrol of NATO soldiers walked through the same area. The bomber’s explosion killed two NATO soldiers and two Afghans, according to a NATO spokesman and a spokesman for the Zabul governor. In a rural area of Kandahar Province, a roadside bomb exploded as a minivan passed, killing nine civilian passengers, three children, the Kandahar governor said, and a NATO soldier was killed in eastern Afghanistan.

headline: Yanni Liu and Kapil Mohabir
text: Yanlin Liu and Kapil Mohabir were married Saturday evening in Brooklyn. James Raybould, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated in Brooklyn Bridge Park.

headline: 5 Officers Indicted in Katrina Killing
text: NEW ORLEANS  A federal grand jury charged five police officers Friday in connection with the shooting death of a civilian in the days after Hurricane Katrina.

headline: Do You Take This Immigrant?
text: THE retired mechanic from Michigan looked shell-shocked beside his bride, a classical pianist from Moscow who clutched the printed e-mail exchanges of their Internet romance. Young newlyweds from Long Island, still recovering from their reception for 600 guests the previous weekend, faltered as their lawyer quizzed them on the details of their City Hall ceremony four months before. A Manhattan woman bickered with her Turkish spouse about the kinds of questions they had been warned to expect.

headline: State Plan Makes Fund Both Borrower and Lender
text: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson and legislative leaders have tentatively agreed to allow the state and municipalities to borrow nearly $6 billion to help them make their required annual payments to the state pension fund.

headline: Could Your Marriage Pass the Test?
text: Note: Because of an editing error, an earlier version of this post said immigration officers always question couples separately. In fact, they do so only when their suspicions are aroused.

text: To the Editor:
