text: Claremont, Calif.

headline: Bloomberg Spent More as Market Bounced Back
text: After a decade of conspicuous consumption  a town house here, a private jet there  Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg seemed to slam on the brakes in 2008 during the recession. He bought no new property, rented out space in a vacation home and  horrors!  cut back on household staff.

headline: On the Streets of New York, Cheers for the World
text: Vuvuzelas blasting along 52nd Street. Yellow jerseys out in front of the Paley Center for Media. People chanting “Bafana Bafana” just one door down from the landmark jockeys outside the 21 Club. The World Cup has arrived.

headline: France: Russia Stresses Iran Pledge
text: Russia’s prime minister, Vladimir V. Putin, told French President Nicolas Sarkozy that Moscow would continue to freeze delivery of S-300 missiles to Iran after the United Nations Security Council passed further sanctions against Tehran, Mr. Sarkozy’s office said Friday. The sanctions do not specifically cover the missiles, but Mr. Putin apparently underlined Russia’s commitment, made privately to Washington and to Israel as well, not to destabilize the region through arms sales  especially of the S-300, a mobile, long-range air defense system. In Paris, Mr. Putin also agreed with the French to speed up talks on the possible sale of four French-made transport ships that can carry helicopters and tanks. France wants to sell the ships, known as the Mistral, without sophisticated guidance and weapons systems; Mr. Putin wants the ships fully equipped.

headline: Day 52: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: Gas Leak Sickens 36 on Service Vessel

headline: More Disputes Over Handling of Drug Recall
text: The feud between Johnson & Johnson and Congressional investigators over the company’s recent recalls of over-the-counter medicines deepened on Friday as they disputed the meaning of company documents turned over to a House committee.

headline: Relying on Heart, U.S. Takes Aim at England
text: RUSTENBURG, South Africa  When Bob Bradley was the Princeton soccer coach, he took a team of college players to Italy, where he met Fabio Capello, the manager of the Italian and European champion A.C. Milan.

headline: A Tourist Mecca Fears a Long-Term Oil Smear
text: GRAND ISLE, La.  They are not selling many fried Snickers bars à la mode these days at the Kickin Chicken restaurant here, located by a wide, sandy beach that is now off limits to swimmers because of the oil spill. So its owners are going after different customers, with the help of a roadside sign: “Disaster Catering Available! Let’s Talk.”

headline: Brooklyn Welcomes the World Cup
text: A large crowd of South African soccer fans gathered at Madiba Restaurant in Brooklyn to celebrate the World Cup's opening match, and to cheers the first World Cup hosted in Africa.

headline: Oil Revenue Bill Stirs Political Uproar in Brazil
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil  Brazil’s Senate has approved a bill that would divide billions of dollars in oil royalties equally among the country’s states, threatening the country’s largest oil producing state, Rio de Janeiro, with the loss of up to $4 billion in revenue.

headline: The Latest Work Dodge: A Shutdown
text: Once again, Albany’s lawmakers are disgracing the state. In this case, the $135 billion state budget is more than 70 days late and around $9.2 billion short. An annoyed governor, David Paterson, has begun adding sections of the 2010-11 budget every week to emergency budget extenders. If lawmakers refuse, they will shut down the entire state government.

headline: Rangers’ Sale Price Could Have Been Higher, Creditors Say
text: Since the Texas Rangers agreed to a sale to a group led by Chuck Greenberg and Nolan Ryan for $575 million earlier this year, creditors of the team’s parent company have insisted that other bidders would have paid more.

headline: BP’s Responsibility
text: The Times reported on Friday that investors and politicians in Britain are increasingly upset at America’s criticisms of BP. This isn’t an issue of American pique or British patriotism. Americans are rightly angry at BP’s inability to stop a disastrous leak for which it was wholly unprepared and its failure to tell the truth about the extent of the damage.

headline: This Time, There’s No Helping Hand for France
text: CAPE TOWN  France qualified for the World Cup in large part because of an uncalled hand ball by Thierry Henry last November.

headline: Nebraska Moves to Big Ten and Pushes Big 12 to Brink
text: In another dizzying day that will long be remembered as part of the reshaping of college sports, two universities with brand-name football programs announced they were leaving their conferences.

headline: The King and Us
text: WHEN I first told my son Ferran that the 17-year-old king of Tibet would be staying with our family for a week, he raised a 14-year-old eyebrow and said, “I hope he’s not expecting me to serve him.” My 17-year-old son, Alex, was more generous. “I think I should give the king my bed,” he said, wondering aloud if the king, who had been living in a Tibetan refugee settlement in India, would require security.

headline: Supreme Court Runs Financial Gamut
text: WASHINGTON  When President Obama announced he was nominating Sonia Sotomayor to the Supreme Court last year, he said “an understanding of how the world works and how ordinary people live” was a necessary trait for a justice.

headline: Credit Unions Begin to Promote Their Strengths
text: Credit unions have a reputation for being rather dull and conservative, and for decades, America’s First Federal Credit Union in Birmingham, Ala., was no exception.

headline: What Happened on the Mavi Marmara?
text: Nearly two weeks later, and the world still doesn’t know the full story behind the disastrous attack by Israeli commandos on a Gaza-bound aid ship that left eight Turks and one Turkish-American dead.

headline: A Gallery of Credit Union Ads
text: In Saturday’s Times, Andrew Martin and Ron Lieber wrote about the marketing campaigns some credit unions have used to lure new customers away from traditional big banks.

headline: The Baker Finds Her Green Thumb
text: Amy Scherber, the owner of Amy’s Bread, opened her first shop in Hell’s Kitchen in 1992, after training in France. (There are three locations now.) Last year, Ms. Scherber, 49, who lives on the West Side of Manhattan, and her husband, Troy Rohne, 37, a sales manager at Amy’s Bread, bought a house in central Connecticut, dating to the 1760s. They spend weekends there with their son, Harry, 5.

headline: Snake Oil for Breakfast
text: More than a century after President Theodore Roosevelt signed the Pure Food and Drug Act, deception is still a far too popular marketing tool for food makers.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: To Serve, Protect and Give Directions
text: A middle-aged couple approached a police officer on Fifth Avenue on a recent Monday morning. The man said, “We are having problem,” in a thick German accent. He pointed  not at a mugger running away, not at a bleeding bullet hole, but at a map. Specifically, the part marked “Rockefeller Center.”

headline: An Esoteric Menu for an Eclectic Crowd
text: True to its name, the Gilt restaurant on Madison Avenue is carved out of the study of the 19th-century Villard Mansion at the Palace Hotel, seats 55 and oozes opulence. With cathedral ceilings, sparkling mosaic tile floors and elaborately carved moldings and paneling, the restaurant pays homage to the Gilded Age. The $89 prix fixe menu, known for skilled combinations of esoteric ingredients, plus a 2,100-bottle wine list, with 50 offerings by the glass, attracts an eclectic crowd. On Tuesday night, it was an elegantly appointed mix of serious-looking men in gray (not flannel) suits, couples, ladies who might be lunching if the place were open for lunch, and close friends out for a laugh-filled night on the town.

headline: Mindful of TV Blackouts, Jets Slash Their Seat Fees
text: With the first regular-season game in their new stadium three months away, the Jets again slashed the price of thousands of personal seat licenses Friday in a bid to ensure that their home games are broadcast on television.

headline: A World of Eternal Childhood (With a Hook for Adults)
text: Take the children to “Peter Pan” for the flying, the pirates and the crocodile. Take yourself for Douglas Sills as the most delicious Captain Hook in memory.

headline: The Courage to Leave
text: There is no good news coming out of the depressing and endless war in Afghanistan. There once was merit to our incursion there, but that was long ago. Now we’re just going through the tragic motions, flailing at this and that, with no real strategy or decent end in sight.

headline: Bad News: They Only Think They’re Happy
text: Imagine a golden summer. You and your spouse are cooking, drinking wine, nuzzling and getting ready to watch the sunset from your house on Martha’s Vineyard. There you are with your best friends, who will soon marry and have two children roughly the same age as yours. Imagine that the summer lasts 12 years. And that one night, over lemon almond polenta cake, it ends.

headline: Trying to Make History, With 6 Votes Per Person
text: PORT CHESTER, N.Y. — There is little in this Westchester County village to suggest that one of the most important elections in its history is under way. Demure campaign signs punctuate lawns here and there. Even more rarely, residents may run across a candidate shaking hands at the mall.

headline: Down to the River to Play, and Sing and Dance
text: LAST year, when Jeff Rumpf was planning the 32nd annual Great Hudson River Revival  some version of the event, widely known as the Clearwater Festival, has been held since the mid-1960s  he made what he now calls a big mistake.

headline: Arabic Class Becomes a Popular Choice
text: Luke Smith-Stevens was 9 when he heard a roar and looked up to see one of the two planes that would hit the twin towers flying directly over his classroom’s skylight. In the subsequent months, he tried to make sense of the conversations he overheard and half-understood, the ubiquitous feelings of rage.

headline: A String Quartet in Tangles
text: “Dissonance” is the name by which a popular Mozart string quartet is known; it is also the name of Damian Lanigan’s prickly play about a group of musicians practicing the piece for an important Carnegie Hall concert. Their relationships are full of conflict and power plays.

headline: On the Stage, Reviving a 300-Year-Old Patient
text: It might be nice to report that the Schoolhouse Theater has mounted Molière’s classic French comedy “The Imaginary Invalid” in order to add its two cents to the nation’s health care discussion. But for better or worse, and I suspect it’s for better, Pamela Moller Kareman’s production seems to have been intended just for the fun of it. To the extent that there’s commentary, it’s all Molière’s, as the much-abused intimates of Monsieur Argan  and in particular, his marriageable daughter  cope with his all-consuming hypochondria.

headline: Will Last Century’s Styles Open Today’s Wallets?
text: For some clothing brands, the summer of 2010 looks a lot like the summer of 1910, and 1949, and 1957  basically, any time but now.

headline: ‘Taming of the Shrew’ Vaults Off the Page
text: Some works for the theater play much better than they read. Reading Shakespeare’s “Taming of the Shrew,” for instance, can make you squirm. The play’s one-sided battle of the sexes, pitting the alpha male Petruchio against the self-possessed but unempowered Katherina, seems brutal on the printed page.

headline: S.C. Strikes Again
text: Alvin Greene filed for our sins.

headline: The Original Milk Makers
text: With its long driveway swooping past a small pond, an expansive meadow, a tidy white Colonial and several whitewashed outbuildings, Fish Family Farm is the very embodiment of pastoral New England. Completing the Norman Rockwell image is the farm’s 50-head herd of Jersey milk cows.

headline: Unexpected Cuisine at a Sports Club
text: YOU might expect, as I did, that a restaurant in a sports club would feature straightforward, robust alpha-type food.

headline: Do-It-Yourself Sushi
text: It’s not that easy to find good mochi ice cream in Westchester. The small round shells of sticky-rice dough filled with ice cream, served at some Japanese restaurants, are usually thick and hard, not thin and soft like the best versions I’ve tasted.

headline: Friends, Neighbors and Facebook
text: Mister Rogers would be so disappointed in me.

headline: South Sea Breezes on Long Island Sound
text: THE draw at Pier Restaurant and Tiki Bar, like that at its sister restaurant, Seaside Johnnies, is its location on Long Island Sound. The view from Pier Restaurant, however, is wider, virtually uninterrupted, and can be enjoyed from under the cool thatch of the tiki bar or from a table on the adjoining breezy patio, a haven on a sultry summer’s day.

headline: Clams With the Crowds
text: “We really are a barometer of summer,” said Mace Colodny, 49, of Centerport, whose family has owned and operated the Shack, an open-air clam bar and restaurant there, since 1980. “When people see the crowds, they know summer is here.”

headline: A Classic Bistro With a Pedigree
text: WHEN Bar Frites opened in Greenvale in late April, it was instantly popular. Even in the first few weeks, diners calling for a weekend reservation two or three days in advance were left with a choice of 5 or 10 p.m.

headline: One Might Say ‘Nevada’ in Las Vegas
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Joe DiPietro is an experienced constructor who leans toward the hard end of the week. This is the kind of Saturday puzzle the pros live for — tough but with some fantastic clues.

headline: The Quality of Hitters
text: On-base plus slugging at each position, as a percentage of the league average.

headline: A Long, Chilly Path to Lively Asian Flavors
text: THERE’S something disorienting about stumbling onto an ambitious restaurant in a suburban hotel complex, where the virtues of familiarity and utility tend to trump those of adventure and surprise. It just feels weird. That’s particularly true of Ming II, a few steps down the hall from the Hyatt hotel that anchors part of the cavernous Headquarters Plaza office complex in Morristown.

headline: Yankees Pick Teams for World Cup
text: The Yankees on Friday turned their attention to the beautiful game. And no, that is not a reference to Stephen Strasburg’s 14-strikeout debut on Tuesday, but rather to the World Cup.

headline: At Middle Age, Back In the Saddle
text: Alan Charles, 50, a salesman from Manhattan, saw his harness racing career die after a paralyzing spill 20 years ago. Now, with child-support payments, a humdrum job and a bad back, he wants it back.

headline: Trotters and Silks
text: Twice a week, Alan Charles, 50, heads out to the Meadowlands Racetrack in pursuit of his harness racing dreams.

headline: For Supporters of Bafana Bafana, the Dream Lives
text: Soweto, South Africa

headline: Bloggingheads: A Smarter War on Hamas
text: Heather Hurlburt, left, of the National Security Network and Eli Lake of The Washington Times debate how to delegitimize Hamas.

headline: Bible Buying Spree
text: Steven Green, president of the arts and crafts store chain Hobby Lobby, has been aggressively building his collection of rare bibles to open the nation’s pre-eminent Bible museum.

headline: Breeders’ Cup to Return to Kentucky
text: The Breeders’ Cup awarded Churchill Downs its featured event, one of the richest in racing, for a second consecutive year. After a two-year run at Santa Anita in Arcadia, Calif., Churchill Downs was picked as the host for the 2011 Breeders’ Cup. This year’s two-day event was already set for Nov. 5-6 at the track, home of the Kentucky Derby. Churchill seemed the logical choice for 2011 because of several factors: in California, a lease dispute and drainage issues at Santa Anita; in New York, finances and politics. cup (AP)

headline: Craft Shop Family Buys Up Ancient Bibles for Museum
text: OKLAHOMA CITY  At least one example of the printed word is in great demand even in the digital age: ancient Bibles.

headline: Joan Hinton, Physicist Who Chose China Over Atom Bomb, Is Dead at 88
text: Joan Hinton, a physicist who worked on the Manhattan Project, which developed the atom bomb, but spent most of her life as a committed Maoist working on dairy farms in China, died on Tuesday in Beijing. She was 88.

headline: Vice Chairman of Fed to Remain Until Successor Is Named
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve’s vice chairman, Donald L. Kohn, who had planned to retire this month, announced Friday that he would remain as a governor of the central bank for a short while longer.

headline: Royal Host to World Cup Invests in His Subjects
text: PHOKENG, South Africa  The handsome young king of the Bafokeng people conjured a 39,000-seat stadium from the bush in the hope that one day the World Cup would come to this dusty overgrown village. “Let’s build this thing for the future,” one of his advisers, George Khunou, recalled his saying.

headline: World Cup Shines Spotlight on Royal Bafokeng Nation
text: The leader of the Royal Bafokeng Nation is trying to remake his tiny dominion into a meritocracy where hard work and talent are rewarded.

headline: Where to Watch the World Cup in New York City
text: The World Cup is often referred to as the world’s biggest party, and bars around New York City are eagerly joining in the festivities. With 7:30 a.m. drink specials to a 60-seat indoor stadium, there’s a bar for every fan throughout the city. An interactive map of bars picked by Times staff members can be found here, but, still, a few highlights:

headline: War Insight, Beyond ‘Bang-Bang’
text: At midlife, in a soft job, and nagged by questions that no one was answering, Carol Dysinger boarded a plane from New York to Dubai and then caught a connecting flight into Kabul. It was May 2005. She was a film professor at New York University and wanted to know about Afghanistan.

headline: Repayments Top Loans Outstanding in Bailout
text: The Treasury Department said Friday that repayments to the Troubled Asset Relief Program reached $194 billion in May, surpassing the $190 billion in funds outstanding. “TARP repayments have continued to exceed expectations, substantially reducing the projected cost of this program to taxpayers,” Herbert Allison, the Treasury’s assistant secretary for financial stability, said in a statement.

headline: Sigmar Polke, Whose Sly Works Shaped Contemporary Painting, Dies at 69
text: Sigmar Polke, an artist of infinite, often ravishing pictorial jest, whose sarcastic and vibrant layering of found images and maverick painting processes left an indelible mark on the last four decades of contemporary painting, died Thursday in Cologne, Germany. He was 69.

headline: Groupe Danone Agrees to Buy Medical Nutrition
text: Groupe Danone, the yogurt maker, agreed to buy Medical Nutrition USA for about $62.3 million, adding protein supplements for the elderly to its medical-nutrition business in the United States. Danone will pay $4 a share, 44 percent more than the closing price Thursday for Medical Nutrition, which makes Pro-Stat proteins, Danone said. The purchase would bolster Danone’s medical nutrition unit, which increased sales 8.3 percent last year to 925 million euros ($1.1 billion), accounting for 6 percent of total revenue. Medical Nutrition USA makes liquid proteins that are predigested by fruit enzymes, helping people with protein deficiencies and accelerating tissue healing in patients with ulcers, according to its Web site.

headline: For Hartford Stage, Facelift at the Theater
text: ELAINE Stritch, Chita Rivera and Ben Vereen are doing Hartford Stage’s “Broadway Legends” series this summer, but you won’t find them at the usual place on Church Street. They’ll be about five miles away, in the Roberts Theater at the Kingswood-Oxford School in West Hartford, while Hartford Stage’s 33-year-old theater gets a $4 million makeover. The renovation is the first phase of a two-part project expected to be completed by 2013, before the celebration of the theater’s 50th anniversary.

headline: A Weekend at Farm Camp, With Lessons in the Earthy Side of Food
text: GREENWICH, N.Y.  Outside the kill room at the Garden of Spices, a band of little boys played by a parked truck. Between giggles, they kept a curious eye on the open room. Inside, a half-dozen visitors surrounded their father, Ben Shaw, as he grasped a chicken.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

text: The executive who oversaw Major League Baseball’s umpires for the past five years has been reassigned in a clear indication of Commissioner Bud Selig’s unhappiness with the quality of umpiring in recent years.

headline: For North Korean Refugees, Little to Cheer About in the World Cup
text: With the World Cup on, little pockets of immigrant New York will be stopping for hours at a time to watch their homelands compete. They will gather in groups large and small, in ethnic restaurants and sports bars, in Little Brazil in Midtown and Little Ghana in the Bronx.

Norms Bloom in Arizona
text: Five players earned performance norms needed for titles at the Copper State International tournament.

headline: Independence Party’s Lawyer Is Ordered to Testify
text: A Manhattan judge on Friday ordered the lawyer for the state’s Independence Party to testify before a grand jury after prosecutors argued that the party was not cooperating with an investigation of a Republican political operative who has worked for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

text: A 4-year-old boy was killed in the Bronx on Friday when he fell off an apartment balcony and plunged more than 20 stories to his death, the police said.

text: A view of the tournament, from an opening ceremony in Johannesburg to distraught fans in France.

headline: For Food Professionals, a Camp Down on the Farm
text: Scores of food professionals from New York City have headed upstate to Washington County to participate in a farm camp program that teaches skills like how to slaughter chickens.

headline: Record Bill for Lunch With Buffett: $2.6 Million
text: Someone really wants to share a steak with Warren E. Buffett. The total bill for dining with him is a record $2,626,311.

headline: A Timely Pledge of $1 Million for Chess
text: Kirsan Ilyzumzhinov, the president of the World Chess Federation, announced Friday that he is personally putting up $1 million to finance a series of 10 tournaments in Asia over the next 10 years to honor Florencio Campomanes, his predecessor as president. Campomanes, who was from the Philippines, died in May at the age of 83.

headline: Carlsen Back in Action
text: After a break of several months (during which he went to New York to do some fundraising for the presidential campaign of Anatoly Karpov), Magnus Carlsen, the 19-year-old Norwegian who is ranked No. 1 in the world, returns to action beginning Monday in the Kings Tournament.

text: MANCHESTER, Tenn. — Here are reviews, in brief, of some of the performances at the Bonnaroo Music & Arts Festival on Friday evening.

headline: In Life as in Soccer – I Hope the Grays Win
text: BAGHDAD — I was at the house of an old friend last week. As is often the case in Baghdad these days, we were chatting about the long-delayed formation of a new Iraqi government. Her husband interrupted us. He is a Shiite Muslim, who lost cousins under the government of Saddam Hussein. But he was not sectarian, and he was not happy. He said he preferred a government that looks beyond sect.

headline: Obama Urges Congress to Avert Medicare Pay Cuts
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Saturday implored Congress to provide more aid to states and cities to blunt “the devastating economic impact of budget cuts” by local governments that imperil the jobs of teachers, the police, firefighters and other public employees.

headline: Classic Ad: Ford Mustang
text: In this Sunday’s Automobiles section, John Pearley Huffman offers a glowing review of the 2011 Ford Mustang, calling the Mustang’s new V-6 and V-8 engines “the single greatest technological leap for the Mustang since it entered production 46 years ago.”

headline: Kyrgyzstan Seeks Russian Help to Quell Unrest
text: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan  As violence spiraled out of control in a third day of clashes in southern Kyrgyzstan on Saturday, the Kyrgyz provisional government asked Russia to send in troops.

headline: Downpours + Steep Hills + Sleeping Campers = Horror
text: The nightmarish flash floods in southwestern Arkansas early Friday morning that swept away dozens of campers — with some 18 confirmed dead and many more still missing — resulted from a horrible confluence of a late-night burst of extreme rains over a region of steep-sided, isolated river valleys long popular with folks eager for a taste of nature.

headline: Urban Forager | Wayward Weed
text: Recently, I was walking with a friend along a busy street in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, when she stopped suddenly outside a medical office and pointed to the bottom of a hedge. “Do you see that?” my friend asked, as a bus drove by.

headline: Insightful Lessons in Time for Father’s Day
text: Maybe it’s the color drawings that look like regular golfers I have known. Maybe it’s the thick paper that reminds me of my old grade school projects. Maybe it’s the simplicity of the tasks and the guidance offered, but I have always loved the Private Lessons section at the back of Golf Magazine. Four years ago, a collection of the most insightful lessons culled from the magazine through the decades was published. This year, new material has been added in the revised edition, “Private Lessons: The Best of the Best Instruction.” (Abrams Books)

text: President Obama speaks with British Prime Minister David Cameron on Saturday morning as tensions continue to mount between the countries over the tough rhetoric the White House has directed at the British oil company, BP, which is responsible for the damaged well gushing thousands of barrels of crude oil into the Gulf of Mexico.

text: In the home of soccer, England prepares for a World Cup campaign, starting with the United States.

headline: Fallon: ‘Tea and Crumpets’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: South Africa played Mexico in the opening match of the World Cup today, and it ended in a 1-1 tie. The game went on and on and ended up with no resolution. I guess that explains the game’s sponsor, B.P.

headline: Leno: ‘Full of Errors and Severely Flawed’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: The U.N. has passed some new sanctions against Iran, and they are pretty tough. Apparently, Iran cannot go to any post-season bowl games for two years.

headline: North Korea Renews Threat on Propaganda
text: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea renewed its threats on Saturday to destroy South Korean propaganda loudspeakers, vowing a “merciless strike” that could turn Seoul into “a sea of flame.”

headline: Floodwaters Recede, Leaving Death and Debris
text: LANGLEY, Ark.  In the steamy heat of an Arkansas summer, more than 200 rescue workers spread across the banks of the Little Missouri River on Saturday to search for victims and survivors of a devastating flash flood that killed at least 18 people who were caught unaware in the dark of a secluded campground. They found two more bodies, after locating 16 on Friday, but were worried that perhaps dozens more might be hidden in the thick brush of a craggy gorge.

headline: June’s Political Best Sellers
text: Books about the economy and President Obama’s administration continue to have staying power on this month’s list of political best sellers, along with those by two well known members of the Bush White House — Laura Bush and Karl Rove. New titles about the war and an imprisoned journalist join the ranks.

headline: Faux Diagramless
text: This diagramless puzzle is a little different. You need to download the grid prior to solving. Diagramless puzzles, of course, can’t have gimmicks like shaded or circled squares, and yet this one has both. The locations of the black squares are for you to determine, of course. Here is the starting square hint if you need it.

headline: Uncertainty Restores Glitter to an Old Refuge, Gold
text: It is the resurgent passion of the doomsday crowd, a bet that everything will go wrong. No matter what has you worried, they say, the answer is gold.

headline: Rap Invites the Party Onstage
text: MANCHESTER, Tenn. — Who are the real communal utopians at Bonnaroo? Sometimes it seemed to be the rappers. Wale, late on Thursday night, and Jay Electronica, on Friday afternoon, both invited the audience to dance onstage during their sets and were soon surrounded by flailing arms and grinning faces–so many that Jay Electronica’s security ended up clearing the stage again during the set. Meanwhile, the proudly disorganized neo-hippie band Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros–who play an amiably ramshackle blend of 1960’s skittle rock and soul, with singalong lyrics about sunshine, love and other, as one song puts it, “sentimental lies”–rambled loosely around the stage themselves, but left the audience offstage.

headline: Florida Skips Offshore Oil Binge but Still Pays
text: KEY LARGO, Fla.  When rigs first started drilling for oil off Louisiana’s coast in the 1940s, Floridians scanned their shoreline, with its resorts and talcum-white beaches, and said, No thanks. Go ahead and drill, they told other Gulf Coast states; we’ll stick with tourism.

headline: Rodriguez Discusses His Injury
text: Alex Rodriguez learned Friday that tendinitis in his right hip flexor had been the source of the tightness near his groin area. Rodriguez, who left after the first inning of Thursday’s loss in Baltimore, did not play in the Yankees’ win over the Houston Astros on Friday and is considered day to day. The following is a transcript of Rodriguez’s meeting with reporters after Friday’s game.

headline: Cover Songs Set Free at Bonnaroo
text: MANCHESTER, Tenn. — It’s not a Bonnaroo set without a wild-card cover version. The Flaming Lips and an allied group, Stardeath and White Dwarfs, played the entirety of Pink Floyd’s “Dark Side of the Moon” with no deference at all. With fuzztone bass and wah-wah guitars, a garage-rock kick and non-portentous vocals, it went lurching toward Flaming Lips’disheveled version of madness rather than Pink Floyd’s majestic one.

headline: A Decade Later, Genetic Map Yields Few New Cures
text: Ten years after President Bill Clinton announced that the first draft of the human genome was complete, medicine has yet to see any large part of the promised benefits.

headline: At Bonnaroo, Looking Inward
text: The big party that is Bonnaroo teetered on an uncharacteristic mood on Friday: introspection. The headliner, Kings of Leon, has taken some of Southern rock’s basic tensions–between faith and hell-raising, gospel and blues, pride and guilt, lust and repentance–into songs that wrestle private demons but ring like arena-rock. And the more pensive side of Kings of Leon rippled down through the rest of the day’s bill. The National brooded cryptically over smoldering crescendos and U2 guitar chords. Dr. Dog pondered mortality, even as its songs bounded forward with cascading guitars and casual vocal harmonies.

headline: Offensive Equivalent of the Perfect Game
text: A display case in the press box at Nationals Park shows a scorecard from Don Larsen’s perfect game in the 1956 World Series. It belonged to Shirley Povich, a longtime Washington Post sportswriter, and in its margins is a reference to Charlie Robertson and the year 1922.

headline: Gardner Hopes to Return to Lineup
text: Brett Gardner, who has been relegated to pinch-running situations because of a mild sprain in his left thumb, took about 30 swings in batting practice Saturday and said he hoped to return to the Yankees’ lineup on Sunday. Gardner said after batting practice his thumb felt good and that he would be available to play Saturday against the Houston Astros. “I feel like I could hit today or play the field today or whatever they need me to do,” Gardner said before the game. Gardner said he would continue to heavily tape the thumb, which he did before taking batting practice. Gardner felt discomfort in the thumb Tuesday after a check-swing groundout in the sixth inning against Baltimore and then he jammed it during an at-bat in the eighth. He missed 40 games last year with a fracture in the same thumb.

headline: Expectations Have Fallen as Woods Flounders
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  As Tiger Woods returns to the United States Open this week at Pebble Beach, the site of his still-stunning victory in 2000, he is facing some uncomfortable truths and difficult barriers. Four days before the tournament begins, Woods is trying to find a game that will hold up under major championship pressure.

headline: Breaking Gender Barriers in the Negro Leagues
text: WASHINGTON  Mamie Johnson feels a kinship with Eri Yoshida, the Japanese female knuckleballer who recently became one of the few women ever to pitch in professional baseball. She nods knowingly at suspicions that Yoshida, the 18-year-old so-called Knuckle Princess, pitches for the far-flung Chico (Calif.) Outlaws less as a competitor than as a curiosity.

headline: Rodriguez Unavailable Again
text: For a second straight game, Alex Rodriguez was not in the Yankees’ lineup because of tendinitis in his right hip flexor. His availability to pinch hit against the Houston Astros was not known. Rodriguez is considered day to day with the tendinitis, which is not believed to be related to the hip surgery he had in 2009. Manager Joe Girardi did not know if Rodriguez would be available as a pinch-hitter Saturday because Rodriguez did not meet with the training staff before Girardi briefed reporters. “He’s not ready to go and we’ll continue to evaluate him every day and see what availability we have of him every day,” Girardi said before the game. “He’s not a starter for us. I came to the ballpark not planning on starting him. I’ll keep talking to our doctors.” Rodriguez was not available to reporters before the game. Rodriguez did not play on Friday. He had complained of tightness in his groin area and exited after the first inning of Thursday’s loss at Baltimore. Rodriguez also exited early in a Yankees win over Toronto last Sunday, a day after a 14-inning loss to the Blue Jays. Asked if Rodriguez’s workout regimen to warm up his surgically repaired hip might have caused the tendinitis, Girarid said: “He didn’t have a problem until we played that 14-inning game on the turf. So is it more of his workload or was it more the 14 innings on the turf, a day game after night game? If I was a guessing man, I’d guess it was the latter.” Girardi said he did not know whether Rodriguez might be used as a designated hitter when he returns. Kevin Russo was listed as the Yankees’ starting third baseman on Saturday. Ramiro Pena started at third base Friday and went 0 for 3.

headline: Daily Web Deals, but With Daily Laughs
text: SPACKLE should never be used as toothpaste. And Spanky was the only member of the Little Rascals brave enough to donate his brain to science during World War II.

headline: The Ahab Parallax: ‘Moby Dick’ and the Spill
text: A specially outfitted ship ventures into deep ocean waters in search of oil, increasingly difficult to find. Lines of authority aboard the ship become tangled. Ambition outstrips ability. The unpredictable forces of nature rear up, and death and destruction follow in their wake. “Some fell flat on their faces,” an eyewitness reported of the stricken crew. “Through the breach, they heard the waters pour.”

headline: Finally, Borrowers Score Points
text: WHILE the wheels of justice have turned very slowly in the years since our nation’s financiers and regulators nearly cratered our economy, the Federal Trade Commission’s settlement last Monday with Countrywide Home Loans suggests that they haven’t entirely ground to a halt.

headline: Where to Watch the World Cup in New York City
text: Our friends over at the Goal blog have rounded up some local highlights especially for soccer fans in New York City. An interactive maps out your choices for where to watch the games, based on which country’s team you’re rooting for. And on Goal, our soccer blog, The Times’s Nick Corasaniti highlights the very best venues in different categories to help you decide where to get your particular game on.

headline: Posada Thrown a Curve at D.H.
text: Jorge Posada said his right foot feels good, and he hopes to return to catching soon. Manager Joe Girardi said he hoped to have an answer Sunday about when Posada might take the field.

headline: The Lesson of the Ladder
text: I’M the last of three children, born to parents who were part of the “greatest generation.” After serving as a medic in the Philippines in World War II, my father was chief inspector for a water commission. My mother kept the books at an auto parts dealership near Capitol Heights, Md.

headline: Position No Longer Pigeonholes a Hitter
text: Many of baseball’s best hitters used to be among the worst fielders  designated hitters, who did not have to field at all, or slow-footed outfielders who did not cover much ground. But such players have become less common. Relative to past decades, more of today’s best hitters play middle infield, like Hanley Ramirez and Chase Utley.

headline: During the 24 Hours of Le Mans, the Biggest Factor Is Human
text: The cars taking part this weekend in the 78th edition of the world’s most famous 24-hour endurance race, Le Mans 24 Hours, are not the most technologically advanced in the world. This single competition draws on more human qualities, challenges and team demands than any other race in the world.

headline: In Politics, the Sun Rises in the West
text: LOS ANGELES — The West may not be the geographic center of the country, but these days it sits at the heart of its political culture.

headline: Some Return to Work for Honda Amid Strike
text: ZHONGSHAN, China  Cracks emerged on Saturday afternoon in the unity of workers on strike at a Honda auto parts factory in southeastern China, the latest in a series of strikes in China in which blue-collar employees have demanded sharply higher wages.

headline: Vital River Is Withering, and Iraq Has No Answer
text: SIBA, Iraq — The Shatt al Arab, the river that flows from the biblical site of the Garden of Eden to the Persian Gulf, has turned into an environmental and economic disaster that Iraq’s newly democratic government is almost powerless to fix.

headline: In Midlife, Boomers Are Happy — and Suicidal
text: If you are suddenly feeling confused about whether to greet middle age with open arms or dread, it is understandable. In recent weeks, researchers reported that Americans in midlife are a remarkably contented lot, and that they also have the highest rate of suicide.

headline: No Cake for This Party Bus
text: THE Haggler is sent plenty of birthday-party-gone-wrong stories. This one could be a new gold standard.

headline: The 'BrinBot'
text: The robotic form of Sergey Brin made an appearance at a recent executive program at Singularity University.

headline: Chinese Walls, Pocked With Peepholes
text: Maybe it’s time for Chinese masons to consider a class-action defamation lawsuit. Because time and again in recent years, when there’s a catastrophe, somebody blames the failure of a Chinese wall.

headline: The Futurist and His Followers
text: Singularity University attracts some of Silicon Valley’s smartest and wealthiest for its executive programs. Earlier this year, participants paid $15,000 for a nine-day course to discuss advances in nanotechnology, artificial intelligence bio-tech and robotics.

headline: What an Estate Looks Like to the Taxman
text: When Congress passed a law that eliminated the estate tax for people who die this calendar year — with plans to bring it back with a vengeance in 2011 — the joke among estate planners was that 2010 might go down as the year of  “Throw Momma From the Train.”

headline: In Bryant’s Path, the Celtics’ Defense Rises Again
text: BOSTON  This is Kobe Bryant’s gift and curse. Each time he grabs the carrot tied on a rope in front of him, it is quickly replaced with another.

headline: The Tough Match of Young Workers and Insurance
text: SINCE 2008, the global economy has been reeling from the one-two punch of a major financial crisis and a sharp worldwide recession. Unemployment remains high, and employers are extremely cautious about committing to new hires.

headline: No Closing Time for Income Taxes
text: ON March 19, 1928, eight years into the reign of constitutional Prohibition, Pierre S. du Pont wrote a letter to William P. Smith, one of the very few people he ever addressed by first name. Du Pont was among the wealthiest men in the world, chairman of both his family’s chemical colossus and the du Pont-controlled General Motors Corporation. Smith worked for a less well-known enterprise that Pierre du Pont also dominated: the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment.

headline: At Yale,  a Fight to Help a Teammate Off the Ice
text: Mandi Schwartz had played hockey her entire life, being named the captain of a powerhouse high school team in her native Saskatchewan and earning ice time in 73 consecutive games for Yale.

headline: Now in Blogs, Product Placement
text: Welcome to quid pro post.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Recipes for Ruin, in the Gulf or on Wall Street
text: AS the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico follows on the heels of the financial crisis, we can discern a toxic recipe for catastrophe. The ingredients include risks that are erroneously thought to be vanishingly small, complex technology that isn’t fully grasped by either top management or regulators, and tricky relationships among companies that are not sure how much they can count on their partners.

headline: At Pebble Beach, the Memorable Shot Wins the Open
text: In the United States Open, a lengthy or final putt often defines the winner. His many other shots, no matter how important, seem to drift together in memory like surf sliding up the sand. But with the Open returning to Pebble Beach, each of the four previous champions there  Tiger Woods, Tom Kite, Tom Watson and Jack Nicklaus  will always be identified by a specific shot.

headline: The President’s Moment
text: If ever there was a test of President Obama’s vision of government  one that cannot solve all problems, but does what people cannot do for themselves  it is this nerve-racking early summer of 2010, with oil spewing into the Gulf of Mexico and far too many Americans out of work for far too long.

headline: Daily Life in Gaza
text: While troubled, life in Gaza often has the staggering quality of the very ordinary.

text: JOHANNESBURG

headline: Gaza, Through Fresh Eyes
text: GAZA — For some, it’s the relative modernity — the jazzy cellphone stores and pricey restaurants. For others, it’s the endless beaches with children whooping it up. But for nearly everyone who visits Gaza, often with worry of danger and hostility, what’s surprising is the fact that daily life, while troubled, often has the staggering quality of the very ordinary.

headline: Don’t Let the Euro Dictate Your Portfolio
text: FOR Americans with significant exposure to foreign stocks, the euro’s 16 percent decline against the dollar this year may lead to second thoughts.

headline: Posada Slowly Warming to Designated Hitter Role
text: Jorge Posada said his right foot felt good and he hoped to return to catching soon. Manager Joe Girardi said he hoped to have an answer Sunday about when Posada might get back behind the plate.

headline: Dancing in a Seagull Suit Is Not for the Faint of Heart
text: As a 22-year-old fresh out of college, I felt great to be recruited by a baseball team last spring.

headline: O.K., Newbies, Bring Out the Hula Hoops
text: This interview of Niki Leondakis, chief operating officer of Kimpton Hotels & Restaurants, was conducted, edited and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Police Officer Shoots Man Armed With Knife in Brooklyn
text: A police officer shot and wounded a disabled man who was wielding a knife on a Brooklyn street after the man ignored orders to drop the weapon, shook off a blast of pepper spray and kept advancing, the police said on Saturday.

headline: Correction: Metrics
text: A chart last Sunday with the Metrics feature about health care statistics for various countries mislabeled the scale for the number of angioplasty procedures. The figures represented the number per 100,000 people in each country, not 1,000. A corrected chart can be found at nytimes.com/businessday.

headline: When Bonnaroo’s Energy Wave Crests
text: MANCHESTER, Tenn. — They were hollering at first, as they escaped their overstuffed cars and pulled into the campground, some having waited in the car line for 8, 10, 12 hours. (The local and state police here keep the non-Bonnaroo traffic running reasonably smoothly on Interstate 24, but all the Bonnaroo road trippers just have to wait in line.)

headline: Lament for a Once-Lovely Waterway
text: It was plaintive the way that Jabbar Amin Jabbar, chairman of the provincial council in the Iraqi city of Basra, pulled up old photographs of the Shatt al Arab on his computer. More than anything else, it is this waterway that shapes this port city in southern Iraq.

headline: Strange Arguments For Higher Rates
text: So Raghuram Rajan has posted a further explanation of his case for raising interest rates in the face of very high unemployment, presumably a response to Mark Thoma.  It’s good to see Rajan put his cards on the table — but what he says only further confirms my sense that we’re talking about some kind of psychological desire to be tough, rather than the kind of analysis one would expect from a highly trained economist.

headline: The RMB And The WTO
text: China says that accusing it of subsidizing its exports via its exchange rate policy — and imposing a countervailing duty — would violate WTO rules. Hmm.

headline: Denver Aims to Sell Home Too Odd to Be the Mayor’s
text: DENVER  The mauve mansion on Shangri-La Drive is decidedly more James Bond than John Hickenlooper, the mayor of Denver.

headline: Battle Over Reform
text: Lawmakers from the House and Senate began meeting last week to meld their respective financial reform bills. The lobbying on Capitol Hill is fast and furious and it is disturbingly unclear whether Congress will come up with the strong changes needed to avert another meltdown  or do the bidding of the banks and opt for weak reforms and pretend they are strong.

headline: A Race for Governor of Arizona, With a Lap in New York
text: Seeking to harness some of the national uproar over Arizona’s new immigration law, the state’s likely Democratic candidate for governor this fall and the chairman of Arizona’s Democratic Party visited New York last week.

headline: Masai Wins Mini 10K, While Radcliffe Enjoys Fun Run
text: Linet Masai and Paula Radcliffe had two very different goals as they attacked the hills of Central Park on Saturday morning during the 39th New York Mini 10K.

headline: Across Atlantic, Much Ado About Oil Company’s Name
text: WASHINGTON  When is the word “British” an international insult?

headline: Elena Kagan’s White House Years
text: A bit of the fog is beginning to lift on the work and thinking of Elena Kagan, President Obama’s nominee to the Supreme Court. An initial perusal of thousands of pages of documents from her years in the Clinton White House show her to be an adept centrist  much like her old boss  who tried to remain thoughtful while shielding President Bill Clinton from ideological extremes.

headline: Posada Finds Some Comfort in a Grand Slam
text: Jorge Posada’s return from the disabled list has been measured in baby steps. He hoped to play catcher soon after rejoining the Yankees, although the team activated him on June 2 knowing he would not be ready to catch for some time.

headline: Chevrolizing Chevy
text: For a while last week, General Motors was telling employees at its Chevrolet headquarters to stop using the word Chevy, explaining it was important for brand “consistency.” After a report in The Times provoked a widespread “Huh?,” Chevrolet said it was talking about expanding foreign markets and was not “discouraging customers or fans from using” Chevy. But the original effort, and the response, left us thinking about the emotional tie of automobile names and their evanescence.

headline: Do You Suffer From Digital Addiction?
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Florida, a Lifeline to Patients With TB
text: LANTANA, Fla.  The last of the nation’s original tuberculosis sanitariums sits, improbably, just off Interstate 95, near a Dunkin’ Donuts and a Motel 6, and just behind fields of children playing soccer. The fading signs out front simply say A.G. Holley State Hospital. There is nothing to suggest that one of history’s greatest killers lurks inside.

headline: An Earlier Israeli Raid, When Reagan Was President
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lakers’ Bynum Says He Will Be Ready to Go for Game 5
text: BOSTON — Los Angeles Lakers center Andrew Bynum expects to play Game 5 of the N.B.A. finals after receiving limited minutes Thursday because of swelling in his right knee and having fluid drained from the knee the next day.

headline: Prime Number
text: 21.5: The percentage drop in pay in New York City’s securities industry in 2009, the biggest year-to-year decline in the last 80 years, including the Great Depression. Still, the average worker was paid $311,279 in salary, bonus and exercised stock options, according to David Belkin, an economist with the city’s Independent Budget Office. Between pay cuts and the loss of 18,400 jobs on Wall Street, about $21.4 billion in wages and salaries vanished last year from the city’s securities sector, Mr. Belkin said.

headline: Courtesy for the Disabled
text: To the Editor:

headline: Long Road to Adulthood Is Growing Even Longer
text: Baby boomers have long been considered the generation that did not want to grow up, perpetual adolescents even as they become eligible for Social Security. Now, a growing body of research shows that the real Peter Pans are not the boomers, but the generations that have followed. For many, by choice or circumstance, independence no longer begins at 21.

headline: 1984: Bhopal
text: It's been more than 25 years since a plume of toxic gas from a Union Carbide plant killed 3,000 people almost instantly in Bhopal, India, and thousands more from the aftereffects. Last week, several former executives, all Indian citizens, were convicted in Bhopal of negligence and sentenced to two years in prison.

headline: The Tissue Turnaround
text: Retail sales fell unexpectedly last month, according to the Census Bureau, but the news on consumer spending has not been all bad. MSN Money reports that there has been a shift among consumers from one-ply toilet paper to more expensive two-ply tissue. Not only that, but a new three-ply bath tissue was ranked by one market research firm as the hottest new product of 2009, according to MSN, and earned Georgia-Pacific nearly $125 million. A company executive said skeptics had wondered “if it was right to launch this ultrapremium product.” But he said the success of Quilted Northern Ultra Plush bath tissue indicated a desire among consumers for affordable indulgences even in tough times.

headline: Obama Presses for Aid to Cities and States
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Saturday implored Congress to provide more aid to states and cities to blunt “the devastating economic impact of budget cuts” by local governments that imperil the jobs of teachers, the police, firefighters and other public employees.

headline: The Self-Employed
text: To the Editor:

headline: One Candidate’s Idea: Office of the Repealer
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — In some corners of the country, people seem to have grown so grumpy about the tangle of government rules and regulations that it may be easier for politicians to promise not what they will do, but what they will undo.

headline: Fighting Words
text: Carly Fiorina, winner of the Republican primary for California’s Senate seat, was waiting to be interviewed at a Sacramento television station when she was caught on an open mike talking about her opponent’s hair.

headline: Obese and Pregnant
text: To the Editor:

headline: Oil Spill May Spur Action on Energy, Probably Not on Climate
text: WASHINGTON — Images of gushing oil and dying pelicans in the Gulf of Mexico have stirred anger and agony in Washington. But are they enough to prod the Senate to act on long-delayed clean energy and climate change legislation?

headline: U.S. Medics Leave No One Behind
text: The experiences of an Army air crew that retrieves the wounded show the challenges of distance, sandstorms and Taliban fighters waiting near landing zones.   Warning: Graphic Images.

headline: United Nations Could Hasten Removal of Taliban Leaders From Terror Blacklist
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The United Nations is speeding up efforts that could lead to the removal of Taliban leaders from an international terrorist blacklist, the top United Nations official here said Saturday.

headline: As Afghan Fighting Expands, U.S. Medics Plunge In
text: MARJA, Afghanistan  The Marine had been shot in the skull. He was up ahead, at the edge of a field, where the rest of his patrol was fighting. A Black Hawk medevac helicopter flew above treetops toward him, banked and hovered dangerously before landing nearby.

headline: Two Weddings, a Divorce and ‘Glee’
text: THOSE of us left off the guest list could only fantasize about Rush Limbaugh’s nuptials last weekend. Now cruising into marriage No. 4 — an impressive total for a guy not quite 60 — Rush staged a lavish luau at the Breakers in Palm Beach. The revelers included what some might regard as the Rat Pack from hell — Sean Hannity, Rudy Giuliani, James Carville and Clarence Thomas. The scriptural readings remain a mystery. But we did learn the identity of the pop deity anointed as the wedding singer. That would be Elton John, whose last, albeit second-class, wedding was a civil union with David Furnish in 2005.

headline: Clashes and Protests Reported in Iran
text: TEHRAN  The first anniversary of Iran’s disputed presidential election passed largely without violence on Saturday, as protesters generally stayed off the streets amid a heavy presence of the riot police.

headline: Isn’t It Ironic?
text: WASHINGTON

headline: For Turkey, an Embrace of Iran Is a Matter of Building Bridges
text: ISTANBUL  Viewed from Washington, Turkey and Iran are strange bedfellows. One is a NATO member with a Constitution that mandates secularism, and the other, an Islamic republic whose nuclear program has been one of the most vexing foreign policy problems for the United States in recent years.

headline: For a Mogul, Money and Magic Touch Have Limits
text: Only a certain type of person would even want to buy a house named Le Petit Trianon.

headline: Top 2 G.O.P. Candidates Don’t Reflect the Valley
text: Jonathan Weber, the editor in chief of The Bay Citizen, writes a weekly column.

headline: Stanford Considers Guideline for ‘Conflict Minerals’
text: Stanford University, an incubator for dozens of Silicon Valley companies, has become the focus of a grass-roots effort to pressure the technology industry to crack down on “conflict minerals.”

headline: This Time Is Different
text: My friend, Mark Mykleby, who works in the Pentagon, shared with me this personal letter to the editor he got published last week in his hometown paper, The Beaufort Gazette in South Carolina. It is the best reaction I’ve seen to the BP oil spill  and also the best advice to President Obama on exactly whom to kick you know where.

headline: Local Intelligence | Sun Yat-sen Statue
text: Sun Yat-sen, born in 1866, is revered in both the People’s Republic of China and Taiwan as the “Father of Modern China.” His anti-imperialist activism helped overthrow the feudalistic Qing dynasty in 1912, but for the 16 years before the revolution, Sun lived in exile. When he visited San Francisco in the early 1900s, he often relaxed in St. Mary’s Square, where this statue was erected in 1937.

headline: Flag Day
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — For the second year in a row, we get an extraordinary puzzle celebrating Flag Day. In 2009, Alex Boisvert, gave us rules for coloring squares (Across Lite, Solution, blog.) Today, Francis Heaney reminds us that other countries have flags, too, in this even more ambitious grid. The gimmick is something completely new. If you came here because you gave up, go back and try again. All the clues you need are there for you. If you read on, fair warning: I’m going to explain the trick in detail. When you’ve got it, come back for the constructor interview at the end.

headline: Two Men and Two Paths
text: When Wes Moore won a Rhodes scholarship in 2000, The Baltimore Sun published an article about his triumph. He was the first student at Johns Hopkins to win a Rhodes in 13 years, and the first black student there ever to win the award.

headline: French Protest of Israeli Raid Reaches Wide Audience
text: PARIS  A small cinema chain has set off a sharp debate in France about the deadly Israeli raid on a Turkish ship trying to break the blockade of Gaza, and whether some French are overreacting to the episode.

headline: Assessor’s Race Centers on Balance of Tax Burden
text: Homeowners have been far less successful than businesses in winning appeals for lower property tax assessments, a Chicago News Cooperative analysis shows — a discrepancy that strikes at a key issue in the race to replace James Houlihan, the retiring Cook County assessor.

headline: Don’t Follow the Leader, Follow the Register
text: Amid the trial of former Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, we may reflexively equate government with skulduggery. But government can be far more benign, even if at times confounding, as the Federal Register reminds daily  in ways sure to drive libertarians bonkers.

headline: The Cubs-Sox Series Brings City’s Sports Fans Back to Reality
text: The Blackhawks’ white-knuckle Stanley Cup victory was uplifting in its own right, but it also merits props for diverting our attention from a truly crummy local baseball season.

headline: Despite Disorder, Musician Finds Way to Play
text: He had, quite literally, the golden touch. He began winning musical competitions when he was 11, and by the time he was 30, Alex Klein had won a job as the Chicago Symphony Orchestra’s principal oboist. Ovations and accolades, including five Grammys, were his due. Critics hailed him as one of the great wind players of his generation.

headline: Hamilton Scores Pole and Pays Fine
text: It was an amazing qualifying session in Montreal on Saturday, with Lewis Hamilton setting the fastest time of the session to score pole and become the first non-Red Bull driver of the year to start the race from the first spot on the grid.

text: KAMPALA, Uganda  Defense lawyers at the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda, which has been prosecuting ringleaders of the 1994 genocide, are threatening to stop participating in cases after one of their colleagues was jailed by the Rwandan government last month.

headline: Suspect in Killing of Hamas Official in Dubai Is Arrested

headline: Heskey’s Impact Is Felt by Howard
text: RUSTENBURG, South Africa — England forward Emile Heskey does not score much, but he does the little things, like holding up the ball well and occupying defenders to take pressure off Wayne Rooney. His pass Saturday helped Steven Gerrard get free in the American penalty area for the first goal in a 1-1 tie with the United States in Group C.

headline: Fred Plum, Neurologist Who Helped Coin ‘Persistent Vegetative State,’ Dies at 86
text: Dr. Fred Plum, a neurologist whose pioneering research advanced the understanding of consciousness and the care of comatose patients and who helped coin the term “persistent vegetative state,” died Friday in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: Sweat | Ho-Hum Salesman to Chariot Warrior

headline: Bonnaroo: Behind the Music, The Effort to Keep it Green
text: MANCHESTER, Tenn. — At Bonnaroo, everything exists on a vast scale. The hundreds of acres of camping. The tens of thousands of sweaty bodies shoving against one another for a better view of the Kings of Leon. And, as at any big festival, the volume of trash, which overflows from bins and by the end of each night lies scattered, crushed and muddy throughout the grounds.

headline: In Showdown, Sure Hands and Shaky Ones
text: The Hands Theory is often invoked by Americans who are spooked by soccer and insist the sport will never get anywhere in the United States because we Yanks only understand games that involve the use of hands.

headline: U.S. Intelligence Puts New Focus on Afghan Graft
text: WASHINGTON  The military’s intelligence network in Afghanistan, designed for identifying and tracking terrorists and insurgents, is increasingly focused on uncovering corruption that is rampant across Afghanistan’s government, security forces and contractors, according to senior American officials.

headline: After Crucial Fumble, Goalkeeper Moves On
text: RUSTENBURG, South Africa  England was ready to celebrate Steven Gerrard, the captain of the national soccer team, when Robert Green, the goalkeeper, presented himself to be vilified instead.

headline: Hop, Skip and a Tie
text: RUSTENBURG, South Africa  In the end, Robert Green did not blame the much-criticized World Cup ball or the wet grass at night or the short hop that bounced dreadfully off his gloves. He could blame only himself.

headline: Fewer Highlights in a Track Meet Lacking in Glamour
text: There were few empty seats Saturday at the Adidas Grand Prix on Randalls Island. But the meet at Icahn Stadium carried a subdued feel because of what it did not have rather than what it did.

headline: Vows: Kavita & Kabir
text: Kavita Mariwalla and Kabir Bhasin met at Yale-New Haven Hospital. Three years later, he surprised her with a scavenger hunt that took her to Bermuda, where he was waiting on the beach with a ring.

headline: Does Fiscal Austerity Reassure Markets?
text: Here’s a thought I should have had earlier about the debate over whether now is a good time to start fiscal austerity.

headline: When London’s Food Comes Out to Play
text: If you dream of eating at London’s top restaurants and don’t possess a fortune, there’s a solution. During the seventh annual Taste of London festival, which runs from June 17 to 20, 40 of the city’s best dining spots will establish outposts in stately Regent’s Park, offering samples of their most renowned dishes at reasonable prices.

headline: The Day the Shucking Stopped
text: Last weekend, Sal Sunseri, co-owner and vice president of P&J Oyster Company, the oldest oyster processor and distributor in New Orleans, presided over the city’s inaugural Oyster Festival. Throughout, he refused to entertain the notion that given the closing of many gulf oyster beds because of the oil spill, the first such festival could be the last.

headline: Ethnic Rioting Ravages Kyrgyzstan
text: OSH, Kyrgyzstan  After three days of ethnic rioting that spread across the south of this strategically important Central Asian nation, many streets in this city lay in smoldering ruins on Sunday night.

headline: U.S. Team Awaits Status of Goalkeeper
text: IRENE, South Africa  The United States’ satisfaction with a 1-1 draw against England was tempered Sunday by the uncertainty of goalkeeper Tim Howard’s availability for Friday’s World Cup match against Slovenia because of a rib injury.

headline: The Early Word: Obama Pushes Spending Plan
text: President Obama implored Republican and Democratic Congressional leaders Saturday to approve $50 billion in aid to cities and states to blunt “the devastating economic impact” of budget cuts on teachers, firefighters and other state workers. Both chambers have stalled on the package amid concerns over the rising national debt, but many economists argue that more spending could help ease unemployment.

text: Data by Match Analysis

headline: With Concessions, Honda Strike Fizzles in China
text: ZHONGSHAN, China — A strike at a Honda auto parts factory here in southeastern China collapsed on Monday morning, as Honda’s hiring of hundreds of replacement workers on Sunday prompted most of the strikers to return to work.

headline: Green Faces the Music; Chaochi Repeats His Mistake
