headline: Obama Plans First Oval Office Speech to Put Pressure on BP
text: WASHINGTON  Searching for a way to satisfy both the United States government and its own shareholders, the board of BP was examining three options for what to do with its next dividend, a person with direct knowledge of the board’s discussions said Monday.

headline: Audi Wins Le Mans, Finishing First, Second and Third
text: It may have been one of the fastest 24 Hours of Le Mans in history, with average speeds of 220 kilometers an hour, but at the end of the world’s most illustrious endurance race, the Audi car manufacturer proved once again that winning in Le Mans is not about setting the fastest lap times.

headline: Attack of the 40-Foot Iguana!
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — The thing looks fearsome enough on the ground, 40 feet from teeth to tail, spikes raised and claws extended, rearing its head as though to give some lacertilian battle call. New Yorkers of a certain age, and a certain musical persuasion, may remember it well.

headline: ‘Friday Night Lights’ Watch: Leaving Is Such Sweet Sorrow
text: There’s a lot to cover from Friday night’s episode of “Friday Night Lights,” but let’s start relatively off-road with Landry’s funny pregame interview. I love the way he embraces his nerdiness with so little ambivalence. For anyone who might have missed it, he brings up his high math score on the SATs as proof that  the game of the week is going to be a winner.

headline: Montreal Conductor to Lead Philadelphia
text: Yannick Nézet-Séguin, a fast-rising Canadian conductor barely known in the United States until recently, has won a major prize in the classical world: the music directorship of the Philadelphia Orchestra, a storied franchise that has been struggling.

headline: Growth and the Right
text: Should the current recovery falter, as some recent economic statistics suggest it might, the national stage might be perfectly set for a surge by Tea Party Republicans.

headline: Bank Raid and Battle Paralyze Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD  Attackers wearing military uniforms tried to storm the Central Bank of Iraq on Sunday, setting off explosions and engaging in gun battles with the police and soldiers that lasted hours during the afternoon rush and paralyzed parts of the capital. At least 15 people were killed and 50 were wounded, officials said.

headline: Newest Yankee Asks, Where Did I Sleep Last Night?
text: The previous 24 hours had been so hectic for Chad Huffman that on Sunday morning he was not entirely sure in which New York City borough the hotel where he slept Saturday night was located. But he had made it to Yankee Stadium, and that was all that mattered.

headline: Kyrgyz Riots Kill Nearly 100
text: Ethnic riots in Kyrgyzstan have killed nearly 100 people, which prompted Interim leader Roza Otunbayeva to call on Russia for help. President Medvedev of Russia turned down the offer.

headline: Ghana Gives Africa Its First Victory
text: PRETORIA, South Africa  Ghana and Serbia came into their opening game of the World Cup with different agendas.

headline: Final: Germany Dominates Australia
text: With the most comprehensively excellent performance of any team thus far in the World Cup, Germany made a proud Australian side look hopeless on Sunday night in Durban and cast itself as perhaps more of a contender than observers thought.

headline: Even With a World Cup Backdrop, Rugby Is Making Noise of Its Own
text: CAPE TOWN — However difficult to believe after the opening days of the World Cup finals, there are at least two places in South Africa where the drone of the vuvuzela cannot be heard.

headline: Switzerland Secures Release of Businessman From Libya, and Aims to Mend Ties
text: PARIS  Switzerland and Libya appeared Sunday to have finally resolved their fierce and bizarre dispute, which began two years ago when the Swiss arrested a son and daughter-in-law of the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, on suspicion of beating their servants.

headline: Little Rest for Top Chinese Players
text: After competing in the national championship, which ended a week ago, many of China’s top players are now playing each other in another tough tournament.

headline: The Dutch Look Great Again. Oh, No.
text: PRETORIA — What is it about the Dutch? Since the early 1970s, they have had great talents — Cruyff, van Basten, Gullit, Bergkamp, Rijkaard and others — playing some of the most expansive soccer in the history of the sport.

headline: Cablevision Strikes $1.36 Billion Deal for Bresnan
text: 7:48 a.m. | Updated Cablevision on Monday announced that it will acquire Bresnan Communications for $1.365 billion. It also announced a share buyback of up to $500 million.

headline: Lewis Hamilton Wins Second Grand Prix in a Row
text: Lewis Hamilton started in the pole position and finished first in the Canadian Grand Prix in Montreal, despite frequent upsets and passing elsewhere down the pack. He took his second victory in a row, and the 13th of his career, winning the race in his McLaren Mercedes and taking the lead of the drivers’ standings after eight races.

headline: Israel Backs Panel to Examine Raid
text: JERUSALEM — In an effort to dampen international criticism and stave off calls for an international inquiry, Israel’s cabinet on Monday unanimously approved a government-appointed commission with foreign participation to investigate the circumstances surrounding its deadly commando raid on a flotilla bound for Gaza in late May.

headline: Somalia Experiences New Type of Fighting
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia  From interclan fighting to religious battles to pirate wars, Somalia is plagued by countless kinds of conflict. But this weekend, another kind erupted: between the army and the police.

headline: Bonnaroo: Four-Word Reviews: Saturday
text: Weezer: Caustic, candied pop. Antijam.

headline: World Cup 2010 | Soccer at a Supermarket
text: Ghana was having a tough time with Serbia, finishing the first half in a scoreless tie before many New Yorkers had had their second cup of coffee Sunday morning.

headline: No Decision From Izzo
text: The weekend came and went with Tom Izzo still deliberating whether to accept a lucrative offer to jump to the Cleveland Cavaliers or remain in the collegiate ranks with Michigan State.

headline: Vote Widens Divide Between Flemish- and French-Speaking Regions
text: BRUSSELS  The move to break up Belgium gathered pace on Sunday as a separatist won an emphatic election victory in Flanders, the more prosperous Dutch-speaking region of the divided nation.

headline: More Questions About Mysterious South Carolina Senate Candidate
text: WASHINGTON — David Axelrod, President Obama’s senior adviser, has added his voice to those saying they smell something fishy in a Democratic primary in South Carolina that selected a jobless man who faces felony obscenity charges as the party’s nominee for the Senate.

headline: First Sweep on Road for Mets Since 2008
text: BALTIMORE  Steamy conditions, a cozy ballpark and poor opposition were the main ingredients in the Mets’ most successful trip in almost a year and a half. The Mets pounded Kevin Millwood and the Baltimore Orioles, 11-4, on Sunday in what left fielder Jason Bay called one of the four hottest games he has ever played in.

headline: The Very Angry Tea Party
text: Sometimes it is hard to know where politics ends and metaphysics begins: when, that is, the stakes of a political dispute concern not simply a clash of competing ideas and values but a clash about what is real and what is not, what can be said to exist on its own and what owes its existence to an other.

headline: Balanchine Protégé Transplants the Spirit to the Southwest
text: PHOENIX  Thirty years ago the Danish dancer Ib Andersen joined New York City Ballet, becoming the last new man of importance to work with George Balanchine. Elfin, fleet, witty, he had already been the youngest principal in the history of the Royal Danish Ballet (at the age of 20). In New York he created roles in three Balanchine ballets that survive today, and he became the final great exponent of Apollo in Balanchine’s ballet of that name during the choreographer’s lifetime. Ten years ago he became artistic director of Ballet Arizona.

headline: Ailey Presents Its Devotional Moods
text: I’d be willing to bet a “Revelations” Barbie doll that not 1 in 10 audience members at the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater’s performance Thursday night could have told you the title of the evening’s program. And why should they be able to? These mixed-bill titles  a relatively new dance world phenomenon  seem mostly to be a marketing strategy that the public simply ignores.

headline: In Visit to Kandahar, Karzai Outlines Anti-Taliban Plan
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai flew to this restive city on Sunday and told a gathering of local leaders to prepare themselves for sustained operations to rid the area of Taliban insurgents  and for the pain those operations would exact.

headline: Posada Hits Another Slam in His Return to Catching
text: Jorge Posada could get used to weekends like this.

headline: What to Expect on the Tonys Telecast
text: At Radio City Music Hall on Sunday morning, theater fans were given a sneak preview of tonight’s Tony Awards ceremony, at a run-through that — while not revealing any winners — did divulge a few production tidbits that three rehearsal attendees passed our way.

headline: New CDs
text: SARAH MCLACHLAN

headline: Debt Burden Falls Heavily on Germany and France
text: FRANKFURT — French and German banks have lent nearly $1 trillion to the most troubled European countries and are more exposed to the debt crisis than the banks of any other countries, according to a new report that is likely to add pressure on institutions to detail their holdings.

headline: Teenagers in Post-Kurt, Pre-Monica Years
text: If you get stuck in the closet with the wrong person, Seven Minutes in Heaven  the Russian Roulette of grade-school kissing games  can seem more like Five Days in Hell. That’s one of the amusing jokes of Steven Levenson’s slice-of-life portrait of six high school freshmen gossiping, flirting and trading insults in a suburban basement.

headline: Godzilla vs. the Louvre and Other Culture Clashes
text: Among the amazingly particular cultural phenomena associated with Japan is this minor but dazzling tidbit: roughly a dozen of the Japanese tourists who travel to Paris each year require psychological treatment when, Reuters has reported, “the reality of unfriendly locals and scruffy streets clashes with their expectations.” Symptoms include paranoia, depression and insomnia.

headline: One-Armed Bandit
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — For those who haven’t made summer vacation plans, today’s puzzle offers three options. Just one suggestion, don’t buy a ROUND TRIP TICKET. You’d be wasting your money.

headline: Holly Golightly, Before She Was Immortal
text: In 1961 Paramount Pictures’ publicity department attempted a remarkable acrobatic feat. It tried to explain why Holly Golightly  the professionally adorable heroine of “Breakfast at Tiffany’s,” a woman who stayed out all night and regularly accepted $50 gratuities from sundry gentlemen friends  was actually squeaky-clean.

headline: A Last Hurrah on Long Island, With a Sandwich No-Trump
text: There was a sad event this spring: The Vanderbilt Bridge Club in Lake Success, on Long Island, closed its doors.

headline: Letting the Arrows Fly at Hollywood Stereotypes
text: In his documentary “Reel Injun” the Cree filmmaker Neil Diamond takes a road trip to places that resonate in American Indian history, including the Black Hills of South Dakota, the Crow Agency in Montana and the Navajo Nation, and an imaginative journey through the shifting stereotypes Hollywood has used to obscure that history: the noble native, the brutal savage, the groovy wise man.

headline: Taking a New Concert Hall Out for a Spin or Two
text: ROCKPORT, Mass.  With good reason, congratulations flew in all directions as the Rockport Chamber Music Festival continued its opening weekend at its remarkable new home, the Shalin Liu Performance Center in this quaint seaside town 40 miles north of Boston, on Friday and Saturday evenings. But not every eminence was on hand to accept the accolades.

headline: Let’s Get Serious and Severe (and Dance With a Stool)
text: Let’s get one thing out of the way: 2 hours 15 minutes is far too long for a dance sampler. Curatorial prudence, people!

headline: The Greatest Laker? That Depends
text: BOSTON — This is not so much a debate as it is a love-fest. Two of the greatest players in Los Angeles Lakers history are arguing, politely and indirectly, about who should be known as the greatest Laker of all time.

headline: Germany Opens With Rout of Australia
text: DURBAN, South Africa  It would have been perfectly understandable if Joachim Löw’s German team had opened this World Cup looking unsettled instead of in tune.

headline: Today and Yesterday Sing Harmony at Bonnaroo
text: MANCHESTER, Tenn.  The aspirations and survival tactics of the Bonnaroo Music & Arts Festival, the annual four-day marathon of musical overload and muddy shoes, were neatly summed up in its headliners this year: a jam band, current hitmakers and a longtime pop giant. They balanced Bonnaroo’s neo-hippie aura with attention to the present.

headline: Wed in 1993, but Stuck in Immigration Limbo
text: In their cluttered studio apartment in Astoria, Queens, after nearly 17 years of marriage, Shari Feldman and Inderjit Singh seem like a pair of old shoes — a little the worse for wear but comfortable with each other’s creases.

headline: What Do China’s Workers Want?
text: Labor conditions in China have drawn scrutiny in recent weeks, with worker strikes at Honda plants and a cluster of suicides or attempted suicides at Foxconn Technology, the world’s largest contract electronics supplier, that were at least partly linked to job pressures. Foxconn and Honda have responded with wage increases, but strikes seemed to have spread. Late last week, workers at a Honda auto parts plant in Zhongshan held protests to demand the right to form their own union, and workers held walkouts at foreign-owned factories in at least five other cities.

headline: Separatists Behead 3 Men in Philippines
text: MANILA  Militant members of an Islamist separatist group abducted and beheaded three Filipino loggers in the southern part of the country, officials said Sunday.

headline: A Disaster, Privately Managed
text: The three journalists crept along in a boat captained by James Ledet in a bayou near Golden Meadow, La., one early afternoon. We were all looking for the same thing as we traversed narrow stretches of water framed by swamp grass, in a landscape dotted with docked shrimp boats and old oil rigs.

headline: Debt Burden Falls Heavily on Germany and France
text: French and German banks have lent nearly $1 trillion to the most troubled European countries and are more exposed to the debt crisis than the banks of any other countries, The New York Times’s Jack Ewing reports, citing a new report that is likely to add pressure on institutions to detail their holdings.

headline: In Connecticut’s G.O.P., a Vanquished Rival Lingers On
text: Last week’s primaries were a great moment for women in American politics, an inspiring reminder that women are just as able as men to buy elections with big bucks, get nominated while fending off allegations of marital infidelity, say unfortunate things into a live microphone while in a Type A BlackBerry trance and win while espousing far-right, far-out ideas.

headline: Joyce Found Too Graphic, This Time by Apple
text: The question of whether James Joyce’s “Ulysses” is obscene seemed to have been settled for more than 75 years. Until last week, that is, when the creators of a Web comic version of the classic novel, called “Ulysses Seen,” said that Apple required them to remove any images containing nudity before the comic was approved as an application for the iPad.

headline: At the Movies, Please Turn On Your Cellphone
text: Best Buy is giving away a cellphone application intended to get audiences to use their phones during movies.

headline: Celtics Take 3-2 Lead in N.B.A. Finals
text: BOSTON – The Boston Celtics are one victory away from claiming their 18th N.B.A. championship and their second in three years. They will have to do it in Los Angeles.

headline: In Deal-Making, Flat Is the New Up
text: Some bankers made rosy predictions for a big bounce-back in mergers and acquisitions this year. Yet deal volumes in the United States are recovering as if the recession just endured was run of the mill. After two down years, the value of American corporate match-making is flat in 2010. That’s no boom — but if history is any guide, it’s also nothing for bankers to complain about.

headline: Not Even Sand and Sea Are Luring Usual Crowds to Greece
text: RHODES, Greece  Faliraki, a resort in this island’s northeast known for its long sandy coastline and raucous night life, is a picture of calm these days as summer begins. The pristine beaches are sparsely populated, the bars are all but empty and Vassilis Minaidis’s gleaming new five-star hotel is distressingly quiet.

headline: Libertarian Talk, Now on Fox Business Network
text: “Welcome to this struggle,” Andrew Napolitano said triumphantly as he wrapped up the first television episode last weekend of his libertarian talk show, “Freedom Watch.” He saluted the camera and concluded, “From New York, defending freedom, so long America.”

text: To the Editor:

headline: Once Just a Site With Funny Cat Pictures, and Now a Web Empire
text: SEATTLE  Three years ago Ben Huh visited a blog devoted to silly cat pictures  and saw vast potential.

headline: Rethinking Cell Service in a Remote Flood Region
text: LANGLEY, Ark  For many visitors and residents of this heavily forested region, the appeal is in the disconnect. Without so much as a cellphone tower near these vast campgrounds, some come here happy to leave behind their ties to the urban world, preferring a soundtrack of tweeting birds over a chirping BlackBerry.

headline: U.S. Drops Inspector of Food in China
text: Organic food from China, like tea and frozen broccoli, has increasingly found its way onto American store shelves, typically emblazoned with the green “U.S.D.A. organic” seal also found on food grown in this country.

headline: AT&T Explains iPad Security Breach
text: On Sunday evening, AT&T sent an e-mail message to owners of the Apple 3G iPad notifying them of a security breach that was publicized early last week.

headline: Red Carpet at the Tony Awards
text: A look at the fashions at the 2010 Tony Awards ceremony.

headline: Studying Engineering Before They Can Spell It
text: GLEN ROCK, N.J.  In a class full of aspiring engineers, the big bad wolf had to do more than just huff and puff to blow down the three little pigs’ house.

headline: Hollywood Hopes ‘Toy Story 3’ Can Spur Summer Sales
text: LOS ANGELES  Save us, Buzz Lightyear.

headline: Partners on Some Work, and Opponents for the Prize: Control of the House
text: WASHINGTON  Representatives Chris Van Hollen of Maryland and Pete Sessions of Texas shared an Easter Seals award in May for their Congressional work on behalf of people with disabilities. But only one of the two rivals can win another noteworthy prize that they are aggressively pursuing this year: partisan control of the House of Representatives.

headline: No Mystique About Feminism
text: When historians set out to date the moment when the women’s movement of the 1970s officially consolidated its gains, they could do worse than settle on last Tuesday’s primaries.

headline: The Separation of Politics and State
text: Minneapolis

headline: All Her Life, Nikki Haley Was the Different One
text: BAMBERG, S.C.  Nikki Haley, the favorite to become the first governor of South Carolina who is neither white nor male, has always challenged established norms with her own brand of moxie.

headline: Clemens’s Foundation Comes Under Scrutiny
text: Roger Clemens’s former trainer has told federal authorities investigating Clemens for perjury that Clemens’s nonprofit organization paid him for his training services, including the performance-enhancing drugs he said he provided Clemens, according to several people briefed on the investigation.

headline: In China, Unlikely Labor Leader Just Wanted a Middle-Class Life
text: SHANGHAI  Tan Guocheng is hardly a self-styled labor leader. Age 23 and introverted, he grew up among rice paddies and orange groves far from China’s big factory towns.

text: Cullowhee, N.C.

text: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Identifies Vast Mineral Riches in Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON  The United States has discovered nearly $1 trillion in untapped mineral deposits in Afghanistan, far beyond any previously known reserves and enough to fundamentally alter the Afghan economy and perhaps the Afghan war itself, according to senior American government officials.

headline: Day Labor and Free Speech
text: Cities and suburbs across America have tried to muscle immigrant day laborers off the sidewalk, passing laws that prohibit job solicitation in public places and enforcing them with ticketing and arrest sweeps. Federal courts have repeatedly struck down these laws, recognizing that the First Amendment protects all people who want to speak freely and assemble peaceably.

headline: Peru's Coca Conflict
text: After intensive American-funded eradication efforts in Colombia, coca cultivation has shifted once again. Now Peru is on its way to reclaim its title as the world's largest exporter of cocaine.

headline: On Randalls Island, Private Schools Play Free
text: On a blazing May afternoon, a group of lanky seventh- and eighth-grade softball players from the Dalton School were locked in a fierce battle against a rival private school, St. Hilda’s & St. Hugh’s. The championship game was being played on Randalls Island, on an immaculately manicured field that sparkled in the sunlight. Not far away, boats chugged along the East River.

headline: HUD Steps Up in Texas
text: Washington too often looks the other way as state governments rob low-income victims of their fair share of federal disaster aid. The Department of Housing and Urban Development did the right thing recently in forcing Texas to revise a $3 billion spending plan for aid provided in the wake of the 2008 hurricanes Ike and Dolly.

headline: For Wright, Production at Plate Trumps Power
text: BALTIMORE — With two home runs in the Mets’ 11-4 victory over the Orioles, David Wright exceeded his total from last season by two, but he was not passing out cigars.

headline: Duplicate Result
text: Fresh off his victory in the World Rapid Championship, Sergey Karjakin wins the 11th Poikovsky Karpov tournament.

headline: Washington’s Teachers’ Contract
text: Teachers’ unions around the country are realizing that they can either participate in shaping reforms or have others’ reforms forced upon them. The latest example comes from Washington, where the union has wisely negotiated and ratified a contract that gives the city greater leeway to pay, promote or fire teachers based on performance.

headline: Taking Stock in Afghanistan
text: There are not a lot of good weeks in Afghanistan. But last week was particularly bad. At least 26 American or NATO soldiers were killed in attacks by insurgents. The commanding general, Stanley McChrystal, announced that his long promised offensive in the Taliban’s home base of Kandahar would be delayed for months.

headline: At the Parade, a Day of Traditions and Familiar Faces
text: As beauty queens beamed and Latin dancers shimmied up Fifth Avenue, the Garcia, Gomez and Vazquez families reclaimed the spread of pavement that becomes their temporary home one day each year.

headline: Coca Production Makes a Comeback in Peru
text: TINGO MARÍA, Peru  Coca cultivation is surging once again in this country’s remote tropical valleys, part of a major repositioning of the Andean drug trade that is making Peru a contender to surpass Colombia as the world’s largest exporter of cocaine.

headline: For Forgetful, Cash Helps the Medicine Go Down
text: It has long been one of the most vexing causes of America’s skyrocketing health costs: people not taking their medicine.

headline: Guggenheim and YouTube Seek Budding Video Artists
text: For artists, being included in a museum exhibition generally means first having to penetrate the well-guarded gates of a prestigious art gallery. But now the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation and YouTube are aiming to short-circuit that exclusionary art-world system, at least briefly, in much the same way that other hierarchical systems have been blown apart in the Internet age.

headline: 3 Men Rescued From Colombian Guerrillas
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  Colombian soldiers stalking leftist guerrillas in the country’s remote jungles have rescued three hostages held by the rebels, including a police general who was their highest-ranking captive, Colombian officials said Sunday.

headline: Report Says Pakistan Intelligence Agency Exerts Great Sway on Afghan Taliban
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Pakistan’s main intelligence agency continues to provide financing, training and sanctuary to Afghan Taliban insurgents and exerts a far greater influence on Taliban strategy than previously thought, according to a report prepared by the London School of Economics.

headline: Swerving Like a Jabulani Through City Cultures
text: The World Cup’s funny ball was still performing the dipsy-doodle on Sunday. Red cards were flying all over South Africa, and cheers in diverse languages were flying all over New York.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Insults Across the Water
text: Well, now: it seems our dear ally across the pond feels that a row has broken out over the intemperance of the American president toward mighty BP.

headline: MTV Serves as Model for AOL Site
text: The next time the Jonas Brothers release an album or announce a tour, they can skip “Entertainment Tonight” and YouTube and go straight to Cambio.

headline: 24-Hour Read-In Protests Cuts to Libraries
text: It was the literary equivalent of a filibuster, a bookworm’s take on 1960s-style protest.

headline: Drafting the Audience Into Very Active Service
text: Audience participation. Is there a more unpleasant conjoining of nouns in the English language?

headline: Somalia's Child Soldiers
text: Children, some as young as 9, are being recruited to become soldiers by Somalia's government, which is partially funded by the U.S. taxpayer.

headline: With Flood Toll at 19, Question Is, How Many More?
text: LANGLEY, Ark.  Search crews canvassing dozens of miles of muddy, rugged vegetation in scorching heat and humidity on Sunday recovered a 19th victim of last week’s deadly flash floods that flushed out the Albert Pike campground, and officials said they were not certain how many people might still be missing.

headline: ‘Red’ and ‘Memphis’ Win Top Tony Awards
text: The American rock ’n’ roll story “Memphis” won the Tony Award for best musical on Sunday night, and the British production “Red” took best play and five other Tonys, one of the highest totals for a play in recent years. Yet all but eclipsing those shows was the unusually powerful star wattage in Radio City Music Hall, full of well-known figures from film, television and music who became dominant forces on Broadway during the 2009-10 season.

headline: Managing Reputations on Social Sites
text: In response to growing privacy concerns on the Internet, people are increasingly monitoring their online identities. And young Internet users are the most vigilant in restricting access to personal information, according to a Pew report.

headline: Under a Withering Sun, Spill Cleanup Workers Must Break Frequently
text: GRAND ISLE, La.  On a beach where the sea breeze reeks of oil, about a dozen workers stoically shoveled contaminated sand into plastic bags on a recent afternoon, while others lolled on chairs and beverage coolers under a white tent nearby, chatting and dozing against the tent’s poles.

headline: Zenyatta Sets Record
text: INGLEWOOD, Calif.  For a horse that carries herself with inimitable style, quaffing Guinness after workouts and prancing around the paddock as if she were preparing for dressage, Zenyatta high-stepped her way into the record books with a characteristic flourish.

headline: Children Carry Guns for a U.S. Ally, Somalia
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Awil Salah Osman prowls the streets of this shattered city, looking like so many other boys, with ripped-up clothes, thin limbs and eyes eager for attention and affection.

headline: Economic News in the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Reports this week will include import prices for May (Tuesday); producer price index for May; housing starts for May; and industrial production and capacity utilization for May (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims; consumer price index for May; Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index for June; and leading economic indicators for May (Thursday).

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

text: The White House Turns Up the Pressure on BP

headline: In Case of Storm, Spill Containment and Relief Drilling Could Be Suspended
text: BP may finally be achieving success in capturing oil from its runaway well in the Gulf of Mexico, and relief wells are on pace to permanently stem the flow this summer, but a formidable obstacle still looms: the weather.

headline: After Some Demises, a Reinvented Food Magazine
text: MEDIA executives are behaving like the cast of “Glee,” belting out their new favorite Broadway tune, “Food, Glorious Food.”

headline: Cablevision Said to Bid $1.3 Billion for Firm
text: Cablevision agreed on Sunday to pay more than $1.36 billion for Bresnan Communications, a cable services operator whose owners include the private equity firm Providence Equity Partners, people briefed on the matter said.

headline: Criticism Flowing Like Oil, but Obama’s Rating Is Steady
text: Oil has gushed into the Gulf of Mexico for eight weeks now — and sent a bipartisan wave of criticism crashing into the White House.

headline: Robert J. Wussler, CBS Executive and Aide to Ted Turner, Dies at 73
text: Robert J. Wussler, a senior executive for the CBS news and sports divisions and president of the CBS Television Network in the 1970s, and later the top aide to Ted Turner in the expansion of his cable TV operations, died June 5 at his home in Westport, Conn. He was 73.

headline: In Albany, Questions on Averting a Shutdown
text: ALBANY  State leaders said on Sunday that they expected to pass another short-term emergency spending bill on Monday, averting a government shutdown, though they could not say exactly how they would muster enough votes in the narrowly divided State Senate to do so.

headline: Flaming Drinks Are Exotic, but Flaming Bars Are a No-No
text: Albert Trummer, libations impresario and co-owner of the Prohibition-era styled Chinatown bar Apotheke, has built a reputation for concocting highly stylized drinks. Staggeringly strong and infused with herbs, his cocktails are said to cure one’s ailments  the menu lists “Stress Relievers,” “Pharmaceuticals” and “Therapeutic Treatments”  though they may inflict their own damage on livers.

text: Looking for the federal government to come to the rescue of newspapers? Don’t hold your breath.

headline: War on Drugs in Peru
text: Drug traffickers are stymieing efforts to combat cocaine’s resurgence there and raising the specter of greater violence in a nation still haunted by war.

headline: Frank W. Ballard, Who Trained Puppeteers at UConn, Dies at 80
text: Frank W. Ballard, a master puller of strings who helped bring the study of puppetry into the university curriculum and in so doing trained a generation of lively, manipulative disciples, died on June 4 in Storrs, Conn. He was 80 and lived in Storrs.

text: BOSTON — Paul Pierce and Kobe Bryant repeatedly scorched the nets, traded baskets and jostled for postseason supremacy as the N.B.A. finals swayed with each flick of their wrists.

headline: Bonnaroo: Four-Word Reviews: Sunday
text: Calexico: Mariachi horns = soothing refreshment.

headline: ‘Memphis,’ ‘Red’ and ‘Fences’ Win Big at the Tony Awards
text: Tonight, Broadway honored the year’s best musicals, plays, performers and theater artists. ArtsBeat followed the program live. Patrick Healy’s article can be found here. A complete list of winners can be found here. A slide show of the red carpet can be found here.

headline: Reflections of Paris
text: Are Yvon’s photographs as resonant as they are because they capture the spirit of Paris so well? Or is Paris as resonant as it is because it captures the spirit of Yvon’s postcards so well?

headline: Riot Police End Workers’ Protest at Durban Stadium
text: DURBAN, South Africa — A World Cup Sunday that began at the soaring new arch of Durban Stadium ended in smoke and shrieks as police officers fired tear gas and what witnesses said were rubber bullets to break up a large group of protesting security guards.

headline: New Rules on Changes to Benefits
text: WASHINGTON  The White House on Monday will issue new rules that strongly discourage employers from cutting health insurance benefits or increasing the costs of coverage to employees, administration officials say.

headline: World Cup Replay: Day 3, June 13
text: Germany got creative, Ghana brought joy to its home continent and Slovenia persisted on the third day of the World Cup.

headline: Taiwan Pulls Films From Chinese Festival
text: Taiwan’s film commission withdrew eight Taiwanese films late last week from the Shanghai International Film Festival, expressing concern that organizers would use the occasion to assert China’s sovereignty over Taiwan, The Associated Press reported. The organizers of a recent television festival in Shanghai identified TV series from Taiwan as originating in “Taiwan, China.” “We are worried that a similar situation to the TV series will recur,” Anne Lu, a spokeswoman for the Taipei Film Commission, told The A.P. The film festival opened Saturday night and continues next Sunday.

headline: Footnotes
text: Melissa Etheridge, a two-time Grammy Award winner, will make her Broadway debut on June 23, performing a to-be-announced rock-’n’-roll number during the finale of the evening performance of the musical “Million Dollar Quartet.”... The original director, cast members and design team of the 2008 world-premiere production of Lynn Nottage’s Pulitizer Prize-winning play, “Ruined,” will reunite for runs of the play at the Intiman Theater in Seattle beginning July 2 and the Geffen Playhouse in Los Angeles beginning Sept. 7. Kate Whoriskey, who directed “Ruined” in its world premiere at the Goodman Theater in Chicago and then at Manhattan Theater Club, is now the Intiman’s artistic director.

headline: Kodak Gives ‘World’s Largest Photographs’ to Museum
text: The Eastman Kodak Company has donated its archive of Colorama images  the huge panoramic photographs that were displayed as advertisements in the Main Concourse of Grand Central Terminal for four decades beginning in 1950  to the George Eastman House International Museum of Photography and Film in Rochester, the museum announced on Friday. Coloramas, towering backlighted transparencies that were 18 feet high and 60 feet wide, were promoted by Kodak as “the world’s largest photographs.” More than 500 were publicly displayed, for runs of three weeks each. (Above, “Family in Convertible, Texas.) They often contained idealized depictions of American daily life, usually showing a Kodak camera being used to photograph a family, activity or beautiful scene. The archive gift includes display images of all Coloramas, including those that were never displayed, along with research documents, negatives and other prints and files. An exhibition of 36 Coloramas, focusing on the 1960s, will be on view at the Eastman House from Saturday through Oct. 17.

headline: Smithsonian Gets Itself a Lifeboat
text: No, it’s not a federal bailout, but an actual lifeboat: the Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company has donated a 100-year-old boat, used on two early attempted crossings of the Atlantic by airships, to the Smithsonian’s National Air and Space Museum. The lifeboat, above, was first used by the journalist Walter Wellman and his crew in their attempt at the first powered flight across the Atlantic in 1910. They flew for 38 hours before being forced down by engine problems near Bermuda and rescued by a steamer. The boat’s next mission ended less happily. In 1912 Wellman’s chief engineer, Melvin Vaniman, tried to cross the Atlantic on the Akron, the first Goodyear airship. It had barely gotten over water when it exploded, sending the crew members to their deaths. The lifeboat, however, was saved and has been kept in storage by Goodyear since then. After being cleaned, it will go on display at the museum near two historic aircraft that succeeded in crossing the Atlantic: the gondola of the first balloon to do so, and the Concorde.

headline: Jackson’s Doctor Fighting to Keep His License
text: A fight over whether Michael Jackson’s doctor, Conrad Murray, should keep his California medical license is expected Monday in Dr. Murray’s pretrial hearing in Los Angeles Superior Court in his involuntary manslaughter case, which stems from Jackson’s death last year. The office of California’s attorney general, Jerry Brown, is trying for a fourth time, on behalf of the state’s medical board, to suspend Dr. Murray’s medical license, and Dr. Murray’s lawyer is crying foul. On Friday he filed papers arguing that prosecutors were simply taking the same motion before a different judge, without any changed circumstances, The Associated Press reported. A previous judge in the case, Keith Schwartz, prohibited Dr. Murray, above, from administering anesthetics but did not suspend his license. The case has now been taken over by Judge Michael Pastor.

headline: Shutterbug’s Complaint Accuses Jodie Foster
text: A 17-year-old has filed a police report accusing Jodie Foster of attacking him after he photographed her and her children leaving the movies at the Grove shopping center in Los Angeles on May 29. The youth said that Ms. Foster, right, poked him in the chest and grabbed his elbow, causing visible injuries. Ms. Foster’s representative fought back, telling People magazine that the youth was “a professional paparazzo,” and that the police report was a “fabrication” of what actually happened. RadarOnline.com reported that the representative said Ms. Foster had merely “touched him on the elbow in an attempt to take him aside to talk to him and tell him to stop,” adding, “‘He scared the kids.” According to the site, the youth’s father denied that he is a professional photographer, and the Los Angeles police said they were looking into the matter.

headline: Libertarian Talk, Now on Fox Business Network

headline: A Peek at a Changed Pebble Beach
text: On Thursday, we begin the equivalent of a four-day national holiday of golf. And although every United States Open is good theater, this year’s stage is the Pebble Beach Golf Links, which will make the drama seem tinged with history even in real time.

headline: Getting Ready for Free-Agent Season
text: At 12:01 a.m. on July 1, the Knicks will officially and openly begin wooing LeBron James. At that same moment, a new Knicks-themed show will make its debut on the MSG Network. It will not be called “The LeBronathon,” but only because that might violate league tampering rules.

headline: Uncertainty Restores Glitter to an Old Refuge, Gold
text: It is the resurgent passion of the doomsday crowd, a bet that everything will go wrong. No matter what has you worried, they say, the answer is gold, Nelson D. Schwartz reports in The New York Times.

headline: In Deal-Making, Flat Is the New Up
text: Some bankers made rosy predictions for a big bounce-back in mergers and acquisitions this year. Yet deal volumes in the United States are recovering as if the recession just endured was run of the mill, Reuters Breakingviews says.

headline: Bloomberg Spent More as Market Bounced Back
text: After a decade of conspicuous consumption — a town house here, a private jet there — Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg seemed to slam on the brakes in 2008 during the recession. He bought no new property, rented out space in a vacation home and — horrors! — cut back on household staff.

headline: Genocide and the 2014 Olympics
text: Today’s idea: Charges of genocide a century and a half ago could haunt Russia as it holds its first post-Soviet Olympics in Sochi, former capital of forcibly exiled Circassians.

headline: From Gambits to Gambler: One Man’s Path
text: It seems that Patrick Wolff has taken the path less traveled to get to his career as a hedge fund manager.

headline: Qatar to Dominate in Overseas Real Estate?
text: Qatar is expected to be the largest source of global real estate capital during 2010, Reuters said, citing a report published Sunday by real estate consultancy Jones Lang LaSalle.

headline: Xinjiang Goldwind Cancels Hong Kong I.P.O.
text: Xinjiang Goldwind, the Chinese alternative energy company, said Monday that it had decided to cancel its $1.2 billion initial public offering because of “unexpected and excessive market volatility.”

headline: Data for 500 UBS Clients Said to Already Be in U.S.
text: Swiss authorities have already handed over 500 accounts of UBS clients to the United States under an agreement to end a tax dispute that has threatened the bank’s existence, Reuters said, referring to a Swiss newspaper report published on Sunday.

headline: The Sagging of the Middle Class
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

headline: A Hong Kong Street Is a Taste of the Past
text: Hong Kong looks relentlessly to the future. But the city is experiencing an unexpected bout of nostalgia, thanks to the success of the movie “Echoes of the Rainbow” — and much of that nostalgia is centered on a narrow lane called Wing Lee Street, where the movie was shot.

headline: Russia Weighs Pleas to Step In as Uzbeks Flee Kyrgyzstan
text: OSH, Kyrgyzstan — As four days of ethnic violence in southern Kyrgyzstan threatened to build into a major refugee crisis on Monday, both sides of the conflict were calling on Russia to step in, saying third-party peacekeepers were needed to defuse standoffs between Uzbeks and Kyrgyz.

headline: Resolution Eyes $4 Billion Deal for Axa Units
text: Resolution, the acquisition vehicle founded by Clive Cowdery, announced Monday that it’s in talks to buy some of the British operations of French insurance giant Axa in a £2.75 billion ($4 billion) deal, MarketWatch reported.

headline: SocGen Poised to Buy French Lender for $1.1 Billion
text: Société Générale said Monday that its Crédit du Nord unit was in exclusive negatiations to acquire a regional French bank for 872 million euros.

headline: What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
text: We’re asking this question every Monday this summer for our Summer Reading Student Challenge. You can post your answer here anytime until next Monday, June 21, when we’ll close this post and open a new one with the same question.

headline: As I Always Say…

text: So, one more time: here’s an attempt to put together some key arguments about why the rush to fiscal austerity is deeply misguided.

headline: E.U. Said to Consider Hedge-Fund Compromise
text: The European Commission has tabled a suggested compromise on recent moves to ramp up regulation of hedge funds operating in the European Union, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing European officials familiar with the matter.

headline: Getting Out of Trouble
text: Golf expert Bryan Jones shows Bill Pennington how to think outside the box in tough situations on the golf course.

headline: Apotheke Owner Arrested by Fire Marshals
text: Albert Trummer, the co-owner of the Chinatown bar Apotheke known for his highly stylized drinks, was arrested by fire marshals early Sunday morning on charges of doing something else he’s become noted for — pouring alcohol along the bar top and setting it aflame.

headline: Antipathy To Low Rates
text: Richard Serlin, in comments at Mark Thoma’s place, makes a very good point about the efforts of Rajan and others to come up with a reason to raise interest rates even in the face of high unemployment and incipient deflation. He suggests that it reflects a general distaste for anything that looks like government intervention to support the economy:

headline: Italy Calls 2010 Last Year of Fiscal Independence
text: Giulio Tremonti, the Italian minister of the economy, said Sunday that this year would be the last that European Countries decide their budgets independently.

headline: There’s a Business in My Trash
text: I buy a lot of wood. Beautiful hardwoods, from domestic and foreign forests, that we use to make very fine furniture. But here’s a weird thing: we throw a lot of it away. Not sawdust — though we make lots of that, too — but perfectly good chunks of cherry, walnut, mahogany, oak and maple. We toss several hundred dollars’ worth in the Dumpster every week.

headline: Merely Human? That’s So Yesterday
text: On a Tuesday evening this spring, Sergey Brin, the co-founder of Google, became part man and part machine. About 40 people, all gathered in Mountain View, Calif. at a NASA campus for a nine-day, $15,000 course at Singularity University, saw it happen, The New York Times’s Ashlee Vance writes.

headline: Petrobras Said to Prepare $25 Billion Share Issue
text: Petrobras, Brazil’s national oil company, is preparing a $25 billion share issue for July, The Financial Times reported,  in a move toward developing its “presalt” fields — so named because they are beneath thousands of meters of sea water, rock and a layer of salt.  The fields  have the potential of making the South American nation one of the world’s largest oil exporters.

headline: Media Decoder: ‘Ulysses’ a Little Too Graphic for Apple
text: The question of whether James Joyce’s “Ulysses” is obscene seemed to have been settled for more than 75 years. Until last week, that is, when the creators of a Web comic version of the classic novel, called “Ulysses Seen,” said that Apple required them to remove any images containing nudity before the comic was approved as an application for the iPad.

headline: Submit Your Funny Caption
text: Beholder | Tell us what’s going on in the picture above (use the comment link below). It’s the latest of the uncaptioned images we’re posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. The latest funniest captions are at right.

headline: Anger With Political Class Grows Among Iraqi Public
text: BAGHDAD  Even as Iraq’s Parliament convened Monday, three long months of court challenges, recounts and disqualifications after it was elected, Saif Ali, a shopkeeper, was venting his anger at Iraqi politicians.

headline: Greece’s Rating Is Cut, and the Markets Ebb
text: Stocks on Wall Street slipped on Monday after Greece’s debt was downgraded, the latest development in the deepening challenges of the euro zone countries.

headline: The Temporary Vegetarian: Steamed Eggs à la Harbin Restaurant
text: When Eva Chang was a growing up in Shanghai, steamed egg custard with sauteed Chinese mushrooms, peas and scallions appeared on the lunch or dinner table at least twice a month. In the 1940s her family fled the chaos of China and moved to San Francisco, where she became the owner and executive chef of the Harbin Restaurant from 1967 to 1990. Today she is 90 and still cooks for her family. One recipe in particular evokes childhood memories.

headline: Twilight of the Coal Era?
text: The electricity market is in the doldrums, but the market for new generating stations that use natural gas is going strong, industry experts say. Why? Because gas is beginning to replace coal, according to Randy H. Zwirn, president of the Siemens Power Generation Group.

headline: Video of Kyrgyz Unrest on YouTube
text: As my colleague Michael Schwirtz reports from Kyrgyzstan, the southern city of Osh is mostly quiet on Monday morning, “after four days of violence left swaths of the country’s ethnically mixed south in ruins.”

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Turns out Afghanistan is a pauper on the surface, but a prince underground. The New York Times breaks the story of the minerals that may change everything in the country’s economy, and its war. In a weird way, it’s the opposite of the situation faced by European banks, which were looking fine on the surface but get scary when you look inside.

headline: A Labor Market (and Baseball) Mystery
text: Our sports section ran a chart yesterday showing that, in relative terms, shortstops and second basemen are better hitters than they used to be and outfielders and designated hitters are worse. That is, all four groups have converged toward the average in recent decades. Baseball fans will have no trouble coming up with examples: good-hitting infielders like Chase Utley, Derek Jeter, Dustin Pedroia, Hanley Ramirez — or the general lack of good D.H.’s this season.

headline: Are Employer Contributions Now Taxable Income?
text: Q.

text: President Obama sets out today for a two-day tour of three of the states most affected by the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, starting with Mississippi and Alabama.

text: JOHANNESBURG — Zinedine Zidane lashed out at France Coach Raymond Domenech and chastised his countrymen for their lackluster play.

text: This week, Rebecca Forman, who has been working as a court reporter in the Manhattan federal courthouse since February 2003, responded to readers’ questions about her job, where she says she hopes to stay until she retires.

text: The fiscal food fight that has been consuming the Senate and House continues this week, with unemployment benefits, Medicare fees to doctors and health aid to states among the potential casualties.

headline: Obama, Visiting Gulf, Tries to Lift Economy and Mood
text: THEODORE, Ala.  President Obama on Monday stepped up his efforts to limit the economic fallout from the oil spill, announcing steps to assure consumers that seafood from the Gulf of Mexico is safe and promoting tourism in the region as BP, under pressure from the White House, agreed to accelerate the cleanup.

headline: Japan Eases Past Cameroon
text: In a turgid affair in Bloemfontein, South Africa, Japan beat Cameroon, 1-0, on Monday.

headline: A Boy and His Kalashnikov
text: 2:32 p.m. | Updated As Jeffrey Gettleman reports in The Times today, American money is helping the Transitional Federal Government in Somalia recruit an army that includes heavily armed boys. Welcome to Planet Teen, where the fate of children — particularly the world’s billion-plus teenagers — will substantially shape the quality of life in developing countries for decades to come.

headline: Skilling Behind Bars: Enron’s Ex-Chief Speaks
text: While he awaits word from the Supreme Court over the appeal of his Enron conviction, Jeffrey K. Skilling has decided to open up.

headline: Terrazzo, Terrazzo! And Inadvertent Verity
text: You can gaze at its constellation-filled ceiling, or admire those sky-high Corinthian columns, but there is one way to appreciate the neo-Classical splendor of Grand Central Terminal that does not require a craned neck: stare at the floor.

headline: For Salon Reporter, a Long Commitment to Arlington Burial Story
text: For most reporters, there is nothing less interesting that the last story they did. They report something, write it up and then it is on to next. But investigative reporters are autodidacts, grabbing a single subject by the throat and hanging on, like a dog on a soup bone.

headline: The Life, Death and Rebirth of ‘Big Bad John’
text: You may remember Jimmy Dean, the country music star and entrepreneur who, The Associated Press reported, died Sunday at age 81, as a “Tonight Show” guest host, a purveyor of sausage products, or as Willard Whyte, the eccentric Las Vegas billionaire from the James Bond movie “Diamonds Are Forever.”

headline: Caregiving and Alzheimer’s: A Road Map
text: What I like about the new guide for those caring for people with Alzheimer’s disease, published by the National Institute on Aging, is that it’s:a) simply written;b) comprehensive, covering issues from medical conditions and legal documents to why you shouldn’t try to take your relative’s temperature with a glass thermometer;c) free.

headline: Brief Paddock News From Montreal
text: Over the last four and a half years of blogging I have occasionally shared short news briefs from the paddock from my friend and journalist colleague Agnès Carlier. Agnès has just sent me a load of fresh gossipy items from the Canadian Grand Prix:

headline: Researchers Sail to the Spill Site
text: One journey I’ll be following closely over the next week is the voyage of the Cape Hatteras, a 135-foot research vessel operated by the Duke/University of North Carolina Oceanographic Consortium. As we reported here last week, scientists from these and other universities are sailing into the heart of the oil spill to study its environmental impact. After a stop in Gulfport, Miss., the crew departed Saturday for the spill site in the Gulf of Mexico and is blogging from the boat.

headline: Brooklyn Heights, 6:45 A.M.
text: Jogging on the Brooklyn Heights Promenade on an overcast morning.

headline: Indictment Over Bloomberg Campaign Funds
text: Updated, 1:29 p.m. | A top Republican political operative was charged on Monday by the Manhattan district attorney’s office with grand larceny, money laundering and three other counts in connection with accusations that he stole $1.1 million from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg during last year’s campaign.

headline: 24 Hours of Le Mans From the Best Seat in the House, Literally
text: When I covered my first 24 Hours of Le Mans, in 1976, I wrote my story on a yellow legal pad as I sat in the shade of a small tree on a cinder block patio behind the pit area. I passed the handwritten copy to a Telex operator in a small press office next to the patio, and she typed it for my editors in New York. Then I walked right out onto pit lane for the victory celebration.

headline: A Quiet Victory for the Netherlands
text: JOHANNESBURG — Simon Poulsen can almost be excused for falling asleep on the job. Poulsen, a Danish defender, nodded a harmless Robin van Persie cross into his own goal just after halftime of a slow, droll affair Monday between the Netherlands and Denmark at Soccer City.

headline: Monday Reading: Getting Paid to Take Medicine
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that hits your wallet.

headline: Cysts, Pancreatic Disease and Cancer
text: Can diseases of the pancreas like cysts or pancreatitis progress to cancer? Are melanoma or colon cancer related to pancreatic cancer? Those are among the questions recently posted to the Consults blog. Dr. Eileen O’Reilly, a pancreatic cancer expert at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, responds.

headline: Skadden Hires Brussels Lawyer From Clifford Chance
text: Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, the giant American law firm, said Monday that it had hired Simon Baxter, a partner at Clifford Chance, for its Brussels office.

headline: Final Scenes From Bonnaroo
text: The ninth annual Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival wrapped up on Sunday in Manchester, Tenn., after four days of performances by more than 100 acts.

headline: What We’re Reading: Investing in the Companies You Regulate
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: See You in the Funny Pages: Little Orphan Annie Says Goodbye
text: The lizards have ceased leaping, and the sun isn’t coming out tomorrow or even today: on Sunday, after an 86-year run as the pluckiest pupil-free young adventurer in the funny pages, Little Orphan Annie appeared in her last newspaper comic strip.

headline: Numberplay: Trapped in the Fourth Dimension?
text: We have not received this week’s dispatch from Pradeep Mutalik, the Numberplay author. As you all know, he was intent on acting on the e-mail he received from the mysterious Dr. I. J. Matrix last week.

headline: Resort Report | Jenni Kayne, Smooth Sailing
text: Jenni Kayne knows a thing or two about what to wear on a spectacular cruise during the winter months. Her presentation was held on her family’s personal yacht — upon which Kayne has traveled to far-flung places like Corsica and Tahiti. The clothes were simple and easy to mix and match, including Kayne’s signature leather shorts and T-shirts. The navy cotton cape will come in handy should it start to drizzle on deck.

headline: A Blogger Taps Out; Combatants Want In
text: In a city marked by constant change, some find that its transformations come too quickly, while others complain that the status quo is not upended — and slammed down against the boxing mat — fast enough.

headline: A History of Luxury
text: A new tome includes the history of the Goyard family and the object is nothing less than a bible of luxury.

headline: Picking the Best Cash-Back Credit Cards
text: In the market for a cash-back rewards card and wondering which one to get? Here’s some advice to help you decide.

headline: On Our Radar: Whaling Payoffs?
text: Assertions that cash in envelopes was exchanged for pro-whaling votes on the International Whaling Commission.

headline: Easy Dishes With Exotic Grains
text: Whenever I go to an ethnic grocery, I wind up buying items that are not on my shopping list. I can’t help myself. Sometimes I am intrigued by something I’ve never tried before, like the buckwheat flour and cornmeal polenta mixture I bought several months ago at an Italian deli. (I wasn’t crazy about the polenta I eventually made with it.) Other times an item will spark memories of a dish I’ve eaten in my travels or haven’t made in a while.

headline: Chickpea Flour Crêpes With Roasted Pepper, Tomato and Goat Cheese Filling
text: Chickpea flour crêpes make great wrappers for all sorts of fillings. This savory combination of tomato sauce with roasted pepper and goat cheese is easy to make with ingredients you can keep on hand in the refrigerator and pantry.

headline: Indian Semolina Pilaf
text: I know of some great polenta dishes, but they usually require a lot of butter and cheese. So to find a recipe for a bag of Italian semolina polenta that had been languishing in my pantry, I turned to the cuisines of Southern India. Upma is a favorite breakfast dish in Southern India, although you’re more likely to want it for dinner. This version is simplified; I made it with the ingredients I had on hand. Traditional ingredients in upma include curry leaves, cashews, hulled chickpeas (chana dal) and white split gram bean (urad dal). You can add other vegetables of your choice.

headline: Democrats Add to List of Campaign Challengers
text: In the midst of what looks to be a difficult election cycle, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee is adding 11 candidates to a program that mainly looks to capture Republican-held seats.

headline: Agency Sues City Over Foster Care Contract
text: A longtime New York City foster care provider is suing the city and its child welfare agency in an effort to halt the severing of its contracts, which would transfer the cases of about 1,400 foster children to other agencies.

headline: New President at National Trust for Historic Preservation
text: Stephanie Meeks, president and chief executive of the development organization Counterpart International, has been named the eighth president of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, the trust announced Monday.

headline: Indian Semolina Pilaf With Tomatoes
text: This version of upma, an Indian semolina pilaf, is inspired by a recipe in Julie Sahni’s wonderful book, “Classic Indian Vegetarian and Grain Cooking.”

headline: Bulgur and Cherry Pilaf
text: Cherries have arrived in Southern California, so I’m inspired to make a Turkish pilaf that I love. It is traditionally made with sour cherries and bulgur or rice, but I’ve also added dried cherries or cranberries (two other ingredients I found in my pantry) to the mix. Ground fennel contributes to the sweetness.

headline: Last Body Missing  in Ark. Flood Found
text: LANGLEY, Ark.  Crews searching dozens of square miles of riverbank and muddy, rugged vegetation in steamy heat and humidity on Monday found a 20th victim of the deadly flash floods that swept through a cherished family campground area early on Friday.

headline: Resort Report | Chris Benz, Dreaming of Pat Nixon
text: Chris Benz has an eBay obsession. That’s where he discovered the midcentury California sculptor Sascha Brastoff — the inspiration for his resort collection. Brastoff made beautiful tabletop pieces in pastel and metallic finishes, a palette befitting the modern day Pat Nixon whom Benz had in mind when designing his tweed jackets, cropped pantsuits and long, slinky dresses.

headline: F.B.I. Releases Files on Edward M. Kennedy
text: After two brothers fell to assassins’ bullets, Senator Edward M. Kennedy received repeated threats that he, too, would meet the same fate, according to thousands of pages of documents released Monday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

headline: BP Provides Plan to Speed Up Siphoning
text: Responding to a request by the Obama administration over the weekend that BP collect more oil sooner, the company on Monday announced a plan to siphon off 40,000 barrels to 53,000 barrels of oil a day from its leaking well by the end of June, up from the current 15,000 barrels a day.

headline: Readers React to News of Afghan Minerals
text: 1:12 p.m. | Updated The New York Times article reporting that Afghanistan lies atop nearly $1 trillion in untapped minerals has become one of the most commented nytimes.com pieces of the year, with more than 900 published comments and still counting. The discovery, which could make Afghanistan the “Saudi Arabia of lithium,” according to an internal Pentagon memo, aroused considerable suspicion from Times readers. For most who commented on the article, trust for American motives in the Middle East appears frayed by the Iraq war and mixed results in Afghanistan.

headline: Update: Apple Rethinks Its ‘Ulysses’ Ban
text: Score one for “Ulysses” – Apple has decided that it is not obscene after all.

headline: The Fight at Landry’s Gets Uglier
text: The management buyout of Landry’s Restaurants first earned the dubious honor of being a “deal from hell” well over a year ago.

headline: The Claim: Mosquitoes Are Attracted to Women More Than to Men
text: THE FACTS

headline: Some Fans Stranded After Netherlands-Denmark Game
text: JOHANNESBURG — According to radio reports here, hundreds of soccer fans were stranded at Soccer City after Bus Rapid Transit bus drivers started striking. Fans letting out of the Netherlands-Denmark game were being advised to take rail lines to get out of Soccer City. Rush hour is approaching here and traffic will snarl around the city.

headline: Do Kids Still Matter to Marriage?
text: One of the more surprising trends in marriage during the past 20 years is the fact that most couples no longer view children as essential to a happy relationship.

headline: Spirit Airlines Cancels Flights Through Wednesday
text: Spirit Airlines has announced on its Web site that it is canceling flights through Wednesday in the wake of a strike by its pilots late last week. Spirit is offering stranded travelers credit for the full amount of the unflown portion of the trip and a $100 credit. Though the carrier had pledged last week that service would continue in the event of a strike, Spirit started canceling flights on Saturday, disrupting plans for thousands of travelers, the Associated Press reported. Spirit, according to the A.P., operates 150 flights daily and is Fort Lauderdale’s sole carrier to 14 international and five domestic destinations. Whether the strike will be resolved soon remains unclear. Spirit and its pilots have been in talks for more than three years. The pilots had been seeking pay raises and the airline said it had offered to raise pay by 29 percent over five years.9:53 a.m. | Updated  An earlier version of this post inaccurately described the amount of compensation that Spirit is offering its stranded passengers.

headline: James N. Wood, President of Getty Trust, Dies
text: James N. Wood, who served as director of the Art Institute of Chicago for 25 years and took over as president and chief executive of the Getty Trust in Los Angeles in 2006, helping to steer the institution through a turbulent period in its history, died Friday at his home in the Brentwood neighborhood of Los Angeles, the trust announced. Mr. Wood was 69. A statement by the trust said that Mr. Wood had died unexpectedly, of natural causes, but that no exact cause of death was announced.

headline: Quote Unquote | Ready to Rumple
text: — British actor Bill Nighy advises readers of The Telegraph to never trust a man in a linen suit. Good thing he’s not in charge of the fashion police.

headline: Final Scenes From Bonnaroo
text: More Photographs

headline: Dutch Find Goals in Unusual Places, Including From the Opponent

headline: Media Decoder: A Second Edition for Shopping Channel
text: Not content with selling handbags and home décor on television 24 hours a day, HSN now wants to sell for 48 hours a day.

headline: Safety: Distracted Driving as a Medical Condition
text: Family doctors routinely ask their patients whether they smoke, watch their diet, remember to fasten their seat belt.

headline: William J. Mitchell, Vanguard of Urban Transportation and Planning, Dies at 65
text: William J. Mitchell, a noted theorist and planner on urban and transportation issues, died on June 11 after a long battle with cancer, according to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology’s news office. He was 65.

headline: Afghan Media Criticize Security Officials’ Resignations
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The recent resignations of Afghanistan’s interior minister and intelligence chief have been covered extensively in the Afghan papers.

headline: Ailing Levine Withdraws From Tanglewood
text: Health problems have taken yet another toll on the schedule of the conductor James Levine. He has pulled out of all appearances at the Tanglewood Music Festival this summer because he needs more time to recover from the back surgery he underwent in April, the Boston Symphony Orchestra, which runs the festival, announced on Monday. Mr. Levine was to have conducted six Boston Symphony Concerts and three by the Tanglewood Music Center orchestra, which is made up of young musicians. Michael Tilson Thomas, Christoph von Dohnanyi, Hans Graf and Johannes Debus, music director of the Canadian Opera Company, will substitute for Mr. Levine, the Boston Symphony said.

headline: Patterns: Uninsured More at Risk Even in Hospitals
text: Uninsured Americans often have difficulty getting care and paying for medications. But what happens once they are admitted to a hospital with a life-threatening illness?

headline: TimesCast | June 14, 2010
text: In today's Timescast, Obama presses BP for cleanup funds and reports on the crisis in Kyrgyzstan, child soldiers in Somalia and the resurgence of coca in Peru.

headline: Song of the Vuvuzela: Can You Stand It?
text: Just five days into the World Cup, and the No. 1 topic of conversation around the world isn’t about results or tactics, but rather the vuvuzela — the $2.50 plastic horn that, blown nonstop by the thousands, has provided a bleating soundtrack to every match at South Africa 2010.

headline: Europe’s New Wind Power Rivals Gas
text: The amount of power generated by new wind turbines in the European Union this year will be about the same as the amount from new gas plants, according to the European Wind Energy Association, an industry group.

headline: Cirque du Soleil’s ‘Banana Shpeel’ Will Split at Month’s End
text: There will be no more terrible banana-related puns around these quarters, and no more reminders of how a long-running rock ‘n’ roll tradition was pushed aside to make room for an ultimately ill-fated Cirque du Soleil show. On Monday the circus company from Montreal said “Banana Shpeel,” its current production at the Beacon Theater, would play its final performance there on June 27.

headline: Buffalo Developer Wants to Turn Albany Upside Down
text: ALBANY — Carl Paladino, the 63-year-old Buffalo developer and candidate for governor, has been an outspoken presence on the campaign trail — outspoken being an understatement for a man whose campaign slogan is “I’m mad as hell.”

headline: U.S. Keeper’s Ribs Bruised, Not Broken
text: JOHANNESBURG  Goalkeeper Tim Howard does not have broken ribs and is expected to be available to play Friday against Slovenia in the World Cup, the United States Soccer Federation said Monday.

headline: Vindication for the Buying Spree?
text: Private equity has been criticized for its seemingly profligate acquisition history during the boom times, paying huge premiums with billions of dollars in borrowed cash. But the industry may be vindicated as a number of its portfolio companies are getting ready to hit the market and appear likely to produce decent returns for their investors.

headline: Don’t Bother Following Me on Twitter
text: O.K., here’s my deal with Twitter. Personally, I have a hard time doing anything in 140 characters or less. Maybe it’s a difference of the sexes thing. Research tells us more men than women are on Twitter while the Facebook community (which offers free-flowing prose if you choose) is heavier in estrogen. No surprise there really. Men tend to be bottom-liners and women seem to enjoy talking about their experiences more.

headline: For News Corporation, Significant Online Investments
text: Reflecting Rupert Murdoch’s belief that consumers should pay for more content online, the News Corporation said Monday that it had acquired an e-reading platform called Skiff and had made an investment in a company that manages pay models for newspapers and magazines.

headline: Ireland, Ulster and the Flotilla Inquiry
text: As my colleague Isabel Kershner reports, “Israel’s cabinet on Monday unanimously approved a government-appointed commission with foreign participation to investigate the circumstances surrounding its deadly commando raid on a flotilla bound for Gaza in late May.”

headline: An Apartment Building Where Babies Reign
text: New York City apartment buildings are often a menagerie of types, including old-timers who remember precisely who lived in each apartment 25 years ago, midlifers preoccupied with their families, and residents so new that they still find the clanging radiators and groaning midcentury elevators charming.

headline: Alas, Afghanistan
text: While Marc Ambinder and Blake Hounshell, among others, wonder if the weekend’s big news about Afghanistan’s enormous lithium deposits is really all that new, I wonder how long it will take some inventive Afghani politician to come up with a lithium-appropriate equivalent to “the devil’s excrement,” which is how a farsighted Venezuelan oil minister described his country’s enormous — and eventually enormously destructive — petroleum resources 30 years ago. It’s possible, I suppose, that lithium could be a “game changer” that redounds to the benefit of Afghanis and their American occupiers alike, but the history of these kind of things suggests otherwise, and strongly. It’s very hard to imagine that a country as misgoverned as Afghanistan will be an exception to the rule that whom the gods destroy, they first make rich in natural resources.

headline: Bonnaroo: Stevie Wonder and Jay-Z
text: Stevie Wonder came to Bonnaroo prepared, though it’s impossible to say if it was by disposition or research. Jam-band fans? His second song was “Master Blaster,” about “jammin’ until the break of dawn”(something the Disco Biscuits were scheduled to do until 5:15 a.m. on Sunday).

headline: World Cup Replay: Day 4, June 14
text: A view of the tournament, with the Netherlands beating Denmark, 2-0, and Japan beating Cameroon, 1-0.

headline: Priorities: Children or Spouse?
text: Who is more important to you — your spouse or your children?

headline: Maybe They Should Call It ‘Greener Acres’
text: What do you get when you cross “Green Acres” with “Queer Eye for the Straight Guy,” then subtract Eddie Albert, Eva Gabor and most of the straight guys? A campaign for a new weekly television series seeks to provide a humorous answer to that quirky question.

headline: Waiting on Izzo
text: The Cleveland Cavaliers’ courtship of Michigan State Coach Tom Izzo drags on to another week.

headline: Dancing the Night Away With Microsoft’s Kinect
text: 3:36 p.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES— The one thing you have to admire about Microsoft is its tenacity.

headline: New Strike Threat at a Chinese Honda Parts Plant
text: ZHONGSHAN, China — Workers who returned to their jobs on Sunday and Monday at a Honda auto parts factory here in southern China were threatening to go back on strike this week if the company did not improve its offer of a wage increase.

headline: World Cup’s Incessant Drone Will Stay for Now
text: JOHANNESBURG  The loud trumpets called vuvuzelas will continue to be allowed for the time being at the World Cup, despite complaints from some international broadcasters, players and fans, the tournament’s organizing committee said Monday.

headline: Fair Warning | Design Miami/Basel: The Blog
text: This is the week the design world heads to Basel, Switzerland for Design Miami/Basel which opens to the public on Tuesday, a day ahead of Art Basel. But if you can’t go to the design fair, the design fair will come to you: This year marks the debut of its blog, the aptly-titled Design Miami/Basel Blog (http://designmiamibaselblog.com/). It will afford journalists and design fans access to breaking news, quotes, images, and updates from participants in the fair like designers and gallery owners, as well as the option to sign up for an RSS feed that sends alerts in real time — in case you can’t wait until your first cup of morning coffee in New York to find out which celebrities bought what before dashing off to lunch at Chez Donati.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Lars Bastholm, chief digital creative officer at Ogilvy & Mather North America, New York, part of the Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide division of WPP, is taking the added post of chief creative officer for the Ogilvy New York headquarters. The post had been filled on an interim basis by Steve Hayden, vice chairman at Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide. Also, Dan Burrier, chief creative officer at Ogilvy & Mather West, Los Angeles, becomes chief innovation officer for Ogilvy North America, a new post, and Lauren Crampsie, director for business development at Ogilvy North America, becomes chief marketing officer there, also a new post.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: Breaking Down United States vs. England
text: John O’Brien played professionally with Ajax Amsterdam and for the United States in the 2002 and 2006 World Cups.

headline: When the Man Is a Mosquito Magnet
text: Ever wonder why your dear husband complains so much more than you do about the mosquitoes in the backyard? It may be that he is indeed more appealing to these flying pests.

headline: I Want My @MTV: Cable Network Seeks Its First Twitter Jockey
text: If you can remember MTV 1.0 personalities like Mark Goodman, Martha Quinn, Nina Blackwood and J. J. Jackson, you may already be too old to contend for a new hybrid on-air and online position that the cable network is creating.

headline: Governor Rebuffs Clemency Board in Murder Case
text: WASHINGTON  Ronald Kempfert was a young boy in 1975 when his father was sent to prison for murder, and they had no contact for 28 years.

headline: Italy Salvages a Draw Against Paraguay in the Group F Opener
text: Italy and Paraguay scrapped to a 1-1 draw Monday night in a match subdued as much by the near-constant downpour in Cape Town as the knowledge that the next two games, for both squads, will be considerably easier than this one. Group F is the World Cup’s weakest division, and both teams will now try to gather the points necessary to advance from this stage in their upcoming matches against Slovakia and New Zealand.

headline: Tom Watson, Ever Young at 60, Prepares for Pebble Beach
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — How can Tom Watson be 60? He still looks much the way he did in 1982, boyishly romping around the 17th green at Pebble Beach, the cliffside par 3, after holing what is commonly regarded as one of the greatest shots in golf history: a 16-foot pitch from the left rough that landed softly and darted into the cup, securing his first and only United States Open championship and closing out his rival Jack Nicklaus.

headline: Fashion Report | Guinness Buys Blow Collection
text: Daphne Guinness, the art and fashion collector, has bought the entire Isabella Blow wardrobe, including seminal pieces by the late designer Alexander McQueen, which was to have been sold by Christie’s in the fall.

headline: Escaping Depression, From a Field of 5 Plays
text: Some prominent names turn up in Ensemble Studio Theater’s Series B group of one-acts, part of the company’s annual marathon of short plays, but it is a couple of lesser names that deserve the most attention: Rachel Bonds, whose lovely “Anniversary” concludes the program, and Julie Fitzpatrick, the actress who brings that play to life.

headline: Despite Flirtations, Texas Agrees to Stay in Big 12 and Save It
text: Left adrift amid the chaos of conference realignment, the Big 12 on Monday found an improbable savior. The combination of furious 11th-hour television negotiations by the Big 12 commissioner, Dan Beebe, and Texas’ demanding too much from the Pacific-10 have saved the league from oblivion.

headline: World Cup 2010 | Eye on the Eel, Eye on the Ball
text: It may not be wise to try this at home, rooting for one’s World Cup soccer team around a lot of sharp kitchen knives.

headline: The Beautiful Game: Teaching and Learning With the World Cup
text: The 2010 World Cup got underway on Friday, June 11. As soccer fans all over the world drop everything to root for their team, we present some ideas for teaching and learning about this global phenomenon.

headline: Lewis Hamilton Rides Momentum to Canadian Grand Prix Win
text: From our colleagues at Formula One blog:

headline: Etheridge, Caught on Video, Apologizes
text: Representative Bob Etheridge, Democrat of North Carolina, issued an apology on Monday for grabbing a young man by the hand, arm and neck – as a video camera rolled – as the man tried to ask him whether he supports President Obama’s agenda.

headline: More on 1970s Nostalgia
text: I’m obviously sympathetic to the main point of Peggy Orenstein’s column on the sexualization of pre-teens in this Sunday’s Times Magazine, but I think she’s fallen into the same nostalgia trap as Caitlin Flanagan:

headline: Bonnaroo: Stray Moments
