text: Some stray moments from Saturday and Sunday at Bonnaroo:

headline: For BP, Toll Likely to Extend Past Cleanup
text: On the face of it, BP can easily afford to pay the short-term costs of the oil well that is leaking millions of gallons into the Gulf of Mexico. Last year, the company earned $17 billion, and it ended the year with more than $8 billion in cash.

headline: Ethnic Uzbeks Flee Violence in Kyrgyzstan
text: Thousands of Uzbeks were reported to be flooding into Uzbekistan and thousands more  were massed at the border as they fled violence in the southern Kyrgyz cities of Osh and Jalalabad.

headline: Answers About Social Security: Part 5
text: “Ask an Expert” is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

headline: Re-Freshman
text: A mature student embarking on a second degree.

headline: Afghan Officials Elated by Minerals Report
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Government officials sounded headily optimistic Monday as they fielded questions from local and international reporters about a new report on the extent of Afghanistan’s mineral wealth that suggests considerable potential for products other than opium, which until now has been the country’s most lucrative export.

headline: Therapies for Cancer Bring Hope and Failure
text: CHICAGO  The experimental drug PLX4032, which reverses the effects of a mutation found in certain tumors, is considered a prime example of the “targeted” cancer therapies of the future. The drug  the subject of a three-part series in The New York Times in February  produced seemingly miraculous results in some patients with melanoma.

headline: A Church Rite Shrouded in Haiti’s Loss
text: When they filled the church a few days after the earthquake, they were still in shock, swathed in coats and hats, faces illuminated by orange candlelight in the darkness. Now, five months later, the women were in flowered dresses, little girls wearing white first-communion frocks and flowers in their hair, and the sanctuary  white-bright from the summery glare.

headline: Aiming at Rivals, Starbucks Will Offer Free Wi-Fi
text: Many coffee shops try to discourage people from buying a cup of coffee and then lingering for hours to use the free Internet access. Starbucks will soon encourage them to stay as long as they want.

headline: Artifacts | Broadcast Blues
text: Like many other people in the New York art world, I watched the Wednesday night premiere of Bravo’s “Work of Art: The Next Great Artist” with zero expectations of either art or greatness. I didn’t think the artificial conditions of a gladiatorial competition between untried talents could create a realistic or even a very entertaining picture of what it means to make art. In fact, I slept through some of it. If the contestants had been seasoned professionals and we got to watch them work under pressure, it might have been a juicier proposition – a clash of titans, or something like “Iron Chef.”

headline: Pipe Organ Returns to Alice Tully Hall
text: Skepticism stirred when Lincoln Center spirited the pipe organ out of Alice Tully Hall before the building’s renovation in 2006, promising its eventual return. The skepticism only grew when the renovated hall reopened in early 2009 with no sign of the organ.

headline: Israeli Policeman Killed in West Bank Shooting
text: JERUSALEM  An Israeli police officer was shot dead in the West Bank on Monday and two more were wounded in the first fatal shooting attack on Israeli security personnel in the area in more than a year.

headline: A Near-Zero Fed Funds Rate Until 2012?
text: Observers of the Federal Reserve have been speculating for months about when the central bank might start lifting the benchmark short-term interest rate from near-zero, where it has been since December 2008.

headline: Cause of Mystery Ills Splits Indonesian Fishing Village
text: BUYAT BAY BEACH, Indonesia - This is a simple village where the fishermen's families live on the sea in wooden shacks lighted by oil lamps and most everyone knows one another. But the people are divided by more than just the sandy track that passes for Main Street.

headline: Tangled Strands in Fight Over Peru Gold Mine
text: SAN CERILLO, Peru - The Rev. Marco Arana drove his beige pickup over the curves of a dirt road 13,000 feet high in the Andes. Spread out below lay the Yanacocha gold mine, an American-run operation of mammoth open pits and towering heaps of cyanide-laced ore. Ahead loomed the pristine green of untouched hills.

headline: Behind Gold's Glitter: Torn Lands and Pointed Questions
text: There has always been an element of madness to gold's allure.

headline: Lincoln Center Theater Announces Two LCT3 Projects
text: Thomas Kail, the Tony-nominated director of “In the Heights,” and Sam Gold, who directed Annie Baker’s plays “Circle Mirror Transformation” (for Playwrights Horizons) and “The Aliens” (for Rattlestick Theater), will direct the world premieres of new works by Nick Jones and Nathan Louis Jackson for the 2010-11 season of Lincoln Center Theater‘s LCT3 theater, the company said on Monday.

headline: Scotland: A New Study Presents a Grim Picture of the State of Health in Scotland
text: Scotland, home of the deep-fried Mars bar and caffeine-fired Buckfast Tonic Wine, has a huge number of people “living dangerously,” according to a national study released last week.

headline: More Signs of Support for Lincoln’s Derivatives Plan
text: 4:44 p.m. | Updated Senator Blanche Lincoln, Democrat of Arkansas, is expected to pick up support for her controversial derivatives restrictions from two more Federal Reserve bank presidents, a person close to the situation told DealBook.

headline: After Heatstroke, When Is It Safe to Exercise?
text: It was 90 degrees in Buffalo when Douglas Casa stood on the starting line of a track, ready to run 25 laps in a race that was part of the Empire Games, a championship event for high school students.

headline: Justices Ease Deportation Rule in Minor Drug Cases
text: WASHINGTON  Immigrants who are legally in the United States need not be automatically deported for minor drug offenses, the Supreme Court ruled Monday in a unanimous decision.

headline: Exchanges Bring Questions of Eligibility
text: For several months, the Prescriptions blog at nytimes.com/health has been fielding readers’ questions about how the new health care law will affect them. Here are three recent ones, starting with a popular subject: health insurance exchanges, the online marketplaces, to be available starting in 2014, where individuals and small businesses will be able to compare plans and buy coverage.

headline: Two Brothers Keep Connected as Volunteers at the U.S. Open
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. – The two men walking down the lonely road in the early-morning fog Monday looked as if they were either really lost or needed a ride. But it was clear moments after Carmen Battista and his brother Paul hopped in the backseat of a reporter’s car that they knew just where they were going.

headline: Life as a Widow or Widower
text: In today’s Science Times, the Personal Health columnist Jane Brody writes about the challenges of juggling yard work, finances and home repairs after the death of her husband Richard in March. She writes:

headline: Getting on With Life After a Partner Dies
text: Mickey Martinez was the kind of husband many women dream about. He loved grocery shopping and did it weekly at a nearby supermarket, took care of household repairs, washed dishes, and was always ready with a broom or vacuum when needed.

headline: Natural Winemaking Stirs Debate
text: THE world of wine is full of hornets’ nests. The minute you step on one, whether you nudge it accidentally or boot it with malice aforethought, the angry buzzing begins, rising to a high-pitched howl that would send anybody in search of shelter and a beer.

headline: Ranting About Shopping Before It’s Time
text: Hearing “Jingle Bells” piped through a retail store’s speakers at Halloween just doesn’t sound right. But to some, it’s even more frustrating to search for a plastic beach pail at a Wal-Mart in July — prime beach season —  only to find that only a few are left, and all of the summer item shelves have been cleared to make way for back-to-school pens and pencils for September.

headline: The Rich on Trial at a Private School
text: Seymour Herson is a sorry prospect. He lacks athletic, academic, social and grooming skills, relegating him to the third table in the cafeteria of a second-rate private school, where, solo, he strives “to drink as many chocolate milks as possible.” Seymour seems at peace with his station, even the regular beatings, his only worry being that one of the popular eighth graders has called him “Chunk-Style,” a sobriquet that, if repeated a couple more times, may stick.

headline: BP Hires Financial Advisers as Pressure Mounts
text: BP has hired several investment banks, including Goldman Sachs, the Blackstone Group and Credit Suisse, to advise on its options as it faces financial and political pressure over the Gulf of Mexico oil spill, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Monday.

headline: Agency Two Fifteen Gets One More Executive
text: Agency Two Fifteen in San Francisco has hired its first senior executive since its recent formation.

headline: Bonnaroo: The Dave Matthews Band and Some Final Thoughts
text: The Dave Matthews Band wound up Bonnaroo for the jam-band faithful, still head-bobbing and flinging glowsticks after four days.

headline: Supporting Older Americans
text: Ever wonder what the population of the United States will look like in four decades? Here you go:

headline: The Morning Skate: Was This the Best Season Ever?
text: The Blackhawks paraded the Stanley Cup around Wrigley Field on Sunday, before the White Sox-Cubs game, and got both teams to pose for a photo with them (and there’s more video from this event at the bottom of the post). This was after two million fans turned out for the Stanley Cup parade, and it demonstrates that those who dismiss hockey’s impact in the United States can be out of step.

headline: Barron Says He’s Running to Protest Cuomo
text: Councilman Charles Barron provided details Monday of his plans to begin a protest bid for governor, and blasted Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo and the Democratic Party for putting together an all-white statewide ticket.

headline: Trial of Newburgh Men Accused of Terror Plot Delayed
text: A federal judge on Monday indefinitely delayed the trial of four Newburgh, N.Y., men charged with trying to bomb Bronx synagogues and shoot down military planes, saying prosecutors had failed to turn over information that should have been given to the defense.

headline: Vain Glorious | Christophe Robin’s Shade Variation Care
text: Who: Christophe Robin, the French hair-color expert whose clients include les femmes du cinema (e.g. Binoche, Deneuve, Bourgoin, Sagnier) and whose address is not, as Sun-In users might guess, at the House at Pooh Corner, but in a discreetly appointed suite at Le Meurice.

headline: On Natural Wines
text: My column is about the seemingly emotional, threatening issue of natural wines. I use the term natural wines throughout the column, but it’s a measure of how nebulous the issue is to say that many people disagree on the use of that phrase. Some prefer other terms, like real wine, or natural winemaking.

headline: Departing President of United Autoworkers Tells Union to Fight On
text: DETROIT  Ron Gettelfinger, whose tumultuous eight-year tenure as president of the United Automobile Workers union ends this week, encouraged workers on Monday to keep fighting the “antiunion forces” that want to kill off the U.A.W.

headline: Bloomberg Scolds Reporters Again
text: On some days, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg can be quite charming and courteous with the press, congratulating reporters who have gotten married or given birth.

headline: Recovering From Heatstroke
text: Summer is the season when athletes are at high risk of heatstroke. Gina Kolata explores this hot weather hazard in her latest Personal Best column.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Kyrgyzstan and Elsewhere
text: Our show opens amid the grim violence of Kyrgyzstan in central Asia. Several days of chaos have started reshaping the ethnic landscape there, with more than 70,000 ethnic Uzbeks reported to be flooding into Uzbekistan and thousands more at the border (Slides 1, 2 and 3). For something considerably lighter, check out the waterfront image from Mumbai (Slide 10) or the picture of a soccer fan playing his vuvuzela at a World Cup game (Slide 11).

headline: The Cavalacanga Ate My Cellphone
text: At around 2 p.m. on Thursday, I arrived in Atins via slow boat from Barreirinhas. But my destination was still about 90 minutes away: the home and restaurant of Luzia Diniz Santos and family in Canto de Atins, a little settlement of 30-odd people on a strip of sandy prairie between the ocean and the dunes of Lençóis Maranhenses National Park in northeastern Brazil. Luzia’s grilled shrimp is famous, at least locally, and her place receives a steady stream of  lunchtime guests. Her four simple guest rooms (for 20 reais, about  $11, a night) are far less known. I  found out only from a fellow boat passenger heading home to Atins, and changed my lodging plans accordingly.

headline: Despite Killing, Mexican Backs Drug Policy
text: MEXICO CITY  Faced with a surge in drug-related killings in recent days, President Felipe Calderón on Monday offered a spirited defense of his government’s antidrug offensive.

headline: Obama Rallies His Base to Push Energy Shift
text: President Obama sent a letter to supporters Monday emphasizing the risks of the country’s dependence on fossil fuels and exalting the economic and environmental benefits of alternative energy sources.

headline: Obama’s Choices on Energy and Climate
text: June 15, 10:56 a.m. | Updated When President Obama addresses the nation from the Oval Office tonight after two days spent in the field examining the environmental calamity in the Gulf of Mexico, he will undoubtedly discuss broader energy challenges facing the nation, even though his prime focus is likely to remain restoring confidence in his administration’s handling of the immediate crisis.

headline: Legislation Won’t Close Gender Gap in Sciences
text: If the Senate passes legislation establishing regular “workshops to enhance gender equity” in academic science, what exactly would scientists and engineers do at them? The legislation, already approved by the House, is a little vague beyond directing researchers and heads of academic departments to participate in “activities that increase the awareness of the existence of gender bias.”

headline: Stupid Teenage Tricks, for a Virtual Audience
text: Is the Internet making teenagers do more dumb things than ever?

headline: A Poor Nation, With a Health Plan
text: MAYANGE, Rwanda  The maternity ward in the Mayange district health center is nothing fancy.

headline: A Case Against Transhumanism
text: As a supplement to Ashlee Vance’s entertaining survey of the Singularity enthusiasts from last Friday’s Times, I recommend Roger Scruton’s brief for human beings as they actually exist:

headline: Male Barbary Macaques With Infant
text: Two male Barbary macaques engaging in a so-called "triadic interaction" with an infant. The males lip-smack and teeth-chatter at each other and the infant, and nuzzle the infant.

headline: Tweets of Fictional Galvão Birds Echo Online
text: A colleague on our Graphics desk, Sergio Peçanha, points out that the vuvuzela is not the only thing generating a maddening din during World Cup matches in South Africa. Apparently, Brazilian soccer fans have been reaching for the mute button to block out the commentary of Galvão Bueno, the country’s best-known sports announcer.

headline: Weight-Lifting Gains Bring Pains, Too
text: More and more people are lifting weights these days — and sometimes dropping them where they shouldn’t.

headline: So Near, So Far
text: Would a daily workout for the eyes forestall the need for reading glasses?

headline: Inconvenient Truths | Jenny Holzer Takes On South Africa
text: Jenny Holzer’s “truisms” have appeared on billboards, posters and LED displays. This month, her provocative pronouncements are competing for chest real estate in World Cup-obsessed South Africa.

headline: Deglazing With Tomatoes
text: This deglazing with tomatoes thing, which I wrote about last week, has some legs.

headline: Glimmerglass Changes Name and Broadens Agenda
text: Francesca Zambello, the new general and artistic director of the Glimmerglass Opera in Cooperstown, N.Y., has put an immediate stamp on it, changing its name to the Glimmerglass Festival and adding musical theater as a regular feature. Starting next summer the festival will also include lectures, symposiums, cabarets and concerts for the public. Such activities have already been offered on a limited scale to donors, a spokeswoman said.

headline: Moody’s Cuts Greece Debt to Junk, Rattling Wall St.
text: Moody’s Investors Service cut Greece’s credit rating to junk on Wednesday, prompting Wall Street to give up its earlier gains, The New York Times’s Christine Hauser reports.

headline: Playing Virtual Tennis With Real Rackets
text: If you have ever played virtual tennis on a Nintendo Wii, you know the feeling of flailing your arms around in mid-air while trying to lob an invisible ball through space. You also most likely know that there is one important component missing from the game: the feeling of a real tennis racket.

headline: On Second Thought …
text: New York City Transit will change a set of subway signs that inadvertently resembled a vaguely profane Internet meme.

headline: Bathed in the Limelight, but Quietly Taking Leave
text: After the bouquets and flowers from his colleagues, the laughter and hugging and joking, Philip Neal stood alone on the stage, his final performance as a principal dancer with New York City Ballet over. His bearing was that of the danseur noble  upright, shoulders back, head high, one hand placed flat against his heart. As those in the audience rose to their feet, Mr. Neal slowly opened out his arms, his face grave, acknowledging the wave of love and appreciation that flowed over him as tangibly as the confetti that rained from above and the flowers that flew onto the stage.

headline: The Bubbles Bursting in Air
text: The most mysterious moment in a bubble’s life is when it pops and instantly loses its glorious form.

headline: A Short History of World Cup Goalkeeping Blunders
text: Robert Green’s “hand of clod” goal against the United States, painful as it was to watch (here it is again!) …

headline: Brooklyn Museum’s Populism Hasn’t Lured Crowds
text: When it opened a new glass entrance in 2004 meant to beckon the masses, the Brooklyn Museum said it hoped to triple attendance in 10 years by concentrating on a local audience. It had stopped worrying about competing with Manhattan museums or about its image  despite its world-class collections  as a poor man’s Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Just How British Is BP?
text: In a story in The Times on Sunday, our colleague Sheryl Gay Stolberg wrote of growing displeasure in Britain over the use of the name “British Petroleum” by top federal officials in the United States in referring to the party responsible for the gulf spill. The company officially changed its name to BP several years ago, and to some on the other side of the pond, invoking the old name is a backhanded slap at Britain and even a threat to the “special relationship” our two nations share.

headline: Early-Season African Wave Getting Better Organized
text: Back on June 9, an African easterly wave exited the western coast of Africa and has gradually gotten better organized as it trekked westward. It’s presently located near 10N 41W, or about 1400 miles east of the Windward Islands. It’s moving WNW at 12-13kts and that motion is expected to continue for the next several days. There is a 1010mb surface Low associated with the disturbance.

headline: In the Hunt for Planets, Who Owns the Data?
text: We are about to find out just how generous nature really is.

headline: Dry Rub and Wet Sidewalks
text: Last weekend, the eighth annual Big Apple Barbecue Block Party was held in and around Madison Square Park. Rain that fell for at least half of Sunday did not tame the flames. This year’s event included food from 18 of the country’s best pit masters, 5 of them from New York City. Barbecue lovers were able to get their hands dirty with food from as far away as Las Vegas and Driftwood, Tex.

headline: Kyrgyz Tensions Rooted in Class, Not Ethnicity, Experts Say
text: MOSCOW — The violence that has claimed scores of lives in Kyrgyzstan is frequently ascribed to ethnic tensions, but regional experts say the causes are more complex.

headline: Glimmerglass Changes Name and Broadens Agenda
text: Francesca Zambello, the new general and artistic director of the Glimmerglass Opera in Cooperstown, N.Y., has put an immediate stamp on the institution, changing its name to the Glimmerglass Festival and adding a regular piece of musical theater to the agenda. Starting next summer future festivals will also include lectures, symposiums, cabarets and concerts for the public. Such activities have already been offered on a limited scale to donors, a spokeswoman said. Ms. Zambello takes over on Sept. 1. Her first season, the summer of 2011, will include new productions of Bizet’s “Carmen” and Cherubini’s “Medea.” The festival will also present a double bill of new works: “A Blizzard in Marblehead Neck,” by the composer Jeanine Tesori and the playwright Tony Kushner and commissioned by Glimmerglass, and “Later the Same Evening,” by John Musto and Mark Campbell, based on five Edward Hopper paintings. The musical will be Irving Berlin’s “Annie Get Your Gun.” While Glimmerglass put on “Kiss Me, Kate” in 2008, musicals will now become a regular feature, to be performed with a full orchestra and without amplification.

headline: Little Orphan Annie Says Goodbye For Now
text: The lizards have ceased leaping. On Sunday, after an 86-year run as the pluckiest pupil-free young adventurer in the funny pages, Little Orphan Annie (above with her dog, Sandy) appeared in her last newspaper comic strip. In May, Tribune Media Services announced that it was ending the syndication of “Annie,” the comic strip chronicling that red-headed ragamuffin created by the cartoonist Harold Gray in 1924. But fans hoping for some narrative closure may have had better luck with the “Lost” finale. The last “Annie” comic concluded with its title character missing in Guatemala, and, according to a caption, Daddy Warbucks “resigning himself to Miss Annie’s being lost forever.” A final panel bore the legend, “And this is where we leave our Annie. For now  ” But Steve Tippie, vice president of marketing and licensing at Tribune Media Services, said, “Annie is not dying, she’s moving into new channels,” according to an interview with BBC News (which also looks at one of Annie’s earliest comic adventures). He said the character would continue to appear in graphic novels, games and in online and mobile projects.

headline: A Movable Feast of a Festival
text: The best way to fight a pervasive assumption is to pretend it doesn’t exist. The organizers of the first Undead Jazzfest, which ran Saturday and Sunday night at three clubs in the center of the West Village  Le Poisson Rouge, Sullivan Hall, and Kenny’s Castaways  are not necessarily hostile to the idea that jazz audiences like to sit and stay in one place and enjoy a set from beginning to end in silence and then go home. They’re just not interested in it.

headline: Preservation Trust Has a New President
text: Stephanie Meeks, president and chief executive of the development organization Counterpart International, has been named president of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, the trust announced Monday. Ms. Meeks, 45, who also spent 18 years at the Nature Conservancy, will succeed Richard Moe, who retired this month after 17 years. Ms. Meeks, who has been a member of the trust for many years, plans to begin in her new position in July. At the Nature Conservancy she held a number of positions including chief operating officer and, for nearly a year, acting president and chief executive. The trust, a nonprofit that supports the preservation of historic buildings and neighborhoods, issues an annual list of America’s 11 most endangered historic places.

headline: Awaiting the Genome Payoff
text: NORTH WALES, Pa.  At Merck’s “automated biotechnology facility” here, robot arms adapted from automobile factories deftly shuttle plates containing human cells.

headline: Levine Withdraws From Tanglewood
text: Health problems have taken yet another toll on the schedule of the conductor James Levine, right. He has pulled out of all appearances at the Tanglewood Music Festival this summer because he needs more time to recover from the back surgery he underwent in April, the Boston Symphony Orchestra, which runs the festival, said on Monday. Mr. Levine was to have conducted six Boston Symphony Concerts and three by the Tanglewood Music Center orchestra, which is made up of young musicians. Michael Tilson Thomas, Christoph von Dohnanyi, Hans Graf and Johannes Debus, music director of the Canadian Opera Company, will replace Mr. Levine, the Boston Symphony said. Mr. Levine has canceled many performances at the orchestra and at the Metropolitan Opera, where he is also music director, in recent years because of various ailments. They include a torn rotator cuff from a fall onstage in 2006, kidney surgery in 2008, surgery for a herniated disk last year and, most recently, lower-back surgery.

headline: Killer Art
text: Examples of viruses and bacteria rendered in blown glass from Luke Jerram’s “Infectious Beauty” exhibition.

headline: Cirque Du Soleil’s ‘Banana Shpeel’ to Close
text: There will be no more terrible banana-related puns around these quarters, and no more reminders of how a long-running rock ’n’ roll tradition was pushed aside to make room for an ultimately ill-fated Cirque du Soleil show. On Monday the circus company from Montreal said “Banana Shpeel,” its current production at the Beacon Theater, would play its final performance there on June 27. The show, a mix of broad vaudeville comedy, dance and acrobatics, was presented in Chicago last year, where it was flogged by critics. A Beacon Theater transfer was originally planned to start performances on Feb. 4 and run through June at least, bringing an end to the 20-year Beacon residency of the Allman Brothers Band. But the first preview date for “Banana Shpeel” was pushed back several times, to Feb. 25, then to March 17 and finally to April 29. It had its official opening on May 19. In a news release its producers said the show would begin a tour of North America in the fall.

headline: Are Killer Viruses, Rendered in Glass, Also Things of Beauty?
text: In a gallery in Manhattan’s meatpacking district, balanced delicately on mirrored surfaces and quivering slightly with each passing truck, is a lineup of history’s greatest killers: smallpox, influenza, H.I.V.

headline: Bombing in Kenya Recalls 2008 Election Violence
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  The hospital floors on Monday morning were littered with bloody bandages. Young men writhed in bed, their hands in mittens of gauze, their faces studies in pain. Scrums of Kenyan politicians cruised the corridors, flanked by the victims’ relatives, who spoke darkly of a political conspiracy.

headline: Time Is Short to See Tony Winners
text: If you want to see a 2010 Tony Award recipient onstage this summer, you are probably out of luck. Or you may have to shell out big money, depending on the newly crowned show or star you want to see.

headline: Merkel’s Coalition Under Pressure in Germany
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany faced calls from opposition leaders on Monday for new elections, as bickering and fighting within her governing coalition has led to growing speculation in the German news media that a collapse of her government could be imminent.

headline: Settlement Was Paid in Whitman Shoving Incident
text: SAN FRANCISCO  During her 10 years as chief executive of eBay, Meg Whitman, the Republican candidate for governor of California, was known as a demanding leader who did not hesitate to express displeasure with employees who failed to live up to her standards.

headline: Insects That Can’t Beat Them Scare Them
text: Imagine that you are a one-half-ounce, two-inch-tall insect-eating bird foraging for dinner on the dimly lighted floor of a Costa Rican rain forest. You come face to face with a pair of beady eyes. Study them for a moment.

headline: Eyes of a Snake?
text: Examples of caterpillars or chrysalises that display false eye and face patterns mimicking those of snakes, lizards or other animals.

headline: For Pioneer, Long Road Of Highs And Lows
text: ROCKVILLE, Md.  For the pharmaceutical industry, the genomics gold rush did not begin with the White House ceremony in June 2000. It started seven years earlier, in May 1993.

headline: One on One: Fred Wilson, Union Square Ventures
text: Fred Wilson, a New York City partner in the venture capital firm Union Square Ventures, struck gold in the late 1990s, when he helped in the multibillion-dollar sale of Geocities to Yahoo. Since then, Mr. Wilson’s firm has invested in a number of big-name Web brands including MeetUp, Twitter, Foursquare, Zynga, Outside.in and Etsy. Below is in an edited version of a one-on-one conversation with Mr. Wilson:

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Touch of Evil'
text: A. O. Scott looks back at Orson Welles's thriller set on the border between Mexico and the United States.

headline: Should People Be Paid to Stay Healthy?
text: Updated, June 15, 5:10 p.m. |  Gary Charness and Uri Gneezy, economists, explain when incentives work and when they don’t.

headline: For Armchair Travelers, the World, Intertwined
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Go to dance and see world culture. Midway through, the San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival has addressed the 100th anniversary of the Mexican Revolution, shamanism in Korea, the Indian goddess Parvathi, an initiation ceremony in the voodoo tradition, a bridal preparation in the Northern Philippines, and the Hawaiian deity Hi’iaka’s preparation for battles with dragons and demons. I refer to just the second of the festival’s four weekend programs: a glorious achievement.

headline: Styles of Judging: The Rhetoric and the Reality
text: The upcoming judiciary committee hearings on the nomination of Elena Kagan to be an associate justice of the Supreme Court will likely unfold under the shadow of Chief Justice John G. Roberts’ declaration (at his own hearing) that “judges are like umpires; umpires don’t make the rules, they apply them.” Kagan will probably be asked to pledge allegiance to this account of judging and repudiate its disreputable alternative — judges who make law, legislate from the bench and import their politics into precincts where they don’t belong.

headline: Paternal Bonds, Special and Strange
text: Not long ago, Julia Fischer of the German Primate Center in Göttingen was amused to witness two of her distinguished male colleagues preening about a topic very different from the standard academic peacock points  papers published, grants secured, competitors made to look foolish.

headline: Unfolding the Colorful Architecture of Butterflies
text: Scientists have known since the 1970s that complex structures make up butterfly scales and produce their vivid colors. Now a new study sheds light on just how those structures are formed in certain types of butterflies.

headline: Rabbi’s Biography Disturbs Followers
text: Dressed in a white straw hat, tan chinos and a blue shirt, Samuel Heilman, the co-author of a new book about Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson, stood at the rebbe’s grave site among scores of pilgrims — a vanguard of the thousands expected to visit on Tuesday, in the Jewish calendar the 16th anniversary of his death — who arrived at a Queens cemetery a few days early to commune with their beloved leader.

headline: In Hunt for Food, Sharks Have a Sense of Timing
text: Sharks are scent hunters, using their noses to steer them toward unsuspecting prey.

headline: The Fresh Tutu Brigade
text: If there is a heaven for people in the costume industry, it surely includes an infinite walk-in closet: one-stop shopping no matter the fabric, historical period or one-of-a-kind button needed.

headline: Feds Approve Trading of Box-Office Futures
text: Federal regulators on Monday approved a plan by Media Derivatives Inc. to begin trading futures contracts based on box-office revenue, though the film industry has continued to lobby Congress to ban such film-related trading.

headline: A Mass Revived, With Something Extra
text: Heitor Villa-Lobos was a remarkably prolific composer, but in the United States he is known mainly for his guitar music, his “Bachianas Brasileiras”  a set of Brazilian-flavored glosses on Bach  and a handful of colorful orchestral scores. Occasionally, an ensemble digs more deeply into his catalog and helps fill out the picture, as the women’s chamber choir Amuse did on Sunday afternoon when it revived Villa-Lobos’s appealing “Missa São Sebastião,” the centerpiece of its program at St. Ignatius of Antioch Episcopal Church on the Upper West Side.

headline: Microsoft’s Game Controller Killer Has a Name
text: Microsoft’s Hype Advisory System reached the red, severe level on Monday. The company announced new video gaming products in a press release under a headline: “Xbox 360 Transforms the Way Everyone Has Fun.”

headline: Tom Graves Is Newest Member of House
text: Tom Graves, Republican of Georgia, was sworn in Monday as the newest member of the House after winning a special election last week to fill the vacancy created when Nathan Deal left to run for governor.

headline: James N. Wood, President of the Getty Trust, Dies at 69
text: James N. Wood, who was the director of the Art Institute of Chicago for 25 years and took over as president and chief executive of the Getty Trust in Los Angeles in 2006, helping to steer it through a turbulent period, died Friday at his home in the Brentwood neighborhood of Los Angeles. He was 69 and also had a home in Bristol, R.I.

headline: What We’re Reading: Vuvuzela Apps
text: He’re what the tech editors and reporters have been reading Monday:

headline: A Mission to Mars? (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: From Hotel Rivals to Allies
text: Amid signs that their industry has finally turned a corner after two dark years, hotel executives have begun to plot strategies for better times ahead. But those strategies differ, depending on whether they are running a big chain or independent hotel.

headline: Science and Equality (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Summer Invasion of the Body Scanners
text: AT 6 a.m., Tucson International Airport was already busy in these initial days of the summer crush. Buying a newspaper at the gift shop, I heard loud cackling from the floor. A furry toy dog was tumbling around by my feet, laughing manically.

headline: For Decades, Watching China Grow
text: I’VE been flying for business for the last 30 years or so. A lot of my trips are international, mostly to Asia.

headline: Brazil Prepares for Match With North Korea
text: JOHANNESBURG  Soccer in Brazil resembles figure skating in that artistry is no less important than performance.

headline: A Q.&A. With Fred Wilson, Union Square Ventures
text: From Nick Bilton at Bits:

headline: Charter Schools in New York City
text: A comparison of charter schools and public schools.

headline: Halladay vs. Sabathia: Now It Counts
text: In a summit of aces, C.C. Sabathia and Roy Halladay will face each other Tuesday night at Yankee Stadium. It will be their third career matchup – each pitcher is 1-1 – and the first since 2008, according to the Elias Sports Bureau. But this particular meeting was foreshadowed back on March 4, in Clearwater, Fla., where Halladay made his Phillies debut opposite Sabathia.

headline: Glucosamine and Chondroitin, Drinks to Unlimber With
text: WHILE tablets that combine glucosamine and chondroitin are popular for those seeking relief from arthritis, Elations offers the supplements in the form of a bottled eight-ounce juice drink or powder mix, and it turns out the beverage appeals to consumers who have trouble swallowing not just pills  but also the fact of aging.

headline: City Budget May Cut Short Cries for Help
text: Groups that depend on government assistance can usually muster plenty of troops to fight budget reductions. Students rallied against a threat to their free subway and bus rides. Library workers held a read-in to protest branch closings. There have been demonstrations against cuts to schools, health clinics, day care centers and programs for the elderly.

headline: Some Euro Countries Find Ample, Low-Cost Credit
text: PARIS  While the Greek crisis has unnerved credit markets and required some European countries to pay the highest interest in a decade to sell bonds, France has been getting some of its best terms ever.

headline: The 2011 VW Jetta: For $16,000, an Entry-Level Choice
text: There are 13 Volkswagen models, which means plenty of opportunities for “punch buggy” slug fests. Car spotters will have to be on the lookout, because the Jetta is about to change its plumage — a brand-new and more affordable 2011 model is making its world debut Tuesday in Times Square in Manhattan.

headline: Murdoch Said to Seek Full Control of BSkyB
text: Rupert Murdoch appears to be on the prowl again, with British Sky Broadcasting as his target.

headline: The Unemployed Held Hostage
text: Since June 1, when federal unemployment benefits began to expire, an estimated 325,000 jobless workers have been cut off. That number will swell to 1.25 million by the end of the month unless Congress extends the benefits. The Senate, so far, has failed to act.

headline: New York Charter Schools Lag in Enrolling Hispanics
text: When charter schools began opening in New York a decade ago, they were hailed as a better opportunity for children in poor neighborhoods, where failing schools had been the norm. But while charter schools are open to all, they have catered to one demographic group far less than another.

headline: A Good Day for Judicial Discretion
text: Equity is an elusive legal concept that occasionally allows some leeway in applying the rules of the law and is often unappreciated by judges who insist the law means only what it says. That was clear in 2008 when the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit refused to allow federal courts to consider a death-penalty conviction of Albert Holland because his lawyer had inexcusably let the filing deadline pass. Fortunately, seven members of the Supreme Court proved less rigid in their thinking on Monday and reversed that blinkered decision.

headline: The Dictator and the Unesco Prize
text: Giving $3 million annually in prize money for scientific achievement is an excellent idea. It is irredeemably tarnished when the benefactor is a corrupt and repressive dictator.

headline: Haiti 1, Italy 0
text: Tuesday is the anniversary of what may be the greatest day in the history of Haitian sports. On June 15, 1974, at the World Cup in Munich, in the 46th minute of the first game of its first appearance in the World Cup, Haiti scored a goal against Italy.

headline: After Many Leaders, Japan Still Hopes for Recovery
text: TOKYO  Just a week into office, Japan’s new prime minister, Naoto Kan, has already broken with politics as usual here by making unusually frank warnings about the nation’s growing social inequalities, unsustainable national debt and need for painful tax increases.

headline: Ethics Panel Looks at Votes of 8 Congressmen
text: WASHINGTON  A Congressional ethics watchdog body is investigating whether as many as eight House members may have improperly shifted their positions on a bill to overhaul financial regulations in return for campaign contributions.

headline: Giving In on Trading, Bankers Turn to Other Losses
text: WASHINGTON  Bankers have all but given up on defeating one of the most contentious provisions in the financial regulation bill  one that would effectively bar federally insured banks from trading for their own accounts  and are now focusing on battles like heading off a prohibition on derivatives trading.

headline: The President and the Oil Spill
text: To the Editor:

headline: Talk of Fairway Cafe Closing Prompts Patrons to Mobilize
text: The Trader Joe’s planned for the Upper West Side of Manhattan does not even have an official opening date, but it may already be claiming a casualty: The chief executive at the nearby Fairway market said the company was leaning toward shuttering Fairway’s second-floor cafe to make room for more groceries and ease congestion on the ground floor.

headline: Child Preventive Services
text: To the Editor:

headline: Chef’s Choice Is Rooting for Italy, Family Style
text: Italy’s defense of the World Cup began on Monday with the normal mix of ansia and agità. Nobody would have it any other way.

headline: Afghan Security Protector
text: To the Editor:

headline: Piling Up Hits, Cano Is as Good Erasing Them
text: In the seventh inning last Wednesday in Baltimore, Robinson Cano dived to his left to smother a ground ball that was headed toward right field. The play prevented the tying run from scoring, but that was not the only reason why Mick Kelleher, the Yankees’ infield coach, was beaming in the dugout.

headline: Rivers’s Place in Celtics Lore Is One Victory Away
text: BOSTON  In the basketball sanctuary known as Boston’s new Garden, history does not need to be sought out. It hangs from the rafters and wafts from the parquet. But Doc Rivers went looking anyway.

headline: Credit Ratings Agencies
text: To the Editor:

headline: G.O.P. Consultant Accused of Stealing Campaign Money
text: A top Republican political consultant was accused on Monday of stealing $1.1 million from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg during the campaign last year and using part of the money to buy a house.

headline: Trading in Film Futures Contracts Approved
text: LOS ANGELES  Federal regulators on Monday approved a plan by Media Derivatives Inc. to begin trading futures contracts based on box-office revenue, though the film industry has continued to lobby Congress to ban such film-related trading.

headline: Resolution of Key Issues on Financial Regulation
text: Five critical differences between House and Senate versions of financial legislation that need to be dealt with by the conference committee.

headline: Obama Will Take to Oval Office With a Familiar Theme
text: WASHINGTON  The venue says it all. By choosing to speak to the nation on Tuesday night for the first time from the Oval Office, where his predecessors have spoken of wars and disasters, President Obama is conveying the gravity of the spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: As Mess Is Sent to Landfills, Officials Worry About Safety
text: PORT FOURCHON, La.  Cleanup crews here wear a common uniform of straw hat, white rubber boots and a sheen of sweat as they collect the bedraggled and oil-soaked pompoms that are strung along Fourchon Beach.

headline: Setbacks Cloud U.S. Plans to Get Out of Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON  Six months after President Obama decided to send more forces to Afghanistan, the halting progress in the war has crystallized longstanding tensions within the government over the viability of his plan to turn around the country and begin pulling out by July 2011.

headline: A Program Is Suspended After Positive Drug Tests
text: OTTAWA  A leading Canadian university suspended its football program on Monday after a special investigation resulted in antidoping violations by nine players.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Iran’s Revolution: Year 2
text: Washington

headline: A Benefit of Being an Unmarried Politician: No Adultery Scandals
text: While the rest of the country is trying to decide whether this is the Year of the Woman, or just the Year of Conservatives Who Happen to be Women, New York can turn its attention to contemplating the possibility of its own cultural milestone: the Year of the Boyfriend.

headline: Efforts to Repel Oil Spill Are Described as Chaotic
text: GRAND ISLE, La.  Deano Bonano, the emergency preparedness director for Jefferson Parish, marched from a motor home being used as a command center to an office across the street filled with BP officials.

headline: One Crowd Still Loyal to Goldman Sachs
text: Lots of people are talking about what is happening at Goldman Sachs. This is a column about what is not happening at Goldman.

headline: Twitter Will Add Places to Its Posts
text: Twitter posts already answer who, what and when. Now they will also tell people exactly where a post was written.

headline: Unfazed by Reality
text: Imagine that you’ve got the gas pedal to the floor (or almost to the floor) as you try to get your vehicle to the top of a mountain, where the road will level off. You’ve made real progress, but the vehicle is straining and wheezing. You’re not there yet.

headline: Bloggingheads: Gay Rights vs. Religion
text: Sarah Posner of Religion Dispatches and Mollie Ziegler Hemingway of Christianity Today debate whether same-sex marriage infringes on religious freedom.

headline: No Matter Who Gets Blame, Own Goal Hurts Danes
text: JOHANNESBURG — Denmark conceded the first own goal of the 2010 World Cup in the 46th minute against the Netherlands on Monday, an embarrassing gaffe that helped cost the Danes a game they had done well to contain. The Netherlands won, 2-0.

headline: Venezuela’s Military Ties With Cuba Stir Concerns
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  The ties between President Hugo Chávez and Cuba’s Communist leaders are plain enough: Cuba has thousands of doctors here, not to mention a smaller number of advisers who help on a breadth of issues, like agricultural engineering and even training Olympic athletes.

headline: Another Emergency Bill Averts Albany Shutdown
text: ALBANY  State lawmakers narrowly approved the latest in a series of emergency budget bills on Monday night, temporarily averting a government shutdown that officials said would be catastrophic for New Yorkers.

headline: Mayor Scolds Reporters Over Unwanted Queries
text: On some days, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg can be quite charming and courteous with the press, congratulating reporters who have gotten married or given birth.

headline: Like a Scout Out in the Bleachers, Baseball Seeks the Next Sure Thing
text: There are fair-weather fans, loyal fans and down-right fanatics. And then there are die-hards who are willing to spend nearly $4,000 to be buried in a casket emblazoned with the logo of their favorite baseball team.

headline: South Korea vs. North in a Soccer Dispute
text: SEOUL  As if they did not have enough things to disagree about, North Korea and South Korea have found one more: World Cup soccer.

headline: Italy Starts Slowly but Salvages Tie in Opener
text: CAPE TOWN  This is a World Cup of abrupt transitions. It is not just about going from high altitude to sea level. In the afternoon, you can be in Durban, wearing shorts and flip-flops and squinting as the sun glints off the surf. In the evening, you can be walking to Green Point Stadium in Cape Town in a winter jacket and gloves and seeking cover from a mix of hail and heavy rain.

headline: News Corp. Prepares for Paid Online Content
text: The News Corporation took several significant steps on Monday toward preparing to charge readers for access to its content online.

headline: Fed Study Suggests Rates Will Stay at Record Lows Until ’12
text: WASHINGTON  Given high unemployment and low inflation, the Federal Reserve is likely to wait until 2012 before it starts to raise interest rates, a new Fed research paper states.

headline: Pub Deliveries
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Back in March we ran a never-before-published poem by Sally Bliumis-Dunn called “Crossword.” She’s back with another original ode to our favorite pastime, which we’ll get to, but first today’s puzzle, a debut by Jill Winslow of Dallas, Texas.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,093 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: The Larger Struggle
text: These days we are transfixed by the struggle between BP and the U.S. government. This is a familiar conflict  between a multinational company trying to make a profit and the government trying to regulate the company and hold it accountable.

headline: Equatorial Guinea: U.S. Call to Suspend Controversial Unesco Award
text: The American ambassador to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, Unesco, sent a letter on Monday urging the organization’s director general to suspend plans to award a controversial prize endowed by and named for President Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo of Equatorial Guinea. Mr. Obiang, left, has been accused by rights groups and anticorruption activists of embezzling hundreds of millions of dollars from his oil-rich West African state, while most of its people scrape by in dire poverty. Ambassador David T. Killion said that a suspension would give time “for quiet consultations among member states to find a way forward,” consistent with Unesco’s “basic values.” Desmond Tutu, the retired Anglican archbishop and Nobel Peace Prize winner from South Africa, released a statement on Monday criticizing the prize and urging Unesco to reconsider it.

headline: South Africa: Court Date in Death of Mandela Relative
text: Sizwe Mankazana, the driver in a one-car accident that killed Nelson Mandela’s great-granddaughter on Friday, will not appear in court until July 26, two weeks after the end of the World Cup, authorities said Monday. Mr. Mankazana, 23, was arrested after the accident on possible charges of drunken driving and culpable homicide. His father is in a relationship with Zenani Mandela-Dlamini, a daughter of Mr. Mandela and a great-aunt of the dead girl, Zenani Mandela, 13. “Sizwe is part of the Mandela family,” said a statement from the Nelson Mandela Foundation. Normally, a person arrested for drunken driving makes a court appearance within 24 hours, but the police say they are still investigating the case.

headline: More Employers to Require Some College, Report Says
text: The number of jobs requiring at least a two-year associate’s degree will outpace the number of people qualified to fill those positions by at least three million in 2018, according to a report scheduled to be released Tuesday by the Center on Education and the Workforce at Georgetown University.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Friday with an article about the Tony Awards misidentified the actor shown with Montego Glover in a scene from “Memphis,” which won for best musical on Sunday night. He is J. Bernard Calloway  not James Monroe Iglehart, a star of the show.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Sarkozy Criticized in Selling of Paper
text: PARIS — A group of shareholders in the French newspaper Le Monde has denounced President Nicolas Sarkozy for interfering in the process of selling the struggling publication.

headline: State Backing Films Says Cannibal Is Deal-Breaker
text: LOS ANGELES  When Andrew van den Houten got a letter two weeks ago rejecting his request for Michigan public money to help finance his latest horror movie, “The Woman,” it came with an admonition about the state’s good name.

headline: To Rival Wii, Microsoft Unveils a Motion-Control Game System
text: LOS ANGELES  Looking to outdo Nintendo and its popular Wii, Microsoft on Monday officially introduced Kinect, its camera-based, motion-control game system. The company also announced that it had redesigned its Xbox 360 game console, making it smaller and quieter, and adding a built-in hard drive and Wi-Fi.

headline: An ESPN Channel to Stream Through Xbox 360 Console
text: In another content deal for a video game console, ESPN said Monday that it would stream thousands of sporting events to owners of Microsoft Xbox 360 consoles this year.

headline: Mets Left-Hander Leans on His Right-Hand Man
text: The baseball statistic often used to gauge a catcher’s effectiveness with regard to pitching is known as catcher’s earned run average. It measures the E.R.A. of a team’s pitchers when a particular catcher is behind the plate.

headline: Documents Show Risky Decisions Before BP Blowout
text: Internal BP documents, including an e-mail message calling the well drilled by the Deepwater Horizon a “nightmare,” show a pattern of risky choices made to save time and money in the weeks before the disastrous April 20 blowout, according to a letter sent to the oil company by the leaders of a House committee on Monday.

headline: Developer of Novel Reactor Wins $35 Million Infusion
text: A start-up company with a design for a nuclear reactor that extracts far more energy from uranium than do conventional ones has attracted a $35 million investment from venture capital firms.

headline: Nets Owner and Newark Mayor Throw Plenty of Bricks
text: The smiles and backslaps came to an uneasy halt after someone threw a basketball onto the court at the Prudential Center on Monday afternoon. For most of an hour, Jeff Vanderbeek, the chairman of the arena and the New Jersey Devils, the building’s main tenant, had been giving an animated tour of the building to Mikhail D. Prokhorov, the new owner of the Nets, who will play their next two seasons there before moving to Brooklyn.

headline: Newsweek Rises From the Dead
text: Programmers for Newsweek’s Web site, Newsweek.com, have apparently placed a hidden joke on the magazine’s home page for readers who enter a special keyboard combination, triggering a page of headlines purporting to provide coverage of an uprising by the undead.

headline: As Aide, Kagan Battled Colleague Over Policy
text: WASHINGTON  Elena Kagan was not responding to messages, so Christopher Edley Jr. fired off an exasperated e-mail message to higher-ranking White House officials. He had just learned that Ms. Kagan’s office was preparing a policy for President Bill Clinton to discourage “social promotion” in schools.

headline: Plea to Buy Is Hard Sell in Germany
text: FRANKFURT  Germany’s trading partners want the country to go on a shopping spree, increase imports and help countries like Greece and Spain grow faster so they can pay off their debts. But a look at recent history suggests that it might be a bad idea to rely on German consumers for a European recovery.

headline: Turning to the Property Toll After the Flood
text: As search crews on Monday found the 20th victim of the flash floods that ripped through a remote Arkansas camping area last week, local residents and officials began turning their attention to the financial effect of the disaster.

headline: Seeing Threat to Individual Policies, State Officials Urge a Gradual Route to Change
text: WASHINGTON  State insurance officials say they fear that health insurance companies will cancel policies and leave the individual insurance market in some states because of a provision of the new health care law that requires insurers to spend more of each premium dollar for the benefit of consumers.

headline: Jimmy Dean, Folksy Singer, Dies at 81
text: Jimmy Dean, a country singer and television-show host whose good looks, folksy integrity and aw-shucks Texas charm served him especially well when he went into the sausage business and became his own pitchman, died Sunday at his home in Varina, Va., outside Richmond. He was 81.

headline: Tuesday’s Matchups: New Zealand vs. Slovakia, Ivory Coast vs. Portugal and Brazil vs. North Korea
text: New Zealand vs. Slovakia

headline: BP Is Likely to Lose on Escrow Fund
text: The big risk with setting money aside upfront is that BP shareholders’ money ends up covering spurious claims.

headline: Families in 9/11 Financing Case Ask to Have Judge Replaced
text: Lawyers for families of 9/11 victims have taken the unusual legal step of asking a federal appeals court in Manhattan to replace a judge overseeing a group of terrorism-financing lawsuits, saying he is moving too slowly in resolving key motions.

headline: Egon Ronay,  Publisher of Food Guides, Dies at 94
text: Egon Ronay, whose restaurant and hotel guides, first published in the late 1950s, alerted austerity-pinched Britons to the possibilities of fine dining and helped pave the way for Britain’s current culinary renaissance, died Saturday at his home in Yattendon, Berkshire. He was 94.

headline: Employers Increasingly Expect Some Education After High School
text: The number of jobs requiring at least a two-year associate’s degree will outpace the number of people qualified to fill those positions by at least three million in 2018, according to a report being released Tuesday by the Georgetown University Center on Education and the Workforce.

headline: Untold Suffering: Opium in Afghanistan
text: “I walk through a low entrance, stepping over a large puddle while crouching to avoid the wooden beam of a door frame,” A. K. Kimoto wrote. “It’s dark. As my eyes adjust, I see a figure sitting in a corner as gentle wisps of smoke slowly dance across the room. … I’ve come to these remote settlements in Badakhshan, Afghanistan, to find out why so many of the inhabitants have become addicted to opium.”

headline: F.B.I. Opens Kennedy File
text: Most of the death threats made against Senator Edward M. Kennedy warned of shootings, but one claimed that a crossbow would be used. For years after two of his brothers were slain by assassins, Mr. Kennedy received repeated warnings that he would meet the same fate, according to thousands of pages of documents about Mr. Kennedy that were released Monday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

headline: Word of the Day | deface
text: deface •\di-ˈfas, de-\• verb

headline: Day 55: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: President Visits the Gulf Coast

headline: Virgin Group Takes Chance on Game Site
text: LOS ANGELES  If you want to gamble using the Internet, legally that is, you will have to find an offshore site. But if you want to wager on the Web that you can win a video game, you can stay put.

headline: Trading in Film Futures Contracts Approved
text: Federal regulators on Monday approved a plan by Media Derivatives Inc. to begin trading futures contracts based on box-office revenue, though the film industry has continued to lobby Congress to ban such film-related trading, Michael Cieply reports in The New York Times.

headline: Another Book on the Way From Ellen Degeneres
text: The book publishing industry may be in a slump, but not when it comes to celebrity authors. The comedian and talk show host Ellen DeGeneres has signed a deal with Grand Central Publishing, part of the Hachette Book Group, to write her third book, “a look at her life through her humor,” the publisher said on Sunday. The book is scheduled for publication in the fall. “I found that between my talk show, ‘American Idol’ and my late-night blogging, I didn’t have enough ways to express myself,” Ms. DeGeneres said in a statement. Her first two books were best sellers.

headline: 2 in Custody at Florida Air Force Base
text: A man and a woman were taken into custody Monday evening after they tried to gain unauthorized access to MacDill Air Force Base outside Tampa, Fla., and weapons were found in their vehicle, military officials said.

headline: BP’s ‘Nightmare Well’ is Now Everybody’s
text: I encourage you to read “Documents Detail Risky Decisions Before BP Well Blowout,” by Henry Fountain of The Times. If you have time, you can dive into the related company documents, collated by the House Committee on Energy and Commerce, which will be questioning Tony Hayward, the appropriately embattled chief executive of BP, on Thursday. [11:09 a.m. | Updated  The link above to documents at the House committee Web site appears to be down for the moment.]

headline: Reactor Developer Wins $35 Million Infusion
text: A start-up company with a design for a nuclear reactor that extracts far more energy from uranium than do conventional ones has attracted a $35 million investment from venture capital firms, Matthew Wald reports in The New York Times.

headline: Andreessen Horowitz Hires a Female Partner
text: 1:50 p.m. | Updated  Added information about partners at Andreessen Horowitz and Google Ventures.

headline: North Korea, the Darlings of 1966
text: Tuesday’s Brazil-North Korea match may shape up as a one-sided affair, the world’s most beloved soccer nation clobbering the soccer nation most shrouded in mystery. But before you make any assumptions about Tuesday’s outcome, consider this: In 1966 North Korea beat Italy, eliminating them from that year’s World Cup tournament.

headline: Schapiro Says S.E.C. Must Grow to Meet Demand
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission needs to continue to grow to meet demand for more regulation on things like ratings agencies, derivatives, and swaps, the chairwoman,  Mary L.  Schapiro, said on Monday, Reuters reported.

headline: Fed Study Suggests Rates Low Until ’12
text: Given high unemployment and low inflation, the Federal Reserve will probably  wait until 2012 before it starts to raise interest rates, a new Fed research paper states, Sewell Chan writes in The New York Times.

headline: News Quiz | June 15, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Ceding on Trading, Bankers Turn to Other Fronts
text: Bankers have all but given up on defeating one of the most contentious provisions in the financial regulation bill — one that would effectively bar federally insured banks from trading for their own accounts — and are now focusing on battles like heading off a prohibition on derivatives trading, Edward Wyatt reports in The New York Times.

headline: One Crowd Is Still Loyal to Goldman Sachs
text: Despite all the bad headlines — the accusations of fraud, the talk of a big settlement, the risk, however remote, of criminal charges — there’s an inconvenient truth that’s been largely ignored: Most of Goldman Sachs‘s big customers are not bolting, The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

headline: Sarkozy Criticized in Selling of Paper
text: A group of shareholders in the French newspaper Le Monde has denounced President Nicolas Sarkozy for interfering in the process of selling the struggling publication, Eric Pfanner reports in The New York Times.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Skenningly
text: Today’s word, in association with the informative Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: CBOE Shares Jump 12 Percent in Market Debut
text: Shares of CBOE Holdings jumped 12 percent in their market debut as investors flocked to the last major North American financial exchange to go public and a potential takeover target, Reuters reported.

headline: Striking It Rich
text: WHAT has the United States discovered in Afghanistan that is worth nearly $1 trillion?WHAT is lithium used for?WHAT is Afghanistan’s “existing war-bedraggled economy” based on?

headline: Evidence of Plans for Kyrgyz Violence
text: JALALABAD, Kyrgyzstan  Violence ebbed on Tuesday and people began emerging from their barricaded homes in Kyrgyzstan’s ethnically torn south, as evidence mounted that days of brutal bloodletting had been deliberately organized to ignite long-running tensions between Kyrgyz and Uzbeks.

headline: BSkyB Rejects News Corp.’s  $11.5 Billion Approach
text: The News Corporation said Tuesday that it had approached British Sky Broadcasting, the satellite television company, about a possible bid of $11.5 billion for all the shares in the company that it does not already own.

headline: News Corp. Buys Skiff as It Preps for Paid Content
text: The News Corporation‘s $11.5 billion offer to buy the rest of BSkyB isn’t the only deal the media company has been eyeing this week.

headline: Just How British Is BP?
text: From John Collins Rudolph at Green:

headline: Newsweek Rises From the Dead
text: In an apparent effort to lift spirits at Newsweek, which has been put on the block by the Washington Post Company, the staff recruited some zombies.

headline: Ex-Hevesi Aide Led Fraud Scheme, Cuomo Says
text: New York’s attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, accused an indicted top aide to Alan G. Hevesi, the former state comptroller,  of running a $35 million fraud over the placement of billions of dollars of investments by the state’s biggest pension fund, Reuters reported.

headline: What Merit Badge Would You Create?
text: The Web sites Nerd Merit Badges and Science Scouts offer Scouting-esque badges that recognize various skills and accomplishments, like spelling homonyms and building robots. What badge-worthy skills do you have or want to attain?

headline: Fremont, Former Subprime Lender, Emerges From Bankruptcy
text: Fremont General, once one of the nation’s largest subprime lenders, emerged from bankruptcy after a California judge approved a reorganization plan by private investment firm Signature Group, The Associated Press reported.

headline: House Democrats Seek to Stop Senate’s Credit Ratings Measure
text: House Democrats on Monday moved to kill a Senate plan to shake up how credit rating agencies work, a key part of a landmark Wall Street reform bill that will be debated on Tuesday.

headline: One on One: Fred Wilson, Union Square Ventures
text: Fred Wilson, a New York City partner in the venture capital firm Union Square Ventures, struck gold in the late 1990s, when he helped in the multibillion-dollar sale of Geocities to Yahoo.

headline: The Economics of Libertarianism, Revealed
text: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

headline: J.M.W. Turner (and Friends) at the Prado
text: Until recently, Spanish art enthusiasts had to travel to London, Paris or New York to see the resonant, shimmering paintings of Joseph Mallord William Turner (1775-1851). Fortunately things have changed. Through Sept. 19, the Prado is hosting the first major exhibition of his work in Spain.

headline: Sovereign Investors Said to Back AgBank I.P.O.
text: Agricultural Bank of China has had 40 percent of the Hong Kong section of its initial public offering covered by several international investors, The Financial Times reported, tempering fears that interest is low in the high-profile listing.

headline: News Corp. Digs in on Paid Content Model With BSkyB Bid
text: PARIS — Rupert Murdoch underlined on Tuesday his commitment to the idea that consumers should pay for news and entertainment, as his media empire moved to take full control of the pay-television company British Sky Broadcasting.

headline: UBS Tax Bill Faces New Hurdle
text: The lower house of the Swiss Parliament on Tuesday voted to accept a deal that aims to end a thorny tax dispute between the country’s biggest bank, UBS, and the United States, David Jolly reports in The New York Times.

headline: Is CBOE’s Price Too High?
text: CBOE Holdings said Monday that it had priced its initial public offering at $29 per share, in what is the the most anticipated American I.P.O. so far this year.

headline: The Great De-Stimulus of 1946
text: Today’s idea: The abrupt withdrawal of government spending ushered in the post-World War II economic boom, two economists write. So why worry about winding down stimulus now?

headline: Hawaii Biotech to Be Sold at Auction
text: Hawaii Biotech, a company conducting clinical trials to produce vaccines for dengue fever and the West Nile virus, will be sold at auction, The Associated Press reported.

text: Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

headline: Pickens: Leave BP Alone — For Now
text: BP doesn’t seem to have a lot people rushing to its defense these days. But T. Boone Pickens thinks the firm should at least get a little breathing room.

headline: Advertising Spending Will Grow, Report Says, But Not Until 2011
text: Advertising spending in the United States will not begin to grow again until next year, according to an annual forecast from PricewaterhouseCoopers.

headline: Are Female Business Owners Less Likely to Ask for Help?
text: After more than three years, $21,000 in wasted fees, and four Web developers, Melissa Hyatt Hirsch finally introduced StenoCentral in March. Ms. Hirsch, 37, is chief executive of the company whose namesake Web-based software application provides networking and staffing services for the court-reporting industry. These days, StenoCentral’s Web development, which is outsourced to India, runs smoothly. But it didn’t always.

text: Data by Match Analysis

headline: S.E.C. Drops Investigation Into Third Point
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission has ended an investigation of Third Point, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing a letter sent to the hedge fund’s investors.

headline: Cameron Calls N. Ireland Killings ‘Unjustified’
text: LONDON  Prime Minister David Cameron offered an extraordinary apology on Tuesday for the 1972 killings of 14 unarmed demonstrators by British soldiers in Northern Ireland, saying that a long-awaited judicial inquiry had left no doubt that the “Bloody Sunday” shootings were “both unjustified and unjustifiable.”

headline: The Creative Landscape of Independent Curators
text: LONDON — You may not have heard of the “precarious age,” but for freelance curators in Europe, the term sums up today’s job market.

headline: Zynga Said to Raise $147 Million
text: Zynga Network, the maker of games for social networks, has landed 13.5 billion yen ($147 million) from Softbank, Bloomberg News reported, citing two people familiar with the agreement.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Lawmakers from the House and Senate are moving into another day of reconciliation to complete the financial overhaul bill (see the issues on the table here). Reconciliation, oddly, has involved going beyond what the bills passed by either chamber envisioned. But whether they strip investment banks of their prop trading functions, houses like Goldman Sachs have convinced the clientele to stick around by taking care of business the old-fashioned way, advising and raising funds.

headline: Markets Make a Run, Rising More Than 2%
text: Stocks in the United States closed higher on Tuesday, sustaining a broad-based rally that for once did not lose steam at the end of the session.

headline: On Our Radar: The White House and Climate Change
text: A look at climate change policy battles at the White House. “Just a chronic pattern of infighting,” one insider says.

headline: Charles River Sticks to WuXi Despite Jana’s Critique
text: Charles River, the pharmaceutical research company, told Jana Partners on Monday in a letter obtained by DealBook that its agreement to acquire WuXi PharmaTech, a research outsourcing company, was justified, despite the opposition of Jana, an activist hedge fund.
