headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Touch of Evil’
text: In light of news events and discussion about immigration policy, A. O. Scott looks back at Orson Welles’s thriller “Touch of Evil.” While the film is set on the border between the United States and Mexico, Mr. Scott says it is “skeptical about very the idea of fixing any kind of boundary; political, moral, psychological, spiritual.” Mr. Scott praises the performances in the film, including those of Charlton Heston, Janet Leigh, Marlene Dietrich and Welles himself, calling their turns “fleshy and real.” And he appreciates how their complexities make it difficult to tell which side they are on. Have you seen “Touch of Evil?” Please share your thoughts on the movie.

headline: Live Blogging Congressional Testimony From Oil Executives
text: On Tuesday, The Lede offered updates as executives from Exxon Mobil, Chevron, ConocoPhillips and the American arms of BP and Royal Dutch Shell testified at a hearing of the House Energy and Environment Subcommittee in Washington. The hearing is now over, but to read an overview of what was said, see this news article by my colleague John Broder, who is in the hearing room. To read the updates — and the full prepared testimony from all the executives — see the text below the MSNBC video player (which had a live stream of the event as it unfolded):

headline: Obama to Lay Out Broader Energy Plan in Speech
text: PENSACOLA, Fla. — President Obama will use his first Oval Office address to the nation Tuesday night to talk about “what our fundamental energy approach must be going forward to reduce our dependence on oil and fossil fuels,” a senior White House official said.

headline: Professors and Traders: The S.E.C. Wants You
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission has embarked on an expansion campaign, hoping to bolster its ranks to avoid missing frauds like Bernard L. Madoff again.

headline: Co-Founder of OutCast Communications to Join Andreessen Horowitz
text: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

headline: A Scoreless Draw for Ivory Coast and Portugal
text: A World Cup game billed as crucial for Portugal and Ivory Coast ended 0-0 in Port Elizabeth, South Africa, leaving both teams’ fortunes undetermined.

headline: Oil Executives Break Ranks in Testimony
text: WASHINGTON — The chairmen of four of the world’s largest oil companies broke their nearly two-month silence on the major spill in the Gulf of Mexico on Tuesday and publicly blamed BP for mishandling the well that caused the disaster.

headline: Comptroller Backflips on Pension Borrowing
text: ALBANY — State Comptroller Thomas P. DiNapoli is trying some political acrobatics as he voices opposition to the tentative deal reached by state leaders last week to borrow billions of dollars from the state pension fund.

headline: An Apple App to Buy an Apple Phone
text: 10:17 a.m. | Updated Removed the reference to the app as Apple’s second application. The company has created a few other apps.

headline: ‘Mortal Kombat’ Reloaded: A Director’s Quest to Remake a Game-to-Movie Franchise
text: Even for dedicated video gamers who dropped countless quarters and callused their fingers playing Mortal Kombat on arcade machines and home consoles, it has probably been a while since they thought about that nearly 20-year-old fighting series and its 1990s-era film and television adaptations.

headline: Yes We Kan
text: T-shirt slogan which appeared in Japan after Naoto Kan was elected prime minister.

headline: Senate Democrats Might Change Jobs Bill
text: Senate Democrats are exploring whether to eliminate an extra $25 a week in unemployment benefits,  part of the economic stimulus legislation passed in 2009, as a way to cut costs and attract Republican votes for a stalled package of tax breaks, tax increases on the affluent and safety-net spending.

headline: More on the K.K.R. and Creative Artists Talks
text: Deadline.com and others on Monday followed up on DealBook’s exclusive report two weeks ago about conversations between the Creative Artists Agency and private equity firms like Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, adding an investment figure of $200 million to $250 million (which we have confirmed). Nikki Finke also said some of the erstwhile Young Turks at C.A.A. are simply trying to cash out.  As a refresher, here’s the original item from June 3.

headline: VW Says Hybrid Jetta Is on Its Way
text: The new 2011 Volkswagen Jetta makes its global debut in New York on Tuesday, with a new $16,000 model and an emphasis on appealing to the entry-level market. A hybrid is on its way, too, though there’s no sign of it today — it will appear in 2012.

headline: Participants in Climate Reviews Suggest Changes
text: Addressing a meeting in Montreal Tuesday morning, a range of participants in past reviews of climate research undertaken by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change have suggested changes in how the panel runs and communicates its assessments. The meeting is the second step in an independent review of the climate panel undertaken by the InterAcademy Council, which represents the world’s scientific academies, at the request of United Nations Secretary General Ban Ki-moon.

headline: Tesla Raises I.P.O. Goal to $178 Million
text: Tesla Motors has raised the target it has set for its planned initial public offering to about $178 million, weeks before the money-losing electric carmaker is scheduled to go public, the company disclosed in a regulatory filing.

headline: Senators Challenge Afghan Deadline
text: WASHINGTON  The commander of American forces in the Middle East, Gen. David H. Petraeus, on Tuesday confronted intense bipartisan challenges to the Obama administration’s decision to set a deadline of July 2011 to start pulling troops out of Afghanistan.

headline: Tuesday Reading: The Status of Unemployment Benefits
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: When Titans Clash: Comic-Book Creator Edition
text: Comic-book creators are generally better known for imagining and illustrating the larger-than-life conflicts of fearsome opponents, not for engaging in them themselves. So it was somewhat unusual to find Neil Gaiman, the best-selling fiction writer and comics author (“Sandman”), in a Wisconsin court on Monday, where he is suing his onetime colleague Todd McFarlane over royalties that Mr. Gaiman says he is owed from Mr. McFarlane’s Spawn comics series.

headline: Fallon: ‘Containing the Oil’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: The White House said today that BP is moving up its timeline for containing the oil by two weeks. They said they’d get it “done, even if they have to work six hours a day, four days a week.”

headline: United States Looks in the Mirror and Sees Slovenia
text: IRENE, South Africa – With the drama and hype of the England game behind them, the Americans must now turn their attention to Slovenia, a similar team to the United States.

headline: Letterman: ‘The Backstreet Boys Are Boycotting’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: How about that oil slick in the Gulf of Mexico. And you know, the oil slick is going everywhere. So the next time somebody lands on the Hudson, it won’t be that big a deal.

headline: Pianos as Public Art, and the Public’s Playthings
text: Jerome Ware Jr. pressed his palm into a tray of orange paint. Then he found exactly the right spot for a handprint on the top of an upright piano he had just painted gold.

headline: Leno: ‘Pilotless Commercial Flights’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: The F.A.A. now looking into the possibility of pilotless commercial flights. I guess that they figure if they take away the leg room, the pillows, the blankets, the food, they might as well take away the pilots, too.

headline: When Titans Clash: Poets Edition
text: The circus that is the election for Oxford University’s professor of poetry post added another ring this week as 2 of the 10 remaining candidates engaged in a name-calling battle, just days before the vote’s winner is to be announced.

headline: Are You Ready to Publish Your Novel?
text: Here’s something for aspiring writers to stick to the wall, the ceiling, whatever blank space you tend to stare off into as you’re waiting for brilliance to strike: an exuberantly designed, tongue-in-cheek motivational/advice poster that asks: “Are you absolutely, positively and wholeheartedly ready to publish your novel?”

headline: Inside Out | Old Chairs, New Look
text: Rita Konig is a decorator based in New York who has written about style for British Vogue, The Telegraph and Domino.

headline: Nomura Securities Names Managing Director
text: Nomura Securities said on Tuesday that it had hired Mark Epley from Deutsche Bank to be a managing director in its investment banking division in New York, as the Japanese bank continues its expansion in the United States.

headline: It’s Official: White House Party Crashers Will Appear in ‘Housewives’
text: To the cynics who said there’s no way that Bravo would cut the White House party crashers out of “The Real Housewives of D.C.”: you were right.

headline: Summer Rituals | The Morning Works
text: From late July through Labor Day, at an hour when most people are asleep, trainers at Saratoga Race Course put their horses, and themselves, through “the morning works.”

headline: What We’re Reading: Debtors’ Prisons
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: U.S. Recognizes an Indian Tribe on Long Island, Clearing the Way for a Casino
text: ALBANY  The Shinnecock Indians’ 32-year battle for federal recognition ended with prayer, drumming and an Algonquin victory song on Long Island on Tuesday after the Obama administration approved the tribe’s petition.

headline: Above the Din
text: After four days of riveting World Cup action, the buzz remains all about the buzz. Yes, it is hard to escape the fact that the games in South Africa sound as if they are being played among an infestation of locusts. Commentators have called it the vuvuzela orchestra, in honor of the plastic horns that have taken over a major international event, a sound that nothing short of the mute button can mitigate.

headline: Travel Deals: 20% Off at Joie de Vivre Hotels in California
text: To mark the 40th anniversary of the San Francisco Pride parade, taking place June 26 and 27, the San Francisco-based Joie de Vivre hotels is offering a 20 percent discount at more than 30 of the company’s California boutique hotels, through the end of 2010.

headline: Chinese Nuclear Plant Experienced a Small Leak Last Month, a Stakeholder Says
text: A fuel rod at a state-owned nuclear power plant in southeastern China last month leaked traces of radioactive iodine into the surrounding cooling fluid, but no radiation escaped the building, a Hong Kong electric utility with a 25 percent stake in the power plant said Tuesday.

headline: Nevada’s Angle Makes Washington Visit
text: 5:03 p.m. | Updated Sharron Angle, the Tea Party-embraced Nevadan who hopes to oust Senator Harry Reid in the November midterms, ventured into Mr. Reid’s domain Tuesday when she stopped by the Capitol to lunch with Senate Republicans who are eager to see her succeed in her campaign against the majority leader.

headline: The Not-So-Straight Dope From Betty White
text: ArtsBeat takes no joy in picking a fight with Betty White, a k a The Most Beloved Entertainer in America™, but we’ve got to call them the way we see them.

headline: In China, an Attempt at a Hollywood-Style Movie
text: HUAIROU, China  The movie has ancient Greek warriors, pirates, underwater kingdoms, a villain called the Demon Mage and mermaids that kill men during sex. There is a sultry Bond girl, too, playing the mermaid queen. Most of the actors are American, and the cameras use 3-D technology.

headline: Eating Brown Rice to Cut Diabetes Risk
text: Next time you order takeout wonton soup and a spicy Number 82, you might want to make sure it comes with brown rice.

headline: Recalling When Summer Meant a Break From Stress
text: The summer after my junior year in high school, I learned to gauge when, precisely, a honeydew will ripen and how to work a register and give change, after doing the math in my head (yes, I’m seriously dating myself).

headline: Artist, 11, Campaigns to Save Gulf Birds
text: Relying on her artistry, an 11-year-old who loves birds has helped raise more than $70,000 to protect pelicans, manatees, whooping cranes and other birds who are threatened by the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: China's Blockbuster Gamble
text: Can China break Hollywood's hold on epic blockbuster films?  Real estate magnate turned film producer Jon Jiang hopes so. A look behind the scenes of his $100 million spectacle "Empires of the Deep."

headline: ABT Ballerina Is Attacked
text: Two muggers attacked Natalia Osipova, a major international ballet star, as she left an  American Ballet Theater performance early Tuesday morning, striking her in the nose and stealing her bag, Ms. Osipova’s agent said.

headline: Federal Panel Advises Less Salt, Saturated Fat and More Cooking
text: The latest federal suggestions for how Americans should eat were issued on Tuesday morning: You can have an egg for breakfast, just not the bacon. There is nothing wrong with eating meat, but the government admits vegetarians might be on to something.

headline: World Cup 2010 | An Early Game Means Early Beer
text: In the city’s largest watering hole for its Slovakian population, there was a grand total of one native Slovakian sitting at the bar of the Beer Garden at Bohemian Hall in Astoria, Queens, on Tuesday morning.

headline: Answers About Social Security: Part 6
text: “Ask an Expert” is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

headline: Magical Foreigners, Austerity Edition

headline: Helen Hunt to Play Stage Manager in ‘Our Town’
text: A great many secrets are revealed about the characters in Thornton Wilder’s “Our Town” with one exception, the Stage Manager, who narrates the three-act play without saying much of anything about himself. Or herself, in the case of the acclaimed Off Broadway production at the Barrow Street Theater.

headline: CBS to 48HR Magazine: We Want Your URL
text: When we last looked in on the dispute between CBS and 48HR Magazine — CBS felt the made-in-a-weekend publication violated their trademark on “48 Hours” — it seemed as if the Rodney King rule was about to be invoked and everybody was deciding to hug it out. “We would like to work something out,” said Louis Briskman, CBS vice president and general counsel.

headline: BP’s Stock Rises in U.S., but Bad News Abounds
text: As BP took its turn on the hot seat — taking fire from lawmakers and its peers in the oil industry, its shares climbed — in the United States, at least.

headline: TimesCast | June 15, 2010

headline: More Than Zero

headline: Draft Prospects Looking Past Memphis

headline: An Unlikely Path to a Great Workplace

text: The antithesis of the 5,400-passenger megaship, Seabourn Sojourn – capacity: 450 — was recently launched in London. It is the second of three new Yachts of Seabourn ships to set sail over three years.

text: Deutsche Bank on Tuesday said that it had named Anshu Jain as its head of global banking, succeeding the retiring Michael Cohrs.

text: As part of its continuing efforts to carry out the credit card legislation that President Obama signed last year, the Federal Reserve announced a few new tweaks today.

headline: The Budget-Cut Fandango, and a New Messenger
text: With the stuttering city economy, the dance of the budget cuts — perhaps it is more like a multipartner tango — has become an annual early summer ritual for principals across the city. It begins with the grim reports from Albany and City Hall in January, typically accented with a plea from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg not to think of this as an idle threat.

headline: American Detained in Pakistan Had Sights on bin Laden
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  An ailing, middle-age construction worker from Colorado, on a self-proclaimed mission to help American troops, armed himself with a dagger, a pistol, a sword, Christian texts, hashish and night-vision goggles and headed to the lawless tribal areas near the border of Afghanistan and Pakistan to personally hunt down Osama bin Laden.

headline: Seeking Hope From a Support Group
text: My fiancé drove me 30 miles to the nearest support group meeting, and I was eager to attend.

headline: IPhone 4 Orders Swamp AT&T and Apple Sites

headline: Government Bonds and the Financial Crisis
text: Lorenzo Bini Smaghi, a member of the executive board of the European Central Bank, gave a speech in New York on Monday that shed some light on why Europe’s sovereign debt crisis is such a threat to euro-zone banks — and why the European Central Bank felt compelled to intervene last month in the bond market.

headline: Resort Report | Balenciaga
text: For resort, Nicolas Ghesquière was inspired by the uniforms that Cristobal Balenciaga made for Air France in 1968. Graphic op-art prints in bright colors looked cheerful and modern. (A closer viewing revealed them to be deconstructed architectural prints.) The house launches its first bag for Edition — a clean tote shape with a cut-out circle for the handle — based on a style from the archive. Swimwear was a highlight, done with scuba details in vivid prints and colors.

headline: Aerial View of a Battle for Survival
text: First thing each morning, an assistant hands Capt. Roger Laferriere of the Coast Guard a red folder with the word “hot” written on its cover in bold letters and double-underlined. Inside is a list of the most pressing needs of the day in fighting the BP spill in the gulf, the worst accidental discharge of oil in the nation’s history.

headline: Call Him Crazy, but bin Laden Bounty Hunter May Have Been Close
text: By now, you’ve probably heard the news: a middle-aged construction worker from Colorado was arrested in a forest in northwest Pakistan, carrying a samurai sword and a pistol, looking for Osama bin Laden.

headline: Global Heat Is On in 2010 So Far
text: The National Climatic Data Center has released its summary of global climate conditions so far this year and finds that the month of May, as well as the period from January through May, were the warmest since thorough record keeping began in 1880.

headline: Books and Boots
text: Soldiers, sailors and Marines experience the hardships of war firsthand, often serving in  countries where the culture and customs differ greatly from their own. International civilian aid workers, United Nations representatives and contractors are there, too, working tirelessly in harsh conditions and often without the resources — money, equipment and personnel — they need.At home in our armchairs, we learn about Afghanistan from network news and political pundits. Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal’s counterinsurgency strategy and President Obama’s security policies are debated over dinner and drinks, while combat statistics are recorded as numbers of civilian or military casualties. The highly personal nature of war and the impact it has on the people — the victims — are lost in those numbers.

headline: Cuomo Claims Charity Pocketed Aid Money
text: New York Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo on Tuesday said he had filed a suit against a charity that accepts donated cars, accusing it of pocketing money that was intended for humanitarian aid.

headline: BP’s Options to Limit Liability From the Oil Spill
text: 10:42 a.m., June 16 | Updated As the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico worsens, the financial markets are rife with speculation about BP’s next steps to control its growing liabilities — a pot that the oil giant has further stirred by hiring investment advisers to assist it in managing these liabilities.

headline: Greenpoint Vendors Will Eat, Learn and Talk, but Won’t Sell
text: After The New York Times ran this article about the scrappy and creative vendors at the Greenpoint Food Market, the market’s organizer, Joann Kim, learned that the market was not operating within the New York City health department’s code. (All food sold in New York City must be made in an approved commercial kitchen by someone who has passed the city’s course on food handling.) Today, Ms. Kim announced that she was cancelling the scheduled June 26 market and will be holding a Think Tank Potluck instead, to educate (and brainstorm with) the almost 250 vendors who have applied to sell food at the market.

headline: In Pictures | The Great American Road Trip
text: Last summer, Jennifer O’Keeffe, a photographer in San Francisco, was feeling stuck, “creatively and in my life,” she says, and she wanted to get lost. So she bought a cargo van retrofitted with a bed and took to the road for a two-month solo road trip, photographing her way up the coast of California, to Oregon and the Olympic Peninsula of Washington, then through Idaho, Montana, Utah and Nevada. “I didn’t have a definite plan and I didn’t want one,” O’Keeffe says. “I love maps and navigation, but I wanted this trip to have a different sort of pattern — one that came from directions scribbled on the back of napkins, questionable decisions and wrong turns.” Besides her camera, her other constant companion was a copy of Steinbeck’s “Travels With Charley,” which helped O’Keeffe put her experiences of everyday American life in a larger context: a young woman in 2009 comparing her observations with those of a man at the end of his life in 1960. “He was witnessing a new era of modernity in full swing, and I was looking at a lot of the broken pieces.” O’Keeffe made a selection of her images from the trip available to T; the full portfolio is on her Web site.

headline: After Riots, Uzbeks Say They’ll Defend What Is Left
text: OSH, Kyrgyzstan  As gunfire cracked and popped nearby, the few remaining men in a large Uzbek enclave here on Tuesday grabbed wooden poles and metal pipes, crouched behind makeshift barricades of rocks and readied for a possible onslaught.

headline: Small Firms May Not Keep Current Health Plans After White House Decision
text: Although President  Obama and many Democrats promised during the health care reform debate that “if you like your health plan, you can keep it,” the health insurance plans that are now offered by small businesses probably will not survive the transition to a regulated marketplace. The Obama administration acknowledged this on Monday, when it proposed regulations for determining what insurance plans can remain exempt from market reforms. And while participants in those plans will probably be grateful for it, business owners may be less sanguine about the outcome.

headline: The Plot Unthickens
The Tonys Need a New Home
text: 5:00 p.m. | Updated Where would you hold next year’s 65th annual Tony Awards? The ceremony’s usual home, Radio City Music Hall, has a sustained booking for June 2011, so the Tonys are in the hunt for a new space for the awards show next season.

text: I flicked on my TV one day and heard someone say this: “Science and technology have reached a point where our means are finally catching up with our imagination.”

headline: Demand for Precision Burnishes Pebble Beach Champions
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  The United States Open is returning this week to a golf course that was made for it, a spectacular site where seaside topography, strong strategic design and a dry summerlike climate have meshed in a way that has never failed to produce a national champion worthy of the title.

headline: Resort Report | Nina Ricci
text: Peter Copping presented a feminine collection with a ’60s spin that looked to Jackie Onassis and her time in Greece. Copping made this oft-used icon his own, though, nixing the expected earth tones in favor of a pale palette for delicate lace, light pleating and ruffles. A gorgeous white lace gown had a lingerie feel, with exposed-corset boning and a sheer back.

text: The New York City health department published its new restaurant letter-grading rules Tuesday so next month, for the first time, signs bearing A, B or C ratings will be issued to the city’s more than 24,000 restaurants to publicly announce their cleanliness.

headline: In Oval Office Speech, Obama Calls for New Focus on Energy Policy
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama summoned Americans on Tuesday to a “national mission” to move away from reliance on oil and develop alternative sources of energy, casting the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico as an imperative for Congress to act quickly to overcome “a lack of political courage and candor.”

headline: Money Flows for Spill Research
text: Scientists say that one of the most critical needs in responding to the oil spill is a far more vigorous research effort in the Gulf of Mexico to track the impact that the oil is having. But money for that purpose has been slow to arrive. In exasperation, some scientists and universities have essentially whipped out their own checkbooks to get a start, hoping to land financing later.

headline: No Body Hair Left Behind
text: MARK BRYCE, the operations manager at a semi-trailer dealership in Grand Rapids, Mich., has lost most of the hair on his head, but he is “really good at growing it everywhere else,” particularly on his back, said his wife, Anna, a publicist for Amway. “My husband is blond, so he doesn’t look like a big hairy ape, but he does look like a golden retriever,” she said.

headline: Many Ways to Shear a Man
text: WHEN it comes to removing back hair, “each option has its own set of pros and cons,” said Dr. Andrew Alexis, an assistant professor of dermatology at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons.

headline: Estimates of Oil Flow Jump Higher
text: A government panel on Tuesday released yet another estimate of the amount of oil flowing from BP’s damaged well, declaring that as much as 60,000 barrels a day could be spewing into the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: A Summons for the Commissioner
text: A small group of homeless people and advocates gathered Tuesday in a sun-dappled Police Plaza in Manhattan to give Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly a gift: a mock-up summons for disorderly conduct printed on a poster-size white card.

headline: ‘Young and the Restless’ Watch: The Triumphant Return of the Hoff
text: If you are old enough to remember the 1990s, then you know that there was a sustained period of time in which the name David Hasselhoff was the punch line to every other joke about the lunacy of European pop cultural taste. (How this came to be is explained by his hit single following the fall of the Berlin Wall, “Looking for Freedom.”) If you are of the right age and also German then you probably recall that between the years of 1975 and 1982 Mr. Hasselhoff inhabited the role of Dr. William “Snapper” Foster, Jr. on the CBS soap opera “The Young and the Restless.” On Tuesday, the Hoff returned to the show that made him a star, where he’ll be playing Snapper all week. His daughter Taylor Ann (the one who recorded a drunken episode of her father’s three years ago) will show up beginning Wednesday to play a nurse.

headline: Design Miami/Basel | The Future Perfect
text: Tomorrow always comes today at Design Miami/Basel, where exhibitors take forward thinking as seriously as beauty in form. Still, any future worth imagining contains its history, and the London sculptor Graham Hudson brought a piece of it to Monday’s VIP preview, when W Hotels Worldwide unveiled commissioned projects by the four young winners of the fair’s Designers of the Future Award. (The others are Jamie Zigelbaum and Marcelo Coelho of Future Matter, based in Boston; Beta Tank, founded in Berlin and London by Michele Gauler and Eyal Burstein; and Stuart Wood, Flo Ortkrass and Hannes Koch, of Berlin’s rAndom International.)

headline: Pictures of the Day: Northern Ireland and Elsewhere
text: The publication of a long-awaited report on the 1972 “Bloody Sunday” shootings in Northern Ireland drew cheers from crowds and an unequivocal apology from the British prime minister, David Cameron. Violence began to abate in Kyrgyzstan between the Kyrgyz majority and the Uzbek minority, and residents of Osh ventured outside for food aid and medical care (Slides 2-3).

headline: ‘Bloody Andrew’ Offered a Home on Broadway
text: It has been an open secret for some time that the Public Theater is eyeing a transfer to Broadway for its critically acclaimed musical “Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson.” But the timing of such a move, if it happens, remains up in the air. The Shubert Organization has offered the Jacobs Theater, a prime piece of real estate, for the show in the fall, according to two theater executives with knowledge of the conversations. But one wrinkle is that Benjamin Walker, the star of “Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson,” has been offered an enviable movie role in a coming “X-Men” project, said the executives, who would only speak anonymously because they were not authorized by the Public to announce the information.

The summer  with its risk of hurricanes and the threat of airline strikes  promises little respite.

headline: Removing Mysterious Sell-By Date From Milk Cartons

headline: Watchdog Group Files Complaints Over South Carolina Primary
text: The unemployed South Carolina man whose surprise victory in last week’s Democratic primary race for a Senate seat has drawn intense scrutiny now faces another obstacle. A watchdog group, Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington, on Tuesday filed formal complaints with federal and state election officials (pdf) asserting that he and three other candidates violated election law.

headline: Resort Report | Lanvin
text: At his recent resort presentation, Alber Elbaz explained that his collection was all about finding solutions. Most of these solutions were of the two-in-one variety. He interpreted fashion’s current minimal mood in what he called a Lanvin way: sleeveless black T-shirt dresses, when turned inside out, transformed into feminine tulle confections. These were very charming (albeit a bit scratchy) when worn in the minimal way. The swimwear was divine; when each suit was paired with its appropriate cover-up, the combo took the shape of a cocktail dress or beach-appropriate gown.

headline: Disturbance Struggling in Poor Environment
text: A combination of marginal vertical shear and decreased low-mid-level relative humidity seems to have taken a toll on the developing vortex. Deep convection associated with the disturbance has diminished, and it’s now an exposed swirl of clouds centered near 13N 46W and tracking WNW at 13kts. It is not expected to regenerate. See http://einstein.atmos.colostate.edu/~mcnoldy/tropics/atcf/latestATL.png for the current location and prior track.

headline: A New Tool to Start Those Coals
text: If Dad wields a spatula at a grill fueled by charcoal, here’s a gift for him. It looks like a giant curling iron, but plug it in, hold it at the bottom of a nice pyramid of chunks or briquettes in the grill, and within a minute, thanks to a heating element and a blower, you have fire enough to get the coals going. You can apply it to a couple of more spots to speed things up. Within about 20 minutes your coals will be glowing and hot enough for cooking. It heats up only when the button is depressed and cools down instantly. It is clean and has a long cord, and when outdoor grilling season is over, it can be used in a fireplace.

headline: Bucket Grills for Portable Cooking
text: Grilling at the beach or on a picnic will be easier with the new little bucket grills that are showing up this season. This one, fire-engine red like an official sand bucket, has a 10.2-inch grate and a liner that holds the charcoal and lets the ash drop to the bottom of the pail. Fill it with coals, perhaps with some newspaper underneath to speed up ignition, before heading out, so it’s ready to get to work on the hot dogs or burgers.

headline: A New Chocolate Cake in New York
text: To New Yorkers, chocolate cake might mean crumb-dusted blackout, not layers of chocolate meringue and chocolate mousse with a thin glaze of ganache. But that is the signature dessert at the Best Chocolate Cake in the World. A restaurateur in Lisbon, Carlos Lopes, with his Manhattan partner, Adriano Lucas, created a version of a dacquoise he saw at Fauchon in Paris. Now Mr. Lopes’s shops sell his creamy confection in Portugal, Spain and Brazil, with a factory turning out 150,000 a year just in Portugal.

headline: Putting the Fresh in Refreshment
text: FIVE THOUSAND pounds of ice: as heavy as a young elephant, or five wading pools filled to the brim. Dylan Williams, the owner of Beaucoup Nola Juice in New Orleans, hauled it all in a refrigerated truck from New Orleans to Manchester, Tenn., last week, to supply his snow cone stand at the Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival.

headline: In Albuquerque, French-Style Wines That Sparkle

headline: Design Your Own Shaved Ice
text: The Dining section of The Times has an article this week on shaved ice. Diner’s Journal is asking readers to post their ideas for a new shaved-ice recipe. Fany Gerson, a pastry chef in New York and the author of the forthcoming “My Sweet Mexico: Recipes for Authentic Pastries, Breads, Candies, Beverages, and Frozen Treats” (to be published by Ten Speed Press in September) will pick a suggestion from the comments and create a recipe for it. Write your ideas in the comments below. Be creative and have fun.

headline: Takashi
text: A LOBE of sea urchin sits on a small tile of raw, red, marbled steak placed on top of a single shiso leaf, the shape of the ace of clubs, and a rectangle of nori slightly larger than the meat. The package is meant to be folded onto itself, then touched to a low bowl of soy sauce and eaten in perhaps two bites: a raw surf-and-turf canapé, elegant and spare.

headline: N. Korea Warns of Response to U.N.
text: UNITED NATIONS  North Korea’s ambassador to the United Nations said Tuesday that his country’s military would respond forcefully to any Security Council condemnation over the sinking of a South Korean warship, warning that “our people and army will smash our aggressors.”

headline: Animal Husbandry, SoHo Style
text: The premise of “The Fabulous Beekman Boys”  a couple, uptight Brent and laid-back Josh, give up the Manhattan media world to become gentlemen organic farmers in upstate New York  inspires hopes of a gay “Green Acres.” The chores! The culture wars!

headline: Dodging Bill Collectors, Plotting for a Crown
text: When the doorbell rings, nobody answers it. The same goes for the telephone. It could be a collection agent from Sears or the modeling school or the bank.

headline: Stay. Eat. Make Yourself at Home. Maybe Find a Man.
text: In an episode from the first season of “30 Rock,” Tina Fey’s schlumpy character, Liz Lemon, is delighted to discover that in Cleveland, she passes for a model. “You’re so skinny,” a complete stranger tells her. “You really should eat something.”

headline: A Reconsideration for Online ‘Ulysses’
text: Score one for “Ulysses”: Apple has decided that it is not obscene after all. After the makers of a Web comic version of the epic James Joyce novel said last week that Apple had rejected several images containing nudity, Apple reversed its decision on Monday and asked that the panels be resubmitted, said Chad Rutkowski, the business manager for Throwaway Horse, the publisher of the comic “Ulysses Seen.” “They basically apologized,” Mr. Rutkowski said. “They said they gave it a second look and realized that it wasn’t obscene or anything like that. They’re clearly drawing a distinction now and they understand what we’re doing.” The initial installments of “Ulysses Seen” are available in the App Store and on the Web site ulyssesseen.com.

headline: Curses, Fairies and Fantasies for This Beauty
text: “The Sleeping Beauty” is the grandest of all of the 19th-century classical ballets, the most complex in detail, the most fairy-tale-like of the fairy tales we believe, sometimes, onstage. Its vision of social order is also that of the world in which ballet originated. And the collaboration between its choreographer, Marius Petipa, and its composer, Tchaikovsky, is the idealized prototype for the relationship between great music and great dance.

headline: Obama Party-Crasher Makes ‘Housewives’ Cut
text: To the cynics who said there’s no way that Bravo would cut the White House party-crashers out of “The Real Housewives of D.C.”: You were right.

headline: Romance Grounded With a Bit of Gravity
text: The jazz singer and pianist Patti Wicks is all about rhythmic deconstruction. Like the much-missed Carmen McRae, Ms. Wicks, who appeared at the Metropolitan Room on Monday evening with the bassist Linc Milliman, scrutinizes songs with a raised eyebrow. Words and phrases are dismantled with a wry deliberation and an improvisatory boldness that put a question mark at the end of songs, especially when the lyrics are sentimental. Her attitude suggests a certain disbelief: “Oh, really?” she seems to imply.

headline: Expanding N.Y.U. Sets Sights on Ground Zero
text: New York University has already proposed to expand from its Greenwich Village home into Brooklyn, Manhattan’s East Side and Governor’s Island. Now it has another idea: ground zero.

headline: Visit Florida Ad
text: Florida's tourism office is running television spots to protect the state's tourism industry from the oil spill.

headline: In Israel, From Storage Unit to Loft
text: JAFFO, ISRAEL — As a refugee from the former Yugoslavia, Nesh Bruic knew how to build homes. He arrived here in this Bible-era port town, now a part of Tel Aviv, in the 1990s, descended from a long line of builders. “We always constructed our own homes back in Croatia,” said Mr. Bruic, 41, who has designed restaurants and bars both in Tel Aviv and Belgrade. “So when I first saw the place,” he said, referring to his 700-square-foot studio that he restored, “it felt like a pearl I had to rescue from destruction.”

headline: ‘Bachelorette’ Lifts ABC
text: “The Bachelorette,” with Ali Fedotowsky, above, lifted ABC in the ratings on Monday night, with 8.3 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. ABC and CBS finished in a virtual tie for first place, even though CBS broadcast a lineup of repeats. Sitcom reruns on CBS averaged 7.4 million viewers from 8 to 10 while the network’s repeat of “CSI: Miami” led the 10 p.m. hour with 7.6 million viewers, outperforming ABC’s “True Beauty” (5.4 million) and NBC’s “Persons Unknown” (3.4 million). NBC ranked fourth for the night with back-to-back episodes of “Last Comic Standing,” a rerun at 8 (3.5 million) and a new installment at 9 (4.8 million). Fox placed third, with 6.5 million for “Lie to Me” at 8 but only 4.4 million for “The Good Guys” at 9. On Sunday, HBO’s third-season premiere of “True Blood” attracted an audience of 5.1 million viewers, up from the 3.7 million who tuned in to the season opener a year ago.

headline: When Titans Clash: Comic-book Edition
text: Comic-book creators are generally better known for imagining and illustrating the larger-than-life conflicts of fearsome opponents, not for engaging in them themselves. So it was somewhat unusual to find Neil Gaiman, the best-selling writer, in a Wisconsin court on Monday, where he is suing his onetime colleague Todd McFarlane over royalties that Mr. Gaiman says he is owed from Mr. McFarlane’s Spawn comics series. The Associated Press reported that Mr. Gaiman and Mr. McFarlane testified in United States District Court in Madison. Mr. Gaiman said that a character called Dark Ages Spawn was essentially a copy of Medieval Spawn, which he had created for Spawn issue No. 9 in 1993, and that angel characters called Domina and Tiffany were copies of Angela, who also first appeared in that issue. A jury found in 2002 that Mr. Gaiman was a co-copyright holder for the Medieval Spawn and Angela characters, as well as a third named Cogliostro, and was owed royalties. They have yet to come to an agreement on payment.

headline: Road Kill in the Serengeti?
text: Imagine. You are lying in the grass in the east African savannah, watching wildebeest fording a shallow river. You can hear the funny grunting noises they make, and as they pass by, you can feel the impact of their hooves on the ground and smell their rich animal smell. You see their kicking heels, their beautiful sleek bodies. Then you look up, and you realize that the herd stretches as far as you can see, that the plain is dark with wildebeest. If you were to wait for them all to pass, you would be there for days.

headline: World Cup Replay: Day 5, June 15
text: A view of the tournament as Brazil beat North Korea and the other teams tied — with bright, sunny skies at some matches and winter coats at others.

headline: Helen Hunt to Play ‘our Town’ Stage Manager
text: A great many secrets are revealed about the characters in Thornton Wilder’s “Our Town” with one exception, the Stage Manager, who narrates the three-act play without saying much of anything about himself. Or herself, in the case of the acclaimed Off Broadway production at the Barrow Street Theater. The Academy Award-winning actress Helen Hunt (“As Good as It Gets”), left, will join the cast as the Stage Manager for a limited run, July 6-Aug. 1, the producers said on Tuesday. She will succeed Michael McKean, becoming the sixth actor to assume the role in this long-running production, directed by David Cromer, who played the Stage Manager in the first several months of the run of the play, which opened in February 2009. Ms. Hunt is no stranger to “Our Town,” having played the role of the young Emily Webb in the 1988-89 Lincoln Center Theater production. Ms. Hunt’s last major stage production in New York was Yasmina Reza’s play “Life x 3” at Circle in the Square on Broadway in 2003.

headline: Successfully Surrendering It All to Crack
text: There are two kinds of crack addicts, those who cook their own  a complicated business that involves cocaine, baking soda, water and a flame  and those who grab the stuff to go, in ready-made chunks called rocks. Most people go for the rocks. Even when it comes to killing yourself, slowly and gruesomely, who has time to cook anymore?

headline: Star Ballerina Attacked Near Lincoln Center
text: Two muggers attacked Natalia Osipova, right, a major international ballet star, as she left an American Ballet Theater performance early Tuesday morning, striking her in the nose and stealing her bag, her agent said. Ms. Osipova had attended a performance of Ballet Theater’s “Sleeping Beauty,” in which she is scheduled to dance on Saturday night, at the Metropolitan Opera House and was crossing Amsterdam Avenue on her way home when she was mugged, said the agent, Sergei Danilian. “Two guys just came from her back and they hit her and they took her bag,” he said. “She was so brave and so smart  she didn’t scream,” he said of the 5-foot-4 ballerina. Ms. Osipova had left her money at home and her computer at the Met, but the muggers got away with her point shoes and a small hammer used to shape them. The Met doctor was to examine her on Tuesday, Mr. Danilian said, and would determine whether she could dance full-out during an afternoon rehearsal or would just walk through it. She will “absolutely, no doubt,” perform on Saturday, he said. The police also interviewed her at the Met, he said. Ms. Osipova, who is Russian, is a star of the Bolshoi Ballet and in her second season as a guest artist with Ballet Theater.

headline: When Titans Clash: Poets’ Edition
text: The carnival that is the election for Oxford University’s professor of poetry post added another ring this week when one of the 10 remaining candidates, the Beat poet Michael Horovitz, criticized another, the biographer Roger Lewis. The Guardian reported that the dispute was touched off by an essay in The Telegraph written by Mr. Lewis. The essay, titled “Now here’s what I call poetry,” listed details like the color “of Elizabeth Taylor’s eyes,” the “tilt of Garbo’s face in profile” and the “bend of Chaplin’s cane.” In a letter to The Telegraph, Mr. Horovitz wrote that Mr. Lewis’s list “was at first sight quite intriguing, but contained few allusions to actual poetry.” He added: “Mr. Lewis could presumably spout the hind legs off a donkey about these subjects, but how does this qualify him to follow Masefield, Auden, Graves and Heaney as the next Professor of Poetry?” Mr. Lewis did not immediately respond to Mr. Horovitz. Last week Paula Claire, the only woman in the running this year, withdrew from the race, saying it unfairly favored the poet Geoffrey Hill. Another candidate, Michael George Gibson, questioned Ms. Claire’s decision, saying last week that she “has rather flown off the handle with this one” and calling the election a “circus.” Oxford is to announce the election results on Friday.

headline: ‘Breaking Bad’ Versus ‘Mad Men’
text: I had early doubts about “Mad Men,” but eventually I gave myself over to its charms, and after three excellent seasons I took it for granted that the saga of Don Draper was the best show on TV — the rightful heir, insofar as one could possibly exist, to “The Sopranos” and “The Wire.” But after working my way through AMC’s other drama, “Breaking Bad,” which had its season finale Sunday night, I find that I’ve changed my mind. And not only because “Breaking Bad” is brilliant — though it is, it is — but because its dramatic strengths expose some of the weaknesses of “Mad Men,” and puncture, ever-so-gently, the mystique that’s built up around Matthew Weiner’s show.

headline: U.S. Team Focusing on Starting Strong

headline: Said the Playwright to the Young Actor...
text: IN “The Grand Manner,” at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center, Bobby Steggert plays Pete, a stand-in for the playwright A. R. Gurney during a galvanizing moment in his life. In 1948 Mr. Gurney traveled from his boarding school in New Hampshire to Manhattan, where he had a brief, nervous backstage exchange with the celebrated actress Katharine Cornell after a performance of Shakespeare’s "Antony and Cleopatra," an exchange that he uses as a jumping-off point in the comic drama.

headline: ‘Portrait of an Addict as a Young Man’

Instead he usually says he tried it at a party, that he was pulled into a bedroom by someone he knew, a couple, a friend, someone he didn't know. It's someone different every time. The phony story always sounds less shameful to him, less weird, more normal, even glamorous. But that's not how it happens.

headline: Is New York Ready for No-Fault Divorce?
text: In 1969, Gov. Ronald Reagan of California signed the nation’s first no-fault divorce law. He later called it the worst mistake of his life. But other states eventually followed California’s lead, and no-fault — under which one spouse can end a marriage, with no proof required of wrongdoing by either party — more or less became law of the land. New York State was the longtime holdout, since South Dakota passed its law in 1985.

headline: Mets’ Hitters Finally Make Things a Little Easier for Santana
text: CLEVELAND  On a night when Johan Santana was not at his best, he finally got the run support he had been missing for much of the season. Santana gave up four runs in the first four innings, but after he found a better rhythm, the Mets’ offense came alive and took advantage of several mistakes by the opposition to give Santana the kind of cushion he has rarely enjoyed this season.

headline: Romanian Government Survives No-Confidence Vote
text: PRAGUE  Romania’s center-right government narrowly survived a no-confidence vote on Tuesday as thousands of angry Romanians protested outside Parliament against tough new austerity measures meant to stave off a Greek-style crisis.

headline: Corrections

headline: Ethiopia: Supreme Court to Hear Election Challenge
text: Ethiopia’s Supreme Court will consider a request by the Medrek opposition alliance to void the results of the country’s May 23 election and hold a new one after widespread reports of voter harassment and intimidation by security forces and governing party activists, a Medrek spokesman, Negasso Gidada, said Tuesday. The opposition said that three of its activists were killed during the campaign and that hundreds more were arrested and beaten. Medrek also accused the government of using food aid and other resources provided by the United States, the World Bank, and European donors as a political tool during the campaign. Prime Minister Meles Zenawi’s governing party, which has denied the opposition’s charges, and its allies won more than 99 percent of the parliamentary seats in the election.

headline: Prime-Time Fox Anchor to Extend Her Contract
text: The Fox News Channel has sealed a new contract with its 10 p.m. anchor, Greta Van Susteren, giving its hugely popular prime-time lineup an added measure of stability.

headline: Gaza: U.N. to Distribute Aid Seized by Israel in Blockade
text: The United Nations expects to soon distribute the aid brought by a Turkish flotilla trying to run the Gaza blockade and seized by Israel after a bloody confrontation. Robert H. Serry, the United Nations envoy to the Middle East peace negotiations, told the United Nations Security Council on Tuesday that despite such attempts, Gaza received only a fraction of its needs. Three-quarters of the damage caused by the 2009 war including homes schools and hospitals  has not been repaired or rebuilt, Mr. Serry reported. In roughly the past month, he said, an average of 566 trucks of goods entered Gaza weekly, a 6 percent drop from recent numbers.

headline: Series Rematch Proves Lopsided
text: This game was billed as a pitchers’ duel, a classic matchup and a World Series rematch, but something different unfolded Tuesday night at Yankee Stadium. The Philadelphia Phillies team that returned to the Bronx is no longer a defending champion or even the unquestionable class of the National League. This group has a lot of the same sluggers, and perhaps an even better ace, but they are in a real rut.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: The ‘Learning Knights’ of Bell Telephone
text: FIFTY-SIX years ago today, a Bell System manager sent postcards to 16 of the most capable and promising young executives at the company. What was written on the postcards was surprising, especially coming from a corporate ladder-climber at a time when the nation was just beginning to lurch out of a recession: “Happy Bloom’s Day.”

headline: House-Senate Talks Drop New Credit-Rating Rules
text: WASHINGTON  House and Senate negotiators voted on Tuesday to strip new conflict-of-interest rules for credit rating agencies out of a sweeping overhaul of the nation’s financial regulatory system, leaving in place a process that many analysts say contributed to the proliferation of troubled mortgage-backed securities that were a cause of the 2008 financial crisis.

headline: Tanker Procurement: 2 Congressmen Speak Out
text: To the Editor:

headline: Shedding the Collar to Lace Up Cleats
text: ROME  On a recent weekend morning, a crowd gathered on a field behind St. Peter’s Basilica to cheer as a team of South American and Italian soccer players faced off against a team of Americans. Some fans played guitars and drums, while others dressed up like superheroes and Vikings.

headline: Nintendo and Sony Show Competing Visions for 3-D at a Video Game Convention
text: LOS ANGELES  With Microsoft and Sony looking to leap ahead of Nintendo’s Wii motion-control video game technology, Nintendo took off in another direction on Tuesday with a 3-D portable game device.

headline: Giants Try Out New Stadium, With a Happy Throng in Tow
text: It was only a minicamp practice, but the small and vocal group of Giants fans at New Meadowlands Stadium treated it like game day on a Tuesday.

headline: Showing TV, and Commercials, on the Shelves and in the Aisles
text: FOR many marketers, advertising in stores is an increasingly important way to influence shoppers at the so-called moment of truth, as they finally make up their minds about which brands of soup, soap or cereal to buy  or not buy. Now, a company is hoping to bring commercials to the retail point of purchase on screens that will be attached to shelves and above aisles.

headline: Seeking to Balance Beauty and Safety on the Cliff Walk
text: NEWPORT, R.I.  The Cliff Walk, a promenade that winds more than three miles along this city’s rugged coast, is not for the vertigo-prone. It looms high over the crashing surf, drawing a constant stream of visitors who peer over the stunning precipice as they stroll.

headline: Pelfrey Earns Praise From Hall of Fame Pitcher Palmer
text: CLEVELAND  Mets fans need no more evidence of Mike Pelfrey’s success this year than his 9-1 record and 2.39 earned run average. But there are other indications of how the rest of baseball is taking notice of his impressive work thus far.

headline: Drake Concert Is Canceled at Seaport
text: A free concert featuring the hip-hop artist Drake and the pop band Hanson at the South Street Seaport in Manhattan on Tuesday was closed down amid concerns about the size of the crowd, according to accounts from the police, performers and people in attendance.

headline: Errors Mar Initial Sales of iPhone 4
text: Apple fans who were already unhappy with AT&T, the exclusive carrier for the iPhone in the United States, got another reason to complain about it on Tuesday when Apple and its partners began taking orders for the new iPhone 4.

headline: Obama's First Oval Office Address
text: President Obama used his first Oval Office address to discuss the cleanup of the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, BP's responsibility for the accident and the development of alternative energy sources. (Video: MSNSBC)

headline: Obama Seeking New Ideas on Energy and Climate
text: June 16, 7:57 a.m. | Updated President Obama kept the focus of his first Oval Office address on the prime issue at hand — restoring public confidence in his administration’s handling of an unfolding environmental calamity triggered by corporate malfeasance and bureaucratic negligence. He did a workmanlike job, touching all the beats needed in such a speech.

headline: Finding Mirages in Brazil
text: Imagine you’re the hero in one of those old movies, desperately lost in a windswept desert, undulating dunes stretching to the horizon. Out of water, tongue parched and skin blistered, you drop to your knees. Vultures circle overhead. (O.K., maybe you’re in a comic strip, not a movie.) Yet there, in the distance, is a crystal blue pool – no, wait, dozens of them – and you push forward, fantasizing about diving in, slaking your thirst, soothing your miserably sunburned skin. It’s a mirage, of course. Dozens of perfect blue pools don’t just magically appear in the desert.

headline: Commercial Firms Fight Back in a Post-Boom World
text: After taking a battering in the severest recession in modern memory, commercial real estate brokerage firms are trying different strategies to compete in a post-boom world. Some are weighing options for infusions of capital, while others are aggressively hiring or consolidating far-flung affiliates.

headline: Afghanistan’s Civic War
text: Lt. Col. Guy Jones, commander of the 82nd Airborne Division’s Second Battalion, 508th Parachute Infantry, is on his fourth tour of Afghanistan. The first time around, in June 2002, when he was a 31-year-old company commander, his job was to find Osama bin Laden. He still has happy memories of working alongside Gul Agha Shirzai, the local strongman in Kandahar, who may have been loathed by the people but could be counted on to deliver American war materiel to anywhere in the region for only $5,000 a truckload.

headline: J.&J. Unit Under Scrutiny Recalls Additional Over-the-Counter Drugs
text: The Johnson & Johnson unit whose recall of liquid children’s Tylenol and other pediatric medicines is under Congressional investigation said on Tuesday evening that it was recalling additional over-the-counter drugs.

headline: College and Hospital Combine Forces to Revitalize Site
text: LANCASTER, Pa.  The Northwest Gateway Project has been hailed as the revitalization of a sizable chunk of this city of 55,000 in south-central Pennsylvania, yet a bird’s-eye view of it from atop a rusted pedestrian bridge seems underwhelming  a large green field with an undulating walkway lined with decorative lamp posts, an empty boulevard and a working rail yard.

headline: Phillies’ Slump Stretches to 15 Losses in 21 Games
text: Fifteen times in the last 21 games, Charlie Manuel has tried to explain why his team lost a game. The Philadelphia Phillies are sinking toward .500, a place they never expected to be after winning the last two National League pennants.

headline: Swiss Lawmakers Turn to Voters on UBS Disclosure
text: Swiss lawmakers have approved a deal to disclose the names of thousands of American clients suspected of evading taxes through accounts at a UBS bank, but whether American prosecutors get the names could now be up to Swiss voters.

headline: Fifteen Economists Issue Crisis-Prevention Manual
text: WASHINGTON  Rather than setting pay levels, the government should require banks and other critical financial institutions to withhold a share of each senior manager’s total pay for several years, a group of leading economists is urging in a new book. The money would be forfeited if the company went bankrupt or had to be bailed out.

headline: Familiar Face Leads Cuban Tournament in Honor of Capablanca
text: Vassily Ivanchuk, who has won the Capablanca Memorial three times, is leading at the half way point.

headline: A Scandinavian Hit Sets Publishers Seeking More
text: Camilla Lackberg has written seven blockbuster novels in her native Swedish but, until now, no one bothered to translate and publish any of them in the United States.

headline: Pelfrey’s Hot Start Draws Attention
text: CLEVELAND — Mets fans need no more evidence of Mike Pelfrey’s success this year than his 9-1 record and 2.39 earned run average. But there are other indications of how the rest of baseball is taking notice of his impressive work thus far.

headline: A Big, Oily Gash  in Confidence
text: Forget Greece. The biggest blow to global investor confidence right now lies 5,000 feet below the waters of the Gulf of Mexico. That may sound odd. At worst, the disaster at the Macondo well would wipe out one big company, BP; a sovereign default, on the other hand, could domino throughout stock, bond and currency markets, bringing down some of the Continent’s biggest banks and potentially breaking up the single currency.

headline: Obama Seeks to Shift Arc of Oil Crisis
text: WASHINGTON  Fifty-six days, millions of gallons of oil and countless hours of cable television second-guessing later, President Obama finally addressed the nation from the Oval Office on Tuesday night to declare war.

headline: Cost of Debt Adds to Fear About Spain
text: Spain is battling to convince skeptical investors that it can continue to service its mounting financial obligations.

headline: Lakers Stroll Into Game 7
text: LOS ANGELES  The portrait of a defending champion too stubborn to let go came in many guises Tuesday night: Pau Gasol absorbing hard fouls, and standing tall. Jordan Farmar skidding across the floor for loose balls, and winning them. And in the midst of it all, Kobe Bryant, shooting fire from his eyes and redemption from his fingertips.

headline: Bloggingheads: Hillary's Next Post?
text: Timothy Noah of Slate and James Pinkerton of Fox News discuss Hillary Clinton as the next defense secretary.

headline: S.&P. Warns of Rising Corporate Defaults
text: Standard & Poor’s is growing increasingly concerned that many companies in the United States could find it difficult to refinance their enormous debt loads in the coming years, possibly leading to an explosion of defaults and bankruptcies.

headline: U.S. Education Dept. Delays Rules on For-Profit Colleges
text: The Education Department said Tuesday that it had split off and delayed a decision on the most controversial part of proposed new student-aid regulations  the treatment of for-profit college programs whose graduates do not earn enough to repay their loans.

headline: Phys Ed: A Workout for Your Bloodstream
text: What does exercise do to your body? It may seem as if science, medicine and common sense answered that question long ago. But in fact, the precise mechanisms by which exercise alters your body — at a deep, molecular level — remain poorly understood. A number of analyses of the effect that exercise has on heart disease, for instance, have concluded that working out lessens a person’s chances of developing heart problems far more than scientists can account for. They understand the physiological reasons for about 60 percent of the reduced risk. The rest is a mysterious if welcome bonus.

headline: Experimentation in a Sonic Salon
text: Mark Stewart, an electric guitar player, musical instrument inventor and sound maker, operates a sonic salon on Rivington Street. Mr. Stewart has been the musical director for Paul Simon for close to 20 years and recently took on the role for Simon and Garfunkel. He’s a founding member of Bang On a Can, a professor at the Manhattan School of Music and one half of the duo Polygraph Lounge. Mr. Stewart talked to Ozier Muhammad for the 11th installment of “Sounds From Uncommon Spaces.” His remarks have been condensed and edited for brevity and clarity.

headline: Toys ‘R’ Us Offers a Holiday Savers Club
text: Toys “R” Us is counting on an Eisenhower-era tactic to get consumers to spend this Christmas. The toy retailer will begin offering a “Christmas Savers Club” on Wednesday that allows shoppers to put money away with the company for holiday gifts.

headline: Word of the Day | covenant
text: covenant •\ˈkəv-nənt, ˈkə-və-\• noun, verb

headline: Safety Concerns About Oil Spill Waste
text: Felicity Barringer reports on concerns about oil spill waste being dumped in Southern Louisiana.

headline: Government Bonds and the Financial Crisis
text: From Jack Ewing at Economix:

headline: Asian Stocks Climb After Wall Street Gains
text: Stock markets in the Asia-Pacific region rose on Wednesday, and the Nikkei 225 index in Japan climbed above the 10,000 mark for the first time in nearly a month, extending a rally of more than 2 percent on Wall Street overnight, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

headline: William J. Mitchell, Architect and Urban Visionary, Dies at 65
text: William J. Mitchell, an architect and urban theorist who envisioned the modern city as an electronically interconnected network of systems and who, while serving as dean of the school of architecture and planning at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, enlisted top architects to carry out an ambitious expansion of the M.I.T. campus, died Friday in Boston. He was 65 and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

headline: E. Fleischmann, Impresario of Los Angeles, Dies at 85
text: Ernest Fleischmann, the imperious impresario who ran the Los Angeles Philharmonic for nearly three decades, helping to elevate its stature to that of an orchestra of the first rank, died Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 85.

headline: Jonathan Wolken, a Founder of Pilobolus, Dies at 60
text: Jonathan Wolken, a nondancer who four decades ago helped found a dance troupe, named it after a fungus and watched gleefully as that troupe  Pilobolus Dance Theater  became one of the most popular modern-dance companies in the world, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 60 and lived in Washington, Conn.

headline: Markets Make a Run, Rising More Than 2%
text: Stocks in the United States closed higher on Tuesday, sustaining a broad-based rally that for once did not lose steam at the end of the session.

headline: News Quiz | June 16, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Cost of Debt Adds to Fear About Spain
text: Spain is battling to convince skeptical investors that it can continue to service its mounting financial obligations, Landon Thomas Jr. reports in The New York Times.

headline: Fifteen Economists Issue Crisis-Prevention Manual
text: Rather than setting pay levels, the government should require banks and other critical financial institutions to withhold a share of each senior manager’s total pay for several years, a group of leading economists is urging in a new book. The money would be forfeited if the company went bankrupt or had to be bailed out, Sewell Chan writes in The New York Times.

headline: Congress Drops Changes for Credit-Rating Agencies
text: House and Senate negotiators voted on Tuesday to strip new conflict-of-interest rules for credit rating agencies out of a sweeping overhaul of the nation’s financial regulatory system, leaving in place a process that many analysts say contributed to the proliferation of troubled mortgage-backed securities that were a cause of the 2008 financial crisis.

headline: Hong Kong Land Sale Worth $342 Million Collapses
text: Hong Kong billionaire Lee Shau-kee’s Henderson Land Development said the sale of 20 luxury apartments collapsed, ending 2.67 billion Hong Kong dollars ($342 million) in deals that sparked a government inquiry and fueled efforts to rein in home prices.

headline: Promotion Raises Questions on Deutsche’s Next Chief
text: Anshu Jain has been named sole head of investment banking at Deutsche Bank, the Frankfurt institution said Tuesday, an announcement that will fuel speculation that Mr. Jain is poised to succeed Josef Ackermann as chief executive, Jack Ewing reports in The New York Times.

headline: Oil Worse Than Greece for Slip in Confidence
text: Forget Greece. The biggest blow to global investor confidence lies 5,000 feet below the Gulf of Mexico, Breakingviews says.

headline: Radio Journalist Slain in Philippines
text: MANILA  A commentator known for scathing on-air attacks on corruption has been killed in the second fatal attack in 24 hours on a radio broadcaster in the Philippines, one of the world’s most dangerous countries for journalists.

headline: The Sirens of Sudan
text: In words and images, photographer Frédéric Noy explores the hakamas, the Arabic name for women in rural Sudan who, through chantlike song, motivate the men of their tribe to fight during times of war and maintain the social order during peacetime.

headline: I’m Mild And Soft-Spoken
text: At least compared with Adam Posen (pdf) of the Bank of England’s Monetary Policy Committee. On those claiming that the ECB has lost its purity by buying bonds to help avert economic catastrophe:

headline: With C.A.A. Deal, a Revival of an Old Buyout Rivalry?
text: The buyout kings Henry Kravis and Teddy Forstmann duked it out for nearly 30 years. Mr. Kravis outlasted Mr. Forstmann, who bowed out of active duty in 2004. Now, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts reportedly wants to invest in the Creative Artists Agency — an echo of Mr. Forstmann’s success with his swansong acquisition of IMG.

headline: Marfrig to Tap U.S. Investors as It Buys Keystone
text: Marfrig Alimentos, the Brazilian beef company, said Tuesday that it would issue American depositary receipts, opening itself up to new investors a day after it said it would buy the American meatpacker Keystone Foods for $1.26 billion.

headline: Stimulus Bond Program Has Unforeseen Costs
text: They are supposed to help states and cities that are short of cash build roads, schools and bridges.

headline: What Do You Think of Obama’s Oval Office Speech on the Oil Spill?
text: In his first speech from the Oval Office, President Obama addressed the nation about the Gulf oil spill and related energy policy issues. What do you think of what he said and what he is doing and planning to address the situation?

headline: BP Chairman Gets Moment in Spotlight
text: Carl-Henric Svanberg, the chairman of BP and a former semiprofessional ice hockey player in Sweden, could use all the protective gear he can get when he meets President Barack Obama on Wednesday to discuss the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Plan Advanced for Returning $22 Million to Lehman Creditors
text: PricewaterhouseCoopers, the European administrators for Lehman Brothers Holdings, have “avant garde” plans for returning up to $22 billion in assets to the unsecured creditors who lost out when the bank failed, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Panel Seeks Release of U.S. Lawyer in Rwanda
text: KAMPALA, Uganda  The United Nations International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda has formally requested that the Rwandan government release a jailed American lawyer who has represented genocide defendants, saying he has diplomatic immunity.

headline: The Retirement Revenue Mirage
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: How to Dress Like a Berliner
text: If you want to look like a Berliner — at least one on the cutting-edge of fashion — head straight for Mulackstrasse, a tiny, ever-hipper shopping stretch. It’s there that local designers Maria Thomas and Thoas Lindner opened their first shop for their four-year-old label BUTTERFLYSOULFIRE in December.

headline: Lawmakers Back Fund Registration
text: Private equity and hedge funds would face more oversight under a provision that lawmakers in the United States on Tuesday included in the final version of a financial-regulation bill, Reuters reported.

headline: Divisive UBS Referendum Rejected
text: The Swiss upper house on Wednesday rejected the idea of a popular referendum to decide on the UBS client data deal, putting it at loggerheads with the lower chamber and casting doubt on how Bern will keep its promises to Washington.

headline: French Rogue Trader Admits to Inventing Client
text: Former Société Générale trader Jérôme Kerviel admitted on Tuesday to creating a fake client called Matt to cover massive unauthorized bets with a broker, Reuters reported.

headline: France and Spain Proceed With Austerity Plans
text: The French government proposed a series of measures Wednesday to rein in the budget deficit, including raising the retirement age by two years and increasing income taxes on the rich, Matthew Saltmarsh reports in The New York Times.

headline: Vampires Make a Lot of Sense
text: Today’s idea: The fear of the undead climbing out of coffins “didn’t emerge out of thin air,” a writer says. Vampires are understandable from the perspective of natural history.

headline: Rangers’ Creditors Seek Vote on Bankruptcy Plan
text: Some creditors of the Texas Rangers baseball club on Tuesday sought a chance to vote on the club’s bankruptcy plan, hoping to kill the team’s proposed sale and restart the bidding process.

headline: Libya Backs London Hedge Fund, Report Says
text: The Libyan government is pouring hundreds of millions of dollars into a new hedge fund set to open in London this summer, The Independent reported.

headline: Visteon Lenders Oppose Bondholder Agreement
text: A Delaware bankruptcy judge is weighing whether to approve key financial arrangements between the auto parts supplier Visteon and bondholders who are fighting secured lenders for control of the company, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Negotiators in Congress to Discuss Rule for Brokers
text: Will stock and insurance brokers be required to put their clients’ interests before their own?

headline: Inside a Family Business: Maybe This Isn’t the Best Place for Everyone
text: In my first post about Consolidated Printing, I described a family business that is long on family — seven family members to be exact — and short on infrastructure.

headline: SpaceX Lands Satellite Deal With Iridium
text: Space Exploration Technologies, known as SpaceX, has inked a $492 million deal with Iridium Communications to launch a fleet of next-generation commercial satellites aboard its Falcon 9 rocket, The Associated Press reported.

headline: World Cup Live: Honduras vs. Chile
text: Chile established itself as an exciting team to watch, if not yet a genuine Cup contender, with a swashbuckling 1-0 victory over Honduras on Wednesday in Nelspruit, South Africa.

headline: Speed Read for Wednesday, June 16
text: Here are some highlights from Wednesday’s edition of The New York Times:

headline: Understanding the Bond Car Market
text: Ever since 1962 when James Bond made his debut on the big screen in “Dr. No,” the public has had more than a passing interest in things Bond-related: Bond girls, Bond villains and certainly Bond cars.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: The A-word, austerity, is on the march in France and Spain, which are passing measures for later retirement and a labor overhaul, but that does not solve the immediate dilemma of calming the markets, where Spain has had to pay more dearly to issue debt.  In America, a new perspective on the Build America Bonds is making some rethink how much the stimulus is costing taxpayers.

headline: Wal-Mart Invests in Green Dot
text: Wal-Mart Stores has bought itself an indirect link to commercial banking space through a deal to invest in the prepaid debit-card seller Green Dot, The Financial Times reported.

headline: The Early Word: BP’s Day at the White House
text: Carl-Henric Svanberg, BP’s chairman, is headed to the White House this morning for a meeting with President Obama.

headline: Debating Dawn’s Drop in the Bucket
text: In The New York Times on Wednesday, I report about how the dishwashing liquid Dawn has become the cleaning agent of choice for oiled birds — and as a brand, a good corporate citizen in the gulf spill.

text: Q.

text: It seems that, relatively speaking, the private equity industry hasn’t been all that kind to the Fortress Investment Group in the last five years.

text: Many things can be made out of Legos.. Now someone has used them to make a remarkable chess set. Here it is:

headline: Rules for Monitoring TB Are Tightened
text: The city’s Board of Health passed a regulation Tuesday strengthening the city’s control over the treatment and monitoring of tuberculosis patients.

headline: Army’s Hand Suspected in Kyrgyzstan
text: OSH, Kyrgyzstan  As the armored personnel carrier rumbled down the street, men in Kyrgyz military uniforms clinging to its sides, residents of an ethnic Uzbek neighborhood here felt a surge of relief. The peacekeepers, it seemed, had finally arrived.

headline: Fannie and Freddie Told to Delist
text: Shares in Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the mortgage finance companies 80 percent owned by taxpayers, plunged by nearly 40 percent after regulators told them Wednesday to delist their common and preferred shares from the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: The Safety Dance
text: When a sentence from a journal article you read years back gets lodged in your brain, the writer is probably onto something. Two sentences I can quote almost verbatim, for instance, came from Rosalie A. Kane, a gerontologist at the University of Minnesota School of Public Health and a leading teacher, researcher and thinker about aging and long-term care.
