headline: Howard on a Keeper’s Nerves: ‘I’d Like to Play Out in the Midfield’
text: IRENE, South Africa — Tim Howard is managing the pain of his bruised ribs ahead of the United States’ game Friday against Group C rival Slovenia, but there’s no cortisone shot or massage that will relieve his demons.

headline: After German Refusal, Opel Cancels Aid Requests
text: General Motors‘ Opel/Vauxhall unit, expressing frustration with the slow pace of government decision-making, said it is no longer seeking aid from European countries and will finance a planned five-year, 11 billion euro ($13.5 billion) new-product drive with help from the parent company, Jack Ewing reports in The New York Times.

headline: SBNR
text: Initialism for “Spiritual But Not Religious.”

headline: The Oil Spill Speech
text: Nobody liked it. Well, of course nobody liked it: Until the oil well stops belching crude into the Gulf of Mexico, there’s nothing that the president of the United States can say about the crisis that will make anyone feel better about it. So maybe the speech shouldn’t have been given at all — except that it had to be given, because for weeks and weeks the White House has been pilloried by the cult of the presidency’s true believers (and the occasional opportunist) for not doing enough about the spill, not talking tough enough or acting engaged enough or something, anything, whatever, just do something, Mr. President! And so the White House did what White Houses do, and especially White Houses with a lot of confidence in their occupant’s oratorical powers: They scheduled a prime-time address, and hoped for the best.

headline: ‘Not Just Another Day on the Calendar’
text: Jackie Bischof is a South African freelance writer living in Johannesburg.

headline: Opel to Go Ahead Without Government Aid
text: FRANKFURT — General Motors’ Opel/Vauxhall unit, expressing frustration with the slow pace of government decision making, said Wednesday it was no longer seeking aid from European countries and would finance a five-year, new-product drive with help from the parent company.

headline: BP Chief to Express Contrition in Remarks to Panel
text: WASHINGTON  BP’s embattled chief executive, Tony Hayward, prepared to tell Congress on Thursday that he was “deeply sorry” for the oil disaster in the Gulf of Mexico, seeking to demonstrate that he and the oil giant understood the enormity of the spill’s environmental, economic and human toll.

headline: Fannie and Freddie Told to Delist Their Stocks
text: The mortgage finance giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac were ordered to delist from the New York Stock Exchange by the federal agency that oversees the two companies, Reuters reports.

headline: Wednesday Reading: One Way to Save for Holiday Shopping
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Send Us Your Subway Rat Snapshots
text: From the safe vantage point of the platform, the subway system’s rat population, now enduring the renewed and disapproving scrutiny of the authorities, can be a wonder to behold: by turns industrious and playful, ever-curious and even — track workers, station cleaners and others are welcome to disagree on this — cute.

headline: Fallon: ‘A Snow Cone on the Beach’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: While he was in Mississippi yesterday, President Obama ate mini crab cakes, fried shrimp and shrimp salad sandwiches to show Americans that seafood from the Gulf Coast is safe to eat. And if you don’t believe Obama ate all that stuff, just ask our new president, Joe Biden. He’ll tell you.

headline: Ferguson: ‘Our Biggest Hope Is Kevin Costner’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: I’m sorry the show is on later than usual. It was delayed by the president’s speech about the gulf oil spill. Obama has been criticized for not doing enough. To be fair, he’s been using every strategy in the book. Unfortunately, it’s the same book President Bush used for Katrina.

headline: Letterman: ‘Horrible Timing’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: President Obama was in the gulf region again today, having lunch at a local seafood restaurant. Horrible timing. A clam coughed up a tarball.

headline: Designer Gains Foothold in China With a Local Partner's Help
text: HONG KONG — Next to a children’s amusement park and upstairs from two huge nightclubs in Shenzhen, the creative minds of Tecatech are at work designing remote controls, headphones and the packaging for your next set of sunglasses.

headline: Leno: ‘A Pistol and a 40-Inch Sword’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: Well, President Obama said today he’s going to use the gulf disaster to immediately push a new energy bill through Congress. I got an idea. How about first using the gulf disaster to fix the gulf disaster?

headline: World Cup Live: Spain vs. Switzerland
text: Data by Match Analysis

headline: On Our Radar: A New Minerals Chief
text: A former federal prosecutor and Iran-contra investigator is named to head the scandal-plagued Minerals Management Service.

headline: Living With Music: A Playlist by Janelle Brown
text: Janelle Brown is the author of the novels “All We Ever Wanted Was Everything” and “This Is Where We Live,” which has just been published.

headline: Case Study | The Bramble
text: Years ago, I wrote that the bramble cocktail would be the next big thing to hit these shores. I keep waiting to be right. The bramble is the riesling of the cocktail world, known by drinks weenies since seemingly forever (like, the ’80s), yet still unfamiliar to most overheated pilgrims sidling up to the bar in search of a puckery summer drink.

headline: Study Faults School Accountability System
text: Like a chief executive officer answering to his board of directors, New York City public school principals are held accountable for their bottom-line numbers — their test scores, graduation rates, and in high school, how many credits their students accumulate.

headline: Military and Pentagon Leaders Urge Patience for Afghan Mission
text: WASHINGTON  The commander of American forces in the Middle East, Gen. David H. Petraeus, returned to Capitol Hill on Wednesday to offer a full-throated endorsement of President Obama’s order to pull out of Afghanistan starting next summer, while senior Pentagon officials urged patience as troops began operations to stabilize the southern Afghan city of Kandahar.

headline: A New Publisher at Bloomberg Businessweek
text: Bloomberg continues to poach top-tier talent from rival news organizations, announcing on Wednesday that it has hired a top executive from Fortune as the publisher of Bloomberg Businessweek.

headline: New Twist in ‘Desperate Housewives’ Lawsuit

headline: Pawlenty Sets Up PACs in Iowa and N.H.

headline: Test Vote on Tax Breaks Fails in Senate
text: A Democratic effort to break a Senate impasse over a major package of tax breaks, tax increases and unemployment pay failed Wednesday morning on a test vote, forcing the leadership to begin scaling back the measure in order to win over Republicans and Democrats worried about the bill’s $140 billion cost and its impact on the national deficit.

headline: A British Fan Manufacturer Goes Where Its Customers Are
text: HONG KONG — Halifax Fan began manufacturing industrial fans in 1965; its factory in West Yorkshire, England, with fewer than 75 workers, produces heavy-duty machinery for customers like power plants, food processors and pharmaceutical makers. But in recent years, the company noticed more and more of its products were being made for use in Asia.

headline: BP Opens Second Containment System
text: BP on Wednesday began collecting crude oil from a second containment system that the company hopes will help stem the thousands of barrels escaping from their damaged well in the Gulf of Mexico, an amount that scientists said could be as high as 60,000 barrels a day.

headline: The ‘King’ Gets a Castle in Denmark
text: Elvis Presley’s Graceland estate in Memphis is being duplicated in Denmark and is set to open in 2011 as part of a Presley museum, Agence France-Presse reported. Workers laid the first brick on Tuesday in the small western town of Randers, which already has an Elvis Presley museum that opened 15 years ago and now receives around 25,000 visitors a year.

headline: Game 7, Finally

Yes, you are correct to suspect the season would not be allowed to finish until July. And yes, these teams have taken turns stinking up their respective joints, making Game 7 an inevitability. Tuesday night was the Celtics’ turn. With a championship at their fingertips, they scored a whopping 67 points and looked like a bunch of guys who just dropped in from the rec league.

headline: When Artist Becomes Muse
text: WHEN the designer Lisa Perry saw the Carl Fischer photograph of Andy Warhol drowning in a sea of soup, she immediately thought to herself, This would be a phenomenal dress. She modeled them after several paper dresses she owned, including a kooky one made by the Campbell Soup Company, a 1960s marketing gimmick that embodied the Pop Art motif of consumer culture. Ms. Perry’s dresses, which are made of cotton twill, have the same clean shape and bold graphics ($1,295; later this summer, T-shirts, $100). Ms. Perry secured the rights to the photo, which appeared on the cover of Esquire, from Mr. Fischer himself. She also secured the rights to Nat Finkelstein’s photographs of Andy Warhol and Edie Sedgwick for two other dresses. The collection will be available at the end of June and by order starting June 17

headline: And They’ll All Go Looking Good
text: BEFORE the new vintage boutique Everybody’s Going to Heaven (left) opened on the Lower East Side, the owner, Greg Armas, sat down with friends to come up what they deemed the 10 iconic pieces of the season. The list includes the usual suspects (a crisp white oxford button-down for spring) to the more esoteric (1900s French work wear). Staples like tanks, denim and hoodies are also in stock. “The concept is to be a reliable go-to retailer for better everyday pieces at cost-effective price points,” Mr. Armas said. The average price is $150, dipping down to $50 and up to $500. His first store, Assembly New York, is also on the Lower East Side and sells international and hard-to-find luxury labels alongside vintage. The new store’s name is borrowed from a Todd Rundgren song. Everybody’s Going to Heaven, 129 Rivington Street (Norfolk Street), daily noon to 9 p.m., everybodysgoingtoheaven.com.

Ms. Smith started her company in her native Buenos Aires in 2007, where the bags are designed and handcrafted. Clutches start at $300. Shoes are priced from $240 to $295. Valeria Smith, 85 Mercer Street (at Spring Street), (212) 202-1404, valeriasmith.com.ar.

Here we were, underground, being moved from stack to stack by forces we couldn’t fully understand, and had little hope of escaping from. It was like a scene from  “Metropolis,”  or  “Demolition Man,”  or  “The Mole People.”

headline: Feeling for … the Kerchief
text: In my continuing quest for alternatives to wearing a necktie during the hazy days of summer, I recently rediscovered the neckerchief. I was going to a theater opening on a recent evening and just didn’t feel like sporting my usual “tie slightly undone/white shirt open at the neck/sport jacket” combo. I rummaged through my bureau looking for who knows what, when I came across a stack of faded-print cotton bandannas (the nostalgic cowboy kind). Perfect! If the Parisians can pull off their origami-like mastery of the scarf, why can’t I give it a try? I first folded it in half to make a triangle, then rolled it up tightly, à la Fruit Roll-Up. I wrapped it snugly around my neck and tied a small, tight knot in front, tucking the ends into my shirt. I instantly felt dressier, more suitable for the special evening I had in store. Any slight apprehension I had about winning a Charles Nelson Reilly look-alike contest was quickly assuaged when I received some very nice, unexpected compliments. Since then, I’ve been on the hunt for vintage bandannas so I can give my well-worn neckties a break.

headline: ‘Last Generation?': A Response
text: The role of philosophers — and I take it, of The Stone — is to stimulate people to think about questions that they might not think about otherwise.  That so many people were roused to comment on my piece, “Should This Be the Last Generation?” — despite comments being closed at one point — suggests that it achieved this aim.  That said, it would have been good if some of those commenting had read the piece with a little more care, and all the way through.The comments show two common misunderstandings of what I was trying to do.  As an example of the first, Rob Cook of New York writes that “this piece frames overpopulation and environmental destruction in the wrong terms. It assumes that developed countries cannot cut down on consumption.”  But “Last Generation?” isn’t a piece about overpopulation or environmental destruction, and it makes no assumptions about whether developed countries can cut down on consumption.  It just isn’t about that question at all.  It asks a deeper question, one not dependent on the environmental constraints on our planet, nor on the number of people now on Earth.  Even if there were only 1 million humans on this planet, all living at the level of an average citizen of, say, Switzerland, we could still ask whether it would be a good thing to have children in order to continue the species.

text: You’ll be forgiven if the following news makes you wonder why your boss hasn’t lavished gifts on you lately.

headline: American Airlines Lets You Board Early, for a Fee
text: If you’re one of those passengers who hates waiting around until they call your seat zone number to board your flight, American Airlines has a solution for you: pay up. The carrier is offering its customers a chance to board earlier than everyone else (except priority customers) for an introductory rate of $10 each way.  The perk can be purchased alone but is also also part of a broader bundling of benefits that the carrier is calling its “Boarding and Flexibility” package. In addition to getting you on the plane a little earlier, the package offers a $75 discount off of flight changes and allows you to fly standby on an earlier flight on your day of departure at no extra charge. That package starts at an introductory rate of $9. The airline said in a release that this is the first of many customized perks that it plans to offer to travelers. Our vote for the perk we wouldn’t mind paying for: flight attendants who can help land planes.

headline: Unclogging Sewer Lines, One Alligator at a Time (Not Really)
text: Strange things can be found on New York City’s streets. Even stranger things turn up below, in the sewer system.

headline: Council Hears From Vendors and Residents on Proposed Food Truck Restrictions
text: The truck stops here.

headline: Nisipeanu, Gelfand Lead Kings Tournament
text: The local favorite and the oldest player in the field have gotten off to good starts, while Magnus Carlsen, the No. 1 seed, is stuck in neutral.

headline: WCBS-FM Regains Top Spot in New York
text: For the first time in 16 years, the oldies station WCBS-FM is the overall most popular radio station in New York City, according to the latest monthly ratings from Arbitron, capping a quick rise to the top after an equally sharp downfall.

headline: 2 New York Lawmakers Back Wall St. on Derivatives
text: Two Democratic representatives from New York City, Gary L. Ackerman and Michael E. McMahon, are coming to the defense of Wall Street, urging members of the House-Senate conference committee on the financial regulatory bill to reject provisions that would force banks to spin off their lucrative derivatives trading units.

headline: Fitzgerald ‘Case,’ Just as Curious When It’s Sung
text: The composer John Eaton’s concept of chamber opera has always been so quirky that he long ago coined the term pocket opera. Of his 20 operatic works, 12 are of the pocket variety, scored for a small cast and a small instrumental ensemble. Typically the singers play instruments, and the players do some singing and acting. Mr. Eaton, 75, a winner of a MacArthur Foundation grant, has an intriguing compositional voice that blends a microtonal harmonic idiom, elements of pastiche and quotations from popular songs, dances, marches and whatnot.

headline: City Alleges Theft by School Contractor
text: A Queens electrical contractor bilked the Department of Education of more than $1 million by submitting fraudulent invoices, falsifying payrolls and charging for work that was never completed, according to allegations released Wednesday by Richard J. Condon, the special commissioner of investigation for the city schools.

headline: The Real Marshall Mathers
text: On your new album, “Recovery,” which comes out on Monday, you assume a confessional tone and back off from the misogyny and demented violence you pushed in your earlier work. Would you agree? I think I’d have to go back and listen to it. Did I?

headline: Making Video Files Compatible, and Paying for Texts
text: Q. I’m using iMovie to make a DVD for my wife’s 50th birthday and want to include video greetings from her friends in far-flung places. I imagine they’ll use anything from DV to an iPhone to film the greetings. Do you have any suggestions for how they should send the files, and in a way that I can import and edit them?

headline: Add Government to the List of ‘Fat Cats’
text: WASHINGTON  The thrashing of BP this week, in private meetings at the White House and in public hearings on Capitol Hill, was perhaps the most direct confrontation to date between governing Democrats and a corporate behemoth, but it was hardly the first.

headline: BP: ‘We Care About the Small People’
text: My friend Jacob Weisberg at Slate did well with a line of novelty books of “Bushisms.”

headline: How I Saved My Company: Gnosis Arts
text: Like a lot of business owners, Eric Bryant of Gnosis Arts, an Internet marketing firm started in 2007, found himself struggling during the recession. He thinks his company survived only because of two counterintuitive decisions he made. To hear his story, please watch the video below.

headline: Artifacts | Art Unlimited
text: Art Basel in Switzerland is not like Art Basel in Miami. For one thing, there are twice as many people in town for the fair (more than 60,000), and few of them are American. There is way too much art that looks like other art. And the Swiss maintain a level of decorum that would seem foreign at the beach.

headline: For Whitney, Downtown Is Its Crucible
text: As expansion efforts go, the Whitney Museum of American Art’s record of futility is hard to match. Over 25 years it commissioned six expansion designs for its Upper East Side site, each of which, good or bad, ran up against a similar fate: killed in infancy by the neighborhood’s notoriously conservative community board or subjected to a drawn-out death by the board’s indecisiveness.

headline: A Best Friend? You Must Be Kidding
text: FROM the time they met in kindergarten until they were 15, Robin Shreeves and her friend Penny were inseparable. They rode bikes, played kickball in the street, swam all summer long and listened to Andy Gibb, the Bay City Rollers and Shaun Cassidy on the stereo. When they were little, they liked Barbies; when they were bigger, they hung out at the roller rink on Friday nights. They told each other secrets like which boys they thought were cute, as best friends always do.

headline: Innocence and Nerve Wrapped Into One
text: The radiance of Julia Roberts and the zany spunk of Holly Golightly: that only begins to describe the seductive charms of Sutton Foster in her irresistible cabaret show, “An Evening With Sutton Foster,” at the Café Carlyle. Directed by Mark Waldrop, it might be described as a successful Moon shot in which it discovered that the orb is really made of green cheese; that’s one small step for cosmic dairy products.

headline: A Father’s Role?
text: What makes a father? That is the question I asked in a post earlier today, and it is one that Douglas L., a management consultant in Pennsylvania, has been asking for several months now. He is a father. He became one last October when his daughter was born. The baby’s mother was a woman with whom he had what he describes as a “casual” relationship.

headline: What We’re Reading: Editing Out Vuvuzelas
text: Here are the articles that caused the New York Times tech editors and reporters to pause as they browsed the Web on Wednesday:

headline: Whitneys That Never Were
text: As Renzo Piano works to finalize his design for a new Whitney museum building in downtown Manhattan over the next several months, it’s a good moment to look back at a quarter century of efforts to expand the original museum uptown.

headline: YouTube News Feed Shows Kyrgyz Violence, French Floods and ‘Touchdown Jesus’ Ablaze
text: On Monday, Google announced a new initiative to help users, and news organizations, make better use of the 24 hours of video uploaded to YouTube every minute: the YouTube News Feed.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: ‘Star Trek’ and Critical Thinking
text: In this week’s New York Times Tech Talk podcast, J.D. Biersdorfer talks to Nancy Hill of the University of Texas at El Paso about lessons from “Star Trek.” Ms. Hill’s course for incoming freshmen – “Thinking Boldly With Star Trek” – aims to teach critical thinking, while exploring classic themes of science fiction. She says students respond to the course because the “Star Trek” theme is familiar and makes them feel comfortable.

headline: FedEx Posts $419 Million in Profit for Quarter
text: FedEx, the package delivery company, swung to a fourth-quarter profit on Wednesday and offered a conservative outlook that relied on international sales, an area that also led growth in the last three months.

headline: Nine to Know: Hard to Figure
text: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

headline: When Wayward Ball Meets an Unyielding Defense
text: Adidas has heard much mockery of its latest, most troublesome child.  The Jabulani football has attracted all manner of critics, who decry its tendency to move mysteriously in midflight. Goalkeepers have complained in training that it is a difficult customer, a diva even. As far as all members of the anti-Jabulani crowd are concerned, footballs, like children, should be as unobtrusive as possible; they must be seen and not swerved.  That may be true. What’s probable, though, is that the Jabulani just wants to be loved.

headline: Goose Shot Through Neck in Prospect Park
text: The drama never ends at Prospect Park lake. Wednesday afternoon, there was a Canada goose running around with an arrow or dart through its neck, the parks department said.

headline: A Pair of Durable Troubadours, Contrasting and Complementing
text: They were a strange pair, actually: dry and wet. He, 62, with the guarded, narrow excellence of his fingerpicking, putting his voice through a heavy soul-compressor, like Marvin Gaye in a telephone booth; she, 68, practicing generosity, singing as loudly as possible and straining at the high edges, coming down hard on her songs’ pivot-point chord changes.

headline: Shopping With Ron Gilad
text: The Brooklyn-based product designer found pieces created by New Yorkers that suited his taste for pared-down but playful products.

headline: ‘Spies of the Balkans’
text: Dying in Byzantium

headline: Cloaks and Daggers and Boudoirs in War
text: The man around whom Alan Furst’s new spy novel revolves is Constantine Zannis, a highly placed police official in Salonika, Greece. In late 1940, as “Spies of the Balkans” begins, Zannis’s specialty is discretion. He heads a new department charged with handling delicate situations. Is a politician being blackmailed by a prostitute? Call Zannis. Has a woman of some importance killed her husband and then insisted she’s glad he’s dead? “Naughty girl,” Zannis says, giving the Furst hero’s characteristic knowing shrug.

headline: Investors Worry That BP May Default on Debt
text: Credit-market investors are pricing in a 36 percent chance that BP will default on its debt within five years as it deals with the cleanup costs and damage claims from the enormous oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: A Bold Phone Fades a Bit in the Details
text: Fine print, baby. It’s all about the fine print.

headline: Murkowski Rival Grabs Tea Party Support
text: Joe Miller, who is trying to knock off Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska in a Republican primary, has won the backing of the Tea Party Express, giving him a second major endorsement this month.

headline: A Faculty Recital, With Lectures, Too
text: Like New York’s other conservatories, Mannes College the New School for Music presents performances throughout the school year. But Mannes’s concert life blossoms most fully in the summer, when it offers several tightly focused festivals associated with training sessions and master classes. The one now occupying the school’s auditorium  with a couple of concerts at Le Poisson Rouge as well  is the Institute and Festival for Contemporary Performance, a celebration of new music that opened on Tuesday evening.

headline: Between Brilliance and Rage
text: Dr. Amy Bishop had shown evidence through the years that a small slight could set off a disproportionate reaction.

headline: ‘Catio’ Enclosures Protect Cats Outside
text: New Yorkers who would never let their cats roam free outside have created special outdoor spaces at home.

headline: For the Vanderbilt’s Founders, a Rather Unlikely Grand Slam
text: Frank and Diana Schuld, who founded the Vanderbilt Bridge Club 35 years ago on Long Island, played several memorable deals together, but only one where they jumped to a grand slam with a void in the trump suit.

headline: WNET Unit Gives Up Grants to Settle Lawsuit
text: A subsidiary of the New York public broadcaster WNET.org has settled a lawsuit by agreeing to repay the United States government $950,000 and to forgo about $1 million in federal grant money that it had been awarded but not yet received. The suit, filed by the office of the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, asserted that the subsidiary, the Educational Broadcasting Corporation, failed to adequately track the spending of grant money from the National Science Foundation, the National Endowment for the Humanities and the National Endowment for the Arts. It also said that in some cases the Educational Broadcasting Corporation used money for expenses that were not allowed under terms of the grants. The grants were for the production of programs including “American Masters” and “Great Performances.” As part of the settlement, reached on Tuesday, WNET.org and the Educational Broadcasting Corporation agreed to adopt a plan to ensure compliance with federal grant requirements.

headline: Another Slam Dunk in TV Ratings Game
text: Professional basketball again boosted ABC in the ratings on Tuesday night as the Los Angeles Lakers forced the N.B.A. Finals to Game 7. Nielsen’s preliminary overnight estimates show Tuesday’s Game 6 easily topped the night as the most-watched programming in prime time, but the numbers were down slightly compared to Sunday’s broadcast of Game 5, which attracted an impressive 18.7 million viewers according to the final ratings. CBS ranked second on the night with reruns of its crime shows, while NBC was third despite gaining an audience of 10.3 million viewers at 9 p.m. for “America’s Got Talent.” Fox finished fourth.

headline: Star’s Future a Factor in ‘Bloody Bloody’ Move
text: It has been an open secret that the Public Theater is eyeing a transfer to Broadway for its critically acclaimed musical “Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson.” But the timing, if it happens, remains up in the air. The Shubert Organization has offered the Jacobs Theater, a prime piece of real estate, for the show in the fall, according to two theater executives with knowledge of the conversations. But one wrinkle is that Benjamin Walker, above, the star of the show, has been offered an enviable role in a coming “X-Men” movie, said the executives, who would speak only anonymously because they were not authorized to announce the information. It was not clear whether Mr. Walker was taking the film role, or when shooting might begin.

headline: Search for Tony Home Reaches Far Uptown
text: Where would you hold next year’s Tony Awards show? The ceremony’s usual home, Radio City Music Hall, has a sustained booking for June 2011, so the Tonys are in the hunt for a new space for the 65th-annual awards next season. There are not many places in Manhattan with Radio City’s seating capacity (roughly 6,000) and acoustics, not to mention its prime Midtown location. Sites being assessed by Tonys officials include the Beacon Theater (3,000 seats) on the Upper West Side and the Apollo Theater (1,500 seats) in Harlem. Word on the Rialto was that the Broadway Theater and the Marriott Marquis Theater have also been discussed. Also under consideration is the United Palace, a 3,000-seat theater at 175th Street and Broadway in Washington Heights. The Tonys have been held at Radio City since 1997, except for 1999, when they were at the Gershwin Theater, the current home of the musical “Wicked.”

headline: Researchers Identify Bones as Caravaggio’s
text: The remains of Caravaggio, the Baroque artist, have almost certainly been found in a Tuscan ossuary, lifting a centuries-old mystery over his burial, Reuters reported. Researchers for the National Committee for Historical, Cultural and Environmental Heritage in Italy said on Wednesday that they were confident that the bones found in the ossuary, shown above by Silvano Vicenti, president of the committee, matched those of Michelangelo Merisi, the artist known as Caravaggio. “We have carried out DNA testing on these remains and looked at the results alongside presumed relatives of Caravaggio, people with the same family name,” Giorgio Gruppioni, a physical anthropologist, told Reuters television. “We have compatibility with these genetic strands.” Theories about the artist’s death have had him succumbing to syphilis or being murdered. Caravaggio, who was 38 when he died on a beach north of Rome in 1610, pioneered chiaroscuro, the painting technique of contrasting light and dark. He was also a rogue given to brawls, chasing men and women, and even murdering a tennis foe.

headline: Talks Over Author’s Profits Break Down
text: Talks over a financial settlement between Stieg Larsson’s companion and his family have broken down, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Larsson, the author of the hugely successful Millennium thrillers died suddenly in 2004 at 50, leaving behind the manuscripts that became the trilogy. Though they were a couple for 32 years, Mr. Larsson and his companion, Eva Gabrielsson, right, never married, and because Sweden does not recognize common-law marriage Ms. Gabrielsson was not legally entitled to profits from Mr. Larsson’s books, which have sold more than 35 million copies worldwide. “The discussions which have been going on for six months between Stieg Larsson’s heirs and his former partner Eva Gabrielsson have ended,” Mr. Larsson’s father and brother said in a statement released on Tuesday. “Unfortunately she did not want to accept all or part of our proposal.” Mr. Larsson’s family has said that it offered to share with her some proceeds from the novels, which have touched off a race to find the next great Scandinavian noir writer, but that she declined. Ms. Gabrielsson does have a crucial piece of the Larsson legacy: a laptop computer containing roughly three-quarters of a fourth novel.

headline: ‘Glee’ Takes Biggest Bite of Album Sales
text: The Billboard album chart this week answered one burning question: Which are more powerful, vampires or members of a high school glee club? Turns out it’s the gleeks. “Glee: The Music, Journey to Regionals” (Columbia), a new six-song collection that is the show’s fifth release in its first season  and its third to reach No. 1  sold 152,000 copies last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. That is about 8,000 more sales than the soundtrack to “The Twilight Saga: Eclipse” (Chop Shop/Atlantic), also released last week. Also on this week’s album chart: Christina Aguilera’s new “Bionic” (RCA) is No. 3 with 110,000 sales; Jack Johnson’s “To the Sea” (Brushfire) fell three spots to No. 4, with 89,000 sales; and the Florida rapper Plies’ new album, “Goon Affiliated” (Slip-N-Slide/Atlantic), is No. 5 with 56,000.

headline: President Obama’s Gulf Speech Drew Fewer Viewers Than Other Recent Addresses
text: One in five households with television sets watched President Obama‘s Oval Office address about the gulf oil spill on Tuesday night, according to the Nielsen Company. An average of 24 million households and 32 million people tuned in to the almost 20-minute address, according to Nielsen, which counts only at-home viewing.

headline: A Midcentury Tree House
text: A California home in the redwoods where each room is designed to face the view.

headline: Kurdistan Is Urged to Ban Genital Cutting
text: SULAIMANIYA, Iraq  Human Rights Watch urged Kurdistan’s government on Wednesday to ban genital cutting of women and girls, a practice the organization said is widespread and dangerous there, but which they said Kurdish officials had failed to move aggressively to stop.

headline: Police Look Into Security After Melee at Concert
text: The police are looking into the causes of the rowdy scene at South Street Seaport in Manhattan on Tuesday night when a way-overcapacity crowd turned out for a free concert by the rapper Drake and the pop band Hanson.

headline: Pulling Museum Mile Uptown
text: SHE was sometimes by his side when William C. Thompson Jr. worked the rubber-chicken circuit last year, a poised, attractive woman in no rush to pose for the cameras, confident that her husband, the New York City comptroller, could make his own case for why he deserved to be mayor.

headline: Newly Released Books
text: Add a few more volumes to the bookshelf that holds the expanding literature of the Great Recession. This month’s protagonists watch as jobs, homes, boyfriends and opportunities disappear — and those are in the comic novels. Meanwhile, Glenn Beck delivers a conspiracy thriller with a P.R. executive as its villain.

headline: Reclaiming Causes of a Filmmaking Rebel
text: When Nicholas Ray, the pathbreaking filmmaker and director of “Rebel Without a Cause,” died from lung cancer in 1979, he left behind a substantial collection of artifacts that had never, or rarely, been seen. There is, for instance, the original typed treatment for “Rebel” with a bizarre twist that had Plato (played by Sal Mineo in the 1955 film) shoot Jim (James Dean) and commit suicide by falling on a live grenade, as well as an unfinished experimental movie, “We Can’t Go Home Again,” to which Ray devoted the last years of his life.

headline: Searching the Globe for Authentic Materials
text: Contractors and designers like Fernando Sanchez travel the world to find rare and beautiful building materials for their clients.

headline: France and Spain Act to Rein In Budgets
text: PARIS  Under pressure from anxious lenders, the French government took steps on Wednesday to help reassure markets about its creditworthiness, announcing that it would raise the retirement age and increase income taxes on the rich to help rein in its budget deficit.

headline: Tiny Moments That Tell One Small Town’s Story
text: A beguiling slice of Midwestern impressionism, “45365” drops in on the residents of Sidney, Ohio, to observe their lunches and haircuts, trials and transgressions. Filmed over nine months in 2007, this remarkable patchwork of unremarkable lives was assembled by Bill and Turner Ross, brothers, native sons and natural filmmakers. Alighting on county fair and high school football game, retirement home and voting booth, their detached, glancing gaze requires neither narration nor intertitles: the images  and the chatter of local radio  say it all.

headline: Democrats Trim Back Spending Bill
text: Hoping to break a stubborn impasse over a major spending and tax package, Senate Democrats late Wednesday unveiled a trimmed-back measure they said was paid for except for emergency unemployment compensation and state aid money.

headline: The Shadow of BP’s Stock on Capitol Hill
text: Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the  Republican leader, bought stock in BP and other oil companies last year while other lawmakers were a little more fortunate, getting rid of BP stock before the enormous oil spill caused the environmental disaster in the Gulf of Mexico, The Associated Press reports.

headline: A.I.G. Executive Won’t Be Sued
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission will not sue Joseph J. Cassano, the former head of the Financial Products unit at the American International Group, a lawyer representing him said on Wednesday.

headline: Britain Moves to Revamp Financial Regulation
text: LONDON  Britain will abolish its main financial regulator and consolidate its authority in the Bank of England, the chancellor of the Exchequer, George Osborne, said Wednesday night.

headline: U.S. and Europe Press Tighter Sanctions on Iran
text: WASHINGTON  A day after the Obama administration imposed sanctions on more than a dozen Iranian companies and individuals with links to the country’s nuclear and missile programs, the European Union followed suit on Thursday with what it called “inevitable” new measures against Tehran.

headline: S.E.C. Drops Case Against Former A.I.G. Executive
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission will not sue Joseph J. Cassano, the head of the Financial Products unit at the American International Group before the giant insurer nearly collapsed, a lawyer representing him said Wednesday,  Gretchen Morgenson of The New York Times reports.

headline: Trade Tensions With China Shadow G-20 Meeting
text: WASHINGTON  Anger toward China’s currency, trade and industrial policies has been steadily mounting in Congress, adding pressure on President Obama to take a tough stance with his Chinese counterparts at the Group of 20 leaders’ meeting next week in Toronto.

headline: Spider-Man Is Among the Most Wanted
text: MEXICO CITY  Spider-Man has successfully taken on the Green Goblin, Doctor Octopus and Venom, to name just a few of his foes over the years, but the web-spinning superhero was no match for Mexico’s federal police, who recently manhandled him and easily took him into custody.

headline: In Illinois Race, a Teaching Career Is Questioned
text: WASHINGTON  Representative Mark S. Kirk of Illinois, a Republican candidate for the United States Senate, has often reminisced about his time as a teacher.

headline: Bernhardt Design’s Pillar Chair
text: Many ultra-modern chairs look sharp but, unfortunately, they can also feel sharp. Brad Ascalon, a New York designer, addressed this by creating the Pillar chair for Bernhardt Design.

headline: Sales at ABC Carpet & Home and Others
text: During ABC Carpet & Home’s summer sale, through July 18, nearly everything in stock will be up to 75 percent off (the Hampton sofa, originally $1,895, is $1,395; the Louis console by Reeves Design, regularly $1,095, is $769; and the Tom Dixon Cage light, originally $215, is $129); 888 Broadway (19th Street), (212) 473-3000 or abchome.com.

headline: Road Test: Stain Removers
text: The Process

headline: The Pet Lamp From Foscarini and Diesel
text: Diesel’s new Pet lamp was made in collaboration with the Venetian lighting manufacturer Foscarini. It may seem like an odd fit for the denim-dominated fashion label, but Diesel has been producing furniture and lighting for two years.

headline: Looking for the ‘Made in N.Y.’ Label
text: RON GILAD, the Israeli product designer, does not see himself as a shopper. “I’m probably the last person to go shopping,” he said. “If I need something, I will make it for myself or I’ll get it from my neighbors.”

headline: ‘Catios’ Bring Cats Outdoors
text: WHEN it comes to their homes, there are few things New Yorkers prize as much as a little outdoor space — a terrace, perhaps, or a small deck in the backyard.

headline: ‘DIY Art at Home’
text: “DIY Art at Home” ($22; Watson-Guptill), by Lola Gavarry, a Paris-based textile designer and artist, is a book of do-it-yourself art — pictures of leaves, flowers and trees — that leaves nothing to chance.

headline: In California, a Midcentury House in the Redwoods
text: Mill Valley, Calif.

headline: Italian Oasis Reopens in Long Island
text: The Italian Garden at Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster Bay, N.Y., will open to the public on June 18 after an eight-year, $500,000 restoration. The sparkling pool has new tiles that replicate the originals, the camellias are blooming and Antonio Canova’s marble sculptures of scantily clad nymphs rise from pedestals in the pool.

headline: Talking With a Cooper-Hewitt Design Award Winner
text: Today, the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum announces the winners of its National Design Awards, its own Oscars. William Sofield (above right), the Princeton-educated designer who created sleek containers for Tom Ford’s Gucci juggernaut, will take the prize for interior design. Mr. Sofield’s work ranges from the thunderously sensual — like Mr. Ford’s post-Gucci emporia, which telegraph an  “Eyes Wide Shut”  men’s-club naughtiness — to a quieter, more intense exposition of luxury, as in the between-the-wars finishes on a Fifth Avenue penthouse once owned by Jackie Onassis, the dining room of which Mr. Sofield veneered with eggshell marquetry. Mr. Sofield, who has also designed retail boutiques for Bottega Veneta and Yves Saint Laurent, David Barton gyms and the SoHo Grand hotel, was asked to submit 10 projects to the Design Awards jury. He included the Studio at Laurel Canyon (above left), a Craftsman bungalow in Los Angeles he owned and restored over 10 years, which once belonged to Douglas Fairbanks.

headline: Trophy Hunters With Their Eye on Interiors
text: BRAGGING rights for homeowners are fleeting, hard to hold as a fistful of fog. You think your home is special because your backsplash is covered in tile imported from Mexico? There are those who think nothing of dispatching their architects and builders to the ends of the earth to personally scope out far more exotic goods — to the Middle East for the perfect limestone, even as bombs are going off, or to Indonesia for centuries-old reclaimed teak.

headline: At World Cup, Little Faith in France
text: DURBAN, South Africa — It never seems easy for the French at major soccer championships. Even when they won their lone World Cup — at home in 1998 — they did it with a coach, Aime Jacquet, who was heavily criticized much of the way for his supposed tactical and leadership deficiencies.

headline: Paterson Splits With No. 2 on Budget
text: ALBANY  Nearly a year ago, Gov. David A. Paterson went to court to fight for his appointment of Richard Ravitch as lieutenant governor, a man whose acumen and experience the governor said could help the state weather its financial challenges.

headline: Revis and Jets Make Nice
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Jets and the All-Pro cornerback Darrelle Revis have made peace — for now.

headline: The Chalk Table
text: The Chalk table was created by Aruliden, a New York design firm, with the sportswear company Puma, to look at home in a modern interior — so table tennis doesn’t have to be relegated to the basement. “We’ve been working with Puma on recreating iconic elements of after-hours sports,” said Rinat Aruh, a founder of Aruliden. “Everyone always does things for basketball and baseball, but there’s so much love for Ping-Pong.”

headline: Tom Stith, All-American at St. Bonaventure, Dies at 71
text: Tom Stith, a two-time all-American forward and center who brought St. Bonaventure University to national basketball prominence in the early 1960s, then overcame tuberculosis and went on to play for the Knicks for a season, died Sunday at a hospice in Melville, on Long Island. He was 71 and lived nearby in Farmingville, N.Y.

headline: When the Bases Are Loaded, the Yankees’ Preparation Pays Off
text: David Herndon is a 24-year-old right-handed reliever for the Philadelphia Phillies who, before the seventh inning Tuesday night, had 19 career appearances. He had never faced anyone on the Yankees. And yet. ...

headline: Iran Tests Iraqi Resolve at the Border
text: ALI RASH, Iraq  This remote village high in the rugged mountains along the border with Iran has been deserted, its people having fled Iranian air and artillery bombardments with everything they could carry and whatever livestock that could be coaxed down the steep mountain trails.

headline: As Defenses Start to Put on the Shift, Davis Decides to Break Out the Bunt
text: CLEVELAND  For the first time since he was in college, Ike Davis attempted a bunt Tuesday night against the Indians. Technically, it did not work because the ball went foul. Strategically, however, it worked very well.

headline: Rare Scene of Woods by Himself at Practice
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  Among the strange sites at the practice putting green Wednesday morning was Tiger Woods, alone. No caddie, no coach, no agent or press attaché. It has been a long time since Woods, the world’s No 1. golfer, has been found alone at any tournament. Once he would have been surrounded by a doting entourage that included security. On Wednesday, it was just Woods working on his game for the United States Open with a putter and four balls.

headline: Surprising the World, and Almost Brazil
text: JOHANNESBURG

headline: After Obama’s Address on the Spill
text: To the Editor:

headline: 38 Years Later, a British Apology for ‘Bloody Sunday’
text: To the Editor:

headline: With Criminal Charges, Costs to BP Could Soar
text: As BP watches its bill rise quickly for the oil spill, including $20 billion it is setting aside for claims, it could find the tally growing much faster in coming months if the United States Department of Justice files criminal charges against the company.

headline: White-Collar ‘Ulysses’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Battered by Oil
text: The Niger Delta has endured the equivalent of the Exxon Valdez spill every year for 50 years by some estimates.

headline: Climate Change Polls
text: To the Editor:

headline: Far From Gulf, a Spill Scourge 5 Decades Old
text: BODO, Nigeria  Big oil spills are no longer news in this vast, tropical land. The Niger Delta, where the wealth underground is out of all proportion with the poverty on the surface, has endured the equivalent of the Exxon Valdez spill every year for 50 years by some estimates. The oil pours out nearly every week, and some swamps are long since lifeless.

headline: World Cup Week 1 in Review: ‘The Vuvuzela Song’
text: The first week of South Africa 2010 is in the books, and thanks to Dave Henson, resident tunesmith at “BBC Radio 5 Live,” we have this review of everything important that has happened so far — sung to the tune of the Rihanna hit “Umbrella”:

headline: Smart Moves on Drilling in New York
text: It may be hard to believe, but New York’s dysfunctional state government has done one big thing right over the past three years.

headline: The Media Mogul’s Ditties
text: THERE is something unsettling about a newspaper owner suggesting that reporters spice up their articles “with a little skin.” But that was the theme of a song penned by James L. Dolan, the chief executive of Cablevision and Newsday’s owner, about a rival tabloid he said manufactures sensationalist front-page news.

headline: Braves’ Jones Says No Decision on Quitting
text: ATLANTA — Braves third baseman Chipper Jones pleaded for some patience in front of his locker Wednesday before the Braves’ game with the Rays. He created a stir Tuesday when he hinted that it might be time for him to retire after this season and hinted that only contract details and a buyout from the Braves needed to be resolved.

headline: Spill Takes Toll on Gulf Workers’ Psyches
text: NEW ORLEANS  On a normal night, Hong Le, a deckhand on a fishing boat, would be miles out on the water laying nets and lines to catch tuna. Instead, he lies awake in his rented room agonizing over the money he is not sending to his wife and children in Vietnam and the delay in his longtime dream of bringing them here, apparently dashed by the oil spill.

headline: U.N. Voices Concern on Child Soldiers in Somalia
text: HARGEISA, Somalia  As the United Nations Security Council expressed a “deep concern” on Wednesday over the continued use of child soldiers and a “readiness” to adopt sanctions against individuals who deploy them, an American lawmaker warned that the United States might have broken several laws by providing assistance to the Somali military, which uses children in conflict.

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. O’s first O.O. address. Oh.

headline: The Boring Speech Policy
text: On Monday night in Ohio, a 62-foot-tall statue of Jesus got hit by lightning and burned to the ground. (The adult bookstore across the street was unscathed.) Less than 12 hours later, Gen. David Petraeus  who is not God, although certain members of Congress have been known to worship at his altar  semifainted at a Senate Armed Services Committee hearing.

headline: City’s Former Chief Crane Inspector Goes to Prison for Taking Bribes
text: After apologizing for falsifying inspections and casting a stain upon his colleagues, the city’s former chief crane inspector began Wednesday to serve his prison sentence of two to six years for taking bribes.

headline: Day 57: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: Second Oil Containment System Is Opened

headline: Dad Will Really Like This
text: No more neckties!

headline: Push to Market Pill Stirs Debate on Sexual Desire
text: Ever since Viagra met blockbuster success in 1998, the drug industry has sought a similar pill for women.

headline: One ‘Small’ Statement Backfires on BP
text: It took just a few minutes and a few words about “small people” to undercut any brownie points that BP won by agreeing to put $20 billion into escrow to compensate victims of the Gulf of Mexico oil spill.

headline: Watson Is in a Familiar Place
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. — At this United States Open, Tom Watson is equal parts curator and competitor. He played the course a dozen times while he was a student at Stanford, made his professional debut in 1972 at the regular P.G.A. Tour stop here and has graced every Open that the course has hosted.

headline: For Ironworkers Up High, a Movable Feast
text: It will never make the Michelin Guide, but New York City’s newest restaurant is almost certainly one of the world’s most exclusive.

headline: Salutes for Graduates Who’ll Be Saluting Soon
text: PHILADELPHIA  The valedictorians stood out with their bronze medals, and the honor-society members wore turquoise stoles and decorative cords to mark their successes at Cherry Hill High School West in New Jersey.

headline: Housing Market Slows as Buyers Get Picky
text: Before the recession, people simply looked for a house to buy. Later they got squeamish just thinking about buying. Now they are on a quest for perfection at the perfect price.

headline: Administering Fund, a Master Mediator
text: WASHINGTON  Kenneth R. Feinberg bristled when reporters dubbed him the compensation czar for his Treasury Department job monitoring executive pay at companies that received government bailouts. The term, he lamented to ABC News last year, “makes it sound like I’m going to issue some imperial decree.”

headline: Review Panel Judges See a Culture of U.N. Secrecy
text: UNITED NATIONS  Independent judges appointed to revamp the way the United Nations reviews decisions on matters like hiring, firing, promotions and raises are accusing Secretary General Ban Ki-moon of shielding an unhealthy culture of secrecy and trying to undermine the new system.

headline: Divorce, No-Fault Style
text: Olympia, Wash.

headline: Professor Is Charged in ’86 Killing of Her Brother
text: BOSTON  Amy Bishop, the biology professor accused of killing three colleagues at the University of Alabama, Huntsville, this year, was indicted Wednesday in the death of her brother in 1986 at their home outside Boston.

headline: Danger Lurks at a Picturesque Course
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  The 110th United States Open begins Thursday at the Pebble Beach Golf Links, the fifth time since 1972 that the spectacular 7,054-yard layout on the Monterey Peninsula above the Pacific Ocean has hosted the world’s most demanding golf championship.

headline: BP Begins to Ante Up
text: Given the size of the disaster in the Gulf of Mexico, we suspect that $20 billion may not be enough to compensate all of the people whose lives and futures have been derailed by the spill. But it’s a good start.

headline: Blumenthal Comments Stir New Questions on Military Service
text: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut sat down with a reporter for a local news outlet this week in an effort to move beyond an issue that has bedeviled his Senate campaign: his claims about his military service during the Vietnam War.

headline: Seeing a Grandson Play in the Majors, if Not Very Clearly
text: CLEVELAND  His eyesight decimated by glaucoma, Bill Carter now sees his grandson Chris Carter from the stands as a hazy gray image swaying in the batter’s box.

headline: A Path Through Political Murk
text: The National Rifle Association has managed to carve itself a nice loophole in a bill that seeks to counter the Supreme Court’s disastrous decision to give corporations free rein to dominate American politics. We wish lawmakers had more spine, but the House still should approve the measure, which would impose disclosure mandates on the shadowy propaganda drives that will likely flood the hustings from deep-pocketed corporate, labor and special-interest groups.

headline: Sanchez, at Jets’ Minicamp, Feels the Embrace of Fans
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Mark Sanchez jogged a loop around the field at New Meadowlands Stadium on Wednesday, his penance for botching the snap count on the previous play. The fans, however, did not mind the false start: they roared as if Sanchez were taking a victory lap.

headline: Injured at New Stadium, Hixon Is Out for Season
text: In what the Giants hope is not an unsettling omen, receiver and returner Domenik Hixon injured his knee at the team’s first practice at the New Meadowlands Stadium and will miss the 2010 season.

headline: Still Waiting for Those Names
text: After UBS was caught red-handed in the United States offering tax evasion strategies, the Swiss government agreed last year to give the Internal Revenue Service the names of Americans on 4,450 accounts where their riches were secretly stashed with the bank. Swiss leaders appear determined to comply, but they are not finding it easy.

headline: Field Report: A Modern Dairy Tale
text: In Oxford, Miss., where Faulkner’s grave is a major tourist attraction, writers are heroes. (John Grisham is said to have awakened to find a couple being married on his lawn.) When the local author Larry Brown died in 2004 at age 53, he was revered in Oxford for his blunt prose and bleak tales, like those in  “Big Bad Love”  and “Fay,” as well as for his long struggle to be published while working as a firefighter.

headline: Clipper Master
text: Whimsical patterns shaved into hair are making a comeback. These are from the repertory of Rico London at Levels Unisex in East Harlem.

headline: Redoing Those ’80s ’Dos
text: IN the evolution of black barbering according to Kamal Nuru, the list of begats begins with the Fade (which some folks refer to as the Jersey).

headline: In China, Labor Movement Enabled by Technology
text: ZHONGSHAN, China  It is labor revolt by text message and video upload, underwritten by the Chinese government.

headline: Game 7 Familiar to Franchises, but Not to Players
text: LOS ANGELES  For six games, the pendulum has swung between the historic Boston Celtics and the decorated Los Angeles Lakers. Ecstasy wears green and hopelessness is dressed in gold and then, suddenly, the colors switch sides.

headline: Rising Waters
text: There’s a trick to filling sandbags. Usually one person stoops over and holds open the bag while another shovels sand into it. That is back-achingly slow and inefficient. The better way is to insert a section of pipe into the bag and shovel sand into the top of the pipe. In Fremont County, Wyo., where the Popo Agie and Little Wind Rivers are flooding, volunteers are using white irrigation pipe, the kind you see tracing the high contours in pastures and hayfields across the state.

headline: Butter
text: 1 pint best-quality cream (see note)Maldon salt. 1. Clean the bowl of a standing mixer fitted with a whisk attachment and chill. Pour in the cream and beat at medium speed for at least five minutes; it will form stiff peaks, then break and look like scrambled eggs while the buttermilk separates.

text: 6 egg yolks

text: For the peaches:

headline: Change to Divorce Law Could Recall a TV Quiz Show: ‘To Tell the Truth’
text: There are certain to be consequences if New York State introduces no-fault divorce, as now seems likely. The divorce rate might climb. Matrimonial battles will focus on bitter issues like support and child custody. The poor will be able to get divorced as easily as the rich. But there is something else. Those who are splitting up can just tell the truth.

headline: Harlem Hospital Ends Review of Unread Heart Tests
text: Harlem Hospital Center has completed an investigation of 7,000 heart tests going back five years, most of which had never been reviewed by doctors, a spokeswoman for the hospital said on Wednesday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Chris With the 1991 Hit ‘Wicked Game’
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Whodathunk the rebus word used in today’s theme would have worked so well, and provided so many examples? Or that, remarkably, the rebus squares could be arranged symmetrically? And finally, that a 15-letter entry relating to the theme could then be included in the middle? Not me.

headline: Designing Board Games Is All Play, No Work
text: Part Geppetto, part Willy Wonka, part Tom Hanks’s character in “Big,” Gaetano Michael Bisogno, 28  who goes by Mike  has a dream of a job: He’s a toy designer. He graduated from the Fashion Institute of Technology’s Toy Design program in 2008, runs his own toy company

headline: 26 Are Accused of Identity Theft
text: A Staten Island-based ring of Nigerian immigrants was charged with gaining access to the personal and financial information of at least 200 people, including active-duty members of the armed forces, and using it to steal in excess of $5 million before the scheme was stopped, officials announced on Wednesday.

headline: Knee Injury Knocks Celtics’ Perkins Out of Game 7
text: LOS ANGELES  The extra-extra-long metal crutches were designed to support Kendrick Perkins’s stride, but first they had to prop up his chin.

headline: In Utah, Execution Evokes Eras Past
text: DRAPER, Utah  The death penalty re-emerged here, behind the gray stone walls of the Utah State Prison in early 1977, in violence and blood. A murderer named Gary Mark Gilmore, famous even before the books about him, died before a five-man firing squad, ending a national moratorium on capital punishment. The law-and-order era of the 1980s and ’90s  if not quite by calendar, then by symbol and deed  had begun.

headline: A Winter Break Is Now the Longest Season in Fashion
text: A RESORT collection used to be the equivalent of staring at pictures of Bali when you lived in Kansas and the truck was broke. The clothes were for people who actually went somewhere, who made plans that included special wardrobes.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,397 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,100 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Mets’ Streaks Are in Right Direction
text: CLEVELAND  Positive streaks of various kinds have become the rage for the Mets in recent days. They have pitched well, hit and scored runs, and won.

headline: Unclogging Sewer Lines: Weird Debris, but No Alligators
text: Strange things can be found on New York City’s streets. Even stranger things turn up below, in the sewer system.

headline: Orders for the iPhone 4 Top 600,000, Apple Says
text: Apple said on Wednesday that it and its partners took more than 600,000 orders for the new iPhone 4 on Tuesday, the first day they were accepted, despite technical flaws that prevented many orders from going through.

headline: Big Budget Gap? Call In the Big Guy
text: LOS ANGELES  And on the first day without a state budget, the men and women of God gathered in prayer at the Capitol to beg that he guide the mortals in closing a gap of biblical proportions.

headline: Season Spanning
text: Looks from the Lanvin, Donna Karan, Oscar de la Renta, Diane Von Furstenberg, Michael Kors and Calvin Klein resort collections.

headline: France: Deadly Flash Floods Strike
text: At least 19 people died and several were missing after flash floods caused by torrential rain swept through southern France. In the worst-hit town, Draguignan, between Marseille and Cannes, some districts were under more than six feet of water and hundreds of vehicles had been swept away. Local officials said more than 1,200 people took refuge in schools and other government buildings, while the police evacuated more than 400 prisoners from a flooded jail.

headline: BP’s Shareholders Take It on the Chin
text: Just how big is this oil spill, really? For BP shareholders, about $88 billion big — and growing.

headline: Girl, 15, Turns Professional
text: Alexis Thompson, 15, became the youngest female golfer to turn professional, signing an endorsement agreement with Cobra-Puma Golf. Thompson will compete in her first professional event this weekend at the Shoprite L.P.G.A. Classic in Galloway, N.J. Thompson’s decision to turn pro came after she went undefeated last week in the United States’ Curtis Cup victory against Britain and Ireland.

headline: Internet File-Sharing Service Is Sued by Music Publishers
text: A coalition of eight music publishers sued the file-sharing service LimeWire on Wednesday, accusing it of copyright infringement, according to the National Music Publishers’ Association, the industry group that organized the suit.

headline: A Record-Smashing Sea Journey, and Not for Its Speed
text: ABOARD THE ANNE, off New Jersey  After 1,152 days meandering the world’s oceans on a 70-foot schooner he built himself, Reid Stowe plans to sail into New York on Thursday afternoon and claim the record for the longest sea voyage in history  eclipsing a century-old record by almost three months. But it is not ending exactly as planned.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the film “Empires of the Deep,” an effort by Chinese businessmen to establish China as a global moviemaking powerhouse, omitted a credit. Xiyun Yang contributed reporting.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: At 47 Years Old, and at 80 M.P.H., Moyer Stymies Yanks
text: After 24 seasons, 680 regular-season appearances and 16,977 batters faced, there exists a great wonder about Jamie Moyer. Not only that, at age 47, he is still pitching, however remarkable that is. More so that at 47 he can befuddle hitters  elite hitters who work in the Bronx, wear pinstripes and pummeled Roy Halladay the night before  to the point of dominance.

headline: Freshman Enrollment Climbed in 2008
text: Freshman enrollment at the nation's colleges and trade schools set records in 2008, the first year of the recession, and almost three-quarters of the increase came from minority high school graduates, especially Hispanics, seeking higher education, according to a Pew Research Center report released Wednesday. Enrollment of Hispanic freshmen at four-year and community colleges and trade schools increased 15 percent, compared with 8 percent among blacks, 6 percent among Asians and 3 percent among whites. The data was the most recent available from the Department of Education, but other government statistics suggested the trend had continued into 2009, the report said.

headline: Look for Them at the Top
text: When the wind blows across the firm fairways and small, sloping greens at Pebble Beach, good ball strikers with excellent short games will rise to the top. With that in mind, here are five golfers with a good chance to win the United States Open.

headline: World Cup Replay: Day 6, June 16
text: A view of the tournament as Switzerland defeats Spain, 1-0, and records the tournament’s first major upset. The host nation, South Africa, also lost, 3-0.

headline: Britain to Make Bank of England Its Chief Regulator
text: Britain will abolish its main financial regulator and consolidate its authority in the Bank of England, the chancellor of the Exchequer, George Osborne, said Wednesday night.

headline: Ring Pops and a Marriage Proposal Inspire Mariah Carey Fragrances
text: WHEN the singer Mariah Carey and her husband, the actor and rapper Nick Cannon, appeared on “The Oprah Winfrey Show” last September, Mr. Cannon told of how he proposed in 2008: he presented Ms. Carey with a Ring Pop, the gem-shaped lollipop on a ring. Inside the package was a proper engagement ring. Upon hearing the story, executives at Elizabeth Arden, the cosmetics company that since 2007 has sold a Mariah Carey fragrance collection, began to develop a proposal of their own.

headline: New Autoworkers Leader Hopes to Revitalize Union
text: DETROIT  As a young law student and electrician apprentice at the Ford Motor Company’s mammoth Rouge factory complex, Bob King won support from co-workers who agreed with his radical viewpoints.

headline: Cameron’s Deep-Sea Team Issues Ideas for Well
text: The deep-sea engineering experts and other specialists assembled on June 1 in Washington by the filmmaker James Cameron have issued recommendations (pdf file) for stanching the gulf gusher, undertaking an independent forensic examination of the rig wreckage and devising a fast-response system to get deep-diving submersibles to any future seabed disaster.

headline: Limited Brands to Cut Ties to The Limited
text: Limited Brands will finally shed its remaining ties to the store franchise it arose from, agreeing to sell its 25 percent stake in The Limited to the retailer’s majority owner.

headline: Thursday’s Matchups: Argentina vs. South Korea, Greece vs. Nigeria and France vs. Mexico
text: Argentina

headline: Too Many Lenses, Too Few Eyes
text: BANGKOK — For many travelers, the goal of tourism now seems as much to be recording the trip as living the experience.

headline: Fannie and Freddie Falling Off the Big Board
text: The mortgage financing giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are at last slipping into a form of obscurity. The companies will delist from the New York Stock Exchange under order of their federal watchdog. When they start trading in the penny stock market, investor attitudes may change — but the government fiction that the two are private companies almost certainly won’t.

headline: Doctors Recouped Cuts in Medicare Pay, Study Finds
text: When Congress aims to reduce Medicare spending, lawmakers often rely on cutting the prices they pay doctors and hospitals.

headline: Word of the Day | climactic
text: climactic •\kli-ˈmak-tik, klə-\• adjective

headline: E.U. Faces Shortages of Key Tech Minerals
text: The European Union is facing shortages of 14 “critical” raw materials needed for mobile phones and emerging technologies like solar panels and synthetic fuels, according to a study by the European Commission that was scheduled for release on Thursday.

headline: Limited Brands to Cut Ties to The Limited
text: Limited Brands will finally shed its remaining ties to the store franchise it arose from, agreeing to sell its 25 percent stake in The Limited to the retailer’s majority owner, Michael J. de la Merced and Stephanie Clifford report in The New York Times.

headline: Calpers Asking California for More Money
text: The board of Calpers, the biggest public pension fund in the United States, voted on Wednesday to ask California’s government for an additional $600 million in funding to bolster its finances, Reuters reported.

headline: News Quiz | June 17, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Bobby Fischer’s Body Ordered to Be Exhumed
text: Wednesday, Iceland’s Supreme Court ordered that the body of Bobby Fischer, the former champion, be disinterred to determine if he is the father of Jinky Young, a 9-year-old Philippines girl, according to a report by Agence France-Presse.

headline: Dividends Like BP’s Look Safe, Until They’re Not
text: If you own BP shares and rely on the dividends for your retirement income, you now matter less than shrimp boat owners and tourism workers in the Gulf of Mexico, Ron Lieber writes in The New York Times.

headline: Returning Home After 1,152 Days at Sea
text: Reid Stowe, a veteran sailor, is ending the longest sea voyage in history, and reuniting with his companion and a son he has never met.

headline: Zambia: AIDS Funds Blocked
text: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria said it had blocked the disbursement of $137 million to the Zambian Ministry of Health since August after finding evidence of spending the ministry could not account for.

headline: Fighting Off Distractions at the Range
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. — Space was at a premium on the practice range Wednesday morning. There were more golfers than there were designated spots, creating a scene in which golfers waited at the back of the range, staring at the players in front of them like hungry diners waiting for a table.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Mortido
text: Today’s word, in association with the valued Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: Hollywood of the East?
text: WHERE is “Empires of the Deep” being shot?

headline: LimeWire Sued by Music Publishers
text: A coalition of eight music publishers sued the file-sharing service LimeWire on Wednesday, accusing it of copyright infringement, according to the National Music Publishers’ Association, the industry group that organized the suit, The New York Times’s Joseph Plambek reported.

headline: Swiss Give Final Approval to UBS Tax Deal
text: 5:58 a.m. | Updated Swiss lawmakers Thursday overcame the last obstacle to a deal with the United States under which UBS, Switzerland’s biggest bank, will hand over account information on 4,450 suspected tax cheaters to United States authorities, David Jolly reports in The New York Times.

headline: S.E.C. Seeks Greater ‘Target Date’ Fund Disclosures
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission said on Wednesday it will propose increased disclosure in the marketing of the increasingly popular “target date” mutual funds, Reuters reported.

headline: More Than 90 Banks Miss May TARP Payments
text: More than 90 banks and thrifts in the United States missed making a May 17 payment to the federal government under its main bank bailout program, signaling a rising number of lenders are struggling to meet their obligations, Reuters reported.

headline: Reform Bill Likely to Preserve Fed Independence
text: After suffering sustained criticism of its role in the financial crisis, the Federal Reserve looked set on Wednesday to emerge from an overhaul of financial regulations with its jealously guarded independence intact, Reuters reported.

headline: Fujitsu and Toshiba to Merge Cellphone Units
text: In Japan’s second cellphone merger this month, Fujitsu and Toshiba said Thursday they will merge their handset operations, as manufacturers here regroup to take on Apple‘s increasingly popular iPhone at home as well as giants like Nokia and Samsung overseas, Hiroko Tabuchi reports in The New York Times.

headline: AOL to Sell Bebo to Criterion
text: 8:35 a.m. | Updated AOL said Thursday it will sell its Bebo social network to Criterion Capital Partners for an undisclosed sum, Reuters reported.

headline: Icahn Says Lions Gate Stake Reaches 31%
text: Carl Icahn said on Wednesday that 12.5 percent of Lions Gate Entertainment‘s shares were tendered after his $7 a share offer, effectively giving him a 31 percent stake in the studio he has criticized for being poorly managed, Reuters reported.

headline: AgBank to Introduce Shanghai I.P.O. This Week
text: Agricultural Bank of China, seeking to raise more than $23 billion in the world’s biggest initial public offering, will introduce the Shanghai portion of its I.P.O. this week, potentially stretching market liquidity and diverting funds away from rivals, Reuters reported.

headline: Tall Tales of the Pony Express
text: Today’s idea: Much of what you know about the Pony Express may be wrong, an article suggests, starting with the fact that it didn’t use ponies.

headline: F.T.C. Said to Send ‘Second Request’ on Hertz Deal
text: Car rental company Hertz Global Holdings said United States regulators sought more information on its potential acquisition of rival Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group, Reuters reported.

headline: Canadian Private Equity  Players Eye Emerging Markets
text: Canadian investors are increasingly looking for deals in emerging markets as the global economy recovers, following deep-pocketed pension funds into Asia in particular, even as valuation concerns linger, Reuters reported.

headline: BP’s Shareholders Take It on the Chin
text: Just how big is this oil spill, really? For BP shareholders, about $88 billion big — and growing, Christine Hauser reports in The New York Times.

headline: A Burst of Summitry May Backfire Against Euro
text: Are European summit meetings helping, or hurting, the euro?

headline: What’s the Most Challenging Assignment You’ve Ever Had?
text: An essay on the Op-Ed page tells the story of a program at Bell in the 1950s in which young executives were plunged into “what amounted to a complete liberal arts education” in 10 months. Many of the students – most of whom had backgrounds in technical fields like engineering – found some of the advanced material quite challenging. yet in the end they got a lot out of it. What are the hardest tasks you have had to tackle in school? How did the experience affect you?

headline: Australian Buyout Revival May Stall as Sellers Balk
text: A recovery in Australian buyouts may be curtailed as private equity firms with as much as 8 billion Australian dollars ($6.9 billion) of cash to spend grapple with reluctant sellers and scarce credit, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Why Living Wills Fail
text: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: In Paris, Hip-Hop Takes Center Stage
text: Street culture will be put in the spotlight during the Paris Hip-Hop festival, about to begin its fifth year, from June 22 to July 4. The festival (paris-hiphop.com), organized by Hip Hop Citoyens, a group that promotes the musical genre, in partnership with the city of Paris, is packed with concerts, films, workshops, roundtable discussions and block parties. Over 300 artists will be performing across more than a dozen venues.

headline: Israel to Ease Gaza Land Blockade
text: JERUSALEM — Under intense international pressure after its commandos killed nine activists aboard an aid flotilla trying to breach its blockade of Gaza last month, Israel on Thursday announced what it called “adjustments” in its policy, promising to ease the entry of civilian goods by land while maintaining its naval blockade.

headline: Nomura Said to Plan U.S. Hiring Drive
text: Nomura Holdings, Japan’s largest brokerage, may hire as many as 35 bankers in the United States this year, part of a push to become a global securities firm rivaling Goldman Sachs and Credit Suisse, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Executive Warning on Hedge Fund Ucits Boom
text: Investors clamoring for Europe-based “hedge fund lite” portfolios in the wake of the credit crisis could still be cut off from their cash in a crisis, hedge fund executives have warned, Reuters reported.

text: Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

headline: Seed Investors Return to Start-Up Hedge Funds
text: Sovereign wealth funds and pension funds are backing start-up or small hedge funds again, FRM Capital Advisors has said, bucking a trend seen since the credit crisis for clients to favor the perceived safety of big funds, Reuters reported.

headline: Legos World Cup
text: Animation | Relive the drama of the United States-England tie, re-enacted with plastic figurines:

headline: British and Swedish Premiers’ Plan to Fix Europe
text: The recently elected British prime minister, David Cameron, and his Swedish counterpart, Fredrik Reinfeldt, spelled out their uncompromising stance on the European debt crisis in a joint opinion piece for The Financial Times before their meeting at the European Union summit in Brussels on Thursday.

headline: BP Shares Rise After Deal on Cleanup Costs
text: Shares in BP made up on Thursday part of their recent losses as investors welcomed a deal struck with President Obama to set up a compensation fund for the victims of the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: The Three Tradesmen
text: Once upon a time, there were three tradesmen: a carpenter, a painter and a plumber. All three were working on the same project for a man who was known far and wide to be fair but demanding.

text: Data by Match Analysis

text: Here are some highlights from Thursday’s editions of The New York Times:

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: “Money doesn’t talk, it swears,” in the words of Mr. Dylan, the unofficial sponsor of this edition of Morning Take-Out.  It’s BP shareholders’ turn to cuss today as they see what the cleanup is doing to their stocks and dividend, but what would be the fun of equity if you couldn’t lose your shirt?

headline: Wall Street Manages a Small Gain
text: Investors made a last-minute push on Thursday that sent stocks slightly higher, overcoming new data on jobs and consumer prices that showed the pace of a recovery was likely to be modest.
