headline: Uncle Sam, Solar Landlord, Is Under Fire
text: The nation’s biggest landlord, the United States government, has set the rent it will charge developers who build solar power plants on federal land, and some prospective tenants are not happy.

headline: Nocturnalist | What Lies Beneath
text: The air over Sheepshead Bay in Brooklyn was so thick with fog on Wednesday evening that Capt. Bill Reddan steered his boat, the Jeanne II, by GPS, staring more intently at computer screens than at the monotonic mist that was starboard, port and everywhere between.

headline: The Early Word: ‘Sliced and Diced’
text: Tony Hayward, the chief executive of BP, faces an all-out grilling by House lawmakers on Capitol Hill today.

headline: AOL Sells Social Site to Investment Firm
text: AOL said on Thursday that it sold Bebo, the struggling social networking site, to Criterion Capital Partners, a private equity fund based in Los Angeles, for a fraction of what AOL paid for the site two years ago.

headline: U.S. Consumer Prices Fall on Lower Energy Costs
text: Consumer prices fell in May for the second consecutive month, largely because of the lower cost of gasoline, the government reported on Thursday.

headline: ArtsBeat Offers Free Public Relations Advice to BP
text: The chairman of BP, Carl-Henric Svanberg, found himself having to do some public relations damage control on Wednesday after his remark at the White House that his company cares “about the small people” was taken as condescending and tone-deaf.

headline: Semiconductor Provider Inphi Files for I.P.O.
text: Inphi Corporation, the semiconductor provider, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering, the company announced Thursday.

text: Data by Match Analysis

headline: Victory for WikiLeaks in Iceland’s Parliament
text: At 4 a.m. on Thursday, at the end of an all-night session, Iceland’s Parliament, the Althing, voted unanimously in favor of a package of legislation aimed at making the country a haven for freedom of expression by offering legal protection to whistle-blower Web sites like WikiLeaks, which helped to craft the proposal.

headline: Race for Oxford’s Poetry Position Now Brings Out the Verse
text: Taking a page from barb-tossing rhymers like Eminem, Lil Wayne and M.I.A. — not to mention the original diss track artist, M.C. Geoffrey Chaucer — the standing candidates for Oxford University’s professor of poetry have begun to malign each other in verse.

headline: The Concierge | The Paris Anniversary Splurge
text: Christine Muhlke, T Magazine’s food editor and de facto concierge, is at your service. Have a dining or imbibing quandary for her? Leave your question in the comments section below.

headline: How Obama and Dimon Drifted Apart
text: Jamie Dimon once was so close to the White House that The New York Times once called him “President Obama’s favorite banker.”

headline: Girardi’s Approach Is From the New School
text: It is somewhat amazing how completely the Yankees’ dynamic has changed. In another era  not that long ago, really  a highly paid pitcher’s failing to cover first base might have caused an eruption in the owner’s box. Now, it brings a pep talk from the manager on the mound.

headline: BP’s Chief Offers Answers, but Not to Liking of House Committee
text: WASHINGTON  Tony Hayward, the chief executive of BP, facing relentless questioning by Congressional Democrats on Thursday, denied any personal responsibility for the decisions that led to the calamitous oil leak in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Knight Foundation Hands Out Grants to 12 Groups, but Not WikiLeaks
text: The Knight Foundation announced on Wednesday 12 winners of its News Challenge grants, projects costing a total of $2.74 million that will use new technology to spread information in local areas. The winners included a platform for collaborating to report local news and a plan to spread virtual town halls across Vermont.

headline: Live Blogging BP’s Tony Hayward in Congress
text: On Thursday, The Lede followed testimony to the House Energy and Commerce Committee from BP’s chief executive, Tony Hayward.

headline: SAS
text: Acronym describing those who are Single, Attractive and Successful.

headline: On Our Radar: U.S. Households and the Climate Bill
text: The E.P.A. tallies the costs of the Kerry-Lieberman climate bill: for the average household, $79 to $146 per year.

headline: Before Teeing Up, Bowing to Pebble Beach
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  Ian Poulter had never been to Pebble Beach Golf Links before this week, although he had played the course numerous times on PlayStation.

headline: A Treasure Hides Downtown
text: One would think there are few places in downtown Manhattan that are truly novel or unexplored. But Nick Carr of Scouting New York found his way into one — 5 Beekman Street, practically opposite City Hall Park — and got some remarkable pictures of the building’s cavernous, palatial interior and one-of-a-kind glass roof. The sight impressed even the most jaded of seen-it-all bloggers, from Gawker to Gothamist to Curbed to Daily Intel.

headline: Thursday Reading: Paying to Board a Plane Early
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Thomas S. Buechner, Former Director of Brooklyn Museum, Dies at 83
text: Thomas S. Buechner, who led the Brooklyn Museum through an ambitious renovation as its director in the 1960s and who was the founding director of the Corning Museum of Glass, died on Sunday at his home in Corning, N.Y. He was 83.

headline: The Week Ahead: June 20 — 26
text: Art

headline: Another Weak Economic Report
text: This morning brought some more disappointing economic news. Jobless claims rose last week. They are largely unchanged over the course of 2010.

headline: Bounce in Ads Returns, but Skips Newspapers
text: They say that bad news comes in threes, but it’s really just a convenient trope that journalists use as a crutch to avoid writing an actual lead. Then again, it’s a nice way to cluster all the bad news about one’s profession so as not to dwell on it. Suffice to say that the in-box contained some signs this week that the long-running question of whether newspapers were suffering mostly from a cyclical (ads are down) or secular (ads have gone elsewhere) decline seems to have been settled. The answer is both.

headline: Ex-JPMorgan Official Joins British Bank Panel
text: From Julia Werdigier, a DealBook colleague:

headline: Security Tops the Environment in China’s Energy Plan
text: BEIJING  When President Obama called this week for a “national mission” to expand the use of clean energy and increase American energy independence, Chinese officials might have nodded knowingly.

headline: E.U. Agrees to Publish Results of Stress Tests on Biggest Banks
text: BRUSSELS — Hoping to repair shattered confidence in the health of its financial sector, the European Union agreed Thursday to publish the results of stress tests imposed on 25 major banks operating across the borders in the 27-nation bloc.

headline: Fallon: ‘A Bolt of Lightning’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: A new poll found that Hillary Clinton is now more popular than President Obama. Hillary was like, “Look, I don’t pay attention to the silly polls like that — what were the numbers exactly?”

headline: Obama Gets High Marks Abroad, Survey Finds
text: BERLIN  Struggling at home, President Obama has maintained much of his high popularity abroad after more than a year in office, a new global survey has found, receiving high marks for his handling of the economic crisis and the lowest for the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

headline: Ferguson: ‘Engulfed in Flames’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: Obama said we need a new energy strategy, one with more alternatives, like solar power. I agree. But let’s not forget about lunar power. Remember, the moon is what gives power to werewolves.

headline: Letterman: ‘Even Greater Beauty and Prosperity’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: Last night, President Barack Obama spoke from the Oval Office about his plan to clean up the oil spill. Did you folks get a chance to see it? Yeah. Well, I’m glad that problem’s behind us.

headline: Leno: ‘On Top of the Situation’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: Last night, President Obama delivered a prime time address on the oil spill. He said his administration “has been on top of the situation since Day 51.” I mean, “Day 1 .” I’m sorry.

headline: AOL Unloads Social Networking Site Bebo
text: AOL’s $164 billion acquisition of Time Warner in 2000 is widely remembered as one of the most disastrous deals in corporate history.

headline: British Directors Will Oversee Ceremonies for 2012 London Olympics
text: Short of a feel-good movie about young Scottish heroin addicts who aspire to become ballet dancers, the 2012 Summer Olympics have found a more constructive way to bring the filmmakers Danny Boyle and Stephen Daldry together. Mr. Boyle, the “Trainspotting” director (who also won an Academy Award for “Slumdog Millionaire”), and Mr. Daldry, whose films include “Billy Elliot,” will be the creative heads of the London games, The Guardian reported. At an official announcement ceremony on Thursday, the 2012 Olympic Organizing Committee said that Mr. Daldry would serve as the overall creative director of ceremonies while Mr. Boyle would be the artistic director of the opening ceremony, which is scheduled for July 27. The Guardian said that the two directors would have a budget of £40 million (about $59 million) for a total of four ceremonies during the 2012 games, presumably a little more than Mr. Daldry had to play with as director of “Billy Elliot: The Musical.” In addition to that hit production, Mr. Daldry is also developing a stage version of “Dumbo” for Disney Theatrical Productions, while Mr. Boyle is directing “Frankenstein” for Britain’s National Theater.

headline: Forget the Tote Bag; Cablevision Is Offering Free SAT Prep
text: In the latest sign of the premium that society places on an elite education, and the lengths some will go to get a leg up in securing it, Cablevision announced today that it was offering a free SAT preparation course as an incentive for people to subscribe to its Optimum service.

headline: Food Network Gets a Cruise
text: The Food Network is setting out to sea.  Starting in August, Celebrity Cruises and the Food Network are offering a “Food Network at Sea” trip, which will pair two of the Food Network’s celebrity chefs with a seven-night Caribbean journey aboard the Celebrity Solstice.

headline: World Cup 2010 | Silencing the Clappers
text: Much has been made of the vuvuzela horns, whose buzzy drone has been the soundtrack for these World Cup games being played in South Africa stadiums.

headline: A Father’s View of Infertility
text: Wanting a child makes no sense. It means signing up for sleepless nights, strained bank accounts and years of worry. Fortunately for the species, the wanting comes from a part of us that has nothing to do with common sense.

headline: New Feature: Poetry Pairings
text: It is difficultto get the news from poemsyet men die miserably every dayfor lackof what is found there.–William Carlos Williams, from “Asphodel, That Greeny Flower”

headline: Poetry Pairing | June 17, 2010
text: Welcome to the first post in our new weekly “Poetry Pairing” series.

headline: ‘A Clear Day’ Is Born Again in New Concert Production
text: Brian d’Arcy James and Anika Noni Rose will be among the stars of a reimagined — or should we say reincarnated? — version of “On a Clear Day You Can See Forever” that Michael Mayer will direct this summer at Powerhouse Theater, the Poughkeepsie collaboration between Vassar College and New York Stage and Film. The concert workshop of that Alan Jay Lerner/Burton Lane musical, whose cast will also include David Turner, Kerry O’Malley, Colin Hanlon and Sarah Stiles, will feature many changes from its stage and film versions. But what kind, exactly? Its director isn’t ready to say yet.

headline: The Choice: Forget the Tote; Cablevision Offers Free SAT Prep
text: Our sister blog The Choice is reporting that Cablevision has announced that it is offering a free SAT preparation course as an incentive for people to subscribe to its Optimum service. Cablevision has systems throughout the New York area, an epicenter of the highly selective college admissions chase. By dangling the prospect of higher test scores as a carrot for subscribers, the company has elevated SAT tutoring to a status previously occupied by such come-ons as the PBS tote bag, the Sports Illustrated fleece jacket and the Time magazine alarm clock.

headline: Bullish Signals From G.M. and Toyota
text: DETROIT  Two of the world’s largest automakers signaled confidence in the economic recovery on Thursday, with Toyota announcing it would resume construction of a long-delayed plant in Mississippi and General Motors increasing output at most of its American operations.

headline: Blind Advocates ‘Disappointed’ in Nissan E.V. Sounds for Pedestrians
text: 5:09 p.m. | Updated

headline: There’s Room on His Plate, 9/11 Mediator Says
text: Lawyers for about 10,000 ground zero rescue and cleanup workers met with their clients Wednesday evening in a town hall meeting at the Marriott Marquis hotel in Times Square to explain the terms of the new settlement of their lawsuits against New York City and its contractors.

headline: Resort Report | Bill Blass
text: The name Bill Blass is legendary in American fashion. The late designer was a champion of the tradition of American sportswear, creating clothes that were elegant but also extremely wearable. Jeffrey Monteiro is the latest young designer to be given a chance to interpret the house; resort marked his first collection. He kept it simple, channeling the spirit best with a sexy gray blazer dress.

headline: Will Premiums Be Higher for Adult Children?
text: Q.

headline: A Converted Barn
text: A look at a one-bedroom, two-story converted barn in Bucks County, Pa.

headline: Chanos Is Shorting Oil Firms — but Not BP
text: James Chanos, the well-known short-seller, has never been timid about sharing his current stock bets. In an interview with Bloomberg Television, the hedge fund manager says that he’s betting against several big oil producers.

headline: Rethinking the Way We Rank Medical Schools
text: During my internship, the first year after graduating from medical school, I took care of a middle-aged woman who began our first conversation with a question that patients still ask me today.

headline: Redefining ‘the Best’ Medical Schools
text: It’s impossible to wait in a grocery checkout line or walk by a newsstand without coming to the conclusion that Americans like ranking things, prioritizing everything from colleges and restaurants to lotions and belly-flattening foods. These rankings can make quick work of complicated decision-making, allowing individuals to sift through a myriad of options while assuring them of the best value for their time or dollar.

headline: Former Artisanal Workers Sue Over Tips
text: Terrance Brennan’s Artisanal Fromagerie, Bistro and Wine Bar is the latest restaurant to face a lawsuit over the way tips are appropriated.

headline: Racing Along the Park With JPMorgan Chase
text: Wall Street strapped on its running shoes Wednesday night for the 34th annual JPMorgan Chase Corporate Challenge in New York. The two-day event, which continues on Thursday night, pits companies in a 3.5-mile dash around Central Park in order to claim bragging rights and prizes for fastest time and best company T-shirt.

headline: Mandela Attends Relative’s Funeral
text: JOHANNESBURG  Nelson Mandela attended funeral services on Thursday for his 13-year-old great-granddaughter, whose death in a car accident on June 11 brought a somber start to the monthlong World Cup.

headline: Iraqi Sunni Leader and His Family Are Killed in an Ambush
text: BAGHDAD  Gunmen with automatic weapons stormed a house outside Falluja on Thursday, killing an Awakening Council member, his wife and three of his children who had all been sleeping in the backyard to escape the summer heat, the authorities said.

headline: N.Y.U. Shows Plan for Addition to Pei’s Towers
text: The controversial 38-story tower that New York University seeks to add to its University Village site in Greenwich Village would be made of concrete with floor-to-ceiling glass windows on the Bleecker Street side, according to plans made public Thursday by N.Y.U.

headline: Q&A: To London With an 8-Year-Old
text: Q.

headline: A Steady Voice on Jazz and Politics, Still Going Strong
text: Nat Hentoff hasn’t retired yet and he probably never will. Mr. Hentoff, the columnist, preeminent jazz critic, prolific liner-notes writer, civil liberties activist and constitutional scholar who turned 85 last Thursday, recently published his 35th book, “At the Jazz Band Ball: Sixty Years on the Jazz Scene” (University of California Press), and has plans for several more. Having endured more masthead changes than United States presidents, Mr. Hentoff, a self-declared “Jewish atheist civil-libertarian pro-lifer,” hasn’t lost his sense of rage.

headline: A Circle of Comfort in Baghdad
text: KARADA, Baghdad — At times of crisis people resort to religion, especially the most vulnerable. A holy place among the alleyways of Iraq’s capital, the Sayyed Idrees shrine is a spiritual gathering place where women take comfort and encouragement. It may be among the few public locations in the city where women outnumber men.

headline: The ‘Me’ Generation?
text: Christian Smith is the Notre Dame sociologist whose last book, a study of religion among American youth, coined the extremely-useful phrase “moralistic therapeutic deism” to describe the theological inclinations of American teenagers. Now he’s tackling the faith lives of twentysomethings, with “Souls in Transition: The Religious and Spiritual Lives of Emerging Adults,” co-written with Patricia Snell. Alan Jacobs is reading it, and offers this quote as grist for the great “whither the millennial generation” debate:

headline: BP’s Tony Hayward Testifies Before House Panel
text: Tony Hayward, BP’s chief executive, is testifying before a House committee today about the energy giant’s response to the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. Check out live blogging of the hearing on our sib-blog, The Lede.

headline: White House Throws the Shame Word Back at Barton
text: The White House has just piled on with environmentalists, Democratic activists, bloggers and just plain folks in expressing outrage that Representative Joe L. Barton, Republican of Texas, has expressed his personal shame over what he called “a $20 billion shakedown” by the Obama administration and “a tragedy.”

headline: It’s All Tutu Much: McCartney Writing Ballet Music
text: Sorry, Sting, but it sounds like Paul McCartney has just lapped you in the race to be the pop musician with the most classical bona fides. Mr. McCartney, the former Beatle and Wings man whose orchestral works include “Standing Stone” and “Ecce Cor Meum,” told BBC News that he has agreed to write the music for a ballet and has already started work on the project. “I’m interested in doing things I haven’t done before,” Mr. McCartney said to the BBC. “That offer came up and I love writing music, the two went together and I said, ‘Yeah,’ so I just accept things before I even know what I’m doing.” Mr. McCartney did not say who the music was being written for or when it might be performed, but he acknowledged that it was an unusual excursion, even for someone who has ridden shotgun in a yellow submarine, designed his own postage stamps and been recorded eating vegetables by both the Beach Boys and Super Furry Animals. “I don’t really know that much about it yet,” Mr. McCartney said. “I’m just writing music for it, but it’s a switch.”

headline: Maradona Starts the Attack, and Messi Keeps Driving It
text: JOHANNESBURG  Nearly a quarter-century later, an old antagonism was renewed Thursday. The two men had been opposing players in a long-ago World Cup. Now they were coaches in suits and shined shoes instead of jerseys and cleats.

headline: Few Low Scores, and Less Logic, at Pebble Beach
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  It was pretty much an upside-down opening round of the United States Open on Thursday at the Pebble Beach Golf Links. Early starters struggled in benign conditions, late starters flourished on treacherous afternoon greens, and lesser lights outshone most of the game’s biggest stars as the sun slipped beneath the horizon.

headline: Resort Report | Celine
text: According to the show notes, Phoebe Philo of Celine was inspired by the ’70s, the ’90s, dapper dandy day wear, Hollywood hippie and shaman evening wear. This translated into a great micro-heart print on a fan-pleated, below-the-knee silk dress, a striped cotton poncho (like one you might buy in Mexico but wear in Topanga Canyon) and a continuation of Philo’s signature clean and super-sophisticated silhouette. The horse leather collar on a silk halter dress and the contrasting color stitching on a men’s style V-neck cashmere sweater were all the details that were needed.

headline: TimesCast | June 17, 2010
text: In today's Timescast, reports on how BP's costs could soar, a town divided over undocumented workers and from the Congo Republic, Op-Ed columnist Nicholas Kristof on some men's bad spending choices.

headline: On Refusing to Disclose Your Salary in a Job Interview
text: In response to Wednesday’s Bucks post, “On Lying About Your Salary in Job Interviews,” about whether it’s ethical to inflate your current salary during a job interview, many readers recommended refusing to disclose your salary in the first place. After all, by disclosing your salary, you may be hurting your chances for a big pay increase.
