headline: Ticket Prices for Game 7 Head Toward Rafters
text: Attending Game 7 of the N.B.A. finals on Thursday night at Staples Center may require raiding the savings account.

headline: Ramirez Explored Drug-Policy Exemption
text: Around the time Major League Baseball suspended Manny Ramirez for violating its drug program last season, his representatives told officials in the commissioner’s office that they planned to file for permission to use a banned drug that would boost his testosterone levels.

headline: Director for ‘The Octoroon’ Withdraws
text: The director Gavin Quinn, a co-founder of the acclaimed Irish theater troupe Pan Pan, has withdrawn from the coming Off Broadway production of “The Octoroon: An Adaptation of The Octoroon Based on The Octoroon” after creative disagreements with the play’s author, Branden Jacobs-Jenkins.

headline: Boehner Holds Barton at Arm’s Length
text: The White House is far from alone in disagreeing with Representative Joe L. Barton, the Texas Republican who said he was ashamed at the White House’s handling of BP.

headline: Let the (Smaller) Crooks Alone
text: It appears that the Congress is going to repeal the law that requires most public companies to have adequate financial controls, and to get that fact certified by auditors.

headline: Goose With Arrow in Neck Still Evades Capture
text: Updated, 6:18 p.m. | A goose with a nine-inch arrow through its neck would seem to be a severely compromised animal.

headline: Sealing Deals in Virtual Space
text: If I tell you I’m about to talk about video conferencing, many of you will want to click “next.” I know: you’re thinking, that’s so 1964 World’s Fair.

headline: Stage Scenes: Paul Sparks
text: Photos from some of the actor's performances.

headline: Voyage to the Bottom of the Day Care Center
text: “Toy Story 3” begins with a rattling, exuberant set piece that has nothing to do with the tale that follows but that nonetheless sums up the ingenuity, and some of the paradoxes, that have made this Pixar franchise so marvelous and so successful. The major toys  Woody (Tom Hanks), Buzz (Tim Allen), the Potato Heads (Don Rickles and Estelle Harris), Hamm (John Ratzenberger), Jessie (Joan Cusack), Rex (Wallace Shawn) and the others  are in a setting at once wholly unfamiliar and instantly recognizable. They’re in a western, albeit one made in the amped-up modern action style, rather than the more stately idiom of old-time oaters. A train is hurtling down the tracks; a bridge explodes; stuff is falling out of the sky. There are force fields and laser beams and a big noisy surprise every time you blink.

headline: A New Home for African Art
text: Images from the Museum for African Art, which is set to open next spring.

headline: World Cup Live: France vs. Mexico
text: Data by Match Analysis

headline: In the Senate, Seersuckers Seldom Seen
text: Even on the annual “Seersucker Thursday” in the Senate, the lighter suits that were once a summertime standard were hardly the uniform of the day, although more than a few were sported by lawmakers and staff members alike.

headline: Pete Peterson and the Deficit
text: Some commentators have vilified Peter Peterson, the investor and former Commerce secretary, for raising alarms about the deficit. They argue that Mr. Peterson is really trying to shred the American safety net. I’m not among the vilifiers. We should be taking the deficit more seriously, and Mr. Peterson is trying to make that happen.

headline: Europe to Disclose Results of Bank Stress Tests
text: The European Union agreed on Thursday to publish the results of stress tests imposed on big cross-border banks, a move aimed at restoring confidence in the health of Europe’s financial sector, Stephen Castle and Jack Ewing of The New York Times report.

headline: Books Over Beer
text: Reporting from the Democratic Republic of Congo, Nicholas D. Kristof asks why some men spend more on beer than on their children's education.

headline: Popcast: Drake, Devo and More
text: This week: Jon Caramanica discusses Drake, the former child actor shaking up hip-hop; Ben Ratliff reviews Devo’s first album in 20 years; and the Los Angeles band Chief plays live in the studio. Ben Sisario is the host.

headline: Study Criticizes Swine-Flu Follow-Up
text: There is too little genetic surveillance of last year’s human pandemic flu, which has gone on to infect pigs in China and is readily mixing with other flus there, according to a study released Thursday by researchers in Hong Kong.

headline: Expert Answers on Pancreatic Cancer Treatment
text: Pancreatic cancer will be diagnosed in about 42,000 Americans this year, and some 35,000 will die of it. What can be done to treat pancreatic cancer, or prevent recurrences after treatment? Readers recently posted questions about pancreatic cancer treatment and prevention on the Consults blog. Here, Dr. Eileen O’Reilly of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York responds.

headline: The Earrings? Not for Sale. Funzy Said So.
text: There’s a pair of rhinestone and silver chandelier earrings resting on a shelf amid hundreds of other baubles, bangles, pins and pendants in Alfred Albrizio’s jewelry store in Greenwich Village. But if a customer asks to see them, Mr. Albrizio mumbles a demurral: Why not choose something else? Just not that trinket carved from fossilized ivory; oh, and not that necklace of amethyst tiles.

headline: Is Verizon Wireless Making It Harder to Avoid Charges?
text: As longtime readers know, I think the cellphone industry is one step away from a big-city mugger. Some of their practices are outrageous ripoffs-like how they charge so much for text messages (both the sender and the receiver), even though text messages cost them nothing. Or how the purpose of two-year contract is to sell you an expensive phone cheaply, on the premise that you'll pay it off over the next 24 months -- but once you've paid off the phone, your monthly bill doesn't go down. (Except at T-Mobile.)

headline: What We’re Reading: Free Checking
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Two Favorites Are Tied for Lead of Dutch Championship
text: Anish Giri, the 2009 champion, and Jan Smeets, the 2008 champion, lead with three rounds to play.

headline: Obscure But Powerful Agency Gets New Leader
text: It’s an obscure city agency with a big stick. And now it has a new leader.

headline: Resort Report | Marc Jacobs
text: Marc Jacobs went to St. Tropez for resort. Instead of the modern-day decadence and nearly naked look typical of this locale, these clothes were more innocent. There was a playful ’60s feel with youthful silhouettes in sweet pastels and prints featuring scalloped edges. Polka dots popped up often for a chic and upbeat mood. Feminine short dresses had nipped waists with fuller skirts – some with a volume of peplum in the back. There was still plenty of skin, with most hemlines landing well above the knee, and bandeau tops galore. These wraparound tops — done in most of the collection’s fabrics — could be paired with matching briefs at the pool or under a little tweed suit.

headline: Justices Allow Search of Work-Issued Pager
text: WASHINGTON  A California police department did not violate the constitutional privacy rights of an employee when it audited the text messages on a pager the city had issued him, the Supreme Court unanimously ruled on Thursday.

headline: The Growing Push to Impose a Transaction Tax
text: Among the hot button issues that Wall Street will be following closely next week at the Group of 20 economic summit meeting in Toronto is the idea of imposing a worldwide tax on financial transactions. The move, championed by the Europeans, is aimed at curbing excess speculation and building revenue.

headline: Sexsomnia
text: A sleep disorder which apparently causes sufferers to engage in sexual activities while sleeping.

headline: Jobs Growth Continues in May, as Unemployment Rate Falls
text: New York City’s unemployment rate fell again in May, remaining below the national unemployment rate for the second month in a row, according to data released on Thursday by the State Labor Department.

headline: On a Wing and a Prayer: Chevron’s Deep Well
text: One of the deepest offshore oil fields in the Gulf of Mexico lies beneath 7,000 feet of water and under more than 20,000 feet of rock and sand. Estimated to hold as much as 100 million barrels of crude, the field was discovered by Chevron in 2001, and production began in 2008. It is less than 20 miles west of the Deepwater Horizon blowout.

headline: Resort Report | Givenchy
text: A modern-day Frido Kahlo was the muse for Givenchy. Riccardo Tisci spoke of a lightness and sensuality in the clothing, with a mixture of masculine and feminine and a larger focus on cocktail and evening looks. Lace was worked into more tailored pieces in blocks of black, white and red, while a new leopard print felt cool. The more feminine pieces were grounded with a sturdy shoe done with a new shorter heel.

headline: Apps to Make Your Guitar Gently Weep
text: Electric guitarists can get a little carried away with their gear – especially effects pedals (a k a stompboxes), amps and cabinets.

headline: Sarbanes-Oxley Gains Some Acceptance, Survey Finds
text: It has been nearly eight years since the Sarbanes-Oxley Act was signed into law. And ever since, its worth has been the subject of hot debate by the chattering classes.

headline: The Earrings? Not for Sale. Nor the Comb.
text: There’s a pair of rhinestone and silver chandelier earrings resting on a shelf amid hundreds of other baubles, bangles, pins and pendants in Alfred Albrizio’s jewelry store in Greenwich Village. But if a customer asks to see them, Mr. Albrizio mumbles a demurral: Why not choose something else? Just not that trinket carved from fossilized ivory; oh, and not that necklace of amethyst tiles.

headline: Status of Written Confirmations From Comcast
text: In a January Bucks post, “Why You Can Get Written Confirmation From Comcast,” we described the crusade of Marc Pachtman, a lawyer in Boothwyn, Pa., to get Comcast to provide written confirmations of what was agreed to on customer service calls.

headline: F.C.C. Moves to Expand Role in Broadband
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Communications Commission voted 3 to 2 on Thursday to move toward giving itself the authority to regulate the transmission component of broadband Internet service, a power the commission’s majority believes is central to expanding the availability of broadband.

headline: Afghanistan Moves Quickly to Tap Newfound Mineral Reserves
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Ministry of Mines announced Thursday that it would take the first steps toward opening the country’s reserves to international investors at a meeting next week in London even as Afghans expressed a mixture of hope and doubt about the government’s commitment to develop the country’s newly documented mineral wealth.

headline: The Morning Skate: Devils Name MacLean Coach, Trade Rumors Fly
text: Hockey really doesn’t have an off-season. It’s just that games are not played. But the news never stops.

headline: Photo of the Week
text: A surfer jumps into the sea from the beach in Durban.

headline: Barton: What I Meant to Say
text: From the hearing room, John Broder updates with Rep. Joe L. Barton revising and extending his remarks about BP’s liability fund, as follows:

headline: Artifacts | Worshiping at Basel’s Altar
text: Art Basel isn’t just an international marketplace for modern and contemporary art. It’s a mindset for both creative types and wealthy spark plugs seeking intellectual stimulation, visual pleasure and fellowship. Especially fellowship.

headline: Fashion Spawn for Sale
text: In the late 1990s, Cecilia Pagkalinawan had a business advising fashion labels about selling their stuff online. There were actually some people who knew what she was talking about, although there wasn’t really a market. Then came the dot-com bust, and Ms. Pagkalinawan closed her business and went to work for Burberry in London and later Frette and La Perla, developing e-commerce.

headline: Who Needs a Mirror When You Have a Cellphone?
text: The mobile phone, the Swiss Army knife of the digital generation, has already left a trail of lifeless gadgetry in its path. Many phone owners no longer carry around point-and-shoot cameras, video cameras, music players, notepads or their old sturdy Filofax. Instead, they choose a single-serving device: the smartphone.

headline: Higher Prices = Less Soda Drinking
text: The American Journal of Public Health released a study this afternoon finding that when the price of soda goes up, consumption goes down. From the news release:

headline: Answers From a Court Reporter, Part 2
text: We are no longer accepting questions for this feature.

headline: U.S. and Europe Press Tighter Sanctions on Iran
text: WASHINGTON  A day after the Obama administration imposed sanctions on more than a dozen Iranian companies and individuals with links to the country’s nuclear and missile programs, the European Union followed suit on Thursday with what it called “inevitable” new measures against Tehran.

headline: Appeals Court Judge Is Sworn In
text: Judge Denny Chin was sworn in to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit on Wednesday, becoming the only Asian-American to fill an active judgeship on a United States Court of Appeals.

headline: Little Slovenia Is Ready for the U.S.
text: What has 305 million people fewer people than the United States but could still knock the Americans out of the World Cup?

headline: God and the Political Romantic
text: Like most English-speaking scribes, I’ve spent the last few weeks dipping in and out of Christopher Hitchens’ memoir, “Hitch-22.” Of all the reviews to date, David Runciman’s essay in the London Review of Books seems to me to cut closest to the heart of Hitch. This part, in particular:

headline: Pictures of the Day: Capitol Hill and Elsewhere
text: Lawmakers grilling Tony Hayward, the chief executive of BP, grew frustrated on Thursday when he repeatedly sidestepped their questions, saying he was unaware of engineering decisions before the oil disaster in the Gulf of Mexico and refusing to speculate about what investigators would discover about its causes. John M. Broder and Liz Robbins report that even as Mr. Hayward apologized for a catastrophe that “never should have happened,” he offered few specifics about why.

headline: Along Lafayette Street, Some Very Odd Lots
text: THE three blocks of Lafayette Street from Houston to Great Jones are mostly an ugly scar, still raw from the ruthless clear-cutting that created it a century ago. As the most recent surge of development sweeps over NoHo, Lafayette’s ragged edges are softening, but this unusual strip will always have an awkward limp.

headline: Starbucks Hopes There Is No Java Jive From Contest Results
text: The next time you visit your local Starbucks and there is a big crowd keeping you from ordering a cup of coffee as fast as you would like, consider this: someone in that crowd may have contributed an idea to cutting down on cup waste.

headline: Bronx Up, Battery Down; It’s Your Sense of Direction
text: Midtown is a grid and it’s easy to figure out where you are, but Wall Street’s a different story, and so is the West Village. It helps to have a sense of direction in the city. But are we born with that sense, or do enough visits to the corner of Stone and Broad Streets teach us?

headline: Theater Listings: June 18 — 24
text: Theater

headline: Helping Dads Become More Fatherly
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Thursday announced a broad initiative to help fathers become more active and productive members of their families.

headline: Not So Sinister in Stockholm
text: THERE’S nothing particularly remarkable about the mustard-colored building at Bellmansgatan 1, in Stockholm’s Sodermalm neighborhood. But that doesn’t stop tourists from taking photos of the place.

headline: The Sprint Evo 4G Phone
text: The Evo 4G seems wonderful at first, but it has some significant drawbacks.

headline: A Culinary Tour Through Monrovia
text: In the Liberian capital, Southern cooking takes on a coastal African twist.

headline: A Liberian Tour With Fork (and Fingers)
text: I KNEW my plan to spend my recent trip home eating my way around Monrovia was off to a good start when my sister showed up at the airport to greet me accompanied by a pot of bitterleaf over doughy fufu.

headline: Tips for June Gardens
text: How to help annuals and perennials thrive through summer.

headline: ‘The Ninth’
text: “The latest news in Vienna”

headline: A Musical Battle Flag, Waved by All Sides
text: For generations Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony, with its choral finale espousing universal brotherhood, has been the work of choice to solemnize a peace treaty, open a new concert hall or foster communal bonding. Leonard Bernstein conducted the Ninth at an indoor concert in Berlin to celebrate the fall of the Berlin Wall. Then again it was conducted profoundly by the great Wilhelm Furtwängler in Nazi Germany, leading orchestras and choruses purged of Jews.

headline: S.&P. Cuts BP Ratings, Citing Liabilities and Politics
text: Standard & Poor’s cut its credit ratings for BP on Thursday afternoon and warned that it might downgrade its ratings again because of the growing liabilities from the enormous oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. It also said that BP faced “intense political pressure” in the United States.

headline: Deep in the Carpathians, Painted Parables
text: WHEN the Moldavian prince Stephen the Great won his first decisive victory against the Turks five and a quarter centuries ago, he decided to mark the occasion with a grand monastery and adorn its walls with the colorful work of artisans of the day. With his second victory came another monastery. With the third, yet another.

headline: Avant-Gardist in Retreat
text: PHILADELPHIA — What to think of the art of Pierre-Auguste Renoir?

headline: ‘Late Renoir’
text: Images from a new exhibit at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

headline: Miami Art Museum Names New Director
text: The Miami Art Museum has named Thomas Collins, currently the director of the Neuberger Museum of Art in Purchase, N.Y., as its new director, effective Aug. 16, the museum said on Thursday. The Miami museum has been without a permanent director since Terence Riley, the former chief curator of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art, resigned abruptly in October after less than four years in the post. The museum is planning to break ground later this year on a new $131 million building designed by the firm Herzog & de Meuron, which is scheduled to open in 2013.

headline: Keeping the June Garden Colorful
text: This is another in a series of articles on the maintenance and development of a flower garden. Previous articles can be found here and here.

headline: Barton: What I Really Meant to Say
text: Representative Joe L. Barton on Thursday quickly backpedaled, and then recanted, the remarks he made about BP’s liability fund that had caused an immediate uproar from Democrats and Republicans  alike. At last count, Mr. Barton, Republican of Texas, retracted the apology he gave the energy giant during the House hearing earlier in the day, where he criticized the $20 billion fund created to help those affected by the Gulf of Mexico oil spill.

headline: The Food of ‘I Am Love’
text: A look at some of the dishes that appear in the film.

headline: Beyond Masks of Human ‘Multiplicity’
text: In program notes for “Cloak,” which had its premiere Wednesday night at the Baryshnikov Arts Center, the Montreal choreographer George Stamos invokes Oscar Wilde and Leigh Bowery. Both men had marvelously intense, complicated identities, so it makes sense that they would be named in a work “inspired by the multiplicity of self that is in all of us.”

headline: Andy Warhol, Outside His Comfort Zones
text: In the 10 years before his sudden death at 58 in 1987 Andy Warhol had more new, good ideas about making paintings than he knew what to do with. But he rarely let on.

headline: MySpace Co-President Leaving Company
text: Updated: 5:28 p.m.: Barely four months after becoming a co-president of MySpace, Jason Hirschhorn is leaving the company.

headline: Where Families Learn Sailing  Basics
text: THE sun cast a dreamy orange glow as it settled toward the horizon, and a parade of pristine sailboats began slipping back into the marina at Liberty State Park after a spin around New York Harbor. The Gonzalez family of Chatham, N.J., was on one of those boats, and Tony and Maryury Gonzalez and their three children were more than just passengers.

headline: Canadiens Trade Halak to St. Louis
text: One of the big stars of the just concluded Stanley Cup playoffs has been traded.

headline: The Buzz in Basel: Art, Alive and Well and Selling Briskly
text: BASEL, Switzerland — Minutes after a limestone head by Modigliani sold for $52.6 million at a Christie’s auction in Paris on Monday, word spread to the collectors arriving here for the annual art fair. And everyone wanted the details.

headline: Coming-Out Conversations, Moderated With Pride
text: SAME-SEX marriage, religion, sex toys, Botox: no topic is taboo at “Qtalk.” Fitting for a live talk show that boldly embraces complex subjects, the Gay Pride Month edition, on Saturday night at 9:45 at the Metropolitan Room, will tackle an issue that is central to gays and lesbians: coming out.

headline: Federal Officials Continue AT&T iPad Investigation
text: 4:05 p.m. | Updated Adding more about the controversy over the threat posed by exposed ICC-ID numbers. 10:45pm | Updated Amended statement from AT&T.

headline: Resort Report | Proenza Schouler
text: A few weeks in India was all it took for the Proenza Schouler designers to add some glint to their chic-beach-bum-in-the-city resort hits. The puckered, gold-flecked fabrics looked rich and cool when mixed with their signature tie-dyes and relaxed cottons. The combination of day and evening fabrics felt easy and fresh. Baby-doll tops, dresses and skirts wrapped and tied in front like a sari. They introduced adorable Baja ponchos in orange and green stripes, and also used the fabric for shorts and relaxed pants that girls will want to live in when on holiday.

headline: Suspect in Failed Times Square Car Bombing Is Indicted
text: Updated 5:46 p.m. | Faisal Shahzad, the Pakistani immigrant charged in the failed Times Square bombing plot, was indicted on Thursday by a federal grand jury in Manhattan, prosecutors said.

headline: House Tour: Erwinna, Pa.
text: WHAT A one-bedroom converted barn.

headline: Author’s Brooklyn Town House Gets a Price Trim
text: The Brooklyn Heights town house of the children’s author Karla Kuskin, who died last year, recently got a price reduction, and is listed for $3.4 million.

headline: Magical Thinking at the ECB
text: And the march to a lost decade continues. In its latest Monthly Bulletin (pdf) , the European Central Bank goes all in for immediate fiscal austerity. It justifies this by buying in, wholeheartedly, to the notion that fiscal contraction is actually expansionary. As evidence, it points to … well, things I’ve already debunked: the allegedly expansionary Irish fiscal contraction of the 1980s that was probably largely about devaluation and falling interest rates, the Alesina-Ardagna study that makes no effort to distinguish between liquidity-trap and non-trap episodes (and whose method for identifying fiscal stimulus doesn’t seem to capture actual policy.)

headline: Deal Near on Student Transit Fares
text: Students will likely keep the discounted transit fares they pay to ride New York City’s buses and subways, as state legislators neared an agreement on Thursday to save a service that had been threatened by budget woes.

headline: Bowling Ball, Shoes and Wig
text: Sitting on a musty couch in an East Village karaoke bar recently, I was fully aware I should have been home writing, but I blame my bowling team for the transgression. It may sound old-fashioned, but this league is more like a weekly party and it is sometimes hard to let the party end.

headline: A Weekend in Bordeaux, France
text: Bordeaux sparkles with the addition of stellar restaurants and innovative wine bars.

headline: A Survey of Italy in a Hurry: 8 Cities, 2 Centuries, 1 Show
text: The title suggests a leisurely Grand Tour, but “An Italian Journey: Drawings From the Tobey Collection, Correggio to Tiepolo,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is more of a whirlwind trip. A couple of lines from Vasari, a map of Italy and you’re off, dashing through two centuries and at least eight cities in fewer than 100 works.

headline: Mid-’50s Melodrama, via Antonioni
text: “Le Amiche”  it translates as “The Girlfriends” but sounds so much better in Italian  is about a group of women negotiating the complicated demands of work, love and looking fabulous in a bustling modern city. The city, to dispel any confusion, is Turin, and the sex, since this movie was made in 1955 in a country still ruled by traditional mores, is off-screen and unspoken. And the film, which American audiences may have encountered in revivals and retrospectives but never in theatrical release, was directed by Michelangelo Antonioni. (It opens on Friday for a weeklong run at the Film Forum.)

headline: Irreverent Bingo, a Virtual Subway Series and a Chinatown Arcade
text: They say this city is a playground, so this week the Miser found some excellent ways to play without having to pay ... much.

headline: Griffin Dunne and Wife Buy a Condo
text: EARLIER this year, this column reported that the actor and director Griffin Dunne, who starred in the cult classic “American Werewolf in London,” had transformed to an apartment seller from an apartment owner.

headline: 36 Hours in Bordeaux, France
text: TASTING notes for the 2004 Bordeaux — the stony French city, not its famous wine — might have read something like this: lifeless and bland; aromas of dirt and dust; a once majestic city well past its prime. But recent years have shown real progress. Today’s Bordeaux is smooth and elegant, thanks to reclaimed docklands and a beautification effort that is removing centuries of soot from its venerable squares and medieval churches. There’s also a new liveliness, including avant-garde art spaces and fledgling concept stores. Throw in some stellar upstart restaurants and innovative wine bars, and Bordeaux sparkles once again.

headline: Connoisseurs of Tragedy Disperse Relics of Wrecks
Is Verizon Wireless Making It Harder to Avoid Charges?
text: 11:38 p.m. | Updated Clarifying the difference in wording –noted by many readers — between what the whistleblower said and what the Verizon Wireless spokeswoman said about firing reps.

headline: ‘Talent’ Takes Wednesday
text: “America’s Got Talent” topped the ratings race on Wednesday night as 11.4 million viewers tuned in to that NBC reality show at 9 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. NBC was first over all; Fox placed second on the night with “So You Think You Can Dance” (6.5 million). CBS was a close third, with the Paley Center for Media’s special, “TV’s Greatest Surprises” (6.6 million). ABC was fourth.

headline: Magnum’s Treasures, Open to the Public
text: “I think there’s something quite magical about holding the stuff of history in your hands,” said David Coleman, the curator of photography at the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas at Austin.

headline: It’s All Tutu Much: McCartney Writing Ballet Music
text: Sorry, Sting, but it sounds like Paul McCartney has just lapped you in the race to be the pop musician with the most classical bona fides. Mr. McCartney, the former Beatle and Wings man whose orchestral works include “Standing Stone” and “Ecce Cor Meum,” told BBC News that he has agreed to write the music for a ballet and has already started on the project. “I’m interested in doing things I haven’t done before,” Mr. McCartney said to the BBC. “That offer came up and I love writing music, the two went together and I said, ‘Yeah,’ so I just accept things before I even know what I’m doing.” Mr. McCartney did not say who the music was being written for or when it might be performed, but he acknowledged that it was an unusual excursion, even for someone who has ridden shotgun in a yellow submarine, designed his own postage stamps and been recorded eating vegetables by both the Beach Boys and Super Furry Animals. “I don’t really know that much about it yet,” Mr. McCartney said. “I’m just writing music for it, but it’s a switch.”

headline: Putting Sandra Lee’s Lasagna to the Test
text: On Tuesday, the Food Network star Sandra Lee’s cooking — specifically her lasagna — took a public knock from her possible future mother-in-law, Matilda Cuomo, mother of the New York State attorney general and Democratic gubernatorial candidate Andrew Cuomo.

headline: A Realist Among Fans of South Africa
text: Alexandra, South Africa

headline: Selling Paradise to the People
text: Want to get away? No problem. Take a plane, train, bus or car to some distant place and you’ll find the serenity that eludes you in daily life. Or so the tourist industry would have you believe.

headline: Gay, Female and Overworked Like Everyone Else
text: The old joke surfaces early on “The Real L Word.” ”What does a lesbian bring on a second date?” The punch line: “A U-Haul.” “The L Word,” which has inspired this new series, spent its five-year tenure on Showtime tirelessly working to upend the perceptions that underlie such bons mots: that lesbians mate like penguins, for life, with comparatively less vigorous libidos and healthier bean dishes.

headline: Rachel Comey Buys SoHo Loft
text: FOR certain hip young things, the name Rachel Comey might evoke images of a fabulous pair of boots or a chic librarian. For those of us who frequent the Gap, she may be unfamiliar. But we can learn!

headline: Readers’ Photos: Space Shuttle Launchings
text: A selection of photos submitted by readers and chosen by Times Travel editors.

headline: Budget Boutiques in New York City
text: Six highly designed hotels, many rolled out by chains, offer wallet-friendly rates.

headline: Affordable Boutique Hotels in New York City
text: FINDING a decent place to sleep in New York City has never been easy. Traditionally, you either had to spend a ton of money (the Ty Warner Penthouse at the Four Seasons for $35,000 a night, anyone?) or scrimp and hope for the best (warning: a recent search for “bed bugs” on TripAdvisor found 877 mentions for city hotels).

headline: British Directors Will Oversee 2012 Olympics Ceremonies
text: Short of a feel-good movie about young Scottish heroin addicts who aspire to become ballet dancers, the 2012 Summer Olympics have found a more constructive way to bring the filmmakers Danny Boyle and Stephen Daldry together. Mr. Boyle, the “Trainspotting” director (who also won an Academy Award for “Slumdog Millionaire”), and Mr. Daldry, whose films include “Billy Elliot,” will be the creative heads of the London games, The Guardian reported. At an announcement ceremony on Thursday, the 2012 Olympic Organizing Committee said that Mr. Daldry would be the overall creative director of ceremonies while Mr. Boyle would be the artistic director of the opening ceremony, which is scheduled for July 27, 2012. The Guardian said that the directors would have a total of £40 million (about $59 million) to present four ceremonies during the 2012 games, presumably a little more than Mr. Daldry had to play with as director of “Billy Elliot: The Musical.”

headline: N.Y.U. Shows Plan For Tower
text: The controversial 38-story tower that New York University seeks to add to its University Village complex in Greenwich Village would be made of concrete with floor-to-ceiling windows on the Bleecker Street side, according to plans, above, made public Thursday by the university. The design by Grimshaw Architects, published in The Wall Street Journal, calls for a 240-room hotel in the bottom 15 floors for visiting professors and university guests that would also be available to the public. The top floors would be for faculty housing. Opponents of the tower, show above in a rendering as seen from Houston and Greene Streets, have objected to adding a fourth building to the original three-tower modernist design by the architect I. M. Pei. The University Village site received landmark status in 2008. As a result, the university’s plans must be approved by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission. On Monday the university is scheduled to make a preliminary presentation to the local community board. The building is part of a plan to add six million square feet of classrooms, dormitories and offices over the next 20 years on the core campus and at locations like Governors Island, downtown Brooklyn and the East Side of Manhattan.

headline: ‘The Octoroon’ Director Withdraws
text: The director Gavin Quinn, a founder of the Irish theater troupe Pan Pan, has withdrawn from the coming Off Broadway production of “The Octoroon: An Adaptation of The Octoroon Based on The Octoroon” after creative disagreements with the play’s author, Branden Jacobs-Jenkins. Vallejo Gantner, the artistic director of the New York theater company Performance Space 122, which is producing the show, said in an interview on Thursday that the two artists agreed that Mr. Quinn would withdraw from the project because each of them had different visions. “Sometimes collaborations don’t work out, and this is one of those times,” Mr. Gantner said. Mr. Quinn’s production of “The Crumb Trail” at P.S. 122 drew acclaim last year. Neither he nor Mr. Jacobs-Jenkins could immediately be reached for comment. Mr. Jacobs-Jenkins’s most recent production was “Neighbors,” which drew attention for its use of blackface and minstrelsy when the work was presented this winter in the Public Theater Lab series. He will now direct “The Octoroon,” which is described by P.S. 122 as a “bombastic, supertheatrical, full-scale investigation” of the intersection of theater and identity politics involving “The Octoroon,” a 19th-century melodrama by the Irish playwright Dion Boucicault about the residents of a Louisiana plantation and a mixed-race romance. Performances are to begin on Saturday, three days later than originally planned, to give the cast more time to work on the production. The play is scheduled to run through July 3.

headline: Mommy Dearest, You’re Mine Forever
text: In “Cyrus,” a creepy-funny comedy about man and boy love  not for each other  the actor Jonah Hill enters with a polite smile that is likely to send a chill straight up your neck, leaving your little hairs aflutter. As the title character, a 21-year-old man-child with a manic stare, an endless supply of neatly laundered button-down shirts and a seriously unhealthy attachment to his mother, he looks like the kind of guy who has been setting fire to the neighborhood cats, the one everyone says seemed so nice after the cops dig up the bodies. Best known for playing testy smart alecks in comedies like “Superbad,” Mr. Hill taps the spirit of Norman Bates so well he quickly pushes this comedy into horror.

headline: Rethinking the Whiteboard
text: WhiteyBoard — maker of stick-on-the-wall whiteboards — has obtained approximately $500,000 in seed funding, the company’s founders announced today. Bill Liao, who is best known as a founder of Xing.com, the dominant social network for business professionals in Europe, led the investment. He has taken eight companies public and is the author of “Stone Soup: The Secret Recipe for Making Something From Nothing.”

headline: Resort Report | Reed Krakoff
text: For pre-spring, Reed Krakoff showed muted colors, architectural shapes and a great pair of riding boots with a mesh top half — perfect for warmer weather! His silhouette reflects the new minimalism with looser, sometimes boxy shapes, sports references and an art-gallery-cool sophistication. There was a surprising apron dress in tan leather that was so simple yet so flattering. His first eponymous store will open this August in New York and then Tokyo in the fall, so these clothes will be some of the first to hit the streets. They will look right at home in those cities.

headline: ‘A Clear Day’ Is Born Again in New Concert Production
text: Brian d’Arcy James and Anika Noni Rose will be among the stars of a reimagined  or should we say reincarnated?  version of “On a Clear Day You Can See Forever” that Michael Mayer will direct this summer at Powerhouse Theater, the Poughkeepsie collaboration between Vassar College and New York Stage and Film. The concert workshop of that Alan Jay Lerner/Burton Lane musical, whose cast will also include David Turner, Kerry O’Malley, Colin Hanlon and Sarah Stiles, will feature many changes from its stage and film versions. But what kind, exactly? Mr. Mayer isn’t ready to say. “I’m really not trying to be coy, but I don’t want to overexplain it,” said Mr. Mayer, the Tony Award-winning director of “Spring Awakening,” in a telephone interview. He added: “By playing a little bit with gender, I thought I could make a different kind of love triangle at the center of it. That’s the goal.” The Powerhouse Theater production of “On a Clear Day” will run from July 29 through Aug. 1.

headline: Race For Oxford Poetry Position Now Brings Out the Verse
text: Taking a page from barb-tossing rhymers like Eminem, Lil Wayne and M.I.A.  not to mention the original diss track artist, M.C. Geoffrey Chaucer  the standing candidates for Oxford University’s professor of poetry have begun to malign one another in verse. The mudslinging started earlier this week when Michael Horovitz, the Beat poet and one of 10 remaining contenders for the Oxford post, criticized an essay by a fellow candidate, Roger Lewis, that was published in The Telegraph newspaper. Perhaps sensing an opportunity for a bit of mischief  and to promote his own candidacy for the Oxford position  Michael George Gibson has insinuated himself into the debate with a letter to The Telegraph, a copy of which was also sent to The New York Times. With a poem of his own, Mr. Gibson writes of Mr. Lewis:That Ox.Prof.Po.Candidate, Roger,Is a diss-all-his-rivals old codgerWhose Telegraph prose-hymnProsodically shows himA ‘My Favo rite-Things’ silly splodger. Mr. Lewis has not responded to either of his rivals. Oxford is to announce the election results on Friday.

headline: Hotel Review: Hotel Shangri-La in Santa Monica, Calif.
text: THE BASICS

headline: To Stage a Spoof Is Human. To Run and Run? Divine.
text: WHEN the musical “Nunsense,” about the singing, dancing, double-entendre-wielding Little Sisters of Hoboken, opened Off Broadway at the Cherry Lane Theater in 1985, it was a somewhat risky venture. When the curtain goes up on Sunday  same show, same theater  it arrives as the flagship of a comic mini-empire that shows little sign of slowing down.

headline: Rodriguez Is D.H.; Posada Sits
text: The rules say you can only have one designated hitter in your lineup. So Yankees Manager Joe Girardi had to make a choice between Alex Rodriguez and Jorge Posada, his two aching veterans, for Thursday night’s game against Philadelphia.

headline: Metropolitan Opera Says Assets Fell 38% Last Year
text: The Metropolitan Opera’s net assets declined 38 percent in the last fiscal year, according to its most recent financial statements, largely because of stock market losses and a decline in new donations. But officials said they were encouraged by rising attendance figures at performances.

headline: Alicia Keys Selling Long Island House
text: THE musician and actress Alicia Keys has accumulated a few awards in her 29 years. Actually, she’s got a ton of them, including 12 Grammy awards, 11 Billboard Music awards, 3 BET awards and 3 MTV Video Music awards. (Who else feels unaccomplished today?)

headline: Worlds of Movement Collide in One Space
text: WASHINGTON  The audiences thronging the Opera House at the Kennedy Center this week for the return of Ballet Across America (the first was in 2008) include a high number of dance practitioners. With nine companies participating, those not dancing tend to watch one another’s performances. Meanwhile the Dance USA conference has brought more leading figures. Intermissions are thoroughly buzzy.

headline: Adoring Throngs for ’80s Rock Revival
text: Matt Berninger, the lead singer of the National, got to play rock star at Radio City Music Hall on Wednesday night. He shook outstretched hands and repeatedly walked into the audience as he sang  even, for one encore, ascending the hall’s catwalk into the balcony  while the obliging fans held up the long, long cord on his old-fashioned, nonwireless microphone. It was a show of closeness and confidence that nicely contradicted what he sang: thoughts of isolation and estrangement, of fear and anxiety: “I don’t know what to do/in my best clothes.” Often the crowd was singing along.

headline: Israel’s Ultra-Orthodox Protest Schools Ruling
text: JERUSALEM  Tens of thousands of ultra-Orthodox Jews took to the streets of this city on Thursday to accompany dozens of Hasidic parents who were on their way to prison for two weeks after refusing to comply with a Supreme Court ruling against ethnic segregation in their children’s school.

headline: Where Composers Lend Their Voices
text: The American Composers Alliance, founded in 1937 by Aaron Copland and others, publishes new scores, maintains an important archive of American music and provides other forms of support for composers and new music. But its public face is the annual festival it has presented at Symphony Space since 2000: a lively, dogma-free celebration of mostly recent work by composers old and young.

headline: Should Parents Be Jailed When Kids Drink?
text: It’s graduation party season, which means social host laws that hold parents responsible for teenage drinking are back in the news. Last week, two Harvard Medical School professors were arrested because teenagers were found drinking at their daughter’s graduation party, though they said they did not see the alcohol.

headline: A Determined Ballerina, Propelled to the Top
text: THE Bolshoi ballerina Natalia Osipova smiled brightly, theatrically, projecting outward as she danced the solo that Princess Aurora performs moments after arriving on stage in Act I of “The Sleeping Beauty.”

headline: 2011 Infiniti M37 and M56
text: The new M’s solid foundation in chassis, engines and handling comes into sharper focus.

headline: Marching in the War on Gay Marriage
text: Reed Cowan’s polemical film “8: The Mormon Proposition” examines the successful campaign against gay marriage in California that was heavily financed by the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, which is implacably opposed to homosexuality. The highly emotional documentary is narrated by Dustin Lance Black, the screenwriter for “Milk,” who, like Mr. Cowan, is gay and grew up in a Mormon household.

headline: Goalkeeping Is Not Only Question for Embattled England Coach
text: Whether  to start the gaffe-prone goalkeeper Robert Green is only one of the questions facing Manager Fabio Capello ahead of England’s  match against Algeria in Cape Town on Friday. In his final day of preparations, Capello faced a storm of criticism at home, questions over an injury-depleted defense and even some crafty psychological warfare from the Algerians.

headline: Panel Demands NASA Documents to Support Budget
text: Annoyed that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has been slow to explain how it plans to overhaul the human space-flight program, a Congressional committee is demanding that the agency provide a host of records related to its budget request for 2011.

headline: Your Father’s Keeper
text: I spend time with my parents in social situations that include people outside our family. My mother, who has been married to my father for over 40 years, has a habit of subtly maligning him with every sentence: “Sorry we’re out of mustard. Someone forgot to go to the market — again.” (It gets much worse.) It’s painful to watch her cut my lovely father down, but I doubt she’ll change her ways. Is there anything I can say, in the moment, to bring a temporary stop to it?

headline: From Tapestried Villa to Sylvan Glade, Aristocratic Women in Love
text: Amid all the luxuries on display in the Italian film “I Am Love”  the chandeliers, tapestries and paneled walls, the paintings, statuary and white-gloved servants  nothing holds your gaze as forcefully as Tilda Swinton’s alabaster face. The first time you see that vision, her character, Emma Recchi, a Russian who’s married into a wealthy Milanese family, is stage-managing the lavish birthday party that opens the film. By the end of this often soaringly beautiful melodrama, which closes with a funeral, Emma’s face will have crumpled into a ruin. But it will also be fully alive, having been granted, like Pygmalion’s statue, the breath of life.

headline: World Cup Replay: Day 7, June 17
text: Argentina had reason to celebrate after a 4-1 victory over South Korea, while Greece defeated Nigeria, 2-1.

headline: Media Decoder: MySpace Co-President Leaving Company
text: Barely four months after becoming a co-president of MySpace, Jason Hirschhorn is leaving the company, writes Brian Stelter on Media Decoder.

headline: Is Technology Unhinging Our Brains?
text: To the Editor:

headline: No Summer Tour for Simon and Garfunkel
text: Simon and Garfunkel’s summer tour of the United States and Canada, already postponed once because of Art Garfunkel’s vocal strain, has now been put off indefinitely. A statement posted on the group’s Web site says Mr. Garfunkel is recovering from vocal paresis. That condition “inhibits the duo from performing shows at the highest possible level,” the statement says, “and it is for that reason and out of respect for their fans that Paul and Art have decided to put the tour on hold.”

headline: Assessing Who Should Pay for the Oil Spill Damage
text: To the Editor:

headline: Surfin’ Safari
text: A nomadic Californian surfer once took a wrong turn somewhere in Europe and ended up at the Berlin Wall. His faithful board still slung across his back like a guitar, he gazed up at one of the border guards, ensconced in a tower behind a machine gun and miles of barbed wire, and yelled out, “Man, you are bummed, because you will never know what true surfing really is!” That ringing indictment of totalitarianism — reported in a 1980s issue of Surfer magazine — turns out to be wrong. In Michael Scott Moore’s clued-in and far-flung “Sweetness and Blood,” the border guard, so to speak, exchanges his military uniform for baggy shorts and a rash vest. The surfer who came in from the cold. Trabants out, woodies in.

headline: The Pulp Inside Him as It Turns to Rot
text: “Around here, if you’re not a man and a gentleman, you’re nothing,” says Lou Ford, the protagonist of “The Killer Inside Me.” A murderous sociopath, cowardly and cold and particularly brutal toward women, Lou is in effect introducing the tale of his own self-annihilation. On the surface a polite, upstanding fellow  a sheriff’s deputy with fine manners and a clean white shirt  Lou guides us on a grisly tour of the abyss that is his soul.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: Pop

headline: Rodriguez Is Installed as D.H., Leaving Posada as the Odd Man Out
text: The Yankees have two ailing sluggers whose bats Manager Joe Girardi would surely like to keep in the lineup. Unfortunately for him, he only has one place to put them.

headline: Day 58: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: BP Chief Testifies Before Congress

headline: Colombian Coal Mine Blast Kills at Least 18
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  An explosion at a coal mine in northwest Colombia killed at least 18 miners, and dozens more trapped inside were feared dead, Colombian rescue officials said Thursday. The officials said the death toll could reach more than 70 when all the bodies were recovered.

headline: Former Phenom Hopes to Repair His Career
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  Eight years after making his first million, the golfer Ty Tryon got his first regular job.

headline: Women’s Rights, Then
text: To the Editor:

headline: Panel Recommends Approval of After-Sex Pill to Prevent Pregnancy
text: GAITHERSBURG, Md.  A federal advisory panel voted unanimously Thursday that federal drug regulators should approve a medicine that could help prevent pregnancy if taken as late as five days after unprotected sex.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: Classical

headline: You Have Issues? So Does Everybody
text: The personal is political in the films of Agnès Jaoui, a sort of Gallic Woody Allen whose comedies of manners reveal a sensibility acutely attuned to the tiniest nuances of the mind games people play. Ms. Jaoui’s films may lack Mr. Allen’s comic shtick, quotable one-liners and showy metaphysical angst, but they are precisely calibrated dissections of the pretensions and insecurities of the French chattering class. As critical as she can be of her characters, Ms. Jaoui portrays them with the evenhanded sympathy of a wise therapist who likes her clients despite their annoying foibles.

headline: Tale of a Bounty Hunter
text: Jonah Hex, the titular tough guy of the enjoyable neo-B-movie of the same title, is so unforgiving that he doesn’t kill a man once  he brings one unlucky victim back from the dead just so he can kill him again.

headline: Lockheed in Talks to Reduce Price of F-35 Planes by 20%
text: WASHINGTON  Lockheed Martin is negotiating to cut the price for the next group of its new F-35 fighter planes to at least 20 percent less than Pentagon officials projected last fall, Robert J. Stevens, the chief executive, said Thursday.

headline: Slovenes Hold U.S. in High Regard
text: Slovenia has never played the United States in soccer, but that does not mean there is no mutual awareness heading into their game Friday.

headline: Seeking Excitement in Jamaica
text: Horizons are expanded and exoticism explored in “Wah Do Dem,” a shaggy road movie about relinquishing your comforts to find your bliss. Our halfhearted traveler is Max (Sean Bones, drifting rather than acting), a Brooklyn musician reconciling two tickets for a Caribbean cruise and a last-minute kiss-off from his unrepentant girlfriend (a minuscule cameo by Norah Jones).

headline: Students Gain After Strike in Puerto Rico
text: MIAMI  Thousands of students at the University of Puerto Rico who went on strike two months ago to oppose severe budget cuts declared victory on Thursday after reaching an agreement with administrators.

headline: Letter: Questions for Christopher Hitchens
text: Not that a man as intelligent, worldly, honest and entertaining as Hitchens needs the likes of me to defend him — he has made a career out of giving as good as he gets — but the tone that Deborah Solomon took in her interview with him was churlish and disrespectful.

headline: Up Front: Jennifer Senior
text: In her cover review of Christopher Hitchens’s memoir, “Hitch-22,” Jennifer Senior admits she was hoping for more self-disclosure from the author.

headline: Do I Contradict Myself?
text: If anyone in this world is positioned to write a toothsome memoir, it’s Christopher Hitchens. He’s gone from international socialist to Iraq war enthusiast; he has a moving personal story and is a pasha of vice. His present solar system of intimates includes James Fenton and Salman Rushdie and Ian ­McEwan; his past included Susan Sontag and Edward Said (both deceased) and Gore Vidal (still alive, but banished to a growing Kuiper belt of discards and debris). He’s gone to a New York brothel with Martin Amis and delivered bluejeans to Polish dissidents; he’s gotten smacked on the tush by Margaret Thatcher and beaten up by thugs in Beirut. He argues ruthlessly and writes like a drunken angel, making targets of subjects as various as Mother Teresa, Henry Kissinger, the Clintons and God. (In 2007, he published the best seller “God Is Not Great” — a title Rushdie ruefully deemed one word too long.)

headline: In Kyrgyzstan, Failure to Act Adds to Crisis
text: OSH, Kyrgyzstan  Kyrgyzstan, an obscure country with a coveted location in Central Asia, is in serious danger of fragmenting. The crisis here, ebbing for now after days of ethnic violence and military atrocities, could have ramifications all the way to Washington.

headline: A Second Chance for Joshua
text: Two Republican senators find the memos that Elena Kagan wrote as a Supreme Court law clerk to be mysteriously “troubling.” Truth be told, reporters on the Kagan beat have found the memos troubling as well, due to an almost complete absence of news value that has left journalists scrambling to construct articles from the thousands of pages of Kagan-related documents pouring forth in the run-up to the Senate confirmation hearing that begins a week from Monday.

headline: Court Grants Bail and Frees American Lawyer in Rwanda
text: KAMPALA, Uganda  Peter Erlinder, the American lawyer jailed in Rwanda after being accused of denying the country’s genocide, was released Thursday on bail amid growing international pressure, allowing him to leave Rwanda, possibly for good.

headline: As Strikeouts Go Down, Wright’s R.B.I. Go Up
text: CLEVELAND  There was a time this season when David Wright was leading the league in one category he did not care to be involved in at all, and was nowhere near the top in a category that is very important to him.

headline: Asking Big Questions
text: Roger Nygard’s documentary “The Nature of Existence” is an extreme example of ADD filmmaking. Religious leaders, gurus, shamans, scientists, philosophers, waitresses and cab drivers flash by, giving quotable answers to Mr. Nygard’s big questions: Why do we exist? Is there a God? Is masturbation a sin?

headline: Lakers Defeat Celtics in Game 7
text: After playing from behind for most of Game 7, the Los Angeles Lakers surged past the Boston Celtics in the final minutes to capture their 16th N.B.A. Championship.

headline: Justices Debate Issues in an Oceanfront Case
text: WASHINGTON  A project to restore eroded beaches in the Florida Panhandle did not violate the Constitution’s takings clause even though the state claimed ownership of the strip of land the project created next to the ocean, the Supreme Court ruled on Thursday.

headline: Hijacking Their Way Out of Tyranny
text: LATE one summer night 40 years ago this month, Yosef Mendelevich, a young Soviet Jew, camped with a group of friends outside the Smolny airport near Leningrad. The next morning, they planned to commandeer a 12-seat airplane, fly it to Sweden and, once there, declare their purpose: to move to Israel, a dream they had long been denied.

headline: Doctors’ Group Fights a Bill That Would Ease Restrictions on Midwives
text: Amy Paulin, now a New York State assemblywoman pushing for more independence for midwives, was 27 when she became pregnant with her first child and started doctor-shopping in New York City.

headline: Known Faces Are Displacing the Amateurs in Online Videos
text: Just as the unknowns who showed up on screen in the early days of television gave way to radio and movie stars like Jack Benny and Bob Hope, more famous faces are supplanting everyday people in Web series, particularly when the video clips are sponsored by advertisers.

headline: Feinberg to Visit 2 Gulf Governors  on Friday
text: Two days after President Obama put him in charge of a $20 billion fund for victims of the Gulf oil spill, Kenneth R. Feinberg will fly on Friday to meet with the governors of Mississippi and Louisiana.

headline: Spill May Have Taken Its Largest Victim Yet
text: Over the last weeks, the carcasses of oily pelicans, turtles and other animals have washed to shore in the Gulf of Mexico. Now the first dead whale has been found  a juvenile sperm whale floating 77 miles from the leaking oil well.

headline: An Indian Epic With Bollywood Glamour
text: This film has been designated as a Critics' Pick.

headline: Film Series and Movie Listings
text: Movies

headline: He Shoots, He Scores. Why Quibble?
text: JOHANNESBURG

headline: Republican Backpedals From Apology to BP
text: WASHINGTON  Representative Joe L. Barton had to be truly sorry by the time he apologized for his apology on Thursday.

headline: World’s Mining Companies Covet Afghan Riches
text: WASHINGTON  Mining companies around the world are eager to exploit Afghanistan’s newly discovered mineral wealth, but executives of Western firms caution that war, corruption and lack of roads and other infrastructure are likely to delay exploration for years.

headline: Making Their Own National Noise, but Losing Anyway
text: Much has been made of the vuvuzelas, whose buzzy drone has been the soundtrack of the World Cup games being played in South Africa’s stadiums.

headline: Staten Island Church Reconsiders Deal to Sell Vacant Convent for Use as a Mosque
text: A plan to sell a Roman Catholic convent on Staten Island to a Muslim group for use as a mosque is faltering in the face of community opposition.

headline: Trim the ‘Experts,’ Trust the Locals
text: On Tuesday, The Times ran a front-page article on the chaotic efforts to clean up the oil washing around the Gulf of Mexico. Campbell Robertson reported on an incident in which boats that were supposed to be laying boom were, in fact, anchored on the wrong side of a bay in Louisiana. They were helpless as oil oozed in from the gulf, and BP had no way of contacting the workers to get the boats moving.

headline: Deal to Save Student Transit Discounts Is Near
text: Students are likely to keep the discounted fares they pay to ride New York City’s buses and subways, with legislators and transit officials close to an agreement on Thursday to save the service.

headline: Cooper Becomes Loud Voice for Gulf Residents
text: “There aren’t any small people here,” the CNN anchor Anderson Cooper said from Louisiana on his prime-time program Wednesday night, emphatically rejecting the remarks by BP’s chairman that the oil company cares “about the small people.”

headline: Dusting Off a 150-Year-Old Ode to the City’s Favorite Samurai
text: From an ornate balcony above a ballroom on the East Side of Manhattan, a nine-piece string ensemble played a sprightly number Wednesday evening for the benefit of several dozen people who stood below. None had heard the two-minute piece before. How could they have? “Tommy Polka,” as it was called, had not been played in public for 150 years.

headline: Federal Judge Rejects Terrorism Suspect’s Plea to Halt His Strip-Searches
text: A federal judge has refused to order the Bureau of Prisons to stop conducting strip-searches of a former detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, who is now jailed in Manhattan awaiting trial in a terrorism case.

headline: That ’30s Feeling
text: BERLIN

headline: Seventy Years Later, Churchill’s ‘Finest Hour’ Yields Insights
text: CAMBRIDGE, England  Historians have called it one of the greatest speeches ever delivered in English, and surely one of the greatest ever delivered by an Englishman, at a moment of national peril unparalleled in modern times.

headline: Man Accused of Stealing Sewer Firm From Widow
text: A Queens man was charged on Thursday with fraudulently taking over a sewer-cleaning company from a widow while she was in Israel burying her husband and son.

headline: Canada: Inquiry Into 1985 Attack Cites Flaws in Antiterror Preparedness
text: A commission that investigated a 1985 airplane bombing that killed 329 people criticized the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, the government and the intelligence service on Thursday for failing to prevent the attack. John C. Major, the former Supreme Court justice who headed the investigation of the Air India bombing, Canada’s deadliest terrorist attack, said that the series of failures was “inexcusable” and suggested that the episode could have been prevented with better coordination between agencies. Justice Major said that Canada’s air security and intelligence systems were still flawed with regard to handling terrorism.

headline: Iceland: Bobby Fischer’s Estate Dispute
text: The Supreme Court on Wednesday ordered that the body of the former American chess champion Bobby Fischer be exhumed so that a paternity test could be performed to see if he is the father of a 9-year-old Filipino girl. The order is part of a fight over his estate, which is reportedly worth about $2 million. Mr. Fischer died in Iceland in 2008. Other claims have been filed on the estate by Miyoko Watai, a Japanese chess official, who said she is Mr. Fischer’s wife, two nephews of Mr. Fischer’s and the United States, which says he owed back taxes.

headline: For Finalists, Tough Calls the Morning After
text: LOS ANGELES  After the Champagne celebration comes the hangover, a blurry, throbbing aftermath of doubt and reflection.

headline: Afghan Mineral Wealth
text: To the Editor:

headline: Somalia: U.S. Military Aid Denounced
text: A second United States senator complained Thursday about American military assistance to Somalia’s government, which the United Nations considers one of the most flagrant users of child soldiers in the world. Senator Russ Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin, said in a letter to Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton that the American government should press the Somali military to halt any use of child soldiers and “until we have that confirmation, I believe it is inappropriate to continue providing the T.F.G. with security assistance.” American officials said they have urged the Somali military not to recruit children but that with few American personnel in Somalia, it is impossible to guarantee this does not happen.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Business School Model
text: To the Editor:

headline: Nonprofit Advocate Carves Out a For-Profit Niche
text: Speaking on behalf of the Center for Consumer Freedom, Richard B. Berman takes no prisoners.

headline: In Coney Island, Where Old and New and Weird Rub Elbows
text: About noon on Surf Avenue in Coney Island on Thursday, three hot dogs walked down the street.

headline: 14 Stores Accused of Selling Illegal Knives
text: At least 14 retail stores in Manhattan  including major retailers like the Home Depot, Eastern Mountain Sports and Paragon Sports  have been selling illegal knives, District Attorney Cyrus R. Vance Jr. said on Thursday.

headline: State Party in S. Carolina Rejects Bid for New Vote
text: In this age of candidate Twitter accounts and robocalls, the surprising victory in a South Carolina Democratic primary by Alvin M. Greene, 32, an unknown candidate without so much as a Web site, harks back to another era.

headline: No Stranger to the Devils, MacLean Is Hired as Coach
text: NEWARK  Two bald men in navy suits and blue ties, one old enough to be the other’s father, strode to a podium together Thursday at Prudential Center and sat at a table. The older man, Lou Lamoriello, the Devils’ general manager, had another new coach to introduce.

headline: Turks Put Twist in Racy Soaps
text: ISTANBUL  A topless hunk lights candles in the bedroom.

headline: Common Sense and Private Property
text: Not a single Supreme Court justice agreed with the harebrained notion that some Florida property owners were entitled to the extra land created when the state widened the beach in front of their houses.

headline: Loopholes Grow in Bill to Offset Ruling on Campaigns
text: WASHINGTON  Congressional Democrats are pushing hard for legislation to rein in the power of special interests by requiring more disclosure of their roles in paying for campaign advertising  but as they struggle to find the votes they need to pass it they are carving out loopholes for, yes, special interests.

headline: Finish the Job, Albany
text: Hard as it may be to imagine, New York legislators have actually managed to agree to about half of the state’s $135 billion annual budget through Gov. David Paterson’s tactic of attaching parts of it to the weekly emergency-spending measures that are keeping the state government from shutting down.

headline: Two Children Are Killed in a Queens House Fire
text: A fire that started in a rear bedroom and engulfed a two-story house in Queens killed two young brothers on Thursday morning, officials said.

headline: A Bad Day for BP and Mr. Barton
text: It’s hard to imagine anyone having a worse day than Tony Hayward, BP’s embattled chief executive, who spent Thursday in the cross hairs of an angry Congressional committee and turned in a mind-bogglingly vapid performance. But he got a run for his money from Representative Joe Barton, a Texas Republican, who inexplicably decided to call the escrow account agreed to by BP and the White House a “$20 billion shakedown.”

headline: Vogue’s Publisher Is Leaving Condé Nast
text: The publisher who oversaw Vogue through some of its most robust times  and issues  said Thursday that he was leaving Condé Nast after nearly 25 years.

headline: That Cheats the Kids
text: The parents of children attending George Washington Elementary School in Baltimore were understandably outraged when they learned last month that someone at the school had altered thousands of answers on students’ 2008 state math and reading tests to raise their scores. Following a lengthy investigation, state education officials did exactly the right thing. They revoked the principal’s state teaching license and made clear that educators elsewhere could expect the same if they tampered with test results.

headline: Senate Stalemate Persists on Spending Bill
text: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats failed Thursday night to break a partisan impasse over a major package of tax changes and safety-net spending, leaving the future of added unemployment benefits and a series of business tax breaks up in the air.

headline: Twisting Arms at BP, Obama Sets Off a Debate on Tactics
text: WASHINGTON  First there was General Motors, whose chief executive was summarily dismissed by the White House shortly before the government became the company’s majority shareholder. Chrysler was forced into a merger. At the banks that received government bailouts, executive pay was curbed; at insurance companies seeking to jack up premiums, scathing criticism led to rollbacks.

headline: Torn by Violence, Vendors Unite to Rebuild Market
text: OSH, Kyrgyzstan  For some visitors, it was the rainbow of fruits and vegetables or the aroma of spices that drew them to the big bazaar in Osh. Kanyshai Jusupova came for the fresh-baked flatbread. And she said it did not matter who was behind the counter.

headline: Mexico Court Clears Officials in 2009 Fire at Care Center
text: MEXICO CITY  For more than a year, the parents of 49 children killed in a fire at a day care center have managed to keep public attention on the case. The case was back in the news on Thursday, after a Supreme Court ruling that was a blow to many of the parents.

headline: Bloggingheads: America's Soccer Problem
text: Dayo Olopade, left, of The Daily Beast and Stephen Spruiell of National Review debate why Americans haven't embraced soccer.

headline: For U.S., Slovenia Stands in Way of Bigger Things
text: JOHANNESBURG  At least four American cities have larger populations than the nation of Slovenia, the United States’ opponent Friday in the teams’ second match in the group stage of the World Cup.

headline: Sale of Property Positioned Queens Pastor to Gain
text: For 25 years, the Rev. Floyd H. Flake’s Greater Allen African Methodist Episcopal Cathedral of New York successfully ran a 300-unit apartment complex for the elderly in southeastern Queens.

headline: More New Jersey Towns Force Big School Cuts
text: About 17 percent of the New Jersey school districts that had budgets rejected by voters this spring have been ordered by town councils to make cuts to lower their proposed school taxes by at least 3 percent, according to an analysis by The New York Times of state education data released on Thursday.

headline: The Deal to Buy a Queens Housing Project
text: The Rev. Floyd H. Flake and his partners used public money to buy control of a lucrative Queens housing project in 2006.

headline: Judge Rejects Many Claims in 9/11 Cases
text: A federal judge in Manhattan who was criticized by families of victims of 9/11 for taking too long to decide motions in lawsuits they had filed has handed down a ruling dismissing claims made against many of the defendants.

headline: Robert B. Radnitz, Producer of ‘Sounder,’ Dies at 85
text: Robert B. Radnitz, a producer of family moviesincluding “Sounder” and “Where the Lilies Bloom” and who was praised for not playing down to his audience or filling the screen with violence, died on June 6 at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 85.

headline: Suspect in Times Sq. Bomb Attempt Is Indicted
text: Faisal Shahzad, the Pakistani immigrant charged in the failed Times Square bombing plot, was indicted on Thursday by a federal grand jury in Manhattan, the government said.

headline: Master of the Mets’ Domain
text: Every Father’s Day, dads get barbecues, neckties and golf tchotchkes. Then there is the gift Jerry Seinfeld will get this year.

headline: Rapper/Actor Woolard
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — My solve got off to an inauspicious start today. Wading in at the end of the Down clues and then working my way up, my first thought was, “Oh no, a puzzle with a lot of stuff I don’t know!”

headline: Inquiry Aimed at Transfer of Aqueduct Bid Papers
text: The state inspector general is investigating whether a senator or Senate staff member gave internal documents regarding the competition for a slot-machine franchise at Aqueduct Racetrack to a lobbyist for one of the bidders, an official with knowledge of the investigation said Thursday.

headline: ‘Mind and Matter’: Alternative Abstractions, 1940s to Now
text: Museum of Modern Art

headline: Jim Nutt: ‘Trim’ and Other Works: 1967-2010
text: David Nolan Gallery

headline: Kelli Williams: ‘Scala Naturae’
text: Leo Koenig

headline: ‘Richard Wilson and the British Arcadia’
text: The British painter Richard Wilson (around 1713-82) is considered the father of British landscape painting in his homeland, but he is little known in the United States. The 11 paintings  in this exhibition may change that.

headline: Amy Gartrell: ‘Whatever and Ever’
text: Daniel Reich Gallery

headline: Drill Ban Means Hard Times for Rig Workers
text: In addition to the fishermen and hoteliers whose livelihoods have been devastated by BP’s hemorrhaging undersea oil well, another group of Gulf Coast residents is beginning to suffer: the tens of thousands of workers like Ronald Brown who run the equipment or serve in support roles on deepwater oil rigs in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Looking for Answers, Finding One
text: WASHINGTON  On the 58th day, an outraged nation summoned the man it holds responsible for one of the worst environmental disasters in American history. He walked through the oversize wooden doors, shed the protective cocoon of his dark-suited entourage and took his place at a long table.

headline: Elzbieta Czyzewska, Polish Actress Unwelcome in Her Own Country, Dies at 72
text: Elzbieta Czyzewska, a star of Polish movies and television in the 1960s whose marriage to the American journalist David Halberstam made her an outcast in her home country, and whose career frustrations in the United States became a cautionary tale for immigrant artists, died on Thursday in Manhattan. She was 72.

headline: Keeping Score: Luck Is Likely to Catch Up to Jimenez
text: When Ubaldo Jimenez allowed three earned runs in a rain-shortened, six-inning victory against the Blue Jays last Friday, it was by far his worst outing of the season. Once upon a time, a pitcher would have considered himself fortunate to escape Coors Field with a performance like that, but for Jimenez, the Rockies’ 26-year-old ace, it was a blemish that raised his earned run average above 1.00 for the first time in nearly two months.

headline: Nonprofits Paying a For-Profit Firm
text: Six nonprofits provide as much as 70 percent of revenues for Berman and Company. Many of the groups’ board members are current and former employees of the company.

headline: Former Police Commander Denies Abuse
text: CHICAGO  For almost three decades, allegations of brutality have swirled around Jon Burge, dogging him through his last years as a police commander all the way to his retirement in a beach town near Tampa, Fla. For all that time, some here have called for Mr. Burge to publicly answer, under oath, charges that he routinely tortured confessions out of suspects who were largely poor black men from the South Side.

headline: Heads Found in 3 Boxes Set for Flight
text: A Southwest Airlines cargo worker last week opened three suspicious boxes at Little Rock National Airport and found 45 human heads, bound for a medical laboratory in Fort Worth. The heads were to be used to help train neurosurgeons.

headline: After Round 1, a Big Crowd in the Mid-70s
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. — Sometimes it’s hard to tell what a good score is during the first round of the United States Open, although anything close to par usually qualifies. But Thursday, more than a third of the field posted scores from two-over 73 to four-over 75.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Toyota’s Image Falls in J.D. Power Survey
text: A new consumer survey shows that Toyota has paid dearly among car owners for its recalls over accelerator pedal problems.

headline: 2010 Mets Are Starting to Resemble 2005 Yanks
text: The Mets never work in a vacuum. Everything they do is measured against the Yankees, fairly or not. Sometimes the comparisons are unflattering.

headline: Nuclear Agency Weighs a Plan to Dilute Waste
text: BETHESDA, Md.  A competition between nuclear waste dumps has pulled the Nuclear Regulatory Commission into an unusual reconsideration of its rules to allow moderately radioactive materials to be diluted into a milder category that is easier to bury.

headline: Against the Phillies, the Yankees’ Offensive Spigot Is Quickly Shut Off
text: The Yankees have feasted in recent weeks on some of the league’s worst pitching staffs. Then the Philadelphia Phillies came to town, and with them came an offensive famine for the home team.

headline: Mets Find Solution for Road Problems
text: CLEVELAND  The American League may be considered superior to the National League, but the Mets found its flabby underbelly in Baltimore and Cleveland. Playing those two struggling A.L. clubs has been the salve the Mets needed to reverse their confounding road difficulties.

headline: City in Nebraska Torn as Immigration Vote Nears
text: FREMONT, Neb.  In this city of 25,000, far from any international border, the fight over illegal immigration has boiled over.

headline: Watchdog Proposes Dividing N.C.A.A. Money Based on Academics
text: An influential watchdog group on Thursday called on members of the N.C.A.A. and the Bowl Championship Series to change the way they divide millions of dollars in men’s basketball and football revenue, proposing the creation of a fund that would allocate money based on academic success rather than victories or tournament appearances.

headline: F.D.A. Seeks Explanation of Marlboro Marketing
text: When the F.D.A. says no “light” cigarettes, it evidently means it.

headline: Spaniard’s Round a Dream, After a Trip That Wasn’t
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  Growing up in the Canary Islands, Rafael Cabrera-Bello dreamed of playing in major golf championships. This month, Cabrera-Bello  a 26-year-old Spaniard ranked 204th in the world  finally earned his way into one, the 2010 United States Open at the Pebble Beach Golf Links.

headline: Fujitsu and Toshiba to Merge Mobile Phone Units
text: TOKYO  In Japan’s second cellphone merger this month, Fujitsu and Toshiba said on Thursday that they would combine their handset operations.

headline: Dutch Rider Takes Lead
text: Robert Gesink of the Netherlands won the grueling sixth stage of the Tour of Switzerland and claimed the race leader’s jersey, while Lance Armstrong showed he was returning to top form by finishing fifth.

headline: What Crisis? The Euro Zone Adds Estonia
text: BRUSSELS  Guess what? The funniest thing happened in Europe on Thursday. A new country joined (yes, joined) the euro zone. And the mood here was upbeat.

headline: House-Senate Panel Broadens Audits of Fed
text: WASHINGTON  House and Senate negotiators agreed Thursday to broaden the scope of a new set of audits of the Federal Reserve by the Government Accountability Office to include transactions involving the Fed’s discount window and open market operations. But the Federal Reserve dodged attempts to extend Congressional review over its monetary policy decisions.

headline: Swiss Approve Deal for UBS to Reveal U.S. Clients Suspected of Tax Evasion

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: SUMMER SOLSTICE CELEBRATION June 22, 1633, did not go well for Galileo Galilei. On that day, the summer solstice, the Inquisition forced him to renounce his theories of a Sun-centered planetary system. What a difference a few centuries make. Galileo would no doubt be gratified that on June 20, 2010, in honor of the solstice, a major scientific institution is offering a festival that builds on his work. That’s the American Museum of Natural History, whose Summer Solstice Celebration (the actual solstice is Monday) promises to bring light to any benighted minds — particularly children’s — who might underestimate the Sun’s importance. “You’d be surprised at how many people think the Sun is moving around the Earth,” said Suzanne Morris, the museum’s associate manager of public programs. There’s no chance of making that mistake at the festival, which will include an inflatable planetarium in which museum educators will hold demonstrations illustrating the Earth’s motion and explaining the summer solstice, which occurs when the tilt of the Earth’s axis maximizes the hours of daylight. Families can look at the Sun safely through a solar telescope and examine it indirectly (above, right) with a device to observe sunspots. “It reflects an image of the Sun onto a piece of paper, so you can see the contrast,” Ms. Morris said. In a nod to the Sun’s cultural importance, the Rose Center for Earth and Space will host an ancient solstice ceremony by members of the Kichwa Nation, a group representing the Andean peoples. Activity stations will demonstrate the Sun’s power. In what might be called cool chemical reactions, children can make solar prints (images created with chemically treated paper and sunlight) and UV bead bracelets, which turn from white to colored in sunshine. To emphasize “that energy is possible without batteries and electric cords,” Ms. Morris said, the Arthur Ross Terrace will become a mini Indy 500 for racing solar-powered model cars. She acknowledged that the Sun can be a temperamental guest of honor. Indoor activities, like making Sun models from clay, will take place regardless of weather. And young visitors should come away knowing that whether or not it shows its face, the Sun is undeniably a star. (Sunday, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m., Rose Center, 81st Street and Central Park West, 212-769-5200, amnh.org. Free with suggested museum admission: $16; $12 for ages 62+ and students; $9 for 2 to 12; free for under 2 and members.) LAUREL GRAEBER
