headline: Haiti: Reconstruction Panel Meets
text: More than five months after the earthquake, with rubble still clogging the streets of the capital and some 1.5 million Haitians still homeless, the interim commission for Haiti’s reconstruction met Thursday for the first time. The panel, chaired by former President Bill Clinton and Prime Minister Jean-Max Bellerive, met behind closed doors, but Mr. Clinton said that future meetings would be open. The commission announced $45 million in grants from Brazil and Norway to help the government close its budget gap and a $20 million fund created by Frank Giustra, a Canadian businessman, and Carlos Slim Helú, a Mexican businessman, to provide loans for small businesses. Resolving central issues like debris removal and moving Haitians out of tent camps will take time, Mr. Clinton said.

headline: English Accents | Burberry Beauty
text: Christopher Bailey’s accolades at Burberry are enough to make him blush — in five shades, to be precise. The designer’s latest project, Burberry Beauty, is a comprehensive collection of foundations, powders, bronzers, lipsticks and eye shadows that were inspired by the label’s classic trench coat and by the moody hues of the British climate. Two years in the making, the line pays homage to Mr. Bailey’s vision of a modern English rose. “The Burberry girl wears just a trace of makeup — no crazy eyes or crazy lips,” he says. “Makeup should enhance women, not just cover up what they perceive as flaws.” Of the sexy reflective checked packaging, he adds, “The idea was for the products to look and feel like things you really want to have in your bag.” The range will be available on Nordstrom.com starting Monday and on Burberry.com starting Friday.

The 250 photographs on display are organized thematically rather than chronologically, beginning with the concept of the unseen photographer.

Currently, the gap opens when a Medicare recipient and his plan have spent $2,830 on prescriptions; at that point, he must pay for medications himself until he’s paid $4,500 out of pocket. headline: Officials to Dutch Concertgoers: No Snoop for You
text: Having spent the better part of four years fighting for his right to travel to Britain, the hip-hop star Snoop Dogg now finds himself a rapper non grata in the Netherlands, where the authorities had him scratched from the lineup of a free concert planned for later this month, BBC News reported. Snoop Dogg was scheduled to perform at the Parkpop festival in The Hague on June 27, but the mayor and law enforcement officials there asked its organizers to find another artist to replace him to ensure the “open and friendly character” of the festival. Snoop Dogg is scheduled to perform at the Glastonbury and Wireless festivals in Britain this summer, after a ruling in March by a tribunal there that said the rapper should not have been denied a visa for entry in 2007 after a 2006 public disorder at Heathrow Airport involving members of his entourage resulted in Snoop Dogg’s arrest.

headline: Alfa at 100: Prewar to Post-Graduate

headline: Beethoven, Even Bigger Than Usual
text: LOVING it may be difficult. But awe? No problem there.

headline: Friday Reading: Toyota Drops in Quality Survey
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Advice for a Nervous, Expectant Dad?
text: A reader, Dena, is newly pregnant (very newly), and thrilled. Her husband is trying to be thrilled, but the emotion that keeps getting in the way is terror. She is looking for advice from Motherlode readers on how to help ease his unexpected fears of fatherhood.

headline: What Broke My Father’s Heart
text: One October afternoon three years ago while I was visiting my parents, my mother made a request I dreaded and longed to fulfill. She had just poured me a cup of Earl Grey from her Japanese iron teapot, shaped like a little pumpkin; outside, two cardinals splashed in the birdbath in the weak Connecticut sunlight. Her white hair was gathered at the nape of her neck, and her voice was low. “Please help me get Jeff’s pacemaker turned off,” she said, using my father’s first name. I nodded, and my heart knocked.

headline: Dysregulation Nation
text: The gulf oil fiasco is just the latest instance in which a lack of regulation — or dysfunctional system of regulation — has led to a major American disaster. After the failure of the levees during Hurricane Katrina, the Wall Street meltdown of 2008, the collapse of the housing market and now the BP spill,we have come to what feels like a moment of reckoning, with some tentative signs that our country’s decades-long love affair with deregulation is starting to chill.

headline: King of His Multigenerational Castle?
text: There is a trend, the Internet tells me, of grown adults, sometimes even married and with kids of their own, moving back in with their parents. As much as I try to steer clear of trends, I have recently been considering this possibility, but in reverse. I grew up outside Miami, and when my youngest brother and I first moved to Brooklyn, my parents used to visit pretty often. When I married, the visits fell off. I think they were happy that I was taken care of: good job, good wife, good riddance. When I had kids, the visits started to pick up again. I didn’t take it personally. They are now those kinds of parents, meaning that they are now grandparents. Last year my parents rented for a few months in the neighborhood. Then about a month ago, on the phone, my mother told me that they were thinking of coming to Brooklyn.

headline: Jil Sander: Detox
text: Though it was dusk and apparently damp when the Jil Sander men’s show started in Florence — I watched the Web stream — the colors cleared the head. Intense yet cheerful, the blues, greens, yellows, pinks and oranges could have been taken from nature or a Warhol or a Koons canvas. Anyway, they were distinctive colors without navel-gazing and they worked best in assemble. Raf Simons seemed energized by this collection, which included belted jackets, quite a number of boyish shorts, and T-shirts in solid colors as well as grid patterns and deep-hued, splashy prints.

headline: Honda Reveals New 2011 Odyssey
text: Honda revealed its fourth-generation Odyssey minivan Thursday in an online news conference from its research and development center in Ohio.

headline: You Make the Call
text: “Every Tiger out there was telling me that I had kicked the call because they’d seen the replay. . . .So I told Tim our clubhouse guy to cue it up, and — I missed it. I missed it. This isn’t a big call. This is a history call.”

headline: Bromance? Renaissance Boston Suggests Brewmance.
text: Bonding over brews – that is what the Renaissance Boston Waterfront Hotel has in mind with a new beer-themed special available this Father’s Day through Labor Day.

headline: The Recycling Thief
text: We put our paper, plastic and other recyclables in city-issued containers in  our backyard and move them to the curb for weekly pickup through our  town’s recycling program. A scavenger regularly removes cans and bottles,  presumably to redeem for cash. I say that by depriving the city of these  items, he adds to our recycling costs. I want to ask the police to apprehend  the “thief.” My wife says I lack compassion. You? J.M., BURLINGAME, CALIF.

headline: Implacability
text: In my recent column on cool, I wrote, "From Old English to the ages of Chaucer and Shakespeare all the way to the present, cool has been able to mean 'dispassionate, calm, self-composed.' Some of our latter-day cool expressions — 'stay cool,' 'play it cool,' 'cool as a cucumber,' 'cool customer' — play off this ancient connotation of implacability." Catherine Harris e-mails: "I believe you meant to use imperturbability rather than implacability, describing the calm sense of cool. Someone who is implacable is relentless and unappeasable, not necessarily perpetually unruffled."   If there's one lesson I learned from many years of reading my illustrious predecessor William Safire, it's to show humility when called out by the Gotcha Gang. In a 1984 column, he introduced the Gotcha Gang as "that shock troop of Lexicographic Irregulars who specialize in correcting other language mavens." Safire later revealed the hidden benefit of publicizing Gotchas: "By ostentatiously wolfing down one slim slice of humble pie, I buy the license to take pops at everybody else for months without appearing to be a wiseguy."  Let this be my first On Language mea culpa: Harris (along with fellow Gotcha-ers Brian Hoffman, Peter Glasgow and Wade Richardson) rightly questions my use of implacability, which does not quite fit in the context of cool. Imperturbability would indeed have been a better choice, as would the more modern unflappability.  I cop to the malaprop, though my mix-up was not as blatant or farcical as the eponymous Mrs. Malaprop's constant misuse of language in Richard Brinsley Sheridan's 1775 play "The Rivals" (e.g., "He is the very pineapple of politeness," with pineapple standing in for pinnacle). I might have been influenced in my word choice by such cool words as placid and placate, but of course, implacability tends to imply just the opposite, an inability to be made calm.  In my modest defense, the "relentless, steadfast" shade of implacability can intersect with the unruffled nature of imperturbability, and in fact the adjectives implacable and imperturbable often appear side by side - or as linguists would say, they can easily "collocate" with each other. For instance, the newly published translation of Simone de Beauvoir's "Second Sex" by Constance Borde and Sheila Malovany-Chevallier contains a line about "precise, imperturbable, implacable logic."  The overlap in usage between the two words doesn't absolve the linguistic error, however. In a vicious dissection of James Fenimore Cooper's many "literary offenses," Mark Twain offered some simple rules for writing as an antidote. My favorite is: "Use the right word, not its second cousin." This advice hits close to home, since I work as executive producer of the Visual Thesaurus, which essentially creates interactive family trees of words with similar meanings. Implacability and imperturbability might have a passing family resemblance, but it's best not to treat them as blood brothers.

headline: Bryant Sets Narrative for Next Season
text: A popular story line for next season was crafted Thursday night when Kobe Bryant won his fifth championship ring, putting him one behind Michael Jordan, the player he seems to mimic in so many ways, including celebratory post-title moments.

headline: Long Live the King
text: In addition to the legacy that is Michael Jackson’s discography, the King of Pop also left behind a trove of collectibles — from his bedazzled gloves and rhinestone-covered military garb to the countless tacky tchotchkes that filled his Neverland compound. Though many of the clothes and objects have been sold at auction, the museum-worthy collection has been preserved by the Swiss-born photographer Henry Leutwyler in a new book, “Neverland Lost: A Portrait of Michael Jackson” (Steidl 2010; $45). Mr. Leutwyler photographed the items prior to Mr. Jackson’s death in 2009, forgoing visual trickery and relying instead on a plain black background. Many of the images point to the otherwordly realm the star inhabited; others, such as an ordinary tube sock studded with rhinestones, bring him heartbreakingly down to earth.

headline: Complaint Box | Abusive Customers
text: Let’s face it, folks. The customer is not always right. In fact, some are just plain old abusive, cheap and crass. I say this not as a salesman but as a dyed-in-the-wool middle-class consumer.

headline: From Alfa to Omega
text: At its best, Alfa Romeo combined striking design with driving joy.

headline: A Reason for Optimism
text: The latest economic data has not been very good. Yet Robert Barbera — an economist at ITG, who’s been more right than most over the last couple of years — says he isn’t especially worried.

headline: Zen and the Art of Image Maintenance
text: IF luxury brands have identities, Infiniti’s has too often seemed a secret one.

headline: Lead Actor Withdraws from Bollywood Hitler Film
text: A plan for the Bollywood film industry’s first feature about Hitler has already drawn an outcry from Indian moviegoers and historians, and now the project has lost the actor who was to play the lead character, Agence France-Presse reported.

headline: Small People
text: BP chairman Carl-Henric Svanberg’s controversial description of those affected by the Gulf of Mexico oil spill.

headline: Flight Training: Building an Army of Billy Elliots
text: A BOY in a tutu. This was the image Lee Hall saw in his mind’s eye when he began the original screenplay for “Billy Elliot,” the tale of a striking coal miner’s son who crashes the gates of the Royal Ballet School in London. “We thought it would be impossible to find one kid for the movie,” Mr. Hall said on a recent visit to New York. “Doing the show live, with singing, is so much harder.”

headline: Classical Music, Plugging In
text: THOUGH the electric guitar was introduced in the early 1930s, its adoption into classical music came decades later. Composers like Leonard Bernstein and Michael Tippett used the instrument chiefly for its vernacular allusions. Later Rhys Chatham, Glenn Branca and Lois V. Vierk tapped into its capacity for producing complex overtones and, yes, punishing volume.

headline: ‘Twilight of the Gods’
text: Electronic samples from the Klez Dispensers; Ray Marchica and Sons of Sound; Thomas Buckner and Ellen Band, vocalists. Tzadik TZ 8069; CD.

headline: Aftercare Tips for Patients Checking Out of the Hospital
text: IN mid-March my 85-year-old father checked into a prominent New York City hospital for a scheduled operation. The procedure, to remove a cancerous tumor from his thigh, went well, and soon he was sent home.

headline: Preparing to Leave the Hospital
text: In this week’s Patient Money column, Lesley Alderman looks at ways to prepare patients to leave the hospital — and minimize the chances of returning.

headline: Inside the List
text: BECK BUMP: Swedish socialism may still rule the hardcover fiction list, via Stieg Larsson’s megahit “The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet’s Nest.” But Larsson, who died in 2004, was recently given a run for his money by the free-market Austrian economist Friedrich von Hayek (who died in 1992), thanks to a mighty fist-bump from Glenn Beck. Hayek’s classic treatise “The Road to Serfdom,” first published in the United States in 1944, shot to the No. 1 spot at both Amazon and Barnesandnoble.com after Beck devoted the entire June 8 episode of his television show to the book. A perennial seller for the University of Chicago Press, Hayek’s libertarian cri de coeur had already received a big boost from Barack Obama, who has been cited by conservative pundits as the embodiment of the kind of creeping government tyranny that Hayek warned of. After Obama’s election, sales went from about 7,000 copies a year to almost 30,000, according to Garrett Kiely, director of the press. After Beck’s program, the book sold about 60,000 to 70,000 copies in one week. This surge came too late to push the book onto this week’s paperback nonfiction list, which records sales until June 12. But stay tuned.

headline: Cocktail Recipe: Bourbon Sidecar for Two
text: Forgive me, but I’m about to go pedantic for a minute. I’m always disturbed by the scene in which the beleaguered spouse – alright, the beleaguered guy – arrives home after a hard day, flops down on the chair and announces, “I need a drink.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE LAST STAND: Custer, Sitting Bull, and the Battle of the Little Bighorn,  by Nathaniel Philbrick (Viking, $30.) The author of “Mayflower” gives appropriate space to Sitting Bull, Crazy Horse and others who fought that day, but Custer steals the show.

headline: Paperback Row
text: MY FATHER’S TEARS: And Other Stories,  by John Updike (Ballantine, $16.) All but one of the 18 stories in Updike’s final collection (he died in January 2009) were published in the last decade. Their protagonists are elderly gents who share biographical details and concerns with Updike himself. “Updike once described himself as ‘a literary spy within average, public-school, supermarket America,’ ” our reviewer, T. Coraghessan Boyle, recalled. “These are his last smuggled dispatches, made all the more poignant for their finality.”

headline: Execution by a Hail of Bullets … and a Message on Twitter
text: Politics Daily is reporting that Utah’s attorney general, Mark Shurtleff, used his Twitter account to update citizens on the execution of the convicted killer Ronnie Lee Gardner by firing squad, including the moment when he gave the green light to proceed.

headline: Letter: From Boys to Pros
text: Congratulations to Michael Sokolove for his thoroughly researched article on the Ajax youth academy. It was also very informative about U.S. youth soccer. As a professional polo player and father of three soccer-crazed boys, the implications of Sokolove’s accurate assertions about international youth development in the sport are very personal. The U.S. system does not fit either a Dutch skills-based teaching method or the “just play” method of the kind my kids have experienced in South America. The U.S. method is probably a detriment to many because of its focus on winning even with very young players. Where is Johann Cruyff when we need him?

headline: Letter: The Corporate Challenge
text: While it’s obvious from Frank Bruni’s profile that Carly Fiorina’s personal experience informs her position on abortion, her experience has done nothing for her opinion on health care reform. She obviously cannot imagine what it is like for uninsured women with breast cancer who have limited access to timely and quality health care.

headline: Letters: The Freegan Establishment
text: In Jake Halpern’s recent article about freegans in Buffalo, Kit is definitely onto something when he says: “Just be nice to people. Just make connections. It’s all about connections.” Indeed, not only can people live on what we throw away in this country; children’s lives around the world can also be saved by it.

headline: Casualties of War
text: I’ve read somewhere that in the approximately 5,000 years of recorded history, there have been a little more than 200 years of recorded peace. No wonder so many writers have something to say about what we’ve done for the other 4,800, which is to slaughter one another. Imagine a tower built of all the war novels, memoirs, poetry, histories and commentaries written since the “Iliad.” Now imagine yourself standing on the roof. You would probably need an oxygen tank.

headline: Geoffrey Hill Is Oxford’s Next Professor of Poetry
text: The 2010 race for Oxford University’s professor of poetry had it all: newfangled rules to allow online voting, an 11th-hour withdrawal by its only female candidate, a furious final round of campaigning by its 10 remaining contenders and plenty of name-calling. And in the end, the front-runner won, anyway.

headline: Geopolitical Cycles
text: O to be young and biking in Ameri­ca at the close of the 19th century and have nothing to worry about, except perhaps the roads (which were an issue only if they were good: on the big-wheeled “boneshaker” bikes, as one cycling reporter put it, “the element of safety is rather distasteful to a good many riders who prefer to run some risk, as it gives zest to the sport”)! O to ride when cyclists were called wheelmen, Bicycling World covered bike races as if they were moon launches and spectators cheered on men in short-legged pants and caps that — wait! — looked a lot like what that guy on the G train in Brooklyn was wearing the other day! O to ride between bicycling meccas like Pittsburgh and Buffalo, at a time when America was embracing travel and just setting out, like bicyclists, into the wide world!

headline: What We’re Reading: Beard Ban
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Inside the Box
text: Video games have created what must be the biggest generation gap since rock ’n’ roll. Sure, a generational rift of sorts emerged when the World Wide Web showed up near the end of the last century, but in the case of the Web, the older cohort admired and tried to emulate the younger crowd, rather than looking down on them with befuddlement or disdain. With games, a more traditional “Get off my lawn” panic has reared its head.

headline: Name That Stimulus Proponent
text: The raging debate over what to do about the deficit is now getting its own lingo.

headline: Sharp Images, Bright Screen on New Samsung Phone
text: Samsung has announced the release of the Captivate, the first in a new line of Galaxy S smartphones with startlingly bright and detailed screens.

headline: Preparing Women to Build Growing Businesses
text: Gail Warrior understands the real issues faced by small-business owners. Depending on how you define “small,” she is one herself. In 1997 she founded Warrior Group, which specializes in permanent, modular construction, and is today chief executive and president of the 50-plus-employee company, which had 2009 revenue of $124 million. Based in DeSoto, Tex., Warrior Group handles projects in 30 states.

headline: 10 Ways to Celebrate Father’s Day
text: How are you celebrating Father’s Day? Here are some creative things to do with your favorite dad, all of them inspired by pages in The Times.

headline: S.E.C.’s Revolving Door Draws More Scrutiny
text: Peter J. Henning follows issues involving securities law and white-collar crime for DealBook’s White Collar Watch.

headline: A Close-Knit Team on a Plus-Size Show
text: SANTA CLARITA, Calif.

headline: Pharma Drama
text: Lauren Belfer’s death-haunted medical thriller begins in December 1941, just three days after the Japanese assault on Pearl Harbor. Claire Shipley, a photojournalist working for the phenomenally successful Life magazine, has come to the Rockefeller Institute in New York to record one of the earliest trials of a new medication called penicillin. Highly effective in experiments involving bacterial infections in mice, this substance is about to be tried on a human. Will the drug work? Or will it have serious, potentially lethal, side effects? For the patient and the doctors, there’s no real choice: this experiment is a desperate last chance for a 37-year-old man who had been robustly healthy until a seemingly harmless scratch, acquired during a game of tennis, rapidly developed into a life-threatening infection.

headline: Should Your Neighbor Be Banned From Smoking?
text: Many of us work in smoke-free offices, eat in smoke-free restaurants, even drink in smoke-free bars or outdoor cafes. But if we live in an apartment, should the whole building also be smoke free?

headline: The Luck (or Misfortune) of the Draw
text: WIMBLEDON, England –- Just below the spotlights aimed at Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal, and Serena and Venus Williams, some of the world’s top unseeded tennis players got a glimpse of the road ahead at The Championships on Friday.

headline: One World, One Voice
text: I found it a pleasure to read Robert McCrum on the English language’s development in, for instance, the 14th century: “After centuries of repression, the recognition of ‘Everyman’ and the ‘true commons’ was . . . expressed in the simple English words that hold good still.” By the time he reaches the 21st century, however, our connection is shakier.

headline: The Love Not Taken
text: Last summer, at a beach house in the Hamptons, a weekend guest arrived carrying a novel she’d picked up abroad and was loath to put down. Called “One Day,” it was written by David Nicholls, whom some of us recognized as the author of another novel, “Starter for Ten,” a coming-of-age story about a ­working-class boy who goes to an elite university, falls in love with a girl who’s out of his league (and not nearly as nice as he is) and enters an intercollegiate quiz contest. Those of us susceptible to nostalgic reveries of youthful heartache and self-invention (which is to say, all of us) longed to get our hands on Nicholls’s new novel, once our friend revealed its premise:

headline: Where the Times Square Suspect Is Just a Client
text: When the suspect in the Times Square bombing plot appeared in a packed courtroom last month, the government’s table was full: three prosecutors and an F.B.I. agent sat side by side. At the defense table, the suspect, Faisal Shahzad, sat next to a single federal public defender, Julia L. Gatto. They seemed badly outnumbered.

headline: The Kagan Family: Left-Leaning and Outspoken
text: ON a crowded train somewhere in Pennsylvania in the aftermath of World War II, Robert Kagan gave up his seat to Gloria Gittelman, a fellow student from Pennsylvania State University, on a trip home during a school holiday. He was bound for Brooklyn, she for South Philadelphia.

headline: McDowell Leads; Mickelson Charges at U.S. Open
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  The alarm went off at 4:20 on Friday morning, awakening Graeme McDowell, the man from Portrush, Northern Ireland, and setting in motion a most remarkable chain of events in the second round of the United States Open at the Pebble Beach Golf Links.

headline: Samurai Shopper | Here Comes the Sunblock
text: Please tell me you’ve received at least one of the 10,000 memos detailing with grisly relish the terrible effects of sunlight on skin. Then again, if you’ve missed the memos, good for you! Hiding under a rock where the sun don’t shine has definite advantages.

headline: Giving the Crowd What It May Not Crave
text: A LATTER-DAY Mark Twain may eventually coin the perfect name for the current era of failing institutions and diminished expectations. Until then there is the summation of recent history that Louis C. K. provided in an interview with Conan O’Brien.

headline: Counterfeit Condoms and a New Arrangement
text: New Yorkers long ago stopped being fooled by the luxury knockoffs peddled from sidewalk card tables at prices too good to be true. Not that they always keep their wallet in check — as a close inspection of many a supposedly pedigreed Louis Vuitton handbag might reveal, if the penny-pinching owner would allow it.

headline: ‘War and Peace’: The Fact-Check
text: Dominic Lieven, a professor of history at the London School of Economics, is a distinguished scholar of the czarist empire, and in this superb book he has written his masterpiece. The story he tells — Russia’s gargantuan struggle with Napoleon — will be known to most people through Tolstoy’s  “War and Peace,”  and it takes a brave man to challenge the great novelist. But that indeed is Lieven’s goal, and for the most persuasive of reasons. He believes that Tolstoy’s account is badly misleading (Lieven has a historian’s natural concern for the facts) and perhaps more important has skewed our view of Russia and contributed to our tendency to misunderstand and belittle its role in international affairs.

headline: In 90 Seconds, Germany Falls Back Into the Pack
text: A week ago, Germany was the power of this World Cup, having pounded Australia into submission, 4-0. Serbia was nobody’s favorite to advance out of the group stage after losing in a most uninspired way to Ghana.

headline: Goose Search Is Postponed Pending Feather Loss
text: Rangers in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, have called off efforts to apprehend an elusive goose with an arrow through its neck until it gets easier to catch. That should happen soon, when the Canada goose, variously known as Sticky or Target, begins molting.

headline: Bair’s Next Target: Fannie and Freddie
text: Sheila C. Bair, the chairwoman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said Friday that overhauling the nation’s mortgage-finance system “should rise to the top of the agenda” as soon as Congress completes its sweeping financial regulatory bill, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Maiko Matsushima and David Brick
text: IT was just another intense artistic collaboration, or so Maiko Matsushima, a costume designer, and David Brick, a choreographer, thought during an April 2008 production in Princeton, N.J.

headline: Dangerous Zeal
text: Young people have doubtless heard the trash talk about President Obama’s being “un-American,” but they probably have no idea that similar charges against ordinary citizens nearly brought the government to a standstill during the height of the Red scare in the 1950s. Exposure of real spies after World War II and fears of Stalin’s Russia had created a tense mood in Washington. So when a junior Republican senator from Wisconsin, Joseph R. McCarthy, began accusing the State Department of harboring “card-­carrying members of the Communist Party,” for a time he tapped into a popular cause. But as chairman of the Senate’s Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, McCarthy would pursue his anti-­Communist crusade with a zeal that would ensnare and wrong many innocent people.

headline: Drawn and Courted
text: The idea of a collaboration between Lois Lowry and Jules Feiffer is exciting news. Lowry, twice winner of the Newbery Medal, is the author of dozens of much-loved works for children and young adults, from the popular “Anastasia Krupnik” series to the “Giver” trilogy, while Feiffer is a prize-winning cartoonist and playwright who has also written and illustrated numerous picture books and children’s novels. With “The Birthday Ball,” this illustrious pair tries something new for both: the comic fairy tale.

headline: Under the Spotlight
text: Dance: 10. Looks: 3. What is adolescence but a long, grueling theatrical audition? The cruel spotlight and the snickering from the darkness might as well describe the morning walk to the locker through a gantlet of rich kids, bullies and fabulous, distant beauties. This is one reason the authors of two new gay-themed young adult books center their plots on the production of a high school musical. The other is that “gay” and “musical” tend to exert a world-­bending magnetic force on each other.

headline: A Decent Man
text: To the Editor:

headline: Children’s Bookshelf
text: GOAL!  By Mina Javaherbin.Illustrated by A. G. Ford.  Candlewick. $16.99. (Ages 6 to 10)

headline: In Evil’s Clutches
text: A bleeding-heart sensibility isn’t the first thing you expect from a thriller. Unless, of course, the author happens to be John Harvey, whose boundless empathy imparts a grave and tender tone to his bleak crime novels. In FAR CRY (Otto Penzler/Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $26), that compassion is aroused by Ruth Pierce, a London schoolteacher whose husband sweet-talks her into letting their preadolescent daughter, Heather, join a classmate’s family on a camping trip to Cornwall. Under this permissive clan’s slapdash care, the girls become lost in a treacherous coastal fog, and Heather’s battered body turns up on a cliff ledge near the crumbling remains of an old mine shaft.

headline: Changing the Rules
text: This week’s column is by Capt. Joseph Himpelmann, who has recently returned to the United States after serving as a Battery Commander in a heavy brigade combat team based in Mosul. The name of the base has been withheld to avoid jeopardizing service members still operating in that area. The views expressed in this blog are those of the author and do not reflect the official policy or position of the Department of the Army, Department of Defense or the United States government. If you are an active-duty service member and would like to submit a post, please e-mail us at AtWar@nytimes.com.

headline: Week in Pictures, June 18

headline: Special Edition of Kimmel’s Show Friday Night — With the Lakers
text: Jimmy Kimmel and ABC will get an unexpected gift Friday night: a new show when a repeat had been scheduled. And the show  will include about the most prominent guests a talk show could land this week: Kobe Bryant and other members of the Los Angeles Lakers.

headline: TimesCast | June 18, 2010
text: In today's Timescast, reports on the refugee crisis in Kyrgyzstan, Mississippi governor Haley Barbour, casting the next Billy Elliot and an interview with author Christopher Hitchens .

headline: End Times, Perhaps, for Late-Night Annoyances
text: What constitutes an urban nuisance is often in the eye — or ear — of the beholder.

headline: Senate Leader Says He Leaked Memo to Aqueduct Bidder
text: ALBANY–The messy bidding process over a casino at Aqueduct got even messier on Friday.

headline: World Cup Replay: Day 8, June 18
text: Serbia upset Germany, which played much of the game short-handed and could not convert a penalty kick.

headline: While Oil Gushes, Invisible Ocean Impacts Build
text: One reason the public, and politicians, have been so focused on the unchecked environmental disaster unfolding in the Gulf of Mexico is the vivid nature of the assault from gushing oil. We have a much harder time with less visible, and more incremental, environmental disruptions. The carbon dioxide being added to the atmosphere at a rate of about 1,000 tons a second is invisible and will have impacts that are spread in time and space and often are a matter of shifted odds of adverse events, not direct harm. The same is true for changes in the oceans driven by human activity, including the CO2 buildup.

headline: Lighten Up
text: The Takeaway Yes, we’re painfully aware of how important it is to maintain structure in our lives, especially these days. But what about the boredom that comes with it? Fortunately, loosening up doesn’t mean you have to look like a slob; this spring’s tailoring is refreshingly, well, untailored.

headline: Fallon: ‘Lost in Transition’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: Yesterday during a press conference, B.P. chairman Carl-Henric Svanberg caused some controversy when he said B.P. cares about the “small people.” Part of his new strategy — plug the hole by digging himself into a deeper one.

headline: Ferguson: ‘The Power to Shut Off the Internet’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: There is a new bill in the Senate that is upsetting a lot of people. This bill would give the President the power to shut off the Internet. Al Gore is strongly opposed to it. Not because he invented the Internet. Because he did. But because he just signed up for Match.com.

headline: Letterman: ‘He’s Dying His Hair’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: Have you seen President Obama lately? People are saying he’s dying his hair. Right there, that’s a good use for the oil.

headline: Snoop Dogg Is ‘Astonished’ by Dutch Festival Ban
text: Earlier Friday, ArtsBeat reported that Snoop Dogg was dropped from the lineup of a coming festival in The Hague, where authorities said they wanted to ensure the “open and friendly character” of that concert.

headline: Around the World With Exotic Grains
text: If you’re like most adventurous cooks, your pantry probably contains at least one or two bags or canisters of unusual grains that looked enticing at the exotic food store but which you’re not quite sure what to do with. In this week’s Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman offers five delicious ways to cook with chickpea flour, a staple of Indian cooking, Italian semolina, the flour traditionally used to make pasta, and bulgur, a Middle Eastern favorite. Even if you don’t have these ingredients on hand, it may well be worth a trip to the market to get them.

headline: Jumble Fever
text: Matchy-matchy is so last decade.

headline: Leno: ‘A Little Weasel Guy’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: Well, the big story, President Obama will set aside $20 billion to pay the victims of the oil spill in the Gulf. Well, that is good news. The bad news — it still comes out to less than, like, a dollar a gallon.

headline: Obama: Ten Thousand Points of Infrastructure
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — With the unemployment rate still stuck close to 10 percent, President Obama flew to this political swing state on Friday to promote his economic stimulus program, which he credited with its 10,000th road project.

headline: Is It Illegal to Lie About Your Pay in a Job Interview?
text: When the DailyWorth retracted its recent post about a woman who had inflated her current salary during a job interview, the site’s editor wrote that a number of human resources personnel had said that “even slight salary history inflations are illegal and could jeopardize your job application.”

headline: Congrats, Michigan
text: For the first time in four years, Michigan did not have the highest monthly state unemployment rate, according to a new Labor Department report for May.

headline: Weekend Competition: Voulez-vous Vuvuzela?
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to dally with sounds, descriptions of sound, and onomatopoeia.

headline: Across the Threshold of Fatherhood
text: IN early 2006 I was coming out of an extended trip through what I can now only call a spiritual wasteland. The first line from Dante’s “Inferno” had been rattling around inside me  I, too, had come to the middle of my life and found myself in a dark wood, having lost my way.

headline: Vain Glorious | Grooming Rx
text: “The world doesn’t need more products, just better ones,” says Chad Murawczyk, who opened MiN New York, an old-style apothecary, on one of SoHo’s few remaining gritty stretches six months ago. To this end, Murawczyk has stocked the shop’s dark-wood shelves with exclusive and hard-to-find fragrances like Linari’s “Notte Bianca” (a favorite of David Bowie; $195) and Arabian Nights from Kilian Perfume as an Art ($395), as well as grooming products from Taylor of Old Bond Street and handmade straight razors from the French firm Thiers-Issard ($200-500). More a cabinet of curiosities than a drugstore, it’s as if Zitomer had been transported to Savile Row.

headline: Volvo Recalling 500 Cars for Shifter Problem
text: Volvo is recalling about 500 of its 2010 and 2011 vehicles because of a problem with the gearshift lever, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: England Changes Keepers for Algeria
text: After talking about the value of giving players second chances, England Coach Fabio Capello decided that one big mistake was enough in a World Cup for goalkeeper Robert Green. Capello’s lineup was released an hour before Friday night’s game against Algeria in Cape Town, and the starting goalkeeper was David James.

headline: The Dead Gulf Whale
text: In Friday’s paper, I write about a dead whale found in the Gulf of Mexico less than 100 miles from the site of the Deepwater Horizon oil leak. Government scientists say the whale is so decomposed that they will never be able to determine if oil was the cause of death.

headline: Unexpected Harmony
text: OVER the last few months the four Filipino-American R&B singers from the San Francisco Bay Area known as Legaci have appeared on some of the biggest stages of American pop. There they were, belting perfect four-part harmony on “Saturday Night Live,” finger-snapping and line-dancing like the Temptations on “The View,” “Ellen” and  “Today,”  and crooning to a hysterical, sold-out crowd of 15,000 at the annual KIIS-FM Wango Tango blowout in Los Angeles. (They took the stage just after Kesha and Adam Lambert, just before Ludacris and Usher.)

headline: In the Shadows Onstage, Stars Online
text: The members of Legaci, a Filipino-American R&B ensemble, were rising stars on YouTube even before becoming backup singers for the pop star Justin Bieber.

headline: Trouble Seen for Gothamist Sale to Cablevision
text: 3:00 p.m. | Updated The proposed sale of Gothamist, the city-focused blog network, to Cablevision may be in trouble. The Village Voice’s Runnin’ Scared blog reported Friday that the deal had collapsed, citing unnamed sources.

headline: Value to Big Powers May Not Save Kyrgyzstan
text: MOSCOW  A year and a half ago, the world’s great powers were fighting like polecats over Kyrgyzstan, a landlocked stretch of mountains in the heart of Central Asia.

headline: Larry King to Host Oil-Spill Telethon
text: Larry King will host a two-hour celebrity telethon on Monday night to raise money for the response to the Gulf oil spill, CNN said.

headline: Oil Workers Muse on Renewable Energy
text: Two weeks ago, I had the opportunity to visit a deepwater rig not unlike the Deepwater Horizon. This one was called the Ocean Monarch, and as I note in Friday’s Times, the lower-level workers on board — the roustabouts, roughnecks and others in the brawny nomenclature of offshore work — worried openly about their futures amid a six-month moratorium on deepwater oil drilling.

headline: Senate Makes Medicare Fix for Doctors
text: With lawmakers worried that older Americans relying on Medicare could begin losing access to health care, the Senate on Friday approved a six-month plan to prevent a steep cut in doctor fees paid by the federal health program.

headline: Resort Report | 3.1 Phillip Lim
text: Certain editors were rifling through the racks of Phillip Lim’s resort clothing in a bit of a frenzy. (Most popular were the cropped gray sweaters and A-line leather skirts.) This collection — which was inspired by Bianca Jagger — contains so many wearable, affordable separates, one couldn’t help but start planning December’s purchases. The soft color palette — pale peach, meadow green, daffodil and cream — will mix easily into any closet and stretch well into spring/summer.

headline: World Cup 2010 | Snatching a Tie From the Jaws of Victory
text: If anthropologists ever wind up studying why soccer did or did not ever take hold as a demi-religion in the United States, they might be interested in this sociological World Cup dispatch from Soccer Headquarters.

headline: School Officials Say Candidate Overstated His Role

headline: Referee Again in Center of Controversy
text: 10:23 p.m. | Update  An article in the Journal du Mali from two days before the match profiles Coulibaly and offers a brighter view of his performance in the African Nations Cup final last January than those of other observers: “When Koman called his family to inquire about the news, his wife informed him that the house was swamped by neighbors who came out to show their joy and pride after the excellent performance of their compatriot in the final of the CAN.”

headline: Stunning Rally, Shocking Call
text: JOHANNESBURG — As resilient as the United States soccer team was again, falling behind and then catching up, Friday’s 2-2 draw with Slovenia at the World Cup brought mixed feelings: satisfaction with a fierce comeback and disappointment that something greater had been earned but not awarded.

headline: Surveying Wildlife in Alaska
text: While packing the waterproof “dry bag” with clothes and supplies from my duffel, I find I am missing the bug hat. I have the right clothes and layers to keep me warm and dry across changing Arctic conditions, but finding the bug hat represents the difference between being sane and insane on warm windless days. It is a baggy net of sanity.

headline: Balancing Levity and Heft in an Exploration of Desire
text: IN Alain Resnais’s splendid and elliptical 1977 film, “Providence,” the narrator  a dying writer played with dyspeptic gusto by John Gielgud  explains that it’s been said his search for style has often come at the expense of feeling. “I put it another way,” he says, “that style is feeling in its most elegant and economic expression.” It’s a wittily self-reflexive moment from a director who for much of his long, astonishing career has been accused of creating mere exercises in style, films without the requisite drama and empathetic characters with obvious motivations, a cinema (or should we say sin?) of the brain instead of the heart.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Gates'
text: The new ABC vampire drama is largely set in a subdivision.

headline: Iran Security Officials Call West’s New Sanctions Illegal
text: The top security body in Iran condemned as illegal sanctions imposed on Iran this month by the United Nations, the United States and the European Union, and warned that it would respond to any measures that threatened its national security, the semi-official ISNA news agency reported.

headline: Faulty Propulsion System Eyed in Ferry Crash
text: The crash on May 8 of a Staten Island ferry that was previously involved in a deadly wreck may have been caused by defective parts in the boat’s propulsion system, according to a report from federal investigators that was released on Friday.

headline: Edward or Jacob, Have It Your Way at Burger King

headline: The Heart and Soul (and Divas) Behind a Summer Songsmith
text: CAN there be a summer that’s not soundtracked by The-Dream? This Atlanta producer and songwriter helped create hits like Rihanna’s  “Umbrella”  and Beyoncé’s “Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It),” for which he won two Grammys, as well as “Me Against the Music” for Britney Spears and Madonna, and  “Baby”  for Justin Bieber. This summer he is releasing his third solo album, “Love King,” out June 29 from Def Jam. In an interview at a Midtown hotel, The-Dream, 31, born Terius Youngdell Nash, ordered Patrón for himself and Melena Ryzik, and talked about his strict grandfather, songwriting and the music he’s listening to. Here are excerpts from the conversation.

headline: Full Figured Fashion Week
text: Shopping can be a dreadful experience in general. But if you’re the sort of woman who actually enjoys eating on a semiregular basis, and who prefers fashions that look like they weren’t manufactured by the American Tent and Awning Company, it’s downright traumatic. Designers and clothing stores have slowly become aware of this; according to the NPD Group, a market research company, the women’s plus-size apparel market hovers at $17.9 billion, up from $17.7 billion in 2009.

headline: Iraq Killings Point Up Persistence of Militants

text: The gay scene in this city is vibrant and flourishing.

headline: Signs of Hope as BP Captures Record Oil Amounts

text: Following is the third and final set of responses from Rebecca Forman, who has been working as a court reporter in the Manhattan federal courthouse since February 2003.

headline: Better Teams Are Giving the Yankees Problems
text: The Yankees enter this weekend’s series against the Mets tied for first place in the American League East, not to mention the best record in all of baseball. They have not started a season this well since 2004.But underneath their gaudy win-loss record lies an unsettling pattern: The Yankees don’t necessarily rise to the occasion when playing teams with similar talent.

headline: Recipe: Strawberry-Horchata Raspados Shaved Ice
text: On Wednesday, we asked readers to post suggestions for shaved-ice recipes here on Diner’s Journal. The pastry chef Fany Gerson, who grew up in Mexico City and is the author of two forthcoming cookbooks, “My Sweet Mexico” and “Paletas and Aguas Frescas,” kept an eye on the comments, selecting an idea that she would use to generate a recipe. “It was really hard picking one so I went with one that had to do with Mexico and the seasons, something I craved,” she wrote in an e-mail.

headline: For Want of a Goal …
text: I am not a soccer fan, particularly. I hated playing the game as a kid, I’m easily exasperated by the ties and the low scoring and the penalty-kick finales, and I loathe what Jonathan Last calls “the ritual attack of the soccer scolds” every World Cup season. (Also, I had college roommates — and dear friends — who insisted on referring to the game as “football,” even though they were Americans going to college in America, for crying out loud.) But today’s United States-Slovenia match was a beautiful, remarkable, riveting thing to watch — and a game seemingly perfectly engineered, in its stakes and scoring and sudden reversals, to hoist me on my own soccer-hating petard.

headline: If All Politics Is Local, Is All Marketing, Too?
text: An entrepreneur who helped local radio stations go online to snag advertising revenue is back with another venture, this time for local cable systems as well.

headline: Drug for Sexual Desire Disorder Opposed by Panel
text: A federal advisory panel on Friday unanimously voted against recommending approving a drug to treat female sexual desire disorder, but it encouraged the company to continue its research.

headline: Oprah Winfrey Opts for Her Own Private Financial Adviser
text: Oprah Winfrey has been a pioneer in television, her signal achievement being her syndicated talk show as the basis for a media empire. But when it comes to overseeing her vast personal wealth, Ms. Winfrey recently made a choice that harks back to a different age: opting to have her fortune managed by what is known as a family office.

headline: Another House Republican Calls For Barton’s Demotion
text: A day after he took awkwardly to center stage on Capitol Hill, Representative Joe L. Barton of Texas is still getting heat from some of his Republican colleagues for sounding too cozy with BP.

headline: I.P.O.’s Start Showing Some Signs of Life
text: The market for initial public offerings picked up this week as five new issues raised $1.2 billion, making this the biggest week for new American stock offerings so far this year. A number of new issues are scheduled to hit the market in the coming weeks and their weekly values could exceed this week’s total, but continued nervousness in the stock market could lead to further delays and cuts in the size of some offerings.

headline: E.P.A. Delays Ruling on Increasing Ethanol Content in Gasoline
text: A major association representing ethanol manufacturers is furious that the Environmental Protection Agency has delayed making a decision on whether to allow the ethanol content in gasoline to be increased to 15 percent, from 10 percent. But those worried that the increase will damage existing engines applauded the agency’s decision.

headline: A Push-to-Talk Android
text: The first Android phone with push-to-talk walkie-talkie capability will become available from Boost Mobile, the prepaid phone arm of Sprint, on Sunday.

headline: Pitti Uomo | Jil Sander
text: Getting to the Jil Sander show — the main draw this time around at Pitti Uomo, the biannual men’s-fashion trade fair held in Florence — at times felt like being in a remake of “Planes, Trains & Automobiles.” Held in the elaborate garden of a spectacular villa in the far hilly reaches of Florence, the runway presentation was accessible only by a convoy of buses and then smaller vans, which shuttled the fashion folk who had flown in from all over to attend the inaugural show of the spring-summer 2011 season.

headline: Reflections in the Facebook Mirror
text: HOW many times in life must we engage in self-description? Let us count the ways: There’s the anxiety of college applications. The ignominy of Match.com dating. The embroidery of a C.V. sent to prospective employers. And, of course, there is Facebook.

headline: Terror Suspect Wanted in U.S. Released in Kosovo
text: On Friday in Kosovo, a European Union judge ordered the release of an ethnic Albanian man arrested just one day earlier at the request of the Unites States government, which has accused him of “plotting to harm America and Americans.”

headline: Cooking Tools: Crème Brûlée for the Barbecue
text: Last week I enlisted my father-in-law John, a devoted barbecue enthusiast, to help test grill gadgets of dubious value:  thermometer tongs, a water-filled grill brush and wire skewers. Though they all seemed like gimmicks, each one held up surprisingly well under testing. Perhaps pressing our luck, I ordered a barbecue-based cast-iron crème brûlée set. What better way to make “burnt cream” than with a scorching hot cast-iron salamander, right?

headline: Justice Dept. Will Fight Arizona on Immigration
text: The Obama administration has decided to file a lawsuit to strike down a new Arizona law aimed at deporting illegal immigrants, thrusting itself into the fierce national debate over how the United States should enforce immigration policies.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Kyrgyzstan and Elsewhere
text: Even as some refugees who fled the brutal violence in Kyrgyzstan began returning home on Friday, tens of thousands remained in tent camps in neighboring Uzbekistan, Clifford J. Levy of The Times reported, and the United Nations said that one million people could be in need of food and other assistance. Although the bloodletting has ebbed, Kyrgyzstan, an obscure central Asian country that houses American and Russian military bases, remains in serious danger of fragmenting. The provisional Kyrgyz government has lost control of large areas in the southern part of the country because of its failure to quell attacks that have killed at least several hundred ethnic Uzbeks, and possibly many more. Uzbeks have set up de facto autonomous zones and are refusing to recognize the authorities in the Kyrgyz capital. The first two slides were shot for The Times by James Hill.

headline: Shake-Up at BP as Hayward Steps Back From Spill
text: A day after Tony Hayward, the chief executive of BP, was pummeled by members of a House committee over the company’s role in the disastrous oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the chairman of the company said in an interview that Mr. Hayward would step away from daily involvement in BP’s enormous response efforts in the gulf, The New York Times’s Liz Robbins reports.

headline: New Blood for Lineage of Desperate Housewives
text: To anyone who has noticed the alarming number of middle-aged women sublimating their erotic fantasies through the “Twilight” books, the arrival of  “The Gates” Sunday on ABC will come as no surprise. The series has the sensibility of something incubated in a focus group of 40-year-old women complaining of busyness and boredom  of demanding children, sexless marriages and the high prices at Restoration Hardware. In deciding what to call the show, the producers, one suspects, landed on and then rejected something like “The Real and Desperate Vampire Housewives of Somewhere that Looks an Awful Lot Like ‘The Truman Show.’ ”

headline: Sunday Preview
text: Is there such a thing as a budget boutique hotel? Yes, at least in New York, where Stephen Heyman reports that such places have been cropping up over the past three years. He does a test run of rooms at six new hotels — Distrikt, Eventi, Fashion 26, Hotel Indigo, the MAve and the Strand — that are aiming to  offer boutique frills at midrange prices.

headline: Wanderlust | Mr. Mudd and Mr. Gold
text: Now that there’s a Red Wing concept store in Berlin, you can buy Filson in Paris, and scarves from Brooklyn’s Hill-Side have made it to Amsterdam and Trieste, it’s clear that the fetishization of American “heritage” style is no longer just for American men. And few shops in Europe are more faithfully dedicated to heirloom denim and classic work wear than the new Stockholm shop Mr. Mudd and Mr. Gold. The name alone, taken from a Townes Van Zandt classic, is like Carhartts incarnate. The shop, in Södermalm, the city’s answer to Brooklyn and the only party of town that could be called gritty, is outfitted almost entirely in unfinished knotty pine boards; they line the walls and form blocky benches and tables for merchandise that includes Mr. Freedom work shirts, Quoddy moccasins, Pendleton blankets and Wesco motorcycle boots. And true to the cult of craftsmanship, the narrative behind every company the store does business with is highlighted on its Web site. The expertly focused selection of brands includes plenty of international origin — canvas satchels from Brady Bags of England, founded in 1877; Grunden rain gear (Sweden, 1926); jeans by The Real McCoy’s (Japan, 1990) — but the effect is nonetheless a mashup of styles that feels unmistakably American. Easy rider meets California gold miner meets New England stevedore, all crammed into your dad’s tool shed, circa 1976.

headline: Letters to a Father
text: Clearing out my mother’s house, preparing for a move, I found letters I sent home years ago from college. None of them said outright what I should have said — that I was grateful to my parents, for so many reasons, not least of all the fact of their reading and listening. But it was there between the lines.

headline: Green Features Help Sell Homes
text: WHEN Dean Pulsinelli rebuilt his 2,800-square-foot bayfront ranch in Massapequa Park as a gabled 4,900-square-foot colonial in 2004, eco-consciousness was just coming into vogue.

Dyed a crackling shade of red, it shot virtual sparks as Ms. Benatar signed autographs at a Barnes & Noble in Midtown Manhattan, a model in every other way of affably smiling decorum.

text: Crown Heights, Brooklyn, might not have always seemed a safe bet. But residents today are attracted to the area’s ethnic diversity, affordability and relative greenness.

text: ACCORDING to the early evidence, the New Jersey residential market went a bit weak in the knees in May  or even swooned  after the federal home buyer tax credit expired on April 30.

headline: Caught in the Web
text: IN an age when people reflexively turn to the Web to screen everyone from blind dates to baby-sitters, the Internet search has become a part of one of the most opaque and arcane screening processes of all: the New York co-op board review.

headline: Manhattan Was the Dream; Jersey City Fit the Budget
text: RITA MARANDINO spent years hunting for a new home. She could never quite commit to actually buying one  her hands were tied until some business affairs were wrapped up.

headline: A Couple Remake Their Brownstone, Twice
text: HALF a century on, it’s hard to remember the starry-eyed idealism that marked the creation of the West Side Urban Renewal Area, the widely praised effort to replace 20 blocks of notorious slums with housing for a broad mix of social and economic groups.

headline: Planning to Repaint? Read This First
text: HOMEOWNERS and contractors considering renovation projects are grappling with the impact of a new Environmental Protection Agency regulation designed to shield children from exposure to lead paint.

headline: Crown Heights, Brooklyn
text: THERE was a time, more than a century ago, when a stretch of mansions in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, was known as Millionaire’s Row. Most of the biggest houses there are gone, and Crown Heights has had a busy history since that time. But if millionaires are scarcer today, the good news is that in much of the neighborhood the comfortable ambience they once prized is intact. And finding a place to live is less daunting than even a few years ago.

headline: Douglas Durst
text: Mr. Durst, 65, is the chairman of the Durst Organization, one of the city’s largest family-owned real estate businesses. He is also co-president with his cousin Jonathan, known as Jody, though he plans to relinquish that position.

headline: As BP Staggers, Pension Funds Skid
text: Since the Deepwater Horizon rig went down in flames on April 20, BP’s share price has also crashed and burned, losing roughly half its value in just over seven weeks.

headline: Resort Report | Marc by Marc Jacobs
text: Phoebe Philo wasn’t the only one to think that pairing a floral tunic with matching pants would be fresh approach to resort. The team at Marc by Marc Jacobs included a full-on print look in their latest collection, along with some Marc by Marc staples such as whimsical tuxedo shirts, easy silk baby-doll dresses and unfussy brocade shorts. Beauty-wise, Jacobs’s fondness for grunge hair and makeup still prevail.

headline: Verifying Borrowers’ Finances
text: MORTGAGE brokers and lenders will often caution borrowers against charging up their credit cards or changing jobs before the closing date on a home loan. Now that advice seems especially prudent.

headline: A Newcomer Trying to Make Friends
text: Alan Gilbert is in the final weeks of his first season as music director of the New York Philharmonic, and whether or not he thinks in terms of having something to prove  it’s hard to think of a conductor who would not  his programs seem built to please.

headline: When the Going Gets Rough, Try Distraction
text: The World Bridge Federation divides the globe into eight zones. And this is the season for the zonal championships.

headline: Ronald Neame, Filmmaker, Dies at 99
text: Ronald Neame, who was an assistant cameraman on Alfred Hitchcock’s first sound film before going on to photograph, produce and direct more than 70 movies, among them “Tunes of Glory,” “The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie” and “The Poseidon Adventure,” died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. He was 99 and lived in Beverly Hills, Calif.

headline: Woman Rescued From a Trash Chute in Brooklyn
text: A 36-year-old woman who got stuck in a garbage chute in a building in Brooklyn was rescued by dozens of firefighters and other responders after falling about 15 feet down the chute.

text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Will the Americans Advance?
text: England’s shocking 0-0 draw with Algeria in Cape Town on Friday left Wayne Rooney ruefully noting, as he walked off the field, “It’s nice to see your own fans boo you.”

headline: BP Moves Chief Executive to Lesser Role in Spill Response
text: A day after he came under relentless attack at a Congressional hearing, the BP chief executive, Tony Hayward, was pushed aside as the man in charge of the company’s response to the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: A Master of Crossover Relives ’70s Ballads
text: BROOKVILLE, N.Y.  Growing up in the Washington housing project in East Harlem in the 1970s, the singer Marc Anthony came to realize early on that “every family’s identity was based on the music they were blaring out their windows” toward the courtyard below. As he moved about, he recalled this week, he would hear Marvin Gaye coming from one apartment, Ray Barretto from another, the Bee Gees from a third.

headline: In a Sicilian Bundle, a Mediterranean Mix of Everyday Life and Dreams
text: The distant, legendary past and the complicated present are never far apart in the songs of Carmen Consoli, a Sicilian songwriter who’s a superstar in Italy. On Thursday night she played to a club-sized crowd at Le Poisson Rouge. She sang about the myth of Narcissus and about plastic surgery. She also sang about politicians dallying with hookers and about being sexually abused by her uncle.

headline: The Week in Pictures for June 18
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a farm camp, a sandwich shop in the sky, a sailor’s return to land after 1,152 days at sea, and late-night scuba diving.

headline: Lead Actor Withdraws From Hitler Film
text: A plan for the Bollywood film industry’s first feature about Adolf Hitler has already drawn an outcry from Indian moviegoers and historians, and now the project has lost the actor who was to play the lead character, Agence France-Presse reported. Anupam Kher, who was to play Hitler in “Dear Friend Hitler,” said he was withdrawing because of the criticism of the production. On his Twitter account Mr. Kher wrote, “Sometimes human emotions are more important than cinema.” In a statement reported by Reuters, Mr. Kher, left, added: “I have never been moved by commercial considerations, but I have always respected social opinions.” In an earlier description of the film, which is to be directed by Rakesh Ranjan Kumar and will focus on Hitler’s final days, its producers said “Dear Friend Hitler” would reveal the German dictator’s “insecurities, his charisma, his paranoia and his sheer genius.” The filmmakers said the project would not glorify Hitler, but the project, scheduled to begin filming in August, was widely condemned.

headline: Larry King to Host Oil-Spill Telethon
text: Larry King will host a two-hour celebrity telethon on Monday night to raise funds for the response to the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, CNN said. The broadcast, “Disaster in the Gulf: How You Can Help,” will feature appearances by Justin Bieber, Deepak Chopra, Cameron Diaz, Kathy Griffin, Lenny Kravitz, Tim McGraw, Robert Redford and other celebrities, as well as a performance by Sting. Mr. King’s friend Ryan Seacrest will interact with online participants. CNN journalists will report live from the affected region during the telethon. CNN said the funds raised for people and wildlife affected by the oil spill would benefit three charities: the United Way, the National Wildlife Federation and the Nature Conservancy. In January, Mr. King held a similar telethon for victims of the Haiti earthquake.

headline: Big Numbers for ABC
text: The Los Angeles Lakers’ Game 7 victory in the N.B.A. Finals on Thursday lifted ABC to No. 1 on the night by a wide margin. Preliminary overnight numbers for the broadcast were the highest for any N.B.A. Finals game on any network since 1998. Final audience figures were expected to easily surpass the sizable audience of 18.7 million viewers who tuned in to Game 5 on Sunday. CBS ranked second on the night with two repeats of “The Mentalist” at 8 (7.2 million) and 10 (8.2 million) and a rerun of “CSI” in between at 9 (8.3 million). Fox was third, earning 6.1 million viewers at 9 for the first results episode of “So You Think You Can Dance.” NBC finished a distant fourth.

headline: After Rough Campaign, a New Professor of Poetry
text: The 2010 race for Oxford University’s professor of poetry had it all: newfangled rules to allow online voting, an 11th-hour withdrawal by its only female candidate, a furious final round of campaigning by its 10 remaining contenders and plenty of name-calling. And in the end, the front-runner won, anyway. On Friday Oxford said that Geoffrey Hill, author of “King Log,” “Mercian Hymns” and “Without Title,” had won the election to become the university’s 44th professor of poetry. Mr. Hill claimed the victory with a commanding lead, winning 1,156 of more than 2,500 votes; the next closest candidate was Michael Horovitz, the Beat poet, who picked up 353 votes. The voting was open to Oxford alumni and academics. Paula Claire, who was the only woman vying for the position this year, predicted the outcome when she pulled out of the election earlier this month, saying it was “seriously flawed” and too heavily tilted in favor of Mr. Hill. Mr. Hill, an Oxford graduate, is to assume the mantle of poetry professor in the fall, succeeding Christopher Ricks. The post was left open last year after Ruth Padel, the first woman in more than 300 years to win the seat, resigned after it was learned she had alerted reporters to a book describing a decades-old act of sexual harassment that Derek Walcott, a 2009 candidate, was accused of having committed.

headline: Snoop Dogg ‘Astonished’ by Dutch Festival Ban
text: Having spent the better part of four years fighting for his right to travel to Britain, the hip-hop star Snoop Dogg, left, now finds himself a rapper non grata in The Hague, where the authorities had him scratched from the lineup of a free concert planned for later this month, BBC News reported. Snoop Dogg was scheduled to perform at the Parkpop festival in The Hague on June 27, but the mayor and law enforcement officials there asked its organizers to find another artist to replace him to ensure the “open and friendly character” of the festival. In a statement the rapper’s management wrote that Snoop Dogg was “astonished by the decision of the Mayor of The Hague,” and is “a mainstay at music festivals all over the world and has performed at all of these without incident.”

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 18
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Simon and Garfunkel Suspend Tour
text: Simon and Garfunkel’s summer tour of the United States and Canada, already postponed once because of Art Garfunkel’s vocal strain, has now been put off indefinitely. A statement on the duo’s Web site, simonandgarfunkel.com, says Mr. Garfunkel is recovering from vocal paresis. That condition “inhibits the duo from performing shows at the highest possible level,” the statement says, “and it is for that reason and out of respect for their fans that Paul and Art have decided to put the tour on hold.” The tour was to have begun on July 3 in Vancouver, British Columbia, and included stops in Tanglewood in Lenox, Mass., and Atlantic City. The two played the New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival in April, where Mr. Garfunkel complained from the stage that his voice was “a little elusive.” That show was to have kicked off a tour, but within a few days it was postponed. Mr. Garfunkel has also canceled recent solo concerts, including one last month at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark.

headline: A Church Sells Its Tiffany Window
text: Movers this week took out a Tiffany window, below, from the First Baptist Church in Brattleboro, Vt., after the church sold the century-old scene of St. John the Divine in a garden to an antiques collector. The collector, Cameel Halim, is building a stained glass museum in Illinois and paid $85,000 for the window. Mr. Halim’s only competition, from a group of philanthropists including Michael Eisner, the former chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, offered the church $47,500 to leave the window in the choir loft. The movers replaced the window with simple colored panes. “It happened very quickly,” said Karen Davis, a trustee of First Baptist. “It’s sad for the church for sure.” The proceeds will pay for repairs to the Gothic brick building and to operate a homeless shelter. Mr. Halim is turning a Victorian house in Evanston, Ill., into a museum with an 8,000-square-foot gallery for his windows by designers including Louis Comfort Tiffany and his arch-rival, John La Farge.

headline: Week in Culture Pictures, June 18
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Hamming It Up, With Pink Light, Flashes of Murakami and Flowered Bikinis
text: The title of John Jasperse’s recent full-length work is a long and unwieldy one. But it’s as perfect a description of theater as any you’ll come across. It is (drum roll): “Truth, Revised Histories, Wishful Thinking and Flat Out Lies.”

headline: From the Street, but Domesticated
text: Once upon a time, you could glue a cigarette butt to a canvas or haul dirty tires into a gallery and upset people’s nervous systems. Now, art is so adept at absorbing any whiff of mischief that it is difficult to retain any meaningful vestige of the street. This is especially true in “Keith Haring: A New Dimension” and “Chakaia Booker: Eminent Domain,” on display in the Museum Building and the Domestic Arts Building at Grounds for Sculpture in Hamilton.

headline: From Memphis to Arizona to Seattle, Navigating Dreams and Blues
text: WASHINGTON  The questions often arise: “What is American about American ballet? What is peculiar to American ballet?” They arose formally at the Kennedy Center Opera House on Thursday evening in a post-performance discussion after Ballet Memphis, Ballet Arizona and Pacific Northwest Ballet each presented a ballet as part of the Ballet Across America season.

headline: Thieves Are in the House, and They’re All Related
text: “Scoundrels,” a new series about a family of thieves and con artists in Palm Springs, Calif., pulls a small con of its own during its premiere Sunday night on ABC. It starts out looking like one show, a sexy, light-hearted comedy about larceny, and ends up looking like another: a slightly more serious, and potentially irritatingly sentimental, dramedy about trying to go straight.

headline: Legal Eagle
text: Gloria Allred started out as a pioneering legal advocate for women’s rights. Now, she is the fierce go-to lawyer for the tabloid-friendly mistresses of celebrities like Tiger Woods. You have  a problem with that?

headline: Book Review Podcast: Christopher Hitchens
text: This week: Christopher Hitchens on his memoir, “Hitch-22″; Chris Suellentrop on Tom Bissell’s “Extra Lives: Why Video Games Matter”; Patricia Cohen describes a brewing controversy in the Orthodox Jewish community; and Jennifer Schuessler has bestseller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: Creative Types, Learning to Be Business-Minded
text: Paul Barman thinks his is a great idea for a business: personalized, hip-hop versions of the traditional Jewish wedding contract, known as the ketubah, that he writes and sings.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Christopher Hitchens
text: This week: Christopher Hitchens on his memoir, “Hitch-22″; Chris Suellentrop on Tom Bissell’s “Extra Lives: Why Video Games Matter”; Patricia Cohen describes a controversy brewing in the Orthodox Jewish community; and Jennifer Schuessler has bestseller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: The Avenger
text: ON a May morning in Los Angeles, a beautiful, somber brunette sat to the left of the lawyer who would present her case to a room full of about 75 reporters, photographers and camera people. “We are here today because another alleged victim of Roman Polanski’s sexual predatory conduct has come forward,” the lawyer explained, her face set in a familiar, concerned frown as the cameras whirred. “Charlotte Lewis, of London, England, who appeared in Roman Polanski’s film ‘Pirates,’ alleges that she was victimized by Mr. Polanksi when she was 16 years old.”

headline: Goldman Is Said to Seek More Time for S.E.C. Reply
text: Goldman Sachs asked for more time to respond to the Securities and Exchange Commission’s civil charges accusing it of securities fraud, Bloomberg News reports, citing two unidentified people with direct knowledge of the matter.

headline: Sports Fans Break Records on Twitter
text: Sports fans have spent the week furtively watching the World Cup during the workday and staying up late to watch the N.B.A. playoffs. They have also been logging on to Twitter.

headline: Just Wanna Have (Family-Friendly) Fun
text: In the 27 years since her exuberant anthem “Girls Just Wanna Have Fun” catapulted her to fame, Cyndi Lauper, 56, has become known as much for her dotty persona as for her high-octane voice. (Her next album, “Memphis Blues,” is being released this month.)   On Sundays, she turns the volume down to spend quality time with her husband, the actor David Thornton, and their 12-year-old son, Declyn, in and around their Upper West Side home.

headline: Twice-Baked Sour Cherry Pie
text: Time: 1 hour 45 minutes, plus chilling time

headline: A Fruit Pie Crust With Crunch
text: IN a quirk of pie-making tradition, open-faced pies, such as custards, chocolate cream or pumpkin chiffon, get the best crust  pre-baked shells that are flaky, crisp and golden. But fruit pies, baked with raw dough that is often pale and soggy, get short shrift.

headline: Obama Girls Go Hollywood, With Mom
text: LOS ANGELES — Michelle Obama and her daughters, Malia and Sasha, had something of a Hollywood moment this week on a private family trip to California.

headline: Salade Lyonnaise

headline: Lionel Richie at Tuskegee University
text: The singer Lionel Richie delivered the commencement address at Tuskegee University on May 9, 2010.

headline: The Secret to a Great Salade Lyonnaise
text: WHETHER Lyon ever was the gastronomic capital of France is debatable, but it sure has spawned some great dishes, including salade Lyonnaise, not the most simple salad ever made but one that approaches perfection in a way others do not. The combination of bitter greens (traditionally frisée, though escarole, dandelion, and arugula all work beautifully), crisp bacon, barely cooked eggs and warm vinaigrette is really unbeatable.

headline: Manny Being Manny Being Quiet
text: BOSTON — Manny Ramirez, wearing designer jeans and his trademark dreadlocks, entered the visitors’ clubhouse at Fenway Park about three hours before game time on Friday and took a seat in front of his small locker

headline: Where Classical Meets Pop
text: CHAMBER music has been a key part of the Caramoor International Music Festival in Katonah for most of its 64 years. But rarely has the festival presented as wide a spectrum of chamber offerings as it will in its 65th season, which opens this month.

headline: Salade Lyonnaise, Stateside
text: It’s been 20 years since my first visit to Lyon, France, my first taste of real salade Lyonnaise, and the birth of one of those lifelong food memories. Unlike many of them, however, this one is easily duplicated, and without much work. See this week’s Minimalist column for more.

headline: Credit Unions Are Beckoning With Open Arms
text: Everyone can join a credit union, but not everyone can join any credit union.

headline: Small Space, Big Egos: Something Will Explode
text: GLENCOE, Ill.  If you’ve ever wondered, with either fascination or revulsion, just what it might be like to get in bed with Stanley Kowalski, consider a trip to this Chicago suburb forthwith. The Writers’ Theater production of “A Streetcar Named Desire” directed by David Cromer takes you within a millimeter or two of this carnal knowledge. If you happen to be seated in the right spot  the easily unnerved might call it the wrong spot  you can practically see those “colored lights” going yourself when Stanley and Stella engage in a fraught bout of lovemaking after that poker game ends in violence and tears.

headline: After a Friend’s Death, Giving His Novel Life
text: WHEN Jack Rosenblatt died at work six years ago, 58 years old and stamping passports at the immigration desk at Kennedy International Airport, he left behind a family, a close-knit group of friends and a troubled first career at a string of equally troubled independent bookshops. He also left behind, on his computer, the manuscript for a New York-based detective novel that he had been unable to sell.

headline: Art Studios as Big as All Outdoors
text: A MAN grappling with three shopping bags, two canvases and a wooden easel scurried behind Belvedere Castle in Central Park on a recent Saturday, his gaze trained on the horizon. Just short of slamming into a willow tree, he stopped, dropped his gear and dumped an untidy mountain of acrylic paint tubes onto the banks of Turtle Pond.

headline: Katie Park, Jason Song
text: Sung Hee Katie Park and Dr. Jason Jikang Song are to be married Sunday at the Tides Estate, a caterer in North Haledon, N.J. The Rev. Joseph Byun, a minister of the Christian Reformed Church in North America, is to officiate.

headline: Fault or No-Fault: Divorce Case Studies
text: The New York Senate approved legislation this week that would pave the way for no-fault divorces in the state. Room for Debate took a look at how no-fault laws have affected the rest of the country, and what the law would mean for New Yorkers. Many readers wrote in to share tales of their exits from failed marriages or their attempts to hold on to what was a lasting commitment. Here are excerpts of their stories.

text: IT is weak on narrative, has a hackneyed title, refers haughtily to the author in the third person, and lacks the eloquence for which the author’s father is famous. But the plot is strikingly unconventional.
