text: More mothers die during pregnancy or soon after in New York than in almost every other state, and according to reports released on Friday by the New York Academy of Medicine and the city’s health department, social factors like poverty, obesity and lack of insurance may be responsible.

headline: For BP, Purgatory or Apology?
text: Presidential addresses come and go, but oil spills are forever, or at least for the foreseeable future. So while President Obama’s speech on Tuesday was panned by nearly everyone (a notable exception being my colleague Ross Douthat), he can perhaps take some solace in the fact that the appearance by BP’s chief executive, Tony Hayward, before Congress on Thursday wasn’t exactly a spellbinder, either. Unless, as Esquire’s Marty Beckerman suspects, the rubes on Capitol Hill were simply unaware that Hayward “is not an empty suit; he is a visionary modern philosopher on par with Sartre and Foucault, perhaps even a mystic.” Here is Beckerman’s deconstruction of Hayward’s deconstructionism:

headline: Among the Flotsam and Jetsam
text: “The Sea Around Us” at the Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn Harbor sets out to explore 19th- and 20th-century European and American artists’ attraction to bodies of water. The exhibition, organized by Constance Schwartz, the museum’s director emerita, includes many decent paintings borrowed from private collections and regional museums. However, the curatorial impulse frequently overwhelms the art on view.

headline: Partner Accuses BP of Recklessness
text: HOUSTON  The chief executive of Anadarko Petroleum, a BP partner, accused BP late Friday of recklessness in the way the company managed the gulf well project before it ended in environmental disaster.

headline: For the Father Who Eats Everything
text: WHEN Godfrey Polistina wants to unwind, he grabs some of his buddies and heads to a restaurant for a beer and a bite. But it isn’t your typical burger he’s looking for. Instead, Mr. Polistina and his pals — mostly investment bankers, tennis pros and old neighborhood friends — head to Los Gemelos in Port Chester for a veal head or tongue taco. If it’s a Saturday, they might go for the tripe stew special.

headline: A Young Father’s Balancing Act
text: Leon Britton Jr. is a graduate of the Bronx Fatherhood Program, a service that trains men ages 16 to 24 in the ways of fatherhood.

headline: For a Young Parent, Lessons in Fatherhood
text: Like many young fathers, Leon Britton Jr. begins his day early, at 5 a.m. But not because of a crying baby. He lives two miles away from his daughter, Diamond, who is 2 1/2, and her mother, Rosa Colon, who is expecting their second child in August. Mr. Britton commutes from the Pelham Parkway neighborhood of the Bronx to Long Island City, Queens, where he works as an animal control technician. At 3 p.m., he heads for Ms. Colon's apartment in the Gun Hill section of the Bronx, where he hangs out with Diamond until about 9 p.m., then returns to his own place to sleep.

headline: Katie Albert and William Bolton
text: Katie Ia Albert and William Burnside Bolton were married Saturday at Edgewood Farm in Truro, Mass. Dr. Frank Silagy, an uncle of the bride, received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate.

headline: Where Gulf Spill Might Place on the Roll of Disasters
text: From the Oval Office the other night, President Obama called the oil leak in the Gulf of Mexico “the worst environmental disaster America has ever faced.” Senior people in the government have echoed that language.

headline: Nell Clement, Benjamin Yurman-Glaser

Nancy Yurman, an aunt of the bridegroom, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at Martha Clara Vineyards in Riverhead, N.Y.

headline: Torre’s Back in Boston
text: BOSTON — Los Angeles Dodgers Manager Joe Torre had to veer through a swarm of reporters before he could take a seat on the bench in the visitors’ dugout before batting practice on Friday night. When he sat down, he could not help but smile.

headline: Japan’s Far Right Blocks Screenings of ‘The Cove’
text: YOKOHAMA, Japan  “The Cove,” an Oscar-winning documentary about dolphin hunting in Japan, would seem to be a natural fit for movie theaters here, but so far the distributor has yet to find a single one that will screen the film.

headline: ‘Pan-Southern’ Barbecue
text: Nat Hayden’s Real Pit Barbecue, specializing in slow-cooked, wood-smoked meats, is named for a Windsor native who served in the Continental Army, yet its menu is hardly provincial.

headline: Pan-Asian Cuisine for the Eye and Palate
text: SOON after we were seated at Wild Rice, a smart-looking pan-Asian restaurant on Route 1 in Fairfield (not to be confused with the restaurant of the same name in Norwalk), the waiter plunked down a little dish of marinated cabbage, cucumbers and carrots. It was light, crisp, fresh tasting, and just a little sweet. Our order was taken expeditiously — and when it arrived, we were enchanted. The food was vibrant looking, colorful and exquisitely presented.

headline: Andrea Thompson, Michael Peed
text: Andrea Kim Thompson and Michael Fansher Peed were married Saturday at Madison Valley Ranch, in Ennis, Mont. The Rev. Amy Peed McCullough, a sister of the bridegroom and United Methodist minister, officiated.

text: CAPE TOWN  Even the vuvuzelas were no match for England’s traveling army of soccer fans, no matter what their mood.
