headline: U.N. Leader Criticizes Israeli Plan for Inquiry
text: UNITED NATIONS  The panel announced by Israel to investigate the deadly assault on a flotilla seeking to run the Gaza blockade lacks adequate international weight to make the panel credible, the United Nations secretary general said Friday.

headline: Natia Rtveliashvili, Patrick Mangan
text: Natia Rtveliashvili and Patrick Nugent Mangan are to be married Sunday at the Shrine of St. Elizabeth Ann Seton at the Church of Our Lady of the Rosary in Manhattan. The Rev. Mark J. Lane, a Roman Catholic priest, is to lead the ceremony.

headline: Tastes of Local Bounty, From Vine and Sea
text: ONE evening last winter, Jim Waters, a North Fork vintner, and Tom Schaudel, the chef and co-owner of A Mano Osteria and Wine Bar in Mattituck, met for dinner at the restaurant. According to Mr. Waters, the two men, who are good friends, opened several bottles of wine, including one of Mr. Waters’s own, a Waters Crest 2007 cabernet franc, and a bottle of Mr. Schaudel’s private label cabernet sauvignon. Then, as Mr. Schaudel tells it, he uncorked some “big Italian reds,” which they finished off with the help of late-arriving friends. Between one glass and another, the Long Island Wine and Food Festival was conceived.

headline: Farley Whetzel, John Bills
text: Farley Walton Whetzel and John Vincent Bills were married Saturday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Rev. James L. Burns, its rector, performed the ceremony.

headline: Amy Jaick, Steven Gottlieb
text: Amy Lauren Jaick, a daughter of Eleanor and Kenneth Jaick of Florham Park, N.J., was married Saturday to Steven Lloyd Gottlieb, the son of Rita and Ronald A. Gottlieb of Brookville, N.Y. Rabbi Michael S. Churgel officiated at Tribeca Rooftop in New York.

headline: Hoping Tourists Will Flock to Hogwarts (and Spend a Few Galleons)
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  First Harry Potter helped rejuvenate book publishing. Then he powered a boom in family mega-movies. Can the boy wizard now use his global popularity to give a lift to central Florida’s $31 billion tourism business?

headline: New York Reaches Deal to Raise Cigarette Tax
text: Cigarette taxes in New York would jump by $1.60 a pack under a tentative deal reached between Gov. David A. Paterson and legislative leaders, which would give New York the nation’s highest state cigarette taxes.

headline: Coach’s Son Supplies Energy for U.S. Rally
text: JOHANNESBURG  Michael Bradley refused to let it go. Not the unexplained foul in the 85th minute of a 2-2 tie with Slovenia  “I have no comment about that play,” he said  but everything else about a physical, clutch-and-grab World Cup soccer game at Ellis Park that more strongly resembled the rugby usually played here.

headline: A Marine, a Mosque, a Question
text: A few hours after the town hall meeting began, deep into the question-and-answer portion, Bill Finnegan lined up for a turn at the microphone. He had not come with any intention to speak, but as the evening dragged on, he changed his mind.

headline: After the Security Council Vote
text: There has been a lot of talk, for a long time, about reining in Iran’s nuclear ambitions. Far too many countries have found Iran’s oil wealth simply too hard to resist. There are encouraging signs that for at least some major players, patience with Tehran may be running out.

headline: A Tricky Balance for Oil-State Politicians
text: WASHINGTON — The outburst by Representative Joe L. Barton of Texas in support of BP underscored the potential peril for lawmakers forced to respond to crises involving industries vital to their regions, and whose bountiful donations finance their political campaigns.

headline: Sara Gallagher and Benjamin Midberry
text: Sara Aileen Gallagher, a daughter of Valerie S. Gallagher and William T. Gallagher of Hatfield, Pa., was married Saturday to Benjamin James Midberry, the son of Lavonne K. Midberry and the Rev. James H. Midberry of Yardley, Pa. The Rev. David H. Kim, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the German Evangelical Lutheran Church of St. Paul in New York.

headline: Clara Platter, Michael Alexander
text: Clara Sophia Platter and Michael Alexander were married Saturday in Pottersville, N.J. The Rev. James. M. Taylor, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the home of William Welch and Andrea Filippone, the bride’s aunt and uncle.

headline: Privacy in the Cellular Age
text: Do people have a right to privacy in a closed telephone booth? In 1967, the Supreme Court said they do and prohibited government eavesdropping there without a warrant. But what about a cellphone with no booth? What about a phone that also sends messages, scours the Internet and records your exact location?

headline: Cory Mescon, Benjamin Baumer
text: Cory Ellen Borfitz Mescon and Benjamin Strong Baumer were married Saturday at Smith College in Northampton, Mass. The Rev. Stephen Philbrick, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated.

headline: Caroline Mallonée and Eric Huebner
text: Caroline Joanna Mallonée and Eric Heinz Huebner were married Saturday in a Quaker ceremony at the Baltimore Monthly Meeting of Friends, Stony Run, a Quaker meetinghouse in Baltimore.

headline: Elise de la Selle, Oliver Jones
text: Elise Catherine de la Selle, a daughter of Nancy and Sebastien de la Selle of Paris, was married Saturday to Oliver Holdship Jones, a son of Christina C. Evans and Peter D. Jones, both of New York. The Very Rev. Dr. Ernest E. Hunt III, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at All Souls Church in Onteora Park, N.Y.

headline: U.S. Cracks Down on Farmers Who Hire Children
text: WHITE LAKE, N.C.  The Obama administration has opened a broad campaign of enforcement against farmers who employ children and underpay workers, hiring hundreds of investigators and raising fines for labor and wage violators.

headline: Stacey Paradise, Noah Kushlefsky
text: Stacey E. Paradise and Noah H. Kushlefsky were married Thursday at the Manhattan Penthouse in New York. Cantor Rebecca Garfein officiated.

headline: Far Over the Line
text: It’s no surprise to political realists that once Sharron Angle secured the Republican nomination for the United States Senate in Nevada as a Tea Party insurgent, she would soften some of her most pugnacious stances. Sure enough, she is toning down her calls for abolishing the energy and education departments, phasing out Social Security and repealing the income tax.

headline: From Bomb Traces, Chile Terror Inquiry Builds
text: SANTIAGO, Chile  Muhammad Saif ur Rehman Khan said he had traveled from his native Pakistan to Santiago to learn Spanish and work in a hotel. But five months after his arrival, Mr. Khan finds himself under investigation as a terrorism suspect, after traces of a rarely used explosive were discovered on his belongings when he visited the American Embassy.

headline: New York’s Moment for Divorce Reform
text: As a particularly dismal legislative session limps to a conclusion in Albany, lawmakers have a chance to do something right by ending the logjam over no-fault divorce. New York is the only state where a court must find fault before granting a divorce unless the spouses have lived apart for a full year under a formal separation agreement  a proven formula for inviting false testimony, endless litigation and generally making divorce far more painful than it needs to be.

headline: Elena FitzPatrick and Justin Sifford-Angotti
text: Elena Maria FitzPatrick, the daughter of Verna and Richard FitzPatrick of Roosevelt Island, was married Saturday to Justin Dario Alexander Sifford-Angotti, the son of Belinda Sifford of Berkeley, Calif., and Thomas Angotti of Brooklyn. The Rev. Lewis C. Johnson, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

headline: Tejas Gawade, James Bouklas
text: Tejas Ashok Gawade, a daughter of Vidya A. Gawade and Ashok S. Gawade of Livingston, N.J., is to marry James Brian Bouklas, a son of Naomi Bouklas and Dr. George J. Bouklas of East Setauket, N.Y., on Sunday. The Rev. Nicholas A. Montanino, a World Christian Ministry minister, is to officiate at a nondenominational ceremony at the Watermill, a catering hall in Smithtown, N.Y.

headline: BP Fund Is a Magnet for Fraud, Experts Say
text: The $20 billion BP compensation fund announced by the Obama administration this week has those along the coast hoping that it will provide a more benevolent gusher than the one at the bottom of the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Holly Jackson, Sari Edelstein
text: Holly Jackson and Sari Lynn Edelstein were married Saturday at the Red Inn in Provincetown, Mass. Rabbi Howard A. Berman officiated, and James Mack, a chaplain with the Unitarian Universalist Meeting House of Provincetown, participated in the ceremony.

headline: Canada: Thieves in Quebec Grab a Tiger by the Trailer
text: Thieves who made off with a truck and trailer outside a motel near Montreal early Friday morning may have been surprised to discover its cargo: a tiger and two camels. Quebec has recently experienced a rash of truck and trailer thefts. The police speculated that the thieves were probably unaware that they had also acquired the animals, which were traveling to a private zoo near Toronto from Nova Scotia when their two handlers stopped for the night. The handlers told the police that the trailer and the animals were gone when they woke up on Friday morning. The tiger, they said, had been caged within the trailer, which was designed to carry cattle.

headline: Debbie Dao, Alexis Dang
text: Debbie Yen Dao and Alexis Bao-Chuyen Dang were married Saturday at St. Irenaeus Church in Cypress, Calif. The Rev. Brian Cool, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Illinois: School Scraps Plans for Sculpture
text: The University of Illinois, which is responding to a budget crisis by raising tuition and turning to short-term borrowing to meet its operating expenses, decided this week to drop its plans for a $98,000 sculpture honoring its president, Stanley O. Ikenberry, The Chicago Tribune reported. The paper said the plans for the sculpture were scrapped after the newspaper began inquiring about the artwork. University officials said Friday that no one was available to comment on the situation. The university’s new president, Michael Hogan, will start next month.

headline: China: Tang Dynasty Coffin Returned by U.S. Businessman
text: A 27-ton imperial sarcophagus from the Tang Dynasty that was stolen by tomb raiders has been returned to China from the United States, according to a report in China Daily, an official English-language newspaper. The coffin, which was stolen from the tomb of the Tang empress Wu Huifei, who died in 737, arrived at the Shaanxi History Museum on Thursday. Chinese police officers first discovered that the relic had been stolen in 2006. They traced it to a businessman in the United States, who had bought it for $1 million, China Daily reported. The businessman agreed to return the coffin unconditionally after three rounds of negotiations. The coffin was shipped from Virginia on March 16.

headline: Making Sure the Check Is Not in the Mail
text: President Obama ordered federal agencies on Friday to create a uniform “do not pay list” to reduce some of the $110 billion in improper or erroneous payments made by the government last year. The list is intended to prevent benefit checks, grants or contract payments from being made to individuals or companies that are not qualified to receive them. A government-wide database would screen contractors, subcontractors, businesses and individuals who obtain federal contracts to see if they have been convicted of federal fraud, operate phony businesses, owe back taxes or otherwise would be ineligible for government payments or benefits.

headline: Chronicle of a Changing City
text: THE JUICE PRESS on East First Street is here to prove the unlikely hypothesis that the East Village needs another place to get a drink. Its cheerful storefront is next door to Juicy Lucy Juice Bar, the neighborhood’s longtime go-to for fruity concoctions. But Marcus Antebi, the tattooed co-owner, said his “is the only place around” for people who “want strictly organic ingredients and juice that is pressed according to every health code.” There is a $60 eight-juices-in-a-day cleanse and alluring juice cocktails like the Pompeii ($8.75 for 16 ounces of tomato, green pepper, celery, carrot and homemade Tabasco) and the Ginger Fireball ($7 for 8 ounces of ginger, lemon, orange, colloidal silver, oregano and cayenne pepper.) Luna, the juice-jerk on duty at Juicy Lucy on Friday, seemed unmoved by the competition. “People here really like juice,” he shrugged. “Plus, ours is cheaper.”

headline: Wishing Will Make It So
text: Americans have always raised their children to believe in the power of the dream. This is probably why hundreds of thousands of young people are certain they are destined to become the American Idol. Or Next Top Model. Or marry a Jonas Brother.

headline: Florida: Senate Candidate Faces Foreclosure
text: A bank began foreclosure proceedings this week on a Tallahassee home co-owned by Marco Rubio, the Republican candidate for the Senate, after he failed to pay his mortgage for five months, according to court documents. Mr. Rubio, a former speaker of the Florida House, and State Representative David Rivera, who is running for Congress, bought the home in 2005 for $135,000 and lived there when they were in Tallahassee for legislative sessions. Alex Burgos, a spokesman for Mr. Rubio’s campaign, said Mr. Rubio and Mr. Rivera were selling the home and stopped paying the mortgage during a dispute with the bank. He said they made a final payment of $9,524 on Thursday. “Marco and David resolved this, so this process won’t go any further,” Mr. Burgos said.

headline: Dartmouth Atlas: A Response to Its Researchers
text: A front-page article in The New York Times on June 3 examined the Dartmouth Atlas of Health Care, a compendium of research on Medicare spending that has often been cited by the Obama administration in the debate over health care legislation.

headline: Fuel Maker for Reactors Has China as Investor
text: HONG KONG — A company here that is partly owned by the Chinese government has quietly purchased a 5.1 percent stake in the only American-owned provider of enriched uranium for use in civilian nuclear reactors.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Corrections
text: A television review on Wednesday about the new TV Land sitcom, “Hot in Cleveland,” referred incorrectly to the audience laughter heard on the show. It was from a live audience at the taping, not from a laugh track.

headline: For Neighbors, a Hospital’s Demise Leaves a Hole
text: Until St. Vincent’s Hospital Manhattan officially shut its doors at the end of April, Eddie Najda ordered 20 dozen bagels a day for his deli down the street. He now orders four dozen. Henry Valerio parked 50 transient cars a day in his Quik-Park garage; he now gets 15. And, without doctors and patients, the flower shop on Greenwich Avenue is selling half the flowers it once did.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Senate Passes Plan to Stop Medicare Pay Cuts to Doctors
text: WASHINGTON  With lawmakers worried that older Americans relying on Medicare could begin losing access to health care, the Senate on Friday approved a six-month plan to prevent a steep cut in doctors’ fees paid by the federal health program.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Corrections
text: THE ARTS

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: BP Ignored the Omens of Disaster
text: “We have to get the priorities right,” the chief executive of BP said. “And Job 1 is to get to these things that have happened, get them fixed and get them sorted out. We don’t just sort them out on the surface, we get them fixed deeply.”

headline: The Thrill Is Gone
text: President Obama’s relationship with America, like many a young marriage, is growing sour.

headline: Obama Hopes ‘Recovery Summer’ Will Warm Voters to the Stimulus
text: The shovels are finally ready. But is anyone paying attention?

headline: $3.4. Billion Guarantee for New Nuclear Plant
text: The Southern Company, the giant utility owner, agreed to a $3.4 billion federal loan guarantee to build the country’s first nuclear power plant in three decades. The guarantee covers up to 70 percent of Southern’s eligible projected costs, the company said Friday. “This is another step forward on the road to nuclear power playing a prominent role in America’s energy future,” David Ratcliffe, the chief executive, said in a statement. Southern would be the first to receive federal aid under a five-year-old law aimed in part at helping add nuclear stations, which usually cost more and take longer to build than coal or natural-gas-fired generators. Southern plans to add two reactors to its Vogtle station near Waynesboro, Ga., in 2016 and 2017.

headline: Companies Bet on Rise in Demand for Uranium
text: WASHINGTON  Uranium enrichment, the market that the Noble Group has entered with its purchase of USEC stock, is a globalized business fraught with uncertainty.

headline: In California, Facing Illegal Immigration
text: In the closing days of the Republican primary in California, Meg Whitman vowed to get tough on illegal immigrants, and in a radio commercial even brought out a big gun, a former governor, Pete Wilson. He is known for his advocacy of Proposition 187, a 1994 initiative that sought to deny public services to illegal immigrants. It was blocked by a federal court, but remains a sore point with Latino voters. Now, after winning the primary, Ms. Whitman reveals her opposition to the proposal in new Spanish-language television commercials, and embraces concerns dear to Latinos.

headline: Insider Leaks Tarnish Aqueduct Casino Plans
text: ALBANY  New revelations of insider leaks involving the proposal for a casino at Aqueduct Racetrack in Queens have further marred a selection process that has attracted the attention of state and federal investigators.

headline: Olympic Figure Skater Ilia
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — What more do I need to say about Samuel A. Donaldson’s construction other than it’s terrific.

headline: The Mets’ Foundation Is Not Cracked
text: How could you blame Mets fans for irrational theories? Three season-ending heartbreaks and the thorough embarrassment of 2009 could scramble the senses of even the wisest fans.

headline: Bloggingheads: American War Crimes?
text: Matthew Yglesias of the Center for American Progress and Eli Lake of The Washington Times debate the drone strike program.

headline: An Odd-Looking Hit, and an Even Stranger Path to a Penalty
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  There was a time when what happened to Shaun Micheel on the 10th hole of his round Friday at the 110th United States Open would have made him so mad he would have seethed all day.

headline: City Opens East Side’s First New Public School Building in 50 Years
text: With teenagers running through its shiny halls for only a few weeks, East Side Middle School still has that new-school smell.

headline: Crowd Gathers to Watch Woods, but Warms to Els
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  They came in great numbers to see Tiger Woods tee off just past 8 a.m. on Friday. And within an hour, it seemed half the crowd tromping around the Pebble Beach Golf Links trailed the threesome of Woods, Ernie Els and Lee Westwood.

headline: Keeping Children Out of the Fields
text: Facing new scrutiny by the Obama administration to detect underage-workers and wage violations on farms, blueberry growers in North Carolina are trying to clean up their act.

headline: Turkey’s Gain Is Iran’s Loss
text: Princeton, N.J.

headline: Jurors Watch Video of  Officer Hitting Man With a Baton
text: Surveillance video played before a Manhattan jury on Friday showed a police officer who is charged with assault repeatedly lashing a man with a baton even as the man lay on the floor, and again after he was handcuffed.

headline: Is There a Nurse in the House?
text: Pittsburgh

headline: Chamberlain Hits Another Bump in the Road
text: Tell Joba Chamberlain that it is raining, and he will be happy that the flowers will bloom. Negative thoughts never seem to leave his lips, and they did not on Friday, the day after all three batters he faced in the ninth inning scored in the Yankees’ 7-1 loss to the Philadelphia Phillies.

headline: Plea to Obama Led to an Immigrant’s Arrest
text: The letter appealing to President Obama was written in frustration in January, by a woman who saw her family reflected in his. She was a white United States citizen married to an African man, and the couple  college-educated professionals in Manhattan  were stymied in their long legal battle to keep him in the country.

headline: Honda Strikers in China Offered Less Than Demanded
text: ZHONGSHAN, China — Wage negotiations between workers and managers at a Honda auto parts factory here ended on Friday night with the company’s final offer of a pay increase that was substantially less than employees had been seeking, a worker involved in the discussions said.

headline: Manuel Talks Softly Despite the Mets’ Recent Success
text: Considering the criticism he took in the first two months of the season, Mets Manager Jerry Manuel might have felt at liberty to boast about his team’s recent accomplishments.

headline: To Help the Little Guy, the Government Proposes New Rules for Big Meatpackers
text: The Obama administration proposed new rules on Friday seeking to increase competition and rein in potentially unfair practices by large meatpackers and poultry processors. The move is aimed at helping small livestock and poultry farmers survive in an industry dominated by corporate giants.

headline: Kagan’s E-Mail at Clinton White House Reveals a Blunt, Savvy Legal Adviser
text: WASHINGTON  An enormous trove of e-mail messages from Elena Kagan’s years in the Clinton White House released late Friday afternoon offered glimpses of a savvy, sharp-elbowed and sometimes salty-tongued lawyer at ease with politics, policy and bureaucratic infighting.

headline: For English Men, a Shutout in the Wimbledon Draw
text: LONDON  When Wimbledon released its draws Friday morning, attention here focused not on Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal or the Williams sisters. Instead, tennis fans here bemoaned the lack of an English men’s singles player in the main draw, a first in the 133-year history of the tournament.

headline: I.M.F. Backs Spain’s Austerity Measures
text: The International Monetary Fund gave its blessing on Friday to Spain’s efforts to bolster its banks and reduce its budget gap. But the fund also stressed that passage of a proposed loosening of labor market rules was crucial to stimulate flagging growth.

headline: Machinery Sales Jump 11% at Caterpillar
text: Caterpillar, the world’s largest maker of construction equipment, said worldwide retail sales of machinery measured over three months rose for the first time in almost two years. Sales as reported by dealers climbed 11 percent in the period through May, the company reported Friday. The previous gain was posted in September 2008, said Jim Dugan, a spokesman. North American sales rose 15 percent in the period, the first improvement since August 2006.

headline: Blumenthal Contradicts Past Remarks on the Draft
text: Recent remarks by Attorney General Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut recounting his enlistment in the Marine Corps Reserve did not only contradict historians’ accounts. They also contradicted his own previous statements on the subject.

headline: Peddling Relief, Firms Put Debtors in Deeper Hole
text: PALM BEACH, Fla.  For the companies that promise relief to Americans confronting swelling credit card balances, these are days of lucrative opportunity.

headline: Park Domes Fenced Off to Protect Children
text: When three stainless-steel climbing domes were unveiled in Brooklyn Bridge Park in March, many parents praised their appearance. But almost right away, several reported that their children’s hands turned bright pink after touching the metal on sunny days  and word spread quickly on local blogs that the scorching-hot two-foot-high domes were to be avoided.

headline: Plus-Size Revelation: Bigger Women Have Cash, Too
text: Corseted into a size 18 white denim dress, wearing heels that made her about 6-foot-2, Gwen DeVoe, a former model and fashion-show producer, stepped onto a runway in Manhattan this week and made a pitch to retailers for the plus-size woman.

headline: Gay and Ready for Marriage
text: To the Editor:

headline: Net Benefits of Biomass Power Under Scrutiny
text: GREENFIELD, Mass.  Matthew Wolfe, an energy developer with plans to turn tree branches and other woody debris into electric power, sees himself as a positive force in the effort to wean his state off of planet-warming fossil fuels.

headline: Cuddling With a Child, and Listening to Mom
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ramirez’s Return to Fenway Park Meets Everything but Indifference
text: BOSTON  Two years ago, Manny Ramirez seemed to do everything in his power to get away from Fenway Park. He slapped a teammate, shoved a team employee and took himself out of the lineup with a mysterious injury  all before the trading deadline.

headline: For Some Subway Riders, an Abiding Appreciation of Rats
text: Early this week, after the city announced a new plan to combat rat infestations in subway stations, City Room asked readers to send in photographs of rats. They are still coming in, and we will publish them online early next week. But we also got something that surprised us: passionate e-mail messages defending, applauding, lauding and otherwise expressing affection for ... rats. Who knew so many New Yorkers, and others, loved their rats so much? We certainly didn’t.

headline: Peeking at the Negative Side of High School Popularity
text: PROM time has come and gone, and while it didn’t affect me or my sons this year (I’m too old, they’re too young), it still caused a reminiscent tightening in my stomach.

headline: F.D.I.C. Closes Nevada Bank, 83rd Failure of Year
text: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation on Friday took over Nevada Security Bank, based in Reno, with $480.3 million in assets and $479.8 million in deposits. Umpqua Bank, of Roseburg, Ore., agreed to assume the assets and deposits. The failure is expected to cost the deposit insurance fund $80.9 million. It is the 83rd failure of the year, setting a pace more than double that of 2009.

headline: Yankees Struggle as Magic Belongs to the Mets
text: There is not much of a precedent, but the Mets do not find Yankee Stadium hospitable. Their first game here last season ended with a dropped pop-up that symbolized both teams’ fortunes. The Mets were cursed, the Yankees charmed. The Mets would be delighted if their 4-0 victory Friday night was as prophetic. In extending their winning streak to eight games, the surging Mets stayed as sharp against one of baseball’s best teams as they did against two of their worst.

headline: Odd Delivery Aside, Outs Add Up for Takahashi
text: Hisanori Takahashi has his skeptics. Some say the best he can do is fool hitters who are not familiar with either his pitches or the odd hesitation in his windup.

headline: Gen. Marcel Bigeard, French Hero of 3 Wars, Dies at 94
text: PARIS  Gen. Marcel Bigeard, one of France’s most decorated veterans, who led troops in the French Resistance in World War II and in wars in Algeria and Indochina, died Friday in Toul, France, where he lived. He was 94. His death was confirmed by his wife, Gabrielle Grandemange.

headline: FIFA and the Drawing of Lots: A Brief History
text: If England and the United States tie their respective games next Wednesday, and the English score two more goals in their game than the Americans do in theirs, both teams will be dead even in the Group C table. According to FIFA regulations, the two will have to draw lots to see who advances and who goes home.

headline: Mets Get the Jump in Subway Opener
text: Even when things seemed bleak for the Mets in the season’s first few weeks, the team saw encouraging signs. Infielder Alex Cora pointed out that the Mets were losing a lot of road games in their last at-bat, meaning they were in games until the end. Manager Jerry Manuel saw a lot of hits and figured the Mets would start making them timely.

headline: Saturday’s Matchups: Netherlands vs. Japan, Ghana vs. Australia and Cameroon vs. Denmark
text: Netherlands vs. Japan

headline: The New Poor: Unsettled Anxieties
text: Debt settlement companies offer help to individuals in financial turmoil. Peter S. Goodman reports on the growing criticism  the industry has inspired.

headline: In Defense of Koman Coulibaly. Sort Of.
text: They say there is holding on every play in the N.F.L., but that the referees can’t call it every time because no one would watch. The same goes for free kicks in soccer.

headline: The Morning Skate: New Rule May Ban Intentional Head Shots
text: The movement to ban some checks to the head took a step forward on Friday when the N.H.L.-N.H.L.P.A. Competition Committee proposed a five-minute major penalty and a game misconduct for blindside hits to the head.

headline: The Facts Have A Well-Known Keynesian Bias
text: There are many things to say about Alan Greenspan’s op-ed yesterday, none of them complimentary. But what struck me is the passage highlighted by Tim Fernholz:

headline: Beat and Eat
text: Video | Martial art of meal prep? Wikipedia has this explanation:

headline: Celebrating the Short, Sweet Ride of Freedomland
text: Frank Adamo guided his Jeep down Bartow Avenue in the Bronx. To his left were the towers of Co-Op City. To his right, the Bay Plaza shopping center. But in his mind, he was someplace else entirely.

headline: Violence Up Sharply in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  With an average of an assassination a day and a suicide bombing every second or third day, insurgents have greatly increased the level of violence in Afghanistan, and have become by far the biggest killers of civilians here, the United Nations said in a report released publicly on Saturday.

headline: Saturday Word: Politics of Jobless Claims and the Oil Spill
text: After a week in which Democrats failed to break a Republican filibuster on an extension of unemployment benefits — something that is usually noncontroversial in a troubled economy — both parties used their weekly national addresses to call for an end to the politicking.

headline: Fan Busts In on England Dressing Room
text: Not content to boo Wayne Rooney and his England teammates after a poor 0-0 tie With Algeria on Friday, one fan barged into the locker room to give the players a dressing down while they were undressing.

headline: Japan’s Hard Right Keeps Dolphin Film from Theaters
text: An article in The Times today shows how a small, but potent ultra-conservative faction in Japan has intimidated theater owners pondering showing “The Cove,” the Oscar-winning documentary that revealed in bloody detail the annual roundup of dolphins by a Japanese town and the slaughter of the animals that don’t get auctioned to dolphin shows and aquariums.

headline: World Cup Live: Netherlands vs. Japan
text: Data by Match Analysis

headline: Nadal May Not Be the Best, but He Beats the Best Ever
text: Roger Federer may be the best men’s tennis player in history. Or he may not be as good as his contemporary rival Rafael Nadal.

headline: Getting Back to Sales
text: I’ve always had a passion for sales even though I really never had a sales background. When I redefined my role as chief executive last year, I made the decision that I could no longer be the only one responsible for sales if we were to start scaling this company aggressively. This meant that I needed to start relying on others to make these deals happen.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: He Forgot to Leave Tickets for the Queen
text: At 96, Gardnar Mulloy recalled “the most impressive incident of my life” as if it were yesterday. It was on Centre Court at Wimbledon in 1957 as Mulloy was receiving the cup for the men’s doubles title from Queen Elizabeth II.

headline: World Cup Live: Ghana vs. Australia
text: Data by Match Analysis

headline: Still a Fan, Just With a Shorter Favorite Player
text: I trained hard for the World Cup, and I like to think I’m in better shape than I was for the 2006 tournament  as a fan, and as a father.

headline: In the Arizona Desert, Promise Tumbles Away
text: Chase Field, the home of the Arizona Diamondbacks, feels like a giant airplane hangar and sits close to Sky Harbor International Airport in Phoenix. So General Manager Josh Byrnes picked an apt analogy to describe his once-promising team.

headline: Al Kaline: A Star Who Knew to Hit the Cutoff
text: Al Kaline, a Hall of Fame outfielder for the Detroit Tigers, retired in 1974 with a career batting average of .297, 3,007 hits, 399 home runs and 1,583 runs batted in. Kaline, 75, now a special assistant to the Tigers’ president, Dave Dombrowski, was in Manhattan in May. He accepted the Vin Scully Lifetime Achievement Award in Sports Broadcasting on behalf of Ernie Harwell, the longtime Tigers broadcaster who died just before the presentation. The award is sponsored by WFUV, Fordham University’s radio station.

headline: No Pro Baseball in Montreal, and Little Hope of Any
text: MONTREAL — The game resembled baseball as best an 8-year-olds’ skirmish can. The Beloeil Braves and the Boucherville Seigneurs smacked grounders and attempted double plays in full uniform, with batting gloves dangling out of their back pockets. Just like the pros.

headline: Legislative Hurdles in an Era of Conflict
text: WASHINGTON  It was a little-noted vote on an unremarkable bill, but it spoke volumes about the current state of Congress.

headline: Kimmel: ‘More Important Priorities’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: Sarah Palin was on the Fox Business Network and surprised a lot of people by calling marijuana quote, “a minimal problem in America.” She said law enforcement has more important priorities than arresting people smoking pot in their homes and also admitted that she herself has tried pot, which could explain some of the things that she’s said over the years. It’s not Sarah, it’s old baked Alaska talking.

headline: China Signals a Gradual Rise in Value of Its Currency
text: HONG KONG  China announced on Saturday evening that it would allow greater flexibility in the value of its currency, a move that could deflect growing international criticism of its economic policies and defuse one of the greatest sources of tension between Beijing and Washington.

headline: Fallon: ‘An Unprecedented Combination of Failures’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: Tonight, I’m not going to do any jokes about oil spill related news. I thought it might be nice to just pretend for a few minutes that the oil spill isn’t happening. You know, kind of like B.P. does.

headline: Ferguson: ‘100 Times More Water’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: Did you know that NASA says there’s 100 times more water on the moon than they first thought? In fact, there is so much water on the moon that B.P. is planning to go up there and ruin it.

headline: Letterman: ‘They Could Go Out of Business’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: There are rumors now that the C.E.O. of British Petroleum is saying they could go out of business. And I thought, well, yeah, great. But if they go out of business, who will be in charge of not stopping the leak?

headline: Fighting Words
text: Representative Joe L. Barton, Republican of Texas, condemned a White House deal that requires BP to establish a $20 billion fund for victims of the oil spill.

headline: Leno: ‘They Can’t Wait for the Oil’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: Let’s see what’s going on with B.P. C.E.O. Tony Hayward, otherwise known as “the lying king.”

headline: Prime Number
text: 62: The proposed new retirement age in France, as of 2018. Raising the age from 60 is essential to reduce the nation’s debt, the French government said. As onerous as it may seem to the French, 62 looks pretty good to other Europeans. In Britain, Spain and Italy, you’ve got to work until you’re 65. Germany recently raised its retirement age by two years, to 67. The French Parliament must approve the change; a summer of demonstrations and strikes is likely.

headline: E-Mail: Press Delete
text: Life without e-mail? The day may be coming, according to Sheryl Sandberg, Facebook’s chief operating officer. Only 11 percent of teenagers use e-mail daily, Ms. Sandberg told Nielsen’s Consumer 360 conference last week. Teenagers increasingly use text messaging and social networking sites to communicate — a shift that Ms. Sandberg said pointed to “what people like us will do tomorrow.” That is good news for businesses, said Fast Company, which reported on the conference. Personal e-mail addresses are tough for businesses to get. It’s easier for businesses to connect with consumers on services like Facebook, which has 400 million members and 100 million daily mobile users.

headline: Back Then: 1977
text: When Ronnie Lee Gardner was convicted of murder 25 years ago, he could choose death by firing squad or hanging. He chose the bullets. On Friday, he was executed.

headline: Turks and Kurdish Rebels Clash After Raid on Post
text: ISTANBUL  In one of the deadliest attacks in recent months, Kurdish rebels fighting for autonomy in southeast Turkey attacked a military post in a far eastern town on Saturday, killing 8 soldiers and wounding at least 14, the semiofficial Anatolian News Agency reported.

headline: Fishing Tournament Cancellations Spread With Oil Spill
text: Shawna Meisner, the director of the Emerald Coast Blue Marlin Classic offshore sports fishing tournament in the Gulf of Mexico, had been one of the last holdouts. But on Thursday  five days before the tournament’s start  the spreading BP oil spill left her little choice.

headline: Voice of Expos Is Still Heard in Quebec, in French
text: QUEBEC  As the ball bounced toward right, the gray-haired announcer almost bounced right out of his booth.

headline: On Border Violence, Truth Pales Compared to Ideas
text: When Representative Gabrielle Giffords, Democrat of Arizona, announced that the Obama administration would send as many as 1,200 additional National Guard troops to bolster security at the Mexican border, she held up a photograph of Robert Krentz, a mild-mannered rancher who was shot to death this year on his vast property. The authorities suspected that the culprit was linked to smuggling.

headline: Now, Dad Feels as Stressed as Mom
text: Father’s Day brings this offering of a dubious milestone: Husbands are now just as stressed out as their harried wives.

headline: Baghdad Nights Glitter, Behind Shatterproof Glass
text: BAGHDAD  However loudly you protest, you still have to check your gun at the restaurant’s door. (Customers take valet tickets in return.) Guards in tight jeans and tighter shirts patrol the entrance, toting that ubiquitous paraphernalia of authority here: a walkie-talkie. Even cavalier guests cast leery glances down the road for a car that could be rigged with a bomb.

headline: Shades of Weekly Foursome, but a Tournament All Its Own
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  How is the United States Open different from any other golf tournament?

headline: In Budget Crisis, States Take Aim at Pension Costs
text: Many states are acknowledging this year that they have promised pensions they cannot afford and are cutting once-sacrosanct benefits, to appease taxpayers and attack budget deficits.

headline: Human Rights Defenders Seek Protection in Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY  With a drug war raging around them and an unreliable judicial system in place, Mexico’s human rights activists have their hands full as they grapple with a growing new class of victims: themselves.

headline: Penny-Farthing Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — The acrostics regularly include clues and answers that relate to their quotes. That’s nice for two reasons. The first is artistic; it strengthens the theme of the puzzle. The second is helpful; it can provide a hint as to the author, the title or words in the quote.The Details:

headline: For English Fans, Days of Tears
text: LONDON  The overcast streets of South Kensington were oddly, creepily silent Friday night. This neighborhood resembled the quaintest of ghost towns, with few cars and fewer pedestrians traveling Cromwell Road, save for the occasional tourist.

headline: In Bloody Sunday Apology, a Promise of Closure
text: LONDON — By any measure, it was a moment to mark in the anguished history of sectarian dispute in Northern Ireland: 10,000 people, mostly Catholics, mostly enlistees in the ranks of Irish nationalism, applauding last week as a giant television screen in Londonderry relayed a British prime minister apologizing in the House of Commons for the brutality of British troops in the city on “Bloody Sunday.”

headline: For U.S., Only Frustration Is Clear
text: Johannesburg

headline: For Fathers, a Tough Balancing Act
text: For decades, the debate about balancing work and family has been framed as a woman’s issue, focused on the struggle of women to balance career and family life. But now several studies show that fathers are struggling just as much — or sometimes even more — than mothers in balancing work and home responsibilities, an issue I explore in the Week in Review section.

headline: A Night at the Electronics Factory
text: SHENZHEN, China — Inside one of the world’s largest electronics factories, Yuan Yandong, 24, sits on a stool six nights a week, 12 hours a night barring meal and bathroom breaks, and assembles computer hard drives for an American company called EMC.

headline: In Eritrea, the Young Dream of Leaving
text: AMMAN, Jordan  Long before he learned to dunk on warped wooden backboards, Awet Eyob nursed a dream: to play basketball in America.

headline: Roddick’s Pre-Wimbledon Thoughts
text: WIMBLEDON, England – At his Saturday news conference, Andy Roddick presented his list of Wimbledon favorites: Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal and Andy Murray. Roddick did not name himself until prompted, despite his five-set loss to Federer in the final here last year.

headline: U.S. Hopes Afghan Councils Will Weaken Taliban
text: NADALI, Afghanistan  More than 600 men, most of them farmers with weathered faces and rough hands, sat on the ground under an awning, waiting all day to deposit their ballots in plastic boxes. They had braved Taliban threats and road mines to come here to select a district council, part of a plan to strengthen local government in the most unstable parts of Afghanistan.

headline: World Cup Live: Cameroon vs. Denmark
text: In the first World Cup to be held on African soil, the best team on the continent are now the first team to be knocked out.

headline: Save Rule Dictating Strategy? Save Us
text: With an important baseball game still in doubt Friday night, a manager did what most managers do. He executed a strategic decision dictated by a statistic invented by a sportswriter over 40 years ago.

headline: The Town That Loved Its Bank
text: MAYWOOD, Ill.

headline: Calm in the Face of Tiger Woods’s Charge
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  With echoes of the cheers from Tiger Woods’s back-nine charge still rolling over Pebble Beach Golf Links, Dustin Johnson grabbed the lead, kept his composure and birdied the final two holes at dusk to take a three-stroke lead over the overnight leader Graeme McDowell and a five-stroke lead over Woods into the final round of the 110th United States Open.

headline: Many Leaders Succumb to Pressure in Golf Majors
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  You know it’s a major championship when a golfer is walking up the fairway with a bounce in his step, feeling as if there is no shot he cannot pull off or no putt outside his range, and then, quick as a glance at a leader board, he falls apart.

headline: Kyrgyz Officials Order Uzbeks to Remove Barriers
text: OSH, Kyrgyzstan  The Kyrgyz authorities demanded on Saturday that makeshift roadblocks that have turned this distressed city into a patchwork of no man’s lands be removed, setting up a confrontation with ethnic Uzbeks that could lead to more bloodshed.

headline: By War or Peace, No Easy Exit From Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — There’s no way we can kill our way out of Afghanistan, Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, the American commander, has said. By now, that’s become a mantra.

headline: Next for Afghanistan, the Curse of Plenty?
text: Let’s suppose there is $1 trillion worth of minerals under Afghanistan, as senior American officials and a confidential Pentagon memo said last week.

headline: For the U.S. Team, the Best Revenge Is to Win
text: Johannesburg

headline: Surgeon vs. Knee Maker: Who’s Rejecting Whom?
text: CHICAGO

headline: Does It Matter if Obama Loses the Pundits?
text: WASHINGTON — The reviews of President Obama’s first address from the Oval Office came in fast and harsh.

headline: Want the Job? Tell Him the Meaning of Life
text: This interview of Michael Mathieu, C.E.O. of YuMe, an online video advertising firm in Redwood City, Calif., was conducted, edited and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: The Inflatable Loan Pool
text: AMID the legal battles between investors who lost money in mortgage securities and the investment banks that sold the stuff, one thing seems clear: the investment banks appear to be winning a good many of the early skirmishes.

headline: BP Chief Draws Outrage for Attending Yacht Race
text: BP officials on Saturday scrambled yet again to respond to another public relations challenge when their embattled chief executive, Tony Hayward, spent the day off the coast of England watching his yacht compete in one of the world’s largest races.

headline: Senate Poised to End Secret Holds
text: Senator Claire McCaskill, Democrat of Missouri, announced Saturday that she has enough Senate support to overturn members’ ability to anonymously delay confirmation proceedings for nominees and legislation requiring Senate confirmation.

headline: Yes, People Still Read, but Now It’s Social
text: “THE point of books is to combat loneliness,” David Foster Wallace observes near the beginning of “Although of Course You End Up Becoming Yourself,” David Lipsky’s recently published, book-length interview with him.

headline: Fighting PC Delays, Hourglass by Hourglass
text: FORGET about desperate housewives. To witness true frustration, watch desperate PC users trying to type, send e-mail or work on a spreadsheet, only to be delayed by those pesky hourglass icons for seconds or even minutes until their computers finally respond.

headline: Help Prevent a Sequel. Delay Some Pay.
text: CONGRESS’S approach to financial reform has been a bit like my own household’s response to a moth infestation in our kitchen a couple of years ago. After we got over the initial shock, my wife and I responded rapidly, disposing of food in which moths were breeding. Then we broadened our focus, throwing away items that had passed their expiration date or were no longer needed. Then we made a list of things to buy and went shopping.

headline: ‘Friday Night Lights’ Watch: Of Tragedy and Resiliency
text: Pregnant or sick and without health coverage? Well, you can always hold a fundraiser and get the strippers to work for no charge. Once again “Friday Night Lights” poignantly got at the hardships experienced by the more troubled sector of the two Americas. Mindy’s early contractions signaled complications with her pregnancy and Billy does not have any insurance. To even keep her safely in the hospital for a night — she’s got to go on bed rest — is going to be a huge struggle for him financially. But Mindy’s stripper friends rally together to offer their services for free to raise money for her treatment. It is moments like these that give “Friday Night Lights” the tempered levity that keeps it from being relentlessly melodramatic. Terrible things keep happening to people, but there are always displays of resilience and wherewithal.

headline: Deadly Rains Ravage Southern China
text: Zhongshan, Guangdong  A week of pounding rain in southern China has left at least 88 people dead and scores of others missing as officials evacuated more than a million people living alongside swollen waterways, the state media reported on Saturday.

headline: Letters: Sizing Up the Singularity
text: Sizing Up the Singularity

headline: Missile in Pakistan Kills 16 Militants
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A missile strike in North Waziristan killed at least 16 militants on Saturday as they were making plans to go fight NATO forces in Afghanistan, residents and an intelligence official said.

headline: Perspective on the Spill (Before It Began)
text: AMERICA’S addiction to oil is making itself felt on the blackened wings of pelicans in the Gulf of Mexico. As BP takes heat for the environmental and economic damage caused by the Deepwater Horizon spill, a timely new book by Tom Bower titled “Oil: Money, Politics, and Power in the 21st Century” (Grand Central, $26.99), reminds us that our insatiable thirst for oil makes us as much a part of the larger problem as the major oil companies.

headline: Sharapova Is Trying to Regain Her Edge
text: WIMBLEDON, England – Not sadder but a bit wiser, a struggling Maria Sharapova has returned Wimbledon, where she recorded a breakthrough victory in 2004 that launched a highly lucrative dual career of tennis and business endorsements.

headline: The Tremors From a Coding Error
text: INVESTING is always an act of faith, but perhaps never more so than when you entrust your money to a quant fund.

headline: When Making the Cut Is a Milestone
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. — Ty Tryon was talking about his up-and-down third round at the United States Open on Saturday when Johnny Miller, whose two major championships included the 1973 United States Open, approached with an outstretched hand.

headline: To Bow, or Not to Bow
text: WIMBLEDON, England – The queen of England is scheduled to attend Wimbledon next Thursday for the first time since 1977. That put Andy Murray, Britain’s greatest hope, in the line of journalistic fire Saturday.

headline: Taking the Leap to Self-Employment
text: SITTING in their cubicles, rolling their eyes over the latest bureaucratic slowdown or marveling at the near-incompetence of higher-ups, some employees are thinking: If only I were my own boss, I wouldn’t have these problems.

headline: Another Bad Idea From Arizona
text: Not satisfied with a shameful new law that invites, indeed demands, racial profiling, some Arizona politicians are now pushing for a law that would deny citizenship to babies born in Arizona whose parents cannot prove they are legal immigrants.

headline: Call of the Circus
text: I COME from a small town called Grand-Mère, or “grandmother,” about halfway between Quebec City and Montreal  in other words, in the middle of nowhere.

headline: Afghan Civilians Said to Be Killed in an Airstrike
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Ten civilians, including at least five women and children, were killed in NATO airstrikes in Khost Province, the provincial police chief said Saturday. Five other civilians were killed, as were two Afghan National Army soldiers and two police officials, in other violence around the country on Saturday.

headline: In Ireland, Tuesday’s Grace
text: Dublin

headline: Congress Defends the Big Guys
text: In the first week of talks over a financial regulatory reform bill, Democratic lawmakers  in some cases with apparent White House backing  have been defeating or delaying reforms to protect individual investors. Instead, they are catering to corporate interests that prefer the status quo  and write big campaign checks.

headline: A Tourism Director for the Gulf Coast
text: There is no sign of oil in Mississippi. There's also no sign of tourists. Therein lies the quandary for the state's governor, Haley Barbour.

headline: G.O.P. Stalwart Says Come, the Gulf’s Fine
text: GULFPORT, Miss.  “Get a picture of that beach!” Gov. Haley Barbour ordered a group of television photographers standing along an oil-less stretch of sand Monday.

headline: Cleanups of Spill and an Agency Test Salazar
text: WASHINGTON  When President Obama boasted in his televised address on Tuesday about his team of leaders fighting the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, he spoke glowingly of his energy secretary, his Coast Guard commander, even his Navy secretary.

headline: A Rare Hole in One at Pebble Beach
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. — Thongchai Jaidee’s hole in one Saturday at the 181-yard, par-3 fifth hole was the seventh hole in one in United States Opens held at the Pebble Beach Golf Links. According to the United States Golf Association, Jaidee’s ace is the 41st hole in one in United States Open history, although the association referred to the feat as the 41st “known” hole in one at the national golf tournament. It is also the first hole in one at the event since 2006 when Peter Hedblom had one in the third round at the 238-yard third hole at the Winged Foot Golf Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

headline: Bill Clinton Speaks Out on Kagan
text: WASHINGTON  Former President Bill Clinton vividly remembers the first presentation that his young legal adviser, Elena Kagan, made in the Oval Office.

headline: Another Dutch Victory, and a Familiar Man of the Match
text: DURBAN, South Africa  Wesley Sneijder’s Dutch teammates are asking him, with varying degrees of seriousness, whether he has a lock on the Man of the Match award in this World Cup, no matter what happens on the field.

headline: All-Star Feel in Bronx as Hughes Tops Pelfrey
text: High atop Yankee Stadium, an electronic marquee distilled the Yankees’ 5-3 victory over the Mets on Saturday to its basic elements  WP: Hughes, LP: Pelfrey. Phil Hughes won, which is something he does quite often. Mike Pelfrey lost, which happens with the regularity of a traffic-free commute at rush hour. Their figurative subway cars are zooming through separate boroughs but along parallel paths, toward potential appearances in the All-Star Game next month.

headline: Bill Dixon, Leading Edge of Avant-Garde Jazz, Dies at 84
text: Bill Dixon, the maverick trumpeter, composer, educator and major force in the jazz avant-garde movement of the 1960s, died on Wednesday at his home in North Bennington, Vt. He was 84.

headline: In Indiana, Centerpiece for a City Closes Shop
text: EVANSVILLE, Ind.  Having seen her father make a solid living at the Whirlpool refrigerator factory, Natalie Ford was enthusiastic about landing a job there and was happy years later when her 20-year-old son also went to work there.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,103 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: As Reform Falters, Immigration Battle Rages in Arizona
text: Milestones in the nation’s struggle with immigration since 2004 and the New York Times editorials that have followed it.

headline: A New Panorama at an Old Marvel
text: BOULDER CITY, Nev.  Generations of photo albums are filled with images of children squinting in front of the enormous canyon here, one of the greatest engineering feats in America’s history.

headline: ‘Smart on Crime’ Mantra of Philadelphia Prosecutor
text: PHILADELPHIA  The new district attorney in violence-weary Philadelphia had vowed not to get tough on crime but to get “smart on crime.” This month, R. Seth Williams began to make good on his word, downgrading penalties for possessing small amounts of marijuana from jail time to community service and fines.

headline: Dispute Over Pesticide for California Strawberries Has Implications Beyond State
text: SACRAMENTO  Even as the sweet strawberry harvest reaches its peak here, a bitter disagreement has erupted between the State Department of Pesticide Regulation and a scientific review committee over the approval of a new chemical, the outcome of which could affect farmers across the country.

headline: The Toys Are Us
text: NEARLY 2,000 years after St. Paul of Tarsus wrote his poetic epistles to the people of Corinth, we still equate our capacity for selfless love with the putting away of childish things. That is to say, the time comes for each of us to grow up and pack up our toys.

headline: Publishing Trade
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — “Publishing Trade” is a clever title for today’s theme, one involving book titles whose letters have traded places. Well, some of the letters. I’m not going to spill the beans as to the specifics, but I will say that Tarzan of the Apse* would be right at home in this grid.

headline: Obama’s Oil Spill Team
text: A look at the people leading the Obama administration's response to the oil spill:

headline: Sikh Gurdwara Sahib Temple
text: Located in the foothills of the Mount Diablo range on a former apricot orchard, Gurdwara Sahib is one of the largest Sikh temples in North America. The architecture is Indo-Persian, a fusion of Hindu and Islamic elements. Gurdwara Sahib features onion domes, frilled archways, fountains and panoramic views.

headline: Mystery and Millions in North Beach
text: Most mornings for more than a decade, Giuseppe Viola sat with his back against the wall in the corner of Caffe Roma in North Beach. He always wore a suit and tie, and his rosary beads were regularly on display. In small, tidy handwriting, he would track the financial markets and chart his findings on graph paper.

headline: Costs and Questions Continue to Mount Following Cow Palace Rave
text: Over the Memorial Day weekend, the emergency room at Seton Medical Center in Daly City activated its disaster plan for the first time since the Loma Prieta earthquake in 1989. Five patients arrived by ambulance within about 45 minutes of one another, sending medical staff members scrambling for reinforcements.

headline: Embargoing Arizona Proves to Be Not So Easy
text: When Arizona enacted a controversial immigration law in April, the Oakland City Council imposed an economic embargo on the state. The unanimous resolution prohibited Oakland from doing business with companies based in Arizona.

headline: Play It Again, Vieuxtemps. But for $18 Million?
text: After playing a few notes on the celebrated Vieuxtemps violin some years ago, Ruggiero Ricci, the American virtuoso, is said to have offered to trade his wife for the instrument.

headline: Anti-Hate-Crime Video Offers Unsettling Lesson
text: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: In Pilsen Neighborhood, Collecting Latino Stories
text: Some people’s stories emerge organically  around a dinner table, on a long car trip or on a rainy afternoon. But most of us need a bit of a nudge before we will face down the Big Questions: Who are we? What do we believe? Who do we love? Why?

headline: Thousands Protest Electricity Shortage in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  Thousands of demonstrators surged through the sweltering streets of Iraq’s second-largest city to protest persistent shortages of electricity on Saturday, clashing with the police in a disturbance that underlined the growing popular anger here over the Iraqi government’s inability to provide the basic necessities of life.

headline: The Genome Project: A Balance Sheet
text: To the Editor:

headline: Civilian Investigator of Burge Recalls the Excitement, but Now Feels Pity
text: Whenever Francine J. Sanders taught a film class at Oakton Community College in Skokie, Barbara Schwartz made sure to sign up. But like most of her classmates, Mrs. Schwartz had no idea that her charming teacher, who rhapsodized on a recent summer morning about the zany merits of the 1938 classic “Bringing Up Baby,” had a past littered with smoky West Side pool halls, dank public housing stairwells and resentful men who carry guns.

headline: Generations in the Balance
text: DANIEL Had I been 18 in November 2008, I would have voted for Barack Obama. However, being 14, I settled for voicing my support for him and expressing joy at his election. I believed, innocently, that his administration would put its foot down, stamping out the environmental crisis that his predecessors had allowed to fester unnoticed. I felt Mr. Obama knew how to do the right thing morally, even if it meant going against the “right thing” politically.

headline: The Man Who Left, the Father Who Came Back
text: MY father, Richard B. Snow, was happily running his own Manhattan architecture practice when Pearl Harbor was attacked, and he was quickly taken into a service that needed people who knew about structures.

headline: Clean the Gulf, Clean House, Clean Their Clock
text: PRESIDENT Obama is not known for wild pronouncements, so it was startling to hear him liken the gulf oil spill to 9/11. Alas, this bold analogy, made in an interview with Roger Simon of Politico, proved a misleading trailer for the main event. In the president’s prime-time address a few days later, there was still talk of war, but the ammunition was sanded down to bullet points: “a clean energy future,” “a long-term gulf coast restoration plan” and, that most dreaded of perennials, “a national commission.” Such generic placeholders, unanimated by details or deadlines, are Washingtonese for “The buck stops elsewhere.”

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 20
text: After a brutal week on the Hill for BP, the growing Gulf Coast oil spill disaster remains at the center of Sunday’s talk shows.

headline: World Cup Photo Replay: Day 9, June 19
text: The Netherlands advanced and Cameroon was knocked out during a busy day of action in South Africa.

headline: Why the Pigeon Couldn’t Fly
text: After a few calls to bike shops, it became clear: No one wanted to put the Flying Pigeon together.

headline: Weddings for Everybody!
text: SAN FRANCISCO

headline: Letter From Istanbul, Part 2
text: Istanbul

headline: My Father’s Gift to Me
text: YAMHILL, Ore.

headline: Basics for Haiti
text: The list of what needs to be fixed in Haiti is distressingly long, and progress has been frustratingly slow. But two areas require urgent attention from the Haitian government and its main international backers, the United Nations and the United States:

headline: The Half-Life of Phones
text: June comes, and a new iPhone is introduced to the world, creating a shock wave of obsolescence. In the aftermath of first-day preordering chaos last week  caused, apparently, by a major computer glitch  it is worth thinking about the cycle of novelty and the very brief half-life of handheld electronics. There is something feverish in the rush to adoption, something almost obsessive in the way our desires are driven by these objects. The question is rarely ever, do I need a new phone? It is almost always, do I want one?

headline: Oil Drilling in Florida
text: To the Editor:

headline: It’s Cold War II: Capitalism vs. Capitalism
text: To the Editor:

headline: Melville’s Genius: Parallels to Today in ‘Moby-Dick’
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Pope’s Path
text: To the Editor:

headline: Who Are the Boomers?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mets’ Reyes Has Mates on the Move
text: Jose Reyes is given to fits of excitement. He speeds on the basepaths like a No. 7 train bound for Flushing. He flashes megawatt smiles and claps his hands. He might point to the dugout after a big hit. Manager Jerry Manuel says the Mets do not know how to react, so “we just point back.”

headline: A Player Steps Up His Game and Wins the National Open
text: Chess players often talk of the creative aspect of chess  the role of imagination in conceiving strategies. Sometimes the desire to execute an original plan can overwhelm even the desire to win.

headline: In Defeating Celtics, Bryant Relied on a Son of Boston
text: LOS ANGELES  Mike Procopio grew up near the old Boston Garden, close enough to view the iconic building from his living-room window along the city’s West End. With basketball in his heart, but not in his genes, he lived the dream of many Boston children by working his way up to become part of the Celtics eight years ago.

headline: Let’s Link Lady Gaga and David Wright
text: Move over, Mr. Met.

headline: Cost of Seizing Fannie and Freddie Surges for Taxpayers
text: CASA GRANDE, Ariz.  Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac took over a foreclosed home roughly every 90 seconds during the first three months of the year. They owned 163,828 houses at the end of March, a virtual city with more houses than Seattle. The mortgage finance companies, created by Congress to help Americans buy homes, have become two of the nation’s largest landlords.

headline: Manute Bol, N.B.A. Player and Activist, Dies at 47
text: Manute Bol, a towering Dinka tribesman who left southern Sudan to become one of the best shot blockers in the history of American basketball, then returned to his homeland to try to heal the wounds of a long, bloody civil war, died Saturday at the University of Virginia Medical Center in Charlottesville, according to Sally Jones, a spokeswoman for the hospital. He was 47 and lived in Olathe, Kan.

headline: African Team Out Just as Cup Seems Invigorated
text: PRETORIA, South Africa

headline: Stars Stay Off the Field, and a Franchise’s Future Is Glimpsed
text: The Yankees played a ballgame Saturday without Alex Rodriguez and Derek Jeter on the left side of their infield, roughly $55 million a year worth of aging Hall of Fame talent. It was one day in June, no sign of the times, but perhaps a glimpse into a not-too-distant future.

headline: My Dad, My Column, My Loss
text: My column for Father’s Day was a particularly painful one to write: it’s about my own Dad, who died just a few days ago. I’m out here with my Mom, planning his funeral right now — and thinking about all our years together.

headline: Correction
text: An article last Sunday about the movie directors Mark and Jay Duplass misspelled the name of the town in Louisiana where they grew up. It is Metairie, not Metarie.

headline: Educating Donovan
text: After being in the New York City public school system for 15 years, Donovan Forde, 20, who has severe cognitive disabilities, is still being taught the most basic of facts.

headline: A Struggle to Educate the Severely Disabled
text: Donovan Forde was dozing when the teacher came around to his end of the table. Pale winter light filtered in through the grated classroom window, and the warm room filled softly with jazz. It fell to his teacher’s aide to wake him up from his mid-morning nap.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Lottery Numbers
California Man Shoots 4 People and Himself
text: A man rode a bicycle up to a taco chain restaurant in San Bernardino, Calif., on Saturday afternoon and shot four people inside, including his stepdaughter, leaving two dead, before fatally turning one of his two handguns on himself.

headline: Sunday’s Matchups: Slovakia vs. Paraguay, Italy vs. New Zealand, Brazil vs. Ivory Coast
text: Slovakia vs. Paraguay

headline: A Race With a Backdrop of Prime Real Estate
text: JERSEY CITY  A large sign, “No Kite Flying,” had been fixed to one of the temporary chain-link fences erected in Liberty State Park before the weekend, clearing even more air space for 12 shiny airplanes to put on a high-speed show of derring-do at normal kite-flying altitude.

headline: Manute Bol: Beloved and Above the Game
text: More than a very tall man, Manute Bol was a basketball player with extraordinary shot-blocking instincts, which was obvious on the first night he donned an N.B.A. uniform.

headline: Creating Memories With Dad
text: For Father’s Day, Larissa Kosmos remembers. Hers are simple memories of everyday moments, like the ones so many of us have, whether our fathers are still with us, or not. Like the ones our children will have of us, ones we are making each day.

headline: Bending Shot Caps a Blistering Charge
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  Behind and somewhat beneath a tree in the 18th fairway, 264 yards from a green protected by two bunkers and the Pacific Ocean, Tiger Woods stood over his ball with a 3-wood in hand. Suddenly, he backed away.

headline: For Sake of a Save, Manuel Puts Closer in Position to Face Peril, Not Deter It
text: On Saturday, with the Mets trailing for much of the game, Francisco Rodriguez was able to rest. The only reliever that Mets Manager Jerry Manuel used was Ryota Igarashi, who pitched a hair-raising eighth inning without surrendering a run.

headline: Corrections
text: A report in the In Transit column last Sunday about the hotel auction site Off & Away, offandaway.com, misstated the amount of “bid packs,” essentially chits, that bidders can buy in order to bid for a hotel room. Participants can buy $1 bids in packs of 10, 20, 50 and 100; it is not the case that they can buy only packs of 100 for $100. The report also misstated the surname of the company’s chief executive officer. He is Doug Aley, not Anley.

headline: Vows: Jessica & Ben
text: Jessica Boyd and Ben Livingston both worked in the Broadway show "Mamma Mia!" They started dating after an awkward night of Jessica working as Ben's substitute dresser.

headline: Death Toll Rises in Southern China
text: Zhongshan, CHINA  A week of pounding rain in southern China has left at least 132 people dead and scores of others missing as officials evacuated 800,000 people living alongside swollen waterways, the state media reported on Sunday.

headline: Diving Into the History of Amsterdam’s Canals
text: In the 17th century, Amsterdam was a growing city. Foreign adventures and the colonial wealth they brought with them enriched a merchant class eager to display its might with opulent new homes outside the city’s inner core. The result was Amsterdam’s Grachtengordel, or canal belt. Three canals — the Herengracht, Keizersgracht and Prinsengracht — saw a building frenzy that created what is now one of the city’s most popular destinations.

headline: Your Jokes: ‘Impersonating a Congressman’
text: Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

headline: World Cup Live: Slovakia vs. Paraguay
text: Paraguay is in a great position to advance to the knockout stage of the World Cup after piecing together a complete performance en route to a 2-0 win over Slovakia in Bloemfontein.

headline: Rise in Value of Currency to Be Slow, China Insists
text: HONG KONG — A day after announcing that it would allow a more flexible currency, China said on Sunday that any appreciation in its value would be gradual, and it set the renminbi’s value in early trading on Monday at the same level as it traded on Friday.

headline: The Father’s Day Balance Sheet
text: The meaning of Father’s Day has changed for me over the years. My father has been gone a couple of years now, and my kids are almost out of the house. I’ve been a father for 28 years, an entrepreneur for 32. As with any demanding job, balancing the responsibilities of parenthood with the responsibilities of the business has been a challenge. My perspective has changed, and I write today’s post for the benefit (I hope) of younger parents, fathers and mothers, who are dealing with this struggle.

headline: Choosing the Next Billy Elliot
text: The musical “Billy Elliot” is constantly looking for new Billys as the boys' voices break or they grow too tall. So the production created Billy Camp, a training program.

headline: World Cup Live: Italy vs. New Zealand
text: Italy, the defending World Cup champion, remained in danger of crashing out of the tournament after it was held to a 1-1 tie by New Zealand on Sunday in Nelspruit.

headline: Ahead of Valencia
text: The European Grand Prix takes place on the Valencia street circuit a week from today, but the extraordinary Canadian Grand Prix is still echoing in the mind. The main thing that made the Canadian race so good was Bridgestone’s tire choice, which caused problems for the teams as they had a hard time putting heat into the tires in the lower-than-predicted temperatures and on the smooth track surface.

headline: Referee Back to Work, But Without His Whistle
text: JOHANNESBURG – Koman Coulibaly will be back on the job Sunday. Despite reports that he would be ferried out of the country or relieved of his refereeing duties at the World Cup, the referee from Mali will be on the sideline as the fourth official for the Italy-New Zealand game in Nelspruit this afternoon. He will back up the referee Carlos Batres of Guatemala for the Group F encounter.

headline: Playing With Woods, and Hoping France Watches
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  Gregory Havret was not whistling through the cypress trees when he said he was looking forward to being paired with Tiger Woods in the penultimate group of the final round of the United States Open.

headline: The Sunday Word: Partisanship, Public Relations and Smartphones
text: Washington has become extremely partisan — an environment that is likely to persist until November. Indeed, it is “becoming nearly impossible to lure lawmakers across the aisle,” even to pass common sense, typically noncontroversial legislation, explains The Times’s Carl Hulse.

headline: Teddy Is Restored. In Paint, at Least.
text: Gillian Randell put one hand on the patient’s shoulder and tapped with her other hand, like a doctor palpating someone with bursitis.

headline: Serena Williams Discusses Concerts, Curtsies and Soccer
text: WIMBLEDON, England — In preparation for Wimbledon, Serena Williams took in a Green Day concert at Wembley Stadium and, with the Queen of England scheduled to visit the tournament Thursday, practiced her curtsy in front of the mirror.

headline: Jil Sander Sets the Stage for Unreal Men
text: MILAN — Days are like years during fashion show season. It was just 72 hours ago that Raf Simons presented his spring 2011 menswear collection for Jil Sander, beneath the sentinel cypresses and clipped yew hedges that form an enormous green apse in the gardens at the 16th century Villa Gamberaia in Florence.

headline: Chinese Order Stops Printing of Memoirs by Ex-Premier
text: BEIJING — A Hong Kong publisher said Sunday that he was forced to halt the publication of memoirs ostensibly written by Li Peng, the former Chinese prime minister who was instrumental in bringing a violent end to student-led protests in Tiananmen Square 21 years ago.

headline: Smoke on the Water
text: The expanse of oil spreading across the Gulf of Mexico is best perceived from above.

headline: Talking to a Dining Room Table
text: Gah. I’m still in Germany, and the event was lovely. The policy conversations, not so much.

headline: Car Bombs Hit Crowds Outside Bank in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD  A pair of car bombs detonated simultaneously outside Iraq’s Bank of Trade on Sunday morning, killing 26 people and wounding 52 others in the second attack on a major government financial institution in eight days.

headline: A Setback for Maine
text: Mets starter John Maine has had an apparent setback in his rehabilitation from weakness in his right shoulder, Manager Jerry Manuel said Sunday.

headline: For First Time, Attention on Schiavone
text: WIMBLEDON, England  Francesca Schiavone insisted Saturday that she felt no different than she did a month ago, before she planted kisses on the clay at Roland Garros, before she unexpectedly captured the French Open and became the first Italian woman to win a Grand Slam singles title.

headline: World Cup Controversy
text: A contested call against the United States, the flight of the Jabulani and the pan-Africa feeling that's spreading as Bafana Bafana's hopes slip.

headline: Early BP Worst Case on Flow: ‘100,000 Barrels Per Day’
text: 12:57 p.m. | Updated  Representative Edward J. Markey, the Democrat of Massachusetts who heads the House select committee on energy independence and global warming, has released a BP document providing an early worst-case estimate of the oil flow up the casing of the wrecked Gulf of Mexico well that is dozens of times higher than the company’s initial public estimates.

headline: Pitti Uomo | Super Casuals
text: I dove into the spring-summer 2011 men’s-wear collections at Pitti Uomo in Florence with a party presenting the collaboration between the designer Neil Barrett and Sundek, the iconic surf brand with the signature rainbow on the rump. Marcelo Burlon, Milan’s man about town (and now fashion blogger), directed a video featuring the generously tattooed model Daniel Bandad and an infectious remix of the Bon Iver song, “Re:Stacks.” The collection was a clever reworking of board shorts in pinstripes, camouflage and, most cleverly, a trompe l’oeil faded denim short.

text: The Spring/Summer 2011 collection from Burberry at Milan Fashion Week.

headline: France Fiasco Is Cautionary Tale for England
text: JOHANNESBURG — Franck Ribery is leading an unofficial investigation to find out who spilled to the news media the details of Nicolas Anelka’s outburst at France Coach Raymond Domenech.
