text: A contested call against the United States, the flight of the Jabulani and Bafana Bafana's declining hopes.

headline: Now Screening | Jil Sander
text: The Spring/Summer 2011 men’s-wear collection from Jil Sander at Pitti Uomo in Florence.

headline: Armstrong a Strong Second in Tour De France Warm-Up
text: PARIS — In his last tune-up before the Tour de France starts on July 3, Lance Armstrong showed Sunday that he was nearing strong form as he jumped from seventh place overall to finish second in the weeklong Tour of Switzerland.

headline: British Newspaper Apologizes to Climate Scientist
text: In 2007, the top United Nations climate body, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, said the Amazon was vulnerable to drought as a result of trends linked to climate change.

headline: Now Screening | Calvin Klein
text: The Spring/Summer 2011 collection from Calvin Klein at Milan Fashion Week.

headline: Some Winners Emerge From Europe’s Debt Crisis
text: FRANKFURT — Don’t say it too loudly, but for some European businesses, the sovereign debt crisis is not so bad. Assuming that the turmoil does not destroy the euro zone, there are some positive side effects, including a falling currency and extraordinarily low official interest rates.

headline: In Surprise, McDowell Wins U.S. Open
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  Graeme McDowell did what no one else seemed willing or able to do Sunday at Pebble Beach Golf Links, grabbing hold of the United States Open and then hanging on to become the first man from Northern Ireland to win the championship and the first European to do so since Tony Jacklin in 1970.

headline: Now Screening | Costume National
text: The Spring/Summer 2011 collection from Costume National at Milan Fashion Week.

headline: Impressive End to a Fun Week
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. — The first player off the first tee Sunday was Pablo Martin, a Spaniard, and he didn’t dally. Martin made his way around the Pebble Beach Golf Links on a cold, overcast morning in 79 strokes and, more impressive, 2 hours 39 minutes.

headline: Lady Power
text: If you want to get a bead on the state of feminism these days, look no further than the ubiquitous pop star Lady Gaga. Last summer, after identifying herself as a representative for “sexual, strong women who speak their mind,” the 23-year-old Gaga seemed to embrace the old canard that a feminist is by definition a man-hater when she told a Norwegian journalist, “I’m not a feminist.  I hail men!  I love men!”  But by December she was praising the journalist Ann Powers, in a profile in The Los Angeles Times, for being “a little bit of a feminist, like I am.” She continued, “When I say to you, there is nobody like me, and there never was, that is a statement I want every woman to feel and make about themselves.” Apparently, even though she loves men — she hails them! — she is a little bit of a feminist because she exemplifies what it looks like for a woman to say, and to believe, that there’s nobody like her.

headline: Teixeira’s Slam Gives Sabathia All He Needs
text: After winning the first six games on a nine-game trip, the Mets came back to New York on Friday with a distinct swagger. Winners of seven straight over all, they had beaten the Yankees on Friday night and had their two best pitchers, Mike Pelfrey and Johan Santana, ready to take the mound on the weekend.

headline: Like a Tight Relay Team Handing Off the Baton
text: At several points during Friday’s show at Symphony Space by an ad-hoc band called the Jazz Gallery All-Stars, an ancient ritual took place. Over a repeating cycle of chords, the saxophonist Miguel Zenón took a solo. Then the bassist Ben Williams took a solo, then the trumpeter Roy Hargrove, then the guitarist Lage Lund. It didn’t always happen in that order, and others were sometimes involved. The pianist Gerald Clayton. The trumpeter Ambrose Akinmusire. The hand-drums percussionist Pedro Martinez. The drummer Kendrick Scott. The singer Claudia Acuña.

headline: Veterans Finding Their Way
text: It took a while for Keith Jarrett to locate his muse at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night. From his station at the piano he worked through familiar cycles of theme and variations with his longtime partners, the bassist Gary Peacock and the drummer Jack DeJohnette. The music in the concert’s first half was sympathetic and duly elegant but also vaguely unsettled, even a bit labored. When intermission arrived  abruptly, after well under an hour  it registered as a relief. There was still time to regain the lead.

headline: Carefully Constructed Program in a Floating Hall
text: Some performers try to dazzle you with their brilliance and charisma. Others, though just as accomplished, take a more self-effacing approach to making music. That group includes the superb violinist Miranda Cuckson and the exemplary pianist Steven Beck, two young performers who teamed up for a deeply satisfying recital at Bargemusic in Brooklyn on Friday night.

headline: Now Screening | Versace
text: The Spring/Summer 2011 collection from Versace at Milan Fashion Week.

headline: World Cup Controversy
text: JOHANNESBURG — Maurice Edu could have been, perhaps should have been, the latest American hero.

headline: Cheparinov Wins Ruy Lopez
text: A tournament in honor of one of the earliest writers on chess is won by the second of Veselin Topalov.

headline: It Ain’t Hard
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Congratulations to Fred Piscop. This is his 100th New York Times puzzle. I interviewed him last year.

headline: New in Gadgetry: 3-D Escapades Without Glasses
text: LOS ANGELES  Have you ever consumed 3-D entertainment of any kind without wearing special glasses? Faced a television and chosen from a menu merely by waving your arm? Or paused a movie just by saying “pause”?

headline: Auroras With Different Auras: One Vulnerable, One Vigorous
text: Most of the ballets of the 19th century have a Romantically tragic sense of another world. Characters from the other world may meet those from this one, but they can never truly join them this side of death. “The Sleeping Beauty” takes the opposite view. Here characters from fairyland are, like Greek gods, actively involved in human affairs.

headline: Los Angeles Opera Company’s ‘Ring’ Festival
text: LOS ANGELES  The high chord that opens “Götterdämmerung” keened out, and the stage burst into light, revealing three Norns looking like Teletubbies in their bulbous costumes. As they sang of the one-eyed Wotan, eyeballs floated into view. Rings and fragmenting lines (Wotan’s broken spear?) appeared on a scrim, and spectral figures representing time’s passage floated across the stage.

headline: Polish Presidential Election Appears Headed for Runoff
text: WARSAW  Poland’s presidential election on Sunday appeared headed for a runoff between the acting president and the twin brother of the man he succeeded, who died in an April plane crash that also killed his wife and many of the country’s civilian and military leaders.

headline: 'The Sleeping Beauty'
text: Two performances of American Ballet Theater’s “Sleeping Beauty” made New York look like the indisputable capital of world ballet.

headline: Barriers Removed in Kyrgyzstan Despite Uzbek Protests
text: OSH, Kyrgyzstan  Kyrgyz soldiers with heavy machinery pulled down barricades on Sunday that minority Uzbeks had erected to protect their neighborhoods and that have been among the most visible symbols of this city’s venomous ethnic divide.

headline: Wisdom of Leaders and Guidance for Graduates
text: President Obama’s speech to cadets at West Point last month marked the ninth consecutive commencement with the nation at war, and he traced the focus of the fighting from Afghanistan to Iraq and back to where it started.

headline: Stuck at the Bottom
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. — While there was a lot of moving around at the top of the leader board Sunday, several prominent names were mired at the bottom of the scoreboard. They often added high scores in the final round to keep them there.

headline: The Roommates: Updike and Christopher Lasch
text: John Updike’s letters display youthful eruptions of self-doubt fed by his Harvard roommate, Christopher Lasch, an equally ambitious provincial (by way of Omaha and Chicago) who would go on to become a renowned historian and social critic. The two freshmen sized each other up instantly.

headline: Literary Ore of Updike, Do-It-Yourself Man of Letters
text: In the mid-1960s, when John Updike began giving selected papers to the Houghton Library at Harvard University, they were cataloged and, for the most part, made available to researchers. But after an amendment to the tax law in 1969 eliminated the sizable deductions authors reaped from such donations, Updike, though he continued to deposit papers, did so only for warehousing purposes. He retained ownership of this material and let very few look at it. The calculation was proprietary. His literary cosmos was still expanding, and he was loath to expose its workings.

headline: John Updike’s Archive: A Great Writer at Work
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — When John Updike died of lung cancer in January 2009, at 76, there seemed little left to learn about him. Not only was he among the most prolific writers of his time, but he was also among the most autobiographical, recasting the details of his life in an outpouring of fiction, poetry, essays and criticism that appeared with metronomic regularity in the pages of The New Yorker and in books published at a rate of almost one a year for more than half a century.

headline: Bomb Kills 3 Near a Bank in Southern Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  A boy, a girl and a woman were killed Sunday when a bomb stashed in a pushcart exploded in front of a bank in the southern city of Lashkar Gah.

headline: Speakers Stitch ‘Tapestry of Opinion’ for Class of 2010
text: As the last of the mortar boards of the class of 2010 are tossed into the air, my colleague Sam Dillon has sifted some words of wisdom and laughter, as well as some lines intended to prod and provoke, from this year’s commencement speeches.

headline: Iran Executes Sunni Rebel Leader
text: Iran hanged a Sunni rebel leader, Abdul-Malik Rigi, on Sunday morning after a revolutionary court found him guilty of 79 criminal charges, the ISNA news agency reported.

headline: Farewell to a Great Teacher and Journalist
text: Chris Welles, who wrote one of the great books on Wall Street, “The Last Days of the Club,” and was an excellent business journalist when there were few such people to be found, died Saturday. He had been in poor health, but the pain for those who knew and loved him is still great.

headline: Critics’ Choice: New CDs
text: THE ROOTS

headline: Navy Bans Tobacco Use on Its Submarine Fleet
text: WASHINGTON  The smoking lamp is going out all across the Navy’s submarine fleet, where the mission to “run silent, run deep” now will be carried out by sailors ordered to run undersea operations without cigarettes, cigars or pipes.

headline: A Wimbledon Journey That Began in a Van
text: WIMBLEDON, England  Dustin Brown, the most accomplished tennis player in the history of Jamaica, was born in Germany and trained by an American before polishing his game near the picturesque shores of Montego Bay.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,398 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,104 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: A Draft of the Past Remains on Tap in Egypt
text: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt — These two women were veiled, true. They are religious, too, or at least as religious as their community expects them to be. But do not tell them they cannot stop into Sheik Ali’s bar and sit at a table and eat fried calamari and laugh over a glass of juice while surrounded by men drinking beer and whiskey.

headline: The Costs of Natural Gas, Including Flaming Water
text: “Gasland,” a documentary making its television premiere on HBO on Monday night after winning a special jury prize at the Sundance Film Festival, is maddening in several distinct ways.

headline: ‘A Visit From the Goon Squad’
text: Found Objects

headline: Trying to Breathe Life Into a Canyon of Concrete
text: In the last several years, almost every part of New York City’s financial district has been torn up for rebuilding, rewiring and repaving. But Water Street, the wide corridor lined with office towers that skirts the eastern edge of Lower Manhattan, has largely been left alone.

headline: Phone Software Takes the Taps Out of Typing
text: SEATTLE — Back in the 1990s, typing out “hello” on most cellphones required an exhausting 13 taps on the number keys, like so: 44-33-555-555-666.

headline: Israeli Easing of Blockade of Gaza Draws Praise of U.S.
text: JERUSALEM  Bowing to worldwide pressure and condemnation, Israel on Sunday formally announced an eased blockade of Gaza that could significantly expand the flow of goods overland into the impoverished coastal Palestinian enclave, isolated by the Israelis for three years.

headline: Pixar’s ‘Toy Story 3’ Is a Strong No. 1
text: To infinity and beyond may not be a stretch for Pixar’s “Toy Story 3,” which sold $109 million in ticket sales in North America over the weekend and is on track to deliver a total domestic gross of over $400 million, analysts said.

headline: Centuries-Old Tradition Lies Behind Diplomas of Today’s Graduates
text: The tens of thousands of engraved cream-colored diplomas that New York high school graduates will receive this week can trace their birth to an old-fashioned source: an ink-splattered, cluttered printing workshop in Greenpoint, Brooklyn.

headline: Time, Thrashing to Its Own Rock Beat
text: A music mogul named Lou is one of the many characters who drift through Jennifer Egan’s spiky, shape-shifting new book, “A Visit From the Goon Squad.” Whether this tough, uncategorizable work of fiction is a novel, a collection of carefully arranged interlocking stories or simply a display of Ms. Egan’s extreme virtuosity, the same characters pop up in different parts of it. Lou is a case in point. He appears early and then burns through a few of Ms. Egan’s adjacent (though not consecutive) chapters, ending up very much the worse for wear.

headline: Litmus Test in Primary: Overhauled Drug Laws
text: For many Democrats in Albany, it was a landmark achievement: the long-sought overhaul of New York’s strict Rockefeller-era drug laws, repealing mandatory minimum sentences for drug offenders that critics said disproportionately and unfairly fell on blacks and Latinos.

headline: Ink Gushes in Japan’s Media Landscape
text: TOKYO  For years, the online newspaper JanJan News mounted a scrappy challenge to Japan’s blandly conformist press, offering articles written by readers who took on taboo subjects like whaling and the media’s collusion with the government. But the site never attracted enough readers or advertising and was finally forced to shut down most of its operations three months ago.

headline: Before Trial, Bush Reflects. Or Does He?
text: The problem with “When We Go Upon the Sea” is not that it’s yet another derisive play about George W. Bush. Nor is it that the playwright Lee Blessing (“A Walk in the Woods,” “Cobb”) offers a liberal fantasy of Mr. Bush on trial for war crimes. The real trouble, dramatically speaking, is that this Bush character (played by Conan McCarty, with perfect squinting eyes) doesn’t do anything of interest. He doesn’t engage in soul-searching or in an elaborate defense of his presidency  or anything else that might cause much conflict. He just generally acts smug.

headline: Razing the City to Save the City
text: DETROIT  For generations, residents of this hollowed-out city hoped that somehow Detroit could be reborn  its population would return and its crumbling core would be rebuilt. No idea was more heretical than widespread demolition of thousands of derelict buildings.

headline: Mejia Gets Good News: He’s Going to Minors
text: Rarely has a player been so upbeat about hearing that he would be sent down to the minor leagues. But Mets reliever Jenrry Mejia knows it is the best path for his long-term goal to be a starting pitcher.

headline: Field of 23 for Bermuda Bowl Begins to Narrow in Chicago
text: The open trial to select the U.S.A.-1 team for the 2011 Bermuda Bowl world team championship started on Friday in Chicago.

headline: ‘A Day in the Life’ Lyrics Sell for $1.2. Million
text: Lyrics handwritten by John Lennon for a song on the Beatles’ “Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band” album sold for $1.2 million at Sotheby’s auction house in New York on Friday, The Associated Press reported, exceeding Sotheby’s presale estimate of $500,000 to $800,000. A scrawled version of “A Day in the Life” appears on one side of the single sheet of paper, with revisions, corrections and annotations; on the other side is a cleaner version in mostly all caps, above. The corrected version adds the phrase “I love to turn you on,” which helped to get the song banned in Britain by the BBC when the album was released in 1967 because of the line’s implication of drug use. (The lyrics differ slightly in the finished recording.) The album won four Grammy Awards in 1968. Sotheby’s would not release the name of the purchaser, who made the winning bid by phone.

headline: South African Artist to Receive Kyoto Prize
text: The South African visual artist William Kentridge will receive Japan’s Kyoto Prize in Arts and Philosophy, the Inamori Foundation announced on Friday. The foundation, in Kyoto, Japan, honors individuals who have made “significant contributions to the betterment of society.” Mr. Kentridge is best known for his animated films, which he calls “drawings in motion,” about the history and social circumstances of postcolonial South Africa, which he began sketching from charcoals and pastels in the 1980s. The foundation praised Mr. Kentridge, above, in a statement on its Web site “for his originality as an artist whose wide-ranging activities encompass drawing, animation, stage direction and writing.” It continued, “His deep insights and profound reflections on the nature of human existence provide opportunities to consider fundamental issues that could face any individual in the world.” Mr. Kentridge joins two other winners: Dr. Shinya Yamanaka, a Japanese medical scientist who will be awarded the prize for advanced technology, and the Hungarian mathematician Laszlo Lovasz, who will receive the award for basic sciences. Each recipient will be given a diploma, a gold medal and about $550,000 during a week of ceremonies in Kyoto, beginning on Nov. 9.

headline: Debut Novel Wins Major Literary Award
text: “The Twin,” the debut novel of the Dutch author Gerbrand Bakker, has won the 2010 International Impac Dublin Literary Award, besting the well-published authors Marilynne Robinson (“Home”) and Joseph O’Neill (“Netherland”). The Impac award, organized by Dublin City Public Libraries and chosen from submissions by libraries in 43 countries, will earn Mr. Bakker, a sometime gardener and skating instructor, more than $123,000, almost $31,000 of which will be given to the book’s translator, David Colmer. “It’s wonderful,” Mr. Bakker told The Guardian while in Dublin on Thursday to receive his prize. “But for me it was also wonderful to read the book in English. I said to David the translator, ‘Who wrote this book?’ I didn’t recognize it. I thought it was very good. It made me realize it really is a book, and I am a writer.” “The Twin” is about a man who resigns himself to taking over his family’s farm in the remote Dutch countryside after his twin brother dies in a car accident. It was first published by Uitgeverij Cossee in Amsterdam in 2006 and published in English in Britain two years later by Harvill Secker. This is the third year in a row that a debut novel has won.

headline: In ‘Blockade Billy,’ King Drifts Back Into Baseball
text: In the season of Stephen Strasburg comes another phenom, a fictional one created by Stephen King. William Blakely is weird and not all that smart. He’s out of sync with his New Jersey Titans teammates and, being a King character, he possesses a horrible secret.

headline: N.Y.U. Abu Dhabi Scours Globe for Top Students
text: Laith Aqel, co-valedictorian of his high school graduating class in Wayne, N.J., and juggler of too many activities to list, says he always envisioned himself on a classic New England campus with “Gothic architecture and big grass lawns.” He weighed offers from Tufts University, Boston College’s honors program and New York University.

headline: Heat Cannot Break Sabathia’s Control
text: C. C. Sabathia stood in front of his locker in the Yankees’ clubhouse Sunday with a navy blue towel slung over his left shoulder. Surrounded by reporters, he dabbed his forehead from time to time as he reflected on his scoreless outing against the Mets.

headline: Larry King’s Endgame at CNN
text: At the beginning of June, CNN’s Larry King celebrated 25 years in the same slot on the same network  a remarkable achievement in a come-and-go business  and was joined over a week by Bill Gates, LeBron James and the leader of the free world to mark the occasion. Not bad for a former color commentator of the Shreveport Steamer of the World Football League.

headline: Watson Comes Full Circle

headline: ‘Anything Goes’ Returns to Broadway

headline: ‘Anything Goes’ Returns To Broadway
text: Reno Sweeney is steaming back to New York. Twenty-three years after its last Broadway revival, “Anything Goes” will return in February in a Roundabout Theater Company production starring the Tony Award winner Sutton Foster (“Thoroughly Modern Millie”), right, as Reno, the nightclub singer aboard an ocean liner of colorful characters created by Cole Porter (music and lyrics) and Guy Bolton, P. G. Wodehouse, Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse (book). Kathleen Marshall will direct and choreograph the show, at a Broadway theater to be named later, Roundabout plans to announce on Monday. (Ms. Marshall won a Tony for choreography for her last outing for Roundabout, the 2006 revival of “The Pajama Game,” starring Harry Connick Jr.) The 1934 musical, which features songs like “You’re the Top,” “I Get a Kick Out of You” and the title number, starred Ethel Merman as Reno; its only previous Broadway revival, in 1987, starred Patti LuPone as Reno, Howard McGillin as the lovesick Billy Crocker, and Bill McCutcheon as the gangster Moonface Martin. The opening-night date and additional casting will be announced later. Todd Haimes, Roundabout’s artistic director, said in a statement that this revival would not be in line with the current Broadway trend of scaled-down musical revivals, most recently “La Cage aux Folles” and “A Little Night Music.” Noting that the show is “a big ensemble piece,” he said, “I don’t think you can do ‘Anything Goes’ properly without embracing its size.”

At 23, he may still live under his father’s roof — his magisterial living room in the Palazzo Chupi is studded with artwork by McDermott & McGough, Dan Colen, Ron Gorchov and Terence Koh — but as an art dealer, he is quickly fashioning himself more of an art-market prodigy than the prodigal son of the painter known as Julian Schnabel.

headline: Upsets Abound at New York International
text: At a tournament at the Marshall Chess Club in Manhattan, young players have been upsetting strong grandmasters.

headline: Ralcorp Strikes Trio of Food Deals
text: Ralcorp, the food company, said on Monday that it had agreed to three deals, including the $1.2 billion purchase of the American Italian Pasta Company, a major maker of dry pasta.

headline: Updike at Work: A Conversation
text: John Updike seemed like a man who was easy to know. His work was voluminous and autobiographical. He made speeches and gave interviews. He was an urbane presence, a man who made being a literary phenom look easy.

headline: Hong Kong Moves Ahead on Reforms
text: HONG KONG  After many years of negotiations and a series of false starts, Hong Kong’s chief executive and some of the city’s pro-democracy politicians have reached a compromise on a plan to make the legislature at least a little more democratic.

headline: Can the River Save the Deltas?
text: When water cascades from the Mississipi River into Lousiana’s delta wetlands, it may help mitigate oil contamination, researchers hypothesize.

headline: Giving Interns a Shot, and Paying for the Flu Fight
text: It is a Shangri-La of the New York City subway: cellular service, loud and clear, in the underground. For the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, years of planning have fallen victim to a century-old system that is no friend to new technology.

headline: Father’s Day, World Cup, W.P.S. and More
text: Midfielder Yael Averbuch helped lead Sky Blue F.C. to the championship of Women’s Professional Soccer in the league’s first season. Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., product by way of the University of North Carolina, will be filing to the Goal blog during the defending champions’ 2010 season.

headline: U.S. Shares Pull Back in Late Trading
text: Stocks in the United States ended slightly lower on Monday, reversing a surge that came after the Chinese currency strengthened to its highest level in nearly two years.

headline: A Basketball Deal in India, Where Cricket Is King
text: Yao Ming put China on the world’s basketball map. Now others want to find the next star in India.

headline: Federer Survives a Scare in the First Round
text: 11:40 a.m. | Updated WIMBLEDON, England -– Top-seeded Roger Federer, wearing an expression of mild irritation and disbelief, came back from a two-set deficit against Alejandro Falla of Colombia to win, 5-7, 4-6, 6-4, 7-6 (1), 6-0.

headline: Acergy to Acquire Subsea 7 in $2.5 Billion Deal
text: Acergy, the Norwegian oil and gas engineering firm, said on Monday that it would acquire its industry peer Subsea 7 to create a company with a market capitalization of $5.4 billion.

headline: Speed Read for Monday, June 21
text: Highlights from today’s media coverage:

headline: Referees Chief Defends Job by Officials
text: PRETORIA, South Africa — Three days after a  referee’s controversial call negated an apparent goal by the United States, and a day after another referee was duped into ejecting the Brazilian star Kaká, the head of World Cup referees defended the match officials.

headline: For Next Season, ‘American Idol’ Says the Kids Are All Right
text: The next season of “American Idol” isn’t officially subtitled “The Search for the Next Justin Bieber,” but one wonders if that teenage pop sensation had any influence on a newly announced adjustment to that reality contest’s rules. On Monday the producers of “American Idol” announced that they will lower the minimum age of eligibility for the singing competition to 15, the “Idol” host Ryan Seacrest said on his official Web site. In previous years, the minimum age for “Idol” hopefuls had been 16, but now performers like Aaron Kelly and Haeley Vaughn (who were well shy of voting age when they appeared on the show’s ninth season) will look like seasoned war horses compared to the 10th season’s crop. Sorry, Larry Platt, but you still can’t officially compete on the show: the maximum age remains 28.

headline: Ambrose’s Gaffe Gives Johnson His First Road Course Win
text: Marcus Ambrose, a road course specialist, was cruising to his first Sprint Cup win, at Infineon Raceway in Sonoma, Calif., when he stalled his car during a late-race yellow.

headline: Justices Back Monsanto on Biotech Seed Planting
text: In its first-ever ruling on genetically modified crops, the Supreme Court on Monday overturned a lower court’s ban on the planting of alfalfa seeds engineered to resist Monsanto’s Roundup herbicide.

headline: Monday Reading: A Travel Insurance Primer
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

text: The HBO documentary explores the effects of a type of natural gas drilling on residential water supplies.

headline: Pakistan's Burqa Drama
text: For some, "Burqavaganza" is a funny love story in the time of jihad. For others, it mocks Islam. The government's recent ban on the play highlights Pakistan's liberal-conservative divide.

headline: S.E.C. Cites Asset Firm in a Fraud
text: Beginning a new stage in the government’s investigations of the mortgage industry, the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday accused a New York firm that managed complex mortgage securities of defrauding investors and misleading the American International Group, the government-controlled company that insured some of the firm’s deals.

headline: At Buffalo News, New Rules for Online Comments
text: In a significant step toward reigning in the largely unpoliced world of anonymous online commenting, The Buffalo News said Monday that it would require all people who leave comments on its Web site to identify themselves.

text: “Burqavaganza” is a love story in the time of jihad. A young couple struggle to form a relationship as societal forces try to keep them apart.

text: In some Chinese groceries in New York, suspected thieves often abide by store rules that include having their photographs posted unless they pay money to avoid arrest.

headline: Celebrate Summer: Fun Ideas for Teaching With The Times
text: It’s not all business here on The Learning Network: even we recommend taking some time out just to enjoy the season — and today’s summer solstice.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Firm of Fraud in Mortgage Deals
text: 12:46 p.m. | Updated The Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday accused a New York firm that helped manage complex mortgage securities of defrauding investors as the housing market collapsed, The New York Times’s Louise Story reports.

headline: Ilyumzhinov Promises to Open His Checkbook Again
text: Ten days after Kirsan Ilyumzhinov, the president of the World Chess Federation, pledged to personally provide $1 million in prizes for a series of tournaments in Asia, he has promised $500,000 for two tournaments in the Caribbean and in Latin America.

text: Solar plants in the Sahara could send power to Europe as soon as 2015.

headline: Court Affirms Ban on Aiding Groups Tied to Terror
text: WASHINGTON  In a case pitting free speech against national security, the Supreme Court on Monday upheld a federal law that makes it a crime to provide “material support” to foreign terrorist organizations, even if the help takes the form of training for peacefully resolving conflicts.

headline: Exclusive Clip: 'The Law'
text: A scene from "The Law,"Jules Dassin's 1959 film with Marcello Mastroianni and Gina Lollobrigida. The film will be released at BAM on June 23.

headline: ASCAP Files 21 Copyright Suits Against Bars and Clubs
text: The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers said on Monday that it had filed copyright suits against 21 bars, nightclubs and restaurants across the country, including Doug’s Burger Bar in Imperial, Mo., and The Vibe in Riverside, Calif.

headline: A Proposal to Increase Securities Fraud Liability
text: 4:23 p.m. | Updated: An amendment to the financial bill to increase liability in securities fraud cases has been replaced by a provision for the Securities and Exchange Commission to study the issue, a spokesman for the House Financial Services Committee said Monday.

headline: National Academy Museum and School of Fine Arts to Renovate Building
text: The National Academy Museum and School of Fine Arts will cloJunese its Beaux Arts museum building on Fifth Avenue on Sunday for a renovation of its exhibition galleries and the creation of a new visitor center and a school studio gallery. The project, to be announced on Tuesday, will modernize the existing galleries for the first time in more than 100 years, providing dedicated space for the semipermanent exhibition of works from the academy’s collection of more than 7,000 paintings, drawings, prints and sculptures by American artists and architects.

headline: Federer Escapes With Victory
text: WIMBLEDON, England  On the first afternoon of Wimbledon, in the first match on Centre Court, Roger Federer found himself in an unfathomable position, losing by two sets. His face filled with frustration, exasperation and disbelief, a host of unfamiliar emotions, matching the monumental upset in the making.

headline: Panel Is Unlikely to End Deepwater Drilling Ban Early
text: WASHINGTON  The bipartisan commission named by President Obama in May to study the Deepwater Horizon oil spill and the future of American offshore drilling will hold its first formal meeting in mid-July at the earliest, most likely delaying the delivery of its final report into next year, a co-chairman of the panel said Friday in an interview.

headline: Making a Life, and a Living, From Rags and Turtle Wax
text: William Brown, 50, has been washing cars from the same sidewalk spot in Harlem for the last eight years, armed with a dozen multicolored rags, several spackle buckets and an assortment of waxes and cleansers.

headline: In Portugal, Saramago’s Funeral Draws 20,000 Mourners, But Not the President
text: President Anibal Cavaco Silva of Portugal defended his decision not to attend the funeral of the author José Saramago, saying he had never known Mr. Saramago during his lifetime, BBC News reported.

headline: Details Emerge on Weakness in Well Design
text: The Times has published a detailed and devastating report on weak links in the design and operation of the blowout preventer that was the last line of defense against an uncontrolled seabed gusher like the one at BP’s Macondo Prospect well in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Grading Your Life as a Parent
text: How would you grade yourself as a parent? As a spouse? On a scale of 1 to 100, how satisfied are you with your life?

headline: To Sell a Luxe Apartment, No Ordinary Snapshot Will Do
Thailand Acts Against Suspected Red Shirt Backers
text: BANGKOK  The Thai government has moved into the next phase of a campaign against the dissident movement known as the red shirts, freezing the assets of scores of people it says helped finance recent protests, and planning to summon them for questioning.

headline: Zombies Have Already Killed The Deficit Commission
text: It must have sounded like a good idea (although not to me): establish a bipartisan commission of Serious People to develop plans to bring the federal budget under control.

headline: Survey Finds Jump in Health Insurance Cost for Individuals
text: Even as the nation was debating whether to overhaul the health insurance market, people who were buying coverage on their own were experiencing sharp increases in the cost of their policies, according to a survey released Monday.

headline: Confirmation Fight on Health Chief
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama’s nominee to run Medicare and Medicaid, Dr. Donald M. Berwick, is a man with a mission, a preacher and a teacher who has been showing hospitals how they can save lives and money by zealously adhering to clinical protocols for the treatment of patients.

headline: Anti-Noise Activists Oppose Sounds for Electric Cars
text: The ultraquiet Nissan Leaf battery car will produce a synthesized sound to warn blind people and other pedestrians, but the driver can turn it off. The on-off feature has caused some consternation among advocates for the blind. But the very existence of this new addition to the standard traffic cacophony has also raised the hackles of another community — anti-noise activists.

headline: WNYC Hires a Vice President
text: The radio station WNYC — now officially known as New York Public Radio — has hired Graham Parker, the executive director of the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, to run its classical music arm, WQXR-FM. Mr. Parker will have the title of vice president, a newly created job that more sharply defines the station’s profile. WNYC, which acquired WQXR nine months ago in a deal with The New York Times, said WQXR would continue to operate Q2, an Internet stream where the station presents most of its contemporary music programming and broadcasts live concerts.

headline: World Cup Live: Chile vs. Switzerland
text: Chile topped Switzerland 1-0 in Port Elizabeth on Monday afternoon in a match Switzerland had to play with 10 men after a controversial red card decision in the first half.

headline: TimesCast | June 21, 2010
text: In today's Timescast, reports on the cause of the Deepwater Horizon blowout, a novel approach to combating shoplifting and a controversial play banned in Pakistan.

headline: Lessons From Federer’s Narrow Victory
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Much can be learned from how Roger Federer survived his own poor play on Monday in a five-set victory against Alejandro Falla. Perhaps the biggest lesson is that he kept his temperament in check and his body language fairly neutral, despite missing routine shots time and time again. That stands in contrast with Falla, who crumpled in the fifth set after losing the fourth-set tiebreaker, 7-1.

headline: It’s Your Waterfront. Help Plan It.
text: Why is New York City’s 578-mile waterfront such an oddly small part of the life of the city, and what can anyone do to change that? Funny, the Department of City Planning has been wondering the same thing.

headline: Rig Worker Says BP Was Told of Leak in Emergency System Before Explosion
text: Updated | 2:37 p.m. In an interview published online on Monday, a technician who worked on the Deepwater Horizon told the BBC that the rig’s blowout preventer, which failed to seal BP’s Macondo well in the Gulf of Mexico after an explosion on April 20, was leaking fluid weeks before the accident.

headline: ‘Red’ Makes Back Its Investment
text: “Red,” the 2010 Tony Award winner for best play, has recouped its $2.25 million production costs after 14 weeks of performances on Broadway, the producer Arielle Tepper Madover said on Monday.

headline: For E-Readers, a Price War
text: On our sister blog, Bits, Brad Stone reports that on Monday, Barnes & Noble started a round of e-reader price-cutting by dropping the price of the original Nook, with Wi-Fi and 3G wireless connectivity, to $199 from $259. It also introduced a new, Wi-Fi-only Nook at $149. That compares to the Amazon Kindle at $259 and the Sony Reader, whose least expensive version, the Pocket Edition, costs $169 and has no wireless connectivity at all.

headline: Summer’s Most Delicate Fruit: Apricots
text: Apricots and cherries are the first of the stone fruits to arrive in the farmers’ markets  right about now, in most parts of the country. Like peaches and plums, apricots are best if they’re locally grown. If they’ve been shipped over long distances, then they were picked green, and so the texture is likely to be soft and mealy, with very little flavor.

headline: Apricot Smoothie
text: An apricot smoothie should be pure apricot, with no other fruits to dilute the intense flavor. This smoothie makes a great drinkable breakfast or mini-meal in the afternoon.

headline: Apricot Purée
text: If you want to preserve apricots at their best for a few weeks, cook them down to a purée. Use it as a fresh apricot jam, stirred into yogurt or spooned onto toast, or serve it over melon or sliced peaches.

headline: Stores’ Treatment of Shoplifters Tests Rights
text: The A & N Food Market on Main Street in Flushing, Queens, has an almost entirely Chinese clientele. The inventory includes live eels, turtles and frogs, frozen duck tongue and canned congee. These goods, like products sold in every neighborhood of the city, attract their share of shoplifters. But A & N Food Market has an unusual way of dealing with the problem.

headline: Apricot and Yogurt Parfaits
text: Apricot yogurt, my favorite French yogurt, was the inspiration for these parfaits. The presentation transforms the mixture of apricots and plain yogurt into a beautiful dessert.

headline: Roasted Apricots With Almond and Breadcrumb Topping
text: This dish is like an apricot crumble but with less topping  you don’t need much to provide contrast with the tart baked apricots.

headline: More About the Business in My Trash
text: Thanks for your suggestions as to what to do with my scrap wood. I’d like to follow up with some further information about our waste stream and respond to some individual comments. I understand that many of you find it distressing that we are throwing away wood, and so do I, or I wouldn’t have written about it. I need to reiterate that the problem isn’t that the scrap is worthless or that someone couldn’t find a good use for it, but rather that my business requires me to concentrate on more lucrative activities.

headline: The Made Here Project: Looking at Artists’ Lives
text: What does it take to make it as an artist in New York? Talent, gumption, luck, and, perhaps most of all, cheap rent. (A little rehearsal never hurt either.) A new documentary video and interactive web series, the Made Here Project, explores how the creative class functions in the city, from finding spaces to making ends meet. In this month’s episode, artists including the theater performer Taylor Mac, the burlesque star Julie Atlas Muz, the b-girl Rokafella and the choreographer Elizabeth Streb talk about their day jobs (cleaning toilets, temping, making donuts) and how they made the transition to full-time creative careers.

text: WIMBLEDON, England –- Across a sunlit All England Lawn Tennis Club, the first day’s matches produced few surprises but some unexpected struggles.

headline: Augmented Reality Comes to Home Depot
text: Give a gift card, and a store is guaranteed a sale. Or, if there is no sale, because the recipient did not use the gift card, the store can keep both the money and the goods. So, naturally, businesses love gift cards.

headline: Spanish Press Blasts English Paper for ‘Nonsense’ About Their Goalkeeper’s Girlfriend
text: As The Lede explained on Friday, after Spain lost 1-0 to Switzerland in its opening World Cup match last week, a thinly sourced article in an English newspaper, The Times of London, suggested that the team’s goalkeeper had perhaps let himself be distracted by the great beauty of his girlfriend, a television reporter who was stationed behind his goal during the game.

headline: Autocorrect Follies
text: The autocorrect feature in iPhones, Android phones and other smartphones go a long way toward erasing the inefficiency that comes from having no physical keyboard. You type a few letters of a word—or you mistype something—and the little autocorrect bubble appears, proposing a full completed (or corrected) alternative. On the iPhone, if you just keep typing, the suggestion replaces what you typed. (If the suggestion is wrong, you tap it to dismiss it.)

headline: Prospect Park Goose Now Arrowless
text: Sticky the Prospect Park goose appears to have shed the arrow through its neck –- without the benefit of human intervention.

headline: The World of ‘Percy Jackson’ Lives on in ‘The Lost Hero’
text: Human children aren’t the only ones who enjoy summer camp: the offspring of the Greek gods have a getaway all their own, though non-divine readers will have to wait until the fall to catch up on their adventures there.

headline: Numberplay: Spooky Action at a Distance
text: After my whimsical travels of the last week, it is good to come back to Numberplay (incidentally, we finally have this convenient URL that you can bookmark to get access to all Numberplay posts). In today’s post, I will leave all whimsy aside, and show you that the universe we inhabit is stranger that our fictitious imaginings. Today we will explore a fundamental and almost unbelievable result of Quantum Mechanics (QM) through a set of simple puzzles. This famous result is “Bell’s Interconnectedness Theorem” which was discovered by the physicist John Stewart Bell in 1964. Bell’s theorem has been called by physicist Henry Stapp “the most profound discovery of Science.” It is profound because it shows that the universe has the property of non-locality: two particles can be light years apart, yet they are linked to each other instantaneously. How instantaneously? Recent measurements have shown that this phenomenon occurs more than 10,000 times the speed of light! In order to show that the universe in non-local, Bell showed that a certain simple and obvious inequality – Bell’s inequality – is violated. Amazingly, the only math that you need to understand this profound inequality is contained in the following simple problem.

headline: Abortion Rights Supporters Squabble Over Bill
