headline: The Secret Frontrunner
text: Over drinks last week, a conservative journalist friend made a plausible case that Mike Huckabee — who was first out of the gate to criticize the Mitch Daniels “truce on social issues” trial balloon — should be considered the real front-runner for the Republican presidential nomination in 2012. Ariel Levy’s profile of Huckabee, in this week’s New Yorker, lines up plenty of reasons why this might be flat wrong, from Huckabee’s proven inability to raise money or organize a ground game, to his perpetually-simmering war with the conservative establishment, to his tendency to self-pigeonhole (his protests to the contrary notwithstanding) as the candidate of Southern evangelicals and only Southern evangelicals. (There’s also the fact that he might just be happier as a well-compensated entertainer than as a politician.) But Levy also captures many of the qualities that make Huckabee more formidable than many handicappers acknowledge: His immense charm and “relentless niceness,” his intense bond with one of the G.O.P.’s largest constituencies, his high favorable numbers among Republican voters and his strength in early polls. And, of course, his ability to appear on any TV show, any time and anywhere, and charm the socks off the audience.

headline: Prognosis: When Cancer Patients Opt for Surgery
text: Most lung cancer patients who undergo surgery are still alive three years later, compared with just 10 percent of those who do not. Yet at least one-third of patients choose not to have the operation. Why not?

headline: What Counts as Abetting Terrorists?
text: Updated, 8:30 p.m. | Richard Epstein of the University of Chicago Law School takes on the positions of other panelists in this discussion. Scroll down to read his added comments.

headline: Risks: Blood Pressure Drugs Are Tied to Cancer
text: A class of blood pressure medicine used by tens of millions of patients is being linked to a slight but significant increase in cancer, especially lung cancer.

headline: New Tools for Helping Heart Patients
text: On a recent Monday, Helen Elzo got a call from her doctor’s office. A device implanted in her heart was not functioning. She needed to go to the hospital and have it replaced.

headline: A Partial Price on Carbon
text: The odds remain slight that Congress will put a price on carbon across the whole economy. But there’s still a chance that it may put a price on carbon for only power plants (but not for factories or transportation.)

headline: An Elderly Man’s Last Love Story
text: On The New Old Age blog, writer Anne Underwood shares the story of her elderly father who left his retirement home to move in with his girlfriend. Her father called it “part of the adventure of life,” but his daughter was worried about the toll the move might take on him physically and financially. She writes:

headline: House Agrees to Put Consumer Watchdog at Fed
text: Democrats in the House of Representatives said on Monday that they would agree to a Senate plan to make a proposed financial consumer watchdog part of the Federal Reserve, instead of an independent agency, Reuters reports.

headline: Weight-Lifting Injuries on the Rise
text: More and more people are lifting weights these days — and sometimes dropping them where they shouldn’t.

headline: Ice Craving May Signal Health Problem
text: Crunching on ice can be annoying to fellow diners. But now new research suggests it also may signal a health problem, writes Anahad O’Connor in today’s “Really?” column.

headline: How Would You Make an Apartment Photo-Ready?
text: In this week’s edition of my column, The Appraisal, I go behind the camera with real estate photographers and learn the tricks of making apartments look great in listings. This is a big business: these photographs are the first images most buyers see of properties. Some apartments require subtle changes, like taking out clutter and slightly moving chairs. Others require photographers to completely clean out the apartments or to move all of the furniture. Then there are apartments that require nothing less than Photoshop to make them presentable.

headline: For Denied Claims, a Bit of Help in the Health Law
text: Fighting with a health plan over a denied claim can leave people feeling they’ve been injured all over again.

headline: Faster Claims Payment Needed, Feinberg Says
text: BP said on Monday that it had so far spent about $2 billion in its response to the oil spill disaster in the Gulf of Mexico, including containment efforts, economic and environmental claims and state and federal costs.

headline: Language Lessons as Survey Winds Down
text: Wednesday, June 16

headline: When Tanning Turns Into an Addiction
text: Welcome to summer! For many of us, that means more time outdoors and less time lost putting on and taking off multiple layers of clothing. That in turn means more time and tissue exposed to the single biggest cause of skin damage and cancer: ultraviolet radiation.

headline: Tuberculosis: Mining Plays Bigger Role in TB in Africa Than Had Been Realized, Study Finds
text: Dust-choked mine shafts, crowded working conditions and stifling hostels where up to 16 miners share a room  all conspire to make mining a more important contributor to tuberculosis in Africa than had been realized, a new study finds.

headline: Seeking to Illuminate the Mysterious Placebo Effect
text: The phrase “mind-body connection” has many connotations. For some, it’s shorthand for New Age quackery. For others, it’s a source of hope and a way to reconcile their spiritual life with modern science.

headline: Carlsen Express Rolls on
text: The top-ranked player ran his winning streak at the Kings Tournament to four games on Monday.

headline: Barroso Defends Europe’s Move Toward Austerity
text: BRUSSELS  The European Union’s top official rejected concerns that Europe was moving too quickly toward economic austerity, saying it was vital to cut debt to restore market and voter confidence as the key to future growth.

headline: The Times Announces New Public Editor
text: The New York Times announced on Monday that Arthur Brisbane, a longtime journalist, will become its new public editor. Here’s an edited draft of the memo sent out by the company:

headline: The Era of the Oil Gusher
text: By some odd twist, oil gushers have come down in American cultural memory as a form of good news — evidence of riches found, like the popping of some geological champagne cork.

headline: Broadway and 46th Street, 11 A.M.
text: Several hundred yoga enthusiasts saluted the sun in Times Square Monday to mark the longest day of the year.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Dazed and Confused'
text: A. O. Scott looks back at Richard Linklater's film about the last day of school in 1976.

headline: Addicted to Tanning?
text: In today’s Personal Health column, Jane Brody explores whether repeated exposure to ultraviolet radiation through tanning has the potential to become addictive.

headline: Throwing Out Toys
text: As I have written here before, we have spent a lot of time cleaning out the garage and basement lately, a literal and psychic purging. (Remember that Dumpster I got for Mother’s Day?)

headline: The New Yorker Sings ‘O Canada’
text: The new issue of The New Yorker magazine might as well be called The Canadian. Yes, The Canadian.

headline: Gooooooaal in Manaus
text: Back in 2004, when the Boston Red Sox were on their way to their first World Series in many years, I was going to be late to my one-on-one Portuguese class because the game was running long. I called my Portuguese teacher – now my friend — Camila  and told her to meet me at the bar where I was watching.

headline: In Vatican Fresco, Visions of the Brain
text: It has been hiding in plain sight for the past 500 years, and now two Johns Hopkins professors believe they have found it: one of Michelangelo’s rare anatomical drawings in a panel high on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel.

headline: Chimps, Too, Wage War and Annex Rival Territory
text: Every day, John Mitani or a colleague is up at sunrise to check on the action among the chimpanzees at Ngogo, in Uganda’s Kibale National Park. Most days the male chimps behave a lot like frat boys, making a lot of noise or beating each other up. But once every 10 to 14 days, they do something more adult and cooperative: they wage war.

headline: A Thin Field of American Gewürztraminers
text: I’VE been a big fan of California gewürztraminers for a long time. Let me be more precise. I’ve felt that many California gewürztraminers, particularly those from the Anderson Valley in Mendocino County, were exactly the sorts of dry, lively, aromatic wines that would make almost anybody fall in love with this unusual, idiosyncratic grape.

headline: A Quiet Exit for Wawrinka at Wimbledon
text: WIMBLEDON, England –- A year ago, Stanislas Wawrinka of Switzerland fought Andy Murray of Scotland toe to toe in the first night match at Wimbledon, drawing cheers and shouts of approval as he was extending the British favorite to five sets under the new Center Court roof.

headline: Who’s the Best Brick Seller?
text: A winner has been selected in a contest sponsored by OgilvyOne Worldwide to find “the world’s greatest salesperson” — a person proficient enough in pitching to be able to sell a common brick.

headline: Sorting Through the History of Science, With Plenty of Side Trips
text: You can sometimes judge a book by its cover.

headline: At Ground Zero, a Step Forward on Performing Arts Center
text: At its board meeting on Tuesday, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is expected to approve an agreement under which it will be reimbursed by the city for the cost of building infrastructure below the planned performing arts center at ground zero. The construction of footings and foundations for the arts center has been estimated at $44 million. The authority, which owns the World Trade Center site, and the city have said that they are expecting that money to come from a $50 million fund controlled by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.

headline: Wanted: Ideas for a New Stop Sign
text: Two weeks ago, we wrote about Gary Lauder, a venture capitalist in California who had devised a new take on the stop sign, which he presented at a TED Talk in February.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Dazed and Confused’
text: School’s out, now what? That’s the central question asked by this week’s Critics’ Pick, “Dazed and Confused,” Richard Linklater’s period look at high school life in 1976. Mr. Scott praises the film’s soundtrack and Mr. Linklater’s attention to authenticity when recreating the looks, clothes and mood of the era. He also makes note of the film’s pacing, saying it “has a meandering, almost haphazard structure. You’re not sure who you’re going to run into next or where you’re going to end up, which, of course, is what life is like when school is out.” Have you seen “Dazed and Confused?” Please share your thoughts.

headline: Disney Seeks to Take Its ‘Phineas and Ferb’ Cartoon Hit to Next Level
text: LOS ANGELES  Picture the early days of “SpongeBob SquarePants”  before the theme park tie-ins, the movies and the merchandising blitz. Back when it was just a goofy animated show that somehow developed a loyal audience.

headline: Seabrook’s Lawyer Notes a Possible Conflict
text: The lawyer for City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook informed a federal judge on Monday that he might have a conflict of interest with a potential witness, which could further disrupt a case that has already been troubled by delays.

headline: Forward March!
text: Q. A student of neurology told me that a child of 3 or 4 months has lower-limb muscles ready to walk, but cannot because the inner ear (the vestibular system) is not yet developed, and that it is only at 11 or 12 months that the child can stand and walk because the inner ear has developed sufficiently. Is this true?

headline: Protests Over Power Shortages Force Iraqi Minister to Quit
text: BAGHDAD  Iraq’s electricity minister abruptly resigned Monday evening because of growing public outrage over the relentless power shortage crisis in the country, which exploded into violent weekend demonstrations that carried into the first day of summer’s 110-degree heat.

headline: Bidding Farewell to Ghosts of Pain
text: Early each morning I deal myself a daily hand of pills: Wellbutrin (450 milligrams) and Zoloft (200 mg) to ply the capricious oceans of postcancer depression, Provigil (200 mg) to keep exhaustion at bay and a chewable orange baby aspirin (81 mg) as a sweet and modest hedge against a heart attack.

headline: Rat Daddies
text: Just a quick note to say that since Nick’s Thursday column, which proposed giant bomb-sniffing, Tuberculosis-detecting rats as alternatives to more traditional Father’s Day gifts, Apopo, the organization behind the so-called HeroRATS, has received more than $150,000 in donations. And according to Mari Kuraishi, president of GlobalGiving.org, an online donations company that sponsors projects around the world like Apopo, an additional $30,000 went to non-rat-related enterprises.

headline: In Search of a Good Wine List
text: My column is on American gewürztraminer, a category that got me to wondering whether anybody drinks much gewürztraminer these days. I don’t drink it too often myself, although I do love bringing a bottle of good gewürztraminer with me when I go to Phoenix Garden, one of my favorite places in New York for excellent Cantonese food.

headline: The Fossil Record of Prehistoric Gnawing
text: Small mammals have been gnawing on bones for calcium and protein to supplement their diet for 75 million years, according to a report on the oldest known evidence of gnawing: on dinosaur bones.

headline: Damselfish Cultivate Their Algae Gardens
text: Gardeners who are vigilant against weeds may have a newfound appreciation for damselfish, which, a  new study reports, are diligent weeders of algae gardens in coral reefs around the world.

headline: Ancient Mesoamerica’s Rubber Industry
text: The Mesoamericans were robust users of rubber, according to historical and archaeological records. With it they made sandals, rubber bands and also balls, which they used to play a ceremonial game in stone-walled courts.

headline: Resort Scorecard | Stella McCartney Wins!
text: When did resort become a fully fledged season (like those divisions of the year, spring and fall, that actually represent a change in weather)? About that, we’re not sure exactly. But as the fash pack has been busy since before Memorial Day taking in the 67 shows/presentations/European house reshowings/roving “street-sides,” Scorecard has, as ever, kept tabs on all the critic talk for you. One thing’s for certain: when reviewing collections intended expressly to lure the dollars of women who winter in the urban jungle, qualities like prettiness, wearableness and merchiness are suddenly very good things.

headline: Under Pressure, Commission Discusses Lifting Whaling Ban
text: The International Whaling Commission on Monday began what promises to be a contentious, high-stakes meeting in Morocco on whether to maintain a 24-year-old moratorium on commercial whaling in the face of pressure from Japan, Norway and Iceland to permit the hunt.

headline: Updike Typewriter for Sale
text: John Updike’s papers may have gone to Harvard, but his typewriter could be yours. Christie’s will auction off on Tuesday an Olympia “electric 65c” typewriter and metal typewriter cart that belonged to the late novelist. The estimate is $4,000-$6,000. The serial number indicates that Updike probably purchased the typewriter while his family lived in London, from 1968 to 1969, shortly after he wrote “Couples.” He gave it to one of his daughters about 15 years before his death in 2009. A member of the writer’s family is selling the typewriter now and will donate half the proceeds from the sale to the New York Public Library.

headline: Pharaohs Are Given an Update
text: A new study provides detailed information about the timeline of ancient Egypt’s Old, Middle and New Kingdoms using radiocarbon dating.

headline: English Man Who Killed as a Child Accused of Downloading Child Pornography
text: On Monday, a British court made public new charges against a man who had been convicted of killing a 2-year-old boy in 1993, when he was just 10 years old himself, and then released from prison in 2001 and given a new identity.

headline: Dent Charges Into the Second Round
text: WIMBLEDON, England -– Taylor Dent of the United States serves, rushes the net, and volleys winners with the abandon of a 20th century player who doesn’t realize the 21st century game of tennis favors duels from the baseline.

headline: Discovering the Wonders of Skin Cells
text: Q. OVER THE YEARS, WHAT HAS BEEN THE DISCOVERY YOU ARE MOST PROUD OF?

headline: Nice View. How About a Game of Chess?
text: A bit late, but maybe worth the wait.

headline: Hallucinations in the Hospital
text: Hospital stays can be disorienting for any patient, but for some elderly patients the experience is particularly risky, triggering an unusual phenomenon called “hospital delirium.” As New York Times reporter Pam Belluck explains, these frightening hallucinations can be triggered by medicine, infection, surgery or even simple medical procedures.

headline: In Price War, E-Readers Go Below $200
text: A price war is brewing in the growing market for electronic reading devices.

headline: I Love My Wife (Hmm, Now How Can I Kill Her?)
text: Adam Ross’s “Mr. Peanut” is a dark, dazzling and deeply flawed novel that announces the debut of an enormously talented writer. An account of three troubled marriages, the book is a Rubik’s cube of a story that reads like a postmodern mash-up of Tolstoy’s  “Kreutzer Sonata,”  Edward Albee’s "Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?” and one of James M. Cain’s noirish mysteries.

headline: The Best Games of E3: From New Halo to Epic Mickey Mouse
text: The new technologies from Microsoft, Nintendo and Sony provided the most important news from the Electronic Entertainment Expo in Los Angeles last week, but there were plenty of exciting new games on display as well. No one person is able to see anything close to everything at E3 – the show is just too big – but these are some of titles coming in the next year that appeared particularly interesting and impressive.

headline: Labor Rule Changes Expected to Advance in Spain
text: MADRID — The Spanish government was expected to secure parliamentary approval Tuesday for its planned labor market overhaul despite concerns among economists that the changes would do little to alleviate Spain’s unemployment burden.

headline: Now Screening | Gucci
text: The Spring/Summer 2011 collection from Gucci at Milan Fashion Week.

headline: Spanish Press Blasts English Paper for ‘Nonsense’ About Goalkeeper’s Girlfriend
text: Before Spain’s 2-0 victory over Honduras on Monday moved it back into contention for a spot in the final 16, the nation’s news media spilled a lot of ink, and pixels, defending the national team’s captain and goalkeeper, Iker Casillas. As The Lede blog explained on Friday, last week Casillas was the victim of an apparently baseless rumor started by a report in The Times of London, which claimed that “many in Spain” said the team was in crisis because its keeper was too distracted by the beauty of his girlfriend, a sideline reporter for Spanish television, to do his job properly.

headline: Ex-Citi Trader, Hall, Raises $1 Billion
text: Andrew J. Hall, the former Citigroup energy trader whose proposed $100 million bonus created an uproar about excessive Wall Street compensation, has raised $1.08 billion for an offshore version of his hedge fund, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Candidates for Attorney General Make Their Case
text: The five Democratic candidates vying to become New York’s top prosecutor gathered together for the first time on Monday to make their cases.

headline: I See England, I See France
text: The amateur pantomime that is England’s 2010 World Cup campaign took another theatrical turn on Monday, perhaps more entertaining in its way than the mercy flight of WAGs winging its way to South Africa in defiance of Coach Fabio Capello’s ban on wives and girlfriends.

headline: The World of ‘Percy Jackson’ Lives On In ‘The Lost Hero’
text: Human children aren’t the only ones who enjoy summer camp: the offspring of the Greek gods have a getaway all their own, though nondivine readers will have to wait until the fall to catch up on their adventures there. The publisher Disney Hyperion said on Monday that it would release “The Lost Hero,” a new work by Rick Riordan, the author of the hit “Percy Jackson & the Olympians” adventure series, as well as “The Red Pyramid,” s children’s best seller. The new young-adult novel will be the first in a “Heroes of Olympus” series that will bring existing “Percy Jackson” heroes and new characters together at Camp Half-Blood, the training ground for demigods. Mr. Riordan said on Monday that he had been contemplating this series well before completing the previous one. “I knew already that there was more to the story that I wouldn’t be able to fit into the arc,” Mr. Riordan said in a telephone interview. “Really, it’s a balancing act between wanting Percy Jackson to have a strong ending and acknowledging that there are a lot of fans out there who weren’t ready to say to goodbye to that world.” “The Lost Hero” will go on sale Oct. 12.

headline: National Academy Museum To Renovate
text: The National Academy Museum and School of Fine Arts will close its Beaux Arts museum building, on Fifth Avenue at 89th Street, on Sunday to renovate its exhibition galleries and create a new visitor center and a school studio gallery. The project, to be announced on Tuesday, will modernize the galleries for the first time in more than 100 years, providing dedicated space for the semipermanent exhibition of works from the academy’s collection of more than 7,000 paintings, drawings, prints and sculptures by American artists and architects. The renovation is part of the academy’s larger effort to address some of the problems that forced it to sell two important Hudson River School paintings in 2008 to pay its bills. Because of its strict policies against deaccessioning art to pay operating costs, the Association of Art Museum Directors advised other museums to cut off all loans to the 184-year-old academy and forgo any collaborations. During the renovations  expected to be completed in September 2011  the academy will continue to host its evening roundtable discussion, “The Review Panel,” and the school will maintain a full class schedule, both on the premises.

headline: For Next Season, ‘American Idol’ Says the Kids Are All Right
text: The next season of “American Idol” isn’t officially subtitled “The Search for the Next Justin Bieber,” but one wonders if that teenage pop sensation had any influence on a newly announced adjustment to the reality contest’s rules. On Monday the producers of “American Idol” announced that they would lower the minimum age of eligibility for the singing competition to 15, the “Idol” host Ryan Seacrest said on his Web site, ryanseacrest.com. In previous years the minimum age for “Idol” hopefuls was 16, but now performers like Aaron Kelly and Haeley Vaughn (who were well shy of voting age when they appeared on the show’s ninth season) will look like seasoned war horses compared to the 10th season’s crop. Sorry, Larry Platt, but you still can’t officially compete on the show: the maximum age remains 28. The “Idol” producers also said that the show’s next round of auditions would begin on July 17 at the Bridgestone Arena in Nashville. Auditions will continue through the summer in Milwaukee; New Orleans; East Rutherford, N.J.; and Austin, Tex., before concluding in San Francisco on Aug. 19. And to answer your next question: No, a replacement for Simon Cowell, the outgoing “American Idol” judge, has not been announced.

headline: ‘Red’ Recovers Its Investment
text: “Red,” the 2010 Tony Award winner for best play, has recouped its $2.25 million production costs after 14 weeks of performances on Broadway, the producer Arielle Tepper Madover said on Monday. That financial benchmark makes “Red” one of a handful of plays from the 2009-10 Broadway season that earned back their investors’ money, among them the revivals of “Fences” and “A View From the Bridge” and the new plays “Race” and “A Steady Rain.” “Red,” a two-character drama by John Logan about the artist Mark Rothko (played by Alfred Molina, right, standing), won six Tony Awards overall this month, including best director (Michael Grandage), best featured actor in a play (Eddie Redmayne, above, kneeling) and best set for a play (Christopher Oram). The production is to close on Sunday after 101 regular performances and 22 previews, an unusually short run for a best -lay Tony recipient. This was necessary, Ms. Madover has said, because the two stars had commitments, and she did not want to recast their roles.

headline: Wnyc Hires a Vice President
text: The radio station WNYC  now officially known as New York Public Radio  has hired Graham Parker, the executive director of the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, to run its classical music arm, WQXR-FM (105.9). Mr. Parker will have the title of vice president, a newly created job that more sharply defines the station’s profile. WNYC, which acquired WQXR nine months ago in a deal with The New York Times, said WQXR would continue to operate Q2, an Internet stream where the station presents most of its contemporary music programming and broadcasts live concerts. Mr. Parker was hired even though New York Public Radio is still a bit more than two-thirds of the way toward raising $15 million for the acquisition and start-up costs. Laura R. Walker, the president and chief executive, said the appointment was not adding another layer but rather a move she had long envisioned. “In fact, it’s a pretty lean staff,” she said. “The audience for the station is very high, and it deserves its own leader.” Orpheus said that its general manager, Jim Bredeson, would be acting executive director while a replacement is sought.

headline: Scorecard | Jil Sander Wins!
text: If it’s Monday, Scorecard must be in Milan. Resort may have just wrapped for the ladies, but as our color-coded master fashion calendar reminds us, it’s time to get up to speed on the spring 2011 men’s-wear shows, which is why we’ve pulled double duty reading all the reviews so you don’t have to. Between John Varvatos’s 10th-anniversary rocker-chic redux and Dolce & Gabbana’s 20th-anniversary Sicilian sartorial extravaganza, this weekend designers were taking a long look back. Yet it was Raf Simons’s Koonsian pastiche for Jil Sander, which was actually shown in Florence last Thursday as part of Pitti Uomo, that blew everyone else out of the water, reminding us that granddad-like isn’t necessarily chic. Celebration, indeed.

headline: At Ground Zero, a Step Forward On Performing Arts Center
text: At its board meeting on Tuesday the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is expected to approve an agreement under which it will be reimbursed by the city for the cost of building infrastructure below the planned performing arts center at ground zero. The construction of footings and foundations for the arts center has been estimated at $44 million. The authority, which owns the World Trade Center site, and the city have said that they expect that money to come from a $50 million fund controlled by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. The development corporation has been working toward an alternative plan: moving the arts center to the Deutsche Bank building site at 130 Liberty Street, which the corporation owns and where it believes that the arts center can be built much faster and more cheaply. The city has argued for the importance of honoring the original master plan for ground zero, which calls for a performing arts center in the area bounded by Fulton, Greenwich, Vesey and Washington Streets  the architect Frank Gehry was selected in 2004 to design the building for its anchor tenant, the Joyce Theater. The Port Authority’s plan to address the infrastructure issue “is a tangible sign that the performing arts center is moving forward,” Linda Shelton, executive director of the Joyce, said on Monday. “There were a lot of skeptics that this wouldn’t happen, but this is a great step forward.” The Port Authority and the development corporation declined to comment on their expectations for Tuesday’s meeting.

headline: Carlyle’s Booz Allen Plans $300 Million I.P.O.
text: Booz Allen Hamilton, the consulting firm taken private less than two years ago by the Carlyle Group, is planning an initial public offering to raise as much as $300 million, Bloomberg News reports, providing another sign that the I.P.O. market appears to be thawing out from its chill earlier this year.

headline: Answers From the Investigative Team
text: Following are responses from David Barstow, one of the reporters who examined the lax oversight of the oil rig’s blowout preventer.

headline: Maurice and Marlene: Love Story Retold
text: Don’t assume from the title “Dietrich & Chevalier: The Musical” that you’re going to get diamonds and white tie and old Euro-Hollywood glamour. You are, to some degree. But if you see the show, at St. Luke’s Theater, you’re also going to get Nazis: edicts from Hitler, cheery messages from Goebbels (reichsminister for enlightenment) and threats from French collaborators. And they’re a lot more interesting than the pallid little romance.

headline: João Gilberto Concert at Carnegie Hall Canceled
text: Because of international travel restrictions, the João Gilberto concert at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night as part of the CareFusion Jazz Festival has been canceled. George Wein, the producer of the festival, said in a statement: “I am heartbroken over this unfortunate situation. Joao Gilberto is one of the most important musical artists of our generation, and it has always been a privilege to present him at Carnegie Hall.” Tickets will be refunded where they were purchased.

headline: Eminem Reasserts His Core Values
text: Maybe there should never have been room for Eminem in the first place.

headline: Cold, Dark and Teeming With Life
text: The deep seabed was once considered a biological desert. Life, the logic went, was synonymous with light and photosynthesis. The sun powered the planet’s food chains, and only a few scavengers could ply the preternaturally dark abyss.

headline: Take Your Time, Crime Will Wait
text: Slow Food, a movement that began in Italy in the 1980s as a protest against agribusiness and fast food, promotes organic farming and regional cooking. That cult of less-is-more parochialism spread to other fields, including tourism (Slow Travel) and investment (Slow Money).

headline: Poll Finds Deep Concern About Energy and Economy
text: Overwhelmingly, Americans think the nation needs a fundamental overhaul of its energy policies, and most expect alternative forms to replace oil as a major source within 25 years. Yet a majority are unwilling to pay higher gasoline prices to help develop new fuel sources.

headline: For Final Bow, a Shower of Flowers and Adoration
text: It’s difficult to be phlegmatic when a packed theater is cheering for you, with dazzled fans calling out your name in rock-star fashion. But Albert Evans more than managed it Sunday afternoon at the David H. Koch Theater, when he danced the third (Phlegmatic) variation of “The Four Temperaments” for the final time as a New York City Ballet principal. They don’t call them old pros for nothing.

headline: A Box-Office Bump for Tony Winners
text: The Broadway productions “Memphis” and “Red” — the winners of the 2010 Tony Awards for best musical and best play, respectively — each enjoyed box-office bumps of about 20 percent last week in the immediate afterglow of the CBS telecast on June 13, according to Broadway box-office data released on Monday.

headline: Back to the Cabaret, With Stories From a Long Career
text: At 76 Tammy Grimes has amassed a lifetime of stories and loves to tell them. She was discovered singing in a cabaret by Noël Coward, knew she would marry Christopher Plummer the first time she saw him onstage (and she did), was the first and in some people’s minds the only “Unsinkable Molly Brown” (sorry, Debbie Reynolds), and once showered with a young Marlon Brando.

headline: The Love of a Father (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Reality TV Show Faces Ultimate Test
text: Reality TV has brought birth, dating, marriage, divorce, drinking, dieting, hiring, firing and old age into American homes. And now, death.

headline: A Call for Preservation (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Work of Being First, Expectations Attached
text: It makes a kind of sense to take a didactic approach to a story about education. That’s what Charles Smith has done in “Freed,” his play about a former slave attending college in the 1820s. Some scenes take their cues from the Socratic method, others are point-counterpoint or stand and deliver, but almost all involve two people exchanging ideas or arguing. That’s the play’s strength and its weakness.

headline: Teens and Online Video (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Credit Unions for All: Pentagon Federal
text: In response to my column about big credit unions with loosey-goosey membership rules, one reader wrote in to chastise me for not offering more details on which credit unions specifically tended to have the best deals.

headline: Leave-Takings Above a Bar in Brooklyn
text: In his documentaries “The Boys of 2nd Street Park,” “Ring of Fire” and “Crazy Love,” Dan Klores established himself as a keen observer of specific New York stories, with a solid grasp of sociohistorical context. But specificity and context are two things missing from his first full-length play, “Little Doc,” which opened on Thursday night at the Rattlestick Playwrights Theater.

headline: Surviving a Spouse (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ethnic Uzbeks Find Calm but Fear for Those Still Behind
text: KARASU, Uzbekistan  “I have three children  9, 7 and 4 years old  and they are just in shock,” a woman named Ursanoy Mamadaliyeva said on Monday. “My youngest said to me, ‘Mama, if we return to Kyrgyzstan, then you have to buy me an automatic weapon.’

headline: A Brazilian Makes Playful but Serious Art
text: At the New Museum last Friday the artist Rivane Neuenschwander was on her knees, slicing up the carpeting in a third-floor gallery as she searched energetically for microphones hidden in the floorboards and walls. A security and surveillance team had secreted the bugs there at her request, but without her knowing their locations; now the devices were recording her hunt in the otherwise silent room, in preparation for a fast-approaching show.

headline: Academic Series in Jazzy Surroundings
text: Maybe location really is everything. When Mannes College the New School for Music presents its annual summer festival concerts in its auditorium on the Upper West Side, they seem low key and academic, no matter how vividly played and well attended they are. But following in the footsteps of the Keys to the Future festival, which was held at the similarly quaint Greenwich House Music School until this year, Mannes has moved a few of the concerts in its Institute and Festival for Contemporary Performance to Le Poisson Rouge.

headline: Improvisational and Atmospheric Dialogues: A Tribute to an Avant-Gardist
text: The avant-garde composer and multireedist Anthony Braxton had plenty of words for his admirers at Le Poisson Rouge on Friday night, when it was officially his turn to take the stage. He talked about the striving of noncommercial artists. He referred to “geopolitical dynamics,” adding that the world was still full of “men and women of goodwill.” He expressed appreciation for the costume splendor of Lady Gaga. And finally he struck a note of retirement-party humor: “If you have to be 65, this is the best way to do it.”

headline: Outer Court Heaven, Away From Wimbledon Crowds
text: One of the joys of Wimbledon is finding a match on the outer courts and settling in to watch. There’s an intimacy to these matches, as you can sit in the first row and watch a match between two world class players who often battle through qualifying to earn a spot in the main draw.

headline: Concern Over Foreign Trials for Drugs Sold in U.S.
text: WASHINGTON  Medical ethicists have worried for years about the growing share of new drugs whose human trials took place in foreign countries where federal auditors could not make sure patients were protected, but no one knew how big the potential problem was.

headline: A Complex Food Chain
text: A cold-seep community in the Gulf of Mexico includes microbes that live on oil and gas seeping up from the seabed.

headline: White House Seeing Hope in Illinois?
text: Is the White House suddenly doubling down to try and keep President Obama’s old United States Senate seat in Democratic hands?

headline: Battles in California Over Mortgages
text: As the housing market continues to sputter, the real estate industry is increasingly split on the responsibilities of overextended and foreclosed homeowners.

headline: Next Worry for Wall Street: Basel Bank Rules
text: As the debate over the financial regulatory bill nears an end in Congress, many on Wall Street are shifting their attention to Switzerland to see what new regulations will come out of the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, the international banking watchdog.

headline: Intel and F.T.C. Agree to Talk
text: Intel has reached a legal cease-fire with the Federal Trade Commission.

headline: Iran Bars Nuclear Inspectors In Response to Sanctions
text: WASHINGTON  Iran on Monday barred two United Nations nuclear inspectors from returning to the country, apparently the first step in what Iran’s government has said will be a series of actions in response to the latest round of United Nations Security Council sanctions.

headline: Drug Use Has Increased in Afghanistan, U.N. Report Says
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The last several years of poverty, conflict and widely available opium are taking a toll on the Afghan population, with roughly 800,000 Afghan adults now using opium, heroin and other illicit drugs, a jump from five years ago, according to a study by the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime.

headline: Banker Is Said to Be Mayor’s Choice for Economic Development
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is expected to announce Tuesday that he has selected a former Wall Street banker as the next deputy mayor for economic development, according to administration and business officials.

headline: South Africa: 6 Arrested in Shooting of an Exiled Rwandan Army Chief
text: The South African police said Monday they had arrested six suspects in the Saturday shooting of the exiled Rwandan army chief Lt. Gen. Faustin Kayumba Nyamwasa, an attack his wife claims was an assassination attempt by the government of Rwanda’s president, Paul Kagame. The police withheld the nationalities of those arrested. General Nyamwasa, who is in stable condition, was shot in the stomach as he returned with his family to their suburban Johannesburg home. He left Rwanda this year after a falling out with Mr. Kagame, above. The Rwandan government called accusations of an assassination attempt “preposterous.”

headline: A New Path to Divorce in New York
text: To the Editor:

headline: Feinberg Seeks Faster Payments of BP Claims
text: BP said Monday that it had so far spent about $2 billion in its response to the oil spill disaster in the Gulf of Mexico, including containment efforts, economic and environmental claims, and state and federal costs, The New York Times’s Liz Robbins reports.

headline: Oil Spills in Nigeria
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Health Insurer Pays More to Save
text: Like a lot of doctors, Patrick Kilduff has too many patients and too little time. He and the five other physicians in Shavertown, Pa., oversee the care of about 12,000 people, and a typical office visit lasts just 15 minutes.

headline: Excerpt: 'Memphis Beat'
text: The new TNT procedural stars Jason Lee as a Memphis detective who sings on the side.

headline: Nets Look at Big Men While Pining for a Guard
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Nets continued their search for a complementary big forward to center Brook Lopez on Monday by working out the college freshmen DeMarcus Cousins of Kentucky and Derrick Favors of Georgia Tech.

headline: Spirit of the ‘Refuseniks’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Teaching Engineering to Children
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Iraqi Danger Zone, Violence Resists a Timetable
text: MOSUL, Iraq  Staff Col. Ismail Khalif Jasim, the top intelligence officer in Nineveh Province, was scrutinizing faces last week as he walked through what the police say is the most dangerous neighborhood in Iraq’s most violent city. The place is so risky that some of his colleagues apologetically offered reasons why they would be unable to accompany him there.

headline: China’s Currency Off the Table, G-20 Focuses on Europe
text: WASHINGTON  China’s decision to allow its currency to rise gradually against the dollar has strengthened the Obama administration’s hand going into a summit meeting of the Group of 20 countries this weekend in Toronto. But other challenges, from Europe’s debt crisis to changes in banking regulation, could test the unity of the G-20 as it moves from crisis control to a more complicated agenda of economic coordination.

headline: Taxing Investment Profits
text: To the Editor:

headline: Solar Power in Colorado
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cigarette Tax Increased to Keep State Running
text: ALBANY  New Yorkers who like to smoke will have to dig a little deeper to light up next month, after the Legislature passed a bill on Monday that will give the state the highest cigarette taxes in the country.

headline: Obama Says Fathers Just Need to Be There
text: In what has become his tradition within a tradition, President Obama for a third straight year seized on June’s celebration of fathers to promote “a national conversation” about responsible fatherhood, infused with his own experiences as an abandoned son and now as a busy parent.

headline: Spain Impresses, but Knows It Has Work Still to Do
text: JOHANNESBURG — Spain played with urgency Monday night, to survive in the World Cup, to defeat one opponent in hopes of avoiding another.

headline: Africa Hosts the Cup but Imports the Coaches
text: CAPE TOWN  This is supposed to be Africa’s World Cup, but Africa’s teams, many on the verge of elimination, are still not entirely Africa’s teams.

headline: Ratner Content to Succeed in the Shadows
text: Unlike his outsize real estate undertaking in downtown Brooklyn, Bruce C. Ratner blends in. In the commercial heart of the neighborhood that he is reshaping and where many are said to resent him, Ratner walked the perimeter of the footprint for his $1 billion sports arena during a recent weekday lunch hour without drawing a glance.

headline: Diamond Find Could Aid Zimbabwe, and Mugabe
text: JOHANNESBURG  New mining in Zimbabwe has quickly yielded millions of carats of diamonds and could help catapult the nation into the ranks of the world’s top diamond producers, according to the head of a group of experts for the United Nations-backed effort to stop the trade in conflict diamonds.

headline: Let the Pill Go Free
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Leathery Veteran Faces the End of a Big Career
text: A weathered veteran, weakened and graying at the edges, is facing the end of its baseball career with the Mets. There are perhaps only one or two more starts in the coming week before a designated replacement is in the lineup.

headline: Deep in the Heart of Texas
text: A number of responses to my column about the education I received at Classical High (a public school in Providence, RI) rehearsed a story of late-flowering gratitude after an earlier period of frustration and resentment. “I had a high school (or a college) experience like yours,” the poster typically said, “and I hated it and complained all the time about the homework, the demands and the discipline; but now I am so pleased that I stayed the course and acquired skills that have served me well throughout my entire life.”

headline: Amid Controversy, Little Time for Feel-Good Questions
text: Johannesburg

headline: U.S. Said to Fund Afghan Warlords to Protect Convoys
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  American taxpayers have inadvertently created a network of warlords across Afghanistan who are making millions of dollars escorting NATO convoys and operating outside the control of either the Afghan government or the American and NATO militaries, according to the results of a Congressional investigation released Monday.

headline: Blow Up the Well to Save the Gulf
text: TONY HAYWARD, the chief executive of BP, made an astounding admission before Congress last week: after nearly two months of failure, the company and the Coast Guard have no further plans to plug the Macondo oil well leaking into the Gulf. Instead, the goal is merely to contain the leak until a relief well comes online, a process that could take months.

headline: Referees Talk Openly, but Not About That One Call
text: PRETORIA, South Africa  The referee Koman Coulibaly blew his whistle almost 90 times during the United States’ 2-2 tie with Slovenia on Friday, but one blast stands out, and his decision to disallow an apparent go-ahead goal by the Americans in the 85th minute remains without an explanation.

headline: Raymond Parks, Nascar Pioneer, Dies at 96
text: Raymond Parks, who got to know fast cars while transporting moonshine along Georgia’s back roads and went on to become a pioneering figure in Nascar as the owner of its first championship team, died Sunday at his home in Atlanta. He was 96.

headline: A Bruise on the First Amendment
text: Forty-three years ago, when the nation lived in fear of Communist sympathizers and saboteurs, the Supreme Court said that even the need for national defense could not reduce the First Amendment rights of those associating with American Communists.

headline: A Neck as Arrow-Free as the Rest of the Gaggle
text: Early Wednesday morning, Anne-Katrin Titze and her partner, Ed Bahlman, went to feed their favorite Canada goose, Beaky, near Prospect Park lake in Brooklyn.

headline: In Law Schools, Grades Go Up, Just Like That
text: One day next month every student at Loyola Law School Los Angeles will awake to a higher grade point average.

headline: 27-Year Sentence for Plant Manager
text: A federal judge in Iowa on Monday announced a prison sentence of 27 years on financial fraud charges for Sholom Rubashkin, the former manager of a kosher meatpacking plant where hundreds of illegal immigrant workers were arrested in a 2008 raid that garnered national attention.

headline: The Bloomberg-Blagojevich Connection, or Campaign Politics Before a Fall
text: It turns out that Rod R. Blagojevich, the impeached former governor of Illinois, flamboyant reality television star and billboard for the helmet hairdo, had an unexpected admirer in New York City: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: 2 Suspects in Spate of Shootings
text: The police have suspects in two of four unrelated killings that occurred within a three-hour period over the weekend, the police said on Monday.

headline: Easing the Gaza Blockade
text: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has made the right decision to significantly ease Israel’s punishing and counterproductive blockade of Gaza. The move was clearly intended to mollify Washington and Europe in the wake of Israel’s deadly raid this month on an aid flotilla trying to run the blockade.

headline: Taxes for Your Health. Yeah, Sure.
text: Thank Heaven for those of you in New York who behave self-destructively. Without you, what would the politicians do to balance their budgets? There they were in Albany on Monday exploring ways to dip into your pockets once again.

headline: People in Gaza Await Easing of Israeli Blockade
text: GAZA — The beach was teeming with children and their parents, and it seemed the whole neighborhood had come out to kick a ball, fly kites or just sit in the sand as the sun set in the Mediterranean Sea. So Muhammad Ali decided it was the perfect time to start a business, to try to sell corn on the beach.

headline: Lottery Numbers
The High Cost of Immigrating
text: When it comes to America’s immigration bureaucracy, there is one thing that newcomers to the United States can count on: the fees have a way of going up.

headline: Elon Musk, PayPal Pioneer, Is Paper-Rich, Cash-Poor
text: The funny thing about Elon Musk is that he does  sort of remind you of Tony Stark. Minus the Iron Man suit.

headline: U.S. and Canadian Drug Makers Agree to a $3.2 Billion Merger
text: Two drug makers with sometimes stormy pasts, Biovail and Valeant Pharmaceuticals International, said Monday that they had agreed to merge in a $3.2 billion deal. The merger will create a big Canadian-American player in the world of specialty pharmaceutical companies.

headline: Faustus Makes a Deal
text: It was the winter of 2007. Dr. Faustus, the famous left-wing philologist, was sitting in a coffee shop in despair over the Bush-Cheney regime and the future of his country.

headline: Use of Eyewitnesses in New Jersey Courts Needs Change, Ex-Judge Says
text: Courts should do more to gauge the accuracy of witnesses to crimes, and to let juries know how flawed their testimony can be, according to a former appellate judge assigned by the New Jersey Supreme Court to review the matter.

headline: When Greatness Slips Away
text: We’ve blown so many enormous opportunities over the past several years. In the immediate aftermath of Sept. 11, 2001, when most of the world had lined up in support of the United States, President George W. Bush had the chance to lead a vast cooperative, international effort to combat terrorism and lay the groundwork for a more peaceful, more secure world.

headline: Orszag Leaving as Budget Director
text: Peter R. Orszag will leave his job as the White House budget director in July, according to someone familiar with his plans, making him perhaps the first official to leave the Obama Cabinet and removing a major player from President Obama’s economic team.

headline: Exporters Optimistic Over Move on Currency
text: Embracing China’s decision to let its currency move more freely, American businesses said on Monday that the move would make it easier to compete against Chinese companies and would help reduce the United States trade deficit.

headline: Word Game
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — If you’re one of those people who like word games … Wait, you are. Right. Then you probably know all about the game in the center of the grid. To me, it’s one of those rare games that is just as much fun if nobody bothers to keep score. Players take turns adding on to a growing sequence of letters. You lose if you complete a word or if you fail to create a new fragment that can begin a longer word. Look it up using your favorite Internet search engine if you’d like to find the details.

headline: McCain Is Now Running Just to Stay in Place
text: PARKER, Ariz. — He still tells the story about the call he got at 2 a.m. from the woman in Chandler who was upset about changes in her garbage pick up, and the ossified joke concerning two Irish brothers (“The only ethnic group in America you can still joke about”) boozed up at a bar.

headline: With 2nd Ave. Project, Brief Moves May Pay
text: Say the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has decided to eject you from your Upper East Side walk-up for a month, maybe two, to help make way for the Second Avenue subway.

headline: One Person, One Vote for President
text: Nearly 10 years after George W. Bush lost the popular vote to Al Gore and became president anyway, the New York State Legislature has a chance to withdraw from the archaic and unfair way this country picks its chief executives.

headline: A Campaign for M&Ms With a Salty Center? Sweet
text: FOR those who like a bit of salt and crunch in their chocolate, M&Ms has a new twist on its 69-year-old candy classic. The company put a nugget of pretzel inside its candy, to cater to the growing consumer taste for mixing sweet and salty flavors.

headline: Bloggingheads: Goodbye Gun Control
text: Bill Scher of the Campaign for America's Future and Matt Lewis of Politics Daily debate the politics of gun control.

headline: Prep Classes for College Are Latest in Perks
text: SAT tutoring and private college admissions counseling have long been perceived as giving an unfair advantage to the children of the wealthy, at least in the opinion of those who may be unable to afford such services.

headline: The Anosognosic’s Dilemma: Something’s Wrong but You’ll Never Know What It Is (Part 2)
text: (This is the second part of a five-part series.)

headline: City Seeking New Test for Gifted Admissions
text: The city will search for a new admissions test for its gifted and talented public school programs, a Department of Education official said on Monday, in part to address concerns that some families were “gaming” the test through extensive preparation.

headline: In Body Scans, Less Attitude Please
text: THERE was robust reader reaction to last week’s column describing those body scan machines that the Transportation Security Administration is busily installing in airports  and my experience with one of them.

headline: Gay Workers Will Get Time to Care for Partner’s Sick Child
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama will soon expand the rights of gay workers by allowing them to take family and medical leave to care for sick or newborn children of same-sex partners, administration officials said Monday.

headline: From Fellow Passengers, an Embrace of Louisiana
text: WHEN I was in college, I went with a group of 14 friends to London. We took a flight from Miami that cost us only $199. We had a blast.

headline: Report Cites U.S. Financing of Afghan Warlords
text: Dexter Filkins reports on a Congressional investigation that found that American taxpayers have inadvertently created a network of warlords across Afghanistan who are making millions of dollars escorting NATO convoys. These warlords operate outside the control of either the Afghan government or the American and NATO militaries.

headline: Corrections
text: A film review on Friday about “8: The Mormon Proposition,” which looks at the campaign against gay marriage in California, referred incorrectly to the current status of same-sex marriages in that state from the time licenses for them began being granted in June 2008 until a constitutional amendment in November of that year limited marriage to a man and a woman. They retain all state-level marriage rights including  not excluding  recognition of the legal term “marriage.”

text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: White House Budget Chief Is Leaving
text: WASHINGTON — Peter R. Orszag will leave his job as the White House budget director in July, according to someone familiar with his plans, making him perhaps the first official to leave the Obama cabinet and removing a major player from President Obama’s economic team.

headline: Rewarded for Flying Coach
text: Long before the economy foundered, Energizer Battery Company was looking for ways to cut its travel costs. After all, two-thirds of the company’s 5,000 to 6,000 employees travel for work, many of them overseas.

headline: World Cup Photo Replay: Day 11, June 21
text: The day’s action featured a lot of scoring, if only by Portugal, and plenty of physical play.

headline: As His Innings Mount, Hughes Will Skip Start
text: PHOENIX  Phil Hughes is a victim of his own success. By pitching so well this season, by logging so many innings, Hughes has accelerated the Yankees’ preservation plan for him. They will skip his scheduled start Friday in Los Angeles to give him three more starts before the All-Star break instead of four.

headline: A Russian Billionaire, the Nets and Sweetheart Deals
text: The Russian billionaire Mikhail D. Prokhorov, the Nets’ new majority owner and the N.B.A.’s first overseas owner, magnetized members of the news media during his recent whirlwind tour of New York.

headline: Martinez Uses First Baseman’s Mitt to Catch Knuckleballer
text: BOSTON — When Victor Martinez took his place behind the plate for the Boston Red Sox on Saturday, something looked amiss. On his left hand was not a catcher’s mitt, but a first baseman’s glove.

headline: Obama and Senator Differ on Narrative of Meeting
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama and Senator Jon Kyl on Monday waged a “he said, he said” war of words, disputing what the president said about enforcing the nation’s borders in a private meeting with Mr. Kyl, an Arizona Republican. But in usual Washington fashion, only their spokesmen did the talking.

headline: Despite Obama’s Plea, European Bank Renews Call for Austerity
text: FRANKFURT  European countries need to keep a sharper eye on one another’s finances, and sanctions against fiscal rule-breakers should kick in automatically, the European Central Bank president, Jean-Claude Trichet, said on Monday.

headline: Still a Fashion Statement, but Quieter
text: WIMBLEDON, England  Four years ago, the last time Bethanie Mattek-Sands played Wimbledon during a World Cup, soccer inspired her outfit, and her outfit inspired outrage. Andy Murray’s mother told reporters she would have sent her son home to change if he had dressed like that.

headline: Times Chooses a Public Editor, Giving Him a 3-Year Term
text: The New York Times said Monday that it had selected Arthur S. Brisbane, a longtime journalist who has been a reporter and editor at The Washington Post, the editor and publisher of The Kansas City Star and a senior executive at Knight Ridder, as its next public editor.

headline: Views on the Oil Spill
text: Respondents are impatient with President Obama's response to the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Anadarko Hopes Blame Is Pinned on BP
text: Rival oilmen have every reason to cast BP as a rogue. But none more so than Anadarko, its silent partner in the leaking Macondo well in the Gulf of Mexico. If BP is proved to be grossly negligent, Anadarko is absolved of liability. If that doesn’t happen, it could face crippling costs.

headline: Notes From Wake of Blowout Outline Obstacles and Frustration
text: In the first frantic days after the blowout of the oil well in the Gulf of Mexico, crisis managers in Houston, concerned about the potential for an even greater catastrophe, weighed the risks of using more aggressive methods to try to control the well or leaving it alone, according to meeting notes and other documents.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,107 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Nebraska Town Votes to Banish Illegal Immigrants
text: CHICAGO — Residents of a small city in eastern Nebraska voted Monday to banish illegal immigrants from jobs and rental homes, defying an earlier decision by the city’s leaders and setting off what is all but certain to be a costly and closely watched legal challenge.

headline: Guilty Plea in Times Square Bomb Plot
text: The defendant in the Times Square bomb plot pleaded guilty on Monday for his role in the aborted attack, an abrupt and expedited end to a terror plot that extended into Pakistan and an Islamic militant group there.

headline: Fatality Crash Rate Falls for Older Drivers
text: The rate of older drivers involved in fatal road crashes plunged during the last decade, according to a report released on Tuesday by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.

headline: As Law Takes Effect, Obama Gives Insurers a Warning
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama, whose vilification of insurers helped push a landmark health care overhaul through Congress, plans to sternly warn industry executives at a White House meeting on Tuesday against imposing hefty rate increases in anticipation of tightening regulation under the new law, administration officials said Monday.

headline: France, Germany and U.K. Support Bank Tax
text: The three largest European countries on Tuesday solidified their commitment to direct bank taxes as part of the build-up to a summit meeting of the Group of 20 countries, where agreement on the matter is far from assured, Matthew Saltmarsh reports in The New York Times.

headline: Inquiry Is Sought Into Practices of For-Profit Colleges
text: Concerned about the disproportionate share of federal student aid flowing to for-profit colleges, several Democratic lawmakers on Monday asked the federal Government Accountability Office to investigate the for-profit institutions, in terms of both quality and finance.

headline: Day 62: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: BP Has Spent $2 Billion on Recovery

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted June 16 through June 20 with 1,259 adults throughout the United States, including 318 who live in 15 counties along the Gulf Coast in Alabama, Louisiana and Mississippi.

text: jollity •\ˈjä-lə-te\• noun

headline: One Big Thing We Don’t Know About Stocks

headline: U.S. Shares Pull Back in Late Trading
text: Stocks in the United States ended slightly lower on Monday, reversing a surge that came after the Chinese currency strengthened to its highest level in nearly two years.

headline: Carlos Monsiváis, Mexican Who Wrote of the Great and the Humble, Dies at 72
text: Carlos Monsiváis, the Mexican writer and cultural critic whose trenchant literary chronicles laid bare the foibles of political power brokers and gave everyday Mexican life a surreal majesty, died Saturday in Mexico City. He was 72.

headline: News Quiz | June 22, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Elon Musk, of PayPal and Tesla Fame, Is Broke
text: Update: Here’s a link to court filings from Elon Musk’s divorce proceeding. The documents were first reported on and uploaded to the Internet by VentureBeat last month before “going viral” by email around the West Coast.  VentureBeat, a content partner of The New York Times, regularly follows Mr. Musk’s latest moves here.

headline: Burnett Struggles Again, Digging Too Deep a Hole
text: PHOENIX — As A. J. Burnett trudged toward the dugout after the second inning Monday night, the speakers at Chase Field blasted what the Yankees might have been thinking. The timing was coincidental, but “Who Are You” by the Who seemed an appropriate selection. Burnett’s June swoon reached its nadir in the Yankees’ 10-4 loss to the lowly Arizona Diamondbacks, who slugged three two-out homers off him in a five-run first inning and chased him after the fourth.

headline: Orszag Leaving as Budget Director
text: From Jackie Calmes at The Caucus blog:

headline: Battles in California Over Mortgages
text: As the housing market continues to sputter, the real estate industry is increasingly split on the responsibilities of overextended and foreclosed homeowners. On one side are the bankers, who say borrowers should be liable for what they owe. On the other side are real estate agents, who say those who lost their houses should not be so burdened by debt that they cannot move on, David Streitfeld reports in The New York Times.

headline: China Pegs Renminbi’s Value Higher
text: China’s central bank on Tuesday set a key daily rate for the renminbi at its highest level in five years, in a closely watched move that echoed a 0.42 percent rise in the Chinese currency on Monday and suggested possible further increases, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

headline: Despite U.S. Plea, European Bank Pushes Austerity
text: European countries need to keep a sharper eye on one another’s finances, and sanctions against fiscal rule-breakers should kick in automatically, the European Central Bank president, Jean-Claude Trichet, said on Monday, Jack Ewing reports in The New York Times.

headline: Barroso Defends Europe’s Move Toward Austerity
text: The European Union‘s top official rejected concerns that Europe was moving too quickly toward economic austerity, saying it was vital to cut debt to restore market and voter confidence as the key to future growth, Steven Erlanger and Stephen Castle report in The New York Times.

headline: CNH Global to Sell $1 Billion in Bonds
text: Dutch equipment maker CNH Global said Monday it plans to offer $1 billion in seven-year bonds to pay back older debt, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Panzootic

headline: Aegon Eyes Sale of Transamerica Re
text: Aegon, the Dutch insurer, said Tuesday that it was restructuring its business in Britain and seeking to sell its U.S. reinsurance unit Transamerica Re as it seeks to repay the remaining 2 billion euros it owes on the bailout it received in 2008.

headline: Andreessen Horowitz Grows Up
text: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

headline: Can You Beat a Computer at ‘Jeopardy!’?
text: I.B.M. has built a computer that can beat human contestants at the game “Jeopardy!,” which involves providing answers to trivia questions that are often worded in clever ways. What does this development suggest about the future of artificial intelligence?

headline: Heinz Has a Taste for Chinese Soy Sauce
text: H.J. Heinz said Monday that it agreed to buy Foodstar, a private equity-backed Chinese food company that makes soy sauces and fermented bean curd, for $165 million, The Associated Press reported.

headline: I.P.O. Coattails After CBOE? Not in Style for 2010
text: A smattering of companies will try to make initial public offerings this week following the successful debut of CBOE Holdings, though few are expected to do as well in what has become a decidedly dicey year for the market, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Intel and F.T.C. Agree to Talk
text: From Ashlee Vance at Bits:

headline: Busy Canada Builders Said to Scout for Acquisitions
text: Canadian construction companies, strengthened by government stimulus projects and the end of the economic downturn, are casting about for acquisitions as the work they bid on gets bigger and more complex, Reuters reported.

headline: Hedge Funds Said to Back Spyglass to Run MGM
text: Spyglass Entertainment has emerged as the leading contender to run Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, after impressing a group of hedge funds holding large amounts of the movie studio’s debt, Reuters said, referencing a report by The Wall Street Journal, which cited people familiar with the matter.

headline: BNP Said to Be in Talks With Apax on Cetelem
text: BNP Paribas is in talks with Apax Partners over the planned sale of its Belgian consumer-credit unit Cetelem Belgique, Bloomberg News said, citing a story in the French daily La Tribune.

headline: 5 Killed in Attack on Turkish Military
text: ISTANBUL  In the latest of a series of attacks on the Turkish military, a remote-controlled bomb killed 5 people and wounded 15 on a busy highway in Istanbul early Tuesday, the governor’s office announced.

headline: Telesp Said to Win Loan Commitments to Buy Vivo

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Austerity — it’s moving to Europe, so you might as well get used to it. But aside from cuts and more cuts, what does it mean exactly? With an odd poetic justice, it’s a word with Greek roots, meaning harsh and bitter, not far from the taste people will have in their mouths when the new budgets start kicking in. In the last century, it made the rounds with the wartime policies of the 40s, but this new rationing doesn’t have a western front to justify it — just yesterday’s glut.

headline: An Improptu Concert in Van Cortlandt Park
text: The rumble of the southbound train faded along Jerome Avenue, replaced gradually by the tinkling of piano keys being pounded into joyful dissonance. In the cool shade by the entrance to Sachkerah Woods Playground, Em’press Martin — almost 2 — was entranced by the high notes, while a changing cast of passers-by joined her in impromptu duets, trios and more.

headline: Crystal Bowersox Lets America Know What’s Up
text: Does it seem like there are way more things in the world to be concerned about than usual? A blown oil well that continues to gush crude into the Gulf of Mexico; a populace that believes, by a 2-to-1 margin, that the nation is on the wrong track; a World Cup tournament filled with disobedient players, questionable referees, and endless vuvuzelas. Though it is tempting to point to a certain dark day in May as the Moment It All Went Wrong, a second-place finish hasn’t dampened the exuberance of the “American Idol” finalist (and woulda-coulda-shoulda-been winner) Crystal Bowersox.

headline: Greenpeace Disrupts BP Executive’s Speech to Oil Industry Conference
text: On Tuesday in London, protesters from Greenpeace briefly interrupted an address to the World National Oil Companies Congress by a BP executive. As my colleague Liz Robbins reported, Tony Hayward, BP’s chief executive, was originally scheduled to deliver the speech, a keynote address to the congress, but was replaced by another executive from the oil company, Steve Westwell, on Monday.

headline: Sophie Hicks | Chloé’s Architect
text: “If I were to put a dress on, I wouldn’t look like a woman,” says Sophie Hicks. “I’d look like a man in drag.” The sternly chic British architect began wearing mannish suits as a fashion editor at glossies like Tatler and British Vogue. Then, in the late 1980s, she quit her editorial job and went to architecture school. Sure, high fashion frustrated her. (Madonna, at the very last moment, once bailed on a big photo shoot that Hicks had dreamed up with Azzedine Alaïa.) But Hicks’s concerns about the industry went deeper. “I was only 26, and I started seeing fashion go in circles,” she says, noting that the legends she worked alongside — like Grace Coddington — “must have seen the same things go around 12 dozen times.” Hicks’s biography has fabulous footnotes: She appeared in a Fellini film (“Intervista,” in 1986), designed a Picasso exhibit for the Royal Academy of Arts, and made a perfume bottle for Paul Smith. Her most famous buildings are, perhaps predictably, fashion boutiques. She has designed shops for Yohji Yamamoto in Paris, Paul Smith in London and 100 or so Chloé stores, including flagships in Tokyo, New York and Hong Kong. Today, she’s at work on a small home in South Kensington. For that building, she’s invented a “geometric building block” with the British brick maker Ibstock. “It’s a bit like mesh,” she says of the partially translucent brick. “So you’ll get little glimpses of what’s going on outside.”

headline: Didn’t Like That Grade in Torts? It Just Went Up

Ms. Cannon, who is based in Austin, Tex., has become something of an expert on the topic since her Web site debuted in September, 2008.

headline: Players Union Releases 2010 M.L.S. Salaries
text: Under cover of the World Cup and amid Major League Soccer’s first break for it, the union that represents the North American league’s players has released its list of salaries for the 406 players under contract in 2010. And while the world’s most highly compensated soccer players scurry across the fields of South Africa, the more modestly paid M.L.S. players, where the average pay package is $138,169, down 6.6 percent from last season’s $147,945, are preparing to return to action this weekend.

headline: Dealing With Momentum in Final Group Games
text: In the last games of the World Cup group phase, results are everything. Players will be willing to give all they have to secure a win. Much attention gets paid to the offense in those situations, but what about defending a lead? Certain teams, like Italy, are known to absorb pressure by defending compactly just outside the 18-yard box. Many teams in these last few group games will resort to this tactic. Sometimes it works, but quite often it does not. There are other options.

headline: Tips for Using Your Cellphone Abroad
text: There are plenty of cheap ways to make calls when abroad, including a combination of local SIM cards and Skype. But setting up these methods can be complicated and time consuming, and it’s often more convenient just to use your cellphone. It’s no wonder, then, that many people get hit with high roaming charges when they travel out of the country.

headline: Consumer Advocates Critical of Annuity Proposal
text: The deceptive marketing tactics used to sell equity-indexed annuities have been well documented. In case you haven’t heard of these annuities, they’re a complex financial product that promises a guaranteed return. Salesmen often make house calls, and they’ve been known to lure senior citizens to their so-called “educational” seminars by promising them a free meal. In many cases, elderly investors were sold products that were simply wrong for their circumstances, while the agent walked away with a hefty commission.

headline: Letter: Humanity and History
text: To the Editor: I had to tell you how moved I was by Steve Dougherty’s article “In Germany, War and Reunion,” (May 30) about the encounter between his father, Lt. Dick Dougherty, and Maj. Hannibal von Lüttichau in Tegernsee, Germany, near the end of World War II. I read and reread the article, then e-mailed it to everyone I knew who would enjoy it. I visited this idyllic German village in 1984 and had no idea how close it had come to destruction. This wonderful story portrayed humanity and history at their finest moments.

headline: Senate Democrats Call for House Support on Disclose Bill
text: Senior Democratic Senate leaders wrote a letter to their colleagues in the House on Tuesday urging support for legislation aimed at curtailing the power of special interest groups by requiring them to disclose more information about their role in purchasing campaign advertisements. And the senators promised to work aggressively to pass the bill in their own chamber.

headline: Letter: Let Passengers Speak
text: To the Editor: Regarding the June 13 Practical Traveler (“Air Travel’s Costly Future”): Airline industry insiders believe that the path to restoring their sector’s viability will be charted by their new Aviation Advisory Committee. Security issues and service cutbacks at all levels have taken all the joy out of flying. Inviting customers (the industry may have forgotten that’s what passengers are) to be better represented on the committee would be a more effective first step to earning the public’s interest to start flying again. George R. Horhota

headline: Did ‘Jaws’ and ‘Star Wars’ Ruin Hollywood?
text: On the 35th anniversary of the great white blockbuster, John Podhoretz has an essay blaming the unprecedented box-office success of “Jaws” for the rise of the lousy, disposable summer tent-pole movie. In his review of “Toy Story 3,” David Edelstein takes a different tack, arguing that if you want to trace Hollywood’s decline into dreck like “The A-Team” and the umpteen “Shrek” sequels, “the beginning of the end was ‘Star Wars,‘ synthetic then as now, clever but never exhilarating, infinitely merchandisable.”

headline: After Loss, Blake Questions Tennis Future

headline: Obama Says Health Law Shouldn’t Be Excuse to Raise Rates
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama, whose vilification of insurers helped push a landmark health care overhaul through Congress, warned industry executives at the White House on Tuesday not to use the bill “as an opportunity to enact unjustifiable rate increases that don’t boost care and inflate their bottom line.”

headline: In Kosher Ice Cream, a Taste of Traditional Baking
text: Move over Soy Vay sauces. Chozen is a new kosher ice cream with mix-ins that would make Tevye happy. Rugelach, coconut-almond macaroon and chocolate matzo are the flavors, all swirled in a fine vanilla ice cream base with no gums or stabilizers. It started as a kitchen table concoction by Ronne Fisher and her daughters, Meredith Fisher and Isabelle Krishana, as they shared memories of traditional Jewish baked goods and ate homemade rugelach straight from the freezer. Nonetheless, one bite of the coconut-almond macaroon had me happily recalling a Good Humor toasted almond ice cream pop. Chocolate babka and honey-apple are future flavors. How about hamantaschen for Purim?

headline: A Newsletter Is Revived, This Time as an E-Zine
text: David Rosengarten has started publishing his highly detailed, thoroughly researched food newsletter again after a two-year hiatus. The Rosengarten Report is now a monthly, available only online as an e-zine.

headline: Uruguay Edges Mexico, but Both Teams Advance
text: RUSTENBURG, South Africa  Uruguay and Mexico did not have to try very hard. A tie in their final Group A match Tuesday would have sent both teams to the second round of the World Cup. Neither the overmatched host team, South Africa, nor hapless France, meeting at the same time in Bloemfontein, posed a viable threat in their group.

headline: Russian Envoys Back European Criticism of Kremlin’s Caucasus Policy
text: MOSCOW  To the surprise of human rights activists, Russian delegates to the Council of Europe’s Parliamentary Assembly on Tuesday approved a sharply critical draft resolution on Russia’s policy in the North Caucasus, which says “human rights violations and the climate of complete impunity were bound to foster the rise of extremist movements.”

headline: Kagan Backed by Former Solicitors General
text: Former solicitors general from both sides of the political spectrum are backing the nomination of Elena Kagan to the Supreme Court.

headline: Made in America: New Bacons Go to Market
text: La Quercia of Norwalk, Iowa, has made its name curing pork from heritage breeds for Italian-style meats like prosciutto. This spring, Herb Eckhouse, an owner, started making his first American-style dry-cured, applewood smoked bacon. It’s quite smoky and very rich, thanks to a high proportion of fat to streaks of lean. Slices should be cooked over moderate heat because the fat has a fairly low smoke point.

headline: Opposites Attract
text: Recently, I saw a charming little movie about two characters, opposites in temperament and outlook, hostile at the start, who gradually learned not only to find delight in each other, but also to appreciate how much they had in common. This film is whimsical, inventive, crammed with visual virtuosity and six minutes long. It’s called “Day and Night,” and it can be seen when you purchase a ticket for “Toy Story 3.”

headline: Astor Bake Shop Opens in Queens
text: After 22 years as a pastry chef at Regine’s, TriBaKery and more recently at Blue Fin, George McKirdy finally decided to go out on his own.

headline: Beijing Prepares to Be Host

headline: Sleep-Away Separation Pains
text: It’s the time of year for name tags on shorts and T-shirts, stamps on preaddressed postcards and lots of bug spray. It’s also time to trawl a password-protected Web site, looking for glimpses of your children and their bunk mates in photographs, reading their expressions for clues because the no-cellphone rule means you can’t talk to them every day.

headline: The Sign That Marked Wall Street: Sold for $116,500
