headline: Belarus Escalates Dispute With Russians Over Gas
text: MOSCOW  The president of Belarus ordered a halt to the transit of Russian natural gas to Europe on Tuesday, escalating an energy conflict with Moscow over unpaid debts that he said was turning into a “gas war.”

headline: Words Woven, for the Price of a Donation
text: Robert Samuel Snyderman, a wild-haired 23-year-old who lives in Bedford-Stuyvesant, is one of the more visible of the seemingly ever-growing ranks of the city’s street-poets-for-hire. Lately, he’s been setting up shop outside the Brooklyn Flea in Fort Greene, accepting whatever price customers feel compelled to put on a work of art and pounding it out on his light blue typewriter. Read more on The Local, the Times’s blog about Fort Greene and Clinton Hill, Brooklyn.»

headline: A Surging Kanepi Eliminates Stosur
text: WIMBLEDON, England — The Estonian Kaia Kanepi played superb tennis through the clay court season, and she has continued her good form on grass. She is the kind of player seeds hope not to play in the early rounds. Samantha Stosur drew that unlucky assignment, and lost, 6-4, 6-4, in a match that could have tipped Stosur’s way but for some huge serving and steady nerves from Kanepi.

headline: On Our Radar: Victory for Biotech Industry
text: A Supreme Court victory for Monsanto and the biotechnology industry; justices vote 7 to 1 to overturn an appellate court decision banning the planting of herbicide-resistant alfalfa.

headline: Milan Fashion Week | Backstage at Burberry
text: The label’s designer, Christopher Bailey, discusses the collection backstage.Related: Now Screening | Burberry

headline: Minnows Batter Reputations of Game’s Traditional Powers
text: This World Cup is not going according to plan. That much is obvious.  If we look at the tournament results so far, we quickly become aghast at the vast number of bizarre results. Italy drawing with New Zealand? England drawing with Algeria?  Spain losing to Switzerland? Uppity countries with meager FIFA rankings are queuing up to outthink and outplay their more distinguished opponents; and we can’t remember the last time a World Cup saw so many anomalies.

headline: Soderling Routs Ginepri to Reach Second Round
text: 3:38 p.m. | Updated WIMBLEDON, England –= Robby Ginepri of Atlanta had a word for his first-round loss to the sixth-seeded Robin Soderling of Sweden.

headline: New Law Expands Rights of Some Loft Residents
text: Gov. David A. Paterson on Monday night signed a hotly debated bill into law that expands protections for dwellers of lofts in industrial buildings throughout New York City.The sponsor, Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez, who said he had been working on the legislation for two decades, said the law would protect tenants who had been living in loft spaces for at least a year in 2008 and 2009. These tenants will have new protections, like the right to rent stabilization.

headline: Saab’s Future Can Be Found in Saab’s Past, Says Its New Designer
text: 4:58 p.m. | Updated

headline: How Did Rolling Stone Get the McChrystal Story? (A Volcano Helped)
text: Of all the questions surrounding the Rolling Stone article that detailed Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal’s surprisingly blunt criticisms of the Obama administration’s handling of the war in Afghanistan, few are as puzzling as this: Why would a top military commander allow a journalist so much unfettered access to his inner circle?

headline: Prospect Park, 7:30 A.M.
text: Sticky, a k a Target, the Canada goose of Prospect Park lake who spent days or possibly weeks walking around with an arrow through its neck, showed off its new arrow-free look Tuesday morning.

headline: Manioc Showdown: Farofa v. Farinha
text: Manioc, the root vegetable more commonly known to Americans these days by the Spanish word yuca, makes it to the Brazilian table in infinite ways, from tapioca to chopped-and-fried mandioca frita to a dense but spongy cake. But it is most common in floury form, served as ever-present side dishes called farinha and farofa.

headline: Quote Unquote | Roadkill By Any Other Name…
text: –Ke$ha explains her ridiculous wardrobe to Paper Magazine. Next time, please leave the feathered headdress where you found it. Thanks.

headline: Bloomberg Talks About Donation to Blagojevich
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Tuesday that the $25,000 campaign donation he made to Rod R. Blagojevich in 2006 was motivated by nothing more than their agreement on important issues.

headline: Should the ‘Runaway General’ Be Fired?
text: Updated, June 23, 2:10 p.m. | President Obama has dismissed General McChrystal as commander of American forces in Afghanistan, and chosen Gen. David H. Petraeus, the architect of the 2007 surge in Iraq, to be his replacement.

headline: Drilling Ban Blocked; U.S. Will Issue New Order
text: WASHINGTON  A federal judge in New Orleans on Tuesday blocked a six-month moratorium on deep-water drilling projects that the Obama administration imposed after the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. The White House swiftly vowed to appeal the ruling.

headline: Agency Works to Free Political Prisoners
text: The advertising agency JWT has teamed up with Human Rights Watch for an unusual display in Grand Central Terminal on Tuesday that seeks to generate support for freeing political prisoners in Myanmar (formerly Burma).

headline: Most Americans Support Paid Sick Leave, Poll Finds
text: A bill in Congress that would require employers to offer workers seven paid sick days a year has fostered a classic debate between liberals who want government to protect workers, and conservatives who say the last thing business needs is another government-imposed mandate.

headline: Algerian Federation Boss Gets Angry at His Players
text: Wednesday’s United States-Algeria match for survival in Pretoria is our main concern today — but first, in honor of South Africa’s victory over France, let’s take a moment to enjoy a musical interlude. Here’s the South African pop group Four Jacks and a Jill playing their 1968 hit, “Master Jack,” and I hope you watch on full screen to see the lions and springbok:

headline: Tsukin-ist
text: A portmanteau term describing bicycle commuters in Japan. (Tsukin [commuter] + cyclist)

headline: A Look at Budget Boutique Swag
text: In this Sunday’s travel section, I wrote about “budget boutiques,” an emerging category of New York City hotels that offers hipper design and snappier service than your average tourist trap — all for the cheap-for-Manhattan price of about $250 a night. In May, I slept in six of them. Like any self-respecting guest, I swiped everything in my room that wouldn’t result in a charge, either on my hotel bill or in court. That meant all those little bottles: shampoo, conditioner, body lotion, body balm, body milk, and so on.

headline: Article Prompts Speculation About McChrystal’s Future
text: Updated | 4:47 p.m. Ahead of a meeting at the White House on Wednesday between Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal and President Obama, speculation is rife in Washington and online about whether the general will remain America’s top commander in Afghanistan. As my colleague Dexter Filkins reports, Mr. Obama summoned the general to Washington “after a magazine article portrayed the general and his staff as openly contemptuous of some senior members of the Obama administration.”

headline: Now Screening | Dsquared2
text: The Spring/Summer 2011 collection from Dsquared2 at Milan Fashion Week.

headline: Excerpt: 'Jimmy Kimmel Live'
text: A power outage forced the host to shoot his show with his laptop. The episode will air on Tuesday night.

headline: Annual Broadway Bares Fund-Raiser Surpasses $1 Million
text: The annual fund-raiser Broadway Bares, which features dancers and actors in bawdily choreographed stripteases, has broken the $1 million mark for the first time in its 20-year history of raising money for the organization Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS, the show’s producer, Jerry Mitchell, announced on Tuesday.

headline: Trying Out Wi-Fi in the Sky
text: I WAS about halfway through a cross-country flight from San Francisco to New York when I made a Skype call to my wife, Karen.

headline: The Usefulness of Anger: A Response
text: If I were angry, and someone came along and told me that I was not angry for the reason I thought I was, but for a completely different one, I would be furious. Although it was neither the intention nor argument of my June 13 essay for The Stone, “The Very Angry Tea Party,” to deny that Tea Party supporters had political reasons for their anger, it is probably not surprising that it was read by them as discounting those reasons altogether and putting an underlying set of commitments in their place.

headline: Poll: Strong Support for Paid Sick Leave
text: A new poll by the National Opinion Research Center at the University of Chicago shows strong public support for legislation, currently in Congress, that would require employers to offer workers seven paid sick days a year. The bill has fostered a classic debate between liberals who want government to protect workers, and conservatives who say the last thing business needs is another government-imposed mandate. Read more on Economix.

headline: Rocking Awake With the Octiv Mini Speaker
text: Most iPhone owners are familiar with the alarm clock feature, which can wake you with a number of sound effects like a marimba or barking dog. But what if you would like to be nudged to consciousness by the dulcet sound of, say, Green Day?

headline: Rebound of the Rich: Wealth Rises to $39 Trillion
text: Great Recession? What recession? The world’s millionaires and billionaires — now totaling 10 million — saw their overall wealth jump 18.9 percent last year, to $39 trillion.

headline: Parents in N.J. to Be Billed for Daughter’s City Schooling
text: It may not be surprising that the lure of fame and the promise of top-notch performance instruction is enough to tempt some parents to lie to get their children into the most coveted New York City schools. After all, students who enroll at the Fiorello H. La Guardia School of Music & Art and the Performing Arts -– or simply La Guardia, as the school is more commonly known –- have a chance to really make it.

headline: Q. and A.: Woody Biomass, Pros and Cons
text: As I wrote in an article over the weekend, electricity derived from burning organic matter, particularly wood, has long enjoyed a reputation as a green alternative to coal-fired power — and why not? Trees and plants, renewable by definition, release planet-warming gases into the atmosphere when they burn, and absorb it again when they are growing.

headline: Speculation About McChrystal’s Future Rampant
text: Updated | 4:59 p.m. Ahead of a meeting at the White House on Wednesday between Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal and President Obama, speculation is rife in Washington and online on whether the general will remain America’s top commander in Afghanistan. As my colleague Dexter Filkins reports, Mr. Obama summoned the general to Washington “after a magazine article portrayed the general and his staff as openly contemptuous of some senior members of the Obama administration.”

headline: Ask an Expert: Overcoming Insomnia
text: Falling asleep, or staying asleep, is a challenge for those with chronic insomnia. In addition to the anguish and fatigue that comes with lack of sleep, studies link sleep deprivation to a variety of health ills, from heart attacks to obesity.

headline: France, Germany and U.K. Support Bank Tax
text: PARIS — The three largest European countries on Tuesday solidified their commitment to direct bank taxes as part of the build-up to a summit meeting of the Group of 20 countries, where agreement on the matter is far from assured.

headline: As Public Transit Shrinks, an Option Is Added
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced a yearlong pilot program Tuesday that will allow commuter vans to pick up passengers in parts of Brooklyn and Queens with limited access to public transportation or where bus service cuts will take effect next week.

headline: Watch This Space | MADE in Berlin
text: The conversion of unused office space into a gallery is nothing new in Berlin’s Mitte district. But MADE, a new art center opened by three of the city’s creative ringleaders (and sleekly designed by the architect Alexis Dornier), is aiming to do something out of the ordinary. A collaboration between Philip Gaedicke, Nico Zeh, Tadi Rock and Luise Biesalski, MADE provides free studio space to emerging artists, pays for their materials and then puts on a show of new work — and it will even throw in some publicity. The only catch is that they have to try something new. In other words, a photographer can’t just take pictures and a painter can’t just paint.

headline: World Cup Live: Greece vs. Argentina
text: Late goals from Martin Dimichelis and Martin Palermo preserved Argentina’s perfect 3-0-0 record in Group B with a comfortable 2-0 win over Greece in Polokwane Tuesday night. Argentina won Group B with the maximum nine points and will face Mexico in the round of 16 on Sunday.

headline: World Cup Live: Nigeria vs. South Korea
text: In a stirring match worthy of dredging tears from both sides by its conclusion, South Korea found its dream while Nigeria exited the World Cup with some fresh, near-miss nightmares.

headline: No Power? No Problem: ‘Jimmy Kimmel Live’ Relies on a Webcam
text: Most television hosts will do whatever it takes to keep their programs on the air, but when a power failure struck Jimmy Kimmel‘s show on Monday evening, he really went the extra mile: he grabbed a laptop computer and shot the entire episode on a Webcam, becoming director, cameraman and lighting designer for the night.

headline: Marketers Have ‘Goals’ at World Cup, Too
text: The 2010 World Cup is the first to be played under the auspices, or maybe under the influence, of the social media. So companies that analyze data from Facebook, Twitter and other social media outlets are eagerly providing data on how advertisers — official and otherwise — are faring among soccer (or football) fans.

headline: Canvas Footwear, in 2 Senses
text: ON the very long list of nondesigners who have eagerly crashed the gates of fashion (think of the models, actors, athletes, rappers, pop stars and reality show castoffs who have their own clothing lines), perhaps the most strikingly underrepresented profession to date is that of the artist.

headline: Law Schools Visit Lake Wobegon
text: 5:20 p.m. | Updated

headline: Three Million iPads Sold but Frustration for Some Customers
text: Apple announced Tuesday that it had sold its three millionth iPad, just 80 days after it first went on sale.

headline: Annisa
text: TEN years ago this summer, Anita Lo opened Annisa on Barrow Street in Greenwich Village. The restaurant was quietly ambitious. It was the sort of place serious couples went to for serious dinner dates, elegant without being fussy, adult. The décor was beige and said little. The point was on the plate: food that was vaguely Asian and informed by classical French technique. This was still a novel conceit, then.

headline: Reviewing Annisa, in Greenwich Village
text: This week’s restaurant review is of Annisa, which Anita Lo and Jennifer Scism opened on Barrow Street a decade ago this summer. It demands our attention today not just for its age, but for its rebirth — an electrical fire in the kitchen during the summer of 2009 severely damaged the restaurant, and it reopened in April.

headline: Incredible, Edible
text: “It’s about friends, but not just friends in your own circle,” said a beaming Alice Waters as she scanned the scene that was quickly thickening around her. The occasion was a dinner for Edible Schoolyard New York, the latest branch of Waters’s urban garden initiative now breaking ground — 18,000 square feet of asphalt to be exact — at P.S. 216 in Brooklyn. A slab of wood festooned with local salumi wended its way through the crowd, followed by platters of Island Creek oysters and Maxwell’s Farm fava bean toast. “Suddenly you are friends with a lot of people,” Waters said.

headline: Geithner and Warren Duel Over Banks’ Health
text: When it comes to the health of the banking system, Timothy F. Geithner and Elizabeth Warren don’t see eye to eye.

headline: For New Cruise Movie, Forecasts Are Mixed
text: For weeks, the movie capital has smelled blood in the waters surrounding “Knight and Day,” the $100 million-plus action comedy starring Tom Cruise and Cameron Diaz that arrives in theaters on Wednesday. Services that track audience interest have shown moviegoer apathy about the picture.

headline: Frick Gets Go Ahead For New Gallery
text: The Landmarks Preservation Commission on Tuesday unanimously approved the Frick Collection’s plan to create a new gallery for sculpture and decorative objects by enclosing the portico on the north side of its Fifth Avenue garden in glass.

headline: Arctic Ice Forecasters Split on Summer Retreat
text: Sept. 1, 4:39 p.m. | Updated The leading teams of Arctic researchers tracking sea-ice trends have issued their updated forecasts for this year’s peak ice retreat. They largely do not foresee a decline matching last year’s, or the jarring 2007 retreat.

headline: France, Germany and Britain Support Bank Tax
text: The three largest European countries on Tuesday solidified their commitment to direct bank taxes as part of the buildup to a summit meeting of the Group of 20 countries, where agreement on the matter is far from assured,  Matthew Saltmarsh of The New York Times reports from Paris.

headline: Mating Bears and a Wolverine Sighting
text: Monday, June 21

headline: Tuna’s End
text: In the international waters south of Malta, the Greenpeace vessels Rainbow Warrior and Arctic Sunrise deployed eight inflatable Zodiacs and skiffs into the azure surface of the Mediterranean. Protesters aboard donned helmets and took up DayGlo flags and plywood shields. With the organization’s observation helicopter hovering above, the pilots of the tiny boats hit their throttles, hurtling the fleet forward to stop what they viewed as an egregious environmental crime. It was a high-octane updating of a familiar tableau, one that anyone who has followed Greenpeace’s Save the Whales adventures of the last 35 years would have recognized. But in the waters off Malta there was not a whale to be seen.

headline: House to Vote on Subpoena Power for Spill Investigators
text: The House will take up legislation Wednesday that would grant subpoena power to the panel investigating the Gulf Coast oil spill disaster.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Openings

headline: Dining Calendar
text: The Ruler of Late Night

headline: Loss Completes France’s Dishonor
text: JOHANNESBURG — France exited in disgrace from the World Cup on Tuesday with no victories and little sympathy for a team that infamously used an intentional handball to get into the tournament and self-destructed on the way out.

headline: Artifacts | Art Frazzle
text: When the 41st Art Basel closed last Sunday, 62,500 people had passed through its doors in a week. That was a record number. They were artists, private collectors, consultants, artists, museum trustees and curators, historians and critics, and they looked at art in 300 galleries from 36 countries. These are the only solid statistics. No one tracks how much money changes hands at these assemblies of art and fraternity, but a conservative guess would be a few hundred million dollars. Considering how many people plunk down $35,000 for a couture handbag, taking home a more unique $2 million Paul McCarthy or a $15 million Picasso doesn’t seem like such a stretch in Basel.

headline: Two’s a Crowd With World Cup and Wimbledon
text: English sports fans, especially those at Wimbledon, face a tough choice on Wednesday afternoon. The tennis tickets they hold are difficult to obtain, as if tinged with gold, and yet, at 3 p.m. England will also play for its World Cup survival.

headline: Dark Ecosystems Nurtured by Oil
text: How much oil flows into the sea aside from the BP spill? That question arose as I researched a story about a fascinating group of sea creatures that live on the bottom of the Gulf of Mexico. Over the eons, the animals have evolved to thrive on oil and gas seeping up from the seabed.

headline: Sept. Sale Seen for Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper
text: The foreclosure sale of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, the sprawling sister apartment building complexes on the East Side, is expected to take place in September, according to executives who have been briefed on the future of the properties.

headline: Performance of  Work of Iannis Xenakis in Make Music Festival
text: The fourth annual Make Music Festival in Central Park offered a performance of “Persephassa,”  by the Greek composer Iannis Xenakis.

headline: Former SocGen Chairman Has Sharp Words for Trader
text: PARIS — Daniel Bouton, the former chairman and chief executive of Société Générale, stood Tuesday for the first time alongside Jérôme Kerviel, the former trader whom Mr. Bouton once labeled a “terrorist” for generating nearly €5 billion in losses for the French bank in 2008.

headline: Israeli Official Assails Plans for Demolition of Arab Homes
text: TEL AVIV  A top Israeli official scolded local officials on Tuesday for giving preliminary approval to a plan calling for the demolition of 22 Palestinian homes, in an echo of past stumbles over Jewish development in East Jerusalem.

headline: Good Marks for Press Coverage of Oil Spill
text: Americans aren’t known for their long attention spans, but so far they haven’t grown tired of the media’s sweeping coverage of the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Girl, 12, Drowns on Class Trip
text: Updated Wednesday, June 23 | A complete version of this story appeared in Wednesday’s editions of The New York Times and can be read here.A 12-year-old girl from a Harlem public school drowned Tuesday during a class trip to an unpatrolled beach in Long Beach, Long Island, officials said. The girl, Nicole Suriel, was one of two dozen students on the sixth-grade class trip from the Columbia Secondary School for Math, Science and Engineering.

headline: Going to Work When You’re Sick
text: A new poll shows that most Americans support proposed legislation requiring companies to offer at least seven days of paid sick leave, reports the Economix blog.

headline: A K.K.R. Executive Goes Back to School
text: Kenneth W. Freeman has had a long career in corporate America, topped off with an executive position at Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the big private equity firm.

headline: Resort Report | Still Gucci, Even on Holiday
text: The Gucci girl never strays far from her sexy, urban roots – even when she is on holiday. Frida Giannini’s Resort collection included plenty of leather motorcycle jackets, military references and animal prints, but the fabrics were mostly comfortable and functional: washed silk, cotton and linen. The best look was a brown jacket with a swing back and a black horizontal stripe paired with an easy burnt red canvas skirt and, as the dress code in the Gucci world demands, a pair of towering heels.

headline: Celebrating With a Democratic Spirit
text: If Make Music New York, the daylong musical celebration of the summer solstice, were to have a signature piece, Terry Riley’s “In C” would be an ideal candidate. It has a history with this festival: Composers Collaborative assembled 120 musicians for a performance of “In C” at the first Make Music New York event, in 2007. Last year Face the Music, a student ensemble from the Lucy Moses School, gave an involving performance. And at this year’s installment, on Monday, Composers Collaborative’s Mighty CCi House Band performed the work again, this time with about 50 musicians, outside the Cornelia Street Café, where the organization presents a new-music series.

headline: A Percussion Obsessive Adds Even More Drums
text: When Kid Millions plays the drums, it’s all about stamina.

headline: Is the Oil Dispersant Helping? Official Says Yes
text: The rate at which BP’s well is spilling oil into the Gulf of Mexico could be calculated easily if the well were capped and the flow then controlled, a senior official of the Environmental Protection Agency says. But if the well is killed by intercepting it near the bottom with a relief well, “you’ll never be able to completely do it,’’ the official adds.

headline: Now Screening | Dsquared2
text: The Spring/Summer 2011 collection from Dsquared2 at Milan Fashion Week.

headline: Lenders Ease Up on Lions Gate as Icahn Looms
text: Lions Gate Entertainment said Tuesday that its lenders had agreed to amend the terms of a $340 million revolving credit line so that it would not default on its debt because the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn had amassed a big stake in the movie studio, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Triumph Over ‘Demons’ (and a Budget)
text: MILAN

headline: Rocked by Waves of Drumrolls
text: The ducks that frequent Central Park Lake are used to keeping clear of people in rented rowboats lurching about the water. But on Monday afternoon they looked rattled by the strange sights and stranger sounds coming from makeshift platforms floating in the middle of the west side of the lake.

headline: Next Philharmonic First: A Visit to Georgia
text: Lisa Batiashvili, the violin soloist, is one of the most famous classical musicians to have emerged from Georgia, so it was no surprise when that country’s president met with her before a rare concert appearance in Tbilisi, the capital, in October.

headline: An American Style Is Born
text: In a game where the tactics and rhythm can make you feel you are watching a ballet choreographed in the logic of a pinball game, the question of style is a tricky thing, a slippery fish of the mind. Still, we know in a knee jerk way that the Spanish have artistry and grace, the Germans have an organized, disciplined attack and the English have a stolid defensive predictability that puts one in the mind of lukewarm tea and rainy Tuesdays.

headline: Scorecard | Emporio Armani Wins!
text: At the moment of a debut marked by pomp and bitter circumstance, Scorecard pauses to applaud fashion’s continued ability to shock. Don’t call my name, Roberto — Sunday it was the Italian maestro Giorgio Armani himself whose parade of leather-clad models proved that in a world gone Gaga, bad romance never looked so transgressively chic.

headline: Kerouac and Updike Typewriters Ring Up Sales
text: Two typewriters associated with famous writers, but not with their most famous works, sold for just above their low estimates at Christie’s on Tuesday. Jack Kerouac’s last typewriter, a Hermes 3000 manual that he used from 1966 until his death in 1969, brought $22,500 at the auction, having been estimated at $20,000-$30,000. Meanwhile, a typewriter that belonged to John Updike from the late 1960s until 15 years before his death sold for $4,375, having been estimated at $4,000-$6,000. (Updike produced several major novels in this period, but Christie’s didn’t determine whether he actually typed them on this machine.) Updike’s typewriter was being sold by a member of his family; half the proceeds will go to the New York Public Library.

headline: New iPhone Arrives; Rivals, Beware
text: Apple’s new iPhone, its fourth in four years, reaches stores on Thursday. Ordinarily, this is where you’d expect to find a review of it. But honestly  what’s the point?

headline: Country Singer, With Entourage of Characters in Tow
text: PIERMONT, N.Y.  There wasn’t much room on stage during Elizabeth Cook’s Sunday afternoon set at the Turning Point here, what with the limited square footage and all the ghosts cramming the space, vying for attention. There was the frustrated housewife who “slid on my tightest pair of jeans/combed my hair like it was 1983,” in hopes of rekindling old passions. There was the no-goodnik boyfriend who “likes to talk about Elvis/but only in the Sun years.” And there were family members, demanding complicated love:

headline: Former Aide to Madoff Is Freed on $10 Million Bail
text: 6:38 p.m. | Updated The former finance chief for the convicted swindler Bernard L. Madoff was released on $10 million bail on Tuesday, months after he admitted his role in an enormous Ponzi scheme that cost thousands of investors billions of dollars and agreed to cooperate with prosecutors, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Panel Enlarges Landmark Zone and Cites 2 Bronx Sites
text: The city’s Landmarks Preservation Commission voted unanimously on Tuesday to extend the Greenwich Village Historic District for the second time in four years. The commission also granted landmark status to two Bronx sites – the Beaux-Arts-style Haffen Building, completed in 1902, and the Art Deco Noonan Plaza apartment complex, completed in 1931.

headline: Free-Jazz Manifestoes, Declared Nightly
text: Nate Wooley, sitting and aiming his trumpet toward a microphone about four feet in front of him, played free improvisation almost without affect. On Monday, at the Lower East Side bar Local 269, he was a third of the band Crackleknob: on his right, the guitarist Mary Halvorson, also seated, her feet resting on two pedals; on his left, the bassist Reuben Radding, standing.

headline: No Power? No Problem. Use Jimmy Kimmel’s Webcam
text: Most television hosts will do whatever it takes to keep their shows on the air, but when a power failure struck Jimmy Kimmel’s show on Monday evening, he really went the extra mile: he grabbed a laptop computer and shot the entire episode on a Webcam, becoming director, cameraman and lighting designer for the night. That episode of “Jimmy Kimmel Live,” which ABC was to show on Monday, was instead to be shown on Tuesday. And it still featured segments with Seth Rogen (who was on hand to introduce his new movie, “The Green Hornet”) and the comedian John Henson, as well as a performance by the country musician Dierks Bentley  only slightly more pixelated than home viewers are used to seeing. Mr. Kimmel, whose late-night talk show is produced at El Capitan Theater in Los Angeles, said his control room lost power just before taping was to start at 7 p.m. Pacific time. “I blame BP for this,” he said in a telephone interview. “I’m sure they’re responsible somehow.”

headline: Getting Fresh in the South Bronx
text: A new farm share program brings fresh produce to a low-income area in New York City by linking customers with upstate farms.

headline: What We’re Reading: Life as a Computer
text: Here is where the tech editors and writers of The New York Times paused on the Web on Tuesday:

headline: Jay-Z and Eminem Go Outside for Letterman
text: After boasting on “Empire State of Mind” that he could make it anywhere, Jay-Z was denied a first attempt to play a surprise show at the Ed Sullivan Theater, which is home to “Late Show With David Letterman.” But on a second go-round on Monday evening, Jay-Z was joined by Eminem for a three-song set performed on the theater’s roof. Last week word surfaced that Jay-Z was preparing a performance  meant to be unannounced  on the marquee of the theater. But with the city recovering from a free Drake concert last Tuesday that turned into a melee, Jay-Z’s marquee moment was halted. The crucial distinction for Monday’s team-up between Jay-Z and Eminem, which will be seen Friday on “Late Show,” was that it was staged on the roof of the theater, and not the marquee.

headline: Fiction About Anne Frank Is Faulted Over Sex
text: The author of a coming young-adult novel about Anne Frank said in an interview that her book, which imagines a romantic relationship between Anne and a teenage boy who hid with her from the Nazis, was not exploiting the Holocaust or oversexualizing that famous young diarist. The novel, called “Annexed,” and written by Sharon Dogar, is told from the point of view of Peter van Pels, a teenage son of the Dutch family called the van Daans in Anne’s diaries. A report published Sunday in The Times of London said the novel included scenes of Peter yearning for and having a physically intimate relationship with Anne. But the book’s depiction of Anne and Peter was disputed by Buddy Elias, Anne’s only living relative. “Anne was not the child she is in this book,” Mr. Elias told The Times. “I also do not think that their terrible destiny should be used to invent some fictitious story.” In an interview with The Guardian, Ms. Dogar said she had corresponded with Mr. Elias about the project and said the novel did not overemphasize Anne’s sexuality. “The sexual awakening of Anne plays more of a major part in her diary than this book,” she said. The United States publication of “Annexed” is planned for Oct. 4 by Houghton Mifflin Books for Children.

headline: First Day of Polaroid Sale Sets Ansel Adams Record
text: The first day of a forced sale of photographs owned by the Polaroid Company  a collection that includes work by dozens of well-known artists  brought in more than $7 million on Monday at Sotheby’s, and also broke a record for the highest price paid for an Ansel Adams picture. “Clearing Winter Storm, Yosemite National Park,” above, a large 1938 black-and-white landscape, went for $722,500, including a buyer’s commission to the auction house, topping the $609,000 that was paid for another Adams work in 2006. Polaroid, founded in 1937 by Edwin H. Land, fell victim to the digital revolution, going bust in 2001 and again in 2008. To pay off creditors, a bankruptcy court in Minnesota ordered the company to sell a portion of its collection, which includes 400 photographs by Adams alone, along with prints by Chuck Close, William Wegman, Robert Rauschenberg, David Hockney, Robert Frank, Robert Mapplethorpe, Andy Warhol and Lucas Samaras, whose photograph “Ultra-Large (Hands)” went for $194,500 on Monday, breaking a record for Mr. Samaras set in 1989. Sotheby’s said it expected the 1,200 pieces in the sale to fetch $7.5 million to $11.5 million. As of late afternoon on the sale’s second day, it had brought in $11.2 million so far.

headline: Cast Is Announced for ‘Angels in America’
text: The producers of this fall’s Off Broadway revival of Tony Kushner’s “Angels in America” announced the full cast on Tuesday, including the Tony Award winner Frank Wood (“Side Man”), below, as the closeted lawyer Roy Cohn; Bill Heck (star of “The Orphans’ Home Cycle”) as the gay Mormon lawyer Joe Pitt; and Zoe Kazan (“A Behanding in Spokane”), also below, as Joe’s Valium-addicted wife, Harper. Casting for this Signature Theater Company revival  the first major New York production of “Angels” since its Tony-winning Broadway run ended in December 1994  also includes Robin Bartlett (the 2007 Broadway revival of “Prelude to a Kiss”) as Joe’s mother, Hannah, and Robin Weigert (the 2001 revival of “Noises Off”) as the Angel. The actor Christian Borle (the musical “Legally Blonde”) will play Prior Walter, Billy Porter (“Smokey Joe’s Cafe”) will play Belize and Zachary Quinto (Spock in the 2009 “Star Trek” movie) will play Louis. With performances set to begin Sept. 14 at its 160-seat theater on West 42nd Street, Signature also announced on Tuesday that opening night has been scheduled for Oct. 28. The two parts of “Angels,” “Millennium Approaches” and “Perestroika,” will alternate in repertory from the start of performances to closing night, scheduled for Dec. 19. The revival, to be directed by Michael Greif (“Next to Normal,” “Rent”), is part of Signature’s yearlong season devoted to Mr. Kushner’s work.

headline: Deal Eases Way to Build Ground Zero Arts Center
text: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey on Tuesday approved an agreement under which the city will reimburse the authority up to $44 million for building underground foundations and infrastructure for a performing arts center at ground zero.

headline: A Year Later, Jackson Estate Is Prospering
text: In death, Michael Jackson has had the comeback he always wanted. His estate, managed by two longtime associates, the entertainment lawyer John Branca and the music executive John McClain, has nearly settled his troubled finances by making a string of big deals: a record-contract extension with Sony, a new Jackson-themed video game, two Cirque du Soleil shows and a plethora of merchandise.

headline: A Lackluster Art Auction in London
text: LONDON  Sales were spotty at Sotheby’s here on Tuesday night at the first of this week’s two major Impressionist and Modern art auctions.

headline: Military Blogs Ask: Should He Stay or Go?

headline: Now Screening | Gucci
text: The Spring/Summer 2011 collection from Gucci at Milan Fashion Week.

headline: Saving Time and Stress With Cooking Co-ops
text: DINNERTIME in our home, once a source of great pride and pleasure, became a rather lackluster affair after the birth of our son in 2008. Mostly it involved repurposing takeout leftovers or, on a more ambitious night, mixing chunks of frozen vegetable purées, meant for the baby, with macaroni and cheese. It was family dinner in the sense that it was marginally edible food, consumed together in the home, but prepared with the same care and passion I brought to refilling the cat’s water bowl.

headline: Tapping Feet Keep Going and Going at Hummingbird Speed
text: The tap choreographer-dancer Savion Glover is a puzzle. He is the most famous tap dancer to have emerged in decades. He has been hailed as the greatest tap dancer who has ever lived by people well qualified to pass such judgment. He is the man who has done most to make tap a youthful genre again. But it is hard to think of a celebrated dancer performing today who is more tedious, more devoid of stage sense, more undancerly and more lacking in musicianship.

headline: For a Healthier Bronx, a Farm of Their Own
text: IT’S hard to imagine two places in New York State more different than the South Bronx and Schoharie County.

headline: Krill Harvest Certification Upsets Conservationists
text: A decision by a nonprofit organization to certify a company’s Antarctic krill harvesting has drawn fierce criticism from conservationists and undercut the group’s image as a diligent steward of ocean fishing stocks.

headline: The Art of the Potentially Deadly Deal: Marketing Heroin on the Street
text: The empty glassine packets can be found in Manhattan, Brooklyn and beyond, scattered on streets and sidewalks with only obscure slogans or graphic images to suggest their former use. At one time they contained heroin and the markings stamped on the packets were meant to differentiate strains of varying purity or provenance.

headline: To Bleed or Not to Bleed? Plays Explore the Scary
text: JAMES COMTOIS, a 33-year-old playwright, has fond memories of his parents’ taking him to see a production of Edward Albee’s “Delicate Balance,” but if you want to know what really got him interested in writing, go back to when he learned about Freddy Krueger.

headline: How to Create a Dinner Co-op
text: This week the Dining section has a story on dinner co-ops, an agreement by two or more individuals or households to provide prepared meals for each other, according to a schedule. Are you in a dinner co-op? Or do you often have to cook for a crew? Then we’d love to hear from you. Post your additional tips or recipes that you’d like to share in the comments below.

headline: Food Is the Thrill at Some Bachelor Parties
text: BY tradition, a bachelor or bachelorette party is a night of Dionysian excess. How that unfolds is a matter of taste.

headline: In Defense of Video Games: A Player’s Manifesto on the Sublime Buzz
text: The critic Leslie Fiedler was writing about comic books, not video games, when he tallied up the charges against “vulgar art” in 1955. The censors and middlebrows, Fiedler wrote, claimed that this kind of stuff  not just comics but pulp novels, too  was “sadistic, fetishistic, brutal, full of terror; that it pictures women with exaggeratedly full breasts and rumps, portrays death on the printed page, is often covertly homosexual, etc., etc.”

headline: Obama Aims to Build Economic Ties With Russia
text: In his quest to restore relations with Russia, President Obama focused first on security issues like disarmament and Iran. But with an arms control treaty signed and sanctions against Tehran approved, Mr. Obama hopes to open a new phase this week aimed at building the robust economic relationship that has eluded his predecessors.

headline: Now Screening | John Varvatos
text: The Spring/Summer 2011 collection from John Varvatos at Milan Fashion Week.

headline: Producer Sues Jackson Estate Over Musical
text: A prominent Broadway producer who is seeking to create a musical from Michael Jackson’s songs is suing the  singer’s estate, arguing that the executors are thwarting a 2008 contract for a stage production that would feature hits like “Thriller” and “Beat It” and possibly new songs that Jackson may have written before his death last June, according to a copy of the civil suit.

text: In Chelsea Market, 75 Ninth Avenue (15th Street), the meatpacking district, (212) 242-2630, dicksonsfarmstand.com.

headline: With Strike, Toyota Idles Auto Plant in China
text: TOKYO — Toyota Motor halted production at a car factory in China on Tuesday for the second time this month after workers at a supplier staged a walkout. It was the latest in a string of strikes that has hit Japanese carmakers just as they look to increase production in China, the world’s biggest auto market.

headline: Kalmen Opperman, Master Clarinetist and Teacher, Dies at 90
text: Kalmen Opperman, a master clarinetist whose intensive teaching methods helped mold some of the top players of the last 50 years, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 90.

headline: Wendell Logan, Composer of Jazz and Concert Music, Dies at 69
text: Wendell Logan, a composer of jazz and concert music who more than two decades ago founded the jazz department at the Oberlin Conservatory of Music, long a bastion of high-level classical training, died on June 15 in Cleveland. He was 69 and lived in Oberlin, Ohio.

headline: Obama Requests Money for Border Security
text: LOS ANGELES  The Obama administration is asking Congress for money to expand the Border Patrol by 1,000 agents, add scores of other federal law enforcement officers and deploy two more aerial drones as part of heightened security at the Mexican border.

headline: When Caution Carries Risk
text: WASHINGTON

headline: General Faces Unease Among His Own Troops, Too
text: Riding shotgun in an armored vehicle as it passed through the heat and confusion of southern Afghanistan this month, an Army sergeant spoke into his headset, summarizing a sentiment often heard in the field this year.

headline: Bookstore in Capital Seeks Its Next Chapter
text: WASHINGTON  First came shock  the venerated Politics and Prose bookstore here was up for sale. Then, almost immediately, the fantasies started  what would it be like to be the new owner, an influential tastemaker at the intersection of the nation’s political and literary worlds?

headline: Hockey Hall of Fame Set to Induct Its First Two Women
text: Women’s ice hockey has come a long way since 1990, when members of the Canadian national team wore hot-pink uniforms instead of red-and-white uniforms for the world championships in Ottawa. The Canadians won the gold medal, anyway.

headline: What You Get for ... $400,000
text: TRENTON, N.J.

headline: Homes for $400,000
text: A five-bedroom town house in Trenton, a one-bedroom condo in Denver and a four-bedroom house in Tulsa, Okla.

text: OTTAWA  Frank Stronach, the chairman and founder of Magna International, the successful auto parts maker and car assembler, has long been its blessing and its curse.

text: Pretoria, South Africa

headline: Europe and India Push to Seal Free-Trade Deal
text: MADRID  With global trade negotiations stalled, India and the European Union are pressing to complete a bilateral free-trade agreement in the autumn that is intended to triple their 53 billion euro ($66 billion) trade flow within five years.

headline: Suspected Drug Lord Taken in Jamaica
text: MEXICO CITY — A reputed gang leader wanted in the United States on gun and drug charges was taken into custody by Jamaican authorities on Tuesday as the furious search for him, which set off violent clashes in Kingston, the Jamaican capital, entered its second month.

headline: A Villa on the Lake
text: A five-bedroom four-bath villa in the village of Villeneuve is on the market for 3 million Swiss Frances, or about $2.7 million.

headline: Bankruptcy Judge Requires Revision of Plan to Sell Rangers
text: A federal bankruptcy court judge said Tuesday that he would not approve the plan to sell the Texas Rangers unless it was modified by a newly appointed chief restructuring officer.

headline: Getting Dad to Do Diaper (Buying) Duty
text: FATHERS are changing more diapers than ever, but you would never guess that while walking down the diaper aisle, where packages feature mothers but never fathers.

headline: Haley Wins Primary for S.C. Governor
text: WASHINGTON – Nikki Haley won the Republican nomination for South Carolina governor on Tuesday, a victory that swiftly elevates her to become one of the leading faces of the national Republican Party and puts her within one step of winning election in the fall as the state’s first female governor.

headline: Descent Into Slavery, and a Ladder to Another Life
text: He wore a satin suit onstage, so new that a tag was still fixed to the cuff. His 2-year-old daughter wiggled in his arms. The crowd cheered. Lifting his right hand to his lips, Jose Gutierrez seemed to blow a kiss to the audience. But it was more.

headline: D-League Graduate Sets New Course to the N.B.A. Draft
text: TULSA, Okla.  As the N.B.A. draft approached last year, perhaps the biggest subplot involved Brandon Jennings. After struggling to qualify academically for a college scholarship, he had played professionally in Rome for a season.

headline: Outside a Former Temple of Big Tobacco, Feeling Put Upon Once More
text: There was a time when people did not think twice about smoking. That was when a pack of cigarettes could be bought for pocket change, when it was still legal to smoke in bars and restaurants, when Philip Morris  the nation’s largest tobacco company still had its headquarters in the Philip Morris building.

headline: For Jeb Bush, Life Defending the Family Name
text: CORAL GABLES, Fla.  For months now, Jeb Bush has been listening as President Obama blasts his older brother’s administration for the battered economy, budget deficits and even the lax oversight of oil wells.

headline: Ex-Aide to Paterson Takes Fifth Amendment
text: David W. Johnson, the former senior aide to Gov. David A. Paterson whose domestic violence case prompted the governor to abandon his election bid, has invoked his Fifth Amendment right not to incriminate himself, refusing to answer questions in the investigation into the matter, according to a person with knowledge of his actions.

headline: U.A.W. Chief Is Taking On Toyota Plants
text: DETROIT  Locked into concessions to the Detroit carmakers and with its membership at a 70-year low, the United Automobile Workers union is picking a fight with a longtime adversary, Toyota, in a bid to regain some of its clout.

headline: In Istanbul, From Ransacked to Revived
text: ISTANBUL  A ransacked 19th-century town house in the quiet community of Kuzguncuk may seem an odd choice of residence for a worldly former diplomat like Stephen Kimmel. But for Mr. Kimmel  now an adviser to Koc Holding, the largest conglomerate in Turkey  the empty four-story brick structure came as a relief after previous remodeling projects.

headline: Nun, 83, Is Killed by a Van Fleeing the Police in Harlem; Four People Are Injured
text: An 83-year-old Roman Catholic nun was killed and four others were injured after a minivan racing to flee the police crashed into another car in Harlem on Tuesday, sending the minivan over a traffic island and into a group of pedestrians.

headline: What Would Lincoln Do?
text: IF Abraham Lincoln’s experience is any guide, Gen. Stanley McChrystal’s fate will be determined by President Obama’s judgment of how his firing would affect the war in Afghanistan.

headline: The Other Truman Doctrine
text: Washington

headline: Bubbles, Bread and Beer
text: A couple of teaspoons of dried yeast. A pinch of sugar. A cup of warm water. And a few minutes later, you’ll have a foamy, bubbly brew of lively yeast cells, ready to be added to a bowl of flour and turned into bread.

headline: South African Soccer Pride Gets a Shot in the Arm Before a Kick in the Gut
text: DIEPSLOOT, South Africa  The crowd at Walter’s Tavern began the game a chastened group.

headline: Carlsen Does Not Win, but He Still Leads
text: After four consecutive wins in the Kings Tournament, the top-ranked player was held to a draw, but he preserved his lead.

headline: Is G.M. Rushing Its I.P.O.?
text: The chief of General Motors, Ed Whitacre, has accelerated the automaker’s initial public offering. Underwriters have been chosen and fees negotiated. For a fourth-quarter deal, a prospectus should come within weeks. What’s the big rush?

headline: Judging McChrystal’s War
text: ON Tuesday, Gen. Stanley McChrystal, the top commander in Afghanistan, was called back to Washington to explain disparaging comments he and his aides made to a Rolling Stone reporter about senior administration officials. The general’s ill-advised remarks, which have prompted him to prepare a letter of resignation, will only feed the general sense of despair and impatience that Americans seem to feel about our progress in Afghanistan.

headline: Gone Fishing on Scholarship, With Hopes of Turning Pro
text: GIBSON COUNTY LAKE, Tenn.  The college freshmen Jake Lawrence and Jacob Hardy have two priorities: getting good grades and catching big fish. Standing on the deck of a 20-foot-long bass boat on a 560-acre lake in west Tennessee, they almost look like two tanned brothers. They wear the same uniform of flip-flops, wraparound polarized sunglasses, frayed Bethel University ball caps, and fishing shirts plastered with sponsor logos.

headline: Chris Welles, Award-Winning Business Writer, Dies at 72
text: Chris Welles, an award-winning business reporter and former director of a prestigious fellowship program at Columbia for business reporters, died Saturday at a nursing home in Salisbury, Conn. He was 72 and lived in Brooklyn.

headline: Auto Dealers Could Be Exempt From Proposed Regulator’s Oversight
text: WASHINGTON  The nation’s 18,000 auto dealers appeared likely on Tuesday night to win a legislative triumph that would protect their businesses from oversight by a new consumer protection regulator.

headline: The President and His General
text: Until this week, Gen. Stanley McChrystal had a reputation for fierce self-discipline. That makes his hugely undisciplined comments in Rolling Stone magazine  including derisive quotes from his aides about Vice President Joseph Biden and other top officials  all the more puzzling and disturbing.

headline: On Location: A Labor of Love in Istanbul
text: A diplomat renovates a 19th-century town house formerly owned by an unhappy couple.

headline: What the Hosts Can Build On
text: BLOEMFONTEIN, South Africa

headline: Wide Range of Payments Is Outlined in Ground Zero Suit
text: Under a new settlement reached this month, payments to rescue and cleanup workers who say their health was damaged at ground zero will range from a few thousand dollars to $1.8 million or more, lawyers for the workers said on Tuesday.

headline: Nikki Haley Is Winner in South Carolina Runoff
text: WASHINGTON — Nikki Haley won the Republican nomination for governor of South Carolina on Tuesday, a commanding victory that elevates her to become one of the leading faces of the national Republican Party and places her within one step of being elected this fall as the state's first female governor.

headline: Out of Jail, Ex-Aide to Madoff Awaits Sentencing at Home
text: Frank DiPascali Jr., who pleaded guilty to helping Bernard L. Madoff carry out history’s biggest Ponzi scheme, was released on bail provided he stay at home and wear a monitoring device.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,111 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: JPMorgan Sets Sights Overseas
text: JPMorgan Chase emerged from the financial crisis as one of the strongest banks on American soil. Now it wants to make up lost ground overseas.

headline: Lawyer Calls Contractor in Crane Collapse a Scapegoat
text: The crucial error that led to the toppling of a tower crane and the deaths of seven people two years ago was made well before the day of the collapse, the defense lawyer for a rigging contractor said in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Tuesday.

headline: Militant’s Path From Pakistan to Times Square
text: As dawn broke on July 10, 2007, Pakistani commandos stormed the Red Mosque in Islamabad, ending a lengthy standoff with armed militants in a blaze of gunfire that left more than 100 dead. In Washington, officials applauded the siege as an important demonstration of Pakistan’s willingness to confront Islamist militants.

headline: 2 Sides Clash at City Hall Over Domino Housing Plan
text: By some standards, a developer’s plan to transform the defunct Domino Sugar refinery north of the Williamsburg Bridge in Brooklyn is a good deal, offering 660 of its planned 2,200 apartments to poor and working-class New Yorkers, shops to animate the streets and a public esplanade along the East River.

headline: New Accounting Rules Ruffle the Leasing Market
text: A new accounting standard is taking shape that could change the way tenants choose to lease space, with broad consequences for the commercial real estate market.

headline: Lottery Numbers
General Uproar
text: Three writers consider how Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal's recent remarks in a magazine profile might affect his command in Afghanistan.

headline: Pop-Up Stores Become Popular for New York Landlords
text: “Four days ago this was nothing; that wall didn’t exist,” an ebullient Charles Gibb, the president of Belvedere Vodka, said on a recent night as he pointed to a pristine white wall in a meatpacking district space covered with images of a model wearing a citrus-pink caftan.

headline: Yearlong Effort Will Add Vans to Transit Options
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced a yearlong pilot program on Tuesday that will allow commuter vans to pick up passengers in parts of Brooklyn and Queens with limited access to public transportation or where bus service cuts will take effect next week.

headline: Obama Vows Progress on Gay Rights Agenda
text: President Obama vowed Tuesday night to push ahead with his gay rights agenda, assuring an audience of gay men and lesbians at the White House that he remains committed to repealing the Defense of Marriage Act, which allows states to refuse to recognize same same-sex marriages performed in other states.

headline: As Concourse Regains Luster, City Notices
text: Supporters of the Grand Concourse often compare the Bronx thoroughfare to the Champs-Élysées, and once upon a time, the tree-lined promenade was indeed the most prestigious address in the borough.

headline: Perils for the New Breed of Commander
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Like his boss, mentor and friend, Gen. David H. Petraeus, Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal modeled himself as one of a new breed of American commanders: intellectual, open with the press and as politically savvy as the elected officials he was hired to serve.

headline: Day 63: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: Judge Blocks Drilling Moratorium

headline: City Growth May Affect Party Power in Albany
text: New York City accounted for two-thirds of the state’s population growth since 2000, according to census estimates, suggesting that after redistricting is completed in 2011, the State Legislature could remain controlled by Democrats for years to come.

headline: The Fury of a General, Released by Nature
text: Of all the questions surrounding the Rolling Stone article that detailed Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal’s surprisingly blunt criticisms of the Obama administration, few are as puzzling as this: Why would a top military commander allow a journalist so much unfettered access to his inner circle?

headline: ‘Next Fall’ to Close
text: The little-show-that-could couldn’t make it on Broadway after all.

headline: Still Mooing
text: This Wednesday puzzle has an unusual visual element. It is solvable in Across Lite or the Java applet (look closely at the notepad) but the print version is easier to understand.You can see what the grid should look like here.NOTE: if the Across Lite link does not work for you, use this link instead while we sort out the problem.

headline: World Cup Photo Replay: Day 12, June 22
text: The day’s action saw reasons for hope in South Africa and worry in France, despite both teams being eliminated from the tournament.

headline: In Battle of Bug vs. Shrub, Score One for the Bird
text: DENVER  Got an alien invader plant species? Unleash an alien insect invader to fight back. One invader eats the other, and then abracadabra: problem solved. That was the theory, anyway.

headline: Girl, 12, Drowns at Beach on Class Trip to Long Island
text: A 12-year-old girl from a Harlem public school drowned Tuesday on a class trip to an unpatrolled beach in Long Beach, on Long Island, officials said.

headline: New York Budget Talks Stall on University Proposal
text: ALBANY  State budget negotiations have further stalled over whether the Assembly will accept Gov. David A. Paterson’s proposal to overhaul the state’s public university system, according to executive and legislative officials involved in the discussions.

headline: As the Return of Beltran Nears, Pagan Prepares for a New Role
text: Angel Pagan speaks with Carlos Beltran frequently on the telephone. “He always tells me the good job I’m doing,” Pagan said. “And I always tell him, ‘Hey, we need you here.’ ”

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Adrift, Burnett Is Missing His Command and His Coach
text: PHOENIX  Since establishing himself as a premier pitcher in 2008, when he won 18 games for Toronto and led the American League in strikeouts, A. J. Burnett has endured rocky stretches that reinforced the reputation that trailed him for years: immensely talented but maddeningly inconsistent. Never during this period, though, has he lurched into the sort of rut he is now, with four straight poor starts that culminated Monday night in a 10-4 loss to the Arizona Diamondbacks.

headline: The Anosognosic’s Dilemma: Something’s Wrong but You’ll Never Know What It Is (Part 3)
Spill’s Effects Trickle Down Into Everyday Life
text: ORANGE BEACH, Ala.  When the Deepwater Horizon exploded on April 20, Nadejda Damian had just arrived in Alabama from Moldova, the former Soviet Republic, to spend the summer cleaning beachfront condominiums. But with the spill, there are fewer tourists, which means fewer condominiums to clean  which, for Ms. Damian, 21, means a summer of losing money instead of amassing a nice sum to take home.

headline: China’s Currency Falls a Day After a Gain
text: HONG KONG  The Chinese currency slipped Tuesday in its second day of trading since Beijing promised increased flexibility in the exchange rate.

headline: Chess Hustling, a Look Back
text: Part of the fabric of night life in New York City, particularly during the summer, are the street chess games. Dozens of players in places like Washington Square Park, Union Square and St. Nicholas Avenue and 141st Street are up all night, taking on all comers, for a few dollars a game. The games are fast and gritty and often peppered with non-stop and colorful banter.

headline: For Gulf Victims, Mediator With Deep Pockets and Broad Power
text: WASHINGTON  Kenneth R. Feinberg is the $20 billion man with an open-ended checkbook full of BP’s money. Just as jaw-dropping as the sum is the power he has to spend it: Mr. Feinberg will not only decide who is paid for losses from the gulf oil spill, and how much, he also gets to pick the three judges to handle appeals of his decisions.

headline: South Africa: Labor Leader Avoids Punishment by Governing Party
text: The governing African National Congress backed away Tuesday from disciplining Zwelinzima Vavi, leader of Cosatu, the powerful trade union federation, but scolded Mr. Vavi for “alien behavior” for publicly accusing two A.N.C. government ministers of corruption, saying he had unfairly dragged their names “through the mud.”

headline: Peru: Report Shows Gains in Coca
text: Peru is poised to overtake Colombia as the world’s largest producer of coca, the plant used to produce cocaine, the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime said in a report on Tuesday. The agency cited a 6.8 percent increase in areas under coca cultivation in 2009 compared with 2008, part of broader expansion of coca growing in Peru in recent years. There was a 16 percent decline in areas under coca cultivation in Colombia for the same time period, and an increase of 1 percent in Bolivia. About 55 percent more coca is grown in Peru now than a decade ago, the United Nations said. Colombian and Mexican trafficking groups, as well as small factions of the Shining Path rebel group, are feeding off the coca trade in Peru’s remote forest regions.

headline: No Love Lost for Half-Brothers
text: The Germany-Ghana match set for Soccer City stadium in Johannesburg on Wednesday is not only a struggle for survival for both teams, it is also a clash of half-brothers, with a hint of revenge in the air.

headline: Panel Named to Steer Course on Dealing With Sri Lanka
text: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, appointed a three-member panel on Tuesday to advise him on how to proceed with accusations that war crimes may have occurred in the months leading up to the end of Sri Lanka’s civil war in May 2009. The Sri Lankan government has staunchly opposed any United Nations action, calling it an infringement on national sovereignty, particularly since it has formed its own commission to look into possible human rights violations as the war against the Tamil Tigers ended. Human Rights Watch issued a statement saying that the Sri Lankan government has repeatedly failed to undertake real investigations and urging Mr. Ban’s advisers to recommend a serious international inquiry.

headline: Israel: Spy Satellite Is Launched
text: Israel launched a spy satellite into orbit Tuesday night from an air force base near the center of the country. The new satellite, known as Ofek-9, will help Israel more efficiently monitor the region, including Iran, said Chaim Eshed, the director of Israel’s military space program.

headline: Canada: Missing Animals Found
text: A tiger and two camels that were thought to have been inadvertently stolen by truck thieves in Quebec last week were recovered unharmed and in good health on Monday night not far from where they had been taken. The animals were being moved from Nova Scotia to a private zoo near Toronto when the truck and trailer carrying them disappeared from a motel parking lot early Friday. The zoo offered a $20,000 reward, and police officers, acting on a phone tip, found the trailer containing the animals abandoned on a rural road not far from the motel. The animals were driven through the night and reached the zoo early Tuesday.

headline: Cutting Off the Unemployed
text: It was bad enough when the Senate left town for a long Memorial Day break without passing a bill to extend expiring unemployment benefits. It’s worse now.

headline: About Those Premiums
text: President Obama told health insurers on Tuesday not to use health care reform as an excuse to raise the cost of premiums. The warning is timely. With critics still scare-mongering about the supposed cost of reform, insurers in several states have been seeking double-digit premium increases that look hard to justify as necessary to keep up with medical inflation.

headline: Thrush’s Song
text: In the woods the other day — redwoods and coastal oaks — I stopped to listen to a Swainson’s thrush, a bird more often heard than seen. Usually its song is tempered by distance, its maker hidden in the understory. But this thrush was standing on a fallen limb right in front of me. The physical effort of its singing seemed so slight — head tilting, beak parting — compared with the quantity of its delicate, laddering song.

headline: Fierce Recycling Effort in Fighting Oil’s Spread
text: VENICE, La.  Pete Parker’s not-so-small frame radiates purpose. Striding around a dockside yard where his “decontamination unit” works, he keeps an eye on 11 workers who are stooped over drills, bolts and iron mallets to repair oil-containment booms damaged by waves and strong currents in the gulf.

headline: Seven Days in June
text: So this general with the background in intelligence who is supposed to conquer Afghanistan can’t even figure out what Rolling Stone is? We’re not talking Guns & Ammo here; we’re talking the antiwar hippie magazine.

headline: The Boom Mender

headline: What’s Second Prize?
text: Gen. Stanley McChrystal’s trashing of his civilian colleagues was unprofessional and may cost him his job. If so, it will be a sad end to a fine career. But no general is indispensable. What is indispensable is that when taking America surging deeper into war in Afghanistan, President Obama has to be able to answer the most simple questions at a gut level: Do our interests merit such an escalation and do I have the allies to achieve victory? President Obama never had good answers for these questions, but he went ahead anyway. The ugly truth is that no one in the Obama White House wanted this Afghan surge. The only reason they proceeded was because no one knew how to get out of it  or had the courage to pull the plug. That is not a sufficient reason to take the country deeper into war in the most inhospitable terrain in the world. You know you’re in trouble when you’re in a war in which the only party whose objectives are clear, whose rhetoric is consistent and whose will to fight never seems to diminish is your enemy: the Taliban.

headline: After 3 Years, Labor Board Seats Are Full
text: The National Labor Relations Board has all five seats filled for the first time since December 2007 after the Senate confirmed two of President Obama’s nominees for full terms: Brian Hayes, a Republican Senate aide, and Mark Pearce, a Democrat. The board, which remedies unfair labor practices and certifies union elections, traditionally requires a majority of three to act on divisive issues. The board has three Democrats and two Republicans.

headline: Phys Ed: Do Sport Bars and Gels Provide the Energy of Sports Drinks?
text: According to a study published this spring in the journal Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise, people who exercise for more than about two hours at a time can benefit from sports drinks. Most of us know that, of course. The carbohydrates in the drinks provide immediate fuel, which allows our bodies to avoid dipping into its own energy stores, meaning that, theoretically, you can exercise longer or more intensively before running out of fuel. But few people, in practice, can or will drink enough calories during a long workout to benefit significantly, the study authors suggest. The volume of fluid needed is, to say the least, daunting. Achieving the ideal “carbohydrate-intake rates,” the authors write, requires toting and stomaching about a half gallon of a typical sports drink every hour. Good luck with that.

headline: New Test Approved for Swine Flu
text: A new and improved diagnostic test for the 2009 swine flu was approved Tuesday by the Food and Drug Administration. The new kit, developed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, has been shown to be 96 percent accurate on samples taken from nasal swabs, which can be done in a doctor’s office. It takes about four hours. The test replaces the one authorized for emergency use in April, 2009, when the flu pandemic was just beginning. That test was less accurate and worked more consistently on samples from the lungs, which are usually taken in hospitals.

headline: What Would Get You to Move Your Checking Account?
text: In a Your Money column on Wednesday, I take a look at Perk Street, a company that offers a 2 percent rebate on every dollar its checking account customers spend when they sign for purchases using their debit cards. You have to have a $5,000 balance to qualify; otherwise, the reward is 1 percent instead of 2 percent, which is still far higher than what most banks pay in debit card rewards, if they offer them at all.

headline: Sounds of the Past
text: The original cast recording of “Gypsy,” battle sounds from World War II, Patti Smith’s debut album, and Tupac Shakur’s single “Dear Mama” are among 25 recordings selected for the Library of Congress’s National Recording Registry. The National Recording Preservation Act of 2000 directed the Librarian of Congress to select 25 recordings annually that are “culturally, historically or aesthetically significant” and at least 10 years old. Nominations are made online by the public and by a group of professionals in the fields of music, recorded sound and preservation. The recordings are preserved at a state-of-the-art facility in Virginia. The 25 additions also include a May 1941 radio broadcast featuring a debate between the theologian Reinhold Niebuhr and John Flynn, the New York chairman of the noninterventionist America First Committee, over whether the United States should aid Britain in the war; the blues singer Howlin’ Wolf’s song “Smokestack Lightning”; Bill Cosby’s comedy album “I Started Out as a Child”; Loretta Lynn’s “Coal Miner’s Daughter”; and Willie Nelson’s “Red Headed Stranger.” The library is accepting nominations online for the next registry.

headline: Beijing Keeps a Tight Rein on Currency’s Rise

headline: No Power? Jimmy Kimmel’s Webcam
text: Most television hosts will do whatever it takes to keep their shows on the air, but when a power failure struck Jimmy Kimmel’s show on Monday evening, he really went the extra mile: he grabbed a laptop computer and shot the entire episode on a Webcam, becoming director, cameraman and lighting designer for the night. That episode of “Jimmy Kimmel Live,” which ABC was to show on Monday, was instead to be shown on Tuesday. And it still featured segments with Seth Rogen (who was on hand to introduce his new movie, “The Green Hornet”) and the comedian John Henson, as well as a performance by the country musician Dierks Bentley  only slightly more pixelated than home viewers are used to seeing. Mr. Kimmel, whose late-night talk show is produced at El Capitan Theater in Los Angeles, said his control room lost power just before taping was to start at 7 p.m. Pacific time. “I blame BP for this,” he said in a telephone interview. “I’m sure they’re responsible somehow.”

Yes, his hip flexor feels better. Yes, he feels healthy. And no, he is not concerned that, nearly three months into the season, he has slugged fewer home runs than John Buck and Juan Uribe.

headline: It’s a Bird, It’s a Plane – It’s Superman on Your iPhone
text: DC Comics, the home of Superman, announced two digital publishing and distribution initiatives on Wednesday. The company has teamed up with comiXology to produce a DC Comics App and store for the iPhone, iPod Touch and iPad devices. Digital versions of DC Comics will also be available on the Sony PlayStation Network and the Comics by comiXology app and Web site. The PlayStation platform opens with more than 80 comics and will add more than 50 issues per month, while comiXology begins with more than 100 titles and will add another 100 per month. Both platforms share a tiered pricing structure of 99 cents to $2.99 per issue. Newsarama.com has a list of the issues currently available, including two free comics that tell the origin stories of Superman and Batman.

headline: Such Devoted Sisters: ‘Office’ Mates Carrie and Ellie Kemper Will Publish a First Book

But things worked out better for Ms. Kemper, who not only isn’t an orphan and wasn’t raised in a foster home, but has a creative younger sister, Carrie, with whom she is about to write a comic novel planned for 2012.

headline: Lawmakers at Impasse on Trading
text: WASHINGTON  Derivatives trading, a business long prized by Wall Street but little noticed by anyone else, is rapidly gaining prominence as the rare part of the nation’s vast financial infrastructure that Democrats cannot agree how to regulate.

headline: New Look for Travel Booking Engine

But the service, which also powers major booking engines like Orbitz, Kayak and Bing, was clunky and hard to use, requiring users to click through multiple drop-down menus and and screens.

Here are some philosophical questions and creative activities stemming from the ongoing developments in the pursuit of conscious computers and inspired by the Times Magazine article on I.B.M.’s Watson, a machine that can play “Jeopardy!”.

headline: Baby Turtles Seize the Day
text: In May, I wrote about an endangered Kemp’s Ridley sea turtle off the coast of Padre Island National Seashore in Texas, highlighting the danger that the gulf oil spill poses to these ancient endangered animals. Since then, hundreds of Kemp’s Ridley and other sea turtles have been found stranded or dead, some of them covered in oil, although it is unclear whether the oil played a role in their deaths.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S. vs. Algeria
text: Just when it looked like the United States team was headed home, Landon Donovan pounced, and the United States won. The United States won Group C and advanced to the Round of 16, where they will play Ghana on Saturday. It marks the first time the United States team won a World Cup group since 1930, the inaugural tournament, in Uruguay.

headline: Desperate Hope, Dramatic Ending for U.S.
text: PRETORIA, South Africa — Chance after frantic chance the United States had Wednesday in its 1-0 victory over Algeria at the World Cup, each one more tempting and frustrating than the other. Finally, desperation seemed to tighten like a noose, strangling the Americans’ patience and accuracy.

text: In today's Timescast, reports on the fate of General McChrystal, unease among the troops in Afghanistan, and what the offshore drilling moratorium means.

headline: House Drops Demand for Bank Liquidation Fund
text: House negotiators working to complete legislation to overhaul the nation’s financial regulatory system have agreed to drop a proposal for a $150 billion fund that would be used to liquidate failing financial companies, The New York Times’s David M. Herszenhorn reports from Washington.

headline: Favela Fab
text: Thanks to Jeroen Koolhaas and Dre Urhahn, one of Rio’s bleakest neighborhoods now has a permanent rainbow. As part of their project “O Morro” (which literally translated means “the hill” but really signifies the presence of “the slum”), the Dutch artists have enlisted the community to transform the facades of 34 houses (about 7,000 square meters!) into a colorful community art project. Local residents who picked up a brush received a small salary (the painting took about a month) and an education in the production process. Koolhaas and Urhahn, who have been painting favelas for the past two years as part of a greater initiative to transform the hillside slums into places that residents are proud to live in, plan to return to Brazil to finish painting the entire hill.

headline: ‘I Was Buried Alive,’ Victim of Fallen Crane Says at Trial
text: John Gallego was relaxing on the couch of his second-floor apartment on East 50th Street, sipping coffee and watching television when he heard what he describes as a breaking noise.

text: Greg Bishop, who is covering the tournament for The Times, and John Martin and Geoff Macdonald, two Straight Sets contributors, are at Wimbledon and provided updates.

headline: The Excessive Rates for Hybrid Rental Cars
text: When my aunt and uncle recently traveled to San Francisco, their flight arrived hours late and then had to wait nearly three hours at the airport for a rental car to be available. The rental company tried to appease them by offering a Toyota Prius hybrid as an extra perk. It was an upgrade, the agent told them.

headline: Video and Transcript of President Obama’s Remarks on Gen. McChrystal
text: Update | 2:09 p.m. Here is a full transcript of President Obama’s remarks at the White House this afternoon, as he explained his decision to replace Gen. Stanley McChrystal with Gen. David Petraeus as America’s top commander in Afghanistan, and stressed the importance of civilian control of the military.

headline: A ‘Thankful’ Spitzer Anticipates Some Criticism
text: Eliot Spitzer described himself as “extremely thankful” to be getting an opportunity to revive his reputation as a television news host after the tawdry circumstances of his forced resignation as governor of New York.

headline: Drake Tops Charts
text: With impressive sales of his debut album, the rapper Drake leads a wavelet of new releases on the Billboard album chart. Drake’s “Thank Me Later” (Aspire/Young Money/Cash Money) sold 447,000 copies in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan. It was the third biggest opening week of the year, after Sade (502,000) and Lady Antebellum (481,000).

headline: After Earlier Troubles, BP Says It Restored Cap
text: BP’s effort to contain the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico suffered another setback on Wednesday when a discharge of liquid and gases forced the company to remove the containment cap that for three weeks had been able to capture much of the oil gushing from its damaged well.

headline: In Stock Plan Dispute, Sitrick Asks for Dismissal of Lawsuit

headline: Ac-shun! Now Brace for Impact
text: THIRTY-FIVE years ago last weekend Steven Spielberg’s “Jaws” opened on more than 400 screens across the country, breaking box office records and inaugurating the era of the modern summer blockbuster. Whether that was a catastrophe or a boon depends on whom you ask or what mood you’re in. But ever since “Jaws” it has been a truism that, especially in the summertime, movie audiences want action.
