headline: Wendell Berry Takes Back His Papers
text: For decades the Kentucky poet, critic, and farmer Wendell Berry has advocated personal activism on behalf of the environment. There should not be a “split between what we think and what we do,” he has written. “Once our personal connection to what is wrong becomes clear, then we have to choose: we can go on as before, recognizing our dishonesty and living with it the best we can, or we can begin the effort to change the way we think and live.”

headline: Is Apple a Victim of Sour Grapes?
text: SAN FRANCISCO  As Apple fans line up at stores on Thursday morning for the release of the fourth iteration of the iPhone, the company is riding high.

headline: Barton to Keep Committee Slot
text: Representative Joe L. Barton will keep his spot as the top Republican on the House Energy and Commerce Committee in spite of his apology to BP at a hearing last week.

headline: Fed Leaves Rates, Citing Overseas Threats
text: The Federal Reserve’s policy-making arm said on Wednesday that it had decided to keep short-term interest rates near zero for “an extended period,” citing challenges to economic growth, including the effect of new financial troubles abroad.

headline: Bottled Water Ban Vexes Concord Vendors
text: In Wednesday’s paper, I wrote about Jean Hill, who persuaded her fellow voters in Concord, Mass., to ban sales of bottled water there. The town of about 17,000 people is more environmentally conscious than most – it is home to Walden Pond, after all – but many who support the ban in theory are calling it impractical.

headline: Against The Super-Asinine, The Gods Themselves Contend in Vain
text: Brad DeLong wonders how the proponents of tight budgets and tight money are prevailing in the midst of mass unemployment, low interest rates, and incipient deflation.

headline: 2nd Suspect Being Questioned After Nun’s Death
text: A second suspect has been taken into police custody in connection with a minivan crash that left an elderly nun dead in Harlem.

headline: Fashionable Shorts | These Movies Have Credits
text: Not every creative director can be a Tom Ford, distilling two decades of sexy design into a cool cocktail of stylish cinematography, earning an Oscar nomination in the process. But that isn’t stopping everyone from trying. In a time when the iPad has eclipsed the September issue, and editorial channels are growing while advertising page numbers are shrinking, luxury labels have to promote their collections somehow. The result? A fashion film movement, in full swing.

headline: Earthquake Shakes New York: Did You Even Notice?
text: Updated, June 24 | A 5.0-magnitude earthquake struck north of Ottawa around 1:45 p.m. Wednesday, rattling buildings as far away as Vermont, Albany and even New York City. There are no reports of any serious damage.

headline: America’s Love-Hate Affair With Big Government

headline: In Oakland, Innovation Is on the Menu
text: BOCANOVA, a new industrial-chic restaurant on Jack London Square in Oakland, Calif., has all the characteristics of a sophisticated urban restaurant: banquette seating, wooden tables, irregularly shaped Edison light bulbs hanging from the ceiling, and a stained-glass bar in the middle of the spacious dining room. The most significant detail about Bocanova’s location, however, is what’s no longer there: just a few years ago, this same space was an Old Spaghetti Factory.

headline: Reinventing Oakland’s Restaurant Scene
text: Jack London Square has been reborn through a number of noteworthy restaurants.

headline: Racial Tinge Stains World Cup Exit in France
text: PARIS  After France was booted from this year’s World Cup on Tuesday without winning a match  amid scenes of selfishness, indifference and indiscipline  the French news media piled on about the humiliation to the country and the misbehavior of its players. There were calls for a complete restructuring of the French team: its management, its method for choosing players, its training.

headline: A Letter to My Younger Self
text: While we are on the subject of capturing the moment in letters — from son to father, from campers to parents — two Web sites have caught my eye recently that are filled with old-fashioned letters. (Well, as old fashioned as you can be on a Web site.) We’ll talk about them one at a time. Come back later today for more.

headline: Do You Agree With Obama’s Decision to Relieve McChrystal?
text: In the wake of controversy over comments he and his staff made in a Rolling Stone article, General Stanley A. McChrystal resigned as commander of U.S. forces in Afghanistan. President Obama accepted his resignation and replaced him with General David H. Petraeus. Hundreds of New York Times readers have posted their reactions. What do you think?

headline: Gregg Allman Recovering After Liver Transplant
text: Gregg Allman, the Allman Brothers Band musician and singer who has had chronic health problems related to Hepatitis C, had liver transplant surgery on Wednesday morning at the Mayo Clinic in Jacksonville, Fla., the band announced. “I feel pretty good, considering everything that’s happened,” he said in a statement.

headline: The Saudi Arabia of Lithium
text: Term used suggest that Afghanistan (and previously Bolivia) could be to lithium as Saudi Arabia is to oil.

headline: The Time Is Right: Gooseberry Relish
text: Last year, my wife and I had a terrific Sunday lunch at our London friend Liz Murray’s apartment (RvrVu of the Thames and all). Even though ten months or so have passed since we scoured our plates with bread, knife blades and fingers, I still think of an aromatic sweet-tart-spicy gooseberry relish she served with a pork roast. I’d extracted the recipe from her at the time, but since I couldn’t immediately lay my hands on two of its ingredients — bottled elderflower cordial and the gooseberries themselves — I filed it away for future reference.

headline: Motorola’s Co-Chief Calls Icahn ‘a Force for Good’
text: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn has been called a lot of things during his career of pressuring corporate boards and executives. On Wednesday, Sanjay Jha, the co-chief executive of Motorola, called Mr. Icahn “a force for good” at his company.

headline: McConnell Questions Kagan’s Impartiality
text: 5:55 p.m. | Updated The Senate Republican leader, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, on Wednesday questioned the ability of Elena Kagan to serve impartially as a Supreme Court justice, seizing on notes scribbled on a page when she was working as an adviser in the Clinton White House that suggested she supported changes in campaign finance laws that would hamstring Republicans but not Democrats.

headline: Fine Points | The Caftan Brings a Middle East Touch

headline: Think Beach, Without Water
text: HANG on to your harem pants. That perplexingly popular garment isn’t the only one with roots in Middle Eastern dress that’s making a splash this summer. The holy haboob that blew into cinemas last month  that is, “Sex and the City 2”  seems to have missed (or sunk) the boat on every score, save one: its procession of floaty caftans. The four gals may be mired in narrative quicksand, but at least they look happily on trend.

headline: Does Insomnia Always Have an Underlying ‘Cause’?
text: “Everybody suffers from a few sleepless nights, but most people do not suffer from the disorder of insomnia,” explains Dr. Michael Thorpy, a neurologist and director of the Sleep-Wake Disorders Center at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. “Insomnia disorder typically occurs when the sleeplessness occurs for at least one month, though even a few days of bad sleep may be sufficient to require treatment.”

headline: Top Dance Award Goes to Martha Clarke
text: Martha Clarke has won what is described as the largest yearly prize given to a modern dance choreographer, the $50,000 Scripps/ADF award, the American Dance Festival said Wednesday. Ms. Clarke, 66, is also a director, known for weaving together music, dance, visual art and texts. The festival on July 5 is presenting the premiere of her work “Angel Reapers,” which is based on the life of Ann Lee, the founder of the Shaker movement.

headline: Now Slathering | A D.I.Y. River Cottage Breakfast
text: There’s something oddly exhilarating about baking a great loaf of bread. But unless you’re a seasoned baker or a no-kneadist, it’s not a feeling you get to experience that often. Thanks to the new “River Cottage Bread Handbook” from Hugh Fearnley-Whittingstall and the River Cottage baker Daniel Stevens, I was quickly able to master that barely considered breakfast staple, the English muffin. Thomas, be afraid.

headline: Judge Sides With Google in Viacom Video Suit
text: SAN FRANCISCO  In a major victory for Google in its battle with media companies, a federal judge in New York on Wednesday threw out Viacom’s $1 billion copyright infringement lawsuit against Google’s YouTube, the No. 1 Internet video-sharing site.

headline: Getting More From an Electric Miles Davis Model
text: The Miles Davis album “Tutu”  his first for Warner Brothers, released in 1986  was a proud and polarizing creature in its day. For a sizeable portion of the jazz citizenry it was one of Davis’s more garish heresies in a late career full of them. Others saw a creditable synth-pop salvo, another reinvention. It won a Grammy Award and spent eight weeks on the Billboard 200, but even some of the less reactionary responses to it conveyed a withering distaste. “Fusion music for the hot tub,” Robert Palmer wrote in The New York Times.

headline: Rangers’ Lundqvist Sells Condo

text: Mets pitcher Johan Santana was accused of sexual assault near his home in Fort Myers, Fla., in October. The police investigated but did not bring charges against him, citing lack of evidence.

text: In a story we’ve just published, Pamela Ryckman writes about Bizdom U, an intense program in entrepreneurship that helps students like James Smith Moore, shown above, start businesses — and that also has ambitions to revive the city of Detroit.

text: Henrik Lundqvist, the New York Rangers goalie, has sold his 1,300-square-foot two-bedroom on West 83rd Street. The price was not available, but he was asking $1.75 million. Read more in Real Estate.

text: A behind-the-scenes look at the comedian's life and career.

headline: A Winsome Climate Panel Presents Its New Cast
text: Embarking on a bit of a charm offensive, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change just released the names of more than 800 scientists selected to take part in writing its fifth assessment report on climate change, due out in 2014. The panel is charged with releasing periodic reports summarizing the state of knowledge about climate change as a guide to policy makers.

headline: U.S. Soccer’s Moment to Savor
text: A game fraught with tension ended happily for the United States soccer team and its fans.

headline: How I Saved My Company: GroundLink
text: GroundLink, which provides global transportation services, had been growing at an annual rate of 40 percent. It had 140 employees and expected annual revenues to hit $30 million. It borrowed $10 million to finance its growth. And then, in July 2008, corporate travel went off a cliff. With interest payments and vendor payments coming due, its chief executive, Alex Mashinsky, instituted what he calls “The Yes Campaign.” Watch the video below to see how he turned the company around.

headline: Schumann Performed as Others Hear Him
text: Most performers commemorating the Schumann bicentenary are playing his music straight up. Not so Michel Galante, the founder and director of the Argento Chamber Ensemble. When Mr. Galante and his players paid tribute to Schumann on Tuesday evening at the Chelsea Art Museum, they looked at his music  or, in one case, his style and persona  through the eyes of other composers.

headline: Cuomo Accepts Millions From Interests He Assails
text: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, declaring his candidacy for governor of New York, could not have been clearer.

headline: 'Vidal Sassoon: The Movie'

headline: Diller Scofidio + Renfro to Design Berkeley Museum
text: The University of California, Berkeley on Wednesday announced the selection of the New York firm Diller Scofidio + Renfro to design a new Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive, the university’s second attempt at the project. Last year, it abandoned plans for a $200 million, 140,000-square-foot museum designed by the Japanese architect Toyo Ito because it would have been too expensive; the budget for the new version is $95 million.

headline: Under All the Glitter, a Message: Be Yourself
text: Adam Lambert made his entrance at the Nokia Theater on Tuesday night with a glam-goth flourish. Wearing an oversize top hat, fringed leather tatters and a streak of silvery glitter across one temple, he gestured above each of his zombie-styled dancers to freeze them in place as supplicants or victims.

headline: (Insert Celebrity Name Here): The Movie
text: IT’S 1965: the Beatles play a historic concert at Shea Stadium. A restless 16-year-old from Levittown, N.Y., named Billy Joel is inspired to become a musician. He’s a hit with the Brendas and Eddies from Long Island he sings about.

headline: A Heart Bisected, a Concerto Repurposed
text: Let’s give credit where it’s due. Peter Martins, ballet master in chief of New York City Ballet, keeps his company both new and old. He with the one hand commissions a globally unequaled number of choreographic world premieres and with the other maintains the largest active repertory of important works by dead masters.

headline: The Wondrous Delight of Freedom, and Its Dear Price
text: Casual followers of ballet might be forgiven for thinking that American Ballet Theater has only one Russian star in its midst, as New York this spring has been aflutter over Natalia Osipova, a guest from the Bolshoi Ballet. Could it have been only a few seasons ago that the city was swept up in the arrival of another great Russian ballerina, Diana Vishneva, who joined Ballet Theater full time in 2005 as a principal?

headline: Brazilian Oil Giant Petrobras Delays Offering
text: Petrobras, the Brazilian national oil company, said on Tuesday that it would defer a rights issue worth up to 150 billion reais ($85 billion) until September pending a government decision to evaluate certain oil assets.

text: A cottage in the Catskills that she renovated herself fulfills a dream for a woman who was once homeless.

headline: Roses Without Scents at the New York Botanical Garden
text: Luscious roses like Rosanna, Aloha, Red Corsair and Amadeus are all on display.

headline: Becca’s 2010 List of Outdoor Summer Movies
text: Updated, June 24 | The longest day of the year has passed, but warm red and gold sunsets await. As the summer lights go down, the perfect ambiance for watching films on rooftops, grassy parks and piers is set.

headline: Endangered-Species Status Is Sought for Bluefin Tuna
text: Fearing that the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico will deal a severe blow to the bluefin tuna, an environmental group is demanding that the government declare the fish an endangered species, setting off extensive new protections under federal law.

headline: Before Loading Up the Surfboard, Check the Phone
text: The Internet has been good to surfers and other water-sports enthusiasts, who can check a webcam or online surf report before taking a futile trip to the beach.

headline: The Unknown Loved by the Knowns
text: “IF you want to disappear ... come around for private lessons,” the artist Brion Gysin once offered in a prose poem. And during a period in Paris in the late 1950s, when he and the novelist William S. Burroughs were experimenting with crystal balls, mirrors and other contraptions of the occult, a mutual friend swore that he saw Gysin exercise the powers of dematerialization, perhaps with help from the various narcotics that always seemed to be lying around for the taking.

headline: Talking With Shari Mendelson

They are bubbly and precious-looking, and Ms. Mendelson fashions them out of plastic bottles that she harvests from the trash, slices with metalworking shears and hot-glues back together.

But Americans celebrated the same way, wherever they were.

Information: (800) 944-2233 or dwr.com.

headline: ‘Imperial Bedrooms’
text: They had made a movie about us. The movie was based on a book written by someone we knew. The book was a simple thing about four weeks in the city we grew up in and for the most part was an accurate portrayal. It was labeled fiction but only a few detailshad been altered and our names weren't changed and there was nothing in it that hadn't happened. For example, there actually had been a screening of a snuff film in that bedroom in Malibu on a January afternoon, and yes, I had walked out onto the deck overlooking the Pacific where the author tried to console me, assuring me that the screams of the children being tortured were faked, but he was smiling as he said this and I had to turn away. Other examples: my girlfriend had in fact run over a coyote in the canyons below Mulholland, and a Christmas Eve dinner at Chasen's with my family that I had casually complained about to the author was faithfully rendered. And a twelve-year-old girl really had been gang-raped — I was in that room in West Hollywood with the writer, who in the book noted just a vague reluctance on my part and failed to accurately describe how I had actually felt that night — the desire, the shock, how afraid I was of the writer, a blond and isolated boy whom the girl I was dating had halfway fallen in love with. But the writer would never fully return her love because he was too lost in his own passivity to make the connection she needed from him, and so she had turned to me, but by then it was too late, and because the writer resented that she had turned to me I becamethe handsome and dazed narrator, incapable of love or kindness. That's how I became the damaged party boy who wandered through the wreckage, blood streaming from his nose, asking questions that never required answers. That's how I became the boy who never understoodhow anything worked. That's how I became the boy who wouldn't save a friend. That's how I became the boy who couldn't love the girl.

headline: From ‘Less Than Zero’ to More Anomie
text: Bret Easton Ellis’s “Imperial Bedrooms” can be described euphemistically as an extension of, sequel to, meditation on or deliberately cobwebby meta-reworking of “Less Than Zero,” the debut novel that put its disaffected young author on the map 25 years ago. It can also be seen as an act of desperation, and it may be all of the above. Whatever its genesis, what this vacant new book does best is demonstrate that there are more ways to be bored and boring in Los Angeles in 2010 than there were in 1985.

Now, before any trip, I seem to have to pack an electronic bazaar into my luggage just to avoid forgetting anything important. After lots of trips with gadgets in tow  and after consulting many friends and followers on Twitter  I’ve compiled my favorite tips for traveling with technology.

text: The school of relational aesthetics  the knotty-sounding, French-influenced idea that art can be more about social interactions than about objects  has been going strong in museums and galleries for more than a decade now. But it has probably never come across a social interactor (interactress?) like Lauren Burke, a 26-year-old Manhattan lawyer who describes herself as a “super people person” who is “crazy in love with New York City” and unable to drink more than one caffeinated beverage a day.

Maybe it’s not as inspirational as Liverpool’s “You’ll Never Walk Alone,” but it’s all-American, cheesy, stadium rock at its best/worst and can’t be ruined by spectators or bar patrons (drunk, optimistic or both).

The garden party, which was trimmed back last year, nonetheless cost nearly $1 million. Mr. Sarkozy’s spending has been criticized by government auditors.

headline: Turkey: A Warning on Security
text: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan, left, warned European leaders on Wednesday that Europe’s security could not be guaranteed unless European countries stepped up support for Turkey in its struggle with Kurdish rebels, including extraditing suspects sought by the Turkish authorities. “We have bilateral agreements on extradition of criminals, but which one of these have you actually complied with?” Mr. Erdogan asked at a southeast European summit meeting in Istanbul.

headline: Canada: Air Crash Kills 7
text: A chartered airplane struggled on take off and crashed into a residential yard near Quebec City on Wednesday, killing seven people. The pilot reported an engine problem after taking off and said he intended to return to the airport. The twin engine Beechcraft King Air, owned by Aéropro, had been headed to a school construction project on an native Canadian reservation. The five passengers were reported to be government employees, representatives of an architectural firm and an engineer.

headline: Monaco: Albert II Is Engaged

headline: Even for Picasso, Bidding Stays Cautious in London Auctions
text: LONDON  Even the magic of a Blue Period Picasso could not seduce collectors into loosening their purse strings at Christie’s here on Wednesday night, in spite of considerable excitement leading up to the sale. Although five bidders went for Picasso’s “Portrait of Angel Fernández de Soto (The Absinthe Drinker),” a soulful 1903 canvas depicting the artist’s friend seated at a Barcelona cafe table and shrouded in tobacco smoke, bidding was slow and deliberate. The painting sold to an unidentified collector for $46.3 million, or $51.8 million with commission  just above the low end of the price range that had been estimated, and far below the high of $60 million.

headline: In Hospitals the Reality Is Real
text: To call “Boston Med” reality television feels like sacrilege, even if there seems to be a clear invitation to do so. The series, which burrows deep down into the culture and caseload of premier hospitals (Massachusetts General, Brigham and Women’s, and Children’s Hospital Boston), opens with glittery, evocative shots of its title city, the kind that make those of us who did not spend part of our 20s near the Charles River wonder why we hadn’t. A moody pop song gradually swells, vaguely conveying themes of youthful desire. This, you say, is going to be “The Hills” with biopsies.

headline: Lose a General, Win a War

So for most of our presidents there would have been no question about whether to oust Gen. Stanley McChrystal for making public his differences with the White House on policy in Afghanistan. If President Obama had not fired General McChrystal, it would have been like President Truman keeping on Douglas MacArthur after his insubordination during the Korean War.

headline: Rudd Steps Down as Prime Minister of Australia
text: SYDNEY, Australia - Faced with a revolt from within his own governing party, Prime Minister Kevin Rudd stepped down on Thursday morning. Party officials decided to replace him with his deputy, Julia Gillard, who was sworn in a few hours later as the nation's first female prime minister.   Mr. Rudd, who faced rising opposition from within his own center-left Labor Party, ceded control of the party's leadership to Ms. Gillard in the capital, Canberra. Mr. Rudd, who once enjoyed the highest approval ratings in Australian history, became the shortest serving prime minister in nearly 40 years and one of a handful to be thrown from office before completing one term.

headline: One Goal, No Cheers
text: The Times’s Stephen Farrell checked in from Baghdad during the United States’ World Cup match on Wednesday, where Iraqis found unity in backing a fellow Arab nation, Algeria. Battling the summer heat, blackouts and security scares, Iraqis watched the United States celebrate Landon Donovan’s last-minute goal in silence, while the announcer consoled disappointed viewers, “Nevermind.” With the Iraq national team having failed to reach the World Cup, most of the fans in Baghdad said they supported Algeria for sporting reasons and Arab solidarity, but others shared a different reasoning.

headline: Tibetans Fear a Broader Crackdown
text: Karma Samdrup and his two younger brothers were the kind of Tibetans who put the Chinese Communist Party at ease. Vaunted environmentalists, they were pillars of their community who steered clear of politics. Even better, Mr. Samdrup had become a rich philanthropist and planned to donate part of his immense Tibetan art collection to a state-run museum.

Shares in Hasbro had been halted after briefly spiking in premarket trading.

headline: For-Profit Colleges Find New Market Niche
text: Kaplan University has an offer for California community college students who cannot get a seat in a class they need: under a memorandum of understanding with the chancellor of the community college system, they can take the online version at Kaplan, with a 42 percent tuition discount.

headline: Notes From the Whaling and Warming Wars
text: I was out on the Hudson River most of Wednesday, watching New York State biologists net, study and release a 120-pound, 80-inch male Atlantic sturgeon (a small one by historic standards) as part of a project tracking what appears to be a slow recovery after a terrible population crash from overfishing. I’ll be filing a post and video report soon, but wanted to note several recent developments around the world related to the focus of this blog (busy times):

headline: Vanguard’s Free E.T.F. Trades a Big Early Hit
text: Vanguard appears to have a hit on its hands. The index mutual fund pioneer is seeing a strong initial response to its offer of commission-free trades in its exchange-traded funds, a fast-growing business where Vanguard is playing catch-up, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Georgia: Witnesses in Murder Case Recant
text: In an unusual hearing ordered by the Supreme Court that began in Savannah on Wednesday, several witnesses said they had concocted testimony that Troy Anthony Davis killed a police officer, Mark MacPhail, in 1989. Last August, the Supreme Court ordered a federal district court to determine if new evidence “clearly establishes” Mr. Davis’s innocence, its first order in an “actual innocence” petition from a state prisoner in nearly 50 years, according to Justice Antonin Scalia, who dissented. Seven of the witnesses who testified against Mr. Davis at his trial have recanted, and some have implicated the chief informer in the case. Mr. Davis’s execution has been stayed three times.

text: The United States team advanced, as did England.

headline: Charles Ensley, Labor Leader and Union Critic, Dies at 69
text: Charles Ensley, who led the union representing New York City social workers for 26 years and was a forceful critic of union corruption, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 69.

headline: On Wall Street, So Much Cash, So Little Time
text: Only on Wall Street, in the rarefied realm of buyout moguls, could you actually have too much money, Julie Creswell writes in The New York Times.

headline: Edith Shain, Who Said Famous Kiss Came Her Way,  Dies at 91
text: Edith Shain, who became something of a celebrity decades after World War II, asserting that she was the nurse kissed by a sailor in Life magazine’s memorable photograph of V-J Day in Times Square, died Sunday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 91.

headline: Fed Leaves Rates Unchanged, Citing Overseas Threats
text: The Federal Reserve‘s policy-making arm said on Wednesday that it had decided to keep short-term interest rates near zero for “an extended period,” citing challenges to economic growth, including the effect of new financial troubles abroad, Christine Hauser reports in The New York Times.

headline: News Quiz | June 24, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Lawmakers at Impasse on Derivatives Trading
text: Derivatives trading, a business long prized by Wall Street but little noticed by anyone else, is rapidly gaining prominence as the rare part of the nation’s vast financial infrastructure that Democrats cannot agree how to regulate, Binyamin Appelbaum reports in The New York Times.

headline: What’s in a Name? Firm Will Find Out
text: The architecture firm Polshek Partnership, which is responsible for the renovations of Carnegie Hall, the Brooklyn Museum, City Center and the Public Theater, will from now on call itself Ennead, the firm is to announce on Thursday. The name, pronounced EN-ee-add, is a Greek term for a group of nine deities in Egyptian mythology and reflects the firm’s reconfiguration as a collective of nine partners. James Polshek, who has been at the firm for 55 years, said he was comfortable with the change. “This is what has to happen if you’re going to pass the torch in a creative way,” he said in a telephone interview. “That’s what I wanted to do.” The firm also announced the creation of Ennead Lab, a private foundation dedicated to research, education and advocacy. Mr. Polshek, 80, left the partnership five years ago and became design counsel to the office, a title he will retain. “I will continue working,” he said. “I have a lot of years left in me.” What happens to the name if the number of partners grows or decreases? “It’s the name of the moment,” Mr. Polshek said. “Maybe they’ll remove three gods or add two more gods, or whatever.” He added, “Certainly, my name is always going to be associated with this office. It will be whispered, not spoken out loud.”

headline: Drake’s Debut Album Tops Charts
text: With impressive sales of his debut album, the rapper Drake, below, leads a wavelet of releases on the Billboard album chart. Drake’s “Thank Me Later” (Aspire/Young Money/Cash Money) sold 447,000 copies in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan. It was the third biggest opening week of the year, after Sade (502,000) and Lady Antebellum (481,000). “Mojo” (Reprise), the first album in eight years by Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers, is No. 2 with 125,000, and Sarah McLachlan’s new “Laws of Illusion” (Arista) opened third with 94,000. The 34th volume of “Now That’s What I Call Music!” is No. 4 with 88,000 sold; Billboard reports that it is the first time in that series’ 12-year history in the United States that a new volume has opened with fewer than 100,000 in sales. Also on this week’s chart, Jack Johnson’s “To the Sea” (Brushfire) falls one spot to No. 5 in its third week out, with 68,000 sold, and the soundtrack to “The Twilight Saga: Eclipse” (Chop Shop/Atlantic) fell four spots to No. 6, with 55,000.

headline: Jackson Estate Sued Over Song Rights
text: A Broadway producer seeking to create a musical from Michael Jackson’s songs is suing the singer’s estate in an effort to force the executors to provide the rights to “Thriller,” “Beat It” and other hit songs and also to bar the estate from licensing song rights to another party for use in a stage show. The lawsuit, filed by Nederlander Presentations last Thursday in Los Angeles County Superior Court, came two months after the Jackson estate announced a deal with Cirque du Soleil, the acrobatic-theater company, to create two shows based on Jackson’s music. Whether the lawsuit is a direct response to the Cirque deal is unclear: James Nederlander Jr., who is pursuing the court action, declined to comment through a spokesman. A lawyer for the Jackson estate, Howard Weitzman, said in a telephone interview on Tuesday that the Cirque deal had no bearing on the Nederlander musical project because Cirque shows “are not musicals but rather big arena, circuslike spectaculars.” In 2008 Nederlander Presentations signed a contract with a production company of Jackson’s, obtaining exclusive rights through October 2011 to develop a musical based on selected Jackson songs, with an option to extend through October 2013. Mr. Nederlander is also seeking songs that Jackson may have written for the musical; the civil suit does not indicate whether he wrote any such compositions.

headline: Wouldn’t It Have Been Nice? No Reunion for Beach Boys
text: God only knows how the idea that Brian Wilson and Mike Love, founding members of the Beach Boys, might team up to commemorate the band’s 50th anniversary, got out there. But the two surf-rock survivors won’t be getting around to that reunion any time soon. After a report last week in The Las Vegas Sun said that Mr. Love and Mr. Wilson were considering writing and recording again, Mr. Love has quashed that possibility. In a statement, Mr. Love said: “The Beach Boys continue to tour approximately 150 shows a year in multiple countries. At this time there are no plans for my cousin Brian to rejoin the tour. He has new solo projects on the horizon and I wish him love and success.” Mr. Wilson, who with his brothers Carl and Dennis, Mr. Love and Al Jardine, formed the Beach Boys in 1961, stopped working with the band in the 1980s, and is currently working on new music based on unfinished compositions by George Gershwin.

headline: Man of Steel Lands on the iPhone
text: DC Comics, the home of Superman, announced two digital publishing and distribution initiatives on Wednesday. The company has teamed up with comiXology to produce a DC Comics App and store for the iPhone, iPod Touch and iPad devices. (Above is a frame from “All-Star Superman.”) Digital versions of DC Comics will also be available on the Sony PlayStation Network and the Comics by comiXology app and Web site (www.comixology.com). The PlayStation platform opens with more than 80 comics and will add more than 50 issues a month, while comiXology begins with more than 100 titles and will add another 100 a month. Despite industry concerns that digital comics could cannibalize sales of their print counterparts, DC will offer new issues of Justice League: Generation Lost, a biweekly series, at the same time (and at the same price) they are available in stores.

headline: ‘Office’ Mates To Publish a First Book
text: Fans of “The Office” know that childhood wasn’t so great for Erin Hannon, the emotionally vulnerable Dunder Mifflin receptionist played by Ellie Kemper. But things worked out better for Ms. Kemper, who not only isn’t an orphan and didn’t grow up in a foster home, but also has a creative younger sister, Carrie, with whom she is about to write a comic novel planned for 2012. On Wednesday the Three Rivers Press imprint of Crown Publishing said it had acquired the book, tentatively titled “Monday Sessions,” in which Ellie and Carrie Kemper chronicle a fictitious Manhattan psychiatrist named Dr. Amy Rice through her diary entries and patient files. Asked in a telephone interview how long she and Carrie had this project up their sleeves, Ellie Kemper said: “Oh my gosh. Well, we’re not sure. We hope that it ends up coming out of our sleeves.” The Kemper siblings are already used to working together at “The Office,” where Carrie recently joined as a staff writer, and occasionally writes lines that emerge from her sister’s mouth. “It’s a great sense of power over her,” Carrie Kemper said. “If she makes one false move, she’s off the show.”

headline: ‘Next Fall’ To Close On July 4
text: The little-show-that-could couldn’t make it on Broadway after all. The producers of the play “Next Fall” said the production would close at the Helen Hayes Theater on July 4, after 26 previews and 132 regular performances. “Next Fall” cost about $2 million to mount, and one of its lead producers, Richard Willis, said the show would close at a total loss to its producers and investors. A comedy-drama by Geoffrey Nauffts about a gay couple starring Patrick Heusinger, above left, and Patrick Breen, right, wrestling with religious differences and interfering family and friends, “Next Fall” was something of a test case for new plays without well-known cast members trying to make a go of it on Broadway. The play received strong reviews from several theater critics, and enjoyed publicity when Elton John and his partner David Furnish signed on as producer-presenters. (Their names were splashed all over advertising materials.) But in the end the audience did not build. The producers had hoped for recognition at the Tony Awards on June 13, but “Next Fall” lost out to another new play, “Red,” for best play and best director of the play, the two categories in which it drew nominations.

headline: America Wants Its ‘Talent’
text: “America’s Got Talent” dominated the ratings on Tuesday as 11.4 million viewers tuned in to this NBC reality series, according to Nielsen’s estimates. NBC led the night over all, outperforming CBS’s lineup of crime show reruns. ABC was third with the season premiere of “Wipeout” (9.5 million). In fourth place, Fox broadcast a two-hour block of “Hell’s Kitchen” (6.1 million).

headline: A Death Wish?
text: Just a quick thought. Round 9 of the Kings Tournament in Romania is underway and Magnus Carlsen of Norway has White against Liviu-Dieter Nisipeanu of Romania. The game, which is live, started 1 e4 e5 2 Nf3 Nc6 3 Bb5 and then Nisipeanu trotted out the Schliemann Defense with 3 … f5. Now maybe Nisipeanu did not want to suffer several hours of the “Spanish Torture,” the nickname for the Ruy Lopez. But playing the Schliemann, which is a bit unsound to begin with, against Carlsen seems a bit like committing harakiri. Maybe he figured he has a puncher’s chance of winning if he just goes in and trades blows. Or maybe he is testing Carlsen’s knowledge. We’ll see.
