Luckily, beauty companies are offering a slew of pigmented yet high-shine shades that flatter us regular folk. Here are some of the best popsicle-colored shades for summer.

headline: World Cup Live: Slovakia vs. Italy
text: Slovakia bounced Italy out of the 2010 World Cup, by a 3-2 score, at Ellis Park in Johannesburg, the biggest shock of the tournament thus far. The Italians are the defending champions, and while it’s difficult to repeat (only Italy in 1934 and 1938 and Brazil in 1958 and 1962 have done so), it’s another thing to go out in the first round. It was a pulsating match, especially the second half. For Slovakia, which led 1-0 at halftime, Robert Vittek scored his second goal in the 73rd minute. The teams then traded goals in the 81st (Antonio DiNatale), 89th (Kamil Kopunek) and 92nd (Fabio Quagliarella). Paraguay and Slovakia qualify from Group F, and will meet their counterparts from Group G in the Round of 16. You can follow the Group E games, Denmark-Japan and Cameroon-Netherlands, here, at 2:30 p.m. Eastern time.

headline: World Cup Live: Paraguay vs. New Zealand
text: Sustaining South American dominance in South Africa, Paraguay edged into the knockout round for the third time in the last four quadrenniums in a tepid, goalless affair in Polokwane that closed down New Zealand’s daydream World Cup.

headline: East Village Pianos and a Hardscrabble Tale
text: Nineteen years old, rail thin, longhaired and topped with a beret, Dylan Meek was anything but. The intensity of his performance seemed to rattle petals off the roses planted beside the piano he played in front of St. Mark’s Church in-the-Bowery, at Second Avenue and 10th Street.

headline: How Do You Recover From 163 Games?
text: The Times will continue to live blog the third day of the  Isner-Mahut  match at Wimbledon, which is tied in the fifth set, 59 games apiece. It is scheduled to restart Thursday sometime after 10:30 a.m., Eastern.

headline: On Our Radar: BP’s New Face
text: Robert Dudley, BP’s new face for the oil spill cleanup effort in the gulf, dives right into controversy, calling criticism of BP a “rush to justice” on his first day on the job. “Time will tell,” if the company should be held responsible for the spill, he tells reporters.

headline: Kyrgyzstan Asks European Security Body for Police Teams
text: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan  Kyrgyzstan’s interim government, which has struggled to control ethnic violence and even apparently its own police and military, has asked the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe to send in an international police force, akin to those deployed in the former Yugoslavia.

headline: OOAN
text: Initialism for “Oval Office Address to the Nation.”

headline: Speed Read for Thursday, June 24
text: Highlights from media coverage in today’s New York Times:

headline: Live Analysis: Isner Wins Marathon Wimbledon Match, 70-68
text: WIMBLEDON, England – John Isner of the United States outlasted Nicolas Mahut of France, 70-68, in the fifth set of their epic three-day first-round match at Wimbledon on Thursday. In an astonishing display of endurance, the players fought for 11 hours and 5 minutes, breaking all records for length of match, games played, and aces served.

headline: Poetry Pairing | June 24, 2010
text: Last week we began a new series called “Poetry Pairings” in which we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation by featuring a poem from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes.

headline: A Zero-Tolerance Fight at a Nursery School
text: The school year for Old First Nursery School in Park Slope, Brooklyn, wraps up on Friday. And for some parents, it will not be a moment too soon.

headline: Supreme Court Finds Fault in Skilling and Black Rulings
text: 2:23 p.m. | Updated The New York Times’s Adam Liptak provides more details on the Supreme Court’s ruling.

headline: Analysis: How Federer Avoided a Fifth Set
text: The fourth-set tie breaker between Roger Federer and Ilija Bozoljac was a microcosm of the entire match. With a vocal following by Serbian expatriates, Bozoljac began the breaker looking to extend the match to a fifth set. A qualifier ranked No. 152 in the world, Bozoljac hits with two hands off both sides, generating tremendous power that forced Federer to defend and counterpunch throughout the match.

headline: Class Action Against Apple and AT&T Is Amended
text: A lawsuit filed on June 9 against Apple and AT&T over the discontinued unlimited-data plan for the iPad 3G has been amended and re-filed to include additional iPad 3G customers.

headline: Thursday Reading: More on Making Local Calls Abroad
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Hasbro Says It Isn’t in Takeover Talks
text: Hasbro, the big toymaker behind the Transformers and G.I. Joe brands, on Thursday denied currently holding any talks to sell the company.

headline: Opening Day: The iPhone 4
I Think It’s the ’80s Now: Tiffany and Debbie Gibson Unite for TV Movie
text: Is it possible that, though the years on the calendar appear to have kept advancing, we have somehow remained stuck in the late 1980s or early ’90s? Consider the evidence: now, as then, our nation is engaged in war in the Middle East, transfixed by an environmental disaster and celebrating a victory by the Los Angeles Lakers over the Boston Celtics. And once again, Tiffany (top) and Debbie Gibson are about to go head-to-head.

headline: The Kindness of Strangers: A Spontaneous ‘Streetcar’ in Chicago
text: Writers Theatre from Ben Thiem on Vimeo.

headline: Imagining a Liberal Court
text: I.THE CRISIS

headline: What We’re Reading: Gaming the Budget Window
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: U.S. Declares Chechen Militant a Terrorist
text: MOSCOW  Russia on Thursday hailed a decision by the United States to designate the Caucasian insurgent leader Doku Umarov a terrorist, a step announced on the eve of President Dmitri A. Medvedev’s visit to the White House.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: YouTube and the Guggenheim
text: On this week’s New York Times Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein looks at a joint project of YouTube and the Guggenheim Museum to find and showcase the latest in video art. She talks to Nancy Spector, deputy director and chief curator of the Guggenheim Foundation, and Ed Sanders, senior marketing manager for YouTube, about how the project evolved and how it will work. Called “YouTube Play: A Biennial of Creative Video,” it’s open to anyone who submits a video by July 31. Up to 20 videos will be displayed at the Guggenheim Museum in New York on Oct. 21, with simultaneous showings at the museum’s other venues, in Bilbao, Berlin and Venice.

headline: Off the Menu: Jezalin’s $39.95 Sandwich
text: Forget about those foie gras and truffle burgers. A ham sandwich has stepped up to the plate, promising to indulge your appetite while wrecking your budget. And it could not be simpler. The single ingredient is that most elite of Spanish hams, jamòn Ibèrico de bellota, from black-footed pigs that rummage in the woods for acorns. At Jezalin’s Gourmet Market, which recently opened in the Limelight Marketplace, at Sixth Avenue and West 20th Street, about a quarter-pound of the nearly mahogany slices, each well-marbled with creamy fat, come piled on a simple crusty baguette for a sandwich that the owner, Michael Tzetzailides, calls Conquistador and for which he charges $39.95. (This ham is priced anywhere from $150 to $250 a pound at various retail outlets.) And there is enough meat in the sandwich for two people to share.

headline: Black and White Dispatches From Bronx Front Lines
text: In the early ’80s, a freelance war photographer named Ángel Franco decided to take breaks from chasing conflicts in Central and South America for a few years to cover the everyday drama of gunplay and arrest near where he grew up the 46th Precinct in the Bronx, a place so violent officers there named it the Alamo. Mr. Franco joined the Times as a staff photographer in 1985. Today, the Lens blog has a show of his early Bronx street work. Read more at Lens.

headline: Fallon: ‘A Nightmare Situation’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: Today, President Obama fired Gen. Stanley McChrystal, saying McChrystal showed poor judgment in his Rolling Stone interview. It turns out when it comes to criticizing the White House, the general’s policy is “just ask, and I’ll tell.”

headline: Ferguson: ‘It’s Called Glastonbury’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: Starting today, there is a huge rock festival in England. It is called Glastonbury. These days, every country has its own music festival. England has Glastonbury. Here, we have Lollapalooza and Coachella. In North Korea, they have the Kim Jong Ill-ith Fair.

headline: Letterman: ‘He Was Trashing Everybody’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: You know about the big change in Afghanistan? General McChrystal did an interview in Rolling Stone and he was talking about how much he didn’t like Joe Biden. He was talking about the administration. He was trashing everybody. So President Obama calls the guy home from Afghanistan, and they had, like, a sit-down in the White House, in the Oval Office, today. It was very, very intimate. It was the president, it was General McChrystal, the Salahis, and that’s it.

headline: Leno: ‘Rethinking Its Boycott’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: General McChrystal was relieved of his duties because of derogatory comments he made about President Obama and other White House staffers. In fact, when he heard that, Joe Biden was shocked and said: “What? You can get fired for saying something stupid? What? When’d they start that? Is that new?”

headline: 9 Policemen Killed in Bombings Around Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  Nine Iraqi police officers were killed during a series of attacks in Mosul and Baghdad late Wednesday and Thursday as the country’s political stalemate dragged on.

headline: Finding Bargains (but Not Alligators) at a Jungle Lodge
text: Four days aboard the Dois Irmãos had left me with a healthy budget surplus of $72 for the rest of the week. And a quirk of geography gave me a tempting way to blow it all. I’d be crossing the Brazil-Bolivian border in the tiny town of Guajará-Mirim. There’s not much there, but it is home to the Pakaás Palafitas Lodge, a legit jungle getaway like the kind you find all around tourist-clogged Manaus but without the clog of tourists. In other words, it has the three elements that make higher-end lodging affordable for even frugal travelers: lack of location, lack of location, and lack of location.

headline: Conviction in Bruno Case Is in Doubt After Ruling
text: A United States Supreme Court decision on Thursday to limit the “honest-services” law under which Joseph L. Bruno, a former New York State Senate majority leader, was found guilty of fraud last year has put his guilty verdict into question.

headline: In Madoff Case, Action Is Mainly Civil, Not Criminal
text: Peter J. Henning follows issues involving securities law and white-collar crime for DealBook’s White Collar Watch.

headline: T Exclusive | Ari Marcopoulos for YSL
text: The photographer and filmmaker Ari Marcopoulos, whose subjects usually include snowboarders, musicians and the like, has set his sights on the tattoo artist Mark Mahoney for his latest documentary, “No Way Back,” to commemorate the launch of the YSL men’s collection in Paris. The Moment has the exclusive video, which will be shown on YSL’s official Web sites starting at midnight, Paris time, on Thursday.

headline: Study Finds Adult Drivers Are the Worst Text Messaging Offenders
text: If you think it is teenagers who are primarily guilty of sending text messages while driving, think again.

headline: 36 Hours in St. Louis
text: ST. LOUIS is more than just a Gateway to the West. The famous arch, of course, is still there, along with plenty of 19th-century architecture and an eye-opening amount of green space. But St. Louis is a lively destination in its own right, full of inviting neighborhoods, some coming out of a long decline and revitalized by public art, varied night life and restaurants that draw on the bounty of surrounding farmland and rivers. Add to that a mix of Midwestern sensibility and Southern charm, and you’ve got a city looking to the future.

headline: A Weekend in St. Louis
text: This lively Missouri city is full of inviting neighborhoods and varied art spaces.

headline: Dear FloFab: My Waiter Joked About My Food Allergies
text: Each Thursday, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

headline: Q&A: Salzburg and Vienna (With Mozart and Beyond)
text: Q.

headline: Sports Illustrated Introduces iPad App
text: Add Sports Illustrated to the magazine app race.

headline: Order and Chaos in a Bustling Cleanup
text: Reporting from Venice, La., and the surrounding marshlands on the shortage of containment booms to defend the gulf coastline against the oil from the spill, my colleague Rob Harris and I got a ground-level feel for the organization of the spill response.

headline: Court Upholds Columbia Campus Expansion Plan
text: Columbia University won a major court victory for its $6.3 billion plan to build a satellite campus in Harlem on Thursday, when New York’s highest court ruled that the state could seize private property for the project.

headline: The Blind Barber
text: Photos of the Blind Barber in the East Village.

headline: Twitter Settles F.T.C. Privacy Case
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Twitter, the rapidly growing Internet messaging service, has settled a Federal Trade Commission investigation into the security and privacy protections it offers its users.

headline: Belgian Police Raid Offices of Church in Abuse Case
text: BRUSSELS  The scandal over sexual abuse of children by priests continued to reverberate across Europe on Thursday when authorities raided the headquarters of the Roman Catholic Church in Belgium and the home of the country’s former archbishop, according to the prosecutors’ office and local media reports.

headline: After Drake Show, More Seaport Concerts Are Canceled
text: UPDATE: South Street Seaport to Relocate Two Concerts

headline: How Divorce Spreads
text: Fascinating stuff from a new study, entitled “Breaking Up is Hard to Do, Unless Everybody Else is Doing It Too”:

headline: A Theoretical Trip, and a New Section of the High Line
text: Get ready to dust off your postmodern theory. It’s time to play Name That Simulacrum!

headline: Diagnosing Alzheimer’s
text: Researchers may have discovered a way to definitively diagnose Alzheimer’s disease in living patients, The Times reports today. If the findings hold up, scientists may have a way to figure out whether drugs are slowing or halting the disease, a step that “will change everyone’s thinking about Alzheimer’s in a dramatic way,” said one expert.

headline: Justices Limit Use of ‘Honest Services’ Law Against Fraud
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Thursday significantly narrowed the scope of a law often used by federal prosecutors in corruption cases and called into question the fraud convictions of Jeffrey K. Skilling, a former chief executive of Enron, and Conrad M. Black, a newspaper executive convicted of defrauding his media company.

headline: Acer Lines ‘Em Up
text: Acer, which is ranked globally as the No. 2 maker of personal computers, is apparently determined, on the sheer force of numbers and volume and SKUs, to make it to No. 1.

headline: Six Questions to Protect Elderly Patients
text: This week, Pam Belluck reported in The Times on the risk that elderly patients may become confused and delirious while in the hospital. Here she offers advice on how to prepare when an elderly patient is headed to surgery or a hospital stay.

headline: Poorer Countries Taking Over Global Economy
text: Ten years ago, the world’s richest countries accounted for a significant majority of the globe’s economic activity. But the pendulum is swinging in the other direction, according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

headline: ZelnickMedia Acquires Firm Behind ‘Gossip Girl’
text: Alloy, the teenager-focused media company behind the “Gossip Girl” franchise, is being acquired by an investor group led by the private equity firm ZelnickMedia for approximately $126.5 million.

headline: Children and Genetic Tests
text: We live in a scientific moment between promise and certainty. We stand at a point where genetic tests can predict some diseases that can’t be cured, leaving parents like Jessica Apple wondering whether a little more knowledge is a dangerous thing.

headline: Wachovia’s Policy on Foreign A.T.M. Transactions
text: If you forget to call Wachovia before traveling out of the country, will your debit card be  automatically denied if you use an A.T.M. abroad?

headline: Theater Talkback: When Stars Take Over the Tonys
text: Hunter Foster is hopping mad. The baby-faced, big-voiced Broadway performer currently appearing in “Million Dollar Quartet” has ignited a Facebook firestorm — well, started a Facebook page anyway — with a clarion call to scrub the Tony Awards free of the creeping mold of celebrity. Shortly after this year’s unusually star-glutted and star-friendly awards telecast, Mr. Foster posted a page called “Give the Tonys Back to Broadway” on the social networking site. The group had more than 8,000 members at last count.

headline: Germany, Not France, Delights in Multicultural World Cup Squad
text: That a German player named Mesut Özil scored the goal that sent his nation through to the second round of this year’s World Cup is a sign that something fundamental has changed about what it means to be German. A country which, until quite recently, refused to give citizenship even to the German-born children of immigrants now finds itself represented by a squad of 23 players so ethnically diverse that 11 of them could have chosen to play instead for other nations.

headline: World Cup Live: Denmark vs. Japan
text: Data by Match Analysis

headline: Hemingway’s Catch
text: Paul Greenberg has a terrific article in this Sunday’s Times Magazine about the end of the bluefin tuna.

headline: Opera Orchestra of New York Stages a Comeback
text: The Opera Orchestra of New York, a small but beloved institution for fans of off-beat repertory and big voices, is staging something of a comeback. The company said Thursday it would end its financially induced hiatus and mount two concert productions next season: Meyerbeer’s “L’Africaine,”and a double bill of Massenet’s “La Navarraise”  and Mascagni’s “Cavalleria Rusticana.”

headline: TimesCast | June 24, 2010
text: In today's Timescast, reports on General Petraeus as he takes on a 'Tougher Fight', the Supreme Court sides with an Enron defendant and the economic divide in South Africa.

headline: Seeing Things | Turning the Tables
text: If you happen to visit U.C.L.A.’s campus this summer, take a detour through the courtyard of Schoenberg Hall, which is home to the university’s Herb Alpert School of Music. There, Ball-Nogues Studio, an enterprising young Los Angeles architecture practice, has created “Table Cloth,” a site-specific installation that is on view through the summer. In a play on its name, “Table Cloth” doesn’t cover a table, but rather is a cover that is made of tables. Hundreds of them.

headline: John Burns and Dexter Filkins Answer Questions on McChrystal’s Dismissal
text: If anybody doubted that President Obama’s decision to fire Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal was a watershed moment — not only in the war in Afghanistan, but in the history of that fundamental principle of the American republic, civil control of the military — Times readers have given their own judgment, with a wave of responses that have come in to the paper’s Web site over the past 24 hours.

headline: A Large Audience for ‘Catch’ Episode About Captain’s Stroke
text: Interest in the death of the Capt. Phil Harris propelled “Deadliest Catch” to its highest ratings ever, the Discovery Channel said Wednesday.

headline: Homeless Organization Is Shut Down
text: Updated 6:18 p.m. | The United Homeless Organization, whose clear plastic jugs and solicitations to fill them with pennies have long been a common sight in New York, has been permanently shuttered.

headline: Tibetan Environmentalist Receives 15-Year Sentence
text: BEIJING  A prominent Tibetan businessman and philanthropist who was lauded by Chinese officials for his environmental work has been sentenced to 15 years in prison on charges that he traded in looted relics more than a decade ago, his lawyer said Thursday night.

headline: At the Blind Barber, a Haircut and a Drink
text: With all the high-minded attention these days to which drinks suit which foods, a set of more pressing, fundamental questions about proper pairings gets lost. Does bourbon, vodka or quite possibly grain alcohol go best with a mullet, and what’s the right tonic for a buzz cut?

headline: Jamaican to Face Charges in New York
text: MEXICO CITY  Christopher Coke, a reputed gang leader from Jamaica accused of running a major smuggling operation of drugs and guns in the United States, arrived in New York on Thursday evening after waiving his right to an extradition hearing in Jamaican courts.

headline: iPhone 4 Q&A
text: Wow, what a couple of days! The annual release of a new iPhone always seems to whip my readership into an emotional frenzy. All that hope, all that hype, all those religious warriors bent on disparaging people who choose other phones! Can't we all just get along?

headline: Battle Company: Loving Life, Making War
text: “Restrepo,” a documentary that sticks close to a company of American soldiers during a grueling 14-month tour of duty in an especially dangerous part of Afghanistan, is an impressive, even heroic feat of journalism. Not that the filmmakers  Sebastian Junger, an adventurous reporter perhaps best known as the author of “The Perfect Storm,” and Tim Hetherington, a photographer with extensive experience in war zones  call attention to their own bravery. They stay behind the portable high- and standard-definition video cameras, nimble flies on a wall that is exposed to a steady barrage of bullets.

headline: Mannequins Take to the Streets to Help Garment District
text: Thirty-two designers are participating in a public art exhibition that opened on Broadway in Manhattan’s garment district on Thursday, which, in essence, is the fashion version of those cow statues that plastered New York a decade ago.

headline: World Cup Live: Cameroon vs. Netherlands
text: The Netherlands wrapped up Group E play with a 2-1 win over Cameroon in Cape Town this afternoon. The victory gave the Dutch maximum points from its three group games, and sets them up for a round of 16 clash with surprise qualifier Slovakia on Monday.

headline: A Coach and a Player, Reunited
text: There was a sweet moment early in the first set against the Williams sisters, when Julie Ditty huddled briefly with her partner Renata Yurocova. Down by 15-30, Ditty knew that an early break against the best doubles team in the world could spell disaster. She gathered herself, bounced the ball three times on the fresh grass at the baseline as part of her ritual, then hit a wicked lefty slice that Venus couldn’t touch. Ace.

headline: Cue the Choir: A High School Experience Ends With One Last Performance
text: I never imagined that my last lap of high school would be so rigorous, but that made graduating all the more rewarding.

headline: Indians, Envious of U.S. Spill Response, Seethe Over Bhopal
text: NEW DELHI  The contrast between the disasters, more than a quarter-century and half a world apart, could not be starker.

headline: Are Antarctic Crustaceans in Peril?
text: As I wrote in The Times on Wednesday, the Marine Stewardship Council has come under fire for certifying as ‘‘sustainable’’ the Antarctic krill of AkerBiomarine, a Norwegian company that turns the tiny crustaceans into omega-3 dietary supplements and feed for farmed fish such as salmon.

headline: Now Opening | The Standard’s Stairway to Heaven
text: With rooftop bars popping up across the city skyline with dizzying frequency this summer, none has managed to stir up more getting-on-the-list finagling than Le Bain at the Standard Hotel, where the 18th floor lounge (informally known as the Boom Boom Room) was already considered the ultimate velvet rope to cross even before it had an open-air addition.

headline: Hatch Says He Has Qualms About Kagan
text: Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the Utah Republican, voiced a heavy dose of skepticism about Elena Kagan’s nomination to the Supreme Court on Thursday, indicating that he had concerns she would take what he called an “activist judicial philosophy” to the court.

headline: TimesCast: A New Leader in Afghanistan
text: On the latest edition of TimesCast, Helene Cooper, a White House reporter with The Times, discusses the political risks of President Obama’s decision to fire Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal as his top Afghanistan war commander

headline: Henry James Walked Here
text: IT was love at first sight. Henry James was 26 when he crossed the border from Switzerland and made his way, on foot, down into Italy  “warm & living & palpable,” as he wrote ecstatically to his sister on Aug. 31, 1869. The romance kindled that day lasted nearly 40 years, and played a significant part in his career; he set some of his greatest works in Italy, including “Daisy Miller,” “The Aspern Papers” and “The Wings of the Dove.”

headline: Tuscany and Umbria as Henry James Knew Them
text: An 1874 essay by the author Henry James can be used as a modern guide to Italy.

headline: Trial of Iran’s ‘Blogfather’ Begins in Tehran
text: More than a year and a half after he was arrested in Tehran, Hossein Derakhshan, an influential Iranian-Canadian blogger also known as Hoder, was put on trial on Wednesday, according to Iranian news reports and statements by his family posted online.

headline: In Turkey, Sunlight and Enlightenment
text: TO find the Kabak Valley, drive east along Turkey’s Mediterranean coast. Park your car when the pavement runs out, and walk (or hitch a ride on a truck) to a portal to another dimension.

headline: On the Trail of Hansel and Gretel in Germany
text: ONCE upon a time — about 200 years ago to be more precise — there were two brothers, Wilhelm and Jacob Grimm, who lived in the Kingdom of Hesse, now part of Germany. They loved fairy tales and set about collecting and publishing them — to the delight of readers around the world, young and old, forever after.

headline: Judge Won’t Stay Drilling Decision
text: The Obama administration’s efforts to suspend deepwater oil drilling were dealt another setback in court on Thursday when the federal judge who struck down the administration’s six-month moratorium refused to delay the decision’s effects. .

headline: An All-Japanese Mash-Up
text: THOUGH the Japantown area of San Francisco has remained largely static since the 1970s — stretches of concrete, blocky mini-malls and lots of sushi restaurants — a new wave of Japanese popular culture, from monster movies to Lolita dresses, has hit the area, thanks to the recent arrival of New People, a five-level, glass-walled, 20,000-square-foot shrine to all things Japanese.

headline: Hotel Review: The Louis Hotel in Munich
text: THE BASICS

headline: Store Review: Azaad Bazaar in Mumbai, India
text: Nestled in the heart of a chic shopping district in Bandra, the Azaad Bazaar is part store and part clubhouse, just the place to pick up that handmade rainbow lampshade, check the bulletin board for coming parties and, if you’re lucky, drink a cup of chai with the shop’s owners.

headline: No Way Back
text: Mr. Marcopoulos's latest documentary features the tattoo artist Mark Mahoney.

headline: Can You Die of Insomnia?
text: Lack of sleep can make getting through the day a challenge and is increasingly tied to a host of medical problems. But can insomnia actually prove fatal? That was among the hundreds of questions recently posed by readers of the Consults blog at “Ask an Expert: Overcoming Insomnia.”

headline: ‘Edward Scissorhands’ Gets a Stage Debut but No Burton-Size Budget
text: As befits a fractured fairy tale about a man with blades for fingers, the stage version of “Edward Scissorhands” that will open on Friday at the Bayard Studio Theater in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is going to be cut down a bit from the original film.

headline: ZelnickMedia to Buy Company Behind ‘Gossip Girl’
text: From Brian Stelter at Media Decoder:

headline: Bipartisan Introduction of Kagan Planned
text: Elena Kagan will get a bipartisan introduction when she appears before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Monday for the start of her confirmation hearings.

headline: A Blockbuster’s Paean to Pontiac Power
text: June Havens, as portrayed by Cameron Diaz in the movie “Knight and Day,” is a tomboy tuner with a passion for Pontiacs. The character Ms. Diaz plays is also well-versed in the lore of Pontiac power plants, and apparently so too is the film’s director, James Mangold.

headline: With iOS 4, New Features for Old iPhones
text: People purchasing the new iPhone 4 are not the only ones getting something new.

headline: Young Writers Fill-In
text: Fill in the missing words in this essay from the Sunday Book Review about young authors.

headline: When East 70th Street Was Horse Heaven
text: THE rich are different, said F. Scott Fitzgerald, but Ernest Hemingway could have told him that they, too, want a good parking spot. So although East 70th Street is known for its capacious mansions, one block has private stables to match.

headline: Italy Coach Blames Himself for Early Exit
text: JOHANNESBURG  Like a car on a frigid morning, Italy always seemed to need time for its engine to turn over at the World Cup.

headline: Creating Your Own Version of a 401(k)
text: As a freelancer, I no longer have an employer-sponsored 401(k) and the benefits attached to it, like automatic contributions and contribution matching.

headline: Prawn-ography
text: Actress Tilda Swinton’s description of a lustful food scene in the movie “I am Love.”

headline: Photo of the Week
text: Children play with bubbles at the Glastonbury Festival 2010, in England.

headline: Just a Couple of Guys Grabbing Burgers
text: So what is it with Ray’s Hell Burger? Could it be winning the White House Burger Battle?

headline: Nature, Up Close and Personal
text: Summer, which can be hard in the city, could be heaven to the painter Charles Burchfield, the 20th-century mystic of American light. Because he spent most of his time in a leafy suburb of Buffalo, to him the season meant trees aureoled in noonday sunshine, afterglow skies as cool as the song of a thrush and gardens pulsing with the music of crickets in moonlight.

headline: ‘The Paintings of Charles Burchfield’
text: Images from a new exhibit at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

headline: A Parade by Any Other Name Moves to the Sidewalks
text: Updated June 25 | There has been much talk and some consternation about the shortening of parades in New York this year, a product of the city’s budget constraints.

headline: The Morning Meeting
text: A peek inside the daily session in which leaders of the spill cleanup in Venice, La., develop a constantly evolving approach to fighting back the oil spreading along the Gulf Coast.

headline: Someone to Watch Over Me
text: A few years ago after learning of the death of a favorite teacher, a friend from surgical training and I began exchanging e-mail messages reminiscing about the man we once alternately referred to as “the Silver Fox” because of his dapper looks and “Chuckles” because of his easygoing manner. Dr. M was well known in the hospital for his elegant surgical technique and deep respect for patients as individuals. But what my friend, Dennis, and I, and the other doctors-in-training cherished most was his uncanny ability to recognize exactly how much we residents could and couldn’t do. Or, perhaps more aptly, how much he should and shouldn’t do when teaching us.

headline: New Supervision Rules for New Doctors
text: For nearly a decade now, the effort to reform doctors’ training has been focused almost exclusively on the number of hours spent at the hospital. But new rules released Wednesday go a step further, focusing on the supervision of doctors in training, writes Dr. Pauline Chen in the latest Doctor and Patient column.

headline: Now Showing | The YSL Retrospective
text: I recently had a chance to catch the Yves Saint Laurent retrospective in Paris, a tour through over 40 years and 300 creations from one of the 20th century’s greatest designers. While certainly familiar with his groundbreaking “Le Smoking,” an alternative to the little black dress based on a man’s tuxedo, I was struck by how consistently he drew from the world of men’s wear.

headline: Isner Wins Match That Wouldn’t End
text: WIMBLEDON, England — The final tally looked impossible, like a misprint or a joke. The numbers sat there on the scoreboard — 6-4, 3-6, 6-7 (9), 7-6 (3), 70-68 — daring those gathered around Court 18 at Wimbledon to believe they were authentic.

headline: Congress Fails to Pass an Extension of Jobless Aid
text: WASHINGTON — Legislation to extend unemployment subsidies for hundreds of thousands of Americans who have exhausted their jobless benefits teetered on the edge of collapse on Thursday, as Senate Democrats and Republicans traded bitter accusations about who was to blame for an eight-week impasse.

headline: No Break for Meek, or Actress on the Run
text: In March, Jonathan Reynolds took aim at abortion-rights politics in “Girls in Trouble.” Three months later Andrew Dinwiddie respectfully recreated a culture war sermon by Jimmy Swaggart in “Get Mad at Sin!” And to complete this unofficial conservative trilogy in small-scale theater, Americas Off Broadway presents the New York premiere of “Ideal,” a 1934 philosophical murder mystery by none other than Ayn Rand.

headline: Climate 411
text: When I was starting out in science journalism in the early 1980s, a writer had three choices to begin reporting a story. You could go to your publication’s wall of dusty encyclopedias of professional and scientific associations, phone directories and other reference tomes lining the walls (in my case, at Science Digest magazine). You could raid a more experienced colleague’s Rolodex. Or you could call the Scientists Institute for Public Information, S.I.P.I, a nonprofit group founded in 1963 and mainly paid for by media companies and foundations to provide, in essence, directory assistance for journalists seeking scientists.

headline: Carlsen Secures at Least a Tie for First at Kings Tournament
text: All the games were drawn in Round 9 on Thursday, assuring Magnus Carlsen, the top seed, of at least a share of the title heading into Friday’s final games.

headline: Nature Had Other Plans at the Naumburg Bandshell
text: It takes more than a little rain to chase away an audience of tenacious New York classical music lovers, a point proved when the first drops started to fall just before a concert by the Knights, a stylish, adventurous young chamber orchestra, at the Naumburg Bandshell in Central Park on Tuesday evening. The concert, presented by Naumburg Orchestral Concerts as the first event of its 105th season, drew what appeared to be hundreds of aficionados and curiosity seekers.

headline: Will Obama’s Small-Business Agenda Survive Congress?
text: It was late October when President Obama first called for measures to stabilize struggling small businesses. Then, in his State of the Union address in January, he emphasized the role small business would play in healing the nation’s wounded economy. But it is only now, eight months after that speech, that Congress finally seems ready to act. And the House and Senate are so far apart that it is not clear that they will be able to agree on a bill that contains more than just a few of the president’s ideas.

headline: Feliciano Steps In for Pagan
text: The Mets’ lineup for Thursday’s series finale against the Tigers has been posted and, as expected, Angel Pagan is not in it.

headline: Sometimes That Inner Demon Just Needs to Win
text: David Byrne in “Psycho Killer” could be speaking for Tom Blander when he sings, “I hate people when they’re not polite.” The lyric seems tailor-made for the ironically named philosopher-turned-cannibal in “Order,” Christopher Stetson Boal’s deliciously nasty little horror comedy, running at Theater Row.

headline: In Whaling Wars, Resources vs. ‘Beings’
text: High-stakes international negotiations in Morocco over the future of whaling collapsed this week, with anti-whaling nations like Argentina unwilling to accept compromise proposals that Japan reduce, but not eliminate, its killing of whales in Antarctic and Pacific waters.

headline: In Queens, Dismantling a Monument to Floral Excess
text: Residents of Forest Hills Gardens thought this day would never come.

headline: Dickey’s Knuckleball Seeking a New Target
text: R.A. Dickey continues to provide the Mets with one of the most delightful surprises of the season, extending his record to 6-0 after eight masterly innings against the Tigers in the Mets’ 5-0 victory at Citi Field on Wednesday night.

headline: Cocktail Recipe: Sour Cherry Gin Muddler
text: Melissa Clark (@goodappetite) writes A Good Appetite for the dining section.

headline: Antiques Beach Reading (Yes, That’s Right)
text: ANTIQUES BEACH READING

headline: Galea’s Aide Pleads Guilty; Helping With Investigation
text: BUFFALO  The assistant to Anthony Galea, the Canadian doctor accused of smuggling human growth hormone and other banned substances into the United States, pleaded guilty in federal court Thursday to making false statements to border authorities.

headline: May Orders in Durables Fell Slightly
text: New orders for durable goods fell slightly in May, but the overall trend shows that spending by consumers and businesses has improved from last year, according to government figures.

headline: Leaving Vietnam and Readers’ Questions
text: Friday, June 18

headline: Popcast: The Roots, Nina Nastasia and More
text: The Roots, long one of the best — and only — live acts in hip-hop, have been the house band on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” for more than a year now. How has playing on television every night affected its music?

headline: Local Stop: Brighton Beach
text: Known as Little Odessa, the neighborhood offers an urban seaside feel, with a Russian accent.

headline: Resort Report | Akris in Capri
text: Albert Kriemler of Akris was yet another designer with Brigitte Bardot on the brain! He was inspired by her role in Jean Luc Godard’s 1963 film, “Contempt,” specifically the parts set in Capri. This translated into twin sets with clear crystals on the shoulders, wide leg pants in white but also in a strong shade of orange and a few different photo prints of cafe life and the boardwalk in Capri. No matter the season, it’s always very sophisticated at Akris, and this resort collection was definitely that.

headline: Streetwise New Yorkers Caught in Their Unguarded Moments
text: If you wanted to assemble a compendium of street photography clichés, you could simplify the task by picking from “Hipsters, Hustlers and Handball Players: Leon Levinstein’s New York Photographs, 1950-80” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Punk Fans Find a Home in Brooklyn
text: IF there were such a thing as a punk-rock festival checklist, an event taking place in downtown Brooklyn this weekend would cross off all the items. Seminal band? Check. Accompanying skate park? Check. Vendors offering the latest gear? Check.

headline: An Air of Russia and Ocean Breezes
text: What do travelers get for a subway swipe these days? At the end of the B and Q lines in Brighton Beach, they get ocean views and homemade pirozhki, a great toy store and hand-knit woolens sold on the street. And while the strip is famous for its post-Soviet explosion of cheap stuff, there is also quality amid the quantity, as well as friendly people chatting in Russian, and waves tickling the shore.

headline: ‘A Day Like Any Other’
text: Images from the Rivane Neuenschwander exhibition at the New Museum.

headline: Curry’s Option Now May Give Knicks Options Later
text: In a move that should come as a surprise to no one, Knicks center Eddy Curry has exercised his contract option for the 2010-11 season. Curry locks in $11,276,863 in guaranteed salary by electing to forgo free agency and remain with the Knicks for another year. He had until June 30 to decide whether to opt in or out.

headline: Violence Expert Visits Her Dark Past
text: Jessica Stern is among the world’s experts on violence and evil, a woman who spends her time thinking about bad men and bad deeds. She has lectured at Harvard about terrorism and is the author of a respected book, “Terror in the Name of God: Why Religious Militants Kill” (2003). During the Clinton administration she was on the staff of the National Security Council. She presents herself as hard, no-nonsense, buttoned up. She is certainly possessed of the perfect surname. “If the plane goes down,” she writes in  “Denial,”  her new memoir, “you want me at the controls.”

headline: Flirtatious Bunch, Instigating Playful Adventures
text: BECKET, Mass.  Prima ballerinas know how to work a crowd, sweeping their arms and eyes up and out as if to embrace the farthest reaches of cavernous theaters. So it was on Wednesday at the Ted Shawn Theater here, when Nina Ananiashvili warmly acknowledged her public on opening night at the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival.

headline: A Peek Into the World of Nadal and the Upset That Wasn’t
text: “Routine is a condition for survival,” wrote Flannery O’Connor, and Rafael Nadal would certainly agree. With a difficult second-round match looming against Robin Haase of the Netherlands, Nadal declined an invitation to meet the Queen of England. Asked why he passed up the chance to meet Her Majesty, who was making her first trip to Wimbledon since 1977, Nadal explained that Haase was a difficult opponent and, “I have my routines.”

headline: South Street Seaport to Relocate Two Concerts
text: In response to reports that some concerts at South Street Seaport had been canceled as a result of the melee at a free Drake show there last week, the Seaport and Paper magazine, which presented the Drake event, say the concerts will still take place, but not at the Seaport.

headline: Pulling Up a Chair With the Great Vin Scully
text: The other night, driving home on the Merritt Parkway after a game at Yankee Stadium, I listened to a tape of a 30-year-old World Series broadcast from CBS Radio. It was a one-run game in the bottom of the ninth inning, with two out and the bases loaded. The broadcaster cut through the tension with enthusiasm.

headline: Italy Was the Old Man of Europe
text: Johannesburg

headline: In Defense of Student Evaluations
text: Stanley Fish inveighs against the practice of asking students to assess the quality of their professors’ teaching:

headline: Leader of the Opposition
text: The Israeli security cabinet just voted to ease the three-year blockade on Gaza, in the wake of the tragic naval attack on the Mavi Marmara by Israeli commandos. What does that mean in practical terms?  I’ve heard that the cabinet changed the list to allow more goods to enter. There shouldn’t be any limitations on food, but things that can be used for terror cannot be permitted. The reason for the blockade on Gaza was not to punish the Palestinians but to continue to delegitimize Hamas. There is no hope for peace with Hamas, and we need to continue the peace process with the legitimate Palestinian government.

headline: Finding Marriage Without Losing a Self
text: WHEN I met Scott, I was somewhere between the before and after picture  in a no man’s land called cosmetology school. We went on our first date on a balmy night in the early fall of 2003. I had met him the week before at a bowling party and he’d asked me what I did.

headline: Subprime Case Costs Morgan Stanley $102 Million
text: Morgan Stanley agreed Thursday to pay $102 million to end an investigation in Massachusetts into unfair lending practices, Reuters reports.

headline: Art on Your Sleeve
text: Uniqlo’s UT project was conceived as a futuristic convenience store for T-shirts, with some 1,000 new styles added every year. But as the cast of contributors to the collection has grown — Nobuyoshi Araki, Terry Richardson and Peter Saville have all teed up — UT has come to seem more like Gagosian-to-Go than Kwik-E-Mart. The latest series, “A Function of Forms,” is curated by the photography writer Ken Miller along with Gallery Target in Tokyo and features black and white images by the likes of Daido Moriyama, Lee Friedlander, Linus Bill and Peter Sutherland.

headline: Kids Books Today
text: From the perspective of one Christian reader, the trouble with young adult books is that they’re tawdry and dangerous:

headline: From Pentagon, Messages of Dismay and Support
text: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates and Adm. Mike Mullen, who had sponsored Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal as commander in Afghanistan, expressed profound disappointment in his judgment on Thursday  tempered with thanks for his years in combat  after he was fired from the post. The dismissal followed publication of a profile of the four-star general in Rolling Stone that quoted him and his aides disparaging other officials.

headline: Advances in Oil Spill Cleanup Lag Since Valdez
text: Two decades after the Exxon Valdez oil spill, cleanup technology has progressed so little that the biggest advancement in the Gulf of Mexico disaster  at least in the public’s mind  is an oil-water separator based on a 17-year-old patent and promoted by the movie star Kevin Costner.

headline: Clear the Aisle
text: At our upcoming wedding, my fiancé and I would like to honor our families by having our parents and siblings walk down the aisle before us. I have four siblings, and he has one, plus a cousin he considers a brother. So that’s four for me and two for him. He’s been making a big fuss that things are not “balanced.” He wants me to eliminate two of my siblings, or add a couple of his friends. I’m flabbergasted! The whole idea is to honor family. What am I missing here?

headline: Brooklyn Diocese Seeks Sainthood for Priest Who Fought Bigotry
text: Brooklyn, the borough of churches and trees, Walt Whitman and Woody Allen, Barbra Streisand and Mike Tyson, has never lacked for people of distinction — except perhaps in one category.

headline: Solemn, Strange and Demanding Sounds
text: In September Alan Gilbert made a statement about his artistic priorities by opening his first program as music director of the New York Philharmonic with the premiere of a work by the Finnish composer Magnus Lindberg, the orchestra’s newly appointed composer in residence. So it was fitting, and another indication of Mr. Gilbert’s vision, that on Wednesday night he began the final program of the season with another Lindberg premiere, the 25-minute single-movement “Al largo,” a lushly colorful, brilliantly orchestrated, teeming, intriguing yet baffling work.

headline: Douglas Manor, Queens, 2:45 P.M.
text: Storms swept through northern Queens Thursday afternoon, knocking trees onto utility lines and cutting power to 2,300 Con Edison customers. “I looked up and it was like a swirling water fountain,” said Fred Ganzer, 71, above. “All white, with branches and water just going around in a circle, upwards.”

headline: An Air of Russia Mixes With Ocean Breezes
text: What do travelers get for a subway swipe these days? At the end of the B and Q lines in Brighton Beach, they get ocean views and homemade pirozhki, a great toy store and hand-knit woolens sold on the street. And while the strip is famous for its post-Soviet explosion of cheap stuff, there is also quality amid the quantity, as well as friendly people chatting in Russian, and waves tickling the shore.

headline: Officers Return Fire, Killing Man in the Bronx
text: Police officers killed a man who opened fire on them as they searched for drugs at a Hunts Point apartment in the Bronx on Thursday, the authorities said.

headline: Supreme Court Rolls Back a Law Born of Enron
text: The timing is exquisite. First the Supreme Court of the United States provided a significant legal victory to the mastermind behind one of the greatest corporate frauds in American history. Next the court may throw out the law that Congress passed to reform corporate America  a law inspired by that very fraud.

headline: A Different Horse Show in the Hamptons
text: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y.  “Equus” rides again at the John Drew Theater at Guild Hall here this summer. Clip-clip, clip-clop, whinny-whinny  oops! Be careful where you step in those Gucci flip-flops.

headline: Conference Panel on Finance Makes Little Progress
text: WASHINGTON  Like procrastinating college students facing an approaching term-paper deadline, House and Senate negotiators on Thursday dawdled through much of what was supposed to be their final day of meetings trying to reconcile competing versions of a financial regulatory bill.

headline: Phil Collins Returns to His Old Hometown, Motown-Upon-Thames
text: In its 1960s prime Motown Records rightfully called its hits “the sound of young America.” Nowadays those songs are the sound of aging British rockers’ nostalgia. Rod Stewart (last year, with the soulless “Soulbook”) and now Phil Collins have recorded album-length soul tributes, recreating old arrangements. The songs remain surefire, as perfectly wrought and indelible as anything in pop history. But the singer makes a crucial difference, and not always for the better.

headline: ‘Big Brother’ or ‘Big Sister?’ This College May Discount Your Tuition
text: Participating in Big Brothers Big Sisters can be emotionally rewarding, but at Marist College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., that experience is about to become financially rewarding, too.

headline: Murkiness of Youth, in Spotlight Once Again
text: The jazz guitarist Kurt Rosenwinkel prizes ethereality and control in his music, but that doesn’t mean he shies away from the unruly or the unknown. His career as a bandleader has involved searching as well as refinement, even when he worked within a tradition, as on “Reflections” (Word of Mouth), a standards album released last year. This week at the Village Vanguard he’s applying the feathery grace of that recording to a murkier, more elusive batch of songs, some new and others dredged from history, including his own.

headline: Star-Crossed, Tamed or Tragic: A Tour of Shakespeare’s Heroines
text: LENOX, Mass.  Because Shakespeare’s Juliet is so irresistibly star-crossed, love-drunk and young, people tend to forget just how intelligent she is. Not Tina Packer. Portraying the female half of tragedy’s most popular double-suicide act, at the Founders’ Theater of Shakespeare & Company here, Ms. Packer glows with the energy of a quick, bright mind discovering  and enjoying  itself.

headline: On the Boards, Out of Town
text: Productions mentioned in the accompanying reviews:

headline: An Ace on the Slopes Has an Ace on the Links
text: I can’t think of any two athletic achievements that have less in common than a hole in one and an Olympic gold medal. One takes seconds, is launched on a whim and involves some luck, while the other usually represents a lifetime of hard work realized in a superior triumph under unrelenting pressure.

headline: House Tour: Athens, N.Y.
text: WHAT Three-bedroom, 2,000-square-foot house

headline: Genre Fair
text: Images from movies in the New York Asian Film Festival.

headline: Obama and Medvedev Talk Economics
text: WASHINGTON  With recent accords on national security behind them, President Obama and President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia engaged in a bit of economic summitry on Thursday, with Mr. Obama pushing for more exports to Russia and Mr. Medvedev seeking more American business investment, especially in technology.

headline: Festival Moves to Fancier Base but Keeps Its Genre-Bending Fare
text: The New York Asian Film Festival has been waving the fan-boy flag proudly since 2002. Glossy crime dramas and horror shows, martial-arts spectaculars, machine-gun-wielding schoolgirls  “the kind of crazed, populist blockbusters that we were born to show,” in the words of Grady Hendrix, one of the festival’s founders  have led the way, as the series, which started with just 11 movies at the Anthology Film Archives, has grown to 45 films and moved to the uptown precincts of Lincoln Center’s Walter Reade Theater.

headline: Lawmakers Wrangle Over Derivatives Rules
text: House and Senate negotiators scrambled all day on Thursday to reach final agreement on how to regulate derivatives and whether to impose restrictions on the ability of banks to trade for their own benefit, Edward Wyatt of The New York Times reports from Washington.

headline: Artist Lofts Hit the Market
text: In the Land of Lofts

headline: A Garden Crawl Through the Garden State
text: NEW JERSEY is the Garden State, but that nickname wasn’t always so secure. Unofficially, it dates to at least 1876, when Abraham Browning of Camden likened “our Garden State” to “an immense barrel, filled with good things to eat and open at both ends, with Pennsylvanians grabbing from one end and New Yorkers from the other.” But in 1954, when the State Legislature voted to add the moniker to license plates, Governor Robert B. Meyner vetoed the measure, saying, “I do not believe that the average citizen of New Jersey regards his state as more peculiarly identifiable with gardening for farming than any of its other industries or occupations.” He was overruled.

headline: Inspired by Wishes, Memories, Dirty Shoes
text: What do you wish for? In Rivane Neuenschwander’s first museum survey, you can write the wish on a piece of paper and perform a ritual to make it come true. You can also, if you like, work with a police sketch artist to recall the face of your first love. This is Ms. Neuenschwander’s contribution to Conceptualism: art that’s conciliatory, collaborative and amenable.

headline: Big Names at Work at a London Gallery
Law to Require Landlords to Come Clean on Bedbugs
text: A bill passed by both houses of the state Legislature on Thursday requires New York City landlords to tell prospective tenants about a building’s recent bedbug history.

headline: The LXD
text: In an excerpt from the first episode of The LXD, a seemingly ordinary teenager, Trevor Drift, discovers his extraordinary abilities at his senior prom.

headline: Madoff Son Sheds Nantucket Home
text: Convenient to Beaches

headline: Scorecard | Ermenegildo Zegna Wins!
text: Today the men’s-wear season gets underway in Paris, yet critics are somehow still filing their final reviews from Milan, so it’s back to Italy for The Moment. As Scorecard can tell you, between men in gray flannel suits, international men of mystery and American gigolos, there was nary a decade this side of Technicolor that wasn’t mined for inspiration in the closing shows. Yet as Famiglia Zegna proved, there’s not much competition in the sport of archive digging when you’re celebrating the centennial of the wool mill that Granddad founded.

headline: Change Comes to a Dakota Apartment
text: Homesteading at the Dakota

headline: School Is Turned Around, but Cost Gives Pause
text: LOS ANGELES  As recently as 2008, Locke High School here was one of the nation’s worst failing schools, and drew national attention for its hallway beatings, bathroom rapes and rooftop parties held by gangs. For every student who graduated, four others dropped out.

headline: Key Job Changing Hands at Justice
text: David J. Barron, the acting head of the Justice Department’s powerful Office of Legal Counsel, will step down next month and be replaced by one of his current deputies, Jonathan G. Cedarbaum, the department said Thursday.

headline: Theater Listings: June 25 — July 1
text: THEATER

headline: Lions Gate and MGM Hold Talks on Potential Deal
text: Lions Gate Entertainment and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer have been holding merger talks, but it is not clear that a deal will emerge, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Thursday.

headline: Spare Times
text: Around Town

headline: Sci-Fi Summer Films, a Free Hip Hop Old School Party, and the UnFancy Food Show
text: Oh, the days of $3 drive-in movies, how our love lives (and wallets) miss them. Well, the Saturday night Sci-Fi Summer film series indoors at the Coney Island Museum can be the modern couple’s next-best alternative. This weekend the program presents “Attack of the 50-Foot Woman” (1958), and continues every Saturday at 8:30 p.m. through Sept. 18, with other classics like “King Kong vs. Godzilla” and the original 1968 “Planet of the Apes.” Doors open at 8, and the evening starts with vintage drive-in trailers, shorts and commercials at 8:15. Tickets are $5 each and include free popcorn. Food and soft drinks and alcoholic beverages beverages are sold at the Freak Bar. (1208 Surf Avenue, between Stillwell Avenue and West 12th Street, Brooklyn; 718-372-5159, www.coneyisland.com.)

headline: From Greece, a Parable About ... Something
text: LIKE many parents, the father in the Greek film “Dogtooth” wants to protect his children. He oversees their education, monitors what they watch and read, and keeps tabs on them in their sunny suburban house. As a matter of fact, the children  a son and two daughters  are not even allowed to leave the spacious, grassy grounds of their home.

headline: Can Obama Create More Jobs Soon?
text: With unemployment at 9.7 percent, recent polls show that the public is not happy with the Obama administration’s inability to create more jobs. Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke, with no good news to offer, has predicted that unemployment will remain high for years and that “a lot of people are going to be under financial stress.”

headline: Oh, the Places You Could Go
text: SOME of the best bike rides in New York come when you know exactly where you want to go and can’t get there. Frustrated by ubiquitous street fairs and parades? Turn a detour into discovery.

headline: Germany, Not France, Delights in Multicultural World Cup Squad
text: That a German player named Mesut Özil scored the goal that sent his nation through to the second round of this year’s World Cup is a sign that something fundamental has changed about what it means to be German. A country which, until quite recently, refused to give citizenship even to the German-born children of immigrants now finds itself represented by a squad of 23 players so ethnically diverse that 11 of them could have chosen to play instead for other nations.

text: POP

headline: World Cup Powerhouses
text: Argentina, Brazil, Germany and Italy have won all but four of the 18 World Cups, and at least one of them has played in every final.

headline: Whiskers, Kittens
text: Full beards on men make us think of Karl Marx and Santa Claus. At least that’s my bipolar reference. But full beards on men in fashion shows just make us giggle.

headline: A Sanctuary and a Prison
text: Plenty of parents try to instill their values in their children and shield the little ones from the perils and temptations of the outside world. The mother and father in “Dogtooth,” a Greek festival-circuit conversation piece directed by Yorgos Lanthimos, present an extreme case of this kind of protectiveness. Their idea of home schooling is to provide their children with daily tape-recorded vocabulary lessons, which would not be unusual if the definitions were less idiosyncratic. The three kids  two daughters (Aggeliki Papoulia as the elder, Mary Tsoni as the younger) and a son (Hristos Passalis)  are taught that “excursion” refers to a kind of flooring material and that a “sea” is a kind of armchair.

headline: Death Match
text: “When David Pepin first dreamed of killing his wife, he didn’t kill her himself. He dreamed convenient acts of God.” So begins “Mr. Peanut,” the daring, arresting first novel by Adam Ross, an author of prodigious talent, which takes as its theme “the dual nature of marriage, the proximity of violence and love.”

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: A Doctor’s Office, Revisited
text: Researchers at Microsoft are developing technology that would allow more than one person to have a conversation with a computer.

headline: Up Front: Scott Turow
text: Reviewing Adam Ross’s first novel, “Mr. Peanut,” on our cover this week, Scott Turow mentions that in the early 1970s he studied in Wallace Stegner’s creative writing program at Stanford.

headline: On New iPhone, a Mystery of Dropped Calls
text: SAN FRANCISCO  For iPhone owners, it always comes back to the antenna.

text: ART

headline: World Cup Photo Replay: Day 14, June 24
text: Italy is shocked by Slovakia and eliminated, while Paraguay moves on after a tie with New Zealand.

headline: Blatant Acts of Naked Regression
text: It doesn’t get worse than “Grown Ups,” Adam Sandler’s sloppy entry into this year’s man-child-comedy sweepstakes. Lazy, mean-spirited, incoherent, infantile and, above all, witless, the farce  which focuses on five 40-something guys in full regression  suggests a hangover from “The Hangover.” If squirting breast milk, simultaneous urination by slobs in a pool at a water park, and a repeatedly flatulent grandmother are your idea of fun, I say go for it.

headline: Revenge on the Bully, Silently, in Japan
text: There are a handful of silent, black-and-white old movies that have the power to make all the subsequent advances in the medium look redundant. When you watch, say, Charlie Chaplin’s “City Lights” or “The General” by Buster Keaton, you are aware of such complete mastery of the emotional and narrative possibilities of cinema that color and sound seem like so much distraction and filigree. Everything you could possibly want is here, and indeed the addition of anything else would only subtract from the perfection of the art.

headline: It’s Hard to Be a Saint in the City
text: Msgr. Bernard J. Quinn (1888-1940), a Roman Catholic priest who became widely known for reaching out to black Catholics in  Brooklyn and on Long Island, has been placed on the long, winding and political road to sainthood. If the effort on his behalf by the Diocese of Brooklyn succeeds, he will join thousands of saints from around the world, including New Yorkers like Elizabeth Ann Seton, a city native who founded the American Sisters of Charity, and Mother Frances Xavier Cabrini, who helped her fellow Italian immigrants.

headline: What We’re Reading: App Creep
text: Here’s what the tech reporters and editors spotted on the Web Thursday–not a word about the iPhone:

headline: Oliver Stone, Tour Guide
text: Political documentaries shadowed by paranoia and apocalyptic foreboding are so commonplace nowadays that “South of the Border,” Oliver Stone’s celebration of the leftward tilt of South American politics, comes as a cheerful surprise. As anyone who remembers “JFK,” his 1991 film about the Kennedy assassination, can attest, Mr. Stone has his own paranoid tendencies, but they are muted in this provocative, if shallow, exaltation of Latin American socialism.

headline: A Diplomatic Traveling Supporter of the U.S. Team Sees the Big Picture

headline: The Other Offshore Disaster
text: Canaries are small. Coal mines are big. Finding one in the other is never easy.

headline: House Looks to Pass War Funding by Recess
text: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Thursday stressed the importance of passing a war spending bill by the time lawmakers leave for an Independence Day recess, but questions remain about what exactly will be included in the legislation.

headline: Anarchic Imagination vs. Humdrum
text: As the camera glides and loop-de-loops through the 88-year-old Alain Resnais’s surreal romantic comedy “Wild Grass,” primary colors take on a luminescent glow. Objects  a yellow car, a red dress, a blue doorway, even traffic lights  assume the heightened visual intensity of symbols in a waking dream.

headline: Zimbabwe Diamonds Fail to Get Conflict-Free Approval
text: JOHANNESBURG  An international undertaking to prevent the trade in diamonds that fuel conflict ended in a stalemate Thursday over whether to approve Zimbabwe’s export of millions of carats of newly-mined diamonds, but the nation threatened to sell the stones on its own anyway.

headline: Boss’s Firing May Result in Departures From Kabul
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The business of running the war in Afghanistan went on seemingly as usual on Thursday, although many in the NATO command headquarters here were reeling over the rapid-fire events that culminated in their boss’s dismissal, forcing many of them to polish their résumés.

headline: After Tough Year, Pay Cuts and Forfeited Bonuses for Top Toyota Executives
text: TOYOTA CITY, Japan  For years, the combined salaries of the president of Toyota Motor and the 38 members of its board have been smaller than the single salary of some top executives at car makers in the United States and elsewhere.

headline: A New Plan for Valuing Pensions
text: The board that writes accounting rules for states and cities has proposed a new approach for pension disclosures that falls far short of what some financial experts hoped, but which would still force many governments to highlight pension shortfalls they have downplayed.

headline: Keeping Score: What’s Made Padres Better? Pitching
text: In 2009, the San Diego Padres had the second-smallest payroll in baseball and finished with a 75-87 record. Given the strength of their divisional opponents and the lack of changes the Padres made during the off-season, most experts viewed them as a likely fourth- or fifth-place finisher again this year.

headline: NEA Will Honor 18 Artists
text: The National Endowment for the Arts will present 18 lifetime achievement awards on Friday in the fields of opera, jazz, and folk and traditional arts. The honorees include the composer Philip Glass, for opera, and five members of the Marsalis family, for jazz. Each award comes with $25,000. Besides Branford, Delfeayo, Ellis, Jr., Jason, and Wynton Marsalis, the other 2010 Jazz Masters are Orrin Keepnews, a writer and record producer; Hubert Laws, a flutist; David Liebman, a saxophonist and flutist; and Johnny Mandel, a composer-arranger. The honorees in folk and traditional arts are Yacub Addy, a Ghanaian drummer; Jim “Texas Shorty” Chancellor, a fiddler; Gladys Kukana Grace, a Lauhala weaver; Mary Jackson, a sweetgrass basketweaver; Delano “Del” Floyd McCoury, a bluegrass guitarist and singer; Judith McCulloh, a folklorist and editor; Kamala Lakshmi Narayanan, a Bharatanatyam Indian dancer; Mike Rafferty, an Irish flute player; and Ezequiel Torres, an Afro-Cuban drummer and drum builder. The opera honorees, besides Mr. Glass, are Martina Arroyo, a soprano; David DiChiera, a composer and the general director of the Michigan Opera Theatre; and Eve Queler, the music director of Opera Orchestra of New York.

headline: U.S. Appeals Court Lifts Stay on Relocating Mentally Ill
text: A federal appeals court has ruled that New York State must comply with a lower court’s order to begin immediately transferring thousands of people with mental illness in New York City out of large, institutional group homes and into their own homes and apartments, where they will continue to receive specialized treatment and services.

text: THE TV quiz show “Who Wants to Be a Millionaire” is about to get a Madison Avenue version, “Who Wants a Million Dollars to Start an Agency.”

headline: With a Bow, a Royal Tradition Returns to Wimbledon
text: WIMBLEDON, England  Andy Murray and Jarkko Nieminen walked onto Centre Court on Thursday, halted at the service line, turned toward the royal box and bowed. The burning question  to bow, or not to bow  had been answered.

headline: Stefan Jacoby of VW to Reportedly Head Volvo
text: Stefan Jacoby, Volkswagen Group of America president and chief executive  who had been the main architect of the company’s efforts in the United States since 2007, is reportedly leaving the company to head Volvo’s worldwide operations. The German newspaper Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung reports that Mr. Jacoby will replace Stephen Odell, a Briton, at Volvo in August.

headline: Sixty Years in Dodgers’ Booth, and Scully Is Still in Awe
text: ANAHEIM, Calif.  The Yankees won the World Series in 1936, when Vin Scully became a baseball fan. Yet Scully, born in the Bronx, did not root for the winning team. He felt sorry for the losers.

headline: MGM Said to Be in Merger Talk
text: Lions Gate Entertainment and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer have been holding merger talks, but it is not clear that a deal will emerge, people briefed on the matter said on Thursday.

text: Every so often, Aalim Moody, 5, and his twin sister, Aalima, break into a kind of secret code, chatting in a language their father does not understand.

headline: Dual Language School Offers Hebrew
text: At the Hebrew Language Academy Charter School in Brooklyn, students learn in English and Hebrew. While most kids come from Jewish backgrounds, many non-Jewish students come to get a better education.

headline: China’s Export Economy Begins Turning Inward
text: BEIJING  For years, Chinese leaders looked to the millions of poor workers from the country’s interior as the engine of a roaring export economy. They would move to coastal provinces, toil in factories and churn out the world’s household goods.

headline: An American Concept, Carried Out in Samoan Style
text: The Tea Party movement has been working to oust the establishment by organizing protests throughout the country. Out in the Pacific, meanwhile, one of the United States’s colonial holdings, American Samoa, is using a more uncommon forum to rethink the role of the federal government. The island territory of 66,000 people is holding a constitutional convention.

headline: Pete Hamill’s Circuitous Route to a High School Diploma
text: Having published 10 novels, finished an 11th, written a memoir and four other works of nonfiction, polished off countless columns and magazine articles, covered a few wars, briefly run the newsrooms of two newspapers and landed on a list of 400 New Yorkers described as helping to define the city over the past four centuries, Pete Hamill figured it was time to graduate from high school.

headline: Across From White House, Coffee With Lobbyists
text: WASHINGTON  There are no Secret Service agents posted next to the barista and no presidential seal on the ceiling, but the Caribou Coffee across the street from the White House has become a favorite meeting spot to conduct Obama administration business.

headline: Racing From Mao’s Bugles
text: The North Korean Army invaded on a Sunday, when most of the young South Korean soldiers had gone home to their family farms to help with the rice planting and many officers were still waking up from a night of dancing and drinking with their American compatriots.

headline: Wizards Take Wall With No. 1 Pick and Begin Task of Rebuilding Team
text: A half-hour before the Washington Wizards, to the surprise of almost no one, selected John Wall with the first pick over all in the N.B.A. draft, Wall sat at a table, wearing a gray pinstriped suit and a scowl, as if he had a game to play.

headline: The Luck of the Draw Now Works for the U.S.
text: Landon Donovan’s stoppage-time goal did more for the United States than stave off elimination from the World Cup and ignite celebrations across the nation. It also put the Americans on a potential path to the semifinals free of a confrontation with soccer’s traditional powers.

headline: Sick Detained Immigrant to Appeal to U.N. for Help
text: A 61-year-old Jamaican man who spent three decades working in New York is likely to die of medical neglect in a Louisiana immigration detention center unless the United Nations intervenes, says an urgent petition that his advocates plan to submit to the international organization on Friday.

headline: New Strategy Announced to Improve City Schools
text: The Education Department on Thursday detailed a new model for turning around some of New York City’s lowest-performing schools, saying that the schools would serve as the first testing ground for new teacher evaluation laws passed by the Legislature in May.

headline: Nun Killed by Minivan Is Remembered for the Lives She Shaped
text: Her room at the convent of the Franciscan Handmaids of the Most Pure Heart of Mary in Harlem remained just as Sister Mary Celine Graham had left it on Tuesday morning.

headline: Pinned Down at Busan
text: I landed in Busan, South Korea, on Aug. 4, 1950. Busan is near the southern tip of the peninsula, and at the time the area around it was all that was left of the country; the rest had been overrun by the North Koreans. The valley we were in, just north of Daegu, later became known as the “Bowling Alley.”

headline: Wal-Mart Gains in Its Wooing of Chicago
text: What would it take for urban areas to welcome Wal-Mart?

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Long, Hard Path to the Public
text: In 2000, when three Yale undergraduates founded an online financial services company called Higher One Holdings, they had visions of rapid growth and successively bigger rounds of financing from investors. With any luck, momentum would build toward the ultimate dot-com dream: a stock listing on a major public exchange.

headline: Building Smarter Machines
text: As computers grow ever smarter, a look at developments in the field of artificial intelligence.

headline: Computers Learn to Listen, and Some Talk Back
text: “Hi, thanks for coming,” the medical assistant says, greeting a mother with her 5-year-old son. “Are you here for your child or yourself?”

headline: Analysts Question a Threat by Fannie
text: Fannie Mae’s decision to begin punishing people who walk away from their unpaid mortgages could prove difficult to sell to the public and might be impossible to execute, housing and lending experts said Thursday.

headline: The Men I Lost
text: By 1952 both sides had been dug in for months along the 38th Parallel. As peace talks began in Panmunjom, a village along what became the border between North and South Korea, they jockeyed for the smallest terrain advantage in anticipation of a cease-fire. The result was an endless series of seesaw battles for outposts in front of mainline positions, similar to the trench warfare of World War I.

headline: As Generals Change, Afghan Debate Narrows to 2 Powerful Voices
text: WASHINGTON  The messy departure of Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal is likely to make the Obama administration’s internal debates over Afghanistan even more pointed, giving the military a powerful advocate for staying the course as it prepares for a reckoning with more impatient officials like Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Nico Smith, Minister and Fighter of Apartheid, Dies at 81
text: The Rev. Nico Smith, a white minister who defied his racist upbringing in South Africa by living in a black township and leading a congregation there while organizing protests against apartheid, died Saturday in Pretoria. He was 81.

headline: Local Debt in China Worries Its Auditor
text: SHANGHAI — China won praise last year for reviving domestic growth with aggressive bank lending and a $586 billion economic stimulus package. But now the nation’s top auditor is warning that the mounting debt of local governments could undermine the recovery in some parts of the country.

headline: My American Prisoner
text: On March 18, 1951, my infantry unit crossed the Yalu River toward a Korean city that had been destroyed by bombs. We each carried 65-pound packs. We would not see China again for almost three years.

headline: Democrats See Signs of Hope in Job Trends
text: A struggling economy has historically meant trouble for the president’s party in midterm elections. So it comes as no surprise that Democrats are girding for a tough November.

headline: Manuel Reflects on Reyes Switch
text: Considering how well Jose Reyes has played since moving back to his preferred leadoff spot in the batting order, it seems self evident that the experiment that had him batting third earlier in the season was a failed one.

headline: The Forgotten War, Remembered
text: Sixty years ago today, units of the North Korean Army crossed the 38th Parallel, invading South Korea and starting the Korean War — which grew into a cold war clash between the United States and China. Although more than two million soldiers and civilians died over the next three years, including more than 54,000 Americans, the war is now an overlooked part of United States history. The Op-Ed editors asked four veterans for their memories of the conflict.

headline: Palin Likes Another Todd
text: Sarah Palin’s at it again.

headline: Santana Said He Had Sex With Accuser, Records Show
text: Johan Santana acknowledged having sex with the woman who accused him of sexual assault last October, Florida police records show. The woman, an acquaintance of Santana’s identified as Jane Doe, accused Santana of assaulting her on a golf course in Fort Myers, Fla., in 2009.

headline: Not Perfect, But Rivera Escapes Another Jam
text: LOS ANGELES  Mariano Rivera has not started in 15 years, but he was three outs from finishing a perfect game.

headline: Learning Hebrew
text: At a charter school in Brooklyn, students from diverse backgrounds learn a language traditionally studied and spoken by Jews.

headline: Abba Hit
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — June 25 is a big day for Robin Schulman. This puzzle, constructed with Byron Walden, is her debut as a New York Times constructor. Congratulations! Could anything be more exciting?

headline: Report Urges More Curbs on Medical Ghostwriting
text: Should more light be shed on the relationships between drug makers and certain prominent doctors who publish scientific articles about their medicines?

headline: Names of the Dead
