headline: Balance of Prosecutorial Power
text: Prosecutors and lawmakers will have to work harder now that the Supreme Court has narrowed the excessively broad federal “honest services” law. Any benefit the ruling gives to public and private miscreants  including Joseph Bruno, Rod Blagojevich and Jeffrey Skilling, who have been charged with or convicted of violating the law  should quickly inspire more thorough investigations and sharper new laws to combat corruption.

headline: Do No Harm
text: Health professionals who facilitate torture are violating the most fundamental medical ethics and ought to be punished. Unfortunately, neither Congress nor the Obama administration has shown any appetite for confronting the problem. The New York State Legislature is considering a state law that would bar such misbehavior and provide grounds for revoking the license of any health professional who participates.

headline: Recalling a Daughter, ‘Born With a Smile,’ Who Drowned on a School Trip
text: Two days after his 12-year-old daughter drowned while on a school trip to the beach, Juan Suriel stood in the doorway of a Harlem apartment and struggled to gather his words. He spoke softly in Spanish, recounting his favorite memory of time spent with her  a vacation to their home country, the Dominican Republic.

headline: Who Approved These Ads?
text: When the Supreme Court cavalierly threw aside decades of controls to let corporations and unions flood federal elections with unlimited campaign funds, the alternative the court suggested was a mandatory dose of transparency. Let voters know who is really behind the new wave of spending was the court’s prescription.

headline: G.O.P. Chief Visits Unfriendly Territory
text: SAN FRANCISCO  It’s tough to find a place less friendly to Republicans than San Francisco, where fewer than one in 10 voters are registered with the party and where the local chairman  a former leader in the sanitary supply industry  says his major goal for 2010 is to get “more moderate” members on the city’s often un-moderate Board of Supervisors.

headline: Marbury’s Enduring Legacy: Jazz, not Knicks, Gets Hayward
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  About an hour before the N.B.A. draft Thursday evening, Knicks Coach Mike D’Antoni settled into a chair and looked at the reporters encircling him.

headline: The Immigration Reform Team
text: Mayor Michael Bloomberg, making good on an inaugural pledge, has stepped up to help lead the national battle for immigration reform. On Thursday, he announced a partnership of mayors and business leaders to make the economic case for reform, including mayors of Los Angeles, Philadelphia, San Antonio, Phoenix, and top executives of companies like Walt Disney, Hewlett-Packard, Boeing and the New York Mets.

headline: Panel Backs Smaller Rent Increases Than Usual
text: Rents for New York City’s one million rent-stabilized apartments will rise less than in the past several years under increases set Thursday evening at a typically raucous public meeting.

headline: The Renminbi Runaround
text: Last weekend China announced a change in its currency policy, a move clearly intended to head off pressure from the United States and other countries at this weekend’s G-20 summit meeting. Unfortunately, the new policy doesn’t address the real issue, which is that China has been promoting its exports at the rest of the world’s expense.

headline: Joe Torre Awaits the Yankees
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. – The Yankees were off on Thursday, so for Joe Torre, the reunion with his old team started early. He had breakfast with Yankees trainers and staff personnel, and greeted several familiar reporters before the Dodgers played the Angels.

headline: Police Officer Says Beating of a Fallen Suspect Was Proper
text: A New York City police officer testified on Thursday that he struck a man with his baton dozens of times while the man lay on the ground because the man was swearing at him, threatening to kill him and thrashing around.

headline: House Passes Plan to Stop Medicare Cuts to Doctors
text: WASHINGTON — The House on Thursday approved a six-month plan to prevent a steep cut in doctors’ fees paid by Medicare, agreeing to a short-term solution that Speaker Nancy Pelosi called “totally inadequate” but said the House had decided to adopt after concluding that the Senate was hopelessly gridlocked and could do no better.

headline: Liability Questions Loom for BP and Ex-Partners
text: Who will pay for the oil spill?

headline: Prescott Bush Jr., Scion of a Political Family, Dies at 87
text: Prescott S. Bush Jr., the brother of one president and uncle of another, and a retired insurance executive who tried but never made it far in the family business  politics  died Wednesday after a long illness. He was 87.

headline: House Approves Legislation That Mandates the Disclosure of Political Spending
text: WASHINGTON — The House on Thursday approved legislation to curtail the ability of corporations and other special interest groups to influence elections by requiring greater disclosure of their role in paying for campaign advertising.

headline: Rwanda: Prospective Presidential Candidate Detained
text: The police detained a prospective presidential candidate, Bernard Ntaganda, on Thursday, and searched his compound on suspicion of ethnic divisionism and attempted murder. He is the second politician to face similar charges since April. President Paul Kagame formally filed papers on Thursday for his candidacy for re-election.

headline: China: Official Links 10 Detainees to 2008 Killings
text: A Chinese security official said Thursday that the police recently broke up a “terrorist group” that was involved in an attack in August 2008 in the western city of Kashgar that resulted in the deaths of 17 paramilitary officers. The official, Wu Heping, said the police had detained 10 members of the group, including two “ringleaders,” Abdurixit Ablet, 42, and Imin Semai’er, 33, both natives of the restive western region of Xinjiang, according to Xinhua, the state news agency. Previously, Chinese officials had said they had arrested a taxi driver and a vegetable seller at the scene of the attack and charged them with the killings.

headline: The Culture of Exposure
text: The most interesting part of my job is that I get to observe powerful people at close quarters. Most people in government, I find, are there because they sincerely want to do good. But they’re also exhausted and frustrated much of the time. And at these moments they can’t help letting you know that things would be much better if only there weren’t so many morons all around.

headline: Greece: Bomb Kills Cabinet Minister’s Assistant
text: A powerful bomb sent in a package to the minister of public order exploded near his office in Athens on Thursday, killing his 52-year-old assistant, who opened the package. The minister, Michalis Chrysochoidis, left, who is in charge of the police and counterterrorism, was not in his office at the time. He described the attackers as “cowards” and said their actions would not divert his ministry from its counterterrorism drive. There was no immediate claim of responsibility.

headline: Favors First Part in Nets’ Puzzle
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Looking to bury a turbulent past in the New Jersey swamplands, the Nets resisted the temptation Thursday night to add a power player with the haunting initials, D.C. With the third pick of the N.B.A. draft, they still landed another Derrick.

headline: Turkey: 3 Suspects Arrested After Fatal Bombing
text: The police arrested three suspects in a bomb attack that killed five people in Istanbul on Monday, the semiofficial Anatolian News Agency reported. Officials did not identify the suspects, but attacks on military targets are generally ascribed to the rebel Kurdistan Workers’ Party. A new attack on Thursday in the eastern town of Elazig killed one civilian and two soldiers, Anatolian reported.

headline: U.S. Calls for Indigenous Whaling Quotas
text: The American whaling commissioner said Thursday that the United States was trying to salvage some progress from an international conference on whaling by calling for a vote to set whaling quotas for indigenous peoples who depend on the animals for sustenance. “These are people who actually need the whales to eat,” the commissioner, Monica Medina, said in Morocco. “But they end up begging for their quotas.” Talks aimed at reducing the hunt globally, specifically hunting by Japan, Norway and Iceland, which circumvent an international moratorium on whaling, collapsed on Wednesday at a conference of the International Whaling Commission in Agadir, Morocco. A proposal put forward by the commission’s top executives had sought to bridge the gap between pro-whaling and antiwhaling nations, calling for approval of the resumption of commercial whaling under strict supervision by the commission and at reduced levels.

headline: Legislature Passes Bedbug-Notification Law
text: A bill passed by both houses of the State Legislature on Thursday would require New York City landlords to tell prospective tenants about a building’s recent bedbug history.

headline: Rethinking District Plan on Condoms in Schools
text: BOSTON  Was the school district in Provincetown, Mass., really planning to dole out condoms to third-graders?

headline: Mets Can’t Recover From Takahashi’s Shaky Start
text: The Tigers’ Gerald Laird and Brennan Boesch gathered in a corner of the visitors’ clubhouse late Thursday afternoon at Citi Field and watched video of Mets starter Hisanori Takahashi pitching last Friday.

headline: Former Prosecutor to Lead New York’s Counterterrorism Effort
text: Richard Daddario, a former federal prosecutor who is now the Department of Justice’s attaché in Moscow, was named the New York Police Department’s top counterterrorism official on Thursday, city officials said.

headline: Jobs Created and Displaced
text: The impact of innovation, by its nature, is unpredictable. But the pattern by which new technologies and high-tech businesses create jobs across the economy is well established. Take the Internet and Google.

headline: Interview With a Robot
text: National correspondent Amy Harmon sits down to talk with the Bina48 about what it's like to be a robot.

headline: Greenblatt to Leave Showtime
text: 11:38 a.m. | Updated Robert Greenblatt, who engineered a slate of original shows for the pay cable channel Showtime, is preparing to step down after seven years there.

headline: City Council and Mayor Reach Accord on a Budget
text: Faced with a sputtering economy and uncertainty in Albany, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council agreed Thursday night on a $63 billion budget that would slash at least 2,000 jobs but increase no taxes.

headline: Court Rejects Secrecy on Ballot Petitions
text: WASHINGTON  People who sign petitions to put referendums on state ballots do not have a general right under the First Amendment to keep their names secret, the Supreme Court ruled on Thursday in an 8-to-1 decision.

headline: Senator Calls for New Rules for For-Profit Colleges
text: WASHINGTON  At the first in a series of oversight hearings on for-profit colleges, Senator Tom Harkin made it clear on Thursday that he saw a need for new regulation of for-profit colleges, to prevent waste of taxpayer money, and fraudulent practices that harm students.

headline: U.S. Game Draws Big Numbers for ESPN
text: The United States’ 1-0 win over Algeria on Wednesday, which put the Americans in the Round of 16, was seen by an average of 6.12 million viewers on ESPN, the most ever for a soccer game on the ESPN networks. Several days earlier, 5.2 million viewers tuned in for ESPN’s broadcast of the United States-Slovenia game.

headline: Massachusetts: Immigrant Crackdown Is Eased
text: A crackdown on illegal immigrants, passed by the State Senate last month, has been scaled back. The House and the Senate on Thursday approved a less stringent version of the contentious plan, which would have required the state attorney general to set up a hot line for residents to anonymously report businesses suspected of hiring illegal immigrants. The compromise plan, adopted as an amendment to the state budget, only codifies existing state policies. But as part of sweeping budget cuts, the legislature also eliminated health care coverage for thousands of legal immigrants.

headline: Texas: Seven Officers Are Fired for Beating
text: The Houston police chief has fired seven officers involved in the beating of a 15-year-old suspected of burglary, a beating that was caught on videotape and outraged many black residents. Four of the officers also face misdemeanor charges for the pummeling of the youth, Chad Holley, who had been handcuffed and forced to the ground after a short chase on March 23. Some black leaders called the charges of “official repression” a slap on the wrist and questioned why prosecutors had not persuaded a grand jury to charge the officers with felony assault.

headline: Steven Krane, Ex-Leader of New York State Bar, Dies at 53
text: Steven C. Krane, who was the youngest president of the New York State Bar Association and an expert on legal ethics, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 53 and had homes in Manhattan and Pound Ridge, N.Y.

headline: Just a Plaything for Private Equity
text: Just a Plaything For Private Equity

headline: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: Senator Seeks to Halt Alaska Project

headline: At City College, a Battle Over Remedial Classes for English and Math
text: At City College of San Francisco, one of the country’s largest public universities, thousands of struggling students pour into remedial English and math classes  and then the vast majority disappear, never to receive a college degree.

headline: Three Who Identified a Need in the Arts — and Filled It
text: If founding an arts organization is a challenge, sticking with it is an extreme sport. It takes bravery, business acumen and blind faith to ensure success over the long haul, and the Bay Area is home to several cultural leaders who started their respective organizations decades ago and have attained local and national significance.

headline: Gay Issues in Vallejo Just Won’t Go Away
text: When Lou Bordisso, an openly gay bishop emeritus in the American Catholic Church, ascended the podium at last month’s Vallejo City Council meeting, he was hopeful that a volatile chapter for local gay men and lesbians had finally ended.

headline: Good Data for Charters, but Some Urge Caution
text: He was born to a drug-addicted mother, struggled in school and as a child was bounced among the homes of several relatives. Yet doors began to open for Shantell Hopkins four years ago after he entered a new charter public high school in Chicago. Now he is preparing for his freshman year at Knox College in Galesburg, Ill., on a full-tuition scholarship from the school.

headline: For Inmates, New Greenhouse Provides New Growth
text: When Adolf Jerger was sent to Cook County Jail in February for failing to pay child support, he never imagined his six months behind bars would include growing produce for upscale Chicago restaurants.

headline: Politics and Money? Shocking. Shocking.
text: It’s too bad that Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.; Representative John A. Boehner, the United States House minority leader; and other big-time politicians couldn’t find time on Monday to show up at the Dirksen Federal Building while they were in Chicago.

headline: A Diagnosis, as LeBron Fever Sweeps the City
text: The real LeBron Watch doesn’t officially begin until July 1, but as a staple of ESPN programming and a source of mind-blowing tedium, it has surpassed the endless will-he-or-won’t-he speculation over Brett Favre.

headline: A Vehicle in Which Performance Is Measured by Wheelchair Access
text: A Miami company that had come to the New York auto show in 2007 to unveil a new taxi that had seating for four in the rear and room for a wheelchair, is about to tour the country to show off a similar vehicle, but this time wheelchair access is taking center stage.

headline: Study Says Natural Gas Use Likely to Double
text: WASHINGTON  Natural gas will provide an increasing share of America’s energy needs over the next several decades, doubling its share of the energy market to 40 percent, from 20 percent, according to a report to be released Friday by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

headline: It’s a Bird! It’s a Plane! No, It’s a Superdancer!
text: “They lie amongst us, preparing for battle, waiting to rise and change things for good. Some are gifted in ability, others are trained to master it and some, some have it bestowed upon them at birth, but they all must choose.” These words, spoken in a James Earl Jones baritone, could be the opening crawl for the latest “X-Men” movie. But they aren’t referring to traditional superheroes, at least not in the masked and overly muscled sense. They are dancers.

headline: ‘Million-Dollar Challenge’ for New Marketing Firms

headline: Hartford Stage Artistic Director to Depart
text: After 12 years as artistic director of Hartford Stage in Connecticut, Michael Wilson has announced he is stepping down in June 2011. “I’m looking forward to being more fully in the rehearsal hall,” Mr. Wilson said in an interview. In January he is scheduled to direct Olympia Dukakis in a production of Tennessee Williams’s “Milk Train Doesn’t Stop Here Anymore” for Roundabout Theater Company, and he hopes to oversee a Broadway production of that playwright’s “Night of the Iguana” in the next 18 months. From 1998 to 2008, Mr. Wilson, above right, presided over a Williams marathon at Hartford Stage that included premieres of three previously unpublished short plays. During Mr. Wilson’s tenure, the theater also produced the acclaimed three-part, nine-hour production of Horton Foote’s “Orphans’ Home Cycle,” which later moved off Broadway. Paul Marte, a Hartford Stage spokesman, said a search committee would be convened next month, with a national search expected to take six to nine months. Mr. Wilson said he would be available past his planned departure to help with a transition if necessary.

headline: South Street Seaport to Relocate Two Concerts
text: In response to reports that some concerts at South Street Seaport had been canceled because of the melee at a free Drake show there last week, the seaport and Paper magazine, which presented the event, said the concerts would still take place, but not at the seaport. “Since it was demonstrated that the escalating popularity of the scheduled artists can result in crowds that exceed even the safe capacity of the Pier 17 concert stage, both Paper magazine and the South Street Seaport have decided that the remaining events of the Sounds Like Paper concert series will be relocated,” a seaport spokesman said in a statement, which was confirmed by Paper. In a letter to Community Board No. 1 of Manhattan last week, General Growth Properties, which owns the seaport, had said the two remaining shows, by the pop singer Kesha, above right, and the band Ratatat, would be canceled. The Seaport’s outdoor concert space has a capacity of about 10,000, but according to some reports, as many as 25,000 people turned out for the Drake concert on June 15. It was not clear whether a new stage had been found, or whether the seaport would be involved. Kesha, whose song “Tik Tok” is one of the year’s biggest hits, had been booked for a free Seaport concert in August, but a spokeswoman at her record label, RCA, said Thursday that she had not yet been informed about a new date or location. BEN SISARIO

headline: ’80’s Pop Stars Face Off in a SyFy TV Movie
text: Is it possible that, though the years appear to have kept advancing, we have somehow remained stuck in the late 1980s or early ’90s? Once again, Tiffany and Debbie Gibson are about to go head-to-head: the Syfy channel has cast the onetime pop rivals in a coming made-for-television film, The Hollywood Reporter said. The film, “Mega Python vs. Gatoroid,” will star Ms. Gibson, above right, as an advocate for animal rights who accidentally helps create supersize snakes, and Tiffany, above left, as a park ranger trying to save endangered alligators in the Everglades. In a statement, Tiffany said: “Only in my dreams have I been able to have a catfight with Debbie Gibson ... until now! This is soo mega cool!” Ms. Gibson added: “I know that pop-culture fanatics have been dying for Tiffany and me to collaborate for the past 24 years! What better way to do it than by battling each other in a campy romp through the Everglades?” The film is to be shown next year. An accompanying shopping mall tour was not immediately announced.

headline: Few Bites for ABC During ‘Twilight’ Special
text: “America’s Got Talent” earned Wednesday’s highest ratings as 12.1 million viewers tuned in to the NBC series at 9 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. No other show came close to matching it in the ratings, and the network led the night over all. Fox was runner-up, averaging 6.3 million viewers for “So You Think You Can Dance” from 8 to 10, while CBS came in third with reruns. ABC was a distant fourth with comedy reruns followed by a special “Jimmy Kimmel Live” at 10 (3 million), featuring Robert Pattinson, Kristen Stewart and other cast members from “The Twilight Saga: Eclipse.”

headline: Opera Orchestra of New York Returns
text: The Opera Orchestra of New York, a small but beloved institution for fans of offbeat repertory and big voices, is staging something of a comeback. The company said Thursday that it would end its financially induced hiatus and mount two concert productions next season: Meyerbeer’s “Africaine” and a double bill of Massenet’s “Navarraise” and Mascagni’s  “Cavalleria Rusticana.”  The double bill, to be conducted at Carnegie Hall by Alberto Veronesi, who takes over as music director in 2011, will feature Roberto Alagna and Elina Garanca in the Massenet, and Mr. Alagna, Maria Guleghina, Krysty Swann and Mignon Dunn in “Cavalleria,” according to Opera Orchestra. Eve Queler, who founded the company in 1967 and is music director now, will conduct  “L’Africaine,”  with Marcello Giordani singing and Chiara Taigi in her United States debut, at Avery Fisher Hall. The organization suspended opera performances in 2008 and has been presenting only recitals. The board chairman, Norman Raben, said it is now debt-free and raising the $1.25 million to $1.5 million needed for next season. “It’s a big comeback,” he said. “The board stood up tall.” DANIEL J. WAKIN

Do you think there will someday be video games that can be compared to the best works of literature, film, music and art?

headline: Ghana Carries Burden of Africa’s Expectations
text: JOHANNESBURG — So much for this being Africa’s World Cup. Despite a record six African teams taking part in the tournament just one yet, Ghana, has made it through to the second round – and even the Black Stars only scraped through on goal difference after losing to Germany. And Ivory Coast, which plays on Friday against North Korea, has only the most remote chance of making it. It is arguably the worst performance by the African contingent since FIFA first allowed more than one African nation to participate in 1982.

headline: Curing the Monsoon Blues in Mumbai’s Cafes

One of the best ways to do so is to find a cafe — one with good views of the cascading showers, of course — and settle in with a cup of tea, a snack or a hearty lunch.

headline: Tip of the Week: Storing Manuals
text: Keeping paper manuals around for electronic gear and gadgets can lead to a lot of clutter, but there’s an easier way to store those reference guides. Most manufacturers’ Web sites offer those same manuals as PDF files you can download to your computer and search when you need to look up something; keeping them all in a folder named “Product Manuals” makes them easier to find on your hard drive. Sites like Manuals Online and Retrevo collect free user guides for everything from mobile phones to household appliances.

headline: Battle Over Casey’s May Weigh on Takeover Law
text: Litigation has erupted over Alimentation Couche-Tard’s hostile offer for Casey’s General Stores. Each side has now filed competing claims against the other in Federal District Court in Davenport, Iowa. Litigation in a hostile offer is quite common; however, the claims brought by Couche-Tard and Casey’s are rather unusual.

headline: Make Your Own Board Shorts
text: The new Web site shortomatic.com lets you transfer any digital image onto a pair of board shorts. We cooked up these with the help of our art department, but you don’t need to be a graphic designer to use the simple step-by-step service, which is a spinoff of the popular, punnier yogamatic.com (custom-designed yoga mats). At $99 (plus shipping), the shorts aren’t cheap, but they’re hand-sewn, made of super-soft polyester microfiber — and using your own image really does lend this summer staple some idiosyncratic pop. Only a men’s style is available now, in sizes 24 through 38, but a shorter option for beach bunnies will go on sale next month.

headline: Banks Likely to Offset Impact of New Law, Analysts Say
text: Banks are expected to find ways to offset the impact of the new financial regulations on their earnings, though they face a potentially complex process of adapting to the new requirements, analysts said on Friday.

headline: Société Générale Trader Remains an Enigma
text: The trial of Jérôme Kerviel, accused of setting off nearly 5 billion euros in losses at the French bank Société Générale, ended Friday with judges and prosecutors conceding that a two-year investigation and three weeks of court hearings had left them no wiser about what had ultimately motivated the former trader to make his enormous, unauthorized bets.

headline: Hong Kong: Plan to Expand Legislature Is Approved
text: The Legislative Council voted 46 to 12 on Friday to approve a plan to add 10 seats to the legislature in 2012. The public would elect lawmakers to fill five seats. Elected members of the city’s 18 district councils would nominate candidates from their ranks to run for the other five seats, with the public voting on them. Eight lawmakers from the oldest pro-democracy political group, the Democratic Party, joined pro-Beijing parties to support the measure. A ninth, Andrew Cheng, resigned from the party this week in protest and joined lawmakers from the Civic Party and minor pro-democracy parties to oppose the measure as too small a step toward greater voting rights for Hong Kong’s seven million people. The legislature approved a separate plan on Thursday to expand the committee that elects Hong Kong’s chief executive, to 1,200 members in 2012 from 800 now.

headline: The Next Crisis: Public Pension Funds
text: Ever since theWall Street crash, there has been a bull market in Google hits for “public pensions” and “crisis.” Horror stories abound, like the one in Yonkers, where policemen in their 40s are retiring on $100,000 pensions (more than their top salaries), or in California, where payments to Calpers, the biggest state pension fund, have soared while financing for higher education has been cut. Then there is New York City, where annual pension contributions (up sixfold in a decade) would be enough to finance entire new police and fire departments.

headline: Is It Energy’s Turn Now?
text: With the overhaul of financial regulation nearing completion, some Democrats are hoping that Congress can turn to the next big legislative challenge – energy and climate change. There is no consensus yet what such legislation should include, but there is strong determination on the part of the White House and Democratic leaders in Congress to try to move something – anything – before Congress leaves town in August.

headline: William S. Richardson, Ex-Chief Justice in Hawaii, Dies at 90
text: William S. Richardson, who as chief justice of the Hawaii Supreme Court for 16 years was a leading proponent of the rights of native Hawaiians, often relying on ancestral custom rather than Western common law in his decisions, died Monday in Honolulu. He was 90.

headline: Cooking Tools: Induction Burners
text: Last Christmas, I received as a gift an induction burner, a square plastic machine with a glass top that uses electromagnetism to heat pots and pans instantly, with little wasted energy. (Kim Severson wrote about induction burners in April.) Before last year, I was aware of induction stove tops, but had no idea that the little portable cookers existed, certainly not ones that cost around $75, like my Max Burton 6000. As kitchen revelations go, this turned out to be a big one, for five reasons.

headline: 2011 Toyota Sienna

headline: How HDTV Scrambles Beauty Standards
text: Maybe human skinwasn’t meant to be digitized. Maybe, to ensure that people keep being attracted to one another, we should refrain from representing our complexions in the points, dots and samples that make up a high-definition image. Sure, the sports fan loves HD, which displays life in staggeringly fine-grain resolution of up to 1,920 by 1,080 pixels. But other TV fans — those who like prettiness, say — sometimes find ourselves shuddering. Technologically, spots may be a gamechanger; dermatologically, they are too often vitiligic, psoriatic or bubonic.

headline: Porn in the Office
text: Arriving at work, I often find that my boss, who owns the business, had been looking at pornography after-hours on the computer we sometimes share. (He has no private office, and this computer  is the most isolated.) Sometimes he leaves those pages open, so I can’t help  see ing  them. I don’t care what he does so long as it’s not in my work space. Asking him to stop might endanger my job. May I turn  on the parental controls and set a password? M.B., PHILADELPHIA

headline: Isner’s Wimbledon Fairy Tale Ends
text: WIMBLEDON, England  One tennis match made John Isner famous. One long, tense, laugh-at-logic match that defied easy explanation. It lasted 11 hours and sprawled over three days, overshadowed the sport’s most famous tournament and catapulted this giant of a tennis player toward international acclaim.

headline: Where Do Gadgets Really Come From?
text: Armed with our laptopsand smartphones, our apps and Twitter accounts, consumers enjoy previously unimaginable access to marketplace information and sometimes even power. The Web crackles with peer reviews; with the right mobile device we can scan a bar code of something at the mall and compare the price with far-flung retail rivals. And we can vent and maybe achieve some satisfaction. Remember the online video of the slumbering Comcast repairman? Remember when the consultant and writer Jeff Jarvis blogged his unhappy laptop experiences into what became the “Dell Hell” public-relations nightmare? Add it all up, and it’s a significant shift, a “transparency triumph,” as Trendwatching.com put it not long ago.

headline: The Nicaraguan Coconut Salesman
text: The coconut salesman appears every morning in front of the tourist hotel in Jinotepe, Nicaragua. He stands there with his cart full of coconuts, his machete to hack the tops off and his bag of straws. He is in his 50s, with a pronounced belly that strains the fabric of the old T-shirts he wears, and dark, wet eyes.

headline: Jamaicans Ponder Cross-Dressing Gangsters
text: On Thursday evening, Christopher Coke, the leader of Jamaica’s powerful Shower Posse gang, was paraded before the cameras in handcuffs by federal agents in New York, after his long-delayed extradition on gun and drug charges.

headline: German Court Liberalizes Rules for Right to Die Cases
text: BERLIN  In a landmark ruling that will make it easier for people to allow relatives and other loved ones to die, Germany’s highest court ruled Friday that it was not a criminal offense to cut off life-sustaining treatment for a patient.

headline: Inside the List
text: SWEDEN FREEZES OVER:“The Overton Window,” the new political thriller from Glenn Beck (inset), enters at No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list, displacing Stieg Larsson’s “Girl Who Kicked the Hornet’s Nest” after a mere three weeks. Weep not for Larsson, however:the first two installments of his Millennium trilogy are No. 1 and No. 2 on both the trade and mass-market paperback lists.

headline: David Mitchell, the Experimentalist
text: As the Eyjafjallajokull Volcano was spewing plumes of ash into European airspace in April, shuttering airports and stranding millions, the British novelist David Mitchell, a tall, gracious, high-spirited man of 41, was marching me across a long, flat tidal beach near his home in Ireland’s West Cork. Along the way, he told me a story about the perils of humility. “I had a short and rather valuable lesson,” Mitchell said after a morning on the beach, “one of these warnings that the universe gives you on a platter sometimes. I’d done an event in New Zealand at a very large auditorium, hundreds of people, and I was kind of pleased with it; it had gone well. A woman came up to me afterwards, a medievalist at the university there, and she said, ‘Have you heard of the humility topos?’ I said no. She explained that, in the medieval era, humility was seen as a great virtue. The humility topos was used for these abbots — you can think of a good one in Eco’s ‘Name of the Rose’ — who were actually monsters of arrogance, but were always banging on about how humble they were — ‘Just like our lord Jesus Christ. We serve him in humility’ — when they were the least humble people you can find in history. Some even became pope. And the woman looked at me and said, ‘Watch out for the humility topos.’ And then sort of disappeared in a puff of smoke.”

headline: ‘The Thousand Autumns of Jacob de Zoet’
text: Chapter Two: Captain Lacy's Cabin on the Shenandoah, Anchored in Nagasaki Harbor

headline: Chris Carter, Ever the Animal
text: In his short time with the Mets, Chris Carter has impressed his teammates and coaches with his enthusiasm, hard work and good cheer. His nickname, the Animal, seems well deserved.

headline: ‘Got Talent!’ at the Staten Island Ferry
text: The shirt said Hard Rock, but the music was anything but. Hunched over a piano, his back to the Staten Island waterfront, Michael Mignemi swayed gently as he played Pachelbel’s Canon. As the sound filled the breezeway, people heading toward the ferry terminal veered off slowly to him.

headline: Uruguay Finds Potential to Add to Legacy
text: PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa  History is a source of pride for Uruguay’s soccer players, but it is also a burden. They are rather like modern-day Athenians and Romans: working, striving, dreaming but well aware that matching the luminous achievements of their ancestors is probably too much to ask.

headline: Cheers at Europe’s Expense
text: JOHANNESBURG

headline: Letters: Democrat in Chief?
text: Regarding Matt Bai’s article on President Obama, I am thankful we have a president who realizes that robocalls and speaking at rubber-chicken fund-raisers are not consistent with the office of leader of the free world. Most politicians have feet of clay and compromise themselves for the wrong reasons. I am proud of President Obama, and I don’t always vote for Democrats. I vote for whoever I think will do the best job for the country, state or municipality.

headline: The Muslim Past
text: In the United States, a country saturated with instant punditry, serious scholars rarely attain celebrity as public intellectuals. Yet Bernard Lewis, a professor emeritus of Near Eastern studies at Princeton, has long radiated influence far beyond his specialization in Ottoman studies. A friend of Henry Kissinger and a mentor to subsequent cohorts of conservative policy makers, Lewis arguably has done more than any Mideast expert to mold American attitudes to the region.

headline: A Jeep for High Rollers
text: Jonathan Ward has a passion for re-creating Army Jeeps with modern parts.

headline: Letters: The Animal-Cruelty Syndrome
text: Charles Siebert discusses empathy and how children’s capacity for it can be impacted by their own maltreatment and by witnessing the abuse of animals. While it is critical to implement therapies to“heal” people who have been thus affected, prevention strategies, like educating children about the humane treatment of animals, can help protect even more people and animals from harm. Teaching empathy and nurturing that quality from an early age is invaluable in helping children develop into humane adults.

headline: Reform Bill Includes Ban on Movie Futures
text: The prospect of trading futures contracts based on box-office revenue appears dim, as the financial overhaul bill approved early this morning includes language that bans the trading of those contracts.

headline: The Week Ahead: June 27 — July 3
text: Art

headline: Old Friends
text: In a long literary career, the Chicago writer Richard Stern has published eight novels, several highly acclaimed. But he has also dabbled in a genre he calls “orderly miscellany.” “Still on Call,” his sixth such book, is a grab bag of essays, reflections, lectures, blog posts and assorted scribblings that has the fragmented, meandering structure from which such collections often suffer.

headline: Letters: Questions for Christopher J. Brownfield
text: Christopher J. Brownfield should speak a little more carefully when discussing the idea of using nuclear weapons to stop the BP leak.Brownfield states that the “Russians did it four times with 100-percent success rate.” The Russians did not destroy oil wells in this way. Rather, they used nuclear explosives to seal runaway gas wells, but never an oil well on land or underwater. Brownfield also never mentions how difficult it would be to emplace a nuclear explosive a mile underwater, set it off and be assured that no other catastrophe would result.

headline: What Price Perfection? The $80,000 Army Jeep
text: EVEN in Midtown Manhattan, where blocklong Hummer limos barely rate a second glance and six-figure supercars rarely draw more than a yawn, an Icon CJ3B attracts a knot of curious admirers. This, despite its no-gloss finish, bling-free wheels and an interior totally lacking in luxury appointments (a good thing, actually, as there is hardly a distinction between its interior and exterior).

headline: Weird Science
text: As Justin Cronin clearly knows, if you’re a writer seeking to slough off highbrow pretensions — to reject your early efforts at “quiet” fiction and write something with commercial appeal, something that will, if not conquer the critics, at least pay for your kid’s college education — you’d be wise to opt for a vampire novel. The genre has proved so indomitable that it’s a wonder the Balkan underclass, whose age-old folk tales began it all, hasn’t started to request royalties.

headline: Bollywood Prepares Bin Laden Satire
text: After plans to make a movie about Adolf Hitler drew widespread protest and resulted in the withdrawal of the project’s lead actor, the film industry in India is now set to produce a feature about another polarizing figure, Osama bin Laden.

headline: Bank Stocks Remain Up After Finance Overhaul Deal
text: Shares in the nation’s biggest banks were still trading higher in midday trading on Friday, after Congressional negotiators hammered out a compromise on a proposed overhaul of financial regulation.

headline: Speech Recognition’s Early Days
text: In 1982, David Nahamoo had just received his Ph.D. from Purdue University and was headed to a prestigious institution, I.B.M’s Watson Laboratory. But his university peers, he recalls, sniffed at his chosen field — speech recognition — as more science fiction than computer engineering.

headline: Weekend Competition: Are We There Yet?
text: This weekend, as the vacations inch closer, co-vocabularists are invited to share word-games suitable for long journeys by plane, train or automobile.

headline: Racing Under a Watchful Eye That’s Thousands of Miles Away
text: STUDYING the stream of numbers flashing across his computer screen, Mark Williams checked the vital signs of Lewis Hamilton’s McLaren MP4-25 racecar as it attacked a corner at the Australian Grand Prix in March. Hamilton pushed hard at the Albert Park circuit in Melbourne, working his way up to a sixth-place finish after starting 11th.

headline: Financial Bill Includes Ban on Movie Futures
text: From Joseph Plambeck at Media Decoder:

headline: Enemy of the Good? The Whaling Stalemate
text: ‘‘Le mieux est l’ennemi du bien,’’ Voltaire said. The perfect is the enemy of the good. That might have been the case this week in Agadir, Morocco, where the International Whaling Commission failed to make any progress on reducing the global whale catch.

headline: Streaming the Data to Fans’ Homes
text: IT’S not quite the same as driving the team’s racecar on Sunday, but Formula One fans can feel some of the thrill virtually this year on Web sites that have been overhauled to provide real-time streaming on race weekends.

headline: Bret Easton Ellis, Back to Zero
text: At first you think: That’s a nice conceit. “They had made a movie about us,” Bret Easton Ellis’s new book begins, and of course, they did, allowing us at least an early glimpse of the genius of Robert Downey Jr. The movie, it should go without saying, is the film version of “Less Than Zero,” Ellis’s headline-­grabbing 1985 debut. Neither the book nor the movie is named, but titles aren’t necessary, for here are the old familiar names: Blair, Julian, Trent — and Clay, the narrator of that novel and this one, “Imperial Bedrooms,” which takes up their stories a quarter of a century on. So there’s a neat, postmodern, self-­referential beginning, with Clay, the cool observer of his own actions and feelings — or lack of them — observing himself being observed, an acknowledgment that his version of the story may be only one of many.

headline: Crack Agent
text: Car crashes happen in different ways, but they all end the same, with the rest of us looking on in sympathy and prurience: I hope they’re O.K., but I’d like to get a look if they’re not.

headline: The Psychology of Bliss
text: In 2003, a German computer expert named Armin Meiwes advertised online for someone to kill and then eat. Incredibly, 200 people replied, and Meiwes chose a man named Bernd Brandes. One night, in Meiwes’s farmhouse, Brandes took some sleeping pills and drank some schnapps and was still awake when Meiwes cut off his penis, fried it in olive oil and offered him some to eat. Brandes then retreated to the bathtub, bleeding profusely. Meiwes stabbed him in the neck, chopped him up and stored him in the freezer. Over the next several weeks, he defrosted and sautéed 44 pounds of Brandes, eating him by candlelight with his best cutlery.

headline: Give Greed a Chance
text: The United States may be known as a place of self-invention and aspiration, but American literature is densely populated with characters who illustrate the perils of trying to change your station. From Lily Bart to Nick Carraway, the road to hell is paved with grand ambitions. And, more recently, with crazy mortgages. In Martha McPhee’s jaunty new novel, “Dear Money,” the spread of subprime mortgages and their frenzied trade on Wall Street forms the backdrop to a traditional story of an individual gradually succumbing to, and being corrupted by, the lure of wealth and all it promises.

headline: The Age of Ambivalence
text: It may be that the hallmark of the modern moment is a certain demi-­pleasurable drift — the timeless unspooling of information and entertainment on the Internet, Twittering, partial employment, life spans getting longer (even as the economy shrinks), no end to the reproductive years, midlife reinventions, TiVo-ing everything, four-day-week job furloughs — accompanied by a free-­floating melancholy. If the last century crashed into the forces of urbanization, fragmentation and world war, this one seems to be on an endless, murmuring skid. Things are . . . O.K. You know. They’re O.K. Click, click. There’s so much time, at least for some people, but it’s filled with doubts about what, exactly, to do. We can often be a bit frictionless, here at the end of the first decade of the new century. When we’re not feeling postapocalyptic, we hover, paralyzed by choice and what can seem a lack of final consequences.

headline: What We’re Reading: G.E.D.’s vs. Diplomas
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Resort Report | Brian Reyes’s Trip to the Island
text: Holiday hot spots like Capri or St. Barths have provided the inspiration for many a resort collection, but Brian Reyes found his inspiration looking at old photos from a rarely evoked destination island: Ellis Island. The palette is simple and soft with lilac, grays, black, and white, and the silhouettes are modern. Standouts include a great beige fur jacket, a black knit dress and a lot of culotte pants.

headline: Borges on Pleasure Island
text: Little is quite as dull as literary worship; this essay on Borges is thus happily doomed. One finds oneself tempted toward learned-sounding inadequacies like: His work combines the elegance of mathematical proof with the emotionally profound wit of Dostoyevsky. Or: He courts paradox so primrosely, describing his Dupin-like detective character as having “reckless perspicacity” and the light in his infinite Library of Babel as being “insufficient, and unceasing.” But see, such worship is pale.

headline: Fiction Chronicle
text: IMPATIENT WITH DESIRE  By Gabrielle Burton.  Voice/Hyperion, $22.99.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: HITCH-22: A Memoir,  by Christopher Hitchens (Twelve, $26.99.) When the colorful, prolific journalist shares a tender memory, he quickly converts it into a larger observation about politics, always for him the most crucial sphere of moral and intellectual life.

headline: Paperback Row
text: HALF THE SKY: Turning Oppression Into Opportunity for Women Worldwide,  by Nicholas D. Kristof and Sheryl WuDunn (Vintage, $15.95.) The struggle for gender equality is “the paramount moral challenge” of our era, write Kristof and WuDunn, who won a Pulitzer Prize for their coverage of China in The New York Times, and their aim is to “recruit” the reader to join a worldwide movement against “gendercide.” Denouncing abuses and offering strategies, they tell stories of forced prostitution, honor killing and maternal mortality. In The Times, Martha Nussbaum called it a “wonderful book.”

headline: Rereading Christina Stead
text: To the Editor:

headline: Recognizing Quebec
text: To the Editor:

headline: Prisoners of Angola
text: To the Editor:

headline: Electronic Expressions in the Service of the Soul
text: LAURIE ANDERSON was home for a few hours last month — a rare occurrence. This musician and multi-media artist had returned from Poland, where she performed improvised music with the saxophonist and composer John Zorn and the bassist Bill Laswell. Soon she would be off to Iceland for a solo recital, and then to Australia, where she was a curator of the Vivid Live arts festival in Sydney with her husband, Lou Reed. In addition to retrospective and work-in-progress performances she would introduce a video installation and give a high-frequency outdoor concert composed primarily for an audience of dogs. (It was apparently a hit.)

headline: Turn Right, My Love
text: I REMEMBER the first time I noticed. I was driving to Boston from my home in Brooklyn after an extended trip to California. In Los Angeles, the voice of my brand-new portable navigation device had guided me effortlessly through the maze of freeways and road rage like a graceful hostess  unflappable, efficient and with just enough sex appeal to give some sizzle to my protracted absence from my wife. Now, stuck on I-95 in Stamford, Conn., my charming companion had somehow been switched to a stern English schoolmarm.

headline: Last Dance
text: DARCI KISTLER has a way of walking onto a stage and casting a spell. For years you could be sure that someone in the audience  in barely a whisper  would remind you that the woman with the honey blond hair, broad shoulders and killer legs was the last ballerina trained and hired by George Balanchine.

headline: Doodle Jump Reaches Five Million Downloads
text: In early 2009, Igor and Marko Pusenjak, two brothers originally from Croatia, decided they wanted to build an application for the iPhone that would enable them to make extra money on the side.

headline: How to Choose a Mover
text: How I chose movers in the past isn’t anything I’m proud of. The last time I picked a mover, I remember doing a quick search online and then signing up with the first mover I called.

headline: Film Series and Movies Listings
text: MOVIES

headline: Karzai Pressed to Move on Taliban Reintegration
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Three weeks after a grand assembly recommended making peace with the Taliban and other armed groups, NATO and Afghan officials are pressing President Hamid Karzai to move more quickly to set up a council to oversee the process and to set in motion a plan to win over low-level Taliban fighters.

headline: Congress Considers Funding for In-Car Alcohol Detection System
text: A government-auto industry program that is trying to develop a device to detect drunken drivers, which would be installed in all new vehicles, is on track to get a six-fold increase in funding.

headline: Hedge Hogs
text: This is not an obvious time to be glorifying financial tycoons. Making enough money to buy your own private island might have earned you an airbrushed magazine cover a decade ago. Nowadays, though, the erstwhile Masters of the Universe are viewed with such opprobrium that one of their favorite lawyers told me recently he was advising his clients to soft-pedal their objections to financial reform legislation because the more Wall Street hates it, the better it plays on Main Street.

headline: New Stephen Hawking Book Is Coming in a Finite Amount of Time
text: The latest book from Stephen Hawking, the British theoretical physicist and author of the runaway bestseller, “A Brief History of Time,” will be released Sept. 7, its publisher Bantam Dell said on Friday. The new book is called “The Grand Design,” and is written with Leonard Mlodinow, a physicist at the California Institute of Technology. Mr. Hawking’s book will address worldly questions – Why do we exist? Did the universe need a creator? – and consider whether there’s a single unifying theory that can explain all the forces of nature.

headline: This Is How They Roll
text: ANYONE wondering which retro childhood pastime is poised for the kind of revival that roller derby and coed kickball enjoyed in recent years might look no further than Full Circle, a recently opened bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, devoted to Skee-Ball, the classic arcade game that involves rolling a wooden ball up a slightly inclined alley and trying to land it in a series of holes.

headline: Subway Woes, Now and Then
text: Since 1904, there have been not two, but three certainties in life: death, taxes and dissatisfaction with the subway.

headline: Aggression Shift: Mathieu Turns Tables on Youzhny
text: One of the quirks of the tennis scoring system is that a player can win more overall games but still lose the match. Mikhail Youzhny of Russia won one more game than Paul-Henri Mathieu of France, but the Frenchman prevailed in a fascinating five-set match on Court 18, 6-4, 2-6, 2-6, 6-3, 6-4. It was a match that each player seemed in control of, with Youzhny storming back from a first-set loss to dominate Mathieu. But he played more conservatively when he had the lead, allowing Mathieu to seize the initiative with bold, aggressive play.

headline: Prophet-Making
text: In late March, the former Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan told Al Hunt of Bloomberg Television that the financial crisis had been a “once in a century” shocker. “We all misjudged the risks involved,” Greenspan said. “Everybody missed it — academia, the Federal Reserve, all regulators.”

headline: Rare Haven of Stability in Somalia Faces a Test
text: BURAO, Somalia  The rallies usually start early in the morning, before the sunshine hurts.

headline: The Week in Pictures for June 25
text: A look back at the week’s events in New York City and the region.

headline: Phantom Calls and Damp Sensors
text: CHRYSLER and Dodge minivans in need of new air-bag sensors and General Motors OnStar systems that make calls on their own are the subjects of some of the latest technical service bulletins.

headline: Q. and A. With Fred Plotkin (Round 3)
text: Fred Plotkin, author of “Italy for the Gourmet Traveler” is answering reader questions. Questions were submitted by readers last week. (Answers to Round One and two.)

headline: Risk Mismanagement
text: Wall Street is a place of big money and bigger egos. So it’s hardly surprising that vicious feuds will occasionally break out, especially when someone’s being blamed for the demise of a major investment bank, as James Cayne was when Bear Stearns collapsed in March 2008. Shortly after that historic event, Alan C. Greenberg, Cayne’s predecessor as the head of Bear Stearns, started working on his memoirs. It was reported that Cayne was wary of the coming Greenberg broadside.

headline: The Minivan, Once a Star Player, Now Sits on Sidelines
text: MAYBE it was an image problem, or soccer-mom backlash. Or perhaps the minivan was a victim of bullying by those big bad S.U.V.’s. But for whatever reason, the family-van market is a shadow of its former self.

headline: London Underground | Time for Architecture
text: Architecture is very much on the agenda this month. The biennial London Festival of Architecture in full swing, with events and activities taking place across the city, and four major institutions have just opened must-see exhibitions that do their best to critique the personal and domestic spaces we inhabit.

headline: Bookmark This: Resources for Oft-Taught Subjects All in One Place
text: School’s finally out for many, but we know that even teachers not staffing summer programs or working in year-round schools use this season to plan curriculum.

headline: Legends of the Fall
text: The fall of Lehman Brothers, the 158-year-old firm bankrupted by its hubris and perilous mortgage bets, was one of the defining episodes of the 2008 financial crisis. Its chief executive, Richard S. Fuld Jr., became overnight, in the words of Vicky Ward, “a poster boy for the naked avarice of Wall Street.”

headline: TimesCast | June 25, 2010
text: In today's Timescast, reports on the new financial reform deal in Congress, a new job for the David Letterman extortionist and a World Cup update.

headline: Policy Conflicts Seen as Obama Arrives in Toronto
text: TORONTO  President Obama arrived here Friday for back-to-back meetings of world leaders that will test international unity on how to restore global economic growth.

headline: Court Upholds Landmark Status of City and Suburban First Avenue Estates
text: The New York Appellate Court on Thursday unanimously upheld the landmark status of the City and Suburban First Avenue Estates on Manhattan’s Upper East Side. In 2006, the two tan-brick apartment houses were designated a landmark, even though the owners had reclad them in reddish-pink stucco, drastically changing their appearance.

headline: That On-Again Brooklyn Yard Party? Now at a New Location
text: Turns out the Gowanus canal is socially, not only environmentally, inhospitable. Just two weeks after announcing its intention to do a summer’s worth of programming there, Sunday Best, the weekly electronica party that tried to make a go of the outdoor space known as the Yard, will move on, its founders said. Though licensing for alcohol and other details were proceeding as planned, there were unforeseen complications with the space, Justin Carter, a founder of Sunday Best, said in a phone interview. Rather than leave fans wondering whether the party would go on each week, they are moving to the courtyard of Brooklyn Fireproof, a warehouse space and café in Bushwick, starting this Sunday, with Kenny Larkin, a Detroit D.J. on the decks, and no toxic odors in the air.

headline: Snowe Urges Stand-Alone Extension of Jobless Benefits
text: 2:46 p.m. | Updated  After joining with her fellow Republicans to block a bill that would have extended unemployment insurance, Senator Olympia J. Snowe of Maine urged Democrats on Friday to put forward a separate bill to help people who have exhausted their jobless benefits.

headline: Vatican Criticizes Raid on Belgian Church Offices
text: ROME  The Vatican expressed “shock” on Friday at the raid on Thursday by the Belgian police of church offices in their search for hidden evidence of child sex abuse by priests. It also voiced its “indignation” at what it called the “violation” of two cardinals’ tombs in the search.

headline: ReTweet | Louis Vuitton Tattoos
text: A tweetpic from T Magazine’s men’s fashion director, Bruce Pask.

headline: Now Screening | Rick Owens
text: The Spring/Summer 2011 collection from Rick Owens at Paris  Fashion Week.

headline: Banks Expected to Offset Impact of Financial Bill
text: 4:14 p.m. | Updated Banks are expected to find ways to offset the impact of the new financial regulations on their earnings, though they face a potentially complex process of adapting to the new requirements, analysts said Friday, The New York Times’s Christine Hauser reports.

headline: Pabst Brewing Sells Itself to Metropoulos
text: The Pabst Brewing Company, the seller of the hipster staple beer Pabst Blue Ribbon, said on Friday that it has sold itself to C. Dean Metropoulos, a veteran food executive known for corporate turnarounds.

headline: Now Screening | Rick Owens
text: The Spring/Summer 2011 collection from Rick Owens at Paris Fashion Week.

headline: After the Leopard, the Deluge
text: LUCHINO VISCONTI’S melancholy epic “The Leopard” was grievously misused when it opened in the United States in 1963. The film’s American distributor, 20th Century Fox, clipped its running time to 161 minutes from 185, released it with a dubbed English-language soundtrack rather than Visconti’s preferred Italian version, printed Giuseppe Rotunno’s muted Technicolor cinematography in Fox’s lesser DeLuxe Color process, and trimmed the top and bottom of the widescreen Super Technirama images to conform to Fox’s slightly wider CinemaScope format.

headline: Correction
text: An article on June 13 about the directors Mark and Jay Duplass described their movie “Do-Deca-Pentathlon” incorrectly. The film focuses on warring siblings. It is not a film about a film that focuses on warring siblings.

headline: From Students, Less Kindness for Strangers?
text: FED up with the Me-Me-Me MySpace generation? Inclined to believe today’s young ’uns are blindingly self-aggrandizing and entitled? According to a major new study of college students, you may well be right.

headline: New Rikers 'Librarian' Looks Familiar
text: Robert Halderman was arrested last fall on charges of extorting David Letterman.

headline: Giants Draft Pick Seriously Injured in Crash
text: Chad Jones, a rookie safety on the New York Giants, was seriously injured in a car accident in New Orleans Friday morning, the Giants confirmed.

headline: TimesCast: The Regulatory Deal
text: On Friday’s edition of TimesCast, David Gillen, a deputy business editor at The Times, discusses how Congressional negotiators came to agreement to advance the most sweeping changes to financial regulation since the Great Depression.

headline: World Cup Live: Chile vs. Spain
text: Data by Match Analysis

headline: Senate Confirms T.S.A. Chief
text: The Senate confirmed John S. Pistole as head of the Transportation Security Administration by unanimous consent on Friday.

headline: Africa’s Last World Cup Hope Is Ghana
text: PRETORIA, South Africa  The six African teams in the World Cup have been whittled to one, meaning that Ghana will carry a continent’s hopes when it faces the United States in the Round of 16 on Saturday in Rustenburg.

headline: After 3,100 Miles, a Word on Diabetes Awareness
text: On March 23, Yijoo Kwon, 64, a Korean immigrant and retired businessman from Palisades Park, N.J., laced up his running shoes in Los Angeles and started jogging east. His destination was the United Nations. His goal was to raise awareness of diabetes, a disease he has suffered from since 1996.

headline: World Cup Live: Switzerland vs. Honduras
text: Switzerland and Honduras were both eliminated from the 2010 World Cup after playing out a dull 0-0 tie in Bloemfontein tonight. Spain beat Chile, 2-1, in Pretoria and both will advance to the round of 16 from Group H.

headline: Pulse
text: What Lara Stone is wearing now, gold-plated stainless-steel watches and more items.

headline: A Solar Bulb May Light the Way
text: Nearly 130 years after Thomas Edison created the first marketable incandescent light bulb, nearly two billion people around the globe still live their lives without a steady supply of electric light. The problem is not light bulbs, of course, but living off the grid.

headline: Music for the BlackBerry, Wirelessly
text: If you’re a longtime BlackBerry user and you haven’t made the iPhone or Android plunge, let’s stipulate to the fact that you probably don’t care much about apps, pinch-and-pull screens and videoconferencing. Give you a phone that works, and reliable e-mail and let everyone else foam at the mouth for the latest gadgetry.

headline: A World Cup Blackout in the Bronx
text: Even before the lineup was announced, organizers expected hundreds of people to come to Lou Gehrig Plaza on the Grand Concourse, just blocks from Yankee Stadium, to watch Saturday’s World Cup game on an outdoor giant-screen broadcast.

headline: BMW Recalls 15,000 Motorcycles
text: It is a tough week for BMW’s motorcycle division, with more than 15,000 bikes being recalled for three different problems, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘How Pleasure Works’
text: This week: Paul Bloom on the origins and meanings of pleasure; Charles McGrath talks about John Updike’s archive; David Carr reviews “Portrait of the Addict as a Young Man” by Bill Clegg; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: Storm Could Disrupt Effort in Gulf
text: Coast Guard officials are on alert for a potential tropical storm system in the Caribbean that could enter the Gulf of Mexico this weekend or early next week and disrupt efforts to contain the vast oil spill from a stricken offshore well there.

headline: In Documentary, Wall of Sound Meets Wall of Law
text: LONDON

headline: Whale Hunting and Whale Jamming
text: The seemingly unbridgeable divide over whale hunting that was on display earlier this week at the 62nd meeting of the International Whaling Commission had as much to do with clashing cultures as international politics or other factors.

headline: Dirty Fun: Band’s Midnight Evolution
text: THOUGH it was afternoon, the shades in the studio were pulled tight, which seemed appropriate for a Scissor Sisters rehearsal. Nighttime suits this band, which got its start playing flamboyant dance-pop at late-late gigs on the Lower East Side and in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, always with the idea that the best stuff happens in the wee hours, in the dark, when anything, or anyone, is possible.

headline: An iPhone Q&A
text: Wow, what a couple of days! The annual release of a new iPhone always seems to whip my readership into an emotional frenzy. All that hope, all that hype, all those religious warriors bent on disparaging people who choose other phones! Can’t we all just get along?

In response, Alan Jacobs points to this study, which suggests otherwise:

headline: Surely It’s 30 (Don’t Call Me Shirley!)
text: WHEN the creators of  “Airplane!”  were lining up actors for their rollicking parody three decades ago, some of the straight-arrow character actors that ended up in the cast worried about the harm it might do to their careers. One of the most skittish participants: Peter Graves, the taciturn  “Mission: Impossible”  star who played the movie’s pilot, a kindly veteran who welcomes a little boy named Billy into the cockpit and asks questions like “Ever seen a grown man naked?”

headline: Kombucha May Be Treated Like Alcohol, Government Says
text: Fans of kombucha know it packs a little kick, but perhaps too much of one? Earlier this week, Whole Foods Market pulled unpasteurized versions of the fermented tea from its shelves because the alcohol content might be high enough to attract attention from the government.

headline: The Cost of Raising a Child
text: The U.S.D.A. numbers are in, and they aren’t pretty. It now costs an average middle-income American family $222,360 to raise a child from birth to 18. That’s 22 percent higher than it was in 1960, adjusted for inflation. And that doesn’t begin to include college costs.

headline: A Blooming Democracy in the Desert
text: Each successful election feeds hope in Somaliland that it will be recognized as a separate nation for carving a functioning space out of one of the world’s most chaotic countries.

headline: Keeping Your Phone on a Digital Leash
text: What happens when you have misplaced your iPhone or Android? You know the feeling — panic. And so many of us can be seen tightly grasping our phones. Maybe we want to be quick on the draw in case a call comes in. Or maybe the cost of replacing the do-everything smartphone is too high. Or maybe the phones have just become a part of our selves.

headline: We Made It Ourselves | Beekman 1802 Blaak Cheese
text: A few years back, two dandies from the Big City — the former drag queen turned ad exec and writer Josh Kilmer-Purcell and his partner Brent Ridge, an assistant clinical professor at Mount Sinai, who served as vice president of healthy living for Martha Stewartthe latter.) Don’t be fooled, though. Meticulously tidy trappings aside, Beekman 1802 — the name of the property and the brand the “Fabulous Beekman Boys” have built around it — is earnestly committed to sustainability and produces some righteously good cheese.

headline: His Last Name Is Reid; Just Call Him Rory
text: Rory Reid, the Democratic candidate in Nevada’s gubernatorial race and son of Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, has swept his political pedigree under the rug.

headline: On the Street | Leg Show
text: With summer's heat comes shorts in all lengths, from pin-up-girl hot pants to men's office wear, with tie and jacket.

headline: Berdych Outlasts Istomin in Another Five-Setter
text: WIMBLEDON, England – Unseeded Denis Istomin of Uzbekistan fought toe-to-toe with the world’s 13th ranked player, Tomas Berdych of the Czech Republic, before falling 6-7 (1), 7-6 (5), 6-7 (8), 6-3, 6-4, in the third round of Wimbledon.

headline: Two Teams Speak Lilting Language, Play Stilted Game
text: Yawn. Brazil may win this World Cup come July 11, but anyone who still has illusions that its coach, Carlos Dunga, is for the Beautiful Game should shed them now.

text: Boy, are the knives out for Tom Cruise.

headline: Paris Men’s: Head Case
text: Junya Watanabe took up sailing today, as a theme for his spring 2011 collection. At Comme des Garçons, Rei Kawakubo investigated skulls, or “les cranes,” as the French say. Some of the cranes appeared as prints on paper shirts and on full, gathered skirts and dresses. There were also some terrific wallpaper effects. I think you could compose a wonderful short story around a boy in Southern small town who wears a skull-print skirt. And I don’t say that because I think there is anything strange about the idea. On the contrary, it now seems normal.

headline: Educated Women, Opting for Motherhood
text: Generally speaking, childlessness is rising: More women are opting to forgo motherhood than their predecessors a generation ago.

headline: Now Screening | Louis Vuitton
text: The Spring/Summer 2011 collection from Louis Vuitton at Paris Fashion Week.

headline: Carlsen Wins Kings Tournament by Wide Margin
text: The top seed won his last game to finish two points ahead of his nearest competitor. It was one of the most impressive performances of his young career.

headline: Target Wants You To Friend Their Sweaters
text: The push by retailers into social media continues, with some even bringing out Version 2.0 or 2.5 of their presences on Web sites like Facebook, Twitter or YouTube. Case in point, Target, which has introduced an application on its Facebook page for its Merona line of clothing.

headline: Embedistan
text: BAGHDAD — Even before a magazine journalist brought down Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, the institutionalized practice of journalists moving and living with military units was one of the most controversial legacies of America’s 21st-century wars.

headline: Resort Report | Acne’s Split Personality
text: If I had a penny for every time a designer mentioned Patti Smith as a source of inspiration, my money worries would disappear. Acne’s Jonny Johansson narrowly escaped owing me a penny yesterday; his resort collection was inspired by a slightly more unusual suspect within the Smith circle: Sam Wagstaff. If you haven’t seen “Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe,” add it to your Netflix queue pronto! Johansson riffed on Wagstaff’s ability to morph from uptown art collector to downtown bohemian in a collection that includes slouchy masculine suits for above 57th Street and sexy, short leather dresses that are perfect for below 14th.

headline: Sunday Preview
text: When Henry James was 26, he took a trip to Italy, a place he described as “warm & living & palpable.” Adam Begley follows in his footsteps, visiting the four Tuscan hill towns that James described in an 1874 Atlantic Monthly article and finds the spirit — if not the landscape — that inspired the author in his later writings.

headline: Rockaway Taco Sprouts a Farm Stand
text: Surfer dudes can always load up on veggies and fruit at some Greenmarket before they jumped on the A Train to Rockaway Beach in Queens. But it’s easier to do the shopping once they get there, at the new little market in the expanding, ramshackle complex anchored by Rockaway Taco. Elizabeth Gilchrist, a partner, said the produce was mainly local (much of it from Blooming Hill Farm in the Hudson Valley) and organic. Right now, greens, including callaloo, are in abundance, $3 a bag. There are also some tropical fruits because they are used by the smoothie stand that shares the premises. The market also sells bread from Roberta’s in Bushwick, Brooklyn, and some locally handmade odds and ends like glasses made from Red Stripe beer bottles, $10 each.

headline: The Shame of JournoList
text: When the intra-liberal e-mail round-robin known as JournoList first attracted attention early last year, it seemed significant primarily as a milestone in the emergence of a kind of “movement liberal” mentality among certain media personalities — a team-player spirit, you might say, that imitated what liberals have long perceived as one of the strengths of movement conservatism. I suspect that some of the journalists who participated in the e-mail list (I’m thinking of figures who write for mainstream outlets like Time and Newsweek and The New Yorker, in particular) would have never dreamed of joining a semi-secret liberal forum a decade ago: That would have seemed too partisan, too compromising, too biased. But now the world had changed, and they were happy to join a members-only political discussion group that deliberately excluded right-of-center writers and thinkers.

headline: Photo Quiz: Controversial Pajamas Edition
text: From time to time, we ask readers of The Lede to help us put news photographs in context and explain why certain images are causing a stir.

headline: A Catskills Cottage Remade on a Budget
text: A Brooklyn couple spent weekends from October to May renovating and decorating their 1920s cottage with thrift-store and Craigslist finds.

headline: Farmhouse Palette
text: A renovated Catskill farmhouse that a painter has filled with vignettes, created by pairing objects old and new, high with low.

headline: Natural Disasters Happen. Will Your Home Be Ready?
text: THE oil spill wreaking havoc in the Gulf of Mexico may be capturing your attention at the moment. But the odds are far greater that a natural disaster  a hurricane, wildfire or windstorm, for instance  will affect you.

headline: Insurance War Stories From Natural Disasters
text: This week’s “Wealth Matters” column offers tips on what you can do to protect your home from hurricanes, wildfires and other natural disasters.

headline: Georgia Knocks Stalin Off His Pedestal
text: GORI, Georgia  In the predawn darkness on Friday, Georgian authorities carried out a clandestine operation in Gori’s central square. Wrapping thick cables around Stalin’s neck and under one of his armpits, they hoisted him off the pedestal where he has stood for 48 years and set him nose-first on the back of a flatbed truck.

headline: How Good Is Michael Bradley? The Stats Say Very Good
text: Anyone who has watched the United States at this World Cup has been impressed by Michael Bradley. He is relentless in midfield — making plays, taking shots, scoring goals, breaking up opposition thrusts. His shaven head always seems to be in the picture, in the middle of where things are happening.

headline: A Look Ahead at the Knockout Phase
text: The World Cup has hurtled into the knockout phase, with half the original 32 teams still alive after today’s conclusion of the group stage. But those numbers will already start dwindling on Saturday, and the American team is one of the first at risk.

headline: Living in Greenlawn, N.Y.
text: A hamlet in the town of Huntington offers a small-town feel, with good schools and homes on generous lots.

headline: The Solution to Bad Calls: The Quadrant Approach
text: In this World Cup, as with every other World Cup in history, wrong calls happen. Whether they are crucial and end a team’s hopes or whether they are inconsequential, the calls are frustrating at the least and infuriating at the most. Naturally we focus our anger on the man on the field wearing a different color shirt. Yes, the referee gets most of the blame, or the whole refereeing team and occasionally a manipulative player who takes a dive to get a call.

headline: Rwandan Editor Who Accused Officials in Shooting Is Killed
text: KIGALI, Rwanda  A Rwandan journalist who accused the Rwandan government of trying to assassinate a dissident in South Africa was himself killed Thursday night in Rwanda’s capital, Kigali.

headline: An Indian Tycoon’s Tale

headline: China Lets Its Currency Hit a New High Against the Dollar Just Ahead of a G-20 Meeting
text: HONG KONG  As global leaders assembled for a meeting in Canada over the weekend, China allowed its currency to close Friday at the strongest level against the dollar since currency policies were overhauled in 2005.

headline: Eurofile | A Fine Metz
text: In Alexander Lobrano’s new column, Eurofile, the author of “Hungry for Paris” writes about the best tables (and beds) on the continent.With the opening last month of the Metz branch of Paris’s Centre Pompidou, a lot of people are suddenly curious about the city in Eastern France (which is pronounced “Mess” in French). The fact is that Metz is a destination that draws blank stares from most foreigners — the American exceptions to this rule are most likely from Kansas City, Mo., Metz’s American sister city — and often far worse from the French.

headline: Fallon: ‘It’s Going to Be Boring’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: I saw the confirmation hearing for Supreme Court nominee Elena Kagan will be broadcast live Monday on C-Span 3. You know it’s going to be boring when C-Span 2 passes on it.

text: PLUS-SIZE actresses like Mo’Nique and Gabourey Sidibe have recently been receiving a big helping of attention, but the petite section of our pop culture has also been seeing some serious action of late.

headline: State Budget Bill Would Cap Property Taxes and Let Grocers Sell Wine
text: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson is including controversial proposals to cap local property taxes and allow the sale of wine in grocery stores in an emergency budget bill that lawmakers are expected to put to a vote on Monday to keep state government operating.

headline: Oil Burning Stirs Fear for Sea Turtles
text: One method for combating the massive oil spill caused by the explosion of the Deepwater Horizon rig has been to corral some of the thicker oil in the Gulf of Mexico and burn it. This week there was an alarming report from a boat captain saying that sea turtles were being burned alive.

headline: TD1 Forms in West-Central Caribbean
text: Since last weekend, there has been an area of disturbed weather gradually making its way from the southern Windward Islands to its current location just north of Honduras. During the past 18 hours or so, it has gotten much better organized… the convection is stronger, more persistent, and more centrally located over the low-level circulation. Based on those indicators plus and an aircraft reconnaissance flight into it, it was upgraded to Tropical Depression 1 at 22Z today (6pm EDT). The intensity was found to be 30kts and 1004mb and on an upward trend.

headline: Scorecard | Rick Owens Wins!
text: When phrases like “post-apocalyptic androgyny” start cropping up in the reviews, you know Scorecard must be in Paris, that City of Light where men’s-wear designers have never been reluctant to engage in a little gender play. Thursday morning, La Roux got things rolling at Viktor & Rolf with a literally borrowed from Monsieur look for her performance, a theme later reversed by Alexis Mabille’s femmy floral appliqués. Yet when it comes to truly mind-bending performative subversions, critics concurred that Rick Owens’s boys who look like nuns in stripper heels carried the day.

headline: V.A. Loans Harder to Get
text: MILITARY veterans have long been accustomed to a relatively easy mortgage process. Even borrowers with no down payment or a low credit score were usually granted V.A. loans, in large part because the Department of Veterans Affairs insures a quarter of the loan amount.

French Building at 551 Fifth Avenue and the retail space at 666 Fifth and the St. Regis Hotel.

text: TAMARA WHEELING considers herself blessed. After 15 years spent living in a basement apartment with her three children, now 21, 18 and 6, she recently bought and moved into a five-bedroom two-bath colonial with a fenced-in yard in Mastic.

headline: Greenlawn, N.Y.
text: SIOBHAN BERNDT grew up in a small town in Ireland and craved “that small-town feel.” Recently she found it, in the 3.8-square-mile hamlet of Greenlawn. With her husband and their children, ages 13, 10 and 7, she made the move after 11 years next door in Huntington Station  where even buying a carton of milk had required getting into the car.

headline: A Design Makeover for Affordable Housing
text: THE TNS Development Group of College Point, Queens, has built about 40 buildings classified as affordable housing over the last two decades, and each has had finer-grade detailing than the one before it. Its latest project, the Shelton in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, continues that trend, with four chandeliers and doormen in the lobby, and a 600-square-foot gym on the second floor.
