headline: Biden to Visit Gulf on Tuesday

headline: Lexus Hybrid Recalled Over Fuel Leak in Crash Test
text: 6:16 p.m. | Updated Lexus announced Friday that it was recalling about 17,000 of its 2010-model HS 250h hybrid sedans, after testing by federal officials found that too much gasoline had leaked in a rear-impact test.

text: The Spring/Summer 2011 collection from Louis Vuitton at Paris Fashion Week.

headline: Ode to the Apricot
text: This week, Martha Rose Shulman celebrates the nothing-like-it-flavor of ripe apricots, with their “tart edge and almond-y overtones.”

headline: Rising From the Pit, to the Moment
text: At the farewell performance of the conductor Maurice Kaplow on Thursday night, something so refreshing occurred at New York City Ballet that you want it to happen at least once a season. After the first intermission, the floor of the orchestra pit at the David H. Koch Theater rose until there was no pit. Mr. Kaplow raised his baton, and Carl Maria von Weber’s overture to “Euryanthe” began.

headline: The Mysteries of Tobias Wong
text: THE designer Karim Rashid was stunned when he read the news online that Tobias Wong, the enfant terrible of the design world, had died on May 30 at 35, in what authorities ruled a suicide. “You’re just starting your career,” he recalled thinking. “Why would you do this?”

headline: Burgers With a Personal Touch
text: Those who love the enhanced fast food of Manhattan’s Shake Shacks will find a fellow enthusiast in Joshua Elstein, who runs the Burger Factory, a family-owned business that opened four months ago in a white clapboard house on a woodsy side street in Armonk.

headline: A Laid-Back Option on Main Street
text: LATE on a Saturday afternoon in Hastings-on-Hudson, Rainwater Grill hummed. Young children coursed in and out of the dining room’s open French doors; diners filled the many tables indoors and the half dozen outside; and a line of hungry customers, with and without reservations, waited to be seated.

headline: In Marketing, Pride Goeth Before the Fall
text: Every late spring and summer, marketers that are aiming sales pitches at gay men and lesbians introduce campaigns and promotions with “pride” themes, seeking to take advantage of the numerous gay-pride events that occur during those months in major markets around the country.

headline: Where Chinese Faltered, New American Thrives
text: JUST before Labor Day in 2006, an upscale Chinese restaurant called Wei Fun opened in East Hampton. It blossomed in the summers but struggled the rest of the year, finally closing in October 2008. The place reopened in May as the Grill on Pantigo, with the same proprietors and the same chef but a different cuisine: New American.

headline: How Cirque Slipped on ‘Shpeel’
text: Less than six weeks after opening in New York, “Banana Shpeel”  the latest high-budget, high-profile show from Cirque du Soleil  is scheduled to close on Sunday. For Cirque, the show was supposed to be another milestone: a production that could compete artistically and commercially with Broadway, blending signature Cirque acrobatics and clowns with elements of vaudeville, dance and musical theater. Instead “Banana Shpeel” will go down as one of the most frustrating failures in Cirque’s history.

headline: A Market Feeds Its High-Rise
text: David Chung rarely lacks topics for elevator conversation in the 37-story Liberty Towers apartment building in Jersey City, where he lives.

headline: Two Southern Cuisines From a Northern Fan
text: AT Drew’s Bayshore Bistro in Keyport, the chef and owner, Andrew Araneo, cooks the happy, brash dishes of Louisiana and the Carolina-Georgia coast: crab meunière, gumbo, shrimp and grits, crayfish, jambalaya and étouffée.

headline: Maturing Dancers in the Spotlight, Shifting From Whirling Cadets to Human Pretzels
text: BECKET, Mass.  What is the alchemy that turns a young dance technician into an artist? You could catch glimpses of that transformation at the Doris Duke Theater on Thursday night, when the Dance Theater of Harlem Ensemble performed at the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival.

headline: Pushing Stylistic Limits
text: On encountering the labels of Anthony Nappa Wines, one might speculate that the winemaker is playful, adventurous, provocative and young. Right on all counts.

headline: Bracing for 35 Probable School Closings Next Year
text: If you thought this year was a dramatic one for school closings — with 19 city schools shut in January over the objections of thousands of parents and teachers before being given a temporary reprieve by a court — wait until next year.

headline: Cambodian Dreams, Far From Home
text: The French-Cambodian choreographer Emmanuèle Phuon, fondly known as Manou during her time as a dancer with Mikhail Baryshnikov’s White Oak Dance Project, digs into her past in “Khmeropédies I & II.” She began training at 5 at the Royal Ballet of Cambodia; in her new two-part work, which opened on Thursday night at the Baryshnikov Arts Center, she applies Western ideas to traditional Cambodian dance.

headline: Now Frosting | The Cake Committee
text: And I thought strawberries were overrated. Who would have guessed that a cake, slathered in a heavy mask of pink frosting and garnished with tiny plastic clown heads, would prove me wrong?

headline: Cabaret: Precarious but Resilient
text: Stability is a word not often used to describe New York City’s fragile cabaret world, where only a few can make a full-time living, and the clubs themselves ride an economic seesaw from week to week. But because Manhattan’s three major supper clubs  the Café Carlyle, the Oak Room and Feinstein’s at Loews Regency  are attached to hotels, their survival is not solely dependent on the box office.

headline: New Hawking Book Is Out In a Finite Amount of Time
text: The latest book from Stephen Hawking, the British theoretical physicist and author of the bestseller “A Brief History of Time,” will be released Sept. 7, its publisher, Bantam Dell, said on Friday. The new book is titled “The Grand Design” and was written with Leonard Mlodinow, a physicist at the California Institute of Technology. Mr. Hawking’s book will address worldly questions  Why do we exist? Did the universe need a creator?  and consider whether there’s a single unifying theory that can explain all the forces of nature. Mr. Mlodinow is the author of “The Drunkard’s Walk: How Randomness Rules Our Lives,” about how mathematical laws affect seemingly simple events around us, and he collaborated with Mr. Hawking on “A Briefer History of Time,” published in 2005.

headline: N.E.A. To Present Achievement Awards
text: The National Endowment for the Arts will announce lifetime achievement awards on Friday in the fields of opera, jazz, and folk and traditional arts. The honorees include the composer Philip Glass, right, for opera, and five members of the Marsalis family, for jazz. Besides Branford, Delfeayo, Ellis Jr., Jason and Wynton Marsalis, the other 2011 Jazz Masters are Orrin Keepnews, a writer and record producer; Hubert Laws, a flutist; David Liebman, a saxophonist and flutist; and Johnny Mandel, a composer-arranger. The honorees in folk and traditional arts are Yacub Addy, a Ghanaian drummer; Jim Chancellor, a fiddler; Gladys Kukana Grace, a Lauhala weaver; Mary Jackson, a sweetgrass basketweaver; Delano Floyd McCoury, a bluegrass guitarist and singer; Judith McCulloh, a folklorist and editor; Kamala Lakshmi Narayanan, a Bharatanatyam Indian dancer; Mike Rafferty, an Irish flute player; and Ezequiel Torres, an Afro-Cuban drummer and drum builder. The opera honorees, besides Mr. Glass, are Martina Arroyo, a soprano; David DiChiera, a composer and the general director of the Michigan Opera Theater; and Eve Queler, the music director of Opera Orchestra of New York. Each award comes with $25,000.

headline: Lilith Tour Cancels Dates, Report Says
text: Just before the resurrected Lilith tour is scheduled to begin on Sunday in Calgary, Alberta, The Globe and Mail newspaper of Toronto reported that the concert series has been canceling dates because of poor ticket sales. The Lilith tour, which spotlights female artists and whose founders include Sarah McLachlan, is preparing for its first season since 1999, with a lineup that includes Mary J. Blige, Sheryl Crow, above, and Erykah Badu. But a manager for Norah Jones told The Globe and Mail that the dates Ms. Jones was scheduled to perform on, from Aug. 10 through Aug. 16 in West Palm Beach and Tampa, Fla.; Birmingham, Ala.; Houston; and Dallas had been dropped. “Norah was prepared to do all the Lilith dates she was contracted for and then those dates were canceled,” the manager, Sam Feldman, said. The Lilith tour had previously announced the cancellations of stops in Phoenix and Nashville. A press representative for the 2010 Lilith tour wrote in an e-mail message that there was “nothing to confirm right now.”

headline: Amid a Wealth of Farmers’ Markets, Marketing

headline: Bklyn Yard Party Now at a New Location
text: Turns out the Gowanus Canal is socially as well as environmentally inhospitable. Just two weeks after announcing its intention to do a summer’s worth of programming at the Bklyn Yard, an event space by the canal, Sunday Best, a weekly electronica party, will move on, its founders said. Though licensing for alcohol and other details were proceeding as planned, there were unforeseen complications with the space, Justin Carter, a founder of Sunday Best, said in a telephone interview. Rather than leave fans wondering whether the party would go on each week, they are moving to the courtyard of Brooklyn Fireproof, a warehouse space and cafe in Bushwick, starting this Sunday, with Kenny Larkin, a Detroit D.J. on the decks, and no toxic odors in the air.

headline: A Good Night for Rookies
text: Two premieres on ABC lifted the network in the ratings on Thursday, though crime show repeats on CBS led the night over all. According to Nielsen’s estimates, ABC garnered its best ratings of the night with “Wipeout” at 8 p.m., which attracted 7.8 million viewers. Following it, ABC’s new police drama “Rookie Blue” made its debut at 9, drawing 7.3 million viewers, while at 10, the network’s eight-part documentary series “Boston Med” got off to a decent start with 5.1 million viewers. Fox was third with “So You Think You Can Dance” (6.4 million) following a rerun of “Glee” (3.9 million). NBC placed a distant fourth with a line-up of mostly comedy repeats.

headline: Bollywood Prepares a Bin Laden Satire
text: After plans to make a movie about Adolf Hitler drew widespread protest and resulted in the withdrawal of the project’s lead actor, the film industry in India is now set to produce a feature about another polarizing figure, Osama bin Laden. But unlike “Dear Friend Hitler,” which will be a historical drama about that German dictator’s last days, the Bollywood movie “Tere bin Laden” (“Without You, bin Laden”) uses the Al Qaeda leader and the 9/11 attacks as a vehicle for satire, Agence France-Presse reported. In “Tere bin Laden,” a reporter played by the Pakistani actor and singer Ali Zafar is blocked from entering the United States after Sept. 11, 2001. The reporter becomes the subject of worldwide attention and a White House investigation when he begins producing fake news reports using a bin Laden impersonator. Mr. Zafar was quoted by Agence France-Presse as saying that the film “is a satire and does not hurt anyone’s ideology.” He added: “The idea excited me and the script was hilarious.” The film’s writer and director, Abhishek Sharma, told the wire service, “People want new concepts, not commercial films.”

headline: Court Upholds Status of Manhattan Buildings
text: The New York Appellate Court on Thursday unanimously upheld the landmark status of the City and Suburban First Avenue Estates on the Upper East Side. In 2006, the two tan-brick apartment houses were designated a landmark, even though the owners had re-clad them in reddish-pink stucco, drastically changing their appearance. “The two buildings clearly have a historical significance that justifies their designation as landmarks,” the court said in its decision. City Councilwoman Jessica Lappin, who represents parts of the Upper East Side and Roosevelt Island and was formerly chairwoman of the council’s landmarks committee, said: “I commend the court for making the right decision. Now the owner should restore these buildings to their former state and stop fighting a losing and wrongheaded battle with the community. The ugly pink stucco has to go.” Brian Maddox, a spokesman for the Stahl York Avenue, which owns the property, said, “We are weighing all legal options, including an appeal, which will permit us to pursue our interest in developing the property.”

headline: Galliano Disc Set
text: John Galliano drew from the movies tonight—scenes from Chaplin, Keaton and Visconti’s “Death in Venice.” It’s hard to know what unites these icons, and why now, but they provided Mr. Galliano and his team with familiar textures, waistcoats, some beautiful cream-colored suits with black details and satin ribbon espadrilles (the Visconti/Mann moment), and trousers that were low at both waist and crotch and shown with undersized frock coats.

headline: Iraq’s Ancient Ruins Face New Looting
text: DHAHIR, Iraq  The looting of Iraq’s ancient ruins is thriving again. This time it is not a result of the “stuff happens” chaos that followed the American invasion in 2003, but rather the bureaucratic indifference of Iraq’s newly sovereign government.

headline: Works From Six Collections, in a Dialogue of Contradiction

headline: For S.E.C., Self-Financing Remains but a Dream
text: One of the overlooked changes in the final financial regulatory bill was the removal of a proposed measure that would have made the Securities and Exchange Commission a self-financed agency, living off the fees it collects. The change means that the S.E.C will instead remain dependent on Congress for money, a big blow to those advocating more independence for the agency.

headline: Yael Kornfeld and Avram Mlotek

headline: A Piano in the Time of Irving Berlin
text: The end of World War II is the highlight of the Irving Berlin tribute “I Love a Piano” at the Gateway Playhouse in Bellport. Fireworks explode. Sadie sings “God Bless America,” Kate Smith-style. A soldier comes home and kisses his girl, à la the sailor in Alfred Eisenstaedt’s famous Times Square V-J Day photo. It’s the Act I windup and proof positive that what this musical revue needs is a strong story line to go with its 58 songs and handful of reprises.

headline: Taking It to the Banks?
text: So, one general is out, another is back and President Obama says it’s time to “persist and we persevere.” Well, House and Senate Democrats seemed to take the message to heart, and after what The Times’s Edward Wyatt called a “20-hour marathon by members of a House-Senate conference committee” on Thursday and Friday, the two chambers reconciled “competing versions of legislation that would transform financial regulation.” An impressive bit of legislative perseverance from the Democratic leadership, to be sure, but will the end product truly “offer families the protections they deserve, help safeguard their financial security and give the businesses of America access to the credit they need to expand and innovate,” as Treasury Secretary Tim Geithner promises? I suppose it depends on whom you ask.

headline: Honoring Heroes of Jazz, With Words, Silence and Improvisation
text: Jazz has a long tradition of heroism, both in practice and reception, in the acts of musicians and how they are understood. For the last few generations, hard-core jazz audiences have spent a lot of time worrying that the academic might be riding up on the intuitive, and that the sense of heroism might be slipping away. But this is never a problem at the Vision Festival, where American free jazz has its annual rites.

headline: More Than Happy to Move Past the Meltdown
text: It took about four months last year for Nathan Williams of Wavves to implode. That was the length of time between the release of the band’s acclaimed second album, “Wavvves” (Fat Possum), and the night at a Barcelona festival when his touring drummer, Ryan Ulsh, frustrated with his behavior, abandoned him onstage. A YouTube clip of the meltdown is titled “Wavves  Have a Whammy at Primavera Sound 09.”In the wake of that whammy came a blog post by Mr. Williams, quickly pulled down, citing drug use and stress, and much chatter, if not quite concern, about how the warp-speed Internet-fame cycle can undo ill-prepared young musicians.

headline: Teenage Drinking Diaries

headline: Brunch? The Chef Has the Morning Off
text: Mario Batali, 49, chef and multimedia brand, co-owns 15 restaurants (including Babbo and Del Posto) with his business partner, Joe Bastianich. Their next business venture, scheduled to open later this year in the Flatiron district, is Eataly — a merger of eat and Italy — which he likens to “a gigantic grocery store.” The author of eight cookbooks (one co-written with Gwyneth Paltrow), he is a mainstay among the competitors on the reality show “Iron Chef America.” Mr. Batali lives in Greenwich Village with his wife, Susi Cahn, and their two sons, Leo, 12, and Benno, 13. headline: For Spain, Two Goals and a Welcome Shot of Confidence
text: PRETORIA, South Africa — After Spain shockingly lost its opener against Switzerland, Diego Maradona snickered, “The way it started off, Spain was coming to pick up the World Cup, and we were all playing for second place.”

headline: Old and New, and Celebrity Power, at a Birthday Party
text: Herbie Hancock’s CareFusion Jazz Festival concert at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night was called “Seven Decades: The Birthday Celebration,” like a sequel in a fantasy-adventure franchise. Fittingly, it was a prestige production with an overspill of talent, but also a bit of a rehash, strangely hollow at the core.

headline: Passports Just in Time for Boarding
text: SHORTLY after sunup, with the West Village beginning to exhale morning life, Jennifer Azlant sat pretzeled on the sidewalk, filling out forms. Behind her, a growing line snaked down Hudson Street.

headline: Applying the Heat with a Pre-empt, and Losing
text: The 120-board final of the open trial to select the U.S.A.-1 team for the 2011 Bermuda Bowl takes place in Chicago on Saturday and Sunday.

headline: What the Gulf Can’t Afford
text: In late May, with a broken pipe spewing tens of thousands of barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico, President Obama imposed a six-month moratorium on new deep-water drilling in the gulf and suspended operations at 33 exploratory deep-water wells. These were common-sense moves  a timeout while a presidential commission figured out why the disaster occurred and recommended ways to prevent future calamities.

headline: They’re Supposed to Lead
text: When the global financial system was teetering on the brink, the world’s leading economies worked together to head off the worst. In coordinated moves, they pumped capital into their banks, guaranteed loans and set up emergency financing for countries sideswiped by the crisis. A few months later, they committed to spend whatever was needed to avoid a global depression.

headline: Smoke Less. No, More. Do It Here. No, There.
text: Dear New Yorkers: Smoke ’em if you’ve got ’em. And then go get more of ’em. Sincerely, Albany.

headline: Ben Sonnenberg, Founder of Literary Journal, Dies at 73
text: Ben Sonnenberg, whose whims and myriad enthusiasms made Grand Street, the quarterly he founded in 1981, one of the most revered literary magazines of the postwar era, died Thursday in Manhattan. He was 73.

headline: Moratorium Won’t Reduce Drilling Risks
text: “This case asks whether the federal government’s imposition of a general moratorium on deepwater drilling for oil in the Gulf of Mexico was imposed contrary to law. Before the Court is the plaintiffs’ motion for preliminary injunction. For the following reasons, the motion is GRANTED."

headline: S. Carolina Candidate Shrugs Off History’s Lure
text: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C.  Tim Scott seemed unburdened by history.

headline: Full Disclosure
text: Americans vote in secret, but they expect most other significant political acts to take place in the sunshine, from passing laws to making campaign donations. Anonymity in those areas is inimical to a robust democracy, and the Supreme Court was right on Thursday to rule that there is no constitutional right to hide in the shadows when signing a referendum petition.

headline: Clip: 'Rush: Beyond the Lighted Stage'
text: The VH1 documentary looks at the Canadian rock band and its fans.

headline: City Renews Effort to End Use of Street Alarm Boxes
text: The Bloomberg administration has asked a federal court to clear the way for a plan to eliminate 15,000 emergency-help boxes on New York streets, setting aside concerns that it might discriminate against deaf residents.

headline: Readers’ Questions Answered
text: Jell-O’s Wiggly Fathers

headline: Manhattan Birth Certificate, Brooklyn Address
text: Over the last decade, a growing stream of the young, the stylish and the family-oriented have been drawn to Brooklyn by its parks, waterfront, cultural life and relatively affordable real estate and acres of graceful brownstones.

headline: Fighting Crime Where the Criminals Are
text: THERE was a predictable chorus of criticism from civil rights groups last month when the New York Police Department released its data on stop-and-frisk interactions for 2009. The department made 575,000 pedestrian stops last year. Fifty-five percent involved blacks, even though blacks are only 23 percent of the city’s population. Whites, by contrast, were involved in 10 percent of all stops, though they make up 35 percent of the city’s population.

headline: U.S. Team Cheered From Stands and the States
text: JOHANNESBURG  The United States team bus, emblazoned with the slogan “Life, Liberty and the Pursuit of Victory,” was mobbed when it rolled through Pretoria on Wednesday.

headline: In the Halls of Congress
text: The first African-American to serve in Congress was a Republican. Hiram Revels, a senator from Mississippi, was also the first of 26 black Republicans in Congress, most serving between the end of the Civil War and the rise of Jim Crow laws. Mr. Revels was elected to the Senate by Mississippi legislators in 1870 and ushered in a generation of 20 other black Republican congressmen, all from the South, in the two decades after the war.

headline: Juniors Watch: Laura Robson Returns
text: After playing the past few weeks on grass in Roehampton, Halle, Eastbourne, even Philadelphia, the world’s best juniors are at last invited inside the gates at Wimbledon, where the Junior Championships begin on Saturday. One of the teenagers competing for the girls title will not need any directions to the locker room or the outside courts at the All-England Club. Laura Robson of Britain, 16, who won the girls title in 2008 and played in the women’s singles, doubles and mixed doubles fields this year, is a surprise wild card entry into the junior event.

headline: Icelander’s Campaign Is a Joke, Until He’s Elected
text: REYKJAVIK, Iceland  A polar bear display for the zoo. Free towels at public swimming pools. A “drug-free Parliament by 2020.” Iceland’s Best Party, founded in December by a comedian, Jon Gnarr, to satirize his country’s political system, ran a campaign that was one big joke. Or was it?

headline: ‘Mommy,’  Boy Said, ‘I Got Shot’
text: His head cushioned against a white hospital bed on Friday, Ronnell Gurley whispered the story of how, the night before, he became a 9-year-old with a bullet lodged in his shoulder bone.

headline: As M.T.A. Cuts Bus Service, a Look at Who Rides Where
text: Interactive map of M.T.A. bus routes, including planned closures, ridership and costs of each route.

headline: New Rules May Affect Every Corner of JPMorgan
text: Not since the Great Depression, when the mighty House of Morgan was cleaved in two, have Washington lawmakers rewritten the rules for Wall Street as extensively as they did on Friday.

headline: In Week of Tests, Obama Reasserts His Authority
text: After two months in which an oil gusher seemed to underscore the limits of his powers, President Obama spent the last week trying to reassert control over a triumvirate of forces that almost always test a new president’s authority: the military, the markets and the lobbyists.

headline: Two Car Models, New York Emblems, Discontinued
text: They are the muscular, leg-roomy fixtures of New York’s crowded streetscape, the automobiles that came to represent the city.

headline: CBS and ESPN Quarrel Over Size of Sports Streams
text: The streaming of live sports events drew two media conglomerates, CBS and ESPN, into a Friday fracas  one that may sound silly but that underscored how important the business has become as people increasingly watch games away from their TV screens.

headline: For Some Students, No More Pencils and No More Books Came a Day Early
text: Annie and Ella Glazer, 6-year-old twins at Midtown West Elementary School in Manhattan, will be playing hooky with parental consent on Monday. In a pattern being repeated across New York City, their mother decided that the girls’ last day of school would be on Friday  even though, due to a quirk of the calendar, all students are supposed to report on Monday for a final half day.

headline: Lottery Numbers
The Age of Nancy
text: Let us sing a song about the wonderfulness of Nancy Pelosi.

headline: All-You-Can-Eat Tacos, 10 A.M. (Go Mexico!)
text: The city still burns bright as a beacon of immigrant aspiration, and the proof these days can be found clustering in bars and cafes, and spilling onto the streets, in raucous displays of multinational pride during the World Cup. On Tuesday morning at the original outpost of Mercadito, a tiny taqueria on Avenue B that attracts a young, hip crowd and feels like a resort cantina, a mellow version of this phenomenon played out as Mexico struggled against Uruguay. Even with a $25 all-you-can-eat tacos or wings special on offer during games, not everyone can show up at 10 a.m. for soccer. Those who did  a few couples up front, a group of men in back  sat transfixed, at times rising halfway out of their seats, calling out “Vamos,” or clasping their hands as if in prayer when either team came close to triumph or disaster.  DIANE CARDWELL IN THE SEATS Giannina Perez, 38, a public policy advocate for children’s issues, and her husband, Guillermo Mayer, 36, a civil rights lawyer.

headline: The Financial Bill and Consumers
text: Personal Finance Reporter Tara Siegel Bernard discusses how consumers benefit from financial reform

headline: Louisiana Wants U.S. Help, and Its Own Way
text: NEW ORLEANS  For weeks, Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana has attacked BP and the Coast Guard for not having adequate plans and resources to battle the oil spill.

headline: Congress Reaches Deal on Financial Bill
text: David Gillen reports on how Wall Street fared in the financial reform bill

headline: A. Godfrey: A Man for a Long, Long Season
text: You may feel that this column should bear the cautionary label, “Warning: Oldies Only.”

headline: Love Stirs at the Port-O-Potty
text: Physical attraction is not a German train: it doesn’t always arrive at the expected time and place. Frequently, in fact, it appears under odd auspices and at inappropriate locations. The following poems about Eros in nonclassical circumstances were “found” last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim with only line and stanza breaks added. The titles are their subject headings.  ALAN FEUER

headline: What Is Albany Doing?
text: Gov. David Paterson of New York has promised to resolve the state’s budget battle by Monday midnight. Legislators need to pass the budget, but there’s a lot of other unfinished business. Here are some of the items they must attend to before going home to ask voters to re-elect them to the jobs they have done so badly:

headline: Murder Charge in Nun’s Death May Test Law
text: The decision by Manhattan prosecutors to charge an 18-year-old man with felony murder in a hit-and-run crash that killed a nun in Harlem represents a novel approach that could test the state’s felony murder statute, legal experts said.

headline: Brooklyn Senator a Focus of Federal Corruption Inquiry
text: Federal investigators are examining whether Senator Carl Kruger, one of the State Legislature’s most powerful members, sought campaign contributions in exchange for political favors, according to court filings and people briefed on the case.

headline: Worse Than a Nightmare
text: President Obama can be applauded for his decisiveness in dispatching the chronically insubordinate Stanley McChrystal, but we are still left with a disaster of a war in Afghanistan that cannot be won and that the country as a whole will not support.

headline: Women’s Grand Prix Off to Very Fast Start
text: The fourth tournament in the series to select a challenger for the world championship opened in Jermuk, Russia, on Thursday. It has been highly competitive, with only one draw though the first two rounds.

headline: Take the Long View
text: This was the week that Democrats cried and Republicans cackled.

headline: Seeking Answers on Oil Spill as Questions Mount
text: Since the Deepwater Horizon oil rig exploded in the Gulf of Mexico in April, killing 11 and setting off the biggest maritime oil spill in the nation’s history, questions about the potential dimensions of the disaster have only multiplied from week to week. Readers have been asking whether the oil can be contained, how serious the damage will be and what they can do to help. Following is a primer on the spill.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,119 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Genetically Altered Salmon Get Closer to the Table
text: The Food and Drug Administration is seriously considering whether to approve the first genetically engineered animal that people would eat  salmon that can grow at twice the normal rate.

headline: Presidential Vote Tests Merkel’s Ailing Coalition in Germany
text: BERLIN  It has been lost on few here in Germany that Angela Merkel, the pastor’s daughter from the former East Germany, sees her reign as chancellor threatened by another pastor from the former East Germany.

headline: Grapevine Cultivator
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I feel as if I’m in a time warp. Yesterday, we had a rebus puzzle, a gimmick which usually signals Thursday. Today, we have a late-week themeless puzzle inside a grid with 38 blocks. That’s higher than the Monday block average. Still, the puzzle is suitably Saturday tough with a low word count of 70.

headline: 2010 World Cup Rankings
text: 2010 World Cup teams, ranked by record and tournament statistics.

headline: Facing Deficit, Oakland Puts Police Force on Chopping Block
text: OAKLAND, Calif.  Already saddled with a reputation as one of the nation’s most violent cities, Oakland may be forced to cut its police force by 10 percent under a budget deal struck Thursday night.

headline: Corrections
text: NEW YORK

headline: Toronto Summit Meeting Brings Curbs on Canadian Rights
text: HUNTSVILLE, Ontario  Canadians discovered Friday that the Group of 20 summit meeting in Toronto has brought not only world leaders but also a temporary suspension of some of their own civil rights, at least in the core of downtown Toronto.

headline: Seeing ‘Crying Girl’ as a Con, Residents Cull Clues Online
text: DAVIS, Calif.  A weeping young woman approaches strangers, tells them a wrenching story about an abusive boyfriend and pleads for $37 for a train ticket. The routine has played out many times on the streets of this college town over the last six months, so many times that some residents have concluded that the woman is a con artist. She is known as the Crying Girl.

headline: Knicks Add Another Second-Round Pick
text: A day after slumbering through the N.B.A. draft without a first-round pick, the Knicks on Friday introduced their two second-round selections in a conference call and made a small ripple by announcing they had purchased another second-round pick.

headline: Aid to States May Be Lost as Jobs Bill Stalls
text: Financially struggling states, already facing record budget shortfalls, are now confronting the possibility of losing out on billions of dollars in federal aid that they had been counting on, if Congress does not revive a jobs bill that stalled in the Senate this week.

headline: The Royal Game
text: Another one of those “a picture is worth a thousand words” moments. During a state visit to Britain in March, President Jacob Zuma of South Africa went to Buckingham Palace, where there was an exhibition of items from his country. During the tour, Queen Elizabeth II showed President Zuma a chess set that Nelson Mandela gave her in 1996. The pieces appear to be African tribesman.

headline: Prosecutors Ease Stance, but Still Seek Long Prison Term for Radical Lawyer
text: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have changed their view on how long Lynne F. Stewart should go to prison.

headline: Before a Pitch Is Made, a Chance to Catch Up
text: LOS ANGELES  As Mariano Rivera jogged toward Joe Torre to engulf him in a warm embrace, no fewer than 25 cameras followed him, their operators eager to chronicle every nanosecond of a long-awaited reunion. Rivera and Torre put their arms around each other and smiled, turning back the clock as they posed for photographers. This way, Mo. Over here, Joe. It went on and on. For about a half-hour Friday afternoon, when the Yankees and Dodgers overlapped in their pregame preparation, Dodger Stadium turned into the hottest spot in town.

headline: Is Simulation Cheating?
text: JOHANNESBURG — The United States has endured two questionable calls by referees in its run to the Round of 16 at the World Cup.

headline: Eighth Grade Prom?
text: Middle school principals Gregory Hodge and Pedro Santana put their lives into supporting their students. But when it comes to eighth grade prom, they have different visions.

headline: For Pelfrey, Win No. 10; For Santana, a Respite
text: As the winning pitcher for the Mets in Friday night’s snappy 5-2 victory over Minnesota at Citi Field, Mike Pelfrey raised his record to 10-2 to enhance his profile as the current ace of the staff and one of the best in a season of pitching revival.

headline: After Stroke, a Poet Hunts for the Language Lost
text: Unable to sleep, the poet Marie Ponsot lay in a hospital bed one night last month trying to figure out what it was that she no longer knew. A few days earlier, she’d had a stroke. Her brain had been ransacked. Poems that she had been reciting from memory for the better part of a century had disappeared. She cross-examined herself: What, she asked, have I lost?

headline: Principal Matters
text: With open arms and a touch of style, Pedro Santana, the principal of Middle School 391 in the South Bronx, has transformed the students and faculty.

headline: The Principal’s Office
text: WHEN Pedro Santana arrived as principal of Middle School 391 in the South Bronx four years ago, it was, as he likes to put it, “a hot mess.” Fights were frequent, windows were slathered over with paint. Only 11 percent of seventh graders had passed their most recent state math tests.

headline: Wear a Party Hat and Bring a Book
text: With five original albums to their credit, Laurie Berkner, a children’s musician based in Manhattan, and her band just released a 20-track greatest-hits collection, “The Best of the Laurie Berkner Band” (Two Tomatoes Records). But while the group is bound to perform some of those favorites when it takes the stage at the Tilles Center for the Performing Arts on July 18 in Brookville, not everything will be familiar.

headline: Summer Camp for Tomorrow’s Stars
text: IT may be impossible to think of drama camp without picturing “Glee”-ready teenagers striking poses, but summer theater programs are not all alike. Some emphasize Shakespeare, while others focus on musical performance; some stress playwriting rather than performing. Following is a sampling of programs that still have spots available.

headline: Joan Rivers on the Receiving End
text: JOAN RIVERS said she “had no idea” what she was getting herself into when she agreed to allow Ricki Stern, the daughter of her Connecticut friends Michael and Marjorie Stern, to make a documentary about her life.

headline: A Building Brings Haves and Have-Somes Together
text: The Kalahari condominium building drummed up a predictable mix of hope and skepticism when it rose along a scraggly stretch of West 116th Street in Harlem. At 249 units, it dwarfed its tenement neighbors. Its zigzagging brickwork, inspired by sub-Saharan tribes, was deemed compelling by fans and an aesthetic fright by detractors.

headline: A Go-It-Alone Strategy
text: Though Gov. Bobby Jindal  of Louisiana has criticized the response to the oil spill by BP and the Coast Guard, interviews suggest that Louisiana has often disregarded its own plans and experts in favor of proposals that many have questioned.

headline: Soccer Fever in the City’s Immigrant Enclaves
text: On June 11, play began in that international ritual of soccer, barstool debate and workplace underproductivity known as the World Cup. While much of America views the event with faint curiosity, its immigrants follow it with microscopic attention. Below, excerpts of World Cup articles from local ethnic newspapers. KIRK SEMPLE

headline: Turtle Deaths Called Result of Shrimping, Not Oil Spill
text: A National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration scientist says he believes most of the dead turtles that have been examined since the Gulf of Mexico oil spill died not from the oil or the chemical dispersants put into the water after the disaster, but from being caught in shrimping nets, though further testing may show otherwise.

headline: Mario Batali’s Veal Chops
text: Mario Batali’s Sunday veal chops with charred green beans and ramps (Mr. Batali cooks with ramps frequently during their spring season):

headline: No Hits, but Plenty of Pitches, Latest Gem
text: A baseball season defined by pitching excellence took another fascinating turn on Friday when Edwin Jackson of the Arizona Diamondbacks threw the majors’ fourth no-hitter this season. It was, perhaps, the most improbable no-hitter in years.

headline: Jury Says Merck Must Pay $8 Million in Fosamax Case
text: Merck lost a second trial to reach a verdict over claims that its osteoporosis drug Fosamax caused so-called jaw death. The jury in New York set damages at $8 million in the case of Shirley Boles, 72, of Fort Walton Beach, Fla., who said she developed osteonecrosis of the jaw by taking Fosamax. With osteonecrosis, a bone is no longer alive and cannot regenerate because of a lack of blood supply, according to the National Osteonecrosis Foundation’s Web site. The first Fosamax case resulted in a Merck victory in May. United States District Judge John F. Keenan, who is overseeing federal Fosamax litigation, scheduled three bellwether trials that might point the way to out-of-court settlements and show each side the other’s strategy. The third case is to be tried in November. “We believe the jury verdict was a result of plaintiff’s counsel’s inflammatory and prejudicial remarks,” Paul F. Strain, a lawyer for Merck, said in a statement.

headline: In a Mentor, Kagan’s Critics See Liberal Agenda
text: Abner J. Mikva has always been something of a talent scout, and Elena Kagan was one of his best picks.

headline: American Jews Who Reject Zionism Say Events Aid Cause
text: One day nearly 20 years ago, Stephen Naman was preparing to help the rabbi of his Reform Jewish temple in South Carolina move the congregation into a new building. Mr. Naman had just one request: Could the rabbi stop placing the flag of Israel on the altar?

headline: At Companies Tied to NASA, Casualties of a Changing Mission
text: In the political battle over the nation’s space program, the first casualties are people like Donny Smith, an engineer who received his layoff notice Monday.

headline: Transportation Agency Gets a Leader
text: The Senate confirmed John S. Pistole as head of the Transportation Security Administration by unanimous consent on Friday. Mr. Pistole, the deputy director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was the third person President Obama had nominated for the job. The previous two, Erroll Southers and Robert A. Harding, withdrew, leaving the agency without an administration appointee at the top for the entire time Mr. Obama has been in office.

headline: Nets’ Thorn Is Said to Be Planning to Step Down
text: Rod Thorn, the Nets’ president and the architect of their N.B.A. finals teams in 2002 and 2003, has told the team that he has decided to step down from the position he has held since 2000.

text: Uruguay vs. South Korea

headline: Fred Anderson, Saxophonist and Club Owner, Dies at 81
text: Fred Anderson, a tenor saxophonist who tied the bebop innovations of Charlie Parker to the explorations of later avant-garde musicians and who owned the Velvet Lounge, a South Side Chicago club known for fostering the careers of emerging players, died on Thursday. He was 81.

headline: Pete Quaife, a Bassist for the Kinks, Dies at 66
text: Pete Quaife, a bassist who joined forces with two schoolmates to form the Kinks, one of the leading rock bands of the 1960s British Invasion, died on Wednesday in Herlev, Denmark. He was 66.

headline: Reunion With Torre Goes to Yankees
text: LOS ANGELES  As manager of the Yankees, Joe Torre instilled a feeling of calm. His players could always sense it. So could his successor, Joe Girardi. As photographers hovered and reporters encircled him in the Dodgers’ dugout before Friday’s game, his first against the Yankees since leaving two and a half years ago, Torre said it would be futile to pretend that he would not become emotional. But he quickly composed himself.

headline: Bloggingheads: Russian Shenanigans
text: Eli Lake of The Washington Times and Charles Kupchan of the Council on Foreign Relations debate the U.S.-Russia relationship.

headline: The Challenges in Educating the Severely Disabled

headline: 'Airplane!' Turns 30!
text: Matt Zoller Seitz narrates a look at "Airplane!" and its comedic influences.

headline: There’s the Occasional Shout, but Not a Vuvuzela to Be Heard
text: WIMBLEDON, ENGLAND — The match that almost didn’t end grabbed front-page headlines, but it’s not always what makes news that makes Wimbledon’s first week special.

headline: Classic Ad: Chrysler Minivan
text: We have minivans on the brain this week, with Cheryl Jensen’s review of the 2011 Toyota Sienna leading Sunday’s Automobiles section. And we have soccer competing for our attention, too, as the World Cup moves from group play to the knockout phase, which begins today.

headline: Surgery Successful for Giants’ Chad Jones, but Career Is in Doubt
text: The outcome could have been much worse for the Giants rookie safety Chad Jones, a third-round pick out of L.S.U. who crashed a sport utility vehicle into a pole Friday morning in New Orleans.

headline: For United States, Mission Accomplished; Now What?
text: JOHANNESBURG – The United States team’s World Cup goal was clear from the beginning: advance out of Group C to the knockout round.

headline: Yanks vs. Black Stars: Looking Back, Looking Ahead
text: That is one of many anthems, official and un-, that have been put out in support of Ghana’s World Cup campaign. None, however, is as ominously grave as “All the Way,” and that makes it apt background music for a look at the elimination clash between the Black Stars and Yanks at Rustenburg on Saturday.

headline: Saturday Word: Obama and Financial Regulatory Bill
text: President Obama called on Congress to pass the final version of the financial regulatory legislation quickly, praising lawmakers for including “90 percent of what I proposed when I took up this fight” in the agreement they reached early Friday morning.

headline: More Federal Aid Needed for Low-Income College Students, Report Finds
text: The Advisory Committee on Student Financial Assistance, an independent committee that advises Congress and the secretary of education on national policy, presented a report in Washington on Friday that did not bode well for low-income college students seeking degrees.

headline: Mullen Visits Afghan Leaders and Allied Troops
text: KABUL  With the American-led military mission temporarily a ship without a captain, the nation’s top admiral spent Saturday in this land-locked war zone reassuring Afghan leaders and allied troops that Washington will not pause in pressing forward its strategy  one that will require enhanced cooperation between civilian and military officials.

headline: World Cup Live: Uruguay vs. South Korea
text: Data by Match Analysis

headline: 8 Legs and 2 Wet Noses of Security
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  New Meadowlands Stadium, the $1.6 billion home of the Giants and the Jets, has only two year-round residents.

headline: Vettel on Pole, Confident of Victory. Too Confident?
text: Guillaume Baptiste/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images From left: Mark Webber, Sebastian Vettel and Lewis Hamilton.

headline: College World Series Is Moving On
text: OMAHA  The field where Dave Winfield played his final college game is still there  for now. But so much in and around Rosenblatt Stadium has changed since 1973, when Winfield, a dominating pitcher as well as an outfielder for Minnesota, won the most outstanding player award at the College World Series.

headline: After Facing Cancer, Navratilova Is Eyeing the Next Mountain
text: WIMBLEDON, England  Martina Navratilova arrived here, at the tennis tournament where she won nine singles titles, free in every sense that mattered. Free of cancer. Free of the radiation treatments she had before, during and after the French Open. Free to resume the life the diagnosis briefly, and only slightly, interrupted.

headline: Tearing Down History in the Future’s Shadow
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It was an otherwise ordinary day in April when John Mara went into Giants Stadium for the last time, to say goodbye. Massive mechanical claws had been picking at the old stadium for weeks, like vultures on a carcass, and construction officials sent word that the section holding the Giants’ offices and locker rooms would go next.

headline: Kimmel: ‘The Exact Opposite’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: Former President Clinton has been in South Africa, cheering the American World Cup team on. He tries to remain on the exact opposite side of the world as Hillary at all times.

headline: Fallon: ‘A Tweet That Was Too Long’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: This week, the Russian president, Dmitri Medvedev, came to the U.S. and visited the headquarters of Twitter. When Medvedev wrote a tweet that was too long, he said: “Don’t worry. I’m very good at eliminating unnecessary characters. Heh, heh, heh.”

headline: A Little Brother With Big Plans
text: In his recently released book, “Hardcourt Confidential,” Patrick McEnroe examined tennis from various vantage points: as a retired player, a longtime Davis Cup captain, younger brother of John McEnroe, general manager for player development with the United States Tennis Association and a television commentator who is working for ESPN at Wimbledon. GREG BISHOP

headline: Leno: ‘The Guy Behind the Counter’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: Yesterday, President Obama met with the Russian president at the White House. And afterward, Obama took the Russian president out for a hamburger. And it was a little awkward, you know. You know who the guy behind the counter serving the burger was? General McChrystal.

headline: Post Blogger Quits After Limbaugh, Drudge Comments Were Made Public
text: The blogger David Weigel resigned from The Washington Post on Friday after it was revealed that he had made disparaging comments about other conservatives on a private e-mail list.

headline: Mexican Violence Deters U.S. Colleges
text: MEXICO CITY  From perfecting their use of the subjunctive in colonial Puebla to exploring the anthropological aspects of Tijuana’s gritty underside, American college students have long used Mexico as a learning lab. This summer, however, far fewer will be venturing across the border, as universities and students alike fear the violence tied to drug gangs that have caught some innocents in the cross-fire.

headline: In Spain, Formula One Is Taking Hold, but the Roots Are Not Yet Deep
text: It is called the European Grand Prix, but the Formula One race taking place Sunday on the street circuit through the Juan Carlos I Marina in Valencia, on the Mediterranean coast of Spain, is a de facto second Spanish Grand Prix.

headline: 4 Shop Owners Die in Iraqi Robberies
text: BAGHDAD — An armed gang went on a rampage Saturday, gunning down four jewelry store owners and robbing more than a dozen shops in the western city of Falluja in what may have been an effort to finance insurgent groups, Iraqi authorities said.

headline: Burnett Falters Again as Yankees Lose to Dodgers
text: LOS ANGELES — In sorting through the latest disaster by A. J. Burnett, the Yankees will be distressed by many things: the six walks, the six runs, a terrible ball-strike ratio and more, much more. In the end, one thing trumps the rest: When Burnett pitches, they do not win. The Yankees’ 9-4 loss to the Los Angeles Dodgers was their eighth defeat this month. Burnett has started five of those games, and the results have gotten progressively worse over his last three starts.

headline: Urban Forager | Finding Life in Dead Horse Bay
text: “They don’t call it Dead Horse Bay for nothing,” said Jarad Astin, walking across the bottle-strewn beach in flip-flops with a seine net over his shoulder.

headline: BP ‘Reporter’ Flies Over Gulf Without Noting Slick
text: A Facebook friend, Kristin Aldred Cheek, pointed me to a pretty wild bit of faux journalism recently concocted by BP as part of its public relations efforts related to the gusher in the Gulf of Mexico. On his blog, a BP “reporter,” Tom Seslar, describes a two-hour helicopter flight over the gulf with a team charting oil patches.

headline: North Korea’s Ruling Party Plans a Leadership Vote
text: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea said Saturday that its ruling Workers’ Party would hold a rare meeting of delegates in September to elect a new party leadership, a move analysts in Seoul said was intended to help a son of the ailing North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il, consolidate his power as heir.

headline: Cryptic Vacuum You Loaned to an Auditor
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — How effective are you at dealing with topless Pennsylvania people? Or the French, for that matter? Part of the fun of cryptics is that questions like those can begin to make sense, if only you parse the clues correctly.

headline: Abuse Loosens Church’s Culture of Silence in Italy
text: ROME  One afternoon last month, a rare thing happened in Rome’s main courthouse: for perhaps the first time ever, an Italian bishop took the witness stand in the case of a priest accused of the sexual abuse of children.

headline: Williams and Sharapova Ready for Another Battle
text: WIMBLEDON, England  Serena Williams and Maria Sharapova met in 2004 in the Wimbledon final, before time and circumstances sent them on divergent paths.

headline: Retweet | Wonderwood by CDG
text: A tweet from T Magazine’s men’s fashion director, Bruce Pask.

headline: Kagan Hearings May Have Wider Focus
text: WASHINGTON  At Supreme Court confirmation hearings, the nominee is usually the star. But Elena Kagan may well be a supporting player in a drama featuring two men not even there: President Obama and Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.

headline: Leaders at Summit Turn Attention to Deficit Cuts
text: TORONTO  Despite President Obama’s pitch at the summit meeting for developed nations here for continued stimulus measures to prevent another global economic downturn, the United States will go along with other leaders who are more concerned about rising debt and join in a commitment to cut their governments’ deficits in half by 2013, administration officials said on Saturday.

headline: World Cup Live: United States vs. Ghana
text: The thrilling run of the United States national team at the World Cup has come to end, finished by Asamoah (Baby Jet) Gyan’s goal in the third minute of extra time and a slew of terrific saves from Ghana goalkeeper Richard Kingson.

headline: Canada Agog at Security Price Tag for Summit
text: HUNTSVILLE, Ontario  Few Canadians expected that hosting world leaders at back-to-back summit meetings here this weekend would be cheap or convenient. With downtown Toronto a security maze, businesses boarded up and even the beloved Blue Jays baseball team sent packing, the meetings have met all expectations for aggravation.

headline: After Kyrgyz Unrest, a Question Lingers: Why?
text: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan  Two weeks after thousands are thought to have died in a wave of ethnic violence in southern Kyrgyzstan, and days before a national referendum on a new constitution, the interim government here has yet to provide a convincing explanation of why it occurred  a reflection, experts and former officials say, of the leadership’s inner turmoil and a possible portent of troubles to come.

headline: How Many Graduates Does It Take to Be No. 1?
text: There will be no valedictory speech at Jericho High School’s graduation on Sunday. With seven seniors laying claim to the title by compiling A-plus averages, no one wanted to sit through a solid half-hour of inspirational quotations and sappy memories.

headline: Guineans Revel in Prospect of First Free Vote
text: CONAKRY, Guinea  For days now, this tattered seaside capital  the site of a government massacre of civilians just nine months ago  has been giddy with anticipation of the country’s first-ever free elections after more than five decades of dictatorship.

headline: Walter Shorenstein, Democratic Donor, Dies at 95
text: Walter H. Shorenstein, a real estate investor who was the largest landlord in San Francisco, a top Democratic donor and fundraiser, and an adviser to several Presidents, died on Thursday in San Francisco. He was 95.

headline: Officials Say Census Workers Forged Surveys
text: About 10,000 census surveys in Brooklyn are being redone after two local managers reportedly filled out many of the household surveys themselves, officials said.

headline: Bulls May Be Front-Runners in James Sweepstakes
text: The LeBron James sweepstakes will kick off in Ohio on his home turf Thursday as five teams  the Chicago Bulls, the Miami Heat, the Knicks, the Nets and the Los Angeles Clippers  travel there in an attempt to woo James away from the Cleveland Cavaliers, an executive of one of the teams in the hunt said Saturday.

headline: Two Brooklyn Census Managers Fired Over Faked Surveys
text: About 10,000 census surveys in Brooklyn are being redone after two local managers reportedly filled out many of the household surveys themselves, officials said.

headline: A-Rod Was Almost a Dodger
text: With the Yankees in Los Angeles this weekend, it is useful to remember that only the randomness of the calendar kept Rodriguez from starting his career with the Dodgers.

headline: Rodriguez and Torre Find No Time for a Greeting
text: LOS ANGELES — It was almost possible to forget there was an actual baseball game Friday night at Dodger Stadium, where Joe Torre spent much of his time hugging and shaking hands with his former players and coaches on the Yankees. Not so for Alex Rodriguez, who apparently was so focused that he said he never saw Torre — even as Derek Jeter, Jorge Posada, Mariano Rivera and other teammates greeted Torre a few feet away from where Rodriguez was getting loose.

headline: Fighting Words
text: The Senate Judiciary Committee is scheduled this week to take up President Obama’s nomination of Elena Kagan to the United States Supreme Court. Republicans spent time last week laying groundwork to oppose her confirmation.

headline: Strong Enough for Tough Stains?
text: OUR nation’s Congressional machinery was humming last week as legislators reconciled the differences between the labyrinthine financial reforms proposed by the Senate and the House and emerged early Friday morning with a voluminous new law in hand. They christened it the Dodd-Frank bill, after the heads of the Senate Banking and House Financial Services Committees who drove the process toward the finish line.

headline: Prime Number
text: THE MINIMUM PRICE, IN DOLLARS AND CENTS,

headline: V-J Day: 1945
text: EDITH SHAIN, WHO CLAIMED TO BE THE NURSE kissed by a sailor in Life magazine’s memorable photograph of V-J Day in Times Square on Aug. 14, 1945, died last week at age 91. “The happiness was indescribable,” Mrs. Shain later recalled, and the joy over Japan’s surrender, captured in that one image by the renowned photographer Alfred Eisenstaedt, swept across the city. “Restraint was thrown to the four winds,” The Times reported the next day. “New Year’s Eve celebrations paled into insignificance. ... In the Times Square area particularly, crowds in bars were four and five deep with servicemen  principally sailors  predominating.” At one dinner club, the Zanzibar, “patrons climbed on tables and shouted and screamed. ...Pandemonium took over.”

headline: A Mao Trinket Must Look Like Mao, Not Elvis
text: Trade in Mao memorabilia is big business in the Chinese city of Shaoshan, birthplace of the Great Helmsman. But there have been recent complaints about the quality of Mao statues sold by local shops and peddlers. “Many statues don’t look like the man himself. Some have a weird appearance,” Mao Anping, a relative of Mao, told Xinhua, China’s official news agency. To remedy the problem, a panel of experts will now examine all mass-produced statues to make sure they actually look like the man they are supposed to portray. Xia Youxin, curator of the Shaoshan Mao Zedong Memorial Museum, worries that the more exacting replicas may not sell: “Many people only recognize the image of Mao impersonators, and I’m afraid the new products may not become popular.”

headline: Next Stop on the W Train: History
text: The conductor of the last W train, which took its final voyage on Friday evening, was a second-generation subway worker named Helen Carames, 32. Her mother still works at a station booth in Queens; her father retired as a car inspector after 35 years. Family legend has it that her great-grandmother sold tokens.

headline: England vs. Germany: Everyone Mentions War
text: LONDON  It has been called the greatest rivalry in soccer, a history of 27 international matches going back to 1930, and its renewal on Sunday, in the bristling tradition of the competition, has generated some eyebrow-raising and occasionally teeth-grinding headlines in both nations.

headline: The Idea Incubator Goes to Campus
text: DOUGLAS P. HART, a professor of mechanical engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who sold his last start-up for a tidy $95 million, is already on to his next big thing.

headline: Men’s Tennis Finds Itself at the Point of No Returns
text: The mind-boggling first-round Wimbledon match between John Isner and Nicolas Mahut assures that it will be remembered for as long as tennis is played. But the players’ fortitude notwithstanding, it will not be remembered for the quality of play.

headline: Sincere Lessons From Watson
text: It has been an eventful 12 months for Tom Watson, from his near victory at last year’s British Open to his emotional exit at last week’s United States Open. Now is a good time for Watson to give his fans a glimpse into his thinking, his technique and his golf wisdom, and that is the principal ambition of Watson’s new, two-disc DVD, “Lessons of a Lifetime.” Watson has stored up a lot of instructional advice over the decades, much of it culled from the golfing greats he has known. But this is no quick-fix highlight reel of golf tricks worth trying.

headline: Overture to Taliban Jolts Afghan Minorities
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The drive by President Hamid Karzai to strike a deal with Taliban leaders and their Pakistani backers is causing deep unease in Afghanistan’s minority communities, who fought the Taliban the longest and suffered the most during their rule.

headline: Roll-Up Computers and Their Kin
text: IF you were one of the few brave readers of printed books in 2007 who crossed the divide into digital reading, your options were sparse and expensive. The original Amazon Kindle, for example, cost $400, and its screen displayed a mere four shades of gray.

headline: Angels Lose Morales, but Then Begin to Win
text: Bobby Abreu was on base ahead of Kendry Morales the day everything changed for the Los Angeles Angels. Morales, the Angels’ biggest offensive weapon, drilled a game-ending grand slam against Seattle on May 29, then broke his left fibula when he leapt onto the plate in celebration.

headline: In Iraq, Divvying Up the Spoils of Political War
text: BAGHDAD

headline: For Liberty, New Faces Are Taking Time to Fit In
text: The lights were turned down, the music was turned up and the dance team turned on its moves in the middle of the court at Madison Square Garden while the Liberty’s starting five were introduced before a recent game against Seattle.

headline: Sex and the Single Drug
text: THERE’S been a lot of hype lately about an experimental drug to treat sexual disinterest in women, a difficulty formerly known as the “Not tonight, Honey, I have a headache” problem.

headline: Four Killed in a Few Hours in Bronx and Brooklyn
text: Three people were killed in Brooklyn and another in the Bronx early Saturday, and the three Brooklyn killings occurred within a six-block radius in Bushwick and Bedford-Stuyvesant, the police said.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 27
text: After General Stanley McChrystal’s ouster this week as President Obama’s military point man in Afghanistan, the change of command dominates the conversation on the Sunday talk shows.

headline: Phelps Routs Field, Then Brings Up Rear
text: PARIS — Back on the international stage Saturday, Michael Phelps had a mixed day at the pool, demolishing his competition in the 200-meter butterfly event but finishing last in the 100-meter freestyle at the Paris Open.

headline: See You in 6 Months. And Your Insurer Is O.K. With the Bill.
text: WHILE you’re putting your clothes back on in the doctor’s exam room, a new conversation could begin. Not between you and the doctor, but between your doctor’s software system and your insurer’s system.

headline: Santana’s Rough Week Ends With Another Loss
text: Johan Santana wore a blue T-shirt and a stoic countenance Saturday afternoon. With a look at him after the Mets’ 6-0 loss to the Minnesota Twins, it would have been hard to tell that he had just bookended perhaps the worst week of his career.

headline: Brainiacs Beneath the Waves
text: Sperm whales possess the largest brains on the planet, roughly six times weightier than the human counterpart. They are far more deeply textured, making for a greater surface area to process information.

headline: Save a Whale, Save a Soul, Goes the Cry
text: WHEN the annual meeting of the International Whaling Commission ended on Friday with the 24-year ban on commercial whaling still intact, however tenuous its hold and leviathan its loopholes, sighs of relief issued from many quarters  along with, no doubt, a volley of whistles, clicks and proudly parochial squeals.

text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Financial Regulation
text: There is much to applaud in the financial regulatory reform bill announced last Friday by House and Senate negotiators. It would limit some of the riskiest activities of banks and regulate the multitrillion-dollar market in over-the-counter derivatives. It would give federal regulators the tools, if they need them, to shut failing large banks and financial firms instead of bailing them out.

headline: Beware the Fine Print
text: Buried in the fine print of most contracts for cellphones, health insurance and credit cards is a clause requiring that all disputes be decided by binding arbitration, rather than a court. Businesses love these provisions, because arbitrators act quickly and almost always rule in their favor, and many employers are requiring new hires to sign similar agreements.

headline: Here Comes Hollywood, Courting All Planets
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: A Little More Help for Your Kid
text: Jobs are depressingly scarce for recent high school and college graduates. Jobs with health benefits even more so. One of the few bits of good news out there is that under the new health care reform law, young adults will be able to stay on their parents’ health insurance policies until they turn 26.

headline: The Cheap Cost of Cheating the Lowest Paid
text: Her baby will soon be due, so Modesta Toribio has to grudgingly admit she may not soon make her current career goal  New York’s supposedly mandatory $7.25 minimum wage  that she has been routinely denied for the past five years. She inched her salary up to $6.60 an hour from the starting $5 at a cut-rate Brooklyn clothing store mainly by pestering her bosses. Ms. Toribio has a brassy knack for that, but she has learned it takes a lot to best scheming employers.

Except as this year’s frenzy approaches on July 1, LeBron James is apparently begging off.

headline: Thousands of Iranian Government Opponents Hold Rally Outside Paris
text: TAVERNY, France  At least 30,000 opponents to the Iranian government gathered on Saturday in a stadium in this quiet town outside Paris to support the National Council of Resistance to Iran in a large rally coming a year after disputed elections in Iran.

headline: The 36 Hours That Shook Washington
text: THE moment he pulled the trigger, there was near-universal agreement that President Obama had done the inevitable thing, the right thing and, best of all, the bold thing. But before we get carried away with relief and elation, let’s not forget what we saw in the tense 36 hours that fell between late Monday night, when word spread of Rolling Stone’s blockbuster article, and high noon Wednesday, when Obama MacArthured his general. That frenzied interlude revealed much about the state of Washington, the Afghanistan war and the Obama presidency  little of it cheering and none of it resolved by the ingenious replacement of Gen. Stanley McChrystal with Gen. David Petraeus, the only militarily and politically bullet-proof alternative.

headline: Drawn to the Music
text: I’VE always loved music. I remember saving 63 cents when I was 6 so my mother could buy me my first single, and my older sisters bringing home Beatles and Rolling Stones albums, which I listened to endlessly. Unfortunately, after several years of trumpet and guitar lessons, it was evident that I had no musical talent. Still, I knew I wanted to be around music.

headline: Born Somewhere Else

headline: Global Migration: A World Ever More on the Move
text: GORDON BROWN’S rant about a “bigoted” voter sped his exit from the British prime minister’s post. What punctured his cool? Her complaint about immigrants. When an earthquake shattered Haiti, Dominicans sent soldiers and Americans sent ships  to discourage potential immigrants. The congressman who shouted “You lie!” at President Obama was upset about immigrants. “Birthers” think Mr. Obama is an immigrant.

headline: Efforts on Bicycling Also Attract Thieves
text: It has become a kind of mantra for cities looking to encourage cycling through a widening network of bicycle lanes: Build them, and the riders will come.

headline: Urban Lands of Opportunity
text: WHEN I was growing up, there was a strict line between work and life. Every morning, my dad downed a bowl of cereal and a cup of coffee and drove his Chevy Impala from our home in North Arlington, N.J., to the eyeglass factory in the Ironbound section of Newark, where he worked.

headline: War, Timeout, War, Time ...
text: Throughout most of their conflict, Arab and Israeli leaders have tended to oscillate between two, and only two, worldviews: I am weak; how can I compromise? I am strong; why should I compromise? Israel today is very much in the second mode.

headline: Wars Fought and Wars Googled

headline: E.P.A. Lags on Setting Some Air Standards, Report Finds
text: WASHINGTON  The Environmental Protection Agency is 10 years behind schedule in setting guidelines for a host of toxic air pollutants, according to a report from the agency’s inspector general.

headline: A Line in the Sand Over Offshore Drilling
text: MIAMI BEACH, Fla.  The first time Dave Rauschkolb staged a rally against offshore drilling with people holding hands across the beach outside his restaurant in Seaside, Fla., barely anyone noticed.

headline: White House to Push Free Trade Deal With South Korea
text: TORONTO  The Obama administration announced Saturday that it would ask Congress to ratify a long-stalled free-trade agreement with South Korea after the midterm elections in November.

headline: Effort Uses Dogs’ DNA to Track Their Abusers
text: ST. LOUIS  Scientists and animal rights advocates have enlisted DNA evidence to do for man’s best friend what the judicial system has long done for human crime victims. They have created the country’s first dog-fighting DNA database, which they say will help criminal investigators piece together an abused animal’s history by establishing ties among breeders, owners, pit operators and the animals themselves.

headline: Both Sides in California’s Gay Marriage Fight See a Long Court Battle Ahead
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Just hours after Judge Vaughn R. Walker banged the final gavel in the trial of Proposition 8  California’s same-sex marriage ban  the two top lawyers challenging the law, David Boies and Theodore Olson, were holding court again: this time at a small private dinner with donors in San Francisco.

headline: Falling Branch Kills Baby at the Central Park Zoo
text: A baby girl was killed and her mother critically injured when a tree branch fell and struck them just outside the Central Park Zoo on Saturday, the police said.

headline: To Thine Own Self Be True
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — When I open up a big Sunday puzzle, my first problem is an ethical one. Should I read the title? Sometimes it doesn’t matter. The title provides a clever joke about the puzzle but doesn’t give anything away. Sometimes it’s a spoiler: the theme can be discerned from the title alone, and I prefer to uncover it myself. Occasionally, the theme provides an essential clue.

headline: Cleanup Hiring Feeds Frustration in Fishing Town
text: BAYOU LA BATRE, Ala. — Nine weeks into the disaster in the Gulf of Mexico, there is more money in this small, hardscrabble fishing town than there has been in decades, residents say. There are more high-paying workdays, more traffic accidents, more reports of domestic violence, more drug and alcohol use, more resentment, more rumors, more hunger, more worry.

text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is poised to award contracts worth hundreds of millions of dollars to about 20 states to run new insurance pools for people with serious medical problems.

headline: Wind Blows Up as Stadium’s Days Wind Down
text: OMAHA — As the last College World Series at venerable Rosenblatt Stadium nears its final days — the best-of-three championship series begins Monday night — one of the big unknowns is whether the wind and sun will be as tricky in the tournament’s new home, TD Ameritrade Park.

He was 58.

headline: For U.S., Holes Come Too Early, Too Often
text: RUSTENBURG, South Africa  Even in the final minute of overtime, down by 2-1 to Ghana, the United States players still thought they had a chance to tie the game and extend their World Cup experience. Goalkeeper Tim Howard ran the length of the field to bolster the attack on one last corner kick.

headline: In Oakland, Shootings at Funerals Cause Concern for Police and Community Leaders
text: It’s a macabre trend: In Oakland and Richmond, young gunmen are targeting funerals and memorial services to attack friends and relatives of slain victims, the police and community leaders say.

headline: Suit Accuses Citibank of Abetting Viola Scheme
text: Giuseppe Viola gave his 2008 holiday party at Trattoria Pinocchio in North Beach. It was a lavish affair, with a menu of salmon and filet mignon. Mr. Viola invited about 45 guests, and most were bankers and staff members from local branches of Citibank, according to the restaurant’s owner, Giovanni Zocca.

headline: The Ace Does Nothing to Quell Fears of His Decline
text: With news of a 149-pitch no-hitter laid at the doorstep of Major League Baseball on Saturday morning, Twins Manager Ron Gardenhire recalled a decision he almost had to make when his erstwhile ace, Johan Santana, was throwing a one-hit gem against Texas and challenging a Minnesota strikeout record in the process.

headline: Legislators Offer Budget That Restores Cuts to Education and Social Services
text: Seeking to outflank Gov. David A. Paterson, the State Senate and Assembly offered a joint budget plan on Saturday that would restore hundreds of millions of dollars in education and social service cuts that Mr. Paterson had sought in an emergency budget bill that he submitted on Friday.

headline: The State’s Green Ways Are Under Attack
text: Jonathan Weber writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Bothered by Aching Knees, Nadal Battles to 5-Set Win
text: WIMBLEDON, England  After his latest five-set victory, on Saturday in Wimbledon’s third round, Rafael Nadal admitted that at different points this season, he had had pain in his knees from tendinitis.

headline: Taco Trucks; Fruitvale, Oakland
text: San Francisco’s Mission District has its burritos, but in Oakland’s Fruitvale District, the taco is king. As one of only two neighborhoods in Oakland where mobile food trucks are allowed to operate without an expensive license, Fruitvale has become the destination for aficionados of Mexican food. According to La Placita, a microbusiness center, Oakland has about 120 legal loncherías, or lunch wagons, half of which are in Fruitvale. HANK PELLISSIER

headline: Scrubbing Our Cell Phones of Conflict Minerals
text: My Sunday column is about the campaign to eliminate “blood minerals” from cell phones, lap-tops, digital cameras and other cool devices. I’m actually mildly optimistic that Congo is gaining traction on the international agenda, and that progress is possible after a pretty bad half century for Congo.

headline: Raf Simons: Feeling It
text: The Gay Pride parade was held this afternoon in Paris, and the streets and boulevards on the Left Bank on this beautiful June day were clogged. At Dior Homme, around 3 p.m., the audience looked sullen as it fanned away the heat in a former train depot, where the Dior crew had erected a blinding-white set with a center room curtained off with enough sheer drapery to close several Broadway productions. Rows of spotlights raised the temperature but they also created the desired effect as the models appeared as shadows behind the drapes.

headline: On Finance Bill, Lobbying Shifts to Regulations
text: WASHINGTON  Well before Congress reached agreement on the details of its financial overhaul legislation, industry lobbyists and consumer advocates started preparing for the next battle: influencing the creation of several hundred new rules and regulations.

headline: A Jazz Great Who Left More Than His Music
text: The passing of Fred Anderson, the Chicago tenor saxophonist who died Thursday at 81, casts a pall over jazz musicians as far away as New York and Europe, which Mr. Anderson frequently visited to play in festivals. But it has especially darkened the scene in Chicago, his base of operations since the 1950s, and for good reason.

headline: Court Rules; Patronage May Benefit

headline: Verdict in Burge Trial Will Not Bring Issue to a Close
text: Whatever the outcome of the Jon Burge perjury and obstruction of justice trial, the legal battles that have swirled around him for more than 20 years, and that have cost the city millions of dollars, will drag on.

headline: One Battalion’s Wrenching Deployment to Afghanistan
text: Pvt. Johnnie Stevenson spent his final hours at Fort Drum alone, trying to put his game face on. He played some Ludacris on his iPod, then turned it off. He unpacked his 72-hour bag, then repacked it. Did he have enough toothpaste and spare socks? Had he paid his bills? Was he ready for war? For a year?

headline: Correction
text: An article last Sunday about the actor Robert Pattinson misidentified his character’s love interest in the Harry Potter movies. Cho Chang, not Hermione, was the girlfriend of Mr. Pattinson’s character, Cedric Diggory. The article also omitted one of movies in which he appeared. Besides “Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix,” he was in “Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire.”

headline: Correction
text: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the playwright A. R. Gurney erroneously included one of the actresses in Mr. Gurney’s play “The Grand Manner.” While Boyd Gaines and Kate Burton were shown, Brenda Wehle was not.

headline: Three Killed at Political Rally in Mexico
text: ZINACANTÁN, Mexico (AP)  A mob armed with clubs, stones and guns attacked a political rally in southern Mexico on Saturday, sparking hours of clashes that left three people dead and six more wounded.

headline: U.S. Keeps Command of Military in Seoul
text: TORONTO  In its strongest move since the sinking of a South Korean warship, the Obama administration said Saturday that the United States would retain control of all military forces in the South during any conflict with North Korea, which has been widely blamed for the attack on the ship in March that killed 46 sailors.
