headline: Keeping the Africa in Africa’s World Cup
text: There were two teams in this compelling contest at Rustenburg. As difficult as it was for the United States to go out in such a fashion, the importance of Ghana’s young, brave and ultimately undeniable victory has ramifications for the World Cup as a whole.

headline: History Repeats Itself With Reliever’s Complete Game
text: Two words best describe what Michael Roth, a South Carolina sophomore left-hander, did at the College World Series on Friday night. Unexpected. Remarkable.

headline: World Cup Photo Replay: Uruguay vs. South Korea
text: In a rain-swept match on a far-from-perfect field, both teams had their moments and chances and dubious calls to cope with.

headline: Ghana’s Turn to Celebrate
text: Americans celebrated across the country last Wednesday when the national team beat Algeria with a last-minute goal. But on Saturday it was the Ghanaians’ turn to celebrate, and they did, all around the world.

headline: Vows: Sarah & Reed
text: Sarah Mead and Reed Burgoyne met in San Francisco in 2002. Both artists, they teamed up in their art adventure and fell in love. Their current project is their handmade paper wedding.

headline: A London Party for Your Inner Child
text: British high society in the 1920s saw a rise of decadent dress-up parties with absurd themes. One, called “Come as You Were 20 Years Ago” resulted in young socialites showing up in giant baby carriages pushed by their butler.

headline: How to Turn an Old iPod Into Cash
text: Earlier this year, we started a recurring feature here at Bucks where we highlight others online who present novel cost-saving strategies we wish we had thought of. In our first installment, we detailed a creative tip for keeping thieves from trying to steal your important possessions. In this second installment, here are some tips we’ve found online for turning your possessions into cash and for saving on your commute that go beyond craigslist and public transportation.

headline: New Czech Prime Minister Is Named
text: PRAGUE President Vaclav Klaus of the Czech Republic said Sunday he would appoint a center-right leader, Petr Necas, as the country’s new prime minister on Monday, clearing the way for a government that is both pro-American and focused on fiscal austerity.

headline: World Cup Live: Germany vs. England
text: Germany crushed England, 4-1, in the round of 16 in Bloemfontein this afternoon, adding Fabio Capello’s team to a World Cup roll of dishonor that includes Italy and France.

headline: Rocky Mountain High
text: Colorado legalized medical marijuana in 2000, now the city of Boulder has at least 50 dispensaries, which range from posh well-lit places to others that revel in the drug's counter culture past.

headline: A Reprieve for an Oasis With an Edge
text: To get to the city pool in Brooklyn’s Gowanus neighborhood in the 1970s, a swimmer ran a gantlet.

headline: Vettel Dominates European Grand Prix, as Webber Flips Out
text: Updated 3:04 p.m. ET

headline: Now Screening | Lanvin
text: The Spring/Summer 2011 collection from Lanvin at Paris Fashion Week.

headline: Pope Lashes Out at Belgium After Raid on Church
text: ROME  In a sign of sharply rising tensions between the Vatican and Belgium, Pope Benedict XVI on Sunday criticized as “surprising and deplorable” a raid on church property last week by Belgian police officers investigating sexual abuse by clerics.

headline: A Modest Proposal: Add Electronic Review for Goals
text: Instant replay arrived in world soccer on Sunday. It became absolutely essential when the field officials totally missed the shot from England’s Frank Lampard that hit the crossbar and bounced fully two feet into the goal.

headline: Sunday Word: Wrapping Up the G-20
text: President Obama wraps up the G-20 summit in Canada today, meeting with three more world leaders.

headline: Now Screening | Raf Simons
text: The Spring/Summer 2011 collection from Raf Simons at Paris Fashion Week.

headline: The Odds Say Arrivederci Fabio, and Pronto
text: The smoke is still rising from England’s incinerated World Cup hopes, but the London bookmakers have already set odds on who will replace Fabio Capello as the next Three Lions coach.

headline: Kyrgyz Voting Calm After Violence
text: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan  Kyrgyzstan’s interim leader, Roza Otunbayeva, declared victory on Sunday in a constitutional referendum that she hopes will legitimize her position as president and help stabilize the country, but in a sign of continuing disarray in her government, the director of the Central Election Committee said too few ballots had been counted to call the vote.

headline: Family of Captured Israeli Soldier Press for Deal
text: TEL AVIV  The family of Staff Sgt. Gilad Shalit, the Israeli soldier who has been held captive by Hamas in Gaza for four years, began a march to Jerusalem on Sunday aimed at pressing the government to make a deal for the soldier’s release.

headline: Pakistan’s Plan on Afghan Peace Leaves U.S. Wary
text: President Obama and the director of the Central Intelligence Agency both reacted with skepticism on Sunday about the prospects for an Afghanistan peace deal pushed by Pakistan between the Afghan government and some Taliban militants.

headline: World Cup Live: Argentina vs. Mexico
text: Argentina stepped out of group play and into the knockout round, where if the pressure was supposed to be ramped up, it was never apparent.

headline: A Little More Time for Beltran
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — For months, outfielder Carlos Beltran has pegged his comeback from off-season knee surgery to the Mets’ series against the Florida Marlins in Puerto Rico.

headline: 40 Winks? She’d Even Settle for 30
text: Dressed optimistically in sweatpants and a starry “Little Night Music” T-shirt, Patricia Morrisroe reported for guinea-pig duty at a Manhattan clinic for sleep disorders. She was there for a $3,200 overnight stay during which her insomnia would be monitored. As a technician hooked her up to 25 electrodes and sensors, he reassured her that if any of these became disconnected while she slept, he would return and reattach them without disturbing her.

headline: Germany, and Referee, Leave England Speechless
text: BLOEMFONTEIN, South Africa

headline: ‘Wide Awake’
text: The House of Punk Sleep

headline: Invisible Friends
text: I’ve written before about the strange power of invisible bond vigilantes:

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Blue Velvet'
text: A.O. Scott reviews David Lynch's unconventional film from 1986.

headline: Vettel Dominant in European Grand Prix
text: His teammate went flying through the air and landed upside down after only eight laps, the safety car then shuffled the order of most of the racers like a croupier with a deck of cards. But nothing ruffled a determined Sebastian Vettel of the Red Bull team.

headline: Plenty of Aggression at Women’s Grand Prix
text: The fourth Women’s Grand Prix is turning out to be highly competitive as very few games have ended in draws. The early leader is Nana Dzagnidze of the Republic of Georgia.

headline: Senator Byrd ‘Seriously Ill’
text: Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, the longest serving senator in U.S. history, is “seriously ill,” his office announced Sunday afternoon.

headline: A Brief Note On German Unemployment
text: Brief because I’m sitting at an outdoor cafe in Luxembourg …

headline: Brands Seems Poised for an Upset
text: I watched Daniel Brands’s tough first-round win over Igor Andreev in three sets and came away impressed. Andreev is a difficult opponent; recall that he had Roger Federer on the ropes in Melbourne earlier this year.

headline: Shalit Family Demands Prisoner Swap
text: Israelis are marching for 12 days to the home of President Benjamin Netanyahu to demand the release of soldier Gilad Shalit who was captured four years ago by Hamas.

headline: Strains of Klezmer and Bashevis Singer, and Then Mendelssohn, Too
text: Among the salient aspects of Mendelssohn’s life, that he was born a Jew could almost have seemed irrelevant had Wagner not seized on it to fuel a notorious aesthetic pogrom that wrecked Mendelssohn’s reputation for some time. Mendelssohn, only four years older than Wagner, was baptized as an infant; still, Wagner held up his former idol’s ethnicity as a sign of artistic blight.

headline: A Haydn Sonata Accented With Ingenuity
text: On Saturday night, less than a month after winning first prize in the prestigious Queen Elisabeth Piano Competition in Brussels, the young Russian Denis Kozhukhin, born in 1986, played a recital at Zankel Hall presented by Monet MGM. Although the auditorium was not full, the audience was understandably enthusiastic. Mr. Kozhukhin gave formidable, freshly considered accounts of two challenging staples: Schumann’s “Symphonic Études” and Mussorgsky’s “Pictures at an Exhibition.”

headline: Lost in the Clouds?
text: Those in the ivory tower might think themselves enlightened; those on the ground find them irrelevant.— Mahmood, Richmond

headline: Francoeur Keeps the Mets in a Groove
text: Earlier this season, after the Mets’ Jeff Francoeur hit a home run off Atlanta’s Kris Medlen, someone asked Medlen if it was difficult to pitch to Francoeur.

headline: World Leaders Agree on Timetable for Cutting Deficits
text: TORONTO  Leaders of the world’s biggest economies agreed Sunday on a timetable for cutting deficits and halting the growth of their debt, but also acknowledged the need to move carefully so that reductions in spending did not set back the fragile global recovery.

headline: New CDs
text: THE-DREAM

headline: Philosophy App
text: In his “Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy,” the science fiction writer Douglas Adams introduces Deep Thought — a computer the size of a small city, designed millions of years ago by a race of hyperintelligent pan-dimensional beings searching for the meaning of life. The super computer is described as a “so amazingly intelligent that even before the data banks had been connected up it had started from ‘I think therefore I am’ and got as far as the existence of rice pudding and income tax before anyone managed to turn it off …”

headline: Box Office Measures Star Power
text: LOS ANGELES  The weekend box office delivered very different results for three A-list stars, as Adam Sandler hit another home run in “Grown Ups,” and Tom Cruise and Cameron Diaz whiffed in “Knight and Day.”

headline: Jazz Tradition and What’s Worth Keeping
text: Ambrose Akinmusire’s opening set at the Jazz Standard on Friday showed some excitement and unease: a young trumpeter and composer still looking for, or maybe still rejecting, a style. The music wasn’t quite there yet, and it wasn’t clear just where “there” was. But the irresolution felt good enough for now.

headline: Police in Toronto Criticized for Treatment of Protesters, Many Peaceful
text: TORONTO  An escalation of aggressive police tactics toward even apparently peaceful protests at the Group of 20 summit meeting led to calls for a review of security activities.

headline: Victory Means a Chance at the Bermuda Bowl
text: The 120-board final of the open trial to select the U.S.A.-1 team for next year’s Bermuda Bowl ended in Chicago late on Sunday. After 90 boards, John Diamond, Brian Platnick, Eric Greco, Geoff Hampson, Fred Gitelman and Brad Moss led Martin Fleisher, Michael Kamil, Bobby Levin, Steve Weinstein, Chip Martel and Lew Stansby, 185 international match points to 182.

headline: The Seating Is the Stage for a Night
text: Jason Jordan’s dance career had humble beginnings: When he was 7, he was voted the best dancer at a Brooklyn house party. (His prize amounted to $5.) He went on to train and perform with Eliot Feld’s Ballet Tech, where he was a particularly luxuriant dancer  sinewy and naïve, yet coolly confident. Now, as part of this year’s Vision Festival, Mr. Jordan presents his own company in a series of dance installations called “Stations,” in which he attempts to capture the essence of human development.

headline: Sleek Playfulness and a Plea to the Heavens
text: Sense and sensuality: that was the credo for the R&B singers-songwriters Maxwell and Jill Scott at Madison Square Garden on Friday night. Their double bill proposed a study in compatible contrasts, and, if you like, a treatise on the interplay of gender and power, seduction and surrender. But that’s probably over-thinking the issue. It’s certainly underplaying the pleasure of a surefooted, playfully intelligent, supremely satisfying show.

headline: Shapes and Spaces for Peripheral Vision
text: Rob List is the sort of artist whose work transfixes, drawing you minute by minute through strange yet familiar terrain; the impulse is always to hold your breath.

headline: No Trendy Bells and Whistles, Just Mozart on a Summer Eve
text: KATONAH, N.Y.  Every summer festival has its own personality  a combination of atmosphere and sense of mission  and though that may evolve with audience demographics and tastes, most find ways to retain some of their original spirit. From 1929 to 1939, Lucie and Walter Rosen cobbled together a large country house at Caramoor, their 90-acre estate here, made up of rooms in disparate styles (from palaces and other buildings) that they acquired in Europe. When the house was finished, the Rosens began presenting concerts in their music room, and in 1946 they opened Caramoor to the public as a performing-arts center.

headline: A Crusader for Boldness as the Arts Face Deficits
text: NEW HAVEN  Watching Michael M. Kaiser, the president of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, speak to arts executives, as he did during two recent swings through New England, is like watching Jack Welch talk to business students.

headline: McChrystal’s Quality Time With Rolling Stone: Impertinent? Check. Insubordinate? Maybe Not.
text: You could say General Stanley A. McChrystal was a victim of his own hubris – the archetypal field commander who got too intemperate with the suits back at headquarters.

headline: Can Girls Be Overweight and Not Be Overwrought?
text: Gitbigger.com, a chronicle of a recent college graduate in Kentucky who is trying to get fat, is an example of one of the Internet’s proliferating “gainer blogs.” Writing this month, the blogger, who calls himself Stupidgit, told readers that although he had reached a point where he was consuming 3,000 calories a day, he was burning them off too easily, and that this deficit had become a problem. “I simply need to set my bar higher,” he announced, expressing the kind of resolve normally associated with people trying to look like Lance Armstrong.

headline: Hacienda Material
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle will have you seeing double, with six “gaga”-like phrases making up the theme. The repeated syllables mostly all rhyme, with RARA AVIS being the biggest deviant (sounds sinister, doesn’t it?). BABA WAWA finishes things up with a double dose of doubling.

headline: Eric Clapton’s Crossroads Guitar Festival
text: BRIDGEVIEW, Ill. — Close-ups of strings, fretboards and guitarists’ callused fingers filled the video screens on Saturday at Toyota Park here, a stadium just outside Chicago, where Eric Clapton’s Crossroads Guitar Festival presented some two-dozen guitar-slingers during a sold-out, 11-hour concert.

headline: Thom Browne: Party Line
text: The American designer Thom Browne, having his Paris debut, invited everyone this evening to the French Communist Party headquarters, in a handsome Oscar Niemeyer building. After a bit of a wait, we were shown into a sloped meeting room with rows of long tables and little French and American flags at each place. Presently four identical-looking models entered the room dressed in crested blue blazers, shorts, white shirts and ties, and wearing chic wire sunglasses. They sat at the head table and addressed the assembly — first in English, then in French — with a comic gravity.

headline: Jackson Collectors Open Their Wallets at Auction
text: This year’s auction houses have seen no shortage of high-priced Michael Jackson memorabilia, and this weekend, on the anniversary of his death, collectors once again showed they were willing to pay tribute to the pop star. Among the 200 items being auctioned by Julien’s Auctions at the Planet Hollywood in Las Vegas, The Associated Press reported, were a Swarovski crystal-studded glove, above, he wore on his 1984 Victory Tour (estimated at $20,000 to $30,000) that sold for $192,000, including buyer’s premium, to Wanda Kelley of Los Angeles. “Let’s just say I wasn’t walking out of here without that glove,” Ms. Kelley, who also bought numerous albums at the auction, told The A.P. A similar glove sold for $350,000 in November at an auction by Julien’s in New York. A pair of signed black loafers worn by Jackson on stage sold for $90,000, though they were listed at $2,000 to $3,000, and a custom jacket he wore during an interview with Barbara Walters, estimated at $6,000 to $8,000, went for $120,000. Perhaps one of the most poignant items was one of the last autographs signed by Jackson, dated June 24, 2009, which sold for $18,750.

headline: ‘Friday Night Lights’ Watch: Dreams Deferred
text: So we begin more or less with Tim Riggins’s dream denied. Again! On last week’s episode of “Friday Night Lights,” there was a glimmer of hope for Riggins’s — real estate. (And that says it all, doesn’t it?) He’d fallen in love with 25 gorgeous, unusually lush acres of tree-lined Texas property, and he could picture a nice life for himself on it. When he inquires about the land, he learns that it costs $85,000. He quite obviously doesn’t have the money, and let’s not even bother to discuss post-recession financing. Riggins puts on a suit to go meet the Realtor — this is a grown-up appointment — but adult life just doesn’t suit Riggins (or it just doesn’t like him). He starts pulling at his tie as if it’s strangling him.

headline: From ‘Potter’ to Trenches
text: Daniel Radcliffe, below, having recently wrapped up filming on the last two “Harry Potter” movies, has signed on to play a more realistic warrior. Mr. Radcliffe will star in a new film version of “All Quiet on the Western Front,” based on the novel by Erich Maria Remarque, BBC News reported. The producer Ian Stokell said Mr. Radcliffe is expected to bring a “vulnerability and innocence” to the character of Paul Baumer, a young German infantryman fighting in the trenches during World War I. Production on the new film is expected to begin in spring 2012, following the completion of Mr. Radcliffe’s work in the Broadway musical “How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying.” Rob Ashford (”Promises, Promises”) will direct Mr. Radcliffe in his Broadway debut in a musical, which is expected to open in spring 2011.

headline: U.C.L.A. Live Cuts Its International Theater Festival
text: U.C.L.A. Live, the popular performance series that brings leading dance, music and theater companies to Los Angeles each year, has eliminated its prestigious international theater festival from the 2010-11 schedule because of budget cuts, The Los Angeles Times reported. The performance series’s annual budget, around $8 million, has been suffering in recent years because of falling attendance and reduced fund-raising, and the number of events this year has diminished to 47 from 85 in the 2009-10 season. David Sefton, U.C.L.A. Live’s artistic director for almost a decade, resigned in May after learning about plans for “a major rethinking and restructuring” of the series. “It was not going to be the program I was originally brought in to run,” Mr. Sefton told The Times in May. “It’s not appropriate for me, and my response was to resign,” he said. In past seasons the theater festival has presented innovative productions and acclaimed actors, including the theater and opera director Lenka Udovicki’s staging of “Medea,” starring Annette Bening; Ian McKellen in “King Lear,” directed by Trevor Nunn; and the National Theater of Scotland’s widely praised “Black Watch.”

headline: Strings and Songs
text: Photos from the Crossroads Guitar Festival just outside Chicago.

headline: Oprah Show’s Online Flap
text: A talent search by Oprah Winfrey has taken a confusing turn, thanks to online voting. Ms. Winfrey’s forthcoming cable channel, OWN, has been holding online and in-person casting calls for “Your OWN Show: Oprah’s Search for the Next TV Star,” a reality show that will have its premiere next year. Last week the search was tainted by allegations from fans of the top two online candidates, Zach Anner and Phyllis Wick-Turner, that the other side had stuffed the online ballot box. Some even suggested that Ms. Winfrey was behind it. The allegations, picked up by the news media, prompted a channel spokesperson to say in a statement that no “contestant has been favored in this competition,” but that an investigation would be undertaken and that all votes would be verified twice. The five most popular online contestants will go before a casting director, but only one is guaranteed a spot on the reality show, though OWN could choose to add more than one. A total of 10 in-person and online contestants will vie for a spot; eventually the show’s winner will be hired by OWN. By Sunday, Mr. Anner had accumulated two million more votes than Ms. Wick-Turner.

headline: Footnote
text: The National Theater of London has announced a second season of National Theater Live, through which live performances will be broadcast to movie theaters worldwide. Screenings will begin Oct. 14 with the 2008 Olivier Award winner for best new play, “A Disappearing Number,” a collaborative work by the director Simon McBurney’s Complicite theater group. Other screenings will include “Fela!,” Nicholas Hytner’s “Hamlet” and Danny Boyle’s “Frankenstein.” Times and locations will be announced later this summer.

headline: A Family News Affair
text: Yahoo has announced that it has acquired a new online current-affairs show created by Ben Stiller and featuring his parents, the comedians and actors Jerry Stiller and Anne Meara, above, The Guardian reported last week. Elisa Steele, Yahoo’s chief marketing officer, told The Guardian that the short Webisodes, probably less than 10 minutes each, would revolve around news items of the day, with Mr. Stiller and Ms. Meara providing commentary and the younger Mr. Stiller directing. “Ben had a great idea,” Ms. Steele said. “He started to talk to us and it was a good fit with Yahoo.” The show is expected to been seen exclusively online by year’s end.

headline: Life Lessons, and Sweet Siren Song of The-a-tuh
text: The title is “The Grand Manner,” but the style of A. R. Gurney’s latest play, which opened Sunday night at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center, is definitely on the cozy side. A homey needlepoint embroidery on Mr. Gurney’s encounter as a prep school student with the fabled American actress Katharine Cornell, this fantasy memoir allows the author’s younger, provincial self a seductive first glimpse of a world where being merely life-size isn’t enough.

headline: The P.R. Blitz for the Presidency
text: In the campaign for the presidency of the World Chess Federation, the two candidates — Kirsan Ilyumzhinov, the incumbent, and Anatoly Karpov, the former champion — are each trying to portray themselves as front runners.

headline: Tracking Gulf Oil and Storms
text: 7:43 p.m. | Updated There were a couple of days of breathless news stories playing up the threat to operations around the BP oil gusher posed by the brewing storm called Alex. But federal storm forecasters never saw much of a chance of this storm shifting northeast toward the region beset by slicks and oiled shores. As of Sunday night, the storm, still a tropical depression, had finished pummeling the Yucatan Peninsula and was projected to strengthen over warm Gulf of Mexico waters before making landfall on shores in the western gulf (although some models still calculate a possible risk to the oily east).

headline: New Diploma Standard in New York Becomes a Multiple-Question Choice
text: When the State Education Department announced five years ago that all students would soon be required to pass five tests to earn high school diplomas in New York, officials applauded themselves for raising standards.

headline: Senator Robert Byrd Is Seriously Ill
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Robert C. Byrd, the longest-serving senator in United States history, is “seriously ill,” his office announced Sunday afternoon.

headline: Guinea Votes Show Elation in Free Election
text: CONAKRY, Guinea  Long lines of voters snaked outside of polling places Sunday in what was widely hailed as this West African nation’s first free presidential election since independence 52 years ago.

headline: Cheney’s Release Is Expected Soon
text: Former Vice President Dick Cheney could be released from the hospital as early as Monday after being treated for a heart ailment, one of his daughters said Sunday.

headline: Endangered Species on Connecticut Coast: Last of the Lobstermen
text: Stonington, Conn.

headline: Seeking God’s Help for a Wounded Gulf
text: BON SECOUR, Ala.  In a small white building along the baptizing Bon Secour River, a building that once housed a shrimp-net business, the congregation of the Fishermen Baptist Church gathered for another Sunday service, with the preacher presiding from a pulpit designed to look like a ship captain’s wheel.

headline: When the Elderly Become Delusional
text: To the Editor:

headline: Study Finds Questioning of Nominees to Be Useful
text: WASHINGTON  Ever since nominees to the Supreme Court started to subject themselves to comprehensive grilling in 1939, their confirmation hearings have been dismissed by the legal elite as an empty charade.

headline: A Stonewall Veteran, 89, Misses the Parade
text: At noon on Sunday, thousands of marchers filled Fifth Avenue for New York City’s annual gay pride parade. Nearly six miles away, on the sixth floor of a nursing home in Brooklyn, the frail, white-haired woman in beige pajamas and brown slippers in Room 609 sat motionless at the edge of her bed, staring out her window.

headline: Faustian Bargains and the Testing of the Liberals
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Beauty of Diversity
text: To the Editor:

headline: Japan’s Coach Is Having the Last Chuckle
text: JOHANNESBURG  Two months ago, a month ago, even two weeks ago, few wanted to listen to this severe man who is said to write poetry and contemplate retirement as a farmer.

headline: Recycling Cellphones
text: To the Editor:

headline: Yes, the Prince Climbed Right Back On
text: Among the throngs aboard the 10 o’clock ferry to Governors Island on Sunday morning were passengers named Gata, Cumpa and Versace, who ate snacks and seemed to be enjoying the harbor breezes.

headline: Accident at Park Puts Focus on Trees
text: The accident occurred on a glorious, postcard-ready summer afternoon in New York, free of the usual culprits of lightning or snow. A large, healthy tree branch, 30 feet above a well-traveled path just outside the Central Park Zoo, snapped, fell and killed a 6-month-old girl as horrified visitors looked on.

headline: 12-Shot Win Gives Kerr L.P.G.A.’s No. 1 Ranking
text: After Lorena Ochoa’s abrupt retirement in May created a vacuum at the top of the world rankings, Michelle Wie was unofficially anointed the heir to Ochoa’s throne.

headline: U.S. Soccer Could Use a Kobe Bryant
text: SOWETO, South Africa  Kobe Bryant walked off the field Sunday afternoon, nearly 100 photographers shadowing every move.

headline: Safety Net Frays in Spain, as Elsewhere in Europe
text: MADRID — This was the deal that Gema Díaz, 34, thought she had made: When she took a job with this city as a purchasing agent 12 years ago, she knew her salary would be low.

headline: Tévez Scores Twice as Argentina Advances
text: JOHANNESBURG  It was forward Carlos Tévez who said the words no one else was willing to speak: the only satisfactory World Cup for Argentina would be to win it.

headline: Heedlessly Hijacking Content
text: Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal was not the only one who had a tough week at the office.

headline: Outing of Anti-Gay Pastor Draws Criticism
text: The reaction was swift when Lavender Magazine, a biweekly for Minneapolis’s gay and lesbian community, reported in its current issue that an outspokenly anti-homosexual local pastor attended a support group for people who want to remain chaste despite same-sex attraction.

headline: At Summit, Banks Avoid New Global Regulations
text: TORONTO  Giant banks, while bracing for a wave of tougher regulation in Washington, will not have to face a new set of global rules on capital and liquidity anytime soon.

headline: Online Bullies Pull Schools Into the Fray
text: The girl’s parents, wild with outrage and fear, showed the principal the text messages: a dozen shocking, sexually explicit threats, sent to their daughter the previous Saturday night from the cellphone of a 12-year-old boy. Both children were sixth graders at Benjamin Franklin Middle School in Ridgewood, N.J.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Pride Marches On
text: The 2010 Pride March celebrating the city’s gay population filled the streets of Greenwich Village with thousands of spectators.

headline: Puerto Rico’s Pipeline Has Been Running Low
text: A decade ago, even a casual baseball fan could name an all-star team’s worth of players from Puerto Rico: Carlos Delgado at first base; Roberto Alomar at second base; Juan Gonzalez, Ruben Sierra and Bernie Williams in the outfield; and Sandy Alomar Jr., Jorge Posada and Ivan Rodriguez behind the plate.

headline: North Korea Rejects U.S. Proposal for Talks on Sinking of Warship
text: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea on Sunday rejected an invitation from the American-led United Nations Command to hold talks on the sinking of a South Korean warship three months ago, which a multinational investigation has attributed to the North Koreans.

headline: BP Loses Trading-Floor Swagger in Energy Markets
text: It seems like Wall Street at its worst: a cowboy on the trading floor plots to corner a market, and gets caught.

headline: Elena Kagan’s Moment
text: Elena Kagan has produced distinguished scholarship on the First Amendment, taking clear positions favoring a broad interpretation of free speech. She opposed bans on flag burning and hate speech, and tried to come up with a framework for deciding when laws unconstitutionally suppress protected speech. In the Clinton White House, as a domestic policy adviser, she was an advocate for responsible positions on campaign finance limits, tobacco regulation and gun restrictions.

headline: U.S. Team Needs a Bradley or Two
text: Irene, South Africa

headline: The Return of Superfund
text: Superfund  which cleans up abandoned hazardous waste sites  is one of the country’s most important environmental programs. It has been struggling since 1995, when a Republican Congress refused to renew the corporate taxes that gave it a steady source of financing. The pace of cleanups has dropped markedly.

headline: ‘Avatar’ Beats ‘Hurt Locker’ Where It Counts: New Oscar Voters
text: Oscar night belonged to a drama, “The Hurt Locker,” but the path to membership in the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences ran through the science fiction genre this year.

headline: Switzerland Starts to Come Clean
text: The United States Treasury forgoes about $100 billion a year in uncollected taxes from businesses and wealthy individuals that keep their money in offshore accounts, out of reach of the Internal Revenue Service. This is not only notoriously unfair; it is a crime. It has also proved notoriously difficult to stop because of the bank secrecy statutes in tax havens around the world.

headline: Lush Land Winds Through a Ravaged Capital
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia  There is a certain spot in this war-ravaged city that is unusually quiet and profoundly lush, where the trees are older and dripping with vines and where the branches interlace over the road, creating a canopy that filters the usually harsh equatorial sun into something softer. The leaves here seem a brighter, glossier version of themselves. The grasses are long and thick, perfect to hide in.

headline: Darci Kistler Stages Last New York City Ballet Show
text: Confetti rained from above, dozens of flowers were tossed at the stage and bouquets piled up at the feet of Darci Kistler as she took her bows at her final performance as a principal of New York City Ballet on Sunday afternoon.

headline: Le Monde’s Board to Choose Investors
text: PARIS  The fate of the iconic French newspaper Le Monde will be decided by its board on Monday, with some of the paper’s journalists fearing that they will lose control to a group of investors backed by President Nicolas Sarkozy.

headline: Labor’s New Critics: Old Allies in Elected Office

headline: Ask Questions About Cyberbullying

There was Derek Jeter at shortstop, Jorge Posada catching and Andy Pettitte on the mound, as special as ever. Mariano Rivera also showed up, but his appearance was unexpected. The Yankees required Rivera’s services Sunday night after tying the score with four ninth-inning runs, then rejoiced as a two-run homer by Robinson Cano boosted them to an 8-6 victory in 10 innings over Torre’s Dodgers.

headline: Paris Film Festival Celebrates Japan and More
text: Feeling out of sorts because you didn’t make it to the Cannes Film Festival this year? Not toworry. The more democratic and off-beat Paris Cinema Festival (pariscinema.org) takes place from July 3 to 13. Supported by the city of Paris, with a jury chaired by the English actress Charlotte Rampling, the festival will screen over 200 new and not-so-new films — the classics include Sergio Leone’s “Once Upon a Time in the West” and George Roy Hill’s “Slaughterhouse-Five” — at over 12 different venues. Traditionally, one country’s cinematography gains the spotlight; Japan is featured this year, with films from new directors, as well as retrospectives of the works of directors Akira Kurosawa and Sadao Yamanaka.

headline: The Dodd-Frank Bill Up Close

headline: Robert C. Byrd, a Pillar of the Senate, Dies at 92
text: Robert C. Byrd served 51 years in the United States Senate, longer than anyone else in history, and with his six years in the House of Representatives, he was the longest-serving member of Congress. But it was how he used that record tenure that made him a pillar of Capitol Hill  fighting, often with florid words, for the primacy of the legislative branch of government and building, always with canny political skills, a modern West Virginia with vast amounts of federal money.

headline: An American Praetorian Guard?
text: Today’s idea: The all-professional military poses a danger to American democracy, a historian says, because it allows politicians to wage prolonged wars with the public disengaged, and thus soldiers’ disdain for civilian authority to fester. This is the lesson of the McChrystal affair.

headline: The Early Word: Kagan’s Confirmation Hearings

His absence imperils President Obama’s agenda as Senate Democrats try to pass a financial regulatory overhaul before the Fourth of July recess, and leaves Democrats one more vote short of the support they need to overcome consistently unified Republican opposition.

headline: A Year at War, Chronicling Soldiers’ Deployment in the Afghan Surge
text: Parents with young children back home. Twenty-year-olds just months out of boot camp. Seasoned officers on their fourth combat tours. Cooks, mechanics, snipers and infantrymen. Soldiers all. Over the coming year, the First Battalion, 87th Infantry Regiment of the 10th Mountain Division, will be opening a new front in the war in northern Afghanistan, patrolling and living alongside the Afghan national police in the increasingly contested provinces of Kunduz and Baghlan.

text: WIMBLEDON, England — Slipping on the grass as she reached for a forehand, Justine Henin of Belgium collided with the earth, falling face down on her right shoulder early in her fourth round match against her countrywoman Kim Clijsters.

headline: Supreme Court Rejects Appeals of Tobacco Ruling
text: The Supreme Court announced on Monday that it would not take up either government or industry appeals of a landmark racketeering verdict against cigarette companies for what a lower court judge had termed a half-century of lying over the health effects of smoking.

headline: Federer Eases Into Wimbledon Quarterfinals
text: WIMBLEDON, England – Roger Federer flashed his familiar style of ease and domination on Centre Court today and ripped through French Open semifinalist Jurgen Melzer in convincing fashion, 6-3, 6-2, 6-3.

headline: Senators React to Byrd’s Passing
text: 11:56 a.m. | Updated Lawmakers from both sides of the aisle reacted to Senator Robert C. Byrd‘s death on Monday morning by issuing statements lauding the late West Virginian’s intellect, loyalty to the Senate, passion for his home state, and the friendships he shared with his fellow lawmakers.

headline: In Upsets, Wozniacki and Bartoli Are Eliminated
text: WIMBLEDON, England –- Unseeded Petra Kvitova of the Czech Republic stunned the third seed, Caroline Wozniacki of Denmark, 6-2, 6-0, to reach the quarterfinals at Wimbledon.

headline: At Glastonbury, Stevie Wonder Helps Britain Nurse Its World Cup Wounds
text: For English-speaking nations, it was a bad weekend for World Cup aspirations but a good one for live music. While American music fans spent Sunday night scrutinizing Chris Brown’s performance at the BET Awards and wondering what was going on with Nicki Minaj’s hair, their British counterparts were watching Stevie Wonder close the books on the 40th annual Glastonbury festival.

headline: Three Cloud Music Companies to Watch
text: Internet observers eagerly awaiting the arrival of “music in the cloud”— services that store people’s music collections on the Web and stream their songs to any computer or mobile device — tend to focus their attention on the plans of the big guys like Apple, Google and Amazon and the brand-name subscription services like Rhapsody and Spotify.

headline: Readers Take Movies and Twist the Plots
text: EXT. WEST 41ST STREET — DAY

headline: Federer and Clijsters Advance on a Busy Day
text: WIMBLEDON, England  All Monday, Wimbledon bombarded the senses with an overload of tennis, an embarrassment of must-see match-ups held from early afternoon to evening, from Center Court to Court 18.

headline: Justices Take Broad View of Business Method Patents
text: The door to the patent office should remain open to those who create methods of doing business, the Supreme Court said in a long-awaited decision announced on Monday.

headline: Vandals Set Fire to U.N. Children’s Camp in Gaza
text: GAZA CITY  A gang of gunmen slashed plastic sheds and toys and vandalized a swimming pool at a United Nations summer camp for children in the Gaza Strip before setting fire to the site Monday, United Nations officials said.

headline: Justices Uphold Sarbanes-Oxley Act
text: The first group established by Congress to regulate the accounting industry survived a constitutional challenge on Monday, emerging only with its members having a little less job security.

headline: Bruce Davidson Revealed
text: Over on the Lens blog, James Estrin and Josh Haner have an interview with Bruce Davidson, a member of Magnum Photos and one of the most influential photographers of the last half century. This week, a long-awaited collection of his work, “Outside Inside,” was published. Read the interview and view more photographs here.

headline: Supreme Court Upholds Sarbanes-Oxley Act
text: 5:47 p.m. | Updated The first group established by Congress to regulate the accounting industry survived a constitutional challenge on Monday, emerging only with its members having a little less job security, Floyd Norris and Adam Liptak of The New York Times report.

headline: Red Bull Racing Takes Off, in More Ways Than One
text: Sebastian Vettel returned to winning form at the European Grand Prix in Valencia, Spain, on Sunday, but his teammate, Mark Webber, had the more memorable drive — or flight, rather.

headline: English Angst
text: We admit Leading Off has been a bit like the United States soccer team lately  disappearing for critical stretches of the World Cup  although we can blame being ransacked by live morning sports events, which is not such a handy excuse for a soccer team. But because it would be a true pity not to round up the reaction to England’s being dumped from the tournament, we are back with an “England’s being dumped from the tournament” edition.

headline: Monday Reading: The Costs of Raising a Child
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: The L-for-Love Train Goes to Williamsburg
text: It turns out that the L train, that horizontal hotbed of hipsters, is also a popular place to fall in love. And then go write about it on the Internet.

headline: The Invisible Bond Vigilantes Continue Their Invisible Attack
text: Ten-year bond rate now down to 3.05 percent. Clearly, we must slash spending immediately to satisfy the market’s demands!

headline: A Final Turn for ‘World’ at Daytime Emmys
text: With its cancellation looming, “As the World Turns” earned three of the top four acting awards at the 37th Annual Daytime Emmy Awards on Sunday night.

headline: Europe’s Enduring Coal Subsidies
text: A tussle over subsidies for the coal industry in the European Union offers another sign of how difficult it will be to phase out government support for fossil fuels, even in the most industrially advanced parts of the world.

headline: In Business Case, Court Rules Against Kagan
text: 12:51 p.m. | Updated  Elena Kagan’s Supreme Court confirmation hearings haven’t even begun, and the score is already 1-0 against her.

headline: Perks Are a Prerequisite for Some Tenants
text: At 200 West 72nd Street, where rents for two bedrooms start at $8,000 a month, tenants can impress their guests on the common rooftop with views taking in Central Park, the Hudson River and the George Washington Bridge. They can send their children to burn off energy in the building’s high-tech playroom, and expend their own in its well-equipped gym.

headline: Soccer Star Left Behind After Shooting
text: JOHANNESBURG  When Paraguay lines up against Japan in the World Cup on Tuesday in Pretoria, Salvador Cabañas will not be there.

headline: Marzorati to Leave Magazine for New Post at The Times
text: The search for a new editor for The New York Times Magazine is on. In a memo to the staff on Monday, Bill Keller, the paper’s executive editor, announced that Gerry Marzorati will be taking on a new role overseeing new initiatives at The Times. Mr. Marzorati will continue to edit the magazine through the summer as the paper searches for his successor. Mr. Keller said he would consider both internal and external candidates for the position. His note to the staff is below.

headline: Germany Goalkeeper Saw the Ball Go In [UPDATED]
text: 5:40 p.m. | Updated  As reader gonzo points out in Comment #46 below, a more accurate translation of Neuer’s original quotation in German would be: “I only watched the shot from Lampard, grabbed the ball quickly and continued to play. If I had looked to the right and left, maybe the referee would have thought about it. Maybe because of that I contributed to the fact that he didn’t give the goal.” His actual remarks, therefore, suggest that he was not completely certain that the ball had crossed the line — and only became convinced when he saw the replay in the doping control room after the match.

headline: Numberplay: Maximum Protection on Board
text: Last week we discussed spooky action at a distance in Quantum Mechanics. This week we consider a game in which action at a distance is commonplace: chess. Actually, this puzzle is long overdue – it suffered a spooky displacement in time. I had meant to run it in late April or early May during the World Chess Championship in Sofia, Bulgaria, when challenger Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria took on reigning champion Vishwanathan (“Vishy”) Anand of India. Like boxing, the world chess championship is decided by a gladiatorial, head-to-head 12-round bout (over 18 days!) between the incumbent champion and a worthy challenger. Chess is a war-game after all!

headline: Justices Extend Firearm Rights in 5-to-4 Ruling
text: WASHINGTON — The Second Amendment’s guarantee of an individual right to bear arms applies to state and local gun control laws, the Supreme Court ruled Monday in a 5-to-4 decision.

headline: A Classic French Sauce, Revisited
text: One of the mainstays of classic French cuisine is the white sauce called béchamel, a “mother sauce” from which many others are made, including the famously rich sauce mornay. Although béchamel is often referred to as a cream sauce, there is rarely any cream in it. What gives it a rich texture is the suspension of a paste called a roux, made with flour and fat, in a liquid — milk in a classic béchamel, or stock in another French “cream” sauce called velouté.

headline: Tour de France Q. and A. With Juliet Macur
text: The Tour de France begins this weekend, and Juliet Macur will be there providing continuous coverage for The Times. The two-time winner Alberto Contador, last year’s winner, will again be the favorite. But this year he will no longer have as his Astana teammate Lance Armstrong, the seven-time winner who broke off and formed his own team last year.

headline: Carrot Gratin With Béchamel
text: A reader recently requested more recipes for carrots and other orange vegetables like squash. Squash will have to wait until the fall, but there are lots of carrots in farmers’ markets right now. This recipe is so simple and so good  I simmer the carrots, stir some of the cooking water into the béchamel, nap the carrots with the béchamel and bake until bubbly.

headline: Small-Business Friendly Provisions Stay in Financial Reform
text: Congressional negotiators haggling over the fate of financial reform produced a bill that largely retained two Senate provisions likely to benefit small businesses.

headline: Analysis: Federer Looking Like His Old Self
text: Roger Federer played clean, simple tennis in routing Jurgen Melzer in straight sets. At 5-2 up in the first set, Federer had hit only one ball — a backhand return — into the net. This includes serves, which means that in seven games, every shot he hit cleared the net.

headline: Asparagus and Herb Lasagna
text: This is a great do-ahead meal for a dinner party. The lasagna takes a little time, but it’s actually very simple and keeps very well for a day or two in the refrigerator before you bake it.

headline: Chard and Chard Stalk Gratin
text: Since most of the weight of the bunch of chard you buy is in the stalks, using them makes a lot of sense. This simple Provençal gratin is a great way to do it.

headline: Lawmakers Restore Cuts, but a Veto Comes Quickly
text: ALBANY  Hoping to seize control of a budget battle dominated for weeks by Gov. David A. Paterson, lawmakers voted on Monday to restore hundreds of millions of dollars in education and health spending that the governor had sought to cut. But just hours later, Mr. Paterson exercised his line-item veto power to cancel the added school aid  and said that more such vetoes were on the way.

headline: Creamed Spinach
text: Classic creamed spinach, the kind you’re likely to be served in a restaurant, is rich with cream and butter. But it tastes just as rich when you use olive oil béchamel. This dish makes a terrific accompaniment to fish.

headline: Chinese Church Turns 100, and Memories Float By
text: At 102, May Fung Lee was tickled to be celebrating an institution nearly as old as she was.

headline: Now Screening | Thom Browne
text: The Spring/Summer 2011 collection from Thom Browne at Paris Fashion Week.

headline: Dear Renter: What Perks Would You Like?
text: In this week’s edition of the Appraisal, we visit some of the dozens of apartment buildings built during the prerecession  boom that are filled with amenities to attract tenants: everything from luxury fitness gyms to wine tastings to complimentary breakfasts. On the whole, many New Yorkers are soaking up these perks. The simplest ones seem to be the most popular — like free coffee and blueberry muffins. But some New Yorkers are working so hard to pay their hefty rents that they can’t afford to use all of the amenities they originally anticipated.

headline: One Child Too Many?
text: There is a monetary cost to raising a child, as we discussed here last week. There are other costs, too, which we tend not to dwell on when deciding to have a child but which announce themselves starkly when we are deciding not to.

headline: Paris Fashion Week | The Best in Shows
text: See all of T’s Fashion Week coverage.

headline: City Commuters Press On Despite Transit Cuts
text: There was a certain where-am-I-now disorientation  not as much as in the 1969 film “If It’s Tuesday, This Must Be Belgium,” perhaps, but enough to cause head-scratching and double takes. What happened to the V train? Why does the M seem to be going in a whole new direction? Where is the QM22?

headline: One Year Later, They’re Still Smooth Criminals (and in Jail)
text: On the one-year anniversary of Michael Jackson‘s death, we heard from nearly everyone whose lives he had touched: his family and friends; his fellow musicians; the journalists who covered him; and even Bubbles the chimpanzee. But what about the convicts in the Philippine prison who became viral sensations for their video re-creation of the zombie dance from “Thriller”?

headline: Can Strep Throat Lead to Anorexia?
text: Dr. Kathryn Zerbe, professor of psychiatry at Oregon Health and Science University and a longtime expert on eating disorders, previously responded to readers’ questions about anorexia, bulimia, binge eating and related problems. Here, she responds to a reader who developed anorexia after a severe case of strep throat.

headline: A New Way to Get Money for Group Events
text: If you’ve ever organized an event like a bachelor party and tried to collect money from a group of friends, you know how difficult it can be to get some people to put up their share.

headline: Warning About Church’s Abuse Documents Led Belgian Police to Raid Its Offices
text: MECHELEN, Belgium  Four days after a series of police raids of Catholic institutions in Belgium that drew sharp criticism from the pope, the reason for the unusually aggressive operation has emerged: a formal accusation that the church was hiding information on sexual abuse lodged by the former president of an internal church commission handling such cases.

headline: TimesCast | June 28, 2010
text: In today's Timescast, reports on a Supreme Court ruling on guns, a preview on the Elena Kagan confirmation hearings and following one unit through the troop surge in Afghanistan.

headline: BMW Says Its Driver in Lexus LFA Crash Was Not Speeding
text: BMW said on Monday that an employee driving a 3 Series sedan in a crash in Germany that killed Toyota’s chief test driver was not speeding.

headline: Serena Williams Avoids Flashback, Beats Sharapova
text: WIMBLEDON, England – In a match that transported tennis back six years, Maria Sharapova and Serena Williams battled toe-to-toe on Centre Court in a replay of their 2004 final.

headline: Kagan Promises ‘Modest’ Approach
text: WASHINGTON  Elena Kagan vowed Monday that if she was confirmed to the Supreme Court, her approach to judging would be “a modest one” that was “properly deferential” to Congress and the president  remarks intended to quell Republican criticism that she is a partisan who would use the court as an instrument to advance a Democratic agenda.

headline: Inouye Sworn In as President Pro Tem
text: 2:15 p.m. | Updated With the death of Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, Senator Daniel Inouye of Hawaii became president pro tempore of the Senate, a mainly ceremonial position that ranks third in line of succession to the presidency.

text: The Spring/Summer 2011 collection from Paul Smith at Paris Fashion Week.

headline: A Wordplay for Chess Players
text: Today’s Wordplay blog has a puzzle for chess players. The problem is to place the eight starting pieces of one side in such a way that they cover, or protect, all 64 squares. Good luck.

headline: Blogrolled: Why David Weigel Left the Post
text: The resignation of Dave Weigel from The Washington Post’s high-profile blog roll sent a shock wave through the ranks of the DC blogworld. But perhaps his downfall, in so short a time, wasn’t that surprising.

headline: Domesticities | Sense and Sensibility
text: An architect and client's shared vision produces a house that's both logical and lyrical -- and energy-efficient.

headline: TimesCast: Supreme Court Rules on Gun Rights
text: The Supreme Court issued a ruling that provides an enormous symbolic victory for supporters of gun rights, and Elena Kagan begins her confirmation hearings in the Senate on Monday’s edition of TimesCast.

headline: How Lazio Says He’d Run the State
text: ALBANY — Rick A. Lazio, the 52-year-old former congressman from Long Island, is the Republican designee for governor, but he’s got an uphill battle in front of him. He is trailing far behind Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, the Democratic nominee, in the polls, and even further behind in fund-raising. And he still faces a challenge from Carl Paladino, a wealthy Buffalo developer who is undertaking a petition drive to get on the ballot. Mr. Lazio is on leave from J. P. Morgan, where he spent several years as a highly paid lobbyist.

headline: Interpublic in Deal to Strengthen London Operations of Lowe
text: The Interpublic Group of Companies is again taking steps to bolster the operations of a major office of its Lowe & Partners Worldwide agency.

headline: Increase in Travelers Expected July 4 Weekend
text: If you’re planning on heading out of town for July 4 weekend, you should expect plenty of company. AAA has estimated that the number of Americans traveling at least 50 miles over the holiday weekend will  increase to 34.9 million from 29.8 last year.

headline: The New Staples | Oat Groats! Hibiscus Flowers! Nutmeg and Mace!
text: In The New Staples, Merrill Stubbs of Food52 highlights ingredients making their way into restaurants and refrigerators, plus recipes from top chefs to help you put them to use.

headline: Resources on Bullying and Cyberbullying
text: Update | April 6, 2012: We’ve published a new page on this topic  with comprehensive resources, including lesson plans, discussion questions, Times articles and multimedia, and links to relevant information from around the Web.

headline: Is a  New Reactor Rust-Prone?
text: Approval of the design for the Westinghouse AP 1000 reactor is slowly moving forward at the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, as are financial arrangements for building the nation’s first one, near Augusta, Ga. Yet the argument about whether its design is safer than past models is advancing, too.

headline: A Long Goodbye From the Last of Balanchine’s Ballerinas
text: On Sunday afternoon at the David H. Koch Theater, the ballerina Darci Kistler made her farewell to dancing onstage, at 46. Some in the audience remembered how she first burst into their lives 30 years before, when she danced the Swan Queen with the School of American Ballet. I cannot forget that when she joined New York City Ballet that same year, she already danced not like a flower in bud but like a full-blown rose, in her first solo role as a professional dancer. The company danced in Paris in September 1980, and she performed the Scherzo in Balanchine’s “Tchaikovsky Suite No. 3.” To choreography that had seemed among the master’s least distinguished she brought an easy hugeness of scale and a sparkling rapture that were intoxicating.

headline: Democrats and the ‘Umpire Analogy’
text: A big question in Elena Kagan‘s Supreme Court confirmation hearings is how she will handle the “umpire analogy” as articulated by Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr., who in his hearings said a judge’s job was to call balls and strikes.

headline: Bounty Now Promises a Competent Clean
text: A year after changing campaigns for Bounty paper towels, Procter & Gamble is refocusing the brand’s advertising again.

headline: Senior UBS Banker Said to Leave for Moelis
text: The chairman of UBS‘s investment bank, Richard Leaman, is leaving to join his former colleagues at the boutique firm Moelis and Company, The Deal reported on Monday, citing unnamed sources.

headline: New Trial Begins in France for Noriega
text: PARIS  The three-day trial of the former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega, convicted of laundering drug money, opened in Paris on Monday.

headline: Wade Says Rumors of his Departure Are Premature
text: The rumors change by the day –- even the hour –- regarding the final destination of the soon-to-be free agent Dwyane Wade.

headline: Diabetes Is Tougher in the Summer
text: For people with diabetes, the heat and humidity of summer can be particularly hazardous, reports Anahad O’Connor in today’s “Really?” column.

headline: Djokovic Holds Off Demons, Outlasts Hewitt
text: Lleyton Hewitt appeared to be climbing into the driver’s seat midway through the fourth set against Novak Djokovic, but he let a few loose errors creep into his normally stingy game and allowed Djokovic to escape with a four-set win. The match was a breakthrough of sorts for Djokovic, who suffered a similar reversal of fortune at Roland Garros, when he let Jurgen Melzer back into the match after leading two-sets-to-love. Melzer won in five, and questions about the Serbian’s conditioning, mental toughness, and will to win began to be heard.

headline: ‘Mixed Results’ for U.S.; Uncertain Future for Coach

headline: Burying Bram Stoker Again: Another Best-Seller for ‘Twilight’ Book Franchise
text: Were it the case that Stephenie Meyer‘s slender new entry in her “Twilight” series somehow underperformed the runaway sales of the earlier volumes in that literary franchise, it would surely fill her rivals with vampiric schadenfreude and have industry observers declaring the craze for those pale-skinned bloodsuckers to be over, thus spawning a new wave of romantic novels about, we don’t know, mummies or creatures from the Black Lagoon.

headline: Stock Markets and the World Cup
text: Worried about your investment portfolio? Maybe you should start watching the World Cup.

headline: Hey, Mr. Critic!
text: More questions about parents and in-laws, as well as requests for an après-rock meal, a G-line repast and some pre-reading Little Italy snacks. This really is the greatest city in the universe. So keep those cards and letters coming!

headline: More Crude Songs
text: Here’s more music in the key of carbon. The songwriter and guitarist David Wilcox has posted a YouTube video of a fresh-penned tune, “Crude Greed,” reflecting on the Gulf of Mexico oil disaster (there’s a fun cat-stretching moment over his shoulder):

headline: Mexican Candidate for Governor Is Assassinated
text: MEXICO CITY — A popular candidate for governor who had made increased security his prime campaign pledge was killed along with at least four others Monday morning in a brazen attack, rattling a nation already alarmed by surging drug violence.

headline: Le Monde Chooses Investors in Close Vote
text: PARIS  The supervisory board of Le Monde, the distinguished and debt-laden French newspaper, chose on Monday to accept a bid from a trio of left-leaning entrepreneurs, saving the paper from bankruptcy but taking control out of the hands of its journalists.

headline: Quote Unquote | All in the Wrist
text: “”–The actor Jon Hamm insists that the only accessory he can pull off is a watch. We beg to differ, but agree that Keith Richards he is certainly not. Glad that’s figured out.

headline: Bluecifer
text: Nickname for a giant blue horse statue at Denver Airport.

headline: Chart: Blair’s ‘Die Young’
text: The artist Andrew Kuo charts the album “Die Young” from the Brooklyn-based singer and songwriter Blair. “Die Young” was released in January and tonight Blair is scheduled to perform at the Delancey as part of the Small Beast showcase.

headline: Living Expenses Rising Far Faster than Wages, Study Finds
text: For New York City families, increases in the cost of living have far outpaced wages, according to a report to be released Tuesday by a national organization working to advance economic equality for women and their families.

text: George Vecsey on U.S. and Ghana.

headline: Weigel on Weigel
text: Dave Weigel’s explanation of the events that led to his resignation from The Washington Post, penned for Andrew Breitbart’s Big Journalism site (and good for them for running it), is a model mea culpa: Forthright and self-critical, rather than defensive and self-justifying. Here he is discussing the role he found himself playing as a participant in the liberal list-serv JournoList, and how it contributed to his (temporary, I trust) unemployment:

text: Suzana Apelbaum joined the New York office of StrawberryFrog in a new post, executive creative director. She had been partner and chief creative officer at Rede, part of the ABC Group, São Paulo, Brazil.

headline: Tsonga’s Confidence Building at Wimbledon
text: WIMBLEDON, England – When Jo-Wilfred Tsonga of France reached the finals of the 2008 Australian Open, a reporter asked his coach, Eric Winogradsky, about the young man’s confidence.

headline: Toxic Mercury Is More at Home in Seawater, Study Finds
text: It has long been known that mercury levels in seafood can prove poisonous to humans. Methylmercury, an especially toxic form of mercury, can lead to kidney dysfunction and neurological disorders.

headline: Why Hearst Liked Carey
text: In an interview on Monday, Frank A. Bennack Jr., the vice chairman and chief executive of the Hearst Corporation, said  he had been impressed with David Carey’s work at Condé Nast and did not want to miss an opportunity to bring him on board. Mr. Carey will become the president of the magazine division of Hearst Publishing.

headline: Apple Sells 1.7 Million New iPhones in Three Days
text: Apple said it sold more than 1.7 million units of the iPhone 4 over the first weekend it was available for purchase.

headline: Investors Pull Money From Hedge Funds
text: Money flowed out of hedge funds in the first quarter of the year as investors grew skittish about parking their money in alternative investments. With hedge funds performing poorly in the second quarter and more regulations set to go into force, net outflows could accelerate in this once-premier asset class.

headline: Turkey Barring Israeli Military Flights From Its Airspace
text: ISTANBUL  Turkey has been blocking Israeli military flights from entering its airspace, Turkish officials said Monday, in the latest diplomatic fallout over Israel’s deadly raid last month on a Turkish ship carrying activists trying to breach the naval blockade of Gaza.

headline: Dispatch | Cooke City, Montana
text: “You’re going to Cooke City?” an acquaintance in Livingston, in south-central Montana, asked. “That’s where all the varmints hide out!”

headline: The Senate’s Elder Statesman
text: During his 51 in the Senate, Robert C. Byrd championed the legislative branch and fought for funding for West Virginia.

headline: Voice and Temperament
text: A look at the stage roles of Patti LuPone.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Blue Velvet’
text: What is the real America? David Lynch had an answer in his dark and mysterious 1986 film “Blue Velvet,” which starred Kyle MacLachlan, Isabella Rossellini, Laura Dern and Dennis Hopper, who died in May.

headline: Roddick Upset by Lu in Wimbledon Round of 16
text: In a stunning upset, Yen-Hsun Lu defeated Andy Roddick in a prizefight of a match, winning 9-7 in the fifth set. Lu showed remarkable composure in the win, competing at an extraordinarily high level throughout the nearly five-hour match. He won the match more than Roddick lost it, hitting out freely as the pressure mounted in the fifth set.

headline: Justices Rule Against Group That Excludes Gay Students
text: WASHINGTON  A public law school did not violate the First Amendment by withdrawing recognition from a Christian student group that excluded gay students, the Supreme Court ruled on Monday in a 5-to-4 decision.

headline: On Our Radar: Bill Clinton on the Spill
text: Bill Clinton weighs in on shutting down BP’s blown-out well: he says it “may become necessary” for the Navy to use explosives on the seafloor.

headline: The Long and the Short of It
text: Q. The hair on one’s head grows ever longer, seemingly without limit, but the hair on one’s legs seems to grow to a certain length and stop. Does trimmed hair somehow “know” to regrow to its maximum length?

headline: Diabetes Drug Linked to Higher Heart Risk
text: WASHINGTON  Two studies published in influential medical journals and using very different methods found that Avandia, a controversial diabetes medicine made by GlaxoSmithKline, substantially increased patients’ heart risks.

headline: McChrystal-Karzai Relationship Steers the News in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The news of Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal’s dismissal is slowly settling here in Kabul. Only in the past few days have the local media gone beyond reporting mere facts as they developed in Washington, and started to include some opinion and analysis.

headline: Losing Asylum, Then His Life
text: One man is dead, shot in the mouth in El Salvador, presumably for speaking ill of a gang. Another man lives in hiding in the Salvadoran countryside, hoping his former gang will not mete out a similar punishment to him.

headline: Officer Is Acquitted of Assault Charges
text: A New York City police officer accused of excessive force in the apprehension of an Iraq war veteran in a Manhattan housing project was acquitted of all criminal charges on Monday.

headline: Childhood: Combination Vaccine and Seizure Risk
text: Toddlers who get a vaccine that combines the measles-mumps-rubella and chickenpox immunizations are at twice the usual risk for fevers that lead to convulsions, a new study reports.

headline: What We’re Reading: Inequality in New York

headline: Doctor, Please Carve Out the Time to Heal Thyself
text: I was sure it was just acid reflux, or sympathy pains for my patients on the gastrointestinal cancer ward. Or at worst, an ulcer from the stress of being an intern too busy playing doctor to go see one herself.

headline: Damien Hirst Audi A1 Sells for $524,000
text: The 2011 Audi A1 hatchback, with its accessible curves and viral-video associations with Justin Timberlake, does not scream “enfant terrible,” nor does it inspire debate on the limits of abstract expressionism.

headline: Tesla to Raise $226 Million in I.P.O.
text: 11:16 p.m. | Updated Tesla Motors has priced its initial public offering at $17 a share, raising about $226.1 million in the first stock debut of a car maker in more than half a century, according to The Associated Press, Reuters and Bloomberg News.

headline: Exercise: Bicycling to Keep Off Extra Pounds
text: Bicycling for exercise may help women control their weight during their 30s and 40s, a new study says.

headline: Regimens: Lower Homocysteine and Heart Risk
text: People with high blood levels of the amino acid homocysteine are at increased risk for heart disease and strokes. But it has never been clear whether reducing homocysteine will cut the risk, and whether the substance actually causes vascular disease.

headline: In Summer’s Heat, Watch What You Drink
text: This is a perfect time of year to take a beverage inventory: what you drink, how much and how to maintain a reasonable intake of fluids  ones that will supply your body with much-needed water without adding to your fat stores.

headline: Of Bagels, Bars and Underpants

headline: Compelling Stories, if Not Literature
text: “A poet,” James Dickey once said, “is someone who stands outside in the rain hoping to be struck by lightning.” But what about the obvious follow-up question, regarding people who happen to be out in the rain and happen to be struck by lightning? Should each of them then become a poet  or perhaps the author of a slim volume of nonfiction?

headline: Patient Memoirs: Are They Worth Reading?
text: Should memoirs of illness really be held to the same standards as other writing? That’s the question raised by Dr. Abigail Zuger in her report about various memoirs written by patients or their loved ones.

headline: Hempstead Prepares a Plan for Coliseum
text: The Town of Hempstead will unveil its own proposal for the development of the Nassau Coliseum and the land surrounding it, the latest volley in the multiyear battle over how to keep the Islanders on Long Island and build a major commercial and residential district.

headline: Sampling American Pale Ales
text: IN popular culture, the Fourth of July connotes hot dogs, hamburgers and cold beer. But the country has changed, and while burgers and hot dogs are still a distinct possibility, so are mofongo and arroz con pollo, or kimchi and kalbi. Cold beer, though, remains universal, and for that we might consider taking a moment to thank the founding fathers of the craft-beer revolution.

headline: Robben’s Dashing Return Gives the Dutch an Edge
text: DURBAN, South Africa  Impressive for extended stretches if not yet entirely convincing, the Netherlands continued doing what matters most on Monday by winning its second-round World Cup match against Slovakia.

headline: Now Shopping | Montauk or Bust
text: Cynthia Rowley’s new squid-ink colored Montauk shack, open for the season until October, is nestled between the $99-a-weeknight Memory Motel and Pizza Village. The store, which beckons with a small neon sign that says “shop,” features Rowley’s flirty summer frocks, brilliantly colored hammocks, books, candles and stylish home accessories. Out back in a second hut, Rowley is hosting a temporary store for Lauren Bush’s Feed projects, which sells burlap bags, teddy bears and other items whose proceeds go toward ending global hunger.

headline: The Options On the Table
text: Noah Millman’s critique of my column today makes reasonable points about the potential advantages of accepting failure in Afghanistan and simply picking up and leaving. I wish, though, that he’d reckoned a bit more with what I intended to be the thrust of the piece — namely, the fact that what many critics of counterinsurgency keep presenting as an exit strategy (drawing down troop levels and focusing on counterterrorism) might well turn out to be anything but.
