headline: Kanepi Continues Inspired Run on Grass
text: Kaia Kanepi of Estonia, also known as the Tall One from Tallinn, beat Klara Zakopalova, 6-2, 6-4, to continue her great run on grass and advance to the quarterfinals. She won despite serving at only 52 percent, stepping up her return game to beat the Czech, who looked tentative on big points. Kanepi, by contrast, won six of nine break points in a match that was a huge opportunity for both players.

headline: Life After Divorce (Don’t Ask About the Monkeys)
text: Personal ads in newspapers and on Web sites don’t usually hold out a lot of demand for the SWML, but comedy has nothing but time for the single white male loser.

headline: The Drug Industry: GlaxoSmithKline, Merck and Novartis Again Rank Highest on Access to Poor
text: GlaxoSmithKline, Merck and Novartis have taken the top three spots again on the Access to Medicine Index, which ranks pharmaceutical companies on how readily they make their products available to the world’s poor.

headline: Beaks, Bills and Climate
text: In the 1800s, an American zoologist named Joel Allen posited that animals in cold climates evolved to have shorter appendages (limbs, ears, and tails) than those in hot climates, in order to minimize surface area and thereby minimize heat loss. The theory, known as Allen’s rule, has long appeared in biology books, but scientific evidence for it has remained weak.

headline: From M.S. Patients, Outcry for Unproved  Treatment
text: For her first appointment with Dr. Daniel Simon, Neelima Raval showed up with a rolling file cabinet full of documents. She had downloaded every word written by or about Dr. Paolo Zamboni, a vascular surgeon from Italy with a most unorthodox theory about multiple sclerosis.

headline: Linking Personality to Brain Structure
text: Some people are usually cheerful. Others are more likely to have sad, depressing thoughts. Such traits help make up our personalities.

headline: The Little Vampire That Could
text: If Stephenie Meyer’s slender new entry in her “Twilight” series somehow underperformed the runaway sales of the earlier books in that literary franchise, it would surely fill her rivals with vampiric schadenfreude and have industry observers declaring the craze for those pale-skinned bloodsuckers to be over, thus spawning a new wave of romantic novels about, we don’t know, mummies or creatures from the Black Lagoon. But no. On Monday Little Brown Books for Young Readers, which published the “Twilight” novella, “The Short Second Life of Bree Tanner,” said the book had sold more than one million copies in the United States since it was released on June 5, The Associated Press reported. That would put the novella, which tells the story of a newborn vampire briefly mentioned in the “Twilight” novel “Eclipse,” on pace to be the best-selling book of the year. The film version of “Eclipse” opens on Wednesday.

headline: A Final Turn for ‘World’ at Daytime Emmys
text: With its cancellation looming, “As the World Turns” earned three of the top four acting awards at the 37th Annual Daytime Emmy Awards on Sunday night. Michael Park, left, who plays Jack on “World,” won in the lead drama actor category; Maura West, who plays Carly, won in the lead drama actress category; and Julie Pinson, who plays Janet, won in the supporting actress category. The award for supporting actor went to Billy Miller, who plays Billy on “The Young and the Restless.” Accepting his award, Mr. Park said, “I can’t think of a better way to say goodbye to a 13-year run on a 53-year-old show.” He noted that taping of his soap opera wrapped last week, telling the audience, “I pray that you never have to endure what we endured on Wednesday.” The final episode is scheduled to be shown in September. “As the World Turns” was not nominated in the outstanding drama category; that award went to “The Bold and the Beautiful” for the second consecutive year.

headline: Why Fish Came Ashore
text: About 365 million years ago, the fins of some fish evolved into limbs, creating a class of animals known as tetrapods that left the water to dwell on land, giving rise to amphibians, reptiles, birds and mammals.

headline: An Unproven Treatment for Multiple Sclerosis
text: An experimental treatment for multiple sclerosis is gaining interest on the Internet, inspiring hope among patients and scorn among skeptics, writes Denise Grady in today’s Science Times.

headline: Inmates, One Year Later, Are Still Smooth
text: On the first anniversary of Michael Jackson’s death nearly everyone whose lives he had touched was heard from: his family and friends, his fellow musicians and even Bubbles the chimpanzee. But what about the convicts in the Philippine prison who became viral sensations for their video re-creation of the zombie dance from “Thriller”? Not to be omitted from the global Jackson remembrances, more than 900 prisoners at Cebu Provincial Detention and Rehabilitation Center assembled on Saturday to dance to Jackson’s songs, including “They Don’t Really Care About Us,” “Billie Jean” and, of course, “Thriller,” Agence France-Presse reported. Judge Geraldine Faith Econg, who led a delegation of jurists to the two-hour event, told Agence France-Presse: “This will set an example to other rehabilitation centers in the country. It will also give people a different view of the inmates.” Mils Bonnen, a teacher from Denmark who was among the 500 visitors who came to watch the performance by convicted murderers, rapists and drug dealers, told the news agency: “It was a wonderful presentation. I was very impressed. Their concentration was really there, and they were really serious about their dance.” The original “Thriller” Web video has been watched more than 42 million times on YouTube alone. A video from Saturday’s performance is expected to be posted this week.

headline: ‘60 Minutes’ Ticks at Top
text: On a low-rated Sunday night CBS earned the most viewers with its broadcast of the 37th annual Daytime Emmy Awards and “60 Minutes,” the night’s most-watched program. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 5.6 million viewers tuned in to CBS from 9 to 11 p.m. for the awards show. At 7 “60 Minutes” delivered 7.4 million viewers followed by a repeat of the celebrity special “I Get That a Lot” (4.4 million) at 8. NBC ranked second on the night, garnering 4.9 million viewers for “Dateline” from 7 to 9 followed by back-to-back reruns of “Law & Order: Criminal Intent” at 9 (5 million) and 10 (5.2 million). ABC placed third as its new dramas “Scoundrels” (3.6 million) and “The Gates” (3 million) struggled at 9 and 10. Fox finished fourth with reruns of its animated comedy lineup.

headline: For Exchanges, Financial Bill Has Some Benefits
text: The sweeping financial regulatory bill does have some benefits for parts of Wall Street. While the banks will face more restrictions, the exchanges potentially stand to win big as a result of new rules on the trading of certain derivative contracts, gaining possibly billions of dollars in new revenue.

headline: Chris Brown Enjoys His Second Chance
text: With fallen stars from Tiger Woods to Eliot Spitzer taking their turns on the comeback trail these days, could the moment be right for a second coming of Chris Brown? The BET Awards on Sunday night certainly gave Mr. Brown, above, the tarnished R&B singer, a prominent platform to demonstrate as emotionally  and, at times, theatrically  as possible that he’s ready for the forgiveness of his audience. Last summer Mr. Brown was sentenced to six months of community labor and five years of probation after pleading guilty to felonious assault on the pop star Rihanna, an incident that seemed to leave his career in tatters. But at the BET Awards, which were held in Los Angeles, Mr. Brown took center stage as part of a tribute to Michael Jackson. During his performance of “Man in the Mirror” Mr. Brown frequently became choked up and at one point fell to his knees. Though many viewers accused Mr. Brown of usurping what was supposed to be an honor for Mr. Jackson, Mr. Brown had the last word when he was announced as the surprise winner of BET’s Fandemonium award, a prize determined by fan votes. “I let you all down before, but I won’t do it again,” Mr. Brown said in his acceptance speech. “I promise you.”

headline: Despite Aging Baby Boomers, N.I.H. Devotes Only 11 Percent to Elderly Studies
text: The health needs of tens of millions of aging baby boomers threaten to overwhelm the nation’s hospitals and caregivers within a decade or two, but the geriatric tidal wave does not appear to have been fully recognized at the National Institutes of Health.

headline: Preparing More Care of Elderly
text: With a nudge from the new health care law and pressure from Medicare, hospitals, doctors and nurses are struggling to prepare for explosive growth in the numbers of high-risk elderly patients.

headline: Introducing ‘Living Rooms’
text: Many animals build shelters, some of them dazzlingly efficient and complex, but only humans design homes that thoroughly reflect the architecture of their lives, families, work — even their thoughts. The home has been central to human existence since the Paleolithic age: recent archaeological work in Israel has found evidence of domestic order — food preparation here, beds over there — dating from around 100,000 B.C.E.

headline: Scorecard | Comme des Garçons Wins!
text: With the usual nonconformist suspects all in a dead heat Friday, Scorecard knows critics were less than tolerant of Junya Watanabe’s non-reinvention of the sailing wheel, so that leaves Rei Kawakubo and Riccardo Tisci head to head. (Or should we say skull to skull?) So whose memento mori was most memorable? We’ll give the win to Kawakubo for not beating us over the head with the self-flagellation thing, but tell us, do you agree?

headline: The Other Real Estate Value
text: Welcome to “Living Rooms,” a new series on Opinionator. Read the editors’ introduction to the series.

headline: Near-Empty Tower Still Holds Hope
text: For those who follow real estate trends, One Madison Park, the new luxury residential tower at 23rd Street and Madison Avenue, is a choice example of the hubris that led to the financial crash. Earlier this year, just as workers were putting the final touches on its glittering facades, the building went into foreclosure, halting construction. The floors meant for a swimming pool, a spa and a wine bar remain cavernous concrete shells. The half dozen or so overly eager tenants who chose to move into the tower before its completion are still navigating through labyrinthine scaffolding, an unfinished lobby and ghostly corridors to get to their luxury apartments, without any idea when  or if  construction will begin again.

headline: Team’s Work Uses a Virus to Convert Methane to Ethylene
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A team of molecular biologists and materials scientists said Monday they had genetically engineered a virus to convert methane to ethylene more efficiently and at a significantly lower temperature than previously possible.

headline: Seeking to Pre-empt Marital Strife
text: Does your marriage need therapy? If you’re like most people, the correct answer may well be yes, but your answer is probably no.

headline: Recovery Effort in Gulf Expected to Continue Despite Storm
text: A tropical storm moving across the western Gulf of Mexico that is likely to strengthen into a hurricane is not expected to seriously disrupt efforts to capture oil gushing from the stricken BP well, officials of the Coast Guard and BP said Monday.

headline: In Ordinary Lives, U.S. Sees the Work of Russian Agents
text: WASHINGTON  They had lived for more than a decade in American cities and suburbs from Seattle to New York, where they seemed to be ordinary couples working ordinary jobs, chatting to the neighbors about schools and apologizing for noisy teenagers.

headline: Sandbagging in the Shadow of the Mississippi
text: An environmental calamity cannot be easy to wrangle onto the stage. It seems unlikely that the ghastly disgorgement of oil in the Gulf of Mexico will ever inspire a Broadway musical. (Let us hope not, at least.) Still, the new play “On the Levee,” which opened on Monday night at the Duke on 42nd Street as part of Lincoln Center Theater’s LCT3 series, manages to manufacture so little compelling drama from a historic natural disaster that neither the ecological scope nor the human cost comes through with much force or clarity.

headline: Feeling Right at Home in Unfamiliar Territory
text: HANOVER, N.H.  The central green at Dartmouth College here, lined by handsome old redbrick buildings and spires, makes for an archetypal New England campus. One of these buildings, the Hopkins Center for the Arts from 1962, without breaking the idyllic tone, still looks relatively modern as architecture. The modernity continues indoors. The Hop has become one of the leaders in commissioning modern-dance works. In the last three years there have been world premieres by Merce Cunningham, Paul Taylor and others.

headline: Feingold  to Vote No Again on Regulation Bill

headline: Alex has Entered the Gulf of Mexico
text: Since my update on Friday afternoon, TD1 was upgraded to tropical storm Alex early the following day. It made first landfall on Belize City, Belize as a 50kt tropical storm, tracked northwest across the Yucatan Peninsula, and entered the southern Gulf of Mexico late Sunday night. Toward the end of the trip across the peninsula, it weakened slightly to a Depression, but almost immediately regained tropical storm strength upon entering the warm Gulf waters. At 15Z today, the intensity was 50kts and 989mb.

headline: Update: An Uncertain Future for Movie Futures
text: For Cantor Fitzgerald, at least, the future is not going to involve trading in box-office futures, despite the approval on Monday of a Cantor-designed contract keyed to the performance of Lions Gate’s “The Expendables.”

headline: Officers Suspended in Prisoner’s Apparent Suicide

The prisoner, James Peterson, 46, was found hanging from the side of a holding cell at the 90th Precinct station house, the drawstring from his shorts tied around his neck, on Sunday about 8:15 p.m.

headline: Worlds Colliding but Never Clashing
text: Several times during this year’s Bang on a Can Marathon, presented at the World Financial Center in the Winter Garden in Lower Manhattan on Sunday, I deemed this particular edition the best-sequenced marathon of the handful I’ve attended from start to finish. (That tally includes 2007’s installment, all 27-and-a-half hours of it: a feat I’m still prone to bragging about.) The concert, presented free in a co-production with the River to River Festival and World Financial Center, started at noon and concluded at 1 a.m., an hour behind schedule.

headline: Roddick’s Drive to the Final Ends in an Upset
text: WIMBLEDON, England  After the final ball bounced past him, Andy Roddick showed a facial expression somewhere between dumbfounded and perplexed. Defeat had sneaked up behind him, suddenly and dramatically.

headline: Obama Reverses Bush’s Space Policy
text: The Obama administration on Monday unveiled a space policy that renounces the unilateral stance of the Bush administration and instead emphasizes international cooperation, including the possibility of an arms control treaty that would limit the development of space weapons.

headline: No Special Election for Byrd Seat
text: The West Virginia Secretary of State, Natalie E. Tennant, said Monday that she would not schedule a special election in November to replace Senator Robert C. Byrd, a decision that means Democrats do not have to worry about holding the seat – until 2012.

headline: Dueling Brooklyns

text: The United States Chamber of Commerce is backing Jane Norton for Senate in Colorado, an establishment endorsement for a Republican candidate trying to fend off an opponent that seems to have more conservative grassroots appeal.

headline: At German Airports, Bees Help Monitor Air Quality
text: Airports in Germany have come up with an unusual approach to monitoring air quality. The Düsseldorf International Airport and seven other airports are using bees as “biodetectives,” their honey regularly tested for toxins.

headline: The Travel Advantages of a Brief Stint on ‘The Sopranos’
text: ALMOST all my travel is for the Nobelity Project, either shooting a film, promoting and showing a film or working with our partners on projects. I traveled to 20 countries on five continents for our feature documentary “Nobelity” and its sequel, “One Peace at a Time.”

headline: When the Day After Tomorrow Has Come
text: Imagine that it is 2050  or even 2020  and you are the president. Your science adviser has brought you alarming news: Greenland’s inland ice sheets are melting so fast that sea levels are about to rise dramatically. Moreover, thawing Arctic permafrost is about to pour huge quantities of heat-trapping methane gas into the atmosphere, which will make the already roasting planet even hotter.

headline: New Record for Spanish-Language TV in U.S.
text: During Monday’s Brazil-Chile game, the Univision play-by-play announcer Pablo Ramírez broke the news that Sunday’s Argentina-Mexico match drew 9.36 million viewers to the network — the biggest audience for any Spanish-language program, sports or otherwise, in the history of television in the United States.

headline: Antibiotics in Animals Need Limits, F.D.A. Says
text: WASHINGTON  Federal food regulators took a tentative step Monday toward banning a common use of penicillin and tetracycline in the water and feed given cattle, chickens and pigs in hopes of slowing the growing scourge of killer bacteria.

headline: Bilski Ruling: The Patent Wars Untouched
text: There were high hopes that the Supreme Court would clear things up in the mushy, litigation-filled realm of patents on methods of doing business.

headline: In Rare Memo, Vatican Rebukes Cardinal
text: ROME — The Vatican drew aside, for a brief and puzzling moment, the thick veil that covers its internal business. It issued an extraordinary communiqué on Monday chastising a powerful cardinal who had criticized another powerful cardinal — proof of a battle inside the Vatican walls that mirrors the anger over sexual abuse raging outside them.

headline: Rhythmic or Ruthless, Beauty Is in Eye of Brazil
text: JOHANNESBURG  Let others complain about a lack of beauty. Dunga, Brazil’s coach, is concerned only about winning. The World Cup is, after all, a soccer tournament. The goal is to put another trophy in the case, not to hang a picture on the wall.

headline: Suit Over Faulty Computers Highlights Dell’s Decline
text: After the math department at the University of Texas noticed some of its Dell computers failing, Dell examined the machines. The company came up with an unusual reason for the computers’ demise: the school had overtaxed the machines by making them perform difficult math calculations.

headline: Two Weeks in Philadelphia
text: For some chess players, July 4th is more than a holiday, it is the time of year for the World Open, which has been held in Philadelphia, or the surrounding area, every year since 1983.

headline: Marlins’ Interim Manager Returns Home Hopeful He’ll Keep Job
text: SAN JUAN, P.R.  When the Florida Marlins arrived at San Juan International Airport on Sunday night, they were met by a group of cheering fans, including the mother of their interim manager, Edwin Rodriguez.

headline: Doping Fraud Case in Cycling Presents Challenges
text: Nearly 200 professional cyclists will mount their bikes Saturday to start the Tour de France, a grueling 2,263-mile journey that kicks off in Rotterdam and ends 22 days later on the Champs-Élysées in Paris.

headline: Death of Byrd Complicates Democrats’ Strategy
text: WASHINGTON  The death of Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia threw into doubt the ability of Democrats to win approval this week of a financial regulation bill and underscored how the smallest changes in the size and composition of their Congressional majority have complicated their efforts to pass ambitious legislation over near-unanimous Republican opposition.

headline: Times Editor to Oversee New Projects
text: The New York Times said Monday that Gerry Marzorati, who has edited The New York Times Magazine for the past seven years, will assume a new role as the editor responsible for overseeing newsroom projects, business ventures and other initiatives at the paper. The Times will also be seeking a new editor for the Sunday magazine.

headline: Hearst Hires Away a Top Executive From Condé Nast to Oversee Its Magazines
text: The Hearst Corporation reached into the management ranks of a longtime rival on Monday, selecting a top Condé Nast executive as the next head of its magazine division.

headline: They Pushed Back
text: A decision by the federal government to grant special visas to about 150 Indian metalworkers is the most encouraging news yet in a case that has cast a harsh light on the dark side of legal immigration. The United States Citizenship and Immigration Services, an arm of the Department of Homeland Security, has concluded that the workers, part of a group of 500 men recruited to work in Gulf Coast shipyards after Hurricane Katrina, had been subject to involuntary servitude and were entitled to visas set aside for victims of human trafficking.

headline: Right-to-Know Law Gives India’s Poor a Lever
text: BANTA, India  Chanchala Devi always wanted a house. Not a mud-and-stick hut, like her current home in this desolate village in the mineral-rich, corruption-corroded state of Jharkhand, but a proper brick-and-mortar house. When she heard that a government program for the poor would give her about $700 to build that house, she applied immediately.

headline: Power Problems Reported in New York
text: Citing problems with electrical equipment, Consolidated Edison announced on Monday that it had decreased voltage to parts of Brooklyn by 8 percent and asked customers there and in part of the Upper West Side of Manhattan not to use “nonessential” electrical appliances, including air-conditioners, until the problems were corrected.

headline: Officer Accused of Torture Is Guilty of Perjury
text: CHICAGO  Three decades after criminal suspects interrogated at a South Side police station began complaining that they were being tortured into making confessions, a jury on Monday found a former police commander who led the unit guilty of crimes related to the abuse.

headline: For Poor New Yorkers, a Little Less of Everything
text: Entering a subway station these days feels a bit like going to the eye doctor. The first thing you see on the wall is a chart with large letters on top.

headline: Crossing Nevada
text: Thirty-five years ago, almost to the day, I made the same drive I’m now making, rising up out of California and crossing Nevada on my way east. I was leaving home for graduate school and a future whose shape I couldn’t begin to guess.

headline: Last Day of ‘Rubber Rooms’ for Teachers
text: There were the hugs goodbye, the exchanges of phone numbers and the almost sure to be broken promises of keeping in touch. They packed up their bags one last time and left Room 619, which had been their daytime home for months, if not years.

headline: Fears of Chaos Gone as Rebuilt Kennedy Airport Runway Opens
text: Most travelers going through Kennedy International Airport did not really notice that the biggest runway there had been closed for four months of repairs.

headline: ATP Tour Is Not in Violation
text: A federal appeals court upheld an earlier ruling that the ATP Tour did not violate antitrust statutes when it reorganized its tour schedule and events to better promote the sport. The decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit announced Friday was a legal victory for the tour, which was sued by the promoters of the ATP Tour event in Hamburg, Germany.

headline: Student Evaluations, Part Two
text: If there is a dominant message in the responses to my column about the dangers of relying on student evaluations to assess teacher performance, it is, “It’s worse than you think.”

headline: African Leader Hires Adviser and Seeks an Image Change
text: CAPE TOWN  The president of Equatorial Guinea, who has ruled the oil-rich West African nation for three decades, sought Monday to recast his reputation as a corrupt, repressive leader in a more progressive mold.

headline: Carell Plans to Leave ‘The Office’ in 2011
text: Steve Carell, the bumbling star of NBC’s “The Office,” plans to leave the series at the end of the next season, potentially dealing a setback to the network as it tries to rejuvenate its prime time schedule.

headline: Blagojevich Tapes Show Tactical Maneuvering and Wishful Thinking
text: CHICAGO  There was a moment in late 2008  when Barack Obama was newly elected president and his successor in the United States Senate was up in the air  that Rod R. Blagojevich, then the Democratic governor of Illinois, got a first inkling that federal agents might be secretly recording him.

headline: Moving Out One by One as Australia Pursues Coal
text: ACLAND, Australia — Glenn Beutel recalled that the phone call came, as it happened, just before the first anniversary of his mother’s funeral. A representative of the coal mining company New Hope Coal, which was seeking to expand its operations, asked whether he could drop by.

headline: Wrong Track Distress
text: It’s getting harder and harder for most Americans, looking honestly at the state of the nation, to see the glass as half full. And that’s why the public opinion polls contain nothing but bad news for Barack Obama and the Democrats.

headline: Officer Acquitted of Assaulting Iraq Veteran
text: A police officer captured by a surveillance camera repeatedly striking an Iraq war veteran with his baton while the veteran lay in the lobby of a housing project in Manhattan was acquitted Monday of assault and other charges.

headline: BP Discussing a Backup Strategy to Contain Oil
text: Since shortly after oil began spewing into the Gulf of Mexico two months ago, relief wells have been discussed as the ultimate solution, their success in permanently plugging the runaway well deemed a foregone conclusion.

headline: Limb’s Crash Was Likely ‘Act of God,’ Mayor Says
text: As angry New Yorkers and aggrieved politicians sought to determine responsibility for the fallen tree limb that killed a 6-month-old girl in Central Park over the weekend, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Monday that the accident was most likely “an act of God” and cautioned the public not to rush to judgment.

headline: In Ireland, a Picture of the High Cost of Austerity
text: DUBLIN  As Europe’s major economies focus on belt-tightening, they are following the path of Ireland. But the once thriving nation is struggling, with no sign of a rapid turnaround in sight.

headline: 5 Confirmed for Cabinet in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan Parliament confirmed five nominees for cabinet posts Monday, leaving six slots vacant.

headline: Robert Byrd, Living History

headline: World Cup Ratings Certify a TV Winner
text: For the ESPN empire and Univision, any questions about the return on their investment in the World Cup are being answered by viewers. On Saturday, the United States’ loss to Ghana was seen by 14.9 million on ABC  an American record for the tournament  and an additional 4.5 million on Univision.

headline: Quest to Neutralize Afghan Militants Is Showing Glimpses of Success, NATO Says
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Despite deepening pessimism back home and disarray in the top American military ranks, officials insist that the buildup of soldiers in Afghanistan is beginning to show results: Commando raids over the last four months have taken scores of insurgent leaders out of action, in a secretive operation aimed partly at pressuring the Taliban to reconcile with the Afghan government.

headline: With Shift in Afghanistan, Talk Turns to Exit
text: WASHINGTON  When he ordered 30,000 additional troops to Afghanistan last December, President Obama stressed that they would not stay forever. “After 18 months,” he said, “our troops will begin to come home.”

headline: The Court: Ignoring the Reality of Guns
text: About 10,000 Americans died by handgun violence, according to federal statistics, in the four months that the Supreme Court debated which clause of the Constitution it would use to subvert Chicago’s entirely sensible ban on handgun ownership. The arguments that led to Monday’s decision undermining Chicago’s law were infuriatingly abstract, but the results will be all too real and bloody.

headline: The Court: Denying Government Support for Intolerance
text: In the guns case, the Supreme Court did the wrong thing (prohibiting gun bans) for the right reason (extending the reach of the Bill of Rights). The opposite was true in another major case on the final day of the court’s term.

headline: Report Criticizes U.S. System for Evaluating Afghan Forces
text: WASHINGTON  The system the United States used for the past five years to rate the readiness of Afghanistan’s Army and police force was seriously flawed and there was no reliable way to measure any progress, according to a report by a special inspector general that was released on Monday.

headline: FIFA Considering Extra Officials, Not Video Review
text: FIFA on Monday continued to resist calls for goal-line technology, a day after match officials failed to see Frank Lampard’s shot go over the line in England’s 4-1 loss to Germany.

headline: The Celtic Tiger Struggles
text: Nearly two years ago, an economic collapse forced Ireland to cut public spending and raise taxes; however, the austerity measures did not stop the downturn.

headline: Bill Wilson’s Gospel
text: On Dec. 14, 1934, a failed stockbroker named Bill Wilson was struggling with alcoholism at a New York City detox center. It was his fourth stay at the center and nothing had worked. This time, he tried a remedy called the belladonna cure — infusions of a hallucinogenic drug made from a poisonous plant — and he consulted a friend named Ebby Thacher, who told him to give up drinking and give his life over to the service of God.

headline: Island Near Java

headline: Market Presents Opportunity and Peril

headline: Fostering China’s Taste for Nuts

headline: Boom for U.S.-Grown Nuts in China
text: Whether walnuts, pecans or almonds, American nuts are in strong demand in China, a turnabout in the usual export story.

headline: The Times Change for Torre, but Rivera Never Seems To
text: LOS ANGELES  Joe Torre’s first season managing the Yankees came at the right time, coinciding with the emergence of a 26-year-old converted starter named Mariano Rivera. John Wetteland closed out the Yankees’ World Series championship that year, 1996, but he never threw another pitch for the Yankees. Rivera seized the responsibility and, after all these years, remains unmatched at his craft.

headline: Serenity of Harvard Club Unruffled by Court Hearing
text: Elena Kagan, the Supreme Court nominee, is a graduate of Harvard Law School as well as a former dean there. What better place to watch her confirmation hearing, which began on Monday, than in a clubhouse with her former students and fellow alumni?

text: Naomi Cahn, co-author of "Red Families v. Blue Families," and Ross Douthat, Op-Ed columnist for The New York Times, debate abortion and contraception.

headline: Thorn Confirms He Is Soon Leaving the Nets

headline: Dickey Suffers His First Loss as Mets Fall in Puerto Rico
text: SAN JUAN, P.R.  A sweltering tropical haze hung low over Hiram Bithorn Stadium on Monday, drenching the players in their uniforms but unable to douse the enthusiasm of 18,073 fans energized by the rare opportunity to watch major league baseball here.

headline: Rwanda: 2 Men Held in Killing of Journalist
text: Two men have been arrested in Friday’s killing in Kigali of the independent journalist Jean-Leonard Rugambage, the police said Monday. One suspect admitted to hiring the other to kill Mr. Rugambage to avenge crimes he thought the journalist had committed during the genocide in 1994. Mr. Rugambage, who was tried and acquitted of genocide crimes in 2006, was murdered while working on a report that linked the government to an assassination attempt against a dissident general in South Africa. His senior editor has blamed the Rwandan government for the murder, an accusation the government has denied.

headline: 'On the Levee'
text: Photos from the show at the Duke on 42nd Street.

headline: Israel: Police Say 7 Arab Men Arrested in April Had Planned Attacks on Jews and Christians
text: The Israeli police on Monday announced the April arrests of seven young Arab men who, they said, had militant Islamic sympathies and had planned attacks on Jews and Christians. Two of the men were charged with the murder of a Jewish taxi driver. The case had been under an order of silence. Six of the seven, all 19 to 27 years old, were from Nazareth, the largest Arab city in Israel, and the seventh was from a nearby village, the police said. Aviv Elgrisi, the police chief for the northern region, told Israeli Radio that the men had been inspired to act after watching speeches by Osama bin Laden and that two of them had tried unsuccessfully to go to Somalia to join the Islamic struggle there against the local Christian community.

headline: Lottery Numbers
North General Hospital Is Closing, but Clinics Are Ready to Take Its Place
text: Barely two months after the closing of St. Vincent’s Hospital in Greenwich Village, North General Hospital, a potent symbol of the city’s political and philanthropic commitment to Harlem, announced Monday that it was declaring bankruptcy.

headline: Yanks Expect Rivera and Jeter to Stay
text: Derek Jeter and Mariano Rivera will be in Yankees uniforms next year. That was the message Brian Cashman, the Yankees’ general manager, and Randy Levine, the team’s president, delivered Monday night.

headline: Hot in, and Away From, Cleveland
text: Cliff Lee will be in the Bronx on Tuesday night, under a microscope as he pitches against the Yankees. Lee, the Seattle Mariners left-hander, is likely to be the most coveted player available as the July 31 nonwaiver trading deadline approaches. The Mets are interested, but so are any number of teams, perhaps even the Yankees, although they may be more inclined to wait until the season ends, when Lee will probably be a free agent looking for a new long-term contract.

headline: Man Guilty of Murder as Hate Crime
text: A 30-year-old man accused of beating an Ecuadorean immigrant to death on a Brooklyn street was convicted on Monday of murder as a hate crime.

headline: Valuing G.M. and Its Legacy
text: What’s the best way to value General Motors as it prepares to go public again? The usual price-to-earnings ratio seems to have lost favor with bankers, as has enterprise value to sales, an auto industry favorite.

headline: Dolph Briscoe, Texas Governor in the ’70s, Dies at 87
text: Dolph Briscoe Jr., a former governor of Texas who helped restore credibility to its government after a major scandal and later built his ranching family’s already vast enterprise into the largest individual landholder in the state, died Sunday at his home in Uvalde, Tex. He was 87.

headline: Despite New Rules, Stranded on the Tarmac
text: PASSENGERS first encountered problems with Virgin Atlantic Flight VS001 last week at Heathrow Airport near London, long before the aircraft was diverted by bad weather to Bradley International Airport, near Hartford, and then sat for more than four hours in stifling heat on the tarmac.

headline: Inspection Flaws Led to Collapse of Subway Ceiling, Report Finds
text: New York City Transit let the brick ceiling of one of the city’s oldest subway stations hang over riders’ heads  on the brink of collapse  for 10 years without taking necessary action, according to an audit released Monday by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s inspector general.

headline: Algirdas Brazauskas, First Lithuanian President, Dies at 77
text: Algirdas Brazauskas, a former Communist bureaucrat who helped steer his native Lithuania through tempestuous political straits to independence from the Soviet Union and then became the country's first president after it broke with the Soviet Union, died Saturday at his home in Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital. He was 77.

headline: At Ravinia, Annie Gets a New Frank Butler
text: In most productions of “Annie Get Your Gun,” Frank Butler waits until the end of the first act to walk out on Annie Oakley. But in the coming Ravinia Festival production of that Irving Berlin musical it has happened a little bit ahead of schedule. Brian Stokes Mitchell, who was to play the roguish sharpshooter opposite Patti LuPone as the well-armed title character, has withdrawn from the production due to a scheduling conflict, the festival’s press representatives said on Monday. But truly, there’s no people like show people: Patrick Cassidy, above, who played Butler in the musical’s last Broadway revival, will take over the role. He has also appeared on Broadway in “Aida” and “42nd Street” and in the film “Longtime Companion.” The Ravinia production, which is to run Aug. 13 to 15, also stars George Hearn as Buffalo Bill, and will be directed by Lonny Price (“110 in the Shade”). The music will be performed by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra conducted by Paul Gemignani.

headline: In Ireland, the High Cost of Austerity
text: As Europe’s major economies focus on belt-tightening, they are following the path of Ireland. But the once thriving nation is struggling, with no sign of a rapid turnaround in sight, Liz Alderman reports in The New York Times.

headline: Nicolas Hayek Dies at 82; His Swatch Saved an Industry
text: Nicolas Hayek, a Lebanese-born business consultant who is widely credited with having saved the Swiss watch industry with the introduction of the Swatch, the inexpensive, plastic  and, as it transpired, highly collectible  wristwatch that made its debut in 1983, died Monday in Biel, Switzerland. He was 82.

headline: John Willis, Ubiquitous Editor of Theatre World, Dies at 93
text: John Willis, who spent more than half a century doggedly keeping comprehensive track of American theater productions and film releases and whose encyclopedic records were published in the annual volumes Theatre World and Screen World, died at his home in Manhattan on Friday. He was 93.

headline: News Quiz | June 29, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Le Monde Chooses Investors in Close Vote
text: The supervisory board of Le Monde, the distinguished and debt-laden French newspaper, chose on Monday to accept a bid from a trio of left-leaning entrepreneurs, saving the paper from bankruptcy but taking control out of the hands of its journalists, Steven Erlanger reports in The New York Times.

headline: Preparing for the Next Big One
text: The Dodd-Frank Act is supposed to ensure that we never repeat that 2008 finale of Wall Street Gone Wild. The bill, if signed into law, might help us avoid that, but one thing it won’t do is prevent another crisis — if only because the next one probably won’t be like the last one, The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

headline: Spying Suspects Seemed Short on Secrets
text: WASHINGTON  The suspected Russian spy ring rolled up by the F.B.I. this week had everything it needed for world-class espionage: excellent training, cutting-edge gadgetry, deep knowledge of American culture and meticulously constructed cover stories.

text: The death of Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia threw into doubt the ability of Democrats to win approval this week of a financial regulation bill and underscored how the smallest changes in the size and composition of their Congressional majority have complicated their efforts to pass ambitious legislation over near-unanimous Republican opposition.

text: The United States Supreme Court said on Monday that it would hear an appeal by Janus Capital Group of a ruling that reinstated a class-action securities fraud lawsuit against the mutual fund company, Reuters reported.

text: A citywide celebration of dance will take place in the streets, courtyards and squares of London from July 3 to 11. Big Dance 2010 includes over 600 events, most of them free, in locations from Eltham Palace in South London to more central spots like Borough Market and Somerset House.

headline: Emerson Fights ABB Over Chloride
text: Spurned U.S. suitor Emerson Electric upped its cash offer for Chloride to $1.5 billion, seeking to tempt the British group away from a recommended $1.25 billion deal from Switzerland’s ABB, Reuters reported.

text: ATHENS  Public services in Greece ground to a halt, and transportation was disrupted on Tuesday as thousands of workers joined a general strike, the fifth this year, to protest deeply unpopular spending cuts that the debt-ridden government has promised its international creditors.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Consider Ireland: it’s further down the path of austerity than any other nation on the benighted edge of Europe, and it’s not out of the woods yet. The lesson? When you make cuts, you bleed. Meanwhile, Google‘s still doing its odd dance with China, trying to keep its license on the mainland while still letting people surf through Hong Kong.

headline: Telefonica’s Fight for Vivo Gets Tougher
text: As Telefónica seeks to convince Portugal Telecom shareholders on Wednesday to approve its 6.5 billion euro ($7.9 billion) offer to buy a Brazilian joint venture both companies own, a regulatory decision just made that job harder.

headline: A State and Its Spill Response
text: Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana is not shy about voicing his displeasure with the federal response to the BP oil leak in the gulf. In near-daily news conferences, he has taken the Coast Guard and other federal agencies to task for poor preparation and a slow-footed response in protecting the fragile coastline.

headline: An E-Reader for the Kindergarten Set
text: A Kindle for  kindergartners? V.Tech hopes so, with this week’s release of V.Reader, formerly called FLiP, a $60 e-book player targeting early readers, ages 3 to 7, with a clear touch screen and a membrane QWERTY keyboard.

headline: Saving a Park Hero From Potter’s Field
text: Butch Kelley was as on-time dependable as the drumbeats at 52 Park in the South Bronx.  In lousy weather or health, he was there to volunteer at the salsa concerts put on by a scrappy group of volunteers that rescued the park from the ravages of abandonment in 1980.

headline: What’s the Most Sinister Part of the New ‘Harry Potter’ Trailer?
text: The trailer for “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows,” the film adaptation of the final installment in that beloved boy-wizard book franchise, hit the Web on Monday, and muggles, it is not for the children. (Let them see the new “Twilight” movie instead.) There are some scary moments, with imperiled young British actors; evil Lord Voldemort, who evokes Patrick Stewart after a plastic surgery disaster; and a booming musical score that WON’T. LET. UP.

headline: Israeli Rules Out Palestinian State by 2012
text: TEL AVIV  In remarks that could further strain peace efforts, Israel’s foreign minister said Tuesday that there was no chance that a Palestinian state would be established in the next two years.

headline: The Conventional Superstition
text: Calculated Risk points us to a speech by Kevin Warsh that strikes me as almost the perfect illustration of the predicament we’re in, in which policy is paralyzed by fear of invisible bond vigilantes. Warsh isn’t an especially bad example — but that’s the point: this is what Serious People sound like these days.

headline: Better Days Ahead for Branded Entertainment, Report Says
text: Branded entertainment — the widespread “brought to you by” type of advertising — faltered slightly last year, according to a new report, but is on track to resume its growth this year.

headline: Money Laundering: The Drug Problem at Banks
text: Are banks in the United States facilitating the drug trade with Mexico? Bloomberg Markets magazine examines this question by looking over a number of transgressions made by American banks in the last few years in which they seemed to have turned a blind eye to money-laundering schemes by drug cartels.

headline: The Early Word: Time to Testify
text: All eyes on Capitol Hill today: Both Elena Kagan, the Supreme Court nominee, and Gen. David H. Petraeus, in line to take charge of the conflict in Afghanistan, sit down before Senate panels today.

headline: World Cup Live: Japan vs. Paraguay
text: After 120 minutes failed to produce a goal, Paraguay won a penalty shootout, 5-3, to eliminate Japan in Pretoria, South Africa, on Tuesday, and advanced to its first World Cup quarterfinal.It was a game in which the ball spent a lot of time in the penalty area, but paradoxically one with few great chances, as both team’s strikers struggled.In the shootout, Paraguay converted all five kicks, but Japan defender Yuichi Komano hit the crossbar to send his team out.Paraguay dominated possession and outshot Japan, and was probably the worthier winner. But on the evidence of this match, the team is going to be a significant underdog to either Spain or Portugal in the next round.

headline: E.U. Criticizes Mobile Phone Roaming Charges
text: BERLIN — Mobile phone operators in Europe are charging close to the highest roaming fees allowed, three years after price caps were first imposed, according to data released Tuesday by the European Commission.

headline: Historic Chess Set for Sale
text: With all the hoopla and fanfare surrounding the 1972 World Championship match between Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky, it would make sense that they did not play on an ordinary table. In fact, the table, or actually three of them, were made just for the match, according to Einar S. Einarsson, a friend of both players.

headline: U.S. Stocks Drop on New Jitters About Global Growth
text: This looks like a long, hot summer for Wall Street.

text: SunRun, a San Francisco start-up that leases rooftop solar arrays to homeowners, said Tuesday it had raised $55 million from investors.

headline: Kagan Follows Precedent by Offering Few Opinions
text: WASHINGTON — Elena Kagan deflected questions about her own views on gun rights and abortion during her Supreme Court confirmation hearings on Tuesday, instead describing Supreme Court precedents. She declined to say whether terrorism suspects must be warned of the right to remain silent, saying the issue was “quite likely to get to the courts.”

headline: Letterman: ‘Pretty Thin Gruel’

headline: Tuesday Reading: Condo Perks Worth Paying For
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Qaeda Figure Is Reported Killed in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Eight militants, including an Egyptian allied with Al Qaeda, were killed Tuesday in what residents and a Pakistani security official said was a United States drone strike in the South Waziristan tribal area near this country’s Afghan border.

headline: Venus Williams and Clijsters Are Out
text: WIMBLEDON, England  An hour later, Venus Williams still seemed stunned. In the 10 previous years at Wimbledon, she had played in eight finals and triumphed five times and, somewhere along the way, this tournament became her tournament.

headline: Petraeus Pledges Look at Strikes in Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON  Calling the protection of his troops a “moral imperative,” Gen. David H. Petraeus said Tuesday that he would closely review restrictions on United States airstrikes and artillery in Afghanistan, which have cut down on civilian casualties but have been bitterly criticized by American troops who say they have made the fight more dangerous.

headline: Poof! Barbara Eden’s ‘Jeannie’ Memoir Will Appear Next Year
text: For the five seasons that she starred on the classic television comedy “I Dream of Jeannie,” Barbara Eden could conjure up anything from valuable artwork to an elephant with a nod and a blink.

headline: Bill Could Make Subletting a Tad Illegal
text: Updated, 3:02 p.m. | The Legislature is debating a bill that would attempt to stop landlords from converting apartments into hotel rooms without city permission, but the wording of the bill leaves open the possibility that tenants who sublet their apartments for short periods could technically be breaking the law as well.

headline: Performance at the Pump Goes Extreme
text: Recently, Ford boasted that a 2011 Mustang, with a 305-horsepower V-6 engine, achieved 48.5 miles per gallon in a 1,457-lap fuel-economy run at the Bristol MotorSpeedway in Bristol, Tenn. A Nascar driver, David Ragan, and four Ford engineers took advantage of the Mustang’s low-speed optimization.

headline: Supreme Court Affirms Ruling on ‘Soft Money’ Ban
text: The Supreme Court on Tuesday affirmed without comment a ruling upholding a ban on so-called soft-money contributions to political parties. Justices Anthony M. Kennedy, Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas voted to hear the case.

headline: Baghdad Traffic Lights: Green, Amber and Go.
text: The first time I sat in the passenger seat, I unconsciously reached out to fasten my seat belt. In an anxious tone the driver said: “What are you doing? They will know that you are a foreigner.” I did not question who “they” were or why, I simply unfastened. And took to the road.

headline: Errors of Admission
text: This morning brings us one of those slap-your-forehead moments, as we witness the head of a major sporting event grasp something so ridiculously obvious that if we didn’t slap our foreheads, we might be stuck for days with this dumbfounded look on our faces. So, read the story of Sepp Blatter, the president of FIFA, suddenly agreeing that there should be goal-line technology and admitting that the World Cup refereeing has stunk and just go slap yourself silly.

headline: How Would You Lure LeBron James?
text: N.B.A. teams hoping to sign LeBron James can begin making their sales pitches to him on Thursday, when the free agent market officially opens for business. What would you say or do to persuade James to join your favorite team?

headline: Why Climate Stumps Even the Brightest Scientists
text: Working climate scientists are almost unanimous in their view that the earth is slowly warming up and that human activity, particularly the combustion of fossil fuels, is the primary cause. But beneath that surface unanimity, predictions vary about how much the planet will warm in the future because of rising greenhouse gases. Scientists’ best guesses range from mild warming, to which the planet and its people might adapt easily, to temperature increases so extreme that life on earth would be radically altered.

headline: Berlusconi’s Attacker Declared Unfit to Stand Trial
text: ROME  The man who struck Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi in the face with a statuette after a rally last December, fracturing his nose and breaking two teeth, was declared unfit to stand trial on Tuesday.

headline: Siegelman, Scrushy Convictions to Be Reviewed
text: The Supreme Court on Tuesday ordered a new review of the convictions in the government corruption case against Donald Siegelman, a former Alabama governor, and Richard Scrushy, a former chief executive of HealthSouth, The Associated Press reports.

text: Rita Konig is a decorator based in New York who has written about style for British Vogue, The Telegraph and Domino.

headline: ‘Birthers,’ Polls and Public Ignorance
text: There’s a new poll out, from Vanity Fair and 60 Minutes, showing that 24 percent of Americans don’t think that Barack Obama was born in the United States. On MSNBC last night, Chris Hayes asked me about it, and I tried to suggest that polls like this should be taken with a large grain of salt — both because Americans will happily express all kinds of outlandish opinions to a pollster without necessarily meaning much by them (does almost half the public really believe in U.F.O.s, at least in any serious way? I’m skeptical …), and because public ignorance is vast and deep enough to account for a good-sized chunk of any apparently-scary fringe opinion. For instance, I suggested that a lot of respondents probably don’t know that birthright citizenship is a requirement for the presidency, and that some respondents may not even be aware that Obama’s birthplace, Hawaii, is actually one of the 50 states.

headline: Wal-Mart Names Executive to Head U.S. Operation
text: Eduardo Castro-Wright, who was once seen as a candidate for chief executive of Wal-Mart Stores Inc., has been replaced as head of Wal-Mart’s United States operations.

headline: Petraeus Testifies and Hastings Addresses Fallout From Rolling Stone Article
text: As our colleagues Elisabeth Bumiller and Brian Knowlton report, Gen. David H. Petraeus told the Senate Armed Services Committee that a July 2011 deadline for the start of withdrawals of American troops from Afghanistan was only “the beginning of a process” and that the United States commitment to the country was an “enduring one.”

headline: U.S. Options and the Global Greenhouse
text: With President Obama and 23 senators meeting at the White House today to winnow provisions that might add up to a viable energy (and climate) bill, it’s useful to review the bidding a bit. A decent starting place is “The Real Options for U.S. Climate Policy,” a column by the economist Robert Stavins at Harvard University charting possible paths to reducing American emissions of greenhouse gases.

headline: BP Protesters Stage Mini-Spill Outside Tate Britain Museum
text: Protesters took their dissatisfaction with BP to the steps of the Tate Britain museum in London, using the occasion of a summer party celebrating that oil company’s 20-year sponsorship of the museum to call attention to its handling of the calamitous oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Brown Reiterates Threat Against Overhaul Bill
text: Senator Scott Brown, Republican of Massachusetts, has again declared his opposition to the financial regulations overhaul bill because of a tax it would impose on large financial institutions to cover billions of dollars in costs, Bloomberg Television reported on Tuesday.

headline: Spill Is Election Issue Far Beyond Gulf
Is Breastfeeding ‘Creepy’?
text: To breastfeed or not was touchy territory before Kathryn Blundell stepped into it. That is why she stepped in, to represent the side not heard from often: the group that decides not to even try to feed their newborn from anything but a bottle.

headline: Paterson Presses Albany on Budget
text: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson criticized lawmakers on Tuesday for passing budget bills this week that did not plan for a likely shortfall of up to $1 billion, saying he would call lawmakers back to Albany in the middle of the fall campaign season if they did not deal with the problem beforehand.

headline: Just Looking | Dijkstra on the Dance Floor
text: The Dutch photographer Rineke Dijkstra likes to dance, but “I’m not really able to do it,” she says, with the utterly unassuming manner that must put her subjects at ease. “So I like to watch people instead.” Some of the fruits of that endeavor go on view at Marian Goodman Gallery on Tuesday, in a series of video portraits, “The Krazyhouse, Liverpool, UK (Megan, Simon, Nicky, Philip, Dee)” (2009-10).

headline: Lautenberg to Head Homeland Security Panel
text: Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, will take over the Senate subcommittee responsible for funneling billions of dollars to homeland security protection, a change in leadership that could put a sharper focus on security needs in the Northeast.

headline: Smokey Robinson Delights Montreal Jazz Festival
text: MONTREAL — “There are a thousand things you could have chosen to do this evening,” Smokey Robinson told a rapt crowd at the Montreal International Jazz Festival on Monday night, right after he cooed a heart-melting “Ooo Baby Baby.” “You chose to come here and be with us,” he continued. “We love you for that.”

headline: Smurf Cheese
text: Tainted mozzarella which turns blue when exposed to air.

text: WASHINGTON  Last June, the Supreme Court term ended with restraint and a cliffhanger, as the court left the Voting Rights Act intact and ordered re-argument in Citizens United, the big campaign finance case.

The kit (as baby raccoons are known), you may recall, was giving its mother some difficulty as she tried to get it to cross the roadway at the north end of Central Park.

headline: Grass Fed | West Coastin’
text: The sun-stunned effects of a California tour-cation have led to a complete breakdown in the interview-transcription machinery here at Grass Fed, so I’m phoning in this week’s entry with what the Dining Section editor Pete Wells once railed against as a grilled cheese blog post: a post about a bunch of stuff I ate. I promise some fine and interesting stuff in the weeks to come, but for now, a litany of things I ate on the West Coast, presented, confusingly enough, in a chronological fashion that follows a little three-show tour my band did: Big Sur, San Francisco, Los Angeles.

headline: How to Cope With the U.S. Gone
text: I get it. Only a few days ago you were at your oil derivatives hedge fund office hugging your boss in a moment of Landon Donovan-induced lunacy. You, the Park Slope mom, once only burdened by carrot-washing duties at the Co-Op and pushing a MacLaren stroller, suddenly felt the weight of a Clint Dempsey crush. And all of you in New York and elsewhere, like surfers riding the Great American Soccer Wave till it came crashing down on a Black Star coral reef, left wondering: What do you do now?

headline: Denis Leary on the Return of ‘Rescue Me’
text: “Rescue Me,” the dark comic firefighter drama on FX, returns on Tuesday night for the beginning of the end. The show will wrap up next year shortly before the 10th anniversary of 9/11, an event that inspired the series and has been revisited repeatedly throughout its run.

headline: Stolen Caravaggio Is Recovered
text: A Caravaggio painting considered to be the most valuable work of art in Ukraine was recovered in Germany, two years after it was stolen from a museum in Odessa, Reuters reported. The painting, called “The Taking of Christ” or “The Kiss of Judas,” was made by Caravaggio in the early 17th century, and depicts Jesus and his apostles John and Judas as they are being separated by soldiers. It had belonged to a Russian ambassador to France and a Russian prince before it was turned over to the Odessa museum, where it was stolen in 2008. On Tuesday Anatoly Mogylyov, the interior minister of Ukraine, said in a briefing that the Ukrainian and German police had recovered the painting and detained members of a gang that focuses on high-value thefts who had tried to sell the work in Berlin. A version of the painting is also in the National Gallery of Ireland in Dublin.

headline: S.E.C. Settles With a Former Lawyer

Samberg.

headline: A Blur of a Senior Year, and Now Focused on Dallas
text: I think it’s about time for an update on my college search adventure. The end of my senior year was a blur as everything came and went before my eyes. After receiving all of my college decisions, it was time to get to work to study for the six Advanced Placement exams I had on my slate. These were going to determine the possibility of quite a few more college credits, so there was no time to let up just yet, as all of my hard work was going to be put on the line.

headline: Healthy, Tasty and Unusual at the Fancy Food Show
text: There used to be a divide between “fancy food” and “health food.” At this year’s Fancy Food Show, which ends its three-day run at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center on Tuesday, it’s evident that the two categories have seamlessly merged. The words most commonly seen were organic, vegan, whole grain, fair trade, anti-oxidant and gluten-free.

headline: Picking a Marketing Firm
text: I remember my first trip abroad in my 20s and going through passport control at London’s Heathrow airport. The desk agent asked me what I did for work. “I’m an advertising professional!” I enthused. To which he, without missing a beat, lifted an eyebrow and wryly replied, “Isn’t that an oxymoron?”

headline: On Linking Brain Damage and Behavior
text: Sean Morey had just tucked in his daughter Sunday night when he learned about Chris Henry, the troubled N.F.L. wide receiver who died last December and was recently found to have trauma-induced brain damage. Chronic traumatic encephalopathy isn’t just for retired players anymore.

headline: First Violinist Resigns From the Juilliard String Quartet
text: Nick Eanet, who joined the Juilliard String Quartet less than a year ago as first violinist, is resigning for health reasons, the group said on Tuesday. Mr. Eanet has “an acute digestive ailment” that makes it difficult for him to take part in the quartet’s extensive touring, according to a statement. The condition is not life-threatening, it said. Mr. Eanet will spend next season with the quartet while a replacement is sought. Mr. Eanet had left a position as a concertmaster of the Metropolitan Opera to join the Juilliard, which was founded in 1946. He replaced Joel Smirnoff, who was named president of the Cleveland Institute of Music.

headline: Global Warming Among the Undead
text: The beginning of “Eclipse,” the third episode of “The Twilight Saga,” finds Bella and Edward (Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson, of course) cuddling passionately  though chastely, of course  in a meadow full of wildflowers. The day is just sunny enough to bring out the frosty sparkle in Edward’s skin, but not bright enough to kill either him or the brooding, minor-key mood. Bella is reciting Robert Frost’s poem “Fire and Ice,” about competing notions of how the world will end. Supposedly it’s for an English paper, but who is Bella kidding? “From what I’ve tasted of desire,” she intones, “I hold with those who favor fire.”

headline: The Secret to Ribs Is Already in the Kitchen: The Oven
text: EVERYONE knows the barbecue mantra “low and slow:” cook tough cuts of meat over low indirect heat for hours and hours until they fall off the bone and melt in the mouth.

headline: Afghan Attorney General Says U.S. Ambassador Pushed for Corruption Prosecutions
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistan’s attorney general disputed published allegations Tuesday that he had been pressured by the Afghan political leadership to sideline corruption investigations into some of the country’s elite, and he turned on the American ambassador, Karl W. Eikenberry, alleging that the ambassador had pressed him to bring particular cases against high-profile figures.

headline: Muted Outcome of White House Energy Meeting
text: The White House this afternoon issued a muted summary of the meeting President Obama held with 23 senators aiming to forge consensus on energy legislation that would also constrain greenhouse gases. (The summary is appended below.) The statement reflects no wavering by Obama on his insistence that “the best way for us to transition to a clean energy economy is with a bill that makes clean energy the profitable kind of energy for America’s businesses by putting a price on pollution.”

headline: We Three Things | Uu Kanata*
text: While most of you are looking forward to the fireworks of Fourth of July weekend, I’m counting down to Canada Day, July 1. It’s when I find myself (a Canadian) at my most patriotic and homesick. With an ear tuned to any mention of my native land’s excellence, I found examples of Canada’s talent for invention, art and knack for getting along with others.

headline: On Government and Playground Water Fights
text: On a hot day, a sprinkler-soaked playground full of screaming children can seem like a kind of oasis, even to the childless. Yet behind the impressions of summer fun, water gun conflicts may be brewing.

headline: About That Thesis…

headline: To Beat Insomnia, a $60,000 Bed?
text: Beds that cost up to $60,000 each are now available, note Dr. Michael Thorpy and Shelby Freedman Harris of the Sleep-Wake Disorders Center at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. But is a better mattress the secret to curing insomnia?

headline: ‘Daisy’ on the Road Back to Broadway in Fall
text: On our short list of people who would look cool taking us to run errands at the Piggly Wiggly, James Earl Jones would have to rank near the top – and Vanessa Redgrave wouldn’t be a bad passenger to ride alongside, either. The producers of a coming Broadway production of “Driving Miss Daisy” evidently agree: they have cast Mr. Jones (a Tony Award-winner for “Fences” and “The Great White Hope”) and Ms. Redgrave (a Tony winner for “Long Day’s Journey Into Night”) to star in a new production of Alfred Uhry’s Pulitzer Prize-winning play about an Atlanta widow and her chauffeur, press representatives for the show said on Tuesday. The Broadway production of “Driving Miss Daisy” will be directed by David Esbjornson (“The Goat, or Who Is Sylvia?”) and presented at the Golden Theater, with preview performances to begin on Oct. 7 and opening night set for Oct. 25. The play was originally presented off Broadway by Playwrights Horizons in a production that starred Dana Ivey and Morgan Freeman, leading to the Academy Award-winning 1989 film adaptation.

headline: Reacting to One College’s Advice for Parents
text: A few months ago during February vacation, my husband and daughter took a trip to Middlebury College in Vermont. Aside from coming home to report on the beautiful campus, the interesting class offerings, the fresh snow and the mostly cool-looking students, my husband handed me a sheet of paper that he knew I’d get a kick out of — and perhaps learn something from.

headline: Digital Magazines Don’t Encourage Socializing
text: You’ve got to hand it to the magazine publishers. They continue to throw spaghetti against the iPad and other e-readers trying to see what will stick and what falls to the floor.

headline: Update: Breitbart Offers a Bounty for E-mail List
text: Andrew Breitbart, the conservative provocateur who has made it a personal crusade to expose what he says is liberal bias in the media, is putting his money where his mouth is.

headline: Gulf Oil Gusher, the Xbox Game
text: In the annals of all things great, weird and sad: It was perhaps inevitable that the gulf oil disaster would spread into the center of global culture — the world of gaming. Users of Xbox 360, including my son Daniel, who tipped me off to this development, can now purchase a $1 downloadable “Crisis in the Gulf” game (hat tip to Kotaku.com). The pitch: “Do you have what it takes to cap the leak?”7:35 p.m. | Updated  More background at msnbc.com.

headline: That’s One Way to Get Out of Student Loan Debt

headline: Travel Deals: Book Now, Save This Winter
text: While most travelers are thinking about a trip to the beach, those who are thinking ahead can save on next winter’s ski vacation.

headline: From Buildings to Baubles
text: At age 102, the renowned Brazilian architect Oscar Niemeyer is still working — and still inspiring. Specifically, he inspired one of his countrymen — Roberto Stern, the president and creative director of the jeweler H. Stern — to bring out a collection of jewelry that was inspired by the maestro’s sketches of buildings (including one of Brasilia, Niemeyer’s masterpiece), flowers and even the female form. The H. Stern Collection by Oscar Niemeyer, which was created in collaboration with the architect, captures the sketches’ light, flowing lines and their general joie de vivre. Niemeyer’s sketch for the exuberantly-curved roof of a church in Pampulha, Belo Horizonte, for example, was translated into a pair of white gold and diamond earrings. An almost childlike drawing of a flower became a graceful, delicate bracelet made of what seems like a single, slender ribbon of yellow gold. The jeweler is known for its creative collaborations, like those with Diane von Furstenberg, the Campana brothers and even Disney (on the surreal-luxe “Alice in Wonderland” collection). But was Niemeyer surprised by Roberto Stern’s request to turn his architectural sketches into rings and necklaces? Not at all. Stern recalled that the architect said simply, “I want to make beautiful things.”

headline: White House Supports McChrystal Retiring as Four-Star Officer
text: The White House said Tuesday that it “will do whatever is necessary” to ensure that Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal can retire as a four-star officer even though his time in service would not normally entitle him to that.

headline: Eiland Returns to Yankees
text: A familiar face was back with the Yankees on Tuesday afternoon — Dave Eiland, the team’s pitching coach.

headline: Invisible Ink and Other Spy Details From Criminal Complaints
text: The next time someone asks, “Excuse me, but haven’t we met in California last summer?” remember the code: “No, I think it was the Hamptons.”

headline: Excursions Into a Dark Territory, With the Desperate and the Lost as Guides
text: In an earlier book of stories, “The Secret Goldfish,” David Means managed a dark portrait of today’s working-class youth, aimless and bereft of the stability that “working-class” once conferred. The darkness, though, was made visible by light. It came from the writer’s diamond-edged prose, occasionally from the desperate comic relief of a tall story (a man is struck seven times by lightning) and from naked moments of compassion winking, flasherlike, through the narrator’s meticulously dressed-up deadpan.

headline: A Diversity of Instruments for a Diversity of Styles
text: Frank Oteri, the writer and critic who runs the 21st Century Schizoid Music concerts at the Cornelia Street Café, has found an unusual but timely niche. His series, which draws its name from a 1969 song (“21st Century Schizoid Man”) by the progressive rock band King Crimson, is focused on musicians whose work straddles several pop and classical styles and who take on different musical personalities, depending on the setting where their work is to be heard.

headline: Now Popping Up | Chanel in St. Tropez
text: The news that Chanel opened a pop-up store in St. Tropez last week came as no surprise, given that the French resort town seems to be Karl Lagerfeld’s latest obsession. The designer recently showed his new Chanel resort collection there and used the town as the setting for his short film “Remember Now.” The shop, in an 18th-century mansion near the Place des Lices, is awash in a Coco-esque palette of black, white, red and beige (along with gorgeously stenciled walls) that match the clothing and accessories for sale. Never mind that the store stocks only the fall ready-to-wear collection; the tile floors and exotic flora in the garden lend plenty of beachy vibes.Chanel in St. Tropez, 25 rue François Sibilli; open from June 23 to Oct. 3, 2010.

headline: Stolen Caravaggio Is Recovered
text: A Caravaggio painting considered to be the most valuable work of art in Ukraine was recovered in Germany, two years after it was stolen from a museum in Odessa, Reuters reported. The painting, below, called “The Taking of Christ” or “The Kiss of Judas,” was made by Caravaggio in the early 17th century, and depicts Jesus and his apostles John and Judas as they are being separated by soldiers. It had belonged to a Russian ambassador to France and a Russian prince before it was turned over to the Odessa museum, where it was stolen in 2008. On Tuesday Anatoly Mogylyov, the interior minister of Ukraine, said in a briefing that the Ukrainian and German police had recovered the painting and detained members of a gang that focuses on high-value thefts who had tried to sell the work in Berlin.

headline: White House: Boehner ‘Out of Touch With America’
text: The White House harshly criticized Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the top House Republican, on Tuesday, calling him “completely out of touch with America” because of his opposition to new regulations on Wall Street.

headline: BP Protesters Stage Mini-Spill at Tate Britain
text: Protesters took their dissatisfaction with BP to the steps of the Tate Britain museum in London, above, using the occasion of a summer party celebrating the oil company’s 20-year sponsorship of the museum to call attention to its handling of the calamitous oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. On Monday night, Bloomberg News reported, members of a protest group emptied BP-labeled cans containing a slick material in front of the party’s entrance and covered the spillage with bird feathers. Other protesters poured out cans of the same material in the museum’s main hall while a separate group dressed in black picketed the event. BP, which spends more than $1.5 million a year to sponsor art institutions including the Tate Britain, the British Museum, the Royal Opera House and the National Portrait Gallery, told Bloomberg News that it would continue to finance those sponsorships.

headline: Poof! ‘Jeannie’ Memoir To Appear Next Year
text: For the five seasons that she starred on the classic television comedy “I Dream of Jeannie,” Barbara Eden could conjure up anything from valuable artwork to an elephant with a nod and a blink. So why did it take her four decades since the series ended its run to write a memoir about her life and career? “Quite frankly, it scared the dickens out of me,” Ms. Eden said in a telephone interview. “I was quite frightened of doing this. I’ve been asked several times, and it’s daunting to talk about yourself. It gets to the soft spots inside you.” On Tuesday the Crown Archetype imprint of Random House’s Crown Publishing division said that it would release a memoir by Ms. Eden, called “Jeannie Out of the Bottle,” in the spring of 2011. As its title implies, the book will have its share to say about “I Dream of Jeannie,” in which Ms. Eden played the mystically empowered title character from 1965 to 1970. “She’ll have a big voice in this story,” Ms. Eden said, “but a lot went on before Jeannie.” Ms. Eden, who is working with a collaborator, Wendy Leigh, on the memoir, said they had a few more soul-baring sessions planned before the manuscript is complete. “I’ll just hold my nose and jump in,” Ms. Eden said.

text: Egalitarianism be damned, women are still much more likely to engage in household chores on a typical day than men are.

headline: A Rock ’n’ Roll Napoleon in Exile in a No-Holds-Barred Interview
text: To say that Phil Spector, the reclusive record producer who created the quasi-symphonic “wall of sound” heard on 1960s hits by the Ronettes and the Crystals, has a mammoth ego is an understatement. During the rare, extended interview that forms the spine of Vikram Jayanti’s creepily riveting documentary portrait, “The Agony and the Ecstasy of Phil Spector,” he compares himself to Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, Bach and Galileo.

headline: Byrd to Lie in Repose in Senate Chamber
text: 7:02 p.m. | Updated  Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia will lie in repose in the chamber of his beloved Senate from 10:15 a.m. to 3:45 p.m. Thursday in a Capitol ceremony that has not occurred for more than 50 years.

headline: Juilliard Quartet Violinist Steps Down; Health Cited
text: Nick Eanet, who joined the Juilliard String Quartet less than a year ago as first violinist, is resigning for health reasons, the group said on Tuesday. Mr. Eanet has “an acute digestive ailment” that makes it difficult for him to take part in the quartet’s extensive touring, according to a statement. The condition is not life-threatening, it said. Mr. Eanet will spend next season with the quartet while a replacement is sought. He left a post as a concertmaster of the Metropolitan Opera to join the Juilliard, and replaced Joel Smirnoff, who was named president of the Cleveland Institute of Music.

headline: Playboy Sues Drake
text: The rapper Drake’s breakthrough single, “Best I Ever Had,” which went from a mixtape to a popular EP, didn’t get to be the best all on its own, according to a copyright infringement suit filed by Playboy Enterprises. In the suit, which Playboy filed in federal court in California on Friday, the company says that Drake used material from the 1975 song “Fallin’ in Love,” by Hamilton, Joe Frank & Reynolds. Playboy owns the rights to that song. Cash Money Records, Universal Music Group and Universal Music Group Distribution are also named as defendants. Representatives for Playboy Enterprises, Drake and Universal said they had no comment. Drake’s single peaked at No. 2 on the Billboard Hot 100 and brought him a pair of 2010 Grammy nominations. The EP, “So Far Gone,” that includes the single has sold almost 500,000 copies.

headline: Join the ‘Glee’ Club
text: Tryouts for Fox’s high school musical “Glee” will be televised on the cable channel Oxygen next year. In a deal outlined on Tuesday, Oxygen will start a “Glee” casting-call reality show in June 2011 as part of a broader deal with Twentieth Television to show repeats of “Glee” in syndication beginning in 2013. The deal was reported by Deadline.com. It’s an unusual cable extension of a broadcaster’s show, and it affirms the popularity of “Glee,” which recently wrapped up its first season. Fox mounted a nationwide call for new cast members earlier this year but last week scrapped its plans for a series of reality specials about the process. Published reports indicated that the “Glee” executive producer Ryan Murphy wanted to concentrate on the second season of the ensemble drama, which will start in the fall. In another deal for a freshman-year series this week, Twentieth Television sold repeats of the ABC sitcom “Modern Family” to the cable channel USA.

Ms. Cyrus, the chatterers argued, was in trouble but could still be saved.

headline: Private Trauma Sheds Light on Terrorism
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Though you wouldn’t necessarily know it from talking to her, Jessica Stern is a renowned expert on terrorists and terrorism. She is a small, cheerful-seeming woman with a ready laugh and a way of making jokes at her own expense. You could mistake her for a preschool teacher. But she has taught about terrorism at Harvard and has served on the National Security Council, and she has spent a fair amount of time talking to terrorists themselves. Her 2003 book, “Terror in the Name of God: Why Religious Militants Kill,” consists largely of interviews with extremists of every stripe: Christian, Jewish, Muslim, anti-abortion militants, even followers of Timothy McVeigh.

Scorecard thinks it’s pretty safe to say that over at the Maison where the fearless lab leader has long since been missing, the white-coated team’s new definition of “recycled chic” was not moving anyone to tears.

headline: Seattle Gets a Maestro of Skill and Luck
