All of those came together for the young Frenchman Ludovic Morlot, who will become the next music director of the Seattle Symphony Orchestra.

headline: Alex Getting Stronger and Heading for Land
text: Tropical Storm Alex has gotten much better organized in the past 24 hours. The convection is becoming centralized and coalescing. Intensity as of 15Z today is 60kts and 982mb. It’s very likely that by later today, Alex will become the season’s first hurricane. Northern Mexico and the southern tip of Texas up to Baffin Bay are under a Hurricane Warning, and a Tropical Storm Warning extends from Baffin Bay to Port O’Connor.

The restaurant is on Mulberry Street, just north of Spring, and sits behind wide glass windows. Trees on the sidewalk act as filters for the streetlight. If you squint, it might be Paris or Boston. It is emphatically New York.

Some of them feature ingredients like corn, eggplant and tomatoes, which will be better a month from now, at least in the Northeast. headline: The Caucus: Daily Kos Plans to Sue Polling Company

headline: The Wrong Way and the Right Way

Yet Mayor Michael Bloomberg and City Council leaders have managed to agree on a four-year budget outline.

headline: Antibiotics and Agriculture
text: The Food and Drug Administration is taking some long overdue but still too timid steps to rein in excessive use of antibiotics in American agriculture. For years now industrial and many smaller-scale farmers have routinely fed antibiotics to their cattle, pigs and chickens to protect them from infectious diseases but also to spur growth and weight gain while using less feed. That may be good for agricultural production, but it is almost surely bad for the public’s health.

headline: To Soak Up the Grease and Toss
text: Disposing of oil used for fish and chips or fried chicken is never simple. Pouring it down the drain can clog plumbing and sewage systems. It can be stirred into fat that has cooled to room temperature, and then tossed into the trash like kitty litter.

headline: A New Cheese of Goat’s and Cow’s Milk
text: In the hands of the cheesemaker Allison Hooper, cow’s milk (for mellow creaminess) and goat’s milk (for bright tangy balance) are joined to make a new soft-textured cheese that’s as easygoing as a summer novel and as hard to resist. The cheese, a compact cylinder with a thin, slightly wrinkled straw-colored edible rind can be cut in wedges or spread, and reveals a clean, milky flavor that is delicately nutty. The name, Cremont, is a mash-up of cream and Vermont.

headline: Off the Menu

headline: A Kitchen Control Freak Learns to Let Go
text: AS a kitchen control freak, I can hardly bear the sight of someone else standing at my stove. But for searing meat and grilling fish, I have no choice. Both require high heat, smoking pans, screaming smoke alarms and the overwhelming urge to surrender: Lower the flame, skip the crust, turn a blind eye to a rubbery middle.

headline: Russian-Style Teas Find a N.Y. Home
text: It started as the tea of the czars in 1867 in St. Petersburg. Then, in 1917, the Kousmichoff family moved Kusmi Tea to Paris, where the teas, often blended with whiffs of citrus and flowers, have remained a quaff of connoisseurs.

headline: When Is a Free Meal Just Part of a Writer’s Job?
text: BY all accounts, the wedding of the food writer Josh Ozersky and Danit Lidor on May 23 in Manhattan was an eater’s idyll.

headline: At Rockaway Beach, a New Veggies and Fruit Stand
text: The surfing dudes could load up on veggies and fruit at some Greenmarket before they jumped on the A Train to Rockaway Beach. But it’s easier to do the shopping once they get there, at the new little market in the expanding, ramshackle complex anchored by Rockaway Taco. Elizabeth Gilchrist, a partner (shown with her dog, Baby), said the produce is mainly local (much of it from Blooming Hill Farm in the Hudson Valley) and organic. Right now, greens, including callaloo, are in abundance, at $3 a bag. There are also some tropical fruits because they are used by the smoothie stand that shares the premises. The market also sells bread from Roberta’s in Bushwick, Brooklyn, and some locally handmade odds and ends like glasses made from Red Stripe beer bottles, $10 each.

headline: Lottery Numbers
At Last, N.B.A. Free-Agent Season Almost Here
text: A spectacular convergence of talent and salary-cap space will finally take place Thursday at 12:01 a.m. when LeBron James, Dwyane Wade, Chris Bosh and other sought-after players can officially meet with representatives from imploring N.B.A. teams.

headline: Year After Evacuation, Brooklyn Tenants Still Aren’t Back Home

headline: The Domes Are Gone!
text: Three silvery domes that had been installed in the new Brooklyn Bridge Park for children to play on — but which instead scorched their young hands — have been removed.

headline: Cisco Finds Its Tablet
text: Forget the frenzy of the consumer market, the jazzy advertising and the retail-shelf-space wars. Cisco Systems intends to hawk tablet computers in the more sedate world of the office.

headline: Couples Accused as Spies Were the Suburbs Personified
text: They raised children, went to work in the city each day, talked the small talk with neighbors about yard work and overpriced contractors. In short, they could have been any family in any suburb in America.

headline: A White Day at the Women’s Grand Prix
text: All the players with White won their games Tuesday in Round 6 of the Women’s Grand Prix. Nana Dzagnidze of the Republic of Georgia leads by a point heading into the break.

headline: With Eiland Back, a Hope That Burnett Returns to Form
text: Dave Eiland, the Yankees’ pitching coach, rejoined the club Tuesday after a three-week leave to deal with an unspecified personal matter. His absence coincided with the confounding trials of A. J. Burnett.

headline: 3 Years Later, Trial to Start in J.F.K. Bomb Plot
text: Three years have passed since the authorities warned that Islamic terrorist plotters had once again placed New York “in their cross hairs,” describing an international conspiracy to detonate fuel tanks at Kennedy International Airport and set off cascading explosions along a fuel pipeline that cuts through much of the city and the surrounding region.

headline: ‘Illegals’  Spy Ring Famed in Lore of Russian Spying
text: MOSCOW  In the lore of Soviet spycraft, few figures command as much respect as the “illegals,” steel-jawed agents with the intelligence of a chess grandmaster and the fortitude of a cosmonaut.

headline: Early Caucus State
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — I found this theme to be solid, tight and funny — three good traits in any puzzle. Each theme entry painted a picture, two in which singers were being crowned and clawed. Another songstress fared a little better, nothing more than a little tickling, while Seal escaped unmolested.

headline: Portugal’s Fans in Spain Enjoy Friendly Rivalry

headline: New Gifted Testing in New York May Begin at Age 3
text: City education officials revealed this month that they would begin searching for a new gifted admissions test in response to complaints about low minority representation in gifted programs and concerns that professional test preparation services skew the results.

headline: Replaying Lost Lead in U.S. Open, Johnson Gains Insights
text: NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa.  In the bucolic setting of Aronimink Golf Club, nine days and some 2,500 miles removed from the bubbling cauldron of pressure that was the final round of the United States Open, Dustin Johnson finally spoke Tuesday about what happened when his three-stroke lead evaporated during a three-hole meltdown.

headline: How Mariano Rivera Dominates Hitters
text: The closer confounded hitters with mostly one pitch: his signature cutter.

headline: After a Skipped Start for Hughes, One He’d Rather Forget
text: Joe Girardi liked how Phil Hughes carried himself around the clubhouse. The Yankees have a plan to limit Hughes’s innings and protect his young arm. That plan included having Hughes skip his scheduled start last Friday, and he took it all in stride.

headline: Mariano Rivera, King of the Closers
text: Before the seventh game of the 2003 American League Championship Series with the Boston Red Sox, Mariano Rivera, the New York Yankees star who is widely considered the greatest relief pitcher in the history of baseball, said a prayer. Rivera, a deeply religious man, prays with his family before every home game. But this was a special prayer, which he delivered within himself, because the two teams, so evenly matched, had fought their way down to this final contest. Rivera’s prayers remained unanswered until the bottom of the eighth inning, when, in one of the great comebacks in playoff history, the Yankees scored three runs against Boston’s ace, Pedro Martinez, to tie the game. Before heading for the mound, Rivera, the most stoical of athletes, had to leave the bullpen for a little shed nearby, where he proceeded, astonishingly, to weep.

headline: Canada: Arrests Totaled More Than 900 During Group of 20 Meeting in Toronto
text: More than 900 people were arrested, and about half of them charged, in connection with last weekend’s Group of 20 summit meeting, Toronto’s police chief, William Blair, said Tuesday. He displayed objects seized from protesters to justify police actions that civil liberties groups faulted. But several items, like notebooks and tennis balls, seemed unlikely to have been used as weapons.

headline: A Democratic Stronghold Loses a Big Pillar
text: SOPHIA, W.Va. — The décor and the conversation in Larry Jones’s cluttered place on Main Street — a former shop where retired miners now gather to sip coffee — convey the split personality of West Virginia politics.

headline: Council Weighs Hearings on Bloomberg’s Hiring

headline: China Returns U.S. Criticism Over Sinking of Korean Ship
text: BEIJING — Three days after President Obama emerged from a tense meeting with President Hu Jintao of China, and accused Beijing of “willful blindness” toward North Korea’s military provocations, the Chinese government on Tuesday continued the argument about how to handle its testy neighbor.

headline: Turkey: Apology From Israel Is Sought Before Envoy Post Is Filled, Official Says
text: Turkey will not appoint a new ambassador to Israel unless the Israeli government formally apologizes for the killing of nine Turkish citizens, including one who also had American citizenship, who were aboard a boat that tried unsuccessfully in May to breach the Israeli naval blockade of Gaza, a Turkish senior Foreign Ministry official said Tuesday. The Turkish government is also demanding compensation for relatives of the dead and the establishment of an independent commission to investigate the Israeli military operation against the flotilla that tried to run the blockade. Israel has agreed only to set up an internal investigative commission with three international observers, which the Turkish official, who would not speak for attribution because of his role in bilateral relations, said would not be “impartial.”

headline: Caribbean Thrill Quickly Fading for Mets
text: SAN JUAN, P.R.  Playing baseball on this picturesque island has provided some spice to the tedium and drudgery of a long season, but with a pair of losses, all the fun and novelty of the San Juan series is starting to wear off for the Mets.

headline: South Africa: At World Cup, Suspects, Too, Come From All Over
text: So far 316 people have been arrested for crimes related to the World Cup soccer tournament, the national police commissioner, Bheki Cele, said Tuesday. A total of 109 were foreign citizens, including 11 Ethiopians, 9 Algerians, 8 Britons, and 6 suspects each from Mozambique, Pakistan, the United States and Zimbabwe. “It’s the United Nations of crime,” Mr. Cele joked. He said seven trophy replicas, two jerseys and four Adidas bags were stolen from FIFA headquarters in Johannesburg.

headline: Stores See Google as Ally in E-Book Market
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Independent bookstores were battered first by discount chains like Barnes & Noble, then by superefficient Web retailers like Amazon.com.

headline: Last Year’s Auto Dealership May Be This Year’s Grocery
text: WHITEHALL, Mich.  The Ford dealership in this town of 2,800 closed nearly two years ago, one more victim of the recession in a state that was among the hardest hit in the economic downturn. Yet the 30-acre site is once again filled with cars and trucks, as the home of a Save-A-Lot discount grocery store that opened in March.

headline: Ethnic Distinctions, No Longer So Distinctive
text: WASHINGTON — If anyone still doubted, after President Obama’s election, that candidates are no longer prisoners of their race or ethnicity, then South Carolina’s Nikki Haley offers further proof. Ms. Haley, 38, was born Nimrata Nikki Randhawa, the daughter of Indian Sikh immigrants. Now she is the Christian, Republican nominee for governor in a state with a brutal history of racial oppression.

headline: Boy Swept Away by Waters Off the Rockaways
text: A 14-year-old boy who went swimming in the waters off the Rockaways in Queens after lifeguards went off duty on Tuesday disappeared after he was swept away by currents, the police said.

headline: No Holdout on Horizon for Jets’ Ducasse

The Jets and Ducasse began discussions on a deal Monday, and Linta said he was hopeful that an agreement would be reached in the “next 7 to 10 days.”

headline: More Twists and Turns in Fight for Chess Federation Presidency
text: The slate of candidates for the top offices of the World Chess Federation were officially announced Tuesday. They are on the Web site of the federation, which is also known by the acronym FIDE (for Fédération Internationale des Échecs).

headline: $1.4 Billion Development at Sugar Refinery in Brooklyn Wins Key Council Support
text: The $1.4 billion plan to transform the former Domino Sugar refinery into a residential development on the Brooklyn waterfront won critical support in the City Council on Tuesday, after the developer agreed to cut the size of the project’s two tallest towers and provide a shuttle bus to the nearest subway.

headline: Phys Ed: What Exercise Science Doesn’t Know About Women
text: Several years ago, Dr. David Rowlands, a senior lecturer with the Institute of Food, Nutrition and Human Health at Massey University in New Zealand, set out to study the role of protein in recovery from hard exercise. He asked a group of male cyclists to ride intensely until their legs were aching and virtually all of their stored muscle fuel had been depleted. The cyclists then consumed bars and drinks that contained either mostly carbohydrates or both carbohydrates and protein. Then, over the next few days, they completed two sessions of hard intervals. One took place the following morning; the next, two days later.

headline: Is Facebook Truly Worth $23 Billion?
text: Facebook has latched on to some good friends. Elevation Partners, a venture capital firm, just gave the social networking company a valuation of $23 billion in its latest secondary market purchase of 2.4 million shares. That’s more than triple what Facebook appeared to be worth a year ago. And at nearly 30 times trailing sales, it’s about twice the multiple Google achieved when it went public in 2004.

headline: William Taylor, Vigorous Rights Defender,  Dies at 78
text: William L. Taylor, who as a lawyer, lobbyist and government official for more than a half century had significant roles in pressing important civil rights cases and in drafting and defending civil rights legislation, died Monday in Bethesda, Md. He was 78 and lived in Washington.

headline: Helen Mirren and Taylor Hackford

headline: Allyn Ferguson, TV Composer, Dies at 85
text: Allyn Ferguson, an Emmy Award-winning composer for television and a co-writer of the themes for the hit shows “Charlie’s Angels” and “Barney Miller,” died on June 23 at his home in Westlake Village, Calif. He was 85.

headline: Rudolf Leopold, Art Collector, Dies at 85
text: Rudolf Leopold, a Viennese art collector and museum director who amassed one of the world’s most significant collections of 20th-century Austrian art, but who faced accusations that some of it had been looted by the Nazis from their Jewish owners, died on Tuesday in Vienna. He was 85.

headline: ‘Daisy’ on the Road to Broadway in the Fall
text: On our short list of people who would look cool taking us to run errands at the Piggly Wiggly, James Earl Jones, right, would rank near the top  and Vanessa Redgrave, far right, wouldn’t be a bad passenger to ride alongside, either. The producers of a coming Broadway production of “Driving Miss Daisy” evidently agree: they have cast Mr. Jones and Ms. Redgrave to star in a new production of Alfred Uhry’s Pulitzer Prize-winning play about an Atlanta widow and her chauffeur, press representatives for the show said on Tuesday. The production will be directed by David Esbjornson and presented at the Golden Theater, with preview performances to begin on Oct. 7 and opening night set for Oct. 25. The play was originally presented Off Broadway by Playwrights Horizons in a production that starred Dana Ivey and Morgan Freeman, leading to the Academy Award-winning 1989 film adaptation.

headline: Dutch Drama
text: The Netherlands’ uncharacteristic team unity at this World Cup could be in jeopardy. Coach Bert van Marwijk said he called a team meeting after Monday’s 2-1 victory over Slovakia to address Robin van Persie’s angry reaction to being substituted out of the match. According to Dutch news reports, van Persie complained as he came to the bench with 10 minutes to play that Wesley Sneijder should have been replaced instead. Van Persie acknowledged Tuesday that he was “very disappointed” by being substituted out but said reports that he used Sneijder’s name or that of any other player were false. “I will never accept anything that could upset the next match,” van Marwijk said Van Marwijk said he spoke to both players. “After that, I called the team together, told them what I think and then drew a line under it,” he said.

headline: Asian Stocks Buckle Under Worldwide Slump
text: The wave of selling that sent the world’s stock markets sharply lower on Tuesday continued in Asia on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 down more than 2 percent by lunchtime in Tokyo, as investors fretted about just how strong — or feeble — the global economic recovery would be.

headline: Suspect in Spy Case Cultivated Friends Made at Harvard
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  If an outsider wanted to gain intimate access to a rarefied group of business and political leaders, attending Harvard’s Kennedy School of Government certainly would not hurt. It was there that Donald Heathfield, now accused of being a Russian secret agent, blended in while forging connections with classmates from around the world.

headline: Living With Music: A Playlist by Allison Amend
text: Allison Amend is the author of a story collection, “Things That Pass for Love,” and a novel, “Stations West.”Asking me to blog about music is like asking a parking meter about foreign policy: it may have an opinion, but it won’t be worth much. You see, I don’t listen to music. O.K., a little bit when jogging, but it’s the same 10 songs in the same order that I’ve listened to on various machines (from yellow sports Walkman, to skipping CD-player, to minidisc player, to Zune — yes, Zune — to iPods) for years.  At the gym I watch reality television (like every  writer, I love “Hoarders”). At home, I listen to NPR.  So there’s no way I can impress with obscure Laplandic bands or neologistic sub-genres. Instead, I’d like to share some songs I came across as I was doing research for “Stations West,” my novel about Jewish immigrants in Oklahoma in the 19th century. One of the subplots surrounds the construction and subsequent development of the intercontinental railroad.  The railroad was the original information superhighway, bringing mail and newspapers, other cultures and foods to the remote West; railroad songs are the viral videos of the 19th century. Studying them  I learned about attitudes and motivations particular to that time and place. If history is written by the winners, then songs are written by the disenfranchised, and literature is mostly about the latter.

headline: Asked and Answered | James Jagger
text: Ever since our Screen Test with James Jagger, we’ve kept tabs on the the 24-year-old actor, the eldest son of Mick Jagger and Jerry Hall. He has distinguished himself in stage performances (James McLure’s “Lone Star” and “Pvt. Wars”) and will play the British musician John Turnbull in the coming Ian Dury biopic, “Sex & Drugs & Rock & Roll.” As if this isn’t enough proof that the apple doesn’t fall far from the family tree, James is in a touring rock band. He plays bass for Turbogeist, which visited Lit Lounge and the Gramercy Theater on a recent jaunt to New York. (The band also has plans to play all around London’s East End this summer, including a performance at Hoxton Bar & Kitchen on Aug. 5.) We e-mailed Jagger to find out where he hangs when in New York and whether he plans to follow his sisters Gloria and Lizzy into the modeling biz.

headline: Correction

headline: Bad Times, Worse Times: Led Zeppelin Sued for Copyright Infringement
text: Led Zeppelin historians have chronicled the creation of that rock band’s early classic “Dazed and Confused” for so long it’s understandable if fans can no longer tell what’s true about its authorship. One thing is for certain: Jake Holmes, a folk singer who asserts he recorded a similar song, also called “Dazed and Confused,” in 1967, says that he is the song’s creator and has filed a copyright infringement lawsuit against Led Zeppelin  and its guitarist, Jimmy Page, as well as the band’s record labels and Mr. Page’s publishing company.

headline: A Filmmaker’s Muses
text: ANGELA ISMAILOS, wearing fitted jeans and a black jersey top, made her entrance through a doorway flanked by extravagant arrangements of Casablanca lilies. The afternoon sunlight streaming through the living room windows of her Park Avenue apartment, which is filled with works by artists like John Currin, Francesco Clemente and Cindy Sherman, illuminated her blond hair and pale green eyes. The overall effect seemed almost purposefully cinematic, but somehow there was not a trace of drama in the way she gestured toward the lilies and said matter-of-factly in her Greek-accented English, “I cannot live without flowers or music.”

headline: A Man and His Dream: Christopher Nolan and ‘Inception’
text: Is Christopher Nolan a household name yet? Certainly, the movies that this 39-year-old director has made, from his breakthrough noir “Memento” to his billion-dollar Batman sequel “The Dark Knight”, have been some of the most influential and popular films of the last decade. But will his pedigree – combined, of course, with the photogenic mug of Leonardo DiCaprio – be enough to reel in moviegoers by the millions for “Inception,” his highly anticipated if enigmatic new movie?

headline: Sun Screens
text: MOVE over, Kanye West. Bless, the avant-garde label in Berlin and Paris, has come out with shades that wouldn’t look out of place in a Steven Klein video. Photoglasses ($240) are printed with a vacation photo and perforated like a colander. Duofringeglasses ($276) take a classic aviator frame and replace the  “Top Gun”  lenses with gold chains that dangle like beaded curtains. Available through Project No. 8 at 138 Division Street (Orchard Street); (212) 925-4271; projectno8.com or bless-service.de.

headline: From Amsterdam to Cobble Hill by Bike
text: WHEN it comes to biking, New York is no Amsterdam. But that hasn’t stopped Ad Hereijgers, an urban planner from the Netherlands, from opening a Euro-style bicycle store in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, that specializes in Dutch imports. That includes sturdy cargo and commuter bicycles by De Fietsfabriek (from $1,500) and Dutch ID (from $1,400), as well as hard-to-find accessories like a rubber bell ($2.50) and Bobike child seats ($215). “The bike store is a spin-off of our urban planning activities,” said Mr. Hereijgers, who divides his time between Amsterdam and Brooklyn. He plans to add film screenings, book readings and other bike-related events. Rolling Orange, 269 Baltic Street (Court Street), (718) 935-0695 or rollingorangebikes.com.

headline: A Geek Never Looked So Good
text: TECHNO-LUST goes designer-chic at Dijital Fix, which opened a second store last month, on the Lower East Side. Don’t expect iPod accessories here. It’s all about glamorous gizmos, like the D.J.-tested, matte-black TMA-1 headphones from the Danish company AIAIAI (tma-1.com), which go on sale later this summer ($199), and Ceramic Speakers by the San Francisco designer Joey Roth ($499). Unlike its first store, in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, the Manhattan one has a gallery and tapas bar called Culture Fix. Shows feature photos taken with a Hipstamatic, a popular iPhone app. David Auerbach (above), the store’s 25-year-old owner, said the idea for the multifunction store came from Japan. “Our demographic appreciates good food, good wine, up-and-coming artists and electronics,” he said. Dijital Fix, 9 Clinton Street (near East Houston Street), (877) 345-4349, dijitalfix.com.

headline: A Boat Shoe Relaunched
text: HUMBERTO LEON, an owner of Opening Ceremony, was obsessed with a pair of Timberland boat shoes from the 1980s. He first spotted them on the artist Nate Lowman, before finding a pair of dead stock for himself. So when Opening Ceremony began collaborating with Timberland, Mr. Leon fished them out of the closet. The new Watershoe ($95) has a narrower shape and two new color schemes (orange and white, left, or classic aqua blue) but otherwise remains faithful to the original.

headline: On Diversity, Bloomberg Remains Silent
text: The Times reported on Monday night that at the top levels of the Bloomberg administration, by several measures, more than 70 percent of the senior officials are white, even though the city’s non-Hispanic white population is 35 percent.

headline: Mint.com Expands Into Financial Planning Tools

headline: Counting the Years by Four
text: With the United States and three-fourths of the other teams having been sent packing many people of different nationalities are feeling a gaping hole. The institutions surrounding the teams have been working toward this tournament for four years if not longer. For them now, knocked out and discouraged, it is a process of regrouping and planning for four years down the road. For the players, however, it is not quite that simple.The U.S. team narrowly avoided heavy criticism by beating Algeria; a compliment can be given for advancing first in the group, and a tinge of pain for the missed opportunity to advance to the quarters can also be checked in with the coffers leaving Johannesburg. With these mixed emotions the players are heading home, neither a failure nor a huge success.

headline: Amazon to Introduce Web-Based Book Previews
text: It has been a busy week for Amazon’s Kindle division: On Monday the company announced that it would start selling new e-books that come embedded with audio and video. On Tuesday, Amazon also released a free Kindle application available for download on Google Android phones.

headline: Learning to Be Tough Beneath a Hard Hat
text: Gail Warrior planned to use the Russian she studied in college to help her open an accounting firm in the former Soviet Union. Instead, she is chief executive and president of the Warrior Group, a company with $124 million in revenue and 58 employees that is based in DeSoto, Tex., and handles modular construction projects in 30 states. “Life happens,” said Ms. Warrior, 42. She recently discussed the deal that almost put her out of business, the nuances of winning government contracts and the balancing act of being a newly divorced parent to a 10-year-old son. A condensed version of the conversation follows.

headline: Old Media vs. New Media
text: David Brooks: Gail, let’s give it up for Disney. I’m down here at the Wide World of Sports complex in Orlando, Fla., watching a bunch of 11-year-old kids play baseball in 105 degree heat for seven hours a day, and I find that even out beyond the right-field fences, Disney provides high-speed Internet access for free. So I can watch my youngest pitch against 11-year-olds, who are shaving, and also monitor the Kagan hearings on my laptop. Astonishingly, most parents do not seem to be doing this.

headline: 1987: Coconut Daiquiris

headline: Recipe Redux: Coconut Daiquiris, 1987
text: If you were in New York in the 1980s, you probably have vivid memories of a vocal and opinionated mayor named Ed Koch, who spent his days noisily trying to tame a Bright Lights Big City that was rampant with crime and AIDS.

headline: Eminem Tops Chart With Others Far Behind
text: Much about the music industry has changed in recent years, but at least one thing remains the same: Eminem’s role as a chart-topping star. The rapper’s latest album, “Recovery” (Aftermath/Interscope), sold 741,000 copies in its opening week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, the most sales in a one week by any artist since AC/DC’s “Black Ice” moved 784,000 copies in October 2008.

headline: Letter: Memories of the Bucovina
text: To the Editor: There are two books that capture the world of the Bucovina between the world wars. Readers who are intrigued by the article “Deep in the Carpathians, Painted Parables” (June 20) might be interested in Gregor von Rezzori’s “The Snows of Yesteryear” and “Memoirs of an Anti-Semite,” both lovely descriptions of his growing up in this area. His description of the city of Czernowitz and its diverse population is moving, especially in light of what became of that diversity.

headline: Letter: A Lerici Secret
text: To the Editor: Regarding “An Italian Beauty Without Foreign Suitors” (June 20) : Our long-kept secret is out! My husband and I discovered Lerici in 1989, while driving from Pisa to Santa Margherita. Eight years later, revisiting the region, we did some research to find this long-remembered, seemingly idyllic spot. In fact, we were not sure until we arrived that Lerici was the place. It was, and we have been back several times since.

headline: What if the Public Had Perfect Climate Information?
text: Not surprisingly, Joe Romm, “America’s fiercest climate blogger,” has assaulted my piece examining ways in which scientists might make scientific information on issues like global warming more impactful. How could I write such a piece — he says — without also including a big dollop of blame for institutions and individuals doling out reams of scientific disinformation to complacent journalists?

The very idea of a professional, full-time drink mixer, he says, was impossible for most of his customers to grasp.

headline: Dealing With Men Who Only Want to Deal With Men
text: Last week She Owns It introduced you to Gail Warrior, chief executive and president of Warrior Group and founder of the Warrior Small Business Academy, which she started to help other women and minority business owners succeed.

headline: Mimosas and Caviar for Breakfast
text: YOU’RE the beauty editor. A fantasy job for some women. You can call up anyone in the beauty business, meet with them and try out their unguents. You are invited to events where unguent-trying is the order of the day; you are sent endless free samples of “product.”

headline: Beauty Spots
text: FREEZING FAT? Lately, the prospect that cooling unwanted fat can make it disappear has been getting a lot of attention. One reason is that a growing number of doctors offer off-label treatments with Zeltiq, a cooling device that aims to make white fat cells die. (This despite the fact that the F.D.A. has not approved the marketing of Zeltiq for non-invasive fat reduction.) Results take roughly two months; each treatment area costs $500 to $1,000. A team of doctors first published on cryolipolysis, as this process is called, in 2008.

headline: Note to Moscow: 911 Is Secret U.S. Telephone Code
text: Anna Chapman, the suspected spy among us who emerged as a tabloid celebrity after her arrest, must have been on a deep cover mission when she attended the FDNY Foundation’s dinner on May 18.

headline: If Cars Could Fly
text: Is it a plane? Is it a car? No, it’s a super flying car-plane!

headline: 9 Domain Names Seized in Fight Against Internet Theft
text: As part of a new initiative against Internet theft of intellectual property, federal officials on Wednesday said they had seized nine domain names of Web sites that were found to be offering first-run movies.

headline: China Partially Blocking Google Searches
text: Ever since tensions erupted between Google and the Chinese government earlier this year, Beijing has made sure the search engine was on unsteady ground, unpredictably blocking and then unblocking search results and other Google services within the country.

headline: ‘Walks With Men’
text: In 1980, in New York, I met a man who promised me he’d change my life, if only I’d let him. The deal was this: he’d tell me anything, anything, as long as the information went unattributed, as long as no one knew he and I had any real relationship. At first it didn’t seem like much of a deal, but my intuition told me he knew something I didn’t yet know about the way men thought - and back then, I thought understanding men would give me information about the way I could make a life for myself. I liked his idea that nobody would know we meant anything to each other: not the college where he taught, or the magazine where he was on staff. Not my boyfriend in Vermont.

headline: Barclays Poaches 2 Senior Industrials Bankers
text: Barclays Capital on Wednesday said it has hired two senior industrials bankers from Citigroup and Credit Suisse, as the British bank continues to expand its investment banking operations in the wake of acquiring the bulk of Lehman Brothers‘ North American banking operations in 2008.

headline: Documents Show Goldman Pressure on A.I.G.
text: 9:18 p.m. | Updated Executives from Goldman Sachs and the American International Group, the Wall Street titans whose long alliance dissolved into a battle that shook the financial world, defended their actions on Wednesday before the federal commission that is investigating the financial crisis, The New York Times’s Gretchen Morgenson and Louise Story report.

headline: Analysis: How Murray Dismantled Tsonga
text: Andy Murray wins in a variety of ways, with superb defense and counterpunching, with deceptive speed and a knack for going on the offensive at just the right time, and with the keenest sense of anticipation on the men’s tour. I watched him dismantle Jo-Wilfried Tsonga in four sets, breaking down the explosive, talented Frenchman, much to the delight of an English crowd still reeling from World Cup disappointment.

headline: Analyzing the Markets
text: Winnie O'Kelley, Deputy Business Editor, and Graham Bowley, Business Reporter, analyze the Labor Department's June jobs report and the sluggish economic recovery.

headline: ‘The Spot’
text: The Botch

headline: Authorities Ask Woods About Doctor
text: Tiger Woods has been interviewed by federal authorities investigating Anthony Galea, the Canadian doctor accused of providing professional athletes with performance-enhancing drugs, Woods’s agent confirmed.

headline: A 29-Foot-Long Car With 36 Mirrors, a Microwave and a For Sale Sign
text: Antti Rahko and his wife, Eini, could have made their last trip from their home in Palm Beach, Fla., to Ontario, Canada, in their famously fantastic Finnjet. That’s because Mr. Rahko is about to put the Finnjet up for sale again.

headline: Senate Takes Up Small-Business Jobs Bill
text: Senate Democratic leaders introduced their long-awaited small-business jobs bill on Tuesday — and in an indication of how urgently legislators viewed the matter, the Senate voted to begin debating the measure even before its details were finalized.

headline: Sketches of Suspects and Senators, and an N.Y.P.D. Critique
text: In a city of struggling artists, perhaps a few could volunteer to work for the New York Police Department?

headline: Opposition Calls Election in Burundi a ‘Masquerade’
text: BUJUMBURA, Burundi — Politicians boycotting the presidential election here dismissed the results as a sham on Wednesday and denounced the president after a vote in which only one candidate — the incumbent — stood for office.

headline: Hitting Wine Trails In Pennsylvania
text: Though less known for its wine than heavyweights like Napa Valley, Pennsylvania has arrived.  In the last five years, the number of wineries in Pennsylvania has grown to more than 130, and the number of visitors has doubled, to one million last year.

headline: The E.P.A. on Dispersants: Cure Is Not Worse Than the Disease
text: Initial tests of Corexit, the oil dispersant that BP is using in the Gulf of Mexico, and of competing products finds that the dispersants range from “practically nontoxic’’ to “slightly toxic,’’ the Environmental Protection Agency says.

headline: No Lingering: Larry King Goes Gently
text: Too many people in public life die with their mikes on.

headline: Forging a Festival for Black Playwrights
text: Does the world need another festival for emerging playwrights?

headline: Authority and Arrogance: A Response
text: What subjects are fit to be addressed in public by a philosopher?  Many of the responses to essays in The Stone raise this issue. Actually, commentators have been pressing at least two versions of the question.  What sorts of things are worth looking at philosophically?  And about what, if anything, do philosophers have any special authority?

headline: Interior Delays Offshore Expansion Hearings
text: WASHINGTON — The Interior Department, preoccupied with its response to the BP oil leak in the Gulf of Mexico, said Wednesday that it was pushing back the date of public hearings on the administration’s plan, announced before the disaster began, to expand offshore drilling.

headline: A Move to Ban Smoking in Cars With Children
text: State lawmakers on Wednesday were on the verge of passing legislation that would make it illegal for occupants of a car to smoke if there are children on board younger than 14.

headline: The N.B.A. Brand, on Display in China
text: Basketball was created in America, but does it represent America? The N.B.A. sure thinks so.

headline: Just How Bullish Is the White House?
text: Brad DeLong is surprised by an upbeat White House memo on the economy.

headline: G.M. Salutes Its ‘Damsel’ Designers
text: General Motors presented “Designing Women,” a candid glimpse of the influence of women automotive designers within the automaker, on Monday at the Museum of the City of New York. It was held in conjunction with the “Cars, Culture and the City” exhibition, on view at the museum until Aug. 8.

headline: Drink. Trade. Refill. Lose $10 Million.
text: LONDON  Alcohol-induced behavior has produced many unintended consequences, but pushing up the global price of oil and losing $10 million must rank among the most novel.

headline: For Sky Blue, Blue Skies East, West, North and South
text: Six members of Sky Blue F.C. of Women’s Professional Soccer have had a whirlwind few days of travel that has taken them coast to coast and north to south … and it is not over yet.

headline: Fête Accompli | Versailles Revived
text: It’s easy to forget — given the cold war that sprung up between France and America during the Iraq invasion and all those hundreds of bottles of sublime French wine that were poured down the drain — about the Treaty of Alliance. This was the pact signed in 1778 by Benjamin Franklin, among others, that swore eternal friendship between the two countries and brought France into the Revolutionary War. The American Friends of Versailles was partly founded on these brotherly principles: the president, Catherine Hamilton, is a sworn Francophile who started the group in 1999 after wandering through Versailles (she is a member of the board of Les Amis de Versailles) and finding the Trois Fontaines Bosquet in utter disarray. There, the inspiration to help restore Louis XIV’s seat of political power — piece by piece — was born.

headline: New Start for Schools, Fish and Human
text: Last weekend I took the free ferry from the Battery Maritime Building in Manhattan to Governors Island. Within minutes, I was transported from the bustle of the city to a picturesque island that for two centuries served as a military base housing Army and Coast Guard officers.

headline: Trade Drunk. Refill. Lose $10 Million.
text: Alcohol-induced blackouts have produced many unintended consequences, but pushing up the global price of oil and losing $10 million must rank among the most novel.

headline: Looking Back, That Did Seem a Little Suspicious
text: They lived in suburban enclaves, they went to barbecues, they raised all-American kids. Now, they are accused of being Russian spies. (Maybe not particularly good ones, but spies nonetheless.) Yes, we are talking about the 11 “illegals” rounded up this week — some as nearby as Montclair, N.J., and Yonkers — and charged in the biggest international spy scandal in years.

headline: Korean Tradition, Italian Style
text: An architect and his family live in a traditional Korean house, or hanok, that is anything but traditional on the inside.

headline: Conductor as Guide on a Trip to Russia
text: The formal concert season has ended, but the New York Philharmonic’s musicians have a 52-week contract. So with the year’s subscription concerts behind them, the players have turned their attention to, well, more concerts: freebies (like the annual tour of the city’s parks), out-of-town performances (the orchestra’s residency at the Vail Valley Music Festival in Colorado) and unusual projects (a Varèse concert at this year’s Lincoln Center Festival). The postseason schedule also includes Summertime Classics, a series in which programs of favorites are made even more user-friendly, now in its seventh season.

headline: 17 Arrests Shut Down Bronx Car Theft Ring
text: A transcontinental car theft ring based in the Bronx that stole hundreds of vehicles was broken up Wednesday, the police said, as 17 people were arrested in a series of early-morning raids.

headline: New Faces Head Off to a Venerable Spot
text: At one time it would have been unthinkable that a hip Greenwich Village music club could host a send-off for young musicians heading to the formidable Darmstadt summer courses in Germany.

headline: Nadal Rallies to Reach Semifinals
text: WIMBLEDON, England — In the first set of his Wimbledon quarterfinal against sixth-seeded Robin Soderling, Rafael Nadal said Soderling served big, hit hard and made basically no mistakes.

headline: Beyond Larry King, Ratings Declines for CNN Programs
text: The announcement that Larry King is planning to leave his long-running CNN program in the fall – and the surge of speculation about who CNN can find to succeed the man who has been its signature prime-time star for 25 years — pushed the latest news about the channel’s ratings doldrums to the sideline for the moment.

headline: Big Phone, Big Screen, Big Pleasure
text: You think technology moves too fast now? You think your camera, camcorder and computer become obsolete quickly?

headline: How Mariano Rivera Dominates Hitters
text: The closer Mariano Rivera has confounded hitters with mostly one pitch: his signature cutter.

headline: Ski on July 4 Weekend. Seriously.
text: When most skiers think of slopes to try come July, Chile and Argentina come to mind. But this year, a couple of ski resorts that don’t require a passport are taking advantage of the buckets of snow that fell this winter to extend their seasons through July 4 weekend.

headline: Railing at a Money-Mad World
text: At the end of the first of half of Daniel Sullivan’s marvelous new production of “The Merchant of Venice,” at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, Shylock the moneylender can be found loudly lamenting his recent losses. These include a) a small fortune in cash and jewels, and b) his daughter, who has eloped with said valuables. As usual, Shylock, molten with sorrow and anger, cannot figure out which matters more.

headline: Leading Only Winning Card Wins Team a Bermuda Berth
text: The U.S.A.-1 team in the 2011 Bermuda Bowl world team championship will be Martin Fleisher, Michael Kamil, Bobby Levin, Steve Weinstein, Chip Martel and Lew Stansby. Seeded third in the trial that ended in Chicago on Sunday, they defeated the top seed led by Nick Nickell in the semifinals and the second seed, John Diamond, Brian Platnick, Eric Greco, Geoff Hampson, Fred Gitelman and Brad Moss, in the final, 260 international match points to 218.

headline: Louisiana Governor Seals Oil-Spill Records
text: For more than two months, Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana has made it clear that he considers the response of the federal government and BP to the gulf oil leak a failure on many fronts.

headline: Scorecard | Thom Browne Wins!
text: Houston, we have liftoff! Today, Scorecard bids farewell to the Paris men’s-wear shows — that weird and wonderful world where high concept is prized, and suits stay on the hanger. Leave it to an American making his Continental debut to pull the ultimate in-joke and suit his models up — for outerspace — before fashion’s General Assembly. That’s one way to score for Team U.S.A.

headline: The Two Faces of the Tea Party
text: Last week, Matt Continetti published a long essay in The Weekly Standard arguing that we should understand the Tea Party as a movement that’s torn between two competing political instincts — one reformist and one reactionary, one that “wants to repair deformities in the American political structure” and another that’s “ready to scrap the whole thing and restore a lost Eden.” He associated these two impulses with CNBC’s Rick Santelli and Fox News’ Glenn Beck, respectively, “who are arguably the Tea Party’s two founders” — Santelli because of his famous on-air rant against the White House’s mortgage bailout, and Beck because of all his labors to promote the Tea Parties, and to supply their inchoate passion with a comprehensive intellectual foundation.

headline: Rammellzee, Graffiti Artist, Dies at 49
text: Rammellzee, an early graffiti writer, hip-hop pioneer and performance artist whose style influenced the Beastie Boys and Cypress Hill, died Sunday in Far Rockaway, Queens, where he was raised. He lived in Battery Park City in Manhattan.

headline: Museum Role Fits a Former Art Dealer
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Chancellor Donates Proceeds From Tobacco Stock
text: Updated: The chancellor of the University of California, San Francisco, has donated $134,000 from the sale of her stock in the nation’s largest cigarette company to the university’s tobacco control center, officials said Wednesday.

headline: Answers About Gay Youth in New York
text: Following is the first set of responses from Kai Wright, the author of “Drifting Toward Love: Black, Brown, Gay and Coming of Age on the Streets of New York” (Beacon Press, January 2008), who is responding to readers’ questions about gay youth in New York City; the challenges they face; and the future lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender community they are creating.

headline: Food Brands Get Sociable on Facebook and Twitter
text: The number of advertisers with presences in the social media like Facebook, Twitter and YouTube are increasing faster than the lines at the supermarket when the values of the cents-off coupons are being tripled.

headline: With Purchase of Woot, a Daily Deal Site, Amazon Expands Its Inventory
text: Amazon.com, which sells millions of products, said Wednesday that it had agreed to buy Woot, a site that sells one item at a time.

headline: A Hoosier Haunting: There’s Something in the Water That’s Very Strange
text: “So cold the river”: that’s the strange phrase uttered by a dying man in Michael Koryta’s calculatingly spooky new novel. The man is a 95-year-old Chicago millionaire called Campbell Bradford. And he is hardly the only person in this book to be rattled by unnaturally chilly fluids. The main character, a washed-up documentary filmmaker named Eric Shaw, spends most of Mr. Koryta’s 500-page story being tormented by haunted mineral water.

headline: Why Nadal Is in and Federer Is Out
text: Who would have guessed that of the top four seeds at Wimbledon, only the six-time champion Roger Federer will miss the semifinals?

headline: Date Is Set for Vote on Alcon Board Candidates
text: Alcon on Wednesday announced that it would hold a meeting on Aug. 16 for shareholders to vote on the appointment of five directors nominated by Novartis, which owns 25 percent of the Swiss eyecare-drug maker.

headline: Welsh Rarebit, Repurposed
text: Welsh rarebit (aka Welsh rabbit) is basically a non-Swiss cheese fondue, generally enriched with egg, poured over toast and typically broiled until brown. There are dozens — hundreds — of recipes for Welsh rarebit kicking around, but here is how I made it a couple of weeks ago: two tablespoons each of flour and butter, made into a pale roux; just shy of 3/4 cup beer whisked in to form a sauce, which then simmered very gently for three or four minutes; six ounces roughly grated English cheddar (in this instance the so-called Borough Market cheddar from Whole Foods ); a tablespoon Dijon mustard; a teaspoon Worcestershire sauce; a scant 1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper; and finally a beaten egg, warmed with some of the sauce then returned to the pan to enrich and slightly thicken the dish. To me, that tastes just exactly right, though a lot will depend on your cheese and your beer, of course.

headline: Flash Crash a ‘Wake-Up Call’ at Getco
text: The co-founders of Getco, a big market maker and high-frequency trader, are arguing that the flash crash on May 6 was a “wake-up call” for the entire securities industry to support stronger regulations to ensure adequate liquidity in the equity markets.

headline: The Icelandic Post-crisis Miracle
text: Iceland is, of course, one of the great economic disaster stories of all time. An economy that produced a decent standard of living for its people was in effect hijacked by a combination of free-market ideology and crony capitalism; one of the papers (pdf) at the conference I just attended in Luxembourg shows that the benefits of the financial bubble went overwhelmingly to a small minority at the top of the income distribution:

headline: For a Night, British Rule at the Ballet
text: It’s amazing how much the whole climate of the Metropolitan Opera House improves once American Ballet Theater stops presenting its 19th-century classics. In the penultimate week of its season at the house, the company is shuffling seven one-act ballets and four pas de deux into different arrangements, and on Tuesday that meant “All-Classic Masters.”

headline: Loan Giants Threaten Energy-Efficiency Programs
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The Obama administration is devoting $150 million in stimulus money for programs that help homeowners install solar panels and other energy improvements, which they pay for over time on their property tax bills.

headline: Mastering the Elements
text: “The Last Airbender”? Let’s hope so, though there is a scene at the very end that gestures toward a sequel. After 94 minutes  was that all? I could have sworn it was days  of muddy 3-D imagery and muddled storytelling, the idea that this is just the first “Last Airbender” seems either delusionally optimistic or downright cruel. An astute industry analyst of my acquaintance, who is 9 and an admirer of the Nickelodeon animated series on which the movie is based, offered a two-word diagnosis of its commercial prospects on the way out of the theater: “They’re screwed.”

headline: On Total Football, Joga Bonito and the Ultimate Goal
text: Is winning ugly better than not winning at all? Brazil and the Netherlands, which didn’t always think so, have apparently come to the conclusion that it is. And while there has been some handwringing from their fans — and others — it is hard to argue that they’re wrong.

headline: Cancer Causes Hitchens to Cancel Book Tour
text: Christopher Hitchens, the author, Vanity Fair contributing editor and frequent television pundit, has suspended a tour to promote his new book while he receives chemotherapy.

headline: Christopher Hitchens to Begin Cancer Treatment
text: Christopher Hitchens, the author, Vanity Fair contributing editor and frequent television pundit, has suspended a tour to promote his new book while he receives chemotherapy.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Videos and Video Games
text: In this week’s New York Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein speaks with Miguel Helft, who has followed Viacom’s lawsuit against Google over  copyright infringement of YouTube videos.

headline: Curse of the Nike World Cup Commercial, Confirmed
text: A week a half ago we noted in this blog that there was something wrong with the Nike “Write the Future” ad, one of the signatures of this World Cup. My son, Asher Klein, a student at the University of Chicago, wrote in to say exactly what it was: the players in the ad were doing badly at South Africa 2010. Today he weighed in again to offer this update on the chilling phenomenon. (This is what you get when you bring up a child in a household where soccer is always on TV.)

headline: Turmoil at School Where Principal and Parents Clashed
text: 5:31 p.m., July 2 | Updated  According to Department of Education employment records, Tomasz Grabski joined the Muscota School as principal on July 1, 2008. The school had received a “B” rating for the 2007-8 school year, following an “F” in the 2006-7 school year. Under Mr. Grabski’s leadership, therefore, the school’s performance grade rose from a “B” to an “A,” not from an “F” to an “A,” as a department spokeswoman said on Wednesday.

headline: Accel Invests in ModCloth, a Social Shopping Site
text: ModCloth, a shopping Web site that sells flirty dresses and vintage blouses, has raised venture capital from Accel Partners, the Silicon Valley firm.

headline: In Seoul, a Traditional House With Modern Style
text: SEOUL, South Korea

headline: I’ll Take a Scoop of Prosciutto, Please
text: The heavily tattooed woman walking the Shih Tzu ordered Secret Breakfast, the most popular ice cream flavor at Humphry Slocombe. The proprietor, Jake Godby — a man so shy and socially awkward that it never occurred to him when he opened an ice cream parlor that such an establishment might attract children — makes the ice cream with bourbon and toasted cornflakes, including so much Jim Beam that the scoops always run soft. The day was a sunny Friday, ice cream weather. Just before noon customers started lining up near the corner of Harrison and 24th Streets, an unrehabilitated crossroads in San Francisco’s Mission district: first, a gold-chained Latino laborer who ordered Chocolate Smoked Sea Salt; then three 20-something guys — each part hipster, part geek — who stared anxiously at the flavor board, as if they had come in on a dare.

headline: Lower Manhattan Cultural Council Picks Sam Miller as Its President
text: The Lower Manhattan Cultural Council has chosen Sam Miller, a veteran arts consultant and cultural policy expert, as its new president. The nonprofit council, formed in 1973 to support arts projects around the World Trade Center (which was then new) and the financial district, provides studio spaces and grants and has been best known in recent years for helping to rejuvenate the downtown arts scene after 9/11. Most recently he served as president of OAM Company, an arts consulting and producing organization he founded in 2009, working with the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation on strategies to help dance and theater programs.

headline: Reyes Scratched With Stiff Back
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. – After enjoying an injury-free spring, Jose Reyes was scratched from the Mets’ lineup Wednesday with a stiff lower back that he appeared to injure during batting practice.

headline: Converting Pixels to Color Prints
text: Q. How can I move a picture that was e-mailed to me over to a photo Web site so that I can order copies?

headline: Eminem Tops the Album Chart With Other Artists Far Behind
text: Much about the music industry has changed in recent years, but at least one thing remains the same: the role of Eminem, left, as a chart-topping star. His latest album, “Recovery” (Aftermath/Interscope), sold 741,000 copies in its opening week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, the most sales in a one week by any artist since AC/DC’s “Black Ice” moved 784,000 copies in October 2008. Eminem’s sales easily exceeded those of other albums, including the new release from Miley Cyrus, “Can’t Be Tamed” (Hollywood), which sold 102,000 copies, good enough for the third slot. The opening week of Ozzy Osbourne’s “Scream” (Epic) had sales of 81,000, putting it at No. 4. Last week’s top-seller, Drake’s “Thank Me Later” (Aspire/Young Money/Cash Money), dropped to No. 2 with sales of 157,000, 65 percent fewer than the week before. Rounding out the Top 5 with 55,000 sales is the 34th volume of “Now That’s What I Call Music!”

headline: Nunn and Mackintosh Duel Over Revival of ‘Les Misérables’
text: The battles in “Les Misérables” are supposed to be between the idealistic French revolutionaries and the army; between Valjean and Javert; and maybe between Éponine and Cosette. But a dispute over the 25th-anniversary celebrations of that musical has pitted its original co-director Trevor Nunn against its producer Cameron Mackintosh, The Telegraph of London reported. In an interview with The Telegraph, Mr. Nunn, who with John Caird directed the original Royal Shakespeare Company production of “Les Misérables,” which opened at the Barbican Theater in London in 1985, said he and his original collaborators “felt betrayed” by Mr. Mackintosh’s hiring of new directors for a revival of the show planned at the Barbican for September. “We were not asked,” said Mr. Nunn, whose Broadway credits include the current revival of “A Little Night Music.” “In fact, we knew nothing of it.” Mr. Mackintosh, who brought in the directors James Powell and Laurence Conner to handle the anniversary revival of “Les Misérables,” said in a statement that he was “saddened by Nunn’s inaccurate and ungracious remarks.” “I believe that each new generation has to be able to put its own stamp on great material,” Mr. Mackintosh said in the statement.

headline: ‘Talent’ Pays Off for NBC
text: “America’s Got Talent” topped the ratings on Tuesday night with 10.1 million viewers on NBC, according to Nielsen’s estimates, but crime show repeats helped CBS earn the night’s most viewers on average. NBC would have led over all were it not for lower ratings for “Losing It With Jillian” (4.2 million) and “Last Comic Standing” (4.9 million). Fox ranked third with a two-hour “Hell’s Kitchen” from 8 to 10 (6.2 million). ABC finished in fourth place, with a World Cup theme episode of “Wipeout” (8.2 million).

headline: David Duchovny to Appear in New Neil Labute Play
text: Over the course of David Duchovny’s acting career his characters have gone to some unusual places, from the alien environs of “The X-Files” to many a Los Angeles bedroom on “Californication.” But there is one place Mr. Duchovny has never been: on the stage in a professional capacity. That’s about to change. On Wednesday MCC Theater said he would make his proper stage debut in its coming production of “The Break of Noon,” a new play by Neil LaBute. Mr. Duchovny, right, said in a phone interview he has previously acted “Off, off, off, off  as many offs as you can put in front of Broadway.” He added, “I’ve never done anything close to this scale.” “The Break of Noon” is described in a news release as centering on a character called John Smith (Mr. Duchovny) who “amidst the chaos and horror of the worst office shooting in American history, sees the face of God,” setting off a “maelstrom of disbelief among everyone he knows.” The play, which will be directed by Jo Bonney, is to begin performances at the Lucille Lortel Theater on Oct. 28. It is a co-production with the Geffen Playhouse, which will present it in Los Angeles next year.

headline: ‘Twilight’ Sequel Slays at Midnight
text: “The Twilight Saga: Eclipse” sunk its fangs into multiplexes on Wednesday morning, selling a record-setting $30 million in tickets for 12:01 a.m. shows. (Above, a famished fan.) “Eclipse,” the third entry in the phenomenally popular series, beat the industry’s previous midnight record holder, “The Twilight Saga: New Moon,” which opened to $26.3 million in November. “Eclipse” also set an Imax record for midnight grosses, selling over $1 million and beating “Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen,” according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing data. At the very least the enormous opening puts “Eclipse” on track to match “New Moon,” which sold about $710 million at the global box office. While the studio behind the series, Summit Entertainment, has been cautious about predicting how “Eclipse” will perform, the hope is that its summer slot will generate repeat business dwarfing that of its predecessors. Filmed at a cost of $68 million, “Eclipse” will be shown in more than 4,400 theaters in North America. The next milestone to beat: “New Moon” holds the record for the biggest single-day gross in box office history with $72.7 million.

headline: Inside Peter Buchanan-Smith’s Design Studio
text: The designer’s TriBeCa studio is filled with axes, slings and objects of inspiration.

headline: At Monticello, Jefferson’s Methods Endure
text: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.

headline: Gardening the Jeffersonian Way
text: The art of saving seeds is alive at Monticello, Thomas Jefferson’s home in Virginia, where gardeners are busy harvesting the pods of spent peas, beans and sea kale.

headline: That’s a Nice Phone, but How’s the Network?
text: When cellphone shopping, many people start by looking for the perfect phone. All the carriers have good smartphones, so most of the time choosing one comes down to taste and budget constraints.

headline: Life as a Runway |  At an Art Marathon, Visitors Are on Display
text: At the Creators Project, a 12-hour marathon of alternative music, sleek digital art and indie films, artsy types turned out in their Saturday best.

headline: Midterm Races Spur Feverish Drive for Donations
text: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers have been toiling away at a feverish pace here this week, working their way through breakfasts, lunches and dinners across Capitol Hill. The urgent task is not simply passing legislation, but raising money.

headline: Released on Bail in Cyprus, Spy Ring Suspect Vanishes
text: ATHENS  The eleventh suspected member of a Russian spy ring broken up by the F.B.I. this week has disappeared on the Mediterranean island of Cyprus, where he was arrested but released on bail Tuesday after surrendering his passport.

headline: A Revamped Playground, No Domes in Sight
text: The playground at Pier 1 in Brooklyn Bridge Park was a slightly less hip place Wednesday morning, absent its pair of sleekly space-agey stainless-steel climbing domes.

headline: Nets Throw First Bucket of Paint at the Knicks
text: Two basketball-themed murals, spaced 121 blocks apart, are taking shape in Manhattan.

headline: Shopping With Steven Johanknecht
text: A founding partner of the Los Angeles design firm Commune looked for entertaining pieces that work indoors and out.

headline: Discounts at Desiron in SoHo
text: Desiron, a furniture showroom in SoHo, is discounting all merchandise 30 to 40 percent in July (the Cooper Chair, originally $1,950, is $1,365; the Cooper Mirror, regularly $4,200, is $2,940; the Hudson sofa, above, originally $4,400, is $3,080); 151 Wooster Street (Houston Street), (212) 353-2600, desiron.com. Good deals may be reported to deals@nytimes.com.

headline: MatterMade, a New Line of Furnishings
text: MatterMade is a new collection of 30 furniture pieces and decorative accessories developed by Jamie Gray, owner and creative director of the shop Matter. Twelve designers — among them, Lindsey Adelman and Stephen Burks — created items for the line, which includes lamps, coat racks, dressers, desks, chairs and upholstered pieces.

headline: Takashimaya Florist Resurfaces as Florisity
text: Fans of Takashimaya’s now-defunct flower shop, take note: While Takashimaya closed last month, the florist, with its remarkable pale pink English roses, double-petaled Dutch tulips and stems of baby crab apples, is still in existence, operating as a shop called Florisity in the Flatiron district.

headline: Italian GD Cucine Opens New York Showroom
text: The Italian kitchen manufacturer GD Cucine will establish a beachhead in this country soon after Labor Day, when it opens its first American showroom in Manhattan.

headline: 1st Dibs’s New Paris Gallery
text: “Opening up the Paris galleries is like going home for us as a company,” said Michael Bruno, the president of 1st Dibs, the online auction site, which added a Paris gallery section this week. “We launched our business in 2001 in Paris at the flea market.”

headline: Peter Buchanan-Smith and the Urban Ax
text: IN the year since Peter Buchanan-Smith started selling axes, his dog died, he and his wife separated and he sold the house he thought he would grow old in at a big loss. Also, he parted ways with his business partner.

headline: Installing Your Own Home Security System
text: INSTALLING a security system has long been considered the domain of professionals — uniformed men and women who build an electronic shield around your home and monitor it from a command center.

headline: Neato Introduces the XV-11 Vacuum Robot
text: You might mistake the new Neato XV-11 Vacuum Robot for an earlier version of a robotic vacuum cleaner. That would be a mistake. While predecessors drunkenly bounced around the room until the job was done, the XV-11 is more Terminator than Ray Milland. Guided by sensors and a laser-based positioning system, the XV-11 scans and maps the area for obstacles, then meticulously vacuums a room’s rugs, hardwood or tile in tidy rows — avoiding walls, furniture and stairs. Once finished, the vacuum cleaner finds an open doorway and moves on to the next room.

headline: Outdoor Entertaining
text: STEVEN JOHANKNECHT, a New Yorker who moved to California 11 years ago, found the transition easy, except for one aspect of life: earthquakes. “I adjusted to some occasional tremors,” he said. “But some of my things did not adjust so easily.”

headline: Ivan Braun, Who Turns Felled Trees Into Bowls
text: The New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx has found a way to give its fallen trees a new life: as hand-turned bowls and vases made by Ivan Braun, a woodworker from the Bronx. The one-of-a-kind objects, sold at the garden, are crafted in yew, red maple, plum, juniper, white oak, cherry, apple and zelkova, a Japanese elm. (Mr. Braun used the zelkova to create dramatically striated bowls with a pinto-pony effect, right.) They range from $45 to $145.

headline: Witching Hour Past for Icahn’s Lions Gate Bid
text: Time has run out for Carl C. Icahn‘s hostile tender offer for Lions Gate Entertainment — but do investors really care?

headline: Me, Myself and iPhone
This Year’s Model: Me
text: Two photographers demonstrate the self-shooting basics with iPhones.

headline: House Gives Final Approval to Financial Overhaul
text: The House on Wednesday adopted legislation to revamp the nation’s financial regulatory system, in a party-line vote that illustrated how the partisan bitterness in Congress prevented cooperation even on the shared goal of averting future economic crises and government bailouts of big banks, The New York Times’s David M. Herszenhorn reports from Washington.

headline: Financial Overhaul Wins Final Approval in House
text: WASHINGTON — The House on Wednesday adopted legislation to revamp the nation’s financial regulatory system, voting mostly along party lines as partisan acrimony impeded cooperation even on the shared goals of averting future economic crises.

headline: Before the Entrees, Apps to Winnow Choices and Find Seats
text: Smartphones have made it simple to find a restaurant at the last minute. The gastronomic triumvirate of Urbanspoon, Yelp and OpenTable each have well-designed mobile apps for Android, BlackBerry and iPhone users, and they’re all free.

headline: Accused of Espionage, but Praised as Moms and Dads
text: Among the 11 people arrested this week on suspicions of espionage were four couples, which brought much about their suburban lives into question  except, perhaps, for their parenting.

headline: The Goal of the Tournament So Far
text: [7:49 a.m. | Updated We’ve added videos of the goals commenters have argued most vociferously for inclusion. They appear at the bottom of the post.]

headline: Yankees Pitching Coach’s Return Provides Answers for Burnett
text: A. J. Burnett had no answers for his struggles. He sought the help of teammates and consulted video of his past outing.

headline: Afghan Soldiers Went AWOL in Texas
text: HOUSTON  If the 17 foreign soldiers who walked away from language training at Lackland Air Force Base in San Antonio had been from, say, Guatemala or Kenya, they probably would not have received much attention. Military officials say it is not uncommon for officers visiting from countries where life is hard to get a glimpse of the American dream while studying here and go absent without leave.

headline: Fury at the Sounds of South Africa’s World Cup
text: Johannesburg
